# Official Style Guide

### About this Guide

**About this Guide**

**The CBC's multiplatform English Language Guide gives all staff one-stop shopping for style and usage queries. It is regularly updated.** Launched in February 2010 by the Office of the Vice-President of English Services, the Language Guide combines a pronunciation database started by CBC Radio in 1992 with a comprehensive style and usage intranet site created by CBCNews.ca in 2003. It moved to a new home in Google sites in 2017.
WS
The Language Guide's [overview](/overview) outlines its main features.

The [contact us](/contact-us) page lists names, numbers and email addresses if you have questions, comments or requests for rulings.

**The rest of this page briefly reviews how this central language resource was created.**

**History of language guidelines at the CBC**





**A not-so paperless office**
When the CBC began broadcasting newscasts in the 1930s, typewriters and manually cranked duplicating machines were how we got out the word about words. Pronounce a short vowel sound here. Avoid redundancy there. Generally prefer the active voice. For more than 50 years, a language "supervisor" or "counsellor" issued rulings and reminders, including **William Brodie**, **John Rae**, **Lamont Tilden**, **George Rich** and **Ken Haslam**. Consistency was equated with professionalism, and by the 1960s decisions about what was preferred and what was acceptable applied to all CBC Radio and CBC-TV news staff. Regular in-house notices about English usage were also distributed by the corporation's old Office of Broadcast Language, such as the monthly _You Don't Say_ bulletin between 1975 and 1983.

**The 'Lang File'**
Soon after being appointed the English news service's broadcast language adviser, national radio news host **Russ Germain** brought the whole process into the electronic age. In 1992, he created a Language File (quickly dubbed the "Lang File") in one of the news service's earliest computer networks. For the first time, the adviser's pronunciation rulings and periodic other notes about diction and grammar were instantly available in a permanent bulletin board. As the CBC moved to different computer systems (from Info to Prolog to iNEWS), Germain continued to add entries until his retirement a decade later. Host **Judy Maddren** took over the language adviser's role in 2003 until her retirement in 2009. By the summer of that year, the Lang File had almost 11,000 entries. Most were very brief (a few words to a sentence or two), and almost all of them (more than 95 per cent) dealt with preferred pronunciations only.

**
Language Online**
Before Germain's retirement, it was clear that the CBC needed to expand its approach to language and style guidelines. An explosion of online news at the turn of the millennium had turned Canada's national broadcaster into an electronic publisher, too. In 2003, CBCNews.ca's senior editor of journalistic standards **Blair Shewchuk** created Language Online, an intranet resource that outlined in-house publishing style (from spelling and punctuation to capitalization and use of italics). Unlike the old Lang File, links could be added to internal and external content. Alphabetical lists were also easier to scan and keyword searches were faster. Given web writing and editing needs, Language Online branched out to tackle numerous topics in far more depth (e.g., [French words](/home/f/french-words-and-accents) embedded in English text and the sometimes tricky rules about [whom](/home/w/who-versus-whom)). As online language adviser, Shewchuk also worked with Germain and Maddren on various CBC News style preferences — ensuring that rulings were consistent across platforms.

**New era of news integration**
The first steps to create a central Language Guide on the iO! portal were taken at the end of 2009. The news service's move toward greater integration between radio, television and web platforms, combined with the revamping of its iNEWS computer system, presented an opportunity to marry the Lang File with Language Online. The best content from each was combined to create a new Language Guide that offered editorial staff far more than either of the previous word warehouses did alone. **Esther Enkin** was named chair of a newly created [CBC Language Advisory Committee](/language-advisory-committee) that would periodically review guidelines and issue recommendations for all English Services. **Blair Shewchuk** was appointed the committee's senior language counsellor as well as standards editor for CBC News, reporting directly to Enkin.

Since the old Lang File was primarily a pronunciation directory full of unverified spellings of proper names and other words, its content was transferred to a [special database](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2FLNG%2FRecherche%2FIndex.aspx&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2p5Bo2D4gXWwBfXu8gqKe3) created by the CBC's IT and iO! departments. This meant that broadcast staff could still look up 20 years' worth of phonetic preferences, only more quickly. In addition, audio files could now be added to make certain pronunciation preferences much easier to convey.

At the same time, a new Language Guide was built on the foundation of Language Online, CBCNews.ca's style and usage intranet site, which already had thousands of entries that had been carefully spellchecked and copy edited over the years, and which generally dealt with grammar, syntax, word choice, etc., in more depth. Lang File entries unrelated to pronunciation (about 500) were reviewed. Content that was still current and not already in Language Online was flagged. Some old pages were revised to reflect the new guide's multimedia nature, and numerous new entries were added, including a summary of how [CBC News style](/cbc-news-style) is now determined. Improved page design and site navigation was created.

**Going gung-ho with Google**
Half a decade later, aging servers and increasingly archaic software retired by Microsoft meant that the Language Guide needed to be moved to a new publishing platform. A Google site was created, and hundreds of files containing thousands of entries were transferred to the new home. HTML had to be manually rewritten so all of the content would be displayed properly — from every comma, colon and French accent to all italics and bold lettering. Hundreds of internal and external links also had to be recoded to continue to work. It was a challenging project, painstakingly undertaken by **Émilie Sorel** in Montreal.

In September of 2017, the new Google site was launched with Shewchuk still at the helm. Benefits included a quicker way to update content and a faster way to search for keywords. But the most significant improvement was letting all staff more easily access the Language Guide from anywhere. VPN accounts or other special security steps were no longer required outside the corporation's firewall. Instead, a CBC Google password matching an employee's existing GMail password was sufficient.

**Embracing Umbraco**
In the fall of 2021, the Language Guide was on the move again, this time to a content management system called Umbraco. Changes at Google had started hampering functionality and the CBC's Technology and Infrastructure Department wanted more control over publishing tools used on the corporation's intranet. The new platform also improved how text was displayed on mobile devices. Once again, the switch involved months of coding and design work, led by **Sébastien Thibaut** and **Émilie Sorel** in Montreal.

Since spoken and written English continue to evolve, the CBC Language Guide is expected to remain a constant work in progress — with new terms added, and old entries reviewed and revised (or deleted), as required.

### CBC News Style

The term "style" actually has several meanings, from distinct voice (writing style) to specific font and layout (design style). In our Language Guide, **style refers to English usage — including spelling, pronunciation, punctuation, capitalization, grammar, diction (word choice), etc.**

**What is CBC News style?**
**We follow a wide range of in-house guidelines when broadcasting words on air or publishing text online.** Sometimes only one approach is considered accurate (a particular spelling or pronunciation) or literate (a certain choice of word or rule of grammar) or in the best interest of our audience (avoiding a term or phrase that suggests bias or is too easily misunderstood). At other times, it's a case of picking one of several options and sticking with it to maintain the professional shine of consistency in our journalism.

**The most common CBC News style categories are:**

**1\. Journalistic choices, editorial caveats**

> Examples: Picking [Myanmar](/home/m/Myanmar) over Burma in first reference. Using "[Dr.](/home/d/dr)" for licensed health-care professionals only, not people with PhDs. Acknowledging [proprietary names](/home/t/trade-names), such as Frisbee and Velcro, with appropriate capitalization. Staying as neutral as possible with labels such as [pro-choice and anti-abortion](/home/a/abortion). Avoiding use of [fundamentalist](/home/f/fundamentalist-extremist) alone as a synonym for "extremist" or "militant."

**2\. Adherence to 'standard English'**

> Examples: Using correct pronoun case, such as [I and me](/home/i/i-versus-me). Maintaining [subject-verb agreements](/home/v/verb-agreement). Retaining distinctions between words such as [affect and effect](/home/a/affect-versus-effect), [lay versus lie](/home/l/lay-versus-lie) and [Maritime versus Atlantic](/home/a/atlantic-versus-maritime) provinces. Avoiding widely condemned usage, such as the illogic of [irregardless](/home/i#irregardless) and the misuse of [begs the question](/home/b/begs-the-question).

**3\. Pronunciation preferences**   

> Examples: Rhyming [Moscow](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2FLNG%2FRecherche%2Findex.aspx%3FProId%3D34108&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0scY4HXAwrRnY2rqYdzANt) with "no" rather than "now," putting emphasis on the first syllable in [kilometre](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2FLNG%2FRecherche%2Findex.aspx%3FProId%3D31685&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1AwZsZsmFYIQvn1IEVw7ld) (matching centimetre rather than thermometer), adding an "f" sound to [lieutenant](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2FLNG%2FRecherche%2Findex.aspx%3FProId%3D35060&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2iNGIuba0RLTuuzHA_-K0e) and pronouncing the last syllable of [missile](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2FLNG%2FRecherche%2Findex.aspx%3FProId%3D28354&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2GHHooMvhxQe7N-NIteZCf) along the lines of "mile" rather than "mill." All preferences are found in a [special pronunciation database](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2FLNG%2FRecherche%2FIndex.aspx&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2p5Bo2D4gXWwBfXu8gqKe3).

**4\. Spelling preferences**

> Examples: Using [Canadian spellings](/home/s/spelling) such as "[colour](/home/s/spelling/our)" and "[centre](/home/c/centre-versus-center)" except in proper nouns (e.g., World Trade Center), adding an extra "c" to raccoon, doubling the "l" in words such as fuelling and following entrenched [transliterations](/home/t/transliterations) (e.g., al-Qaeda rather than al Qaida).

**5\. Typographical preferences (punctuation, capitalization, etc.)**

> Examples: Dropping periods from uppercase [abbreviations](/home/a/abbreviations#uppercase) (RCMP, AIDS) unless geographical (P.E.I., B.C.), generally putting [quotation marks](/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks) outside closing punctuation, limiting our use of [italics](/handy-links/punctuation/italics) and keeping most [titles](/home/t/titles) lowercase (mayor) unless directly in front of the person's name (Mayor Mary Wong) Since the early days of web publishing in the 1990s, our typography has adhered to what we call a "[modified CP style](/home/s/spelling/modified-cp-style)."


**Why does it matter?**

We're the country's public broadcaster, and **Canadians expect us to know and follow standard English**. Since the CBC began broadcasting news in the 1930s, people have been less than shy about contacting us over mistakes in grammar, syntax, pronunciation, etc. With the introduction of web publishing, complaints have rapidly broadened to include slips in spelling, punctuation, capitalization, etc. The level of scrutiny has also intensified. Online audiences can now read and reread sentences at their leisure, spotting mistakes more easily and challenging any wording with the click of a button.

**Establishing and following a CBC News style is important for several reasons:**

-   **Editorial control**
    **Internal guidelines help the CBC as a whole maintain editorial control over its journalism and other content.** Instead of relying solely on external sources (e.g., the Canadian Oxford Dictionary, which may be silent on various new proper nouns in the news, or the most recent Canadian Press style manual, which may include various entries that clash with established CBC News rulings), the corporation sets its own approach to words such as [terrorist](/home/t/terrorist-and-terrorism) and [jihad](/home/j/jihad), decides how to handle disputed terms such as [Nagorno-Karabakh](/home/n/nagorno-karabakh) and [Sea of Japan/East Sea](/home/s/sea-of-japan_east-sea), outlines special parameters around the reporting of [polls](/home/p/polls), etc.


-   **Credibility**
    **Mispronouncing or misspelling the name of a person, organization, etc., makes our journalism poorer. If we can't get that part of the story right, people begin to wonder what else we've botched.** Careful word choice falls into this category, too. Distinguishing between [percentage and per cent](/home/p/per-cent-versus-percentage), [viruses and bacteria](/home/b/bacteria-versus-virus) and [Ponzi versus pyramid](/home/p/ponzi-versus-pyramid-scheme) schemes are all examples of valuing accuracy. When we make a special effort to get things right we build trust. And trust is the foundation of the CBC News brand.
-   **Consistency**
    **In some cases, in-house style boils down to consistency rather than correctness.** When more than one approach is acceptable ([Londonderry](/home/l/londonderry-versus-london) versus Derry, [backward](/home/w/ward-versus-wards) versus backwards, certain [imperial versus metric](/home/m/metric-versus-imperial) measurements), it's important to have a plan in place. Amateurishly bouncing an audience from one style to the next on a whim (in line skates, in-line skates and inline skates), leaves people wondering if decisions depend on the employee, the day of the week or the position of the planets. By contrast, **following a central style** (in-line skates) **telegraphs a level of professionalism appropriate for a national network.**
-   **Speed / Productivity**
    **In addition to meeting audience expectations of professionalism, internal language guidelines help our journalists and other staff do their jobs more efficiently.** Production speed is increased because databases of preferred pronunciations, spellings, etc., can be quickly consulted as deadlines loom. There’s also a system in place for requesting rulings not already covered. As well, internal guidelines increase the efficiency of retrieving archived stories later because search engines are able to rely on consistent spellings of keywords.


**How is our style set?**
As chair of the CBC [Language Advisory Committee](/language-advisory-committee), **Journalistic Standards and Public Trust Director George Achi has overall responsibility for language usage across the English networks** — normally making final rulings on difficult or sensitive editorial guidelines (e.g., [suicide reporting](/home/s/suicide) and the use of [oilsands](/home/o/oilsands-versus-tarsands) versus tarsands). **The JSP director regularly consults the news service's senior standards adviser** and others as required.

**All routine style decisions unrelated to pronunciation are made by the senior standards adviser, who also manages the Language Guide** on behalf of the JSP Office. Rulings cover everything from spelling, punctuation and capitalization preferences to grammatical strictness or latitude (e.g., recommending "Who did you see?" over the stilted and unnatural "Whom did you see?" on the grounds of what's known as the "[interrogative who](/home/w/who-versus-whom#interrogatives)") and other debatable usage (e.g., [media are](/home/l/latin-plurals) rather than media is). **The senior standards adviser also works with colleagues from different platforms drafting various guidelines** (e.g., how and when to censor [offensive language in our online coverage](/home/o/offensive-language)), which are then given to the chair for approval.

**In August 2022, a new Language Advisory Group was formed** as part of the new service's pledge to broaden consultation and to make CBC Language Guide style decisions more inclusive. It's made up of roughly a dozen employees from across the country who serve on a rotational basis for periods of generally no more than two years. They're asked for input on a range of words and phrases that are being debated for various reasons, from newly coined terms to old style manual entries under review. The group's recommendations are then submitted to the JSP Office for consideration. 

**Pronunciation preferences are determined by veteran journalist [Laura Carlin](/language-advisory-committee#Laura)** and other colleagues, chosen by the JSP Office, who regularly update a [special pronunciation database](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2FLNG%2FRecherche%2FIndex.aspx&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2p5Bo2D4gXWwBfXu8gqKe3) started by former broadcast language adviser Russ Germain in the early 1990s. (A brief history of CBC's language advisers can be found in the [About this guide](/about-this-guide) overview.)


**Research and consultation: Primary sources**
CBC journalists are expected to find out and use the correct spellings and pronunciations of proper nouns (e.g., the names of people, companies, products, government agencies) and other words (e.g., terms from the worlds of science, business, arts, sports) in stories they're working on. It's important to collect this information in the field and include it in scripts.

**Always check this Language Guide** (or in the case of pronunciations our special database) **first, to see if a news service preference has been set.** For general spelling and pronunciation guidance after that, our main dictionary is the [Canadian Oxford](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.oxfordreference.com%2Fviews%2FBOOK_SEARCH.html%3Fbook%3Dt150%26subject%3Ds7%26authstatuscode%3D200&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2j5dtl21fzPGOBeXVVJOBv) (2004, second edition), available to all staff online for free through a corporate subscription. When more than one acceptable spelling is listed and a clear preference is not indicated, the Canadian Oxford Spelling book is consulted (e.g., use "adviser" instead of "advisor") but not always followed (e.g., we and numerous other large news agencies, including CP, continue to prefer "tuque" over "toque" for the knitted cap). See also the separate overviews on [Spelling](/home/s/spelling) and [Pronunciation](/handy-links/pronunciation) for specific guidance on handling words with alternative entries.

Our primary reference tool for the names of Canadian cities, towns, villages, mountains, lakes, rivers, etc., is the federal government's comprehensive [Canadian Geographical Names Service database](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww4.rncan.gc.ca%2Fsearch-place-names%2Fname.php&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0ZKjLC72PeNFm20h4xsLKO). Since all provinces and territories contribute to the CGNS's official spellings, entries are generally undisputed. A few exceptions have been identified over the years (e.g., the [St. John River](/home/s/st-saint-ste#StJohnsRiver) rather than the Saint John River in New Brunswick) based on widely established convention or entrenched local preference, and these have been incorporated into the Language Guide's A to Z directory as part of CBC News style. See also the [Provinces and cities](/home/p/provinces-and-cities) overview for a list of communities in Canada that are widely enough known to be mentioned on their own without the need to identify the province for a national audience.

Our primary source for geographical names outside of Canada not already listed in this Language Guide is the National Geographic Atlas of the World, which is also used by The Canadian Press and The Associated Press. Exceptions that are established as CBC News style are listed in the A to Z index (e.g., Kabul not "Kabol," Damascus not "Dimashq," and Rome not "Roma"). See also the [Geographical abbreviations](/home/g/geography-cities) overview for a list of cities around the world that are widely enough known to be mentioned on their own without the need to include the country.

**When making rulings or recommendations, the standards editor often consults internal and external authorities**, depending on how urgently a decision is needed. Experts on certain topics may be asked for input — including the heads of different "content teams" (e.g., sports, business, health, technology, the environment). Various reference material may also be reviewed, including:

**When is our style revised?**
**Language Guide entries are not added, deleted or revised on a whim. But all entries are subject to review.** We stand firm when no solid evidence is presented that our style is wrong or poorer than an alternative. We revise when errors are spotted or if improvements are needed — based on new information, established new usage or evidence that a different approach is better for our audience (e.g., clearer).

**The two chief reasons for shifts in CBC News style:**

**
1\. New information surfaces**
**Sometimes an old preference turns out to be inaccurate, dated, etc.** Examples are revised proper nouns, especially businesses (Stelco became U.S. Steel Canada in 2007) and certain [transliterations](/home/t/transliterations) (Peking became Beijing in the 1980s, and Chernobyl became Chornobyl in the 1990s). We are no strangers to leading the way when a new preference makes sense. CBC News, for example, replaced Nfld. with [N.L.](/home/n/newfoundland-and-labrador) as the abbreviation for Newfoundland and Labrador before The Canadian Press.

It's worth noting that official but secondary sources can prove unreliable, especially for people's names. For instance, Olympic champion speed skater Catriona Le May Doan's official website spelled her name "LeMay" for a long time, and required inquiries by the CBC to confirm that there's a space between Le and May. This was also true of the Governor General's website, which originally spelled the name of Michaëlle Jean's daughter without an accent (Marie-Eden instead of the correct Marie-Éden) until CBC News asked for clarification in 2005. The best way to find out how to pronounce or spell someone's name is to ask the person directly. If that's not possible, consult a relative or someone else close to the individual.


**2\. Usage evolves**
Centuries ago, the word "nice" meant "ignorant" and people pronounced the "k" in "knife" and "knee." We used a more complex system of pronouns (e.g., "thou" for singular and "ye" for plural, instead of plain old "you"). When William Strunk's classic The Elements of Style was first published in 1918, we were told to put hyphens in the words today, tonight and tomorrow ("to-day, to-night and to-morrow"). As recently as 2000, the fourth edition of the same book embraced the word "summarize" as useful while quirkily dismissing the rather common and practical term "finalize" as an abomination. Language changes. Sometimes slowly, over generations, and sometimes much more quickly. But as long as it's spoken and written (English is alive, Latin is dead), a **language evolves. And a news service's style must adjust accordingly, or it risks morphing from a current and valuable set of guidelines into a charming relic of past usage.**

From the CBC's first news broadcasts, memos have circulated about grammar, word choice, clear writing and correct pronunciation. Some of the old guidelines stand the test of time. For example, notes from the early 1940s said don't put a definite article ("the") in front of HMS or you wind up with "the His Majesty's Ship," and don't refer to contract disputes as "labour" unrest, because it emphasizes only one side of labour-management relations. Current style still reflects these early rulings (see [HMCS](/home/h/hmcs) and [labour dispute](/home/l#labourdispute)).

Other advice, however, seems rather odd now based on how English is used today. For example, CBC language notes from the 1930s insisted on avoiding possessives with inanimate objects (e.g., rewrite "the car's guards" as "the men guarding the car"), and on always using honorifics "for well-known and respected persons." The minister of agriculture was cited as a respected person, while Hitler and Stalin were identified as people who shouldn't have "Mr." in front of their names. In the 1960s, CBC News style guides baldly stated that the word "prestigious" meant "deceptive or illusory" rather than "with prestige" — a common view among usage sticklers at the time. A generation later, anyone trying to convey the idea of "deception" with the word "prestigious" would be misunderstood. (For a closer look at "prestigious" and some other cases of evolving meaning, see the CBCNews.ca Words: Woe & Wonder column [Static over style](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews2%2Findepth%2Fwords%2Fstatic_style.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0XSJ_Nui63qTVeXLxPvLMw) from December 2000.)


**Keeping CBC News style current**
**While there's no doubt that English evolves, the tricky part is deciding when and how to revise our style based on changing usage.** Such decisions can be relatively subjective. If change is called for and not deemed controversial, the new service's standards editor often makes independent rulings to keep our style current. Routine pronunciation calls are made by on-air staff with delegated authority. When the need for change is debatable or a particular style point is potentially controversial (including a spelling or pronunciation preference), the full Language Advisory Committee is generally consulted. **When a decision involves setting new and sensitive editorial policy or shifting current editorial policy in a major way, the committee's chair makes the final ruling.**

Throughout the process, **your input is encouraged. The Language Guide is everyone's resource. If you think a preference is wrong or dated, please go to the [Contact Us](/contact-us) page to pass on your concern or to share any other suggestions.**

### Pronunciation FAQs

**Pronunciation FAQs**

CBC News pronunciation preferences are stored in a [special database](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2Flng%2Frecherche%2Findex.aspx&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1XFPfiGVRPwO63-NkaNyUm) that's separate from the main Language Guide's server. **You need to go to the database first to search for entries.** This page answers 10 frequently asked questions, starting with why we use [**SPELLED-OUT PHONETICS**](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/media/521ind0l/cbc-phonetics-legend_september-2017.pdf "CBC PHONETICS LEGEND_September-2017.pdf").

1. [Are international phonetic symbols used?](/handy-links/pronunciation#FAQ1)
2. [How do I search the database?](/handy-links/pronunciation#FAQ2)
3. [What's included?](/handy-links/pronunciation#FAQ3)
4. [How are preferences determined, and how do I suggest a new entry or a change in style?](/handy-links/pronunciation#FAQ4)
5. [Are there audio files?](/handy-links/pronunciation#FAQ5)
6. [Is this database the same as the old 'Lang File'?](/handy-links/pronunciation#FAQ6)
7\. [Are spellings confirmed?](/handy-links/pronunciation#FAQ7)
8. [Why are pronunciations in their own database?](/handy-links/pronunciation#FAQ8)
9. [How do handle non-English words (names, generic words, etc.)?](/handy-links/pronunciation#FAQ9)
10. [Do we want everyone on air to sound the same?](/handy-links/pronunciation#FAQ10)

**1\. Are international phonetic symbols used?**
No. To aid comprehension, "sounds like" or "rhymes with" guidelines are used rather than international phonetic symbols (e.g, SAY, SEE and SEYE rather than "eɪ" and "aɪ" and "i:"). This follows a tradition started at CBC Radio more than half a century ago. Most people simply haven't memorized the dozens of different international symbols (Λ = _u_  in _run_, u: = _oo_  in _mood_, Φ = _th_  in _thin_ ) that represent all possible consonant and vowel sounds of the English language. Similar "sounds like" guidelines are used by many reputable reference books, including the Oxford Guide to Canadian English Usage. To underscore syllabic emphasis, capital letters and/or the apostrophe sign appear ('KILL-oh-mee-ter). **Our [PHONETICS LEGEND](https://docs.google.com/a/cbc.ca/viewer?a=v&pid=sites&srcid=Y2JjLmNhfGxhbmd1YWdlZ3VpZGV8Z3g6NzQxNzEyNzFhYjI3ZWZlYw) outlines the basics for writing clear "pronouncers" in television and radio scripts.**

**2\. How do I search the database?**
Entering a keyword in the search engine (e.g., _Hitler_) is the fastest way to find content. A list of entries containing that word will appear. In this case, the preferred pronunciation of Hitler's first name is "AH-dawlf" rather than "AY-dawlf," based on historical accuracy and vowel sound entrenchment. You can also scan through alphabetical lists of all entries in the database. To speed up scrolling, electronic bookmarks have been created so you can jump to specific spots within a given A to Z directory (e.g., a-ak, al-ap and aq-az). For more details and examples, see the Language Guide's [search tips](/search-tips).

**3\. What's included?**
The database features thousands of pronunciations. Most of the entries are proper nouns (in particular, the names of people, geographical locations and organizations) in the news. There are also preferred CBC pronunciations for generic words ([kilometre](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2Flng%2Frecherche%2Findex.aspx%3FProId%3D31685&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2oXAGFEu3itdTRV_AwXs4L), [lieutenant](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2Flng%2Frecherche%2Findex.aspx%3FProId%3D35060&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0bx5don-5st3Ogst__FMl4)) established over time. New entries are regularly added. To keep the database from becoming overly large, priority is given to names or terms that are commonly mispronounced, are not already listed in the Canadian Oxford Dictionary, are confusing because more than one pronunciation is listed in the dictionary, etc.

**4\. How are preferences determined, and how do I suggest a new entry or a change in style?**
CBC journalists are expected to find out and use proper spellings and pronunciations in the stories they're working on, and to include these in their scripts. This is the database's foundation. In the case of unclear or disputed pronunciations of other words, **the CBC Language Advisory Committee's chief pronunciation counsellor [Laura Carlin](/language-advisory-committee#Laura)** issues rulings. She and colleagues with designated authority also add, delete and revise content in the Pronunciation Database. Periodically, requests to relax or change certain preferred pronunciations are reviewed by a panel of veteran CBC broadcasters from across the country chosen by the counsellor. See also FAQs [9](#FAQ9) and [10](#FAQ10) below for related information on non-English pronunciations, multiple pronunciations, etc.

**5\. Are there audio files?**
 Yes. The Language Guide's Pronunciation Database supports audio.
It was not realistic to create MP3 files for the thousands of existing pronunciations copied from the old, text-based systems (Info, Prolog and iNEWS). But sound was added to a few dozen words when the database was launched (e.g., [Port-au-Prince](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2Flng%2Frecherche%2Findex.aspx%3FProId%3D31773&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3Jw37Sn7lFxO7REaN7THY6), [harass](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2Flng%2Frecherche%2Findex.aspx%3FProId%3D37452&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3XzlANo568T1JB4Uyopclx), [junta](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2Flng%2Frecherche%2Findex.aspx%3FProId%3D26941&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0ryoDvkn-uCoVOn_iqE67F), [Moscow](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2Flng%2Frecherche%2Findex.aspx%3FProId%3D34108&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw27K-4VzdjGtGqER_LrvuNB) and [missile](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2Flng%2Frecherche%2Findex.aspx%3FProId%3D28354&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3BFc0cILu04uP08VOevtKL)). As new entries are posted, the plan is to record and attach audio files whenever possible. This will make it easier to convey specific pronunciation preferences. A small icon indicates that an entry has sound. To play the audio, click on the arrow.

**6\. Is this database the same as the old 'Lang File'?**
Most of it — at least initially. As pointed out in a [historical review](/about-this-guide) of language guidelines at the CBC, more than 95 per cent of the old iNEWS Lang File was made up of pronunciation preferences compiled over two decades. Approximately 10,500 entries were moved into the new web-based Pronunciation Database in December 2009. The only content not included dealt with topics beyond pronunciation (e.g., various grammar and craft tips). These were reviewed separately and added to the new Language Guide if still current and if similar entries did not already exist. As the new pronunciation database grows, and as various phonetic tips are reviewed and potentially revised or deleted (if no longer relevant to daily news coverage), the similarity to the old Lang File is expected to fade.

**7\. Are spellings confirmed?**
Not unless specified. Since the old "Lang File" entries were written for broadcast staff only, virtually none of the original 10,500 pronunciation entries were checked for spelling. In many cases, the keywords were also written in all-uppercase letters — making it impossible to tell what needs to be capitalized and what doesn’t. Therefore, anyone consulting old entries in the database should not rely on the information for web news stories. Instead, they should check other sources, beginning with the main CBC News Language Guide. (For example: The answer to [FAQ 2](/handy-links/pronunciation#FAQ1) above cites a preferred pronunciation of Hitler's first name. There are also several common spellings. For consistency, CBC News uses the historically entrenched _Adolf_ rather than _Adolph_.) Whenever possible, new pronunciation entries will include verified spellings. In these cases, the "Spelling confirmed" field will be marked "Yes."

**8\. Why are pronunciations in their own database?**
For technical and editorial reasons. On the technical side, creating a separate database was the most practical way to move the old "Lang File" content to a web-based format in 2009. Automated migration meant that more than 10,000 individual pages did not need to be individually coded with HTML. On the editorial side, creating a special database meant that people could more easily look for pronunciations. It also meant that thousands of "Lang File" pronunciation entries would not need to be edited for spelling, consistent CBC News publishing style (capitalization, punctuation), etc. An effective Language Guide must model in-house style and usage. A pronunciation database, by contrast, can still serve its primary function using phonetic spellings and unorthodox typography.

**9\. How do we handle non-English words (names, generic words, etc.)?**
We respect known preferences when saying people's names. However, we also keep in mind that CBC News reports in English. Our journalists are not expected to try to mimic all vowel and consonant sounds of a different language (i.e., to attempt to report in Arabic, German, Hungarian, Russian, Spanish, etc.). If CBC News employees happen to be bilingual or multilingual, of course, then it's perfectly natural for them to switch from English to another language and back again. Otherwise, however, we generally strive for the "Canadian English" pronunciation of a given name, generic word, etc. This means we adopt versions that take into account non-English phonetics while encouraging consistency and familiarity, especially when anglicized forms are entrenched (e.g., we do not say "Paris" or "Mexico" the ways local residents would). Furthermore, it's been our experience that citizens of a given country all speaking the same language can pronounce things in slightly different ways — including how someone from Newfoundland, Saskatchewan or Ontario says "Toronto." Regional dialects, educational backgrounds, personal enunciation patterns, can all affect speech. So we need to be cautious when told by a source that there's only one, definitive way to pronounce the name of a non-English town, city, island, river, etc. Tips on how to say [Japanese names](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/updates/2011/2011-03-19/ "2011 03 19") and [Ukrainian names](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/updates/2022/2022-03-01/ "2022 03 01") illustrate our typical approach.

**10\. Do we want everyone on air to sound the same?**
No. We certainly want to be accurate, which means when there's only one way to say something correctly (e.g., if someone's name is known to have a specific long vowel sound) we need to get it right every time. And we also want to reflect [conventional Canadian preferences](/home/a/americanisms) (e.g., putting an "f" in _lieutenant_ and rhyming the prefixes "_anti-_" and "_semi-_" with "BEE" rather than "BYE"). Of course, sometimes established preferences are eventually broadened to include two or more equally acceptable approaches. When that happens, we celebrate the country's diverse dialects, as long as each pronunciation is well enough entrenched to fall into the general category of standard Canadian English (e.g., _schedule_ can be "SKED-jool" or "SHED-yool," and either can be "EE-ther" or "EYE-ther").

For more on the challenge of pronouncing words in a way that's "educated" but not elitist, including the long-standing debate over how to say kilometre, see an excerpt from the April 2000 Russ Germain column, [The ABCs of CBC Pronunciation](/handy-links/pronunciation/the-abcs-of-cbc-pronunciation).

### The ABCs of CBC Pronunciation


**The ABCs of CBC Pronunciation**
**by Russ Germain**, former CBC Broadcast Language Adviser
(Excerpt from an April 2000 column)


On one of our newscasts not so long ago, a network announcer pronounced the AIDS drug AZT as "Ay Zee Tee." The calls came in fast and furious. Canadians don't say _Zee_, they say _Zed_. Make no mistake, we are not American. We've heard similar complaints about other influences from south of the border over the years: quayz-eye for _quasi_; sem-eye for _semi_; ant-eye for _anti_; OH-fence for _offense_; MISS-ill for _missile_; rowt for _route_ (a pathway) rather than for _rout_ (a decisive defeat). The list is long.

Many Canadians regard the CBC as the keeper of their mother tongue. Many others whose first language is not English but, rather, any one of the dozens of others heard in Canada today also turn to the CBC as a definitive source of English — English they expect to hear spoken by educated Canadians. In this sense, these citizens and immigrants use the public broadcaster as a guide....

Exactly who decides what language is right and what isn't on CBC airwaves? Certainly our listeners, readers and viewers have a great deal of influence. If they can't understand what we're trying to say or don't feel we are speaking in their own "Canadian English," then we are not communicating as well as we are supposed to.

But before we go any further, let's differentiate between two kinds of speech you hear on the CBC. The first is extemporaneous or unrehearsed conversation. This can be heard, for example, in an interview, a phone-in show or a debate. The second is speech that is formal, or written and edited before it is aired in, say, a newscast or documentary.

In the first case, we cannot expect people to speak perfectly all the time off the tops of their heads. That would be an almost impossible standard to achieve, let alone maintain. Even professional broadcasters are human, after all. Nevertheless, our on-air journalists are expected to have a better than average command of English. And in the completely scripted language of newscasts, news reports, or documentaries, our listeners should hear speech that conforms to the best possible usage....

If listeners, viewers and readers are part of our quality control, what are they telling us? Many stress the importance of the fundamental rules of grammar.... Some people write or phone to challenge sloppy enunciation. For example, hundred (not _hundert_), picture (not _pitchure_), February (does anyone say _Febrooary_ anymore?), et cetera, (not _eck cetera_). Then there are the pronunciations that everyone agrees to disagree about. Is it _shedule_ or _skedule_, _skallop_ or _skawlop_, _eether_ or _eyether_, _staytus_ or _stahtus_, _dayta_ or _dahta_, ant or _awnt_? It all depends on where you're from and what you learned in school — _er, shool_.

Perhaps the longest-running battle over pronunciation at the CBC is the word _kilometre_. When Canada adopted the metric system of measurement in 1970, it established a metric commission to guide implementation. The commissioners included pronunciation of the various units of measurement as part of their mandate. The rule was simple: Units of measurement had primary stress on the first syllable; KILL-oh-gram, KILL-oh-watt, KILL-oh-pass-kal and KILL-oh-mee-ter. The suffix is spelled _metre_. Instruments of measurement on the other hand have primary stress on the second syllable: spee-DAW-meh-ter, bah-RAW-meh-ter, ther-MAW-meh-ter, etc. The suffix is spelled _meter_.

But to this day, many Canadians continue to pronounce kilometre as kih-LAW-meh-ter. This pronunciation defines it as an instrument of measurement, not as a unit of measurement. Almost all dictionaries show kih-LAW-meh-ter as acceptable because its popular use has been documented enough times. But in such cases, the CBC strongly advises its broadcasters to embrace the pronunciation used by informed or educated Canadians — that is, those who have been trained in science and technology.

More than once an editor has tried to argue that insisting on KILL-oh-mee-ter over kih-LAW-meh-ter — or any other "proper" language — amounts to linguistic elitism. "My listeners don't speak that way in their everyday lives," they say. Perhaps not. But is it the CBC's mandate to simply reflect clichéd, popular jargon as our preferred method of communication? If we buy that argument, we're in danger of supporting the position that education in general is elitist.

On one hand Canadians expect us to subscribe to popular usage, not to talk down to them or talk over their heads; to be real. On the other, they expect us to aim for the highest linguistic common factor, not the lowest common denominator. For those who care passionately about the language, it's no small challenge to find the right balance.

See [Pronunciation FAQs](/handy-links/pronunciation) for general principles and guidelines.
Go to the **[CBC PRONUNCIATION DATABASE](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2FLNG%2FRecherche%2FIndex.aspx&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2p5Bo2D4gXWwBfXu8gqKe3)** for an alphabetical list of more than 12,000 phonetic preferences dating back decades.

**Punctuation**

The architecture of written English is remarkably varied. Although there's consensus over when to write "its" (a pronoun) and "it's" (a contraction), language authorities have their own preferences — some wildly idiosyncratic — for a myriad of other matters, including decisions about capital letters, hyphens, ellipses and commas.

Strunk and White's steadfastly popular the Elements of Style, for instance, recommends another comma in the last sentence of the first paragraph (after the word "ellipses"). But we and most other major news services in North America don't bother with the final comma in a series unless the last element includes a conjunction. This is known as the "bacon and eggs" rule. (See [commas](/handy-links/punctuation/commas))

For consistency, CBC News follows a [modified Canadian Press style](/home/s/spelling/modified-cp-style). **Each page below lists the key guidelines about a given point of typography.** The longest entries deal with apostrophes, commas, ellipses and quotation marks. Some points include links to more detailed discussions (e.g., the use of periods in abbreviations, etc.)
