### Apostrophes

**Apostrophes**

**Avoid mixing up contractions** (it's) **and pronouns** ([its](/home/i/its-versus-its)).

**Avoid confusing closing single quotation marks** (') **with possessive apostrophes**. (See [quotation marks](/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks) and [possessive apostrophes](/handy-links/punctuation/possessive-apostrophe) for relevant guidelines.)

**Treat possessive apostrophes as part of a word.** Do not insert a comma, period or other punctuation between the apostrophe and the word (e.g., The other dog was the Smiths', court was told). But be aware that recasting is sometimes preferable (Court was told that the Smiths owned the other dog).

**Check proper nouns you're not sure about.** For example: It's Queen's University, Maclean's magazine, Ottawa 67's (hockey team), Hudson's Hope, B.C., and Burk's Falls, Ont., but Hells Angels, Rhodes Scholar, San Francisco 49ers, Brights Grove, Ont., Shirleys Bay, Ont., and St. Catharines, Ont.

**Generally add an "s" to form a plural, even when the word already ends with the letter "s"** (Charles's, Eves's, James's, a witness's, the press's, etc.) See [s' versus s's](/handy-links/punctuation/s-versus-s-s)

**Use apostrophes rather than hyphens or other punctuation to indicate when individual letters form verbs** (e.g., X'd out the text, X'ing and O'ing her way to the tick-tack-toe championship).

**Add apostrophes to plural forms of INDIVIDUAL letters, whether lowercase or capitalized** (p's and q's, X's and O's, three A's and two B's on a report card, the Oakland A's). **This applies to SINGLE letters of the alphabet only**, not to clusters of letters or other characters (e.g., ABCs, FAQs, MPs, 747s). See [abbreviations](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/a/abbreviations/#singleletters "Abbreviations") for detailed guidelines and examples.

**Use figures to label decades:** the 1930s, the '30s, the Dirty '30s (not Thirties).

**Do not put apostrophes before the "s" in the plural forms of years** (1980s, 1920s, mid-1940s). Also, generally treat a decade as a descriptive adjective rather than a true possessive (a 1950s radio).

**Abbreviate years with apostrophes when seeking an informal tone** (the '70s), **but not when referring to an official name that doesn't include the punctuation** (Expo 67, Expo 86). See also [World Fair versus world fair](/home/w/world-fair)

**Avoid treating unambiguous attributive nouns as possessives** (the Leafs' first loss of the season but a Leafs player, NOT a "Leafs' player") See [possessive apostrophes](/handy-links/punctuation/possessive-apostrophe)

See also [plurals](/home/p/plurals) (an overview)
Return to [main punctuation page](/handy-links/punctuation)

### Brackets

**Round ( ) versus square \[ \] brackets**





**Parentheses (an overview)**
**Extra detail is usually added to sentences with the simple use of commas:**

> Williams, also known the Splendid Splinter, never made more than $150,000 a season.

**But parentheses work just as well (or better) from time to time:**

> Ted (Splendid Splinter) Williams never made more than $150,000 a season.


(See also [nicknames](/home/n/nicknames))

**Use brackets sparingly.** They stand out in copy, so too many of them in one story are distracting. They can also leave readers with the impression of tentativeness. (Why isn't the writer being more direct? Why all the asides?)

And they can sometimes block the flow of a story, making it harder to read. Long sentences held up in large part by brackets usually signal the need for a rewrite.


**Round Brackets ( )**
**Outside directly transcribed quotations, brackets should always be round:**

> The south pole on Mars was 148 K (–125 C) last month.


Although there's no point including Kelvin and Celsius readings in most stories, the sentence above might work well in a science feature on the history of the Kelvin scale.

> She worked at the Des Moines (Iowa) Register before moving to Canada in 1997.


Adding the state in brackets helps identify where the woman worked. If the city was not part of a proper noun (i.e., the newspaper's name), we would simply put the word Iowa after a comma:

> She worked at a newspaper in Des Moines, Iowa, before moving to Canada in 1997.


**Square Brackets** \[ \]
**Always use square brackets \[ \] to identify anything we've added to transcribed quotations.** This helps our readers know whether the words are CBCNews.ca's insertion or merely an aside by the speaker or writer we’re quoting:

> "Lawrence \[Janet Cooper’s husband\] ran off the stage," Anderson testified. "That’s when I heard the gunshot."
>
> "As I recall (although my memory is going), they booed John Crosbie \[then federal fisheries minister\] until he finally gave them the finger and stormed away," Manchester wrote in her 1989 memoirs.


This applies to definitions we add, such as spelled-out abbreviations, that would normally be in round brackets. Although the extra content in these cases is almost always immediately understood to be information provided by us, it's still important to use square brackets for consistency. That way, no one is left wondering what's been added to the original quote. The punctuation makes it clear.

> "After four consecutive Conservative budgets, it is clear that the current government has failed to live up to its 2006 election promise to move Canadian aid performance toward the OECD \[Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development\] average donor spending levels," Fowler said.


Add information only if it helps readers. Avoid unnecessary asides. In a quote about "eight to 10 inches of snow," for example, there's little point inserting a metric conversion in square brackets. Since the amount of snow is already well understood, the square brackets unnecessarily spoil the quote's flow. (See [metric versus imperial](/home/m/metric-versus-imperial) for related guidelines.)


**Brackets and punctuation**
Periods, commas, question marks and so forth may go inside or outside brackets, depending on whether the punctuation applies to the entire sentence or just to the parenthetical words.


**Outside**
**If the brackets enclose an aside that falls within a larger sentence, the punctuation goes on the outside:**

> "We bought new tires for our used car \[a 1955 Chevrolet station wagon\]," he said, "and then drove to B.C."
>
> Bachner always ate at the same Toronto diner. She got to know all the regulars, including a quiet man who never took off his gloves (pianist Glenn Gould).

**Inside**
**If the brackets enclose one or more separate sentences, put the punctuation on the inside:**

> (Health Canada launched the investigation in 1993.)

**Outside and Inside**
**Sometimes combinations are called for. The key is deciding if the punctuation applies to the entire sentence or merely to the words in brackets:**

> The comedian paused for laughter, broke the uncomfortable silence with familiar patter ("Is this mike on?"), and then continued with his standup routine.

**The 'extra' period**
**If a declarative sentence ends with an abbreviation that falls directly before a bracket, a closing period is still required outside the bracket** unless the entire sentence is parenthetical:

> (All three murder suspects were eventually extradited to the U.S.) 
>
> The violinist had 10 honorary doctorates and one earned degree (a B.Mus.).
>
> He preferred euphemisms ("passed on," "no longer with us," etc.).

**Capital letters**
**In general, capital letters are not used inside brackets unless they begin a direct quote:**

> "After waking everyone up \[by screaming 'Air raid!'\], I ran back outside and tried to find Lt. Jordan," McNally said.


See also [quotation marks](/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks) for more information about when to use capital letters inside inverted commas.

See also [editing quotes](/home/q/quotes-editing) for strict limits on changing words inside inverted commas.

For detailed guidelines on periods, commas, etc. go to the [main punctuation page](/handy-links/punctuation).

### Colons

**Colons**

The ":" sign is **an excellent tool** for web writers because it **allows us to introduce short bursts of text that are easy to read** on computer monitors. (See also [bulleted lists](/home/b/bulleted-list))

**When a colon is used in a sentence, generally use a lowercase word right after it:**

> She took a broad range of courses: chemistry, math, philosophy and art history.


**Use a capital letter only if you want to emphasize a point or introduce a quote:**

> The veteran comedian said he could sum up his success in one word: Timing.
>
> The answer is simple, he said: "Timing."


**Normally, commas introduce short quotes** (one sentence or less). Colons are usually reserved for longer remarks.

**When flush to closing quotation marks, colons always go outside** (i.e., ": rather than :")

(For more examples, see [quotation marks](/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks))

**In certain proper nouns, such as film titles, colons can be helpful to set apart secondary detail.** This punctuation is acceptable even when it's not technically part of the original noun, because colons take up less space and are less distracting than alternatives, such as brackets or dashes:

> _Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1_     (First reference)
>
> _Deathly Hallows: Part 1_    (Second reference)


Return to [main punctuation page](/handy-links/punctuation)

### Commas

**Commas**

"Commas don’t seem to inspire shouting matches the way hyphens do," says Bill Walsh, a senior copy editor at the Washington Post. "But opinions on their proper use probably vary even more widely."

**Sometimes, leaving out commas changes the entire sentence. At other times, putting them in is simply a matter of style.** When commas represent a pause in speech, for example, people disagree on the best place to give the eye or ear a rest. Even when they represent a conjunction, such as the word "and," there are debates.

Essayist E.B. White, known for his magazine writing and stories for children, had this to say about his own employer’s approach: "Commas in The New Yorker fall with the precision of knives in a circus act, outlining the victim."

**Here are some rudimentary guidelines:
**
(a) [How many husbands?](/handy-links/punctuation/commas#husbands) (The Queen and her husband, Prince Philip, then arrived.)
(b) [Serial comma killer](/handy-links/punctuation/commas#serial) beyond the "bacon and eggs rule" (The flag was red, blue and green.)
(c) [Conjunctions](/handy-links/punctuation/commas#conjunctions) (The road was dusty, and the sound of chainsaws filled the valley.)
(d) [Adjectives](/handy-links/punctuation/commas#adjectives) (She was a funny, generous woman. He wore an old brown fishing hat.)
(e) [Pileups cause problems](/handy-links/punctuation/commas#pileups) (Avoid too many adjectives and adverbs.)

**For the use of commas in dates** (e.g., Aug. 13, 2003, versus August 2003), **geographical locations** (She was born in Penticton, B.C., in 1978), **etc., see [abbreviations](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/a/abbreviations/ "Abbreviations")**.

For the use of commas in large numbers (e.g., 1,000), see [numbers](/home/n/numbers).


**(a) How many husbands?**
**Put commas around non-defining** (also known as non-restrictive) **parts.** These are parenthetical matters. **They add detail, but removing them would not change the meaning of the sentence. Do not put commas around defining** (also known as restrictive) parts. **These are essential to the sentence’s meaning.**

**
Correct:**

> The professor and **her husband, Angus**, both play in the orchestra.


(The commas flag an aside. In this case, it's what grammarians call an appositive. The proper noun "Angus" refers to the noun "husband" already introduced. The name adds detail but it could be removed and the meaning of the sentence would remain the same.)


**Wrong:**

> The professor and **her husband Angus** both play in the orchestra.


(In this version, the professor has several spouses. Angus is the husband who plays in the orchestra with her.)


**Maybe right, maybe wrong:**

> The professor and **her daughter Anna** both play in the orchestra.


(The professor has more than one daughter, which may be true.)

> The accused entered the room with **his lawyer Billy Bolours**.


(The accused has more than one lawyer, according to this sentence. In some stories this may be true.)

**Defining and non-defining sentence parts** (clauses, phrases and other fragments) **come up in writing a lot**. See also [that versus which](/home/t/that-versus-which)



**(b) Serial comma killer**
Some authorities (including Strunk and White) recommend including a final comma in a string of three or more elements. But CP (and CBC.ca) style is to **leave out the last serial comma (red, blue and green) unless it’s absolutely needed for clarity** (e.g., when the final element is a compound, such as "gin and tonic"). At The Associated Press, **this is known as the "bacon and eggs" rule:**

> They brought food, clothing and a sense of adventure. 
>
> The report focused on interest rates, rising bank fees and merger rules. 
>
> He drank wine, whiskey, and gin and tonic. 
>
> They talked to prosecutors from Quebec, New Brunswick, and Newfoundland and Labrador.



**(c) Conjunctions**
**Generally use commas before conjunctions** (and, but, or, etc.) **if the subject or central theme changes in the next clause:**

> The road was dusty, and the sound of chainsaws filled the valley. 
>
> Some editors are failed writers, but so are most writers. (_T.S. Eliot_) 
>
> I don't enjoy writing, and I certainly would not do it for a living. Some people do, but some people enjoy flagellation. (_Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh_)


**Commas are unnecessary if the subject doesn't change, if the clause after the conjunction is short, or if the conjunction is merely introducing another adjective or other modifier:**

> The road was dusty and bumpy. 
>
> Some editors are failed writers and drunks. 
>
> The children laughed and sang and raised the old man's spirit. 
>
> It is a mistake to think that books have come to stay. The human race did without them for thousands of years and may decide to do without them again. (_E.M. Forster_)



**(d) Crisp, clear descriptions don’t always need commas**
**When commas represent "and" in a compound adjective, leave them IN:**

> a funny, generous woman
>
> a wide-ranging, detailed report


**But if commas wouldn’t normally be replaced by "and" in conversation, generally leave them OUT.** This is almost always true when the adjective’s sequence would seem unnatural reversed:

> a white toy poodle (_a toy white poodle is something else_)
>
> a Canadian shipping magnate (_a shipping Canadian magnate?_)
>
> a 10-speed racing bike (_a racing 10-speed bike?_)


**In the above examples, the modifiers are integral to the noun. You would probably add a comma if another adjective was added** (e.g., a yappy, white toy poodle) **but not always**. The Globe and Mail’s style manual cites the following as tenably acceptable: "He was wearing his battered old canvas fishing hat."

**Writers obviously have latitude, as long as their sentences are clear.** An "old orange juice bottle" is understood immediately. An "orange, juice bottle" means something quite different (i.e., the juice container itself is orange).




**(e) Pileups cause problems**
Although imagery and detail can make a story better, too many adjectives and adverbs hurt the writing. So **as you debate whether to add commas, be sure to avoid adjectival pileups first:**

> "The old, noisy, red and green, fast-moving, foreign-owned diesel locomotive snaked up the mountain, forming the shape of a giant comma as it disappeared into the cold, misty darkness."


For a look at commas with quotes, see [quotation marks](/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks)

Return to [main punctuation page](/handy-links/punctuation)

### Dash

**Dashes**

We generally prefer commas, but **dashes are ideal when a clause or other fragment in the middle of a sentence already has commas in it:**

> Several provinces and territories have launched legal challenges — including Alberta, B.C. and Quebec — but the federal government says it has no intention of backing down.

**
Dashes can also be handy to avoid ambiguity:**

> The other costs — taxes and legal fees — were lower than projected.


(Using commas in this case wouldn’t make it clear that "taxes and legal fees" were the "other costs.")

**In rare cases, dashes at the end of a quote can represent a speaker being cut off:**

> "I think you should—"


But use "..." instead of "—" if the speaker's voice simply trails away. (See [ellipses](/handy-links/punctuation/ellipses) for more details)


**—, – and -**
**Never use hyphens (-) for "em" dashes (—)**, which are about the width of a capital M, or **"en" dashes (–)**, which are about the width of a capital N.

**Use long** ("em") **dashes whenever demarcating part of a sentence.**

**Use slightly shorter** ("en") **dashes for the minus sign in temperatures. Type these flush to the figure:**

_–15 C_ or –15 degrees (when Celsius is implied)

See also [temperatures](/home/m/metric-versus-imperial#temperatures)


**Proper nouns**
**Generally avoid dashes in proper nouns. Prefer hyphens instead.** For instance, if a title includes a time period with an "en dash" ("1995–2010") or a longer "em" dash ("1995—2010"), there's no need to match the typography exactly. Instead, a hyphen is OK ("1995-2010").

**This use of hyphens also applies to [electoral districts](/handy-links/punctuation/hyphens#electoraldistricts)** (e.g., Dartmouth-Cole Harbour, Mississauga-Streetsville).

**HTML code**
**The HTML code for an em dash is &#8212;**.

> "Dash it all. I prefer em dashes."
>
> — Dashiell Hammettnot, 1946


**The HTML code for an en dash is &#8211;**

But avoid adding manual, unauthorized HTML code to CBC News content. Instead, use the in-house publishing tool.

Return to [main punctuation page](/handy-links/punctuation)

### Ellipses

**Ellipses**

We use a set of three dots (...) to indicate that words are missing from direct quotations. We do not type three periods, because these can become separated in "line breaks" on people’s computer monitors, depending how they have their browsers set. Instead, we use HTML coding to keep the cluster together (generally rendered as "&#133;" or an equivalent through a CBC-endorsed publishing tool).

Several different publishing conventions exist for ellipses. For consistency, follow the guidelines below:

[Rule A](/handy-links/punctuation/ellipses#ruleA)     (Avoid "...)
[Rule B](/handy-links/punctuation/ellipses#ruleB)     (Put spaces ... before and after)
[Rule C](/handy-links/punctuation/ellipses#ruleC)     (When to use four dots)


[Rule D](/handy-links/punctuation/ellipses#ruleD)     (..." means voice trails off)
[Rule E](/handy-links/punctuation/ellipses#ruleE)     (Handling long excerpts in features)
[Trudeau and sex](/handy-links/punctuation/ellipses#trudeauandsex) (An illustration)

**Rule A**
In news stories, **never use ellipses at the start of quotes**. Use them at any point in the middle. **Do not use them at the very end** (except in rare cases when indicating that the speaker's voice trailed off, as outlined in Rule D).

**Rule B**
**Type spaces before and after the three dots**, except in the case of Rule C.


**Rule C**
**If an ellipsis falls at the end of a sentence in the middle of a quote, butt it against the period.... You end up with four dots,** with no space at the beginning.


**ORIGINAL WORDING**

> _"I want you to stop adding dots, and by dots I mean ellipses, to your sentences and concentrate on adding pizzazz instead. I’m wandering off on a tangent now. Oops. I’m back. There’s more to life than punctuation."_

**Correct**

> "I want you to stop adding dots ... to your sentences and concentrate on adding pizzazz instead."

**Correct**

> "There’s more to life than punctuation."

**Wrong**

> "... There’s more to life than punctuation."

**Correct (a) + (b)**

> (a) "I want you to stop adding dots ... to your sentences and concentrate on adding pizzazz instead.... There’s more to life than punctuation."

**Constructions with several ellipses can be distracting, however,** so **it’s often better to break up the quote with attribution:**

> (b) "Stop adding dots ... to your sentences and concentrate on adding pizzazz instead," he said. "There’s more to life than punctuation."

**Two-paragraph quotes**
**A two-paragraph quote that's split at an ellipsis still satisfies Rule A.** In such rare cases, the punctuation is technically in the middle of the quote.


**ORIGINAL WORDING**

> _"Why is babbling so important? The infant is like a person who has been given a complicated piece of audio equipment bristling with unlabelled knobs and switches but missing the instruction manual. In such situations people resort to what hackers call 'frobbing' — fiddling aimlessly with the controls to see what happens. The infant has been given a set of neural commands that can move the articulators every which way, with wildly varying effects on the sound. By listening to their own babbling, babies in effect write their own instruction manuals. They learn how much to move which muscle in which way to make which change in the sound. This is a prerequisite to duplicating the speech of their parents. Some computer scientists, inspired by the infant, believe that a good robot should learn an internal software model of its articulators by observing the consequences of its owns babbling and flailing."_

\\

(Comments by Canadian-born linguist Steven Pinker in 1994)

**Edited version, with paragraph split at the ellipsis**

> "The infant is like a person who has been given a complicated piece of audio equipment bristling with unlabelled knobs and switches but missing the instruction manual. In such situations people resort to what hackers call 'frobbing' — fiddling aimlessly with the controls to see what happens....
>
> "By listening to their own babbling, babies in effect write their own instruction manuals. They learn how much to move which muscle in which way to make which change in the sound. This is a prerequisite to duplicating the speech of their parents."


Four dots are used at the end of the first paragraph because **Rule C applies.**

**See [editing quotes](/home/q/quotes-editing) for more details, including guidelines on inserting attribution instead of an ellipsis at a paragraph break,** as well as advice on picking a different spot for the split.

See also [quotation marks](/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks) for the applicable rule on closing punctuation in such cases (i.e., postponing the final inverted commas until the very end).


**Rule D**
**Close a quote with an ellipsis only when the speaker's voice trails off.** These dots do not mean that words have been left out. They imply that there weren't any more words:

> "I thought I had Rule A down pat, but then again ..."


**This punctuation is rarely used in news stories, but it is a well-known convention.** Do not put three dots at the end of quotes unless the speakers actually stop talking on their own.

**Use a dash instead of an ellipsis at the end of a quote if the person is interrupted:**

> "I thought I had Rule A down pat," said the writer. "But then again – "
>
> "No one cares," snorted the editor.

**Rule E**
**E stands for _extra-long_ exception. When condensing written text** (e.g., putting part of a book or the published transcription of a speech) **in a background feature, you can place ellipses at the beginning, middle and end of sentences and paragraphs** (depending, of course, on where you made your cuts). **This is obviously an exception to Rule A. Rule E applies only to long chunks of written text. It does not apply to brief excerpts of written text inserted into news stories.**

**
Dots easy for you to say**
**Why doesn’t Rule E govern all quotes?** In other words, why is the wider use of ellipses limited to long excerpts of written text reproduced in features?

**In stories an ellipsis at the start or end is implied.** The word ellipsis comes from a Greek term that means "leave out" (_elleipein_). Most quotations fall before or after other words spoken by the same person (and often both before and after). So if we abandoned Rule A we’d have to add dots before and after most quotes. Our pages would become unnecessarily pimpled with periods.

As the Washington Post editor Bill Walsh writes in his delightful book Lapsing Into a Comma, "It's silly to indicate omission at the beginning or end of a quote, since virtually all quotes are from people who have spoken before in their lives and will do so again." This entry appears under the heading: "... And Another Thing ..."

**Trudeau and sex**

Here’s an example of a now-famous quote being lifted from a much longer statement by Pierre Trudeau. He was talking about legislation that he had just introduced in the Commons as justice minister.

**Original comments to reporters on Dec. 21, 1967:**

_"Well, it’s certainly the most extensive revision of the Criminal Code since the new Criminal Code of the early 1950s. And in terms of the subject matter it deals with, I feel that it has knocked down a lot of totems and overridden a lot of taboos. And I feel that, in that sense, it is ‘new.’ But it’s bringing the laws of the land up to contemporary society, I think. Take this thing on homosexuality. I think the view we take here is that **there’s no place for the state in the bedrooms of the nation**, and I think that, you know, what’s done in private between adults doesn’t concern the Criminal Code. When it becomes public, this is a different matter."_

**Correct**

> "There’s no place for the state in the bedrooms of the nation," Justice Minister Pierre Trudeau said.


**Wrong**

> "... There’s no place for the state in the bedrooms of the nation...," Justice Minister Pierre Trudeau said.


Colombo's New Canadian Quotations (1987), by the way, claims that Trudeau never said the above. But the video and audio is on the [CBC Archives](https://www.cbc.ca/player/play/video/1.4715835) website. In a Dec. 22, 1967, interview Trudeau rephrased it: "The state has no place in the nation's bedrooms." This is the version cited by Colombo's. In either case, Trudeau's inspiration was clearly a Globe and Mail editorial by Martin O'Malley, which was published more than a week earlier (Dec. 12, 1967).

For detailed guidelines on strict rules governing "cleaning up" quotes (e.g., removing stammers without using ellipses), see [editing quotes](/home/q/quotes-editing).

Return to [main punctuation page](/handy-links/punctuation)

### Hyphens

**Hyphens**

**There's no overriding logic behind using or not using hyphens.** In the last sentence, for instance, "over-riding" is not an option listed by the Canadian Oxford Dictionary. **And since English is a living language, certain preferences change** (e.g., _e-mail_ eventually became _email),_ **especially compound nouns**(e.g., _think tank_ is commonly written as _think-tank_ now, and _by-product_ as _byproduct_). Here are some general guidelines:

(a) [Adjectives and adverbs](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/handy-links/punctuation/hyphens/#adjectives_2 "Hyphens") (overview)
(b) [Ages](/handy-links/punctuation/hyphens#ages) (33-year-old man versus Darren Dashes, 33, ...)
(c) ["per cent"](/handy-links/punctuation/hyphens#percent) (10 per cent increase, never 10-per-cent ...)
(d) [Adjectives used predicatively](/handy-links/punctuation/hyphens#predicatively) (location can govern whether hyphens are needed)
(e) [Compounds](/handy-links/punctuation/hyphens#compounds) (online not on line, lieutenant-governor but Governor General, sit-in not sit in, Asian Canadian not Asian-Canadian, etc.)
(f) [Electoral districts](/handy-links/punctuation/hyphens#electoraldistricts) (Ottawa West-Nepean and Edmonton-Wetaskiwin)
(g) [Attributive nouns](/handy-links/punctuation/hyphens#attributivenouns) (tree planter, layoff notice, lockout clause)
(h) [Various](/handy-links/punctuation/hyphens#various) (ranks such as Lt.-Gen., prefixes such as anti-, years such as 1975-76, aircraft names such as CF-18, sequences such as 18th- and 19th-century as well as over- and underfed animals, etc.)

**(a) Adjectives and adverbs**
**In general, do not bother adding hyphens to modifiers if the meaning is already clear.** This is usually determined by common usage and convention.

> foreign aid bill
>
> goods and services tax
>
> gun control legislation
>
> long forgotten complaint
>
> now rare wording
>
> once powerful group 
>
> state of the union address
>
> swine flu vaccine
>
> D minor concerto

**
But do hyphenate when modifiers form a single, separate concept that is not instantly obvious without the punctuation:**

> a know-nothing meddler 
>
> all-expenses-paid trip
>
> blood-alcohol level
>
> drinking-and-driving charge
>
> hit-and-run accident
>
> non-life-threatening injuries
>
> tax-free savings account
>
> used-car dealer
>
> worst-paid workers


**When debating which of these two categories specific modifiers fall into, keep the best interests of our audience in mind. If hyphens aid people's ability to scan text in a hurry, add the punctuation** — especially if the modifier is probably not seen or said a lot in this context (e.g., "tree-planting company" versus "high school principal" or "acid rain levels").

In recent decades, **the general publishing trend has been toward fewer hyphens** (e.g., writing about a "once common practice" instead of about a "once-common practice," with the adverb "once" being treated in the same way as "most" and "less" and "very" in routine phrasing (e.g., most efficient method, less prolific writer and very detailed instructions). While certain idioms retain hyphens based on convention, be on the lookout for redundancies (e.g., the intensifier "first" in "[**first-ever**](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/e/ever/ "Ever")" can often be axed).

**In certain cases, a hyphen can change the meaning** of a sentence. For example, the **most-skilled workers** (i.e., workers who are most skilled) versus the **most skilled workers** (i.e., the greatest number of skilled workers).

**TIP: Sometimes the nature of the first word makes a difference. If it can be initially read as a verb or as a noun** (e.g., "boil" instead of "overseas"), **a hyphen is generally recommended** because the sentence becomes potentially less jarring:

> boil-water advisory
>
> overseas travel advisory


Note: A compound such as "hit and run" does not generally take hyphens when used as a noun (e.g., "**a hit-and-run investigation**" versus "**another hit and run**"). Be aware, however, that various nouns are hyphenated (**remarkable know-how**). The Canadian Oxford Dictionary is a good guide for determining such distinctions.

Always remember that **hyphens are primarily added to help readers scanning text.** Since such assessments involve personal judgment, **good writers and editors will sometimes disagree on whether the punctuation is needed**. When adding hyphens, **avoid inserting too many and be certain to place them in the right place**. In the case of adjectives and adverbs, **skip "ly" words**, which are already perceived by the eye as modifiers:

> 120-seat legislature
>
> four-kilometre hike
>
> Pulitzer Prize-winning author
>
> $25-million profit **but** a profit of $25 million (see [adjectival phrases used predicatively](/handy-links/punctuation/hyphens#predicatively) below)
>
> $50-billion US bailout **but** a bailout of $50 billion US
>
> fast-moving car **but** quickly moving train
>
> rarely seen event
>
> tightly woven sweater
>
> well-known person **but** perfectly clear instructions

**(b) Ages**
Although some constructions containing hyphens are common _(33-year-old Darren Dashes)_, they can also be rewritten _(Darren Dashes, 33, ran away)_. **Removing hyphens and putting ages after names frequently makes the web story easier to read.**

See [numbers](/home/n/numbers) for guidelines on when to spell out ages under 10 (e.g., _four_) and when to use figures (e.g., _4_).


**(c) The term 'per cent'**
Hyphens are not needed in some well-known foreign (e.g. Latin) phrases, including "per cent":

> 10 per cent increase (**not** 10-per-cent increase) 

> Two per cent drop (**not** 2-per-cent drop **or** two-per-cent drop)


See also [numbers](/home/n/numbers) for detailed guidelines on using figures instead of words for amounts under 10.
See also [money](/home/m/money) for detailed guidelines on reporting financial amounts, currency conversions, etc.


**(d) Adjectival phrases used predicatively**
This category’s name is intimidating, but the rule is rather simple. Generally **avoid putting hyphens in words that come after the terms they're modifying:**

> a two-and-a-half-year sentence
>
> **but** sentenced to two and a half years (_no hyphens_) 
>
> a $10-million loss
>
> **but** a loss of $10 million
>
> a well-known painter
>
> **but** the painter is well known (_no hyphens_)


**(e) Compounds**

**Short compounds traditionally drift from two words** (_on line_) **to a hyphenated version** (_on-line_) **before becoming fused** (_online_).
**
Sometimes the words don't actually shift** (_thrill-seeker_) **or change only very slowly** (_teeny-bopper_ to _teenybopper_, and _counter-argument_ to _counterargument_), **depending on usage. In other cases, they jump from two words to one without ever getting a hyphen** (e.g., CP moved from "_video cassette_" to "_videocasette_" and "_pay day_" to "_payday_" in 2003, and we switched from _pay phone_ to _payphone_ in early 2020).

**Occasionally, conventions create confusing or illogical usage** (e.g., _child care_ but _daycare_). English, however, is neither consistent nor logical. For instance, we have _front yards_ (two words) but _backyards_ (fused). **It's important to know and follow current style. When in doubt, check.**

**Longer compound nouns normally take hyphens because they're easier to read as one unit** (e.g., a _physicist-turned-novelist_ or a _convict-turned-crime-fighter_).

**Hyphens also commonly set off what amount to syllabic abbreviations represented by one capital letter of the alphabet** (e.g., _H-bomb, T-shirt, U-turn, X-ray_). Although hyphens were initially common in "_e-mail_" as well, the term is now conventionally fused (_email_). The Canadian Oxford Dictionary dropped the hyphen in 2004. The Canadian Press followed suit four years later. **CBCNews.ca adopted email in late 2008. But virtually all other generic terms that use a lowercase "e" as an abbreviation for "electronic" retain the standard [e- format](/home/e#e-)** (_e-book, e-commerce, e-health, e-learning, e-waste_, etc.), **because this punctuation helps flag these constructions**, which can otherwise be jarring when scanned. **Exceptions are based on entrenched convention**, such as _esports_, which lost its hyphen in 2017. **Some proper nouns are also fused** (_eBay, eHealth Ontario, the ePub file format_), depending on the official spelling. Since these are proprietary compounds, they frequently feature a capital letter after the lowercase "e," unlike the generic terms _email_ and _esports_. (See also [quirky capitalization](/home/q/quirky-capitalization) for related guidelines on _iPod_, _Imax_, etc., including why _email_, _e-book_ and _iPod_ all become _Email_, _E-book_ and _IPod_ at the start of sentences.) 

**Capitalization often plays a role in determining whether to add a hyphen in compounds**, especially when individual letters denote sequence, hierarchy, etc. So it's _Exhibit A and B Block_ (no hyphens; initial caps because they're treated as name equivalents), but _A-list_ ("She's on Hollywood's A-list") and _B-team_ ("They rely more on their B-team now"), etc., because the punctuation makes the meaning clearer in the absence of capitalization. Be sure to distinguish between actual compounds (Bombardier's _[C Series](/home/a/aircraft-names)_ jets), which are treated as names, and generic nouns that are merely modified (e.g., a guitar's _C string_). 

**Hyphens appear in some titles** (lieutenant-governor) **but not in others** ([Governor General, secretary general, attorney general](/home/g/generalsuffix)), **and they’re normally kept out of job titles** (_high school principal_). See [titles](/home/t/titles)

**Sometimes, the hyphen is considered the preferred "Canadian" spelling** (especially when compared to a different U.S. form). **This is the case with "_co-operation_,"** for instance, which has a hyphen that represents a diacritical mark (ö) rarely used in English typography nowadays.

**In a few cases, editors refuse to remove the hyphen because they think the combination of letters is too awkward** (e.g., _sit-in_ and _non-Indigenous_  instead of _sitin_ and _nonIndigenous_).

Be aware that **hyphens are no longer used in geographical compounds denoting dual heritage, cultural identity, etc.** (e.g., _African American, Asian Canadian, Caribbean American, Korean Canadian_ and _Mexican American_). See [geographical demonyms](/home/r/racial-terms#geographical) for details.

**Check this site's alphabetical index first to determine if CBCNews.ca prefers a hyphen in a specific compound.** If you can't find the term, look in the Canadian Oxford Dictionary.


**(f) Electoral districts**

**Prefer hyphens rather than dashes in constituency names** (e.g., _Dartmouth-Cole Harbour, Mississauga-Streetsville_). **This avoids the need to pick between long and short dashes, or to distinguish between dashes and hyphens** in various compounds (e.g., _Notre-Dame-de-Grâce-Westmount_ and _Saint-Hyacinthe-Bagot_ versus _Notre-Dame-de-Grâce—Westmount_ and _Saint-Hyacinthe—Bagot_).

**Avoid adding unnecessary punctuation** (e.g., it's _Ottawa West-Nepean_ and _Edmonton-Wetaskiwin_ but _Ottawa South_ and _Edmonton Strathcona_).

**When unsure of a riding's name or spelling, always verify with federal/provincial officials** (e.g., [Elections Canada](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.elections.ca%2Fcontent.aspx%3Fsection%3Dres%26document%3Dindex%26lang%3De&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1rkdR3IBfbcMsawIq_7x1A)). Be aware that constituency names and boundaries can change from one election to the next.


**(g) Attributive nouns**

**Nouns are often used to modify other nouns** (_tea factory, coffee shop, tree planter, layoff notice_). **If the string of nouns is short, avoid hyphens.**

**Be sure to use nouns and not verbs in these constructions as required.** In the case of a fused noun (_layoff_), for example, do not slice the modifier into a two-word form (_lay off_). The "lay" in "lay off" is actually a verb and should not be followed by a hyphen. (So it's always _layoff notice_, **not** _lay-off notice_.)


**(h) Various other lines in the sand**

-   **When adding a prefix, we often use hyphens to keep two vowels apart** (_anti-abortion_ versus _antiwar_). **But there are plenty of exceptions** (_reopen_) **so always check**. See also [_**anti-** versus **anti**_](/home/a/anti-versus-anti)


-   **When faced with a prefix that might be misunderstood, we almost always add hyphens** (_re-cover a chair versus recover from an injury_).


-   **Verbs add complexity because they sometimes take hyphens when turned into nouns.** (_Cars drive in to the local drive-in_.) **Often, however, there are no hyphens.** (_Planes line up and then take off. We stood in the lineup and almost missed the takeoff._)


-   **In a sequence of hyphenated terms separated by unhyphenated words, leave spaces until the very end:** "_18th- and 19th-century astronomers_" and "T_he clock never made a sound on the 15-, 30- and 45-minute marks_."


-   **In a sequence of fused words, it's OK to use hyphens after an orphaned prefix to avoid repeating the same root elements:** "_over- and underfed animals_." **This shorthand can make broadcast scripts more conversational and online text easier to scan** (e.g., spelling out [PFAS](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/p/#PFAS "P") as "_per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances_"), as long as the roots are the same (e.g., write "_overfed and overworked animals_" and NOT "_overfed and -worked animals_").


-   _**Use hyphens between a figure and metric symbol in adjectives** (8-mm film, 9-mm pistol, 105-mm cannon)._


-   **Use hyphens when specifying time periods unless words such as "between" or "from" appear** (_1975-76 season_, **but** _from 1975 to 1976; 1988-98 trade figures,_ **but** _between 1988 and 1998_). **Keep in mind that a hyphen is often preferred because it makes web content easier to scan** (e.g., "presented Oct. 21-23" instead of "presented _from_ Oct. 21 to 23"). **In the case of centuries, use four digits after the hyphen if the first two numbers change** (_1799-1803_ **not** _1799-03_, etc.). See also [time](/home/t/time#1950s)


-   **Use hyphens in the names of some proper nouns,** including planes (_CF-18_) See [aircraft names](/home/a/aircraft-names)


-   **Use hyphens in some ranks** (Lt.-Gen.) See [military ranks](/home/m/military-ranks) and [police ranks](/home/p/police-ranks)


Return to [main punctuation page](/handy-links/punctuation)

### Italics

**Italics**

[Specific guidelines](/handy-links/punctuation/italics#specificguidelines) (two lists)
[Rules about foreign terms](/handy-links/punctuation/italics#foreignterms) (including Latin)


[Newspapers](/handy-links/punctuation/italics#newspapers) (an expanded section)

**Overview**
**Do NOT use italics in heads** (primary headlines), **decks** (secondary headlines), **subheads** (brief headings within articles) **or cutlines** (photo captions). Also, do NOT use single quotation marks as a substitute for italics in any of the above. Instead, use regular type with appropriate capitalization. (See [quotation marks](/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks) for detailed direction on using single inverted commas to flag attribution in headlines, decks, etc.).

**Use italics sparingly to flag certain nouns in the main text of stories,** according to the guidelines outlined below.

**The general rule: Italicize the titles of art, literary works and broadcast programs, but do NOT italicize the names of ships, buildings, holy books, newspapers or magazines.**

This approach distinguishes between titles and names. (Broadcast programs have titles, not names. Newspapers have names, not titles.)

It's consistent with policies at many large newspapers, including the Globe and Mail, the Toronto Star and the Washington Post.

**Note:** Italics are used a lot in many style manuals, including in this Language Guide, for emphasis and to avoid what otherwise would be a flurry of quotations marks and other distracting punctuation. But CBC News writers and editors should _not_ assume this means that they have carte blanche to adopt the same typography in web stories. (The two italicized words in this paragraph are examples of what to avoid in our online journalism.)


**Specific guidelines**



**_USE ITALICS_ for titles of:**

-   **artworks** (including paintings and sculptures)

-   **books** (except holy and reference, as outlined below)

-   **CDs
    **
-   **comic strips**
-   **dance works**
-   **films**
-   **musical works** (symphonies, pop songs, etc.)
-   **plays**
-   **podcasts** (akin to radio programs)
-   **poems**
-   **radio programs** (e.g., CBC Radio’s _Cross Country Checkup_ and _[Q](/home/q)_)
-   **records**
-   **short stories**
-   **TV programs** (e.g., CBC-TV's _The National_, NBC's _Today_ show, [_The Fifth Estate_](/home/f#Fifth_Estate))
-   **videos** (films, plays, and other artworks, but not YouTube videos, as outlined below)
-   **video games** and **computer games** considered artistic creations (e.g., _SimCity, Pac-Man, Guitar Hero_) rather than merely electronic versions of board games, card games or puzzles (e.g., the nouns Monopoly, Scrabble, solitaire and sudoku would be left in regular type)

If a title is italicized, the actual format (e.g., book, VHS, DVD) or platform (e.g., desktop computer, video console, smartphone) is irrelevant. Occasionally, a specific type of game or player is part of the noun and should be put in italics (e.g., _Wii Fit_). Otherwise, leave words such as DS, GameCube, Xbox, Wii in regular type.

(See also [The versus the](/home/t/the-versus-the) for related guidelines, as well as [**CBC**](/home/c/cbc) for details on handling various proper nouns.)


**DO NOT use italics for names of:**

-   **broadcasters** (ABC, BBC, CBC)
-   **commissions**
-   **court cases** (R. [vs.](/home/v#versus) Morgentaler, Roe v. Wade)
-   **exhibits** (at art galleries, museums, etc.)
-   **holy books** (the Bible, the Qur'an, etc.)
-   **legislation** (proposed bills, proclaimed [acts](/home/a/act), laws, regulations, etc.)
-   **magazines**
-   **newspapers**
-   **periodicals**
-   **reference books** (dictionaries, encyclopedias, etc.)
-   **reports** (e.g., a study by Statistics Canada)
-   **ships** (HMCS Corner Brook)
-   **software** other than certain games defined above (e.g., Windows 7, Mac OS X Snow Leopard, Microsoft Word, PowerPoint, Photoshop, QuickTime Pro)
-   **structures** (Empire State Building)
-   **website addresses** (see [URLs](/home/u/urls))
-   **website pages, including blogs** (unless italics are called for based on guidelines above, such as a broadcast program's internet page)
-   **wire services** (CP, AP, Reuters)

**And do NOT use italics when specifying sections of larger works,** such as:

-   **chapters of books**
-   **movements of classical works**
-   **titles of printed articles**

**Instead, use quotation marks when referring to parts of printed works,** including headlines from newspapers. **Always capitalize the first letter of all principal words in these cases,** even if they did not initially appear this way. This also applies to signs at protests, etc. But **do not put the titles of reports in quotation marks**, since these are individual publications rather than excerpts.

(See [quotation marks](/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks))


> _The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King_ swept the 2004 Oscars.
>
> _The Dead_ is a short story from James Joyce's _Dubliners_.
>
> For years, the only thing worth reading in that paper was _Calvin and Hobbes_.
>
> _Like a Rolling Stone_ is the first track on Bob Dylan's _Highway 61 Revisited_.
>
> Statistics Canada's released its report, How to Get Rich or Die Trying, on Thursday.
>
> The study, "Italics and The Bends," appears in the New England Journal of Medicine.
>
> The quote came from a chapter of _Chasing the Chinook_ called "Hustling Crokinole."
>
> The exhibit Tom Thomson Loved Trees includes the oil painting _Birches_.
>
> They played Bach's _Sonata in A minor_, 1st movement, flawlessly.
>
> The headline "Crikey, Just Like Mikey" appeared on the Toronto Sun's front page.
>
> Her short story, _No One Likes Italics_, was first published in The New Yorker.
>
> "The Talk of The Town" is a regular feature in The New Yorker.


**YouTube video titles**, from the silly ("My Dog Plays Harmonica") to the serious ("Making Our Country Safe Again") **should be treated as headlines we quote**, with capital letters at the start of all principal words and the entire title in quotation marks. Apply this style to most other videos that are given names or labels, unless these are artistic works (e.g., plays, films, documentaries) that happen to be on video. In that case, use italics as outlined above. A definition of [principal words](/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks#slogans) is found in the quotation marks overview. **The same applies to podcasts** (e.g., "Episode 4: The Secret Lives of Subversive Women"). **NOTE: Although the podcast name, itself, is italicized** (e.g., _The Secret Lives of Canada_), in the same way that a radio program name is italicized, **the episode title is rendered in regular type.**


**Foreign words**
Some publications, such as the New York Times, put virtually no foreign words in italics. Others, such as the Globe and Mail, go to the other extreme, still italicizing relatively common terms such as "mujahedeen." CBC News style falls somewhere in the middle, following the entries in the Canadian Oxford pretty closely. (Exceptions are listed in this Language Guide, along with some terms not covered by the dictionary.)

**In news stories, fairly common foreign words do NOT require italics:**


> ad nauseam
>
> fatwa
>
> glasnost
>
> intifada
>
> kukri
>
> mujahedeen
>
> perestroika


**This includes currencies, legal terms, musical jargon and other words that have become part of everyday English. (For French words, follow the accents listed in the Canadian Oxford.)**

Examples are:

> ad hoc
>
> allegro
>
> café, café au lait
>
> carte blanche
>
> caveat
>
> communiqué
>
> curriculum vitae
>
> entree
>
> gesundheit
>
> haiku
>
> modus operandi
>
> obbligato
>
> per cent
>
> per diem
>
> resumé \*
>
> tête-à-tête


\* In French, the word is _résumé_. But in English, only one acute accent is required to distinguish resumé (a curriculum vitae) from resume (to start again).

**Some words may have an accent and be put in italics only in certain circumstances.** For instance "[fete](/home/f#fete)" (which means "festival" as a noun and "to honour" as a verb) is a well-established English word. But the French expression _en fête_ (which means to hold or prepare for a celebration) would be in italics and include the accent. (See [**French words and accents**](/home/f/french-words-and-accents) for detailed guidelines)

**If a foreign word is not widely known, it should be put in italics.** Unless the context makes the word obvious, an explanation is required. The definition can be put in quotation marks:


> The sliding door, called a _shoji_, had no handle.
>
> _Allahu akbar_ is Arabic for "God is greater," she said, not for "God is great." At its core, the commonly mistranslated expression is a statement of humility by Muslims.


**The Canadian Oxford dictionary is a good guide.**

For instance:


**NO italics**

ad nauseam
caveat
carte blanche
communiqué
coup
glasnost

kukri
mujahedeen
rigor mortis  



**ITALICS**

_au revoir
carpe diem
caveat emptor
coup de grâce
coup d'état
de rigueur
objet d'art
persona non grata
realpolitik
schadenfreude
shoji_

**Be sure to check spellings of transliterations.** Try the Language Guide first. If the word is not there, consult the Canadian Oxford.

(See also [transliterations](/home/t/transliterations) and [foreign words](/home/f/foreign-words))

**Use italics for obscure foreign terms or phrases, or to highlight words that require translation:**


> Economists refer to it as a _ceteris paribus_ assumption.
>
> Canada's motto, _a mari usque ad mare_, means "from sea to sea."
>
> "There’s one word for it," she said: "_Schadenfreude_."
>
> The term _caveat emptor_ may sound exotic, but it's simply Latin for "buyer beware."
>
> The word "italic" comes from the Greek term _italikos_, which means "Italian."
>
> "No mandate? What about a _mandat de perquisition_ \[search warrant\]," he shouted.


**Religious terms, such as jihad and hajj, do NOT need to be italicized:
**

> After the bodies of the crushed pilgrims were removed the hajj resumed.
>
> The scarf, or hijab, she wore covered most of her face.
>
> He carried a ceremonial knife known as a kukri.


**And italics are NOT required for the names of organizations that are already marked by capitalization close to English (i.e, with most words featuring an initial capital letter):**


> He's accused of having ties to al-Qaeda.
>
> She joined Cirque du Soleil in 2002.
>
> Most of the province's teachers belong to the _Centrale des enseignants du Québec_.


**Scientific names**
Generally avoid Latin terms (e.g., _Aix galericulata_ instead of mandarin duck) except in some science stories or news features that benefit from such terms.

**When scientific names are used for species of animals, plants, etc. italicize all Latin but capitalize only the first word** (the genus):


> _Branta canadensis_ for Canada goose
>
> _Castor fiber canadensis_ for Canadian beaver
>
> _Homo sapiens_ for humans
>
> _Orcinus orca_ for killer whale


**Italicize such scientific jargon only if the genus is capitalized and the full Latin term is spelled out** (e.g., _Bacillus thuringiensis_). But when the genus is abbreviated, such as in the second reference to certain bacteria, do not italicize (e.g., E. coli stands for _Escherichia coli_).

**Do NOT italicize common names of diseases, bacteria, parasitic micro-organisms, etc.** (e.g, coliform and rickettsia). **Do NOT capitalize the generic names of bacteria**, such as bacillus or streptococcus, **or the proper scientific names of diseases such as BSE** (bovine spongiform encephalopathy).

(See Latin [scientific names](/home/l/latin-scientific-names) for more details)


**Emphasizing words**
**In news stories, we do NOT use italics to place emphasis on a word or phrase.** Quotation marks can sometimes be used for this purpose:

"The door was 'unlocked,'" she testified, raising her voice slightly as she said "un."

But there can be problems with this type of punctuation, including unintended sarcasm:

"His 'poetry' is not widely read," she said.

Is the speaker above emphasizing one form of writing or questioning the merits of calling it poetry? Avoid using inverted commas if the meaning can be misinterpreted. (More detailed guidelines on [quotation marks](/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks) can be found in the main punctuation section of the Language Guide.)

**Italics can be used in columns, features, and so forth to convey emphasis or to set a word apart for clarity:**


> They didn't merely like the orchestra's performance. They _loved_ it.


**But we do _not_ use italics this way in news stories.** (The word "not" in the previous sentence is one more example of what to avoid.)


**A final word about newspaper names**
**Capital letters are sufficient to identify newspapers, according to widely followed convention.** (This is the approach taken by the Globe and Mail, Toronto Star, New York Times and numerous other media outlets.) **Italics are unnecessary**.

> the Chicago Sun-Times
>
> the Halifax Chronicle Herald
>
> the Jerusalem Post
>
> the St. John's Telegram
>
> the Vancouver Sun
>
> the Winnipeg Free Press


**In second reference, the names of newspapers can be shortened as long as there's no confusion with a publication from another city** (e.g., the Post and the Free Press but the Vancouver Sun not the Sun in a story that also mentions the Toronto Sun).

In rare instances when the name of a publication may not be readily identified in a sentence (e.g., the Australian), add context to help the reader:


> Indonesia is bracing for another bomb attack, according to the Sydney-based paper the Australian.


**By not putting publications' names in italics, we can avoid the hassle of worrying about whether a specific city is part of the proper noun.** (CP uses similar reasoning with its blanket rule to use a lowercase "the" before all newspaper names, instead of checking to see if it's The Hamilton Spectator but the Toronto Star.)

For instance, the Gazette in Montreal does not include the city in its name. So if we used italics we'd have to write the Montreal _Gazette_ but the _Toronto Star_. Another example is the Times of London, which does not include "London" in its name.

In his book _Lapsing into a Comma_, Bill Wash of the Washington Post says media outlets have four options in a case like this:

1\. _The Times_ of London (if you use italics and a capital "T" in "The")
2\. The (London) Times (if you don't use italics but insist on a capital "T" in "The")
3\. the London _Times_ (if you use italics but a small "t" in "the")
4\. the London Times (if you don’t use italics and prefer a small "t" in "the")
**
CBCNews.ca style is No. 4, the London Times** (which can also be written as the Times of London).

See also [The versus the](/home/t/the-versus-the)
See also [punctuation overview](/handy-links/punctuation/overview) (for a list of links to various guidelines)

### Periods

**Periods**

**Put periods at the end of declarative sentences:**

> The violinist smiled.


**Put periods inside quotation marks:**

> The violinist smiled and said, "I should have worn a bow tie."


**Put periods inside brackets only when the punctuation applies to the material inside the brackets:**

> They complained to the World Health Organization (WHO). 
>
> The prime minister is expected to deliver his address at 8 p.m. ET. (CBC will broadcast the speech live on radio, TV and the internet.)


If the declarative sentence ends with an abbreviation featuring a period, a "second" full stop is required only if (i) the abbreviation falls directly before a bracket, and (ii) the abbreviation's period does not function as the entire sentence's closing punctuation (i.e., it lies within a parenthetical section):

> The violinist smiled as the plane landed in the U.S. 
>
> (The violinist was born in the U.K.) 
>
> The violinist had 10 honorary doctorates and one earned degree (a B.Mus.).


See also [brackets](/handy-links/punctuation/brackets)

**Use periods in most all-lowercase abbreviations** (_a.k.a., e.g., etc., ft., lb., m.p.h., vol., yd._). See [lowercase abbreviation](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/a/abbreviations/#lowercase "Abbreviations")s for details and exceptions.

**Use periods in abbreviations that blend capital and small letters only if the abbreviation ends in small letters** (_B.Ed._ **but** _PhD_). See [university degrees](/home/d/degrees)


**Use periods in geographical abbreviations** (_U.S., U.K._) **including the [geographical components of most proper nouns](/home/a/abbreviations#propernouns-geocomponents)** (_B.C. Hydro, N.B. Power_), except in rare cases of truly unorthodox spellings (e.g., fused names like _SaskPower_ and _WorkplaceNL_).

**Leave out periods in most other all-capitalized abbreviations** (_AIDS, UN, RCMP, MP, BA_). See [abbreviations](/home/a/abbreviations) for more details.

**One common exception involves shortening proper names to a letter or two**, such as:


> _The mysterious witness was referred to as Mr. B._
>
> _Toronto is sometimes called T.O._


**But leave out this punctuation when the letters themselves function as the names of people or things**, such as:


> _Exhibit A was introduced, and people in the courtroom started crying._
>
> _The identity of Lady X was never revealed._


See [abbreviations of single letters](/home/a/abbreviations#singleletters) for more detailed guidelines and examples.


**Do not use periods in currency abbreviations** ($500 US, $750 Cdn). See [numbers](/home/n/numbers)

**Use periods in a.m. and p.m.** (lowercase) **but not in time zone abbreviations** (ET, MT, etc.). See [time](/home/t/time)

**First and middle initials** are usually straightforward:


> C.S. Lewis
>
> J.K. Rowling
>
> John F. Kennedy
>
> J.R.R. Tolkien
>
> Michael J. Fox
>
> Samuel L. Jackson


This includes **initials used without any accompanying spelled-out names:**


> Who shot J.R.?
>
> Did E.T. really call home?


In these cases, J.R. stands for J.R. Ewing, and E.T. is treated as a name rather than merely as an abbreviation for extraterrestrial.

Be aware, however, that **in rare cases abbreviated names that normally include periods lose their punctuation based on convention:**


> _"I first met JFK in 1956," she said. "He told me to call him Jack not John."_
>
> _FDR's speech inspired him to go into politics._



**Headlines and promotional blurbs**
**Do not put periods at the end of headlines, subheads, links or brief blurbs identifying audio or video content on CBCNews.ca.** These are not treated as complete sentences:

> Same-sex marriage leaves House divided 
>
>   (_Headline_)
>
> Detectives puzzled by letter
>
>   (_Subheadline_)
>
> From Sept. 17, 2003: Same-sex marriage leaves House divided 
>
>   (_Link to archived story_)
>
> James Minifie reports for CBC Radio (Runs 1:47)
>
> Michael Maclear reports for CBC-TV (Runs 2:15)
>
> SARS: Latest timeline, background, photo galleries 
>
>   (_A typical promotion on the news page_)


**Sometimes, closing punctuation appears inside a long headline, subhead, etc.**, that contains more than one digested sentence. **Even in these cases, however, avoid adding periods to the end:
**



> 3 asteroids will fly past Earth on Saturday. Here is why there is no need to panic
>
>
> Look up, way up! It's International Observe the Moon Night Saturday
>
>
> Want to soak up the savings from solar? Here's what you should know
>
>
> Re-centralizing? Re-disorganizing? What exactly is Ontario doing to its health-care system?


**When longer (complete) sentences are used in links to material, periods should be included:**

> Stanley Burke talks to Norman DePoe about Washington’s recent ban on beef exports. (Runs 3:15)
>
> The federal government introduced sweeping changes to Canada’s punctuation laws in 1965. Larry Zolf reflects on the controversy in his column, Question period and question marks.


**Put periods at the end of pull quotes**, which are treated as complete sentences:


      "Only dull people are brilliant at breakfast."                                                     —Oscar Wilde


**Bulleted lists**
**Put periods at the end of each entry in a bulleted list, no matter how brief.**

The report recommends:

-   Increasing inspections of water purification plants.


-   Decreasing the GST from 7 to 6 per cent.


-   Tripling the salaries of rodeo clowns.


See also [**bulleted lists**](/home/b/bulleted-list) (for more detailed guidelines)

See also [quotation marks](/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks)

Return to [main punctuation page](/handy-links/punctuation)

### Possessive apostrophe

**Possessive apostrophes**

Adding a possessive apostrophe is **often straightforward. But there are times when writers need to pause** to decide (i) if one is even necessary, and (ii) if so, where it goes.

[False possessives](/handy-links/punctuation/possessive-apostrophe#falsepossessives) (a _Leafs player_ vs. a _Leafs' win_)
[Fewer 'description' exceptions](/handy-links/punctuation/possessive-apostrophe#fewerexceptions) (_leaders' debate, premiers' conference, teachers' strike_)
[Check proper nouns](/handy-links/punctuation/possessive-apostrophe#propernouns) (_Workers' versus Workers Compensation Board_)
[Compound nouns](/handy-links/punctuation/possessive-apostrophe#compoundnouns) (_stone's throw_ and _arm's-length_)
[Time](/handy-links/punctuation/possessive-apostrophe#time) (_three weeks' pay_ but _four months pregnant_)
[Pronouns](/handy-links/punctuation/possessive-apostrophe#pronouns) (_its_ and _whose_ not _it's_ and _who's_)
[s' versus s's](/handy-links/punctuation/s-versus-s-s) (Charles's not Charles')

**General guidelines**


**Rule A**

If the subject is singular (**a doctor**), then the apostrophe goes before the "s" (**a doctor's office**). This applies to terms like "each other" (**each other's tuques**).


**Rule B**

If the subject is plural (**doctors**), then the apostrophe usually goes after the "s" (**both doctors' patients**).

The **big exception to Rule B** is when **the noun itself is plural**. There are two types:


> (1) Words that are always plural (e.g., **children**, as in "the children's favourite books"); and
>
> (2) Words that are both singular and plural (e.g., **aircraft**).


The latter category (**Rule B, Exception 2**) **can cause headaches**. It's wrong to write "the three aircrafts," for instance. The correct form would be "the three aircraft." So, as with children's, the only possible plural would be "_the three aircraft's engines_," which looks rather absurd.

What do you do in these cases? **Never add an "s" to a plural noun that doesn't take one simply because you're looking for a swell place to park an apostrophe** ("the three aircrafts' engines" is wrong).

The consensus among veteran editors is to **recast these troublesome sentences**. In other words, it's perfectly acceptable to write "the aircraft's engines" when you mean one aircraft. But for plural constructions pick another noun that's singular and then add an "s" ("the three planes' engines").

Some other nouns that are considered both singular and plural are: _bison, deer, fish, insignia, moose, species, swine, trout_ and _wheat_.


**Rule C**

The "C" here could stand for controversial. **Don't add apostrophes that aren't needed.** It's sound advice. **But deciding when an apostrophe is required involves judgment, and not everyone agrees on how to handle each case.
**

**False possessives**
Some people who've mastered Rule A and Rule B are very quick to ignore Rule C. They slap apostrophes on the ends of a lot words that don't actually need them. This is particularly unfortunate when writers start changing the formal names of organizations because they wrongly assume that someone has left out punctuation.

**We distinguish between true possessives** (last night's Winnipeg Jets' win) **and indisputably false possessives** (the Winnipeg Jets left-winger). The **latter often feature attributive nouns** (Jets, Jays) functioning as descriptive detail. In these cases, punctuation is unnecessary. For example:


> **ATTRIBUTIVE NOUNS** (leave out apostrophes)

> > the **Leafs** player
>
> > the **Blue Jays** pitcher
>
> > another **Beatles** song
>
> > a Charles **Dickens** novel

> **TRUE POSSESSIVES** (include apostrophes)

> > the **Leafs'** first-round draft pick
>
> > the **Blue Jays'** victory
>
> > the **Beatles'** second Grammy
>
> > Charles **Dickens's** tenth child


The **main exceptions are proper nouns**, such as the formal names of organizations (the Veterans Affairs Department, a Diners Club card), **which may or may not include possessive apostrophes**, depending on stated preferences. (See [check proper nouns](/handy-links/punctuation/possessive-apostrophe#propernouns) below.)


**Fewer 'description' exceptions**
**We steer clear of punctuation in expressions that are unambiguously descriptive rather than possessive**, along the lines of "a toilet seat" and "a library book" (rather than "a toilet's seat" or a "library's book"). For example:


> an **awards** ceremony
>
> a **board of directors** meeting (i.e., a board meeting not a board's meeting)
>
> the **complaints** department
>
> a **1950s** band


But **we usually include possessive apostrophes in constructions that are debatably designated as "descriptive" by CP, AP and some other news organizations.** For consistency, **this means many common, generic expressions take punctuation**, such as:


> **carpenters'** union
>
> **children's** playground
>
> **citizens'** band radio
>
> **farmers'** market
>
> **first ministers'** meeting
>
> **gentlemen's** club
>
> **leaders'** debate
>
> **men's** prison
>
> **pilots'** spokesperson
>
> **premiers'** conference
>
> **seniors'** residence
>
> **teachers'** strike
>
> **women's** soccer team


See [style shift](/handy-links/punctuation/possessive-apostrophe#styleshift) below for background on why we think this approach is preferable.

**Be aware that certain compounds take singular, rather than plural, possessives often because of convention.** The Canadian Oxford Dictionary is a good guide. Examples are:


> **athlete's** foot
>
> **citizen's** arrest
>
> **doctor's** office
>
> **driver's** licence
>
> **farmer's** sausage
>
> **hitchhiker's** guide
>
> **hornet's** nest



**Style shift**
**CBC News expanded use of possessive apostrophes** in December 2020 **to lessen confusion and increase consistency.** We decided a simpler style made more sense, **given the fuzzy differences between certain descriptive and possessive constructions.** More than once, we found ourselves twisted into awkward positions, tortuously arguing that, say, "leaders' debate" and "seniors' home" were fine based on convention but that "premiers' conference" and "teachers' strike" were somehow less desirable, if not actually wrong, based on highly subjective assessments.

**Usage guides are divided over the best path to take.** "More conservative authorities recommend retaining the apostrophe," according to the Oxford Guide to Canadian English Usage. **We think including the punctuation in questionably descriptive cases makes decisions simpler and typography more uniform.** It seems unnecessarily confusing to insist that CP is right to prefer, say, "citizens band radio" and "farmers market" when our primary dictionary, the Canadian Oxford, lists more orthodox renderings (i.e., "citizens' band radio" and "farmers' market"). The same is true of teachers' college and athletes' village (both in Oxford), underscoring the sometimes arbitrary nature of judging what is genuinely possessive.


**HISTORICAL FOOTNOTE:** English punctuation conventions evolve. For example, virtually no one added singular possessive apostrophes until the end of the 17th century (e.g., boy's, girl's), according to the 2015 Fowler's Dictionary of Modern English Usage. Plural possessives didn't appear until roughly 100 years later (e.g., boys', girls'). Fowler's says the "relinquishment of the apostrophe" discussed above began around 1900, as various companies, organizations and publishers decided to start treating certain words as attributive nouns rather than as true possessives. It cites this example: "Barclays Bank is attributive, implying association with Barclays, whereas Barclays' Bank is possessive, implying ownership by people called Barclay. Some other names appear in various forms, with and without apostrophes (e.g., Sainsburys/Sainsbury's). This trend towards the dropping of the apostrophe in such names and titles seems certain to continue."



**Check proper nouns**
**Never change a proper noun** (e.g., the name of an organization) **simply because you assume an apostrophe should be added or removed.** If one group calls itself the "Big Valley Students' Federation" while another prefers the "Mountain Top Musicians Association" then we follow their choices.


**Workers' versus Workers (Compensation Board)**
To show why checking names is important, **here is an example of different approaches taken to "workers' compensation" across the country** in 2019:


> **Workers Compensation Board** (_no apostrophe_ in P.E.I., Manitoba)
>
> **Workers' Compensation Board** (_with apostrophe_ in Alberta, Saskatchewan, N.S., N.W.T. and Nunavut)
>
> **Workers' Compensation, Health and Safety Board** (Yukon)
>
> **WorkplaceNL**, formerly the Workers' Compensation Board (Newfoundland and Labrador)
>
> **WorkSafeBC**, formerly the Workers' Compensation Board (British Columbia)
>
> **WorkSafeNB**, formerly Workplace Health, Safety and Compensation Commission (New Brunswick)
>
> **Workplace Safety and Insurance Board** (Ontario)


When a proper noun is commonly used, it's usually unnecessary to specify that a different, officially registered is still on the books. In British Columbia, for example, the **Workmen's Compensation Board** was officially renamed the **Workers' Compensation Board** in 1974 — a change officially reflected in our journalism. Then in 2004, the agency began operating as **WorkSafeBC**. Although, technically, the legal name was the same (i.e., the Workers' Compensation Board), there was no need to point this out once WorkSafeBC became entrenched. Instead, it was usually sufficient to report the updated operating name: WorkSafeBC. This is no different from countless "legal names" of government bodies that have different "applied names" (e.g., the federal Department of Industry was rebranded as "Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada" in 2015, even though its legal name remained the Department of Industry).

**Alzheimer's disease versus Down syndrome**
Just because a medical condition is named after someone does not automatically mean that a possessive apostrophe is added. It depends largely on convention (e.g., **[Alzheimer's disease](/home/a#alzheimer)** but **[Down syndrome](/home/d#downsyndrome)**). Although there's been a trend in some quarters to start dropping apostrophes from various eponymous nouns, the punctuation remains common in many cases (**[Huntington's](/home/h#Huntington)**, **Parkinson’s, [Lou Gehrig's disease](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/a/#ALS "A")**) in respected medical journals and mainstream media. **Even when a term is treated as a possessive** (Alzheimer's), **a proper noun might be spelled differently** (the Alzheimer Society of Canada, and the Huntington Society of Canada). Always verify an organization's official name.


**Compound nouns**
**Some idiomatic compounds have apostrophes, even though many do not involve possession** (_a week's pay, two cents' worth_). **These have become entrenched over time.** They are generally treated as singular. **Most are listed in the dictionary.** Some are also used in official names:


> _arm's-length, baker's dozen, cow's milk, debtor's prison, Father's Day, fool's paradise, hair's breadth, Mother's Day, Reader's Digest, stone's throw, traveller's cheques, writer's block, writer's cramp,_ etc.

**Time**
**In the case of time or money, there's a fairly simple way to find out if an apostrophe is needed.** Make the construction singular. If the revised form takes an apostrophe, then one is required in the original:


> **three weeks' pay** (_because one week's pay takes an apostrophe_)
>
> **four years' worth of work** (_because one year's work takes an apostrophe_)
>
> **five months pregnant**, not months' (_because one month's pregnant makes no sense_)

**Pronouns**
Rule C (don't add apostrophes that aren't needed) also applies to most common pronouns, including **hers, theirs, ours, and yours**.

In this group, **"its" and "whose" seem to cause the most trouble**. Some people confuse these pronouns with similar looking and sounding contractions: its for it's (which stands for "it is") and whose for who's (which stands for "who is").

**Contractions need an apostrophe to represent what's missing. But most possessive pronouns need nothing more than a measure of care:**

> "The party says **it's** time **its** members vote on the proposal."
>
> "**Who's** going to decide **whose** opinion matters most?"


One should always be on the lookout for exceptions. Indefinite pronouns do require apostrophes: try one's best, anyone's guess, somebody else's problem.

See also [grammar](/handy-links/grammar)
See also [it's versus its](/home/i/its-versus-its)
See also [plural compounds](/home/c/courts-martial-and-other-plural-compounds) (courts martial)
See also [plurals in general](/home/p/plurals)
See also [pronouns](/home/p/problems-with-pronouns) (common problems)
See also [RCMP are versus RCMP is](/home/r/rcmp-are-versus-rcmp-is)
See also [s' versus s's](/handy-links/punctuation/s-versus-s-s) (Eves's not Eves')
