### question marks

**Question marks**

**In most cases, questions marks are straightforward. They generally go at the end of interrogatives.**


> Do you agree?
> What's wrong with this picture? Identify five anachronisms in this movie clip.
> "Does the ? sign have a fancy name?" he asked. "Yes," she explained. "It's called an eroteme in some circles."


**In rare cases, a series of question marks can appear within the same sentence** to represent more than one query:


> Homicide detectives must ask themselves, Are there obvious clues? obvious motives? obvious suspects?


**Questions marks are not necessary at the end of indirect questions:**


> The doctor asked whether she smoked.
> He asked who called for the vote.


**In the case of certain questions that are not intended to solicit actual answers, closing punctuation can vary** depending on the writer's preference:


> "Why don't we go." (No question mark to emphasize it's a suggestion rather than a question.)
> "Why didn't we go?" (Question mark underscores a decision-making review.)
> "Would you mind spelling his last name." (No question mark to emphasize it's a request for action rather than a true interrogative.)


**It's never wrong to add a question mark to a rhetorical question, but the punctuation is also frequently dropped by convention.** Keep in mind, however, that some iconic rhetorical questions do feature questions marks. For example, in the 1960s classic song _Blowin' in the Wind_, Bob Dylan asks:


> "How many roads must a man walk down, before you call him a man?"


There's no right answer, like four roads or 116 roads. It's a rhetorical question, and, so, a period would suffice. But since the lyric is frequently transcribed with a question mark, including on the artist's official website, bobdylan.com, it's OK to match that style in our journalism.

In direct quotes, **question marks can appear inside or outside of inverted commas, depending on the sentence's meaning:**


> "When?"
> "Who asked 'When?'"
> In the words of George Carlin, "Isn't it a bit unnerving that doctors call what they do 'practice'?"


See also [quotation marks](/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks) for related guidelines and examples.

**Question marks take the place of commas or periods in routine attribution:**


> "Do you have anything to declare?" the border guard repeated, raising his voice slightly.


**Question marks are flush to periods at the end of abbreviations:**


> "Do you mean 9 a.m. or 9 p.m.?"
>
> "Does the book mention John F. Kennedy Jr.?"


Return to [main punctuation page](/handy-links/punctuation)

### Quotation marks

**Quotation marks**


[Closing punctuation](/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks#closing) (.")



[Highlighting](/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks#highlighting) (emphasizing a word, irony)
[Quoting slogans, headlines, YouTube videos, podcasts](/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks#slogans) (capitalizing '[principal words](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks/#principalwords "Quotation marks")')
[Bridging gaps](/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks#bridginggaps) (quotes carried over two paragraphs)
[Nicknames](/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks#nicknames) (use brackets, not " ")
[Other guidelines](/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks#otherguidelines) (e.g., strict rules on "cleaning up" quotes)

**"Double" versus 'single'**
**Use double (" ") quotation marks for quotes in the main bodies of stories, and single (' ') quotation marks for quotes within quotes:**

> "They gave it 110 per cent," said the coach. "It was a great game."
>
> "You claim 'they gave it 110 per cent,' but that's not actually possible," pointed out a pedant.
>
> "Well," snapped the coach, "as my shortstop likes to say, 'You've never seen us do math.'"

**
Use double quotation marks in summaries** (brief news capsules of usually no more than about two dozen words that appear on various platforms, including partners' websites).

**Use single quotation marks in headlines** for verbatim attribution:

> 'Not a red cent to Hamas,' MacKay says
>
> Bush praises Harper's 'steely resolve' on softwood
>
> Apple blasts 'state-sponsored piracy' in France


**Use single quotation marks in decks** (secondary headlines), **subheads, pull quotes and photo captions** for verbatim attribution. (See [periods](/handy-links/punctuation/periods) for guidelines on punctuation at the end of headlines, pull quotes, etc.)

Do **NOT** use single quotation marks as a substitute for [italics](/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks#sansitalics).

**When using quotation marks, do NOT alter direct transcriptions** (i.e., by dropping, adding or changing words), **even to shorten headlines, without flagging the revisions with proper punctuation** (e.g., ellipses or square brackets). See [editing quotes](/home/q/quotes-editing) for detailed guidelines.

CBC.ca once had a news writer who assumed that single quotation marks (' ') indicated a paraphrase. They do not. **When you write a summary of someone else's words, you need attribution not special punctuation.**

In Britain, by the way, most writers and editors prefer 'single' inverted commas for the main quote, and "double" inverted commas for quotes within quotes. They also put most punctuation outside quotation marks (".) (",).

For more background, see the Quick Queries feature of CBC.ca's Words: Woe & Wonder site, [single versus double](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews2%2Findepth%2Fwords%2Fquick%2Fcomments%2Fsingledouble.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0hMoBGhMIgvzZiJPMUXcc4) and [inside versus outside](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews2%2Findepth%2Fwords%2Fquick%2Fqueries%2Finsideoutside.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0IJ52nOHQa_ftO9L-Ytqzi).


**Colons, commas and capitals**
**Use a colon to introduce quotes that are longer than one short sentence or that you want to emphasize. Otherwise use commas. Capitalize the first word of a quote only if it represents the start of a new sentence:**

> When asked exactly what kind of proof Canada wants before backing a military strike against Iraq, the prime minister put it this way: "A proof is a proof. What kind of a proof? It's a proof. A proof is a proof. And when you have a good proof, it's because it's proven."
>
> The accused dropped his head as the verdict was read: "Guilty."
>
> The pilot said, "Return to your seats."


(The comma in the last example above is used to separate an introductory statement from a quote. Compare with "Run for your lives!" below.)

> As the shots were fired, students began shouting "Run for your lives!"


(There is no comma before "Run" because the quote is an integral part of the clause about students shouting. Punctuation would hurt the sentence's flow.)

> "It is," he chuckled, "very possible."
>
> "It is sad," she whispered. "They have no money and no hope."

**Most closing punctuation goes inside (.") not (".)**
**Put most closing punctuation on the inside of quotation marks** (including quotes within quotes) **unless there's a question mark or exclamation mark that applies to the entire sentence:**


> The kids had never heard the word "copacetic."
>
> "Most people say 'gild the lily' instead of 'paint the lily,'" he grumbled.
>
> All three shouted, "That's ridiculous!"
>
> Tucker turned and asked, "Where were you born?"
>
> Is Canada really made up of "two solitudes"?


(The question mark is outside the closing quotes in the last example above because it applies to the entire sentence. See also [questions marks](/handy-links/punctuation/question-marks) for related guidelines.)

**When flush to closing quotation marks, colons and semicolons always go outside** (i.e., ": and "; rather than :" and ;"), as in:


> She said another example of common redundancy is "safe haven": "I'm still waiting for someone to name a 'haven' that isn't safe."
>
> The young campers mustered up enough courage to grab the "ghost"; it was a pillow case, a fishing pole and a flashlight.


In summary: **Put periods and commas INSIDE closing quotation marks, put colons and semicolons OUTSIDE closing quotation marks, and put most question marks and exclamation marks INSIDE closing quotation marks.** The exception is when the latter (question marks and exclamation marks) apply to the entire sentence rather than merely to the quoted text.


**"Fragments" are sometimes fine**
**If a speaker or writer has used a few words that are noteworthy** (e.g., they're unusual or controversial), **you can put quotation marks around them in a story.** These brief quotes jazz up leads, capture tone, underscore attribution, etc.


**Correct:**

> The kidnappers made some "stupid slips," the detective said.


**Unnecessary:**

> Police are certain the girl is "nearby."


**Guard against using too many brief quotes. Sentences begin to look odd if they're blanketed with them.** And some readers start wondering about all the words we've left out.


**'Fragments' in headline attribution**
**Brief quotes are OK in headlines with attribution, but the words should be noteworthy. Always use single, not double, quotation marks:**


**Correct:**

> What's a 'boondoggle'? asks PM
>
> 'Free my baby,' pleads mother of kidnapped girl
>
> 'I am above politics': Clarkson


**Unnecessary:**

> Tape proves missing girl 'still alive': mother


**Quotation marks do NOT replace italics in headlines**
**Although we avoid [italics](/handy-links/punctuation/italics) in heads** (main headlines), **decks** (secondary headlines), **subheads and photo captions, we do NOT use quotation marks as a substitute.**

**Instead, we use regular type and proper capitalization** for the titles of books, films, broadcast programs, etc., in these cases (e.g., _As It Happens_ in the body of a story but As It Happens in a headline):

> As It Happens picks new host
>
> Skybreaker, Caramba win children's book awards
>
> Da Vinci Code success sparks Angels & Demons plans


**Reserve single quotation marks for verbatim attribution** in headlines, decks, subheads and photo captions. (For details, see [" " versus ' '](/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks#doubleversussingle) above).

**Highlighting with punctuation**
**Use quotation marks, **not** italics, to emphasize a specific word or phrase in news stories or to indicate irony:**

> Jam-filled doughnuts are called "bismarcks" in some parts of Canada.
>
> She said the "friendly" match ended in a bloody brawl.


See also [so-called
](/home/s/so-called)
**Use italics, **not** quotation marks, for certain foreign terms, such as _caveat emptor_.
**
See [italics](/handy-links/punctuation/italics)

**Quotation marks are unnecessary around most proper nouns with capital letters,** such as the names of newspapers and nicknames:

> The papers for sale include the Jerusalem Post and the Chicago Sun-Times.
>
> Williams, also known as the Splendid Splinter, still holds the record.


See also [brackets](/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks#nicknames) for nicknames (below)


**Quoting headlines, slogans, chapters, YouTube videos, podcasts, etc.**
**When quoting the titles of various parts of larger, published works put all the principal words in capital letters,** even if they weren't printed this way. **This includes newspaper headlines, articles from magazines, and chapters of books:**

> Irwin's stunt conjured up memories of Michael Jackson dangling his baby from a balcony, and prompted one paper to splash "Crikey, Just Like Mikey" across its front page.


The titles of books, poems, short stories, broadcast programs, etc., should be put in italics. But the names of magazines, newspapers, etc., do not require italics. (See [italics](/handy-links/punctuation/italics))

**Slogans should also normally be in quotation marks with all principal words capitalized**, even if the original sign, legislation or other printed material uses a different style:

> One protester carried a placard that read "Smart Bombs but Dumb President." 
>
> Products other than steel and iron could be swept into the "America First" clause of the U.S. stimulus bill, Canada's international trade minister warned.


**YouTube video titles**, from the silly ("My Dog Plays Harmonica") to the serious ("Making Our Country Safe Again") **should be treated as headlines we've quoted**, with capital letters starting all principal words and the entire title in quotation marks. Apply this style to most other videos that are given names or labels, unless these are artistic works (e.g., plays, films, documentaries) that happen to be on video. In that case, use [italics](/handy-links/punctuation/italics). **The same applies to podcasts** (e.g., "Episode 4: The Secret Lives of Subversive Women").



**Principal words ('With' and 'Is' but usually not 'for' or 'in' or 'a')**
When deciding which words to capitalize **in headings, titles, etc.**, the **standard practice** is to **limit capital letters to the first word as well as all principal words**. Determining what qualifies involves more than merely counting the number of characters. **Principal words are commonly defined as nouns, pronouns, verbs, adjectives and adverbs,** **as well as all other words having four or more letters.** We follow this approach for consistency. For example, _with, over, under, more, less, above,_ etc., take initial capital letters in quoted titles, slogans, etc., while _of, in, an, a, the, but, for,_ etc., do not unless they're at the start of the entire string. The principal word  convention explains why _The World **at** Six_ and _The Nature **of** Thing_s keep the prepositions "at" and "of" lowercase, while programs such as _As **It** Happens_ and _This **Is My** Music_ have initial caps across the board (i.e., "It" is a pronoun and "Is" is a "to be" verb, and "My" is a possessive adjective). When in doubt, verify the typographical preference of a given broadcast program. The same convention explains why _**To Kill a Mockingbird**_ and _**How to Get Rich**_ and _**Got to Get You Into My Life**_ feature some brief elements (three characters or fewer) that are capitalized. Non-principal words are capitalized only if they appear at the start of titles (e.g., _**A Star Is Born**_ and _**The Lord of the Rings**_).


**Bridging gaps**
**When a continuous quote by one person extends into a second paragraph, put the quotation marks at the beginning of each but at the end of only the last one:**

> "**S**omerset Maugham wished to be famous and rich, and for at least 60 of his 91 years he had his desire," Robertson Davies said in 1982. "Few authors before him can have had a wider audience or a larger fortune. Few can have been sought out by so many celebrated peopl**e.**
>
>  "**F**ew can have been so much envied, so patronized and belittled by literary critics, so imitated by other writers. Fame and wealth followed him all the days of his life**."**


**If the words in the first paragraph represent only a partial quote, however, use inverted commas at the beginning and end of each paragraph:**

> He said Somerset Maugham wanted to be "famous and rich**.**"
>
>  **"F**ew authors before him can have had a wider audience or a larger fortune. Few can have been sought out by so many celebrated people. Few can have been so much envied, so patronized and belittled by literary critics, so imitated by other writers. Fame and wealth followed him all the days of his life**."**


(See [ellipses](/handy-links/punctuation/ellipses) for rare cases of an edit that falls in the same spot as the paragraph split.)


**Use brackets for nicknames**
**When inserting nicknames into proper nouns, use parentheses (not quotation marks):**

> John Birks (Dizzy) Gillespie
>
> Joseph (Joey) Smallwood


Note: If nicknames are well-known, they can also be used in first reference (e.g., _Dizzy Gillespie_ and _Joey Smallwood_). See also [nicknames](/home/n/nicknames) and [round versus square](/handy-links/punctuation/brackets) brackets.



**Other guidelines**

### s' versus s's

**s' versus s's**

[Overview](/handy-links/punctuation/s-versus-s-s#overview) (Harris's and Charles's)
[A few exceptions](/handy-links/punctuation/s-versus-s-s#exceptions) (Moses' and Euripides')
[Avoid being fooled by familiar-sounding roots](/handy-links/punctuation/s-versus-s-s#deceptiveroots) (Key becomes Key's but Keys becomes Keys's)
[Go with s' over s's on air if it's a lot easier to say](/handy-links/punctuation/s-versus-s-s#easiertosay) (Doris Chambers' estate)
[False possessives](/handy-links/punctuation/s-versus-s-s#leafs) (Leafs versus Leafs')
[Is it plural?](/handy-links/punctuation/s-versus-s-s#GM) (Times's versus General Motors')
[Embedded apostrophes](/handy-links/punctuation/s-versus-s-s#embedded) (McDonald's and the Oakland A's)


**Overview**
As outlined in the main section on [possessive constructions](/handy-links/punctuation/possessive-apostrophe), deciding where to put the apostrophe is usually pretty obvious:

**singular**
a _child's_ pencil, a _mechanic's_ wrench, an _MP's_ conscience

**plural**
the _children's_ desks, the _mechanics'_ tools, the _MPs'_ expense accounts

But when a word ends with the letter "s," even some experienced writers find their confidence slipping. Here's the convention that's been widely accepted for years (tackled as Rule 1 in the classic usage guide by Strunk and White, _The Elements of Style_):

**Singular nouns that end in "s" generally take an apostrophe and then another "s" to convey ownership.** So it's:

> A witness's testimony
>
> The bus's engine
>
> A business's profit
>
> Telus's market share
>
> Your boss's permission
>
> The fortress's gate
>
> A dress's colour
>
> The walrus's tusks
>
> Paris's nightlife
>
> Dallas's debt
>
> Mars's orbit
>
> Pope Francis's health
>
> Mike Harris's kitchen
>
> Premier Ernie Eves's cabinet
>
> Bill Holmes's kitchen cabinet
>
> Oscar Pistorius's medals
>
> Russell Williams's victims
>
> Charles's horse
>
> Burns's poems
>
> Strauss's music
>
> The space shuttle Atlantis's last launch
>
> St. James's Palace

> CBC News's response
>
>     (See [unnecessary possessives](/handy-links/punctuation/s-versus-s-s#unnecessary) — _e.g., prefer "the CBC News bureau" over "CBC News's bureau"_)

> The press's coverage
>
>     (Prefer "media's coverage," _not because we have anything against the letter "s" but because the CBC doesn't use presses._)



**A few exceptions**
There are **three main departures from the above guidelines:**

**(1) Some figures from ancient times,** which have entrenched punctuation. So it's generally:

> Euripides' plays (**not** Euripides's)
>
> Herodotus' story (**not** Herodotus's)
>
> Socrates' trial (**not** Socrates's)


**(2) Some modern proper nouns** with entrenched punctuation:

    Mr. Rogers' Neighborhood (**not** Rogers's, and **not** Neighbourhood with a "u")

**(3) Nouns that end with a definite "iz" sound.** Adding the extra "s" is considered overkill in this case. (You wind up with what amounts to "iz-iz.")

> Moses' laws (**not** Moses's) 
>
>     It's easier to write: the laws of Moses
>
> Jesus' followers (**not** Jesus's) 
>
>     It's easier to write: the followers of Jesus


What falls into this third category is sometimes debatable. But it's worth distinguishing between a clear "iss" sound and a more conversational "iz" sound. Harris ends with an obvious "iss." So _Harris's_ is pretty easy to say. The last syllable of Moses, by contrast, often sounds more like an "iz" than an "iss" when spoken naturally. And that leaves many people preferring _Moses'_ instead of attempting the more challenging _Moses's_.

The longer forms (Moses's and Jesus's) are not technically wrong, just slightly awkward. In his 1997 usage guide _The King's English_, novelist Kingsley Amis has this advice about deciding what merits an exception: "When in doubt always write out the fuller version."


**Avoid being fooled by familiar-sounding roots**
**Sometimes we hear a root that sounds singular** (e.g., _Eve_ or _Key_ in Ernie Eves and Alicia Keys). In these cases, we trick ourselves into writing s' instead of s's. **But the true test is whether we can actually read the sentence out loud and preserve the possessive:**

> 1\. Ernie Eves' first cabinet post. (Deceptive. Possessive sound lost, unless his name is Eve.)
>
> 2\. Ernie Eves's first cabinet post. **(PREFERRED)**
>
> 1\. Alicia Keys' job with BlackBerry. (Deceptive. Possessive sound lost unless her name is Key.)
>
> 2\. Alicia Keys's job with BlackBerry. **(PREFERRED)**
>
> 1\. CBC News' core values. **(Wrong. Cannot actually be said out loud. The _s's_ sound is required.)**
>
> 2\. CBC News's core values. **(PREFERRED)**


**In each of the examples above, the first sentences fail as true possessives.** Eve's and Key's work only if the surnames are Eve and Key. But when writing about the former Ontario politician Ernie Eves or the singer Alicia Keys, we need to retain their actual names regardless of familiar-sounding roots within.

**Although this problem is commonly associated with one-syllable words, monosyllabic names can be equally deceptive when they include familiar roots** (e.g., Williams becomes Williams's, even though the singular William's sounds OK because it's the natural and correct possessive of the singular "William").

> 1\. Russell Williams' wife refused to comment. (Deceptive. Possessive sound lost, unless his surname is William.)
>
> 2\. Russell Williams's wife refused to comment. **(PREFERRED)** 
>
> 1\. Bryan Adams' latest CD. (Deceptive. Possessive sound lost, unless his surname is Adam.)
>
> 2\. Bryan Adams's latest CD. **(PREFERRED)**
>
> 1\. Gabrielle Giffords' husband wept. (Deceptive. Possessive sound lost, unless her surname is Gifford.)
>
> 2\. Gabrielle Giffords's husband wept. **(PREFERRED)**

**Go with s' over s's on air if it's a lot easier to say**
While it's obvious that _Chris's scooter_ and _Paris's nightlife_ are correct, many guides point out that deciding whether to add the extra "s" sometimes involves personal judgment, especially in spoken English. To quote the stylebook published by [The Canadian Press](/home/c/cpap) (which we may happily call the Canadian Press's Stylebook): "If adding the extra 's' would make the word hard to say or grate on the ear, use an apostrophe alone."

But this does not mean suddenly adopting Charles' horse instead of Charles's horse, or Eves' budget instead of Eves's budget, since the longer forms in both cases are unquestionably preferred by convention, as outlined in the [overview](/handy-links/punctuation/s-versus-s-s#overview) above.

> EXAMPLE 1: For consistency, CBC's style recommendation would be **_Bryan Adams's latest CD_** and **_Burton Cummings's comic book collection_**. We can be more relaxed in broadcast scripts and prefer a conversational version over a stilted one if the latter satisfies typographical conventions but causes us to stumble on air. At the same time, however, we must be sure to follow proper punctuation in written forms of text, on the web, in TV graphics, in email alerts, etc. In other words, **while Adams' or Cummings' would be acceptable on air, we must avoid the trap of accidentally publishing Adam's or Cumming's in text written for the eye.** 
>
> EXAMPLE 2: The preferred possessive of Gabrielle Giffords is s's (as in _Giffords's husband_). If broadcast staff find it significantly easier to say "Giffords' husband," they should feel free to adopt that form on air. But **we should still prefer Giffords's in online text, TV supers and banners, etc.** And no matter what, we need to **avoid the mistake of turning Giffords' husband into Gifford's husband — an easy error to make when we start letting our ears dictate what punctuation our fingers type.** 
>
> EXAMPLE 3: **An especially challenging pronunciation is sometimes caused by the word after the punctuation.** _Doris Chambers's estate_ is harder to say than _Doris Chambers's car_ because of the first syllable of the noun being possessed (i.e., **the "ess" sound of "estate"**). In this case, **_Doris Chambers' estate_** would be unquestionably preferred, while _Doris Chambers' car_ would be OK but debatable. And we would need to guard against either of these shortened versions accidentally becoming Chamber's estate or Chamber's car in text for the eye. **Once an acceptable version is chosen, it's best to be consistent throughout a story** (i.e., don't go with Chambers's in one paragraph and Chambers' in another). And **keep in mind: Recasting a sentence to avoid a tricky construction is sometimes best** (e.g., "her estate" rather than "Chambers's estate" or "Chambers' estate"), as pointed out in [Avoid unnecessary possessives](/handy-links/punctuation/s-versus-s-s#unnecessary) below.


**When judging what's easier to say on air, keep in mind that we often add an "s" to words that end in "z" without blinking an eye or tripping over our tongue**, even though we're producing the equivalent of an "s's" sound:

> the quiz's last question
>
> Aaron Hernandez's home
>
> showbiz's biggest names



**RELATED STYLE POINTS WORTH NOTING**


**Leafs versus Leafs'**
**Be sure to distinguish between a true possessive and a mere description:**

> The Leafs winger liked Beatles songs.
>
> The Leafs' last Stanley Cup victory was just before the Beatles' breakup.


**One tip is to consider whether the preposition "of" is appropriate** (as in the breakup of the Beatles) instead of "by" (as in songs by the Beatles) or "for" or "with," etc. In other words, there is a difference between writing about a Hemmingway novel or a Dickens novel and discussing Hemmingway's style or Dickens's style. A similar distinction is made between interviewing a Snowbirds pilot (i.e., a pilot with the aerobatics team known as the Snowbirds) and reporting on the Snowbirds' budget (i.e., the budget of the Snowbirds).

**Another tip deals with sports teams.** By substituting the name of the city or town the franchise is from, you can quickly see if a possessive is required:

> The Canadiens goalie was hit from behind.
>
>     (The Montreal goalie was hit from behind.)
>
> She called the Canadiens' winning streak impressive.
>
>     (She called Montreal's winning streak impressive.)


(See our **[possessive apostrophes overview](/handy-links/punctuation/possessive-apostrophe)** for an in-depth review of true versus false possessives)


**Times's versus General Motors'**
**Some names that end with an "s" are considered singular** (_the New York Times is reporting_) **while others are treated as plural** (_the Beatles **were** famous and the Toronto Maple Leafs **are** on the road_).

These are generally straightforward, although **companies and countries that are normally singular** (_General Motors is losing money_) **are conventionally treated as plural in possessive structures:**

> He cited the New York Times's coverage of General Motors' debt.


**McDonald's and the Oakland A's**
**Sometimes apostrophes are embedded within names.** In the case of the McDonald's fast-food chain, for example, the proper noun includes a possessive. In the case of Oakland's baseball team, a word is being shortened through conventional use of punctuation (i.e., A's represents _Athletics_).

**Do not add an extra "s" or an extra apostrophe to these constructions to create possessives.** Instead, leave them as is:

> the Oakland A's manager
>
> McDonald's new CEO


**Tip: When confronted with this sort of possessive, an appealing option is to adopt different wording** (e.g., the _Athletics' manager_ or the _company's new CEO_), although this is not always possible, especially in headlines.

Oakland's name is yet another example of how apostrophes are not always intuitive. In the previous section, for instance, General Motors was correctly labelled singular (_General Motors is_), even though it takes a plural possessive (i.e., _General Motors' debt_). In the case of the Athletics, however, the team is treated as a plural despite the apostrophe before the "s" (i.e., _the A's **are** not the A's is_).

The plural of McDonald's, by the way, remains McDonald's (e.g., "They went to a McDonald's" and "She owns three McDonald's"). The embedded possessive, in other words, requires a different approach. It's not the same as, say, the name _Jones_, which becomes _Joneses_ in plural. But because McDonald's as a plural can look odd, it's often better to recast the sentence (e.g., "She owns three McDonald's restaurants").

See also [verb agreement](/home/v/verb-agreement) (e.g., "the Colorado Avalanche **are**" not "the Colorado Avalanche **is**") for related style points about sports teams, musical groups, etc.


**Avoid unnecessary possessives**
**Awkward or space-wasting possessives should be reworded whenever possible:**

> Correct: The bus's engine stalled in the middle of the intersection.
>
>     (**Better:** The bus stalled in the middle of the intersection.) 
>
> Correct: The buses all stop near Paris's Eiffel Tower.
>
>     (**Better:** The buses all stop near the Eiffel Tower.) 
>
> Correct: Both buses' passengers were shaken up by the accident.
>
>     (**Better:** Passengers on both buses were shaken up by the accident.) 
>
> Correct: CBC News's London bureau.
>
>     (**Better:** The CBC News London bureau.)


**Jones's versus Joneses'**
It's worth noting that **there's a big difference between a simple plural** (buses) **and a possessive one** (buses').

The **correct punctuation is often obvious.** Consider a story about the Smith family:


> **Smith's car** refers to one person's vehicle (e.g., Sid Smith's car).
>
> **The Smiths' car**, by contrast refers to the entire family's vehicle (i.e., all of the Smiths).


**As the facts change, however, the punctuation can become more complex** — such as when we stop talking about Sid Smith and his family and move on to discuss Janet Jones and her kin. "An accomplished apostrophe wielder," Kingsley Amis points out, "must be able to distinguish instantly between the following":

> He is staying with Janet **Jones**. (_One Jones_)
>
> He is staying at Janet **Jones's** house. (_One Jones_)
>
> He is staying with the **Joneses**. (_More than one Jones_.)
>
> He is staying at the **Joneses'** house. (**_More than one Jones_**.)


So if you want to keep up with the Joneses, visit the Joneses' place to see exactly what they've got (besides that dusty old book with Amis's autograph).

See also [plurals](/home/p/plurals) (an overview)

**ABC** (stands for American Broadcasting Companies, plural; but unnecessary to spell out when referring to either the television or radio networks)

**ABCs**, learning the (no periods, apostrophe or spaces)

**Abba** (_not_ ABBA) A Swedish pop group (See also [quirky capitalization](/home/q/quirky-capitalization))

[**Abbas, Mahmoud**](/home/a/abbas-mahmoud) (Palestinian president)

**Abbott, Sir John** (Canada's prime minister, 1891-92)

**able-bodied** (see [disability terms](/home/d/disability-language#ablebodied))

**ABM** (**automated banking machine**; plural is **ABMs**) This abbreviation was once deeply entrenched in Canada. It remains in use, alongside the increasingly common synonym ATM (for automated teller machine). Both are OK, but be consistent within a given story. Neither needs to be spelled out. But be aware that the A stands for _automated_, not automatic. The Canadian Bankers Association still commonly calls its members' machines ABMs. The term [**ATM**](/home/a#ATM) is used more in the United States. Privately operated ATMS are frequently found at small Canadian businesses, including convenience stores. Generic labels such as "banking machine" or "automated teller" are fine in all contexts. Never write "ABM machine," which is redundant. See also [point-of-sale (POS) terminal](/home/p#POS).

**abduction** (generic term for taking people against their will). The word **kidnapping** generally implies a ransom or other specific demands. So while all kidnappings are abductions, not all abductions are viewed as kidnappings. Make sure the word you pick fits the facts, and that the context is clear to our audience.

**abnormal** (offensive when applied to people; see [disability terms](/home/d/disability-language#abnormal))

**A-bomb**

**abominable snowman** (Prefer the term **yeti** when referring to the Himalayas. The plural is yetis. In stories about Canada, however, use **sasquatch** — a Salish word meaning "hairy men." In stories about reports of such human-like creatures in the U.S., the label **Bigfoot** is OK as long as the story makes it clear that they're also known as sasquatch. The words sasquatch and Bigfoot are both singular and plural.)

**Aboriginal** (adj.), as in Aboriginal people, Aboriginal self-government. Although once common as an adjective to describe all **Indians**, **Inuit** and **Métis** in Canada, **Indigenous** is now the preferred term, especially in first reference. Capitalize as a proper noun modifier. But do not use as a noun alone (i.e., refer to **Aboriginal people** rather than to "Aboriginals"). Also, avoid the offensive slang **Abo** and **Abos**. The word **Aborigine** refers to Australia's Indigenous people. See [**Indigenous**](/home/i/Indigenous) for detailed guidelines.

[**abortion**](/home/a/abortion) (cautionary guidelines on terms such as "pro-choice" and "anti-abortion")

**aboveboard** (one word)

**abridgment**

**absenteeism** (_requires care_) Although it can technically mean simply being absent, the word **strongly implies being away for no valid reason.** Therefore, avoid using absenteeism unless verifiable facts match or the accusation of an unjustifiable absence is attributed. During COVID-19 pandemic coverage, for instance, we were accused of everything from ignorance and sloppiness to political bias when using "absenteeism" as the default noun in stories about employees missing work and students missing school. Recasting kept our journalism fact-based (e.g., referring to **rates of absence** or **attendance levels** or increased **absences**). Be aware that genuine absenteeism can be challenging to track. As Statistics Canada notes in its [labour force surveys](https://www.statcan.gc.ca/en/statistical-programs/document/3701_D68_T25#b): "Although absenteeism is widely acknowledged to be a problem, it is not easy to quantify. The dividing line between avoidable and unavoidable is difficult to draw, and absenteeism generally masquerades as legitimate absence."

**abysmal** (only one "s")

**abyss**

**Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences** (in second reference: **the academy**); an **Academy Award** (See also [Award versus award](/home/a/award-versus-award) for details on how to handle Oscars, such as **Oscar for best picture**)

**accents** (café, El Niño, but Mexico not "México") See [foreign words](/home/f/foreign-words) for general guidelines

**accessible** (_not_ -able), **accessible parking** (avoid the dated term "handicapped parking") See [disability terms](/home/d/disability-language#accessible)

**accident, industrial accident, traffic accident** (see [accidents, collisions, crashes](/home/a/accidents))

**accommodate, accommodation**

**accumulate**

[**accused**](/home/s/suspect_accused) (person charged in criminal case); reserve **defendant** for civil proceedings in Canada (See also [Canadian court terms](/home/c/canadian-court-terms))

**acetylsalicylic acid** (**ASA** is OK in first reference) See also [**Aspirin**](/home/a#Aspirin) below

**Achilles heel, Achilles tendon** (no possessive apostrophe)

**acknowledgment**

**acquit, acquitted, acquittal**

[**Act** versus **act**](/home/a/act) (includes detailed guidelines on handling the titles of proposed legislation, or bills, and proclaimed legislation)

**Act 4, Scene 1; the fourth act, first scene** (See [series](/home/n/numbers#series) in the numbers overview for related guidelines)

**acting police chief** Laurie Smith, **acting deputy chief** Rick McKee, **acting mayor** Laurie Smith, acting Staff Sgt. Rick McKee (See also [**acting** versus **interim**](/home/a/acting-versus-interim))

**Action Démocratique du Québec** (**ADQ** or **Action Démocratique** on second reference) See [French words and accents](/home/f/french-words-and-accents) for detailed guidelines on applicable capitalization rules.

**action plan** (_avoid_ this cliché, which amounts to wordy spin) Just as reporting on an "inaction plan" would suggest something negative, reporting on an "action plan" automatically implies something good. A plan is a plan, no matter what modifier others attach to it. By dropping adjectives such as "action" in cases like this, we keep our sentences shorter and our journalism neutral.

**[active voice](/home/a/active-voice)** (subject-verb-object) Often, but not always, better than a passive construction.

**actor** (OK for both men and women) In some contexts, the word **actress** is both fine and unavoidable, such as in coverage of the Academy Awards. But be consistent throughout a story. Do not refer to a woman as an actress in one paragraph and then as an actor in the next. And if you add the adjective female (usually not necessary) before the word actor (female actor), be sure to include the adjective male as well when referring to men in the same story (male actor). Otherwise, leave out both modifiers.

**ACTRA** (Alliance of Canadian Cinema, Television and Radio Artists)

**AD** (does not need to spelled out as _anno Domini_, which means "in the year of the Lord") Unlike [BC](/home/b#BC), the abbreviation AD goes before the figure, as in "AD 79." When labelling centuries, however, the letters are conventionally placed at the end, as in "the second century AD."

**Adazi** (Latvia); **Camp Adazi** (military base in Latvia) See [non-English words, foreign languages, accents](/home/f/foreign-words#roman_alphabet) for guidelines on why proper nouns like this do not take accents.

**addendum, addenda** (see [Latin plurals](/home/l/latin-plurals))

**[addict, addiction](/home/d/disability-language#addiction)**

[**addresses**](/home/a/addresses) (Street, St., street, etc.)

**Adidas** (uppercase) See [trade names](/home/t/trade-names)

**adieu, adieus**

**adjuster** (_not_ -or)

**adjuvant**, **adjuvant-free** vaccine, **non-adjuvant** vaccine (_avoid_ the disputed construction "_unadjuvant_") The term adjuvant comes from the Latin word for "help." Since it's technical jargon, it should be briefly explained in news stories (e.g., in a piece about [vaccines](/home/i/immunization-vaccination), adjuvant can be defined as an "immune booster"). See [bacteria-virus](/home/b/bacteria-versus-virus) for more details and related guidelines.

**administration** (lowercase, even for **U.S. administration**, **Bush administration**, **Obama administration**, etc.) While this term is fine for American politics, do not use it to describe Canadian governments. In parliamentary systems, the legislative and executive branches are combined. (See also [regime](/home/r#regime) for related guidelines)

**Admiral** (do _not_ abbreviate) see [military ranks](/home/m/military-ranks)

**admissible** (_not_ -able)

**admit** (implies wrongdoing or concession) See **[say](/home/s/say)** for caution

**ad nauseam** (_not_ -eum) [No italics](/handy-links/punctuation/italics)

**Adonai** (see [the Deity and the devil](/home/d/the-deity-and-the-devil))

**[adoption](/home/a/adoption)** (various caveats)

**ADQ** (OK in headlines, or in second reference to [Action Démocratique du Québec](/home/a#ADQ))

**adrenalin** (_not_ adrenaline) Use the shorter spelling (without the second "e") for the natural hormones secreted by the adrenal gland (epinephrine and cortin) as well as for various manufactured stimulants. Generic forms of synthetic adrenalin feature a lowercase "a." Unless specifically referring to the trademarked drug Adrenalin, a capital letter is not required. (See also [EpiPen](/home/e#epipen) and [trademarks](/home/t/trade-names))

**adverse** (contrary, unfavourable); **averse** (reluctant)

**advertise** (_not_ -ize)

(See [adviser versus advisor](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/a/adviser/ "Adviser") for details)

**Air Line Pilots Association** (**ALPA** in second reference) This is a proper noun, which features Air and Line as two separate words. There is no possessive apostrophe. The Washington-based union represents tens of thousands of pilots in both Canada and the United States. The [association's website](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.alpa.org%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3DNwnFuogPhCtJchTFHN9L) includes more information.

**a.k.a.** (colloquial abbreviation for "also known as") Generally limit this term to directly transcribed quotes. When used, there's no need to spell out.

**Akwesasne** (common and acceptable short form in various contexts, as in **Akwesasne leaders**); the **Mohawks of Akwesasne** or the **Mohawk Nation at Akwesasne** (preferred over "Akwesasne First Nation"); the **Akwesasne Mohawk Territory**

**Akkal, Jamal** (_not_ Aqel) Canadian citizen detained by Israel in November 2003 and accused of having ties to Hamas

**Al, al-, al**
**Al-** (as in **Al-Ahram**) and **al-** (as in **al-Qaeda**); **Al** is equivalent to a definite article in English. Whether a hyphen is added to any particular "Al- or al-" compound depends on convention. Often, there's no punctuation (e.g., Al Samoud missiles, Al Wefaq party members and Al Jazeera news coverage). Specific entries appear alphabetically below. See also [Arabic names](/home/a/arabic-names) for broad guidelines.

**al-Abadi, Haider** (Iraqi politician) Prefer this spelling. Use al-Abadi in second reference. See also [transliterations](/home/t/transliterations) as well as [Arabic names](/home/a/arabic-names) for general guidelines.

**Al-Ahram** (large, widely read Egyptian daily newspaper founded in the 1870s) Controlling shares are owned by the Egyptian government, which appoints some of its editors. Critics say the publication is heavily influenced and censored by state authorities.

**al-Assad, Bashar** (second reference, Assad) Became president of Syria in 2000 after the death of his father, Hafez al-Assad.

**al-Golani, Abu Mohammed** (nom de guerre) See [Ahmed al-Sharaa](/updates/2024/2024-12-20-ahmed-al-sharaa/) for further details.

**[al-Sharaa, Ahmed](/updates/2024/2024-12-20-ahmed-al-sharaa/)**

**al-Zawahri, Ayman** (second reference al-Zawahri) Top al-Qaeda leader killed by U.S. drone strike in Afghanistan in 2022. There are several [transliterations](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/transliterations/ "Transliterations") of his name. For consistency, use the entrenched spelling al-Zawahri.

**Alabama (Ala.)** See [United States](/home/u/united-states)

**Alaska** (do _not_ abbreviate) See [United States](/home/u/united-states)

**Alberta (Alta.)** Using the abbreviation in web headlines is optional (See [provinces, territories and cities](/home/p/provinces-and-cities))

**Alcoholics Anonymous** (AA) If stories make the context clear, the terms **Al-Anon** (for relatives of alcoholics) and **Alateen** (for children of alcoholics) are OK. (See [addiction](/home/d/disability-language#addiction) for various caveats about word usage)

**alderman (Ald.), alderwoman (Ald.)** Use alderman and alderwoman only if these are the official titles adopted by a municipality. Otherwise, prefer councillor. Before names, it's: _Ald. Fred Russell, Ald. Betty Ali._ In plural: _alderwomen Betty Ali and Janice Heinz_. (See [titles](/home/t/titles) for general guidelines on abbreviations before names)

**al-Shabaab** (Somali-based militants linked to al-Qaeda) In March 2010, the federal government added al-Shabaab to Canada's list of terrorist groups. Avoid other spellings, such as Shebab and Shabab. See [transliterations](/home/t/transliterations) for general guidelines. For more background on al-Shabaab, see the [CBCNews.ca feature](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fworld%2Fstory%2F2010%2F03%2F09%2Ff-somalia-al-shabaab.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1S-pnrBaiFEXPcO0Foa_U5) about the organization.

**all-star** (n. and adj.), as in _She's an all-star_ and _He's an all-star hitter_. Use uppercase letters only for the proper names of teams (e.g., _baseball's National League All-Stars or hockey's Eastern Conference All-Stars_). Otherwise, keep the term lowercase (e.g., the NHL _all-star roster_, next month's _all-star game_, Mats Sundin leads this year's _all-star balloting_, etc.)

**all-terrain vehicle** (Since the abbreviation **ATV** is more obscure than say, SUV, generally spell out all-terrain vehicle at least once high in the story); **ATV trails**; **ATVers** (people who operate ATVs)

**ALS** ("amyotrophic lateral sclerosis" does not need to be spelled out in stories) It's common and acceptable to say that this neurodegenerative disorder is also known as **Lou Gehrig's disease**. (See [health reporting](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/h/health_reporting/#clarity "Health_reporting") for related guidelines on clear writing.)

**alternate** (one after the other); **alternative** (one or the other)

**alt-right** (shorthand for "alternative right") An increasingly common term for a [far-right](/home/l/left-wing-versus-right-wing) political movement normally tied to **white nationalism**. Should be briefly defined in stories whenever practical to make links to intolerance clear. While alt-right is an umbrella label that does not have a universally agreed on meaning, it can be described as a movement that rejects mainstream conservatism in favour of promoting white identity and espousing ideas widely seen as antisemitic, racist, homophobic, misogynistic, etc. A given story's focus may affect the description chosen (e.g., if you're reporting on alt-right opposition to multiculturalism instead of on alt-right comments about Islam or transgender rights). No need to put alt-right in quotation marks. Adding the modifier "so-called" is optional. (See also [white nationalism](/home/w#white_nationalism))

**aluminum** (_not_ -inium)

**alumnus** (plural **alumni**) A graduate of a specific school. Although "alumnus" is the masculine singular form in Latin, it's now **widely considered gender-neutral in English**. Therefore, prefer it over the comparatively obscure "alum." There's usually no need to use what was traditionally the feminine singular Latin form "alumna," or its plural "alumnae," outside of direct quotes. (See also [emeritus](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/e/#emeritus "E"))

**Alzheimer's disease** (named after German physician Alois Alzheimer, who first identified it in 1906) It's the most common form of [dementia](/home/d/dementia) in Canada. Treat the disease as a possessive (Alzheimer's) based on convention, but be aware that the apostrophe is missing from the official spellings of some proper nouns (e.g., the **Alzheimer Society of Canada**). See the editorial caveat under [possessive apostrophes](/handy-links/punctuation/possessive-apostrophe#alzheimersdown) (Down versus Alzheimer's) for details.

**Al Wefaq** (no hyphen) Bahrain's largest [Shia](/home/s#shia) party. There's generally no need to spell out the full name, Al Wefaq National Islamic Society. See also [Arabic names](/home/a/arabic-names) for broad guidelines on transliterations.

**a.m., p.m.** (lowercase) 3 a.m. AT, 7:45 p.m. MT, etc. (See also [time](/home/t/time))

**_a mari usque ad mare_** (Canada's official motto, "from sea to sea") Unless Latin is part of everyday speech (such as "ad nauseam" or "per diem"), it should be posted in [italics](/handy-links/punctuation/italics).

**APEC** (OK in first reference) **Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation** (Do not put a hyphen in co-operation in this case because it's a proper noun) Technically, APEC is not a group of "countries" but an agreement by more than 20 regional "economies" to hold regular meetings to discuss common interests. Use of the word "economies" permits China, Taiwan and Hong Kong to have their own representatives at the table without controversy over sovereignty. APEC members include Australia, Canada, Chile, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Mexico, New Zealand, Russia, and the United States. For a complete list, as well as more information, consult the [organization's website](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.apec.org%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2eya_bzehZB8J_-4kI_BeN).

**apology, apologize** (_requires caution_) Conventionally refers to acknowledgment of an error, a failure, a transgression, etc. Contrition is normally implied. Avoid calling the mere recognition of something an apology. For example, simply stating that a given act has had regrettable consequences, or acknowledging the emotional distress of others, is not on its own an apology. Be aware that terms like "sorry" and "regret" can be misinterpreted or mischaracterized. For instance, if a country says that it's "sorry" civilians were killed in a bombing, the word "sorry" alone does not mean the government has "apologized" for the bombing. Instead, the country has simply expressed regret that civilians were killed. The distinction is subtle but significant. As always, carefully prepared statements by politicians, military leaders, private companies, etc., merit special scrutiny to keep our journalism accurate.

**apostle, John the Apostle, the Apostle Paul, the Twelve Apostles**

**Archbishop** (capitalize when part of a full title or before a name) _Archbishop Christian Lépine thanked them; Cardinal Gérald Lacroix, the Archbishop of Quebec, agreed; the Archbishop of Toronto laughed at her joke;_ **archbishop** (lowercase for general references and plural constructions) _the archbishops met; the archbishop smiled_. Unless the title archbishop is directly relevant to the story, it's often easiest and sufficient to refer to the person as a [cardinal](/home/c#cardinal) when the person also holds that title.

**archaeological, archaeologist, archaeology** (not _arche-_) Spelling change adopted in the fall of 2022 for reasons outlined in our [lingering ligatures](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/s/spelling/lingering-ligatures/ "Lingering ligatures") overview.

**Argentine** (n. and adj.) Citizens of Argentina are traditionally called Argentines. Prefer over "Argentinians." Argentine is also the recommended adjective (e.g., Argentine oil workers, Argentine music). When government documents in Argentina are translated from Spanish to English, Argentine remains the preferred word. Many Western news organizations, including CP, the New York Times and the Globe and Mail, recommend Argentine over Argentinian as well. When transcribing clips that feature the latter, avoid the rogue spelling "Argentinean."

**argyle** socks, sweater, etc. (_don't use argyll except when used in an official name,_ e.g., Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders of Canada)

**art**

Lowercase art styles, schools, movements, etc., such as **art deco, art nouveau, baroque, cubism, impressionism, and neoclassical**, unless the word is derived from a proper noun (e.g., **Gothic, Norman** and **Romanesque**) or could be confused with a common word (e.g., **Dada** and **Renaissance**). Most compound nouns featuring the word "art" are two words (e.g., **art exhibit, art form, art gallery**). The term **artwork**, however, is fused.

an **article**, but the third paragraph of **Article 7** (formal name), and "**Art. 5, Sec. 1,** outlines the restrictions" (For related guidelines, see [series](/home/n/numbers#series) in the numbers overview)

**artificial intelligence (AI)** Conventionally refers to computer systems or machines that seem to mimic certain cognitive abilities of animals, such as learning and problem solving. AI (no periods) should be spelled out at least once, early on, in stories. (See [abbreviations](/home/a/abbreviations) for general typographical guidelines)

**Asperger's syndrome** (capital A, possessive apostrophe; **Asperger's** OK, even in first reference) Named after Austrian pediatrician Hans Asperger. Conventionally referred to as a mild form of autism. Technically, it falls under the broad medical heading of **[autism spectrum disorder](/home/a#autism)** (an umbrella term), which is why the variation **Asperger's disorder** has become increasingly common. **Some authorities no longer list Asperger's as a separate autism diagnosis. But the proper noun is entrenched and OK when the facts fit and individuals and medical staff, themselves use the name.** People with Asperger's may have average to high intelligence, as well as narrow — sometimes intensely focused — interests, but find certain verbal and nonverbal social skills challenging. The condition is sometimes spelled without a possessive apostrophe. For consistency, however, include the punctuation in our reporting unless referring to a proper noun that's rendered differently (e.g., **Asperger Manitoba**). Be aware that some organizations have changed their names because of what they described as newly documented links between Hans Asperger and Nazis during the Second World War (e.g., the **Asperger's Society of Ontario** was rebranded as the **ASO** in 2020). See also [possessive apostrophes](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/handy-links/punctuation/possessive-apostrophe/#alzheimersdown "Possessive apostrophe") for related typographical conventions (e.g., Parkinson's disease but Down syndrome).

**ATM** (**automated teller machine**; plural is **ATMs**) This abbreviation is deeply entrenched in the United States and increasingly common in Canada. There's no need to spell it out, but be aware that the A stands for _automated_, not automatic. The term [**ABM**](/home/a#ABM) is also used in Canada. ATM and ABM are both acceptable in our journalism, but be consistent within a single story. Generic names such as "banking machine" or "automated teller" are fine in all contexts. Never write "ATM machine," which is redundant.

**attorney** (lowercase as generic term for lawyer or prosecutor, such as Crown attorney Betty Shanks and power of attorney); **Attorney** (capitalized only when part of a unique title directly before a person's name (e.g., **U.S. Attorney Damian Williams**). This capitalization applies regardless of whether a specific regional locator is included (e.g., **U.S. Attorney Damian Williams of the Southern District of New York**). Keep "attorney" lowercase if the person is a deputy (e.g., **assistant U.S. attorney Danielle Sassoon**) as well as when the title is not directly followed by a name (e.g., **the U.S. attorney said**, the assistant U.S. attorney said). Be aware that there are nearly 100 U.S. attorneys in charge of enforcing federal law in districts across the United States. The U.S. Justice Department website offers details about these positions, including the names of current office holders. (See also [titles](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/titles/ "Titles") for general capitalization guidelines)

**attribution** (see [quotes](/home/q/quotes-overview) overview)

**audiotape** (one word for both the noun and the verb)

**auditor general** (generic reference without current office holder's name), **auditor general's report, auditor general's office, auditors general** (plural), but federal **Auditor General Johnny Galbraith, the Auditor General Act** (proper noun) See also [titles](/home/t/titles) and [general as a suffix](/home/g/generalsuffix))

**auger** (drilling tool); **augur** (bode)

**Auger-Aliassime, Félix**

**Aung San Suu Kyi** (pro-democracy leader in **[Myanmar](/home/m/Myanmar)** for several decades, and winner of the 1991 Nobel Peace Prize) **Suu Kyi** OK in second reference and web headlines, as explained more fully in the [Asian names](/home/a/asian-names) overview.
  (See also [pronunciation](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2Flng%2Frecherche%2Findex.aspx%3FProId%3D32903&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3D6ALIpL5AunOo_q5QmnU2))

**aurora borealis** (northern lights); **aurora australis** (southern equivalent) See also [space terms](/home/s/space-terms)

**Aurora** (type of aircraft)

**authorize**

**autism spectrum disorder** (commonly known as **autism**) A neurological condition associated with different degrees of **autism** and **[Asperger's syndrome](/home/a#Aspergers)**. The umbrella term **ASD** should be spelled out in first reference, if used at all. The disorder typically includes varying degrees of difficulty with communication (verbal and nonverbal), which can make social interaction challenging. People with autism spectrum disorder may also repeat certain behaviour, and have a limited number of interests, which they pursue intensely. NOTE: It's common and generally acceptable to use the clipped term autism alone in stories. Furthermore, **the term [autistic](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/d/disability-language/#autistic "Disability language") is usually recommended** over "person with autism" in generic references.

**automaker, autoworker** (but **Canadian Auto Workers** with a space and [no apostrophe](/handy-links/punctuation/possessive-apostrophe#propernouns) because _Workers_ is treated as descriptive not possessive in this proper noun) The CAW merged with another union in 2013 to become [**Unifor**](/home/u#Unifor).

**automated banking machine** ([ABM](/home/a#ABM), plural **ABMs**); **automated teller machine** ([**ATM**](/home/a#ATM), plural ATMs). In both cases, the A stands for _automated_, not automatic. ABM is the more common term in Canada.

**autonomous vehicles** (implies no human backup) Narrowly refers to vehicles that can operate without the need for people to monitor driving decisions (speed, steering, braking), or to survey the environment for possible safety concerns. When manufacturers assess autonomous vehicles on public roadways, it's clearest to call them **autonomous test vehicles** (i.e., the technology is intended to be autonomous, but there are still human beings on board to supervise). Differentiate between **fully autonomous** (driverless) and **partially automated vehicles**, also increasingly referred to as **semi-autonomous vehicles**. The latter feature a range of **driver-assist systems**. While such technology can perform certain tasks (e.g., changing lanes, maintaining specific distances from traffic directly ahead) human supervision is still required. Many automakers now have their own versions of partially automated driving systems. When reporting on these vehicles, use capital letters to identify the names as proprietary (e.g., Nissan's **ProPilot Assist** and Tesla's **Autopilot** versus the generic word **autopilot**).

**avant-garde** (see also [French words](/home/f/french-words-and-accents) for general guidelines)

**Avenue** versus **avenue** (See [addresses](/home/a/addresses))

**averse** (reluctant); **adverse** (contrary, unfavourable)

**avian influenza** (lowercase); **avian flu** (acceptable in first reference); **bird flu** (acceptable in second reference). Since there are many forms of avian flu, be sure to specify whether the type you're writing about threatens people's health.

**awhile** (an adverb) "They talked awhile." But use **a while** after prepositions such as _for, in_, etc. ("They talked for a while" and "It may take a while" and "Every once in a while.") In this case, _while_ is a noun. **A good test:** Use the fused version (awhile) only if the phrase "for a while" can replace it.

**AWOL** (OK in first reference; does not need to be spelled out as "**absent without leave**") The preferred Canadian shorthand used to be AWL, but the acronym AWOL is now common and acceptable. (See also [military terms](/home/m/military-terms-overview#AWOL))

**axe** (_not_ ax)

**axel** (lowercase) This figure-skating jump, named after a Norwegian athlete, was capitalized for many years. It's now lowercase, however, because of common usage, as in a **double axel**, a **triple axel**, etc. (See also [salchow](/home/s#salchow) and [lutz](/home/l#lutz))

**axis** (plural **axes**), but **the Axis** when referring to the Second World War alliance of Germany, Italy and Japan.

**Azerbaijan**

**Aziz, Tariq** (_not_ Tarek or Tareq) Iraq's former deputy prime minister, under Saddam Hussein

**AZT** (Abbreviation sufficient on first reference. If spelled out, prefer [zidovudine](/home/z#zidovudine) over azidothymidine.) See also [**AIDS**](/home/a/aids)

****

### a versus an

**An is used before any word, abbreviation or symbol** (e.g. number) **that begins with a vowel sound.** So it's an _MP_ and an _11-kilometre road_.



**a historic (a helpful rule)**
**Most words that begin with "h" are aspirated** (i.e., the "h" is sounded when spoken). **Always use "a" in these cases** (e.g., _a hotel, a holiday, a history professor,_ and _a historic moment_).


**an hour**
**A few words begin with an unaspirated "h"** (one that isn't sounded when spoken). **These take "an"** (e.g., _an hour, an heir, an honest,_ and _an honour_).

-   See the Pronunciation Database for a note about [a's vowel sound](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2Flng%2Frecherche%2Findex.aspx%3FProId%3D28489&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0V-XY-fClDxHg-K-zI1oxz) ("ay," as in hay, versus "ah," as in hah).

For a further discussion, see the Words: Woe & Wonder column: [A AND AN, EH?](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews2%2Findepth%2Fwords%2Fananda.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3DfiEhXgVwKth4P8fM_1MO)

### Abbas, Mahmoud

**Abbas, Mahmoud**

**Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas
Abbas** in second reference

-   Became prime minister in April 2003.
-   Resigned in September 2003.
-   Replaced by Ahmed Qureia, former Speaker of the Palestinian parliament (known as the Palestinian Legislative Council).
-   Became president of the Palestinian Authority in 2005.

  See also [pronunciation](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fmtlntapps08.apps.in.cbcsrc.ca%2Fapps%2Flng%2Frecherche%2Findex.aspx%3FProId%3D32204&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3mLHIvfUxpinlxiJSXIkC0)

Note: The title prime minister is always lowercase when the position is no longer held (i.e., former Palestinian prime minister Mahmoud Abbas), but uppercase when currently held and directly before the person's name (Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas). See [titles](/home/t/titles)

Although he goes by more than one name, CBC News always uses Abbas in first reference. If necessary, write "Abbas, also known as _Abu Mazen_" later in the story (if the word Mazen appears in a web quote or in a clip from television or radio). Then revert to using Abbas.

See also [Yasser Arafat](/home/a/arafat-yasser)

Read the [CBCNews.ca profile](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews%2Fbackground%2Fmiddleeast%2Fabbas.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1_my6u6BPna1pMGlZs7_YO) of Mahmoud Abbas (from May 2003)

### Abbreviations

**Abbreviations**

[Uppercase](/home/a/abbreviations#uppercase) (RCMP versus P.E.I.)

[Lowercase](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/a/abbreviations/#lowercase "Abbreviations") (a.k.a., m.p.h.)

[Mixed](/home/a/abbreviations#mixed) (uppercase, lowercase)

[Little words usually dropped](/home/a/abbreviations#littlewords) (BA and SCC, not BoA or SCOC)

[Plurals](/home/a/abbreviations#plurals) (FAQs versus p's and q's, 1950s, '30s, etc.)

[Dates](/home/a/abbreviations#dates) (November 2002 versus Nov. 15, 2002,)

[Provinces, states and countries](/home/a/abbreviations#Provinces) (Purple Springs, Alta.,)

[Geographical components of proper nouns](/home/a/abbreviations#propernouns-geocomponents) (B.C. Hydro, not 'BC Hydro,' but DriveBC)

[Time](/home/t/time) (5 p.m. ET, etc.)

[Single letters](/home/a/abbreviations#singleletters) ("p" or P, Mr. P., etc.)

[Foreign language lettering](/home/a/abbreviations#foreign) (CERN, Metfaz)

**TV TEXT REMINDER:** Be aware that television graphics, banners, supers, etc., have some unique typographical conventions that don't always match the basics highlighted below. The biggest difference is the use of more initial capital letters in titles, job descriptions, etc. (e.g., "Former Prime Minister" instead of former prime minister, and "High School Principal" instead of high school principal). See the [**TV Text overview**](/home/t/tv_text) for details.

**Uppercase**
**In most cases, do not put periods in abbreviations formed entirely out of capital letters** (_AIDS, BA, MA, MP, RCMP, SARS, SOB, UBC, URL, UN, VIP, etc._) **unless they refer to geographic locations** (_B.C., P.E.I., U.S._). See [acronyms](/home/a/acronyms) for more information about abbreviations pronounced as words.

One notable exception involves convention, such as the colloquial abbreviation _NYC_ for _New York City_. Although there's technically no C in the official name (i.e., it's _New York, N.Y_.), the abbreviation _NYC_ (without periods) has become entrenched. See [New York](/home/n#NewYork) for details.

Another common exception involves shortening a proper name to a letter or two, such as _"The mysterious witness was referred to as Mr. B."_ and _"Toronto is sometimes called T.O."_ But leave out this punctuation when the letters themselves function as the names of people or things, such as _"Exhibit A"_ or _"The identity of Lady X was never revealed."_ The periods should also be dropped if the letters are functioning as mere abbreviations, such as _ET_ for extraterrestrial versus [_E.T._](/home/e#ET) as the name of an extraterrestrial movie character.

See [Single letters (Madame X but Mr. D.)](/) below for more guidelines and examples.

See [When and how to spell out](/home/a/abbreviations#whenandhow) for related guidelines (e.g., _GST_ becomes _goods and services tax_ while a proper noun such as _UN_ becomes _[United Nations](/home/u/united-nations)_).

**Do not put periods in geographical abbreviations used to brand currency** (_$300 US, $450 Cdn_) See [money](/home/m/money) for more guidelines.

See also [Geographical components of proper nouns](/home/a/abbreviations#propernouns-geocomponents) below (B.C. Hydro, not 'BC Hydro,' but DriveBC).


**Lowercase**
**Virtually all entirely lowercase abbreviations take punctuation**.

Condensed terms commonly end in **one period**: _etc., ft., lb., misc., oz., qt., vol., yd._

Initialisms, by contrast, feature **two or more periods**: _e.g., a.k.a., a.m., i.e., m.p.h., p.m., s.o.b._

But see [single-letter abbreviations below](#singleletters) for exceptions (e.g., mind your _p's_ and _q's_), as well as [acronyms](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/a/acronyms/ "Acronyms") for lowercase initialisms that are now words (e.g., _laser_ and _scuba_).

CAUTION: Metric symbols are NOT considered true abbreviations, and, so, do not take periods on their own (_cm, km, ha, mm_) or when combined with other units (_km/h_ and _m/s_). Be aware, however, that neighbouring lowercase units sometimes take periods (_cu. cm, sq. m_), depending on convention. See [measurements below](#measurements) for details. A table of common metric shorthand is included in our [imperial versus metric overview](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/m/metric-versus-imperial/#abbreviating "Metric versus imperial").


**Mixed (uppercase, lowercase)**
**Most abbreviations made up of lowercase and mixed letters take periods** (_Mr., Mrs., Sgt., B.Comm.,_ etc.) **but there are exceptions** (_Miss_. for _Mississippi_ but _Miss_ as in _Miss Jones_). **In general, use Jr. or Sr. only with a person's full name**, and do not add a comma unless more abbreviations follow (_Edgar Bronfman Jr. may try to buy the company_ versus _The letter was signed "Joe Jones Jr., PhD"_).

**Do not put periods in mixed abbreviations that begin and end with capital letters** (_PhD, PoW, MiG, U of T_).

**Do not put spaces in abbreviations made up of big and small letters** (_B.Ed., M.Sc., P.Eng._) **unless they're separated by a word and don't have periods** (U of A). See also [degrees](/home/d/degrees).

**Sometimes abbreviations lose most or all of their capital letters** (_Nabisco_ instead of NABISCO for what used to be the National Biscuit Company, and _scuba_ for self-contained underwater breathing apparatus), **depending on convention and in-house style.** For instance, we write the _U.S. Patriot Act_ instead of _USA PATRIOT Act_, even though the legislation was formally called "Uniting and Strengthening America by Providing Appropriate Tools Required to Intercept and Obstruct Terrorism" when passed in 2001. **One consideration is whether such abbreviations form an existing common word** (in this case, "patriot"). Even though the White House itself has flipped between the USA PATRIOT Act and the Patriot Act for several years, we stick with the U.S. Patriot Act — along with AP, CP, the BBC and many other news organizations. See also [NORAD](/home/n#NORAD) (which some news organizations spell as "Norad" to avoid five or more uppercase letters).


**Little words usually dropped (SCC, not SCOC)**
**Abbreviations generally include principal words only.** So it's _BA_ (not "_BoA_" or "_BOA_") for _Bachelor of Arts_, _AFN_ (not "_AoFN_" or "_AOFN_") for _Assembly of First Nations_, [SCC](/home/s#SupremeCourt) (not "_SCoC_" or "_SCOC_") for _Supreme Court of Canada_, _CMHC_ (not "_CMaHC_" or "_CMAHC_") for _Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation_, _GST_ (not "_GaST_" or "_GAST_") for _goods and services tax_, _ETA_ (not "_EToA_" or "_ETOA_") for _estimated time of arrival_, etc.

Occasionally, prepositions, conjunctions and other small words are included in short forms, either based on convention (_PoW_ for _Prisoner of War_, with the "o" lowercase) or because they're needed to make the letters pronounceable, such as the I in _NIMBY_ (for _not in my backyard_). But these are exceptions.


**FAQs about VIPs that mind their p's and q's**
**Add apostrophes to plural forms of INDIVIDUAL letters , whether lowercase or capitalized**, to make it easier to scan the text (p's and q's, X's and O's). This applies to SINGLE letters of the alphabet only. **But do NOT add apostrophes to form the plurals of clusters of capital letters or numbers** (ABCs, FAQs, MPs, SOBs, 1950s, the Dirty '30s, 747s). See also [apostrophes](/handy-links/punctuation/apostrophes) and [time](/home/t/time#1950s), as well as [single letters ("p" or P, etc.)](#singleletters) below for a 2023 style change summary.


**Dates**
**Do not abbreviate or put commas after months standing alone or that are followed only by the year.**


> _November 2002 was a month she will never forget._
>
> _He goes to a cottage every August._
>
> _Security at airports was never the same after September 2001._
>
> _She was killed in the July 2005 London bombings._


**Put commas after both the month and the year in specific dates.** In these cases, **abbreviate only months that have more than five letters: Jan., Feb., Aug., Sept., Oct., Nov.** and **Dec.**


> _The ship sank on Feb. 3, 1917._
>
> _On Oct. 16, 1970, the federal government proclaimed the [War Measures Act](/home/e#EmergenciesAct)._
>
> _They cashed the cheque on March 22, 1997, nine months after the lottery draw._
>
> _The Sept. 11, 2001, attacks changed everything._
>
> _He's a suspect in the July 7, 2005, London bombings._


**Do not include ordinal notation** (1st, 2nd, 3rd, etc.) **unless the sentence's syntax requires it** (e.g., in a prepositional construction).


> _On July 7, 2005, ..._
>
> _On the 7th of July, 2005, ..._
>
> _... before Oct. 2, 2012._
>
> _... before the 2nd of October._


See also [ordinals](/home/n/numbers#ordinals)

**Centuries can be clipped in second reference**, using the following guidelines:


> _1965-81_
>
> _1997-98_
>
> _1892-1903_
>
> _1999-2002_


For rules on decades (1950s, the '30s, etc.), see [apostrophes](/handy-links/punctuation/apostrophes) and [time](/home/t/time#1950s).

For guidelines on "AD 79" versus "75 BC," see [AD](/home/a#AD) and [BC](/home/b#BC).

See also [hyphens](/handy-links/punctuation/hyphens) ("1975-76" versus "between 1975 and 1976," and "Oct. 21-23" versus "from Oct. 21 to 23").


**Addresses and roads**
**Generally abbreviate words like Street, Avenue, etc. when numbers that are not part of the road's name** (41st Avenue) **appear in the address** (622 41st Ave.), **except in rare cases established by convention** (e.g., an official government residence). **This applies to major highways**, even in headlines (e.g., write Highway 27 instead of "Hwy. 27"). Do not use hyphens between numbers or between numbers and letters. **Points of the compass** (north, east, etc.) **become a single letter** followed by a period unless they're part of the official name (West Hastings). Blended quadrants follow standard compass abbreviation (southeast becomes S.E.):


> _Yonge Street_
>
> _599B Yonge St._
>
> _205 Wellington St. W._
>
> _101 West Hastings St._
>
> _110th Street S.E._
>
> _5925 110th St. S.E._
>
> _North Service Road_
>
> _3900 North Service Rd._
>
> _24 Sussex Drive_
>
> _10 Downing Street_
>
> _Highway 401_
>
> _Trans-Canada Highway_


See [addresses](/home/a/addresses) for more examples, including guidelines on _Apt_. versus _Apartment_ or _apartment_, and on spelling out ordinal numbers under 10 (_First_ rather than _1st_).


**Provinces, states and countries**

**NOTE: This section focuses on standard text in stories**, including headlines, subheads, photo captions and the main bodies of web articles. **Maps, graphics, etc., sometimes require more condensed abbreviations**, as noted below.


**With the exception of** British Columbia (**B.C.**), Prince Edward Island (**P.E.I.**) and the Northwest Territories (**N.W.T.**), **do not abbreviate provincial or territorial names unless they appear after cities, towns or other communities in the main body of a story.**
_
They bought a farm near Purple Springs, Alta., in 1955.
She was born in Quebec in 1970.
He died in a plane crash near Fort McPherson, N.W.T., three years ago._

**In these cases, always use a comma after the community and a second comma after the province, territory or** (when relevant) **country.** This is a standard publishing convention to aid readers. The additional information is treated as a subordinate fragment that could be removed without changing the sentence's flow or meaning:


> _He took the train from Milan, Italy, to Stuttgart, Germany, last week._
>
> _The bus left Chilliwack, B.C., at 3 p.m._
>
> _Gillian Jones of Pictou, N.S., was first._


By framing extra details with commas, the eye scans the key points more quickly:


> _He took the train from Italy to Germany last week._
>
> _The bus left Chilliwack at 3 p.m._
>
> _Gillian Jones of Nova Scotia was first._


**NOTE: When a geographical reference is used as compound adjective, it's generally best to recast the sentence** so that the second comma doesn't disrupt the sentence's flow.


> _They started a Surrey, B.C., company that created jobs for dozens of ..._ (OK but somewhat jarring)
>
> _They started a company in Surrey, B.C., that created jobs for dozens of ..._ (Preferred)

**
Never shorten [Yukon](/home/y/yukon) or Nunavut**:


> _The fire began at the base of a mountain near Faro, Yukon, a community of about 500 people_.
>
> _Rassi Nashalik is a proud Inuk from Pangnirtung, Nunavut, and was a trailblazer in Canadian media._


**When abbreviations are appropriate, use the following: N.W.T., B.C., Alta., Sask., Man., Ont., Que., N.B., N.S., P.E.I.,** and **N.L.** ([not Nfld.](/home/n/newfoundland-and-labrador)). **Always include periods.**

**In web headlines**, provincial abbreviations are often used to save space. But they're not mandatory (e.g., Alberta or Alta. are both fine). Do not shorten Yukon or Nunavut. Do not abbreviate Canada or Canadian outside of currency references (see [Money](/home/m/money#CdnUS) for details). The abbreviation **Nfld.** is sometimes used in web headlines, but only in rare cases when referring to the island itself (e.g., "southern Nfld," spelled out as "southern Newfoundland" in the main story). **Labrador is never abbreviated when used on its own**, even in web headlines.

See [provinces and cities](/home/p/provinces-and-cities#maps-graphics) for details on why **two-character postal abbreviations like AB and MB are restricted to maps, graphics, etc.**, where space constraints are typically severe.

Pairs of commas are also used when naming most communities around the globe:


> _She moved to Great Falls, Mont., in 1944._
>
> _He was born in Florence, Italy, during the Second World War._


**For details on which cities can stand alone in copy** (without the name of a province, state or country after them), see [provinces and cities](/home/p/provinces-and-cities), [U.S. abbreviations](/home/u/united-states), and [cities around the world](/home/g/geography-cities).


**Geographical components of proper nouns** (B.C. Hydro, not 'BC Hydro;' but DriveBC)
**Include periods in the geographical components of virtually all proper nouns**, regardless of whether an organization or government agency has dropped the punctuation from its registered name.


> Ballet B.C.
>
> B.C. Coroners Service
>
> B.C. Ferries
>
> B.C. Place
>
> B.C. Hydro
>
> B.C. Wildfire Service
>
> Elections B.C.
>
> Finance P.E.I.
>
> N.B. Power
>
> N.B. Research and Productivity Council
>
> P.E.I. Pass


**The only exceptions are rare cases of fused spellings** and other unorthodox typography, **as well as routine, all-uppercase initialisms:**


> DriveBC
>
> FortisBC
>
> NSGC (spelled out as Nova Scotia Gaming Corporation)
>
> SaskPower
>
> UBC
>
> UCLA
>
> UPEI
>
> WorkplaceNL
>
> WorkSafeBC
>
> WorkSafeNB



**SIMPLIFIED STYLE:** CBC News adopted the streamlined approach above in August of 2021 to address confusion over the growing number of exceptions to standard typography. Organizations were increasingly removing periods from geographical abbreviations, often capriciously and sometimes temporarily. Journalists, in turn, were stuck with the time-consuming task of verifying arbitrary spellings advocated by branding consultants. Certain usage was inconsistent (e.g., the "**B.C. Coroner's Act**" referred to the "BC Coroners Service," and the "**B.C. Pavilion Corporation**" decided to change the spelling of a stadium to "BC Place"). The Canadian Press, CBC and other news organizations, meanwhile, wound up hard pressed to explain why we had, say, embraced "NB Power" but still insisted on the "**P.E.I. Liquor Control Commission**" — even though the latter was listed as "PEI" on the provincial government's website — or why the "**B.C. Liberal Party**" was normally used even though "BC Liberal Party" appeared in a lot of the organization's advertising. The Beast of Ad Hoc Punctuation had been unleashed. Before slaying it, we weighed the pros of matching the stated preferences of organizations for certain spellings against the cons of ignoring the jarring incongruity caused by erratic divergences from traditional typography. In the end, we decided that it was in the best interest of our writers and editors, as well as our audience, to re-impose conventional publishing rules about periods in routine geographical shorthand, regardless of whether the abbreviations were standalone modifiers or elements of proper names.


**It's a myth that external typography must be matched verbatim to maintain the principle of accuracy.** See [stylistic latitude](/home/s/spelling#stylisticlatitude) in the spelling overview for details.

As noted in the [previous section](/home/a/abbreviations#Provinces), **we use standard geographical abbreviations (B.C., Alta., Ont.) rather than two-letter postal symbols (BC, AB, ON)** in most of our journalism.
