Exceptions are permitted in maps, graphics, etc., where space is precious. For details, see [provinces and cities](/home/p/provinces-and-cities#abbreviating).


**Measurements**
**Do not add periods to metric terms** (_mm, cm, km_), **but keep them in long-established imperial abbreviations** (_lb., yd., sq. ft._). **Do not add an "s" to form plurals** (_10 km_ never kms, and _100 lb._ never lbs.). See [metric versus imperial](/home/m/metric-versus-imperial).

**In general, all these terms should be spelled out** (_feet, kilogram, minute, hour, metre,_ etc.) unless they appear in graphic tables. **A few common measurements**, however, **can be abbreviated** in stories (_50 km/h, 9-mm pistol,_ the old _60-m.p.h. limit_). **If a metric symbol appears at the end of a sentence, it takes a single period:** _100 km/h_.

See also [temperatures](/home/m/metric-versus-imperial#temperatures).


**Single letters ("p" or P, etc.)**
[Lowercase single letters](/home/a/abbreviations#lowercasesingleletters) ("p" and p's)
[Uppercase single letters](/home/a/abbreviations#uppercasesingleletters) (P, ABCs)
[Logic often dictates size of single letters](/home/a/abbreviations#logicoftendictate) ("w" vs. W)
[How to handle periods after single letters](/home/a/abbreviations#periodssingleletters) (Madame X but Mr. D.)


**Lowercase single letters ("p" and p's)**
**Use lowercase when citing a letter of the alphabet that's also lowercase in the word, abbreviation, etc., you're referring to. Add quotation marks** ("p") to help flag the letter, which can otherwise look like a typo, **unless an apostrophe already does this job** (p's) when a plural form is used:


> _Do not add an "s" to km or lb._
>
> _The "u" in scuba stands for underwater._
>
> _Nowadays, not everyone bothers to pronounce the "n" in government._
>
> _He had trouble saying r's and l's._
>
> _Mind your p's and q's._


See also [apostrophes](/handy-links/punctuation/apostrophes) for uppercase and lowercase treatments of plurals (p's and q's versus VIPs, MPs, etc.)


**Uppercase single letters (P, ABCs, X's and O's)**
**Use a capital when the single letter of the alphabet is also uppercase in the word, abbreviation, etc., you're referring to. Quotation marks are generally unnecessary** to flag capital letters since they already stand out:


> _The T in NATO means Treaty.
> _(The T is uppercase to match the acronym, and the word "Treaty" takes an initial capital letter because that's how [NATO](/home/n#NATO) is spelled out.)
> _The I in AIDS means immune.
> _(The I is uppercase to match the acronym, but the word "immune" is lowercase because that's how [AIDS](/home/a/aids) is spelled out.)_C represents Celsius.
> __He got a B on the test.
> __The jury asked to see Exhibit A again._
>
> _When she sang her ABCs, she always paused midway through and said, "P is for pony."_


**Clusters of capital letters do NOT need apostrophes when rendered in plural form** (e.g., _VIP_ and _FAQ_ become _VIPs_ and _FAQs_). The same applies to two or more figures constituting a plural (e.g., 1980s, the Dirty '30s). **But ADD apostrophes to INDIVIDUAL letters when forming plurals, whether lowercase or capitalized:**


> _She got three A's and two B's on her report card._
> _They want schools to focus more on the three R's — reading, writing and arithmetic._
> _A game of X's and O's.
> __The Oakland A's.
> __Mississauga is spelled with four s's._
>
> _Cross your t's and dot your i's._

**SIMPLIFIED STYLE:** In August 2023, we streamlined our approach to using apostrophes to signal the plural form of individual letters. Until then, the punctuation was added only to lowercase individual letters (p's and q's). We decided it was simpler to match AP style and extend apostrophes to uppercase individual letters, too. This makes our typography more consistent. While the Canadian Oxford says Xs and X's are both acceptable plural forms of a capital X, for example, it specifically lists X's and O's as the colloquial name for tick-tack-toe. And while CP has traditionally recommended no apostrophe for most uppercase individual letters, it does encourage the punctuation in cases when there could be confusion (e.g., when "A's" or "I's" might look like the words "As" or "Is" without the punctuation). By adopting Associated Press style, CBC News journalists no longer have to decide whether the plural form of a single letter takes punctuation. We simply add an apostrophe, regardless of whether the individual letter is lowercase or capitalized.


See also [apostrophes](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/handy-links/punctuation/apostrophes/ "Apostrophes") for handling single letters turned into verbs (X'd, X'ing)


See also [How to handle periods below](/home/a/abbreviations#periodssingleletters) (The T in NATO but Mr. T.)


**Logic often dictates size of single letters ("w" vs. W)**
**Occasionally, either form is OK. Pick the version that is easiest for our audience** to follow:


> _They removed all the w's from the office's keyboards._
>
> _They removed all the W's from the office's keyboards._

**
Here, the first version is more common because it's a generic reference to the alphabet**, even though keyboards typically feature capital letters. But either is acceptable.

The Canadian Press points out: "Whether to write a single letter as a capital or lowercase in a particular context depends somewhat on personal taste." But **logic should be applied**. For instance:


> _There was a T scratched on the door._
>
> (This implies a capital T appeared.)
>
> _There was a "t" scratched on the door._
>
> (This implies a lowercase "t" appeared.)
>
> _It begins with a capital S._
>
> _She always slipped a small letter "x" somewhere in her drawing._
>
> _Good spellers remember to add a second "m" in accommodate._


**The subtleties of such logic can be illustrated by the choice of something as rudimentary as a verb,** such as is instead of _becomes_ below:


> _When MP is spelled out, the "m" is lowercase (i.e., member of Parliament)._
>
> _When MP is spelled out, the M becomes lowercase (i.e., member of Parliament)._

**How to handle periods after single letters (Madame X but Mr. D.)**
**Generally add periods to letters on their own only if they're "true" abbreviations** (i.e., letters that could conventionally stand alone, such as a person's middle initial, rather than merely one letter plucked from an acronym, such as the S in NASA, or letters that are not conventionally written without punctuation, such as metric symbols):


> _"My name is Madame X," she said._
>
> (No period. Madame X is treated as a proper noun, not as an abbreviation.)
>
> _Let's assume A sues B for copyright infringement._
>
> (No periods. The alphabetical designations are generic.)
>
> _F means Fahrenheit._
>
> (No period. Here, the F is considered a symbol rather than an abbreviation.)
>
> _Will a compass needle still hover over the N at the South Pole?_
>
> (No period. Here N is a compass mark rather than an abbreviation for north. A needle doesn't hover over the "north." It points north.)
>
> _John F. Kennedy's middle name was Fitzgerald._
>
> _He's referred to as Mr. D. throughout the documents._
>
> (The D has a period because it's an abbreviation for Mr. Dimple.)
>
> _They found the answer on p. 4._
>
> (Normally, "p. 4" is written out as page 4, but p. is acceptable in graphics, tabulations, etc., where space is at a premium, especially if the spelled-out word would otherwise appear more than once.)


See also the [periods overview](/handy-links/punctuation/periods) for punctuation in names _(J.F. Kennedy_ vs. _JFK_), and the [hyphens overview](/handy-links/punctuation/hyphens#A-list) for punctuation in various compounds involving letters of the alphabet (_Exhibit A_ and _B Block_ but _A-list_ and _B-team_)


**Foreign language lettering**
**If an abbreviation based on another language is better known than its English equivalent, generally use the more familiar letters** (e.g., _CERN_ rather than _EONR_). But **instead of spelling out the foreign wording** (Conseil Européen pour la Recherche Nucléaire), **prefer background context in English** (e.g., _"He worked at the European Organization for Nuclear Research, also known by the French acronym CERN"_).

In such cases, **do not automatically make the foreign abbreviation all uppercase. Follow established convention** (e.g., _"The report looked into a unit of Iran's Defence Ministry called the "Research Center for Explosion and Impact," better known by its Farsi language abbreviation Metfaz"_).


**When and how to spell out**
**Abbreviations that are well-known can be used without being spelled out** (_CBC, MP, RCMP_, etc.). **The list grows over time.** When _NASA_ was first set up in the 1958, it was frequently identified as the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Now, however, the U.S. space agency is a household acronym. The same goes for _LED_, which no longer needs to be defined as "light-emitting diode."

**Abbreviations are normally written out in lowercase** (GST becomes the goods and services tax, GIS becomes the _guaranteed income supplement_, and RRIF becomes the registered retirement income fund) **unless they are proper nouns** (CSIS becomes the _Canadian Security Intelligence Service_) **or include proper noun elements** (MP turns into _member of Parliament,_ with only one word capitalized). A few exceptions have become entrenched, normally based on treating the root term as a formal name (e.g., CPP is spelled out as the **Canada Pension Plan**, and OAS is spelled out as the _Old Age Security_ program).

**Do not assume that all capital letters in abbreviations are retained** in the long form (e.g., _NWT_ stands for the _Northwest Territories_, not the North West Territories, while _TV_ is short for _television_). **And remember that words not represented in the short form may need to be added when spelled out**, especially prepositions (e.g., PoW includes the "o" for "of" in _prisoner of war_ while BA doesn't, even though the latter is spelled out as a _bachelor of arts_ degree).

M**ake sure all spelled-out forms are correct** (ABM stands for "_automated_" not "_automatic_" _banking machine_.)

**Always spell out less-common terms** early on in a story ("_bovine spongiform encephalopathy_" for _BSE_). The longer version does not have to be at the beginning if it makes the lead too unwieldy.

**Avoid spelling out popular abbreviations when the longer form is not in general use** (_DNA_, not _deoxyribonucleic acid_, and _CAT scan_, not _computerized axial tomography scan_).

**While certain terms, such as _BASE jumping_, are never spelled out, they're normally explained in stories if considered obscure** (e.g., _"Parachute jumping from a fixed point, such as a high building, rather than from an aircraft"_). **Explanations do not have to be lengthy, and do not have to include actual definitions of each letter** (in this case, for instance, BASE stands for "building, antenna, span, earth"), since that's rarely practical.

**Generally avoid colloquial shorthand** (_ID'd_ for _identified_) in news stories, **except in headlines and transcribed quotes**. Features may be an exception, as long as the lighter tone of such shorthand (_KO'd, OK'd, PO'd_) suits the piece.

**It's unnecessary to put an organization's well-known abbreviation in parentheses immediately after the longer form is used.** Instead, the shorter version can appear on its own later (_CNIB_ in a story about the Canadian National Institute for the Blind).

**When the shortened form of the noun is not widely known, however, a brief reminder is generally required in second reference** (e.g., _CALPA, the pilots association, took the case to court_). **For this reason, it's often best to avoid such abbreviations in stories** and use a general label instead (e.g., the association, the union, the pilots). See the next section for more details.

**If publishing obscure abbreviations, be certain to confirm which letters to use and whether they're all capitalized.** For example, _CPHA_ stands for the _Canadian Public Health Association_ while _CPhA_ refers to the Canadian Pharmacists Association. Note: To review why it's "_pharmacists association_" instead of "_pharmacists' association_" and "_pilots association_" instead of "_pilots' association_" see [possessive apostrophe](/handy-links/punctuation/possessive-apostrophe).


**When to avoid abbreviations**
Keep in mind that **regional expressions are not familiar to everyone across the country**. If you're writing a story for a local audience, for instance, _MLA_ on its own is OK if it's commonly used in the region. But if you're writing a story for a national audience, "_member of the legislative assembly_" or "_member of the legislature_" would be better. This also applies to _MHA_ in Newfoundland and Labrador ("_member of the House of Assembly_"), _MNA_ in Quebec ("_member of the National Assembly_") and _MPP_ in Ontario ("_member of the Provincial Parliament_"). The same is true for [airport codes](/home/a/airport) (e.g., YVR, YYZ, YUL).

Text looks odd and becomes harder to read when sprinkled too liberally with blocks of capital letters. **Generally avoid abbreviations that seem foreign or forced** (_CA_ for _Canadian Alliance, WMD_ for _weapons of mass destruction_, _HRC_ for _Human Rights Commission_, and _PPP_ or _P3_ for _public-private partnerships_). **Instead, choose generic terms** for subsequent references (_the party, the weapons, the commission,the partnerships,_ etc.). **In general, this approach also applies to abbreviations that border on being obscure** (e.g., CALPA, CPHA), as noted in the previous section on spelling out abbreviations.

Even widely embraced terms such as NATO can very quickly become "typographically intrusive," as the New York Times Manual of Style and Usage puts it. **Instead of bombarding readers with capital letters, type a synonym** (such as "_the Atlantic alliance_" or "_the alliance_") every so often.

**Broadcast journalism is generally more difficult for the ear to follow when it includes too many abbreviations**, especially if they're obscure (e.g., [PKK, YPG, PYD](/home/p#PKK)). For this reason, accurate, generic wording is often clearer in second reference (e.g., "Kurdish-led fighters in Syria" rather than "YPG").


**Miscellaneous caveats**
**Always check the Language Guide for CBC News preferences**, rather than blindly following the abbreviations used by external sources.

**Be careful not to repeat part of a term by mistake** (make it the _NDP_ not the _NDP party_, since the latter stands for "_the New Democratic Party party_"). Similar traps to avoid include: _OPEC countries, RCMP police officer, PIN number, ATM machine,_ and _HIV virus._

**Generally avoid tabloid abbreviations that stand out as overly informal** ("_nukes_" for _nuclear weapons_ and _"pen" for penitentiary_). **And keep in mind that a few abbreviations we permit in headlines** (e.g., _StatsCan_) **are generally spelled out in the rest of the story** (_Statistics Canada_). **Sometimes colloquialisms become entrenched.** The terms _webcam_ and _dashcam_ (for dashboard camera) are examples. **But in such cases, the clipped form almost always becomes part of the fused compound rather than appearing as a noun on its own** (i.e., as "_cam_"). See [camera](/home/c#camera) for other examples (e.g., write security camera rather than "security cam").

**Be consistent when using abbreviations**. For example, if writing _WW II_ in a headline always use _World War II_ and _WW II_ in the main text as well, even though our normal preference would be _Second World War_ (i.e., in stories without [WW II](/home/w#WW1WW2) in the headline).

**Reserve the honorific [_Dr._](/home/d/dr) for health-care professionals.** It's spelled out as doctor unless used in front of a name. **For people with _PhDs_ other than licensed psychologists, use descriptive titles.** (_UBC political science professor Jane Gerrymander_, for instance, or _Mark Newton, who teaches physics at the University of New Brunswick_.) **Common terms** (BA or PhD) **are fine, but do not use obscure abbreviations for academic credentials. When spelled out, university degrees are always in lowercase** (_MA_ but _master of arts_).

**Although it's common to put an article (the) in front of many abbreviations that represent organizations** (the UN or the RCMP), **we often drop this convention with well-known [acronyms](/home/a/acronyms)** (NATO, NASA, OPEC, UNICEF, WHO).

**The Canadian Broadcasting Corporation's internet service is _CBC.ca_ in all news stories.** Do not use the lowercase version that appears in some promotional material (_cbc.ca_). This applies to other titles altered in graphical branding, such as "cbcnews.ca" and "cbc news" (which should be _CBCNews.ca_ and _CBC News_ in our journalism). See [CBC](/home/c/cbc)

**Follow unorthodox capitalization of abbreviations only if it's the preference of a well-known figure** (_k.d. lang, e.e. cummings_). See also [capitalization](/home/c/capitalization)


**Common mistakes**

-   July, 2002 (should be **July 2002**),
-   August 17, 1955 (should be **Aug. 17, 1955,**),
-   Mar. 15, 2001 (should be **March 15, 2001,**),
-   $150 U.S. (should be **$150 US**),
-   $120 Cnd. (should be **$120 Cdn**, without a period and with the "d" before the "n"),
-   75 km/hr, 105-mm. cannon and 30 kms. (should be **75 km/h, 105-mm** cannon and **30 kilometres**),
-   599-B Yonge Street (should be **599B Yonge St.**),
-   POW (should be **PoW**),
-   U.N., M.P. and N.A.T.O. (should be **UN**, **MP** and **NATO**),
-   Lethbridge, Alberta (should be **Lethbridge, Alta.,**)
-   PEI (should always be **P.E.I.**, even in headlines),
-   FAQ's and VIP's (should be **FAQs** and **VIPs**),
-   Bachelor of Arts and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (should be **bachelor of arts** and **severe acute respiratory syndrome**, even though the clipped forms are BA and SARS), and cbc.ca (should be **CBC.ca**).


See also [military ranks](/home/m/military-ranks), [money](/home/m/money), [numbers](/home/n/numbers), [police ranks](/home/p/police-ranks) and [temperatures](/home/m/metric-versus-imperial#temperatures)

### abortion

**Abortion**

**Language used in stories about abortion should be as neutral as possible.** Write "fetus" instead of "unborn child," for instance.

**It's best to describe people's specific positions rather than merely label them as being pro- or anti- something** (e.g., _"Anderson wants to limit abortions to cases involving minors who've been sexually assaulted"_).

**But in headlines and certain sentence constructions, shorthand is the only practical solution. In these cases, use the following terms:**

-   **anti-abortion** (not "pro-life")
-   **pro-choice** or **pro-abortion rights** (but not "pro-abortion")

**The only exceptions are when we're referring to a specific proper noun, such as an organization** that calls itself the Pro-Life Federation of North America. But in news stories, we would still describe members of such a group as being "anti-abortion."

Whenever possible, **prefer specific information about the timing of an abortion** (e.g., the 18th week of a pregnancy versus, say, the 22nd week) **over general labels, such as "late term."** The latter is a vague description with no precise legal or medical definition. It conventionally means "late" into the second trimester (i.e., after the 21st to 24th week), and is commonly linked to fetus viability outside the womb. **Be aware that some people wrongly assume that "late term" means virtually "full-term" pregnancy** (i.e., after the 36th week). Such imprecision can hinder fact-based public policy debates.


**Pro-life is too vague** because it doesn't specifically address the issue of pregnancy (raising questions about people's views on capital punishment, euthanasia, etc.). It also implies that everyone who is not "pro-life" is in the opposite camp (i.e., pro-death).

**Pro-abortion is not always accurate** (e.g., when describing a large crowd of protesters) because many people lobby for a woman's right to choose abortion while not favouring abortion as a personal option, themselves.


People who campaign to expand abortion services (e.g., setting up clinics) can accurately be called **abortion rights activists**, since this term accurately captures the sense of a woman's right to choose. **When naming individuals, it's important to note any known distinctions between personal and general views** (e.g., _"Lang says she would never have an abortion but still advocates other women's right to choose"_).


**Avoid using the terms "women's rights" and "abortion rights" interchangeably.**

**Women's rights broadly refers to equality between women and men**, including many basic legal rights (e.g., voting, working, attending school, owning property). Women's **reproductive rights fall under the umbrella of women's rights** — covering everything from access to birth control and abortion services to freedom from coerced sterilization and other non-consensual medical procedures.

**Abortion rights is common, acceptable shorthand for "women's right to abortion services."** Expressions such as **the right to choose** are also OK, as long as the context of abortion is already clear.

Be aware that **not all people championing women's rights support access to abortion services.** The label "anti-abortion feminism," for example, is sometimes used to describe groups like Pro Woman, Pro Life. Members of such groups fundamentally disagree with pro-choice feminists, who are represented by organizations like the Abortion Rights Coalition of Canada. In other words, **the term women's rights is complicated and does not have the same meaning to all women, especially when abortion is debated.** The history and politics of these competing views of "women's rights" and "abortion rights" are explored in detail in the 2015 book, _The Changing Voice of the Anti-Abortion Movement: The Rise of 'Pro-Woman' Rhetoric in Canada and the United States_, by University of Ottawa academics Paul Saurette and Kelly Gordon.

See also [vs. versus v.](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/v/#versus "V") for Canadian instead of U.S. court cases (e.g., **R. vs. Morgentaler** but **Roe v. Wade**)
See also [anti versus anti-](/home/a/anti-versus-anti) (for guidelines on when to put a hyphen after the prefix).

### accidents

**Accidents, collisions, crashes, etc.**

**Picking a verb**

**When covering stories, it's important to use accurate and neutral language.

In the case of most motor vehicle collisions, for instance, we should be cautious about stating that person A "hit" person B**, unless the information is attributed (e.g., to police) or is not in dispute (e.g., video clearly shows A hitting B). **For this reason, a verb such as "collide" is often a better choice** than "hit" (e.g., the truck and car collided).

**The verb "[door](/home/d#dooring)"** has become a convenient and **increasingly common way to refer to collisions between cyclists and open doors of stopped vehicles** (e.g., "She's in critical condition after being doored riding to work"). Again, **be careful with how stories are worded**. Motorists and their passengers are supposed to check to make sure it's safe before opening their doors in most jurisdictions. So while it might be technically accurate to state that a "cyclist rode into a door," such **phrasing can imply it was the cyclist's fault.** One option is to stick with neutral wording (e.g., "the cyclist collided with the door"). But **when known facts fit, it's often OK to use a verb like "hit" or "stuck" in a dooring accident** (e.g., "the cyclist was hit by a suddenly opened door"), **as long as the details are attributed** to authorities, witnesses, etc., **or are not in dispute** (e.g., verified video shows what happened). It's akin to describing someone being "hit by" debris tossed from an overpass, instead of saying that they "collided with" falling debris. **Use common sense.** Be aware that such accidents can be fatal, and do not always involve the driver's door (e.g., passengers in a taxi may be exiting the vehicle without checking to see if there's any oncoming traffic). Also be aware that while some people strongly oppose the word "accident" to describe dooring, the noun is common and generally OK for reasons outlined below.


**Picking a noun**
**The same principles about accuracy and neutrality outlined above apply. But there's no need to get carried away with adopting awkward constructions solely to avoid use of a word such as "accident"** in our coverage.

**It's a myth that the term "accident" automatically implies something "accidental"** rather than "intentional." **The word has another entrenched meaning: unexpected.** This isn't a recent development. From its original Latin roots, "accident" has referred to an unplanned "befalling" or "happening" — which gradually expanded to mean simply a "mishap."

**In this context, "accident" has become a widely used synonym for collision.** The Canadian Oxford Dictionary, for instance, lists one definition of accident as: _"an automobile collision or crash."_  **This does not imply that a given accident won't be blamed on one or more people, equipment failure, the weather, etc.** Indeed, police may well lay charges. **It simply means that "accident" and "collision" are entrenched synonyms in English.** Investigators fill out "accident reports." Insurance companies offer "no-fault accident" coverage.

**Since "accident" is a perfectly acceptable way to describe an unexpected event,** therefore,  **industrial accidents** do NOT need to be referred to as, say, "industrial incidents," and **traffic accidents** do NOT automatically need to be referred to as, say, "collisions." **At the same time, it's important to be as precise as possible. So when covering a given story, it's best to pick a different word if you consider "accident" inappropriate or misleading** (e.g., when negligence has been proven, or if there's compelling evidence that a particular tragedy was intentional). **Use your own judgment.**

### acronyms

**Acronyms**

**Acronyms are abbreviations that can be pronounced.

When formed from the first letter of each word in a compound noun, they're almost always written in uppercase and without periods:**

> **BAFTA** (British Academy of Film and Television Arts)
>
> **CSIS** (Canadian Security Intelligence Service)
>
> **NAFTA** (North American Free Trade Agreement)
>
> **NATO** (North Atlantic Treaty Organization)
>
> **UNESCO** (United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization)


This normally applies even when an element previously treated as two works or as hyphenated words is now fused (e.g., "interbank"):

> **LIBOR** (London interbank offered rate)


Acronyms are not always "pure" initialisms. They can also be made up of clipped words represented by a cluster of consonants and/or vowels, such as "NOR" for "North." These may or may not be all uppercase, depending on established convention and in-house style


> **[Nabisco](/home/q/quirky-capitalization)** (Originally stood for the "National Biscuit Company")
>
> **[NORAD](/home/n#NORAD)** (North American Aerospace Defence Command)


Be aware that a few news organizations limit the number of uppercase letters (e.g., UNESCO becomes "Unesco" at the New York Times because the acronym has more than four characters). But we write UNESCO for various reasons, including convention, simplicity and ease-of-scanning.

**A common exception to the uppercase rule is when the abbreviation is thought of more as a name on its own than as shorthand** (e.g., the musical group **_Abba_**, which is technically formed out of letters representing the musicians' names). See [Quirky capitalization](/home/q/quirky-capitalization) for related guidelines.

**If you spell out acronyms**, follow the same guidelines governing other abbreviations. **Words should be in lowercase unless they're normally capitalized** (for example, if they're part of the official name of an organization).


> **[AIDS](/home/a/aids)** (acquired immune deficiency syndrome)
>
> **RAM** (random access memory)
>
> **SALT** (strategic arms limitation talks)
>
> **[SARS](/home/s/sars)** (severe acute respiratory syndrome)
>
> **WHO** (World Health Organization)


**Always make sure the longer form still applies. UNICEF** is well enough known to be used on first reference. But if spelled out it should be identified by its new name (**United Nations Children's Fund**) not by its old one (UN International Children's Emergency Fund).

In some cases, letters are added or dropped in the abbreviation — such as one of the Cs in **_ACTRA_**, which actually stands for the Alliance of Canadian Cinema, Television and Radio Artists. When uncertain, always check the noun before spelling it out.

**Many acronyms that are part of everyday language are no longer capitalized. The dictionary is a good guide** in these cases. (For instance, **laser** is short for "light amplification by stimulated emission of radiation," **radar** stands for "radio detection and ranging," and **scuba** represents "self-contained underwater breathing apparatus.")

**Although it's common to put an article (the) in front of many abbreviations** that represent organizations (_the UN_ or _the RCMP_), **we often drop this convention with well-known acronyms.** We do not say or write "the **NASA**" or "the **OPEC**" or "the NATO" or "the UNICEF." In stories about the World Health Organization, therefore, it's usually not necessary to type "the [**WHO**](/home/u/united-nations#WHO)," unless doing so makes a sentence clearer (e.g., underscores that WHO is an abbreviation rather than the pronoun "who" in a broadcast script).

For more on clipped forms in general, including pitfalls to avoid, see [abbreviations](/home/a/abbreviations).

### act

**Act (legislation)**

**Capitalize the specific name of legislation** (often referred to in law as a statute's official "short title"):

> the British North America Act
>
> the Heritage Lighthouse Protection Act
>
> the Income Tax Act
>
> the Privacy Act
>
> the Public Servants Disclosure Protection Act
>
> the Youth Criminal Justice Act

**Use regular type** rather than [italics](/handy-links/punctuation/italics).

**The above applies whether the legislation is merely proposed** (i.e., a bill) **or actually passed and proclaimed as law.** For instance, the **Price Transparency Act** was a bill tabled by the federal government in 2014 that outlined various amendments to the **Competition Act**.

When citing official titles, watch for hyphenated compounds that may have only one capital letter (e.g., Canada's 2001 **Anti-terrorism Act** and the 1997 **Manganese-based Fuel Additives Act**).

**Generally use lowercase wording for generic descriptions or references** to laws (e.g., _the act to protect endangered species_ versus the **Species at Risk Act**), as well as **plural constructions** (e.g., _various human rights acts across the country_) **and generic second references** (e.g., _critics of the act held a demonstration on Parliament Hill_). **However, lean toward capitalized names of what are arguably generic descriptions if the wording is, essentially, an abridged version of the formal title** (e.g., the **Alberta Sovereignty Act** when referring to the 2022 **Alberta Sovereignty Within a United Canada Act**), even in second reference (**the Sovereignty Act**). The primary test should be whether a different generic summary could be chosen that doesn't lift verbatim wording from the formal title. Since some people might easily think of a "sovereignty act" involving formal secession, while others might dispute the term "sovereignty" accurately encapsulating the legislation's intent, it's important to flag the description as the government's. Another example is Ontario's 2022 **Strong Mayors, Building Homes Act**, which could be neutrally described as an act to give mayors special powers or expanded powers. The provincial government's choice of the word "strong" in this case arguably conveys an element of PR spin and, so, might become editorially problematic if left lowercase.


**Official titles optional; clarity is key**
CBC News began capitalizing the titles of proposed legislation in late 2014 to help make our journalism clearer. Some news organizations, including Canadian Press, recommend keeping the names lowercase until the bills actually become law. But this can lead to undesirable confusion, especially when a bill's title includes wording that isn't neutral (e.g., Bill C-42 was called the **Common Sense Firearms Licensing Act**).

TIP: **It's sometimes better to use general, lowercase descriptions of legislation rather than formal titles**, especially when the latter are rambling, ambiguous, etc. **Options include putting quotations marks around certain text** (e.g., _what the government has dubbed its "common sense" firearms bill_) to using words that highlight the legislation's goals (e.g., referring to the **Price Transparency Act** as, say, the _Competition Bureau bill_, since the federal government said it was trying to give the Competition Bureau more powers to investigate certain cross-border price gaps between Canada and the U.S.).


**Bill C-42, the bill**
**Always capitalize the first letter of generic nouns** (e.g., act, article, bill) **that are followed by figures denoting a place in a numbered series** (Act 1, Article 22, Bill C-33), whether the legislation is merely proposed or actually passed.

> **Bill C-68** (numbered series) is considered the strictest **gun control legislation** (general reference) in Canadian history. When passed in 1995, it created the **Firearms Act** (name of proclaimed legislation).


For related guidelines on using Act (e.g., Act 3) versus act (the third act), see [series](/home/n/numbers#series) in the overview on numbers.

See also [Constitution versus constitution](/home/c/constitution)
See [capitalization](/home/c/capitalization)

**List of laws**
For the proper names of all federal legislation in Canada, see the [statute database](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Flaws-lois.justice.gc.ca%2Feng%2Findex.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3dT-4W8tppU0UVHAe0IzF5) on the Justice Department's website.

### acting versus interim

**Acting versus interim**

There's a subtle but useful distinction worth preserving:

The word **acting generally implies something sudden and very temporary**. For example, if a committee's chair is ill or away and someone fills in, this person becomes the acting chair. Acting titles are normally kept lowercase (e.g., _acting Edmonton police chief Dave Korol_).

The word **interim generally refers to a comparatively longer appointment**, usually specified. For example, a political party picks an interim leader for six months, until a convention is held to choose someone permanent. Interim titles follow the same capitalization style of permanent titles (e.g., _interim Premier Dave Hancock, interim Liberal Leader Bill Graham_).

Generally prefer the official title used by the person (e.g., when federal Auditor General Sheila Fraser retired at the end of May 2011, her former deputy became _interim Auditor General John Wiersema_, according to the prime minister's news release and the AG's website).

After being used once in a given story (normally in first reference), it's often unnecessary to repeat the qualifier "acting" or "interim."

**In rare cases, a title like "acting" or "interim" can be controversial** (e.g., if there's political unrest in a country, and someone claims to be the acting or interim leader pending a new election). **To keep stories accurate and impartial, always make it clear when someone has given themselves a title that's disputed by others in power** (e.g., a country with duelling presidential claims). **This often means adding a modifier like "self-declared" in first reference in the body of a story, as well as in headlines and TV supers:**


> _Venezuela's self-declared interim President Juan Guaido_


After that, a qualifying modifier like "self-declared" can usually be dropped.

NOTE: **Capitalization conventions are different in television, which means "interim" would commonly be spelled with an uppercase "I"** when part of a title **in a TV super:**


> _Self-Declared Interim President Juan Guaido_ — (TV super)


(See **[TV text](/home/t/tv_text)** for details, as well as **[titles](/home/t/titles)** for related guidelines.)

Generally **avoid adding quotation marks to "acting" or "interim" in titles**, which can be easily misread as "[so-called](/home/s/so-called)" rather than self-declared.


### active voice

**Active versus passive voice**

**It’s a myth that the active voice** (subject-verb-object) **is always better than the passive.** True, it’s often more direct and energetic. But sometimes it’s not as practical or as effective.


**ACTIVE (preferred)**

> **active:** _Nasser read the book._
>
>     subject (Nasser) – verb (read) – object (the book)

> **passive:** _The book was read by Nasser._


**In the above case, the active voice is clearly preferred.** It has fewer words and more punch.


**PASSIVE (preferred)**

> **passive:** _Wednesday’s 6/49 numbers will be drawn 30 minutes late._
>
> **active:** _Lottery officials will draw Wednesday’s 6/49 numbers 30 minutes late._


**Here, the passive voice is preferred.** The sentence emphasizes what matters (6/49 numbers) rather than the people who will be drawing them. In fact, the lottery officials are not even mentioned in the passive construction because their involvement is sufficiently implied.


**ACTIVE often best**
**In a lot of journalism, the active voice is frequently better:**


> _She smashed the pumpkin._ (**Active; often preferred**)
>
> _The pumpkin was smashed by her._ (Passive)
>
> _He stole the money._ (Active; often preferred)
>
> _The money was stolen by him._ (Passive)


**But there are exceptions.** Bill Walsh of the Washington Post uses the passive voice to debunk the myth that the active construction is always superior:

_The active voice is overrated._ (Brief, clear and **passive**)
_People overrate the active voice._ (Active, but buries the key words)


**PASSIVE has strengths**
**Don’t hesitate to embrace the passive voice for a good reason, such as:**

-   **When you want to place emphasis elsewhere.**

> > **Focus on baseball umpire**
>
> > _The umpire was jeered._ (**Passive**)
>
> > _The crowd jeered the umpire._ (Active)
>
> > **Focus on laid-off workers**
>
> > _Another 500 autoworkers will be laid off in January._ (**Passive**)
>
> > _The company will lay off another 500 autoworkers in January._ (Active)

-   **When the subject is unknown.**

> > _The documents were stolen._ (Passive)
>
> > _One or more people stole the documents._ (Active but without meaningful extra detail)

-   **When it’s better not to specify the subject because of legal or editorial concerns.**

> > _Critical mistakes were made._ (Passive)
>
> > _Anderson made critical mistakes._ (Active but potentially defamatory)

### addiction

**Addiction, drug addiction, substance use, etc.**

**Drug and alcohol addiction are considered TREATABLE DISEASES. Avoid framing them in other ways** (e.g., it's inaccurate to characterize drug addiction as a lack of will power or as a moral lapse). Addiction is influenced by a variety of factors, including people's biology and environment, according to experts.

**"Addiction" is a good way to describe compulsive drug and/or alcohol use** because it's neutral, common and clear. The term **"addiction" is sometimes used in wider or non-clinical ways** (e.g., "porn addiction," "shopping addiction"). While it's OK to describe these as potentially harmful compulsive behaviours, avoid calling them "diseases." Substance addiction, by contrast, is defined as a "complex brain disease" by the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM), which is used by psychiatrists in many countries around the world, including Canada and the U.S. "Gambling addiction" is separately defined by the DSM as a pathological disorder.



[Miscellaneous](/home/a/addiction#miscellaneous) ('overdose' is OK, but avoid 'former' addiction and 'getting clean')


**Avoid 'drug abuse' and 'drug abuser'**
**Prefer "use" over "abuse"** in the context of addiction (e.g., "habitual drug use" rather than "drug abuse") outside of occasional proper nouns (e.g., the U.S. National Institute on Drug Abuse). Compounds like **"drug abuse" and "substance abuse" are increasingly viewed as outmoded because they can stigmatize people who have an underlying medical condition**. Although the noun "abuse" is relatively common in English, the accompanying modifiers often refer to victims (e.g., child abuse, elder abuse, animal abuse). Such compounds, in turn, are associated with criminal and anti-social behaviour. **Do not label people, themselves, substance "abusers."** Instead, stick with language that's non-judgmental (e.g., opioid users, people with a drug addiction). And **do not confuse "misuse" and "abuse."** Substance **"misuse" conventionally means taking painkillers and other prescription drugs too often or in excessive dosages**. Misuse can contribute to addiction, but it's not a synonym for addiction.


**Emphasize people over disorders, behaviour**
**Prefer what's sometimes called "person-first" phrasing** whenever practical. This means emphasizing individuals over specific conditions, diseases, disorders, etc. (e.g., **favour "people with addiction" over "addicts"**). For details and related examples about person-first writing, see our [disabilities overview.](/home/d/disability-language#practicalapplication)

There's **usually no need to adopt clinical jargon verbatim** (e.g., "substance use disorder") outside of directly transcribed quotes. **Steer clear of roundabout expressions** (e.g., "a person who uses drugs problematically" is fuzzy and verbose).

**Be aware that some people object to agent nouns** (e.g., user, drinker, gambler) **and their equivalents on the grounds that they're stigmatizing**. Critics say such constructions unfairly define individuals' identities by specific activity tied to addiction, habitual substance use and various compulsive disorders. **Always take into account known preferences of those we're reporting on, but don't automatically adopt indirect or awkward phrasing** (e.g., "people with a heroin-use disorder" is a very roundabout way of saying "heroin users"). English is full of agent nouns and attributive nouns (a computer user, an end user, a username, a user manual) that are entirely neutral. Put another way, the negative part of a compound like "drug user" is the modifier "drug" rather than the noun "user."


**Addiction versus dependence**
The words **"addiction" and "dependence" are often used interchangeably** in general news reporting. **This can sometimes cause confusion**, since health-care professionals may define the words differently in specific contexts. It's a good idea to **clarify whenever appropriate**. For example, **"dependence" is often used more narrowly to describe measurable physical factors** (e.g., a body's tolerance to a given substance after repeated use, a body's anguished reaction to sudden withdrawal, such as shaking, sweating, nausea and diarrhea). So while gambling is referred to as a compulsive disorder, it doesn't have the same physical dependence associated with, say, alcohol or opioid use. And **while a baby may be born with a chemical dependency** based on the drug use of her mother, **reporting that the infant has a "drug addiction" would almost certainly not match the child's clinical diagnosis.**


**Miscellaneous ('overdose' OK, but avoid 'former' addiction, 'getting clean')**
**Avoid inaccurate modifiers like "former" that suggest cures** (e.g., "former addiction" or "former alcoholic"). Scientific research shows that addiction changes people's brains in ways that are difficult if not impossible to reverse. **Instead, use words like "recovering"** that emphasize treatment and abstinence (e.g., "recovering alcoholic").

**Be fair and respectful, but don't rush to adopt dense or bureaucratic wording that muddies or weakens a story**. It's **OK to use entrenched, conversational shorthand for drug names** ("meth" instead of methamphetamine), **but avoid descriptive slang that's pejorative** (e.g., crackheads, junkies, stoners). **This includes phrases like "getting clean,"** which wrongly link a disease (addiction) to hygiene, contamination, etc. Pick fact-based alternatives instead (e.g., "stop using" and "abstain").

The word **overdose** is a **common, clear and acceptable way to describe a dangerous or lethal amount of one or more drugs** (e.g., died of an overdose). Be aware that some people object to the term because they say it unfairly blames those with substance addiction (i.e., that individuals hurt themselves by miscalculating a safe dose ). For this reason, they recommend alternatives such as "drug toxicity" and "drug poisoning" — along the lines of "alcohol poisoning." However, there's no strong lexicographical evidence that the word "overdose" is considered deprecatory or vilifying. Furthermore, while "alcohol poisoning" is entrenched and widely understood (too much alcohol in one's body at one time), "drug poisoning" doesn't normally convey the same meaning. Instead, the latter is conventionally associated with tainted materials or with intentionally administered toxins (e.g., a chemical-laced drink). Overdose continues to be used widely and neutrally by medical authorities, governments, researchers and others in public policy debates over addiction, including by Health Canada in its updates about the country's "opioid overdose crisis."

See also [health reporting](/home/h/health_reporting) (general principles)
See also [disease, disorder, illness, etc.
](/home/d/disease_illness)

### addresses

**Addresses**

Just because it’s on a street sign doesn’t mean it’s our style. Otherwise, we’d be constantly adjusting how we handle abbreviations, ordinal numbers, etc., depending on the preferences of individual municipalities.

**Capitalize terms like street, road, etc., when they're part of names or general locations, except in plural constructions:**

_Wellington Street
Portage Avenue
Sparks Street businesses
Albert and Broad streets
the Chatterley Apartments_

**Treat ordinal numbers of streets, roads, etc., as part of the official name.** Spell out "_first_" through "_ninth_," no matter what system is used on local signs.

_First Street (**not** 1st Street)
11th Street (**not** Eleventh Street)
110th Avenue
_**Points of the compass (north, east, etc.) generally become a single letter followed by a period** (_N., E., etc._), no matter what system is used on local signs. Quadrant combinations (_northeast_) are represented by two letters and two periods (_N.E._). The only exceptions are compass points that are part of the official name (i.e., which appear before nouns such as street, road or lane, such as _West Hastings_):

_Queen Street W.
110th Avenue S.E.
South Service Road_

**Almost always abbreviate generic terms like avenue, road, apartment, etc., when publishing addresses that include specific locations (numbers)** along the streets, in the buildings, etc. Do not add hyphens (_121A_ rather than _121-A_). Use commas, however, to set off suites, apartments, etc.

_Bloor Street
Bloor Street W.
273 Bloor St. W.
599B Yonge St.
764 First St.
5925 110th Ave. S.E.
4500 South Service Rd.
Apt. 305, Fitzgerald Terrace
The body was found in Apt. 708.
He was mugged a block from his apartment._

**But spell out full addresses in rare cases established by convention** (e.g., in the official residence of the prime minister):
_24 Sussex Drive
10 Downing Street
221B Baker Street_ (fictional address of Sherlock Holmes)

**If the city is not obvious from the context of the story, it can be added after a comma:**

_101 West Hastings St., Vancouver, ...
205 Wellington St. W., Toronto, ..._

See [cities, provinces and countries](/home/a/abbreviations#Provinces) for more details on treating secondary information about a geographical location as a subordinate fragment framed by a set of commas.

**Commas are not needed to indicate thousands in addresses** or other sets of figures used solely for identification, such as serial numbers:

_1582 Inukshuk Ave.
The search began on the 3400 block of Missinaba Street._

See also [abbreviations](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/a/abbreviations/#addresses "Abbreviations")
See also [capitalization](/home/c/capitalization)
See also [numbers](/home/n/numbers)

### adoption

**Adoption**

The fact that a person is adopted should be mentioned only when relevant. The same is true when we refer to adults who either adopt children or place children into an adoption program. Such details can be highly personal.

Generally **avoid the increasingly archaic expression "given up for adoption,"** unless quoting someone directly. Otherwise, **prefer neutral terms like "placed into adoption"** or **"put up for adoption."** While "given up" can convey emotional hardship and feelings of loss associated with adoption placement, the expression is now perceived as judgmental and offensive (i.e., to mean "giving up on a child") by segments of our audience.

**Be aware that some people are offended by various other language tied to adoption.** It's OK to **take into account specific preferences** of those we interview, **but avoid adopting language that is ambiguous, euphemistic or otherwise problematic.**

For instance, **generally prefer either "birth" or "biological"** when referring to the genetic parents of adopted children (e.g., **"birth mother**" and "**biological father**"). **Alternatives tend to be either less clear or less neutral** (e.g., "natural" can suggest the adopted parents are unnatural, "real" can suggest the adopted parents are artificial, and "first" can telegraph unintended qualitative judgment instead of simple chronology). A modifier like "birth," by contrast, is fact-based and instantly understood.

**In rare cases, "birth" and "biological" may not work as synonyms.** For example, a surrogate mother may give birth to a child (i.e., be the "birth mother") even though another woman's fertilized eggs are used. In those cases, prefer "**surrogate mother**" to make the details clearer.


### adviser

**Adviser versus advisor**

In English, "-er" and "-or" endings are both used to describe objects or people performing specific functions (e.g., barber, calculator, computer, translator). Generally, there is only one standard spelling. Sometimes, however, "-er" and "-or" endings are both used. **The words adviser and advisor are an example of two common, competing spellings.**

**For simplicity, we generally use adviser** in our journalism because it's entrenched. **This is also the style at most major Western news organizations**, including CP, AP, Reuters, the Globe and Mail, the New York Times and the BBC:

> a close **adviser**
>
> a campaign **adviser**
>
> a national security **adviser**

The **most common exception is in business reporting**, where **a distinction is now often made between regulated and unregulated individuals** offering financial/investment advice.

> a **financial** or investment **adviser** (_regulated title in Canada; carries specific fiduciary responsibilities_) 
>
> a **financial** or investment **advisor** (_unregulated title, conventionally used by sales or marketing staff, including brokers_) 

**
We should reflect this industry practice whenever the detail is relevant.** Since many in our audience will probably not know the difference between the financial sector's use of these spellings, **a parenthetical explanation may be required to keep a given story clear**.  Specifically: **In Canadian banking, "advisor" is considered an unregulated title that refers to an individual who does not have the same legal obligations that a regulated "adviser" has when offering investment advice to a client.** NOTE: Since spellings are challenging to convey in broadcast journalism outside of TV supers and graphics, modifiers such as "regulated" or "specially designated" before the term "adviser" can help make scripts written for the ear more meaningful. **

Capitalized proper nouns** should retain their original spellings (e.g., the **Financial Advisors Association of Canada**, the **Financial Planners and Financial Advisers Act**). 



**Otherwise, keep 'adviser' as the default**

A few general, related points about spelling to keep in mind: 

1\. The Oxford English dictionary says **adviser and advisor have both been used for centuries**, although "adviser" appears to be the older form. **Other examples of competing spellings: We use converter, convener and conveyor** (rather than "convertor," "convenor" and "conveyer"). The **Canadian Oxford Dictionary lists "adviser" as the primary spelling**, with "-or" classified as a variant, and **the companion Oxford Canadian Spelling Dictionary specifically states: "_Use adviser_."**

2\. **There's no overriding logic behind English spelling**. Some people insist that "advisory" must automatically spawn "advisor," but there are many examples of vowels being added or altered as words change forms — from educate and investigate (versus educator and investigator) to honorary (versus honouree) and voluntary (versus volunteer). Furthermore, since **an adviser's job is to advise**, the "-er' suffix is not the least bit jarring.

3\. **When words are spelled in more than one way, we normally pick one version and stick with it for consistency** (e.g., honour, jewelry, plow, and raccoon rather than "honor" or "jewellery" or "plough" or "racoon," even though the latter are listed as acceptable alternatives in various dictionaries). **The main exceptions are proper nouns** (e.g., the generic Canadian spelling "centre" becomes uppercase "Center" in U.S. names such as Rockefeller Center or Kennedy Center) **and homonyms** (e.g., the generic Canadian spellings "cheque" and "check" are distinct words that sound the same). See our **[spelling overview](/home/s/spelling)** for details and more examples.

4\. **Compounds such as "national security adviser" are treated as generic job descriptions** rather than as true proper nouns in our journalism — along the lines of [defence](/home/d/defence-labour-and-centre) secretaries instead of "defense" secretaries, even when we're reporting on Washington, and [anesthesiologists](/home/a/anesthesiologist-versus-anesthetist) instead of "anaesthesiologists," even when we're referring to doctors in countries that retain ligatured vowels ("ae") in their titles. That's why AP, the New York Times and others commonly refer to the U.S. national security "adviser" instead of "advisor," even though the White House prefers the "or" spelling in its news releases.

### affect versus effect

**Affect versus effect**

These two words are often mixed up. The correct meanings are:

**affect** (_verb_: **to influence**)

**effect** (_noun_: **a result**; _verb_: **to bring about**)

Sleep patterns **affect** (_influence_) concentration.
Poor concentration is one **effect** (_result_) of no sleep.
By concentrating, we can **effect** (_bring about_) change.
Sleeping drugs can produce side **effects** (_results_).
It's possible they will **affect** (_influence_) you in unexpected ways.
The movie’s sound **effects** (_results or impressions_) were good.

The word affect is also sometimes used as a verb to mean to pretend or to adopt pompous affectation:

He **affected** (_pretended_) indifference.
The snob had **affected** (_pompously contrived_) speech.

**If you’re not sure whether to write _affect_ or _effect_, try inserting the text from the brackets above (_influence, result_ or _bring about_). If you're still uncertain, do NOT guess. Find out, or choose a different word.**

### Award versus award

**African swine fever**

While we generally avoid using geographic descriptors in virus or disease names, in this case there is no equivalent alternative for now. 

African swine fever is both the scientific and colloquial name for the disease – the [Canadian Food Inspection Agency](https://inspection.canada.ca/animal-health/terrestrial-animals/diseases/reportable/african-swine-fever/eng/1306983245302/1306983373952), [World Organization for Animal Health](https://www.woah.org/en/disease/african-swine-fever/), [United States Food and Drug Administration](https://www.fda.gov/animal-veterinary/safety-health/african-swine-fever) and [Canadian Pork Council](https://www.cpc-ccp.com/african-swine-fever) all use African swine fever and present no synonyms. 

The names of diseases and viruses can evolve - for example, [mpox was previously known by another name](/updates/2022/2022-11-28/) and was changed to avoid continued stigmatization. So we will continue to monitor and update as appropriate.

Note that African swine fever, the disease, is caused by African swine fever virus.

### after versus after- **After versus after-**

**Do not use a hyphen after this prefix when creating most nouns:**

_aftereffect, aftermath, afterthought, afternoon, aftershave, aftertaste, etc._
**
Use a hyphen when forming compound modifiers:**

_after-dinner drink
_
See also [hyphens](/handy-links/punctuation/hyphens)

### agreement

**Agreement versus agreement**

**Capitalize the generic word "agreement" only if it's part of an official name:**

_North American Free Trade Agreement_ (NAFTA)

_General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade_ (GATT)

_Canada-U.S.-Mexico Agreement ([CUSMA](/home/c/cusma))
_
the free trade _agreement_

a U.S.-Mexico _agreement_ on border security


See general rules on [capitalization](/home/c/capitalization)

### AIDS

**AIDS**

All uppercase, no periods. Spelled out in lowercase: **acquired immune deficiency syndrome**. (See [acronyms](/home/a/acronyms) for more details on punctuation and capitalization of similar abbreviations.)

AIDS is caused by a virus that attacks the body's immune system. It was labelled a syndrome in the early 1980s before **HIV** (the **human immunodeficiency virus**) was identified. It can be accurately called a disease in second reference, instead of the more lofty "syndrome."

In stories, never imply that it's spread only by sexual contact or that only one group (e.g., gay people) is at risk. Those who have symptoms should be called "people with AIDS." Avoid expressions like "victims of" or people who "suffer from" AIDS.

Those who have HIV but who do not show any signs of illness can be accurately called "HIV-positive" or "carriers" of the disease (a term used by the medical community). "AIDS patients" are actively receiving treatment.

The HIV/AIDS drug **AZT** used to be called **azidothymidine**. It's now more commonly known as **zidovudine**, which is simply an arbitrary alteration of the original chemical name.

See also [SARS](/home/s/sars)

### aircraft is and aircraft are

**Aircraft is and aircraft are**

The word **aircraft is both plural and singular:** _“The aircraft ran into trouble over Manitoba” and “The Department of Defence wants to buy more aircraft.”_


The possessive form is fine when you’re referring to a single plane or model. (_“Investigators think that a crack in the aircraft’s left wing caused the crash.”_)

But since the only correct plural possessive is also **aircraft’s** (as in **children’s**), it’s better to avoid this construction by rewording the sentence. (For instance, “the **planes’** wiring” instead of “the aircraft’s wiring.”) See also: [plurals](/home/p/plurals) (an overview) and [possessive apostrophe](/handy-links/punctuation/possessive-apostrophe)

See also [aircraft names](/home/a/aircraft-names)
See also [cockpit versus flight deck](/home/c/cockpit-versus-flight-deck)

### Aircraft names

**Aircraft names**

Use figures instead of spelled-out numbers for airplanes (**Dash 8**).

Normally add a hyphen when switching from letters to numbers (**B-52, DC-8**) but not after numbers (a **747B** or an **F-4 Phantom 2 fighter**). The exception is when the initial letters are merely a series or model designation that's part of the aircraft's name rather than a true abbreviation, such as the A in **Airbus A340** (no hyphen) or the CS in Bombardier's **CS300** (no hyphen).

In most cases, the type of aircraft is identified by an actual abbreviation or initialism (e.g., **B** for bomber, **DC** for "Douglas commercial" plane, **LF** for "Lockheed fighter"). These **letters are routinely capitalized, unless the letters themselves are not actually initials** (e.g., **Yak-42** instead of "YAK-42" because "**Yak**" is short for Yakovlev, a passenger jet built by the Soviet Union in the 1970s).

The word "series" is capitalized only when treated as a proper noun equivalent in aircraft names, such as in the Bombardier **C Series** jets. For more than a decade, the company referred to these planes as its "CSeries." We and many other news organizations, including CP, treated this designation as a name and, so, adopted the fused format. But Bombardier eventually switched to "C Series" (space, no hyphen). This became our style in the fall of 2017. There's [no need for a hyphen in the compound](/handy-links/punctuation/hyphens#A-list) because of the capital letters.

Examples of aircraft names:

**Airbus A320** (no hyphen; A is part of a series name, not an abbreviation)

**Boeing 747**

**Boeing 737 Max 8** (Since 'Max' is not a true initialism only the M is capitalized)

**B-52

C-5A

CF-18** (the Canadian version of the U.S. F-18 fighter jet)

**CS100** (no hyphen; CS is part of a series name, not an abbreviation)

**DC-8

L-1011

LF-117

MD-80

TU-144

****Generally avoid longer, official designations of aircraft sometimes preferred by the military**, especially when shortened versions have become entrenched. For instance, the C-17 transport plane and the CF-18 fighter jet are known within the Canadian Forces as the CC-177 and the CF-188.

Be sure to use the correct abbreviation. Some people wrongly write MIG-25 instead of **MiG-25**, for example. The _M_ and the _G_ stand for the designers (Mikoyan and Gurevich). But the "i" represents "and" in Russian, so it doesn't need to be capitalized.

Plurals of terms ending with numbers or capital letters are formed by adding an "s" (**DC-10s** and **747Bs**). Although some news organizations, including The Associated Press, prefer to add apostrophes after capital letters in these cases (_747B's_), CBC News, The Canadian Press and others reserve this punctuation for possessive constructions (the **747B's cockpit**). See also: [possessive apostrophes](/handy-links/punctuation/possessive-apostrophe) and [aircraft](/home/a/aircraft-is-and-aircraft-are) (plural and singular). For general guidelines, see [abbreviations](/home/a/abbreviations).

### Airline versus Air Line

**Airline versus Air Line**

**The generic** (lowercase) **term _airline_ is always one word.**

**The capitalized version is normally one word, but some companies and organizations use a divided form in their names**. Since these are proper nouns, we follow their preferences. For instance:

_American Airlines
Delta Air Lines
Continental Air Lines
the Canadian Air Line Pilots Association_ (not _Pilots'_) See [possessive apostrophe](/handy-links/punctuation/possessive-apostrophe)


See also [capitalization](/home/c/capitalization)

### airport

**Airport versus airport**

Treat _airport_, _airfield_, etc., as generic (lowercase) words unless they're part of a full, proper noun:


> **Calgary International Airport**
> the Calgary **airport**
> **Kandahar Airfield**
> the Kandahar **airport**
> **Ottawa Macdonald-Cartier International Airport**
> the Ottawa **airport
> ****Lester Pearson International Airport
> **the **Pearson International Airport
> **the Toronto international **airport
> ****Pearson** airport
> **Pearson
> **the **Pierre Elliott Trudeau International Airport
> ****Trudeau International Airport
> **the Montreal international **airport
> ****Trudeau** airport


If a name officially changes, accuracy demands that we abandon the old noun. But always keep our audience's best interests in mind. In 2009, for instance, the "Toronto City Centre Airport" officially became the **Billy Bishop Toronto City Airport**. Since the latter is long and not instantly recognized, however, it's OK to call it the **Toronto City Airport** (uppercase "A" because it's a clipped form of the new proper noun), the Toronto Island airport (lowercase "a" because it's a descriptive name) or **Toronto's downtown island airport**.

**YVR, YEG, YUL**
**Avoid three-letter airport codes** (e.g., YVR, YEG, YYZ, YUL) **unless they;re clearly defined** in a given story:


> YVR (Vancouver airport)
> YEG (Edmonton airport)
> YYZ (Pearson airport)
> YUL (Trudeau airport)


Exceptions are codes that are obvious because they're true initialisms (JFK).

The international Air Transport Association (IATA) assigns unique codes to hundreds of airports around the world. **This shorthand is sometimes plastered all over signs at a given site, making the letters well known to local residents and frequent flyers. But that does not mean they're familiar to most of our audience.** So when using such codes (e.g., LAX for Los Angeles), be sure the meaning is clear. **Spelling out once in brackets is the usually the simplest way to add the detail.**

See also [capitalization](/home/c/capitalization) and [abbreviations](/home/a/abbreviations) for related guidelines.

### allege

**Allege, alleged, allegedly**

**Words such as “allege” and “alleged” and “allegedly” must be used with caution.** In general reporting, **the terms imply an allegation of wrongdoing or impropriety.** They’re not mere synonyms for assert, declare, state, etc.

Always **distinguish between generic references to crimes or other misconduct and specific, unproven references**. For instance, it's accurate to talk about **security concerns over foreign interference in Canadian elections**, just as it's accurate to refer to experts worrying that a given policy might lead to a rise in violent crime rather than to a rise in "alleged" violent crime. However, when narrowly focusing on identifiable groups or people, it's crucial to make clear what's been proven and what's merely alleged (e.g., "**China's alleged interference in Canada's last federal election**").


**NOTE:** The rest of this entry provides only general guidance based on Journalism and the Law workshops designed for CBC staff over the decades. If you have any legal questions, including doubts about the wording of a specific story, always consult a CBC lawyer before publishing or broadcasting.

## **CRIME AND COURT REPORTING**

**Words such as “alleged” can be a practical way to avoid presuming guilt when reporting on formal but unproven charges.**


> FINE: _The pedestrian died Tuesday night after he was hit by a vehicle **allegedly** driven by an impaired, off-duty police officer._
> ("Allegedly" OK here because the constable has already been charged with impaired driving causing death.)
>
> FINE: _She is **alleged** to have unlawfully injected Botox and other filler substances into clients for several years._
> ("Alleged" OK because the story attributes the accusation to medical authorities seeking a court injunction.)


**However**, words such as “alleged” are **not historically considered a special shield against defamation.** This means that **merely inserting** a qualifying term like **“alleged” into a sentence is NOT a guarantee a story is legally sound.**


> WRONG: _The former actor is an **alleged** alcoholic and wife beater._
> ("Alleged" is meaningless in this context. There's no case before the courts, and the libellous rumours are neither provable as true nor otherwise defensible.)
>
> FINE: _Police are investigating the former actor. He is **alleged** to have abused his ex-wife._
> ("Alleged" OK because authorities have confirmed they're conducting a specific criminal probe.)

## **CIVIL CASES**

**Use “alleged” for formal but unproven** — and even defamatory — **claims from official court documents.** But be sure to **keep lawsuit coverage fair and balanced.** For instance, it’s important to point out that all accusations being made by one side or the other (e.g., in a statement of claim) have not been proven.

See also [suspect, accused](/home/s/suspect_accused) as well as [Canadian court terms](/home/c/canadian-court-terms)

### Americanisms

**Avoid inapt Americanisms**

We've been implored to "avoid Americanisms" since we began broadcasting in the 1930s. It's a recurring theme in audience feedback and internal memos. It's also overly simplistic. **Canadian English is a blend of British and American word choice, pronunciation and spelling.** This means that **many so-called "Americanisms" are, in fact, "North Americanisms" — used widely and without complaint in Canada.**

CBC News style, therefore, is narrower: **Avoid inapt Americanisms** — i.e., language common in the United States but that's either inappropriate or generally not recommended in Canadian journalism for various reasons. **Deciding what's unsuitable is sometimes subjective. Furthermore,** since English is organic, **various boundary lines can shift** (e.g., automated tellers are now referred to as both [ABMs and ATMs](/home/a#ABM), even though the latter was initially considered "American" rather than Canadian).

This entry outlines **four areas requiring care:**

[1\. Missing detail](/home/a/americanisms#US) (e.g., add 'U.S.' for accuracy, clarity)
[2\. Spelling](/home/a/americanisms#spelling) (e.g., -our, -re, -lling)
[3\. Pronunciation](/home/a/americanisms#pronunciation) (e.g., Z = ZED not ZEE, except in 'DMZ')
[4\. Word choice](/home/a/americanisms#diction) (e.g., appeal court not appeals court, half-mast, not half-staff, impaired driving not DUI)

**1\. Missing detail** (e.g., add 'U.S.' for accuracy, clarity)
Some "Americanisms" are rooted in geographical perspective, cultural identity, etc., which influence certain turns of phrase. **Since a lot of wire copy comes from the United States, we need to be vigilant to keep our writing, and perspective, Canadian.**

This challenge has been with us from the beginning. In 1946, for instance, the head of CBC News sent an internal memo reminding staff to avoid calling Washington "the nation's capital":


> _"Ottawa is 'the nation's capital' as far as this country is concerned, not Washington.
> To hear Washington referred to in this way in a CBC News bulletin is extremely irritating
> to most listeners and quite properly so."_

> > — Dan McArthur, Chief Editor, CBC News, March 6, 1946


Subtler variations of this problem persist. **We're inundated by so many American proper nouns** (e.g., names of government agencies, titles of politicians) **we must guard against mischaracterizing something or someone as Canadian.** This includes implication by omission. For example, it's important to identify elected officials in Washington as foreign. **Adding U.S. to a title or name in first reference is often sufficient**:


> U.S. President Donald Trump
> U.S. Department of Commerce


**Words like "federal" and "national" are especially troublesome** because they can lead to Canadian proper nouns with similar names being corrupted (e.g., calling the **Transportation Safety Board of Canada** the "national" Transportation Safety Board, which sounds virtually identical to the **U.S. National Transportation Safety Board** in a broadcast script).

For details and related guidelines, see [United States, U.S., US](/home/u/united-states)


**2\. Spelling** (e.g., -our, -re, -lling)
**We get letters of complaint about letters of the alphabet** — from polite to snarky, from justified to unfounded. For example:


> "If _the first 'C' in CBC stands for 'Canadian,' you should not use explicitly American spellings.
> 'Hemorrhagic' is American, 'haemorrhagic' is English_."

> > — Don M., Calgary, Aug. 11, 2014


**"Hemorrhagic," however, is the preferred Canadian spelling**, according to the Oxford Canadian Spelling Dictionary, the Canadian Oxford Dictionary, the Guide to Canadian English Usage and other authorities. Indeed, as we explained in our response to the above email, **replacing many old ligatures ("ae" and "oe") with single vowels is a common feature of North American spelling** — e.g., eon, diarrhea, fetus, medieval and estrogen versus "aeon," "diarrhoea," "foetus," "mediaeval" and "oestrogen." **Notable exceptions outlined in our lingering ligature overview include:**


> **amoeba** (not "ameba")
>
> **archaeology** (not "archeology")
>
> **caesarian** (not "cesarean")
>
> **manoeuvre** (not "maneuver")


Hemorrhage is a bloody good example of how Canadian and British orthography sometimes diverge. We prefer **airplane, aluminum, curb, civilization** and **tire** (over aeroplane, aluminium, kerb, civilisation and tyre). But that certainly doesn't make us American. We also tend to go with **centre, colour, defence, labour, labelling** and **travelling** (over center, color, defense, labor, labeling and traveling). When two or more spellings are fairly widespread, CBC News declares a preference to maintain the professional sheen of consistency (e.g., **catalogue, program** and **raccoon** instead of catalog, programme and racoon).

McGill linguistics professor Charles Boberg sums up the realities — and challenges — of Canadian spelling this way:


> "_\[M\]ost linguists agree that **the main characteristic of Canadian spelling is the absence of any consistent
> pattern, with choices between American and British forms varying by word, context, publication,
> genre, region and social group**, thereby reflecting Canada’s transitional position between the two main
> standards of World English. It might be said that tolerance of disagreement about spelling is in any case
> a truer reflection of the modern Canadian character than a rigid adherence to British standards._
>
>
>
> "_As a result, however, **Canadian writers, editors and other language professionals face sometimes
> perplexing choices and uncertainties** that do not burden their British or American colleagues, at least
> not to the same extent_."

> > — [Canadian English](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca%2Fen%2Farticle%2Fcanadian-english&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1XLRwm39bBLElSLtzXMfAU) (2016 essay), Canadian Encyclopedia (online version)


**CBC News navigates this quagmire by following a few rudimentary principles, outlined in our [spelling overview](/home/s/spelling)** (e.g., "centre" unless a unique proper noun, like "Kennedy Center").

**One nagging style point** worth special mention: **Avoid adopting American spellings of government departments** ("Defense" and "Labor") **as well as various U.S. government titles** (Security "Advisor") **since such words are not traditionally treated as proper nouns.** Instead, **write U.S. Defence Department, Labour Day, U.S. National Security Adviser, etc.**, to avoid needlessly bouncing our audience from one set of spellings to another. Do such small tweaks amount to inaccuracy or disrespect? No. It's the same reason that the New York Times, Associated Press and others refer to, say, the "Defense Department" in Ottawa and to "Labor Day" in Canada. In a nutshell, U.S. media unapologetically steer clear of most Canadian spellings — including what amount to generic words like "defence" and "labour" in government nomenclature. See [defence, labour and centre](/home/d/defence-labour-and-centre) for details on relevant in-house style.


**3\. Pronunciation** (e.g., Z = ZED not ZEE, except in 'DMZ')
The most glaring phonological difference between Canadian and American English is probably how we say the last letter of the alphabet. Americans refer to Z as "ZEE," and find our choice of "ZED" peculiar. But as Wayne Grady points out in 1998 book, Chasing the Chinook: On the Trail of Canadian Words and Culture: **"ZED is not a Canadianism; ZEE is an Americanism,"** since ZED is also standard in England, Scotland, Wales, Australia and New Zealand. **Nevertheless, "ZEE" is not always out of bounds in our journalism.** In fact, it's actually recommended in a few cases. **For instance, the U.S.-coined abbreviation "DMZ"** (for "demilitarized zone") is known to English speakers around the world as "DEE-EM-ZEE."

North American pronunciations can vary substantially from region to region, often influenced by local or neighbouring dialects (e.g., Newfoundland English, southern U.S. English). On the whole, however, **there's far more overlap between Canadian and American pronunciations than there are differences**, according to linguists.

**Some English words have more than one acceptable pronunciation in Canada.** They defy efforts to impose a single, national preference. As the late CBC host and former broadcast language adviser, Russ German, once observed: "Usually, the argument boils down to the way we were taught by our parents or primary and elementary school teachers. People become emotionally attached to these pronunciations." Examples are:


> **aunt** (ANT or AWNT)
>
> **either** (EE-ther or EYE-ther)
>
> **schedule** (SKED-jool or SHED-yool)


**Other words, however, are marked by deeply ingrained Canadian pronunciations.** German cited several in an internal memo in 1992, along with the warning: "Please try to avoid the 'Americanization' of these words." **Examples** still relevant today **include three common prefixes:
**

> **anti-** (ANT-ee, not ANT-eye)
>
> **quasi-** (KWAW-see, not KWAWS-eye)
>
> **semi-** (SEM-ee, not SEM-eye)


A mnemonic for these three: "EYE before EE except in the case of C (i.e., Canada)."

Canadian English is alive, of course, which means we need to keep revisiting and revising certain guidelines as required. Among other things, **we've gradually expanded the number of words with more than one acceptable pronunciation** to better reflect modern usage. **Consult the [CBC Pronunciation Database](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2Flng%2Frecherche%2Findex.aspx&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1XFPfiGVRPwO63-NkaNyUm) for specific recommendations.** It includes over 12,000 entries dating back several decades. **For background on the database**, including how preferences are determined, **see [Pronunciation FAQs](/handy-links/pronunciation)**.


**4\. Word choice** (e.g., appeal court not appeals court, half-mast not half-staff, impaired driving not DUI)
**Determining what's "Canadian English" is not always obvious.** For example, some people treat terms like "GST" and "chesterfield" as shibboleths. But the former is also used in New Zealand, where a goods and services tax was actually introduced five years before Canadian consumers started paying, and saying, GST. And while "chesterfield" for sofa is indisputably Canadian, it's also increasingly a relic — as unfamiliar to many young Canadians as, say, the outdated slang "pogy" for certain government payments, like employment insurance and welfare.

Dozens of words now in wide circulation around the world were born in Canada (e.g., **insulin, kerosene and snowmobile**).
