But the fact they caught on abroad makes them **more global English than Canadian.** Furthermore, several terms were originally adopted from various Indigenous languages (e.g., **chipmunk, kayak, toboggan**), adding to the Latin, Greek, French, Italian, German, Asian, Arabic and other **loan words that make up the simmering stew known as international English.**

**Judging what's an unsuitable "Americanism" in an English-speaking country's journalism can be relative and subjective** — relative, because it may vary depending on geography, and subjective, because it's influenced by everything from one's age to one's overall tolerance for variety in speech. **The BBC's 2018 Style Guide, for example, advises its staff to avoid a number of "Americanisms" that, to most Canadians, are perfectly acceptable** "North Americanisms," such as **downtown, shopping mall, trash can** and **morgue** (instead of town centre, shopping centre, dustbin and mortuary).

Furthermore, the same BBC entry about Americanisms includes the following bizarre claim: "We \[British people\] tend not to convert nouns into verbs." That statement is as inaccurate as it is sweeping. Virtually all linguists acknowledge that English is a highly flexible, adaptable language, including the notable convention of turning a lot of nouns into denominal verbs (e.g., to "butter" bread, "chair" a meeting, "coin" a phrase,' "lace" shoes, "milk" a cow, "petition" for change, "pocket" a different kind of change and "post" a letter). Such conversions fall under the broad category of anthimeria — a rhetorical device that's certainly not unique to North American English.

Numerous nouns, however, can be extremely jarring when they're used as verbs (to "gift" the good, to "rubbish" the bad), which is perhaps what the editors of the BBC Style Guide were driving at. They cite "to hospitalize," "to scapegoat" and "to debut" as undesirable Americanisms. Although it's perfectly acceptable to recommend writers and editors avoid certain unorthodox phrasing — including words that make scripts sound awkward and ugly, if not outright foreign — it's misleading to dismiss the general practice of turning nouns into verbs as either (i) wrong or (ii) a North American phenomenon.

**Most people who've lived in Canada even a few years know that there's a strong preference for North American vocabulary over British**. For example, we say **potato chips** instead of "crisps," call the front of a vehicle a **hood** rather than a "bonnet," and use **football** to mean a North American sport that's distinct from "soccer." ([Soccer](/home/s/soccer), for the record, is not an Americanism. It's actually a British word that fell out of favour in the U.K. last century.)

**We also tend to say apartment, diaper, elevator, sweater**, and **truck driver** rather than flat, nappy, lift, jumper and lorry driver. **At the same time, there's often more than one way to express the same point**, and most **Canadians are neither confused nor concerned when people refer to** bathrooms as **washrooms**, garbage disposals as **garburators**, parking garages as **parkades**, sneakers as **runners**, and hotel taverns as **beer parlours**.

Nevertheless, **national identity appears linked to certain expressions**, at least based on the passionate complaints we receive when alternative "Americanisms" are used in our on-air and online content. **Such language is considered "Canadian" in a special way.** Cherished. Protected. **Sometimes it's a matter of accuracy** (e.g., people are charged with "impaired driving" in Canada, not with "driving under the influence"). **But often it's comparatively arbitrary, reflecting deep fondness for the familiar** more than anything else.

For consistency, **CBC News generally recommends sticking with known Canadian preferences** when these are established, **unless there's strong evidence that a "competing" form has become equally common** (e.g., the American term [**AWOL**](/home/m/military-terms-overview#AWOL) has largely replaced the Canadian version, AWL). **For specific guidance, consult the Language Guide's A to Z listings.** Examples:


> [appeal court](/home/c/courts) **(NOT "appeals court"**) for provincial, territorial and federal appellate courts in Canada
>
> [basic military training](/home/m/military-terms-overview#miscellaneous) **(NOT "boot camp"**) for Canadian recruits
>
> [\-designate](/home/p/pm-designate) (**NOT "-elect"**), as in prime minister-designate, premier-designate
>
> [dismissed with disgrace](/home/m/military-terms-overview#miscellaneous) (**NOT "dishonourably discharged"**) for misconduct in the Canadian military
>
> [government](/home/a#administration) (**NOT "administration"**) for majority leadership in federal, provincial legislative bodies
>
> [guard of honour](/home/g/guard-of-honour) (**NOT "honour guard"**) at military ceremonies, funerals in Canada
>
> [half-mast](/home/h/half-mast) (**NOT half-staff**)
>
> [impaired driving](/home/i/impaired_driving) (**NOT DUI**)
>
> [inspect troops, inspect guard](/home/g/guard-of-honour) (**NOT review troops** or guard) in the Commonwealth
>
> _[Last Post](/home/l/last-post)_ (**NOT _Taps_**)
>
> [prisoner's box](/home/c/canadian-court-terms) (**NOT prisoner's dock**) in Canadian court rooms
>
> _[Rouse](/home/m/military-terms-overview#miscellaneous)_ (**NOT _Reveille_**) for morning bugle call in the Commonwealth
>
> [railway](/home/r/railway-versus-railroad) (**NOT railroad**)
>
> [U.S.](/home/u/united-states) (**NOT America**) in most references to country
>
> [witness box](/home/c/canadian-court-terms) (**NOT witness stand**) in Canadian court rooms


**Canadian English, like all English, is ever-changing.** Shifts in preferences are inevitable. As a result, **the CBC Language Guide is regularly updated to reflect current usage**, as well as to provide editorial recommendations tied to core journalistic principles, including accuracy, fairness and impartiality.


— Blair Shewchuk, Standards Editor, CBC News, June 2019



**FURTHER READING:** Anyone interested in Canadian words and phrases should check out the free online edition of the _[Dictionary of Canadianisms on Historical Principles](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.dchp.ca%2Fdchp2%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0i830EtdG6rmpYPh2dfWAl)_ (2017, Second Edition) — an updated version of the original work published during the country's centennial in 1967. _Canadian English: Origin and Structure_ (1975) and _The Languages of Canada_ (1979) by linguistics professor Jack Chambers remain classics. _Speaking Canadian English_ (1970) by Mark Orkin is an interesting, albeit much less scholarly, work worth a read. Canadian lexicographer Katherine Barber — former editor in chief of the Canadian Oxford Dictionary — has written extensively about Canadian English the past few decades, periodically contributing smart, entertaining essays to CBC television and radio broadcasts about everything from [food](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Farchives%2Fentry%2Fcanadian-food-whats-in-a-name&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2Nlb-afbUxD9VJraKyiuSy) to [hockey](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Farchives%2Fentry%2Fthe-language-of-hockey&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3_DTBVvwmWt7m29aFUg9db). Her 2007 book _Only in Canada, You Say_, is a delightful treasury of Canadian words and phrases.

See also [French words](/home/f/french-words-and-accents) for detailed guidelines on incorporating Canada's other most-spoken language into our English journalism

### ampersand

**Ampersand ( & )**

**1\. Use this symbol for "and" when it’s part of an official name** (A&E, A&W). **But check first.** (For instance, the Globe **and** Mail, Wayne **and** Shuster, etc., do not have ampersands.)

**If & is part of the proper name and it falls between two words, leave a space on each side. If it’s between two letters, there is no space:**

> AT&T
>
> Baltimore & Ohio Railroad
>
> _Quirks & Quarks_ (use [italics](/handy-links/punctuation/italics) because it's the name of a radio program)


**2\. If a company appears to be inconsistent in its use of an ampersand, generally prefer the symbol &** over the conjunction "and" **if it helps our audience identify the abbreviation as a proper noun:** 

> MM&A (for Montreal, Maine & Atlantic Railway)


**3\. An ampersand can also be used in second reference** (or headlines) **in some widely used abbreviations,** many listed in the Canadian Oxford:

> **B&B** (bed and breakfast)
>
> **Q&A** (question and answer)
>
> **R&B** (rhythm and blues)
>
> **R&D** (research and development)
>
> **R&R** (rest and relaxation)


Parenthetical definitions are **not** necessary unless an obscure term is used (e.g., in a transcribed broadcast clip): "She joined L&D \[Learning and Development\] in 2004." Use [square brackets](/handy-links/punctuation/brackets) when explanations are added to direct quotes. Otherwise, regular parentheses are OK.

Note: The Canadian Press began using ampersands in colloquial expressions (B&B, R&B, etc.) in the summer of 2003, several years after some other news outlets, including the Globe and Mail. Until then, CP had preferred the word "and" spelled out in these cases.

See also [abbreviations](/home/a/abbreviations)

### anesthesiologist versus anesthetist

**Anesthesiologist versus anesthetist**

CBC News prefers **anesthesiologist**, although anesthetist is fine in a story if it's the person's known preference.

In the broadest sense the words are synonymous, but they can have different meanings depending on where you live. In some countries, for instance, an anesthetist (usually spelled _anaesthetist_ in Britain) must be a doctor. Elsewhere, however, an anesthetist can be anyone trained to administer anesthetics (e.g., a nurse).

**In Canada, anesthetists are doctors. In the 1990s, a majority of them voted to change the name of their national society and call themselves _anesthesiologists_** (originally a U.S. term for physicians who specializes in anesthesiology). They predicted the new label would clear up any confusion over their medical credentials by identifying them as doctors. The word anesthetist is not even listed as an option in the second edition of the Canadian Oxford Dictionary.

**Having a general style preference** (anesthesiologist) **makes our journalism more consistent, but permitting anesthetist when it's a doctor's stated preference balances consistency with respect.** Just because the word anesthetist appears in one broadcast clip or transcribed clip (web quote), however, does not mean the term needs to be used throughout a story. Use your own judgment.

Avoid the extra "a" (_anaes-_) when spelling any of these words (**anesthesia**, **anesthetic**, **anesthesiologist**, etc.). This reflects entrenched Canadian usage in medical schools, hospitals, academic journals and professional organizations, such as the [**Canadian Anesthesiologists’ Society**](https://www.cas.ca/en/home). See [lingering ligatures](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/s/spelling/lingering-ligatures/ "Lingering ligatures") for an overview of how we approach similar "ae" and "oe" words.

See [**Dr.**](/home/d/dr) for guidelines on using the honorific for health-care professionals only.

### animals

**Animals**

**In general, we keep the names of animals lowercase unless the words are derived from proper nouns.**

For instance, **dachshund** is lowercase (it comes from the German words for "badger dog"). But **Dalmatian** is capitalized because it refers to the ancient region of Dalmatia (which is now southwest Croatia), and **Doberman** is based on a breeder's name. Often proper noun elements are obvious (e.g., **Boston terrier** and **bracco Italiano**), but sometimes they require verification (e.g., Vendée is capitalized in **petit basset griffon Vendée** because it's a region in France). 

**Capital letters are not used when lowercase** (mandarin duck) **has been entrenched through usage.** The dictionary is a good guide. 


**lowercase (examples)**
angora (cat, rabbit, etc.), basset hound, blue jay, brown trout, chinook salmon, collie, dachshund, dragonfly, grizzly bear, herring gull, malamute, mallard, mandarin duck, massasauga snake, muskellunge (a fish), pekinese, pike, pinto, smallmouth bass, spaniel, shorthorn, snapping turtle, snowy owl, spaniel, western rattlesnake


**capitalized names (examples)**
Angus cattle, Arctic fox, Baltimore oriole, Canada goose, Clydesdale horse, Dalmatian, Doberman pinscher, German shepherd, Great Dane, Guernsey cow, Holstein-Friesian, Irish terrier, Jersey cow, Kodiak bear, Labrador retriever, Newfoundland dog, Rottweiler, Scottish terrier, St. Bernard, Shetland pony, Siamese cat, wire fox terrier

See also [Latin scientific names](/home/l/latin-scientific-names) (_Branta canadensis_ and _Homo sapiens_) for guidelines on capital letters and italics.

**Use the pronoun it** (possessive its) **for most animals, unless the sex has been established** in a story (e.g., a person's pet, a zoo's elephant). See [problems with pronouns](/home/p/problems-with-pronouns) for related guidelines.

See also [capitalization](/home/c/capitalization) (an overview).

### Antarctic Ocean

**Antarctic Ocean**

**Prefer Antarctic Ocean when referring to the body of water around the world's southern pole.** It's immediately understood by our audience as the opposite of the Arctic Ocean. **Generally avoid the much more vague noun Southern Ocean** — which has different meanings to different people (e.g., Australians refer to the water directly south of them as the Southern Ocean).

Geographers debate the boundary of the Antarctic Ocean. For this reason, it's usually more meaningful to be as specific as possible (e.g., when accurate, refer to the southern Atlantic, the southern Indian Ocean, the southern Pacific Ocean, or to a precise location, such as "about 200 kilometres southwest of Australia").

See also [Arctic](/home/a/arctic) for various guidelines, including capitalization (Arctic hare versus arctic chill)

### anti-vaccination

**Distinguish between the anti-vaccination movement and vaccine hesitancy. Anti-vaccination means a general, dogmatic opposition** to vaccines while **vaccine hesitancy implies a non-ideological reluctance** to get one or more specific vaccines — based on concerns about everything from how quickly they were developed (e.g., during a pandemic) to how trustworthy the evidence is that they're safe and effective.

Put another way: "Hesitancy" normally suggests delay, indecision, vacillation, etc., rather than the comparatively blanket resistance typically articulated by people who campaign against the conventional medical wisdom of vaccinations. However, **there can be overlap. If anti-vaccine campaigners spread false, distorted or unproven information widely,** large numbers of people can become nervous or uncertain about the advice of reputable public health officials. **In 2019, the World Health Organization listed "vaccine hesitancy" as one of the top 10 threats to global health.**


**CAVEAT:** In coverage of certain stories, such as the COVID-19 pandemic, **it's also important to differentiate between (i) those opposed to vaccinations and (ii) those specifically opposed to mandatory vaccinations** or to a range of restrictions imposed on people who have not been vaccinated, such as limits associated with the introduction of government-issued [vaccine passports](/home/p#passports). The latter group can include individuals who have been vaccinated but who advocate personal liberty over various public health measures. Use clear, direct language that matches known facts (e.g., "Hundreds of people gathered outside the legislation to demonstrate against mandatory vaccinations"). When condensing such detail into headlines, news alerts, etc., keep in mind that **word order can affect clarity.** For instance, an expression such as **anti-mandatory vaccine protests** stresses opposition to specific rules while an expression like "anti-vaccine mandate protests" can be inadvertently misheard or misread as opposition to vaccinations in general. The subtleties of **a prefix can make a difference**, too. For instance, avoid the inaccurate and misleading shorthand "anti-vaxx tax" when reporting on what amounts to a public policy debate over a proposed "**no-vax tax**" or a "tax on the unvaccinated."



**Why 'anti-' is accurate**
Be aware that some people challenge the terms "anti-vaccine" and "anti-vaccination" as too broad. They argue that the descriptions do not apply to those who say they're simply reluctant to embrace vaccines until they can be convinced the treatments are safe.

**But the prefix "anti-" actually has shades of meaning. Sometimes it implies outright opposition** to a thing, person, idea, and so forth (e.g., anti-abortion, anti-monarchy). **At other times, however, it simply means general "antagonism toward"** — as in expressing strong reservations, advocating strict limits, etc. This latter sense has been part of the English language for more than 200 years, according to the Oxford English Dictionary. Common examples include anti-trade and anti-regulation (i.e. anti-trade often suggests "limits on trade," and anti-regulation often means "minimal government regulation").

Therefore, **if people are largely opposed to virtually all vaccination until they can be persuaded otherwise, it's fair and accurate to say they're currently anti-vaccination rather than pro-vaccination** by any reasonable definition.

IMPORTANT: If a person or group has specific, science-based concerns over the effectiveness of a given vaccine, it's misleading to describe them as part of the general anti-vaccination movement. Instead, vaccine hesitancy is a more appropriate term, as noted at the top of this entry.


**Anti-vaxx, anti-vaxxer** **(OK but exercise restraint)**
**Avoid archaic wording** (e.g., "anti-vaccinationist," coined in the 1880s). Generally **prefer simpler, straightforward language (e.g., "people opposed to vaccines").
**
The shorthand **anti-vaxx and anti-vaxxer are acceptable colloquialisms**, especially when space is tight (e.g., in a headline). **But overuse can unintentionally change a story's overall tone.** Anti-vaxx is a modifier (e.g., an anti-vaxx leaflet). Anti-vaxxer is an agent noun. Both are derived from the compound "anti-vaccination." **Exercise restraint to avoid even the perception of belittling or demonizing people** (i.e., do not use "anti-vaxx" or "anti-vaxxer" throughout stories). Instead, prefer accurate, succinct descriptions over labels whenever practical (e.g., "They're against vaccines" instead of "They're anti-vaxxers").

**Avoid language that's inherently judgmental** (e.g., "vaccine-denier") unless attributed. (See [denier](/home/d/denier) for related guidelines)


**Responsible, fact-based reporting**
When directly relevant to a story, it's helpful to briefly state why a group or an individual is against vaccination. But **always make it clear that most medical experts advocate vaccination as a safe, effective way to help prevent the spread of various illnesses**. As Health Canada puts it:


> _"Vaccination is one of the world's greatest public health achievements. For over 50 years, vaccines have helped prevent and control the spread of deadly diseases and saved the lives of millions of infants, children and adults."
> — [Regulating vaccines for human use in Canada](https://www.canada.ca/en/health-canada/services/drugs-health-products/biologics-radiopharmaceuticals-genetic-therapies/activities/fact-sheets/regulation-vaccines-human-canada.html)_ [](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.canada.ca%2Fen%2Fpublic-health%2Fservices%2Fimmunization-vaccine-priorities%2Fimmunization-partnership-fund.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2-HeOx7UAPX0H8abcess3Q)


**Many respected public health authorities rank vaccination in the same life-saving league as sanitation, antibiotics and clean drinking water.** They point out that **some of the diseases now preventable by vaccines have no effective treatment or cure** (e.g., measles, mumps and polio). And they stress that children can become very sick, suffer lifelong disability, or die due to complications of vaccine-preventable diseases.

While we can, and should, report different perspectives over time, including any verified cases of problems associated with specific vaccinations. But **the journalistic principles of fairness and balance do not require us to give equal weight to unorthodox or fringe opinions that challenge prevailing, science-based public health policy in every story.**

See also [immunization, inoculation, vaccination](/home/i/immunization-vaccination)

### anti versus anti- **anti versus anti-**

For preferred vowel sound, see the [pronunciation](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2Flng%2Frecherche%2Findex.aspx%3FProId%3D33574&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0E25B66GwH4mZ_PA4snNAl).

**In general, do not put a hyphen after the prefix "anti" unless it's followed by either a vowel** (_anti-inflammatory_) **or a capital letter** (anti-Canadian):

anti-abortion
anti-aircraft
anti-American
antibiotic
antibody
anti-Canadian
Antichrist (name from the Bible)
anti-Christ (opposed to Christ)
anticlimax
antidepressant
antidote
antifreeze
antihistamine
anti-inflammatory
anti-inflation
anti-intellectual

antiseptic
antitrust
antivenin (not venom)
antiviral
antivirus
antiwar

But there are exceptions to each rule. **Hyphens are sometimes used in newly coined terms, to make words easier to read or because of long-established practice:
**
anti-ballistic missiles (see [ABMs](/home/a#antiballisticmissiles))
anti-democratic
anti-discrimination
anti-gravity
anti-nuclear
anti-social
anti-terrorism
Anti-terrorism Act (official name of federal legislation in Canada)

Each news organization has its own approach. **If the word is not in this list, consult the Canadian Oxford _Spelling_ Dictionary,** which is a clearer guide for hyphens than the main Canadian Oxford. (All CBC newsrooms have access to an online version. See the Language Guide's [spelling overview](/home/s/spelling) for details.)

By the way, there's no need for hyphens before vowels when "anti" has already been shortened to "ant" (_antacid_ and _antalkali_).

**Are we anti-anti?**
In Shakespeare's day, there were virtually no "anti-" compounds, according to New Fowler's Modern English Usage, with the exception of Antichrist and a few fused words like antidote and antipathy. Now, however, it says the number of possibilities seems almost limitless.

**Avoid using most of these newly coined and often awkward-looking compounds** (e.g., "_anti-junta forces_"), **especially when recasting would make sentences more natural** (e.g., "_armed peasants fighting the junta_").

See also [hyphens](/handy-links/punctuation/hyphens)

### Anyone versus any one

**Anyone versus any one**

**We normally write _anyone_** as one word. The pronoun means anybody:


_Anyone can sing that song._

**Split _any_ and _one_ into two words only when “one” functions as a number:**

_Any one of them can sing that song._

**HINT:** If you can insert the adjective “single” between _any_ and _one_, then the words should be separated:

_Any single one of them can sing that song._

### Arabic names

**Arabic names**

**Arabic names in English are mere approximations.** The sounds and original spellings sometimes vary from one region to another, leading to inconsistent transliterations.

**In addition to trying to pick which letters best represent the vowel sounds we're hearing** (_al-Qaeda_ versus _al-Qaida_), **journalists must also make decisions about the use of hyphens, spaces and capital letters.** For instance, the New York Times Manual of Style and Usage points out that the definite article "al" may be left on its own or blended into other words, the "a" in "al" may turn into an "e" or "u," and the "l" may disappear altogether through elision. In most cases, it comes down to convention. See [Al-](/home/a#al) for other examples (Al-Ahram but Al Samoud).

The same is true of "el." For instance, Egypt's _Abdel Fattah el-Sisi_, which some news organizations write as _al-Sisi_ (with an "a" instead of an "e"). Even deciding what follows the "el" or the "al" is debatable (e.g., _Sisi_ or _Sissi_, hyphen or no hyphen). During coverage of Egypt's elections in the spring of 2014, at least four different transliterations of his name were used by major media outlets. Most news organizations in North America initially adopted the double "s" spelling (el-Sissi), including the CBC, but then shifted to "_el-Sisi_" by late 2017 as the latter transliteration became increasingly common.

Common words like _Abu_ (which means father of) can appear as "Abubakr" or "Abul Zalaf," while _bin_ (which means son of, as in Osama bin Laden) is sometimes written as _ibn_ or _ben_. In second reference, the particle _bin_ is retained (bin Laden). A capital letter is used at the start of sentences or headlines (Bin Laden). See also [particles](/home/p/particles-de-du-van-von) for general guidelines (French, Spanish, Dutch, etc.).

**If someone has adopted a specific spelling in English, use that preference. If there's no personal preference but a particular spelling has been established through usage, go with that. In general, follow Canadian Press rulings when they're available unless told otherwise** by our [standards editor](/contact-us). For example, CP switched to the AP spelling al-Qaida several years ago, but after decades of writing **al-Qaeda** we decided to stick with the latter because there was no compelling editorial reason to change. As of mid-2022, the New York Times, Globe and Mail, BBC and countless other organizations continued to use al-Qaeda, as well.

**Do not make up your own spellings.** For advice on how to handle foreign names you're not sure how to write in English, see [transliterations](/home/t/transliterations). The entry includes guidelines on dealing with inconsistent approaches to the same proper noun by various wire services.

**Arabic names are usually two or three words long. We generally treat the last one in this sequence as the family name used to identify someone in subsequent references.** (Moammar Gadhafi becomes Gadhafi).

**But there are exceptions when a person is commonly known by one of the other names**, as in _Saddam_ for former Iraqi president Saddam Hussein (1937-2006).

See also the Words: Woe & Wonder column [Saddam or Mr. Hussein?](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews2%2Findepth%2Fwords%2Fsaddam_hussein.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3ZFOwovVCsFN3oOGxJc_hb)

### Arafat, Yasser

**Arafat, Yasser**

**Former Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat
Arafat** in second reference

Born: 1929
Died: November 2004 (at the age of 75)

Arafat was originally known as "Mohammed Abdel-Raouf Arafat As Qudwa al-Hussaeini," according to the Nobel Foundation's website. He changed it to Yasser (sometimes spelled Yasir, or Yassir) Arafat years later.

**He went by several other names** (with various spellings), including Abu Amar. **We always call him Yasser Arafat.
**
Note: The generic word _leader_ is always lowercase unless tied to a specific political party. (See [Leader versus leader](/home/l/leader) and [Party versus party](/home/p/party).)

See also [Mahmoud Abbas](/home/a/abbas-mahmoud)

### Arctic

**Arctic, High Arctic, Far North, the North**

There aren't tidy, universally accepted definitions of these terms in Canada. Arctic, for instance, is as much a regional identity as a geographical reference, and it commonly applies to some communities below the Arctic Circle.

To keep our word choice accurate, clear and consistent, CBC News prefers the following usage, based on widely entrenched conventions:




**Arctic**
**In the narrowest sense of the noun, Arctic refers to the region above the Arctic Circle** — which runs about halfway between the 66th and 67th parallels, cutting across the tips of [Yukon](/home/y/yukon) and the Northwest Territories and through the middle of Nunavut. **It includes Inuvik and Resolute.** The **Arctic Circle** marks the start of "polar days," when at least once during the year the sun doesn't set during a 24-hour period, and at least once during the year the sun isn't visible during a 24-hour period.

**Conventionally, however, Canada's Arctic also refers some areas that are below the Arctic Circle, depending on where the treeline ends.** For this reason, **it's acceptable to describe communities like Iqaluit, Rankin Inlet, Cape Dorset and Coral Habour as Arctic.** But when using this expanded meaning in stories, avoid lumping in places that are not Arctic-like (e.g., do not include Whitehorse or Yellowknife). See [Far North](/) below for more details.

**Use a capital letter when referring to the Arctic itself:**

> _Arctic Circle, Arctic Ocean, High Arctic, Arctic fish, Arctic hare_


**This includes literal references to the Arctic in weather forecasts**, etc.


> _Arctic air, Arctic cold front, Arctic winds_


Arctic in the above context is comparable to proper noun components in other geographically based meteorological terms, such as _an Alberta clipper_.

**But use lowercase for what amount to figurative expressions** (e.g., generic terms that simply convey the sense of extreme cold in any place):

> _An arctic chill in the room, arctic temperatures in Winnipeg_, etc.


Note: The body of water around the southern pole is called the [Antarctic Ocean](/home/a/antarctic-ocean).


**High Arctic**
The term High Arctic can be used to refer to **high-latitude land and water in the Arctic**. This normally means the northern tip of Baffin Island (e.g., **Pond Inlet**), as well as all of the Queen Elizabeth Islands, including Ellesmere Island (e.g., **Grise Fiord** and **Canadian Forces Station Alert**) and the rest of **the Canadian Arctic Archipelago north of the Parry Channel**. The High Arctic includes Parry Channel, itself, which runs from Lancaster Sound to M'Clure Strait. (Note the spelling of M'Clure, which is named after the 19th century explorer Sir Robert M'Clure.) This channel is the central stretch of the **Northwest Passage** — the Arctic water route that connects the Atlantic and Pacific oceans.

**Generally avoid the vaguer compound Low Arctic**, which is not only comparatively obscure but also unhelpfully ambiguous. Depending on the person using the label, "Low Arctic" can mean either (a) the area between the High Arctic and the Arctic Circle, or (b) the southern portion of a more broadly defined Arctic, including some areas beneath the Arctic Circle. **Also try to steer clear of the term Subarctic**, which is simply a bombastic name for territory immediately below (south) of the Arctic Circle.


**Far North**
**The term Far North traditionally refers to Canada's Arctic as well as to non-Arctic areas above the treeline. It includes Dawson, Whitehorse and Yellowknife.**

While the **treeline** is commonly considered the region's southern boundary, be aware that the noun is imprecise and sometimes confusing because ribbons of stunted trees thrive far into the tundra, depending on factors such as elevation, changing climate and evolving plant species. Although sometimes used as a synonym, the word **timberline** normally describes where trees stop growing on mountains.

**Regional differences are worth noting. Far North is a relative term**, since people who live in Canada's North don't see it as "Far." For this reason, **it generally has less currency the farther north you travel.**

But just as the "Middle East" has come to mean something on its own, regardless of the modifier "Middle," the practical and common compound "Far North" is acceptable when we want to talk about the Arctic as well as areas close to the Arctic in journalism produced for a general audience.

A good rule of thumb: **National stories involving a combination of Nunavut, the Northwest Territories and/or Yukon normally refer to the Far North, while stories involving Nunavut alone and/or the Beaufort Sea area of the N.W.T.** (e.g., Tuktoyaktuk) **generally refer to the Arctic.** See [Arctic](/home/a/arctic#Arctic) above for details.


**Examples of preferred usage:**

-   A story about Inuvik refers to **the Arctic**.
-   A trip by the prime minister to Whitehorse, Yellowknife and Resolute is a visit to **the Far North** rather than to the Arctic, even though it includes a stop in the Arctic. Another acceptable description is the prime minister's annual trip to **the North**.
-   A national park west of Yellowknife, near the N.W.T. border with Yukon, is a **northern national park**, or a park in Canada's **Far North**, but not an Arctic national park. 

**Canada's North**
**This is a sweeping label that includes the Arctic and Far North, as well as areas slightly farther south.**

**There is no simple definition of "North."** Academics measure debatable "nordicity scales" of climate, geographical location, topography, population density, etc., to rank a wide range of "northerness levels" in Canada.

In national media coverage, however, **the North conventionally means Yukon, N.W.T., Nunavut and the uppermost swaths of various provinces.** Once again, regional usage is sometimes different, especially in stories produced for a northern audience (e.g., a radio report in Yellowknife about "the North" may well convey a different meaning than one in Regina).

See also: [North, South, East, West](/home/n/north-south-east-and-west) for point of compass capitalization guidelines

For a wide range of information about Canada's North, including links to various scientific research portals and publications, visit [Polar Knowledge Canada](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.canada.ca%2Fen%2Fpolar-knowledge.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3VzhexBuDEpqY1f9JH8Jeh) as well as the archived website of the [Canadian Polar Commission](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.polarcom.gc.ca%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw203t1TQEaTs8FVgJuxAJJs).

### Asian names

**Asian names**

**In China, Korea and several other Asian countries, the family name comes first, followed by a given name.** So _Mao Zedong_ would be _Mao_ in second reference, _Deng Xiaoping_ would be _Deng_, North Korean leader _Kim Jong-un_ would be _Kim_, and _Chinese President Xi Jinping_ would be _Xi_ or _President Xi_. Be aware that capitalization and hyphenation of Asian names can vary, depending on established usage and individual preference (e.g., South Korean President _Yoon Suk Yeol_, rather than "_Yoon Suk-yeol,_" is _Yoon_ in second reference).

**In other countries, such as Myanmar, there's really no equivalent to surnames, and known personal preferences guide us** (along with entrenched usage in the case of some famous figures). For example, former UN secretary general _U Thant_ is historically "U Thant" in first reference, even though "U" is the equivalent of the honorific "Mr.," and _Thant_ in second reference. And Myanmar's pro-democracy leader _Aung San Suu Kyi_ traditionally becomes _Suu Kyi_ in second reference.

**Be aware of subtle complexities** in the naming conventions of various countries. **In Vietnamese names, for instance, Van is normally uppercase** in the full name and frequently dropped in second reference. So former Vietnamese prime minister **Phan Van Khai** becomes **Khai**, and **Nguyen Van Thanh** becomes **Thanh**. (See also [particles](/home/p/particles-de-du-van-von) for related guidelines on handling non-Asian names, such as Vincent van Gogh.) It's worth stressing that in both cases, the second reference is actually the person's given name — i.e., Khai and Thanh — based on entrenched Vietnamese custom. In other words, **while Vietnamese family names are generally listed first when a complete name is reported, the given name rather than the family name is traditionally reported in subsequent references**, which can mislead some foreigners into assuming that Vietnamese names follow the Western tradition of placing family names last. Watch out for exceptions, however, such as the historical figure **Ho Chi Minh** who went by Ho in second reference.


**Japanese names**
**In Japan, names rendered in English are undergoing a transition.** In late 2019, the government of Japan asked Western news organizations to consider reporting its citizens' family names first as a way of reclaiming a pre-Meiji era tradition. But not everyone in the country adopted this style, which represents a departure from roughly 150 years of practice. Indeed, the approach remains so inconsistent and potentially confusing in Japan that romanized family names are now commonly written either entirely in capital letters (e.g., ABE Shinzo) or are followed by commas (e.g., Abe, Shinzo) to flag them in first reference. Furthermore, as of mid-2022, the country's oldest and largest English newspaper, the Japan Times, continued to use the old system because it's so familiar (e.g., it posted the headline "Former prime minister **Shinzo Abe** assassinated" on its website July 8, 2022).

**Our current style is to continue to put Japanese family names last in the sequence** (e.g., artist and peace activist **Yoko Ono** becomes Ono in second reference) **unless a specific individual is known to prefer a different approach**. This includes references to historical figures (e.g., filmmaker **Akira Kurosawa** and music teacher **Shinichi Suzuki**). Most major news organizations in the West take a similar tack. We will continue to monitor the naming convention, however, and consider adjusting our style if the pre-Meiji practice of putting Japanese family names first becomes the norm.

See also the 2011 guidelines: [How do you say Fukushima? Tips on Japanese words](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/updates/2011/2011-03-19/ "2011 03 19")


**His name is Bill Lee. Lee said ...**
**English spellings of mainland Chinese names are generally based on Pinyin** (which means "spell sound"). Under this system, roman letters usually approximate English sounds. But there are exceptions. For example, "x" represents "sy" or "ch."

**The names of many historical figures retain their older spellings** (e.g., _Confucius_, which is a Latin version of K'ung Fu-tzu, which in turn is a Wade-Giles transliteration of "Kong the master"). **But others do not** (_Mao Zedong,_ not Mao Tse-tung, and _Zhou Enlai_, not Chou En-lai).

**Many Asian people living in Hong Kong, Taiwan and the West have adopted surnames, so follow entrenched preferences.** (_William Woo_ would be _Woo_ in second reference.) This sometimes means a person living outside China puts the family name second while relatives still living in China continue to put it first. For instance, a university student from China murdered and dismembered in Montreal in 2012 preferred to be called Jun Lin (with Lin used in second reference). His father, however, was identified as Lin Diran. Again, known preferences should be followed, with extra detail included in stories whenever required to ensure clarity (e.g., repeating labels like father or mother in second reference).

**Non-Pinyin spellings are common outside of Beijing's influence. Follow people's preferences.** If the preference is not known, **do not guess.** Instead, determine the correct rendering of such names through traditional newsgathering channels.


For further guidance, see [transliterations](/home/t/transliterations) as well as [second reference names](/home/q/quotes-overview#second-reference-names) (family versus first).
For specific phonetics, see the [CBC Pronunciation Database](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2Flng%2Frecherche%2Findex.aspx&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1XFPfiGVRPwO63-NkaNyUm).

### assassination

**Assassination**

The word assassination can be generally defined as **a sudden and fatal attack against a prominent person that's linked to the person's fame or status** (as opposed to being, say, the result of a personal quarrel or a random act of violence). This includes high-profile public figures, such as government leaders and artists, as well as senior members of religious communities, human rights groups, military organizations, crime families, etc.

While assassination used to be more narrowly defined as the murder of well-known people for political or religious reasons, **the exact motivation is not always clear** (e.g., the death of John F. Kennedy was undoubtedly an assassination, but exactly how and why it was carried out are passionately debated to this day). And **sometimes the reason for the attack may simply be the madness or instability of the assassin** rather than a specifically articulated political or religious motive (e.g., the fatal shooting of musician John Lennon in 1980 is conventionally referred to as an assassination).

**Avoid labelling routine killings as assassinations.** Use common sense. For example, if the head of a political party is gunned down while delivering a speech, the word "assassinated" almost certainly applies — unless there's evidence the person was not actually targeted but simply shot by mistake. But if the same politician is killed in private by a jilted lover, the term "murdered" is a better choice.

See also [**assassination versus targeted killing**](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#assassination) in the Middle East glossary.

### Assembly

**Assembly versus assembly**

**Use a capital letter if it refers to a _national_ or _international_ body, or to a Canadian provincial or territorial legislature:**



> _UN General Assembly
> __the General Assembly
> __France’s National Assembly
> __Quebec National Assembly
> _Newfoundland and Labrador _House of Assembly_


But keep the word assembly lowercase on its own or in generic references:


> assembly member
> the assembly (but the National Assembly and the House of Assembly)
> the assembly building


See also general rules on [capitalization](/home/c/capitalization) as well as [legislative bodies](/home/l/legislative-bodies)

### assisted\_dying

**Assisted dying (assisted suicide)**

The terms **assisted dying** and **medical assistance in dying** (**MAID**) have **largely replaced the expression assisted suicide** in public policy debates over the rights of grievously and irremediably ill Canadians seeking help to end their lives. The Supreme Court of Canada adopted this language when reviewing what had been blanket prohibitions against suicide assistance in 2015. Furthermore, Section 241.1 of the Criminal Code of Canada has specifically referred to "medical assistance in dying" since 2016.

It's **not automatically wrong to use the entrenched expression "assisted suicide"** in our reporting when the facts fit. **But assisted dying, assisted death, etc., are often preferred** by patients and medical personnel. While such wording was once dismissed as vague and potentially confusing, it's now instantly clear to our audience, based on widespread usage.

**For many years**, doctors, legislators and the **courts differentiated between euthanasia and assisted dying, also known as assisted suicide.** In this context, euthanasia once meant taking the final steps to end a person's life (e.g., administering a lethal drug dose). By contrast, assisted dying, also known as assisted suicide, once normally meant providing someone with the means to end their own life, but then leaving the final act to them (e.g., prescribing or supplying drugs only, without actually giving them the injection, starting the intravenous drip, helping them swallow the pills, etc.). A distinction is still maintained in some parts of the world. **But in Canada, the lines between euthanasia and assisted dying have become blurred.** (See [euthanasia](/home/e/euthanasia#historical) for detailed historical perspective and related guidelines, including why "withdrawal of life-support" is not normally considered euthanasia.)


**NOTE:**

-   **Use neutral wording.** Be cautious with common but potentially problematic synonyms. For instance, **avoid language such as "dying with dignity" unless attributed**. Formal names of groups and other proper nouns are exceptions (e.g., the Death with Dignity Act). It's a good idea to **take the same approach with "mercy killing,"** which is perceived as biased by some who think the expression strongly implies homicide. **When reporting on specific cases, generally favour the language used by the family and/or doctor** (e.g., "medical assistance in dying").

-   **Prefer the modifier "medical"** over"doctor" or "physician" in assisted dying stories (e.g., **medically assisted death**), since nurses, pharmacists and other health-care professionals may be involved. And generally **spell out the acronym MAID in first reference** ("**medical assistance in dying**"). Exceptions are web headlines, TV banners, etc., where space is limited.

-   The term **"right to die" requires care**. When assisted dying is at the centre of a legal challenge by someone who wants to end her own life, it's usually acceptable to describe it as a right-to-die case, since that frames the debate succinctly. However, some critics argue that the term "right to die" fails to convey what they argue is really at stake: the "right to kill" oneself or others. Increasingly common, neutral alternatives for "right-to-die legislation" are "**assisted dying laws**" and "**end-of-life laws**."

-   **Provide fair balance.** It's valuable to **acknowledge both sides of the debate whenever practical**. This does not necessarily mean giving advocates and critics of assisted dying equal time in every story, or downplaying the suffering of people who want to end their lives. But it's crucial to include this perspective over time. In coverage of proposals to relax MAID eligibility requirements, for instance, we should strive to include pro and con voices (e.g., opponents believe that assisted dying laws increase the risk of elderly and disabled people having their lives ended prematurely, or of being pressured into agreeing to die).

-   **Do not glorify assisted dying or assisted suicide. Include only relevant facts that are necessary to tell the story.** There's generally no need to show video or pictures of how someone died, such as images of equipment used, unless it's central to a followup report (e.g., key evidence at a criminal trial involving allegations that someone unlawfully helped a person kill themselves). Even in those cases, exercise restraint. Descriptions of the death should not include sensational or gratuitous details.

See also: [death reporting guidelines](/home/d/death-general-guidelines) for a summary of related legal and editorial points as well as [suicide reporting guidelines](/home/s/suicide).

### Asteroids, meteors

**Asteroids, comets and meteors**

The terms asteroid, comet, meteor, meteoroid and meteorite are sometimes mixed up. This isn't surprising, since these words have been very loosely defined over the centuries. Astronomers, themselves, often use technical jargon, like "small solar system bodies." But in our journalism, the older, more familiar words are normally preferred.

Here are brief guidelines we follow to keep our stories clear and accurate. The definitions below are based on surveys of language used by various space authorities, such as NASA, as well as entrenched conventions.





**asteroids**
**An asteroid is a rocky object in space that's smaller than a planet.** Most are irregularly shaped and made up of different materials, including various metals and minerals. Asteroids **commonly range in size from hundreds of metres to hundreds of kilometres across**. Although they have no atmosphere, many are large enough to exert gravitational pull. These are sometimes called minor planets or planetoids. For instance, the asteroid Ceres, which has also been known as a dwarf planet since 2006, is about 940 kilometres across. Most asteroids in our solar system are much smaller. **When they're less than 100 metres wide, they're commonly called [meteoroids](/home/a/asteroids-meteors#meteoroids).** Millions of asteroids are believed to orbit the sun, although many are too small to be detected from Earth. More than half a million asteroids have been catalogued. Most are found in what's called the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter, which includes about 40,000 asteroids with diameters of at least one kilometre each. When a large asteroid slams into Earth, the impact can be catastrophic. Based on statistical models, experts estimate that an asteroid wider than one kilometer collides with our planet about once every half a million years.


**comets**
A comet is sometimes called a big, dirty "snowball" in space. **Comets are made up of loosely formed ice, dust, small rocky particles and organic compounds.** The ice isn't just frozen water. It can include carbon dioxide, methane, ammonia and other substances. Comets can be **up to several kilometres in diameter.** They're **similar to asteroids but have tails of dust and gas**, which are produced as they approach the sun and the ice starts to vaporize.

Style note: The word comet is lowercase even in proper nouns (e.g., Halley's comet), along the lines of the generic words asteroid, nebula and star in the asteroid Vesta, the Andromeda nebula and Luyten’s star.


**meteoroids**
A meteoroid is **essentially a small [asteroid](/home/a/asteroids-meteors#asteroids) or debris from a [comet](/home/a/asteroids-meteors#comets)**. There's **no universally applied criteria, such as size or density**. On some scales, meteoroids range from a very small speck to something as big as a boulder. On other scales, meteoroids can have diameters of up to 100 metres. Depending on a given story's facts, it's **acceptable to refer to certain meteoroids as small asteroids**.


**meteors**
**A meteor** (commonly called a "**shooting star**") is simply **a meteoroid that's entered a planet's atmosphere**. Friction heats meteors as they plummet, making them glow and producing a bright streak visible to the naked eye. At least a few can be seen on any given night. When a lot appear (e.g., hundreds per hour), the term **meteor shower** is commonly used. Many meteors vaporize entirely. When large ones break up in the lower atmosphere, the explosive force sometimes produces powerful sonic waves that can cause damage (e.g., shattered windows) on the ground. **Any parts of a meteor that actually strike a planet are called meteorites.**


**meteorites**
**A meteorite is what's left of a meteor when it hits a planet.** Meteorites **usually range in size from tiny grains to large boulders.** They're made up of different rocky and metallic substances, including nickel-iron alloy. Since meteorites are extremely hot and travelling very fast, they can virtually disintegrate upon impact, leaving behind craters and wide areas of dust and melted ore. Large meteorites, such as the one that slammed into Arizona about 50,000 years ago — forming what's known as Meteor Crater in the U.S. — can explode with a force more powerful than hundreds of nuclear bombs. Such strikes are relatively rare, according to experts, occurring about once every 6,000 years. The Earth has been hit by much smaller meteorites countless times. Scientists, for example, have recovered more than 10,000 meteorite specimens from Antarctica alone.

See also [space terms](/home/s/space-terms) (e.g., "red giant" versus the "Red Planet" capitalization preferences)

**The three Maritime provinces are:**
_Nova Scotia, New Brunswick_ and _Prince Edward Island_

> the _Academy Awards_
>
> the _International Indian Film Academy Awards_ (or _IIFA Awards_)
>
> _They handed out awards for ..._

> _the Stephen Leacock award_

> > _(Official name)_

> _Pulitzer Prize_

We do talk about "a blaze of glory" and "a blaze of patriotism," so there's no reason we can't describe firefighters "battling a blaze" if that's the best wording for a given story. Whenever practical, these labels should be briefly explained unless a given story's context already makes the meaning clear. Blood diamonds have been linked to armed struggles in parts of Africa. **blue line, thin blue line** (_caution required when referring to police; limit to attributed usage_) The expression originally described military units in battle, and was tied to a given force's uniforms (e.g., the **thin red line**, the thin blue line). It was first applied to police units in the 1960s, according to the Oxford English Dictionary. Be aware that some people find the figurative language inappropriate, especially in the context of civilian-police tensions, because they say it implies that officers are separate from society. In the mid-2010s, controversy erupted over slogans like **Blue Lines Matter**, along with flags and uniform patches depicting blue lines. Critics accused some police officers and their supporters of using the symbol as an attack against **Black Lives Matter** protests. Since then, **the term "thin blue line" has become polarizing** — with accusations of racism and antisemitism by critics of the expression, and accusations of anarchy and anti-policing by its defenders. For this reason, **the words should be attributed**, either in broadcast clips and directly transcribed quotes or as elements of proper nouns.

**break-in, break-ins** (n.) Colloquial and acceptable shorthand for "break into." Commonly refers to unauthorized access to private property — from houses, businesses and vehicles to computer networks. It's perfectly acceptable to report on, say, an increase or decrease in vehicle break-ins, computer break-ins, residential break-ins, etc. It's also OK to say that a criminal "broke into" a house, an office, a car, a computer, etc. But avoid inaccurately implying that the specific charge of "breaking and entering" automatically applies. The generic noun break-in is not necessarily the same as the specific offence of [breaking and entering](/home/b#breaking-entering). The latter normally applies to "places," which are narrowly defined in the Criminal Code of Canada as either buildings, including animal pens, as well as large vehicles like ships and planes. By contrast, the separate offence of "trespassing" involves the broader term "premises," which many Canadian provinces define as buildings, land, water and various vehicles, including automobiles. It's generally best to include the specific, relevant charges that apply to a given story (e.g., breaking and entering, trespassing, property damage, theft, mischief) when these are known, and when there's room.

**breaking and entering** (no hyphens) is the charge (_not_ "break and enter"). Unless you're referring to the specific indictable offence outlined in the Criminal Code, it's OK to shorten the term (e.g., "He's accused of breaking into the museum," or "He was convicted of three break-ins during the past four years"). _Avoid_ the jargon "b and e," except when transcribing direct quotes. See also [break-in](/home/b#break-in) above for related caveat.

### bacteria versus virus

**Bacteria versus virus**

It's unnecessary to define common terms such as bacteria and virus in stories. But since they have different meanings, it's crucial to use the right word.




**Virus**
Viruses are the simplest known form of microorganism on the planet. Although they can exist on inanimate objects (phones, faucets, doorknobs) for several hours, **viruses need living hosts (plants, animals) to survive and reproduce.** They're generally much smaller than bacteria (between one-tenth and one-hundredth the size). Some viruses nest inside bacteria. Not all viruses are harmful.

**Numerous illnesses and diseases are caused by viruses**, from common colds, influenza (flu) and chickenpox to [AIDS](/home/a/aids) and [SARS](/home/s/sars). Some microorganisms frequently in the news are Ebola virus, West Nile virus, avian flu (H5N1 virus) and swine flu (H1N1 virus). **Antiviral drugs** are used to treat viruses after infection (to reduce symptoms and speed recovery). **Vaccines**, by contrast, are used to try to prevent infection. They sometimes include an **adjuvant** to make them more effective. In stories, this term should be briefly explained (e.g., defined as an "immune booster"). Vaccines without the agent are sometimes called "**non-adjuvant** vaccines" or "**adjuvant-free** vaccines." _Avoid_ disputed constructions, such as _"unadjuvant."_

**Viruses commonly change** as they spread from one host (animal) to another. These mutations may or may not significantly affect transmissibility, illness severity, the effectiveness of specific anti-viral treatments and/or vaccines. **Epidemiologists often distinguish between new "lineages" of a virus and actual new "strains."** Both are forms of mutation, but the number of new strains is usually much smaller than the overall number of logged variations (lineages). **In routine reporting, the words "variant" and "mutation" are often better choices than "lineage"** because they're more familiar. **"Strain" should be reserved for viruses that have not only mutated but also act noticeably different** (e.g., are more infectious, more virulent, require a new or updated vaccine). For this reason, **it's best to steer clear of "strain" unless public health officials are using the term.** NOTE: While new virus strains are less common than mere lineages, a new strain can rapidly become the dominant threat during an epidemic.

**Virus mutations can end up with more than one official designation** (e.g., a variant that surfaced in the U.K. during the COVID-19 pandemic was called "VOC-202012/01" as well as "B.1.1.7," pronounced "B-one-one-seven"). Each component of these lineages represents a unique detail about genome sequencing, geography, chronology, etc. In this case, for instance, the "B" referred to the original novel coronavirus logged in Wuhan, China in late 2019 and early 2020, while the first "1" was associated with the big outbreak in Italy and central Europe a few months later. While it's **rarely necessary to include dense alphanumeric designations in stories**, especially broadcast scripts, precision is sometimes required to keep reporting clear. **Variant mutations are commonly called subvariants or offshoots** (e.g., "an Omicron subvariant"). See [**coronavirus variations**](/home/c/coronavirus#mutation) for more typographical guidance on what's known as Pango nomenclature (e.g., B.1.351 versus B.1.1.7), for background on the gradual adoption of Greek letter labels (e.g., Alpha, Beta, Delta, Omicron), as well as for important caveats against using geographical shorthand or fanciful nicknames when identifying viruses, variants and subvariants.

See also [flu](/home/f/flu) (guidelines on H1N1 influenza, etc.), and [immunization, vaccination and inoculation](/home/i/immunization-vaccination).


**Bacteria**
Bacteria are also microorganisms that can infect other life forms. But **unlike viruses, bacteria have more options to survive because they can grow on non-living surfaces.** They're found all over Earth — in air, water, soil — as well as in a wide range of the planet's plants and animals, from large mammals to small organisms.

Not all bacteria are bad. And some have industrial applications, such as treating sewage or making yogurt. Bacteria that cause harm are referred to as **pathogens**. Numerous illnesses and diseases are caused by bacteria, including anthrax, cholera, diphtheria, listeriosis, syphilis, tuberculosis, and typhoid fever. **Antibiotics**, such as penicillin, are used to treat some bacterial infections. Germs that develop resistance to drugs are commonly called **superbugs**.


**Bacteria (singular and plural)**
The word bacterium is rarely used outside of medical and scientific communities. Instead, **bacteria has become increasingly common as both a singular and plural term**. See [Latin plurals](/home/l/latin-plurals) for details and examples.


**Viral, bacterial**
**Certain illnesses, such as meningitis, can be caused by a virus or bacteria, and should be clearly identified as such** in news stories (i.e., viral meningitis or bacterial meningitis).


**Other microbes**
**Viruses and bacteria are not the only causes of illness.** Prions, for example, are an infectious protein particle linked to [human spongiform encephalopathy](/home/c/cjd) (CJD) and [mad cow disease](/home/m/mad-cow-disease) (BSE). And people get malaria from parasites transmitted by mosquitoes.

**If you're unable to confirm whether a particular illness is caused by a virus, bacteria or other infectious agent, the general term _microbe_ is an acceptable substitute.** There are many good websites to consult when looking up details about various diseases, including: the [Public Health Agency of Canada](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.phac-aspc.gc.ca%2Findex-eng.php&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1sal6ZP3v1gxwi7yB2R6LB); the [Centres for Disease Control and Prevention](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cdc.gov%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0HrZDl0m4-s6mt1A_1ztTF); and the [World Health Organization](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.who.int%2Ftopics%2Fen%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2muMz9ne5SczvbOEZcvX4Y).

**Germs are spread in different ways** — from airborne transmission (coughing, sneezing) to insect bites and sexual contact. Touching dirty surfaces, drinking infected water and eating contaminated food can also lead to infection. **When reporting on specific illnesses, it's helpful to include information about the method(s) of transmission as well as ways to stop the spread** (e.g., regularly and thoroughly washing hands).

See also [epidemic versus pandemic](/home/e/endemic-epidemic-pandemic)

### Balkans

**the Balkans**

**Ten independent countries** (as well as the small European portion of Turkey) make up this region of the world. They are **all in the Balkan Peninsula — which is bordered by the Adriatic, Aegean, Black, Ionian and Mediterranean seas:**

> [Albania](/home/b/balkans#Albania)
>
> [Bosnia-Herzegovina](/home/b/balkans#Bosnia)
>
> [Bulgaria](/home/b/balkans#Bulgaria)
>
> [Croatia](/home/b/balkans#Croatia)
>
> [Greece](/home/b/balkans#Greece)
>
> [Kosovo](/home/b/balkans#Kosovo)
>
> [Macedonia](/home/b/balkans#Macedonia)
>
> [Montenegro](/home/b/balkans#Montenegro)
>
> [Romania](/home/b/balkans#Romania)
>
> [Serbia](/home/b/balkans#Serbia)
>
> [Slovenia](/home/b/balkans#Slovenia)


**When people speak of _the Balkans_, however, they're often referring to the seven states that used to form [Yugoslavia](/home/b/balkans#Yugoslavia):** Bosnia-Herzegovina, Croatia, Kosovo, Macedonia, Montenegro, Serbia and Slovenia. The terms **Balkan war**, **Yugoslav war** and **Yugoslavian war** are all common and acceptable names for the fighting that erupted as Yugoslavia broke up in the early 1990s (e.g., **the UN's Balkan war crimes tribunal**). Be aware, however, that there have been other Balkan wars dating back more than a century, so it's important to make sure the intended meaning is clear from context


**Albania**
Adjective: **Albanian**
People: **Albanians**
Capital: **Tirana**


**Bosnia-Herzegovina**
Although the full name is often used in first reference, **it's common and acceptable to use Bosnia only in many stories.**
Declared independence from [Yugoslavia](/home/b/balkans#Yugoslavia) in 1992.
Adjective: **Bosnian**
People: **Bosnians**, but specify ethnicity when relevant (e.g., Bosnian Serbs, Bosnian Croats)
Capital: **Sarajevo**


**Bulgaria**
Adjective: **Bulgarian**
People: **Bulgarians**
Capital: **Sofia**


**Croatia**
Declared independence from [Yugoslavia](/home/b/balkans#Yugoslavia) in 1991.
Adjective: **Croatian**
People: **Croats**
Capital: **Zagreb**


**Greece**
Adjective: **Greek**
People: **Greeks**
Capital: **Athens**


**Kosovo**
A region in the south of Serbia that **unilaterally declared independence in 2008**. Canada and about 30 other countries recognized Kosovo as a separate state within about a month, but [Serbia](/home/b/balkans#Serbia) has opposed its former province from being formally admitted into the United Nations.
Adjective: **Kosovo**
People: **Kosovars**
Capital: **Pristina**
Kosovo is made up mainly of ethnic Albanians (about 90 per cent of the population). It has not been under Serbian control since NATO launched airstrikes in 1999 during a Serbian crackdown against ethnic Albanian separatists. As of the summer of 2009, Kosovo also included roughly 100,000 Serbs — most of whom lived in separate areas watched over by NATO peacekeepers.
**The term "ethnic Albanian" is a conventional and acceptable way to describe Kosovo's majority**, in order to distinguish them from citizens of Albania (a neighbouring country). Citizens of Kosovo who are **ethnic Albanians** or **ethnic Serbs** can also be called **Kosovar Albanians** or **Kosovar Serbs**, respectively.


**Macedonia**
Declared independence from [Yugoslavia](/home/b/balkans#Yugoslavia) in 1991.
The full name of this country has been disputed for decades. In the early 1990s, Macedonia tried to join the United Nations as the newly sovereign Republic of Macedonia. But Greece lodged a formal international complaint, arguing that the noun "Macedonia" on its own would cause confusion with the Greek region of Macedonia. As a result, the country was referred to as **the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia** in many circles for decades, including at the United Nations. But most news organizations, including the CBC, decided that this long, awkward (and technically unofficial) name was rarely necessary. Instead, we adopted the common approach that it was **OK to call the country "Macedonia" as long as** the details of a given story ensured that there was **no chance of confusion between this sovereign republic and a northern region of Greece** also known as Macedonia. In June 2018, an agreement was reached between Macedonia and Greece to hold a referendum on a new, official name for the country: the Republic of North Macedonia.
Adjective: **Macedonian**
People: **Macedonians**
Capital: **Skopje**


**Montenegro**
One of only two republics left after [Yugoslavia](/home/b/balkans#Yugoslavia) was broken up during 1991-92. It shared a loosely federated country with [Serbia](/home/b/balkans#Serbia) for several years on the condition that sovereignty referendums would be held. In 2006, Montenegro and Serbia became independent countries.
Adjective: **Montenegrin**
People: **Montenegrins**
Capital: **Podgorica**


**Romania**
Adjective: **Romanian**
People: **Romanians**
Capital: **Bucharest**


**Serbia**
One of only two republics left after [Yugoslavia](/home/b/balkans#Yugoslavia) broke up during 1991-92. It shared a loosely federated country with [Montenegro](/home/b/balkans#Montenegro) for several years on the condition that sovereignty referendums would be held. In 2006, Serbia and Montenegro became independent states. Another region, Kosovo, unilaterally declared independence from Serbia in 2008.
Adjective: **Serbian**
People: **Serbs**
Capital: **Belgrade**


**Slovenia**
Declared independence from [Yugoslavia](/home/b/balkans#Yugoslavia) in 1991.
Adjective: **Slovenian**
People: **Solvenes**
Capital: **Ljubljana**


**Yugoslavia**
Formerly called the "Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes," this federation of Slavic states in southeast Europe assumed the name the "Kingdom of Yugoslavia" in 1929. Its capital was Belgrade. For the next six decades, the country's territory changed slightly and it took on several other names, including: the Democratic Federal Yugoslavia and the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia. After the Second World War, Yugoslavia became a communist federation. **It began breaking up in 1991 during violent ethnic fighting.** Four of the six members seceded: [Croatia](/home/b/balkans#Croatia), [Macedonia](/home/b/balkans#Macedonia) and [Slovenia](/home/b/balkans#Slovenia) left first during the first year, followed by [Bosnia-Herzegovina](/home/b/balkans#Bosnia) in 1992. The two remaining republics, [Serbia](/home/b/balkans#Serbia) and [Montenegro](/home/b/balkans#Montenegro), declared a new federal republic of Yugoslavia. The country changed its name to the "Union of Serbia and Montenegro" in 2003 before officially splitting into two separate states in 2006. [Kosovo](/home/b/balkans#Kosovo), in turn, unilaterally declared independence from Serbia in 2008.

### Bank of Canada

**Bank of Canada**

It's also known as the _central bank_. The Bank of Canada is a federally owned corporation that controls the country's money supply. Among other things, it lends cash to private banks and acts as a bank for the federal government (which writes cheques, sells bonds, makes investments, etc., through the central bank).

The governor is appointed for a seven-year term and has a fair amount of independence over monetary policy, influencing the money supply by raising and lowering short-term interest rates. (See [bank rate](/home/b/bank-rate))

Canada's minister of finance, however, has the ultimate responsibility for monetary policy and can overrule the bank by issuing written instructions that must be made public.


**Mandate**
The central bank's broad legal mandate is to keep the economy sailing smoothly by moderating fluctuations in economic growth, external trade, prices, employment and so forth. But for more than a decade, it's largely focused on keeping inflation down, arguing that price stability is the key to sustained economic welfare.

The bank also looks after Canada's gold and foreign currency reserves, and can influence the value of the Canadian dollar by changing interest rates or by intervening in the foreign exchange market (buying or selling Canadian dollars).

America's central bank is called the U.S. Federal Reserve Board. The chairman is appointed by the president for a four-year term.

See also [banks](/home/b/banks)

### bank rate

**Bank rate**

The **overnight** or **benchmark bank rate is the minimum rate of interest that the Bank of Canada charges chartered banks and other customers**, such as money market dealers.

**Since it influences the cost of mortgages and other consumer loans, the rate is closely watched** and frequently reported in the news.

In stories we refer to it as the _overnight bank rate_, the _benchmark bank rate_, the _central bank's trendsetting rate_, the _Bank of Canada's key lending rate_, the _central bank's policy rate_, etc.

**It is NOT the prime rate**, which is what chartered banks charge their best customers.

**Technically, the actual "bank rate" is a slightly higher amount** that chartered banks and other financial institutions pay the Bank of Canada for longer term borrowing. Exactly how much more depends on inflation targets and other factors determined by the central bank. In recent years, the bank rate has generally been a quarter to a half of one percentage point above the overnight rate.

**For consistency, we normally report on changes in the Bank of Canada's overnight rate** (also called the trendsetting or benchmark rate). **In stories written for a wide audience, generally avoid the business jargon "basis point"** (e.g., write "half a percentage point" rather than "50 basis points"). If a sizable segment of our audience doesn't know that a "basis point" equals 1/100th of a per cent, we've failed to tell our story clearly.


**Changes in rates**
**A change in the benchmark bank rate usually signals a shift in monetary policy**. A higher rate, for example, may be an attempt to cool the economy and reduce inflation by discouraging borrowing and spending. On the other hand, it may be an attempt to prop up the Canadian dollar by wooing foreign investors with a better rate of return.

The American equivalent is the U.S. Federal Reserve Board's _discount_ rate.

See also [Bank of Canada](/home/b/bank-of-canada)
See also [percentage versus per cent](/home/p/per-cent-versus-percentage)

### banks

**Banks**

**Capitalize the generic word “bank” when it's part of a proper noun.** Short forms rather than full corporate names are OK in first reference when widely used:

-   [**Bank of Canada**](/home/b/bank-of-canada); the **central bank**; the **bank’s policy** on interest rates
-   **Bank of Montreal** (**BMO** fine in headlines or second reference); **BMO Bank of Montreal** (legal name of Canadian banking operation, rarely necessary to use in full because generally implied); **BMO Financial Group**
-   **Bank of Nova Scotia** (legal name), but **Scotiabank** fine in first reference; **Scotiabank Group**; **ScotiaMcLeod** (retail brokerage); **Scotia Capital Inc.** (corporate investment arm)
-   **Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce** (**CIBC** fine in first reference); **CIBC Wood Gundy** (retail investment division); **CIBC World Markets Inc.** (corporate and investment banking arm)
-   **HSBC Bank Canada** (formerly Hongkong Bank of Canada), **HSBC** fine in first reference
-   **Royal Bank of Canada** (the **Royal Bank** OK in first reference; **RBC** fine in headlines or second reference); RBC is the Canadian banking arm of **RBC Financial Group**
-   **Toronto-Dominion Bank** (**TD Bank** fine in first reference); **TD Bank Financial Group** refers to TD Bank and its subsidiaries; **TD Canada Trust** (banking); **TD Waterhouse** (investing)
-   **World Bank**

Chartered banks are regulated under the Bank Act. They're supervised by the federal minister of finance. When people refer to **Canada's big banks**, they mean: **the Bank of Montreal, Scotiabank, CIBC, the Royal Bank** and **TD Bank.**

See also [capitalization](/home/c/capitalization)

### barrens

**Barren Lands**

Sometimes called the **Barren Grounds** or, in second reference, simply **the Barrens** (_both acceptable_)

It is the massive area between Hudson Bay (on the east), Great Bear and Great Slave lakes on the west, the Arctic Ocean on the north and, approximately, the 59th parallel on the south.

The **Barren Lands** are not actually barren. They're also not entirely tundra. The rolling plain has rocks, short grass, some plants, forests in the south and trees along river valleys.

### Begs the question

**Begs the question**

**"Begs the question" is a criticism of an argument.**

When you use this logician's expression you’re not merely saying “Hey, that raises a question” but are actually stating, **“Your conclusion is unfounded because a key premise is unproven.”**

**Do not write begs the question if all you really want to say is _raises an issue, prompts a question, invites a question, evades a question_** or anything else along those lines.

In this context, **begs** means “improperly take for granted” while the word **question** means “the issue” (as opposed to an interrogative sentence).


**Challenging a premise with 'begs the question'**
**The flaws in certain arguments are more obvious than in others.** Sometimes the problem is a case of faulty A-B-C logic. Sometimes it’s simply a loose paraphrase of an earlier, unproven point. **The common thread is that buried within a proposition is an assumption that needs as much proving as the conclusion itself.**

Here are some examples:

> _“The highways minister should resign because the new legislation is unfair to most motorists.”_


The above speaker is guilty of begging the question of the legislation’s unfairness to motorists, which must be established before it can be used as a premise.

> _“The sculpture is obviously worthless because it’s clearly no good.”_


No evidence has been presented that the sculpture is no good. The person is simply advancing a strong but unproven view.

> _“She can't be Canadian because all Canadians are polite and dull.”_


A generalization about Canadians has been wrongly taken for granted and used as the basis of a conclusion. The argument begs the question because the issue of politeness and dullness requires proof.

> _“Abortion is the intentional and unjustifiable killing of a human being and as such is murder. Murder is illegal. So abortion should be illegal.”_


This argument begs the question about abortion being categorized as murder. The conclusion, that abortion should be illegal, is founded on the statement that abortion is murder. This may be a belief held by many, but it's not an incontrovertible fact. Proof is required that abortion is murder before the rest of the points can be considered.


**But English evolves**

> _English changes over time, and all evolution of language is good. So it’s wrong to insist that people use begs the question in a specific way._


But **the above argument begs the question** about the inherent goodness of all language evolution. **The argument also raises the question:** Does retaining the original meanings of some English words and phrases make communicating more effective?

Begs the question has its origins in the expression _petitio principii_, Latin for petitioning (or laying claim) to a principle. Although many people now use begs the question in other ways, these broader meanings remain disputed.
**Most authorities recommend sticking with the original definition.** Here, for instance, is advice from the Oxford Guide to Canadian English Usage:


> "In Canadian newspapers, 'begs the question' almost always means 'raises the question' or 'brings up the issue.' Although this usage is very common, it should probably be avoided because it is completely at odds with the formal meaning of the expression and constantly criticized by commentators."


**CBC News style is to preserve the original meaning of this expression.** (The same stand has been taken by numerous other news organizations, including CP, the Globe and Mail, and the New York Times.)

Misusing "begs the question" irks some readers, listeners and viewers, and has the potential to leave others confused. It also impoverishes the language by taking a highly specific term and turning it into a synonym for familiar phrases that already serve us well, such as "raises the question" or "prompts the question."

**If you're not 100 per cent certain what premise you're challenging when you write "begs the question," you're probably using the phrase in a disputable way and should pick other wording.**

### bi

**Biannual, biennial, bimonthly, biweekly**

The prefix “bi” can be ambiguous. _Bimonthly_, for instance, can mean every two months or twice a month.

Although _“biannual”_ suggests twice a year and _“biennial”_ implies once every two years, not everyone knows this.

Even fewer are aware that _“sesquicentennial”_ means every 150 years. So what’s the point of tossing around Latin that needs to be explained?

**Unless the meaning is obvious, avoid these labels. _Write specific descriptions instead:_** _twice a year, every two years, twice a month, every two weeks,_ etc.
