### blackface\_brownface

**Blackface, brownface, etc.**


**Overview**

The term blackface, coined in the 1700s, was originally a pejorative label for people with dark skin. By the 1800s, it became synonymous with mocking impersonations of Black people, especially by white performers in minstrel shows in the United States. Such shows featured exaggerated mannerisms and offensive ridicule that perpetuated hurtful stereotypes.

Today, **blackface commonly means use of makeup, polish, paint, etc., to look like a Black person**, regardless of whether wigs, costumes, etc., are also worn. But **blackface is not an umbrella term for the impersonation of other skin colours**. Instead, **there are specific variations** from the original noun's stem, including:

-   **brownface** (to try to appear to be from Latin America, the Middle East or South Asia)
-   **redface** (to try to appear to be an Indigenous person in North America,)
-   **yellowface** (to try to appear to be from Asia)
-   **whiteface** (to try to appear Caucasian)

**Use the term that's most applicable.** Saying that someone wearing brownface is in "blackface" is as inaccurate as saying that someone from Saudi Arabia is African American.

The word **brownface is relatively common** and, so, generally doesn't require defining as long as the context makes the meaning clear. **But "redface" and "yellowface" are comparatively obscure and can be jarring to read or hear unless defined**.


> _Al Jolson became the face of 20th century **blackface** in the 1927 film, The Jazz Singer.
> Peter Sellers wore **brownface**, not blackface, portraying an Indian in the 1968 film, The Party.
> Grey Owl personifies "**redface"** — a variation of blackface — because he spent years pretending to be an Indigenous person.
> The term **"yellowface"** refers to impersonating someone Asian, such as Mickey Rooney in the 1961 film. Breakfast at Tiffany's._


**Another option is to use a description rather than a largely unfamiliar label** like "redface" or "yellowface." For instance:


> _In the 1930s, British-born Archibald Belaney used makeup as well as bald-faced lies to trick people into thinking he was an Indigenous conservationist in Canada. **In addition to calling himself Grey Owl** and adopting fake speech patterns, **he dyed his hair black and secretly coloured his skin with henna.**_




NOTE: For a powerful comment on the racist use of Indigenous costumes and face paint, watch Halifax writer Rebecca Thomas read her **2016 poem [_RedFace_](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews%2Fcanada%2Fnova-scotia%2Fwar-paint-tribe-called-red-poet-laureate-rebecca-thomas-1.3732134&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0zlemR_kypCaroVKs4COVP).**



Bear in mind that when looking at old images — especially black-and-white photos — **it can sometimes be difficult to determine whether a person is in blackface, brownface, etc.** Contrast levels can be distorted and misleading. In these cases, consider other information (e.g., a party's theme, the individual's costume, witness accounts) and use common sense.

While brownface, redface and yellowface are acceptable terms for specific racial impersonations, **avoid calling people "brown," "red," yellow," etc., unless attributed** (i.e., in broadcast clips and directly transcribed quotes). **Even then, be aware such words can be highly offensive.** On the other hand, **"Black" and "white" are entrenched and OK** because they're considered familiar, fact-based descriptions.



**Indisputably racist**

**Donning blackface, brownface, etc., is unequivocally [racist](/home/r/racial-terms#racist-racism)** [](/home/r/racial-terms)— regardless of how common it once was. (Slavery and racial segregation were also once common.) **Appearing in whiteface, however, is not automatically considered racist** because white people do not share the same history of oppression and discrimination as non-white people in Europe and North America. **Whiteface can, however, still be racist in some circumstances** (e.g., in countries where white people are in the minority). And, of course, someone in whiteface may say or do things that are, themselves, racist, irrespective of the makeup.

Whenever practical, **include the voices of people who are not white in reports on blackface, brownface, etc., to help explain the deep pain caused by such racism**. Some people may wrongly assume that the racism threshold is whether caricatures are overtly clownish. But **the makeup and costumes should be assessed from an informed perspective**. For instance, a white person may see blackface as cringeworthy and inappropriate, but a Black person may liken it to witnessing the flaunting privilege of someone who can temporarily change skin colour without actually experiencing the daily anguish of bigotry and discrimination.

**Context can be relevant, including when and where someone appeared in racist facial makeup** (e.g., 30 years ago while trick-or-treating as a teenager, or two years ago at an office party). Societal norms and values evolve over time. **But never frame explanatory context as an actual excuse for blackface, brownface, etc.** This includes being careful when reporting people's own ignorance about what is or is not racist. Put another way: It's insufficient to attribute bogus claims (e.g., that painting one's face is harmless humour, or a heartfelt way of honouring people born with that skin colour). Instead, **it's crucial to make clear in stories that blackface, brownface, etc., are considered unacceptable** in modern Canadian society.

**Distinguish between [true apologies](/home/a#apology) and mere expressions of regret** when reporting on the fallout from scandals involving public figures. For instance, despite being criticized for his outlandish, highly offensive portrayal of the Asian landlord I. Y. Yuniosh in _Breakfast at Tiffany's_, actor Mickey Rooney staunchly defended his role for decades. Then in 2008, a few years before his death, Rooney said he wouldn't have played the part had he known so many people would be offended by it — an expression of regret about a career choice but not an apology for being in "yellowface."

**Define new or obscure words that may cause confusion in stories.** In the entertainment industry, **for instance, "whitewashing" now has a few meanings.** The word sometimes refers to casting white actors, or actors with indeterminate racial features, in non-white roles. Whitewashing also means hiring white actors, directors, cinematographers, etc., over equally qualified people from diverse racial backgrounds. Both practices can be signs of pervasive, systematic racism.

### boat versus ship

**Boat versus ship**

Ships are bigger than boats. Although there are no clearcut definitions to follow, some general guidelines may keep you out of hot water.

**The term "boat" is normally applied to smaller craft**, especially those used on inland waterways (streams, lakes, etc.) as well as in coastal areas. This category includes _fishing boats_ and most pleasure craft, such as small _sailboats_.

**A ship is a larger sea-going vessel.** The big ones that carry a lot of people on long voyages are called ocean _liners_ or _passenger liners_. Those that carry primarily freight, especially containers or crates loaded by cranes, are known as _cargo ships, freight ships_ or _container ships_. Those that carry oil in bulk are called _oil tankers_ or _tankers_.

**The generic word "vessel" can apply to a ship as well as to most boats** (i.e., those bigger than, say, a rowboat or dinghy).

**The word "craft" applies to boats and ships.** It's already _plural_, so don't refer to crafts. (See [plurals](/home/p/plurals))

**A life-raft usually describes an inflatable flatboat** that looks more like a big air mattress with low sides (i.e., like a "raft") than a traditionally shaped dory, pram, dinghy, rowboat, etc. **A lifeboat, by contrast, is generally a sturdier craft, often made of wood, that has the more traditional appearance of a small boat.** Technically, of course, a raft could be made of, say, timber and a dinghy could be inflatable. So there's overlap between the labels. Careful writers, however, avoid using the terms interchangeably. Covered life-rafts look a bit like floating tents.

**If you're certain that a vessel falls into a specific category (e.g., _yacht_, _schooner_, etc.) using that word in second reference can add colour.** In sailing, a craft should have at least three masts with square-rigged sails on each (fore, main and mizzen) to be accurately called a ship. But using such criteria quickly becomes overly technical. Some people, for instance, argue that the Bluenose II is a two-masted fishing schooner while the government of Nova Scotia calls it a ship. In this case, craft, vessel and schooner are uncontroversial choices.

**An [armada](/home/a#armada) refers to a fleet of warships.** Avoid applying it to boats and small ships that are unarmed. Use a term such as **flotilla**, instead.


**Common mistakes**
In news stories, the three errors that bob up the most are: (1) _referring to fishing boats as ships;_ (2) _describing a group of fishing trawlers or other unarmed vessels as an armada;_ and (3) _calling military ships_ (e.g., frigates and destroyers) boats. **Submarines, however, are classified as boats and should not be called ships.**

**Use the pronoun it** (possessive its) **for all inanimate objects, including ships**, planes, cars, guns, etc. See [problems with pronouns](/home/p/problems-with-pronouns) for related guidelines.

See also [HMCS](/home/h/hmcs).

### Both


**Both**

The word can be an adjective (both sides), an adverb (both now and evermore) and a pronoun (both laughed). It can also be annoyingly redundant and prompt complaints.

**To keep your writing tight almost always delete "both" when the word is already implied.** For instance:

> "**They decided to leave**" NOT "They _both_ decided to leave."
>
> "**They collided**" NOT "They _both_ collided."
>
> "**They have different ideas**" NOT "They _both_ have different ideas."
>
> "**His parents agreed**" NOT " _Both_ of his parents agreed."

**
Sometimes, "both" can be left in if it helps emphasize a particular point:**

> "**His parents showed up**" simply states a fact, as in "The phone rang, the door opened, his parents showed up."
>
> "**Both parents showed up**" underscores that both adults were there, especially if one person's attendance had been in doubt.


**When using "both" for emphasis, however, steer clear of obvious redundancy:**

> "**They were at odds with the dean**" (preferred)
>
> "**They were both at odds with the dean**" (OK if this emphasis helps the storytelling, as in "They were both at odds with the dean, but only one of them was prepared to file a formal complaint").

> "They were _both_ at odds with each other" (wrong; always redundant) Make it: "**They were at odds**" or "**They were at odds with each other**," if the conversational and acceptable idiom "with each other" helpfully highlights they were not at odds with a third person.

### boycott

**Boycott**

The term has **a couple of entrenched meanings** tied to protest:


> **1\. To stop buying/consuming** (e.g., a product boycott); **to cease commercial support/transactions** (e.g., a trade boycott).
>
> **2\. To refuse to attend** (e.g., a ceremony, a meeting, a sporting event, as in an Olympics boycott).


In the case of professional sports, **be aware that some people object to the term boycott to describe a walkout**. They insist that the correct word is "strike," **even though a strike by farm workers was actually a central part of the first protest that led to the term boycott being coined** more than a century ago.

**It's a myth that "boycott" narrowly applies only to consumers punishing businesses**. The word was born in Ireland in the 1880s during a dispute between tenants and an aristocrat's land agent named Charles Boycott. To protest what were considered unfair rental hikes and evictions, activists came up with ways to ostracize him — from persuading Boycott's employees to stop working (letting crops spoil in the fields) to encouraging local shops and other businesses to refuse to serve him. **In a nutshell, the original boycott was a combination of the withdrawal of labour** (a "strike") **and a suspension of commerce.**

The eponym became so well known, it turned into a lowercase verb and noun ("to boycott" and "to join a boycott") within a generation. **Although the word now commonly means an organized campaign to stop buying specific goods and/or services, it's also been used to describe "a refusal to ... participate in a particular event" since at least the 1980s**, according to the Oxford English Dictionary.

**Boycott, strike, walkout**
**Sometimes it's crucial to recognize denotative differences between words**. For example, we distinguish between [strikes and lockouts](/home/s#strike) to keep our journalism accurate.

**At other times, however, more than one term applies.**


> EXAMPLE: **In late August 2020, a debate erupted over what to call a protest by hundreds of professional athletes in different sports in North America** (basketball, baseball and hockey). **They stopped playing after another police shooting of a Black man in the U.S.** NBA players, who led the walkout, called it a "boycott" to raise public awareness about racial injustice. But **the term boycott was challenged by some who insisted that it was actually a "strike."** The protest expanded to other sports, including Major League Baseball. But **then the suitability of both "boycott" and "strike" was questioned when the NHL decided to postpone some scheduled games on its own** — essentially eliminating the need for hockey players to decide whether they wanted to sit out or lace up. To further muddy matters, **some media outlets began asking experts in sports and labour law to weigh in on the differences between "boycotts" and "strikes,"** as if common usage depended on legal dictionaries. More than a few lawyers defined "boycott" in very limited and dubious ways (e.g., to starve a business of revenue). Others introduced peripheral complexities (e.g., professional basketball players can "strike" because they're part of a union but professional golfers can't because they're independent contractors). There were also plenty of suggestions to add modifiers (e.g, a "wildcat" strike, a "political" strike), as if putting extra words in front of a contested noun magically settled the debate over that noun. At the end of the day, **anyone in search of categorical direction may well have found the back-and-forths over language as pointless as the final 0-0 score of a game not played.**


**In cases like this, the best way to serve our audience is to ensure that key detail is included.** We should strive to provide answers to rudimentary questions, such as: Are professional athletes refusing to participate in an entire tournament or in just one or two games? What is the objective? To get team owners or tournament organizers to do something? To raise public awareness about something not directly tied to the sport or to the competition? What terminology is being used by the athletes? Strike? Boycott? Are players the only ones participating? How about coaches? What's the position of team owners? The league?

**We also need to accept that there's often no single, convenient noun or verb to turn to.** Most options are imperfect in different ways. For instance:


> **Protest** is accurate but generic and vague. Showing up late or refusing to wear a team jersey are also protests.
>
> **Strike** correctly describes withdrawal of paid labour, but it can also wrongly telegraph a contract dispute, and it's inapt for league-ordered stoppages.
>
> **Boycott** is OK based on convention, but it can peeve people who think it means withholding patronage, and it's also inapt for league-ordered stoppages.
>
> **Walkout** is a fact-based description, but in the middle of a public health crisis like 2020's pandemic it might also suggest a physical exit from the confines of a "bubble" tournament.


**Use common sense and supply context.** For example: **"Walkout" is fine** as long as a story is about a player-led protest, and we make it clear if they intend to resume. **"Boycott" is OK** as long as it refers to an athlete-led protest and not to league-imposed postponements. **"Strike" is fine** for player walkouts, too, **although it's arguably more problematic, especially in headlines**, because of its close association with contract disputes rather than with political causes. This is in stark contrast to, say, a [student strike](/home/s#studentstrike), which is a common and instantly understood description of a protest that's got nothing to do with industrial relations.

The reality is that **it's not automatically wrong to use these words interchangeably in certain coverage**, depending on specific facts. This is **particularly true of generic terms** like "protest" and "stoppage." **In the case of more specific words** (e.g., "boycott" and "strike"), **it's usually best to stick to one within a given broadcast or online story**, outside of attribution (i.e., in a clip or transcribed quote).



### bridge

**Bridge versus bridge**

**Capitalize the generic word “bridge” only in official names of structures:**

_Brooklyn Bridge
Confederation Bridge
Golden Gate Bridge
Lions Gate Bridge
Burrard Street Bridge_
not far from _the bridge_

See also [buildings](/home/b/building)
See also [capitalization](/home/c/capitalization)

### Britain

**Britain**

The noun **Britain refers to one island: England, Scotland and Wales.** It used to be called Great Britain to distinguish it from Brittany.

**"Britain" is generally acceptable as a synonym for "United Kingdom"** (e.g., _"Britain is expected to use its veto when the UN Security Council votes" or "Britain decided to join the war"_), except in stories focused on Northern Ireland. **"British" is the preferred adjective in most cases** (e.g., "the British government" rather than "the United Kingdom government").

**Avoid the words Britain or British when referring to Northern Ireland. Instead, use "United Kingdom" or "U.K."** (The U.K. consists of England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.) This is particularly important in stories involving disputes over Northern Ireland.

**Briton** is the word to describe **a citizen of Britain**. The plural is **Britons**. Avoid the term _Britisher_. Be careful to avoid embarrassing mistakes like "Britains go to the polls on Monday." Make it _Britons_ or _British citizens_.

See also [United Kingdom](/home/u/united-kingdom) and [Northern Ireland](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/i/ireland/#Northern-Ireland "Ireland")

### building

**Building versus building**

**Capitalize the generic word “building” only when it refers to a well-known or important structure:**

_Parliament Buildings
Empire State Building
Crown Life building_
the _Toronto Star building_
campus _buildings_

See also [bridges](/home/b/bridge)
See also [capitalization](/home/c/capitalization)

### Bulleted list

**Bulleted lists**

Bulleted lists are a slick, effective way to convey information in web stories. But when these are added to the main text of stories **you must follow a few basic rules, including:**

-   Consistent punctuation.


-   Parallel construction.


-   Proper HTML code (normally automatic when using CBC publishing tools).

A more relaxed approach can be used within graphics, which are not formally presenting such lists as part of extended sentences or paragraphs.


**Punctuation**
**Introduce lists with a full colon and include punctuation between the bullets.**

**Each point should begin with a capital letter and end with a period**, even if it contains only one word. This punctuation always applies.
**
Leave a space between each entry. Do _not_ use semicolons.**

Periods are not required if the bulleted lists are featured inside stand-alone graphics.

**Parallel construction**
**All points in a list should flow logically from the introductory statement.**

**And all the entries should meet a single syntax test.** In other words, the same grammatical structure and tense should be used throughout.


**Example 1**

_When typing bulleted lists you should:
_

-   _Begin each point with a capital letter.
    _
-   _End each point with a period.
    _
-   _Use parallel construction.
    _
-   _Always leave a space between lines._

**Example 2**

_The report contains several recommendations, including:
_

-   _Fewer trade barriers._ 
-   _Lower taxes.
    _
-   _Higher salaries for editors._

**Example 3**

__The committee recommends:
__

-   _Reducing trade barriers.
    _
-   _Lowering taxes.
    _
-   _Giving editors a raise._

**Wrong (not parallel)**

_The report recommends:
_

-   _Reducing trade barriers.
    _
-   _Tax cuts.
    _
-   _Raise for editors._

**The last example is flawed because the syntax is incoherent.** It does not make sense to write: “The report recommends reducing trade barriers, tax cuts, and raise for editors.”


**Why no semicolons?**
We’ve tried various versions of bulleted lists on our site over the years. Some people, for instance, prefer semicolons after each point until reaching a final period. But many copy editors in North America dislike this style because it technically requires a conjunction (i.e., _and_) before the last entry.

The more streamlined approach adopted by CBCNews.ca is also used by many other organizations, including the Washington Post.

See also [punctuation](/handy-links/punctuation) (an overview)

**cardinal, College of Cardinals, Cardinal Gérald Lacroix** (no abbreviation); in second reference, make it: _the cardinal said_ or _Cardinal Lacroix said._ Avoid putting the word Cardinal between the person's given name and surname (e.g., Albino Cardinal Luciani). This archaic custom was originally based on nobility titles (e.g., _Richard, Duke of York_). Catholic Church authorities no longer follow this practice, except in some very formal documents. This is why most major media outlets now always put the title Cardinal first, including CBC News. (Note: Style manuals from the Globe and Mail, the New York Times and Associated Press have all updated their entries on Cardinal in recent years. The Canadian Press was one of the last news services to abandon the old style, around 2016.) See also [Archbishop versus archbishop](/home/a#archbishop). Since some retired cardinals can still actively participate in certain church duties (e.g., the selection of a new Pope if the retiree is under 80), retain a capital C in their titles: retired Cardinal Jean-Claude Turcotte. This is an exception to our normal style (e.g., retired general John de Chastelain). See [titles](/home/t/titles) for details. Church officials often talk about cardinals being "**created**." But it's an odd verb that can be jarring in scripts. In many cases, more conversational alternatives are preferred, such as: **named** cardinal, **appointed** cardinal, **installed** as cardinal, **promoted** to cardinal, **elevated** to cardinal or even **made a cardinal** — especially when lists of new appointees are first released, as well as later on, when biographical detail is being added to stories. For instance, we'd normally write that Marc Ouellet "became a cardinal in 2003" rather than "was created cardinal in 2003." However, it's OK to use the verb "create," too, especially when covering the specific public ceremony. This normally takes place at what's called a "consistory," where the reading of a papal decree "creates" the cardinal, according to an English translation of the Roman Catholic Church's Code of Canon Law.

But because the word Republic is part of the compound proper noun, a lowercase definite article is common and acceptable (i.e., the Central African Republic). See also [The versus the](/home/t/the-versus-the)

**centre on** (not around) A centre is a point, and central points don't orbit. So make it "centre on" or "[revolve around](/home/r#revolvearound)." The fact that "centre around" has become increasingly common over the years is irrelevant. The term remains disputed and non-standard English. For this reason, "centre on" is the CBC News preference.

**CERN** (OK in headlines, but define in first reference after that) There's no need to spell out as "Conseil Européen pour la Recherche Nucléaire." Instead, provide context in English, such as: "He worked at the European Organization for Nuclear Research, also known by the French acronym CERN." Continue to use CERN throughout story because it's more familiar than the English equivalent. See also [abbreviations](/home/a/abbreviations) for general guidelines.

**CEW** (conducted electrical weapon, also known as a **stun gun**) Generally avoid the abbreviation CEW unless explaining a quote or clip. Use "electrical" instead of "energy" when spelling out the jargon. See [**Taser**](/home/t#Taser)

**chain migration** (generally avoid) The term “chain migration” broadly refers to migrants moving from one country to another, or from one city to another, based largely on where people they know already live — especially relatives. Coined decades ago by demographers studying migration patterns, the jargon remains unfamiliar to most of our audience. It’s also become politicized in recent years by critics of immigration tied to family connections. The word “chain” in this context is muddying at best and dehumanizing at worst. So **to keep our journalism clear and neutral, prefer more descriptive language** (e.g., **family sponsorship**, **family-sponsored immigration**, **family reunification policies**). When “chain migration” is used in a story (e.g., in a transcribed clip), prefer quotation marks and be sure to define/explain the label.

**challenged** (_avoid_ as a synonym for impaired or disabled) See [disability terms](/home/d/disability-language#challenged)

**Charter of Rights and Freedoms, the Charter, Charter rights** (capitalized when referring to a core part of Canada's Constitution); otherwise lowercase (a **bank's charter**, **the charter**, a **chartered boat**) unless part of a formal name (the new [**Veterans Charter**](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/v/#VeteransCharter "V"))

**ChatGPT** (an [artificial intelligence](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/a/#AI "A") chatbot) The web-based tool was released in November 2022 by **OpenAI**, a private, California-based research company. GPT stands for "generative pre-trained transformers," but this jargon doesn't need to be spelled out in stories. ChatGPT is designed to mimic the way people write based on the structure of a massive database of books, magazines and other online text. Users can ask ChapGPT to answer questions or to write a wide range of new material, including essays, letters, document summaries, stories, poems, music, etc., as well as computer code. It does this by making a series of predictions about word and character order, along the lines of how a spellchecker makes predictions about suitable diction, grammar, syntax and punctuation. Although ChatGPT can often produce text that appears to be written by human beings, critics warn that it and other similar artificial intelligence (AI) chatbots can frequently generate passages that contain factual errors.

**Chinese language** (often abridged as **Chinese**) Acceptable umbrella term in generic references to written or spoken forms of what linguists call the Sino-Tibetan language of China (e.g., "_They learned Chinese at home_"). But in certain stories, it's better to be precise when (i) the specific name of the language or dialect is known (e.g., **Mandarin, [Cantonese](#Cantonese), Shanghainese, Hakka**, etc.), and (ii) this detail is considered relevant to the report. **The official spoken language of China is standard Mandarin**, also known as Putonghua. Be aware that written Chinese is not based on an alphabet but, rather, on thousands of distinct glyphs. For this reason, it's misleading to describe someone "writing" Mandarin, Cantonese, etc.. Instead, the convention is to say that they are writing in Chinese. The two most common logographic systems are "traditional" and "simplified" Chinese characters.

**citizen, citizenship** (n.) When referring to citizenship status, always prefer clear, direct language (e.g., a **Canadian citizen**, a **permanent resident**). Avoid vague or dated terms (e.g., "Canadian national" and "landed immigrant"), except in historical references. And try to steer clear of obscure and highly bureaucratic labels (e.g., "designated foreign national"). If you do need to use compounds like that because the detail is central, always define/explain the jargon. (See also [refugee, asylum seeker, migrant](/home/r/refugee))

**city, city council, city hall** (lowercase in virtually all municipal affairs coverage, including general reference to the administration or building) Examples: "You can't fight **city hall**" and "**Calgary's city hall** will reopen next week" and "a **city council meeting**" and "Protesters gathered outside **city hall in Montreal**." The compound "city hall" is capitalized only in rare cases when the building's proper name is used in a story about the structure, itself, according to standard publishing style (e.g., "Built in the 1870s, **Montreal City Hall** was declared a national historic site by Parks Canada in 1984");**City of Calgary** (corporation, as in "They sued the City of Calgary") _but_ **the city of Calgary** (for all geographic references). In second reference, the generic term **city** is always lowercase in either case. See also [**provinces and cities**](/home/p/provinces-and-cities) for general guidelines on identifying communities in Canada.

But the spelling "cacao" is unnecessarily confusing in news stories, even in technical references. Except in rare cases when citing the scientific name (_Theobroma cacao_), prefer **cocoa trees, cocoa crops, cocoa pods,** the **cocoa genome**, etc.

**code blue, code green, code red**, etc. (lowercase) Colour-based codes used by hospital staff, police and other emergency personnel should be defined in stories unless the context makes the meaning clear. For instance, "code blue" usually refers to a medical emergency (e.g., absence of vital signs) but "code brown" may mean anything from a chemical spill to severe weather or a missing adult patient. Quotation marks are optional, and should generally be added only if the jargon is too jarring without the punctuation. The typography of colour codes is conventionally different from capitalized [numeric-based series](/home/n/numbers#series), such as Type 2 diabetes, Phase 3 of a project and a Category 4 hurricane.

**cryptocurrency** (n., adj.) Commonly refers to a specific form of digital currency that's not issued or controlled by a central bank. Cryptocurrency uses sophisticated encryption technology as well as a special type of embedded ledger keeping. The latter, dubbed "blockchain," amounts to a buried log of transactions that makes it: (1) hard for authorities to track private transfers from computer to computer as well as (2) difficult for users to steal, counterfeit or distort (e.g., spend more than once). **Be aware that there's a debate over whether cryptocurrency is actually a "currency" at all,** since that word often implies a type of money (paper, coins) that can be deposited into and withdrawn from banks. This is largely a semantics battle, since the word "currency," itself, can be broadly defined as something of value that's currently in circulation. But **avoid shortening the noun "cryptocurrency" to "currency" in stories. Instead, prefer either the specific name of the cryptocurrency** (e.g., bitcoin) **or nouns such as "tokens" or "coins."** NOTE: The term cryptocurrency, first used in the early 1990s, originally meant a "substitute currency" that had nothing to do with digital money. Instead, the new or makeshift currency's value was "hidden" (cryptic) in ordinary goods (e.g., a carton of cigarettes or a bottle of vodka in a country with hyperinflation). Since around 2009, however, the term has been associated almost exclusively with digital transactions. **The word cryptocurrency has become so common it no longer needs to be defined in news stories** . By contrast, **the names of most unique cryptocurrencies remain largely unfamiliar** (e.g., ether, tether, dogecoin) **and, so, need to be explained** to a general audience. The **primary exception is [bitcoin](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/b/#bitcoin "B")** , which has been around since 2009. In investment circles, bitcoin is so well known that other cryptocurrencies are sometimes informally dubbed "alternatives to bitcoin," with the shorthand "altcoin" used. Avoid "altcoin" in stories, however, unless it's defined. Instead, use clearer phrasing, such as "other cryptocurrencies" or "lesser-known tokens." (See also [NFT](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/n/#NFT "N") )

**crystal meth** (fine in first reference) There is no need to write out crystal methamphetamine. Always point out that crystal meth is a highly addictive drug. It can be defined as a common form of methamphetamine hydrochloride, especially in features or science stories, but this technical term is not required. Methamphetamines are chemical variations of amphetamines. (For more information, see the CBC.ca background piece [crystal meth](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews%2Fbackground%2Fdrugs%2Fcrystalmeth.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3_fQLg-4JI6AHT5pGapDAK) )

In order to encourage a one-word proper noun (along the lines of "France" for the French Republic), Czech authorities have recommended various forms be adopted in different languages. In 2016, **Czechia** was chosen as the official English short form. For simplicity and clarity, however, CBC News prefers Czech Republic in most cases because it's both accurate and widely known. If Czechia is used in stories (e.g., in a broadcast clip or transcribed quote) the name should be explained to avoid confusion (e.g., "also known as Czechia") unless the meaning is already clear from context (e.g., in a sports tournament). While we often prefer entrenched short forms for countries (e.g., South Korea and Sri Lanka rather than the "Republic of Korea" and the "Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka"), audience recognition is a key criterion. ### Canada Revenue Agency

**Canada Revenue Agency**

The federal government's tax collecting body has had a variety of names over the years. Since 2003, it's been the Canada Revenue Agency (shortened from the Canada Customs and Revenue Agency, adopted in 1999).

Generally use the noun **Canada Revenue Agency** in first reference. **CRA is OK in web headlines and second reference**. (For several years, the abbreviation was obscure and confusing. But CRA is now widely recognized.) Lowercase generic terms such as the **agency** are also fine in second reference.

The well-established shorthand **Revenue Canada** remains OK in some cases as long as context is provided. For instance, a story's second reference could be expanded to include wording such as: _"The agency, still commonly known as Revenue Canada, ...."_

**'Revenue Canada' background**
The term Revenue Canada began as an informal name for the Department of National Revenue many decades ago, and has since become part of the Canadian lexicon. The department was eventually turned into a federal agency that reports to the minister of national revenue, but the old, unofficial label stuck.

Numerous news organizations continue to use Revenue Canada as acceptable shorthand in headlines and second reference, in the same way that "StatsCan" is used informally for Statistics Canada, "the Habs" (clipped from _les Habitants_) is a synonym for the Montreal Canadiens, and "the World Bank" is often preferred over the much longer International Bank for Reconstruction and Development. **Criticism that the term Revenue Canada is inaccurate because the agency's official name has changed several times is considered unwarranted since Revenue Canada was never actually an official noun.**

It's worth noting that using shorthand such as Revenue Canada can sometimes help our audience get CBCNews.ca content — based on "search engine optimization" best practices (i.e., because meaningful keywords in our journalism enable tools such as Google to find our online content faster and to rank our stories higher). This was certainly true during the first decade of this century, when the abbreviation CRA had still not become part of everyday speech.

### Canadian court terms

**Use Canadian terms for court coverage**

Despite the increasingly common use of U.S. legal jargon in everyday English, CBC News maintains a preference for Canadian court terminology.

We don't offer gavel-to-gavel coverage, for example, because **Canada's judges do not use gavels**. Our **sheriffs** are court officials rather than police officers, carrying out judges' orders, serving warrants, seizing property, etc. Not all Canadian lawyers are attorneys. (The term attorney is normally reserved for official titles, such as "attorney-general," and specific jobs, such as "Crown attorney" — more commonly known as "Crown prosecutor.") In Canadian criminal cases, the person charged is known as **the accused** rather than the defendant. The words **plaintiff** or petitioner and **defendant** or respondent apply to civil cases. Also, most Canadian courtrooms have distinct physical characteristics, such as a **prisoner's box** (_not_ prisoner's dock) and a **witness box** (_not_ witness stand). Use Canadian terminology (e.g., **[impaired driving](/home/i/impaired_driving)**) rather than Americanisms (DUI).

## **Preferences worth preserving**

Distinguishing between, say, a witness box and a witness stand is comparable to picking [half-mast](/home/h/half-mast) over half-staff and [railway](/home/r/railway-versus-railroad) over railroad. Both sets of terms may be relatively common, but historically the former are considered standard "Canadian English." When we start using American preferences (or American spellings), we get complaints.

The Oxford Guide to Canadian English Usage puts it this way:

> _In Canadian and British courtrooms, witnesses testify from a 'witness box.' Because American legal dramas are common fare on Canadian television, American legal terminology creeps into Canadian usage. American courtrooms have a 'witness stand,' and witnesses 'take the stand.' Some Canadians strongly object to the use of American terminology in Canadian contexts._

## **But sometimes there's no box**

**While preferences such as "witness box" and "prisoner's box" for Canadian court coverage are embraced by CBC News** and many other media outlets, including the Globe and Mail, **a caveat is worth noting:** Trials are sometimes held outside normal courtroom settings (e.g., a school or community hall). In these rare cases, the usual courtroom furniture will probably be missing, and no one will actually be "in the witness box." **Generic terms such as "testify" are recommended when the physical layout of a courtroom is unknown.**

## **Criminal Code terminology**

We're not obligated to include verbatim statute citations when reporting on crime or the courts, but **we should be accurate when referring to actual charges**. If in doubt, always check specific wording.

**In the Criminal Code of Canada, for instance, the expression "necessities of life" does not appear.** Rather, **the comparatively archaic noun "necessaries" is used** throughout Section 215:


> [http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/C-46/section-215.html](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Flaws-lois.justice.gc.ca%2Feng%2Facts%2FC-46%2Fsection-215.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1taGa0-2gQY4pA8Bk2nBEv)


This doesn't mean we can't describe people's obligations to provide the necessities of life to those in their care, or even to report in a generic way on accusations that a parent, guardian or spouse failed to provide the necessities of life. But **we should stick with the statute's actual language** (i.e., "necessaries") **in all direct references to specific sections of the Criminal Code**, including when wording such as "charged with" or "pleaded guilty to" is used.

Verbatim citations can include some wiggle room, of course. For example, although Section 215 also drops the article "the" before "necessaries," it's an acceptable convention to adopt minor syntax adjustments (e.g., adding "the" in this case) if it makes Criminal Code wording either clearer or easier to read.

See also [allege, allegedly](/home/a/allege) and [suspect, accused](/home/s/suspect_accused)
See also [Court versus court](/home/c/courts) as well as [Justice and Judge](/home/j#justice) and [verdict](/home/v#verdict)

### capital, Capitol

**Capitol, capitol and capital**

**Capitol Hill** and **the Capitol** (the official building of the [U.S. Congress](/home/c/congress)) both refer to the legislative branch of government in Washington, D.C.

The term **capitol** (lowercase) is sometimes used to mean legislature buildings in many, but not all, states.

The word **capital** (lowercase) refers to the seat of government in a country, province, state or other region. (Canada's capital is Ottawa. Montana's capital is Helena. And Helena has a state capitol building where the legislature sits.)

Capital, of course, has other meanings. To investors, it represents money. To economists it means a physical "factor of production" (e.g., a factory or a mine) that can be combined with labour. To typographers, it's the difference between O and o, which brings us back to the beginning, and the letter that makes Capitol distinct.

If you're not sure which word to pick, it's always a capital idea to look these things up.

See also [legislative bodies](/home/l/legislative-bodies)

### Capitalization

**Capitalization**

**TV TEXT REMINDER:** Be aware that television graphics, banners, supers, etc., have some unique typographical conventions that don't always match the basics highlighted below. The biggest difference is the use of more initial capital letters in titles, job descriptions, etc. (e.g., "Former Prime Minister" instead of former prime minister, and "High School Principal" instead of high school principal). See the [**TV Text overview**](/home/t/tv_text) for details.

**We generally follow The Canadian Press's lead when making decisions about various points of typography, including capital letters.** (See [Web publishing: Why a 'Modified CP Style'?](/home/s/spelling/modified-cp-style) for details.)

**Names and other proper nouns need to be capitalized** (the _Rocky Mountains_, _Prime Minister Red Buttons_), **but generic terms** (_the mountains_) **and titles not followed by names** (_the prime minister_) **are generally kept lowercase. There are exceptions, however,** including _the King_ and _the Governor General_.

Too Many Capital Letters in Sentences become Distracting, including when a lot of abbreviations appear. (_The VIPs from the NATO-backed group BIGGER plan to OK a UNESCO proposal._)

So **keep words lowercase unless you're sure capital letters apply.** For instance, we would write: _Canada's military_ (but the Canadian Forces), _Israel's army, GM president John Jones,_ the zoo's _chief_ _veterinarian Kim Woo,_ and so forth. Don't use capital letters for titles or events simply because some company or government agency does.

And **don't elevate most generic terms** (e.g., _draft, final, playoffs, game or championship_) **just because an event is held only once a year.** We write _NBA draft, NHL final, Stanley Cup playoffs, Grey Cup game_ and _World Series championship_. **A common exception is _[NBA Finals](/home/b/basketball)_,** with a capital "F," **because the league's championship series doesn't have a proper noun like Stanley Cup or Grey Cup to distinguish it.** NOTE: The same rule for lowercase nouns like "Stanley Cup final" and "Grey Cup game" applies to a host of other labels that include a mix of uppercase and lowercase lettering, such as _Type 2 diabetes_ (**not** "Type 2 Diabetes") and _Category 3 hurricane_ (**not** "Category 3 Hurricane").

Note: **Sentences and headlines virtually always start with a capital letter**, even in the case of quirky nouns that are lowercase, such as **eBay** or **k.d. lang** — which should be posted as **EBay** and **K.d. lang** at the start of sentences (or as **Lang** alone if it's a second reference).

**We do not always follow CP, usually because we think a different version is more accurate, logical or common** (e.g., we used iPod rather than IPod several years before The Canadian Press adopted the lowercase "i") **or easier for readers scanning our web pages** (e.g., Hurricane Katrina rather than hurricane Katrina). **So be sure to consult the Language Guide first.**

**The rest of this page outlines the fundamentals of CBCNews.ca capitalization.** Several sections have links to more detailed discussions (e.g., titles, abbreviations, and trademarks). Online editorial staff should review the Canadian Press Stylebook's detailed, 30-page section on capitalization for anything not covered below.


**In general, capitalize all:**
**abbreviations and acronyms** (AIDS but acquired immune deficiency syndrome; MA, PhD) See [abbreviations](/home/a/abbreviations) (including FAQs and "p" versus the letter P), as well as [acronyms](/home/a/acronyms)

**addresses** (24 Sussex Drive, 205 Wellington St. W.) See [addresses](/home/a/addresses)

**cities, provinces, territories** as nouns on their own (Calgary, Ontario, Nunavut) See [provinces and cities](/home/p/provinces-and-cities)

**generic words** such as [City](/home/c#city), [Town](/home/t#town) and [Village](/home/v#village) **ONLY IF** they're part of the a proper noun (e.g., the legal name of the City of Calgary in a lawsuit) instead of merely a geographical reference (e.g., "in the city of Calgary").

**clubs** (the Scouts versus "two boy scouts," and Hells Angels, which, by the way, has no possessive apostrophe) See [Scouts](/home/s/scouts)

**colloquial names** (Babe Ruth, Hurricane Katrina, Iron Curtain, Milky Way). In the case of weather, specific disturbances (e.g., cyclone, hurricane, typhoon) are uppercase only before proper names (Cyclone Nargis but Category 4 hurricane), while general terms (tropical storm) are always lowercase, even before proper names (tropical storm Noel). See also [nicknames and colloquial nouns](/home/n/nicknames)

**commissions** (Canadian Transport Commission) and **royal commissions** (1902 Royal Commission on Chinese and Japanese Immigration), **but not legislative committees** (Commons finance committee) **or subcommittees** (Senate subcommittee on cities), even when formal names are used (the House of Commons standing committee on finance). See [Commission versus commission, committee, subcommittee](/home/c/commission-committee-subcommittee)

**companies** (Ford, Nortel)

**countries** (Italy, Pakistan) and the **terms for their citizens** (Japanese)

**events that are specific** (Olympic Games) **not general** (opening ceremony)

**geographical labels** (Western Hemisphere but the Northern and Southern hemispheres in plural; Niagara Peninsula; North Pole or the Pole in second reference; [High Arctic](/home/a/arctic); Tropic of Cancer) See also [lakes versus Lakes](/home/l/lakes) as well as [North, South, East and West](/home/n/north-south-east-and-west)

**government departments, agencies, independent offices, regulatory watchdogs, etc.** (Health Canada, Department of Oceans and Fisheries, Alberta Fire Commissioner Office, Manitoba Advocate for Children and Youth, Ontario Labour Ministry, National Parole Service, Library of Parliament) See [Department versus department](/home/d/department)

**historical terms** (Stone Age versus "ice age," which had no single period, the Depression, Second World War, D-Day, the Holocaust, the Industrial Revolution, the Quiet Revolution) See [historical terms](/home/h/historical-periods)

**languages** (English, French)

**legislation proposed** (the Common Sense Firearms Licensing Act) **and proclaimed** (the Access to Information Act, the Copyright Act) **when official titles are used, but not mere descriptions of legislation** (an act to toughen gun control) or **plural constructions** (various human rights acts across the country). See [Act](/home/a/act) for details and related guidelines, including how to handle generic nouns such as "bill" that are part of a numbered series (Bill C-33), whether the legislation is passed or not.

principal words in English titles of **musical compositions** (Tchaikovsky's Symphony No. 4 in F minor)

**principal words** in English **titles of books, broadcast programs, poems, songs, etc.** (_As It Happens, The World at Six, To Kill a Mockingbird_). See [definition of **principal words**](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks/#principalwords "Quotation marks") for details.

proper **names** of people (Stephen Leacock) and buildings (See, for instance, [School versus school](/home/s/school) and [Library versus library](/home/l/library))
**
national holidays, religious celebrations and some other special dates** (Labour Day, Hanukkah, Education Week, New Year's Eve versus "in the new year," [April Fools' Day](/home/a#aprilfoolsday), but not "election day")

**national legislative bodies** (House of Commons, the Commons, Parliament, the Senate, France's National Assembly, Britain's House of Lords, Knesset) **and Canadian provincial legislative bodies** (the Alberta Legislature, the Quebec National Assembly), **but not regional legislative bodies outside of Canada** (California state senate) or **local governments** (Mississauga city council) See [legislative bodies](/home/l/legislative-bodies)

**numbered terms** that are uppercase based on convention (Leopard 1 tank, Type 2 diabetes, Act 3 dialogue, Category 4 storm, Category 5 hurricane, Grade 6 student, Treaty 7, Article 8, Bill C-9, etc.) See [numbers](/home/n/numbers)

**places** (the Crowsnest Pass, Oyster Bed Bridge, P.E.I.)

**proper nouns** even when embedded within common, generic terms (e.g., Texas and Omaha in the old poker games Texas hold 'em and Omaha hold 'em), unless these have become lowercase by convention (e.g., french fries not French fries)

**publications** (but keep "the" lowercase in names of newspapers, e.g. the Globe and Mail, and keep words like "magazine" lowercase unless they're part of the title, e.g., Maclean's magazine versus Harper's Magazine) See [The versus the](/home/t/the-versus-the), and [Magazine versus magazine](/home/m/magazine)

widely recognized **regions** (Prairies, East Coast) See [North, South, East and West](/home/n/north-south-east-and-west)

**religions** (Islam, Judaism, Catholicism) See [Church versus church](/home/c/church)

**slogans** ("America First"), **placards, posters** and other **signs** ("Give Peace a Chance"), the titles of various parts of larger, published words, including **newspaper headlines** and **book chapters**, etc., even if the originals were primarily or entirely lowercase. Capitalize only the first letter of each principal word, and generally add quotation marks. See [Quoting headlines, slogans, chapters](/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks#slogans)

**titles** of books, movies, songs, broadcast programs, etc., except for proper noun elements that are not considered [**principal words**](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks/#principalwords "Quotation marks") (e.g., _As It Happens_ and _A Star Is Born_ but _The Nature of Things_ and _The World at Six_).

official **titles** _before_ names (Premier Howard Meeker; Minister of Health Kathy Needles), but not after names (Meeker became premier two years ago; Needles, the minister of health; Harvest was appointed agriculture minister in 2008). **Keep job descriptions and their equivalents lowercase, however, including what amount to temporary appointments** before names (special mediator, special prosecutor). See [titles](/home/t/titles)

**trade names and trademarks** (Xerox, Aspirin, Band-Aid, Frisbee) See [trade names](/home/t/trade-names) as well as [quirky exceptions](/home/q/quirky-capitalization) (eBay, iMac, etc.)

**unions and other organizations** (Canadian Auto Workers versus "the autoworkers")

**well-known landmarks** (Parliament Hill, West Block, Buckingham Palace, White House) See also [buildings](/home/b/building) and [bridges](/home/b/bridge)

There are plenty of exceptions (Mayor Bill Big but trustee Bob Small), so **consult the CP manual for any words or constructions you can't find listed on this site.**

### carbon\_tax\_levy


**Carbon pricing, carbon tax, carbon levy**

1\. [Carbon pricing](/home/c/carbon_tax_levy#carbon_pricing)
2\. [Carbon tax, carbon levy](/home/c/carbon_tax_levy#tax_levy) (both OK)
3\. [Be aware of political spin](/home/c/carbon_tax_levy#tax_politics) (tax, levy)
4\. [Legal vs. common use of 'tax'](/home/c/carbon_tax_levy#legal_usage)


**1\. Carbon pricing**
**The umbrella term "carbon pricing" refers to government-imposed costs on carbon emissions** to try to reduce pollution linked to global warming. **Two common methods are:**


> **(i) Taxes/levies** (i.e., direct charges on consumers and industry); and
>
> **(ii) A cap-and-trade system on industry** (i.e., companies pay penalties for pollution above certain levels, but they can also buy and sell unused emissions quotas under specified conditions).


**Carbon pricing also describes hybrid approaches**, which combine direct charges with cap-and-trade, as outlined in the [Pan-Canadian Framework on Clean Growth and Climate Change](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.canada.ca%2Fen%2Fservices%2Fenvironment%2Fweather%2Fclimatechange%2Fpan-canadian-framework%2Fclimate-change-plan.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2wyXn4ICgR6zrEVf40_yMG), endorsed by federal, provincial and territorial leaders in 2016. Statistics Canada now includes "carbon taxes" tied to the federal government's "carbon pollution pricing system" when compiling and analyzing data on environmental taxes, such as in this [2019-2020 summary](https://www150.statcan.gc.ca/n1/daily-quotidien/231213/dq231213c-eng.htm) published in December of 2023.

**2\. Carbon tax, carbon levy** (both OK)
It's an **acceptable convention to use the terms carbon tax and carbon levy interchangeably.**

**All taxes are "levied"** through a given government's taxation powers. The word **"tax" traditionally refers to more than just levies for fiscal programs**. Among other things, **the term also applies to various charges imposed by governments to try to influence the behaviour of consumers and/or businesses** in an economy. This common definition appears in many publications, from economics textbooks to various dictionaries, such as:


> _TAX — A mandatory payment made by individuals and corporations to government. Taxes are levied on income or wealth or are imposed on goods and services to finance the cost of government services, to redistribute income, and to influence the behaviour of consumers and investors...._

> > — David Crane
>
> > Canadian Dictionary of Business and Economics


**Higher taxes on cigarettes** to discourage smoking, **higher taxes on gas-guzzling cars** to boost the sale of more efficient vehicles, and **higher taxes on industrial pollution** to encourage businesses to reduce harmful emissions are examples. The word "tax" is also used when referring to numerous tax credits and rebates, including those designed to make greener products more appealing to consumers, and R&D investments more attractive to businesses. Indeed, **behavioural influence is at the very heart of the expression "tax incentive."**

**3\. Be aware of political spin** (tax, levy)
**The word "tax," itself, does not automatically constitute bias in our journalism.** Some people point out that the expression "carbon tax" is often favoured by critics of the government initiative. They argue that "carbon levy" or "carbon charge" are better choices because "tax" has overly negative overtones — often associated with higher prices (consumption taxes), lower take home pay (income taxes), etc. But **we report neutrally on various tax measures all the time, including sales taxes, goods and service taxes, gasoline taxes, excise taxes, etc.** Banning the expression "carbon tax" solely because some individuals prefer different wording would be unjustified and inconsistent.

Furthermore, "**carbon tax" has been the language actually used by different governments at different times.** It's worth remembering that **North America's first broad-based carbon tax was introduced by the B.C. Liberal government in 2008 with the word "tax" in the legislation's title**: British Columbia's [Carbon Tax Act](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.bclaws.ca%2FRecon%2Fdocument%2FID%2Ffreeside%2F00_08040_01&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1tZOqDU6HgjG8-etiQ55IR). Since then, other provinces have used the expressions "carbon levy" and "carbon tax" interchangeably — depending in part on the party in power and whether the charges were being added or removed. In Alberta, for example, the United Conservative government passed the [Carbon Tax Repeal Act](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.qp.alberta.ca%2F1266.cfm%3Fpage%3D2019ch01.cfm%26leg_type%3DActs%26isbncln%3D9780779810574%26display%3Dhtml&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3sBL_k5G-xJvebJ9f58C8r) in 2019 that eliminated what the province's previous NDP government has preferred to call a "carbon levy" in its 2016 [Climate Leadership Act](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.canlii.org%2Fen%2Fab%2Flaws%2Fstat%2Fsa-2016-c-c-16.9%2Flatest%2Fsa-2016-c-c-16.9.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3QIMRFQ12Z8ih2PsEAVBeG). And the Northwest Territories [introduced a "carbon tax" in 2019](https://www.fin.gov.nt.ca/en/services/carbon-tax) that was increased in 2023.

It can be valuable to report changes in a given government's language when there's room in stories and the detail is relevant. Such background may help our audience better understand the overall picture, including any apparent shifts in communications strategy. But **there's no compelling editorial argument to insist on a preference between "carbon tax" and "carbon levy," or to impose narrower definitions in our journalism.** The terms are conventionally considered synonyms in public policy debates, in general business and economics reporting, etc. We consider such usage accurate and clear.

**4\. Legal vs. common use of 'tax'**
A final point about legal versus common usage merits mention. **We have occasionally received complaints that the label "carbon tax" is wrong because some judges have classified the expression in some other way.** For example, when Ontario's highest court upheld Ottawa's Greenhouse Gas Pollution Pricing Act as constitutional in June 2019, it concluded that the disputed "carbon tax" was not actually a "tax" at all but, rather, was a "regulatory charge." The reason? A majority of judges on the panel said that, in law, "taxes" are imposed primarily to raise revenues for general fiscal purposes. (See [paragraph 145 of the Ontario Court of Appeal decision](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ontariocourts.ca%2Fdecisions%2F2019%2F2019ONCA0544.htm&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw30_-n73MQufuUSP32zCVtJ) for details). And [when the Supreme Court of Canada upheld the federal government's carbon pricing regime as constitutional](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fscc-csc.lexum.com%2Fscc-csc%2Fscc-csc%2Fen%2Fitem%2F18781%2Findex.do&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3WeAFa-_CL5wTTybbHxOBg) in a 6-3 ruling in March 2021, the majority decision specifically acknowledged that the common expression "carbon tax" used by many "policy experts" has "no connection to the concept of taxation as understood in the constitutional context."

**However, legal definitions do not always reflect common speech or common sense**, as we've pointed out in our response to formal CBC ombudsman complaints about our use of the expression "carbon tax" in the past. **In 1928, for instance, Canada's top court ruled that the word "person"** in the British North America Act **did not include women.** A more recent example is found in **Ontario's 2016 Trespass to Property Act**, which **says the noun "premises" includes water and motor vehicles.** The wording of [Section 1 (1) of the trespassing law](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ontario.ca%2Flaws%2Fstatute%2F90t21&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3YHKgj_IM2F4zwmUbz8vzx) is a convenient way to cover a wide swath of prohibitions (e.g., it's illegal to swim in a neighbour's pool, or to get into someone else's car, without permission). But it's also a highly unorthodox use of the term "premises" — and one that we would not embrace in our journalism. Put another way: If a CBC reporter described automobiles as "premises," the script would almost certainly be revised, regardless of how the same word is defined in various legal contexts. **At the end of the day, just because a court states that the word "tax" has a relatively narrow, legal definition does not mean that this legal definition is preferred at large.**

**CBC News continues to use the established expressions "carbon tax" and "carbon levy' interchangeably because we think this language is accurate and clear — mirroring everyday usage.** Furthermore, as already noted in Point No. 2 above, economists have used the word "tax" in an equally broad way for years, which makes a compound such as "carbon tax" more than merely colloquial. **It's OK to mention a specific court's comments about a term such as "tax" when it's relevant to given coverage**, and when it's practical (i.e., when there's room in a given story), but it's also important to remember that judges are not the final arbiters of established, acceptable English usage in our journalism.

See also [climate change](/home/c/climate-change)


### Catholic Roman

**Catholic versus Roman Catholic**

Roman Catholics acknowledge the Pope as the head of their church.
**
Generally use Roman Catholic on first reference when specifically excluding Eastern-rites Catholic churches**, such as Eastern Orthodox, Polish National Catholic, Lusitanian (Portugal) and Philippine Independent Catholic.

**But Roman is not necessary if it's obvious from the context** (e.g., "The Catholic school board" is OK, even in the lead).

See also [Church versus church](/home/c/church)



### cattle

**Cattle**

We don't need to define common labels such as cow in news stories. But we do need to use ranching terms correctly.

> **cattle:** A generic word that includes cows, bulls, heifers and steers.
>
> **cow:** A mature _female_ bovine.
>
> **bull:** An uncastrated _male_ bovine.
>
> **calf:** A young bovine (_male_ or _female_).
>
> **heifer:** A young _female_ bovine (usually one that has not borne a calf).
>
> **steer:** A castrated _male_ bovine.
>
> **beef:** The flesh of a cow, steer or bull used as food.
>
> **veal:** The flesh of a calf used as food.


**Avoid phrases such as "a herd of cows"** unless you're sure there are no steers among them. The safest choice is **"a herd of cattle."**

Remember: A significant number of rural Canadians listen to, watch and read CBC News. They complain when we're inaccurate or sloppy about farming language.

See also [animals](/home/a/animals) for capitalization guidelines (_Angus_ cattle but _angora_ rabbit)
See also [mad cow disease](/home/m/mad-cow-disease)

### CBC

**CBC**

The **Canadian Broadcasting Corporation** may be referred to as **the CBC** throughout stories. It's not wrong to spell it out, but it's also not necessary. If shortened versions of the proper name are used in second or later references, they should be lowercase (e.g., the corporation, the broadcaster, Canada's public broadcaster).

**The definite article** (_the_) **can be dropped in headlines, but should generally appear in the main text of online news stories when the abbreviation functions as a noun** (e.g., "_The CBC plans special coverage_" not "_CBC plans special coverage_"), **including in many possessive constructions** (e.g., prefer "The CBC's Jane Smith reports"). **But to keep our broadcast journalism conversational, there is more latitude on air** (e.g., "CBC's investigation" and "CBC's Jane Smith reports" are acceptable). **Compound nouns** (CBC News) **and adjectival forms take articles only when normal rules of syntax require them** (a CBC reporter; CBC coverage began at noon ET; CBC News obtained the documents last month; the CBC-TV program).


> **CBC** (uppercase; no spaces, hyphens or periods), **the
> ****CBC Radio
> ****CBC-TV** or **CBC Television
> CBC News
> ****CBC News** (refers to the entire news service: television, radio and the internet)
> [**CBCNews.ca**](/home/c/cbc#CBCversusCBCNews) (the CBC's web news service; **the preferred address to promote our online journalism**)
> **CBC.ca** (the CBC's entire English website; the corporation's French's website is Radio-Canada.ca, NEVER "SRC.ca")
> **CBC Sports
> ****CBCSports.ca**


Some other common nouns are:


> **CBC Radio One; CBC Music** (previously known **CBC Radio Two** from 1997 until 2007, and then as **CBC Radio 2** until 2018); **CBC Radio 3**
> **the CBC News Network, CBC NN** (OK in headlines) This 24-hour TV news network was known as CBC Newsworld from 1989-2009.


In news stories, never adopt any of the lowercase versions of the above names that appear in graphics, newspaper ads, television promos and other marketing campaigns (e.g., cbc.ca, cbcradio, cbctelevision, cbcnews, etc.).

> _The IOC was responding to comments in a column on CBCSports.ca._
>
> _After publishing her second novel, she began writing a blog for CBCNews.ca._


For guidelines on attribution such as "**told CBC News,**" see the [Quotes overview](/).

The possessive is CBC News's, as in "CBC News's coverage of the election." See [s' versus s's](/handy-links/punctuation/s-versus-s-s) for details.


**Programs**
The article **"the" is uppercase and italicized before the names of programs only when it's officially part of the title:**

> _The Current_
>
> _The House_


**Otherwise, keep "the" lowercase and in regular type:**

> _the Dragons' Den_
>
> _the Royal Canadian Air Farce_


See also [The versus the](/home/t/the-versus-the) as well as [italics](/handy-links/punctuation/italics) for other relevant guidelines.

**CBC News in titles of newscasts**
**In first reference, generally add _"CBC News"_ to the title of the corporation's television and radio newscasts**, as well as to CBC News Network live news programs that are considered extended newscasts. Use italics.

> _CBC News: Now_
>
> _CBC News: The National_
>
> _CBC News: The World at Six_
>
> _CBC News: The World This Hour_


Second reference:

> _Now_
>
> _The National_
>
> _The World at Six_
>
> _The World This Hour_


**Do not add _"CBC News"_ to the titles of CBC News Network programs that are not considered newscasts.** Such shows are either normally not live (e.g., current affairs programs first broadcast on another network) or are live but include the names of hosts in their titles. Use italics.

> _Power & Politics_ (title conventionally does not include host's name in first reference)
>
> _The Nature of Things_ (not a CBCNN original, live broadcast)
>
> _The Passionate Eye_ (not a CBCNN original, live broadcast)


For general guidelines on use of "&" versus "and" (e.g., A&W versus the Globe and Mail), see [ampersand](/home/a/ampersand). For an overview on regular versus slanted type, see [italics](/handy-links/punctuation/italics).

**Text versus logos (Generally use standard capitalization)**
**In web news stories, generally avoid adopting unorthodox capitalization of programs.** For instance:

> _W5 used to be called W-Five_ (not "W-FIVE")
>
> _Play_ (not ">play")
>
> _Counterspin_ (not "counterSpin")
>
> _Nova_ (not "NOVA")


**Be aware of corporate preferences for branding capitalization preferences.** For example, _the fifth estate_ was referred to as "_the fifth estate_" for decades until capital letters were reintroduced in 2017, and then again replaced with lowercase letters in 2025. The CBC Radio program _Q_ was known as "_q_" from 2015 until 2021. Use the current capitalization regardless of the time period cited.

**Do not take capitalization direction from graphics, logos or marketing material** such as posters, coffee mugs and shirts. That's because **we write words** (CBC News and CBC Radio) **not logos** ("cbcnews" or "cbc radio") in our journalism.

**Apply the same principle to channels and networks.** For instance: Bold (not "bold") for the digital channel that replaced CBC Country Canada in 2008.

**This is consistent with our approach to recasting unorthodox capitalization used by other companies.** For example, we write Adidas (not adidas), Amtrak (not AMTRAK), Ikea (not IKEA), Nasdaq (not NASDAQ), Scrabble (not SCRABBLE), Via Rail (not VIA Rail), Visa (not VISA), etc. **We follow unusual capitalization of a few public figures' names, but only if widespread usage has established the exception** (e.g., e.e. cummings and k.d. lang).

See also [quirky capitalization](/home/q/quirky-capitalization), [names versus logos](/home/n/names-versus-logos), [italics](/handy-links/punctuation/italics) in broadcast titles and [The versus the](/home/t/the-versus-the).

For a detailed look at CBCNews.ca's switch to _internet_ and _web_ in the fall of 2003, see the Words: Woe & Wonder column "[i for an I and other capital punishment](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews2%2Findepth%2Fwords%2Finternet_i.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0f1hPq1UK33wYvMaaDnnRq)."

**CBC.ca vs. CBCNews.ca**
**The corporation's entire internet service should be referred to as CBC.ca** (e.g., _The attack shut down most major media websites in North America, including CBC.ca_). **Do NOT use it as a synonym for CBCNews.ca**, which is the name of the CBC's online news service (e.g., _Her first public reaction to the allegation appeared in a column on CBCNews.ca_).

When web addresses are reproduced, they can be lowercase (www.cbc.ca), but this almost never happens on the news site. Normally a link's pathway is hidden under the text we choose to put in HTML code.

Generally leave the slash (/) out of CBC names cited in our journalism:


> **CBC Digital Archives**
>
> **CBC.ca Kids**
>
> **Kids' CBC** (for preschoolers)


Apply this style to specific components of CBCNews.ca as well. For instance:


> **CBCNews.ca Arts**
>
> **CBCNews.ca Health**


Such nouns function as the names of units or services rather than as cyberspace locations.

Different guidelines apply to rare cases when specific web addresses are reported as text (rather than being embedded as HTML in links):

> _Preston Manning's CBC Radio project This I Believe was based on a 1950s program hosted by Edward R. Murrow, who died decades before the interactivity of the web made instant contributions to sites like cbc.ca/thisibelieve possible._


For details, see [URL](/home/u/urls). Peripheral background can also be found under [internet terms](/home/i/internet-terms).

### centre versus center

**Centre versus Center**

**The generic (lowercase) word is always spelled “centre.”

Use “er” only in the proper names of** (mostly) **U.S. buildings, organizations, etc.**


> _Centre of Forensic Sciences_ (Toronto)
> _Hummingbird Centre
> __Munk Centre for International Studies
> __Rockefeller Center
> __U.S. National Hurricane Center
> __U.S. national Centers for Disease Control and Prevention_ (lowercase "national" and plural “Centers”)
> _World Trade Center_ (_WTC_ is fine in headlines or second reference)


**Be aware that anomalous Canadian spellings of proper nouns surface periodically.** We normally use the source's rendering (e.g., "Center") as long as it's determined to be the formal, established name:


> _Canadian Center for Vaccinology_ (Halifax-based research facility founded in 2007)


**In second reference, lowercase "centre" would still be used** in these cases. To avoid needless spelling clashes within the same story, a different generic noun should be considered (e.g., research lab, health unit, music hall, theatre), depending on whatever words apply.

See also [defence, labour and centre](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/d/defence-labour-and-centre/ "Defence labour and centre") for why U.S. government departments that feature American spellings of the words "defence" and "labour" are handled differently (e.g., U.S. Defence Department rather than "Defense").
See also [spelling](/home/s/spelling) (an overview).

### chair

**Chair**

**Generally keep lowercase**, including before names:


> _The board's chair is expected to resign.
> English department chair Himari Tanaka called it indefensible plagiarism._


The **main exceptions are specific research positions treated as proper nouns** based on unique, identified endowments:


> _The [Canada Research Chairs](/home/c#CRC) program.
> The university's Canada Research Chair in Indigenous Law agreed.
> She is the Ontario Research Chair in Bioethics at Queen's University._



**Prefer gender-neutral form**
To avoid sexist language (e.g., referring to a woman as a “chairman”), **the CBC prefers the neutral and increasingly common noun “chair” in general contexts:**


> _She’s been the board’s chair for the past two years.
> __He was appointed chair of the committee in 2003._


**Another option is to pick a different word, such as “head.”

Chair is also fine as a verb:**


> _She chaired the meeting._


**Chairman, chairwoman, chairperson**
**Although “chair” is preferred, it’s OK to use “chairman” or “chairwoman” if the sex of the person is known.**

The term “chairperson” is less common than “spokesperson.” It’s also unnecessary (unless transcribing direct quotations) because “chair” is shorter and equally neutral.

**Warning: It’s inconsistent to use “chairman” for men and “chair” for women in the same news story. So pick one form** and stick with it from beginning to end.

See also [spokesperson](/home/s/spokeperson)

### chemical names

**Chemical names, elements, abbreviations**

Prefer the known over the obscure. When using terms from the worlds of chemistry, biology, etc., this often means words (**sugar** rather than **C12H22O11**) but can mean letters when the shorthand is better known (**DNA** rather than **deoxyribonucleic acid**).

In some cases, technical abbreviations are fine in headlines and second reference (**CO2** for **carbon dioxide**) because they have become common. But be careful to use the correct term. **CO**, for example, is short for **carbon monoxide** — a colourless, odourless toxic gas. Many people have **CO detectors** in their homes.

Even when an abbreviation will be recognized, exercise judgment. While a term such as **H2O** is immediately understood to mean **water**, it is not conversational and is usually reserved for humorous effect.

See also [scientific names](/home/l/latin-scientific-names) in Latin

### child\_pornography

**Child pornography**

The term child pornography has previously been legally and conventionally used in Canada and elsewhere to describe content of a sexual nature involving minors. However, **it is a phrase now best used only with direct attribution and not as shorthand**. This means, for example, that “child porn” should not be used in headlines or banners.

Importantly, as of Oct. 10, 2025, **the term child pornography no longer exists in the Criminal Code of Canada. It has been replaced by “child sexual abuse and exploitation material.”

**This means it is no longer accurate to say that someone in Canada has been charged with making, possessing, distributing or accessing child pornography. Rather, it would be important to specify that the charge is making, possessing, distributing or accessing child sexual abuse and exploitation material. You might consider contextualizing for audiences by briefly mentioning that the charge used to be known as child pornography.
**This also reflects the language choice of many international agencies to avoid using the term.** For example, the Luxembourg Guidelines, established by a working group of 18 organizations including Interpol, Unicef and the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights state:

The term “child sexual abuse material” is increasingly being used to replace the term “child pornography.” This switch of terminology is based on the argument that sexualised material that depicts or otherwise represents children is indeed a representation, and a form, of child sexual abuse, and should not be described as “pornography.”

However, **the phrase child pornography may be appropriate when referencing, with direct attribution, quotations from people or other documents that still use the term.** For example, it is still used in the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child and in the United Nations Optional Protocol on the Sale of Children, Child Prostitution and Child Pornography. **It may also be accurate to use the term in reference to charges that were laid before the update to the Criminal Code of Canada.**

Caveats to keep in mind when covering stories involving this type of content:

-   Follow all relevant JSP policy, including guidelines covering taste, the depiction of violence and audience warnings.

-   Ensure that explicit material has been suitably censored if incorporated into stories. It's illegal to possess, publish or broadcast child sexual abuse and exploitation material. When in doubt, check with the CBC legal team.

-   Be clear but exercise restraint with descriptions, leaving out gratuitous detail when describing content that is, or is alleged to be, child sexual abuse and exploitation material.

-   Avoid slang like "kiddie porn" outside of directly transcribed quotes. Such informal colloquialisms can introduce a tone that's inappropriate and offensive.

-   Recognize that the modifier "child" can be confusing or misleading when the victims are close to 18. (See [child, teen, young adult, etc.](/home/c/child_teen) for related guidelines on age ranges.)

-   The word [pedophile](/home/p/pedophile) is OK when the facts fit (i.e., a perverse sexual attraction to young, usually prepubescent, children). But avoid the expression "convicted pedophile," which is inaccurate, since pedophilia is not a crime one can be charged with in Canada.

See also [child prostitute (avoid)](/home/c/child_prostitution) as well as [pornography, porn](/home/p/pornography/) (an overview)

### child\_prostitution

**Child prostitute (avoid), child sex trafficking**

**Distinguish between prostitution involving adults and "prostitution" involving people under 18**. The former has been at the centre of public policy debates in Canada over the decades, with voices for and against legalization. The latter, by contrast, has been universally decried by legislators as vile sexual exploitation.
