**The term "child prostitution" is increasingly viewed as inappropriate and outmoded.** It still appears in some proper nouns (e.g., the international group ECPAT stands for "End Child Prostitution and Trafficking"), but law enforcement language in many jurisdictions has shifted. **Always frame stories in ways that make it clear the children are victims** in what is essentially human trafficking and assault. **Expressions like "child sex trafficking" and "child sexual exploitation" are often preferred** because the language stresses enslavement and abuse in a way that the word "prostitution" alone may not convey (e.g., a biker gang is accused of running a "child sex trafficking ring" rather than a "child prostitution ring").

**Avoid wording that even indirectly suggests youths in the sex industry are willing participants rather than exploited prey**. In particular, **do not use labels like "child prostitute," "underage prostitute," "teen prostitute," etc.**, unless attributed (e.g., in witness testimony or other quotes). For starters, there's the legal issue of consent. No one under 16 can agree to sex with an adult in Canada, and those between 16 and 18 cannot agree under various conditions (e.g., when the person is a guardian or in a position of authority). Furthermore, **terms like "child prostitute" characterize minors in misleading ways**. Such language can wrongly imply that young people trapped in the horrors of the sex trade are entrepreneurs voluntarily selling their bodies rather than manipulated and abused victims. **Calling kids who are being assaulted "prostitutes" is as inapt as referring to the victims of child pornography as "pornographers."**

In addition to exercising care with descriptions of exploited youths, we should be as precise as possible with how we label the adults involved. **People who pay to have sex with minors are child abusers not "clients."** This applies anywhere in the world. **Avoid expressions like "child sex tourism" and "child sex tourists,"** which are flippant and unsuitable descriptions of predatory assault.

The Criminal Code of Canada has included a section on human trafficking since 2005, as well as specific sections to try to deal with **child sex traffickin**g since 2014 — as outlined in the [Protection of Communities and Exploited Persons Act](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.justice.gc.ca%2Feng%2Frp-pr%2Fother-autre%2Fc36fs_fi%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3Himd2Sjuh44BFv9pDwVW-) passed by Parliament that year. Be aware, however, that these crimes can be difficult for prosecutors to prove in court. So **various prostitution-related charges are sometimes laid against accused traffickers** (e.g., kidnapping, assault, sexual assault, sexual exploitation, forcible confinement, extortion, living off the avails of prostitution). **For accuracy, always report specific charges that apply in a given case.
**
See also [child pornography](/home/c/child_pornography), [pedophile](/home/p/pedophile) and [non-consensual sex](/home/n/non-consensual-sex)

See also [child, teen, young adult, etc.](/home/c/child_teen) (for guidelines on age ranges)

For historical perspective on legislation and public policy debates over "juvenile prostitution" and "child prostitution" in Canada, see the [Library of Parliament's overview of Bill C-36](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Flop.parl.ca%2Fsites%2FPublicWebsite%2Fdefault%2Fen_CA%2FResearchPublications%2FLegislativeSummaries%2F412C36E%23a28&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw19Ib1g3_RMZtsl2HqVL8HU), which led to 2014 Criminal Code amendments.

For background on efforts to combat human trafficking in Canada, including the sexual exploitation of children, see Public Safety Canada's 2019 [National Strategy To Combat Human Trafficking](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.publicsafety.gc.ca%2Fcnt%2Frsrcs%2Fpblctns%2F2019-ntnl-strtgy-hmnn-trffc%2Findex-en.aspx&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2EL18R0zwE7rbLFffW3Sf5).

### child\_teen

**Child, teen, young adult, etc.**

[General terms](/home/c/child_teen#child-teen-etc) (child, teen, senior, etc.)

[On the cusp caveat](/home/c/child_teen#cusp-caveat) (Avoid labels that mislead)

**Overview**

**Age ranges can be challenging to describe.** One pitfall: Applying gender-specific terms (e.g., boy, girl) to people who object to binary classifications. Another problem: Our language's inability to convey certain subtleties in a single word. Life simply isn't as straightforward as a **boy** or a **girl** suddenly becoming a **man** or a **woman**.

**The vocabulary we draw on depends on a given story's facts.** It includes **young man** and **young woman, youth, teen**, etc. The term "tween" has started to catch on to describe those in preadolescence, although it's still not instantly understood by all. **[Tween](/home/t#tween)** also packs an informal tone that's not ideal in certain coverage.

**The rest of this entry outlines common options** based on entrenched CBC News practice as well as a survey of various sources, including Statistics Canada documents, dictionaries and demographic glossaries. **It also flags potential editorial problems certain wording can cause** in some cases.


**General terms**  (child, teen, senior, etc.)

There are **no universally agreed on definitions**. Judgment is required on a case-by-case basis. But **the following guidelines provide broad direction:**


> **1 year and under** — **Baby** or **infant**. (The term "newborn" is generally reserved for those under 2 months.)
>
> **2 to 3** (roughly) — **Toddler** (Implies new to walking) or **child**, as well as **girl** or **boy**.
>
> **12 and under** — **Child** (gender neutral), as well as **girl** or **boy**.
>
> **16 and under** — **Girl** or **boy**, as well as **teenager when applicable** (older than 12).
>
> **15 to early 20s** — **Youth**. But be aware it's a vague word. "Youth" can imply people under 15 in some contexts (e.g., a 13-year-old prosecuted under Canada's [Youth Criminal Justice Act](/home/y#youthjustice)). While the United Nations defines "youth" as 15 to 24, "young adult" is usually a clearer expression for those over 18 and under 25 in Canada.
>
> **13 to 19** — **Teen** or **teenager** (but see [cusp caveat](/home/c/child_teen#cusp-caveat) below for those over 17).
>
> **18 to early 20s** — **Young people, young adults** (e.g., old enough to vote but not to drink in some jurisdictions), as well as the gender-specific nouns **man** and **woman** when applicable.
>
> **18 and over** — **Adults** (e.g., "A youth who will be tried as an adult"), although see [cusp caveat](/home/c/child_teen#cusp-caveat) below, as well as the gender-specific nouns **man** and **woman** when applicable.
>
> **65 and above** — **Senior**. Technically, Canadians can qualify for reduced Canada Pension Plan benefits as early as 60. But 65 is when Old Age Security payments begin. Be aware that some people object to being called "senior" or "senior citizen." Alternatives include **older adults, older men and women, elders, elderly people**, etc. Words like **retiree** may also be OK, depending on the facts (e.g., some people continue to work well after 65, while others leave the labour force before 50).



**On the cusp caveat**  (Avoid labels that mislead)

**Connotation carries weight. While certain terms may be technically accurate** (e.g., a 19-year-old is still a teenager), **they can also unnecessarily telegraph a different meaning out of context** (e.g., in a headline or lead paragraph).

A **common source of confusion** is **when people are on the cusp of moving from one demographic tier to another** (e.g., a young teenager, a young adult, a young senior). **In these cases, it's often best to use nuanced language.**


> **EXAMPLE 1:** In the summer of 2019, Canadian authorities launched a massive hunt for two murder suspects accused of killing three people in B.C. Early reports referred to a search for "two teens." But the **suspects were 18 and 19**. And to some people, headlines about "teenage murder suspects" implied the fugitives were younger. **In cases like this, labels such as "teen" and "teenager" are considered poor choices by many**, especially when there is no context (e.g., in a headline). **Instead, "young men" is clearer**, with specific ages reported as high up in stories as practical.
>
> **EXAMPLE 2:** The term **[child pornography](/home/c/child_pornography) has a legal meaning** in Canada. It refers to unlawful images of people under 18. **But "child" also conventionally implies those 12 and under.** In news coverage, therefore, **saying someone is accused of having "nude pictures of children" on his computer is not automatically the clearest way to report a story.** If the victims are 17 or 16, for instance, "children" is not the best choice. Alternatives such as "teens" or "youths" or "minors" or "girls/boys" (depending on known facts) would be clearer.


**Do not use the terms "[child prostitute](/home/c/child_prostitution)" and "underage prostitute,"** which are inaccurate and misleading.


**Specific ages**

In some stories, it can be **helpful to our audience to report how old people are, especially in police and court reporting**, as well as in features. Otherwise, the detail is not always relevant. Use your judgment.

**Never add an age unless you're certain it's accurate.** Bear in mind that **quick calculations based only on birth years are unreliable**. Specific months and dates are needed, too. **For this reason, ages added to obits require extra care.** In example 1 above, for instance, the younger fugitive turned 19 about a week after the search began.

Ages can be reported in various ways — e.g., in hyphenated compounds (e.g., "The 30-year-old started playing cello when he was four") to figures alone (e.g., "Kogawa, 84, was born in Vancouver"). See our [numbers overview](/home/n/numbers#ages) for typographical guidelines.


### Church

**Church versus church**

**Capitalize "church" only in names of religions and buildings:**

the _Anglican Church_, the _Roman Catholic Church_ (denominations)
_an Anglican church, a Catholic church_ (generic description of buildings)
_but St. Ansgar Lutheran Church_ (specific name of building)
the _Roman Catholic and Anglican churches_ (plural construction)
He said, _"We must keep church and state separate."_


**Keep "church" lowercase when used alone as a synonym for a specific institution:**

the _United Church's_ revitalization committee
the _church's_ revitalization committee
the schools were run by the _Catholic Church_
the schools were run by the _church_
the _Catholic Church_ opposes abortion
the Pope says the _church_ opposes abortion

**Other houses of worship
****The same rules apply to other houses of worship (halls, mosques, synagogues, etc.):**

_hall_, but _Jehovah’s Witness Kingdom Hall_
_mosque_, but _Jami Mosque_
_synagogue_, but _Beth Emeth Bais Yehuda Synagogue_

**Avoid misnaming buildings** (e.g., calling a synagogue or mosque a "church"). Be aware that some religions consider a "church" a building rather than a group or community of followers. It's the reason, for example, that [Jehovah's Witnesses](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/j/#JW "J") refer to their places of worship as Kingdom Halls. 

**Use full names to avoid confusion**
**Some religions/churches have very similar names. In these cases, always spell out the full, proper nouns** if both names are being referred to in the same story or if there might otherwise be confusion.

_the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints_ ([Mormons](/home/m/mormon-mormonism)) versus the _Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints_

See also [capitalization](/home/c/capitalization)

### CJD

**Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease**

This is the name given to **human spongiform encephalopathy**, a fatal illness characterized by [dementia](/home/d/dementia).

The abbreviation **CJD** is acceptable in news stories but it **must be defined**.

A specific type, known as **variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease** or **variant CJD**, is the form related to mad cow disease. [Do not use italics](/handy-links/punctuation/italics).

See also [mad cow disease](/home/m/mad-cow-disease)

### climate change

**Climate change versus global warming**

There's **no doubt the planet is warming.** There's also indisputable evidence that humans have accelerated the trend. The biggest debates now are over how quickly average global temperatures will rise, how devastating the fallout will be, and what specific steps should be taken to combat climate change. It's worth noting that some people wrongly cite short-term weather fluctuations like unseasonable cold snaps to try to downplay global warming. But **weather is not the same as climate.
**
**Weather refers to local atmospheric conditions**, such as temperature, wind and humidity, **at a given moment in time.** Meteorologists predict atmospheric conditions using various statistical models. Such **weather forecasts are typically short-term** (hourly, daily, weekly). **Climate refers to statistically meaningful averages of local atmospheric conditions** (i.e., weather) **collected over many years**.

**Climate change is a broad term that refers to established shifts in normal weather patterns**, such as stronger or more frequent storms and higher or lower than seasonal temperatures. **It can be gradual** (over millions of years, based on scientific analysis of rock, glaciers, etc.), **or comparatively more sudden** (statistically measurable over mere decades). **Global warming is one type of climate change.** Ice ages are another. Shifts in the planet's temperature can be caused by natural phenomena, such as volcanic eruptions, or by air pollution, deforestation, etc. In modern times, **global warming conventionally refers to a slow increase in the average temperature of the Earth's surface** (air and water) **closely monitored since the 1960s.**

The **greenhouse effect** is a colloquial but acceptable label that **refers to an increase in carbon dioxide, hydrofluorocarbons and other greenhouse gases in the atmosphere.** While some greenhouse gases are natural (ozone and water vapour), others are not, or at least not in the concentrations now present. **Greenhouse gases trap heat around the planet by reflecting infrared radiation back toward the surface.** If not enough radiation is allowed to escape into space, the planet begins to warm.


**CBC News style**

-   **Climate change** and **global warming** are **fact-based default terms**, which means they always apply. They're often **used interchangeably.** This **entrenched practice is fine**. Since "global warming" implies a rise in temperature, some journalists prefer the broader label "climate change" when reporting on floods, droughts, fiercer or more frequent hurricanes, etc. But because modern climate change is often directly linked to greenhouse gases and the greenhouse effect, global warming is an acceptable synonym in many stories.

-   **Climate crisis** and **climate emergency** are **OK in some cases** as synonyms for "climate change." **But they're not always the best choice, even in second reference.** For example, "climate crisis" could carry a whiff of advocacy in certain political coverage. And in stories focused on short-term disasters like flooding, words like "crisis" and "emergency" might seem better suited to the fast-rising waters that will eventually recede rather than to the creeping, long-term impact of global warming. When considered appropriate, climate crisis and climate emergency do not need to be put in quotation marks or attributed. (See [**crisis**](/home/c/crisis) for general caveats about the word.)

-   **Avoid the term denier** when referring to people who challenge some aspects of climate change research, findings, etc., unless directly attributed (i.e., in transcribed clips). [**Denier**](/home/d/denier) is not merely considered judgmental, it's also perceived as demonizing, akin to calling, say, some creationists "evolution deniers." **Prefer doubter, critic and other neutral language** that better conveys nuanced positions (e.g., someone might express doubts about projected climate change timelines, or might question/criticize how specific climate change data was collected and interpreted). **Another option is to steer clear of labels and use descriptions instead.**

-   **Be careful with expressions like "winners" and "losers"** when writing about climate change. Such language is **generally OK if stories are narrowly focused on, say, specific species**. For example, different types of penguins in Antarctica have been called global warming "winners and losers" because they rely on dissimilar habitats for their survival. (One penguin species that lives along open waters has thrived in recent decades, while another species that primarily inhabits shrinking pack ice has started to die off in significant numbers.) **But when reporting more broadly on geographical regions** (e.g., provinces, countries, hemispheres), **entire economic sectors, etc., labels such as "winners" and "losers" can be perceived as judgmental, overly simplistic and tone deaf**. Generally **avoid wording that suggests walled-off windfalls for some human beings** as the planet inches toward what scientists fear will be a less habitable state. Instead, **prefer fact-based language about specific, projected economic benefits and losses**. For instance, there's a difference between (i) stating that Canada will probably wind up with more farmland as temperatures rise and (ii) characterizing Canada as a potential "climate change winner" because of the additional farmland that's expected. To some people, the latter may appear flippant, at best, because it ignores the dire threat that global warming poses to life on Earth. In this sense, **the sheer scope and seemingly irreversible nature of climate change makes it distinct from the "winners" and "losers" traditionally associated with temporary economic shocks** like regional trade wars, unexpected production shortages and fleeting transportation disruptions.

**A few words about 'green'**
**A generation ago, using "green" to mean "pro-environment" was novel and, so, commonly defined in news stories**. It originally implied opposition to nuclear power stations, according to the Oxford English Dictionary. This use of "green" was coined in West Germany in the early 1970s — most notably with the _Grüne Aktion Zukunft_ (Green Campaign for the Future), and the _Grüne Listen_ (green lists) of election candidates. In North America, meanwhile, the organization Greenpeace was formed around the same time because of concerns over the U.S. military's plan to test nuclear weapons near Alaska.

Within a few years, the colour "green" expanded from relatively narrow concerns about nuclear energy and nuclear weapons to general efforts to protect the planet from pollution, deforestation, overfishing and other threats to ecosystems. This modern sense of the word is **instantly recognized by our audience now**, from generic uses (**green power, greener energy, a green plan**) to proper nouns (the **Green Party**).

See also [carbon pricing, carbon tax, carbon levy](/home/c/carbon_tax_levy)


### cockpit versus flight deck

**Cockpit versus flight deck**

**Prefer the term _cockpit_ over _flight deck_.** Avoid using _flight deck_ unless the story's context makes the meaning immediately clear.

There are two reasons:

**1\. Our audience instantly understands what we mean by cockpit.** _Flight deck_, on the other hand, is not nearly as well known outside the aviation industry. The term could suggest anything from a waiting area on the tarmac (where planes are "on deck") to a viewing space atop the control tower.

**2\. The common word _cockpit_ is easier for our journalists.** It can be conventionally used to describe any aircraft's flight control area. By contrast, the industry jargon "flight deck" generally applies to larger planes only. Referring to a two-seat jet's "flight deck," for example, is absurd.

See also [black box](/home/b#blackbox) (cockpit voice recorder versus flight data recorder)
See also [aircraft names](/home/a/aircraft-names) (Airbus A320 but L-1011)

### Commission, committee, subcommittee

**Commission versus commission, committee, subcommittee**

**Commission
****Capitalize the generic word "commission" in the proper names of government and royal commissions:**

_Canadian Transport Commission
the 1902 Royal Commission on Chinese and Japanese Immigration
the Royal Commission of Inquiry on the Blood System in Canada
the Royal Commission on the Future of Health Care in Canada_

**This applies to compound nouns featuring the commissioner's name:**

_the Krever Commission (into Canada's blood system)
the Romanow Commission (into the future of health care)_


**commission**
**But keep "commission" lowercase for more general references:**

_the transport commission_
_a royal commission into immigration_
_a federal commission into the tainted blood scandal_
_the health-care commission_

**committee, subcommittee**
**Do not capitalize the names of legislative committees or subcommittees:**

_a House of Commons committee
the Commons finance committee
the access to information and ethics committee
a Senate committee
the Senate energy and environment committee
the Senate subcommittee on cities
the U.S. congressional subcommittee on water resources and the environment_

**This applies even in rare cases when long, formal committee names are used:**

_the House of Commons standing committee on finance
the Canadian Senate standing committee on energy, the environment and natural resources
the U.S. House of Representatives transportation subcommittee on water resources and the environment
_
See also [capitalization](/home/c/capitalization) for an overview of related guidelines

### comprise

**Comprise**

To purists, **_comprise_ is simply a fancy way of saying _contain_ or _include_**. It does not mean compose, which deals with formation or creation.

**Parts form the whole** (e.g., "Brass is composed of copper and zinc"). **The whole comprises parts** (e.g., "The small petting zoo comprises goats, lambs, pigs and a variety of fowl"). But individual components never comprise anything. And **nothing is "comprised of" or "contained of" or "included of" anything.**

Although English is evolving, **CBC News prefers to limit _comprise_ to its original meaning — especially since more conversational** and less controversial **options are available, such as _contain_ or _made up of_.**

**
Disputed usage (avoid)**
In 1969, the committee was **comprised of** a dozen Liberals, four Tories and a New Democrat.

**Undisputed (but lofty) usage**
In 1969, the committee **comprised** a dozen Liberals, four Tories and a New Democrat.

**Conversational alternative (preferred)**
In 1969, the committee was **made up of** a dozen Liberals, four Tories and a New Democrat.

The word **include**, by the way, generally suggests that a list is incomplete. In the above example, then, it would be misleading to write: "In 1969, the committee included a dozen Liberals, four Tories and a New Democrat" unless you intended to imply that members of some other (unmentioned) political party were also members.

### confirmed\_presumptive\_tests

**Confirmed versus presumptive medical cases**

In epidemiology, **doctors routinely distinguish between people who appear to have an infection**, disease, etc., **and those who definitely have it.
**
We should **be as clear as possible in tallies, especially when covering [epidemics and pandemics](/home/e/endemic-epidemic-pandemic)**[](/home/e/endemic-epidemic-pandemic). such as **[COVID-19](/home/c/coronavirus#novelcoronavirus)**. There's **no need to get bogged down in jargon** (e.g., "presumptive positive"). **But avoid muddling unique labels like "confirmed" and "probable"** **under the single heading of "new" cases**, which can wrongly imply "verified." When covering domestic outbreaks, **it's a good idea to ask local or provincial health authorities to explain the language they're using**.

Here are **some common labels:**


**confirmed cases —** **Verified by a standard lab test**. In most news stories, no other information is required. Be aware that **health officials sometimes distinguish between "confirmed" results from a central testing site** like Canada's National Microbiology Laboratory in Winnipeg **and "[presumptive positive](/home/c/confirmed_presumptive_tests#presumptive)" results from initial, local tests**, especially in the case of new or highly virulent pathogens. **At the start of an outbreak, local tests may not be available**. And even as an outbreak spreads, **not all regions may be equipped to run tests quickly or reliably.**


**people under investigation (PUI) —** This is **a potentially confusing category**. It **often means people who are being monitored and/or tested**. It can also include patients who have tested negative — not because the negative results are in doubt but simply to distinguish individuals who've been tested from those who haven't been tested within a given population. **Whenever practical, get a breakdown of relevant numbers and then use straightforward descriptions** (e.g., "Roughly 5,000 people have been tested"). **Generally avoid PUI and other obscure abbreviations**, especially in broadcast scripts.


**possible cases —** Normally **suggests far less certainty than "probable"** (e.g., no symptoms, only indirect exposure to someone infected). **People in this category might be asked to [self-quarantine](/home/q#quarantine)** for a specific period of time to reduce risk to others, but they won't necessarily be tested unless they start developing certain symptoms.


**probable cases —** Traditionally **less precise than "presumptive positive" cases** (see below). **"Probable" generally implies a high likelihood of a given infection, disease, etc., based on symptoms, a person's recent history** (e.g.. logged travel, known exposure to people who are ill), etc. In news stories, it's important to distinguish between confirmed cases and probable cases.


**presumptive positive —** **OK to shorten to "presumptive" as long as the meaning is clear** from context. **"Presumptive positive" usually implies that a local lab test has been conducted** and that the initial results suggest the person has a given infection, disease, etc. **Under testing protocols for new or for known but highly virulent pathogens, samples are sometimes sent to a designated central lab for verification before cases are officially classified as "confirmed."** This can lead to preliminary totals changing if the second lab's results come back negative. The key takeaway is that **a "presumptive positive" result may turn out not to be a new case**, depending on whether additional testing is done. During epidemics and pandemics, when the number of patients worldwide can surge into the thousands relatively quickly, the importance of these distinctions is magnified.

See also [disease, disorder, illness, etc](/home/d/disease_illness).
See also [health reporting](/home/h/health_reporting) for general guidelines about accuracy, clarity, respect, etc.


### Congos

**Congo-Kinshasa and Congo-Brazzaville**

**There's more than one Congo**, which can make writing about this part of Africa confusing.

Zaire changed its name to the **Democratic Republic of Congo** in 1997. We commonly call it **Congo** (_not_ "the" Congo), based on entrenched convention.

A smaller neighbouring country became **the Republic of Congo** in 1992. (It used to be called "the People's Republic of Congo.") We call it "the Republic of Congo."

Since the two official names are now almost identical, it's easiest to **adopt the local custom of incorporating the name of the capital city after a hyphen in second reference:
**
**Congo**, also known as **Congo-Kinshasa ...**

**The Republic of Congo**, also known as **Congo-Brazzaville ...**

If you're writing about only one of them, you can then drop the reference to the capital city and simply call it "Congo" (not "the Congo") after that.

But if you're writing about both countries, keep using the hyphenated names. In this case, it's also helpful to mention that Congo-Kinshasa was formerly known as Zaire.

See also [The versus the](/home/t/the-versus-the)

### congress

**U.S. Congress**

The **United States Congress** is made up of two bodies: the **House of Representatives** and the **Senate**. The abbreviated form **U.S. Congress** is fine in first reference. **Congress** is OK after that.

**In titles, use capital letters only before names**:


> congressman, congresswoman, congressional
> **Sen.** Frank Mills; Mills, a U.S. **senator** ...
> **Rep.** Cheryl Woods; Woods, a **representative** in the U.S. Congress ...


While it's common and OK to abbreviate the above titles before names, be aware that _Rep._ can be easily confused as shorthand for _Republican_. For this reason, **it's generally helpful to identify a person's political affiliation in stories**:


> **Republican Rep.** Hal Rogers
> **Democratic Sen.** Jay Rockefeller
> **Sen.** Bernie Sanders is an **Independent** from Vermont


There are **many acceptable ways to introduce details like party affiliation or geographical connections**. Common options include:


> **U.S. Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez** (with U.S. optional, depending if the context is already obvious)
>
> **New York Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez** (one of many ways to introduce specific geographical detail)
>
> **Democratic Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez** (with "Democratic" optional)
>
> **Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez** (acceptable in many cases)
>
> **U.S. Rep. Devin Nunes** (with U.S. optional, depending if the context is already obvious)
>
> **Calif. Rep. Devin Nunes** (one of many ways to introduce specific geographical detail)
>
> **Republican Rep. Devin Nunes** (with "Republican" optional)
>
> **Rep. Devin Nunes** (acceptable in many cases)
>
> **U.S. Sen. Elizabeth Warren** (with U.S. optional, depending if the context is already obvious)
>
> **Mass. Sen. Elizabeth Warren** (one of many ways to introduce specific geographical detail)
>
> **Democratic Sen. Elizabeth Warren** (with "Democratic" optional)
>
> **Sen. Elizabeth Warren** (acceptable in many cases)
>
> **U.S. Sen. Lindsey Graham** (with U.S. optional, depending if the context is already obvious)
>
> **South Carolina Sen. Lindsey Graham** (one of many ways to introduce a specific geographical detail)
>
> **Republican Sen. Lindsey Graham** (with "Republican" optional)
>
> **Sen. Lindsey Graham** (acceptable in many cases)


**Party affiliation is also optional when referring to the majority and minority leaders in Congress**, depending on what's already obvious from the context of a given story:


> **House Speaker Nancy Pelosi**
>
> Democratic House Speaker Nancy Pelosi
>
>
>
> **House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy**
>
> Republican House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy
>
>
>
> **Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell**
>
> Republican Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell
>
>
>
> **Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer**
>
> Democratic Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer


**the Capitol, Capitol Hill**
The official building of the U.S. Congress is known as **the Capitol**. It's on **Capitol Hill** in Washington, D.C. The Capitol has two sections: The **Senate**, in the north wing, has 100 members (two from each state, regardless of size). **The House of Representatives**, in the south wing, has 435 members (with the number from each state based on its population).

When the House of Representatives and the Senate meet for special sessions, such as the [state of the union address](/home/s/state-of-the-union), it's known as a "joint session of Congress."

In many ways, mentioning the U.S. Congress in a story is comparable to using the term "Parliament" in Canada, which refers to both the House of Commons and the Senate. There are significant differences, of course. For example: **In the U.S., the executive branch of government** (the White House) **is separate from the legislative branch. In Canada, it's not**. (The government is made up of MPs — the prime minister and the rest of cabinet.)


**capitol, capital**
The term **capitol** (lowercase) is sometimes used to mean legislatures in many, but not all, states.


> South Dakota's governor made the announcement at the state capitol building.


The word **capital** (lowercase) refers to the seat of government in a country, province, state or other region:


> Canada’s capital is Ottawa, where Pierre Trudeau once lived.
>
> South Dakota’s capital is Pierre, but it’s not clear if Trudeau spent any time there.


See also [legislative bodies](/home/l/legislative-bodies)

### constitution

**Constitution versus constitution**

**Use a capital "C" in all references to the _Canadian Constitution_** (e.g., _the Constitution, Canada's Constitution_).

**For other country's constitutions, use a capital "C" only when the word is also used there and it's linked directly to the nation's name** (the _U.S. Constitution_, the _French Constitution_, but "_France plans to amend its constitution._")

**Keep lowercase when it's merely a translation** (_China's constitution_).

**Keep lowercase when referring to the constitutions of unions, clubs, etc.**

**Derivatives are always lowercase** (e.g., constitutional, constitutionally), **even in Canada**: "_They plan a constitutional challenge_," "_Ottawa says it wants to avoid another constitutional crisis,_" etc.

See also [Act versus act](/home/a/act)
See also [capitalization](/home/c/capitalization)

### controversial-team-names

**Controversial team names** (Indians, Eskimos, etc.)

It's **normally OK to use a controversial sports team name once in a story FOCUSED on the proper noun** (e.g., the Atlanta Braves, the Kansas City Chiefs, the Cleveland Indians, the Chicago Blackhawks), to ensure clarity. **But there's no need to use such names in other routine coverage** of wins/losses, championship games, player trades, etc., as long as relevant geographical detail and other context is included. **For example, phrasing such as "the Blue Jays beat Cleveland" was sufficient until the latter franchise formally changed its name to the Guardians** in the fall of 2021, and **references to "Chicago's NHL team" were adequate when allegations of sexual abuse surfaced** against a former video coach.

Even when there's editorial reason to use a widely denounced name, **always exercise restraint** in accordance with the principle of respect enshrined in our Journalistic Standards and Practices policy. In particular, **avoid using the name in headlines**, and **avoid repeating the name throughout a story**. Whenever practical, it's a good idea to **add background about why a given name is considered hurtful and inappropriate as a franchise name** if the language, itself, may not be automatically offensive in certain other contexts.

This approach **also applies to historical references to abandoned franchise names**, such as the [Edmonton Eskimos](/home/i/inuit-and-inuk), a football team called the **Edmonton Elks** since the spring of 2021. There's no reason to use the old name in routine coverage of the Elks.

**Take the direct quotes of others into account** when assessing the impact of names on our audience — i.e., whether people interviewed have used the controversial word(s) in a clip or transcribed quote. In those cases, **there may be no need to add additional references to the proper noun** in a broadcast script or online article.

And **always consider alternative wording** if there's no ambiguity or loss of meaning. For example, compare these approaches to a story about Washington's NFL franchise that officially became the Commanders in 2022:


> ORIGINAL: _The team was known as **the Redskins** for more than 80 years._
>
> REWRITE: _The team's name was a **derogatory reference to the skin colour of Indigenous people** for more than 80 years._



**NOTE:** CBC News recognizes that there is no consensus on how to report on the controversial names of sports teams. As pointed out in a [July 2020 Language Guide update](/updates/2020/2020-07-20) as well as in a [companion iNEWS memo](https://sites.google.com/a/cbc.ca/cbc-news-journalism-portal/home/news/jsp---sports-team-note): We are committed to an on-going review of our current guidelines, revising when appropriate.


See also [racial terms](/home/r/racial-terms) for related style points and caveats.


### coronavirus


**Coronavirus**


[Coronavirus disease](/home/c/coronavirus#COVID) (COVID)

[Covering recovery](/home/c/coronavirus#recovery) (vaccines, etc.)
[Miscellaneous](/home/c/coronavirus#CDC) (CDC, WHO)


**Overview**
**Coronavirus is an umbrella term** for various mild to severe microscopic germs that can cause **everything from the common cold to deadly respiratory illnesses**. First identified in the 1960s, the coronavirus was named for its crown-shaped ("corona") visible under electron microscopes.

There are **several types of coronaviruses**. Some are spread only from animal to animal, while others can be transmitted from animals to people. Within each family, there are different strains, and these, in turn, can mutate over time.

**In coverage of severe outbreaks, it's helpful to point out that standard virulence measurements may change** (e.g., mortality rates, transmission risks and rates) as more data is compiled and assessed. **Be clear about what is known or unknown**, attributing as required. And **be cautious before using words like [epidemic and pandemic](/home/e/endemic-epidemic-pandemic)** unless it's clear the terms apply.


**Novel coronavirus**
If a **new strain** is identified, it's common to hear experts refer to it as a **"novel" coronavirus**. When a coronavirus is initially assigned a name, the **standard short form is "CoV"** along with the year the first case was recorded (e.g., 2019-nCoV). **Be aware that virused may subsequently be renamed** as more data is collected and assessed (e.g., "2019-nCoV" officially became **SARS-CoV-2** in February 2020).

It's **OK to use generic wording** (e.g., "the coronavirus outbreak") **rather than dense, technical labels for specific viruses, as long as a given story's context makes the meaning clear**. In the case of national or global health threats, our audience will probably know what we're talking about pretty quickly. At other times, however, extra detail will be required. **Use your judgment**, but avoid the pitfall of assuming that the word "coronavirus" automatically provides a sufficient degree of precision.

**Whenever practical, it's a good idea to supply brief, relevant background to help distinguish one coronavirus from another** (e.g., where and when it was first recorded). **But avoid incorporating geographical detail into virus or disease names, themselves** (e.g., **do not talk about the "China coronavirus" or the "Wuhan coronavirus"**). This applies to mutations. For example, it's OK to refer to "a coronavirus variant first reported in the U.K.," but **avoid shorthand like "the U.K. variant" or "the South Africa variant."** See COVID below for related options.


**Coronavirus disease (COVID)**
In February 2020, the World Health Organization adopted a new **format for naming respiratory illnesses caused by novel coronavirus outbreaks: COVID** (pronounced "coh-vid"). It stands for "corona" (CO) "virus" (VI) "disease (D). The year the first case is reported is added after a hyphen (e.g., COVID-19, which was first documented in China in the fall of 2019). This format will be a template for naming future coronavirus outbreaks, according to officials. Among other things, it lets them discuss specific illnesses without relying on geographical detail (e.g., the "Wuhan virus" or "the China virus"), which can stigmatize people.

**WHO declared COVID-19 a pandemic in March of 2020**, based on confirmed cases in different parts of the world, as well as sustained or growing transmission rates between humans. Three years later, **in May of 2023, the organization announced that the spreading and mutating COVID-19 virus was no longer a global health emergency**, based on decreased death tolls and hospitalization rates, as well as effective vaccination programs that made managing the ongoing disease possible. **But the pandemic, itself, was not deemed over.** Indeed, many leading infectious disease experts have repeatedly warned that vigilance will be required for the foreseeable future, and that COVID-19, itself, would unlikely ever be eradicated.

**Although we're not required to use formal names like COVID-19 in scripts, such acronyms can be a convenient way of identifying specific global health threats** in stories, as long as the terms are briefly explained until they become commonplace (e.g., we initially said "known as COVID-19" until the noun caught on a few weeks later).

**Avoid calling COVID a "virus."** It's not, just as SARS was not. **COVID is the respiratory illness people get after becoming infected**. It's **OK to use COVID as a modifier** (e.g., "the COVID-19 virus" instead of "SARS-CoV-2"), **just as [SARS](/home/s/sars) and [AIDS](/home/a/aids) can be used as modifiers** (e.g., "the SARS virus" and "the AIDS virus"). **But steer clear of stating or implying that COVID-19 on its own is the name of a virus**, which is inaccurate. Examples:


> _To prevent the spread of COVID-19_ ...     (CORRECT)
> _They've contracted COVID-19_.         (CORRECT)
> _Another case of COVID-19_ ... (CORRECT)
> _The COVID-19 virus is_ ...     (CORRECT because the disease name is a modifier that identifies a specific virus, just like the "smallpox virus")
>
> _The virus, known as COVID-19, is_ ...     (**WRONG**)
> _COVID-19 can live on surfaces_ ...     (**WRONG**)


**KEY TAKEAWAY: Diseases spread. People contract diseases. But diseases aren't viruses, don't cling to surfaces, etc.** If you're uncertain whether using COVID-19 is acceptable in a given sentence, substitute another disease name to see if it makes sense (e.g., measles, Ebola, AIDS). As noted above, **conversational alternatives like "the coronavirus" are often sufficient in stories, especially in second reference**, as long as the term's meaning is clear from context.


**TYPOGRAPHY:** For web writers in particular, the all-caps abbreviation "**COVI**" initially required adjustment, since "**CoV**" has typically been used in the past to mean "coronavirus" (e.g., **SARS-CoV** and **MERS-CoV**). The explanation from WHO officials? COVID-19 refers to a specific "disease" (D) rather than to a "respiratory syndrome" (RS). Such minutia is largely irrelevant in broadcast journalism, with the exception of some TV graphics. But **if you're actually incorporating this level of detail into your journalism, follow established publishing norms** (e.g., "SARS-CoV-2" but "COVID-19").



**Virus variations**
**Viruses commonly mutate during an outbreak**, which may or may not affect transmissibility, illness severity, mortality or a specific vaccination's effectiveness. The names of diseases often stay the same, regardless of virus variations. For instance, there were three distinct types of known, "wild" (naturally occurring) polio viruses in the world in 2018, according to the World Health Organization: Wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1), wild poliovirus type 2 (WPV2) and wild poliovirus type 3 (WPV3). While three different vaccinations needed to be combined into a single treatment in order to try to eradicate the health threat, the disease, itself, has been called "polio," regardless. So **generally prefer constructions like "COVID virus variants" or "coronavirus variants" over "COVID variants" to reflect that the virus (not the disease) is mutating.** While occasional second-reference shorthand to "COVID-19 variants" can be acceptable in a broadcast story as long as the meaning is clear from context, it's better to use the modifier "virus" as our default in our coverage of mutations (**e.g., prefer a TV banner like VIRUS VARIANTS**).

It's **OK to report where and when a new variant surfaced** (e.g., "in South Africa a month ago"). **But steer clear of geographical shorthand when naming mutations** (e.g., prefer "a new coronavirus variant" or "what appears to be a more contagious variant," depending on the facts, rather than "the U.K. variant"). **Including the official names of virus mutations in stories is optional** (e.g., B.1.1.7 and B.1.351). Keep in mind, however, that too many alphanumeric designations can be difficult to digest in TV and radio scripts. Instead, **it's often sufficient to keep wording relatively generic**, depending on the story. NOTE: In late May 2021, [the World Health Organization adopted Greek names for specific COVID-19 virus variants of concern](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.who.int%2Fen%2Factivities%2Ftracking-SARS-CoV-2-variants%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw24XU1z7AYm2uV2TGBGdDJm) (e.g., **Alpha** for B.1.1.7, and **Beta** for B.1.351). **Using words like Alpha and Beta and Omicron as the default name can help keep writing tighter and avoid editorial problems associated with geographical-based designations.** Until new labels like this catch on widely, however, it's a good practice to either report both names in stories when practical (e.g., "the Alpha variant, also known as B.1.1.7") or to define/explain clearly (e.g., "the Beta variant, first reported in South Africa"). Use your own judgment. **Variant mutations are commonly called subvariants or offshoots** (e.g., "an Omicron subvariant").  **It's generally OK to call a significant virus mutation a new [strain](/home/b/bacteria-versus-virus#virus)** AS LONG AS health authorities are also using the term.

**Avoid using informal nicknames** (e.g., the Kraken, Minotaur, Centaurus and other fanciful monikers) **outside of direct attribution** (i.e., a broadcast clip or transcribed web quote). Such unofficial labels are arbitrary, sensational, imprecise and potentially misleading (e.g., a given virus mutation assigned the name of a particularly fearsome mythical creature may turn out to be far less virulent than first assumed). For details, see the January 2023 Language Guide update: [Avoid COVID nicknames like 'the Kraken](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/updates/2023/2023-01-17/ "2023 01 17").'


**TYPOGRAPHY: Follow the punctuation used by the World Health Organization when reporting alphanumeric names assigned to variants** — assuming such dense labels are deemed editorially necessary. Not all figures are followed by periods (e.g., **B.1.1.7** but **B.1.351** and **B.1.617.2**). The designations combine data on genome sequencing, geography, chronology, etc., based on nomenclature rules used by Pango lineages software. (Pango stands for Phylogenetic Assignment of Named Global Outbreak, but this arcane detail is virtually never mentioned, let alone spelled out, in stories.) Be aware that many news organizations initially fused Pango names (e.g., "B117") in late 2020 and early 2021, based on past publishing conventions. However, there was a gradual shift to verbatim renderings of the scientific labels. CBC News officially adopted this style in June of 2021.



**Covering recovery**
The word **"recovered" is commonly used by public health officials to describe people** who've previously tested positive for the COVID-19 virus but **who are no longer ill** (assuming they had noticeable symptoms) **and who are no longer considered contagious** based on locally set criteria (e.g., one or more negative tests and/or the passage of a specific quarantine period). **"Recovered" is generally a good choice** when the facts fit. A participle like **"recovering" might be a more appropriate choice in cases when people experience serious, lingering health problems** for months. The term **"survivor" implies a close brush with death and, so, is usually best reserved for COVID-19 patients who were not only hospitalized but extremely ill** (e.g., in intensive care, intubated). Novel coronaviruses are, by definition, initially unfamiliar. As more data is collected and analyzed, be clear with our audience about what is known/unknown about people's immunity after recovery, about the risk of reinfection, etc.

It's OK to use the expression **COVID-19 vaccine**, even though the vaccine is technically targeting the virus rather than the disease, just as it's common to refer to a polio vaccine, a smallpox vaccine, etc. When reporting on vaccinations, **be clear if treatment requires more than one dose and use whatever qualifying language applies** (e.g., differentiate between the total number of doses administered and the number of people who've been either "partially" or "completely" vaccinated within a country or region's population). Whenever practical, include rudimentary efficacy background (e.g., whether it's known how long the vaccination is expected to last).

**Be clear and accurate when referring to vaccines.** If they've been jointly developed by two or more companies, generally acknowledge this at least once in first reference (e.g., the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine rather than just the "Pfizer vaccine" in headlines and leads). Be aware that vaccine names sometimes undergo rebrandings. See [vaccination](/home/i/immunization-vaccination) for examples and guidelines.


**U.S. Centers for Disease Control**
Technically, it’s the "**U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention**," although it's **common (and acceptable) to shorten this to "U.S. Centers for Disease Control." CDC is fine in second reference**. Note that Centers is plural, and "er" not "re." (We generally use American spellings of proper nouns in the U.S., such as World Trade Center, except in the case of government departments, such as [Labour, not Labor, and Defence, not Defense](/home/d/defence-labour-and-centre)).


**WHO, rarely the WHO**
**Although "WHO" stands for World Health Organization, we do not routinely put an article in front of it.** If it's an adjective, "the" is not automatically added (WHO representative, WHO official, WHO advisory, etc.) "The" can usually be left out of web headlines, too. CP, AP and others have been inconsistent with their use of "the" before WHO functioning as a noun in the main body of stories. **CBC News does not write "the NATO" or "the OPEC" or "the NASA." We rarely have to write "the WHO" either** because it's also an acronym (e.g., "Canadian officials are demanding WHO change its mind.") **Be aware, however, that WHO on its own can sometimes sound more like a pronoun** ("who") **than an abbreviation in broadcast scripts. Adding "the" in those cases is OK.** Using a synonym like "the organization" or "the UN body" is another effective option.

See also [health reporting](/home/h/health_reporting) (diseases, medical conditions, etc.)
See also [bacteria versus virus](/home/b/bacteria-versus-virus)
See also [disease, disorder, illness, etc.
](/home/d/disease_illness)
For answers to FAQs about the COVID-19 outbreak, see coronavirus updates from [WHO](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.who.int%2Femergencies%2Fdiseases%2Fnovel-coronavirus-2019&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw257AbgpO8XvQi41oBotsvr) and [Health Canada](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.canada.ca%2Fen%2Fpublic-health%2Fservices%2Fdiseases%2F2019-novel-coronavirus-infection%2Ffrequently-asked-questions.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3YSPOcKvGgWmNHD2tj7M-2).
For technical details about COVID-19 proper nouns, see WHO's February 2020 post, [Naming the coronavirus disease](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.who.int%2Femergencies%2Fdiseases%2Fnovel-coronavirus-2019%2Ftechnical-guidance%2Fnaming-the-coronavirus-disease-\(covid-2019\)-and-the-virus-that-causes-it&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3xQ7lDAvO6aXB5XXE4EYzf).


### corporation

**Corp. versus Corporation**

Corp. can be used for "Corporation" in business stories or in highly formal contexts (e.g., in a story about a lawsuit that demands specific identification of the parties).

But in general, follow common usage. For example, write either **Canadian Tire** (_instead of_ using its complete name, **Canadian Tire Corp. Ltd.**), or **Ontario Lottery and Gaming Corporation** (with "Corp." spelled out in full) depending on how the nouns are widely known.

Reference to "Corporation" is sometimes dropped from abbreviations (e.g., the Ontario Lottery and Gaming Corporation becomes the OLG not the OLGC). Often, however, it's retained as a central component of the proper noun. For instance, the **Canadian Broadcasting Corporation** and the **British Broadcasting Corporation** (not Corp.) are referred to as "the CBC" and "the BBC" — usually without being spelled out in first reference because the short forms are so well known.

In a few cases, the clipped term "Corp." loses its period and becomes fused to another word based on common usage, such as PotashCorp, which has become the preferred way to refer to the **Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan** in second reference.

See also [CBC](/home/c/cbc)

### Corrections and clarifications

**Corrections and clarifications on CBCNews.ca**

> [Criteria for logging changes](/home/c/corrections-and-clarifications#criterialogging)
>
> [Flash-based interactive files, etc.](/home/c/corrections-and-clarifications#flashbased)
>
> [Criteria for altering date/time stamps](/home/c/corrections-and-clarifications#criteriaaltering)
>
> [Level 1 flaw](/home/c/corrections-and-clarifications#level1)
>
> [Level 2 flaw](/home/c/corrections-and-clarifications#level2)
>
> [Level 3 flaw](/home/c/corrections-and-clarifications#level3) 

**Overview**
**To help maintain the credibility of the CBC's entire news service, WE ALWAYS:**

-   **Strive to report accurately.**
-   **Fix mistakes** in our online journalism as quickly as possible.

This is an obligation, not an option. Since online journalism is archived in a way that broadcast material is not, news staff must take steps to correct editorial flaws on our website once they're aware of them, in accordance with these guidelines. If they're not sure what to do in any given case, they should talk to their supervisor.

**When correcting published content, WE SOMETIMES:**

-   **Flag changes by cataloguing them in a "corrections and clarifications" section** of our website (i.e., edits that merit public acknowledgment, as defined under [criteria for logging](/home/c/corrections-and-clarifications#criterialogging) below).
-   **Highlight the revisions in a box** at the bottom of the story.

**The key consideration is whether readers have been misled** (i.e., if they've probably drawn false conclusions based on the original wording that would leave them with an inaccurate understanding of the story).

**Most minor slips** in spelling, punctuation, capitalization, grammar, etc., and small ambiguities that are simply confusing, **can be corrected without alerting readers.**

The [date/time stamps](/home/c/corrections-and-clarifications#criteriaaltering) at the top of articles are not changed when typos are fixed or other minor corrections are published.

**Entire stories are deleted from our server only under certain conditions**, as specified in a separate policy on [permanently removing editorial content](https://docs.google.com/a/radio-canada.ca/viewer?a=v&pid=sites&srcid=Y2JjLmNhfGxhbmd1YWdlZ3VpZGV8Z3g6MWRmMTdlMmI4M2YzZDI4Ng) from CBC.ca.

**The guidelines below outline the general principles and process for posting corrections on CBCNews.ca. They're intended to offer practical direction in day-to-day decision making as we adhere to the corporation's [Journalistic Standards and Practices policy on corrections](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fio.cbcrc.ca%2F%23%2Fresources%2Fcorrections-corrections-et-clarifications-1.4523122&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1hBNc8o5buNxIeXY0ZLLPh).**


**What we correct**
**We fix all inaccuracies and clarify anything that could reasonably mislead readers, including mixed-up photographs and botched captions.**

But flaws in stories fall across a spectrum. Some are obvious while others are debatable. Some are minor while others can lead to readers drawing the wrong conclusions, lawyers demanding apologies, etc.

For this reason, **revisions are handled in a variety of ways**. So while all discovered mistakes and ambiguities are righted, not all changes are acknowledged through correction notices. (Details can be found in the next section, "How we correct.")

**This Language Guide entry is primarily aimed at text and still images on the web. It does not cover revisions to the television "crawl"** — the brief summaries that move across the bottom of the TV screen during some programs.

**We also do not publish corrections or clarifications about the content of radio or television reports**, unless we have repeated a broadcast item's mistake in a web story (i.e., by incorporating misleading text).

**We may decide to strip audio or video off our website, however**, if a senior CBCNews.ca journalist feels that the recorded content contains an error beyond the equivalent of a typo or mispronunciation. In these cases, the deletion protocols mentioned above apply.


**How we correct**
We fix all problems to the best of our ability, but **we don't publicly log every typo or other minor slip.**


**Criteria for logging**
**We always acknowledge changes to stories** in our corrections and clarifications section **when instructed to do so by our legal department.**

**Otherwise, we generally highlight revisions only if** both of the following two conditions are met:

1.  **Readers could not be reasonably expected to recognize the blunder or inconsistency themselves.** (For instance, if we misspelled Pierre Elliott Trudeau's middle name or published a map that referred to Mumbai as Bombay, a correction notice would **not** be required.)


2.  **The original mistake or ambiguity could _mislead_ readers** (e.g., _change the meaning_ of the text or _skew the interpretation_ of the photographs in question).
    In these cases, we clearly summarize the revision or revisions by publishing the date and details in a box at the bottom of each altered article.

For direction on judging whether readers have been misled, see "[Three categories of mistakes](/home/c/corrections-and-clarifications#3categories)" below.

**How much time has passed between initial publication and revision (e.g., five seconds versus five hours) is irrelevant when deciding whether to publish a correction.** Given the nature of cached files on the web, a published error should be considered a published error — regardless of how quickly it is fixed.

This principle reinforces the serious responsibility associated with posting any content on CBC.ca. As with broadcasting, electronic publishing must not be approached lightly, with the cavalier and unacceptable attitude that mistakes can be quickly fixed later without anyone knowing.


**Flash-based interactive files, etc.**
**When fixing photo galleries, interactive maps, etc., it's sufficient to publicly acknowledge revisions on our site's central corrections and clarifications page only.** We do not need to add corrections boxes to Flash-based formats. The same approach it is taken with alerts, which cannot be revised after being issued through mass emailings and other delivery mechanisms.

**CBC.ca-generated podcasts, or any non-text-based content we produce that cannot be easily fixed after being published, are handled in a similar fashion.** Mistakes that would normally be flagged if they were in the form of text must be acknowledged on the main corrections and clarifications page. But we do not need to attach a correction notice to such CBC.ca-produced audio/video files (e.g., in the form of a pop-up window).

Of course, in addition to flagging the flaw on the central corrections and clarifications page, we may decide to permanently remove the podcast or other offending material from our website, according to the formal deletion protocols cited in the overview above.


**Criteria for altering date/time stamps**
The purpose of our date/time stamp is to let readers know when an article was first published, and when new information was last added or old information last updated. It's not intended to record every corrected typo, every broken link that's been repaired, etc.

**We revise a "current" story's date/time stamp only when fixing mistakes that change the meaning of an article.** "Current" is defined as less than 24 hours old.

**We virtually never revise an "archived" story's date/time stamp because these are not true "updates" of current coverage.** We do, however, make it clear to our readers that we have fixed a significant mistake in an archived story by publishing the date and brief details of a correction in a box at the bottom of the article. "Archived" is defined as more than 24 hours old. (For more details, see [archived stories below](/home/c/corrections-and-clarifications#changing).)


**Three categories of mistakes**
This section illustrates how the above policy is applied in practice.

When deciding how to handle corrections and clarifications, **we first determine which of three broad categories the flaws fall into:**


**Level 1 flaw (Most typos and stylistic inconsistencies)**

**Examples**: Accidentally typing "thier" or even "there" instead of "their," dropping the "s" in U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, failing to use a CBC.ca preferred spelling when more than one option exists (e.g., wrongly picking "advisor" instead of adviser), mixing up the names of the Great Lakes in a map, and inconsistently using capitalization, French accents, etc.

Such mistakes are undesirable and can even be quite embarrassing, but they have no potential to mislead readers. **Level 1 Flaws do not need to be publicly logged** (i.e., published in a box at the bottom of the article), even when the gaffe is high-profile (e.g., "pubic" instead of "public" schools in a headline or lead).

When stories are fixed this way, **the date/time stamps do not need to be changed**. This is the equivalent of a newspaper replating a page on the fly, as the presses roll out the first edition, or a national TV unit replacing a bad shot in an item before it's broadcast in the next time zone.


**Level 2 flaw (A seemingly minor error that might mislead)**

**Examples**: Misspelling one MP's name in such a way that the person could be confused with another MP, or implying that a photograph is more recent than it really is.

Normally, fixed typos and the like do not need to be logged. But in cases **when the mistake might mislead people, the change should be flagged on the corrections page as well as in a box at the bottom of the article.**

For example, spelling MP Sherri McDonald as Sherry Macdonald would normally be a Level 1 flaw. But under certain conditions it might be elevated to a Level 2 (e.g., if there happened to be someone with a similar name, such as an MP called Shirley Macdonald, who could be easily confused for the person we intended to identify in our original coverage).

And if the date is missing from an old photo that's been republished in a fresh story, readers might draw the wrong conclusion about what they assume is a recent image (e.g., a stock picture of boats legally setting lobster traps in season added to a story about fishermen threatening to set traps out of season). If, on the other hand, the missing date would probably not cause anyone to misinterpret the image, the incomplete information could simply be treated as a Level 1 flaw, and the detail could be added to the caption without flagging the clarification.

**Deciding whether to publicize this type of correction or clarification requires a ruling by a senior online journalist** — usually the person in charge of the web space where the content was originally published. At least one senior producer should be notified of all Level 2 flaws, and participate in the decision-making process about whether to acknowledge the edit.

**When stories are fixed in this way, the date/time stamps do not need to be changed.** If it's felt that the old version might have misled readers, however, **a separate corrections box outlining the date and details of the change should be included at the bottom of the article**, in addition to being noted on the corrections page.


**Level 3 flaw (An error that either does mislead or could easily mislead)**

**Examples**: Stating that a study was published by Heritage Canada (a charitable foundation) instead of Canadian Heritage (a federal government department), transposing two numbers in a budget figure ($398 million instead of $938 million), or dropping the word "not" before "guilty" in an acquittal we initially report as a conviction.

**Such errors in fact are virtually always acknowledged, although the final ruling rests with a senior online journalist** (usually the person in charge of the web space where the content was originally published). The key consideration is whether readers have been misled. Normally, a managing editor or executive producer participates in the decision-making process about whether to acknowledge the edit. At the very least, a senior producer is involved.

**When "current" stories** (less than 24 hours old) **are fixed in this way, the date/time stamps are normally changed** because the revision adds new/different information.

**A separate corrections box outlining the date and details of the change, should generally be included at the bottom of the altered article**.

**Level 1 flaws** are the easiest to handle (i.e., fix the mistake but don't advertise the change) because it's clear that readers have not been misled.

**Level 2 flaws** are in some ways the trickiest because it's not immediately obvious whether readers have been misled.
**Level 3 flaws** tend to be the clearest (and often the most serious) botch-ups.


**Updates versus corrections**
**It is crucial to distinguish between evolving details and mistakes.** For example, reporting an Al Jazeera claim that some Canadian soldiers had been taken hostage in Afghanistan would NOT constitute a CBC.ca error if Al Jazeera's story ended up being wrong — as long as our initial article was clearly attributed.

If it turned out that no Canadian soldiers were taken hostage, we would simply post an updated version of the story pointing out that Ottawa had denied Al Jazeera's bogus report.

Of course, information such as the original Al Jazeera claim should never be posted by us if we have any reason to believe it's false at the time of publication. See [Wire copy on CBC.ca](/home/w/wire-copy) for relevant rules governing the use of other news organizations' material in our journalism.


**Authorizing correction notices**
All CBCNews.ca staff involved in publishing a story can fix errors or clarify ambiguity in the article as part of their normal working routine — as long as these revisions are sent through the central copy desk. But **all substantive corrections to articles already published** (i.e., beyond minor typos) **must be brought to the attention of the senior digital journalist (executive producer or higher)** in charge of that web space.

If the CBC's Legal Department directs us to publish a correction, we will comply immediately.

In all other cases, decisions are based on criteria in the guidelines already outlined above.

**When ruling on debatable cases, we should generally lean toward publicly acknowledging errors** unless there's strong reason to believe the average reader has not been misled (i.e., that the slip is a Level 1 flaw).

**If there's disagreement over whether a correction is warranted, the final decision will be made by the managing editor of digital news** — who will then notify relevant staff.


**Wording of corrections**
The online employee closest to the story (i.e., the person who wrote the original article) should generally be asked to compose the first draft — assuming they're still on duty and available.

In the case of controversial or highly sensitive corrections, the senior or executive producer in charge of a particular unit must be asked for input.

**CBCNews.ca prefers specific corrections and clarifications rather than vague ones** (e.g., we usually avoid the clichéd reference to "different information" being previously published).


**Typical wording on the corrections and clarifications page:**

> April 15, 2002 
>
> A story about panhandling in southern Alberta published April 14 said that Lethbridge police arrested four people in a downtown park. In fact, the police removed four people from the park but did not detain them. 
>
> » Read the story

**Typical wording at the bottom of the story itself:**


 **CORRECTION**

 We initially reported that Lethbridge police arrested four people in the park. In fact, the police removed all four people from the park but did not detain them.

 Posted: April 15, 2002 | 11:55 a.m. ET


**Less specific corrections should be used, however, if there are legal reasons** to avoid repeating the original wording, **or if it makes more editorial sense to use vague language** (e.g., if repeating the original error would unnecessarily confuse or offend readers).

All of our notices should be brief, unambiguous and neutral. We must not use this forum to take shots at anyone. At the same time, **we do not apologize for mistakes** (e.g., "CBC.ca regrets the error"), **unless instructed to do so by our Legal Department.**

**Unless otherwise stated, errors are assumed to be CBC's.** (If incorrect information has come from radio or television reports, we do not blame them because we're all part of the same corporation.) **If incorrect information has come from outside the CBC** (e.g., The Canadian Press, The Associated Press, Reuters, etc.), **we can specify the source of the mistake as long as we're certain blame rests there.** Otherwise, we simply acknowledge that the error appeared on our website and, by doing so, take full responsibility for it.

**Except in rare cases** when the CBC's Law Department has told us to use certain language, **the journalist in charge of the web space** (or a delegate during a given shift) **approves the final wording of all correction notices**. Even when dealing with a directive from our lawyers, CBC writers and editors can always propose improvements — suggesting any awkward or editorially unsatisfactory language be changed. In such cases, it's up to the Law Department to determine whether the recommendations are acceptable.

**We never publish more than one corrections box at the bottom of an article.** If several revisions are made to a single story, these changes can be summed up in separate entries within the same section of the central corrections and clarifications page, as well as within the same box at the bottom of the story.

**ALL correction notices must be copy edited before being published** to make sure there are no typos or other mistakes.


**Clarifications**
**Making stories easier to understand** by using more precise language, recasting sentences, filling holes, eliminating ambiguity, providing readers with key context, etc., **is part of the normal writing and editing process. Articles can often be improved this way even after the first versions are published with no special flag for readers beyond the date/time stamp being updated.** These revisions represent the equivalent of poor photos being replaced with higher quality or better composed images later in the news cycle.

**Examples**: A story about a death in an ambulance fails to point out that the paramedics had been told to take the patient to a specific hospital, even though the trip would probably take at least five minutes longer. A story implies that a union leader was present when violence erupted on the picket line, when in reality he had left the site hours earlier after delivering a speech imploring strikers to protest peacefully.
**
From time to time, however, we need to acknowledge clarifications — especially if the changes can no longer be made as part of the normal news cycle** (i.e., the stories are more than 24 hours old). **The key criterion is whether the original wording has probably led to a significant misunderstanding of one or more central elements of the story. These changes are called "clarifications" rather than "corrections" because our first story was not actually wrong.** Instead, the journalism was incomplete, fuzzy or in some other way open to easy misinterpretation.

**Example 1**: A story published more than 24 hours ago may give the impression that a historic UN Security Council vote was unanimous when in reality one of the countries with a veto abstained. We can no longer clarify the text as part of the normal news cycle. The story is not wrong as such, merely incomplete and potentially misleading. We've received email complaints about the original version and decide that reference to the abstention should be added. The article's original date/time stamp is left untouched, but we flag the edit with a clarification notice at the bottom of the article.
**
Example 2**: A headline on our site implies that a country's prime minister has apologized for a deadly airstrike when he's only expressed "regret" over the loss of life. We feel the difference in wording is subtle but important. The text is revised as part of the normal news cycle, but we also highlight the change to acknowledge that the original language may have misled some readers. We flag the edit with a clarification notice at the bottom of the article.

CBC.ca does not routinely revise articles this way. Clarifications are not automatically published merely because someone writes in with a complaint, for instance. They constitute a special type of Level 2 flaw because it's usually not immediately obvious if the original wording has led to misinterpretation or misunderstanding of the story by the average reader.

**The same guidelines used for corrections apply to clarifications, with the relevant journalist in charge of the web space** (or delegate during a given shift) **ruling on whether the edit should be publicly acknowledged, and, if so, on the final wording.**

**The only difference is that we use the label "clarification" rather than "correction" in the revision notice.** This box is also published at the bottom of the story. It should include the date and time of the change.

In the case of stories more than 24 hours old, any significant changes (beyond fixed typos and other minor slips) must be acknowledged in the highlight box at the bottom of the article, as outlined in the section on [archived stories](/home/c/corrections-and-clarifications#changing) below.


**Life of corrections and clarifications**
**The corrections and clarification notices published at the bottom of web stories are permanent.** These boxes — generated by our in-house publishing tool — let our audience easily review any significant changes that were made to the text they're reading.


**Changing archived stories**
**Even though technology allows us to revise old articles without electronic fingerprints on the story, we must be extremely judicious** when exercising this power. (In this case, "old" is defined as being published more than 24 hours ago.)

**Only Level 1 flaws** (typos and other equally minor slips) **in archived stories can be corrected this way** (i.e., invisibly revised), **and the journalist in charge of the web space** (executive producer or higher) **must always be alerted.** NOTE: She or he does not need to be notified about Level 1 flaws in "current" content, published in the last 24 hours. Archived journalism, however, is treated differently.

**If any other mistakes are detected in old stories, the errors should be fixed and the revisions acknowledged in a box at the bottom of the story in the usual manner** (as outlined in "[How we correct](/home/c/corrections-and-clarifications#how)" above). The date/time stamp at the top of the article must not be changed. Instead, the date and time of the revision must be included in the corrections box itself.

In addition to supporting honesty and transparency in our journalism, **fixing old flaws this way reduces the risk that the same error will be repeated when fresh stories are written** as we — and some of our readers — review previous coverage of a given event.

**But we must avoid dishonestly rewriting history and making it appear that our original coverage included more or different information** (e.g., additional facts about a hijacking or the cause of a plane crash). As pointed out in the corporation's [Journalistic Standards and Practices policy on correcting archived online material](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fio.cbcrc.ca%2F%23%2Fresources%2Fcorrections-corrections-et-clarifications-1.4523122&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1hBNc8o5buNxIeXY0ZLLPh):


> A dated story is not necessarily wrong. It is a reflection of the facts known at the time of publication. It can be an important part of the historical record.


Since responsibly worded journalism properly attributes anything that's not confirmed as fact, most archived stories should stand as is. But corrections and [clarifications](/home/c/corrections-and-clarifications#clarifications) are periodically warranted.

**Fixing alerts**
Alerts are brief capsules sent directly to other platforms (e.g., email addresses and various wireless devices). Since they're not posted on our website, we cannot go into a file and change them later. For this reason, we must be particularly careful before hitting "send."

If an error is made, our only recourse is to issue a new alert that corrects the old wording — an undesirable option that should be resorted to only when absolutely necessary.

**We publish new alerts to correct flawed ones when a recent alert contains a Level 3 factual error or a Level 2 mistake that could mislead readers** (i.e., change the meaning of what was originally sent).

In this case, "recent" is generally considered within the previous two hours.

**Revised alerts should always begin with the new, correct information. The closing line should acknowledge our error in a brief, straightforward fashion.** For instance:

> A B.C. judge has found both suspects not guilty of all charges in the 1985 bombing of Air India Flight 182. The blast, which killed 329 people, was the largest case of mass murder in Canadian history. A previous alert sent a short time ago included incorrect information about the year of the explosion and the number of deaths.


Be extra careful when sending a second alert as a correction. In the past, we've sometimes rushed to fix one mistake only to discover an embarrassing slip in the correction itself.

**We do NOT publish new alerts to correct previous ones when the flaw is merely a typo or other minor mistake, such as a stylistic blunder.**

Whenever in doubt about sending a correction in the form of a new alert, writers should try to consult their supervisor first. If this is not possible, they should contact another writer or editor on duty to help decide on the best course of action.


**Corresponding with the public**
Mistakes are often brought to our attention by readers who send emails through our website's Report a Typo feature.

Some complaints are unfounded. Many are legitimate. A few require investigation to see if we made an error.

All mistakes are fixed as quickly as possible.
