But it's up to the journalist in charge of the web space where the content was originally posted (senior producer or higher) to determine if we need to flag the revision for our readers (as outlined in [authorizing correction notices](/home/c/corrections-and-clarifications#authorizing) above). Online journalists should give this person as much information about Level 2 and Level 3 flaws as quickly as possible so she/he can make an informed decision in a timely fashion.

When readers fill out our online Report a Typo forms, they're generally thanked for their submission **Periodically, we may decide to respond to an email complaint or query.** But we must always keep in mind that writing clear, sound and neutral emails is challenging, especially since the intended tone of letters can be easily misinterpreted. Extra care should be exercised when a legal issue has been raised or an ad hominem attack launched.

**Learning lessons from our mistakes**
The internet includes all sorts of incredible stuff. It's also chock full of not-so-credible content — otherwise known as rumours, assumptions and generally unreliable claims.

**There are countless reasons for Level 2 and Level 3 flaws**, including not checking with a source, misunderstanding the source and relying on an erroneous source. **Level 1 flaws, on the other hand, tend to be caused by bad spelling, sloppy typing, poor proofreading and unfamiliarity with in-house style.**

**To reduce the number of errors on our site:**

-   **CBCNews.ca writers** should consult our style manual (the Language Guide), use an electronic spellchecker, carefully proofread their own copy before submitting it, answer editors' questions about their stories, be willing to check anything in doubt, and take note of any mistakes pointed out in constructive critiques of their work.
-   **CBCNews.ca editors** should consult our style manual (the Language Guide), use an electronic spellchecker, rewrite with care, ask writers to clarify anything ambiguous or to confirm anything suspicious, flag trends in slips (including typos), and take note of any mistakes pointed out in constructive critiques of their own editing.

**Effective writing and editing is collaborative.** It's a way to (i) produce the best possible journalism for our readers, and (ii) get better at one's craft by learning from colleagues. CBC News staff are encouraged to approach the process in this spirit.

**By taking as much care as possible to make sure our stories are accurate, and by quickly and transparently correcting errors** (or clarifying anything that's potentially misleading), **we maintain the CBC News brand's credibility and help distinguish our journalism on the World Wide Web.**

### Courts

**Court versus court**

## **Capitalize superior courts, courts of appeal, etc., but not generic lower court names:**

> **Admiralty Court**
>
> **Appeal Court, Court of Appeal** (See also U.S. [Court of Appeals](/) below)
>
> **Court of King’s Bench** (or **Court of Queen's Bench** in historical references)
>
> **European Court of Justice**
>
> family **court**
>
> **Federal Court, Federal Appeal Court**
>
> **International Court of Justice**
>
> **Ontario provincial court** (lowercase when generic descriptive label is used)
>
> **Ontario Court of Justice** (initial caps when unique, formal name of provincial court is used)
>
> **Alberta's provincial court system** was established in 1906 (lowercase when generic descriptive label is used)
>
> **Alberta Court of Justice** (initial caps when unique, formal name of provincial court is used)
>
> the **provincial court**
>
> small claims **court**
>
> **Superior Court** (in Quebec)
>
> **Superior Court of Justice** (in Ontario), commonly called the **Ontario Superior Court**
>
> **Yukon Supreme Court**
>
> **Supreme Court** (federal, provincial, or state), as in **Supreme Court of Canada** ([SCC](/home/s#SupremeCourt))
>
> **Tax Court** (Canada and the U.S.)
>
> territorial **court** (N.W.T.), Yukon's **territorial court**, etc.
>
> youth **court**


Be aware that superior courts in Canada go by different names, depending on the province or territory (e.g., the **Saskatchewan Court of King's Bench**, the **B.C. Supreme Court** and the **Quebec Superior Court**).

## **Use lowercase in general references:**

> **courthouse
> courtroom
> the court** ordered, **the court** was told ...
> the **provincial court judge** 

## **Avoid confusing the names of courts of appeal:**

In Canada, it's easiest and accurate to refer to the highest court within a given province or territory as an appeal court (e.g., the **Alberta Court of Appeal**), even if some have slightly longer forms (e.g., the "Court of Appeal of the Supreme Court of Newfoundland and Labrador" can simply be called the **Newfoundland and Labrador Court of Appeal**). Be cautious with historical references, since some proper nouns are no longer used (e.g., the Ontario Court of Appeal was previously called the Supreme Court of Ontario). Two other common nouns are the **Federal Court of Appeal** and the **Supreme Court of Canada** (abbreviated as [SCC](/home/s#SupremeCourt), not SCOC).


**Court of Appeals** **(U.S.)**


**For proper nouns** (with initial caps), **match official names:**

> **the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 7th Circuit**
>
> **U.S. Court of Appeals** (Acceptable when reporting on a specific circuit's court in the U.S. There are 11 of them.)


**For generic references, lowercase "appeal" and "appeals" are both acceptable** — although it's best to be consistent within a story.

> a U.S. federal **court of appeals** will be asked to rule
>
> a U.S. **appeals court**
>
> three U.S. federal **appeals courts**
>
> an **appeal court** or an **appeals court**


See also [Canadian court terms](/home/c/canadian-court-terms) (e.g., witness box rather than stand)
See also [Justice and Judge](/home/j#justice)
See also [capitalization](/home/c/capitalization)

### Courts martial and other plural compounds

**Courts martial and other plural compounds**

**When the key element of a compound noun falls at the beginning of the unit** (e.g., _court in court martial_), **this word takes the “s” in the plural form:**

 chief of staff

 chiefs of staff

 court martial

 courts martial

 daughter-in-law

 daughters-in-law

 editor-in-chief

 editors-in-chief

 going-on 

 goings-on

 notary public

 notaries public

 passer-by

 passers-by

 poet laureate

 poets laureate



**The word “general” requires special care. It may or may not take the “s” depending on whether it’s the key element of the compound.**


In the case of the Governor General, the word Governor is the primary term.

 attorney general 

 attorneys general

 auditor general

 auditors general

 consul general

 consuls general

 Governor General     _(capitalize for current)_

 governors general   _(lowercase for past office holders)_



But in military contexts, “general” is the actual rank:

lieutenant-general 

 lieutenant-generals

 major-general

 major-generals


For a more detailed look at “general,” including when to use a hyphen, see [–general](/home/g/generalsuffix) and [Governor General](/home/g/governor-general).

For more information on when to put these compounds in capital letters (Attorney General, for instance, or Maj.-Gen), see [titles](/home/t/titles) and [military ranks](/home/m/military-ranks).

See also: [plurals](/home/p/plurals) and [possessive apostrophe](/handy-links/punctuation/possessive-apostrophe)

### cpap

**The Canadian Press, The Associated Press**

Unless the word "the" appears at the start of a sentence, a capital "T" (The) is normally reserved for the titles of compositions (many books, broadcast shows, films, poems, songs, etc., such as _The Lord of the Rings_ and _The National_), popular rather than reference magazines (e.g., The New Yorker but the New England Journal of Medicine), and for specialty TV channels that feature "The" in the official name (e.g., The Sports Network, also known as TSN).

Based on established convention, however, we also use a capital "T" when directly referring to North America's two largest news agencies:


> **The** Canadian Press
> **The** Associated Press


(CBCNews.ca adopted this additional exception in the spring of 2009 to reflect common wire story style.)


**Nouns**
In this context, referring "directly" to CP or AP means that the proper names are spelled out and function as nouns rather than as adjectives in the main bodies of stories.


> The plane crashed 30 minutes later, according to **The** Canadian Press.
>
> Budget cuts will be announced Thursday, she told **The** Associated Press.

**Adjectives**
When CP and AP are adjectives, "the" is tied to a different noun (e.g., story, reporter, manual) and should remain lowercase:


> Details were in **the** Canadian Press **story** that ran on the paper's front page.
>
> She based her decision on guidelines in **the** Associated Press **manual**.

**Adjectives versus possessives**
Be sure to distinguish between adjectives (which take "the") and possessive's (which take "The"). Prefer the former construction whenever possible:


> Investigators detained **the** Associated Press reporter for more than an hour.
>
> He worked at **The** Associated Press's Washington bureau for 25 years.

**Newspapers**
Use a small "t" for all other news organizations, including newspapers:


> They sued **the** Globe and Mail and **The** Canadian Press for defamation.
>
> He resigned from **the** New York Times two years later.
>
> She moved to **the** News Corporation, which owns Dow Jones, in 2008.


**CP, AP (Headlines, second reference, photo credits, etc.)**
A definite article ("the") is not required when the initials CP or AP are used in headlines, second reference, etc.


> They talked to **CP** about the lawsuit (_not_ "talked to the CP").
>
> He's expected to resign Thursday, sources told **AP** (_not_ "told the AP").
>
> **CP** Online Video, **AP** Financial News


But our style is to add a definite article in spelled-out photo credits at the end of captions.


> Tannis Toohey**/The Canadian Press**
>
> Hal Buell**/The Associated Press**


See CBCNews'ca's comprehensive [Photo Style Guide & Best Practices](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1o9AGtErLae5I43rHVjO4s446Nn-yeTvc3Dai5lzSNOw/edit) for details.    

Also, always use a capital "T" in spelled-out attribution conventionally linked to a definite article, including credits in italics at the bottom of CBCNews.ca stories:


> _With files from **The** Canadian Press_
>
> _With files from **The** Canadian Press and **The** Associated Press_


See CBCNews.ca's overview on [wire copy](/home/w/wire-copy) for more details about credits.


**CP, AP manuals**
While a capital "T" (The) is normally retained in book titles, a lowercase "t" is used when referring to certain works, including many religious texts (the Bible, the Qur'an, the Talmud) and reference books (the Canadian Oxford Dictionary, the Canadian Press Stylebook, the Encyclopaedia Britannica).

See [The versus the](/home/t/the-versus-the) for general guidelines on the titles of books, broadcast programs, films, paintings, etc. A small "t" is used in definite articles introducing virtually all businesses, public or private organizations, sports teams, music groups, awards, nicknames, etc. (e.g., the Bay, the Blue Jays, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, the Future Shop, the Guess Who, the Oscars, the Red Planet, the United Nations).

See also [italics](/handy-links/punctuation/italics), which includes a section on why [newspaper names](/home/n#newspaper) are kept in regular type.

### Crimea

**Crimea**

Claim to the region is disputed. **Russia annexed Crimea in early 2014. But Ukraine considers the annexation illegal.** Furthermore, Kyiv disputes the results of a controversial 2014 Moscow-led referendum that suggested a majority of citizens in Crimea want to be part of Russia. **Many countries, including Canada, refuse to accept Russia's claim to Crimea.**

**Be precise and judicious with language in coverage of Crimea.** Some wording has prompted complaints to the CBC Ombudsman over the years.

**It's accurate and OK to use the term occupation** (e.g., **Russian-occupied Crimea**). Russia's presence in Crimea is considered an occupation by much of the world community, including a majority of the United Nations as well as the International Criminal Court.

**But avoid terms such as "invaded" and "attacked,"** which imply military battles during the initial takeover. There's no evidence of fighting or of substantial armed resistance by the local population. Instead, some Ukrainian military commanders either stayed on the sidelines or defected. This prompted neutral observers to describe Russian troop movements as akin to military forces walking through an open door.

Organizers of a **March 2014 referendum** said a majority of people in Crimea asked to leave Ukraine and join Russia, but **most of the international community dismissed the vote as illegitimate**. Criticism ranged from the way the ballot questions were worded to how the referendum was conducted, since Ukraine's constitution requires that any changes to the country's territory be approved by a referendum involving all of its citizens.

**Use Crimea alone as a geographical locator in TV supers, maps, etc.** (e.g., Kerch, Crimea). **Avoid either "Crimea, Ukraine" or "Crimea, Russia."** There are two reasons:


> **1\. It's impossible to convey the complexities of the territorial dispute adequately in a geographical locator.** Picking either Ukraine or Russia amounts to siding with either Kyiv or Moscow. And picking, say, Ukraine, to match the UN's stance, or the government of Canada's position, fails to reflect the realities on the ground (i.e., Russian control over Crimea).
>
> **2\. The peninsula is familiar enough to our audience to stand on its own as a geographical name.** This was true even before the 2014 annexation. Referring to "Crimea" alone is similar to writing "Sicily" alone (rather than "Sicily, Italy"). This is standard publishing style at many news services, including CP and AP.


**Prefer the entrenched spelling Crimea.** Avoid the transliteration "Krimea." See also [Ukrainian names](/home/u/ukrainian-names) and [Russian names](/home/r/russian-names)


**NOTE:** The above focuses on the 2014 annexation of Crimea. **For guidelines about the 2022 Russia invasion of Ukraine**, see [Donbas (Donetsk, Luhansk)](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/d/donbas_donetsk_luhansk/ "Donbas_Donetsk_Luhansk") as well as a related 2022 update about [Russia's referendums, annexations](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/updates/2022/2022-09-30/ "2022 09 30").

### crisis

**Crisis**

There's **no single, narrow definition of crisis.** It can mean **everything from "a critical moment" to "a time of great difficulty,"** according to the Canadian Oxford Dictionary. **Despite this subjectivity, crisis normally implies a significant hardship or challenge requiring urgent, sometimes emergency, measures.**

For instance, an expected or unremarkable downturn in employment is NOT a crisis, even though some people may lose jobs, homes, etc. The same is true of a cyclical dip in the price of oil or other resource commodities. But a major, unusual shift in economic conditions that potentially hurts a lot of people directly or indirectly is commonly called a crisis (e.g., **the 2008 financial crisis**, which many reputable economists said pushed the world to the brink of a depression). **A crisis is not limited to a certain size or shape.** It can be global, national, regional or local. It can be primarily limited to one industry, or it can cascade across various economic sectors.

**Three caveats:**


> **1\. Avoid overusing the term crisis.** Like the word "disaster," it **should generally be reserved for something extraordinary** (e.g., a routine wind storm causes damage, but a hurricane causes massive destruction requiring disaster relief). So a rare political dispute that divides the country or paralyzes Parliament might well be called a **constitutional crisis**, but the routine fall of a minority government would normally not qualify. And the outbreak of an unusual, deadly illness might typically be called a **health crisis** (e.g., SARS in 2003), but a slightly nastier, annual flu season would not merit the label. **In many cases, a public policy debate is implied** (e.g., a **housing crisis** might require looking at the merits of rent control, a **debt crisis** might involve weighing the costs and benefits of government borrowing as a specific percentage of GDP, and an **oil price crisis** might involve oil production cuts/increases in times of gluts/shortages). In May 2019, Canada's environment minister tabled a motion in the House of Commons that referred to the climate change as both a "crisis" and an "emergency," underscoring that **climate crisis** and **climate emergency** are increasingly common expressions in debates over what to do about **global warming**, which the United Nations calls "[the defining issue of our time](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.un.org%2Fen%2Fsections%2Fissues-depth%2Fclimate-change%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0r01B2nP4zMzdiJsD8mUO_)." (See **[climate change](/home/c/climate-change)** for caveats about when the word crisis may not be the best choice.)
>
> **2\. Be aware that "crisis" is used in some other contexts in perfectly acceptable ways,** including as a modifier (e.g., a **crisis centre**, a **crisis management** team). This underscores that the word has various shades of meaning to Canadians.
>
> **3\. Be cautious when putting quotation marks around "crisis,"** which **can wrongly convey skepticism** (i.e., the "oil crisis" can be misread as the **[so-called](/home/s/so-called) crisis**). Although attribution is sometimes a sound way to try to stay neutral, it can also backfire with certain language. Since the word "crisis" cannot be objectively defined, and since it's already used in relatively loose ways in everyday speech (a crisis of confidence), **it's generally best to either use the word or not** (based on criteria listed above), **rather than to put "crisis" in quotation marks throughout our coverage** of a given story.


The plural of crisis is **crises**.

See [grammar and diction](/handy-links/grammar)

### Crown

**Crown versus crown**

**Always keep "Crown" uppercase when the word refers to Canada’s head of state** (the Queen) **or to the state itself** (land owned by the state, lawyers representing the state, etc.)

the Crown (_usually prosecution but can also mean judge_)
Crown attorney
Crown attorney Jackie White
Crown prosecutor Jackie White
Crown land
a Crown corporation
the Crown Jewels housed in the Tower of London, but the Queen’s crown
the crown jewel of their collection (_all lowercase because it's a generic label_)
a crown prince, but uppercase in a specific title: Crown Prince Haakon

## **Ceremonies like coronations**

**At coronations, weddings, funerals and other special ceremonies, it's customary to capitalize a lot of royal regalia** and related paraphernalia **when a key object's full name is used**:

St. Edward's Crown (_specific name_)
the coronation crown (_generic description_)
Imperial State Crown
Queen Mary’s Crown
the Sovereign's Ring (_versus generic terms like the "coronation ring" or the "coronation rings"_)
the Queen Consort’s Ring
the Wedding Ring of England
the Sovereign's Orb
the Sovereign's Sceptre With Cross (_versus generic reference to one of the sovereign's sceptres_)
the Sovereign's Sceptre With Dove
the Queen Consort’s Rod with Dove
the Sword of State
the Sword of Offering

**This applies to some components of objects that are, themselves, distinct**, such as a well-known precious stone  (e.g., the Black Prince's Ruby in the Imperial State Crown). **In second reference, such nouns are generally shortened to generic lowercase renderings**, as in the ruby, the ring(s), the sceptre(s), the sword(s), etc.

**Not all Crown-related ceremonial objects are capitalized, however, even in first reference.** In coverage of a coronation, for instance, references to a flask like the golden ampulla, to golden bracelets known as armills, and to the silver spoon used to anoint the sovereign, are traditionally kept lowercase in news reporting.

See also [royal titles](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/r/royal-titles/ "Royal titles") for various related guidelines (e.g., royal is almost always lowercase, except in Royal Family)
See also [capitalization](/home/c/capitalization)

### CT and CAT scans

**CT and CAT scans**

**Use the term CT scan** unless you’re absolutely certain you're writing about the original, less-sophisticated technology (CAT scan). CT scan has largely replaced the older label.

**Background**
X-rays are two-dimensional. But if a series of X-rays are taken at slightly different angles and then combined using a computer, you end up with a cross-sectional image of a patient.

In the 1970s, this diagnostic technology became known as a _CAT scan_.

Since then, a more sophisticated approach has been developed that goes beyond one plane (i.e., that is not limited to “axial” tomography). This technology is referred to as a _CT scan_.

**Abbreviation alone**
**There is no need to spell out CT or CAT** (just as it’s unnecessary to define DNA as _deoxyribonucleic acid_ or MRI as _magnetic resonance imaging_).

But if you do want to use words instead of initials in second reference, refer to CT as “computed tomography” and CAT as “computerized axial tomography.”

Note: Medical experts rarely bother to spell out the initials, and when they do a variety of different forms are used (e.g., CAT is sometimes defined as _computerized axial tomography, computed axial tomography_ or _computer-assisted tomography_, while CT is sometimes defined as _computerized tomography_ or _computed tomography_).

**Abbreviation plus description**
**Briefly describing the technology rather than spelling out the initials is the best option** in a news story. In this case, define a CT scan as a high-tech or sophisticated way to merge a series of X-rays into a detailed picture taken from different angles.

See also [MRI](/home/m#MRI)

### cult versus sect

**Cult versus sect**

It's unhelpful to our audience to toss around names (e.g., the Community of the Lady of All Nations) without putting these nouns into context. At the same time, **we must avoid portraying religious groups and movements unfairly** with convenient but misleading labels.

**Here are some points to consider** before using words such as sect or cult:


**Religions**
Systems of faith and worship that include the belief that God shared direct revelations in the past, and that writings about the faith are now closed to revision. **Established religions include Buddhism, Christianity, Hinduism, Islam, Judaism, Mormonism and Sikhism.**

**
Denominations**
**Groups within an established religion**, such as Roman Catholic, Anglican and Baptist in Christianity. Well-known denominations do not need to be defined as such in stories. The term "ecumenical" refers to all denominations within Christianity. **Sometimes, terms such as "division" are used instead of denomination. Islam, for example, has Sunni and Shia followers.**

**
Movements**
**Groups sharing common objectives**, such as members of a peace movement. It can sometimes have a religious foundation. Quakers, for example, are members of a group known as the Society of Friends— often described as a "Christian movement."


**Sects**
**Breakaway groups.** While they seek a purer form of worship considered lost or abandoned by traditional religions or denominations, **they usually still maintain the basic tenets of a particular faith.**The Community of the Lady of All Nations is an example of a Roman Catholic sect.


**Cults**
**Groups generally considered outside mainstream religion and culture.** They promote unorthodox systems of belief. **The word cult has a sinister connotation** that often suggests brainwashing, secretive communities and rituals, exploitation of members by one or more charismatic leaders, etc. **Some cults have nothing to do with religion.** Convicted murdered Charles Mason is an example of a cult leader.


**Attribute contested labels**
**Unless a particular group is widely known as a "cult," the term should generally be attributed.** To describe Wicca as a "witchcraft cult," for example, offends members who see it as a branch of paganism or shamanism.


**Give audiences background
Including a brief sentence of relevant background can give people enough information to draw their own conclusions about new or obscure groups.** In a story about the Church of the Firstborn and General Assembly of Heaven, for example, we could write: "The self-described religious sect was started by an excommunicated **[Mormon](/home/m/mormon-mormonism)** who claimed to be the Holy Ghost."

### CUSMA

**Canada-U.S.-Mexico Agreement (CUSMA)**

**The new free trade agreement negotiated between Canada, the United States and Mexico in 2018 is referred to by different names**. Preferred options include:


> the **Canada-U.S.-Mexico Agreement on trade** (the word "trade" is not actually in the title)
> **CUSMA** (spelled out once in a story as the **Canada-U.S.-Mexico Agreement**)
> the **new North American Free Trade Agreement**
> the **new NAFTA**
> **NAFTA 2.0**


Since the capital A stands for Agreement, **avoid redundancies like "NAFTA agreement" and "CUSMA agreement,"** which are akin to writing, say, "RCMP police" and "NDP party."

NOTE: NAFTA remains in effect until the new agreement is officially ratified by each country's national legislative body. The signing ceremony by government leaders on Nov. 30, 2018, was essentially just the first symbolic step toward formal ratification. That text was amended a year later (in December 2019) before Democrats agreed to table the legislation in Congress.

**While the U.S. prefers to call the revised deal the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), this is not actually the official name.** The deal's preamble simply refers to "an Agreement between the United States of America, the United Mexican States and Canada," which boils down to something closer to "AUSAUMSC" than to "USMCA." In Spanish, it's referred to as _Tratado entre México, Estados Unidos y Canadá_ (T-MEC).

**A few reasons CBC News prefers CUSMA** over USMCA:


> **1\. CUSMA is clearest to our audience because it's used by the government of Canada**, one of two English parties to the agreement. CUSMA is the noun that appears in federal government documents, and on the [Global Affairs Canada website](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.international.gc.ca%2Ftrade-commerce%2Ftrade-agreements-accords-commerciaux%2Fagr-acc%2Fcusma-aceum%2Findex.aspx%3Flang%3Deng&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3IwAIt4OoMZig6kLDBUSww).
>
> **2\. CUSMA is pronounceable** (i.e., an acronym rather than just an abbreviation), which makes it easier to incorporate into broadcast scripts. By contrast, the only conversational way to turn "USMCA" into an acronym is to introduce one or more additional letters (e.g., "US-Ma-CA"), which is at best an unorthodox approach to abbreviations. CUSMA, of course, does not need to be turned into an acronym, like NAFTA or NATO. Instead, it can simply be spelled out at C-U-S-M-A in radio and TV scripts, if preferred. As of December 2019, there was still no entrenched pronunciation of "CUSMA," with agreed-on vowel sounds, etc.


It's worth noting that **our colleagues at Radio-Canada also put Canada first in the French version of the name**: _Accord Canada–États-Unis–Mexique_ (ACEUM)

When relevant and practical, **consider pointing out that the agreement is also known as USMCA (once, parenthetically, if there's room).** This is particularly important in stories featuring clips or transcribed web quotes that mention USMCA.

Be aware that it's not uncommon for different countries to prefer different names for international agreements. For instance, in the 1980s, the original Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement (CUSFTA) was commonly called the U.S.-Canada free trade agreement south of the border.

**Dawson City** (Although technically a town, it can be referred to as Dawson City based on legislation as well as long-standing convention.) During the Klondike Gold Rush more than a century ago, this [Yukon](/home/y/yukon) community boasted the largest population of any centre north of San Francisco and west of Winnipeg — 40,000 in 1898, compared to Vancouver's 25,000. Today, it's a small fraction of that size. While the Geographical Names Board of Canada officially calls it "Dawson," the territory's own Municipal Act clearly states that the town "shall have the name the City of Dawson." But avoid the generic, lowercase term "city" in second reference. Instead, call it Dawson or the town, the community, etc.

**diaper (noun)** Normally implies a disposable rather than a washable undergarment unless specified. The term is **generally OK when referring to both infants and adults.** But avoid the expression "seniors' diapers," which suggests that only elderly people wear them. Be aware that some adults object to calling disposable briefs "diapers." Respect declared preferences when reporting on specific people. One option is to leave out the noun when it's already implied (e.g., "Investigators said her mother had been left in soiled clothing for days"). However, avoid adopting dense, bureaucratic euphemisms (e.g., "disposable incontinence underwear") outside of directly transcribed quotes. Not all Canadians are familiar with the British synonym "nappy," which means a brief definition may be required if the meaning is not obvious from context. **Steer clear of the verb "diaper" when referring to adults.** The noun is considered a neutral, fact-based detail in stories about an aging population, about various health conditions (e.g., skin infections caused by adult "diaper rash"), about the treatment of residents in long-term care facilities, about environmental issues (e.g., the rise in baby and adult diapers tossed into landfills), etc. By contrast, the verb's use is conventionally reserved for infants (i.e., "to diaper a newborn").

****diaphragm****

**diarrhea**

**diaspora** (lowercase) The term's meaning has gradually expanded in recent years. It comes from an ancient Greek word for "scattering," and initially referred to the dispersion of Jewish people from what is now Israeli and Palestinian territory more than 2,500 years ago (the **Jewish diaspora**). A sense of "forced migration" continues to be associated with the term in certain contexts. The word sometimes also applies to itinerant communities without their own country (e.g., **Romani diaspora**). During the second half of the 20th century, however, **diaspora has acquired a much more general connotation**. In 2018, for instance, the [UN's Organization for Migration (IOM) defined diaspora](https://belgium.iom.int/diaspora-engagement) as "migrants or descendants of migrants whose identity and sense of belonging have been shaped by their migration experience and background." In other words, the term can convey the broad sense of "a transnational community" that extends beyond the borders of any one country, according to [the Canadian Encyclopedia](https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/immigrant-diasporas-in-canada) (e.g., the world's **Ukrainian diaspora**, a given country's **Chinese diaspora**).

**Diavik** (OK in headlines) **Diavik diamond mine** refers to the operation in the Northwest Territories; **Diavik Diamond Mines Inc.** refers to company, and should be spelled out once in full in business stories.

**dictator** (OK as fact-based detail) Generally prefer using a given leader's political title (e.g., president) in first reference, and then the family name in second reference. It's acceptable to add context about totalitarian [regimes](/home/r#regime), however, as long as the detail is demonstrably accurate, and the wording is not intentionally vilifying. The Canadian Oxford Dictionary broadly defines "dictator" as "a ruler with unrestricted authority." Determining what's "unrestricted," of course, is sometimes debatable. Common characteristics of dictatorships are single party states, no elections, no free press, use of the police or military to quell political opposition and to restrict the rights of citizens, etc. In the case of certain historical figures, entrenched use of "dictator" is rarely controversial (e.g., Idi Amin, Jean-Claude Duvalier, Moammar Gadhafi, Saddam Hussein). But **for sitting leaders or those recently in power, avoid labels like "dictator" unless evidence of totalitarianism is clear** (e.g., Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, North Korean Leader Kim Jong-un). **If "dictator" is accurate, always keep the wording fair, and avoid even the perception of demonization** by generally limiting use of the term to one or two references in a single story. For details, see two related CBC ombudsman rulings: [If the word fits, use it](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fcbc.radio-canada.ca%2Fen%2Fombudsman%2Freviews%2F2016-01-28-b&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3stJ0L-J36B48JfdGwvr1X) (Jan. 28, 2016), and [When using 'dictator' is not bias](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fcbc.radio-canada.ca%2Fen%2Fombudsman%2Freviews%2F2017-03-15&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0gdjCOnyEr8G7VGSDAm3kQ) (March 15, 2017).

**drunk tank** (_avoid_ unless a jocular tone is suitable and intended) This North American colloquialism, coined in the 1940s, historically refers to police detention cells where people sober up. It was popularized on TV programs like _The Andy Griffith Show_, where a lovable town drunk would happily spend the night in a safe, warm bed. In recent decades, however, a number of public policy questions have been raised about the practice of using holding cells for cases of public intoxication — from concerns about arbitrary arrests and unjust detention to the importance of addiction treatment and the need to monitor those detained for medical risks. **"Drunk tank" remains OK in rare cases** (e.g., a profile of someone sharing a lighthearted, embarrassing college adventure). **Otherwise, generally steer clear of it**, including in stories about overall incarceration rates, evidence that certain communities are treated differently by police, allegations of systemic racism, etc.

### death general guidelines

**Death (general reporting guidelines)**

When writing about death:

-   **Follow all relevant legal guidelines** (e.g., A ban might be in place on the name of a victim if that name identified an underage suspect). When in doubt, check.


-   **Follow all applicable CBC journalistic standards** (e.g., Overly graphic details may be considered editorially unnecessary and in poor taste).


-   **Report accurately, focusing on known facts** (e.g., Just because someone is charged with murder doesn't mean the victim was murdered, which is a legal finding). See [**homicide**](/home/h/homicide) for related guidelines about specific language — from being careful with the word "murder" to avoiding relatively obscure legalese (e.g., fratricide, matricide, patricide).
-   **Be as precise as possible about the cause of death** (leukemia, lung cancer, bullet to the head) **without overwhelming our audience with medical jargon.** Exercise judgment. While terms such as "hypothermia" and "asphyxiation" are understood, context is important (the water was too cold to survive in for more than 30 minutes). Remember that there's a difference between, say, a "heart attack" (heart muscle damage) and "cardiac arrest" (stopped heart). Since a severe heart attack can lead to cardiac arrest, it's acceptable to use the common phrase "fatal heart attack." And use "die of" rather than "die from" when referring to specific illnesses (die of cancer) or conditions (die of hypothermia).


-   **Be clear when the exact cause of death is unknown** (e.g., "appears to have died of" or "is believed to have died of," if authorities are using such qualifiers). **But generally steer clear of unorthodox phrasing to convey uncertainty** (e.g., avoid using "died with" a given disease instead of "died of," because such prepositional constructions are awkward and jarring). **Instead, favour more direct language** (e.g., "Singh had tested positive for SARS, but the exact cause of death is still under investigation"). Another option is fact-based wording that uses modifiers rather than prepositions (e.g., "A SARS patient in her 20s has died, but the exact cause of death is still under investigation"). Be aware that various underlying health conditions can make individuals more susceptible to a disease. But also be aware that some people may attempt to downplay the total number of deaths during a health crisis like a pandemic for political reasons — claiming that thousands of people actually died of a comorbidity, such as obesity, severe asthma, or previous heart or lung damage, rather than of a virus. While we should be on the lookout for questionably or inaccurately calculated death totals, we should also continue to report official figures, attribute our sources, and pursue reasonably expressed skepticism about overall numbers by asking non-partisan medical authorities for comment.


-   **Report neutrally** (e.g., Avoid adding editorial comments, such as "luckily" or "fortunately" in details like "no Canadians were among the dead," and adhere to all relevant CBC language guidelines, such as a limited use of words like [terrorism](/home/t/terrorist-and-terrorism) and care with terms such as [genocide](/home/g/genocide)). Be aware that in coverage of polarizing stories, including war, attempts to vary phrasing in stories (e.g., "died" and "were killed") can be perceived by one side or the other as biased. In these cases, it's often better to repeat the same language than to hunt for synonyms in death tolls, etc.


-   **Avoid redundancies** (e.g., The phrases "electrocuted to death" or "fatally drowned" are superfluous, since electrocution commonly implies death, and because drowning always means death; also while person X can "try to smother" person Y and fail, if person X actually "smothers" person Y, then person Y is dead).


-   **Be cautious with sensational synonyms** (e.g., slay, execute). Many of these terms are hackneyed. Some are also challenged by our audience as either inappropriate or inaccurate (e.g., The word "execution" traditionally means "executing" or "carrying out" a court-ordered or state-ordered death sentence).


-   **Generally avoid euphemisms** (e.g., "passed away," "slipped away") in daily news reporting. They're clichés. There is no outright ban against indirect language, since softer wording is sometimes the most effective choice for certain writing (e.g., in a feature or column), depending on the piece's tone. But direct wording (died, was killed, drowned, was stabbed to death) is almost always preferred.


-   **Translate military and other jargon** so that our journalism is not muddy (e.g., Tell our audience about "civilians killed" not about "collateral damage," and about "Canadian soldiers accidentally killed by a U.S. air strike" rather than about "friendly fire").


-   **Handle stories about suicide with care** (e.g., Virtually never refer to a specific death as a suicide in headlines or leads, and do not use adjectives such as "successful" or "unsuccessful"). For more details, see [suicide reporting guidelines](/home/s/suicide).


-   **In stories about [assisted dying](/home/a/assisted_dying), prefer the modifier "medical"** (e.g., medical assistance in dying, medically assisted death) **over "doctor" or "physician,"** since nurses, pharmacists and other health-care professionals may be involved.




-   Be aware that the term **[euthanasia](/home/e/euthanasia) is generally considered a poor choice for** what amounts to **"withdrawal of life-support."**

See also [funerals](/home/f/funerals) for various terms and common pitfalls.
See also [casualties](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/c/#casualties "C") for an editorial caveat about fatalities versus injuries.

### Death-to-America

**Death to America**

This **anti-U.S. slogan** is common in parts of the Middle East. Variations of the expression directed at other countries (e.g., “Death to Israel”) are also used.

The **English translation is normally fine** unless attributed to specific person or group on record disputing the wording. For instance, the slogan Death to America is commonly heard chanted by pro-Hezbollah crowds in Lebanon. Its meaning is not contested, and the **original Arabic is unnecessary. The same generally applies to the Farsi version** (“_marg bar Amrika_”) ubiquitous in Iran for decades.

**CAVEAT: Avoid attributing this literal translation to anyone who has publicly insisted on a different, more nuanced meaning.** In those rare cases, we should **acknowledge the disagreement over wording** and ensure that an individual or group’s preferred sense is conveyed, based on the principles of accuracy and fairness.


> Example: In a speech in 2015, Iran’s supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said the slogan essentially means “**Death to U.S. Policies**” rather than an end to the U.S., itself. Since then, the official Iranian government’s English translation has been “**Down with America**.” So while it’s OK to report on, say, crowds in Tehran chanting “Death to America,” when specifically referring to official Iranian government policy or to statements by Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, we should add context and include the alternative translation.


See also "[destruction of Israel](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#destructionofisrael)" (for a similar caveat about coverage of Iranian politics), as well as [quoting slogans](/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks#slogans) (for relevant capitalization guidelines)

### debt versus deficit

**Deficit versus debt**

**Deficit**
Deficit is related to the word _deficiency_. It's **a shortfall**, when **spending exceeds revenue**.

Ottawa's "annual operating deficit" is simply called "this year's deficit."

In February 1998, the federal government tabled its first budget surplus in 28 years. A decade later, the surpluses ended and a deficit of more than $30 billion was recorded during the first year of a deep recession. In 2021, Ottawa's deficit had grown to roughly $90 billion, partly because of COVID-19 pandemic emergency spending.

In times of surplus, avoid the term "fiscal dividend," which suggests a benefit (dividend) from government spending (fiscal) policy.


**Debt**
**Debt is the total amount owed at any given time.** Interest on debt is included as an expenditure in a government's budget.

Ottawa's debt (also called "**the national debt**") is **the federal government's accumulated deficits minus any surpluses applied against the principal since Confederation**. It does not include billions of dollars owed by the provinces.

In 1996, the federal debt was about $583 billion. In 2003, it was just under $508 billion. As of 2008, it had slowly declined to $458 billion. By the middle of 2010, however, the figure had suddenly swollen above $525 billion again, and was projected to keep growing. In 2021, Canada's federal debt was roughly $1.1 trillion. **This does not include billions of dollars owed by the provinces.**

**Most economists prefer to judge the size of the debt by a country's ability to pay it back** — for example, as a percentage of the national income or gross domestic product (GDP). **In news stories, however, care must be taken when citing debt-to-GDP ratios because not all analysts use the same accounting figures for government assets and liabilities.** For example, some measurements factor in billions in assets from funds like the Canada Pension Plan (i.e., "gross government debt") while others do not (i.e., they look only at "net government debt," which boils down to gross debt minus certain financial holdings). Furthermore, some metrics focus only on federal debt while others include the provinces.

When times are good, debt ratios normally fall as long as the economy grows and no sizable deficits are posted. **Be clear and precise about public finances and trends, so that our audience can assess what can be highly partisan statements by a given government as well as by its critics.** For instance, when reporting that the IMF says Canada's net debt-to-GDP ratio is among the lowest of all G7 countries (e.g., approximately 33 per cent in 2021), it's valuable to look farther afield for perspective (e.g., how Canada ranks compared to other industrialized countries beyond the G7, as well as whether any major fiscal changes, such as emergency spending on COVID-19 measures, have raised concerns about projected annual deficits and overall debt sustainability).


**U.S. debt ceiling**
The terms **debt ceiling and debt limit can be used interchangeably.** Although the labels, themselves, seem self-explanatory, be aware that not everyone in our audience will be familiar with the jargon. In particular, **it's important to stress that the debt ceiling has nothing to do with authorizing new spending. Rather, it's about making sure that the U.S. government can borrow enough money to meet all expenditures already authorized** by Congress or required by statute — including military spending, public employee salaries, social security and medicare benefits, tax refunds and interest on the national debt. In the spring of 2023, the U.S. debt ceiling was just over $31 trillion.

**The United States is one of the few countries in the world that operates its national government this way.** Instead of simply hashing out disagreements over spending levels during budget negotiations, **Washington has had a two-step process since 1917.** First, federal politicians vote on a budget. Then later, if there isn't enough money to pay for everything, the same politicians must raise the debt ceiling before the government can legally borrow additional money. This sometimes leads to political brinksmanship between Republicans and Democrats. **If the debt ceiling is not raised when more money is needed, financial obligations cannot be met, including payments to creditors** (i.e., interest on its debt). **This is technically known as debt default**, which economists have repeatedly warned could have devastating consequences — from triggering a recession and increasing unemployment to eroding confidence in the U.S. dollar around the world and downgrading the U.S. credit rating (making it more expensive to service the country's national debt for years to come).

See also [GDP versus GNP](/home/g/gdp-versus-gnp)
See also [per cent versus percentage](/home/p/per-cent-versus-percentage)

### defence, labour and centre

**Defence, labour and centre**

**Rule 1**
**As outlined in the overview on [spelling](/home/s/spelling), we generally use the Canadian Oxford's preferences** (e.g., defence and centre) **for most words. This also applies to translations of proper nouns.** So while U.S. news organizations would use the term _Iraqi Civil Defense Corps_, for instance, we would write _Iraqi Civil Defence Corps_.


**Rule 2**
**We normally retain the official spelling of proper nouns in English** (e.g., the _World Trade Center_, not _Centre_). This applies to the names of political parties in English-speaking countries (i.e., to nouns that haven't been translated). So we report on Britain's _Labour Party_ but on Australia's _Labor Party_. It also includes occasional anomalous Canadian spellings, such as the _Canadian Center for Vaccinology_ in Halifax. When in doubt about an official spelling, be sure to check a reliable source.

**We alter the second rule slightly, however, when reporting on the U.S. government. We do not use the American spellings of "labor" and "defense," even in the names of departments and agencies**, because these appear relatively more frequently than the names of foreign nouns, such as Australia's Labor Party, and because they're less distinct (i.e., because more countries have "Labour Departments" than "Labour" or "Labor" parties).


This approach (also taken by CP and other news organizations), is intended to increase the level of consistent spellings within a given story — as outlined in more detail in the next section. Be aware that **U.S. news media do the same when covering our country**, referring to Canada's "Defense Department" and to a given province's "Labor Department."


**U.S. Defence Department, U.S. Labour Department**
**We want to avoid _Labor_ and _Defense_** when referring to Washington (the U.S. "Labor Department" and the U.S. "Defense Department"), not **because these words look jarring in capital letters but because of what happens when the same terms suddenly appear in lowercase** (generic contexts) **a few paragraphs later**. If we write "labour report" and "defence spending," we're inconsistent based on the earlier capital letters. If we write "labor report" and "defense spending," we're in conflict with our normal position on generic spellings. We end up with a Canadian "defence plan" and an American "defense strategy." The same approach is taken with words such as [**adviser**](/home/a#adviser) (the preferred Canadian spelling). For consistency, we should refer to a **"national security adviser"** in the U.S. or any other country (e.g., "Israel's former national security adviser"), rather than to an "advisor" in some places and an "adviser" in others.

**This style, common in Canadian journalism, distinguishes between a U.S. government department** (e.g., we write "Labour" instead of "Labor") **and a unique federal agency** within a given department (e.g., the CDC, spelled out as the U.S. national **Centers for Disease Control and Prevention**).

The **same approach is taken with what amount to generic words like defence and labour in other countries' ministry headings** (e.g., "defence" in the **Israel Defence Force** rather than the Israel "Defense" Force), but "labor" without a "u" in the Israeli Labor Party, the specific name of a unique entity rather than merely a government department heading).

So it's:

**American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations** (AFL-CIO)
**Hummingbird Centre
Labor Party** (Australia)
**Labour Party** (U.K.)
**Lincoln Center
Munk Centre for International Studies
the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People** (NAACP)
**Pearl Harbor
Rockefeller Center
Technicolor** (a registered [trademark](/home/t/trade-names))
_**The Color Purple**_  (film title in [italics](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/handy-links/punctuation/italics/ "Italics"))
**U.S. National Hurricane Center**
**World Trade Center**

But it's also:

**U.S. Labour Department**, U.S. labour statistics
the U.S. **National Labour Relations Board** (a government agency)
**U.S. Defence Department**, a defence spokesperson (_not_ Defense, defense)
**Defence Advanced Research Projects Agency** (DARP is a research arm of the Pentagon)
**Natural Resources Defence Council** (a U.S.-based environmental organization)
**U.S. National Security Adviser Jane Smith, the U.S. national security adviser** (_not_ Advisor, advisor)
the **Israel Defence Forces** (a government department, so _not_ Defense)
**Israel's national security adviser** (_not_ advisor)


**Wrong:
**_"In its own defence, the White House said that it laboured hard on the defense and labor budgets."
"Australia's Labor Party contested the Labor Department's latest labor statistics."_

**Right:**
_"In its own defence, the White House said that it laboured hard on the defence and labour budgets."
"Australia's Labor Party contested the Labour Department's latest labour statistics." (correct but jarring)
"Australia's Labor Party contested the government's latest employment statistics."_ (_rewrite to avoid spelling clashes_)

**Two mnemonic devices** may help when writing about the U.S. government:

1\. U **(you) need a "u" in labour.**
2\. Always use "c" in defence (**"c" is for Canada,** "s" is for the States).


**Centre of the World Trade Center?**
Some people have correctly pointed out that there will still be inconsistencies (e.g., the centre of the old _World Trade Center_ site). But we can generally find ways to recast such sentences (e.g., use "middle" instead of "centre" when the proper noun includes Center).

This is much harder to do this with government departments, (For instance, would we compare the Canadian and U.S. "defence budgets" or the Canadian and U.S. "defense budgets"? The answer, outlined above, is to always use "ce," whether Defence or defence.)

As for the word defensive, it's the only spelling listed in the Canadian Oxford. No one ever said English was logical or consistent (_honourable_ versus _honorary_). Our job is to present clear, accurate information. **Littering stories with inconsistent spellings of generic terms** (_labour, labor and defence, defense_) **is unhelpful and highly distracting.**

See also [Centre versus Center](/home/c/centre-versus-center)
See also [our and or](/home/s/spelling/our), as well as the general overview [Avoid inapt Americanisms](/home/a/americanisms)

### Degrees

**Degrees**

University and college degrees are **lowercase when spelled out.

Use periods only when there's a mix of big and small letters (B.Sc.) that don't begin and end with capitals (PhD).**

bachelor of arts (**BA**)
bachelor of education (**B.Ed.**)
bachelor of science (**B.Sc.**)
bachelor of laws (**LLB**) but _avoid_ using; prefer "law degree"
a bachelor's degree
an honours bachelor degree

master of arts (**MA**)
master of science (**M.Sc.**)
master of laws (**LLM**), but _avoid_ using; prefer "graduate degree in law"
a master's degree

doctor of laws (**LLD**)
doctor of medicine (**MD**), but prefer "a medical degree" or "a degree in medicine"
doctor of philosophy (**PhD**), a doctorate
**
Don't use obscure abbreviations** for academic degrees (e.g., BSCJ for bachelor of science in criminal justice). Spell out instead.

**Reserve the honorific "[Dr.](/home/d/dr)" for health-care professionals.
**
See also [universities and colleges](/home/u/universities-and-colleges)

See [abbreviations](/home/a/abbreviations) for more details to guidelines governing short forms.

### dementia

**Dementia, senility, Alzheimer's**

**Dementia is a chronic mental disorder** marked by symptoms such as loss of memory, impaired reasoning and judgment as well as changes in personality. It has several causes, including injury, brain disease, infections and unexpected interaction of drugs in the body. The condition is sometimes treatable. [Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease](/home/c/cjd) and **Alzheimer's** are two types of dementia that have received extensive media coverage over the years. [Health Canada's dementia overview](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/dementia.html) summarizes these and related neurological disorders.

**Senility, by contrast, is a colloquial term** used to describe the deteriorating mental capacity commonly associated with old age. It does not refer to a specific cause of slower mental response time, loss of memory, reduced concentration, etc., beyond age. It is not based on a brain scan or other medical diagnosis. Since people of the same age exhibit different cognitive abilities, senility is not considered a scientific label.

**Alzheimer's disease was the most common form of dementia in Canada in the early 2020s**, according to federal government research. It's named after Dr. Alois Alzheimer, who identified specific cellular traits of the neurological disease in 1906. Since then, treatments have been developed to try to slow progress of the disease, but there is no cure. Alzheimer's usually affects people gradually. Memory, reasoning and the ability to perform familiar tasks declines slowly. Sudden memory loss is normally associated with some other illness.

CBC News style: Alzheimer's disease; Alzheimer's; an Alzheimer's treatment; etc. For consistency, do not drop the possessive apostrophe except when it's absent from a formal name, such as the [Alzheimer Society of Canada](https://alzheimer.ca/en).

See also [disability terms](/home/d/disability-language#mentallydisabled) for related guidelines

### Denier

**Denier, denialism**

**Use the terms denier and denialism with caution. They convey an editorial stance.**

Just because something is widely known or believed does not guarantee that it's true. And even if it becomes incontrovertible (e.g., the earth is not flat), **it's uncommon and usually unnecessary to label people "deniers"** (e.g., virtually no one says "round earth deniers"). Instead, there are usually other ways to make the same point.

**Denier has a long history of pejorative overtone**, according to the Oxford English Dictionary (e.g., in the 1500s non-Christians were called "**Christ deniers**" and "**Gospel deniers**," and in the 1800s "**deniers of the Trinity**" surfaced). The word deny also has a close relationship with people accused of wrongdoing (to deny specific accusations). One of the few common, modern compounds involving the noun denier ("**Holocaust denier**") automatically implies antisemitism (i.e., the term telegraphs the sense of hate speech linked to people who reject the historical evidence that Nazis murdered millions of Jewish people during the Second World War). **Holocaust denier is deeply entrenched and OK** largely because society condemns the views espoused (i.e., a pejorative overtone is already implied).

Be aware, in other words, that **"denier" is not considered neutral:** It traditionally **suggests more than merely "denying" an accepted truth** or "advocating" a different view. **The noun is packed with judgment and can be perceived as demonizing.**

EXAMPLE: People who challenge widely held scientific conclusions about global warming, or specific measurements about the varying causes of global warming, are not "deniers" in the same way that fringe antisemites are "Holocaust deniers." **We don't use "climate change deniers" in our journalism for the same reason we don't classify millions of religious people** who believe in various versions of creationism **as "evolution deniers."**

The word denier, which dates back to at least the 1470s, is much older than the noun denialism. The latter was coined in the 1870s, but remained relatively rare until the late 20th century, according to the Oxford English Dictionary. **Denialism** is now commonly defined as "the policy or stance of denying the existence or reality of something, especially something that's supported by most widely respected scientific or historical evidence (e.g., Holocaust denialism)." **The same editorial caveats outlined for "denier" above apply to "denialism."**

In the case of climate change, **it's possible to accept some but not all scientific conclusions because of various interpretations of data** — from disputes over research methodology to data extrapolation and statistical margins of error. This includes squabbles over the estimated speed of future climate change, such as how quickly temperatures will rise, and how various ecosystems will be affected. **Such people are conventionally called critics, doubters, skeptics,** etc. Those words convey relevant detail without resorting to demonizing language. **Rather than reaching for labels, of course, it's often clearest to describe known stands** (e.g., "A third of those surveyed agree the planet is warming but dispute that human beings are largely responsible," or "are skeptical of projected timelines," or "oppose paying higher taxes to try to combat it," and so forth, depending on the views expressed in a given story).

See also [climate change versus global warming](/home/c/climate-change)

### Department

**Department versus department**

**Always use lowercase "department" for local and business departments.** (_Halifax parks department, UBC economics department, Microsoft's sales department_.)

**Capitalize international, national and provincial government departments** (_Department of Health_), **even when abbreviated to proper-noun elements alone**. (_She held senior jobs at Finance and Defence; He worked in Foreign Affairs for 15 years._) **But use lowercase in plural constructions.** (_Expense accounts are being reviewed at the Health and Agriculture departments._)

**Be sure to include the country in the case of foreign government departments** (national and state): _the U.S. Agriculture Department_. (For more details on foreign ministries, see [Ministry versus ministry](/home/m/ministry))


**NOTE: In Canada, the official, legal names of some federal government departments are different from their common "applied" names.** See the related entry on [**ministry names**](/home/m/ministry) for details and best practices.



**Adjectives, people's titles, etc.**
**The actual names of departments are also lowercase when used as adjectives** (the _health budget_, a _finance spokesperson_, a group of _veterans affairs workers_), unless the full name appears (a _Health Canada study_, a _Treasury Board official_). Since full names are rarely used this way (e.g., _finance_ rather than _Department of Finance Canada_ and _veterans affairs_ rather than V_eterans Affairs Canada_), lowercase is more common in adjectival constructions.

**Generally avoid departmental abbreviations, even in web headlines, unless they're well known.** For instance, using _DND_ for _Defence_ is normally OK, since it's common shorthand for Canada's _Department of National Defence_. But using an obscure abbreviation such as _FOC_ for _Fisheries and Oceans Canada_ in a headline is generally confusing and ineffective. Instead, using a slightly longer but more recognizable term (e.g., the single word _Fisheries_) is normally preferred.

**Be aware that some rebranded ministry names are optional.** For example, Fisheries and Oceans Canada technically remains the [Department of Fisheries and Oceans (DFO)](/home/f/fisheries-and-oceans) under the Department of Fisheries and Oceans Act. (It's also had many other names since 1867, including the Department of Naval Services and the Department of Marine and Fisheries.) Also bear in mind that some initially obscure abbreviations can gain common currency over time, such as CRA for the [Canada Revenue Agency](/home/c/canada-revenue-agency), which used to be called Revenue Canada.

**If a department's name is part of a person's current title, capitalize only when that title is _directly_ before the person's name:**


> Health _Minister Leona Aglukkaq
> _Aglukkaq, _Canada's health minister ...
> _Raj Opus, the _minister of community and cultural affairs ...
> _Takasaki, who served as _minister of transportation and public works ...
> _Hnatyshyn, a _former justice minister ..._


See also [titles](/home/t/titles) for related guidelines, including how to handle "junior" members of cabinet with secretary of state designations.

**Although the federal Treasury Board is actually a special cabinet committee, it's conventionally treated in the same way as any department.** Retain the initial capital letters even in adjectival constructions, since this is the full name:


> _Treasury Board President_ Stockwell Day
> Day, who became _president of the Treasury Board_ in January ...
> A _Treasury Board official_ said ...
> She works at the _Treasury Board_.



**'Ministry' as a synonym**
The word **"[ministry](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/m/ministry/ "Ministry")" is used interchangeably with "department"** in news stories. Sometimes both are left out altogether:



> **Department of Crown-Indigenous Relations and Northern Affairs
> ****Ministry of Crown-Indigenous Relations and Northern Affairs
> ****Department of Fisheries and Oceans
> ****Ministry of Fisheries and Oceans****Agriculture Canada
> ****Department of National Defence
> ****Defence Department** (_not_ –se, even in the case of the U.S.)
> **Labour Department** (_not_ –or, even in the case of the U.S.)
> **German Health Ministry
> ****Transportation and Communications
> ****Transportation Department**


Be aware that some provinces and territories prefer the term "department" while some prefer the term "ministry" in official names. However, we're not obligated to try to match their arbitrary choices. The tradition of **treating the generic words "department" and "ministry" as synonyms in Canada is based on conventional usage.** This, in turn, reflects the logic that all federal, provincial and territorial government departments are all run by Crown ministers. **The fact that the default French translation of government "department" is "ministry" has also affected Canadian English over time** (e.g., in French, the formal names of the federal Department of Finance, the Department of Health and the Department of Transport are _Ministère des Finances_, _Ministère de la Santé_, and _Ministère des Transports_, respectively).


See also [defence, labour and centre](/home/d/defence-labour-and-centre)
See also [capitalization](/home/c/capitalization)

### dependant

**Dependent (adj.) versus dependant (noun)**

Although many Americans no longer spell the adjective and noun differently, a lot of Canadian and British writers still do. CBC News maintains the distinction:


**Adjective:**
_All three children are **dependent** on her for everyday needs._

**Noun:**
_Sally is still a **dependant**._

Note: **dependence** (_not_ –ance) is the **opposite of independence**.

### deserter versus resister

**military deserter versus war resister**

Someone who leaves a country's army, air force, navy or special forces without permission (i.e., without being formally discharged) is commonly called a **_deserter_**. The term is **OK in general discussions** about U.S. military personnel who have come to Canada to avoid being sent on combat assignments. **But prefer _war resister_ in stories that name people until these individuals have actually been convicted of desertion.**

While Citizenship and Immigration Canada has used the noun "military deserter" in its refugee guidelines, it acknowledges that confirming the crime of desertion in a foreign jurisdiction is complex. Parliamentary committees, meanwhile, have used "war resister." **Since there can be many reasons for desertion, the compound term war resister actually carries more meaning because it instantly conveys objection to combat duty.**

Deserters and resisters often describe themselves as **conscientious objectors.** Since that label is vague, however, **prefer specifying an individual's reasons for claiming the right to refuse military service** — which can range from religious beliefs to personal views about pacifism and morality. The term **draft dodger** refers to citizens who find ways of avoiding military service during times of conscription or mandatory draft. **They are not deserters** in the traditional sense since they were never actively enlisted in the military. In the 1960s, draft dodger was commonly applied to U.S. citizens who came to Canada to avoid serving in the Vietnam War.

### diagnosis versus prognosis

**Diagnosis versus prognosis**

**A diagnosis involves identifying a problem** based on reviewing symptoms and examining available evidence. It's a noun. The verb is diagnose. **A prognosis, by contrast, is a forecast. It's a noun.**


**Diagnosis**
Although diagnosis often refers to the investigation of a medical condition, it's a generic word that can be applied to other sources of trouble (e.g., diagnosing an electrical or mechanical fault).

**Remember: Experts diagnose problems** (e.g., illnesses, poor wiring, security breaches) **rather than things or people.**


> **Wrong**
>
> After six months of testing, they **diagnosed him** with a rare form of cancer.
>
> **Correct**
>
> After six months of testing, **a rare form of cancer was diagnosed.**

> > > > > > OR

> After six months of testing, doctors confirmed he had a rare form of cancer.

**Prognosis**
Concluding that someone has a specific disease is a diagnosis. Predicting a full recovery within 12 months is a prognosis.

**While it's acceptable to describe a prognosis as "good" or "bad" if that's the only information available, such adjectives are vague. Our audience benefits from more specific information,** such as: "She's started chemotherapy. But doctors say the odds of her living more than six months are remote."

Since prognosis involves a projection, doctors sometimes qualify how certain they are about effective treatment and recovery. If they've specified a margin of error or made their forecast conditional in some other way, always include this information in news stories.

### dike versus dyke

**Dike versus dyke**

**Use dike** (not dyke) **when referring to an embankment or ditch.** Both are legitimate spellings. But the Canadian Oxford lists dike as the preferred term.

**Generally avoid using either word** (_dike_ or _dyke_) **to describe gay women, except in established proper nouns** (e.g., Toronto's annual Dyke March) **that are considered neutral rather than derogatory.** In these cases, dyke is the preferred spelling. (See also [**2SLGBTQ+**](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/l/2slgbtq/ "2SLGBTQ+") for related guidelines)

### dilemma

**Dilemma**

For years, many language authorities argued that the word "dilemma" must refer to a pair of equally unpleasant options — based on the original Greek meaning ("double proposition" or "double premise"). But the word's meaning has gradually expanded over the centuries to include "**a difficult situation**." This **usage is widespread and perfectly acceptable**, according to the Canadian Oxford Dictionary.


Two related points:


> 1\. It's a myth that "dilemma" applies only to two choices. Given the word's roots, however, **careful writers normally limit use of dilemma to cases when the number of alternatives is relatively small, and when each possibility is both specific and unappealing.** Otherwise, a broader synonym such as **predicament** is often preferred.
>
> 2\. It's no bull that the phrase "**on the horns of a dilemma**" offers nothing to most scripts beyond the painful poke of cliché.


See also [grammar](/handy-links/grammar)

### Disability language

**Disability language | An overview**

**This is a highly sensitive area of language.** For example, a perfectly acceptable noun (schizophrenia) might be considered objectionable to some when used as an adjective (schizophrenic) in certain cases, as explained in more detail below. **The rest of this entry outlines broad principles as well as some specific direction. When in doubt about wording not addressed here, ask your supervisor.**


[Specific terms](/home/d/disability-language#specificterms) (from able-bodied to wheelchair)
[External resource](/home/d/disability-language#externalresource) (federal government booklet)


**Guiding principles**

-   **Do not mention physical or mental disabilities/conditions unless they're relevant** to the story.
-   **Make sure the wording is accurate** (e.g., distinguish between temporary brain injury, permanent brain damage, mental disability and mental illness).
-   **Use meaningful language** (e.g., "people with disabilities" is clear while "passengers who need help boarding planes" could also mean the very old, the very young, the ill, someone temporarily on crutches).
-   **Avoid euphemisms** ("physically disadvantaged") **as well as dated or disputed colloquialisms** (e.g., use "joined at the waist" or "conjoined twins" rather than "Siamese twins").
-   **Add specific detail when known** rather than relying on vague labels (e.g., prefer "she can't walk because of a spinal cord injury" instead of "she's immobile," and "he has the mental capacity of a five-year-old" instead of simply "he's mentally disabled").
-   **Emphasize the person rather than the disability whenever possible** by leaning toward nouns rather than adjectives (e.g., "a person with epilepsy" rather than "an epileptic man," and "a person with schizophrenia" rather than "a schizophrenic "), **unless (i) individuals in a given story are known to have a different preference. or (ii) a given community widely leans toward a different approach** (e.g., "an autistic student" rather than "a student with autism"). Since this point comes up a lot in journalism, a longer discussion appears in the [practical application](/home/d/disability-language#nounsvsadjectives) section below.
-   **Embrace neutral, fact-based wording** (e.g., people "use" wheelchairs, they're not "confined" to them, and people "have" cancer, they're not "victims" of cancer).
-   **Be respectful but not patronizing, and avoid perpetuating stereotypes** (e.g., don't imply that all people with disabilities are either super-achievers, with words such as "inspirational" and "remarkable," or tragic figures, with words such as "brave" and "courageous").

**Practical application**
**Direct, neutral and meaningful language**
**To keep our journalism clear and fair, we prefer direct and neutral language.** We recognize that English evolves, and that some previously common terms are no longer considered appropriate. But **we do not automatically embrace all newly coined expressions and politically popular labels about disabilities**. Instead, we assess the pros and cons of wording, keeping in mind our overall audience as well as the specific people we're writing about.


> EXAMPLE: Describing a blind person as "visually impaired" is considered needlessly lofty and potentially offensive, equating members of the sightless community with, say, those with temporarily fuzzy vision. Calling someone "partly blind" is OK, but be aware that it can also be too vague in some cases. When details are known, and when there's room in a story, provide our audience with as much relevant information as possible. Does the man have only peripheral or blurry vision? Does the woman have only 25 per cent of her sight? If you use terms that are open to interpretation (e.g., "legally blind"), be sure to define them (e.g., "less than 10 per cent of central vision"), and keep in mind that classifications such as "legally blind" may not be pertinent unless the story deals with a dispute over, say, special transit passes or government assistance.


**Emphasizing people rather than disabilities, disorders, addictions**

**Something as subtle as choosing to use a noun** (a person with a "disability," a person with "epilepsy," a person with an "addiction") **rather than an adjective** (a "disabled" person) or **an adjective used as a noun** (an "epileptic"), **can change a story's tone.** Using a noun is commonly called **person-first writing** while using an adjective has come to be known as **identity-first writing**. Be aware that there is **no consensus on which approach is best.** Sometimes the choice of certain phrasing is obvious ("a person with bipolar disorder") because the alternative is so jarringly odd ("a bipolar disorder person"). Often, however, it boils down to individual preference. So while some Canadians insist on person-first wording (e.g., "people with disabilities"), others say they strongly prefer identity-first constructions (e.g., "disabled people") because they consider their disabilities or medical conditions to be a core part of their identities. **Whenever possible, ask those we're reporting on how they want to be described and respect those individual preferences.**

When we describe or quote people, we must always remember that they are human beings with disabilities and various medical conditions rather than disabilities or medical conditions occupying the bodies of human beings.

It is important to also be conscious of language that implies disabilities are a negative attribute or refers to them in a derogatory manner. You might think about, for example, word use that [this Government of Canada online reference](https://www.canada.ca/en/employment-social-development/programs/accessible-canada-regulations-guidance/consultation/inclusive-language.html#h2.2) describes as “ableist” language: “Ableism is a view or attitude that treats people without disabilities as ‘normal’ and those with disabilities as ‘abnormal,’ ‘inferior,’ or ‘other.’” **Ableist expressions are common in everyday language, but, outside of quotes, we should consider alternative wording to avoid phrases that include pejorative imagery** — for example, whether the same sentiment might be expressed in a story by using “ignore” rather than “turn a blind eye.”

Be aware that **different trends can emerge over time.** In the fall of 2022, for instance, **Autism Ontario declared its preference for "autistic person" over "person with autism,"** unless a given individual requests different usage. Polling by various research groups strongly suggests that this identity-first writing is endorsed by a large majority of autistic adults across North America. For this reason, we adjusted our approach to the word "autistic" in June of 2023. **CBC News now generally recommends "autistic" over "person with autism" in generic references, but to continue to ask for, and to respect, known preferences when reporting on individuals
**

**Specific terms**
No two stories are identical, and the general principles above are intended to help staff make individual choices. But **since some words and phrases come up more than others, the alphabetical list below provides specific direction to keep our journalism consistent.**

**able-bodied** — Usually unnecessary. People are assumed to be able-bodied unless a relevant disability is mentioned. Instead of using the general term "able-bodied," it's often best simply to specify the opposite of the disability already cited (e.g., people who can see, people who can hear, people who can walk). Another option is to say people with and without disabilities, or in some contexts [disabled people](/home/d/disability-language#disabled) and non-disabled people. Never call those without disabilities "[normal](/home/d/disability-language#normal)" or "healthy," which implies that others are abnormal or unhealthy.

**abnormal** — Offensive when applied to people. Avoid. It suggests those with disabilities fail to live up to some ideal norm or standard. It also implies that they are different in ways beyond a specific disability. See also [normal](/home/d/disability-language#normal) for limited use of that modifier to specify ranges (i.e., to describe specific abilities, such as "normal hearing," rather than to categorize people).

**accessible, accessibility** — A broad term that applies to doors with ramps, transit stations with elevators, washrooms with large stalls, etc. It's also used in descriptive compounds (e.g., **wheelchair accessible vehicles**). Accessible is the preferred adjective for special parking (**accessible parking, accessible parking permits**) as long as there's no ambiguity. For instance, a business without "accessible parking" could refer to a store on a pedestrian walkway, such as Sparks Street in Ottawa, that doesn't have parking for anyone. Make sure the context is clear. Otherwise, [disabled](#disabled) can be considered as a modifier (e.g., "disabled parking," "disabled parking permits," etc.), when referring to specific spots/passes for those who qualify. Avoid the dated term "handicapped parking."

**addict, addiction** — Prefer "people with addiction" over "addicts."
