See [practical application](/home/d/disability-language#nounsvsadjectives) above for guidelines on emphasizing people over specific conditions, disorders, etc., as well as the [addiction overview](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/a/addiction/ "Addiction") for related caveats.

**afflicted by, suffers from, suffers with, etc.** — Avoid. These are considered pitying phrases at best and judgmentally inaccurate descriptions at worst (not all people with disabilities suffer). Use neutral verbs such as "has" (she has cancer, he has AIDS) and "is" (she is deaf, he is blind). See our **[health reporting overview](/home/h/health_reporting)** for related, general principles.

**autistic, person with autism** — While both terms are relatively common, especially in medical circles, **prefer autistic as the default choice in generic references** (e.g., autistic adults, autistic Canadians). This is known as identity-first writing, and since the early 2020s has become the form embraced by many autistic community advocacy groups. **When reporting on specific people, however, follow an individual's preference.** There's no ban against person-first writing (e.g., "children with autism"), and the phrasing can sometimes be used interchangeably with identity-first writing. Although the modifier "autistic" is increasingly used as a noun, too, including in the names of organizations (e.g., the Ontario group **Autistics for Autistics**), it's usually best to recast such syntax unless attributed (e.g., "autistic athletes competed" rather than "autistics competed"). See [practical application](/home/d/disability-language#nounsvsadjectives) above for related background on adjectives and nouns, as well as [autism spectrum disorder](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/a/#autism "A").

**barren** — Avoid this offensive colloquialism for infertility.

**blind** — Fine as an adjective (a blind person, the blind community) or as an attributive noun (people who are blind). But generally avoid using as a noun after the definite article (the blind), which suggests they constitute a separate class within society. Use terms such as **partially sighted** or **partly blind** instead of "visually impaired," which some people find offensive because it negatively stresses a medical condition instead of neutrally identifying someone as a member of the sightless or partially sightless community. The exception is when "visually impaired" is a person's declared preference. Add detail (e.g., "He has only peripheral vision") when known and relevant. See [impaired](/home/d/disability-language#impaired) for related guidelines.

**challenged** — A weak synonym for impairment or disability that is not recommended. Prefer "mental impairment" or "[mental disability](/home/d/disability-language#mentallydisabled)" over "mental challenge." The Canadian Oxford Guide to English Usage points out: "The term 'challenged' ... is a euphemism that has spawned jokes such as 'vertically challenged' for short people and 'sartorially challenged' for sloppy dressers. It's not recommended for serious use."

**confined** — Avoid phrases such as "confined to a wheelchair." See [wheelchair](/home/d/disability-language#wheelchairs) for details.

**congenital** — An acceptable but lofty word that means "from birth," as in a congenital disability or deformity. Prefer specific statements (e.g., blind since birth, born without arms, unable to walk since birth, born with a facial disfigurement that makes it hard to talk). When referring to specific people, avoid terms such as "birth defects," which are considered offensive because they're seen to dismiss individuals as defective rather than to neutrally report information. While general references to "birth defects" are sometimes OK (e.g., "Zika is a mosquito-borne disease that can cause birth defects"), prefer recasting such broad statements whenever possible (e.g, "Zika is a mosquito-borne disease that can cause brain damage in fetuses").

**crazy** — Offensive and judgmental. Do not use. See [mentally ill](/home/d/disability-language#mentallyill).

**cripple, crippled** — Offensive. Do not use as a noun, verb or modifier to refer to people. Although the word "cripple" remains common in other contexts (e.g., to "cripple the economy" and a "crippled industry"), careful writers avoid such usage outside of directly attributed quotes, given the term's close association with outmoded and pejorative labels for physical disabilities. Be respectful. There are numerous conversational and equally effective alternatives available, from "damage" to "hamper" and "hinder" (e.g., to "hurt the economy," a "hobbled industry").

**deaf** — Fine as an adjective in most cases (a deaf person, the deaf students), or as an attributive noun (people who are deaf). But generally avoid using as a noun after the definite article (the deaf), which suggests they constitute a separate class within society. **Deaf** (capitalized) is acceptable when referring to a culture with its own language and customs (the Deaf community). This can lead to constructions such as: "Jones, who is deaf, says she thinks the government needs to invest more in Deaf education programs." Be aware that not all members of the Deaf community use a capital D. There's also no established convention of a capital B for the blind community. Use **hard of hearing** instead of "hearing impaired" because the latter stresses a medical condition with a label rather than a person with a cultural identity. The exception is when "hearing impaired" is a person's declared preference. Another option is **partly deaf** if individuals use this wording, themselves. Be aware, however, that "partly deaf" is not as widely embraced as hard of hearing. Never use the phrase deaf and dumb. Also, avoid deaf-mute, which is inaccurate (most people who are deaf can speak) and belittling. Different sign languages are used around the world. The terms sign language interpreter or signer are common and understandable. Avoid "deaf signer," which implies the interpreter is either deaf or signing solely for those who have no hearing. See [mute](/home/d/disability-language#mute) for more details, as well as [impaired](/home/d/disability-language#impaired) for related guidelines.

**defects, birth defects** — Avoid when referring to specific people or groups. See [congenital](/home/d/disability-language#congenital).

**developmentally impaired** — A term that's often too vague to be helpful since it can cover everything from physical and mental development to emotional maturity, acquisition of basic social skills, etc. There's also debate over how to apply this phrase accurately (e.g., restricted to those under 18 or also OK for certain adults). Prefer more specific language that conveys relevant detail about a mental or physical disability, such as [mentally disabled](/home/d/disability-language#mentallydisabled).

**diabetic** — While "people with diabetes" is preferred when practical, "diabetic" is common and acceptable. See [practical application](/home/d/disability-language#nounsvsadjectives) above for more details about adjectives and nouns.

**disabled, disability** — Use "disabled" as an adjective (disabled Canadians) or as an attributive noun (people who are disabled). Avoid as a noun after the definite article (the disabled), which suggests they constitute a separate class within society. See [practical application](/home/d/disability-language#nounsvsadjectives) above for guidelines on emphasizing people over specific conditions, disorders, etc. The term disability can be used as a synonym for impairment (e.g., "mental disability"). Although disabled is sometimes fine as a modifier, it should not be used inaptly (e.g., use stalled or stopped rather than "disabled" when referring to a vehicle that's not running, and use **injury list** rather than "disabled list" when referring to hurt athletes removed from an active roster while recovering). Also, prefer fact-based phrasing like **wheelchair accessible buses** over "disabled buses" as long as the meaning is clear (see [**accessible parking**](#accessible) for details). Distinguishing between specific disabilities (functional limitations, such as not being able to walk) and diseases or other medical conditions (arthritis, cerebral palsy, multiple sclerosis, Parkinson's) is sometimes important, since there can be a range of impairment that changes over time. Avoid the dated term [handicapped](/home/d/disability-language#handicapped). See also [mentally disabled](/home/d/disability-language#mentallydisabled) for related guidelines.
**
disabled parking, disabled parking permits** — See [accessible](/home/d/disability-language#accessible)

**disadvantaged** — Avoid this unclear euphemism. When reporting on specific problems facing people with disabilities (e.g., lack of accessible public transit), it's fine to point out specific obstacles or disadvantages. But use [disabled](/home/d/disability-language#disabled) when actually referring to physical or mental disabilities.

**dumb** — Offensive. Do not use. See [mute](/home/d/disability-language#mute).

**dwarf, dwarfs, dwarfism** — The term "dwarf" (plural dwarfs not dwarves) is an acceptable term immediately understood by our audience. It's based on the name of a medical condition: dwarfism. Do not use midget. While some advocacy groups in Canada and abroad recommend "little people," that generic compound is normally too vague for news stories. Consider using little people, however, if the context makes the meaning clear. When known, a specific height is a valuable detail. Dwarfism is commonly defined as a medical or genetic condition that leaves adult men and women under 4-10, with the average height closer to four feet.

**dyslexic, dyslexia** — While "people with dyslexia" is the preferred construction when practical, "dyslexic" is OK as an attributive noun (e.g., "people who are dyslexic" and "he is dyslexic"). But do not use it as a noun alone (e.g., Canadian dyslexics). Dyslexia can be described as a [learning disability](/home/d/disability-language#learningdisability).

**epileptic, epilepsy** — While "people with epilepsy" is preferred when practical, "epileptic" is common and acceptable. See [practical application](/home/d/disability-language#nounsvsadjectives) above for more details about nouns and adjectives. People with epilepsy have [seizures](/home/d/disability-language#seizure) not fits, spells, etc.

**handicapped** — Although once very common, the term is now dated and considered offensive, with overtones of "hand-in-cap" begging. There's also the complaint that the word exaggerates limitations (e.g., a person in wheelchair is not handicapped in a workplace if there's a ramp at the door and accessible facilities, including washrooms). Prefer the more neutral word [disabled](/home/d/disability-language#disabled) and its variations (e.g., person with a disability). Note: In golf stories, the entrenched use of numerical "handicaps" to gauge amateur players' abilities is fine.

**hearing impaired** — Avoid. See [deaf, partly deaf](/home/d/disability-language#deaf)

**impaired, impairment** — Acceptable as synonyms for disabled, disability in certain cases, especially when a medical condition is being stressed (e.g., a cognitive impairment). While the word "impaired" usually suggests either partial loss of an ability or a correctable problem, be aware that it can be offensive to people who think it needlessly labels them. Someone who can't see anything is blind, for instance, while someone who has less than full sight is partly blind. Referring to them as "visually impaired" can suggest they're no different from someone with temporarily blurry vision caused by eye drops at an optometrist's office. See also [disabled](/home/d/disability-language#disabled).

**invalid** — Avoid. Originally meant "not strong," especially of wounded soldiers unfit to return to battle. Today, the word invalid suggests not only frailty but also helplessness. It's insulting and inaccurate to label people with disabilities as weak and unable to take care of themselves. See [handicapped](/home/d/disability-language#handicapped) for a similar caveat.

**insane, insanity** — Avoid except when tied to a confirmed medical diagnosis. In court cases, insanity or other language that refers to mental competence may require a legal finding. It's OK to report that a lawyer is arguing that her client was temporarily insane or mentally unfit when a crime was committed, as long as suitable attribution is given. But baldly describing someone as [mentally ill](/home/d/disability-language#mentallyill) is potentially libellous (e.g., just because someone has spent time in a psychiatric ward does not mean they are mentally ill).

**intellectually disabled** — OK when preferred by a given person or group, but prefer [mentally disabled](/home/d/disability-language#mentallydisabled) or mentally impaired in general, public policy coverage. 

**learning disability** — OK when specifically referring to a learning disability, such as [dyslexia](/home/d/disability-language#dyslexic). But don't use as a vague euphemism for [mental disability](/home/d/disability-language#mentallydisabled) (general cognitive impairment). Keep in mind that someone can have a very high IQ but still have some sort of perpetual learning problem. Avoid the awkward noun "learning disabled." Prefer saying that the person has a learning disability. And always define unfamiliar jargon (e.g., say that someone has trouble remembering certain words or names rather than reporting that they have "anomic aphasia"). See also [special needs](/home/d/disability-language#specialneeds).

**mental** — Do not use. Offensive. But see [mentally disabled](/home/d/disability-language#mentallydisabled) for acceptable terms.

**mentally disabled, mentally impaired** — Common and acceptable terms covering a range of cognitive impairment, from low intelligence, slow brain processing and the inability to retain and recall information to difficulty developing language and basic problem-solving skills. But avoid using after the definite article (the mentally disabled, the mentally impaired), which suggests they constitute a separate class within society. The phrase mentally challenged is euphemistic and not recommended (see [challenged](/home/d/disability-language#challenged) above). The term **intellectually disabled** is OK when preferred by a given group or person. But keep in mind that "intellectually disabled" is sometimes a poor choice, especially in general coverage, because it narrowly refers to intelligence. While cognitively disabled is accurate, it's less conversational. Keep in mind that these are all relatively broad labels. When known, it's better to supply specific information (e.g., a person has [Down syndrome](/home/d#downsyndrome)). This includes differentiating between mental disability from birth, temporary or permanent brain damage at some point after birth, and diseases that affect memory and other brain function (e.g., if someone has advanced [Alzheimer's](/home/d/dementia), we should explain this in a story rather describe them as mentally impaired). Do not use the offensive slang "mental." See [retarded](/home/d/disability-language#retarded) for an important, related caution. Also, keep in mind that mentally disabled is not the same as [mentally ill](/home/d/disability-language#mentallyill).

**mentally ill** — This requires psychiatric or psychological testing and diagnosis. It refers to insanity, mental instability, depression, schizophrenia, etc. By contrast, someone who has an extremely low IQ, a medical disorder such as Down syndrome, etc., is [mentally disabled](/home/d/disability-language#mentallydisabled). The compound **mental illness** is common, neutral and factual. Just as we talk about **physical health**, we also refer to **mental health**. Indeed, virtually all provinces have the equivalent of a Mental Health Act. Since terms like mentally ill and insane are potentially libellous, they require special caution (e.g., just because someone has been ordered to undergo psychiatric testing does not mean they are mentally ill). See also [insanity](/home/d/disability-language#insane).

**midget** — Avoid. Considered highly offensive. See [dwarf, dwarfs](/home/d/disability-language#dwarf).

**mute** — Avoid. The label is considered belittling. And never use deaf-mute or deaf and dumb. If someone cannot speak and it's relevant to the story, simply report this fact. But consider framing the detail in a less negative or judgmental way by emphasizing what they can do, as opposed to what they can't (e.g., that they communicate with sign language, with a voice synthesizer, with pen and paper, with the help of a computer). See also [deaf](/home/d/disability-language#deaf) for related guidelines.

**non-disabled** — OK to mean people without disabilities. See [able-bodied](/home/d/disability-language#ablebodied) for details.

**normal** — Never refer to people without disabilities as normal. But the term is OK in general descriptions of specific abilities (e.g., normal vision, near-normal hearing), since it can helpfully and neutrally indicate ranges. See also [able-bodied](/home/d/disability-language#ablebodied).

**paraplegic** — Entrenched and acceptable as a noun (a paraplegic) and as an adjective (paraplegic research), and as an attributive noun (people who are paraplegics). These constructions are much more direct and conversational than alternatives, such as "people with paraplegia." If labels can be avoided, however, prefer reporting descriptive facts (e.g., she's paralyzed from the waist down, her legs are paralyzed, she can't walk).

**quadriplegic** — Entrenched and acceptable as a noun (a quadriplegic) and as an adjective (a quadriplegic specialist), and as an attributive noun (people who are quadriplegics). These constructions are much more direct and conversational than alternatives, such as "people with quadriplegia." If labels can be avoided, however, prefer reporting descriptive facts (e.g., she's paralyzed from the neck down, her arms and legs are paralyzed, she can't move any of her limbs).

**retard, retarded, mentally retarded** — Do not use. Although terms such as retardation and mental retardation remain common in some parts of the world, they are now considered highly offensive in Canada. It's irrelevant that retard simply means "slow" in Latin (the etymology is sometimes cited as an objective and effective way to communicate delayed mental development). It also doesn't matter that the clinical diagnosis of "mental retardation" is still found in respected medical journals. Connotation can be as important as denotation when judging what's appropriate in our journalism, and constructions such as "mentally retarded" are instantly linked to "retard" and other highly objectionable slang. Instead, use [mentally disabled](/home/d/disability-language#learningdisability) or mentally impaired. Even the verb is best avoided unless attributed (e.g., "to retard growth"), along the lines of [cripple](/home/d/disability-language#cripple).

**schizophrenic** — Prefer "people with schizophrenia" over "schizophrenic person." (See [practical application](/home/d/disability-language#nounsvsadjectives) above for more details about adjectives and nouns.) Schizophrenia is a [mental illness](/home/d/disability-language#mentallyill). Its symptoms vary, but can include confusion, delusion and paranoia. Limit use of schizophrenia to its medical meaning of psychosis. Never toss it around as a fancy description for someone who is merely inconsistent, undecided, etc.

**seeing eye dog** — Generally prefer [service dog or service animal](/home/d/disability-language#servicedog), especially in generic references.

**seizure** — This is the proper term to describe the convulsions or blackouts that people with epilepsy have. Avoid terms such as fits, attacks, spells, etc. See also [epilepsy](/home/d/disability-language#epilepsy).

**service dog, service animal** — Preferred terms for dogs that have been specially trained to help people with various disabilities. While service dogs may well help guide individuals who are blind, they sometimes also perform other work, depending on their background — from assisting people who are deaf to pulling wheelchairs, from barking for aid during seizures to calming those having anxiety attacks. For this reason, a broad compound like "service dog" is generally recommended over narrower labels, such as "seeing eye dog" and "guide dog," especially in generic references.

**special needs** — Generally avoid this vague and potentially pejorative euphemism unless it's part of direct quote or a proper noun equivalent (e.g., the name of a school program) and the context makes the meaning clear. Direct attribution is recommended because the expression is increasingly regarded as a dysphemism (i.e., roundabout language more offensive than the original terminology). In generic references, prefer "people with disabilities" over "people with special needs." In narrower references, prefer fact-based details about the disabilities (cognitive, physical, etc.). Saying that someone has special needs raises more questions than it answers. By contrast, saying that someone is in a wheelchair, needs a voice synthesizer to speak or reads at a Grade 2 level helps our audience understand the story we're telling. See also [learning disability](/home/d/disability-language#learningdisability).
**
speech impairment, speech impediment** — Acceptable but vague terms. Prefer specific information, such as a stammer, a cleft palate, a strong lisp, etc. As with all other parts of the story, such detail must be relevant. And never assume someone has a specific condition. A nervous person who stutters a few times during one speech you happened to hear may, in fact, not have a speech impediment.

**suffers from, suffers with** — Avoid. See [afflicted](/home/d/disability-language#afflicted) by for details, including similar phrases considered inappropriate.


**the** (as in the blind, the deaf, the disabled) — Avoid these constructions, which suggest people form separate groups within society based on specific mental or physical conditions. Instead of using the definite article followed by a noun (the blind), use attributive nouns (people who are blind) or adjectives (a blind person). For more details about specific wording, see the relevant entry (e.g., [blind](/home/d/disability-language#blind), [deaf](/home/d/disability-language#deaf), [disabled](/home/d/disability-language#disabled)).
**
visually impaired** — Avoid. See [blind, partly blind](/home/d/disability-language#blind).

**wheelchairs** — Avoid phrases such as "confined to a wheelchair" and "wheelchair-bound." Many people who use wheelchairs consider them mobilizing not confining. There's also the issue of accuracy, since some people in wheelchairs do have other options, including periodic use of canes and walkers. And be sure that all details you include are relevant. Just because someone is in a wheelchair does not mean that this fact needs to be pointed out in the story.


**External resource: Tips for the media covering people with disabilities**
Before tackling specific words and phrases, we make key decisions about story focus and structure. So **when featuring someone with a disability in our journalism, ask:**

-   **Are we pursuing the story because it involves someone with a disability or because it's of interest to the general population?**
-   **Have we picked the best focus?** Concentrating on the obvious human-interest angle (e.g., how a person has overcome great odds) may be clichéd. It can also overshadow issues that haven't received as much attention over the years (e.g., unemployment, income barriers, lack of accessibility to facilities).
-   **Is reference to the disability even necessary?**

Since diversity of voices is important, **we should also reflect on a more general question as all stories are pitched and assigned:**

-   **Are people with disabilities routinely asked for their views about a wide range of topics** — not necessarily because they bring unique perspectives but simply because they're citizens who want to participate in conversations about health care, child care, transportation, the environment, etc., too?

 For more on these and other tips for the media — including advice about interviews — see [Inclusive Language in Media: A Canadian Style Guide](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.humber.ca%2Fmakingaccessiblemedia%2Fmodules%2F06%2Ftransript%2FFinal_Glossary.pdf&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw35Dl4_vnX26bzKzqqJIixy) published in 2017 by Humber College, as well as a 2006 federal government booklet, [A Way with Words and Images: Suggestions for the Portrayal of People with Disabilities](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/media/uyuh3fmh/a_way_with_words_and_images_disabilities_portrayal_gofcanada.pdf "A Way With Words And Images Disabilities Portrayal GofCanada"). For background on mental health, including addiction, see the [Mindset Media Guide](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/media/eszn4anc/mindset_media_guide_thirdedition_2020.pdf "Mindset Media Guide Thirdedition 2020") (3rd edition, 2020) from the Canadian Journalism Forum on Violence and Trauma. Note: While these documents highlight a number of helpful points, they do not necessarily reflect CBC preferences in each case. **Before adopting any external recommendations, always check this Language Guide to see if different internal direction has been specified.**

### disease\_illness

**Disease, disorder, illness, etc.**

There's **overlap between some broad medical labels**, but there are **also distinctions worth noting.**

**Here are a few key points to keep in mind** when using the following common terms:


**condition —** Can refer to overall health (e.g., "their medical condition is good"), as well as to status after injury, surgery, and so forth (e.g., "her condition is stable"). Condition is also commonly used as a synonym for certain diseases, disorders, etc. (e.g., acne is a common skin condition, high blood pressure is a long-term medical condition), An **acute condition is short-lived** (e.g., less than six months), often appears suddenly and can be severe. A **chronic condition lasts longer** (often years), and is sometimes terminal.


**disease —** Describes a **wide array of illnesses**, not just those caused by micro-organisms. The word's **definition is so broad**, in fact, **that it covers virtually anything beyond physical injury that makes a living organism act abnormally**. Technically, therefore, even poisoning is a type of disease. But that's not how the term is commonly used. And it can be unnecessarily confusing to our audience to label, say, exposure to radiation at work an "occupational disease," or to refer to illness from contaminated fruits and vegetables a "food borne disease." Some **common disease classifications** are **infectious** (e.g., hepatitis C, malaria, tuberculosis), **metabolic** (e.g., diabetes, thyroid disease, liver disease), **vascular** (e.g., narrowed or blocked arteries, damaged blood cells) and **degenerative** (e.g., Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, and osteoarthritis). **Other than "infectious," however, specific modifiers are not routinely used in general news reporting**. If someone is born with a specific disease, disorder or condition, it's **congenital**. If it surfaces later and is deemed hereditary, it's commonly called **genetic**. Sometimes, the word "disease" is dropped from a name, especially when more is known about causes and treatments (Hodgkin's lymphoma has largely replaced Hodgkin's disease). This does not automatically mean, however, that the word "disease" is inaccurate (e.g., Hodgkin's lymphoma is a type of cancer, which, by definition, means it's a disease).


**disorder —** Frequently and **acceptably used as a synonym for certain diseases, especially non-infectious diseases** (e.g., a kidney disorder, a sleeping disorder, a psychiatric disorder). **Sometimes, disorder is more narrowly defined** as an identifiable symptom of an overall condition or disease (e.g., arrhythmia, also known as an irregular heartbeat, is a disorder that normally falls under the bigger umbrella of cardiovascular disease). **Be aware that there's a growing trend by certain groups to prefer "disorder" over "disease" because the latter term is viewed as comparatively negative**. Since the two words are now increasingly used interchangeably, there's no need to insist on "disease" when "disorder" is more common in specific contexts.


**illness —** Common and **acceptable as a general label for certain diseases, disorders, etc.** (e.g., "she rarely complains about her illness"). **However, the word is often used in a more narrow way that conveys the sense of specific symptoms** (e.g., difficulty breathing, partial paralysis, vomiting, cognitive impairment). When someone is fighting the flu, for instance, they're described as "ill" or "sick" because they have various flu symptoms, such as fever, sinus congestion and a sore throat. **This sense of "illness" can be useful in certain reporting**, because not everyone who has a given disease, or who is carrying a virus that causes a given disease, will exhibit symptoms right away. **One can have a disease** (e.g., some forms of cancer) **without experiencing illness for months or years**. Just as with the word "disorder" above, **be aware that there's a growing trend by certain people to prefer "illness" over "disease" because the latter term is viewed as comparatively negative.** Although the two words are often used interchangeably, there's no need to insist on "disease" when "illness" is more common in specific contexts. At the same time, there's no reason to abandon entrenched language (e.g., STD for "sexually transmitted disease") and to insist on a variation (e.g., STI for "sexually transmitted illness") solely because some individuals prefer describing, say, chlamydia, gonorrhea, syphilis, etc., in one way (as STIs) but not in another, equally accurate way (as STDs). When faced with two or more acceptable choices, **generally prefer language familiar to our audience, and be consistent within a given story.**


**sickness —** A colloquial and **acceptable term to describe some illnesses**, especially **routine bacterial infections** (e.g., strep throat) **and viral infections** (e.g., the common cold). **Avoid in the context of mental illnesses** (e.g., "sick in the head"), which can trivialize serious health problems, including various psychiatric disorders.


**syndrome —** A set of **symptoms tied to a specific disorder, disease or condition**. In the case of new illnesses, **the word is sometimes used early on to describe an unnamed cluster of symptoms** (e.g., [AIDS](/home/a/aids), for acquired immune deficiency syndrome in the early 1980s, and [SARS](/home/s/sars) for severe acute respiratory syndrome two decades later). **Unless names are self-explanatory** (e.g., dry eye syndrome, chronic fatigue syndrome), **they should be defined**. Sometimes, the names are based on proper nouns (e.g., Down syndrome). Certain psychiatric conditions or psychological behaviour can fall into this category (e.g., hostages displaying signs of sympathy toward their captors is conventionally known as Stockholm syndrome).


**symptom —** A **sign of a possible medical problem** (e.g., severe headache, pain, numbness). **Distinctions are sometimes made between objective, observable "signs"** (e.g., fever, coughing) **and subjective, descriptive "symptoms"** sensed only by the patient (e.g., tiredness, sadness). Unless detail about symptom measurability is central to a given story, it's perfectly acceptable to use "symptom" and "sign" synonymously.

See also [health reporting](/home/h/health_reporting) (diseases, medical conditions, etc.) for general guidelines about accuracy (e.g., epidemic versus pandemic), clarity, respect, and so forth, including how to handle sometimes disputed terms like "battling cancer" and "survivor."

See also [disability language](/home/d/disability-language) (e.g., avoid "afflicted by" and "suffers from"), which includes an overview of our default practice of emphasizing people rather than disabilities whenever practical (e.g., a "person with epilepsy" rather than "an epileptic").



### Crimea

**Donbas (Donetsk, Luhansk)**

**Donbas is a disputed region between southeastern Ukraine and Russia**, where Ukrainian government forces have been fighting Russian-backed separatists since 2014. **It can be accurately called a conflict zone.** Donbas is short for **Donets Coal Basin**, but this does not need to be spelled out in news stories. The industrial area has been known for its coal mining and steel manufacturing since the mid-1800s.

**The region has effectively been divided since 2015.** Kyiv controls the western parts, while **two separatist factions control the eastern parts, which they've named the Donetsk People's Republic (DPR) and Luhansk People's Republic (LPR).** The eastern areas include major cities like Donetsk and Luhansk as well as the border with Russia. Although widely recognized as part of Ukraine by much of the world, many of the region's Russian-speaking citizens no longer consider themselves Ukrainians. **To make clear which areas are not run by government forces, use phrasing such as separatist-controlled or rebel-controlled.**

The exact boundaries of Donbas are a source of debate. In most news stories, the proper noun normally refers to **two neighboring administrative regions: Donetsk and Luhansk.** It's **a common practice simply to report on whatever region applies, rather than to Donbas as a whole** (e.g., we might refer to increased fighting in Donetsk). Be aware that such regions are sometimes called oblasts, based on old Soviet Union terminology. Since each oblast has a city with the same name, **it can be helpful to specify what is meant by a given proper noun** (e.g., the **Donetsk region** versus the **city of Donetsk**), unless the meaning is obvious from context. Although the word "oblast" is in the Canadian Oxford Dictionary, it's relatively obscure and, so, does not need to be used.

**Attribute anything contested**
As with coverage of any disputed territory, **our journalism should be fact-based and reflect the realities on the ground.** This includes how we report geographical detail (e.g., use **"Donetsk" rather than "Donetsk, Ukraine"**). Stories can provide additional information whenever practical, but it's unrealistic to expect something as succinct as, say, a TV locator to capture the subtleties and complexities of fluid territorial fighting.

**Roughly seven months after invading other parts of Ukraine in February 2022**, including land along the country's northern, eastern and southern borders, **Moscow announced that it was formally annexing Donetsk, Luhansk and** two other regions held by Russian troops farther south: **Kherson and Zaporizhzhia**..The move came after hastily organized referendums that Kyiv and most of the international community called illegitimate. It's accurate to refer to the ongoing fighting as **Russia's [war](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/m/military-terms-overview/#war "Military terms overview") in Ukraine**, **Russia's [invasion](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/m/military-terms-overview/#invasion "Military terms overview") of Ukraine**, etc., as well as to **Russian-occupied territory**, and to **widely denounced referendums, unrecognized referendums, contested annexations, self-declared annexations, repudiated annexations**, etc.

Use attribution to flag contested proper nouns, including DPR and LPR. **Phrasing such as "self-proclaimed" or "self-declared" or "which calls itself" is recommended.** For example, over TV footage of soldiers, we might say something like, "Pro-Russian militants with the **self-proclaimed Donetsk People’s Republic** can be seen conducting combat exercises." When practical, providing additional detail can help our audience understand the bigger picture (e.g., **pro-Russian groups in the Donetsk and Luhansk regions declared independence from Ukraine in 2014 after disputed referendums** that most of the international community dismissed as illegitimate).

**Prefer the entrenched spellings Donbas, Donetsk and Luhansk.** Avoid other transliterations such as "Doneck" and "Lugansk." See also [Ukrainian names](/home/u/ukrainian-names) and [Russian names](/home/r/russian-names)


See **[Crimea](/home/c/Crimea)** for related guidelines (e.g., it's accurate to refer to Russia's annexation and occupation of Crimea, but misleading to refer to an "invasion").

### Dr.

**Dr.**

[Avoid gender bias](/home/d/dr#Dr-PhD-gender) (The pros of 'Prof.' for PhDs)

**Apply 'Dr.' to licensed health-care professionals only**
Reserve the honorific Dr. for licensed health-care professionals. **Our style is not intended to diminish the effort needed to get a PhD in any particular discipline. Rather, it's designed to help our audience quickly identify people in the health-care field who are commonly referred to as "doctors."**

In Canada, individual provinces determine which health-care professionals are able to use the honorific "Dr." Legislation, such as [Ontario's Regulated Health Professions Act](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ontario.ca%2Flaws%2Fstatute%2F91r18%23BK31&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3RVmMvR6jlbmYiH65bOBx7), specifies who is eligible. **The list of health-care professionals used by CBC News features the most common categories:**

> **dentists**
>
> **chiropractors**
>
> **optometrists**
>
> **physicians** (including **psychiatrists**) **and surgeons**
>
> **psychologists**
>
> **veterinarians**


Veterinarians are conventionally called doctors because they perform the equivalent work of MDs on animals, including surgery.

**Never imply that people are licensed medical doctors when they're not.** This normally means specifying whether someone is a dentist, optometrist, chiropractor, etc., high in the story.

**A person's specific job** (e.g., virologist, microbiologist) **or employer** (e.g., Public Health Agency of Canada, Mayo Clinic College of Medicine and Science) **does not determine whether "Dr." applies**. For example, if the head of the World Health Organization is a research scientist with a PhD in community health, do not include "Dr." before the name. If the person has an MD, by contrast, add the honorific.

**In the case of PhDs, it's often simplest and clearest to describe a person's job or specialization** ("U of T history Prof. Bert Reith" or "Bert Reith, who teaches history at the University of Toronto" but NOT "Dr. Bert Reith"). **Licensed psychologists are an exception to the PhD rule** because they are considered health-care professionals. **Stick to one honorific per person** (e.g., if an epidemiologist has an MD as well as a PhD, there's no need to add "Prof." before her name when she's already called "Dr.").


**GENDER BIAS CAUTION:** (1) **Ensure that women and men are treated in the same way** (e.g., if one person with an MD in a story is called "Dr." then everyone with an MD in the same report should be called "Dr."); and (2) **Avoid even the perception of gender discrimination when distinguishing between MDs and PhDs**. In particular, **be aware that referring only to men as "Dr." in a story can unintentionally telegraph a misleading message about women in the same report** when the former have MDs and the latter have PhDs — **especially since not everyone in our audience will be familiar with our approach to the honorific.** In 2020, for example, we received more than one ombudsman complaint about COVID-19 coverage that happened to quote male medical doctors (who were all called "Dr.") and female scientists with PhDs (who were not given comparable abbreviated titles before their names in the same stories). **PREFER PARALLEL CONSTRUCTION in such cases by adding applicable detail** (e.g., use "**Prof.**" or "**Assoc. Prof.**" or whatever title is accurate for the person with a PhD, and "**Dr.**" for the person with an MD). **This does not mean that we must always use a job description like "Prof." before scholars' names** solely because they teach at colleges or universities. That would be too formulaic and restrictive. **But in coverage featuring some people with MDs and some people with PhDs, we should use wording that steers clear of even the appearance of gender bias.**



**Prefer specific detail over vague honorifics**
**Since there are so many different types of doctors, it's important to put someone's credentials in context.** Is she a family doctor? An infectious disease specialist? A psychologist with expertise in counselling young victims of sexual abuse? **If a person's health-care qualifications are clear in a story, the honorific Dr. can be dropped** (e.g., "Vancouver dermatologist Azeeza Khan called the research alarming" rather than "Vancouver dermatologist Dr. Azeeza Khan called the research alarming").

**Be certain you understand all labels used** (e.g., a psychiatrist has an MD while a psychologist does not, an ophthalmologist has an MD while an optometrist does not, and the noun [anesthesiologist](/home/a/anesthesiologist-versus-anesthetist) is generally preferred over "anesthetist" in Canada). **In the case of naturopaths, avoid the honorific "Dr."** (e.g., "naturopath Joyce Wong" rather than "naturopathic Dr. Joyce Wong"). Add specific professional affiliations when these are relevant and there's room in the story (e.g., "Wong, a member of the Ontario Association of Naturopathic Doctors, ...").

**Even when someone has a medical degree, don't bother mentioning this fact unless it's relevant to the story:** "Maria Mendez urged council not to increase property taxes" rather than "Dr. Maria Mendez urged council...." If an MP has an MD, for instance, we would still write "MP Joan Johnson" unless she was commenting on a health-care issue.


**Keep news writing conversational**
**Since honorifics can be awkward on air, using "Dr." is optional.** Writing clearly and effectively for a given medium sometimes means restructuring sentences. In the case of "Dr.," what works on the web ("Dr. Bill Jones, a Charlottetown cardiologist") or in a television super may be better recast in an on-air script ("Bill Jones is a cardiologist in Charlottetown"). **Even on the web, where words are written for the eye rather than for the ear, the title Dr. may be clunky.** For example, "MP Dr. Joan Johnson" is a dense pileup. Instead, relevant detail about the member of Parliament's professional credentials can be introduced another way: "MP Joan Johnson, a family doctor from Swift Current, Sask., says many rural centres are having trouble recruiting physicians." Our audience's best interests should be served.

**When referring to medical specialists, common terms do not need to be defined** (e.g., cardiologist, neurologist). **But brief explanations are helpful for more obscure terms** (endocrinologist, gastroenterologist).

**Not all doctors are certified surgeons,** even if they are specialists in certain fields of medicine. A cardiologist is not necessarily a heart surgeon, for example, and a neurologist is not necessarily a brain surgeon. **Do not use the word "surgeon" unless it applies.** While there's no universally accepted definition of surgery, we can apply common sense. Amputating a leg, removing a tumour, taking out an appendix or tonsils, etc., are all examples of surgery. Removing a mole, draining a cyst, etc., are generally not. Instead, these are more broadly referred to as "medical procedures." A doctor called on in an emergency to remove a bullet is a physician performing surgery. A doctor performing a quadruple bypass, on the other hand, is almost certainly a cardiac surgeon. The conventional term "cosmetic surgery" is acceptable, and normally describes altering or restoring a person's appearance. If facts are in dispute, or if there's debate over who can legally call themselves "cosmetic surgeons" in a particular jurisdiction, be sure to make this clear in the story.

If you introduce someone as a doctor and then several paragraphs pass before the person is mentioned again, the term "Dr." is a good way to remind readers, listeners and viewers about the individual's qualifications ("Dr. Low believes ..."). Otherwise, family names are sufficient in subsequent reference ("Low believes ..."). **The word doctor is always spelled out unless it appears directly in front of a name.**

When a person's medical credentials are relevant to a given story, **it's an accepted convention to use the title Dr. even after people retire or die** (e.g., Dr. Frederick Banting). **Exceptions are when people have been formally stripped of their licences** because of improper conduct. To avoid audience confusion, it's helpful to point out when someone is no longer practising medicine by adding a suitable modifier in first reference (e.g., "retired Dr. Nirmala Khatri")

While it's OK to refer to people "smoking" e-cigarettes, the participle "vaping" can be clearer because it distinguishes between the traditional burning of tobacco and the vaporizing of cartridge liquid.

Canada, the United States, Britain, the European Union and most other members of the international community do not recognize the annexation of East Jerusalem. **\-elect (as a suffix)**
**president-elect** (U.S.) _but_ **prime minister-designate** (Canada) — Both terms remain in lowercase even before names (U.S. president-elect Norm Reynolds). Canadian mayors are chosen directly by voters, so we call an incoming civic leader **mayor-elect**. (See [designate versus elect](/home/p/pm-designate) as well as [titles](/home/t/titles))

**elder** (lowercase generic); but **Elder** (as title before name, or component of proper noun) For instance: _Indigenous **elders** gathered in Winnipeg. The **2019 National Gathering of Elders** included a discussion of climate change. **Elder Duke Redbird** helped design the mural. It was rare to have **an Indigenous elder** on staff at a health-care centre in Toronto back then, she said._

**election day** (lowercase, along the lines of **voting day**, based on entrenched convention) There are numerous election days across the country and around the world, from local to regional (provincial, state, territorial) and national. With few exceptions, they're not held on fixed dates. For this reason, election day is treated as a generic term and kept lowercase. By contrast, unique spots on the calendar, such as Father's Day, Valentine's Day and Halloween, are capitalized. See [holidays and other special times](/home/h/holidays) for details.

[**election** versus **elections**](/home/e/election-or-elections) (e.g., a federal election, U.S. midterm elections) See the detailed [election primer](/home/e/election-primer) for guidelines over everything from organizing political panels and reporting on polls to election day blackouts and election night coverage.

**Elections Canada, Elections B.C.** See [**abbreviations**](/home/a/abbreviations#propernouns-geocomponents) for handling geographical components of various proper nouns (e.g., B.C. Hydro but WorkSafeBC).

**electoral college** (lowercase) Several countries have versions of an **electoral college system**, which is why the compound is traditionally treated as a generic term rather than as a capitalized proper noun. The College of Cardinals, by contrast, is a unique global body. When covering closely contested elections that feature electoral colleges, it's common to compare the **electoral college vote** (lowercase) to the **popular vote** (lowercase). Be aware that some U.S. media frequently capitalize electoral college in domestic stories. This is a stylistic preference to distinguish their country's system from foreign electoral colleges.

**electrical** (powered by electricity); **electronic** (connected to a circuit board or similar component for the storage, reproduction, transmission, etc., of electronic data) Avoid mixing up these terms. The former refers to a power source, the latter to a specific type of device — which may also be powered by a direct connection to an electrical source (generally low-voltage). A wide range of household appliances (e.g., refrigerators and stoves), various carpentry tools, stun guns, some cars, etc., are electrical, while TVs, stereos, computers, cellphones, etc., are electronic. This means an [e-bike](/home/e#e-bike) is electrical while an e-reader is electronic. The term electrical is sometimes shortened to **electric**, as in [electric vehicles](#EVs) and electric fencing (also known as "electrified fencing") that carries a current. Security walls may include electric fencing and electronic surveillance.

**Emergencies Act** (passed by the Parliament of Canada in 1988) The Emergencies Act **replaced the old 1914 War Measures Act**, which had been attacked by critics as far too sweeping. Be precise with statutory titles. Avoid calling the legislation the "new" War Measures Act, which is inaccurate and misleading. The Emergencies Act gives the federal government special temporary powers to ensure the safety and security of Canadians during national emergencies. But it requires Parliament review cabinet-issued emergency declarations. It also stipulates that any suspension of civil rights be "reasonable and justified" under the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. A 2001 [Library of Parliament summary of the Emergencies Act](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpublications.gc.ca%2Fcollections%2FCollection-R%2FLoPBdP%2FBP%2Fprb0114-e.htm&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1XrBXgOQnumpqGg7lOqQU1) includes pertinent historical context.

**energy sector** (_umbrella term that requires care_) Many countries' energy sources are increasingly diverse. Canada's energy sector, for instance, includes **fossil fuels** (oil, gas, coal), **hydroelectricity, wind** and **solar** power, **nuclear** energy and **wood** (e.g., from burning forestry and sawmill waste). Whenever practical, be precise to avoid inaccurate generalizations (e.g., **do not imply that "Canada's energy sector" is a synonym for Canada's petroleum sector**). **Use common sense**. For example, it's OK to talk about "off-shore energy" as long as the context of petroleum production is clear in the story. No one is going to assume we mean "off-shore atomic energy." And it's fine to use "energy" as a modifier when accurate and the meaning is understood (e.g., an energy project, Alberta's energy policy, a pipeline proposal being reviewed under the **Canadian Energy Regulator Act**). But it's potentially misleading to refer to, say, Alberta's oil and gas companies as "Alberta's energy companies" in a default, formulaic way. Calling them "energy" companies in second reference, by contrast, would be clear and acceptable. Be aware that we get audience complaints when we repeatedly resort to big labels such as "energy sector" to narrowly mean fossil fuels (e.g., "the West's energy industry" also includes hydroelectricity, wind and solar).

It's usually unnecessary to try to pack in too much detail about various technology (e.g., "regenerative braking" is a way to charge a battery while driving by storing the kinetic energy used when stopping the vehicle). ### earth

**Earth versus earth**

**Capitalize when referring to it as a planet:**

_Scientists hope the new satellite lets them take better pictures of_ _Earth_ _from space.

The atmosphere on Mars is nothing like Earth’s.

We cut trees. We burn fuel. We see global warming all around us. But can we still save the Earth?_

**But keep lowercase in general expressions:**

_down to earth
heaven on earth
move heaven and earth
what on earth do you mean?_

See also [space terms](/home/s/space-terms)

### earthquakes

**Earthquakes**

**Never use** the term **Richter scale** when reporting the intensity of earthquakes. **Use "magnitude"** instead.

Seismologists abandoned the old systems (Richter, Mercalli and other scales) years ago because these focused on local effects without capturing the overall picture.

Experts now frequently talk about "moment magnitude," which we and other news organizations shorten to "magnitude." This number estimates how much and how far the earth moved at a specific time (the moment of shock).


**Preliminary magnitude**
It's important to keep in mind that even "moment magnitude" is an estimate. It may change as more data comes in or if the interpretation of existing data shifts.

**Always report the initial numbers as "preliminary,"** and attribute the source when possible (e.g., the U.S. Geological Survey).

_"The quake had a preliminary magnitude of 6.7," "The quake had a magnitude of 6.7 according to preliminary reports,"_ etc.

The word preliminary can be dropped when the experts agree on a figure (usually within a few hours).

**Aftershocks** are smaller quakes that occur hours (and sometimes days) after the initial quake. The term **temblor** (_never_ tremblor) is another word for earthquake, although it's rather esoteric and leaves some editors shaking their heads when it shows up in copy.


**4.7 versus 6.7**
The "moment magnitude" **scale is logarithmic** (an increase of 1.0 is a 10-fold jump in wave amplitude and a 30-fold rise in "energy output"). This means, for instance, that a 5.7 quake releases 30 times more energy than a 4.7 quake, but that a **6.7 quake releases about 900 times more than a 4.7 quake** (30 times 30).

We don't normally feel quakes with a magnitude of less than 1.0. The scale is theoretically open-ended, although scientists think that "rock mechanics" preclude earthquakes larger than roughly 9.5.

**On the web, follow the publishing convention of adding a cipher to the magnitude if the number is even** (7.0) to help make the figure jump out for readers, to confirm that no information has been inadvertently dropped from the story (e.g., 7.1 became 7 because of a writing/editing slip) and to maintain a consistent decimal style in our online journalism. A hyphen is not required in adjectival constructions (e.g., a 7.0 magnitude quake, a 6.8 magnitude quake).


**Minor, medium, major**
Magnitude numbers don't mean much to the average person. It's helpful to **include descriptions (e.g., a minor, medium, or major quake)** based on the damage normally caused by that level of intensity.


**Mild**
**Under 4.0** – Rattling dishes.


**Minor**
**4.0 to 4.9** – Slight damage.


**Medium**
**5.0 to 5.9** – Moderate to heavy damage, depending how structures are built.


**Medium to Major**
**6.0 to 6.9** – Heavy to severe damage, including the possibility of collapsed buildings.


**Major**
**7.0 to 7.9** – A major quake causing widespread and severe damage.

Anything higher than 8 is considered one of the rare "great" quakes. But **in news stories the real figures that matter are the number of people dead, injured and homeless, as well as the time and money required to rebuild.**

The extent of devastation, of course, depends a lot on how close the epicentre is to a densely populated area. **When it hits a city, town or village directly, say the community is "at" (not over) the epicentre.** An epicentre is not underground but is on the Earth's surface. (It's directly above the "hypocentre" or focus of the seismic rupture, jargon we don't use.)


**Historical numbers**
**It's misleading to compare new magnitudes to old numbers** (e.g., Richter scale figures in the record books). The New York Times Manual of Style and Usage, for instance, points out that the San Francisco earthquake of 1906 was 8.3 on the Richter scale but is now classified as roughly 7.9 on the "moment magnitude scale."

For more information about earthquakes, including detailed guides to all the numbers, consult the [U.S. Geological Survey](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fgeology.usgs.gov%2Findex.htm&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3YqNpfMNBshieADnWzXtcJ) website.

**If you're writing or editing a story right now about a recent earthquake** that happened anywhere in the world, you may find more information about it from a [different spot](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fearthquake.usgs.gov%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2sn8WV1xB6B5v-EU1ZiiOi) on the same USGS site. [**Earthquakes Canada**](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fearthquakescanada.nrcan.gc.ca%2Findex-eng.php&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3NHizYw_sUdVCIr6kzDTf_) is a good source for tracking seismic activity in this country.

See also: [weather words](/home/w/weather-words) (hurricanes, tornadoes, tsunamis, etc.)

### \-ed verus -t

**\-ed versus -t**

**past tense, past participles**
**When there are competing forms of verbs, generally use -ed instead of -t** in past tense and past participle constructions:

**burned** not burnt, as in "The bulb has burned out."
**leaned** not leant, as in "She leaned against the wall."
**learned** not learnt, as in "They've learned a few things."
**smell** not smelt, as in "He smelled smoke."
**spelled** not spelt, as in "She spelled it correctly."
**spilled** not spilt, as in "Fans spilled into the streets."
**spoiled** not spoilt, as in "The surprise was spoiled."

**The main Canadian exceptions are:**

**dreamed** or **dreamt**, as in "They dreamed (_or_ dreamt) of better days."
**kneeled** or **knelt**, as in "She kneeled (_or_ knelt) by the grave."
**leaped** or **leapt**, as in "He leaped (_or_ leapt) to the wrong conclusion."


**adjectives**
**burnt** (preferred), as in "burnt toast" or a "burnt-out bulb"
**learned**, as in a "learned judge"

### e.g. and i.e.

**e.g. and i.e.**

**e.g.
**Latin for "**exempli gratia**," which means "**for example**"

> _He watches a lot of sports (e.g., hockey, baseball, football), but has never seen a cricket game._


**Generally avoid using "e.g." in news stories**, which look cluttered and can be confusing when filled with abbreviations, especially Latin ones.

Although some foreign expressions are common (ad hoc, per cent, per diem, status quo) others are not nearly as well-known or understood. Many usage guides recommend that e.g. and i.e. be reserved for footnotes of scholarly works rather than the main text.

When introducing an example using this abbreviation, **always put a comma after e.g.,** which is treated as a distinct prepositional phrase. This is standard punctuation in most style manuals, according to the Guide to Canadian English Usage. **Italics are unnecessary.**



**i.e.**
Latin for "**id est**," which means "**that is**"

> _She loved Newfoundland and Labrador but was also fond of the Maritimes (i.e., Nova Scotia, New Brunswick and P.E.I.)_


**This abbreviation normally has no place in news writing, but if you do use "i.e." avoid falling into the common trap of confusing it with "e.g."**

The Oxford Guide to Canadian English Usage cites the following example of misuse by a large Canadian newspaper in 1995:

> (WRONG) _"Carsten lacked those silly misconceptions held by some travellers (i.e., all Canadians live in igloos, all Aussies wrestle alligators in their spare time) …"_


In the above case, "i.e." introduces examples rather than an explanation. It should be "e.g."


When adding explanatory detail, **always put a comma after i.e.,** which is treated as a distinct phrase — along the lines of "that is to say." This is standard punctuation in most style manuals, according to the Guide to Canadian English Usage. **Italics are unnecessary.**



### Election or elections

**Election versus elections**

**Prefer the singular** (election) **when referring to a general election to determine a national, provincial, territorial or local government:**

> She plans to run in the next **federal election**.
>
> The 2008 U.S. **presidential election** has a special place in the history books.
>
> Only two incumbent councillors ran in Calgary's **municipal election**.
>
> They're demanding a **federal byelection** be called.


**Limit use of the plural to entirely separate races held on the same day** (e.g., towns and cities in a province picking their own local governments), **or to a series of different elections over time.**

> Ontario's **municipal elections** will be held this fall.
>
> Saskatchewan, B.C. and Alberta **elections** are scheduled for ...
>
> He ran in four **federal elections** and lost each time.
>
> Three **byelections** will be held in two different provinces on Tuesday.

**Foreign coverage**
**Apply the distinctions above to elections in other countries.** For example:

> **Afghanistan's parliamentary election was ...**
>
> (Why singular? The September 2010 general election was to choose MPs for the Wolesi Jirga, along the lines of Canada's federal election to pick MPs for the House of Commons.)

> **U.S. midterm elections are ...**
>
> (Why plural? Since congressional elections in the U.S. involve Senate and House of Representative races, they're conventionally called midterm elections.)

**Elections Canada**
The proper noun is **Elections Canada**. It's an independent federal agency that oversees national (general) elections, as well as federal byelections and referendums. Elections Canada reports directly to Parliament.

While some people argue that individual ridings actually hold separate, individual elections in any given national parliamentary contest, Elections Canada also uses the term "general election" (singular) to describe the overall ballot race for seats in the Commons.

The [Elections Canada website](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.elections.ca%2Fcontent.aspx%3Fsection%3Dele%26lang%3De&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0QiHhK8DHmxxVqSMRSlaxA) offers for a wealth of historical details, including some electoral statistics going back to 1867.

**See also the detailed CBC News [election primer](/home/e/election-primer)** for a wide range of guidelines (e.g., how to refer to incumbents, organize political panels, report on polls), including rules about election day blackouts and election night coverage.
