**OVERVIEW**
**Federal, provincial and territorial elections raise unique editorial challenges, including how we:**

-   Report on polls.
-   Tackle panel discussions and "serial interviews."
-   Handle incumbents' titles.
-   Gauge equitable treatment of parties over time.

The principles of **accuracy, transparency, balance and fairness are central.**

**There can also be legal considerations**, including the way we:

-   Co-ordinate political free-time programming.
-   Deal with illegally recorded content, such as a photo taken from inside a polling station and then posted on social media.

This primer answers common questions. There are also links to supplementary reference material with more detailed information about specific points, including [**Journalistic Standards and Practices policy on politics**](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fio.cbcrc.ca%2F%23%2Fresources%2Fpolitics-1.4523351&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1JzlIMztzK0lZtiRHnpBNa).


**FAQs**
**1\. When does the election period begin?**
Federal, provincial and territorial elections start when the Crown writs are issued, often about a month before the actual election date. Campaigns can, however, be substantially longer (e.g., the 2015 federal election started two months before the scheduled October vote). Even in the case of fixed election dates, writs are required. (See [start of election period](/home/e/election-primer#A).)

**2\. Do we need to log all election-related stories?**
No, not all stories on all platforms, 24/7. But we use an Election Logging System to track representative broadcasts (e.g., election stories aired at certain times or on certain flagship programs). This helps us maintain equitable coverage of parties over time. It's not a substitute for the regular evaluations that editorial units conduct. But it's a good metric to have, especially if we need to respond to criticism from the parties, candidates, special interest groups or others.

**3\. Do we need to give each party equal time in each newscast?**
No. That's not realistic. But we need to track how much time each party is getting, and there must be [balance and fairness over time](/home/e/election-primer#B).

**4\. How do I handle titles like PM and premier?**
Drop parliamentary titles in election stories to avoid even the perception of giving incumbents an advantage (e.g., Premier Jane Smith becomes Conservative Leader Jane Smith). In stories unrelated to the election, however, cabinet references are OK. Use common sense. (See [titles](/home/e/election-primer#C).)

**5\. When organizing panels and "serial interviews," do we need to include all parties?**
No. Any party that we think is likely to have a noticeable influence on the election outcome should be invited to participate in panels (i.e., moderated political discussions) as well as in serial interviews (e.g., a series of one-on-one interviews spread out over the campaign). This generally means mainstream parties with sitting members, but can include other parties expected to win seats or split votes in close ridings. (See [debates, panels and 'serial' interviews](/home/e/election-primer#D) for more guidelines and specific caveats.)

**6\. What do we need to know about political advertising and free-time political programs?**
Newsroom staff are sometimes asked why certain political content is being aired during election campaigns. In order to answer public queries or direct them to the right co-ordinator, it's helpful to have some basic information about [free-time political programs](/home/e/election-primer#F) and [paid political advertising](/home/e/election-primer#G), and to know the difference. On the web, journalists must ensure that political ads do not appear next to election stories by adjusting CBCNews.ca's publishing tool settings as required.

**7\. What are the rules on the way we report polls?**
Methodology must meet CBC standards, and certain information included in stories ― from sample size and margin of error to the identity of the poll sponsor and the firm that conducted the survey. Some of these details are required by law during election campaigns. For instance, in federal elections, it's necessary to report where full survey details can be found (i.e. a third party web address) in the first 24-hour period after a poll's results are released. There are also internal (CBC) editorial guidelines around language used (e.g., polls "suggest" but do not "show"). We avoid poll-driven election coverage by limiting the number of surveys we cover and the prominence these polls are given in newscasts and on web pages. (See [polls](/home/e/election-primer#E) for more details, including tips on questions we should ask ourselves when evaluating surveys commissioned by third parties.)

**8\. What's an election day "blackout"?**
There are actually several types of blackouts, from those dealing with political advertising to results of new opinion surveys. Since the 2015 federal election, however, we've NO longer had to contend with old restrictions about reporting results from one region until polling stations were closed in another. (See [blackouts](/home/e/election-primer#H).)

**9\. What can we report on election day while all polls are still open?**
As pointed out in blackouts, the only content automatically off-limits while all voting stations are open on election day are new opinion surveys. There's no ban against reporting hard news about a particular party or candidate. But we must take extra steps to be extremely even-handed. (See [election day coverage](/home/e/election-primer#I).)

**10\. Does CBC News declare winners on election night?**
No, our election desk projects winners based on analysis of each riding's preliminary returns. (See [election night results](/home/e/election-primer#J) for related style points.)


**DRILLING DOWN**
**(A) Official start of election period**
Federal, provincial and territorial elections can be triggered in several ways (e.g., at the request of a majority government leader, when a minority government loses confidence of the legislative house). In all cases, **writs are required for each riding. They're legal documents signed by the Crown's representative** (the Governor General for federal races and a lieutenant-governor for provincial or territorial ones), and returned after voting ends.

**Writs signal the start of the election period and, so, affect everything from advertising to advance polls. In some jurisdictions fixed election dates are now set** (e.g., in Ontario it's the first Thursday of October every four years, and in Saskatchewan it's the first Monday of November every four years, as long as the confidence of each province's legislature is maintained), with **writs automatically issued according to timelines** (e.g., in Ontario in 2011, the election period was scheduled to begin 29 days before the fixed election date of Oct. 6). **Fixed federal election dates have been in place in Canada since 2007, although, again, the modifier "fixed" can be misleading** because the Canada Elections Act does not preclude other dates (e.g., if a minority government falls because it cannot maintain the confidence of the House of Commons). Assuming an earlier federal election is not triggered, the legislation specifies that balloting be held on the third Monday of October in the fourth calendar year following the previous general election.

Election campaigns commonly last just over a month in Canada, although lengths vary. **By law, national election campaigns must last at least 36 days** (about five weeks) **and no longer than 50 days** (about seven weeks), according to federal legislation.


**TIP: There's usually no need to refer to "writs" in stories. If you do use the word, however, a phrase such as "issuing the writs" is generally preferred.** The cliché "dropping the writ" is best avoided for three reasons: It's hackneyed. It's odd imagery (documents are not dropped on purpose). And it's generally inaccurate unless plural because most federal and provincial elections involve more than one riding. The exception is when a single byelection is held.

**(B) Balance and fairness over time**
Although elections raise a number of special editorial challenges, **the broad principles that guide us are rudimentary: Accuracy, fairness, balance, transparency and independence. These are the hallmarks of our coverage.** The first three are so vital, they're underscored in our official election coverage policy:


> "We ensure that the facts and analysis we present on issues, candidates and parties is timely, accurate, fair and balanced over the course of the campaign. We give all candidates, parties and issues equitable treatment. This does not necessarily mean equal broadcast time."

> > > > > > > > > ― CBC Journalistic Standards and Practices


To fully understand the concept of balance and fairness over time, **here are some important takeaways:**

-   **Report every registered party and Independent candidate's platform in some way, however briefly, at least once during the campaign** (e.g., posting their platforms on a special web page and mentioning them in an on-air roundup) This gives our audience with as much information as possible about all options at the ballot box. 
-   **It's OK if front-runners are followed more closely because equitable treatment is viewed through the prism of known voter support.** Put another way, there's no rule that every candidate, no matter how peripheral, must be given the same amount of coverage. There are no "equal-time" requirements in Canada. Indeed, given limited time and journalistic resources, that approach would not serve our audience best. (See [political panels](/home/e/election-primer#panels) for related guidelines.)
-   **Equitable treatment does not necessarily translate into the same amount of air time or web space on a given day.** That is not always possible or desirable. Averaged over several weeks, however, front-runners normally receive about the same percentage of coverage.


-   **When assessing who qualifies as front-runners, we should bear in mind that surveys of voters' intentions are snapshots, subject to margins of error**, and that support can shift.


-   **When classifying parties as "major," know the election you're writing about** (e.g., the Parti Québécois and the Saskatchewan Party have held power provincially). Don't assume that the trio of usual suspects (Conservatives, Liberals, New Democrats) automatically applies to a specific region.


-   **Even in a first-past-the-post voting system, an election can be significantly affected by more than just front-runners** (e.g., a party expected to win few seats nationally may alter the outcome in some key ridings or in a particular province, and a former party member no longer in caucus and now running as an Independent may merit coverage not normally given to candidates outside the party system). In cases like this, **adjusting the spotlight may make editorial sense. Be flexible.** Reassess and redeploy resources as required.


-   **If one candidate or party attacks another, responses should be reported as soon as possible** (preferably in the same day's "news cycle").


-   Although the opportunity for equitable treatment is initially spread out over a month or more, overall time remains finite. So **as election periods draw to an end, keep in mind that the chance to redress any possible imbalances becomes limited** as the remaining time collapses. (See [serial interviews](/home/e/election-primer#serialinterviews) below for a related caution.)
-   **Past programming rerun in whole or in part during election periods can affect perceptions of fairness and balance** (e.g., an old episode of a current affairs or comedy show that focuses on specific parties, candidates or even issues, such as health-care spending).

**(C) Titles (prime minister, premier)**
**After writs are issued, generally identify incumbents running for re-election by party affiliation only. This includes a premier, the prime minister or other cabinet members.** The guiding principles are impartiality and fairness.


> Liberal Leader Justin Trudeau said ...
>
> Marc Garneau, the Liberal candidate in the Quebec riding of ...
>
> Ontario Conservative Leader Doug Ford is expected to ...


**Exceptions are stories not directly tied to the election**, when the person is speaking on behalf of the government or the country:


> Prime Minister Trudeau called the bombing a tragedy ...
>
> Foreign Affairs Minister Marc Garneau told the UN ...
>
> Ontario Premier Doug Ford urged Michigan's governor to ...


**This doesn't mean we can't put relevant background or context in election stories** (e.g., "Harper has been prime minister since 2006"). **But we must avoid the perception of giving a particular office holder an advantage.
**
For more details and examples, see the Language Guide entry: [Titles during elections](/home/e/election-titles)


**(D) Debates, panels and 'serial interviews'**
**DEBATES**
**Debates are formal, moderated events** generally involving party leaders. They're normally broadcast live. **Decisions about dates, formats, participants, etc., are usually looked after by an independent body.** Since such debates are often held only once during the election, and since they can result in spontaneous and insightful moments between candidates, it's important to plan coverage beyond predictable party spin. This can include everything from live, blow-by-blow blogging to interviewing a group of undecided voters after the event. Always **use current, precise language about who's behind a given event.** For instance, **avoid describing a national debate being aired on all the major networks as a "CBC debate."** In 2019, for example, the independent Leaders' Debates Commission organized the national debate, which was produced by the Canadian Debate Production Partnership (CDPP) rather than by the old "broadcast consortium" group.

**PANELS**
**Panels are less formal debates.** Some feature analysts, including journalists, contributing nonpartisan insight. But **panels made up of partisan guests**, including candidates, managers, party strategists and the like, **require special care. For balance and fairness in these cases, include representatives from all major parties.** 



**TIP: By limiting panels to no more than three or four people, there's enough time for everyone to have a say.** Groups larger than this tend to become too unwieldy for moderators and to drag on too long for audiences.


**Smaller parties do not need to be included on panels.** We satisfy our own policy and CRTC rules about equitable treatment of candidates as long as we give smaller parties some coverage at some point during the election campaign. (See [balance and fairness over time](/home/e/election-primer#B) above for more details about "equitable treatment.")



**TIP: Someone may challenge your decision about panel participation. So have sensible and consistent criteria in place.** For example: (i) Only parties that held seats before the election was called; (ii) Only parties that received a minimum percentage of the popular vote in the last election; (iii) Only parties running candidates in every riding; etc.


**SERIAL INTERVIEWS**
**Serial interviews are one-on-one Q&As** (e.g., the leaders of all major parties, every candidate in a particular riding). They're **usually broadcast or published on different days.**

To maintain fairness and balance:

-   **Match formats** (e.g., the same interviewer, length, live or taped).
-   **Give interviews equal weight** (i.e., similar time slots and online prominence).
-   **Make sure each "major party" is included in the series.** (See [panels](/home/e/election-primer#panels) above for direction on establishing sensible criteria.)

**Since serial interviews are broadcast on different days, put each one into context for our audience** (e.g., "This is the first in a series of ..."). It's important to point out if we've already talked to specific parties in the series, as well as when we're scheduled to air the next interview.


**TIP: Try to secure firm commitments from all major parties before publishing or broadcasting the first serial interview.** Ideally, this will include exactly when/where the interviews will be conducted. Be aware that some parties may be eager to participate (e.g., if they're trailing in the polls), while others may withhold assurances for strategic reasons. This can give them control over the timing of their interview (e.g., delaying and delaying until the final days of the campaign). It can also allow them to back out at the last minute, since they didn't actually commit in the first place, potentially exposing us to criticism about unbalanced coverage. **If at the end of the day one party does not agree to participate, we should say simply and directly that they were offered the opportunity but declined.** And we still have an obligation to ensure that the party's views are exposed in the course of our overall election coverage.

**(E) Polls**
To serve our audience best, **we prefer to focus on election issues ― those identified by candidates as well as those raised by voters** ― rather than on what surveys suggest are the positions of parties in a horse race on any given day. It's OK to refer to poll standings from time to time in certain stories if the numbers are directly relevant But **poll results should not be the primary focus of most newscasts or daily campaign coverage.** At best, they're an accurate but momentary snapshot. At worst, they're unrepresentative, even when solid, scientific methodology is used (i.e., standard margins of error are never guaranteed 100 per cent of the time, which means some polls can be wildly wrong). It's worth noting that those keen to stay abreast of statistical trends have options. During federal election campaigns, for example, CBC News regularly reports and interprets detailed amalgamations of existing national public opinion surveys in special online features, such as the [Canada Votes Poll Tracker](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fnewsinteractives.cbc.ca%2Felections%2Fpoll-tracker%2Fcanada%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1vgKjNrXuuW2Mgi7WI1Tb8) in 2019. Of course, **occasional polls that meet our editorial standards may merit separate coverage if they're deemed newsworthy** (e.g., the percentage of voters who appear to support specific climate change policy), **or if they provide valuable context** (e.g., a better understanding of why parties may be altering tactics or shifting resources midstream). **When commissioning surveys or reporting on other organizations' polls, always follow CBC guidelines.
**
**CBC-COMMISSIONED POLLS**
We're mindful of the potential impact that our surveys might have on public policy debates and elections, especially in the final stretch of a campaign. Therefore:

-   **EIC-level approval is generally required before we commission a survey.**

We assume responsibility for the methodology and quality of CBC-branded polls. So:

-   **Final design must be OK'd by CBC's research department.**

**Be aware that there are specific statutory obligations when reporting on polls during election periods.** In federal election campaigns, for example, it's necessary to report where the full results of a survey can be found (i.e., the web address) in the first 24 hours after results are first released. **Talk to your supervisor if you have any doubts.**

To maximize effective coverage, **be sure to co-ordinate the reporting of CBC polls across platforms.** This may involve giving other units embargoed content
(i.e., compiled/interpreted results) so that various material, such as graphics, can be properly prepared before the story rolls out.

**THIRD-PARTY POLLS**

-   **We do not cover "push" or advocacy polls** (e.g., a survey about teachers' pensions conducted by a union representing teachers).
-   **All polls we report must meet our editorial standards** (random, representative, etc.), with particular attention paid to sample size and margin of error.
-   **Consult CBC's research department when in doubt** about assessing methodology or interpreting results.

**STORY ESSENTIALS**
**When reporting on any poll, always include:**

-   **Who conducted it** (which firm or firms).
-   **Who commissioned it** (the CBC or someone else).
-   **The number of people surveyed.**
-   **How, where and when** (e.g., by phone across Canada Sept. 19-21).
-   **The margin of error** (e.g., 3.1% 19 times out of 20), **unless it's an online survey** — since pollsters don't agree on the scientific validity of calculating margins of error unless a given sample is considered sufficiently random and representative. In those cases, always contact the CBC's research department to see if there are any concerns about a given poll's methodology or overall soundness before reporting the results.
-   **Accurate language** (e.g., polls "suggest" rather than "show," and "percentage" is not the same as "per cent"). **See** [**the Language Guide entry on Polls**](/home/p/polls) for more details.

Depending on the platform, **some poll details may be conveyed in different ways** (e.g., the dates, sample size and margin of error could be placed at the bottom of a graphic in TV, as long as they're on screen long enough for people to read).

**Be aware that there are specific statutory obligations when reporting on polls during election periods.** In federal election campaigns, for example, it's necessary to report where the full results of a survey can be found (i.e., the web address) in the first 24 hours after results are first released. **Talk to your supervisor if you have any doubts.**

**IMPORTANT: On election day, do NOT report the results of new polls** (see [blackout](/home/e/election-primer#H) below). We must also be careful when summarizing past polls (see [election day coverage](/home/e/election-primer#I)) to avoid the perception of influencing voters.

**ADDITIONAL RESOURCES ABOUT POLLS**

 Before writing about public opinion surveys, **make sure you're familiar with accepted industry standards about conducting polls and interpreting results** ― including caveats about how the margin of error can change drastically when attempting to extrapolate, say, provincial results from certain national surveys because the relevant sample size shrinks disproportionately. The **CBC Research Department's four-page [Poll Reporting Guide Sheet](/media/qe2eeik2/poll-reporting-guide-sheet_cb-a29d4cb8a12f2bc2.pdf)** (PDF) is a good starting point.

 To help news organizations develop a critical eye when assessing whether to report polls, the U.S. National Council on Public Polls has created a document worth reading: [**20 questions a journalist should ask about poll results**](/media/j0djdv3u/20-questions-about-polls_ncpp_3rd-edition.pdf) (PDF). It hammers home the need to understand who asked what questions, when, how, etc.

**IS IT NEWS?**
There's an appetite to know when the horses in a race appear to have moved ahead or fallen behind significantly. But **when deciding whether to report polls, bear in mind that they:**

-   **Aren't always right**, even if they meet editorial standards.
-   **Are snapshots.** The results may already be shifting by the time we report the results of a poll conducted a week earlier.
-   **Can distract from important issues or other election stories** that serve our audience better.

**A good practice is to report overall trends once a week, unless a poll suddenly surfaces that suggests a major story is developing** (e.g. the first signs of the NDP surge and the Bloc Québécois collapse in Quebec during the 2011 federal election). **Even then, approach the numbers with caution** because they could be wrong or a temporary blip.

**UNSCIENTIFIC SURVEYS**
**Be careful when asking the audience for their views about election-related topics**, no matter how weighty or frothy. **Unscientific online or on-air surveys must NOT be characterized as bona fide polls** in any way.

Word requests for participation accordingly, including all question-of-the-day and other POV (point-of-view) audience engagement features. And **when reporting results:**

-   **Be clear that the survey is not intended to represent the opinion of our audience as a whole, or of any other group** (e.g., Canadians, Albertans, university students, retirees).
-   **Give only the actual number of votes cast for each option rather than converting figures into percentages.** This helps distinguish the content from scientific polls.

**(F) Free-Time Political Programming**
**In national elections, federal legislation requires the CBC** and some other radio and television networks **to provide a specified amount of free time to each of the registered political parties.** This lets all parties communicate directly to voters to some degree, regardless of individual budgets. (**In provincial elections, it is CBC policy to also offer free time** to registered parties.) **Noteworthy points:**

-   **Free time is allocated to parties, not to candidates, and is based on a formula** that factors in the number of votes and seats won during the last election.
-   In national elections, **the CBC makes this free time available in short-form "programs" of varying lengths** (e.g., 60-second, 90-second and two-minute spots)**.** Political parties can express their views as they see fit without questions or interruption.
-   **Parties sometimes opt to run advertising spots** in their free-time slots.

**CBC assigns a co-ordinator to look after free-time political programming**, either nationally or provincially. **News staff faced with audience queries, complaints or other comments about this programming should direct people to the co-ordinator.** If unsure, they should ask their supervisor.


**(G) Paid Political Advertising**
**CBC Radio is obliged by the federal Elections Act to accept paid political ads during federal election campaigns** ― even though the network doesn't broadcast commercials at any other time of the year. **Advertising is available to parties only and is highly regulated. CBC hosts introduce each ad with a statement** explaining why the commercial is running, and stressing that all registered parties have the same opportunity to buy time if they so choose.

**CBC Television carries political advertising during federal, provincial and territorial campaigns, although the placement of political ads is restricted.

Political advertising is permitted on certain CBC.ca news pages** (e.g., arts, technology, weather) but not on others (e.g., the main CBCNews.ca page, regional landing pages, the politics section). **Although the system is largely automated based on coding, anyone publishing CBC online journalism must understand when/how manual settings are required to avoid the possibility of political ads appearing next to election-related web stories** (e.g., if an arts story is tied to the election, it should be manually classified as "politics" when posted to the arts lineup). There are also encoding rules about election-related video put on CBC.ca Consult a senior web journalist if you're not sure whether a particular online story should be considered election-related.

**Other essentials:**

-   **Commercial time is separate from free-time political programming** [outlined above](/home/e/election-primer#F).
-   **CBC does not accept ads from "third parties," individual candidates or parties not running candidates.**
-   **If excerpts from paid political spots appear in our journalism** (e.g., in stories about "negative advertising"), **we should give major parties equitable treatment.** This normally means matching the duration of excerpts as closely as practical. It can also include giving parties a chance to comment on the ads shown.

**(H) Blackouts**
**There are different blackouts on election day. Since the term is broad, it's important to be specific** when discussing the rules.

**POLLS:** **It's illegal to broadcast or publish the results of NEW opinion surveys on federal election day ― including non-scientific ones, such as beer or hamburger polls.** This is **a good practice to follow on provincial and territorial election days as well.** Previously reported polls are OK, although there are editorial factors to consider. (See [election day coverage](/home/e/election-primer#I) below.) The blackout on new polls begins at midnight local time on election day.

**FREE-TIME POLITICAL PROGRAMMING:** **The CBC stops all free-time political programming 24 hours before election day.** So if the election is on a Monday, the last free-time political programming must air before 11:59:59 p.m. local time Saturday.

**PAID POLITICAL ADVERTISING:** **Political ads cannot be published or broadcast on federal election day.** This means all party commercials must run before midnight local time. Similar rules apply for most provincial elections. In Ontario, advertising is banned 24 hours before election day.

**JOURNALISM:** **Beyond the blackout on previously unreported polls** cited above, **there are no legislative restrictions on election-related stories while all voting stations are still open. There are, however, editorial considerations** outlined in [election day coverage](/home/e/election-primer#I) below.


**(I) Election day coverage**
The principles of [balance and fairness over time](/home/e/election-primer#B) discussed in detail above take on new meaning on election day because time has virtually run out. **Stories have a greater potential to be unfair because they:**

-   **May have an immediate influence** on voters.
-   **Offer little time for reaction** from parties.

**This means we must be very careful about focusing on a party, candidate or issue.

It does not mean that we are restricted to "photo ops"** of leaders at polling stations **or to fluff pieces** about how the weather and voter turnout. **But we must be extremely even-handed in all reports** ― from hard political news that surfaces election day to background pieces on party platforms or recaps of issues and candidates' performances.

**We must also avoid violating election laws**, such as broadcasting or publishing illegally recorded content, including images or videos taken inside a polling station by a voter with a cellphone.


See also [blackouts](/home/e/election-primer#H) above for related restrictions on reporting public opinion polls, etc.


**(J) Election night results**
In this age of social media, many Canadians post virtually endless updates about what's happening around them on a variety of social media platforms. **Since the 2015 federal election, journalists have no longer had to worry about inconvenient and challenging "results blackouts"** — i.e., about old federal rules against reporting results from one region in another part of the country where polling stations are still open.

Once voting stations close, numbers traditionally dribble in. **Provide context and be precise with language as you report election results. For instance:**

-   **Make it clear what percentage of polls in the riding have been counted** (e.g., only three out of 25, or 12%).
-   **Identify incumbents**, especially if they are unfamiliar names (e.g., backbenchers).
-   **Look for narratives** (e.g., the government appears on its way to being re-elected but with fewer seats, a third of the cabinet ministers look like they will be defeated, early results suggest the province will have its first majority government in more than a decade).

CBC's election desk has the editorial experience and the tools/expertise to forecast probable outcomes, based on a review of historical voting patterns and a statistical analysis of current trends. So **wait for our election desk to "call" the election, regardless of what competitors may be reporting, and ALWAYS use qualifying language as required:**

-   **CBC News initially "projects" minority or majority governments.** Avoid verbs such as "declares."
-   **Candidates projected to win specific seats can be classified as "elected,"** based on convention.
-   **Use "prime minister-designate" and "premier designate"** when there's a change in government election night, **not** PM-elect or premier-elect. (See [\-designate vs. elect](/home/p/pm-designate) for details, including how to handle terms such as **MP-elect**)

**In rare instances when our election desk reverses a decision** (e.g., a candidate previously projected to win loses her "elected" status), **we should report the development as quickly as practical and with complete transparency** ― acknowledging the change and, whenever possible, explaining it (e.g., if unreported polls in one part of a riding wound up returning vastly different results from earlier projections).

See also: [non-confidence votes](/home/n/non-confidence), [election vs. elections](/home/e/election-or-elections), [titles during elections](/home/e/election-titles) and [polls](/home/p/polls)

For capitalization and other typographical guidance, see specific entries (e.g., [Party vs. party](/home/p/party), [Leader vs. leader](/home/l/leader), and hyphens in [electoral district names](/handy-links/punctuation/hyphens#electoraldistricts)).

### election titles

**Titles during elections**
**When Parliament or a legislature dissolves, the prime minister is still the prime minister and the premier is still the premier. But that doesn't necessarily mean we should call them that.** Inserting government titles into election stories can be seen as giving incumbents an advantage. **Here are some guidelines:
**



[New PM, premier](/home/e/election-titles#newPM) (designate vs. elect)

[Defeated party leader](/home/e/election-titles#defeated) (who plans to resign)

**Leaders**
**Generally refer to government leaders and cabinet ministers by party affiliation** rather than by titles such as prime minister or premier during federal and provincial election campaigns. **The guiding principles are impartiality and fairness.**


**Conservative Leader Stephen Harper** (not Prime Minister Stephen Harper)
**NDP Leader Darrell Dexter** (not Nova Scotia Premier Darrell Dexter)


**Exceptions are stories off the campaign trail**, when the person is speaking on behalf of the government or the country (e.g., "Prime Minister Paul Martin called the bombing a tragedy" and "Foreign Affairs Minister Lawrence Cannon told the UN that Canada supports the proposal").

**This doesn't mean that titles like prime minister and premier can't sometimes appear in election stories, too. But they should be the exception rather than our default**, and they should serve an editorial purpose, such as providing helpful background or context (e.g., "Harper has been prime minister since 2006").


**NOTE:** **These guidelines kick in the moment that Parliament or regional legislatures** (provincial/territorial) **are officially dissolved, including when fixed election dates are on the books.** But they do NOT normally apply before then. Otherwise, we'd be in the challenging position of subjectively deciding when to stop using titles like prime minister and premier months before a scheduled election date.


When Parliament or a legislature dissolves, there's no longer an Official Opposition. There are simply several leaders of different opposition parties. Identify them by party affiliation:


**NDP Leader Tom Mulcair** (not Official Opposition leader Tom Mulcair)


Again, this doesn't mean we can't mention at some point in election stories that someone was, say, the Official Opposition leader in the House of Commons when the election was called. But the term Official Opposition leader should be reported as background not as a title in these cases.

For capitalization guidelines tied to party names (Liberal Leader Justin Trudeau and Green Party Leader Elizabeth May but party leader Justin Trudeau, party leader Elizabeth May), see [Leader versus leader](/home/l/leader).

**MPs and other incumbents**
Technically, members of federal and provincial legislative bodies continue to hold office during election campaigns. They have reduced staff to help respond to requests from constituents.

(NOTE: For decades, CBC's election style guidelines wrongly claimed that sitting MPs are technically not incumbents after Parliament dissolves. This error was corrected in 2004. But as recently as the 2011 federal election, some of our journalists were still inquiring about the old ban.)

**While the generic term incumbent is perfectly accurate, prefer language that identifies all candidates as competitors first.
**

The **Conservative candidate** for Central Nova ...
The riding's **NDP candidate** said ...


This doesn't mean we avoid wording that supplies valuable context. Depending on the story, describing someone as a constituency's sitting MP once in second reference might be important to clarify who is running for re-election, especially if the incumbent is not widely known to a national audience. But repeatedly describing someone as a sitting MP can be unfair to others vying for the job, wrongly conveying an atmosphere of entitlement.

**If incumbents win, avoid using the word "elect" in compound titles** (e.g., MP-elect, MPP-elect, MLA-elect, MNA-elect, mayor-elect). Although these candidates are directly chosen by voters (unlike premiers and prime ministers, who are picked by individual political parties), **the term "-elect" should be reserved for new political office holders picked by constituents but not sworn in yet. Furthermore, we generally drop the qualifier "elect" for virtually all declared winners within days of the election,** normally around the time cabinet members take their public oaths of office. See [MP-elect](/home/p/pm-designate#mayor) for details.

During election campaigns, Parliament still has MPs, provincial legislatures still have MPPs, MLAs (or whatever other term applies in a given region), municipalities still have mayors. These people continue to be paid. If they win on election night, therefore, they're simply "re-elected." It's neither necessary nor accurate to refer to incumbents as an "MP-elect" or an "MPP-elect" or a "mayor-elect."

See also [New PM, premier (designate vs. elect)](/home/e/election-titles#newPM) below for related caveat

**Governments**
**When referring to governments during federal and provincial election campaigns, emphasize party ties rather than people's names.** The same principles of impartiality and fairness cited above apply.


Federal government, **Conservative government**, etc. (not Harper government)
Provincial government, **Liberal government** in Quebec, etc. (not Charest government)

**
New PM, premier (designate vs. elect)**
**Never use the terms prime minister-elect or premier-elect.** They are wrong. In our electoral system, we vote for candidates running in local ridings rather than directly for provincial or national figures. Parties, in turn, form governments. And those parties pick (designate) their leaders.

If there's a change in government, the terms **prime minister-designate** and **premier-designate** are OK. More conversational options include **incoming prime minister** or premier, the **next PM** or premier, etc.

See [\-designate versus -elect](/home/p/pm-designate) for more details and examples, including the language used for newly elected presidents and mayors and newly appointed governors general.

**Re-elected PM, premier, etc.**
**If the person who was PM in the previous Parliament wins the election and forms the next government, we simply continue to call the person prime minister.** The same convention applies to premiers. **This is true even in rare cases when political party leaders win majority governments but lose their own seats.** Heads of political parties can govern from outside a given legislative body until they formally become members of the chamber, either by ballot or by acclamation after a byelection is called.

It's an acceptable convention to describe incumbent PMs and premiers as "re-elected" even though their ballot wins are technically as individual members of a Parliament or a legislature rather than as the head of a government.

**Defeated party leader** (who plans to resign)
**If someone loses an election and announces plans to step down as a party leader, we continue to refer to that person as the party leader** (e.g., Liberal Leader Stéphane Dion or outgoing Liberal Leader Stéphane Dion) **until either an interim leader or a permanent replacement is chosen**, depending on the succession path followed.

The general [titles overview](/home/t/titles) lists detailed typographical guidelines.

The detailed **CBC News [election primer](/home/e/election-primer) features a wide range of guidelines** (e.g., how to refer to incumbents, organize political panels, report on polls), including rules about election day blackouts and election night coverage. See also: [non-confidence votes](/home/n/non-confidence), [election versus elections](/home/e/election-or-elections) and [polls](/home/p/polls).

### elopee

**Elope, eloper, but not 'elopee'**

Centuries ago, the now-archaic legal term "eloper" described someone who fled a spouse with a lover. Today, the word **elope** simply means to **run away to get married**. A person who elopes is an **eloper**, not an elopee.

In recent years, **some police forces have started using "elopee" to mean anything from "escapee" to "missing person."** To our audience, however, **it's is just confusing jargon. Avoid elopee.**
**Instead of labelling people, report known details.** For instance, **if someone has walked away from a halfway house or a detention facility, say so and attribute allegations to the police** — assuming we've decided the story is worth covering. If someone at large is considered a danger to themselves or to the public, report why.

Police sometimes prefer to be vague, of course. But we need to press them for specifics rather than reiterating terms like "elopee."

There can be various JSP concerns in stories like this. So before identifying anyone, take into account all relevant CBC journalistic standards and practices. This often means weighing the public merits of naming people against individual privacy concerns. When in doubt, contact your supervisor.

### endemic, epidemic, pandemic

**Endemic, epidemic, pandemic**

**Endemic**
**Native to or common within a given place.** While this often refers to plants, animals, etc., the word is also applied to diseases. An endemic illness is one that is generally always present in a particular community because of permanent local factors, such as water, air or soil conditions.


**Epidemic**
**A widespread illness** (e.g., influenza, measles, smallpox, scarlet fever) **within a given community at a particular time.** Community can be defined here in different ways, such as a municipality, an area within a province, etc.

**Note: An epidemic does not necessarily mean people become gravely ill or that a lot of people die.** It simply means that a certain illness has infected a large percentage of a given community. Avoid alarming our audience with a term such as "epidemic" without putting a particular outbreak into context with specific information about the number of people known to be infected, recovery time, fatality rates, etc.


**Pandemic**
**An illness that has spread to a significant percentage of the world's population.** The word is also sometimes applied to an outbreak that has swept across an entire country, with the _mere potential to spread globally_. According to **the World Health Organization (WHO)**, for instance: A "flu pandemic" is a worldwide epidemic of a new influenza virus to which people have little or no immunity, and which has _started_ to spread across borders.

**Unless the [WHO](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/u/united-nations/#WHO "United Nations") has officially declared a pandemic, our normal practice is to avoid using the label** when covering outbreaks. We're also cautious about describing a contagion as a "potential pandemic" without attribution. **And we normally wait for WHO officials to declare the end of a pandemic before using such language in stories** (e.g., reporting on "post-pandemic" developments). **Pandemics are usually considered over when global health authorities deem outbreaks under control.** Actual **eradication is not a requirement.** Modern seasonal flu waves, for instance, are believed to have direct ties to past influenza pandemics, as new variants continue to surface and spread in parts of the world every year.

**As with epidemics, pandemics do not have to be severe. But they can be.** A 1968-69 flu pandemic that began in Hong Kong, for example, killed about one million people. By contrast, **the infamous 1918 flu pandemic is estimated to have killed as many as 50 million.** While the latter is sometimes dubbed the "Spanish flu," it's worth noting that scientists are uncertain where the deadly H1N1 influenza first emerged near the end of the First World War. Many historians now believe Spain was inaccurately and unfairly singled out as the source of the 1918 flu solely because of how war censors limited reporting of deaths elsewhere in Europe at the time.

See also: [flu](/home/f/flu) (including guidelines on H1N1 influenza), [bacteria versus virus](/home/b/bacteria-versus-virus) (including guidelines on terms such as non-adjuvant vaccine), [immunization, inoculation and vaccination](/home/i/immunization-vaccination), as well as [confirmed versus presumptive](/home/c/confirmed_presumptive_tests) medical cases and [superspreader](/home/s#superspreader).

### euthanasia

**Euthanasia**

**Euthanasia is commonly defined as "humanely ending life to relieve suffering."** The adverb "humanely" implies that the act is relatively quick and painless — reflected in the original ancient Greek term _euthanatos_, which meant "easy death."

Although the word euthanasia is OK when the facts fit, **generally prefer expressions such as assisted dying, medical assistance in dying and medically assisted dying in stories about terminally ill patients who want help to end their lives**. (See **[assisted dying](/home/a/assisted_dying)** for core guidelines)

Be aware that **euthanasia sometimes conveys the connotative meaning of non-voluntary death** — i.e., a mercy killing decided by guardians — **partly because of its widespread use in veterinarian medicine** (e.g., to euthanize a pet). **This can be confusing and misleading**, especially if a country's applicable laws restrict medical steps that can be taken when someone is in a coma, has severe brain damage or is unable to provide informed consent.

**Certain forms of medical assistance in dying were once called "voluntary euthanasia"** in public policy debates in Canada. Voluntary euthanasia was defined as direct, "active" aid to help someone die (e.g., administering a drug rather than simply prescribing it). By contrast, "assisted suicide" was defined as relatively "passive" aid, with the final step carried out by the patient. **Today, however, "assisted suicide" is frequently called "assisted dying," and old distinctions between euthanasia and assisted suicide have become largely blurred.** (See [historical perspective](/home/e/euthanasia#historical) below for details.) When reporting on assisted dying in other countries, keep in mind that the local laws and common vernacular may be different. To avoid ambiguity or confusion, it's a good idea to define any known differences in terminology.


**NOTE:**

-   **Report clearly and without jargon.** In particular, **avoid debatable language such as "active" and "passive" euthanasia without direct attribution**. And steer clear of bureaucratic-sounding or illogical constructions (e.g., "euthanasia-related death," which is like saying a "killing-related death").
-   **The term euthanasia is a poor choice if vital medical aid or treatment is stopped** (e.g., a ventilator is turned off at the family's request). **Instead, use phrases like "withdrew life-support."** which describes what happened without plunging us into the debate among medical ethicists over whether a specific act actually constituted euthanasia. (Was the patient suffering? Was the death "painless" or traumatic?) Such wording also acknowledges that **withdrawal of life-support, itself, may not lead to immediate death.**
-   **Generally avoid euphemisms** in stories about people dying ("passed away" or "slipped away").
-   Be aware of the various meanings of words that describe the death of **animals**. Note, for example, that **there are [varying definitions of the word “euthanize”](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/updates/2024/2024-10-04-use-euthanize-with-caution-when-describing-animal-death/ "2024 10 04 - Use “euthanize” with caution when describing animal death")** – some people consider it only to refer to the killing of animals that are ill, injured or otherwise unable to thrive, while others give a much broader definition. So, **outside of direct attribution, “euthanize” should be used with caution and not necessarily as a direct synonym for “killed humanely” or “killed as painlessly as possible.”** The verb “kill” is a neutral term to describe when humans end the lives of animals. But there are others. For example, when describing the humane deaths of animals, especially in a veterinary setting, "put down" is acceptable because it's entrenched. The term "destroy" is another option — especially if several animals are killed. The word "slaughter" is normally reserved for mass killings (e.g., dozens of cattle, hundreds of chickens). [Cull](/home/c#cull), by contrast, describes the selection of a smaller number of animals (e.g., a few cattle to reduce a herd's overall size). Hunters might tell you that they harvest animals. So, whatever phraseology you use, be sure to choose wording that gives audiences an accurate and balanced understanding of the situation.

**Historical perspective**

**Before 2016, "assisted suicide" was illegal in Canada**. In addition, **a distinction was made between "euthanasia" and "assisted suicide," now commonly known as "assisted dying."**

This **previously narrow definition of euthanasia described ACTIVE measures taken by medical personnel** to end someone else's life, at the person's request, often because the individual couldn't actually do it on their own for physical, emotional or other reasons. Examples included helping someone swallow pills, turn on a car, start a lethal intravenous drip, activate a carbon monoxide injector. **By contrast, assisted suicide was commonly defined as comparatively PASSIVE** (e.g., prescribing drugs, carrying someone to a car and closing the garage door, setting up a "suicide machine" that emitted a carbon monoxide injection). **Until "medical assistance in dying" was enshrined as lawful under specific circumstances in Canada, it had been crucial to distinguish between "euthanasia" and "assisted suicide."** This included coverage of Quebec's Bill 52 (end-of-life care legislation) in 2013, as well as the federal government's Bill C-14 (medical assistance in dying legislation) in 2016, which led to Criminal Code revisions. **Since 2016, assisted dying and related expressions** (e.g., medical assistance in dying, medically assisted death) **have become the preferred umbrella terms.**

For details, see the Library of Parliament's 2015 paper on [Euthanasia and Assisted Suicide in Canada](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Flop.parl.ca%2Fsites%2FPublicWebsite%2Fdefault%2Fen_CA%2FResearchPublications%2F2015139E&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1DHIG9wQLyHJXxMB8UfMAp) as well as its [2016 historical review](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Flop.parl.ca%2Fsites%2FPublicWebsite%2Fdefault%2Fen_CA%2FResearchPublications%2FLegislativeSummaries%2F421C14E&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2wz7oQOrXewETYyBopOCN5) of medical assistance in dying legislation in Canada. Health Canada has also posted an [overview of medical assistance in dying in Canada](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.canada.ca%2Fen%2Fhealth-canada%2Fservices%2Fmedical-assistance-dying.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1WVLFnoZGWW64TK7hqZH_U) that outlines the options available as well as the eligibility criteria.

**Some countries continue to distinguish between euthanasia, assisted suicide, etc.** Therefore, **use care when reporting on cases of medical assistance in dying abroad**. In particular, it's a good idea to **define terms that may have a different meaning in another country.** See the Library of Parliament's comparison of [euthanasia and assisted suicide outside Canada](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Flop.parl.ca%2Fsites%2FPublicWebsite%2Fdefault%2Fen_CA%2FResearchPublications%2F2015116E%23app1&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3Ok4qPYQpvTK9SXarYIkTL) for details.


See also: [death reporting guidelines](/home/d/death-general-guidelines) for a summary of related legal and editorial points as well as [suicide reporting guidelines](/home/s/suicide).

### evacuate

**Evacuate**

**Evacuate originally meant "to empty,"** as in to create a void or vacuum. **For many years, therefore, language sticklers argued that while places are commonly evacuated, people are usually not** (unless one administers an enema).

**CBC News style reflected this distinction for decades.** Journalists were told it's OK to write that police _evacuated a house, an office tower, a neighbourhood_, and so forth, but that they shouldn't write "_1,500 people were evacuated" UNLESS the verb was followed by a preposition such as "from" or "to" (e.g., "1500 people were evacuated from the village")._

**English evolves, however**, and **evacuate has the additional, perfectly acceptable meaning of "being urgently and temporarily relocated."** Indeed, it's worth noting that **the primary definition of the transitive verb "evacuate" in the 2004 Canadian Oxford Dictionary is:**

"_Remove (people) from a place of danger to stay elsewhere for the duration of the danger_."

So there's no need to recast clear, conversational and widely used phrases such as "**residents were evacuated**" because of outworn concerns by literalists over whether certain movements involve the bowel.


Those forced from an area because of flooding, a fire, an explosion, etc., are known as **evacuees**. The process itself is called **_evacuation_**.


See also [medevac](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/m/#medevac "M")

### ever

**Ever, first-ever, rarely (if) ever**

[first-ever (adj.)](/home/e/ever#first-ever) Generally avoid; virtually always redundant

**Ever (adv.)**

**Ever is an adverb that commonly means "always" or "at any time."** For example:


> They lived happily ever after.
>
> She's ever optimistic.
>
> Nothing ever happens.
>
> Did you ever see the like?


**Ever is also traditionally used to add emphasis** in a variety of ways:


> When will those two ever stop talking?
>
> Did he ever feel like a fool.
>
> Thanks ever so much.


**Idiomatic intensifier**

Some purists recommend dropping "ever" in cases when the same point can be made more directly. For example:


> Have you ever been to Tuktoyaktuk?
>
> Have you been to Tuktoyaktuk?


But **there's no blanket rule against adding the adverb as an intensifier.**

It's worth noting that **the above interrogatives about Tuktoyaktuk are not, technically, identical.** The first sentence uses "ever" to introduce the detail of "at any time." **The second sentence still suggests the sense of "at any time," but by leaving out the adverb it doesn't stress this meaning in the same way. Either is OK, depending on the writer's preference.** Needless to say, replacing "ever" with a different adverb (e.g., "recently") would change the question: "Have you recently been to Tuktoyaktuk?"

**First-ever (adj.)**

The compound **"first-ever" is frequently a mindless redundancy** (i.e., habitually used without thought or purpose).


> He was the first-ever human to walk on the moon.
>
> He was the first human to walk on the moon.
>
> She was the first-ever Indigenous woman to hold the post.
>
> She was the first Indigenous woman to hold the post.


**For this reason, many good writers and editors axe the intensifier "ever" and let "first" do its job alone.** Some defenders of "first-ever" liken it it "first-time" (e.g., "They're first-time home buyers"). The primary difference, however, is that "first-time" cannot  be shortened to "first" and maintain syntactical sense. Other **defenders of "first-ever" believe "ever" helps highlight a given milestone by giving "first" additional punch. The counterargument, however, is that redundancy usually weakens writing** by making sentences unnecessarily flabby.

**The only time "first-ever" is recommended is when clarity demands it.** In headline writing, for instance, adding "ever" to "first" sometimes eliminates ambiguity:


> Canada imposes first-ever trade sanctions against New Zealand
>
> Canada imposes first trade sanctions against New Zealand


In this case, "first-ever" labels the trade sanctions as historic while "first" alone might be interpreted as just an ordinal marker (i.e., Canada is imposing the first of a series of planned trade sanctions).

**Rarely (if) ever, seldom (if) ever**

The common expressions **"rarely ever" and "seldom ever" are occasionally challenged as either redundant or nonsensical:**


> He rarely if ever goes out nowadays.
>
> He rarely ever goes out nowadays.
>
> He rarely goes out nowadays.
>
> They seldom if ever say hello.
>
> They seldom ever say hello.
>
> They seldom say hello.


**But "rarely ever" and "seldom ever" are entrenched idioms that are perfectly acceptable in conversational writing.** The 2007 Oxford Guide to Canadian English points out that "rarely ever" has been in use for more than 300 years, and that "seldom ever" is a "respectable idiom with a long history in English." In formal writing, "if" tends to be added (i.e., "rarely if ever" and "seldom if ever") to make the constructions more logical. Since the missing preposition is already implied, however, **adding "if" to either familiar abridgment is purely optional.**


See [grammar](/handy-links/grammar)

### expatriate

**Expatriate, expat**

Common and acceptable terms for citizens **living abroad, especially for extended periods of time.**

Residency status varies. **Expatriates sometimes have dual citizenship.** In certain cases, they may be perceived to have a strong association with their country of origin even though they're no longer citizens (e.g., in the case of certain celebrities).

Be aware that **we occasionally receive unfounded audience complaints claiming that the label "expatriate" is racist.** It's a myth, however, that the word has been mainly used to describe white people living abroad. **There are countless examples of people with different racial backgrounds using the words "expat" and "expatriate" to describe themselves.** Books, films and other art forms are full of such references. For instance, famed novelist Salman Rushdie — born in India, educated in England and now living in the U.S. — has written extensively about the "expat experience." There are also several websites devoted to expatriates of diverse racial backgrounds, such as "TheBlackExpat.com" and "AsiaExpatGuides."

Examples of common and acceptable usage:


> **Expat Michael J. Fox** succinctly describes a Canadian-born white actor who became famous working on TV and in films in the U.S.
> **Expat Tina Turner** succinctly describes a U.S.-born Black singer who moved to Switzerland.


The transitive verb "expatriate," coined in the 1800s, originally referred to citizens who had been banished as a form of punishment. However, the current meaning of the noun and modifier (living abroad) has been deeply entrenched for more than half a century and is now part of everyday writing and speech:


> CITIZEN (Having the legal status of citizenship in a given country).



> DUAL CITIZEN (Having citizenship in more than one country).

>
> EMIGRANT (Having moved away from a place).

>
> **EXPATRIATE** (Living in another country, usually for an extended period).

>
> IMMIGRANT (Having moved to a place).

>
> MIGRANT (Being on the move or staying in one place for a limited time, often with no prospect of becoming a permanent citizen, such as a migrant worker).

>
> PERMANENT RESIDENT (Having various specific legal rights within a country without being a citizen).


See also [refugee, asylum seeker, migrant](/home/r/refugee) for specific editorial caveats about terminology used in coverage of displaced people or certain temporary workers.

### fake\_news

**Fake news**

**Do not use the term fake news as a catch-all label** for inaccurate, exaggerated, unverified or otherwise flawed journalism. It conventionally **refers to deliberately produced fiction masked as news**, especially in digital arenas (e.g., on the web, on social media accounts). While the term often implies an intentional attempt to deceive (e.g., political propaganda), it can also be rooted in gullibility as people naively circulate jokes, hoaxes, etc., they simply assume are true.

Quotation marks or the modifier [so-called](/home/s/so-called) can be helpful but are optional (e.g., what the U.S. president refers to as "fake news").

It's OK to flag specific content as false when fact-checking supports that conclusion. But **when there's genuine disagreement over interpretation of details, it's generally clearer to classify such stories as "disputed,"** and briefly outline each side's views.

Bear in mind that the [CBC's Journalistic Standards and Practices (JSP)](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fio.cbcrc.ca%2F%23%2Fresources%2Fjournalistic-standards-and-practices-jsp-normes-et-pratiques-journalistiques-npj-1.4517476&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0h3ExU9LO6RqgUI90XlcTe) lists accuracy as a core principle, and lays out certain verification guidelines. The JSP also requires balance and fairness, but this does not automatically mean giving equal weight to all opinions, or to dutifully reporting all opinions in coverage of a given story, especially when verifiable facts disprove the claims.

### Father, Mother, Brother, Sister

**Father, Mother, Sister, Brother**

**These terms are common and acceptable** ways to identify a person's particular position in a church or religious order. Generally **use only before full names** (first and last). Keep the audience in mind and **supply additional, relevant information as required** (e.g., which order or nuns someone belongs to or which pastor a priest has been assigned to).


**Father**
(Often used when referring to a Catholic priest)

> **Father Albert Lacombe**


Second reference: **Lacombe** or **the priest**. Although parishioners commonly address priests without using surnames in both first and second reference (e.g., "Father Albert"), this familial approach is not our style.

Bear in mind that titles vary depending on the church within a given faith. For instance, several religions have ordained clergy called [priests](/home/p#priest), but not all of them refer to priests as fathers. By contrast, the title [**Rev.**](/home/r#Rev) normally applies across the board. See also [Monsignor](/home/m#monsignor).


**Mother**
(Often used when referring to the head of an order of nuns or similar religious group)

> **Mother Marguerite-Thérèse Lemoine Despins** 

Second reference: **Despins**.


**Sister**
(Often used when referring to nuns, although not all members of a sisterhood are nuns)

> **Sister Antoinette Castonguay**


Second reference: **Castonguay**.


**Brother**
(Often used when referring to monks or other monastery members)

> **Brother Victor-Antoine d’Avila-Latourrette**


Second reference: **D’Avila-Latourrette**

**
Canonization**
When people have been canonized after death, use whatever new title applies (e.g., Mother Marguerite Bourgeoys became **St. Marguerite Bourgeoys** in 1982, and Brother André Bessette became St. André Bessette in 2010, although he's still commonly called **St. Brother André Bessette** in Quebec).

**In cases of well-known figures, first names are often sufficient:**

> Mother Teresa
>
> St. Paul
>
> St. André

### femalemale

**Woman versus female, man versus male**

Generally avoid using the words “woman” and “man” as adjectives, unless the expressions are common and apply to both sexes.

For instance, **womenswear** (not women’s wear) and **menswear** (not men’s wear) are well entrenched.

_But when it’s necessary to specify the sex or gender of a person_, prefer constructions such as “**female lawyer**” (not woman lawyer) and “**male nurse**” (not man nurse).

**Never highlight the sex or gender of a person unless it’s relevant to the story.**

If a surgeon saves a life or a police officer shoots a dangerous fugitive, for instance, there’s no need to write “female surgeon” or “female officer.” And if a nurse is put into quarantine during a SARS outbreak, there’s no need to write “male nurse.”

**The test should always be, would the other sex be treated the same way** (i.e., would we write “male surgeon,” “male officer,” or “female nurse”?) **Names and pronouns are usually sufficient identification.**

See also [**gender versus sex**](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/transgender/#sex-gender "Transgender") for related guidelines.

### fewer versus less

**Fewer versus less**

**Fewer**
**Fewer means a smaller number. Use it to refer to countable amounts, as long as the individual units are not thought of a collective whole** (e.g., _less than two months_).

The word is usually paired with plural nouns:

> _fewer buildings_
>
> _fewer teachers_
>
> _fewer cars_
>
> _fewer mistakes_

**Less**

**Less means a smaller amount. Use less to refer to collective quantity.**

The word is normally paired with singular nouns:

> _less salt_
>
> _less wheat_
>
> _less money_
>
> _less animosity_


**Wrong:**

"Less than 2,000 fans turned up."

**Correct:**
"Fewer than 2,000 fans turned up, so less beer was sold."


**Time, money, distance, etc.**
**The term less is also tied to a few plural nouns (_dollars_) when these are commonly identified with a single amount instead of individual units:**

> _Less than two cups of sugar._
>
> _Less than three weeks away._
>
> _Less than 40 kilometres downstream._
>
> _Less than 50 per cent of students are eligible._
>
> _Less than a million dollars._

Flipping these constructions around in your head often helps highlight the singular nature of the amounts in question: 

> _Two cups of sugar is a lot._
>
> _Three weeks is not a long time._
>
> _Forty kilometres is pretty far._
>
> _Fifty per cent is too low._
>
> _A million dollars is missing._

**Picking a preference**

Depending on the wording you want, you often have the option of using either "less than" or "fewer than." For instance:

> _Less meat might_ become _fewer hotdogs
> _
>
> _Less trouble might_ become _fewer problems
> _
>
> _Less scotch might_ become _fewer glasses of scotch_

CBC is the exclusive Canadian media rights holder for the **2010 FIFA World Cup South Africa™** ("the World Cup"). **Name of tournament**
Full name: **2010 FIFA World Cup South Africa**
Minimum first reference in all journalism: **FIFA World Cup** or **2010 FIFA World Cup**
Acceptable second reference: **World Cup** (or 2010 World Cup)
If a gender-specific modifier is included, capitalize (**Men's World Cup**).^

^ = _If gender detail is deemed necessary, we capitalize for consistency in our coverage  (e.g., Men's World Cup and Women's World Cup), even though technically only the latter (Women's) is included in official FIFA tournament names._

**When writing or editing text** (including on-air scripts and online stories), **always retain the acronym FIFA in first reference** (FIFA World Cup). It doesn't merely strengthen the CBC's coverage as an official broadcaster, **it helps identify the story** (several sports have world cups), **which serves our audience**. And in the case of web journalism, **it also makes content easier to find through keyword searches** when FIFA is in the headlines.

**The acronym FIFA is relatively well known and, so, does not need to be spelled out** as Fédération Internationale de Football Association. When writing about the federation for a general audience, it's helpful to add an explanatory line (e.g., "soccer's world governing body") as high as possible in stories. But this does not normally apply to World Cup coverage if FIFA is simply included as part of the event's name. **Since "football" refers to a different sport in North America, prefer the word "[soccer](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/s/soccer/ "Soccer")"** in our journalism.


**Background**
Location: **South Africa**
Dates: **June 11 – July 11, 2010**

The World Cup is an **international soccer competition held every four years by the sport's global governing body, FIFA**. To participate, teams must have won enough matches in their respective divisions or confederations during the previous few years. (In 2010, Canada and more than 170 other countries failed to make the cut.) **The 32 national men's teams that qualify are divided into eight groups of four.** Each team plays the other three in its group. They're awarded three points for a win and one point for a tie. **The top two teams from each group go into the second phase of the tournament** (known as the Round of 16). **One-game eliminations begin** in Round 16 and subsequent head-to-head competitions. Each game is 90 minutes, with a 30-minute overtime in the case of a tie, and a series of shootouts if there's still no winner in OT. **Eventually, two teams earn a spot in the World Cup final** — the most widely watched sports match on the planet.


**Team names and nicknames**
**Apply standard CBC News style to country names** (e.g., North Korea rather than Democratic People's Republic of North Korea, the Netherlands not Holland, and Ivory Coast not Côte d'Ivoire). **But use England rather than Britain or the U.K.**, since Britain actually has several FIFA teams (e.g., Northern Ireland, Scotland, Wales).

**We almost always identify teams by country in news coverage** (e.g., France plays South Africa). **Nicknames are fine in second reference, however, as long as the context makes the team's identity clear.** If definite articles appear in a nickname in a language other than English (e.g., El or La), capitalize (La Albirroja). But keep "the" lowercase in English (the Three Lions). And prefer English versions when there are options (e.g., Algeria's Desert Foxes rather than Les Fennecs). When teams have more than one nickname (e.g., Germany's Nationalelf or "national eleven" and Nationalmannschaft or "national team"), we prefer the most common (in this case Die Mannschaft, pronounced "DEE-man-shaft," which simply translates to "the Team"). **Here are the correct spellings:**

**Players' names**
**To find the proper spelling of a player's name, as well as the phonetic pronunciation, click on his team's country below.** About 150 of the most commonly mistyped or misspoken proper nouns are listed. Last names always appear first. In a few cases, coaches are included. **Sometimes, soccer players are known by only a single name or nickname** (e.g., Brazil's superstar Edson Arantes do Nascimento was always called "Pele").
