### filibuster

**Filibuster**

Conventionally refers to **one or more people speaking at length in order to delay a vote or other business in a legislative body.
**
The term is sometimes applied to other obstruction tactics. But we prefer to **restrict "filibuster" to delays involving speech** (e.g., an MP reading from a phone book, a politician introducing legislation with a title spread out over 100 pages).

This narrower definition **avoids ambiguity** and, so, **makes our journalism clearer**. It **also reflects traditional definitions of "filibuster" in various books on parliamentary rules and practice**, including the [House of Commons Glossary of Parliamentary Procedure](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ourcommons.ca%2FAbout%2FGlossary%2FIndex-e.html%23LetterF&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0T7AIcoILDveCfiSaPVqqI).

There are **plenty of other ways to describe various opposition protests that don't involve virtually non-stop talking**, from "stonewalling" and "stalling strategies" to "procedural delays" and more specific descriptions, such as "all-night voting marathons."

The word filibuster originally comes from a Dutch term for pirates and other rebellious privateers. It was first applied to disruptions within legislative assemblies in the U.S. in the 1880s. In popular culture, the most famous filibuster is probably a 24-hour speech delivered by Jimmy Stewart on the floor of the U.S. Senate in the 1939 Frank Capra classic, _Mr. Smith Goes to Washington_. Although the modern, political meaning of "filibuster" is less than two centuries old, the delay tactic, itself, was used at least as far back as ancient Rome, according to historians.


### fired

**Fire, fired, firing**

The terms fire, fired, firing are **entrenched colloquialisms for employment termination**. They're **OK as long as the facts fit** (e.g., the person has not been laid off, quit, retired, etc.).

Beyond conveying that the employee did not leave voluntarily, **words such as "fired" imply something other than economic downsizing.
**
Be aware that **some employers may try to couch a dismissal as mere restructuring**, and even brand the move with marketing obfuscation, such as workers being given "opportunities for change." **This sometimes mean assessing whether a word like "fired" applies, especially if there's any evidence of a potential conflict** (e.g., when a watchdog or whistleblower is terminated by a government). In such cases, **put the audience first by using clear, direct wording.** To avoid accusations of possible bias (e.g., pro-worker or pro-employer), **include fact-based descriptions that put use of "fired" into context** (e.g., a person's contract was suddenly terminated months or years early).

NOTE: **If it's clear that someone was forced to resign, it's OK to use the term "fired"** as long as the evidence is overwhelming and the details are put into context. Words such as **"ousted" and "removed" are also common** and acceptable. Generally **distinguish between a contract employee being released long before an agreement's expiration date** (i.e., they are "fired"), **and someone whose expiring contract is simply not extended or renewed** (i.e., they are "let go").

See also [contract dispute](/home/l#labourdispute) (instead of "labour dispute"), and [replacement worker](/home/r/replacement-worker).

### Fisheries and Oceans

**Fisheries and Oceans**

The official name of the ministry is the **Department of Fisheries and Oceans**, commonly known as the **DFO**. Although rebranded **Fisheries and Oceans Canada** in 2008, the ministry still operates under the **Department of Fisheries and Oceans Act**. The abbreviation DFO continues to surface in some government documents, and in some parts of the ministry's website.

For this reason, it's perfectly accurate to use the Department of Fisheries and Oceans in our journalism. The relatively entrenched abbreviation DFO also remains fine, especially in headlines.

But full, formal ministry names are not always required, so it's also OK to shorten the compound noun to something entrenched that our audience instantly recognizes (e.g., the **Fisheries Department**). Depending on a given story's facts, this can sometimes be further reduced to a single word (e.g., a **Fisheries** report), even in a web headline.

While there's nothing wrong with using the rebranded name Fisheries and Oceans Canada, the abbreviation **FOC is normally too obscure to be effective**, especially in headlines.

It's worth noting that Fisheries and Oceans has had many other names since 1867, including the Department of Naval Services and the Department of Marine and Fisheries — an example of the short shelf life of certain proper nouns in government.

See also [Canada Revenue Agency (CRA)](/home/c/canada-revenue-agency) for comparison
See also [Ministry](/home/m/ministry) for general guidelines about related proper nouns
See also [Department versus department](/home/d/department)

### fisherman

**Fisherman, fishermen, fisher**

**The words _fisherman_ and _fishermen_ are acceptable** in news stories, although they're not the only terms available to journalists. **Alternatives include _people who fish_, _fishery workers, fish harvesters_ and _fishers_.** As a generic term, **"fisher" has become increasingly more popular since the start of the millennium**. Before that, it was more widely known as a type of weasel in many parts of North America.

**Reserve _angler_ for recreational fishing.** It does not apply to commercial fishermen.

**Be aware that some members of the fishery strongly oppose being called _fishers_,** including certain women who work in it, and who proudly insist on being called _fishermen_. **Respect individual preferences when known**.

NOTE: For several years, some CBC News units insisted on _fishers_ while others permitted _fishermen_. In 2003, the Editor in Chief's Office clarified CBC News style and ruled that the word _fishermen_ is OK on radio, television and digital platforms. This has been revisited and reaffirmed several times since, including in 2018 and 2020. For a longer discussion of the old debate, see the August 2000 Words: Woe and Wonder column [Men, Women and Fishers](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews2%2Findepth%2Fwords%2Ffishermen.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0SiuspcUJqwl_I3V8pK9Ay).



### flu

**Flu**

**Flu is short for _influenza_**, a highly contagious infection caused by viruses. **Either word is acceptable in first reference.** Symptoms can include fever, severe aches and coughing.

[3 broad categories](/home/f/flu#categories) (Type A, Type B, Type C) 

['Swine flu' versus H1N1](/home/f/flu#swineflu) (CBC News style) 

**3 broad categories**

**Type A**
This is the most common in humans. It includes seasonal flu. The most serious and widespread outbreaks of influenza have also been Type A, including the 1918 flu pandemic that killed tens of millions.


**Type B**
Although it can cause epidemics, this influenza tends to be milder than Type A.


**Type C**
Much rarer and also usually much-less severe. Experts say Type C has never been associated with an epidemic.

Keep in mind that **it's the size of an outbreak rather than the severity of the contagious illness that determines whether it's considered an actual [epidemic or pandemic](/home/e/endemic-epidemic-pandemic).**


**H1N1, H5N1, etc.**
**Only Type A influenza is classified using the H and N system**, which reflects various combinations of proteins that microbiologists know all about but most of us fail to grasp or remember. **In news stories, it's sometimes valuable to include this additional information** (e.g., H2N2) **to distinguish between different types of Type A flu**, (e.g., a Type A flu of the H1N1 strain or the H1N1 influenza A virus), **although a colloquial name** (e.g., swine or avian flu) **is often enough in first reference, depending on context.**
For instance, **H1N1** is one new strain of swine flu first reported in Mexico in early 2009 (evidence suggests it actually surfaced in that country in 2008), while **H5N1** is one strain of avian flu. Such alphanumeric coding is usually optional during reports of particular outbreaks, especially since they are not unique to a particular flu (i.e., there's more than type of H1N1 influenza). The Russian flu of 1977, for instance, was also classified as H1N1. A different type of **[swine flu](/home/s#swineflu)** is called H1N2.


**'Swine flu' versus H1N1**
It's **OK to use swine flu in first reference** (headlines and leads), but not mandatory. It's **common to use H1N1 after that**, but there's flexibility, depending on the length of the story. **Graphics on TV and online should use H1N1**. When adding scientific context in second reference, options include: the **H1N1 influenza virus**, the **H1N1 flu virus**, the **H1N1 flu** and the **H1N1 virus**. Avoid hyphens, slashes, etc., in compound adjectives: **swine flu vaccine, H1N1 flu shot**, etc. It's a [Type A flu](/home/f/flu#categories).

See also Esther Enkin's Inside CBC News blog post, [We are not renaming swine flu](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews%2Fcanada%2Fwe-are-not-renaming-swine-flu-1.788116&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3qoJATB1vQdxuBoS7nF8ok), from May 2009 for details on the decision against banning the term swine flu from stories about the H1N1 virus.


**Limit scientific jargon**
If alphanumeric coding is added to a story to clarify a particular point, extra detail is not normally required — even though a longer label may be used in the official, scientific name of a given form of influenza, such as the year or location of the initial outbreak: _H1N1 (2008, Mexico) influenza A virus_. Depending on context, much shorter options are available, including: [**swine flu** and **H1N1 flu**](/home/f/flu#swineflu) as outlined above. If extra information is added to a label, pick the most meaningful fact. For example, if a new strain of a virus appeared in 2008 but an actual pandemic broke a year or two later, it would make more sense to our audience to tie the name to current coverage (i.e., to describe it as the 2009 H1N1 flu or the 2010 H1N1 flu). If the strain has mutated, this fact is worth reporting at the time of the new outbreak.

In a health or science feature, of course, more background might be called for when explaining, say, what the H (hemagglutinin) and the N (neuraminidase) stand for, and how Type A is broken down into 16 H (H1-H16) and nine N (N1-N9) subtypes. But in daily news coverage **there’s generally no need to pile on scientific jargon**, especially since all obscure terms need to be defined for a broad audience. Use your judgment.


**'Stomach flu'**
**The term "stomach flu" is a common and acceptable label for gastroenteritis.** Although some symptoms are flu-like, **gastroenteritis is not influenza.** It's actually an inflamed or severely irritated stomach or intestinal tract. Unlike influenza, which is caused by a virus, gastroenteritis may be caused by a bacteria, a virus, a parasite, etc. **Do not shorten "stomach flu" to "flu" in stories.** Instead, report specific details that are known (e.g., if it was caused by tainted food or contaminated water).

See also [**bacteria versus virus**](/home/b/bacteria-versus-virus) for related guidelines, including the difference between a **vaccine** and an **antiviral drug**, what a **non-adjuvant** injection means, etc.

**Food**

**Capitalize most proper noun elements in names of food** if the modifier adds a distinctive meaning:


> Alberta beef
> bananas Foster
> beef Wellington
> Belgian chocolate
> Boston cream pie
> Canadian bacon
> Dutch cheese
> eggs Benedict

> French toast

> Mediterranean cuisine
> Montreal smoke meat

**This includes protected brand names** (e.g., Fudgsicle, Hamburger Helper, Popsicles, and Tabasco sauce but hollandaise sauce). See [trade names](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/trade-names/ "Trade names") for related guidelines.

**Exceptions to the general capitalization rule** are proper noun elements that have become lowercase through entrenched usage:


> baked alaska

> chicken kiev

> kalamata olives

> peking duck

**Be aware that certain names are lowercase because a given modifier is not directly associated with the food** (e.g., "french fries") **or because the historical wording is outdated** (e.g., the old spelling of "Kyiv" in "chicken kiev," and the old transliteration of what's now known as "Beijing" in "peking duck").

### foot-and-mouth disease

**Foot-and-mouth disease**

The name is lowercase and with hyphens. It's sometimes shortened to FMD, but _avoid_ this abbreviation in news stories.

Some scientists call it aphthous fever, but we don't have to.

Although the disease affects cloven-hoofed animals, its common name begins with the word **"foot," not hoof**. Do _not_ change it to hoof.

Don't confuse it with "hand-foot-and-mouth disease," an illness contracted by humans.

For a general discussion on the use of the word "foot" in a disease that's associated mainly with cattle and sheep, read the Words: Woe & Wonder column, [Foot or hoof: A sole choice?](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews2%2Findepth%2Fwords%2Fhoofoot.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1tKXFWF0NCpraPmazo3m2Z)

For more background on [foot-and-mouth disease](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews%2Ftechnology%2Ffoot-and-mouth-disease-human-animal-versions-unrelated-1.722807&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0bE45SRS6uJf8zGdWZuJDp) itself, read the 2008 CBC News.ca feature.

### football

**Football terms**

backup centre, ball carrier, ball club, blitz (n., v.), bootleg, end line, end zone, field goal, fourth-and-one (adj.), fullback, goal line (two words), goal-line stand, halfback, halftime, handoff, kick off (v.), kickoff (n., adj.), left guard, linebacker, lineman, nose tackle, offside, out of bounds (adv.), out-of-bounds (adj.), pitchout (n.), place kick, placekicker, play off (v.), playoff (n., adj.), quarterback, runback (n.), running back, tailback, tight end, touchback, touchdown

Do not confuse the Saskatchewan [Roughriders](/home/r#Roughriders) with the Ottawa Rough Riders, which folded in 1996. Ottawa's next CFL team, the Renegades, played from 2002-06, until being suspended by the league because of financial instability. The city's new team, the Redblacks, took to the field in 2014.

For consistency and audience recognition, generally prefer the term [soccer](/home/s/soccer) for the sport most people outside of North America call "football."

See the [sports overview](/home/s/sports-overview) for links to various other entries, including baseball, basketball, curling, golf, hockey and Olympics.

### Non-English words, foreign languages, accents

**Non-English words, foreign languages, accents**

[Italics](/home/f/foreign-words#italics) (_caveat emptor_, but ad nauseam)
[Standard roman alphabet](/home/f/foreign-words#roman_alphabet) ("th" not "þ")
[Preferred transliterations](/home/f/foreign-words#transliterations) (Cologne not "Köln" Germany)
[Accents](/home/f/foreign-words#accents) (El Niño, but Mexico not "México")
[Phonetics](/home/f/foreign-words#phonetics) (optional, parenthetical detail)


**NOTE: Foreign language is defined here as a language that's not known to most English-speaking Canadians.** Some people in English Canada also speak German or Italian or Arabic or Cree or Ojibwa or Blackfoot or numerous other tongues. But to most English speakers, these are foreign languages. In this sense, the modifier "foreign" does not mean "external." It also does not mean "original" or native, since Indigenous languages were spoken in North America long before English. Rather, "foreign" is a relative expression that helps underscore what is still non-English (e.g., _cause célèbre_, _schadenfreude_, and _carpe diem_) versus words with foreign roots that are now considered English (premiere, haiku, gesundheit and toboggan). The latter often have entrenched English spellings and pronunciations. To an unilingual English speaker in Canada, therefore, French, Spanish, Cree, etc., are all foreign languages, in the same way that, to an English speaker living in Japan, "Japanese" is a foreign language.


**Italics**
**CBC News reports in English**, just as Radio-Canada reports in French. **Generic, non-English words should appear in italics if not relatively well-established** as part of our language. The Canadian Oxford is our guide. For instance:


> **ITALICS**
> _au revoir_
> _caveat emptor
> __favela_
> _objet d'art
> __persona non grata
> __schadenfreude
> __shoji_
> **
> NO ITALICS**
> ad nauseam
> bona fide
> carte blanche
> glasnost
> haiku
> mujahedeen
> perestroika


See the [italics overview](/handy-links/punctuation/italics) for more details and examples.

**Standard roman alphabet**
**Use familiar A to Z characters in virtually all cases. The main exceptions are Indigenous languages in Canada**, which have special status. (See [Indigenous spellings and phonetics](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/i/indigenous/#spellings "Indigenous") for details.)

For some languages (e.g., Arabic, Chinese), the original text needs to be converted from entirely different writing systems through a process known as "romanization." For other languages, words from one alphabet are transliterated into another (e.g., variations of Cyrillic letters used in Russian, Ukrainian, Serbian, etc.).

**Always use English forms when they're entrenched** (e.g., Peter the Great not "Pyotr the Great").

**Be aware that some languages use slight variations of the standard roman alphabet**. For instance, Icelandic features a couple of old characters like "thorn" (þ) dropped from English words long ago. In these cases, **use modern English lettering when conventions exist** (e.g., "th" for "þ") because they're more widely understood by our audience. By contrast, an alphabet like Norway's uses a slash called a "miniature" in the letter o sometimes ("ø") to indicate a specific vowel sound. We report entrenched ø spellings (e.g., Thorbjørn) because they're not overly confusing or jarring to our readers.

**Also be aware that some alphabets may look deceptively similar to the roman alphabet at first blush, but are actually considerably different** upon closer examination. Modern Latvian, for example, uses 33 letters. It has no Qs or Ws. It also has more than one distinct form of some other letters, such as As, Cs, Gs and Ks, modified by diacritical markings. **In most cases, we follow the English convention of transliterating spellings from such languages into the standard roman alphabet**, especially when English versions are already reasonably well established (e.g., **Camp Adazi** rather than "Camp Ādaži" for the **military base in Latvia**, which the locals write as "Latvija"). The most common exceptions are people's names when specific spelling preferences, including accents, are known. While we get periodic audience complaints from individuals who think CBC News should always use foreign spellings and dialectical markings based on the principles of accuracy and respect, the reality is that **we report in English, and, so, need to make decisions about orthography that best serve our English audience.** At the end of the day, using an English spelling like Camp Adazi instead of the Latvian spelling Camp Ādaži is no different from, say, a Latvian news organization spelling Canada, Quebec and New Brunswick as "Kanāda," "Kvebeka" and "Ņūbransvika," respectively.

**Preferred transliterations**
**When deciding between alternative English spellings** of foreign names and words, **generally pick the most familiar or entrenched version** (e.g.,Rachmaninoff instead of "Rakhmaninov"). If you're not sure, check the Language Guide for declared preferences (e.g., al-Qaeda instead of al-Qaida).

**Be aware that preferred transliterations can change over time** (e.g., czar instead of tsar). This includes proper nouns (e.g., Beijing, Mao Zedong, and Mumbai rather than Peking, Mao Tse-tung and Bombay). For this reason, **we sometimes abandon old, entrenched spellings for editorial reasons** (e.g., Ukraine's shift from old Russian spellings, such as "Kiev" to "Kyiv").

For details and other examples, see [transliterations](/home/t/transliterations)

**Accents**
**Add diacritical markings to foreign words, including proper nouns** (e.g., people's names) **when accurate and appropriate.** "Accurate" means **known/confirmed**. "Appropriate" means that **no common, accent-free English forms are entrenched** (e.g., we write Mexico rather than "México"):


> **ACCENTS**
> António Guterres
> Céline Dion
> communiqué
> El Niño
> exposé
> Eyjafjallajökull
> fiancé
> Götterdämmerung
> Gwìch’i
> Jonas Gahr Støre
> La Niña
> ménage à trois
> Nil Köksal
> Plácido Domingo
> raison d'être
> Saša Petricic
> tête-à-tête
>
> **NO ACCENTS** (because alternatives are entrenched)
> Baha'i faith (not "Bahá'í faith")
> Benedictine (not "Bénédictine" for herbal liqueur; see [wines, spirits](/home/w/wines_spirits))
> Haiti (not "Haïti")
> inukshuk (not "iñuksuk")
> Mexico (not "México")
> Montreal rather than "Montréal" (except in proper nouns like "Le Journal de Montréal")
> Munich (not "München")
> Nuremberg (not "Nürnberg")
> Peru (not "Perú")
> Quebec rather than "Québec" (excpet in proper nouns like "Hydro-Québec")
> pinatas (not "piñatas")
> Thordis Thorhallsdottiri rather than "Þórdís Þórhallsdóttir" (Icelandic politician)


**Be aware that French requires special care** because of its unique history in Canada. See [**French words and accents**](/home/f/french-words-and-accents) for detailed guidelines and examples.


NOTE: **We began routinely adding accents to foreign languages that use traditional roman lettering** (e.g., Italian, German, Spanish) **in March 2019.** Previously, we primarily included accents in French words only. **This shift in style was adopted for two reasons:**


> **(i) An increase in the use of accents by various people and groups in Canada**, prompting requests to match these spellings whenever practical; and
>
> **(ii) Technical improvements**, making it easier to display a bigger range of diacritical markings on digital platforms, including mobile devices.


**Never assume diacritical markings are correct.** It's better to leave out accents than to add incorrect ones. **When omitting accents, be aware that standard guidelines may apply.** The [German name](/home/g/german-names) Göbbels, for instance, would normally appear as Goebbels in English, following the convention of inserting an "e" after the applicable vowel. And _danke schön_, which means "thank you very much" in German, would become _danke schoen_.

**Do not confuse the French accent tréma** (e.g., the ë in Michaëlle Jean) **with an umlaut** (e.g., the ü in Düsseldorf, which we would write as Duesseldorf).

**If a diacritical mark is used, make certain that it's the right accent over the correct letter.** Even familiar words can be messed up when people aren't careful. Consider this blunder: In 1992, Canada Post had to reprint a Christmas stamp because the original design mistakenly spelled _Noël_ as "_Nöel_."

Unless entrenched English forms exist, **generally match spellings — including accents — of foreign place names, building names, etc., found on official signage** featuring the roman alphabet. For instance, go with a capital É in the name of a famous Paris building (Élysée Palace), and the name of a famous Paris street (Champs-Élysées).

**Ignore invented umlauts** (e.g., Haagen-Daz ice cream, not Häagen-Daz, and Motley Crue, not Mötley Crüe).

**Phonetics**
We routinely add phonetics to broadcast scripts to boost accurate, consistent pronunciation of unfamiliar words, including proper nouns from foreign languages. **Phonetics are sometimes added to published text** as well. Depending on the story, **parenthetical pronunciations can help our audience confronted by unusual accents and/or long, daunting spellings.**

In stories written for the eye (e.g., web articles), the easiest approach is to use brackets, with uppercase letters for syllabic stress:


> Iceland's **Eyjafjallajökull** (pronounced AY-uh-fyoot-luh-YUH-kootl-uh) last erupted in ...
> The Cree word _**mâmawêyatitân**_ (pronounced MAW-maw-way-AT-ah-tin) means ...
> **Stó:lō** (pronounced 'STAW-loh) leaders say the project ...


Such detail is optional on digital platforms like CBCNews.ca. When adding phonetics, always check the [CBC Pronunciation Database](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2Flng%2Frecherche%2Findex.aspx&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1XFPfiGVRPwO63-NkaNyUm) first to see if there's a preferred in-house style. Also, follow the [CBC Phonetics Guide](https://docs.google.com/a/cbc.ca/viewer?a=v&pid=sites&srcid=Y2JjLmNhfGxhbmd1YWdlZ3VpZGV8Z3g6NzQxNzEyNzFhYjI3ZWZlYw) when spelling out vowel and consonant sounds.

See also [Pronunciation FAQs](/handy-links/pronunciation) for answers to common questions about CBC phonetics.

**Overview**
**Although CBC News publishes and broadcasts in English, French words frequently surface in our journalism.** This is particularly true of proper nouns, such as the names of people, certain organizations and geographical locations.

**As a Crown corporation in a country with two official languages, we treat French with special care.** In 1994, Ottawa identified the CBC as one of several federal institutions with a major role in implementing the country's Official Languages Act. We're committed to "fostering the full recognition and use of both English and French in Canadian society."

**In 2006, the CBC established editorial guidelines for the logical and consistent use of accents, italics, capital letters and so forth in French words we publish in our English news coverage.**

For example, our style is:


Métis leaders are urging Quebec to sign the accord.
She met her fiancé at the University of Quebec in Montreal.
He led the Parti Québécois from 1996 to 2001.
"It's a _fait accompli_," complained Quebec's premier.
She plans to resign Friday, according to Le Journal de Montréal.
St-Jean-Baptiste Day is better known as _Fête nationale_ in Quebec.
Hydro-Québec said it hopes to have power restored by Monday.
One of the investors is the _Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec_.
"_Vive le Québec libre,_" de Gaulle told the cheering crowd.

Several other national news organizations in Canada, such as CP and the Globe and Mail, follow a similar approach when including French words in English text.

**A few in-house style preferences are worth emphasizing:**

-   French words considered part of everyday English (e.g., fiancé) are not in italics.
-   Most words considered French rather than English (e.g., _fait accompli_) are in italics.
-   For generic French words or phrases, we follow the spelling and capitalization featured in the Canadian Oxford Dictionary (e.g., resumé not _résumé_, and _coup d'état_ not _coup d'État_).
-   Newspaper names (French or English) are not in italics.
-   French geographical names (Trois-Rivières) are not in italics and generally follow English capitalization — i.e., uppercase letters are featured at the start of principal words.
-   English versions of "pan-Canadian" names (Quebec not Québec) are always used, unless the French form is part of a proper noun (Hydro-Québec).
-   French names of organizations that either officially or conventionally follow English capitalization (e.g., Les Grands Ballets Canadiens) are not in italics.
-   French names of organizations that do not follow English capitalization (e.g., _Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec_) are in italics to help flag these nouns for readers.
-   The titles of artistic works (French or English), such as novels or movies, are in italics.
-   The titles of French news programs (e.g., _Le Téléjournal_) follow English capitalization.
-   The titles of French artistic works follow English capitalization only if the uppercase lettering is established through convention (e.g., _Les Misérables_ but _La détresse et l'enchantement_).

For journalists accustomed to "French" versus "English" typography, it's worth noting that different approaches are taken by websites that serve primarily French audiences (such as Radio-Canada.ca).

**Detailed CBC News guidelines and other examples are outlined below.**

**French accents – A matter of consistency and accuracy**
**Include accents on French words that aren't already part of everyday English, as long as you're certain that these diacritical markings are correct.** When verifying French words or names, check our internal style manual or a reliable external source. Consulting broadcast scripts is not sufficient.

CBC-sanctioned publishing tools give online writers and editors quick access to all standard uppercase and lowercase diacritics. Avoid adding raw HTML, which can cause technical problems.

  

  **GENERAL NAME**

  **SPECIFIC ACCENT**

  acute (_aigu_)

  é, É

  grave (_grave_)

  à, è, ù, À, È, Ù

  circumflex (_circonflexe_)

  â, ê, î, ô, û, Â, Ê, Î, Ô, Û 

  diaeresis (_tréma_)

  ë, ï, ü, Ë, Ï, Ü

  cedilla (_cédille_)

  ç, Ç

Using accents consistently, according to set criteria, makes our text more sensible to readers. We're not left referring to Jean Chrétien, Gaspé, Parti Québécois or café in one sentence and then, for no logical reason, to Michaelle Jean, Rene Levesque, communique or cliche in the next (instead of Michaëlle Jean, René Lévesque, communiqué and cliché).

French accents also reinforce accuracy in our journalism. As the Editors' Association of Canada points out in its manual Editing Canadian English, French diacritics are "as much a component of correct spelling as the letters they appear with." In other words, turning Stéphane Dion into "Stephane Dion" is just one step shy of calling him "Stephen."

Of course, **some French words do not require accents because of convention. In other instances, the diacritical marks are dropped based on the established preference of an individual or organization.**

**Café, communiqué and protege**
**French words that are now part of our common English vocabulary**, such as café and protege, **do not need to be in italics.** They often have no accents or limited accents (resumé instead of the original French _résumé_).

Keep in mind that while a term's etymology may be French, the word may very well be treated as English now. Obvious examples are the prefixes "Anglo" and "Franco":
