**People's names**
One of the Fathers of Confederation, George-Étienne Cartier, used the English form of George rather than the French ("Georges") in honour of King George III. It's a reminder that names can be tricky, if not a royal pain.

**We're expected to spell people's names correctly** (e.g., MacDonald, Macdonald, McDonald, or some other variation). **In the case of French accents, this means following known preferences:**

> Jean Béliveau
>
> Geneviève Bujold
>
> Jean Chrétien
>
> Stéphane Dion
>
> Anne Hébert
>
> Michaëlle Jean
>
> Paul-Émile Léger
>
> René Lévesque
>
> François Mitterrand
>
> Jeanne Sauvé


**Don't make assumptions about diacritical markings inside or outside of Quebec.** In 2005, Ontario appointed André Marin as the province's ombudsman. On the other hand, Jean-Luc Pepin (a Trudeau-era cabinet minister from Quebec) dropped the accent in his name when writing in both English and French.

The names of high-profile people are fairly easy to determine. In the case of Marin and Pepin, for instance, numerous official provincial and federal documents clearly show whether to include an accent. And with a search engine such as Google, it takes only seconds to find the official website of [Roméo Dallaire](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.romeodallaire.com%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1Rk3uKtwEdOWg2TDZ15Y5l) to see how the retired Canadian lieutenant-general's name should be spelled. (You can also clearly see the accent on the cover of his book, _Shake Hands With the Devil_.)

Of course, **we don't limit diacritics to an elite — e.g., politicians, famous ex-soldiers and governors general. But we do accept that some preferences will be harder to determine than others,** even in the case of someone moving into Rideau Hall.

When **Michaëlle Jean** was named governor general-designate in 2005, for example, virtually all large English media outlets in Canada included the diaeresis (_e tréma_). But few bothered to add an acute accent to her daughter's name for several days: **Marie-Éden**. Once the correct spelling was known, however, the "É" was widely embraced. (Note: CBC.ca's French colleagues, Radio-Canada.ca, used Marie-Éden from the start. But outside of Quebec, it took a phone call from CBCNews.ca to Rideau Hall to confirm the accent and get the Governor General's official website corrected.)


**'But I didn't know it was Nadège'**
If writing about Michaëlle Jean's time as a child in Haiti, we should refer to the regime of dictator **François (Papa Doc) Duvalier**, since this is a well-known historical figure. The country itself would have no accent — **Haiti** not "Haïti" — because this is an entrenched English convention. (See [geographical names](/home/f/french-words-and-accents#geographicaldomestic) below for more details).

If mentioning Jean's uncle **René Depestre**, we should have no trouble determining that his name includes an acute accent because he's a published author.

But leaving out the grave accent in her sister's name (**Nadège**), for instance, would be justified only if we had been unaware of its existence. **Ignoring a correct French accent intentionally is unacceptable.**

**
Flag clashes between sources**
**Some names appear in more than one way, of course, depending on the source.**

For years, for instance, we followed the Canadian Oxford's spelling of the country's twelfth prime minister, Louis St. Laurent, since this anglicized version of the name had become relatively common in news coverage of his time in office in the 1940s and 50s.

But for consistency we now use his original (French) preference, Louis St-Laurent, which is also the spelling found in Parliament of Canada publications, the Library of Parliament, the Dictionary of Canadian Biography and the Canadian Encyclopedia. (The Canadian Press, which previously used Saint-Laurent, also switched to St-Laurent in 2005).

**When two different spellings are offered by sources that seem equally reliable, flag the clash and request a ruling.**

See also [Verifying accents and spellings](/home/f/french-words-and-accents#verifying) at the bottom of this page for guidance on breaking stories and tips on sources.

**Geographical names in Canada**
**For the names of domestic cities, towns, villages, lakes, rivers, etc., we generally follow the official spellings adopted by the [Canadian Geographical Names Board of Canada](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww4.rncan.gc.ca%2Fsearch-place-names%2Fsearch%3Flang%3Den&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2lOY1kZcpa3sVZHHX8XWOf)**. In addition to adding correct accents, this means **we embrace the common practice of using hyphens instead of periods or spaces** in French place names featuring two or more words:

> Gaspé
>
> Saint-Jérôme
>
> Sept-Îles (**not** Seven Islands)
>
> Trois-Rivières (**not** Three Rivers)


**French accents are dropped if English forms have been established through convention.** The Geographical Names Board lists a few dozen such "[pan-Canadian](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nrcan.gc.ca%2Fearth-sciences%2Fgeography%2Fplace-names%2Feducation-resources%2F9232&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2jxvoz_g6XyIDVEW3RhXvw)" entries (i.e., communities with two different and equally acceptable English and French spellings). In these rare cases, we always use the English form:

> Lake Champlain (**not** "Lac Champlain")
>
> Montreal (**not** Montréal)
>
> Quebec (**not** Québec)
>
> Quebec City (the uppercase "C" is akin to New York City)
>
> Saguenay River (**not** Rivière Saguenay)
>
> St. Lawrence River (**not** "Fleuve Saint-Laurent")


**Exceptions are made only when such pan-Canadian geographical names are part of a French proper noun** (e.g., Le Journal de Montréal and Hydro-Québec).

**Always use English names of buildings, parks, bridges, etc., if these have been established** (e.g., the Jacques Cartier Bridge rather than "le pont Jacques-Cartier" or the "Jacques-Cartier Bridge"). If you're not sure an official English form exists, check a relevant, reliable source (in this case, the Federal Bridge Corporation's website).


**A special note about hyphens**
**Even in the case of geographical names with two or more words, no hyphen is required if the only other word is a definite article** (such as "La"). Sometimes this article is fused to the main word:

> La Morandière (a Quebec village)
>
> L'Épiphanie (a Quebec city)


**Hyphens are not usually included in the names of geographical features, such as lakes, rivers or mountains:**

> Île Lamèque (a New Brunswick Island)
>
> Lac à la Truite (a Quebec lake)


**But hyphens are often included when the names of geographical features** (such as lakes, rivers or mountains) **are part of a community's name:**

> Baie-Comeau (a Quebec city)
>
> Île-à-la-Crosse (a Saskatchewan village)
>
> Îles-de-la-Madeleine a.k.a. [Magdalen Islands](/home/m#Magdalen_Islands) (Quebec islands that are also municipalities)
>
> Lac-à-la-Tortue (a Quebec community)
>
> Rivière-Verte (a New Brunswick village)


**The federal government's database listed above provides correct spellings, including the proper use of hyphens and accents**. But taking the time to become familiar with the above rules will help you spot typos in stories.

Keep in mind that there can be subtle differences in punctuation and spelling of similar words in different parts of the country. For instance, see [St., Saint, St-, Sainte, Ste-](/home/s/st-saint-ste) for caveats about various forms of "Saint" and "Sainte" found inside and outside of Quebec (e.g., Sault Ste. Marie, Ont. versus Saint-Antoine, N.B.). 


**Geographical names abroad**
**For communities outside Canada, we follow the National Geographic Atlas of the World** (e.g., Nîmes, France) **unless English forms have been established through convention** (e.g., Haiti not Haïti, Munich not München, and Ivory Coast instead of "Côte d'Ivoire"). Our preferred international atlas, also used by Canadian Press, generally includes the established English forms in parentheses.

In the case of international French place names, the same pattern of accents and hyphens are common around the globe. Some foreign words have different slightly different spellings (Élysée versus Élysées) depending on context. For instance, the French president's official residence is the Élysée Palace, which is not far from the Champs-Élysées in Paris.

**Street names and addresses**
**Quebec street names frequently require hyphens. Our spellings of principal words should reflect what's on the sign** (including any accents), **although we should use standard English forms** (capitalization and location) **of generic labels** (Street, Boulevard, etc.) to help our readers since these are not technically considered part of the official name:

> Côte-des-Neiges Road (**not** "chemin de la Côte-des-Neiges")
>
> De Maisonneuve Boulevard (**not** "boulevard de Maisonneuve")
>
> Rivière-des-Prairies Boulevard (**not** "boul. Rivière-des-Prairies")
>
> Ste-Catherine Street (**not** "rue Sainte-Catherine")
>
> St-Denis Street (**not** "St. Denis Street" or "rue Saint-Denis")
>
> 1400 René-Lévesque Blvd. E. (**not** "1400, boul. René-Lévesque Est")


Consult a good street map if you're unsure of a specific spelling. See [addresses](/home/a/addresses) for general guidelines on when to abbreviate words such as "Boulevard" and "East."

**Names of organizations**
**In general, we prefer the conventional English versions of organizations' names** (e.g., Doctors without Borders rather than Médecins Sans Frontières) **unless these are not well-established or if acceptable translations are impossible.**

**When a body's French name is used, English descriptions should be provided** in a subordinate clause or in the next sentence — **except in cases when the meaning is already widely understood** or can be readily inferred.

> Bloc Québécois (**no** English translation or description required)
>
> _Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec_ (the province's public pension fund)
>
> _Centrale des syndicats du Québec_ (the province's largest teachers union)
>
> Hydro-Québec (**no** English translation or description required)
>
> Montreal Transit Corp. (**not** _Société de transport de Montréal_)
>
> Parti Québécois (**no** English translation or description required)
>
> Quebec Labour Federation 

> > (**not** _Fédération des travailleurs et travailleuses du Québec_)

> Quebec Liquor Corp. (**not** _Société des alcools du Québec_)
>
> Sûreté du Québec (Quebec provincial police)


**Use the English names of provincial government departments, courts and most other official bodies:**

Quebec Court of Appeal (**not** la Cour d'appel du Québec)
Quebec's Department of Justice (**not** _ministère de la Justice_)
Quebec National Assembly (**not** _Assemblée nationale du Québec_)

**Be aware that there are sometimes subtle but important differences in the entrenched English forms of French proper nouns** (e.g., a word such as "association" dropped). In such cases, **prefer the English usage most common in that province:**

> Quebec Bar (**not** the Barreau du Québec and **not** the Quebec Bar Association)


**Organizations sometimes include accents in only the French version of their names, especially when these nouns feature what are known as "[pan-Canadian](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nrcan.gc.ca%2Fearth-sciences%2Fgeography%2Fplace-names%2Feducation-resources%2F9232&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2jxvoz_g6XyIDVEW3RhXvw)" words** (e.g., Montreal/Montréal or Quebec/Québec). For instance, Québecor has an accent in French but has been known for decades in English as Quebecor Inc. or simply Quebecor. **No accent is required in CBC News stories in these cases** (i.e., write Quebecor). This is akin to Radio-Canada adding accents to established French versions of nouns for its audience (e.g., Bell Média and Cogeco Câble instead of Bell Media or Cogeco Cable).

See [Capitalization and italics](/home/f/french-words-and-accents#capitalization) below for guidelines governing nouns such as Action Démocratique du Québec (ADQ) and Québec Solidaire (QS), as well as [Use English conventions in certain translations of names](/home/f/french-words-and-accents#englishconventions) for related guidelines and examples, such as chief electoral officer instead of directeur général des élections.


**Retain established or familiar English names**
While CBC News style generally follows a specific organization's official preference, we also tend to **lean toward an English version of a name if this has become entrenched through long use or is considered the most familiar or comprehensible to our national audience:**

> Les Grands Ballets Canadiens (adding "de Montréal" is unnecessary)

> > (second reference: Les Grands; the ballet company)

> the Montreal Symphony Orchestra (MSO)

> > (second reference options: MSO; the symphony; the orchestra)

> the Opéra de Montréal

> > (second reference: the opera company)

> the Royal 22nd Regiment (**not** the "Royal 22e Régiment")

> > (second reference: the 22nd; the regiment; the Van Doos)

> University of Quebec in Montreal
>
> University of Moncton


Sometimes confusion arises when previously used English names are largely abandoned by the group in question. The Canadian Encyclopedia of Canada, for instance, points out that the _Orchestre symphonique de Montréal_ (OSM) adopted a bilingual name in 1953, but then officially dropped the English version in 1979.

But the name "Montreal Symphony Orchestra" (MSO) continues to be widely used, including on many CBC Radio music programs. The English form of the name is also still frequently found in the Montreal Gazette, The Canadian Press and at the bottom of the orchestra's own website. It is the preference of CBC News as well.

The same is true of the University of Montreal. Although the school's documentation features the "Université de Montréal" almost exclusively, including throughout its English website, this French version is uncommon outside of Quebec.

Since CBCNews.ca is the online division of the corporation's main English news service, **it's often instructive to look at how certain French nouns are handled on air when deciding whether to prefer the English form on the web.** For example, we write Quebec's "Royal 22nd Regiment" rather than "Royal 22e Régiment" since that is how this infantry unit is best known in English Canada. CBC Radio and TV broadcasters do not say "Royal 22e Régiment" in French in the middle of English newscasts. They do, however, use the acceptable nickname "the Van Doos" (an English version of the French word for 22nd, _vingt-deuxième_). We also use Van Doos in headlines and second reference. (See [military forces](/home/m/military-forces) for related guidelines on regiment and battalion names.)

**An abridged version of a French name is occasionally acceptable and preferable in first reference. For example, we can write Montreal's Orchestre Métropolitain** (instead of the Orchestre Métropolitain du Grand Montréal), with either the Orchestre Métropolitain or "the orchestra" used in subsequent references. Two criteria should be considered in these cases: Is a shortened French name endorsed (i.e., sometimes used) by the organization itself? Does posting the shortened version on CBC.ca help our readers?

**Capitalization and italics (proper nouns)**
**There are several different approaches to capitalization in French.** Under one system, only the first letter of an organization's name is capitalized, along with any proper nouns. For example, _la Cour suprême du Canada_ for the Supreme Court of Canada. **When considered part of the formal name, the "L" in the first definite article** (Le, La, L' or Les) **is also uppercase**. Under a more traditional and complex system, the first regular noun after the article also takes an initial capital letter, along with any intervening adjectives.

**In general, follow the capitalization preference of individual organizations**. This is the simplest approach for our English journalists because it does not require thorough knowledge of, and judgments calls about, various parts of French speech.

**If the capitalization preference of the French name is close to standard English** (with uppercase letters clearly flagging the noun), **italics are not required. Otherwise, the entire name should be in italics to help our readers:**

> Chez Mes Amis (a charity that provides meals to seniors in Montreal)
>
> the _Confédération des syndicats nationaux_ (confederation of provincial unions)
>
> Cirque du Soleil (no description required)
>
> École Polytechnique (an engineering school in Montreal)
>
> _Union des producteurs agricoles_ (the farmers union in Quebec)


See the note on [Le, La](/home/f/french-words-and-accents#articles) below for more examples.

**Sometimes, imposing English capitalization on certain common French nouns is much better for our readers than using italics and lowercase lettering** — especially when this approach has become conventional over time. The names of Quebec political parties are an obvious example. Although _Parti québécois_ is the official French version, Parti Québécois has become widely accepted in the English media. So our style is:

> Action Démocratique du Québec — **not** _Action démocratique du Québec_

> > (second reference options: ADQ or Action Démocratique)

> Bloc Québécois — **not** _Bloc québécois_

> > (second reference options: prefer the Bloc, but BQ is OK in headlines)

> Coalition Avenir Québec — **not** _Coalition avenir Québec_ 

> > (second reference: CAQ)

> Parti Québécois — **not** _Parti québécois_

> > (second reference: PQ)

> Québec Solidaire — **not** _Québec solidaire_

> > (second reference: QS) 

See [Party versus party](/home/p/party) for related guidelines, such as preferring the possessive term PQ's over the awkward but correct Parti Québécois's. Another example is Montreal's transit system, which is often written as "METRO" on local subway signs or as "metro" to match the French capitalization, _métro_. By contrast, CBC News adds an initial cap to make scanning easier for our audience. This approach also matches our overall style for transit systems (e.g., the Washington Metro, the London Underground).

> Montreal Metro (**not** _métro or chemin de fer métropolitain_ or "metro")

> > (second reference: Metro)


In recent years, initial uppercase letters have become more common in French (just as there has been a rise in unorthodox use of lowercase lettering in English, such as eBay and iPod). The capital "S" in Soleil above (in both the French and English versions of this performing troupe's name) is one example.

This has led to some notable differences in preferences:

> the Alliance Française (considered a global leader in French instruction)
>
> _Office québécois de la langue française_ (office in charge of Quebec's language law)


The former non-profit network's decision to adopt an uppercase "F" in its name clashes with decades of teaching. But since this approach to capitalization helps our English readers spot the full name immediately, we don't bother using italics.

**Instead of judging which organization is right, we simply follow individual preferences within reason** (i.e., just as in English, we do not use all uppercase or all lowercase letters simply because some group decides it's fashionable). See [quirky capitalization](/home/q/quirky-capitalization) for more details on English names versus logos, such as Kazaa instead of "KaZaA" and CBC.ca instead of "cbc.ca." 

**A special note about Le, La, etc.**

**Use the English definite article** ("the") **rather than any French equivalent** (_l', le, la, les_) **unless the French article is part of a formal title** (e.g., book, film, TV program, poem), **or is officially part of the name of a building, business, etc.** (e.g., on a hotel or restaurant sign, on a newspaper masthead). **Include italics when French rather than English capitalization is used.** This helps readers who may otherwise be jarred by the lack of capital letters:

> L'Actualité (a magazine)
>
> L'Auberge du Grand Lac (a hotel)
>
> _la belle province_ (nickname for Quebec)
>
> _la Francophonie_ (acceptable in first reference to _Organisation internationale de la Francophonie_; the group's full name is not required)
>
> La Presse
>
> _Le guide du rédacteur_ (a book)
>
> Le Journal de Montréal
>
> Les Grands Ballets Canadiens
>
> _Le Téléjournal_
>
> Les Terrasses de la Chaudière (a government complex)
>
> the Bloc Québécois
>
> the _Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec_
>
> the Cirque du Soleil
>
> the _Confédération des syndicats nationaux_
>
> the _Office québécois de la langue française_
>
> the Parti Québécois


**General CBC News style governing the use of [italics](/handy-links/punctuation/italics) in the titles of films, television or radio programs, works of art, etc., also apply.** This means that if English text is italicized according to our guidelines, the French equivalent should be as well, regardless of capitalization (e.g., _Quirks & Quarks_ and _Découverte_). We apply English capitalization to Radio-Canada's flagship news and current affairs programs (e.g., _Le Téléjournal_ and _Le Point_ instead of "_Le téléjournal_" and "_Le point_") because of convention. But equally brief program names that don't begin with a French article (e.g., _Zone libre_) retain their original lowercase lettering.

**Check for official or individual preferences.** We use the "Cirque du Soleil" and "Les Grands Ballets Canadiens," for instance, because these are the groups' preferences. The Canadian Press, on the other hand, has traditionally recommended the _Cirque du soleil_ and _les Grands ballets canadiens_.

**The convention of capitalizing the first letter of the article in French newspaper names** (e.g., Le Devoir) **does not apply to English publications** (e.g., the Toronto Star) on CBC.ca. See also general guidelines on [**The versus the**](/home/t/the-versus-the) for English style points (e.g., the Globe and Mail but The National).

**If the French article is lowercase in a title or name, do not use a capital "L"** (e.g. "_La Francophonie_" instead of the correct "_la Francophonie_") **except at the start of sentences.**

**Avoid writing "the _la_" or "the _le_," etc., which is redundant.

Keep in mind that articles are sometimes fused to other words in a name, so always check to make sure a spelling is correct:**

Lac de la Trappe (a lake in Quebec)
Lac Latrape (another lake in Quebec)
Rivière Lafleur (a river in Quebec)
John le Carré (author)
Roméo LeBlanc (former governor general)

See also [particles](/home/p/particles-de-du-van-von) for tips on whether to retain words such as da, de, du, la, etc., in names in second reference (e.g., Charles de Gaulle become "de Gaulle" but Dominique de Villepin becomes "Villepin").


**Abbreviations**

**Widely known abbreviations do not need to be spelled out. Since they feature capital letters, italics are not required:**

-   FLQ (OK in first reference; no need to write the _Front de libération du Québec_)
-   CROP (identify as "a Quebec-based polling firm," **not** the _Centre de recherches sur l'opinion publique_)
-   RDI (identify as the French all-news television service of the CBC, **not** _Réseau de l'information_)

**Abbreviations uncommon outside Quebec should be avoided in national stories whenever possible. But when they're used, provide a description rather than merely spelling out** the original French words:

-   CEGEP ("a Quebec postsecondary education program" for high school graduates preparing for university or who are studying various vocational trades, not _Collège
    d'enseignement général et professionnel_ — which a recent Canadian Press Stylebook wrongly spelled as "_professionel_").
-   CLSC ("a community health centre," not the _Centre local de services communautaires_)

Some French abbreviations that can be pronounced as words feature a blend of upper and lowercase characters, along the lines of the generic English acronyms "radar" and "scuba" (which originally stood for "radio detection and ranging" and "self-contained underwater breathing apparatus"). Depending on how theses letters are pronounced, accents may be added by some French writers and editors. Unless such abbreviations (known as _sigles lexicalisés_) are well-established through convention, use capital letters and no accents to flag proper nouns (e.g., our style is "CEGEP" rather than "_Cégep_" or "_cégep_").

**As with English abbreviations, periods are not generally used unless the French letters represent geographical locations.** Both languages' rules can be complex when dealing with, say, [university degrees](/home/d/degrees) that include uppercase and lowercase letters, such as PhD versus B.Ed. For CBC News purposes, however, **the main difference worth noting here is the presence of hyphens in French geographical abbreviations:**


**English**
U.S. (for United States)
P.E.I. (for Prince Edward Island)
RCMP (for Royal Canadian Mounted Police)


**French**
É.-U. (for États-Unis)
Î.-P.-É. (for Île-du-Prince-Édouard)
GRC (for _Gendarmerie royale du Canada_)

We almost invariably report geographical locations in English. But in rare cases when the original French abbreviation appears (e.g., directly transcribed quotes or excerpts from written texts), follow the above guidelines.

For specific guidelines on how to handle political parties in first reference (BQ, ADQ, PQ, etc.), see [Capitalization and italics](/home/f/french-words-and-accents#capitalization) above.


**Translations (overview)**
**Do not bother translating a brief French phrase if its meaning will be obvious to most English-speaking Canadians:**

> "I believe in Canada," Chrétien said as he ended his final speech to the Liberal Party with his trademark rallying cry: "_Vive le Canada_!"


**Avoid publishing lengthy French text.** If you have two comparable quotes from Question Period, for instance, pick the English one. If the French quote is better, use an accurate English translation flagged as such.

**If you're not skilled at translating French and if you don't have a good understanding of acceptable English versions of French idioms, do not guess. Check a reliable source or leave this information out of the story** until an accurate and meaningful translation can be obtained.

**Don't over-emphasize translation.** It's unnecessary to remind readers that someone spoke in French, as long as this is established once, early on, for readers:

> "I didn't ask any questions," Brault testified in French. "It was never mentioned to me that there would be IOUs attached to these contracts."


**Even in cases when several different French speakers are quoted, a single reference to all the material being translated is sufficient.** For instance, if readers are told that a court case was heard in French or that a political leaders' debate was held in French, it's unnecessary to mention this fact again.

But just because comments appear on, say, Radio-Canada doesn't mean the people interviewed spoke in French, particularly if their first language is English. So additional clarification is needed:

> "I think I will never be truly free, because there are different kinds of prisons. There are concrete prisons, and there are internal prisons," Homolka told Radio-Canada, the CBC's French language service.
>
> "I think I will always be in an internal prison," she added. The exclusive interview was conducted entirely in French only hours after Homolka finished serving her 12-year sentence for manslaughter.


**It's generally unnecessary to provide the source of brief translations in news stories** unless there's some concern that the interpretation could be challenged (e.g., in coverage of a legal dispute over contract language). **But when publishing lengthy excerpts from books, magazines, radio or television interviews, etc., identify the source of the English wording whenever possible** (e.g., "The translation was provided by CBC Montreal"). In the case of sizable projects (e.g., transcribing and translating the entire 13-minute Karla Homolka interview cited above), individual credit can be given if the translators are known to us if they request their names be used.

**English punctuation**
**Always use English punctuation, even if large chunks of French text from a document are posted verbatim on CBCNews.ca.**

For instance, **type inverted commas** (_"D'après moi, le bilinguisme est irréversible au Canada"_) **rather than guillemets or chevrons** (_«D'après moi, le bilinguisme est irréversible au Canada»_) around direct quotes, **and use periods rather than commas in numerical references** (3.75% not "3,75 %").

**The same rule applies to people's names.** The spelled-out form should include accents and hyphens when applicable (e.g., Marie-Josée Bédard and Félix-Adrien Gauthier), because these are standard in both languages. But **the abbreviated form should use English punctuation** (i.e., periods only), as in Quebec Justice M.J. Bédard and the Quebec ferry F.A. Gauthier, **rather than French punctuation** (i.e., hyphens with periods), as in "M.-J. Bédard" or "F.-A. Gauthier").

The only exception is when an entire original document (e.g., presented as a PDF) is posted to allow our bilingual readers to compare the wording with an English translation. In these rare cases, the original French (including punctuation) will obviously be left intact.

**Transcribed French should be in italics. Accurate translations falling within direct quotes should be in square, not curved, brackets** so these words are not misread as a speaker's parenthetical comments in another language. **Unless including the original French helps the story, prefer an accurate English translation to maintain smoother-flowing copy:**


**Correct but awkward**

> "It's true in Ontario, et _c'est la même chose au Québec_" \[and it's the same thing in Quebec\]," the prime minister said.

**Shorter and preferable**

> "It's true in Ontario," the prime minister said. "And it's the same thing in Quebec," he quickly added in French.


**Always use proper capitalization and accents from a reliable source when posting the original French.** Otherwise, stick to an accurate English translation or paraphrase, identified as such.

**Other types of translations, such as book or movie titles, can be in regular brackets.** Newspapers, news programs, etc., do not require translations:


> _Le cœur de la baleine bleue_ (_The Heart of the Blue Whale_)
>
> Le Devoir (newspaper title; **no** italics; do **not** translate)
>
> _L'Éclusier_ (_Lock-keeper_)
>
> _Zone libre_ (do **not** translate as "_Free Zone_"; instead, simply identify it as a documentary program on Radio-Canada, the CBC's French language service)


But see [Titles](/home/f/french-words-and-accents#titles) and [French idioms](/home/f/french-words-and-accents#idioms) below for caveats about translating even brief phrases, including the wording found in book and film titles.


**Titles**

**Use the English versions of titles (films, books, etc.) alone if they're well-known** (e.g., _The Little Prince_, not _Le petit prince_). **Use the French versions of titles alone, with no translation, if this is how the works are known in English.** In these cases, use English capitalization if the initial uppercase lettering on principal words has been established by convention (e.g., _La Bohème_ not _La bohème_).

**Otherwise, use the original French title first with an English translation or description in parentheses.** Keep in mind that French and English titles frequently feature different wording for artistic or cultural reasons:

> _Bonheur d'occasion_ ("second-hand happiness" in French, but published in English as _The Tin Flute_)
>
> _La détresse et l'enchantement_ (_Enchantment and Sorrow_)
>
> _La vie en rose_ (**no** English translation necessary)
>
> _Les feuilles mortes_ ("dead leaves" in French, but the song was recorded in English as _Autumn Leaves_)
>
> _Les Misérables_ (**no** English translation necessary; use English capitalization)
>
> _Jesus of Montreal_ (English title sufficient; **not** _Jésus de Montréal_)
>
> _Mon oncle Antoine_ (_My Uncle Antoine_)
>
> _Sur le seuil_ ("on the threshold" in French, but called _Evil Words_ in English)
>
> _The Decline of the American Empire_ (English title sufficient; **not** _Le déclin de l'empire américain_)


**Check for official translations when dealing with even seemingly straightforward wording.** For instance, _La moitié gauche du frigo_ (which literally means _The Left Half of the Fridge_) was called "_The Left Side of the Fridge_" by the New York Times and "_The Left Half of the Fridge_" by Playback magazine. But the Canadian Film Encyclopedia lists the English title of this 2000 movie by Philippe Falardeau as "_The Left-Hand Side of the Fridge,_" which is CBC News style. And the 1979 novel _Le sourd dans la ville_ is officially translated as _Deaf to the City_ rather than as "the deaf person in the city."

**Provide context to translations if it enhances the story.** Although the novel _Un habit de lumière_ was published in English with a literally translated title (_A Suit of Light_), for instance, many of our readers won't know that this French phrase actually means a bullfighter's costume unless we supply the background.

And instead of merely noting that the biography _Jacques Demers en toutes lettres_ roughly translates as _Jacques Demers From A to Z_ we should make it clear that the title reflects the book's startling revelation that the former NHL coach spent his career hiding his inability to read or write. (Note: When the book was launched in Quebec in November 2005, the publisher was still debating whether to issue an English version. In the meantime, other unofficial translations of the title offered by English media included "Jacques Demers All Spelled Out.")

So in a feature on, say, René Lévesque, it would be fine to briefly mention his involvement in a broadcast programs such as Point de mire with no translation in brackets. (The well-known current affairs program _Point de mire_, which roughly means "focus of attention," would be treated like a newspaper name and retain its French wording.) But when mentioning Lévesque's biography, _Attendez que je me rappelle_ ("Wait while I recall that"), we would better serve our readers by adding some context — reporting that the book was published in English as _Memoirs_ while also pointing out the faint echo of Quebec's official motto, _Je me souviens_ ("I remember"), in the original title.

**French idioms**
**Translations of sentence fragments are unnecessary if the short French expression is relatively common and the meaning is already clear because of context.** For instance, if someone refers to a _cause célèbre_ in a clip you're transcribing from a TV interview, there's no point adding the literal meaning ("famous cause") in brackets. Readers can always consult an English dictionary, just as they might look up a polysyllabic word such as "superfluous" if it's not part of their vocabulary.

**Literal translations are frequently insufficient, even for sentence fragments.** Although bon means "good" and _mot_ means "word," when placed next to each other they convey the meaning "witty remark." The expression is so common in English, of course, that italics are not required, let alone a definition. But "bon mot" is an example of how a literal translation ("good word") would fail to do its job.

**For more obscure idioms** (e.g., _trouver chaussure à son pied_), **a better option is to describe the meaning of the original French in an English paraphrase** instead of bothering with a literal translation ("to find a shoe that fits"):

> Near the end of his life the novelist was very lonely, she said. "He eventually gave up the search for _chaussure à son pied_," a French expression that means finding a suitable match. "He resigned himself to the companionship of whisky and books."


Another example would be the old Quebec TV program _Entre chien et loup_. Our readers learn little if we simply translate it as "between dog and wolf" without telling them that the expression means "at twilight" (when it's hard to tell between one thing and another). But as with many expressions, even this seemingly straightforward translation might be misleading if _entre chien et loup_ is being used in a different context (e.g., it could also suggest a measure of fear in the uncertainty between the comfortable and the potentially dangerous unknown).

**Use English conventions in certain translations of names**
Problems can arise even when literal translations are applied to organizations' names. **If similar groups or government agencies are common in other provinces, prefer English translations that follow established patterns used across Canada:**

-   Quebec College of Physicians

    -   not _Ordre des médecins du Québec_

    -   not "the Order of Quebec Doctors"
-   Quebec health insurance

    -   not _d'assurance maladie du Québec_

    -   not "Quebec sickness insurance"

See also [Quebec Bar](/home/f/french-words-and-accents#bar) rather than "Quebec Bar Association" above for related guidelines

This applies to a wide range of other French terms as well, such as:

> chief electoral officer

> > **not** _directeur général des élections_
>
> > **not** "director of the election"

> manslaughter

> > **not** _homicide involontaire_
>
> > **not** "involuntary homicide"

> president and CEO

> > **not** _président-directeur général_
>
> > **not** "president and director general"


**Use common sense when translating.** While _président-directeur général_ makes sense as "president and CEO" of a company, _directeur général_ doesn't work well as "CEO" if applied to, say, the head of a union. A title such as "executive director" is better, instead.

**And watch out for words in French that look like their English counterpart but actually have different meanings**, such as: _déception_ (disappointment), _exploiter_ (operate), _formation_ (training, in certain contexts) and _nomination_ (appointment).


**Verifying spellings and accents**

**Our primary reference book for commonly used French words in English is the [Canadian Oxford Dictionary](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.oxfordreference.com%2Fviews%2FBOOK_SEARCH.html%3Fbook%3Dt150%26subject%3Ds7&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2OKFN4tVZvBoLEWW60f-h9)** — e.g., chargé d'affaires (no italics) but _coup d'état_ (italics, and _d'é_ **not** _d'É_), resumé not résumé, and protege not protégé.

**In the case of proper nouns** (the names of people, place, organizations, etc.), **do not guess simply to meet a deadline**.
**Add accents to French words only if these are known to be accurate.** Just as we're expected to take the trouble to check an English spelling (Cariboo Mountains in B.C. versus Caribou Mountains in Alberta), we must make the effort to use accents consistently and accurately.

When handling breaking news, **post urgent stories without accents (or without the French names in question, if these are unessential to the story)**. But be sure to add the correct accents as soon as reasonably possible.

**Good sources for checking the spellings of, and accents in, French names include:**

-   Government websites (e.g., the [**Parliament of Canada**](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.parl.ca%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2aJTuNcT7N3EfV49wDqBOn) lists the names of all MPs and Senators, past and present, and the [**Quebec National Assembly**](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.assnat.qc.ca%2Fen%2Findex.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0JIyGCbxE6vN3SbKzxsY5_) lists all its members).
-   The [**Geographical Names Board of Canada**](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww4.rncan.gc.ca%2Fsearch-place-names%2Fsearch%3Flang%3Den&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2lOY1kZcpa3sVZHHX8XWOf) (for the proper spellings of all domestic cities, towns, villages, mountains, lakes, rivers and so forth).
-   The online editions of [**Canadian Dictionary of Biography**](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.biographi.ca%2FEN%2Findex.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3vgBVYGQt8BgRdT3vnOjH9) (through Library and Archives Canada), the [**Canadian Encyclopedia**](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca%2Fen%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0thqn6p5HO2-pGPiYc00Lo) (available free through the Historica Foundation) as well as the [**Oxford Companion to Canadian History**](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.oxfordreference.com%2Fviews%2FBOOK_SEARCH.html%3Fbook%3Dt148%26authstatuscode%3D200&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3Tfn_UCrXdC8B5kgba95u9) for double-checking the names of thousands of figures from the past.
-   The websites of relevant and reliable organizations (e.g., the [Canadian Film Encyclopedia](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Flegacy.tiff.net%2FCANADIANFILMENCYCLOPEDIA%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1WzkAZTy-TQ-NP6GBL7PLm) in a story about the Quebec film industry, or the alphabetical list of authors on [_L'Infocentre littéraire des écrivains québécois_](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.litterature.org%2Frecherche%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0JzH0TGW5LX1ILFmFb4O6E) website in a story about Quebec writers).
-   Radio-Canada's French website, [**Radio-Canada.ca**](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fici.radio-canada.ca%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1aQ1dcl6dKxWg1P5ah-IJk). Its editors and newsroom linguist take special care to get spellings and French accents correct.
-   **Various French newspapers and magazines in Quebec.** The [CBC Reference Library](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fio.cbcrc.ca%2F%23%2Fresources%2Fcbc-s-libraries-and-archives-1.3180491&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2h7baoB3i0M-TZQqjoD2HM) in Toronto has access to a commercial database called Eureka. There's a small fee for every request, so you'll need your supervisor's permission (and a budget number) to use this service. CBC News staff can also check the websites of [Le Devoir](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ledevoir.com%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1YzMe8eZrsjWAYowdKeAcA) and [La Presse](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.lapresse.com%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2MHAGepDAtVfB4ESDkfvzI), although the amount of free content is substantially less than what's available through Eureka. If you go this route, Radio-Canada.ca journalists suggest trying Le Devoir first. For international names, [Le Monde](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.lemonde.fr%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2Y4UFRK1c5TMVOpjve0dMF) (in France) is recommended.


In the case of unknown or low-profile people featured in CBC Radio or CBC-TV reports, **another option is to contact broadcast journalists working on these stories** to see if they know the correct spellings, including accents. **But do not rely solely on radio or television scripts, which are not intended for publication.
**
As mentioned in the section on [people's names](/home/f/french-words-and-accents#names) above, **when two different spellings are offered by sources that seem equally reliable, flag the clash and request a ruling.**

The best source, of course, is the actual person featured in a story. When CBC News employees interview anyone, correct spellings of names should be verified at this stage.

See also [foreign words](/home/f/foreign-words) (El Niño, but Mexico not "México"), as well as [transliterations](/home/t/transliterations) (Mao Zedong not "Mao Tse-tung").

### ful versus fuls

**\-ful and -fuls**

If you write about **more than one handful, cupful, spoonful**, etc. **put the “s” at the end.**

_Three **spoonfuls** of lemon juice_ (not spoonsful or spoons full).

_Two **cupfuls** of flour_ (not cupsful or cups full).

_A few **handfuls** of popcorn_ (not handsful or hands full).

**But** _“I have my **hands full** at the moment.”_

Replacing perfectly acceptable words like “tablespoonfuls” with “tablespoons full” can be a recipe for disaster. Grammarian Theodore Bernstein cites the following example:

(WRONG) _“Now throw in two tablespoons full of chopped parsley and cook 10 minutes more. The quail ought to be tender by then.”_

As Bernstein quips, “Never mind the quail; how are we ever going to get those tablespoons tender?”

### fundamentalist extremist

**Fundamentalist, extremist, militant, rebel, etc.**


**Avoid overly broad brush strokes in stories involving _militant fundamentalism_.** While it may be relevant to point out that an Islamic extremist is behind an attack, or that a Christian extremist is advocating a violent response to a bombing, we should **never suggest that militants represent the teachings or beliefs of an entire faith** (i.e., that all followers of [Islam](/home/i/islam), Christianity, Judaism, etc., advocate violence). We should also **never imply that someone who is a fundamentalist or a separatist is automatically a _militant_.**

**While it's generally best to [prefer details over labels](/home/f/fundamentalist-extremist#details), here are some guidelines on potentially controversial words** that sometimes appear in news stories:











**Anarchist**
Chaos and anarchy are sometimes confused. Chaos means utter disorder. Anarchy means a type of societal order without government. **An anarchist promotes living without government. While anarchy, itself, does not mean militancy, the term has this strong connotation** — despite the writings and teachings of peaceful anarchists. Attacks against a government should not automatically be considered acts of anarchy. The motivation of the assailants is relevant. If some people want to overthrow the government with their own regime, for instance, they are rebels, militants, etc., not anarchists.


**Extremist**
In a religious context, the word **extremist suggests a zealot or fanatic engaged in some type of "holy war."** This person is not merely an advocate of a strict interpretation of a doctrine. The individual is also prepared to go to extreme measures (including violence) in a campaign to promote this religious belief. Historically, the Crusades are an example of extreme Christian fundamentalism. Since extremists are not limited to a particular faith, it is important in stories to provide as much background as possible to put stories in context (e.g., a Christian extremist or an Islamic extremist). The term extreme fundamentalist is acceptable and generally suggests a [militant](/home/f/fundamentalist-extremist#militant).


**Fundamentalist**
Be cautious when using the word fundamentalist to describe religious beliefs. The word simply describes a person **who subscribes to** (and generally, but not always, advocates) **what is perceived to be the literal truth of a given religion's holy writings. Fundamentalism alone does not mean militancy.** Millions of law-abiding citizens of many different faiths in all corners of the globe fall into the category of fundamentalists. Far fewer are [extreme fundamentalists](/home/f/fundamentalist-extremist#extremist) or [militant fundamentalists](/home/f/fundamentalist-extremist#militant).


**Guerrilla versus non-combatant**
Government forces sometimes clash with the country's own citizens. **Unarmed civilians should be described as such**. Another term is **non-combatant**. By contrast, **armed and organized citizens who attack the police or the military** are conventionally described as **rebels or guerrillas**. These are neutral terms to describe fighters waging a campaign against a given regime. They are generally trying to oust a leader, overthrow a government or break away from a country (in which case they are **armed separatists**).


**Insurgent**
See [rebel](/home/f/fundamentalist-extremist#rebel) below


**Islamist**
See [Islamicist versus Islamist](/home/i/islam#islamicist)


**Militant**
**Militants are prepared to use violence to carry out a campaign**, which may or may not be based in religion. While it's conventional and acceptable to use the words extremist and militant synonymously to describe violent [fundamentalists](/home/f/fundamentalist-extremist#fundamentalist), it's important to remember that **militancy always involves force** while **extremism and fanaticism simply imply it**. The term "extreme militant" is redundant. A militant, by definition, is prepared to go to extreme lengths. The term **militant fundamentalist**, on the other hand, is acceptable when framing militancy in the context of fundamental religious beliefs.


**Radical**
**The terms radical and radicalism are rooted in fundamentalism.** They are synonyms for [extremist](/home/f/fundamentalist-extremist#extremist) and extremism (i.e., implying that individuals are prepared to go to extreme measures, including violence, to wage a particular campaign).


**Rebel**
**The word rebel is tied to rebellion.** It generally describes people who have taken up arms against a government in power, from isolated unrest to widespread civil war. Organized rebels are often called **anti-government forces, insurgents, opposition fighters**, etc. If they gain control over most of a country, **the term rebel is conventionally dropped once an interim or transitional government is established.** Since it's often difficult to gauge whether the tide of war has shifted in a given conflict, we rely heavily on CBC foreign correspondents for informed assessments whenever possible. (See also [guerrilla versus non-combatant](/home/f/fundamentalist-extremist#guerrilla))


**Separatist**
**The word accurately describes anyone who openly supports establishing an autonomous country or territory** (e.g., Chechen separatists, Kurdish separatists). But being a secessionist does not automatically mean backing militancy. **Avoid stating or implying that all separatists are advocates of violence. Use qualifying language** (e.g., extreme separatists, radical separatists, militant separatists) **to distinguish rebels from non-violent separatists.** Another option is to specify membership in a given group or movement (e.g., [Khalistani extremists)](/home/k#Khalistani), defining and/or explaining any comparatively obscure proper nouns as required.


**Prefer details over labels**
When reporting on violent attacks, **specific information is often more helpful to our audience than broad labels alone**, if details of particular allegations or confirmed actions are known. Words such as **bomber, gunman, sniper, etc.**, convey more information than, say, terms like extremist or militant repeated throughout a story.

See also [terrorist and terrorism](/home/t/terrorist-and-terrorism)
See also [Middle East glossary](/home/m/middle-east-glossary)

### funerals

**Funerals**

Funerals are solemn events. All relevant CBC journalistic standards and practice apply, including general principles about respecting individual privacy while reporting on matters of public interest.

**Prefer simple language** (e.g., **funeral director** or **undertaker** instead of mortician, and **bury** instead of inter). **To help keep the wording of stories accurate and consistent, here are brief reminders about a few terms** that have caused occasional confusion over the years:







[funeral](/home/f/funerals#general) (general)

[inter, interment](/home/f/funerals#interment) (never "internment")


[military funeral](/home/f/funerals#militaryfuneral) (gun carriage, firing party, etc.)
[national funeral](/home/f/funerals#nationalfuneral) (Quebec)




**book of condolence** — The entrenched term is singular (condolence) because the word is synonymous with sympathy in this context (e.g., a message of condolence, a letter of condolence, a book of condolence). It's parallel to, say, a book of prayer that contains many different prayers. While the alternative form "condolences" is sometimes used, prefer the original construction "book of condolence" for consistency. The plural is **books of condolence** (e.g., when messages are compiled in different locations).

**bury** — A common and acceptable verb to describe placing a body (or remains) in a final, enclosed resting place. Burials do not literally need to be underground (e.g., a burial at sea, a burial in a tomb). This expanded sense of the word, established over the centuries, is why **the Oxford English Dictionary lists "inter" as one definition of "bury."** Be aware that we get occasional audience complaints from people who do not embrace this usage, including in coverage of the 2021 funeral of Prince Philip. It's worth noting, however, that Windsor Castle, itself, uses the expression "[royal burials in the chapel](https://www.stgeorges-windsor.org/about-st-georges/royal-connection/royal-burials/royal-burials-chapel-location/)" going all the way back to Henry VIII half a millennium ago.

**casket** — Acceptable as a synonym for [coffin](/home/f/funerals#coffin). Usually made of wood. Can be highly ornate. Commonly used in the compounds open casket and closed casket (e.g., it was an **open-casket viewing**, it was a **closed-casket service**, they approached the **closed casket**).

**coffin** — A rectangular box in which a corpse is either buried or cremated. Usually made of wood. The word coffin is preferred by some writers and editors because it's considered more conversational than [casket](/home/f/funerals#casket). But the latter is very common in North America, especially in the compounds open casket and closed casket.

**cortège** — Generally prefer the simpler term **funeral procession** in English news reporting. But if you use cortège, include the accent (see [French words](/home/f/french-words-and-accents) in English journalism).

**die of** — Use "die of" not "die from" for specific illnesses or conditions (e.g., "She died of cancer" and "He died of hypothermia").

**flypast, flyby** (lowercase, no hyphens) — Either word is correct. If an aircraft is missing (or deliberately peels away) during the flypast, prefer **missing plane formation** or **missing member formation** over "missing man" formation. (See also [military funeral](/home/f/funerals#militaryfuneral) for related language)

**funeral** — May or may not be religious (e.g., specific ritual, readings from scripture). In North America, often conducted in a church, temple or chapel. Can be **public** or **private**. The **body or ashes are usually present**. The casket may be open or closed, depending on the family's wishes. In many cases, a **private viewing** or **visitation** may have been held ahead of time at a different location. Even in the case of public funerals, the actual **burial service** (also called a **graveside service**) afterward may be restricted to immediate family and friends. (See also [memorial service](/home/f/funerals#memorialservice), [military funeral](/home/f/funerals#militaryfuneral) and [state funeral](/home/f/funerals#statefuneral))

**half-mast** — The preferred Canadian terminology for flags lowered to honour the dead. (See [half-mast versus half-staff](/home/h/half-mast))

**inter, interment** — Generally prefer the simpler words [**bury** and **burial**](#bury). At all costs, avoid using the completely different word "internment" (which means imprisonment or forcible confinement).

**lie in state** — Normally associated with state funerals. The remains of the deceased are placed on view to allow large numbers of people to pay their final respects. Depending on protocol, there may be an honour guard. The casket is often inside a public building, such as the Centre Block of Parliament Hill. Present tense: "She **lies in state**." Present participle: "She is **lying in state**." Future: "He **will lie in state** until Friday." Past tense: "He **lay in state** until Friday." The past participle: "People who **have lain in state** include a number of former premiers and prime ministers." ALWAYS WRONG: "laying" and "laid" when referring to a dead body. (See also [lay versus lie](/home/l/lay-versus-lie)) The verbal phrase has no hyphens (e.g., "She will lie in state for four days"). But the noun and adjectival forms take punctuation (e.g., "The lying-in-state began on Thursday"). In Canada, a **lying-in-state vigil** often lasts several days. The exact duration varies. In rare cases, the expression "permanently lie in state" is used in some countries to describe government leaders whose embalmed bodies are displayed in special shrines, museums, mausoleums, etc., year-round (e.g., Vladimir Lenin in Russia and Mao Zedong in China). **Be aware that some people differentiate between "lying in state"** (usually at a major government or "state" building) **and "lying in repose"** (at some other location). However, such distinctions are rarely made outside bureaucratic and diplomatic protocol circles now. Furthermore, it's become an acceptable convention in Canada to refer to high-profile figures, such as sports legends, "lying in state" before public ceremonies tied to special honours, such as what's called a [national funeral](#nationalfuneral) in Quebec.

**memorial service** — Usually held **without the body or ashes present** because the actual funeral was a private service or because the remains have already been buried. (See also [funeral](/home/f/funerals#general))

**military funeral** — In Canada, the Defence Department is in charge of military funeral protocol, including who is eligible. A **gun carriage** refers to a towed artillery weapon with the casket secured on top. The **bearer party** carries the casket. The **firing party** conducts any ceremonial discharge of weapons (volleys) at the graveside. Wreaths are **laid** or **placed**. Flags fly at [half-mast](/home/f/funerals#halfmast). Planes roaring overhead in a specific formation can be called either a [flypast](#flypast) or a flyby. Trumpets are sounded. Bugles are blown or sounded. Guard against calling the **[_Last Post_](/home/l/last-post)** something else (e.g., "_Taps_").

**national funeral** (Quebec) — Has **specific meaning in Quebec**. Similar to a [state funeral](/home/f/funerals#statefuneral) but with **less elaborate protocol**. Only former (or sitting) premiers and certain other former or sitting members of the National Assembly are granted full state funerals by the province. The term "national funeral" is used for virtually all other prominent citizens. Details can be found on the [government's funeral protocol page](https://www.quebec.ca/en/government/protocol/state-ceremonial-funerals). National funerals are not a type of state funeral in Quebec but, rather, are simply a different type of official funeral. Therefore, **it's inaccurate to call national funerals in Quebec "state funerals."** On the other hand, people outside the province may be confused by use of the term "national" without context. Therefore, if the detail is included in stories it's usually best to frame it as a provincial term with brief background or a some form of attribution (e.g., Montreal Canadiens legend Jean Béliveau was given "what's known as a national funeral in Quebec" or "what the province calls a national funeral" or even, simply, Jean Béliveau "was given a Quebec national funeral"). When public visitation honours are scheduled, it's an acceptable convention to use the expression "[lying in state](#lieinstate)" or "lying in repose" in such cases.

**peal versus peel** — Bells peal (are sounded), although the comparatively more sombre verb **toll** is usually recommended for funerals. Planes peel (break or roll away) from aerial formation during special [flypasts](/home/f/funerals#flypast).

**state funeral** — A special honour generally given to former prime ministers, premiers, presidents and other government leaders, as well as certain esteemed or popular citizens. Protocols vary from country to country. In Canada, state funerals can be offered by the federal government as well as by provincial and territorial governments. The Canadian Heritage Department has compiled answers to [**FAQs about states funerals in Canada**](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.canada.ca%2Fen%2Fservices%2Fculture%2Fevents-celebrations-commemorations%2Fcommemorations%2Fstate-funerals.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0KYLLGi8CZ0pYDcEk-JXyP). Be aware that the terms state funeral and national funeral are different in Quebec (See [national funeral](/home/f/funerals#nationalfuneral)).

**the late** — Acceptable term to describe someone who recently died (e.g., the late Jane Smith, son of the late Jane Smith). But avoid when referring to people who have been dead for years (e.g., writing "the late" Terry Fox is considered as odd and as unnecessary as writing "the late" John A. Macdonald or "the late" Charles Dickens). While misuse of "the late" is rarely an issue at funerals, it can surface in coverage of special memorials, such as the official reburying of the remains of a soldier many decades after a war. (See also [former versus the late](/home/l#thelate))

**widow** (wife of dead spouse), **widower** (husband of dead spouse) — Avoid redundancies (e.g., write "wife of the late" or "widow of" but not "widow of the late" since the word widow already implies that the spouse is dead).

See also [death reporting guidelines](/home/d/death-general-guidelines) for related tips (e.g., generally prefer direct language such as "died" over euphemisms such as "passed away")

**G** 

**[g-gg](/home/g#g)**

**[gh-gq](/home/g#gh)**

**[gr-gz](/home/g#gr)**

**g-gg**
**G7, G8, G20** (no hyphens); **Group of Seven, Group of Eight, Group of 20**; See [**G8 and G20**](/home/g/g8-g20-2010-summits) for a general overview, as well as for specific spellings and pronunciations of participants in the 2010 G8 and G20 summits in Canada. Although a comma is fine (**G8, G20 summits**), a slash is acceptable and easier to scan (G8/G20 summits), especially in graphics and web headlines. Do _not_ use a hyphen, which suggests a joint meeting (i.e., avoid "G8-G20"); **G7 countries, G8 leaders, G20 finance ministers**, etc.

**gadfly** (Someone who is irritating. It does not mean a social butterfly or gadabout.)

****gadget, gadgetry****

**Gadhafi, Moammar** (For consistency, use this entrenched [transliteration](/home/t/transliterations). Variations to avoid include an "h" in Moammar and Gadhafi with a "Q") He became the leader of Libya during a military coup in 1969. Use the spelling **Seif al-Islam Gadhafi** for his second son. A CBCNews.ca profile includes background on [other family members](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews%2Fworld%2Fstory%2F2011%2F02%2F22%2Ff-gadhafi-family.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1y9iDbRSxpyosR9LNKPbnH).

**gaffe** (mistake); **gaff** (type of spar in sailing; also a pole with hook for landing fish)

****gaiety****

**gale** (See [weather words](/home/w/weather-words#windspeed))

**Gallup poll**

**Gambia** (country in West Africa) Common and acceptable name for **the Republic of The Gambia** throughout stories. Generally prefer Gambia over "The Gambia," although adding "The" is not actually wrong. See [country names](/home/g/geography-cities) for general guidelines on shortening geographical proper nouns

**Game Boy** (video game)
**
GameCube** (one word)

**Games, the** (acceptable second reference for the Olympic Games, the Paralympic Games, etc.) See also [Olympics](/home/o/olympic-games)

When accurate, the term **Gazan is increasingly common and acceptable in periodic second reference** or in the occasional web headline where space is tight. The demonym is no different from countless other nouns that provide precise geographical detail — e.g., Albertan, Quebecer, Torontonian, Winnipegger, Maritimer, Floridian, Crimean, Egyptian, Qatari and Muscovite. Be aware that the word Gazan is used neutrally by various international organizations, including the United Nations and Amnesty International. **Avoid Gazan as a generic synonym for the much broader word Palestinian.** The former refers to people living in the Gaza Strip while the latter refers to people of Palestinian heritage who could be anywhere in the world, including the West Bank.

**gender** (in grammar: masculine, feminine and neuter; in society: male, female identity, which may or may not match one's biological classification) Some people object to using the word gender to describe male or female characteristics outside of the realm of grammar. The term is common and acceptable in certain descriptions of cultural and societal differences between men and women. Labels include the nouns **gender bias, gender gap, gender role**, and the adjectives **gender-neutral** and **gender-specific**. But when reporting on anatomical, biological or genetic differences, the term gender can be problematic. It ignores the reality of "gender identity." It can also sound prudishly euphemistic. More direct language, such as **sex** or the sexes, is often better. Be aware that using "gender" instead of "sex" can cause confusion and be challenged as inaccurate, in some contexts. (See [**gender vs. sex**](/home/t/transgender#sex-gender) for details.)

But include a space in **Giving Tuesday** when referring to the specific date in late November, to plural constructions (**Giving Tuesdays**), as well as to the global **Giving Tuesday movement**. **globalization** (to make global) The term, coined in the 1930s, originally referred to existing or influencing on a worldwide scale in the broadest sense. For more than half a century, globalization has more narrowly applied to business and investment. It normally implies an increase in free trade and open markets. Proponents say globalization boosts economic efficiency, growth and overall wealth. Critics say it erodes national identity and the ability of countries to protect certain industries, public policy goals, etc. Globalism commonly means the pursuit of economic or political goals based on international rather than on national or local values and principles. The terms **globalism** and **globalist** are conventionally synonymous with globalization because they emphasize business connections across borders and between continents. Words such as globalism, globalist, globalization and **anti-globalization** do not normally need to be defined in news stories as long as the context makes their meanings clear. The terms are generally considered neutral descriptions of political and economic ideology. But be aware that some fringe groups use the words globalism, globalist and globalization in xenophobic or racist ways. In rare cases when this applies, the pejorative meaning should be attributed and explained to give our audience the full picture.

**Global North, Global South** (initial caps) Shorthand for wealthy, developed countries, primarily in the **Northern Hemisphere**, and less wealthy, less developed countries, primarily in the **Southern Hemisphere**. The geographical divide is not exact, however, since Australia and New Zealand are included in the Global North. For consistency, avoid all lowercase ("global north") or mixed case ("global South"), which are both harder to scan and relatively difficult to justify, especially given the conventional capitalization of countless [nicknames](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/n/nicknames/ "Nicknames"), from the Deep South to the Red Planet. (See also [North, South, East, West](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/n/north-south-east-and-west/ "North south east and west") for related guidelines)

**grandfather clause, grandfathering** (AVOID) Coined in the 1890s to mean a "special legal exemption," this use of "grandfather" is now considered outmoded and offensive by many, not only because of its sexist overtone but also because of its racist roots. "Grandfather clause" originally meant special provisions that allowed white Americans to continue to vote even if they couldn't meet new suffrage conditions imposed on Black people after the U.S. Civil War (e.g., new literary tests, poll taxes). Acceptable alternatives include **special provision, continued exemption, ongoing exception**, and a contract's **historical clause**.

Another option is to include the term [so-called](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/s/so-called/ "So called") before the quotation marks (i.e., **so-called "great replacement" theory**). Limit use in web headlines or TV banners because key context can be lost. All stories that refer to the "great replacement" conspiracy theory should succinctly explain that its origins are found in old [white nationalist](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/w/#white_nationalism "W") fearmongering about a plot to diminish the influence of white people.

**greenbelt** (generic) an area of fields, forests, wetlands, and other green space around a community where development is either prohibited or severely restricted; **Greenbelt** (the name of specific, protected land that's become a proper noun through widespread usage). To ensure accuracy and clarity, be precise when reporting on different greenbelts that could be confused by some in our audience. For instance, **Ontario's Greenbelt** refers to provincially controlled and protected land, mainly around the Golden Horseshoe, while **Ottawa's Greenbelt** refers to federally controlled and protected land managed by the National Capital Commission. Such common names do not need to be defined in every story as long as context makes the meaning clear. In second reference, Greenbelt alone is capitalized (e.g., Ontario's Greenbelt becomes **the Greenbelt**).

**gurdwara** (a Sikh house of worship) Use this spelling of the Punjabi [transliteration](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/transliterations/ "Transliterations") for consistency. The plural is **gurdwaras**. Keep lowercase unless part of a proper noun (e.g., the **Guru Nanak Sikh Gurdwara** in Surrey, B.C.). Gurdwara does not need to be defined in stories as long as the meaning is clear from context. While gurdwaras are conventionally referred to as Sikh temples in Canadian English, including in the official names of centres (e.g., the **Okanagan Sikh Temple and Cultural Society**) as well as on some historic plaques outside buildings (e.g., the [**Abbotsford Sikh Temple**](https://parks.canada.ca/culture/designation/lieu-site/temple-sikh-abbotsford-sikh-temple)), be aware that some community members dislike the English word "temple" as a generic synonym for "gurdwara." While using both terms (gurdwaras and temples) interchangeably in stories can help foster greater cultural awareness in Canada, respect known preferences whenever practical in specific coverage.

**Gypsy, Gypsies** (avoid when referring to the nomadic people now widely known as [**Roma**](/home/r#Roma)) The word is also inappropriate when used to imply unlawful conduct, whether capitalized or lowercase, whether in its root form or as a derivative. For example, **do not use gyp as a verb** (e.g., to "gyp" or swindle someone) **or as a pejorative modifier** (e.g., to drive a **gypsy cab** — an archaic label for "illegal" or unlicensed taxi). Be aware that some people object to "gypsy" across the board, regardless of whether the expressions, themselves, are incontestably demonizing. Therefore, it's a good practice to either avoid "gypsy" in these contexts or to limit use to one reference if leaving out the word altogether might confuse our audience. For example, **gypsy swing** and **gypsy jazz** are entrenched genres heavily influenced by traditional **Romani music**. Be respectful while still ensuring audience clarity. For instance, there's no need to refer to the **LDD moth** as the gypsy moth throughout a story. There's also no need to resort to the dense scientific proper noun _Lymantria dispar dispar_. Instead, it's generally OK to use the common name once in if the detail is deemed necessary for audience understanding, and if we flag that the word "gypsy" is offensive (e.g., "**also known as the gypsy moth, which is now considered an ethnic slur**"). Then return to LDD for the rest of the report. When there's more than one common name, prefer the version without the word "gypsy" in it (e.g., "bugleweed" instead of "gypsywort" for the plant scientists call _Lycopus europaeus_).

**About the G8**
(Also known as **the Group of Eight**)

MEMBERS: **Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, Russia, the U.K.** and **the U.S.**

BACKGROUND: **The label G8 describes an informal association of the world's major industrial democracies.** There is no actual organization known as the G8, just as there was no formal institution called the G7. It is not founded on any international treaty. It has no office, staff or budget. Its "presidency" is rotational, with one of its members taking on the role the year that leader's country hosts the G8 summit (e.g., Stephen Harper in 2010).

The term Group of Eight was first used in 1998, when Russia became a part-time member of what had been previously referred to as the G7 (formed in 1975). By 2006, Russia had become a full-time member participating in all talks, including economic and financial discussions.

SUMMITS: **G8 leaders hold annual summits. Each member country hosts the event on a rotational basis.** Agendas deal with everything from international trade and banking regulations to arms controls, policing and security, health, employment, environment, and energy policies. Before the summit, various smaller G8 meetings are held by government representatives (e.g., foreign affairs ministers and their equivalents). Communiqués are normally issued when talks wrap up. News conferences are also common at summits.

**It's worth noting that G7 leaders or their representatives sometimes still get together** (e.g., a meeting of G7 finance ministers). **In other words, the creation of the G8 did not end the G7**, just as creation of the G20 did not end the G8.


**About the G20**
(Also known as **the Group of 20**)

MEMBERS: **Argentina, Australia, Brazil, Canada, China, France, Germany, India, Indonesia, Italy, Japan, Mexico, Russia, Saudi Arabia, South Africa, South Korea, Turkey, the U.K, the United States** and the **European Union**.

BACKGROUND: **Formed in 1999, the G20 is made of up of finance ministers and central bank governors from 20 of the world's largest economies** (19 countries as well as the European Union). **In 2008, the heads of governments began participating as well** — turning the previously lower-profile meetings into major summits. In 2010, the G20 economies represented about 85 per cent of the world's gross national product and roughly two-thirds of the planet's population.

There is no actual organization known as the Group of 20. It's merely a forum for consultation, discussion and co-operation on a wide range of issues tied to international finance and trade — from taxation rates and banking regulations to fiscal stimulus plans. During the deep global recession of 2009, G20 leaders announced that they would replace the G8 as the main international group debating economic issues and policies. **Unlike the G8, the G20 includes major developing economies, such as China and India, rather than merely established or "advanced" economies.**

SUMMITS: **Various smaller G20 meetings are held annually** (e.g., the heads of central banks, the finance ministers, deputies). Normally, one or two summits are also held each year (e.g., in London and Pittsburgh in 2009, and in Canada and South Korea in 2010). **Senior officials from the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank traditionally take part in an unofficial capacity.** Communiqués are usually issued at the end of each summit. News conferences are also common.

**Miscellaneous**

-   **When covering protests, all relevant CBC journalistic standards and practices apply.** Remember that crowds are rarely monolithic at international events such as the G8 or G20 summits. **Be as precise as possible** when a particular person or group's grievances are known. Are they environmentalists? Human rights advocates? Anti-poverty lobbyists? Anti-establishment activists? Beyond that, what do they actually want (e.g., tougher laws against pollution, higher corporate taxes, an end to free trade, smaller government, a complete overhaul of the financial system)? **Use accurate language** (e.g., words such as [demonstrators, militants, anarchists, etc.](/home/f/fundamentalist-extremist), have different meanings). **Prefer specific detail over vague descriptions** (e.g., write "Hooded protesters overturned parked cars" rather than "Angry militants destroyed property," and write "Police fired a water cannon on protesters trying to scale a fence" rather than "Police kept the crowd under control"). **Attribute anything contestable**, from estimates of crowd sizes to claims about which side started a clash.
-   **Shorten officials' titles whenever possible** (e.g., Argentina’s Foreign Affairs Minister Jorge Taiana rather than "Argentina’s Minister of Foreign Affairs, International Trade and Worship Jorge Taiana").
-   **Use equivalents whenever possible**, since the English words are often translations (e.g., French Finance Minister Christine Lagarde rather than "French Minister of the Economy, Industry and Employment Christine Lagarde"). **But retain established exceptions** (e.g., the U.S. has a secretary of state not a foreign minister, and the U.K. has a chancellor of the exchequer not a finance minister).
-   **Follow CBCNews.ca publishing style for [titles](/home/t/titles)** **when posting web stories** (e.g., use capital letters in titles only when directly in front of the current office holder's name, such as Brazil's president but Brazilian President Luiz Ignacio Lula da Silva). **In television, follow in-house style for "supers"** (the text superimposed over clips and images), which tends to lean toward more initial capital letters in titles.
-   **Follow CBC News style for country names** (e.g., South Korea rather than the Republic of Korea). **Be sure to refer to proper nouns accurately** (e.g., the Bank of Korea), **but make certain the meaning is clear to our audience** (e.g., it might be preferable to talk about South Korea's central bank rather than the Bank of Korea). For this reason, it's often best to use lowercase English equivalents of certain proper nouns (e.g., Germany's central bank rather than Germany's Bundesbank or the Deutsche Bundesbank).
-   **Use a conjunction (G8 and G20) or an oblique stroke (G8/G20) when referring to the summits.** Although the solidus ("/") often indicates "either/or" constructions, it's conventionally acceptable in a compound such as G8/G20. It also helps our audience when scanning web headlines or TV graphics. **But avoid a hyphen**, since that punctuation implies a joint summit (along the lines of Canada-U.S. trade talks). **Keep the words summit and summits lowercase** in web journalism (G20 summit).
