### GDP versus GNP

**GDP versus GNP**

**GDP**
**The gross domestic product (GDP) measures the value of all goods and services produced in the country, whether by Canadians or foreign investors.**

It includes income earned by workers, profits made by companies, interest charged by lenders and indirect taxes (e.g., the GST) collected by governments.

The term “**real GDP**” means that the **effects of inflation have been subtracted**. It’s now **the most common gauge of economic activity in Canada**.

Since Confederation, real GDP is estimated to have grown by more than 8000 per cent. If GDP is positive but smaller than a previous month’s increase, the economy is still expanding – although at a slower pace.

Avoid illogical jargon, such as “negative growth.” If GDP falls for an extended period of time, it’s fine to say that the economy is weakening or contracting. “Growth” can slow or stop, but it can never be negative. (See also [recession](/home/r/recession))


**GNP**
In some countries, gross domestic product is used to measure economic activity. (This was the case in the United States until 1991.)

**GNP is the value of all goods and services produced by a country’s citizens, whether at home or through investments abroad.**

GNP is equal to GDP, therefore, plus profits and interest that Canadians receive from other countries, minus profits, dividends and interest paid to foreigners who’ve invested in Canada.

**Given the large amount of foreign investment in Canada, our GNP tends to be smaller than GDP.**

### \-general

**\-general**

When "general" is the second half of a compound, **use a hyphen only when it is the key word:**

  lieutenant-general

  lieutenant-generals

  major-general

  major-generals


A clue is which side takes the "s" in a plural construction. In the above cases, the word _general_ is acting as the noun that's being modified.

**Usually**, however, **there is no hyphen**:


  attorney general

  attorneys general

  auditor general

  auditors general

  consul general

  consuls general

  director general

  directors general

  Governor General    _(capitalize for current)_

  governors general    _(lowercase; past office holders)_

  postmaster general

  postmasters general

  secretary general

  secretaries general


**Since general is acting as an adjective in these compounds, the word does not take the "s" to indicate more than one** senior attorney, auditor, etc.


**United Nations**
Although the United Nations slips a hyphen into the title of the person at its helm, we do not. (**UN Secretary General Kofi Annan**, the **secretary general of the United Nations, the secretary general,former UN secretary general Kurt Waldheim, past UN secretaries general**, etc.)

When someone is named to a position but hasn't actually begun working in an official capacity yet, the qualifier "designate" is often used. In these cases, add only one hyphen and keep the label lowercase, even before a full name:

> UN secretary general-designate Ban Ki-moon was officially scheduled to replace Kofi Annan on Jan. 1, 2007.


Less formal labels such as "incoming" or "next" UN secretary general are also fine in such cases.

See [\-designate versus -elect](/home/p/pm-designate), and **[Governor General](/home/g/governor-general)** and [plural compounds](/home/c/courts-martial-and-other-plural-compounds) (e.g., courts martial).

For more information on when to put these compounds in capital letters (Attorney General, for instance, or Maj.-Gen), see [titles](/home/t/titles) as well as [military ranks](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/m/military-ranks/ "Military ranks").

### genocide

**Genocide**

**The word genocide**, coined in the 20th century, **refers to the intentional and widespread extermination of a particular group.** The term "**ethnic cleansing**" is sometimes used, since the victims are often targeted because of their racial or national background.

The 1948 United Nations Convention on Genocide broadens the meaning to include acts intended "to destroy, in whole or in part, a national, ethnic, racial or religious group."

**In news stories, use the word genocide with care. If facts are in dispute, mention this and attribute claims, conclusions, etc., accordingly.**

**For instance**, historians consider the Holocaust a genocide of the Jewish people. Despite the strong views of a few fringe communities, **the Holocaust can be considered a genocide without qualification.** Nazis murdered **six million Jews** from 1933 to the end of the Second World War in 1945. [International Holocaust Remembrance Day](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.canada.ca%2Fen%2Fcanadian-heritage%2Fservices%2Fcanada-holocaust%2Fabout.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1OyTAwU9uW0i1UASxLlHVG) is marked on Jan. 27 in many countries around the world, including in Canada. Be aware that wildly different estimates of the total number of dead are sometimes cited, especially when non-Jewish victims are included. While it's accurate to say that the Nazis killed **millions of other non-Jewish people** because of their race, religion, sexual orientation, etc., the **exact figure is unknown.**  In particular, the estimate of 11 million that surfaced in the 1970s has no foundation in fact according to historians. [This article](https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/non-jewish-victims-of-the-holocaust) published by the American-Israeli Cooperative Enterprise's Jewish Virtual Library offers additional details.

**Some proper nouns are comparatively obscure, so require a definition high in stories**. For instance, **the Holodomor** is the name of the Soviet-orchestrated mass famine that killed millions of Ukrainians in the early 1930s. It is **recognized as a genocide by many governments around the world, including Canada**, which passed the [Ukrainian Famine and Genocide (“Holodomor”) Memorial Day Act](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Flaws-lois.justice.gc.ca%2Feng%2Facts%2Fu-0.4%2Fpage-1.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3klzdgYKYUHapFL1zW8WLH) in 2008.

The word genocide is lowercase, as in **Bosnian genocide** and **Rwandan genocide**.


**Armenian genocide**

In the case of the **mass executions of Armenians by the Ottoman Turks during and after the First World War**, Canada and dozens of other countries have formally recognized the killings as genocide, including Belgium, France, Italy and Russia. So has a United Nations commission, the European Parliament and the Vatican.

Turkish authorities dispute the number of dead, which they set at 300,000. They also maintain that many of the deaths were a legitimate military response to revolution and banditry. They blame the rest on starvation, disease, emigration, etc. However, a strong majority of scholars and historians agree that an estimated 1.5 million Armenians were killed in what was, indeed, a genocide.

**CBC practice is to refer to these events as a genocide. We should also note, where relevant, that Turkey continues to dispute this term.
**
Armenians commemorate the date **April 24, 1915**, when several hundred Armenian intellectuals were rounded up, arrested and later executed. The word genocide in this context is uppercase because it's treated as a proper noun: **Armenian Genocide Remembrance Day**.

Examples of usage from CBC's coverage of the 100th anniversary of April 24th:


> "Thousands of people are gathering on Parliament Hill this afternoon and will march through Ottawa's downtown streets to mark the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide. On April 24th, 1915, Ottoman authorities in what is now present-day Turkey began rounding up and executing Armenians under their rule. An estimated 1.5 million Armenians were killed. Millions of people around the world mark April 24 as the Armenian Genocide Remembrance Day, and more than 20 countries, including Canada, recognize the slaughter of Armenians during the First world War as genocide. Turkey, however, rejects the term."
>
>
>
> "The small nation of Armenia came to a standstill today to mark the day 100 years ago when a genocide began against its people. As many as 1.5 million dead were remembered in a sombre ceremony at the country's massive memorial. In other commemorations and demonstrations around the world, Turkey was condemned for refusing to acknowledge that the killings were an organized campaign of genocide."


See also [war crimes](/home/w#warcrimes)

### Geography-Cities- World

**Geographical abbreviations**

In first reference, most places need to be identified by more than their full name. **We generally add the province, state, or territory for locations in North America, and the country for other spots in the world.** This extra detail appears between commas:


> _They drove to Estevan, Sask., on Saturday.
> __She moved to Great Falls, Mont., in 1944.
> __He was born in Florence, Italy, during the Second World War._


**Exceptions are made for well-known communities**, as well as for other places when the story has already established the location. If a piece focuses on fruit orchards in B.C., for example, we can write _Kelowna_ (instead of _Kelowna, B.C._,) midway through the copy.

See [provinces and cities](/home/p/provinces-and-cities) for guidelines on geographical abbreviations in Canada.
See [United States](/home/u/united-states) for guidelines on geographical abbreviations in the U.S.

**Country names
****The Language Guide lists CBC News preferences for the names of certain countries that are referred to in more than one way** around the world (e.g., [**Myanmar**](/home/m/Myanmar), also known as Burma). Always prefer English forms when these are entrenched (e.g., **Ivory Coast** instead of "Côte d'Ivoire" and **Cape Verde** instead of "Cabo Verde"). See [foreign words](/home/f/foreign-words) for related guidelines about accents.

**Many countries have slightly different, official names**. Some of these proper nouns still surface periodically in highly formal contexts. Others have virtually disappeared through intentional lack of use by governments over several generations (e.g., "the Dominion of Canada"), even though old legislation remains on the books. **It's an acceptable convention to clip official names of countries**, which can be much longer than what's commonly reported. For example:


> **Afghanistan** (NOT the "Islamic Republic of Afghanistan")
> **Algeria** (NOT the "People's Democratic Republic of Algeria")
> **China** (NOT the "People's Republic of China")
> **Ethiopia** (NOT the "Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia")
> **[Gambia](/home/g#Gambia)** (NOT "The Gambia" or the "Republic of The Gambia")
> [**Macedonia**](/home/b/balkans#Macedonia) (NOT "the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia")
> **Sri Lanka** (NOT the "Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka")
> **U.K.** or **[United Kingdom](/home/u/united-kingdom)** (NOT the "United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland")


**In some cases, detail such as a compass point is added to avoid any ambiguity.** Even though this sort of colloquial name is not official, it frequently serves our audience best and, so, is generally the most sensible preference:


> **East Timor** (instead of the "Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste")
> **[North Korea](/home/n#NorthKorea)** (instead of the "Democratic People's Republic of Korea")
> **[South Korea](/home/s#SouthKorea)** (instead of the "Republic of Korea")


**From time to time, it can make sense to include an alternative name in a story** (e.g., "**East Timor, also known as Timor-Leste**"). The most common editorial reason is when the alternative name is mentioned in a broadcast clip or a transcribed quote, especially if the less-common proper noun's meaning might not be instantly clear from context. Otherwise, it's usually best to stick with the most common name throughout a report (e.g., East Timor).

NOTE:  **Even when countries have only one official name, care must be taken to avoid errors** (e.g., mistakenly referring to **[Ukraine](/home/u#Ukraine)** as "the Ukraine"). See ["the" before certain geographical proper nouns](/home/t/the-versus-the#geographical) for related guidelines.

**In territorial disputes, we prefer neutral language** (e.g., using "island" instead of "country" in the case of **[Taiwan](/home/t/taiwan)**).

**When two countries' names are very similar, it's important to distinguish between them** to keep our journalism clear and accurate. [**Congo** versus the **Republic of Congo**](/home/c/Congos) are examples.

**Bear in mind that we're not obligated to use short forms or non-English forms**, even when these are recommended by a specific country. **Audience recognition is a core consideration**. So while, say, **France** is virtually always preferred over **the French Republic** because it's so entrenched, **Czechia** is NOT preferred over [**the Czech Republic**](/home/c#Czech-Republic) because the less formal, one-word name is not as widely known. And we continue to use [**Turkey**](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/turkey/ "Turkey") instead of **Türkiye**.

**We normally use only one spelling or version** of a proper noun in our journalism. **But in rare cases, [alternative forms of certain geographical names](/home/p/provinces-and-cities#alternative-spellings) may be OK**, depending on the context or the platform (e.g., **St-Pierre-Miquelon, St-Pierre-et-Miquelon** and **Saint Pierre and Miquelon**).

**Cities around the world
****Proper nouns sometimes change for various reasons.** Turkey's largest city, **Instanbul**, was once known as Constantinople, and long before that as Byzantium. Russia's second-largest city, **St. Petersburg**, was changed to Petrograd in 1914, and then to Leningrad in the 1920s, before being rebranded as St. Petersburg again in the 1990s. **Beijing** was commonly known as Peking until the second half of the 20th century, when the new Pinyin "romanization" system was adopted (i.e., new rules for writing Chinese in the roman alphabet).

**The National Geographic Atlas of the World is our main reference book for the spellings of communities outside of Canada. But in some cases we use widely accepted alternatives** (e.g., **Kabul** not "Kabol," **Damascus** not "Dimashq," and **Rome** not "Roma"), so check this intranet site first. Some **[transliterations](/home/t/transliterations)** have changed in recent decades. For example, we write **Kyiv** and **Chornobyl** instead of "Kiev" and "Chernobyl" because these are closer to the original Ukrainian. The same is true of **Kolkata** instead of "Calcutta."

Always put the audience first. Therefore, **if a story doesn't make the location obvious, it's generally best to add the name of the country.**

### German names

**German names**

**When you encounter a German name with an umlaut (e.g., ö or ü), generally type the letter "e" after the vowel that has the diacritical mark** if these spellings have become the entrenched forms in English:


> Bruennhilde
> Duesseldorf
> Goebbels
> Goering
> Schroeder


This is a **well-established convention** for handling German nouns. It **does not apply to other languages.**


**Exceptions**
It's **OK to post umlauts or to ignore them** (i.e., not to add the "e") **if you're following:**


> 1\. An individual's **known preference.**
>
> 2\. An **established English spelling** (e.g., Beethoven's Für Elise).

**Phöney stüff**
**Do not treat invented and pretentious umlauts as real:**


> _Haagen-Daz ice cream_ (ignore Häagen-Daz, a noun concocted by a U.S. entrepreneur)
>
> _Motley Crue_ (ignore Mötley Crüe; do not add extra vowels)
>
> _Moxy Fruvous_ (ignore Moxy Früvous; do not add an extra "e")


The absurdity of fictional accents is illustrated nicely by the second musical group above. At one point, the official "Früvous" website included a link to "nüz flashes."

See also [foreign words](/home/f/foreign-words) (an overview), [French accents](/home/f/french-words-and-accents) (detailed guidelines) and [transliterations](/home/t/transliterations)

### gerunds\_possessives

**Possessive before gerund**

**It's a myth that nouns and pronouns placed directly in front of gerunds must always be in the possessive form.** English speakers and writers have options. Details and examples are outlined below.



**Grammar at a glance**
**EACH of the following IS CORRECT:**


They do not condone **us smoking** in the house. — (**NP = NON-POSSESSIVE** because "us" is used)
They do not condone **our smoking** in the house. — (**P = POSSESSIVE** because "our" is used)


Critics of the first (NP) sentence say (i) it can initially suggest that "they" do not condone "us" rather than "us smoking," and that (ii) fused participles (e.g., "us smoking") are inherently ungrammatical because comparable constructions do not exist in Latin.

Defenders of the first (NP) sentence say (i) the meaning of "us smoking" is instantly understood because it's so widely used. and that (ii) assessments about English grammar should not be based only, or even primarily, on rules of Latin.


**What's a 'gerund'?**
To better understand why non-possessive constructions such as "us smoking" above are OK, it's **helpful to review some general terminology** before analyzing specific sentence structure. Consider the word WALK:


They will **walk** through the park. (**VERB**)

They were last seen **walking** through the park. (**PRESENT PARTICIPLE**)

They both used **walking** canes. (**PARTICIPIAL ADJECTIVE**)

**Walking** is good for you. (**GERUND**, also known as a **VERBAL NOUN**)


In English, then, **a "gerund"** — pronounced with a soft "g" sound, like general — **is simply a specific "-ing" form of a verb acting as a noun.**


**NOTE:** **Many modern grammarians prefer to call gerunds "verbal nouns"** because that label lets them steer clear of a peripheral debate over whether the Latin term "gerund" should even apply in various English constructions. This lack of consensus over suitable jargon illustrates an ideological divide between those who are rigid and those who are more flexible when adjudicating English through a Latin language lens.



**Old quarrel: Possessive vs. non-possessive**
In the **mid-18th century**, a relatively arcane **disagreement erupted: Should a noun or pronoun directly in front of a gerund always be possessive?**


He did not like **them walking** through the park. (**NP = NON-POSSESSIVE**)
He did not like **their walking** through the park. (**P = POSSESSIVE**)


**Some writers and editors insisted on the P form** because it better tracked the way certain verbs become nouns in Latin. **Others questioned whether the P form is even suitable, let alone mandatory, in many English cases.** Since then, **both the NP and P constructions have become well established**, and **many reputable usage guides say that either is usually fine. Nevertheless, a debate continues to rage in some quarters,** especially among disciples of grammarian Henry Watson Fowler who insisted on the possessive form.

In the 1920s, Fowler and renowned Danish linguist Otto Jespersen sparred over sentences like this:


**Women having** the vote reduces men's political power. (**NP**)
**Women's having** the vote reduces men's political power. **(P**)


**Fowler classified "women having" as a bastardized construction** he dubbed a "fused participle." **Jespersen replied that Fowler's insistence on the possessive form ("women's having") was flawed** because it relied on parallels with Latin that are not absolute. Be wary of the "instinctive grammatical moralizer," Jespersen warned. "Each language surely has a right to be judged on its own merits."

Fast forward a century. **The 2015 Fowler's Dictionary of Modern English Usage points out that several factors can influence whether to take the NP or the P path — from individual preference to what a writer wants to emphasize in a given sentence**: "The **non-possessive stresses the verbal action**" while "the **possessive stresses the noun-like quality of the phrase** that follows," it says. For example, the verbs "smoke," "go," "choose" and "to be" arguably stand out more in the NP versions below:


They do not condone **us smoking** at work. (NP)
They do not condone **our smoking** at work. (P)

To many, **the Queen going** there was a surprise. (NP)
To many, **the Queen's going** there was a surprise. (P)

**Picasso losing** the bet led to the painting. (NP)
**Picasso's losing** the bet led to the painting. (P)

Try to imagine the **baby being** born in a moving taxi. (NP)
Try to imagine the **baby's being** born in a moving taxi. (P)


Some writers seem to switch between NP and P on a whim. **The non-possessive form can sound more conversational in some contexts. But there are also times when the NP version can seem to cross the line from being colloquial to strikingly odd** — if not actually uneducated. Personal pronouns at the start of sentences often fall into this category:


**Me dating** his mother made him uncomfortable. (NP and **non-standard**)
**My dating** his mother made him uncomfortable. (P and standard; widely recommended)


**Be on the alert for times when the choice of possessive or non-possessive can change a sentence's meaning**, even subtly:


The dog didn't like **him singing**. (NP)
The dog didn't like **his singing**. (P)


Given all of the above, **CBC News style is to permit both non-possessive and possessive nouns and pronouns before gerunds**, as long as the intended meaning is clear and the choice of wording is not awkward or jarring. Use your judgment. **This approach mirrors a recommendation found in the 2007 Canadian Oxford Guide to English Usage**: "It appears that writers have always varied their use of the possessive with the gerund according to considerations of formality, emphasis, and sound without much self-torment (unless they have read Fowler) and we suggest they continue to do so."

See also [possessive apostrophes](/handy-links/punctuation/possessive-apostrophe) (including true vs. false possessives, such as a Leafs' win vs. a Leafs player)

See also **[grammar](/handy-links/grammar)** for a list of common topics (e.g., split infinitives, who versus whom)

### green paper versus white paper

**Go missing, gone missing, went missing**

**All of these expressions are OK.**

Be aware that **some people find the phrasing inelegant, and prefer alternatives such as vanished, disappeared, etc.** Others, however, don't like what they consider the literal "dematerialization" sense of a magician's puff of smoke that "vanish" and "disappear" can sometimes convey. It largely boils down to personal preference.

**It's a myth that "go missing" is ungrammatical.** The bogus argument is based on the observation that "missing" is a state of being rather than an activity, such as fishing, swimming, walking or skating. You can "go fishing," according to this logic, but you can't "go missing."

"Missing," however, is not a gerund (often called a "verbal noun") like fishing or swimming, so the analogy is hollow and the argument misleading. **"Missing" is simply a noun** (to be missing) **that can also function as an adjective** (a missing person). And **just because a noun happens to have an "ing" ending does not mean that there's a syntactical rule against using it after what amounts to a linking verb** ("go" or "be"), also known as a copula.

**Put another way: One can go crazy, bankrupt, berserk, limp, numb, nuts, Hollywood, etc.** These "go predicative" constructions often suggest an undesirable change, such as deterioration (e.g., **to go bad** means old food has become inedible). But the "go" and "went" developments can be neutral or desirable, too (e.g., **to go all in, green, live, platinum, public**).

In linguistics, the various "go/went" constructions above are all merely "inchoatives," which means they describe a process of change. And **since at least the 1840s, "go missing" and "gone missing" and "went missing" have referred to a sudden or mysterious disappearance clearly and succinctly.** As such, they're highly practical idioms for journalists reporting on missing people, planes, money, etc.

Be aware that for many decades, various prominent CBC broadcasters decried use of "go missing" and "went missing." As recently as the 1990s, CBC Radio and TV style manuals denounced the phrasing, clinging to a misinterpretation of basic grammar. The criticism was never backed by any scholarship, however, illustrating the need for care before internal staff notes are circulated about language.


See also [grammar](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/handy-links/grammar/ "Grammar")

### got versus gotten

**Got versus gotten**

**Both _got_ and _gotten_ are considered acceptable** as the past participle of _get_ in North America. The same was true in Britain until about 200 years ago. Authorities there now prefer _got_.

**In news stories, it’s generally better to choose _“got”_ because it’s shorter.** (_“The children love the zoo. They’ve got to see the elephants up close many times.”_)

In Canada and the U.S., **“has gotten” often implies a recent acquisition.** (_"Tom's got a bicycle"_ means he owns one, while _"Tom's gotten a bicycle"_ suggests it's just happened.)

In Britain, on the other hand, people have gotten into trouble for trying to breathe life into what's seen as an archaic word.

### Governor General

**Governor General versus governor general**

**The abbreviated title** (before the full name) **is Gov. Gen. There's no hyphen** in either the long or short form. **GG is fine in headlines only.** But avoid using this boiled-down version in the main text except in directly transcribed quotes.

The King is Canada's head of state. Although **the Governor General** is acting head of state when the King is not in the country, we don't generally use this viceregal description in news stories. Instead, we write "**the King's representative,**" etc.

**The plural is governors general.** For more details and related examples (attorneys general but major-generals), see [\-general](/home/g/generalsuffix) in compounds.


**Capitalization**
**Capitalize all references to Canada's current Governor General, even when the title is not followed by the name.**

> He plans to meet **the Governor General** Thursday morning.
>
> **The Governor General's** New Year's message focused on Afghanistan.


This is different from prime minister and most other official posts or designations (See [titles](/home/t/titles)). **Interpret this to mean that references to the position of Governor General in Canada not modified by specific terms such as former, past or next are essentially indirect references to the office holder.** So while we'd talk about _former governor general_ Adrienne Clarkson in a story about her, we'd report that Adrienne Clarkson, Romeo Leblanc and Roland Michener have all served as Canada's _Governor General_ in a feature about the viceregal role. This approach leads to a more consistent use of initial capital letters in coverage.

> **the Governor General** (referring to _Canada's_, even when not in front of a name)
>
> **the role of the Governor General** in Canada (indirectly refers to Canada's current office holder)
>
> **Gov. Gen. [Mary Simon](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/s/#marysimon "S")**
>
> **former governor general** Michaëlle Jean
>
> **Canada's next governor general** will be sworn in next month
>
> **the governor general-designate**
>
> **past governors general** (plural)


Also use uppercase (Gov. Gen.) when placed in front of the name of another country's current governor general.

> **the governor general** (_other countries_)
>
> **Australian Gov. Gen. Michael Jaffery**, _but_ **Australia's governor general**


Other common terms tied to Canada's Governor General:

> **Governor General's Awards**
>
> **Governor General's Literary Awards**
>
> **Governor General's Award for non-fiction**
>
> **Governor General's Award for poetry**
>
> **Governor General's Horse Guards**
>
> **Governor General's Foot Guards**


See [awards](/home/a/award-versus-award) overview for relevant capitalization guidelines


**Spouses**
There is no special term for the spouses of governors general or other viceregal office holders. They are simply identified by name and relationship (husband or wife). For instance:

> **Johnston's wife, Sharon, was also ...**
>
> **Gov. Gen. David Johnston and his wife, Sharon, were greeted ...**
>
> **Johnston and his wife, Sharon, flew to ...**


If the viceregal office holder hasn't been referred to yet by name, the spouse's full name is given:

> **Sharon Johnston, the Governor General's wife, said ...**
>
> **The Governor General's wife, Sharon Johnston, announced ...**


Don't bother including the relationship to the viceregal or former viceregal if it's irrelevant (e.g., in a story about John Ralston Saul that has nothing to do with Adrienne Clarkson).


**The PM picks and the King appoints**
**Prime ministers do NOT appoint governors general. The King must OK the prime minister's choice for this post.** But never write that the King _appoints_ the governor general without putting the verb into context. In essence, the King approves the prime minister's selection. It's often easiest to say that the **prime minister has named** a new governor general, or that **the prime minister has picked** a new governor general and that the King has approved the appointment.

**governor general-designate**
**Until sworn in, this individual is known as the governor general-designate** (lowercase, one hyphen). It's the official term used by the Canadian Heritage Department, although the government's version features capital letters and no punctuation. (See also [designate](/home/p/pm-designate), as in prime minister-designate and governor general-designate.)

The ceremony is officially referred to as an "**installation**," but we can also call it a **swearing-in** since the governor general-designate always takes an oath. It is technically not an investiture, although parts of the installation do include the presentation of honours and ranks.

More information can be found on the [Governor General's website](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.gg.ca%2Findex.aspx&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw13SFoqkAjv6FSvCt4Hw2VG).

### green paper versus white paper

**A green paper versus a white paper**

**Green paper**
A report outlining a problem or an issue, and inviting people to comment on proposed solutions.

**White paper**
A report outlining the government’s plans to introduce specific legislation.

The biggest difference is that **a green paper raises something for discussion before any legislation is drafted.**

**Do not capitalize the names of reports unless you’re using the full, proper title:**

The white paper on defence.
The 1994 white paper on defence.
Challenge and Commitment: A Defence Policy for Canadians. (_This is the official name of a 1987 white paper on defence._)

See also [Royal Commission versus royal commission](/home/r/royal-commissions).

### grey jay

**Grey jay, whisky jack**

Use the conventional Canadian spelling (grey) for this bird in all cases. The noun **grey jay** is as entrenched in Canada as **grey goose, greyhound, grey whale** and **grey wolf**. The bird's other popular name is **whisky jack**, believed to be an English corruption of the original Cree word _weskuchanis_. (See also [whisky instead of whiskey](/home/w/whisky))

While **some bird enthusiasts insist that the "correct" spelling is "gray,"** this is based on the U.S. spelling of the word adopted by groups such as the American Ornithologists' Union. **But that doesn't make "gray" an official name.**

A global body, the International Ornithological Committee (IOC), publishes comprehensive lists of bird names that specifically state "grey" and "gray" are equally acceptable. In its flexible spelling rules, the IOC points out other parts of bird names may be rendered differently outside the U.S., such as **colour** (instead of "color"), **moustache** (instead of "mustache"), **sombre** (instead of "somber") and **sulphur** (instead of "sulfur").

The Canadian Oxford Dictionary lists grey jay and whisky jack as the preferred spellings. In scientific circles, the bird is technically known by its [Latin name](/home/l/latin-scientific-names): _Perisoreus canadensis_. But the translation **Canada jay** is not as widely known as either grey jay or whisky jack.


### guard of honour

**Guard of honour**


Prefer the Canadian term **guard of honour** when reporting on all military ceremonies. The U.S. equivalent is honour guard.

It's simpler and more consistent to apply the Canadian term across the board rather than referring to, say, guards of honour in Ottawa and honour guards in Washington. It also avoids the troublesome matter of misspelling "honor." **Never adopt foreign spellings of generic words**. Since this means writing "honour guard" rather than "honor guard" for a U.S. ceremony, the simplest approach is "guard of honour."

The principle of adopting Canadian preferences applies to related ceremonial language, such as always writing [half-mast](/home/h/half-mast) when describing lowered flags around the world rather than identifying and switching to local preferences (e.g., "half-staff" in the U.S.).

In Commonwealth countries, **dignitaries inspect troops** and **inspect guards of honour**. In the U.S., they "review" them. Canada's Defence Department outlines [detailed inspection protocols](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.canada.ca%2Fen%2Fdepartment-national-defence%2Fservices%2Fmilitary-history%2Fhistory-heritage%2Fdrill-manual%2Fchapter-10.html%232-18&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1AVVMdjiZlfiEkCY8GBrW4) in its ceremonial drill manual.


See [defence, labour and centre](/home/d/defence-labour-and-centre) for related spelling guidelines (e.g., the generic word "centre" versus the proper noun "World Trade Center")

The [Canadian Heritage website](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.canada.ca%2Fen%2Fcanadian-heritage%2Fservices%2Fprotocol-guidelines-special-event%2Fhonours-salutes.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2Rx4iGKeJOZCWdjNTU9ehb) provides details about various military honours, including different types of musical and gun salutes, as well as general criteria for determining the size of a specific guard of honour.

### Guinness World Records

**Guinness World Records**

This is the publication’s new name. So we write, "**the Guinness World Records** book."

Until the 2000 edition, it was known as the Guinness Book of Records. Reporters sometimes wrongly added “World” to the title.

Now the challenge is to add “World” but **keep the word “book” lowercase**.

Correct: _“They hope to get into the Guinness World Records book.”
_
The book, by the way, was originally called the Guinness Book of Superlatives when it was first published by the brewery in 1955. It was pitched as a way to settle bar bets.

For more information, you can visit the [Guinness World Records](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.guinnessworldrecords.com%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw38jt2Hv__IERKhWF_79RyY) website.

See also [The versus the](/home/t/the-versus-the)

### gyp

**Gyp, blacklist, Indian summer, paddy wagon, etc.**

**Some expressions are considered offensive** because they feature **apparent or inferred epithets**, are tinged with **perceived racial overtones**, etc. They may or may not feature proper noun elements (Dutch, Indian).

Demonyms are not inherently unsuitable (e.g., French bread, Greek salad, Chinese cabbage are common and fine). **We don't automatically ban specific terms solely because there's a connection to a country, nationality, culture, etc.** For instance, German measles is a neutral and acceptable synonym for "rubella" that's immediately recognized by our audience.

**But care needs to be taken with language that is derogatory or even potentially derogatory.** Concerns about possible inappropriateness should be taken seriously — given that societal taste and tolerance evolve, along with connotative meanings and usage. **Key factors to consider when reviewing any words or phrases are whether they're clear, entrenched and neutral.** The latter is subjective and includes assessing if a given term could be reasonably perceived as a form of ethnic denigration, cultural misappropriation, etc.

**Examples of acceptable and unacceptable terms appear below.** When in doubt about certain wording, talk to your supervisor.















See also [**'**sounds like' considerations](#sounds-like) at the bottom of this page (e.g., niggardly).


**blackball: Avoid** unless attributed. **Considered racist by an increasing number of people**. The term has meant to eliminate or to vote against for half a millennium, based on the dark-coloured marbles once used when casting "no" in secret balloting. However, the arbitrary choice of black to describe an undesirable outcome makes the term inapt at best.


**blacklist: Avoid** unless attributed. **Considered racist by an increasing number of people.** The term has meant to ban, ostracize or otherwise punish since the 1600s. Its opposite, **whitelist should also be avoided** unless attributed. Because the meanings of "blacklist" (bad, undesirable) and "whitelist" (good, special) are arbitrarily tied to colour, they're outmoded at best. When picking alternatives, **prefer fact-based modifiers** (e.g., do-not-hire list, no-fly list, ineligibility list, approved websites, pre-authorized names, unblocked emails) **and neutral verbs** (e.g., ban, boycott, deny, disqualify, embargo, restrict, allow, approve, favour, grant, permit, qualify). The relatively new word **blocklist** (those blocked) is also an option, as grammatically valid as the old, fused publishing term "backlist."


**black market: Avoid** unless attributed. **Considered racist by an increasing number of people.** The term has meant illicit trade or illegal commerce since the early 1700s, according to the Oxford English Dictionary. Although there's no definitive evidence that it originally referred to skin colour, "black market" is now perceived this way by some — making it potentially offensive. For this reason, it's a good idea to **use fact-based, neutral alternatives** (e.g., the **illicit pot market** and the **illegal drug trade**. Steer clear of vague, bureaucratic neologisms (e.g., "legacy" marijuana market). Instead, prefer direct, clear wording (e.g., "unauthorized" sales, "unlicensed" retailers, "unregulated" marketing, "illegal" cannabis production).


**Chinese checkers: Generally avoid** this dated and misleading name for the German board game sternhalma — which, in itself, is simply a variation of other marble-hopping strategy games from the 19th century. **Exceptions are direct quotes and other forms of attribution** (e.g., historical citations). Sternhalma was renamed in the U.S. in the 1930s as part of a company's marketing strategy, even though the game has no connection to Asia and is not actually a form of "checkers" (e.g., opponents' pieces are not removed from play). Be aware that the name "Chinese checkers" is offensive to some, given its roots.


**Chinese wall: Avoid unless attributed.** This once-common term for avoiding conflicts of interest was coined last century and is believed to be a figurative reference to the Great Wall of China. The expression is now considered outmoded, at best, because it arbitrarily labels the need to erect barricades in a way that can be misinterpreted as a characterization of Asian business or trade practices. Prefer alternatives such as firewall, information barrier, ethical screen, etc.


**dark: Avoid as a pejorative in stories about race.** Dark is entrenched and generally OK in literal contexts (a dark night, a dark hole, and dark matter in the cosmos), as well as in various figurative contexts (e.g., a dark mood to mean gloomy, the Dark Ages to mean the early Middle Ages, and a dark horse to mean either little known or unexpectedly successful). However, **the word is almost invariably unsuitable in stories about race.** In those cases, pick an alternative that matches the facts (e.g., "disturbing" replaced "dark" in this 2020 web headline, "Researcher unearths disturbing family history about slavery in Nova Scotia"). Be aware that negative meanings are sometimes deeply ingrained in English (e.g., "denigrate" is Latin for "to darken"). While there's no outright ban against certain conventional usage of "dark" and "darken," we should strive to find alternative wording whenever practical, outside of broadcast clips and directly transcribed quotes.

**Dutch treat: Generally avoid** this description of each person paying his or her own share of expenses. To some it implies that citizens of the Netherlands are cheap.


**German measles:** A common and **perfectly acceptable** term for rubella.


**grandfather clause: Avoid unless attributed.** Beyond the needlessly gender-specific reference to ancestors (i.e., grandfather instead of grandparent), the term historically carries a meaning of racial privilege. It originally described statutory provisions passed by some southern states after the U.S. Civil War to let the descendants of white people maintain the right to vote even though they failed to meet new restrictions about land ownership and literacy levels imposed on Black people trying to register to cast ballots for the first time. Use alternatives such as **exemption, special privilege, vested rights, pre-authorized exception**, etc. The **same approach applies to the verb "grandfathered"** (e.g., use words such as **excluded, exempted, waived**, etc., depending on the specific facts and context).


**gyp: Avoid this verb**, believed to have its roots in the word Gypsy. Considered offensive as a synonym for "swindle." **Also avoid "gyp" and "gypsy" in any other expressions that imply fraud or cheating** (e.g., a "gypsy cab"). Even when a name is entrenched and considered neutral rather than pejorative by many, caution should be exercised and alternatives considered (e.g., "gypsy jazz" and the [**gypsy moth**](/home/g#gypsy)). See also **[Roma and Rom](/home/r#Roma)**, which are preferred over Gypsies and Gypsy.


**Indian giver: Do not use.** The term is racist. It implies deceit or selfishness.


**Indian summer: Avoid** unless attributed because it can be considered offensive, even though the etymology is uncertain. There's a possibility that Indian summer has nothing to do with "false" summer. It may simply refer to warm fall weather that [Indigenous people](/home/i/Indigenous) traditionally took advantage of for harvesting or hunting. Since the origins are unclear, however, and since it's perceived by many to suggest a phoney season, rewording is recommended.


**paddy wagon: Do not use.** Prefer police van or police wagon. "Paddy" is a common nickname for Patrick. The term paddy wagon, coined in North America in the early 1900s, is the equivalent of calling the vehicles "Irish wagons." There are debates over the exact origin of the expression — from claims that Irish immigrants were often rowdy and needed to be locked up to suggestions that the wagons were commonly driven by Irish police officers in parts of the U.S. In either case, the Oxford English Dictionary points out that the term Paddy, itself, is frequently considered an offensive nickname for the Irish. When we use it, we get complaints.


**scot-free:** It's a common but **potentially problematic** description of getting away without paying. The expression has nothing to do with Scotland. "Scot" is an old Norse word that meant a type of tax. Not everyone knows this, however, so you risk offending some people by using it. You pay another price too, because it's a cliché, which is arguably the strongest reason to use different wording.


**spade a spade: Generally avoid** the expression "to call a spade a spade" because it's **increasingly perceived as offensive**, even though the original meaning had nothing to do with the racial slur "spade." The idiom "to call a spade a spade" has meant "to be blunt" or "to use direct language" since the 1500s. It's based on what appears to be an English mistranslation of a Latin version of the original Greek expression, "to call a fig a fig and a trough a trough," according to the Oxford English Dictionary. The term "spade" has meant a digging tool for more than a millennium, which is why it's synonymous for a modern-day shovel. It's also one of the four suits in a standard pack of playing cards, based on the image of spear-like tips of medieval weapons, such as pikes. (Cards have featured different suit symbols for centuries, depending on the language/culture of players, from bells, roses and leaves to acorns and shields. Today's iconic symbols — hearts, diamonds, clubs and spades — are French, with "clubs" intended to represent clovers.) There are dozens of entrenched idioms based on card games, such as to be "dealt a bad hand," to "play one's cards right," to "follow suit," to "lay one's cards on the table," and to have an "ace in the hole," (i.e., something advantageous but not yet used or revealed, with "hole" meaning a card dealt facedown). These idioms include the **perfectly acceptable expression "in spades"** (i.e., to have in abundance, especially something of value), since the plural noun is unambiguous in this context — with "spades" deemed the highest suit in games like bridge. However, "to call a spade a spade" is different because the word "spade" has also been a racial slur for a Black person since at least the 1920s, originally in the U.S. but later in Europe with books like the 1957 novel, _City of Spades_, about a Nigerian immigrant witnessing the emergence of Black culture in London, England. Given this reality, **careful writers steer clear of "to call a spade a spade," irrespective of its original meaning**, or the fact that it appears in stories by the likes of Charles Dickens and Oscar Wilde. Alternatives include, "to say what's on your mind," "to speak plainly" and "to say it like it is." Another option is to adopt figurative forms from other languages, such as, "to call a cat a cat" (French), and "to call bread bread and wine wine" (Spanish).

## 'Sounds like' considerations

**Careful writers and editors are mindful that certain words can simply look or sound objectionable.** Examples are "**niggardly**" for cheapness and "**a chink in the armour**" for weakness or vulnerability.

Just because linguistic scholarship stresses that such expressions are not innately hateful, or that they have a long history of neutral usage, doesn't mean the phrasing won't cause confusion and inadvertent offence. **Perception matters**, as noted in the [scot-free](#scot-free) caveat above. Furthermore, **when there are plenty of alternatives available** (e.g., frugal, miserly, stingy for niggardly, and a flaw, gap or hole in the armour for chink), **insisting on the "sounds like a slur" choice becomes increasingly difficult to justify.**

Bear in mind that **we make similar editorial choices in other contexts, both consciously and unconsciously** (e.g., generally preferring to refer to court witnesses "identifying the accused" rather than to them "fingering the accused," even though the latter is a synonym). Remember, too, that **etymology, alone, is not sufficient to justify the use of blatantly objectionable language** (e.g., it's irrelevant that the N-word's roots are Latin for "black").

See also **[racial terms](/home/r/racial-terms)** as well as [**offensive language**](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/o/offensive-language/ "Offensive language").

habeas corpus** (sometimes misspelled habeus) _Avoid using_ this legal jargon if possible. A habeas corpus writ requires authorities to bring a detained person to court for a ruling on whether they can legally keep the person in custody.

**Haida Gwaii** (Indigenous name formally restored as official proper noun in June 2010) Always use Haida Gwaii in first reference. For several years, we often added "previously known as the Queen Charlotte Islands" — or words to that effect — once in stories to help our audience identify the location. But such detail has become increasingly unnecessary over time. Haida Gwaii is made up of more than 150 islands about 90 kilometres west of British Columbia's north coast. The [Indigenous](/home/i/Indigenous) name, which means "Islands of the People," was officially adopted by the province several years after becoming the entrenched preference of local residents. Haida leaders called the name change an important step toward abandoning colonialism and building a new relationship between Indigenous and non-Indigenous people. The archipelago is shaped like an inverted triangle, about 100 kilometres wide across its top end and narrowing to a tip about 300 kilometres to the south.
  (See also [pronunciation](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2Flng%2Frecherche%2Findex.aspx%3FProId%3D36261&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2cSt7fzD_aQvXLv6cC9Maq).)

**Holocaust**, the (mass murder of Jews carried out by Nazis during the Second World War) See [**genocide**](/home/g/genocide)

**Holodomor**, the (mass starvation of Ukrainians in early 1930s by Stalinist leaders) See [**genocide**](/home/g/genocide)

**Holland** (only one part of [**the Netherlands**](/home/n/netherlands-versus-holland)) Except in casual contexts or cases established by convention (e.g., descriptions of Second World War battles), generally avoid calling the country Holland.

**holy city** (lowercase) A description that's normally too subjective or vague for general news stories. Exceptions are background features that put the label into context. Since holy city is applied to various spots in the world, from Jerusalem and Bethlehem to Najaf in Iraq, it's conventionally lowercase. Although the term instantly suggests religious significance, the actual historical importance of a one city to a given faith may be irrelevant or disputed by another faith. Compare with [Holy Land](/home/h#HolyLand) below.

**Holy Father** (generally avoid except in quotes) Use [the Pope](/home/p/pope) instead

**Holy Grail** (Christ's chalice at Last Supper); **grail** (any quest, as in "Cars that run on water became their holy grail")

**Holy Land** (capital letters) A common term that refers to what is now Israel and Palestinian territories near or along the eastern shores of the Mediterranean. The region holds significance for several religions, including Judaism, Christianity and Islam. Although Holy Land is acceptable in some contexts, specific proper nouns are normally preferred in our journalism (e.g., Israel, Gaza, the West Bank). Compare with [holy city](/home/h#holycity) above. See also the [Middle East glossary](/home/m/middle-east-glossary) for detailed language guidelines about the region.

**home**
**homebrew, homebuyer, home care** (_two words_), **home field** (_two words_), **homegrown, homemade, homemaker, home movie, home opener** (_two words_), **homeowner, home page** (_two words_), **home plate** (see also [baseball terms](/home/b/baseball)), **homeschool, homeschooled, homeschooler, homeschooling****, homesick, hometown, homework, homeworker**

[**home in on**](/home/h/home-in-on) (not hone in on)

**homeless** (adj.), **homelessness** (n.) Refers to people living on the street or staying in temporary shelters run by governments, charities, etc., rather than to individuals moving frequently to stay employed (e.g., migrant workers). Be clear but respectful when reporting on people without a fixed residence. Mention the detail only when relevant, and avoid stereotyping individuals as unhygienic, mentally ill, addicted to drugs or alcohol, criminals, etc. The word "homeless" is generally OK as an adjective (**homeless people**) or as an attributive noun (**people who are homeless**). But avoid using as a collective noun after the definite article (i.e., "the homeless"), which is considered dehumanizing. This is akin to how we approach reporting on [blind people, deaf people and disabled people](/home/d/disability-language#the). Conversational alternatives include "people without homes," "people without housing," "people living in shelters" and "people living on the street," depending on a given story's facts. Do not use stigmatizing or pejorative labels to characterize homelessness (e.g., bum, beggar, hobo, tramp). Outside of directly transcribed quotes, **generally avoid the comparatively obscure word houseless**, which is less inclusive (ignoring millions of tenants who live in apartments, condos, etc.), and less clear to our audience than homeless. While some activists argue that a pitched tent or other place of shelter can be enjoyed as a "home" under the right circumstances, that reality does not, in itself, alter the conventional meaning of the term "homeless." **The nouns camp and encampment are both common and OK** when describing parks, sidewalks and other public land where people have pitched tents and started living for extended periods. Such usage is similar to compounds like "refugee camp," coined in the 1860s. Many human rights groups and public housing advocates use the terms **homeless camp** and **homeless encampment** neutrally. The language is also found in various government documents, including [Action Canada's 2023 report Tent Nation](https://actioncanada.ca/publications/tent-nation-responding-to-the-rise-of-housing-encampments-the-homelessness-crisis-in-canada/).

**honour killing** (use with caution and a qualifier) Avoid this term unless it's introduced as a "so-called honour killing" (in a web headline, quotation marks are sufficient to convey this point). Then make sure the meaning is clear in the story, either based on the details presented or by a brief definition. "Honour killings" are normally murders committed because of patriarchal concepts of honour and shame. They're considered gender-based crimes, since girls and women are usually the victims. People in some cultures either encourage or tolerate the practice, so the term has gradually become part of everyday speech. Using it conveys a lot of information about a type of death and helps our audience understand a story better. But since there's nothing honourable about the killings, the adjective [so-called](/home/s/so-called) is mandatory. Avoid overuse of "honour killings" within a story, and continue to qualify the term throughout the piece to make it clear that the language is disputed and controversial.

**hormone therapy** (**HT**) Spell out in first reference. Avoid the longer, now-dated label "hormone replacement therapy" (abbreviated as HRT) outside of transcribed clips. Hormone therapy falls into two broad categories: Adding hormones (e.g., estrogen, progestin, testosterone) or blocking/changing hormone production/behaviour. Potential health risks are well-documented (e.g., blood clots, stroke, heart disease, cancer). The term hormone therapy often implies treatment for menopausal symptoms. But since there are other reasons people undergo HR (e.g., to assist gender transition, to try to slow the spread of cancer), it's often clearest to add a relevant modifier in first reference (e.g., **menopausal hormone therapy, transgender hormone therapy**). Another option is to use a conversational, descriptive phrase that applies to a given story ("hormone therapy for women entering menopause").

### hail versus hale

**Hail versus hale**

These words sometimes cause confusion.

**Hail can mean a variety of things,** including frozen pellets from the sky (_“the rain turned into hail”_) and a barrage (_“a hail of bullets”_). As a verb, it can mean to shower (_“hailed abuse at them”_), to signal (_“hail a cab”_), to proclaim or commend (_“hailed her a success”_), to come from (_“he hails from the Maritimes”_) and to greet or communicate with (_“within hailing distance”_).

**Hale normally means healthy** (as in the expression _“hale and hearty”_). As a verb, it refers to dragging forcibly (“haled them into court”), although this form of the word is archaic and will probably be read as a typo by many people. In these cases, you’re better off writing “hauled” or picking a different word.

The expression _“hail fellow well met”_ is commonly misspelled as “hale,” since the latter means robust. The fellow described is someone who is easy to get along with, not someone who is well.

See also homonyms

### half-mast

**Half-mast versus half-staff**

**Use the term "half-mast" to describe flags lowered after someone's death.** This preference was adopted by CBC News decades ago.

When Ottawa orders flags lowered, the term "half-mast" is used. This expression is part of the Canadian Heritage Department's official [flag etiquette](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fcanada.pch.gc.ca%2Feng%2F1444133232495&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3LhGou9NOaZeSsPnNfJjpU), which covers everything from the correct way to drape a casket with the Maple Leaf to the right way to dispose of worn out flags.

Most Americans use the term "half-staff." This wording is also found in the United States official "Flag Code" (Title 4, Chapter 1, Section 7, Subsection M).

As with [railway](/home/r/railway-versus-railroad) (instead of "railroad"), and [witness box](/home/c/canadian-court-terms) (instead of "witness stand"), "half-mast" is considered the "Canadian" choice by many people in this country. See also [military terms](/home/m/military-terms-overview) for other Canadian preferences and related language, as well as [funerals](/home/f/funerals).


**Mast**
**The word "mast" does not automatically imply ships.** According to British and North American dictionaries, there is evidence that it is tied to a Latin word for "stake" (_palus_), an Irish word for "club" (_maite_), and an Indo-European expression for "rod" (_mazdos_). Some lexicographers believe it may also have roots in an old term for "timber."

The Oxford English Dictionary points out that people have been calling tall poles on land masts for more than 350 years — from towers that guide travellers in the mountains to those that support telegraph wires and broadcasting equipment.

For a longer discussion, see the November 2000 Words: Woe & Wonder column, [Flap over Half-Mast](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews2%2Findepth%2Fwords%2Fflagflap.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3BqDGsVj48SMzgKMMpv4dR).

### health\_reporting

**Health reporting** (diseases, medical conditions, etc.)

**Core journalistic principles govern health reporting**, including **how we refer to diseases, illnesses, disorders** and other medical conditions:


[3\. Clarity](/home/h/health_reporting#clarity) (e.g., translate/explain jargon)
[4\. Respect](/home/h/health_reporting#respect) (e.g., some patients object to certain words, like 'battling' and 'survivor')

**In addition, some specific guidelines apply:**

[5\. JSP policy](/home/h/health_reporting#JSP) (e.g., handling medical research)
[6\. CBC News publishing style](/home/h/health_reporting#typography) (e.g., capitalization and other typography)

The rest of this entry expands on the above points.


**1\. Relevance**
**Avoid referring to a person's medical condition** (physical and mental) **unless it's relevant to a given story.** Why are we reporting that someone has hepatitis B, uses hearing aids, is colour blind, needs a wheelchair to get around, etc.? Even when directly relevant, certain information can be highly personal. So pause to weigh all applicable privacy concerns against any clear, public (societal) value of reporting such details.


**2\. Accuracy**
**Use medical terms correctly. If you're not sure what something means, double-check.** Imprecision can lead to confusion and inaccuracy. For instance, [diagnosis and prognosis](/home/d/diagnosis-versus-prognosis) have specific meanings. So do words like [endemic, epidemic and pandemic](/home/e/endemic-epidemic-pandemic), as well as [confirmed versus presumptive](/home/c/confirmed_presumptive_tests). And always take the time to corroborate key facts (e.g., since [bacteria and viruses](/home/b/bacteria-versus-virus) are different, we need to be careful when covering diseases like meningitis, which can be bacterial or viral). Even generic terms that may normally be treated as synonyms might require care in certain contexts to avoid confusion (e.g., the FDA's distinction between [emergency "authorization" versus routine "approval"](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/i/immunization-vaccination/#authorize-vs-approve "Immunization vaccination")). **Be aware that certain common terms sometimes have different meanings in medicine. In daily journalism, however, conventional definitions generally suffice.** This includes some colloquial English words rooted in medicine and science. For instance, while "jaundice" literally describes obstructed bile ducts and other liver disorders, being "jaundiced" also figuratively means bitterness and envy. And while "phobia" and "mania" have narrow, technical meanings in medicine (i.e., a "morbid, incapacitating fear" and an "excited madness," respectively), the same words have entrenched, acceptable meanings in other contexts (e.g., "irrational fear" and "passionate desire," respectively). The compounds [self-quarantine and self-isolation](/home/q#quarantine) are usually OK as synonyms for the same reason. See also [disease, disorder, illness](/home/d/disease_illness).


**3\. Clarity**
**Define unfamiliar terms in understandable English.** It's pointless to be accurate but incomprehensible. **Sometimes, explanations are built-in.** For example, if a researcher refers to something being "asymptomatic" and the context makes the term's meaning clear (i.e., showing no symptoms), we can generally leave the clip or quote as-is without risk of confusion. **At other times, however, the highfalutin stuff should be translated into plain English** (e.g., "pathophysiological" means "abnormal changes to the body"). This includes the formal names of certain medical conditions and procedures (e.g., prefer "clogged arteries" over "atherosclerosis," "taking a blood sample" over performing a "phlebotomy," and "brain freeze" or "ice cream headache" over "sphenopalatine ganglioneuralgia"). **Certain abbreviations are so familiar it's unnecessary to spell them out** (e.g., we simply say DNA instead of "deoxyribonucleic acid"). Other proper nouns, meanwhile, are defined by common synonyms (e.g., ALS is also known as Lou Gehrig's disease). Of course, it can be helpful to explain that ALS is a neurodegenerative condition that affects nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord. But it's generally valueless to spell it out as "amyotrophic lateral sclerosis," unless you're working on, say, an in-depth medical feature on different types of sclerosis.


**4\. Respect**
**When referring to people by name, we should take into account any objections they may have to certain wording.** For instance, **some patients strongly oppose active, descriptive participles like "fighting" or "battling" a disease** for various reasons (e.g., they say combat terminology can suggest that those who die are "losers"). **They also object to words like "victim" and "hero,"** pointing out that some terms can unintentionally imply self-pity or falsely equate medical treatment with altruistic courage. **And they dislike labels like "survivor"** (e.g., a "cancer survivor"), because such words appear to ignore the reality of remission and recurrence. **While we should try to respect known preferences when reporting on specific individuals, we do not ban these conventional expressions across the board.** For starters, many patients proudly talk about trying to "beat" a disease, to "fighting" to spend as much time as possible with loved ones, to "standing up" to cancer, to being "survivors," etc. So there's no consensus over what's appropriate. Furthermore, certain war-like wording is deeply entrenched in medicine (e.g., cells "attacking" other cells, a body's immune system "fighting" an infection). **Nevertheless, be aware that some language surrounding disease is potentially controversial.** At a minimum, we should make an effort to adhere to rudimentary principles of respect when reporting on specific patients. **The simplest approach is to prefer neutral, fact-based constructions** (e.g., they have cancer, she is undergoing treatment for leukemia, he had surgery to remove a brain tumour in 2010).


**5\. JSP policy**
**All applicable [JSP guidelines](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fio.cbcrc.ca%2F%23%2Fresources%2Fscience-and-health-science-et-sante-1.4523552&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw12PF893kltGX46gsTl5iTd) apply, including the way we cover scientific studies and medical research** — from identifying known sponsors of drug trials, health papers, etc., to reporting the true implications of results clearly and responsibly. Among other things, this means we avoid arousing unfounded hopes or fears among patients and their loved ones.


**6\. CBC News publishing style**
**For consistency, follow in-house typography** (e.g., [AIDS](/home/a/aids) is spelled out lowercase as acquired immune deficiency syndrome, Down syndrome and Alzheimer's disease are both capitalized but only one has a possessive apostrophe, and "tumour" is spelled "-our" while "tumorous" is "-or"). **Also, adhere to standard English usage.** For example, do not add the word "surgery" or "operation" after medical procedures ending in "-ectomy," such as appendectomy, hysterectomy , tonsillectomy and vasectomy, since these are already implied by the noun's suffix, and differentiate between "cardiac arrest" (a stopped heart) and a "heart attack" (heart muscle damage), which may or may not lead to cardiac arrest.

See also [disease, disorder, illness, etc.](/home/d/disease_illness)
See also [death (general reporting guidelines)](/home/d/death-general-guidelines)

### Hispanic\_Latino

**Hispanic, Latino, Mexican, etc.**

[Genderless caveat](/home/h/hispanic_latino#genderless-caveat) (Avoid Latina, Latinx, etc.)



**Relevance, accuracy**

**Do not include details about ethnic or cultural backgrounds unless relevant to a given story, whether specific** (Mexican, Cuban, Chilean, Nicaraguan) **or general** (Hispanic, Caribbean, South American, Central American). In features, biographical information is often OK as part of a routine sketch or profile. But in other news coverage, such personal background must be demonstrably tied to the story.

**Be careful not to confuse terminology.** For example, **Hispanic, Latino and Mexican are ethnic descriptions rather than racial labels.** "Ethnicity" refers to nationality, language, regional culture, etc., while "race" is an overused and sometimes hotly debated word that refers to physical features, such as skin colour. (See [Black, white and related racial terms](/home/r/racial-terms) for details)


**Hispanic**

**Hispanic** (plural **Hispanics**) — **Not gender specific.** Conventionally refers to people with Spanish roots, or to **people from Spanish-speaking countries, who are not actually Spanish (i.e., who are not from Spain)**. This includes millions of people in parts of South America, Central America and the Caribbean. **Avoid misidentifying countries as Hispanic.** For instance, Venezuela is classified as Hispanic while Brazil is not because the latter country's official language is Portuguese.


**Latino**

**Latino** (plural **Latinos**) — **Not gender specific in English**. Broadly describes **citizens of Latin America or people with Latin American roots**. Latin America, in turn, is **a sweeping label that includes all countries in central and southern part of the Western Hemisphere where Romance languages are predominately spoken** (Spanish, Portuguese and French). **Avoid Latina, Latinx, etc.**, unless people refer to themselves that way. Even then, obscure neologisms like Latinx need to be defined. (See [genderless caveat](/home/h/hispanic_latino#genderless-caveat) below).

The proper noun **Latin America** was coined in the 1850s. "Latin" in this context refers to the common Latin spoken millennia ago that gave birth to several tongues still alive today, such as Spanish in Puerto Rico and French in Haiti. Although Quebec, St-Pierre-Miquelon and a few other spots in North America technically fall into the broadest definition of Latin America, we describe these places as francophone, instead.


**Mexican**

**Mexican** — Refers to citizens of Mexico and to their descendants living abroad. **It's potentially confusing to use the word to refer to citizens of other countries**, however, since Mexican is a standard demonym, along the lines of Brazilian, Colombian, Panamanian. **For this reason, dual heritage compounds are sometimes used** (e.g., a Mexican Canadian, a Mexican American). **Hispanic or Latino are other common options.** The upside: Hispanic and Latino are more conversational than "Mexican American." The downside: They're vague, since either word could apply to people from numerous other countries. **Avoid terms like Chicano and Chicana** — which refer to U.S.-born males and females of Mexican descent, respectively — unless defined and relevant to a story (e.g., used by someone in an online quote or broadcast clip).

See also [geographical demonyms](/home/r/racial-terms#geographical) for related guidelines on why hyphens are no longer used in labels like African American and Mexican Canadian.


**Genderless caveat**  (Avoid Latina, Latinx, etc.)

We write in English, not in Spanish, Portuguese or other languages. **In English, terms such as [Hispanic](/home/h/hispanic_latino#Hispanic) and [Latino](/home/h/hispanic_latino#Latino) apply to all genders.** It's no different from, say, "amigo" — which means "friend" in English, regardless of gender. Although in Spanish, "amiga" refers to female friends, this fact is irrelevant when reporting in English. The terms "amigo" and "amigos" apply across the board, regardless of gender.

**Be aware that some activists consider "Latino" sexist**, and have campaigned to replace it with various neologisms, such as Latinx and Latin@. **But this push to ban Latino is contested for several reasons:**

-   Many people still call themselves Latino.
-   Most of our audience is unfamiliar with coinages like "Latinx" and "Latin@," which look like typos.
-   There's no consensus over pronunciation of proposed alternatives like Latinx and Latin@.

Furthermore, **the crux of the complaint is that the word "Latino" is masculine in Spanish. But so are countless other words in Romance languages, including French**. And opening that door would require a rudimentary restructuring of those tongues — far beyond the scope of an English news service.

At the end of the day, **many foreign terms are swallowed up by English and used in ways that are different from the original language**. For instance, the Latin word "alumnus" now means any graduate of a school, regardless of gender, just as Latino means anyone from Latin America, regardless of gender. **We steer clear of the gender-specific word "alumna"** (plural "alumnae") **to identify female graduates, just as we normally avoid the gender-specific "Latina"** (plural "Latinas") **to mean women and girls from Latin America**. Exceptions are when people describe themselves as Latina (e.g., in directly transcribed quotes).

### HMCS

**HMCS**

The initials stand for **Her Majesty's Canadian Ship.**

**Never put "the" in front of it**, or you end up with "the Her Majesty's."

> **HMCS Iroquois**, _not_ the HMCS Iroquois
>
> **HMCS Athabaskan**, _not_ HMCS Athabaskan
>
> _but_ **the Iroquois, the Athabaskan**, etc., is acceptable _on second reference_


Be careful to get the spelling correct (e.g., **HMCS Protecteur** _not_ Protector).

The [Defence Department's website](https://www.canada.ca/en/navy/corporate/fleet-units.html) lists the names of Canada's fleet (frigates, destroyers, and so forth), along with other details about each type and class of craft.

**Use the pronoun it** (possessive its) **for all inanimate objects, including ships**, planes, guns, etc. (See [problems with pronouns](/home/p/problems-with-pronouns) for details.)

See also [military forces](/home/m/military-forces), as well as [boat versus ship](/home/b/boat-versus-ship).
