### home in on

**Home in on**

Write **home in on** (_not_ "hone in" on).

The expression means finding a target. This is what homing pigeons and radars do.

Since “hone” means to sharpen, “home in” is sometimes spelled “hone in.”

We sharpen things, but we don’t generally talk about sharpening _in_ on them. For consistency and logic, use the original spelling.

### homicide

**Homicide**

**All murders are homicides but not all homicides are murder.** Do not use these words interchangeably.

Also, **do not assume all homicide investigators are _detectives_.** Use this title only if it applies.

The term **homicide refers to the death of one person by another.**

There are **two types: culpable and not culpable.**


**Not culpable**
**Homicide that is _not culpable_ is not a crime.**

Common examples are when the killer acted in self-defence or when the death was accidental and did not involve negligence.

In news stories, the term “not culpable” is unnecessarily technical. Instead, we prefer to use **simpler but equally accurate language** (e.g., “no charges were laid because investigators said the death was an accident.”)


**Culpable**
**Homicide that is culpable is a crime.** In other words, **there is no legal justification for the killing.**

Common charges are murder and manslaughter.

**Murder** in the broadest sense means to intentionally kill someone, or to willfully cause serious bodily harm without caring if the person might die. The key is intent.

**Manslaughter** describes an unlawful death that is not murder or infanticide. This usually means the killing was either (a) illegal but unintentional or (b) committed “in the heat of passion caused by sudden provocation,” to quote the Criminal Code.

**Set aside most '-icides'**
**Generally avoid neologisms or established but relatively obscure terms** such as **femicide** (killing a woman), **fratricide** (killing a sibling), **matricide** (killing one’s mother), **patricide** (killing one’s father), etc., unless attributed. Even then, the word may need to be defined unless the meaning is obvious from context. **Infanticide**, however, is a Criminal Code charge. It is laid against a mother who kills her newborn child under certain conditions.


**Mass murder**
While **there's no single definition of "mass murder,"** in routine crime reporting **CBC News normally uses the term for cases involving four or more homicides by the same killer(s) within a small geographical area in a relatively short span of time** (measured in hours rather than days). This distinguishes "mass murder" from [serial killing](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/s/#serialkiller "S"), and makes it more precise than the comparatively vague label [massacre](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/m/#massacre "M"). Several law enforcement agencies commonly define "mass murder" the same way, including the FBI.

**We use different language for fewer than four fatalities** (e.g., **homicide, double homicide, triple homicide**). Since most people do not routinely talk or write about quadruple homicides, quintuple homicides, etc., however, we and many other news organizations generally turn to imprecise but conversational compound nouns like "mass murder" when covering such crimes. (See [**mass shooting**](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/m/mass-shooting/ "Mass shooting") for related guidelines.)


**Murder versus murder charges**
**In news stories, generally do not describe specific killings as “murder” until there’s a verdict.** It’s normally up to the courts to determine what's a murder. **Instead, prefer the exact charges** (i.e., first- or second-degree murder). **Exceptions are deaths that are undoubtedly murder based on indisputable evidence** — such as a mass shooting or videotaped killings that are verified and unambiguous — **as well as stories about general trends**, including the RCMP's investigation into missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls ([MMIWG](/home/m#MMIWG)) in Canada. In other words, when a specific case is before the courts, it’s always OK to write that someone is accused of murdering a victim, but we usually avoid referring to the killing itself as a murder until after the verdict. The crime may turn out to be manslaughter or the accused may be acquitted. After trials end, **be aware that verdicts do not automatically govern our choice of language** when the facts are obvious. Consider the 2008 decapitation and cannibalization of a Greyhound bus passenger near Portage la Prairie, Man. The 22-year-old victim was viciously assaulted, and the fact that the accused was eventually found not criminally responsible because of mental illness does not mean it's misleading or inaccurate to describe the killing, itself, as "murder." The infamous 1955 lynching of a Black teenager in Mississippi is another example. Emmett Till was kidnapped and savagely killed hours after being accused of whistling at a white woman. Although an all-white jury acquitted two white men of homicide, Emmett Till's death, itself, can be unequivocally called "murder."

**The same principle may apply to the word "killing" versus "death," depending on the facts** (e.g., an autopsy may determine that someone died of natural causes, despite suspicious circumstances). **But when there's strong evidence of homicide** (e.g., verified cellphone video showing a suspect being beaten unconscious by police), **the term "killing" is often fine because the case usually boils down to a question of culpability rather than to a determination of "homicide."** If you have any doubts, consult your supervisor or the CBC Law Department.

In Canada, you're automatically sentenced to life in prison when convicted of either first- or second-degree murder. The major difference is the amount of time you must serve before being eligible to _apply_ for parole.

### Hong Kong

**Hong Kong**

Hong Kong is no longer a British territory. On July 1, 1997 it became **a Special Administrative Region of China**. It retains a degree of self-government with a separate, but not entirely independent, political system. Hong Kong can be described as a **semi-autonomous region** with a **limited democracy** and a **free market economy**.

It’s officially known as the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China. But we don’t have to use the full name. **Hong Kong** is fine in first reference. **Prefer the term region** as a generic label. **Generally avoid calling it a territory**, which has echoes of its former status under British rule.

Residents are commonly known as either **Hong Kong citizens** or **Hong Kongers**. The entrenched spelling, Hong Konger, is found in the Canadian Oxford Dictionary. Avoid fusing, which is comparable to writing "Novascotian" or "Newzealander." For consistency, **avoid competing demonyms like "Hongkongese."** The latter is not a local preference. For instance, the Hong Kong Public Research Institute uses "Hong Kongers" rather than "Hongkongese" in English translations of its surveys. While there's no tidy rule about suffix choices in cases like this, "-er" is found in numerous other proper nouns (e.g., Winnipegger, Londoner and New Yorker).


**Background**

Under the 1997 agreement ending a century and a half of British control, Hong Kong’s existing economic, legal and social system will be maintained for 50 years. China, however, makes decisions about defence and foreign affairs.

Hong Kong is made up of more than a dozen districts spread out over several big peninsulas and mountainous islands, as well as numerous small islands. **When reporting on Hong Kong's dense, urban centre, it's an entrenched, acceptable convention to use the word city** (e.g., "pro-democracy marches in the city," and "one of the world's wealthiest cities"), even though Hong Kong is not, technically, the name of any single municipality. **In most contexts, however, the term region is probably a better choice**, especially when referring to overall government structure — which includes a chief executive (who is the appointed head government), as well as an elected president who presides as speaker over the Hong Kong Legislative Council.

For more information, see the government of [Hong Kong’s official website](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.gov.hk%2Fen%2Fabout%2Fabouthk%2Ffacts.htm&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw27awUpD5XISk1fvwVTtHQ-)



### House

**House versus house**

**Capitalize the generic word "house" when referring to the House of Commons in either Canada or Britain, as well as to Canadian provincial legislatures that use House in their names:**

House of Commons
the House
the Commons
House leader Cheryl Krawchuk (federal)
Newfoundland and Labrador House of Assembly
House leader John Bowman (provincial)

Although the Commons is also informally known as "the lower chamber" and "the lower house" (no capital letters), prefer the more widely used synonym "the House," which takes an initial cap.

The Senate is sometimes informally called "the **upper chamber**" and "the **upper house**." In daily news stories, however, generally restrict this use to directly transcribed quotes unless the meaning is immediately clear.

See also [legislative bodies](/home/l/legislative-bodies)

### Hudson Bay

**Hudson Bay versus Hudson's Bay**

**Water**
**They sailed into Hudson Bay** (_not_ Hudson’s Bay).

Use **the bay** (not “the Bay”) **in second reference**.

When referring to water, capitalize "Bay" only if used with a specific title (e.g., the Bay of Fundy).

Technically Hudson Bay is an epicontinental sea, not a bay, connected to the Atlantic Ocean by Hudson Strait and to the Arctic Ocean by Foxe Channel. But we can use “the bay” in second reference.


**Store**
**They bought blankets from the Hudson's Bay store.**

They found bargains at **the Bay**. (This is an acceptable abbreviation for the **Hudson's Bay Company** in headlines and throughout general news stories.)

For business stories, however, "**Hudson's Bay Co.**" is preferred in first reference, with either **HBC** or **the Bay** acceptable after that.

They like to shop at the **Hudson's Bay Centre**.

_Mnemonic tip_: You buy possessions from a store, not a body of water. The store (the Bay) has the possessive apostrophe (Hudson's Bay).

### Hunger strike

**Hunger strike**

There's **no single, universally accepted definition** of hunger strike.

The Canadian Oxford Dictionary describes a hunger strike as "the refusal of food as a form of protest."

**The term generally suggests no solid food, and no liquids with significant nutrition, but a broader, connotative meaning is sometimes acceptable.** Historically, some famous hunger strikers have also consumed salt, sugar and vitamins to prolong their lives.

When covering these protests, **it's helpful to report specific detail to put a given hunger strike in context**. For instance, "She has been living on water, tea, vitamins and fish broth for the past six weeks."

Descriptions such as "consuming only liquids" are OK when accurate. But since they can imply juice and other drinks, it's normally better to specify known details. **Avoid awkward constructions such as "liquids-only diet,"** especially in broadcast scripts.

If protesters are ingesting puréed soups and other blended food with significant nutritional content, they are not on a hunger strike. Their bodies may hunger for solid food they're accustomed to, but that's not the same thing.

Prolonged hunger strikes can put the lives of the protesters at stake, even when they're consuming a bit of broth and vitamins. When there's room in stories, it's helpful to supply this context by interviewing doctors or other medical personnel.

**The verb "fast" has a range of meanings.** It can refer to abstaining from all or merely from some kinds of food and drink. **"Fasting"** is commonly tied to religious observances or preparations for medical procedures.

### Hydro versus power

**Hydro versus power**

"Hydro" means "electricity" in some parts of Canada (hydro bills, hydro poles, hydro lines). It's short for hydroelectricity — energy generated by turbines powered by moving water (also known as hydro power).

**Since hydro is a regionalism, using it in stories in certain parts of the country jolts some people.** They either aren't familiar with the word in that context or consider it inaccurate because most of their electricity comes from a source other than water (e.g., coal-fired plants). They're quick to point that while all hydro poles are power poles not all power poles are hydro poles.

**If you're sure hydro is the correct regionalism** (e.g., Quebec and Ontario), **use the word without hesitation. But if you're referring to another part of the country in your story, check first.** Don't automatically rewrite the local term (e.g., "power pole") simply because you're more familiar with the word "hydro."

**TIP:** Unlike "hydro," the generic word "power" and the specific term "electricity" and its derivatives (e.g., "electrical") are accurate and well-known across the country ("The car hit a power pole" and "The apartment had no electricity"). The term "utility" is broader than power, covering cable and phone lines as well (e.g., a "utility pole").

### I versus me

**I versus me**

**The personal pronouns _I_ and me are relatively straightforward. But there are a few pitfalls**, outlined after the brief review of subjective and objective forms below.

['Between you and me'](/home/i/i-versus-me#prepositions) (prepositions can confuse) 

**Subjective versus objective forms**
**"I" is known as a subjective** (sometimes called nominative) **pronoun. This simply means that it's the subject of the sentence's verb**, such as _walk_ below. (Who did the walking? "I" did.)


> **I** walked past him.


**"Me" is known as an objective** (sometimes called accusative) **pronoun. This simply means that it's the object of the sentence's verb**, such as _ran_ below.


> She ran past **me**.
>

**Subjective**

**Objective**

I

me

you

you

he

him

she

her

it

it

we

us

they

them


NOTE: The terms _subjective_ and _objective_ are generally preferred in modern discussions of English grammar, since the old Latin labels _nominative_ and _accusative_ have extra meanings normally reserved for other languages. For instance, _accusative_ refers to the indirect object of a verb (e.g., "mich" in German), while _dative_ refers to the direct objective of a verb (e.g., "mir" in German). In English, however, there's no difference between direct and indirect objectives of a verb (e.g., "mich" and "mir" both mean "me"). The personal pronoun "me," therefore, is labelled objective in all cases.


**Where's the verb?**
**If a pronoun appears before a verb, it takes the subjective form.**


> Betty and **I** (not _me_) **received** free copies.


When in doubt, substitute another pronoun to see whether the correct form is subjective ("I") or objective ("me").


> **He** (not _him_) and Betty **received** free copies.


**'Between you and me'** (prepositions can confuse)
**When the pronoun in question appears after a preposition** (e.g., _from, to, between, before, with, against_), **it takes the objective form.**

Most people pick the right word automatically when there's only one pronoun:


> They'll be hearing **from me** (not _from I_).
>
> I'll be hearing **from them** (not _from they_)


**Confusion sometimes arises when more than one pronoun appears after the preposition. The rule is the same, however**, no matter how many pronouns are in a cluster. Simply use the objective form after a preposition governing the pronoun(s) in question:


> **Wrong**
>
> Between you and I, they can't dance.
>
> They gave free copies to Betty and I.
>
> **Correct (objective from after the preposition)**
>
> **Between you and me**, they can't dance.
>
> They gave free copies **to Betty and me**.


What's behind this common mistake? Grammarians think writers become accustomed to a cluster of subjective pronouns before verbs (e.g., "You and I danced," "Betty and I cried"), and automatically retain the subjective form when confronted by other strings of pronouns. **TIP: To avoid the error, always consider whether a given pronoun appears _before_ a verb or _after_ a preposition.**

**Axe words you don't need**
**Sometimes sentences are shorter and more natural when certain prepositions and pronouns are deleted.** Get rid of anything unnecessary.


> **Correct (BUT wordy and awkward)
> **
>
> Many of us (not _we_) voters are fed up with broken promises.
>
> Few among them (not _they_) inside agreed to talk.
>
> **Better (with prepositions/pronouns cut)**
>
> **Many voters** are fed up with broken promises
>
> **Few inside** agreed to talk.


**In other cases, keeping the preposition but combining two pronouns into one** (e.g., "him and me" = "us") **is the best solution.**


> **Correct (BUT wordy and awkward)**
>
> For him and me, the library was more fun than the amusement park.
>
> **Better (with a plural pronoun replacing him and me)**
>
> **For us**, the library was more fun than the amusement park.


**'More than I/me'**
**If "than" is used as a conjunction** (i.e., as a connecting word such as _and_ or _but_) **to introduce a full clause** (i.e., a group of words with its own subject and verb), **use the subjective form** (e.g., _he_ or _I_).


> Bob's dog weighs **more than I** do.
>
> They liked the film **more than he** did.


**TIP:** When the verb is dropped and "than" is treated as a preposition, it's widely acceptable to use the objective form (e.g., him or me):


> **Technically correct but overly formal**
>
> Bob's dog weighs more than I.
>
> They went to the zoo more than he.
>
> **OK as long as the meaning is unambiguous**
>
> Bob's dog weighs **more than me.**
>
> They went to the zoo **more than him.**


**WARNING:** "More than" comparisons can be tricky, and **the choice of a personal pronoun sometimes changes a sentence's meaning:**


> "She loves cake more than I" means she loves cake more than I do.
>
> "She loves cake more than me" means she loves cake more than she loves me.


**Make certain there's no ambiguity. If something is unclear, recast accordingly.** This often involves reintroducing the dropped verb: "She loves cake more than I do."


**'It is I/me'**
For years, grammarians have insisted on the subjective form (e.g., _I_) of any pronoun that's linked to a "to be" verb (e.g., is, are, was), even if the pronoun comes after this verb.

> **Grammatical but very formal**
>
> It is I. (It is I who called.)
>
> That is he. (That is he in the police lineup.)


But **in a triumph of conversational English over unnecessarily stilted structure, the objective form is now considered perfectly acceptable after a "to be" verb:
**

> **OK and far more common and natural**
>
> It is me.
>
> That's him, officers.


Some traditionalists dismiss this more colloquial approach as ungrammatical. Since it's wrong to write "Me is it" or "Him is the one," they argue that it's equally wrong to put the objective form (e.g., "me" or "him") later in the same sentence.

**If you're uncomfortable with the correct but highly formal construction** (e.g., "It is I"), **but want to avoid criticism from some quarters for the informal and sometimes disputed version** (e.g., "It is me"), **simply recast the sentence** with the subjective form of the pronoun before the verb:


> **I am** the person.
>
> **He's** the one, officers.

**In fact, a lot of roundabout writing can be improved by using a different pronoun at the start.** When a sentence begins with what amounts to a "false subject" (e.g., "It was ..." or "There are ..."), moving the displaced or "real" subject to the beginning produces a shorter and clearer construction:


> **She was** rescued (rather than, "It was she who was rescued").
>
> **He jogged** with her (rather than, "It is she whom he jogged with").
>
> **I flew** over them (rather than, "It is they whom I flew over").
>
> **Some buildings have** only one exit (rather than "There are some buildings that ...").


For more on subjective/objective pronouns, see [who versus whom](/home/w/who-versus-whom)

For general caveats, see [pronouns (common problems)](/home/p/problems-with-pronouns)
See [grammar](/handy-links/grammar) for a list of common topics (e.g., split infinitives and prepositions at the end of sentences)

### illegal\_immigration

**Illegal immigration, illegal immigrant**

The term **illegal immigration** broadly refers to the act of entering or living in a country without legal authority. The term **illegal immigrant** conventionally describes a person who enters or lives in a country without legal authority.

While both compounds are common, **be aware that some object to the term illegal immigrant.** They say it wrongly labels people as "illegal," rather than identifying the unsanctioned acts they're accused of as illegal (e.g., crossing a border or living in a country without permission). For this reason, AP banned the wording in 2013.

**We do not automatically prohibit use of "illegal immigrant."** The same approach is taken by several other news organizations, including the New York Times and the BBC. The compound illegal immigrant, coined in the 1930s, is clear and entrenched. The construction is also standard English. For instance, a motorist without a licence is an unlicenced driver, an unlawful driver, an illegal driver (emphasis on person), as well as a motorist who is driving without a licence or who is driving illegally (emphasis on action).

**But when describing people** rather than acts, **the shorthand "illegal immigrant" is often not the best choice. Alternatives can be considered when deemed appropriate** (e.g., **undocumented worker)**, although certain language may be too confusing or bureaucratic to serve our audience well (e.g., "unauthorized alien"). Use your judgment. **Details about people can also provide valuable context to our coverage** — from how specific individuals entered the country (e.g., overstaying a visa versus crossing a border without valid papers), to where they are from, where they have been living and working, whether they have children, and whether the children have any special legal residency status because of their age or circumstances.

**Never shorten the modifier "illegal" to a noun on its own** (e.g., avoid wording such as "an illegal" or "thousands of illegals").

See also [refugee, asylum seeker, migrant](/home/r/refugee)

### Immaculate Conception

**Immaculate Conception**

This is a label used for Mary’s conception, _not_ the virgin conception of Jesus.

It refers to the Catholic belief that Mary was conceived free from original sin, and so was absolutely sinless throughout her life.

See also [Catholic versus Roman Catholic](/home/c/catholic-roman)

### immunization, vaccination

**Immunization, inoculation, vaccination**

**These words are often treated as synonyms. There are sometimes subtle differences worth noting in certain news stories** — especially when a distinction is being made between live and dead organisms, or between a body's natural immune system and artificial treatments. **In general, however, it's perfectly acceptable to describe a _vaccination_ as an _inoculation_. They're both forms of _immunization_.** 


[vaccination](/home/i/immunization-vaccination#vaccines) (including vaccine names, terminology)


**Immunization (n), immunize (v.)**
This is the **broadest category** of the three. Immunization **simply refers to a natural or artificial process of rendering a person or animal immune to an illness.** The body may do this on its own or through a vaccination or other type of inoculation. By definition, then, **vaccination and inoculation are both forms of immunization.**


**Inoculation (n.), inoculant (n.), inoculate (v.)**
Inoculating involves **intentionally exposing a person or animal to a disease-causing agent to try to make them immune. Inoculants may or may not contain live organisms** — which is the main distinction that some epidemiologists make between inoculation and vaccination. The goal is to induce a mild case of a particular illness before a person is actually infected with a fully potent form.

When referring to specific substances, prefer the word inoculant (plural, inoculants) over _inoculum_ (plural _inocula_).



**Vaccination (n.), vaccine (n.), vaccinate (v.)**
**A vaccination is a common type of inoculation.** The goal is to stimulate the production of antibodies. Vaccinations **traditionally contained dead or modified (weakened) organisms**. In recent decades, however, **a new process has been developed using "messenger RNA" (mRNA) technology** that essentially tricks the body into neutralizing a given pathogen's threat by learning how to deal with the virus's unique protein coating. Most vaccines are still injected rather than swallowed because they lose effectiveness after passing through the digestive system. But needle-free options are sometimes available (e.g., nasal spray and skin patches). **Be aware that some vaccines require more than one dose to be effective, and that logistical hurdles can hamper rollouts** (e.g., production costs and temperature storage requirements).


**Vaccine names, terminology**
**Be clear and accurate when referring to vaccine names.** If they've been jointly developed by two or more companies, generally acknowledge this at least once in first reference (e.g., the **Pfizer-BioNTech** vaccine rather than just the "Pfizer vaccine," and **Oxford-AstraZeneca** rather than just "AstraZeneca"). However, there's **no need to adopt unnecessarily dense proper nouns when one company is owned by another** (e.g., in COVID-19 coverage, the **Johnson & Johnson vaccine** became a common and acceptable name for the **Janssen vaccine**, since Janssen Pharmaceuticals Inc. is actually a subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson). NOTE: **In HEADLINES, it's OK to use only one name** (Pfizer) or to lean on recognizable abbreviations (J&L) because of space constraints.

**Sometimes rebranding occurs.** During the summer of 2021, for example, three companies introduced new names for their COVID-19 vaccines. **Using such rebrandings is optional and depends in part on how widely they're adopted.** One gauge is whether public health authorities embrace the names. **Until new proper nouns become common, it's important to add brief definitions or explanations** so our audience knows what we're talking about:


> **Comirnaty** (from Pfizer-BioNTech)
>
> **Spikevax** (from Moderna)
>
> **Vaxzevria** (from Oxford-AstraZeneca)


**Be precise when using terminology by regulators and other public health officials when generic usage might cause confusion.** In the U.S., for example, the FDA distinguishes between the nouns "**authorization**" and "**approval**," as well as between the related verbs ("**authorize**" and "**approve**"). The former (authorization) applies to "emergency use" during a public health crisis, such as a pandemic, while the latter (approval) applies to the everyday process of collecting and assessing data from routine trials of drugs and other medical treatments. **Since many in our audience will not be familiar with these narrow distinctions, it's generally best to add a relevant modifier** (e.g., "emergency") **to the story when applicable** to underscore the difference (e.g., "**emergency authorization**" versus routine "approval").

The term **"unvaccinated" conventionally refers to people who have not been given any vaccination** against a specific disease. To avoid ambiguity, **use modifiers such as "partially" and "fully" when reporting on vaccinations requiring more than one dose** (e.g., "fully vaccinated against COVID-19"). The level of protection a given individual has after being vaccinated depends in part on the vaccine, the person's immune system, the virulence of mutating virus strains and the passage of time. **Keep in mind that booster shots are sometimes needed** to maintain protection against various diseases (e.g., tetanus and diphtheria but not polio). **Differentiate between booster shots** for the general population long after the initial vaccines are administered **and ordinal dosages administered during the initial vaccination period** (i.e., second doses, third doses). In a nutshell, **the expression "booster shot" conventionally refers to "revaccination" rather than to supplementary initial doses.** During the COVID-19 pandemic, for instance, some Canadians were advised to get "third doses" (also known as "additional doses") by public health authorities because they had compromised immunize systems. Calling these third doses "booster shots" was confusing and technically inaccurate, the experts said.

See also: [anti-vaccination](/home/a/anti-vaccination), [coronavirus](/home/c/coronavirus), [flu](/home/f/flu) (including guidelines on H1N1 influenza), [bacteria versus virus](/home/b/bacteria-versus-virus) (including guidelines on terms such as non-adjuvant vaccine), [epidemic versus pandemic](/home/e/endemic-epidemic-pandemic), as well as general [health reporting guidelines](/home/h/health_reporting) (an overview).

### impaired\_driving

**Impaired driving, not DUI**

**Avoid the U.S.-based term DUI** ("driving under the influence") **when referring to allegations against motorists in Canada**, specific charges laid in Canada, etc. **Even in generic contexts, the Canadian expression impaired driving is usually preferred** (e.g., "His driving skills were so poor he appeared to be in a constant state of impairment" rather than "His driving skills were so poor he appeared to be in a constant DUI state").

**Reserve DUI for specific U.S. contexts**, such as charges laid south of the border.

The compound "impaired driving" was coined around 1950, when the Criminal Code of Canada was amended to include the new offence, according to the 1967 Dictionary of Canadianisms on Historical Principles. The first impaired driver convicted under the new law was an Ontario man who paid a fine of $50 in July 1951.

See also [Canadian court terms](/home/c/canadian-court-terms)

### Indigenous

**Indigenous - First Nation, Métis, Inuit**

[Indigenous](/home/i/Indigenous#indigenousaboriginal) (First Nations people, Inuit and Métis); **Use Indigenous instead of Aboriginal**
