**Indigenous** (recommended umbrella term)
Technically, the uppercase adjectives **Indigenous and Aboriginal** can be used to **refer to all First Nations people** (status and non-status Indians), **Inuit and Métis in Canada.** Although the word Aboriginal still surfaces from time to time, **Indigenous is now preferred in virtually all cases**, outside of verbatim quotes and the occasional proper nouns.

> _Indigenous_ people
>
> _Indigenous_ rights
>
> _Indigenous_ groups
>
> _Indigenous_ leaders
>
> _Indigenous_ [band](/home/i/Indigenous#singular) councils
>
> _Indigenous_ self-government
>
> _non-Indigenous_ fishermen

CBC News adopted capitalized forms (Indigenous, Aboriginal) in the spring of 2016 because the terms have become the equivalent of "proper noun modifiers" describing people, language and culture. One year later, some other Canadian news services followed suit, including CP. **Use lowercase forms only for generic wording unrelated to Indigenous people** (e.g., indigenous plants, native wildlife).


**Ensure detail is relevant**
**Avoid identifying someone as Indigenous unless the detail is relevant to the story.** For example, do not refer to "an Indigenous doctor" or "an Aboriginal man" solely because we know this detail. **A helpful test is whether you would write "white" or "female" instead of "Indigenous" or "Aboriginal" in parallel coverage involving different facts.** If not, leave out the adjective.

When pertinent, it's OK to refer to an Indigenous person's ancestry. But **prefer specific detail** (e.g., Cree, [Mi'kmaw](/home/m/mi-kmaq)) **over catch-all labels** (e.g., Indigenous) **whenever possible**, especially when referring to individuals.

> Skookum is a _Chinook_ word for impressive.
>
> It's a _Blackfoot_ custom.
>
> Two _Nisga'a_ First Nation elders want the B.C. Court of Appeal to strike down the landmark treaty.



**Indigeneity** **(Indigenous identity)**
The term **Indigeneity broadly refers to the distinct identities of Indigenous Peoples** around the world. It's commonly used by anthropologists and other academics differentiating between hundreds of millions of people who are Indigenous and billions who are non-Indigenous. In our journalism, **questions about Indigeneity primarily arise when there are disputes over whether individuals are members of a specific Indigenous community** (e.g., if they are Inuit, if they are Métis, if they are Algonquin). **Such disagreements can have sweeping consequences** over everything from community sovereignty to potential land claims as well as access to resources and government grants.


There's **no succinct, universal definition of Indigenous people** for reasons outlined on p. 6 of a [2013 UN background manual](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/media/lxkat5s5/un_indigenousrightsdeclarationmanual_2013.pdf "UN Indigenousrightsdeclarationmanual 2013") about the 2007 United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples:

_"Indigenous Peoples have argued against the adoption of a formal definition at the international level, stressing the need for flexibility and for respecting the desire and the right of each Indigenous people to define themselves…. As a consequence, no formal definition has been adopted in international law. A strict definition is seen as unnecessary and undesirable."_

Instead, **two broad principles provide direction.** The first is **self-identification** (i.e., individuals say they're Indigenous). The second is **acceptance of this identification by the specified Indigenous population**, as outlined in paragraph 381 of [Chapter 22 of the final 1983 UN report on the Study of the Problem of Discrimination Against Indigenous Populations](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/media/fbznvwko/indigeneity_un_easc_documents_mcstudy_xxi_xxii_1983_e.pdf "Indigeneity UN EASC Documents Mcstudy Xxi Xxii 1983 E") (p. 51).

Given the above, CBC journalists are encouraged to:

-   **Include attribution if someone's Indigenous identity is in dispute** (e.g., "She says she's Indigenous") as well as the reasons others contest the stated Indigeneity.
-   **Be specific about known or claimed Indigeneity at least once in a story** in order to help our audience understand the full picture (e.g., point out that someone says they're Algonquin or Mi'kmaw, rather than merely relying on the generic term Indigenous).
-   **Be balanced and fair**, distinguishing between what amounts to a disagreement between individuals (e.g., two university professors arguing over heritage) and something on a larger scale. In the latter case, **always give suitable weight** (prominence) **to statements by leaders of the Indigenous community in question**, in accordance with the UN criterion of "acceptance by the population" cited above.

In Canada, **be aware that Métis Indigeneity is at the heart of some disputes, and that it's important to present relevant background whenever practical.** For example, here's how context about an agreement between the federal government and the Métis Nation of Ontario has been presented in past CBCNews.ca coverage:

_"The Métis National Council has long said the only people who can rightfully claim to be Métis are those who are accepted by the larger community.... This definition excludes people who live east of Ontario, or those who cannot trace their roots back to an ancestor descended from a mixed European and First Nations marriage, in this area, from the 1700s onwards. But others, including the Congress of Aboriginal Peoples, have said that definition is too restrictive."_

**KEY TAKEAWAY: CBC News is not the arbiter of whether some people in Ontario have the right to call themselves Métis** in stories about deals negotiated with Ottawa. **Instead, our role is to report all relevant facts, including opposition or concerns** that a group such as the Métis National Council may express about claimed Indigeneity.

**The same approach should be taken with a group such as the NunatuKavut Community Council (NCC)**, which says it represents about 6,000 Inuit in south and central Labrador. The NCC was founded in 1981 as the Labrador Métis Nation but then changed its name to NunatuKavut in 2010, saying the latter better reflected its members' heritage. However, Inuit Tapiriit Kanatami, (ITK) which calls itself as "the national representative organization" for all Inuit in Canada, has rejected the NCC's stance as a separate Inuit body. It also disputes NunatuKavut claims of Inuit identity. **In coverage of the NCC, the ITK's position should be mentioned.** In routine stories about specific NunatuKavut people, such as a profile of a scholar or artist, use wording that's clear but respectful (e.g., instead of automatically relying on attribution, such as "who says he's Indigenous," point out that the Inuit identity of NCC members is contested by the ITK).

**Note that the word pretendian should be treated with the same caution and consideration as the word it is based on.** [See guidance considerations specific to pretendian](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/updates/2025/2025-06-03-pretendian/ "2025 06 03 - Pretendian").

See also [racialized](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/r/racial-terms/#umbrella-terms "Racial terms") for important caveats about BIPOC, and why an expression such as "people of colour" should never be confused with Indigenous identity. 

**Use Indigenous spellings of proper nouns**
Our default style is to **match the spellings of proper nouns used by Indigenous people and communities**, themselves, such as the **Kwanlin Dün First Nation** and the **Union of Nova Scotia [Mi'kmaq](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/m/mi-kmaq/ "Mi kmaq")**.

If people share their traditional names with us, these names should take precedence over English forms. This often means that the traditional name (e.g., **Wet'suwet'en Hereditary Chief Na'Moks**) would be used throughout a given story (**Na'Moks** in second reference), with the non-traditional name appearing once in brackets (**John Ridsdale**). Exceptions are cases when people choose to incorporate traditional names into non-traditional names (e.g., **Rainbow Akohserákwas Jacobs** becomes **Jacobs** in second reference). Respect individual preferences. In cases when the meaning of a traditional name is pertinent, specify the language being translated, and generally use the English version only once. For instance, if we report that **Mashkode Bizhiki'ikwe** is Ojibway for **Buffalo Woman**, we should continue to use Mashkode Bizhiki'ikwe in second and subsequent references. **Pîhtokahanapiwiyin** (the Cree name of **Chief Poundmaker**) is another example.

In geographical locations, we generally include initial capital letters to help our audience recognize the proper noun, even if lowercase lettering is used in the Indigenous language (e.g., **Kikiskitotawânawak Iskwêwak Lakes** in Saskatchewan). This makes scanning easier and eliminates the need to render lowercase non-English words in italics, along the lines of how we handle certain [French proper nouns](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/f/french-words-and-accents/#capitalization "French words and accents").

While our spellings of cities, towns, lakes, etc., normally conform to decisions made by the Geographical Names Board of Canada (GNBC), there are exceptions, including when we think an entry in the board's database is contradictory or outmoded. For instance, in early 2023 the GNBC still listed the **Mohawks of Kahnawà:ke** living on a First Nation in Quebec called "Kahnawake" instead of [**Kahnawà:ke**](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/k/#Kahnawake "K"), which is our style. **Leave out provincial or territorial locators when referring to First Nations territory** (e.g., do not put "Que." after Kahnawà:ke, the way you'd write Trois-Rivières, Que.). When geographical detail is needed for the benefit of a wider audience, lean toward alternative phrasing to help pinpoint places (e.g., **Kahnawà:ke** and **Manawan** are **among several First Nation in Quebec** advocating for better policing, and the **Peguis First Nation** is about 200 kilometres **north of Winnipeg**).

NOTE: The [federal government's geographical names database](https://geonames.nrcan.gc.ca/search-place-names/search) is reviewed and revised by the GNBC based on recommendations by provincial and territorial representatives. Its website includes background on what it says are roughly 30,000 [Indigenous place names](https://www.nrcan.gc.ca/earth-sciences/geography/indigenous-place-names/19739) across the country. In 2020, for example, Yukon's **Mount Higgins** was officially changed to the traditional Tetlit Gwich'in name of **Jùuk'an**. Just because a GNBC entry does not currently include accents in a proper noun, do not assume that this is the preference of a given Indigenous community. Instead, check the local source (e.g., a First Nation website, a tribal council directory).

**Strive to reflect Indigenous phonetics**
Although we report in English, we should try our best to reflect the **traditional pronunciation** of names and related words used by Indigenous people. **Be aware that vowel and consonant sounds, as well as syllabic stress, can vary widely** because of regional dialects.

For consistency on air, **reporters should include phonetics in broadcast scripts if the pronunciation is not already obvious**. Sometimes such spelled-out guidance is needed only during initial coverage (e.g., when some islands off Canada's West Coast were officially renamed **Haida Gwaii** in 2010, to reflect the original name used by local Indigenous people, broadcast scripts often included the phonetic "HEYE-dah GWEYE" in brackets until the proper noun became widely known).

**It can also be worthwhile to include phonetics in certain web journalism** to help our English-speaking audience learn how to pronounce unfamiliar text.

EXAMPLE 1: **Kanien’kéha** (GAH-NYEN-GEH-HAH) is the traditional name of the Mohawk language, as noted in the CBC Indigenous feature, [Original Voices](https://www.cbc.ca/originalvoices/language/kanienkeha/).

EXAMPLE 2: In 2018, a public square in front of Vancouver's Queen Elizabeth Theatre was renamed **šxʷƛ̓exən Xwtl'a7shn** (SHWOO'-t'lah-ken HOOT'-AW'-shun). The proper noun combines two First Nation languages (**Hən̓q̓əmin̓əm̓** and **Sḵwx̱wú7mesh**, respectively), spoken by three communities (the Musqueam, Squamish and Tsleil-Waututh nations), and is translated as "a place one is invited to," and "a place where one is invited to celebrate."

The phonetic for **šxʷƛ̓exən Xwtl'a7shn** comes from carefully listening to First Nation people saying the words in this [3-minute video produced by the City of Vancouver](/media/1i5f2lp0/%C5%A1x%CA%B7%C6%9B-ex%C9%99n-xwtl-a7shn_renamed-vancouver-plaza_2018.mp4). Since various symbols and diacritical markings convey specific sounds in the spellings — such as the "7," which is a glottal stop, as in "uh" — it can be a good practice to add additional detail to avoid ambiguity in the English phonetic. For instance, the CBC's chief pronunciation counsellor Laura Carlin has suggested the following tips for our phonetics here, based on a review of Indigenous community members saying the words as well as consultation with veteran broadcasters: 

**šxʷƛ̓exən** (SHWOO'-t'lah-ken)  — _The first syllable is very breathy. It's not like "shoe" but more like you're starting a whistle._
**Xwtl'a7shn** (HOOT'-AW'-shun)  — _The first syllable begins with a very breathy "H," almost like you're blowing out a candle._

**Bear in mind that phonetics can sometimes be very challenging**, depending on the original language. So **the goal is to come up with something that reasonably approximates the sound of the Indigenous proper noun or phrase** using the roman alphabet.  For consistency when spelling out sounds from any language, the [CBC Phonetics Guide](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/media/521ind0l/cbc-phonetics-legend_september-2017.pdf "CBC PHONETICS LEGEND_September-2017.pdf") is recommended.

Please remember that phonetics are pronunciation aids only, and should not be turned into modern [transliterations](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/transliterations/ "Transliterations") (i.e., English forms of the Indigenous names and words). Dozens of now entrenched English words have their roots in various Indigenous languages (e.g., **canoe, hammock, igloo, kayak, raccoon, toboggan**). Today, the original words are generally flagged with italics when cited in our journalism (e.g., **saskatoon berry** comes from the Cree word **_misâskwatômin_**). 

**Generally avoid 'Native,' plus other caveats**
**The term "Native" is largely outdated** as a synonym for Indigenous **in Canada and should be reserved for rare historical references** (e.g., directly quoting from the 1999 landmark Supreme Court decision on Indigenous fishing rights). Be aware, however, that **Native remains a common and acceptable term in some other parts of the world**, including in the U.S. (e.g., a **Native American**, and the **Native American Rights Fund**). While it's OK to use a group or individual's language of choice in these cases, **it can sometimes be preferable to paraphrase with wording more familiar to our audience** (e.g., referring to a U.S. citizen as an Indigenous artist or as an Indigenous rights lawyer). Use your judgment. **Whenever practical, specific detail should be included at some point in the story**  (e.g., a member of the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe in North Dakota). 

**Avoid using Aboriginal or Native as nouns** (e.g., Do **not** write about "Aboriginals" suing the province or about "a Native" found frozen to death).


**Avoid the clipped forms "Abo" and "Abos,"** which are classified as offensive slang by the Canadian Oxford Dictionary.

See also: [residential schools](/home/r/residential-schools) and Canada's [Truth and Reconciliation Commission](/home/t/trc)


**Capitalize foreign coverage too**
For consistency, treat "Aboriginal" and "Native" as proper noun equivalents when referring to other countries' Indigenous populations, such as Native Americans (U.S.) and Aboriginal people or Aborigines (Australia):

> In 2014, she became the first Native American woman appointed to the federal court.
>
> In 1970, Australia abandoned decades of assimilation policies and stopped forcibly removing Aboriginal people from their families.
>
> During such rituals, Aborigines play long, low-sounding wind instruments called didgeridoos.



**Indigenous Peoples**
The compound Indigenous Peoples is **a blanket term that covers all First Nations, Inuit and Métis people in Canada in a relatively formal way**. It's parallel in construction to "Aboriginal Peoples," which appears in Canada's 1982 Constitution. The wording is relatively rare in news stories. The capitalized plural "Peoples" in this context refers to a lot of separate groups, each with distinct histories and cultures, and not merely to a large number of people.

**Métis** broadly refers to descendants of people of mixed First Nations and European ancestry who share a common culture. However, there are varying definitions of what it means to be Métis and who is or isn't Métis can be contentious. In most cases, Métis citizens will be a member of a recognized Métis organization and can trace their family lineage to recognized Métis families and geographic locations

**Inuit** refers to the Indigenous people in Canada's Arctic. **Avoid the term Eskimo to describe people in Canada**, although be aware that it remains the preferred term by some citizens of Alaska. **Do not confuse Inuit with Innu**, who are members of a First Nations people in Labrador and northeastern Quebec. (See [**Inuit and Inuk**](/home/i/inuit-and-inuk) for more detailed guidelines. including why **Inuit** alone **is preferred over "Inuit people."**)


**Avoid 'Indigenous Canadians,' 'Canada's Indigenous people'**


Steer clear of wording that stresses Indigenous people's relationship with Canada over their own culture and identity. In particular, **avoid the term "Indigenous Canadian(s)" unless attributed** (e.g., when transcribing clips or quoting from documents, like a court case or government-commissioned report), or it's an Indigenous person's stated preference. **Instead, generally use alternative forms that add "Canada" as a geographical detail**, such as:


> **Indigenous people in Canada**
>
> **Indigenous and non-Indigenous people in Canada**


**Avoid possessive constructions like "Canada's Indigenous people" or implied possessive constructions like "the Indigenous people of Canada"** for the same reason. Again, a variation of "in Canada" is generally recommended (e.g., Indigenous communities in Canada). As the late writer and teacher Gregory Younging put it in the 2018 book Elements of Indigenous Style:


> _"Indigenous Peoples are independent sovereign nations that predate Euro-colonial states and are not 'owned' by Euro-colonial states. Indigenous style therefore avoids the use of possessives that imply this, such as 'Canada's Indigenous Peoples,' 'our Indigenous Peoples,' and 'the Indigenous Peoples of Canada.'"_

> > — Elements of Indigenous Style: A Guide for Writing By and About Indigenous Peoples
>
> > Appendix A: Summary of Indigenous Style Principles
>
> > Principle 12: Inappropriate Possessives (p. 103)



**First Nations, Indian**
The term **First Nations** conventionally applies to **all status and non-status Indians** in Canada. Be cautious when using the terms "status" and "non-status," however. They're potentially confusing and generally not relevant unless a story specifically deals with land claims, disagreements over funding for government services, etc.

Historically, status Indians were registered on an official list maintained by the federal government — qualifying for certain rights and payments not available to other Indigenous people in Canada, depending on the terms of applicable treaties. Under this system, non-status Indians and Métis were either never registered or were considered ineligible to register by federal officials. But disputes over interpretation of treaties and of "status" versus "non-status" classifications eventually led to various legal challenges.

In a landmark decision on April 14, 2016, the Supreme Court of Canada unanimously ruled that non-status Indians and Métis should be considered "Indians" under Section 91(24) of the 1867 Constitution Act — effectively expanding Ottawa's responsibilities for Indigenous people to approximately 200,000 Métis and 400,000 non-status Indians unaffiliated with specific reserves.



**Singular**
**First Nation** is often used as a synonym for "band" as defined by the Indian Act, even though the term is not officially recognized by law. (A band is a community of Indians with certain land and financial entitlements agreed to by the Crown.) The uppercase words First Nation now often appear in proper nouns in place of "band" or "reserve" (e.g., _the Sagkeeng First Nation_).

> A representative from the Indian Brook _First Nation_ agreed.
>
> Members of the Aamjiwnaang _First Nation_ raised health concerns a decade ago.
>
> A small _First Nation_ in northern B.C. is backing a controversial plan to save endangered woodland caribou.



**Plural**
**First Nations** means (a) more than one band as well as (b) members of one or more bands. It's also commonly used as a modifier for certain singular and plural nouns (e.g., a _First Nations leader_, a _First Nations community_, _five First Nations delegates_, _several First Nations languages_).

> She's from a _First Nations_ band in Alberta.
>
> He was elected head of the Assembly of _First Nations_ in 1997.
>
> The mystery began on a _First Nations_ reserve near Prince Albert, Sask.


**Adding 'the'**
**Generally include a definite article ("the") before the proper noun:**

> They found the artifact on the _Sioux Valley Dakota First Nation_, west of Brandon.
>
> _The Liard First Nation_ wants Yukon's Supreme Court to order a new hearing.


**Unless in a headline where space is scarce or in a construction that doesn't require it**:

> Audit slams _Roseau River First Nation_  (Headline; no 'the' needed)
> Manitoba pledges aid for _Peguis First Nation_  (Headline; no 'the' needed)

**Limit use of 'Indian'**
**Generally prefer the words Indigenous or First Nations unless "Indian" is part of a proper noun or provides extra information that is key to the story** (e.g., status versus non-status). This better reflects modern usage and also helps avoid confusion with people from the Indian subcontinent:

> _Indigenous_ leaders plan to push for faster land claim settlements.
>
> He's in favour of expanding _Indigenous_ self-government.
>
> The Union of Nova Scotia _Indians_ was given a copy of the Whycocomagh _First Nation's_ plan.
>
> Newfoundland's 4,000 Mi'kmaq see the New Brunswick decision as a precedent to extend their rights _as status Indians._


It's worth noting that the word Indian is also being used less by the federal government. For example, while the "legal" name of the Department of Indian Affairs and Northern Development technically remains on the books, what's known as the ministry's "applied title" was officially changed to the **Department of Indigenous and Northern Affairs** in late 2015. (See the [Ministry](/home/m/ministry) overview for details and related guidelines.)

**Avoid the term East Indian.** See [South Asian, Indian, Indo-Canadian](/home/s/south-asian-indian-indo-canadian) for related guidelines.

See also [**racial terms**](/home/r/racial-terms) for **general reporting guidelines on race and ethnicity**, including how to handle words like "racism" and "racist." The entry includes specific caveats about **BIPOC**, why a non-Indigenous term such as "person of colour" should never be confused with Indigeneity, and why "**racialized**" is our default umbrella expression in many contexts.

Note: A special website launched by the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation in 2007 was initially called "CBC Aboriginal." It was renamed [**CBC Indigenous**](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews%2Findigenous&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw07rj_7CDNYfXmJpG-d7bA9) in 2016. The site includes a wealth of news stories, background articles, timelines, FAQs, etc.

**I****nflammable, flammable and non-flammable**

The prefix **in** can get you in trouble.

**Incombustible** means _not combustible_.

**Indestructible** means _not destructible_.

But **inflammable** means _highly flammable_.


**To avoid confusion**
**Use the terms flammable** (it burns) **and non-flammable** (it doesn't).

Another option is plain English, such as “won’t burn.”

A fire retardant, by the way, may not prevent flames. If it simply slows the spread of fire we should say so.

### internet terms

**Internet terms**

**internet, the net** (no longer uppercase, except in proprietary names — for instance, the web browser Internet Explorer, which can be shortened to Explorer in news stories).

Just as we write about television programs (not "Television programs") and radio newscasts (not "Radio newscasts"), we now refer to internet stories and internet journalists, not to "Internet stories" or "Internet journalists."

CBC News dropped the capital "I" in the fall of 2003. Many other media organizations, including the BBC, have done so as well, although some newspapers and wire services continued to capitalize the word a decade later.

**WWW** and **World Wide Web**. Keep this noun uppercase because it's a recognized name given to a specific network on the internet. Continue to write "World Wide Web" (three words) even though the lowercase compound worldwide is normally fused.

**Use a small "w" when shortening** WWW **to "the web"** (in the same way the International Space Station becomes "the space station" in second reference.)


**w not W**
The following terms are lowercase: **web address, web browser, [webcam](/home/c#camera), webcast, web-enabled, web forum, weblog, webmaster, web page, web server, website.**

Also lowercase, **app, blog, chat room, [the cloud](/home/c#cloud)**, **cyberspace, domain name, dot-com, electronic mail, email, home page, hyperlink, instant messaging, server, shareware, site.
**
Some terms are normally lowercase unless part of a name: e.g., **online**, _but_ the **Canadian Atlas Online** (akin to radio versus CBC Radio).

Other terms are uppercase and may or may not be fused: e.g., **BlackBerry** (one word) **Palm Pilot** (two words). Check the spelling of any computer software or tools that you refer to in stories (e.g., **Adobe Acrobat, JavaScript, Microsoft Word** and **PowerPoint**). See also [quirky capitalization](/home/q/quirky-capitalization) (**eBay, iMac, iPad app**, etc.)

Keep well-known abbreviations uppercase (**CD-ROM, FTP, HTML, PDF, RAM, URL**) unless they're part of an internet address (e.g., FTP but "ftp:// typeanurlhere.com"). See [URLs](/home/u/urls) for more details about the structure of addresses.
**Spell out more obscure abbreviations** (e.g., **voice-over-internet protocol**, which is fine as **VoIP** in second reference). Sometimes it's simply better to pick another term (e.g., "web address" rather than URL) to make sure our readers understand.

**And do not use unfamiliar terms unless you explain what they mean.** Keep in mind that the need for such descriptions diminishes over time only if words become widely known.

For instance, at one point we had to tell our readers that a "blog" is a type of online journal that includes commentary and links. But within a few years a definition was no longer necessary. Jargon such as "phreaking" (using computer technology to make free phone calls), however, still requires a clear explanation.

**When a group, business, corporate division, etc., uses a variation of its internet address as a proper noun, capitalize the first word** (or in the case of well-known abbreviations, all relevant letters): Amazon.com, CBC.ca, CTV.ca, etc. **But do not impose web domains on nouns that don't require them**: use CTVglobemedia not CTVglobemedia.com for the corporate entity.

See also [intranet](/home/i/intranet)
See also [CBC](/home/c/cbc) (In news stories, use CBC.ca not cbc.ca, etc.)

For a detailed look at CBC.ca's switch to internet and web, see the Words: Woe & Wonder column, "[i for an I and other capital punishment](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews2%2Findepth%2Fwords%2Finternet_i.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0f1hPq1UK33wYvMaaDnnRq)"

### interpreter\_translator

**Interpreter versus translator**

These **–er and –or endings** are the source of errors. **Guard against common misspellings**.

Conventionally, **an interpreter translates the spoken word almost instantaneously** (usually within seconds) while **a translator tackles written text** under far less urgent time constraints. Interpreters may either speak (oral interpretation) or use gestures (sign language interpretation, also known as signing).

**It's not automatically wrong to use the terms "interpreter" and "translator" interchangeably in some contexts** — especially in an era of hand-held gadgets that provide fast, although very rough, translations from one language to another. **But careful writers generally stick with standard English and preserve the traditional meanings of interpreter** (someone working on the fly) **and translator** (someone working under less pressure, who has more time for nuanced crafting based on careful thought). **The latter conditions can producer clearer, more faithful wording. And this detail can sometimes be relevant in our journalism** (e.g., in stories involving disputes over the meaning of specific statements made in one language or another).

**Translations can involve interpretation**
Each role has its challenges. **A UN interpreter**, for example, must quickly convey a person's words in another language as faithfully as possible. **A scholarly translator**, by contrast, may have months or years to produce a document, but the volume of words will be greater, the scrutiny potentially more intense, and the expectations of critics probably much higher.

Technically, the root word "interpret" simply means "to explain the meaning of" (as in an art museum interpreter), and the root word "translate" simply means "to transfer" or "to move." So a translator might well "interpret" the meaning of various written material very subjectively. This means the final, say, Japanese translation of an English novel might well include specific interpretations of certain poetic passages in the original book.

**'Simultaneous interpretation'**
Since 1959, the Parliament of Canada has offered what it calls "**simultaneous interpretation**" of speeches and debates in the House of Commons. The women and men who actually sit in little booths and instantly give us the French or English versions of the proceedings are members of the **Parliamentary Interpretation Service**. It's worth noting that this unit is actually part of the federal government's larger **Translation Bureau**. Therefore, it would certainly not be wrong for us to refer to, say, a dispute over the "English translation" of the PM's remarks in the Commons — even though that English version was technically supplied by an "interpreter" working for the Department of Public Works.


### intranet

**Intranet**

The prefix **intra** is **Latin** for "**on the inside**" or "within," as in _intravenous_.
**
An intranet is a private or internal network.** Many corporations have them, including the CBC.

The prefix **inter** is **Latin** for **"between" or "among,"** as in _intercontinental_.

**The internet is a public system**. It connects a large number of computer networks around the globe.

See also [internet terms](/home/i/internet-terms) for web page (two words), website (one word), etc.

### Inuit and Inuk

**Inuit and Inuk**

**The Indigenous people in Canada's [Arctic](/home/a/arctic) are called Inuit.** It's an [Inuktut](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/i/inuktut/ "Inuktut") word that **means "people."** The proper noun Inuit was officially adopted in this country by various government organizations in the 1970s, replacing the term "Eskimo." **When referring to Inuit in other countries, be specific** (e.g., Greenland's Inuit, also known as "Greenlandic Inuit").

**Tens of thousands of Inuit** live in small communities from Alaska to Labrador. **They are one of three diverse groups that make up the Indigenous Peoples of Canada** (the other two being First Nations and Métis).


**Inuit are not 'Eskimos'**
**Do not use "Eskimo" to refer to any Inuit in Canada**. Many consider this once common name offensive. It's believed to come either from an Algonquian word for "eaters of raw meat," or from a different Indigenous term for "people who wear snowshoes." Either way, it's viewed as inapt by critics because it's a name that outsiders gave to those in the Far North. **Eskimo is still preferred by some residents of Alaska. It's also used to refer to certain Indigenous people in Siberia**, although they're more commonly called the "Yupiks."

**The word Eskimo is fine in a few conventional contexts, including attributed historical citations**, such as excerpts from books, **and references to some proper nouns**, such as a popular dog breed, a geographical name (e.g., Eskimo Hill Road in Virginia) or an official event (e.g., **the World Eskimo Indian Olympics** in Alaska).


**Edmonton Eskimos** falls into this category but **requires special care**. In July 2020, [the CFL team announced plans to change its name](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews%2Fcanada%2Fedmonton%2Fedmonton-cfl-team-name-1.5657661&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1NN3Ae_mwDfyk7NwOKQEVA) after mounting criticism that it was a racist relic of colonial power. A [2018 editorial in the Nunatsiaq News](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fnunatsiaq.com%2Fstories%2Farticle%2Fpatience-in-time-the-edmonton-eskimos-name-will-change%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1orBmkY4HtFhGZPS-Yf8fX) summarizes the issue — including why the franchise's name was deemed inappropriate by many regardless of whether some Inuit considered the word Eskimo, itself, fine in various other contexts. [In June 2021, the team's new name was announced](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews%2Fcanada%2Fedmonton%2Fedmonton-ee-cfl-football-name-1.6048578&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1zaX27i1frVA2AJUrBDFFI): the **Edmonton Elks**. It's **OK to use the proper noun Eskimos once when actually reporting on the controversy over the name** to ensure clarity. **But avoid repeating the words Eskimo/Eskimos in a story**, and **avoid using the name in headlines**. Furthermore, **there's no need to use the old name in routine reporting about the Elks**. See [controversial sports team names](/home/c/controversial-team-names) for general, related guidelines.


**Any member of 'the Inuit' is 'an Inuk'**
Generally **avoid the expression "Inuit people," which is considered redundant.** Instead prefer "Inuit" or "the Inuit" alone. Although "Inuit people" is relatively entrenched in English, it's unnecessarily wordy. This means that dropping "people" not only acknowledges the original Inuktut etymology, it helps keep our scripts tighter. At the same time, **it's OK to use the definite article "the" (i.e., "the Inuit")**, even though this differs from Inuktut usage, since orthodox English syntax and conventions apply.

**The Inuit are represented by Inuit Tapiriit Kanatami** (which means "Inuit are united in Canada"). This national organization was originally called "Inuit Tapirisat" when it was founded in 1971. The group changed its name in 2001.
**
An Inuk is any member of the Inuit.** Calling someone an Inuk is a general description, while referring to them as, say, an Inuvialuk is much more specific. (An Inuvialuk is a member of the Inuvialuit, the Western Arctic Inuit. But since most of our readers won't know that, a clear explanation is required.)

**Do not confuse Inuit with Innu** (who are members of a First Nations people in Labrador and northeastern Quebec).


**Plural versus singular**
**Inuit is the correct plural** (noun or modifier). **Inuk is correct for most singular constructions** (noun or modifier). Both are always uppercase:

_Inuit scholars point out that all languages evolve, including Inuktut.

She married an Inuk artist and moved to Pangnirtung, Nunavut, in 1988.

The nurses are Inuit. The doctor is an Inuk._ (But never "the doctor is Inuit.")

**The exceptions are when Inuit is used as an adjective before collective nouns** (such as delegation, family, government, etc.), **and when Inuit serves as an adjective that implies a possessive** (e.g., the "Inuit housing shortage" which means "housing shortage of the Inuit").
**
Never add an "s" or an apostrophe and an "s" to either Inuit or Inuk.** It's not grammatically valid to impose an English possessive construction on these Inuktut words, according to the Guide to Canadian English Usage and other language authorities. Instead, recast the sentence (e.g., the Inuit language or the language of the Inuit but never "the Inuit's language").


**Examples**

the Inuit
Inuit children
an Inuk boy
an Inuit delegation (_which means a delegation of Inuit_)
an Inuk delegate (_which means a delegate who is Inuk_)
the Inuit family (_which means all Inuit members of a family_)
Inuit art
Inuit traditions
Inuit policy (_which means policy of the Inuit_)
an Inuk teacher (_which means a teacher who is an Inuk_)

Following the above guidelines, **the Inuk leader** would refer to a leader who is Inuk while **the Inuit leader** would refer to a leader of the people known as Inuit.

See also [inukshuk](/home/i#inukshuk) (the figure of a person made out of stones), as well as [**Indigenous**](/home/i/Indigenous)

### Inuit and Inuk

**Inuktut**

**Inuktut** is not a new term, as [this article published by CBC North in 2019](https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/inuktut-prompts-correction-requests-1.5153188) details.

Inuit Tapiriit Kanatami, the national group representing Inuit in Canada, [defines Inuktut](https://www.itk.ca/projects/inuktut/) as “the language of Inuit, spoken across Inuit Nunaat, which includes Greenland, Alaska and Inuit Nunangat in Northern Canada.”

[Inuit Uqausinginnik Taiguusiliuqtiit](https://www.taiguusiliuqtiit.ca/sites/default/files/public/files/annual_reports/iut_annual_report_2015_-2016-final.pdf), the Inuit language authority created by the Government of Nunavut, says: “The term 'Inuktut' will enable the Government \[of Nunavut\] to refer to all of the dialects spoken in Nunavut as a single unified language. It will replace ‘the Inuit Language’ and ‘Inuktitut/Inuinnaqtun’ in government communications to describe the language in all of its richness and diversity.”

Note that Inuktut encompasses all Inuit language dialects — including Inuktitut, Inuinnaqtun, and Inuvialuktun — that are used in different regions. It is important to differentiate for audiences whether we are referring to a specific dialect (for example, Inuktitut) or all of the dialects together.

As the term Inuktut becomes more common, it could be helpful to consider whether a brief explanation would be useful for audiences when using it in a story.

### Ireland

**Irish Republic versus Northern Ireland**

**Irish Republic, the Republic of Ireland
****The Republic of Ireland, which can also be called the Irish Republic, officially became a sovereign European country in 1948**, breaking the last ties to the British Commonwealth. It joined the United Nations in 1955.

The **capital city is Dublin.**

Ireland had initially gained “dominion status” (akin to early years in Canada) in 1921, and became known as the Irish Free State. In 1937, the region adopted a new constitution after holding a plebiscite, and declared itself independent.

**Do not call it Eire** (the Irish name used before the English proper noun, the Republic of Ireland, was adopted).

**Do not call it Southern Ireland.

Use Ireland alone only in second reference, and only if the story is exclusively about the Irish Republic** (i.e., that there will be no confusion with the separate region known as Northern Ireland).


**Northern Ireland**
**Northern Ireland is part of the United Kingdom.

**The **capital city is Belfast.

Avoid referring to Northern Ireland as Britain** (which has a narrower meaning), **or as a British region.

Do not call it Ireland. Do not call it a country. Refer to it generally as a region or area.**

**Avoid describing Northern Ireland as a province unless that term is attributed**, since the noun is seen by some as belittling, given the region's history as well as its own legislative powers. The label also has misleading echoes of the island's ancient provinces, such as Ulster and Munster. Be aware that **the official name is simply Northern Ireland**, and that the word "province" does not appear anywhere in Westminster's Northern Ireland Act of 1998. It forms the northeastern tip of a large island west of the Irish Sea. The rest of the land mass is a separate country known as the Republic of Ireland (see [Irish Republic above](#Irish-Republic)).

**Northern Ireland has been either a self-governing or a London-ruled region since the U.K.'s Government of Ireland Act was passed in 1920.** During the Irish War of Independence, the British government partitioned the island in 1921, in response to concerns by unionists in the north. The newly created Parliament of Northern Ireland declined to join the Irish Free State to the south, which was formally established in Dublin in 1922.

Originally made up of a majority of British loyalists (called unionists), Northern Ireland has since become more evenly split because of demographic changes. The **unionists, mainly Protestant,** and the **nationalists, mainly Irish Catholic**, have been fighting over the political future control of the place for more than half a century. **Political violence in the region largely ended after the signing of the Good Friday Agreement in April 1998**, which expanded regional legislative powers in a new assembly in Belfast, and enshrined shared decision-making between nationalists (who favour joining the Republic of Ireland), and unionists (who want Northern Ireland to remain part of the U.K.). The Good Friday Agreement is **also known as the Belfast Agreement.**

When reporting on Northern Ireland, **use the terms unionists and nationalists. Avoid the label loyalists**, which can suggest that the nationalists are not loyal to their own cause for independence.

**Do not use the name Ulster as a synonym for Northern Ireland, even informally**, since only six of the original nine counties that historically formed the province of Ulster are in Northern Ireland. (The other three counties are now in the Republic of Ireland.) **Ulster is fine when attributed**, either in directly transcribed quotes or in proper nouns (e.g., **Ulster Unionist Party**).

See also [U.K.](/home/u/united-kingdom), [Britain](/home/b/britain) and [Londonderry](/home/l/londonderry-versus-london)

### ironic

**Ironic, ironically**

**Ironic** has **three primary meanings**, and not one of them is in high demand in news stories.



1.  **When someone intentionally uses language to convey the opposite meaning of the words chosen** (e.g., people say _“that’s a big surprise”_ in order to underscore just how unsurprising a development is)**.**
2.  **When an ending is the opposite of what was expected.**
3.  **When in a movie, play, etc., the audience knows some things that certain characters do not.**

**The terms irony and ironically are _frequently misused_. If something is strange, coincidental, paradoxical, etc., we should simply call it that.**

### Islam

**Islam**

**Islam** (n.) One of the world's largest religions. Does not need to be defined in stories.


She says **Islam** has a similar tradition.



**Islamophobia** (n.) A fear of or hostility toward Muslims or their religion. Does not need to be defined in stories.


The study calls the recent rise in **Islamophobia** alarming.


**Islamic** (adj.) Of, about or related to Islam. Does not need to be defined in stories.


They came from an **Islamic** country.


**Islamicist** (n.) A scholar or expert on Islamic culture, history, religion, etc. Generally avoid in stories. While the generic adjective Islamic is well known, the word Islamicist is not. It's also easily confused with Islamist, which has a completely different meaning.


The professor is an atheist as well as an Islamicist. (_POOR. Term is obscure and potentially misleading_)

The professor is an atheist as well as an **expert on Islam**. (_PREFERRED_)


**Islamist** (n.) Although this word has become increasingly common in news reporting, it can still cause confusion and misunderstanding unless a story's context makes the meaning clear. The **most neutral definition of _Islamist_: A follower of a political and cultural movement known as Islamism**, who believes that the Qur'an should rule all aspects of life (religious, political and personal). **A common implication** is: **A Muslim radical or extremist** who not only believes that Western values are eroding Islam but who is prepared to use violence to create Islamic states that promote fundamental doctrines and enforce strict Shariah law (the legal code of Islam). **In other words, Islamists are Islamic fundamentalists who may or may not be militant.**

**Islamist as an attributive noun**
When referring to entire countries, there's usually no confusion.

They want an **Islamist** state.


But when reporting on specific groups or individuals, more direct language is often preferred.


**Islamist militants** have threatened to carry out more attacks.
He's a member of a **militant Islamist group**.
The pamphlets were printed by **non-violent Islamists**.
They describe it as a **non-militant Islamist party**.


If the facts back the story, for instance, terms such as **Islamist militants** and **militant Islamist groups** can help clarify that the Islamists you're referring to endorse the use of violence. Other options include **Islamic radicals** or **Muslim extremists**. On the other hand, if you're talking about people who are simply highly political and campaigning without force for the creation of an Islamic state, terms like **non-violent Islamists** or members of **non-militant Islamist parties** help our audience understand this important detail.

**Other commonly encountered language**
Followers of Islam are **Muslim**. Their holy book is the **Qur'an**. They say it was revealed by **Allah** (God) to the **Prophet Muhammad** in the seventh century. The term **Shariah law** refers to the legal code of Islam and is based on the Qur'an. Traditional Shariah law deals with both civil and criminal justice, covering everything from banking and business contracts to diet, hygiene, dress, marriage, abortion and homosexuality.

Islam has two main branches or divisions: **Sunni** (representing about 85 per cent of Muslims) and **Shia** (the second-largest sect). Most Shias live in Iran and Iraq, where they are in the majority, as well as in Pakistan and India where they remain in the minority.


CBC News preference: Shia (for n. and adj.); Shias (plural); Shias' (plural possessive). Avoid _Shiite_ except in directly transcribed quotes.


**Some of the many clerical titles**
**Ayatollah** (used by Shias, especially in Iran) to refer to senior clergy.


Ayatollah Ali Khamenei decided …
Several grand ayatollahs openly disagreed with him.


**Mullah** (lower-level clergy)


Mullah Mohammad Omar said …
The mullah spoke first.


**Imam** (a common title for a prayer leader at a mosque)


Imam Hamid Slimi pointed out …
He talked to the imam.


See also [fundamentalist](/home/f/fundamentalist-extremist)
See also [fatwa](/home/f#fatwa)
See also [jihad](/home/j/jihad)
See also [Middle East glossary](/home/m/middle-east-glossary)

### Islamic community centre

**Islamic community centre near WTC site**

**Avoid the term "Ground Zero mosque" or "mosque at Ground Zero."** It's a proposed Islamic community centre in a busy commercial area NEAR Ground Zero (two blocks from the edge of the sprawling old World Trade Center site, and about six standard Manhattan blocks from where the WTC's North Tower stood).

Prefer the terms **Islamic community centre** or **Islamic centre**.

**Since the plans do include a prayer space considered a mosque**, and since that's central to the controversy over construction, **it's OK to use the noun mosque in headlines, where space is at a premium**. Examples of acceptable language in headlines:

> _mosque near WTC site_
>
> _mosque near Ground Zero_


**But always provide essential context high in stories. Do not give the impression that the entire building will be a mosque.** For instance:

> _The proposed Islamic community centre near Ground Zero includes a mosque._
>
> _The group backs construction of the Islamic centre and mosque._

**Optional background**
When space allows in features, etc., it may be beneficial to point out the proposed facility would also have a gym, swimming pool and 500-seat auditorium. Some other facts worth noting as we cover this story: Muslim prayer services have been held at the same location since 2009, inside what used to be a clothing store, and there is already a mosque about five blocks from the old WTC site.

**The idiomatic term "Ground Zero" is a common and acceptable way to describe the site of the Sept. 11, 2001**, attacks in New York City. But **calling it the old World Trade Center (WTC) site is sometimes preferable** because it's fact-based. Use your judgment.

### it's versus its

**It’s versus its**

The rule is straightforward:

**Use it’s as a contraction** (_it is_ or _it has_):

_“It’s a lovely day”_ and _“It’s got potential.”_

The form is similar to she’s (_she is_ or _she has_) and he’s (_he is_ or _he has_).

**Use its** (no apostrophe) to **indicate possession:**

_“The commission released its report earlier than expected.”_

Other possessive pronouns _without_ apostrophes include: his, hers, ours, theirs

See also [possessive apostrophe](/handy-links/punctuation/possessive-apostrophe) as well as [pronouns](/home/p/problems-with-pronouns) (common problems)

**justice** **Chief Justice George Burns**, chief justice in second reference; **Justice Gracie Allen** (not Madam Justice), Allen or the judge or justice in second reference; justice of the peace, **justice of the peace Lou Costello**. The word "justice" is normally reserved for members of higher courts, conventionally defined as those handling various types of appeals — including a province's or territory's highest court (e.g., the Alberta Court of Appeal, the Supreme Court of Newfoundland and Labrador) as well as the Federal Court of Appeal and the Supreme Court of Canada (e.g., **Supreme Court of Canada Chief Justice Beverly McLachlin**, the chief justice or McLachlin in second reference). "Justice" is also OK for members of so-called "superior" courts (e.g., the Alberta Court of King's Bench, the Ontario Superior Court, the Supreme Court of B.C.), as in **Quebec Superior Court Justice France Charbonneau**, Charbonneau or the judge or the justice in second reference. In addition to hearing their own trials, these women and men act as the first level of appeal for certain judgments from provincial and territorial courts. The word "judge" is generally used for lower courts, including provincial and territorial courts, as well as youth and family division courts. Keep in mind that the initial J. before a judge's surname in court documents stands for "justice" rather than a given name, while J. A. means "justice of appeal" and C. J. means "chief justice." The initials J.P. on legal documents commonly refers to "justice of the peace." (See [judge](/home/j#judge) above, as well as [titles](/home/t/titles) and [courts](/home/c/courts))

**just deserts** (_not_ desserts) The term "getting their just deserts" has nothing to do with pastries, ice cream or other desserts. It's based on the French word for "deserve," which helps explain the single "s." Speaking of "deserve," our audience is entitled to something beyond clichés, no matter how they're spelled.

### jail versus prison

**Jail versus prison**

**Jail**
In Canada, **a jail is normally a provincially run institution** where people are held temporarily, or where they serve **sentences of less than two years**.

**Keep the generic word “jail” lowercase unless it’s part of a proper name**, _which is relatively rare_:

… the Central North Correction Centre in Penetanguishene, Ont.
… **the Penetanguishene jail**
… the **Don Jail** in Toronto
… **the Sleepy Hollow provincial jail**
… the old **York County Jail**
… **Passaic County Jail**, _but_ **the county jail**


**Prison**
In Canada, **a prison is a federally run institution** where people serve **terms of two years or more**. There are different categories: **medium-security, maximum-security**, etc.

Do _not_ use the term “prison” when referring to holding cells at a detention centre or to describe provincial jails.

**Keep the generic word “prison” lowercase unless it’s part of a proper name:**

… the **Millhaven Institution** or **Millhaven prison** but _not_ the Millhaven Prison
… the **Prison for Women** in Kingston, Ont.
… the **Kingston Penitentiary**
… the **Saskatchewan Penitentiary** (in Prince Alberta, Sask.)
… the **Prince Albert prison** but _not_ the Prince Albert Prison
… the **prison in Prince Albert, Sask.**

Be sure to use the word “**Institution**” _not_ “Institute” when writing out a name in full (**Springhill Institution** or the **Springhill prison**).

**In second reference, the proper name can be shortened** (the _riot at Springhill_) or lowercase generic terms can be used (the _prison_, the _penitentiary_). Do not call prisons jails. (See jail above)

The Correctional Service of Canada (also known as Corrections Canada) lists [all prisons across the country](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.csc-scc.gc.ca%2Finstitutions%2F001002-0001-eng.shtml&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1FA1OLduXWgX4RMmPR2HqG) on its website.

### jihad

**Jihad**

This was originally an Arabic term for "to strive." In the broadest sense, it means **a struggle to improve oneself or to do good.**

But **it also refers to a holy war carried out by certain Muslims against enemies of their faith.**

Some Islamic scholars say the term is often misused, since they argue that a true holy war must be in self-defence. But the word is found in the names of several well-known organizations, including the **Islamic Jihad** (a militant group that vows to destroy Israel and set up an Islamic Palestinian state).

**The words jihad and jihadist have become well enough known that they no longer require explanation in many cases**, depending on context.

When definitions are deemed necessary, **we can generally describe jihad as a "holy war" against enemies of Islam** based on entrenched usage**. Attribution is preferable when people are pressing for a specific uprising** (e.g., _"Former Iraqi president Saddam Hussein called for a jihad, or holy war, against the United States and other countries that helped topple his regime."_)


> CBCNews.ca style: Do **not** put jihad in [italics](/handy-links/punctuation/italics).


See also [fundamentalist](/home/f/fundamentalist-extremist) (avoid using as a synonym for militant)
See also [Islam](/home/i/islam)
See also the [Middle East glossary](/home/m/middle-east-glossary)

### joual

**Joual**

Be careful when using this term, which first appeared in print in a newspaper editorial in Quebec in the late 1950s.

The Canadian Oxford defines joual as: “**A variety of Canadian French considered to be uneducated, characterized by non-standard grammar and syntax and, especially in cities, numerous English borrowings.**”

_It should not be used to refer to Quebec French in general_. It implies that a person is making mistakes when they speak, either because they’re poorly educated or lazy.

The word’s etymology alone conveys its pejorative nature. It’s supposed to represent the mispronunciation of the French word for horse, _cheval_.

### jumbo jet

**jumbo jet**

This is **a generic term for any wide-bodied jet plane**. **It does _not_ need to be capitalized.**

Examples are: the **Boeing 747, Lockheed L-1011** and **DC-10**

For more background on why "jumbo" is not "Jumbo," see the Words: Woe & Wonder column [Jumbo Jets and other Jargon](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews2%2Findepth%2Fwords%2Fjumbo.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2a9FlPFQnNoWSvI_j4lnCK).

See also [trade names](/home/t/trade-names)

**killer whales** (OK in first reference to **orcas** if preferred) The terms orca and killer whale can be used interchangeably because the latter is deeply entrenched. But generally avoid shortening "killer whales" to "whales" alone in second reference because the noun is too vague. (Experts consider the animals part of the dolphin family. And while all dolphins are technically a type of whale, most of our audience won't know that.) Avoid the needless compound "orca whales," which is redundant at best. It's normally unnecessary to use the scientific name _Orcinus orca_. When reporting names of specific orcas, follow the tradition of fusing the pod group's letter with a given animal's number (e.g., **J50, K44, L90**). **Korean War** (1950-53) For much of the first half of the 20th century, Japan occupied Korea. Then at the end of the Second World War, the peninsula was divided along the 38th parallel. The U.S. controlled the southern region while the Soviet Union controlled the northern territory. North Korea invaded South Korea in 1950. Canada's military joined UN-led forces to push back the assault. Peace negotiations started in 1951, but fighting continued for another two years. **While an armistice was agreed to in July 1953, no peace treaty was signed.** This means **it's inaccurate to claim that the "war ended" in 1953.** Instead, use language such as "fighting stopped" or an "armistice was reached."

**Kurdistan** (avoid this noun on its own) There is no country known as Kurdistan. There is, however, an autonomous section of northern Iraq called **Iraqi Kurdistan**, run by a Kurdish regional government. The territory, commonly described as **the Kurdistan region of Iraq**, is specifically recognized in Iraq's constitution. Either name is OK in our journalism as long as we make it clear it's not a sovereign country. While sizable Kurdish populations living in Turkey, Syria and Iran are fighting for more autonomy, or for the creation of a separate state, it's inaccurate to refer to these places as "Kurdistan." Instead, always specify the country involved (e.g., "a Kurdish-controlled section of Syria") to ensure our audience understands a given story. (See [**Kurds**](/home/k#Kurds) below)

**Kurdistan Workers' Party** (see [**PKK**](/home/p#PKK))

**Kurds** (n.) An ethnic group of about 30 million people primarily living in a region straddling the borders of Armenia, Iran, Iraq, Syria and Turkey. Their language, Kurdish, is related to Farsi and Pashto, and includes several distinct dialects. The cultural identity of Kurds has been under siege by various governments for generations — from language restrictions to traditional clothing bans. As of 2019, Kurds made up less than two per cent of the population of Armenia, approximately 10 per cent of Iran, 15 per cent of Iraq, just under 10 per cent of Syria and roughly 20 per cent of Turkey, where they are the largest minority group in the country. Political campaigns for Kurdish independence have rekindled in recent decades. Be precise when reporting on crackdowns against militant Kurdish separatists. For example, while it's accurate to say the government of Turkey considers groups like the **[PKK](/home/p#PKK)** to be terrorists, avoid stating or implying that it considers all Kurds to be terrorists. (See also [**Kurdistan**](/home/k#Kurdistan) above)

### kibitz

**Kibitz**

kibitz (v.), kibitzer (n.)

**Kibitz was originally pejorative** (the Yiddish term came from a German word that meant busybody or lapwing).

It described **the act meddling or offering unsolicited advice** (e.g., during a card game).

**But it’s primary meaning today is to chat or joke lightheartedly**, according to the Canadian Oxford Dictionary.

### Kremlin

**Kremlin**

Russia is a democracy. Its **parliament is called the Federal Assembly.** There are two bodies: the **State Duma** (the lower house), and the **Federation Council** (the upper house).

The term **_Kremlin_ refers to the president, ministers and staff** (akin to the word "administration" in the United States).

In news stories, **we can write that the Kremlin has outlined certain policies, or that it's opposed to a specific measure.**

**But careful writers avoid calling an actual vote in Russia's State Duma or Federation Council a "Kremlin move" or a "Kremlin decision."
**
In the former Soviet Union, the Politburo was the top policy-making secretariat of the country's Communist Party. It normally had about a dozen members and was headed by the party general secretary.

The old Politburo ran things, more or less. (In theory, its members were elected by the Central Committee, but in reality the powerful minority dominated the larger body.)

See also [U.S.S.R.](/home/s/soviet-union)

### kudo

**Kudos**

The word comes from the Greek term for “glory,” and is now used to offer praise, pay a compliment or acknowledge credit.

**Many language commentators argue that it should always be treated as a singular**, since **there is no such thing as one “kudo.” It’s an “uncountable noun” like pathos or prestige.**

Although singular verbs can look or sound wrong (“the kudos is long overdue” or “the kudos was deserved” or “kudos goes to the copy editor”), these forms are correct.

U.S. writer Bill Bryson says this problem helps expose the word as “a pompous pretender,” **especially when there are other equally good terms available (praise goes to, credit goes to, etc.)**.

The Canadian Oxford Dictionary notes that **the use of plural verbs with kudos is well established in North America. So if you’re transcribing a quote, don’t “fix” this construction.**

But if the sentence is yours, change it. Instead of writing “kudos go to,” for instance, either shorten the phrase (“kudos to …”) or simply pick another word.
