### LGBT

**Overview**
**Sexual orientation, gender identity, etc., should be referred to only when relevant.** In 2010, for example, the following headline appeared in the CBC News Network TV crawl: "2 gay men in Vancouver quit jobs after winning lottery." The text was strikingly inapt, which we immediately acknowledged in our response to an ombudsman complaint.

**Avoid dated and inaccurate expressions** such as "sexual preference" and "alternative lifestyle" **that wrongly imply sexual orientation boils down to choice.**

**2SLGBTQ+ is our default term** in general news stories (e.g., 2SLGBTQ+ rights). **It does NOT need to be spelled out** as two-spirit, lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and queer.

**Opt for precise language when the facts fit** (e.g., a homophobic slur versus a 2SLGBTQ+ slur, anti-trans versus anti-2SLGBTQ+). See [prefer specific over generic](#preferspecific) below for details.

**Consider the word queer** as a synonym in some contexts. (See ['](##queer "LGBTQ (1) --- Revised --- DRAFT")[Queer' requires caution](#queer)).

People are **transgender**, not "transgendered." **Being transgender has nothing to do with sexual orientation.** A transgender person could be gay, straight, bisexual, asexual, etc. (See [transgender](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/transgender/ "Transgender") for related guidelines, including use of pronouns.)

**EVOLVING TERMINOLOGY:** All English is organic, but some areas change faster than others, including words and phrases tied to the 2SLGBTQ+ community. We will continue to revise our style as required to reflect current, common usage. **This entry is based on recommendations by the CBC News language advisory group.** It was last updated in **February 2024**.

**2SLGBTQ+**

**Use 2SLGBTQ+ as the default umbrella term in most stories**, even in second reference (**2SLGBTQ+ rights**, and members of **the 2SLGBTQ+ community**). The abbreviation **does NOT need to be spelled out** as _two-spirit, lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and queer_. **Shorter variations are OK when attributed** (e.g., in directly transcribed clips and the names of groups or events). 

**Generally use 2SLGBTQ+, even in stories outside of Canada** (e.g., 2SLGBTQ+ activists in Europe, China's 2SLGBTQ+ community). This approach simplifies our style, acknowledges two-spirit people within Indigenous communities around the globe, and frames stories in a way that is familiar to our Canadian audience.

**2SLGBTQ+ is suitable as a modifier in plural constructions** (e.g., 2SLGBTQ+ athletes, 2SLGBTQ+ writers, 2SLGBTQ+ lawyers). **But generally avoid the abbreviation in singular references to individuals**. For instance, instead of writing "Jane is 2SLGBTQ+," report the specific detail that's relevant to a given story (e.g., Jane is a gay athlete, Jane is a bisexual politician, Jane is a trans lawyer).

It's now a convention to **include the + sign to underscore that the abbreviation 2SLGBTQ alone does not cover all members of the community.** While the Q, itself, is now usually assumed to be short for "queer" rather than for "questioning," not everyone views the Q as all-encompassing. 

**It's usually unnecessary to add characters after +**, outside of direct attribution. **It's also important to understand the downside of density.** While the instinct of well-intentioned journalists can be to keep tacking on letters to bolster inclusivity, such as A for asexual and I for intersex (2SLGBTQ2SIA+), **the price paid includes (i) alienating various groups** not represented in the expanded abbreviation, **and (ii) making broadcast scripts far less conversational** — not only harder to read on air but also more difficult for our audience to digest.

**Avoid implying that 2SLGBTQ+ includes "allies."** It may be relevant to mention supporters (allies) in stories. But the abbreviation 2SLGBTQ+ becomes virtually meaningless if it's so broadly defined that only intolerant people are left out. At the end of the day, a cisgender, straight person may be a vocal advocate for gay and trans rights, but that doesn't make the individual part of the 2SLGBTQ+ community.

**Do not call 2SLGBTQ+ or any of its variations an "[acronym](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/a/acronyms/ "Acronyms"),"** which traditionally means a pronounceable term like NASA and UNICEF. The fact that the abbreviation 2SLGBTQ+ is not an acronym is central to the challenge speakers face when letters or other characters are added.

**TIP:** To sound as natural as possible on air, **broadcast journalists unaccustomed to saying 2SLGBTQ+ should practice the abbreviation** until it becomes as second nature to say as any other eight-syllable sequence (e.g., "heterosexuality" and "individualization").

**Two-spirit (2S)**

The adjective **two-spirit (2S)**, coined in the early 1990s, is **a broad label used by some Indigenous people who describe themselves having both masculine and feminine spirits.** It has different meanings to different individuals, according to [researchers at the University of Toronto's Dalla Lana School of Public Health](https://lgbtqhealth.ca/community/two-spirit.php). **Two-spirit can refer to sexual orientation as well as to a wide range of gender identities**. Furthermore, the meaning is not static, as noted in this [2021 CBC Radio feature](https://www.cbc.ca/radio/unreserved/how-two-spirit-people-are-coming-in-to-their-communities-1.6272654) by _Unreserved_.

**Two-spirit should not be applied to non-Indigenous people.** Given how familiar the term has become, **it no longer needs to be defined in most stories, as long as the context makes the meaning clear**. When spelled out, use two-spirit rather than "two-spirited" (e.g., a two-spirit person, and a collection of poems by two-spirit writers).


(For use of **Indigiqueer**, see ['Queer' requires caution](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/l/2slgbtq/#queer "2SLGBTQ+") below.)

**'Queer' requires caution**

**Queer has been embraced by many members of the 2SLGBTQ+ community as an umbrella term** to describe themselves. **But it remains offensive to others and, so, demands care.**

**Champions of the word queer believe that widespread usage will numb its derogatory sting**, in the same way that "gay" eventually morphed from an insult into a label of pride. They also point out that queer is much easier to say than 2SLGBTQ+ or its variants, which fills a needed gap until an actual acronym is coined that catches on (i.e., until a new, pronounceable abbreviation gains far-flung currency ). **Opponents say they continue to see and hear the term queer as a slight**, given its common meaning of "odd" or "strange" as well as its history as a pejorative used against the 2SLGBTQ+ community. **Informal surveys suggest there's a generational divide between these two camps, with an increasing number of young people embracing "queer" as a convenient, neutral description.**

**Queer is OK in CBC journalism when we're covering organizations or people who use the term themselves.** This can range from proper nouns (e.g., the 2019 graphic novel **Gender Queer**, the 2018 TV series **Queer Eye**, the 2017 documentary **Queer Nation**) to individuals talking about being genderqueer, or about being part of Canada's queer community. **But we should avoid using queer when specifically referring to any person or group known to object to the term.** EXAMPLES:

-   **Queer OK in profiles of people who refer to themselves this way.**

> > _As a queer director, she says she brings a different perspective to films._

-   **Queer OK in broadcast clips and directly transcribed quotes**, as long as meaning is not hateful.

> > _"Queer voters like us can spot homophobic politicians a mile away."_

-   **Queer OK as an unattributed umbrella term in certain generic contexts.**

> > _It's the city's only queer nightclub._
> > _It's the city's only 2SLGBTQ+ nightclub._

-   **AVOID queer when generic use clashes with an individual's opposition to the term.**

> > _He was in his mid-30s before setting foot in a queer bar._ (REWRITE if the person is known to object to being called queer)
> > _He was in his mid-30s before setting foot in an 2SLGBTQ+ bar._ (OK)
> > _He was in his mid-30s before setting foot in a gay bar._ (OK if the person uses this entrenched wording)



Exercise your own judgment. **When in doubt, generally lean toward 2SLGBTQ+ as the default**, especially in first reference (e.g., 2SLGBTQ+ rights, 2SLGBTQ+ refugees).

**Indigiqueer**

The **same approach above applies to variations of the word queer, including Indigiqueer.** The portmanteau is defined in different ways, but it generally refers to **a unique combination of "Indigenous" and "queer" identity** that some people feel isn't always adequately conveyed by "two-spirit." Regina-born artist Theo Jean Cuthand, a trans man and member of the Little Pine First Nation, is credited with coining "Indigiqueer" at a film festival in Vancouver in 2004, although he spelled it "-ige-" instead of "-igi-" at the time to reflect the vowels in the root word Indigenous. The term is now part of a growing list of proper nouns, from the **Two-Spirit and Indigiqueer Studies Guide** at the University of British Columbia to **Full-Metal Indigiqueer** (a 2017 poetry collection) and the **Indigiqueer Circle of Quebec** (a non-profit organization). It's OK to use the original spelling, Indigequeer, when quoting from a verbatim, written source. Otherwise, stick with Indigiqueer for consistency.

**Avoid outmoded uses of 'queer'**

**Steer clear of queer as an archaic synonym for odd or strange** (e.g., "queer weather" and "a queer choice"), unless in a clip or transcribed quote. **At the heart of such dated phrasing is the sense of queer as abnormal** — which is clearly different from, say, other comparatively quaint fossils, such as "gay" to mean festive, colourful or fun (as in "Don we now our gay apparel" from the 19th century Christmas carol, _Deck the Halls_).

**Prefer specific over generic when facts fit**

It's **a good idea to lean toward specific language** whenever practical (e.g., **anti-trans** instead of anti-2SLGBTQ+, and a **homophobic slur** instead of an 2SLGBTQ+ slur), **as long as the narrower focus is accurate.** Otherwise, stick with generic wording (e.g., 2SLGBTQ+ activists, and discrimination against the 2SLGBTQ+ community).

**Be aware that some individuals tell us that they feel their identities are being erased by what they perceive as overuse of the abbreviation 2SLGBTQ+.** For example, if doctors say **gay men** appear to be more at risk of contracting a virus, we should say so. And if authorities warn that **trans youth** are more likely to take their own lives than other teens, we should report this detail clearly.

**Language that may not be familiar to most of our audience** (asexual, pansexual, polysexual) **should generally be defined when used, with the relevance clearly supplied** (e.g., "Jones considers herself 'polysexual,' saying the word bisexual is too limiting because it implies there are only two genders"). **But do not use wording that's either dated or inaccurate** (e.g., referring to an intersex person as a hermaphrodite).

**Guard against misusing or mischaracterizing terms that you're not familiar with.** For instance, in 2SLGBTQIA+, the A conventionally means asexual. And **while it's accurate to say that asexual people aren't sexually attracted to others, it's overly simplistic to suggest they don't experience other forms of attraction** in certain cases (e.g., romantic or aesthetic). It's also wrong to assume that asexuality is always static as individuals age, or to use "asexual" as a synonym for "celibate."

**Miscellaneous**

**Avoid words such as "admit"** (e.g., "admits being gay"), which suggest an element of wrongdoing. **Reserve expressions such as openly gay or openly lesbian** to rare cases when this detail is essential to keep stories clear or accurate (e.g., when referring to expansion of 2SLGBTQ+ rights in a more tolerant society, or when qualifying a historic election victory by acknowledging that past mayors, premiers, etc., may have been closeted gay men or gay women).

**Be on the lookout for non-standard use of common 2SLGBTQ+ language, attributing any potentially contentious wording as needed.** In June 2023, for example, Johns Hopkins University came under fire for publishing a glossary that defined **"lesbian"** as **"a non-man attracted to non-men."** Critics called the decision to bypass references to women misogynistic. The document was taken off-line, and the school's Office of Diversity and Inclusion said there would be more rigorous editorial oversight of material posted in the future.

**When referring to a same-sex relationship or marriage, follow the individual's preference:** boyfriend, girlfriend, husband, wife, partner, etc. If a preference is unknown, the story's facts are our best guide (e.g., when there's no marriage, a generic word such as "partner" is better than "spouse," which normally implies marriage).

The term homosexual is considered judgmental and offensive by some, since we rarely talk about a "heterosexual" in the same way. **Limit use of the word homosexual to clinical contexts and direct quotations.** Use gay, lesbian, bisexual, etc., instead. By contrast, **the nouns homosexuality, heterosexuality and bisexuality are all fine** in overall discussions about sexuality. The colloquial term **straight** is acceptable as a synonym for heterosexual.

Expressions such as **gay men and women**, **gay people** and the **gay community** are all OK when specifically focused on identities tied to sexual orientation. The description **"gay and bisexual men**" is generally better than "men who have sex with men," because the former neutrally refers to sexual orientation while the latter stresses sexual behaviour. The same applies to "**lesbians and bisexual women**."

**Certain redundancies are deep-rooted and perfectly acceptable** (e.g., the LG in 2SLGBTQ+ refers to "lesbian" and "gay," respectively, even though lesbians are, by definition, gay). English is not always literal or logical, and sometimes a missing word (i.e., gay "man") is both implied and instantly understood. **But avoid needlessly superfluous phrasing**, such as "lesbian woman" (which is repetitive) versus "lesbian firefighter" (which is OK because each element of the compound is distinct).

To bolster inclusiveness, many proper nouns have been formally renamed (e.g., **Pride Month** celebrations, **Pride Week** festivals, and Toronto's **Pride parade**, rather than "Gay Pride Week" festivals and "Gay Pride parade"). It's important, therefore, to verify the official names of organizations and events.

Keep pride lowercase in generic uses only (e.g., "Embrace queer pride," she said). Otherwise, **use uppercase Pride when referring to community events or cultural symbols** (e.g., a **Pride flag**). See [holidays and special times](/home/h/holidays) for related, in-house capitalization guidelines (e.g., time periods, such as Day and Week and Month are uppercase, but generic words such as breakfast, parade, party and fireworks are normally lowercase, as in Labour Day parade). An exception is **Dyke March**, which is historically treated as a compound proper noun.

**2SLGBTQ+ slurs**
**Follow [CBC Journalistic Standards and Practices policy](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fio.cbcrc.ca%2F%23%2Fresources%2Flanguage-langue-1.4523261&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw00j0MyNt5WClLhwDOEulcB) when handling offensive language**. If you have any doubts, talk to your supervisor.

**Homophobic, anti-trans and related slurs do not automatically need to be censored in stories** (i.e., bleeped on air or masked with hyphens online). **But they must never be gratuitous, and audience warnings should be included.
**



> EXAMPLES: When covering an anti-2SLGBTQ+ protest, there's no hard rule about blurring images of repugnant signs like "God Hates Homos" or "God Hates Fags," or bleeping equally offensive chants in a radio story. The same applies to a controversy over song lyrics, past comments by someone running for political office, and a debate over certain words on TV, including Canadian comedian Scott Thompson's fervent opposition to censoring "faggot." Editorial teams must determine the most appropriate way to handle such language based on our JSP principles, as well as on a given story's facts, assumptions about audience taste levels, etc.


**When making decisions about what to include in stories, it may be helpful to consider the following:**

-   **Paraphrases and general descriptions are sometimes sufficient** to convey key information (e.g., an athlete is accused of using a "homophobic slur"). See also prefer specific over generic above (e.g., anti-trans versus anti-2SLGBTQ+).

-   **If you include [offensive language](/home/o/offensive-language), exercise restraint.** There's no need to keep repeating the word or words. For example, it's generally sufficient to report that "faggot" appeared more than a dozen times in two emails, or in several tweets, without bombarding our audience with verbatim citations.

-   Words such as **fag, faggot, homo, dyke, etc., are hateful and hurtful in almost all contexts**, despite various efforts by 2SLGBTQ+ activists to defang the terms though linguistic appropriation. Put another way: Even though "faggot" is commonly used either neutrally or affectionately by some gay people, **audience warnings are required for homophobic slurs.** Entrenched proper nouns devoid of malevolence do NOT require special care (e.g., the comic strip **_Dykes to Watch Out For_** or a **Dyke March** at a Pride festival), but such usage remains relatively rare.

-   **Masking all pejorative usage can result in odd, inconsistent treatment of certain words** (e.g., censoring "Death to Dykes" graffiti in a story about rising anti-2SLGBTQ+ hate in the weeks leading up to a city's annual "Dyke March," or censoring "queer" in one context but not in another).

-   **Leaving homophobic slurs intact on air and online does not, in itself, mean we think the language is inoffensive**. Rather, it's often a matter of deciding whether the language is so out-of-bounds that it must be either axed or sanitized.

-   **Linguists point out that certain words tend to be more shocking than others based in part on "taboo" status** tied to infrequent public use. **We sometimes get complaints from people who think homophobic slurs should almost always be expurgated, along the lines of c--t and n----r. But judging degrees of offence can be highly subjective**. Scholars who study derogatory language say the use of "faggot," "dyke," "queer" and so forth by 2SLGBTQ+ activists has influenced society's overall reaction to these words over the past few decades. **For a detailed comparison of "c--t" versus "faggot" in our journalism, see this [November 2019 reply to an CBC ombudsperon complaint](/media/14pfs2m3/cbcnews_handling-offensive-terms-like-faggot_reply-to-ombud-complaint_nov-2019.pdf)** — which underscores the need to warn audiences when stories include homophobic slurs.



**Historical background** (From LG to 2SLGBTQ+ and beyond)

Nearly 800 years ago, "gay" meant "bright" and "lively" in English, a definition that held fast for more than half a millennium. During the 19th century, "gay" became a nickname for female prostitutes, and by the 1920s, it had morphed into a disdainful label for homosexual men and women. With the rise of the gay rights movement in the 1960s, however, the word was embraced as a symbol of pride rather than as a mark of derision.

The **first known use of the term LGB is from 1985**. There's anecdotal evidence that this was **expanded to include the letter "T" in the late 1980s**, although the earliest recorded written record of **LGBT** and **GLBT** is from **1992**, according to lexicographers at the Oxford English Dictionary. The B stood for "bisexual," and the T represented either "transgender" or "transgendered," depending on the writer. Both abbreviations appeared in early internet forums known as Usenet server newsgroups. The initial posts urged bisexual people to take on louder, more visible roles within what was described as society's non-straight population.

Within a few years, **LGBT became the default name** of the "lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender" community, **although the abbreviation remained uncommon in mainstream news coverage until roughly 2010**. By the mid-2010s, additional letters started appearing. There was no consensus on the best order, however, and certain letters were repeated in an effort to convey different meanings (e.g., T for transgender and T for transexual, Q for queer and Q for questioning, A for asexual and A for allies). A typical cluster in blog posts and emails during this period was: "**LGBTTQQI2SAAP**."

At roughly the same time, a few symbols started surfacing. For instance, some suggested putting an ampersand before the T to distinguish gender identity from sexual orientation (i.e., **LGB&T**). While the & never took hold, a + symbol gained popularity (**LGBTQ+**) because it acknowledged numerous unnamed subcommunities without extending an already long abbreviation with a single syllable: Plus.

In Canada, **"two-spirit" didn't start routinely appearing in the abbreviation in mainstream news coverage until about 2017**, initially as the number 2 (i.e., **LGBTQ2**) before expanding to 2S. While LGBTQ2S+ is used by some people now, the abbreviation has frequently appeared as **2SLGBTQ+** since 2022.



**EXAMPLES OF PROPER NOUNS IN MOTION:** In 2021, U.S. President Joe Biden issued a proclamation affirming June as "**Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender and Queer (LGBTQ+) Pride Month**" ― a decade after U.S. President Barack Obama had first declared June "**Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender Pride Month**," and 20 years after Bill Clinton had designated it "**Lesbian and Gay Pride Month**." Meanwhile, the U.S.-based **National Lesbian and Gay Journalists Association** (NLGJA), founded in 1991, officially changed its name to the **Association of LGBT Journalists** in 2013, to the **Association of LGBTQ Journalists** in 2016, and then to the **Association of LGBTQ+ Journalists** in February of 2023.



**2SLGBTQ+ GLOSSARY**

**agender** — A person who doesn't identify with a specific gender (e.g., woman or man). Sometimes considered distinct from [non-binary](#glossary-non-binary), which usually implies a blend of, or a fluidity between, traditional binary labels.

**asexual** — Someone who is not sexually attracted to others, although they may still experience other forms of attraction, such as romantic or aesthetic.

**biological** — Generally limit to medical or scientific contexts (e.g., biological research, biological instincts, biological weapons, a person's biological mother). In stories about the transgender community, avoid use of the modifier to classify individuals (e.g., do not talk about a "biological man" or "a biological female") unless attributed. See the [transgender overview](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/transgender/#sex-at-birth "Transgender") for details.

**bisexual** — Someone attracted to men and women. While the clipped form bi can be OK in second reference, depending on a story's overall tone, it can be perceived as a breezy colloquialism that's sometimes better suited to attribution.

**cisgender** — Someone who is **not transgender**. OK as long as the meaning is clear. While it can be a highly succinct way to cover certain stories (e.g., medical findings involving transgender and cisgender patients), not everyone is familiar with the word, and not all cisgender want to be referred to this way. See transgender overview for more details on [cisgender usage](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/transgender/#cisgender "Transgender").

**cross-dresser** — Someone who wears clothing traditionally associated with a different gender. **Do not use the outdated term "transvestite."** Cross-dressing is unrelated to sexual orientation, and might not be tied to any erotic fetish. Generic use of the term cross-dresser is fine, but avoid applying to specific individuals unless they use the term themselves. Guard against inaccuracy when referring to gender expression. In particular, while cisgender people may cross-dress, transgender people simply dress. (Compare with [drag performer](#glossary-drag-performer) below.)

**deadnaming** — Calling a transgender person by their former name (usually their birth name). Be aware that not all transgender people consider their old identities completely "dead" for various reasons. **CBC News style is to use a transgender person's current name in virtually all cases.** Exceptions are rare, and, even then, the former name should be used only once for a clear editorial reason. (See [former names](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/transgender/#former-names "Transgender") in the transgender overview for details.)

**drag performer** — An entertainer who dresses and acts like someone of a different gender. Specific usage is common and OK (e.g., a **female impersonator** is a **drag queen**, and a **male impersonator** is a **drag king**). Drag performers sometimes rely on elaborate costumes and exaggerated comportment during shows. While it's accurate to refer to them as **cross-dressing entertainers**, do not use the term drag performer as a simple synonym for cross-dresser.

**female, male** — Primarily adjectives indicating people's sex. (See [gender vs. sex](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/transgender/#sex-gender "Transgender") in the transgender overivew.)

**gender** — Although gender has several meanings (e.g., masculine and feminine groupings in grammar), the word usually refers to society's classification of people under the historically binary headings of woman or man. This gender classification, in turn, is traditionally tied directly to one's sex at birth (female or male). That's why gender labels are considered cultural while sex labels are considered biological. (See [gender vs. sex](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/transgender/#sex-gender "Transgender") in the transgender overview, as well as [non-binary](#glossary-non-binary) below.)

**gender identity** — A person's subjective sense of their own connection, or lack of connection, to the gender category (woman, man) assigned to them at birth based on their sex (female, male). Since cisgender people report feeling a strong link between their gender and their sex, experts say they can have difficulty understanding the incongruence felt by transgender people. (See [gender dysphoria](#glossary-gender-dysphoria) below.)

**gender dysphoria** — A medical term that refers to a person's inner conflict and deep unhappiness over their assigned gender, including society's perception of who they are. It **has replaced the now-discredited 1980s psychiatric label "gender identity disorder," which should not be used.** The word dysphoria is the opposite of euphoria and underscores the depths of depression that doctors may refer to in a given diagnosis. This is important because it means the medical focus is on the distress someone feels over the incongruence between their gender identity (brain) and their biological sex (body), rather than on now-rejected notions of a psychological disorder. The most common reason for including the term gender dysphoria in a news story is when the diagnosis is required in a given jurisdiction before certain medical care (e.g., hormone therapy or surgery) can be approved. (See [gender-affirming care](#glossary-gender-affirming-care) below.)

**gender-affirming care** — A common and OK term for a range of medical treatments tied to transitioning, from hormone therapy to gender surgery. Alternative expressions such as **gender-confirming care** are also fine, although some wording is now widely considered dated (e.g., gender reassignment) and, so, should be attributed. **Do not use the archaic term "sex change" operation**, which focuses on the body (sex) instead of on the person's gender identity. See [transitioning](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/transgender/#transition "Transgender") for details.

**intersex** — Someone born with a body that falls outside of traditional, binary sex categorization (genitalia, chromosomes). Being intersex can include a discrepancy between external and internal reproductive organs, or a combination (e.g., both ovarian and testicular tissue). **Do not confuse with non-binary or transgender. Avoid the outdated label hermaphrodite.**

**man, woman** — Primarily nouns indicating gender identity. (See [gender vs. sex](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/transgender/#sex-gender "Transgender") in the transgender overivew.)

**misgendering** — To misstate someone's gender identity, usually by using the wrong pronoun. It can be done intentionally or unintentionally. Since the term, coined in 1989, remains unfamiliar to many in our audience, it's often clearer to describe the act rather than to rely on a one-word label (e.g., misstating a person's gender, referring to someone by the wrong gender, using the wrong pronoun).

**non-binary** — A person who doesn't strictly identify as a woman or a man. Includes those who are gender-fluid (i.e., whose gender identity may fluctuate), but not necessarily those who are [agender](#glossary-agender) (i.e., who say they don't have a gender). While the term is NOT narrowly synonymous with transgender, **some transgender people are non-binary, and use pronouns other than she or he** (e.g., "they/their"). See [transgender overview](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/transgender/#pronouns "Transgender") for related guidelines.

**queer** — An umbrella term used by many, but not all, members of the 2SLGBTQ+ community to describe themselves. The root term also appears in some words that specify a narrower meaning (e.g., **genderqueer** focuses on gender identity, which has nothing to do with sexual orientation). Be mindful that some people object to being called queer. When referring to specific individuals, respect known preferences. (See '[Queer' requires caution](#queer) above for details.)

**sex** — A biological classification (female, male) usually tied to reproductive organs. Sex is distinct from gender, which is a societal designation historically assigned to individuals based on their binary sex classification at birth. (See [gender vs. sex](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/transgender/#sex-gender "Transgender") in the transgender overview.)

**sexual orientation** — Refers to the gender or genders of people we're sexually attracted to (e.g., to men, women, both, neither). Include in stories only when relevant. **Avoid the dated and inaccurate term "sexual preference,"** which wrongly implies that one's sexual orientation is a "lifestyle choice." The most common categories are gay (men attracted to men), lesbian (women attracted women), bisexual (attracted to men and women), straight (men attracted to women, women attracted to men), and asexual (not sexually attracted to others).

**transgender** — A person whose identity does not match the gender classification traditionally linked to the sex (female, male) they were assigned at birth. Report this detail only when relevant to a story (e.g., a transgender man, a transgender woman). Go with the name and pronouns the individual uses. Being transgender is unrelated to sexual orientation. The colloquial short form **trans** is often OK in stories, especially in second reference (e.g., a trans lawyer). See the [transgender overview](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/transgender/ "Transgender") for details and related guidelines.

**transexual** — **Avoid outside of direct attribution** (e.g., when citing historical documents, or when people currently describe themselves this way). For many years, the term referred to what we now call transgender individuals undergoing certain medical care (usually hormone therapy as well as surgery). Although the word transsexual was relatively common during the mid-20th century, it's now generally perceived as old-fashioned because it stresses "sex" over "gender" in a way that's at odds with how transitioning is conventionally discussed in the 21st century.

**transvestite** — **Do not use.** (See [cross-dresser](#glossary-cross-dresser) above.)

**two-spirit** — A broad label used by some Indigenous people who describe themselves having both masculine and feminine spirits. It's defined in different ways by various people, and can refer to gender identity as well as sexual orientation. **Do not apply to non-Indigenous people.** (See [2SLGBTQ](#2S) above for details.)


**NOTE:** This glossary covers various words that routinely appear in our journalism, or that have sometimes caused confusion. But it does not include every term used in the 2SLGBTQ+ community. **Be aware that some labels can muddy attempts at precision** — such as **pansexual** (often defined as people attracted to others regardless of their sex or gender), **omnisexual** (sometimes defined as people attracted to others regardless of their sex but for whom gender may be a consideration), and **polysexual** (sometimes defined as people attracted to those of any sexual orientation but not necessarily to any gender identity). Since many in our audience may not be familiar with these terms, and since there's not always consensus over the actual denotative and connotative meanings, **a good practice is to skip such labels and lean toward clear descriptions to avoid ambiguity** (e.g. "Mia says prefers to date lesbians, but is also attracted to some bisexual men").

See also [transgender](/home/t/transgender) (including use of non-binary pronouns)

****

### lakes

**Lake versus lake**

**Capitalize the generic word "lake" only when it's part of a proper name.**

Chad Lake
Great Slave Lake
Lake Superior
Lake Ontario
Lake Louise
the Great Lakes
the Lakes (all of the Great Lakes)

**Use a lowercase "l" when referring to only one of the Great Lakes in second reference:**

the lake (in a story about Lake Huron)

**Use lowercase in plural constructions, _unless_ the plural also represents a proper name:**

several lakes
three of the Great Lakes
lakes Superior, Huron and Ontario

See also [capitalization](/home/c/capitalization)

### Last Post

**the _Last Post_ versus _Taps_**

In the Canadian and British military, **the final of several bugle calls marking the time to retire for the night is the _Last Post_.** It is distinct from _First Post_, which would traditionally be played earlier.

**_Rouse_ and _Reveille_ are signals to rise in the morning.** NOTE: The names of these "morning" calls are now used interchangeably in the Commonwealth, even though the original (_Reveille_) is technically longer.

_Last Post_ is also played to remember soldiers and other service personnel who died in wars. The haunting notes are normally sounded by a lone bugler or, occasionally, by a single trumpeter.

At military ceremonies, including funerals, **Canadians play the _Last Post_. Americans, by contrast, play _Taps_.** According to government of Canada protocol booklets, **_Reveille_ is also usually played at Remembrance Day ceremonies.**

**Use the specific noun "call" rather than inapt terms such as "song" or "tune"** when referring to the _Last Post and_ _Reveille_.

See also [funerals](/home/f/funerals) for various terms (e.g., book of condolence, half-mast, interment, lie in state)

### Latin plurals

**Latin plurals**

When deciding whether a word is singular or plural we should do more than look at its roots. **Latin rules do not govern English.** Otherwise, as U.S. author Bill Bryson once noted, we would all be buying insurance premia and watching athletes play in stadia.

Some people, for instance, still insist that data is plural based on its etymology. But it sounds stilted to say, "_The data are not reliable._"

Although reputable dictionaries continue to list archaic words such as aquaria, podia and symposia, we use the more common forms (aquariums, podiums and and symposiums). Sometimes, two versions are spoken and written (millennia and millenniums), and a preference is largely arbitrary (millenniums). 

 **CBC News preferences**

 

 

 **addenda**

 plural

 The addenda include a major addendum.

 singular and plural

 The bacteria is spreading.
 No harmful viruses or bacteria were detected.

 **criteria**

 plural

 The criteria are clear. A key criterion.

 **curricula**

 plural

 It's a blend of several different curricula. \*

 singular

 The data is out of date.

 **dictums**

 plural

 Their latest dictums are unpopular.

 **indexes**

 plural

 The word indexes is more common than indices.

 plural

 The media have been banned from the courtroom.

 **memorandums**

 plural

 Memos are another word for memorandums.

 **moratoriums**

 plural

 They've imposed three moratoriums in five years.

 **referendums**

 plural

 The province has held several referendums. †

 **strata**

 plural

 Geologists study many strata of rock deposits.

\* Writers and editors are encouraged to prefer conversational constructions over unnatural ones. For instance, the Canadian Oxford does not even list "curriculums" as a possible plural. Instead of writing "_a blend of several different curricula,_" however, it would be better to recast the sentence. An option might be something as specific as: "_Three provinces have blended different courses into a shared Grade 10 math curriculum._"


† See also [referendums versus plebiscites](/home/r/referendum-versus-plebiscite)


**A grain of salt**
During the past few decades, many people have relaxed their views on how to handle some Latin words. One widely used rule of thumb is to treat the word as singular when it represents something we generally think of in bulk or as a group. It can be thought of as the sodium chloride test:

"Salt is" being poured into the tank.
"Salt granules are" being poured into the tank.

Preserving the Latin plural is useful if we mean a bunch of individual parts. So various criteria could include a key criterion, and different strata (e.g., geological formations, layers of atmosphere, classes of society) are often worth examining separately.


**Datum? What’s dat?**
In the case of data, most of us don’t think of each individual datum (an obsolete term). Instead, we associate the word _data_ with an entire cluster of numbers.

> _The data they collected are flawed._
>
> _The data they collected is flawed._ (preferred)
>
> _The data are almost ready._
>
> _The data is almost ready._ (preferred)

**Media are ...**
We may not think about each datum in a cluster, but many of us still distinguish between various media (the print medium, the broadcast medium, the internet, etc.). It’s akin to preserving "criterion" as one of the many "criteria."

Others, however, think of the news media as one group, along the lines of "the press." So, depending on one’s view, we end up with different approaches:

> _The media has improved its coverage._
>
> _The media have improved their coverage._ (preferred)


For consistency, CBC News prefers to treat media as a plural (_media are, media have_, etc.).


**Bacteria are ... Bacteria is ...**
Since bacterium is singular, the word bacteria must be plural, ipso facto. Or so said he (_ipse dixit_). But Latin is dead, and the debate over bacteria is very much alive.

While some language authorities recommend keeping bacteria plural, others acknowledge the increasingly common use of bacteria as a singular, too, as in "_The bacteria has mutated and is making us ill_" (rather than "_The bacteria have mutated and are making us ill_").

The Oxford Guide to Canadian English Usage recognizes bacteria as both singular and plural. Since the word is far more conversational than "bacterium," bacteria is not merely acceptable in news stories, it's often the better choice:


**bacteria (singular), commonly means "a strain of bacteria"**


> _The bacteria is spreading quickly. It seems to infect every age group._
>
> (NOT_: The bacteria are spreading quickly. They seem to infect ..._)

**bacteria (plural), means "different strains of bacteria"**


> _She's spent her scientific career looking at viruses and bacteria._


If you're uncomfortable writing "bacteria is" because of its Latin roots, remember that we say "agenda is" rather than "agenda are." If you're still not convinced, reword your story to avoid odd-looking or awkward-sounding sentences. Instead of writing "_These bacteria have scientists stumped,_" for example, try "_This strain of bacteria has scientists stumped._"

The objective isn’t merely good grammar. Clarity is a goal, too, and wording that sounds natural helps. This is why most major news organizations abandoned referenda, memoranda, etc., years ago.

### Latin (scientific names)

**Latin** (scientific names)

**Generally avoid formal scientific names** (e.g., _Aix galericulata_ instead of mandarin duck) except in news stories or features that benefit from such language (e.g., when specific scholarly research is cited).

**When Latin names are used for animals, plants, etc. capitalize only the first word**, known as the genus. **This is true even when the second term, the species, is based on a word that is normally capitalized** (e.g., _canadensis_ for Canada).

_Branta canadensis_ for Canada goose
_Cannabis sativa_ and _Cannabis indica_ for two common species of hemp ([marijuana](/home/m#marijuana))
_Castor fiber canadensis_ for Canadian beaver
_Homo sapiens_ for modern humans
_Orcinus orca_ for killer whale
_Taraxacum officinale_ for dandelion

**A subspecies, also lowercase, appears last:
**
_Homo sapiens neanderthalenis
Branta canadensis leucopareia_

**In the above examples, the entire Latin name should be in [italics](/handy-links/punctuation/italics).** Different guidelines apply to bacteria, diseases, etc. (See below)

**Even in science stories, it is rarely necessary to expand beyond genus and species to other taxonomic classifications**, such as domain (_Eucarya_), kingdom (_Animalia_), phylum (_Chordata_), subphylum (_Vertebrata_), class (_Mammalia_), order (_Primates_), and family (_Hominidae_).

In these cases, the scientific names themselves are capitalized but common words derived from them (nouns or adjectives) are not (e.g., vertebrate and primate). The Canadian Oxford is a good guide.


**Bacteria, diseases, etc.**
**Do NOT italicize common names of diseases, viruses, parasitic micro-organisms, etc.** (e.g, coliform, listeriosis and rickettsia). **Do NOT capitalize the generic names of bacteria**, such as bacillus or streptococcus, **or the proper scientific names of diseases such as BSE** (bovine spongiform encephalopathy).

**Generally italicize all Latin scientific jargon that features an uppercase genus**, including the formal and full name of bacteria:

> They also found _Borrelia burgdorferi_, the corkscrew-shaped bacterium that causes Lyme disease.


**But when the genus is familiar** (Listeria) **or abbreviated** (e.g., E. coli stands for _Escherichia coli_), **do not italicize**.

**If bacteria is widely known** (e.g., E. coli), **the shortened version is fine on first reference.** Otherwise, spell it out once (e.g., _Clostridium difficile_, which can be called C. difficile from that point on in the story). Clipped versions are also fine in headlines.

When relevant, mention the specific strain of bacteria high up in the story, such as **E. coli O157: H7** (Note: The O is the letter "O" not a zero.) Never assume people know what the numbers and letters mean. The sentence should make it clear that this label represents a specific strain.

See also [chemical names and abbreviations](/home/c/chemical-names) (CO2 for carbon dioxide)

### lay versus lie

**Lay versus lie**

Two of the more confusing words in English involve repose, mainly because "lay" also happens to be the past tense of "lie."

The spelling **"layed" is ALWAYS WRONG.** There's no such word in standard English. The correct verb is **either "laid"** (past tense of "lay") **or "lay"** (past tense of lie).

**Picking the correct word depends entirely on a given sentence's meaning and syntax.**

**Lay**
Lay is an action word. It's a "transitive verb," which means it **needs an object**. In other words, **you must specify what is being laid down**: a baby, groceries, the law. ("_She lay her son in the crib._") Its main forms are "**lay**" (present), "**laying**" (present participle), and "**laid**" (past as well as past participle.)

Hens **lay eggs**. Workers **lay bricks**. Collectors want to **lay their hands** on rare finds.


**Lie**
Lie is an "intransitive verb," which means it **does not take an object.** It applies to people or things being in a horizontal position. ("_He lies on a soft sofa._") Its main forms are "**lie**" (present), "**lying**" (present participle), "**lay**" (past), and "**lain**" (past participle.)

Vacationers **lie on beaches.** Insomniacs **lie awake**. Bodies **lie in state**.

Her dog will faithfully **lie down**, but ignores commands to "lay down" because it's a stickler for grammar.

NOTE: The term **"lied" is ALWAYS WRONG as the past participle of lie when we mean a horizontal state. The correct form is "lain."** The word "lied," by contrast, refers to not telling the truth.

The intransitive verb lie also means to be in a certain location or relationship (e.g., the **island lies off the coast**, more **treasure lies below**, our **sympathies lie with them**, and **blame lies elsewhere**).


**'Now I lay me down to sleep'**
Given the above, **the intransitive verb "lie" is almost always correct when referring to people asleep or at rest** (e.g., _"The faithful lie down in green pastures,"_ and _"It's best to let sleeping dogs lie"_). **The exception is when we're describing someone or something being placed into a position of rest.** In that case, the object (e.g., a baby) requires the transitive verb lay ("_She gently laid her child on the hospital bed_"). The same logic is behind the entrenched expression, "_Now I lay me down to sleep._"

If you’re not sure which form to use, take a look at the table below:

**LAY**

 

 Present

 I lay the map on the desk. I am laying the map on the desk.

 Past

 Last week, I laid the map on the desk.

 Present Perfect

 I have already laid the map on the desk.



 **LIE** 

 

 Present

 I lie on the grass. I am lying on the grass. The book is lying on the table. Trudeau lies in state.

 Past

 Last night, I lay on the grass. Snow lay on the ground.

 Present Perfect

 I have lain on the grass all afternoon.

If you’re still uncertain, pick a different word.

See also [lying in state](/home/f/funerals#lieinstate) (funerals)

### Leader

**Leader versus leader**


The generic word "leader" is rarely an official title. There are many types of leaders: presidents, prime ministers, chiefs, and so forth.

Unless it's part of a formal title, therefore, **capitalize "leader" only when (a) it's linked directly to a political party** (in this case it's a semi-official title) **and (b) it appears immediately before a name:**

> Conservative Leader Stephen Harper
>
> NDP Leader Jagmeet Singh
>
> Liberal Leader Justin Trudeau
>
> Green Party co-Leader Jonathan Pedneault
>
> Democratic House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (See [U.S. Congress](/home/c/congress) for related guidelines)
>
> Republican Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (see [U.S. Congress](/home/c/congress) for related guidelines)
>
> but the Liberal leader, the Tory leader, the Senate majority leader, party leader Elizabeth May, etc.
>
> Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping
>
> Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas


Note: CBCNews.ca uses "Party" rather than "party" in abridged nouns that retain most of the original party's full, formal name (e.g., Green Party rather than CP's approach of Green party but Green Party of Canada). This style, adopted in September 2009, avoids inconsistent treatment of party leaders within a story. Under CP's rules, for example, it's Green party Leader Elizabeth May. CBC, however, now goes with the much simpler style: Green Party Leader Elizabeth May.
**
Follow normal capitalization style if someone is appointed to the position for a specified period** (i.e., distinguish between acting and [interim](/home/a/acting-versus-interim)):

> interim Liberal Leader Bill Graham (appointed until a convention can be held to choose a permanent replacement)


**But keep "leader" lowercase if the person no longer holds the title, if it's only a very temporary post, or if it's merely a political job performed by a federal or provincial politician who is not actually the party's leader** (e.g., government House leader):

> former NDP leader Jack Layton
>
> deputy leader Dave Broadfoot
>
> Liberal deputy leader Ralph Goodale
>
> Ontario NDP deputy leader Megan Leslie
>
> acting Conservative leader Jill Wong (filling in only briefly if, say, someone is ill)
>
> House leader Monty Hall (federal)
>
> House leader Monty Burns (provincial)


See also [Party versus party](/home/p/party) as well as [**titles during elections**](/home/e/election-titles) for related guidelines, including how we handle the titles of party leaders who've lost an election and announced their intention to resign.

See [possessive apostrophes](/handy-links/punctuation/possessive-apostrophe#fewerexceptions) for why we include punctuation in **leaders' debate** (rather than treating it as a so-called "descriptive" term).

The general [titles overview](/home/t/titles) outlines detailed typographical style, including related terms such as prime minister and president, and the difference between Deputy and deputy.

### left-wing versus right-wing

**Left-wing and right-wing**

**The labels "left" and "right" require caution.** For example, **the broad terms "left-wing" and "right-wing" are often too imprecise to be meaningful**, especially when used to describe people rather than actual policies. **But the relatively narrower terms "far-left" and "far-right" are entrenched and widely understood by our audience in certain contexts.** The rest of this entry outlines our style and recommended best practice.

[**left, right**](/home/l/left-wing-versus-right-wing#left-right) (common political umbrellas)
[**left-wing, right-wing**](/home/l/left-wing-versus-right-wing/home/l/left-wing-versus-right-wing#left-right-wing) (generally avoid; specific party affiliation often preferred)
[**far left, far right**](/home/l/left-wing-versus-right-wing#far-left-far-right) (OK when facts fit and context is clear)

**Left, right (political umbrellas)**
When applied to political parties, the words mean **"to the left"** or **"to the right" of a traditional public policy spectrum**. The expressions are believed to be based on seating arrangements in legislative chambers in Europe a few hundred years ago. Today, the terms generally convey ideological differences about the size and role of government, as well as about the perceived societal costs and benefits of free markets, regulations, etc.

**This common and frequently acceptable shorthand** (left, right) **can instantly help our audience understand certain stories.** In Canada, for example, the phrase "unite the right" came to mean a movement at the start of the 21st century to [bring together two federal parties](/home/p/party) (the Conservatives and the Canadian Alliance).

**When branding a party or policies, the words conventionally mean socialist (left) and conservative (right).** In a specific party name, terms such as Socialist and Conservative will often be capitalized (e.g., France’s Socialist Party, and the Conservative Party of Canada) but may not appear at all (e.g., Canada’s NDP, Britain’s Labour Party, the Saskatchewan Party).



**Left-wing, right-wing (generally avoid)**
**Labels such as "left-wing" and "right-wing" have large limits and, so, are often a poor choice.** For example, deeply cutting public spending to balance a budget is often called a "right-wing policy," but the approach may actually be adopted by a wide range of parties (e.g., the Liberals in Ottawa or the NDP in Saskatchewan during the mid-1990s).

**If you pigeonhole a person as "left-wing" or "right-wing,"** several problems can arise. First, **the terms may be seen as inaccurate** and the tone perceived as pejorative. Many people who hold public office are convinced that their views are mainstream (in the middle of a spectrum that they believe in, not on the periphery of a spectrum that academics or journalists have constructed).

Second, **each party has moderates**. So classifying people into one group or another can be misleading. A Conservative believes in Conservative ideology, but the person may have either conservative or liberal views on various topics. A Liberal believes in Liberal ideology, but the person may have either liberal or conservative views on various topics.

**In stories about public figures in Canada**, identifying someone as right-wing or left-wing can prompt email from people who dispute the label. **It’s more neutral and generally just as effective to identify specific party affiliations** (a Tory, a Liberal, a New Democrat, etc.).

**The same principle applies to think-tanks and related organizations**. When identifying the authors of studies, the participants of a CBC panel, etc., **prefer using proper nouns alone**, such as: the Fraser Institute, the C.D. Howe Institute, the Macdonald-Laurier Institute, the Canadian Centre for Policy Alternatives, the Wellesley Institute, the Broadbent Institute. **This avoids accusations of inaccuracy** (e.g., if a given group straddles left-right positions) **as well as inconsistency** (e.g., if we use “right-wing” in some cases but no modifier in others).

**When there's room and editorial need for context, a given body’s political leaning can normally be telegraphed by specific mention of policy/advocacy positions** (e.g., _ABC think-tank recommends policies UVW and XYZ_). Another option is to use attribution (e.g., "_which group JKL calls "pro-business_" or "_anti-business_") when two sides are squabbling over specific policies and think-tanks, and whether a given organization is truly non-partisan.



**Far-left, far-right**
**These classifications describe fringes of the political spectrum within a capitalist democracy. “Far left” traditionally refers to anti-capitalism ideology, such as communism.** Proponents commonly favour state ownership of large companies within an economy, as well as limiting the ownership of private property, profit-driven investments, etc. **"Far left" can also mean being actively anti-fascist** (i.e., beyond customary or mainstream opposition to fascism). **“Far right” traditionally refers to ultra-nationalist ideology, such as fascism.** Proponents commonly favour highly restrictive immigration policies, as well as openly racist philosophies (e.g., preferential citizenship that depends on ethnicity, religion, etc.). The compounds are hyphenated (**far-left, far-right**) when used as adjectives, as in far-right rhetoric.

**It’s common and acceptable to use the terms “far left” and “far right” to describe extreme political movements, including people participating at a given rally, as long as the facts fit the story** (e.g., _a far-right protest that turned deadly_ in Charlottesville, Va., _the violent, far-left tactics of Antifa_ began in Germany in the 1930s, and _the far-right group [La Meute](/home/l#La_Meute)_ says multiculturalism threatens Quebec’s culture and society). **But avoid simplistically branding single issues** (abortion, animal rights, human rights, Indigenous land claims, the environment) **as "left" or "right" extremism. Prefer more precise language in those cases** (e.g., an anti-abortion activist, an environmental activist).

**Whenever possible, include brief detail that helps our audience understand what we mean by our use of the labels far-left and far-right** (e.g., protesters were chanting antisemitic slogans, the demonstrators advocate various forms of [white nationalism](/home/w#white_nationalism), such as segregated schools and housing, the group is calling for an immigration ban against Muslims). **Generally avoid euphemistic jargon unless it’s relevant and explained** (e.g., _While some in the crowd called themselves “American nationalists” and “racial realists,” they all openly endorsed white supremacist ideology_).

**Neither "far-left" nor "far-right" automatically means the use of violence. Instead, a word such as “extremist” or “militant” is usually added to describe those prepared to harm others** while fighting for their political beliefs. (For related guidelines, see [fundamentalist, extremist, militant, rebel](/home/f/fundamentalist-extremist)) Governments and police forces sometimes publish lists of protest movements and groups they accuse of violence or other illegal activity. In Canada, for instance, the RCMP's [Awareness Guide to Extremist Groups](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.rcmp-grc.gc.ca%2Fqc%2Fpub%2Fsn-ns%2Fge-eg-eng.htm&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3eOr_wOl4L9C6HgJC83JY8) includes both far-left and far-right networks.



**Politics abroad**
While we can assume that Canadians have at least some sense of where the NDP or the Conservatives are on the political spectrum, we should not expect them to be as familiar with parties in most other countries , beyond, perhaps, the traditional ones in the United States and Britain.

**In stories about political leaders in many other spots around the globe, identifying someone as a member of a group that’s "right-wing," "left-wing," "far-right" etc. can be helpful** to our readers. **But the label must be accurate:** "_Joerg Haider, the leader of Austria’s far-right Freedom Party ..._"

Attribution is an option, although the standard guidelines about fairness and avoiding libel apply. It's one thing to repeat general criticism of politicians' policies, for instance, and quite another to call themHitlers, etc.

Here's another example of when "far-right" is fine. Careful readers will notice that Haider is not actually labelled a Nazi: _"Joerg Haider was forced to resign as governor of the southern province of Carinthia in 1991 after praising Nazi employment policies. Protesters say his far-right views are both a danger and an embarrassment to Austria."_

See also [Party versus party](/home/p/party) for related capitalization style points
