## Overview

**Links are part of the DNA of online news.** Even if we don't add a single link to a story, the story itself is a link somewhere on the internet.

**Virtually all articles are improved by internal and/or external links.** They give our audience instant access to various layers of relevant information. They add depth without making the original story overly long. They interconnect images, audio and text in unique and valuable ways. They turn the stationary concept of a web "address," which implies destination, into the animated idea of a web "pathway," which suggests travel. In brief: **Links in stories let people journey across the web, and journey is at the heart of good web journalism.**

**But links have their limitations.** Off-topic background adds no value, for instance, and too many inline links in a piece can be overly distracting. Also, poorly worded hypertext can confuse people.

**These guidelines are intended to answer common editorial questions about publishing links on CBCNews.ca.** They comply with the corporation's comparatively broader [Journalistic Standards and Practices policies on links](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fio.cbcrc.ca%2F%23%2Fresources%2Fproduction-digital-media-1.4523443&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0M6KmktDy0CxkQtW9MR8gF).

## Serving our audience

Why bother adding links? Isn't it better to try to hold on to web audiences while you've got them? Grazing or digging, people on the web are on the move. **To captivate an audience, we need to publish engaging material. To help serve our audience, however, we also need to post relevant links.** Trying to box in readers by limiting the number of exits is futile. It's also frustrating for online news audiences who expect options while surfing.

Taking the time to find and add good links to web stories, therefore, is important. Some readers may leave sooner than hoped. They're in the driver's seat, after all. But online roads are not one-way, and smartly chosen links actually build traffic over time. People will return to us as an authoritative and comprehensive source of information if we're offering relevant, clearly marked paths to explore.

## INTERNAL

**Internal links direct people to content published and controlled by the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation** (i.e., on CBC.ca or Radio-Canada.ca). These include related stories (past or current), backgrounders, interactives, galleries, databases, analyses and various user-generated contributions. Actual authorship may not be a factor. For instance, a public study into the collapse of a bank would be an external link if posted on, say, a government website, but original government documents into the bank's collapse obtained, scanned and published by CBCNews.ca would be internal.

**Internal links should be:**

-   **On point in a meaningful way.** Avoid cramming a page with links to material that is not sensibly tied to an overall narrative. For example, in a budget story about a plan to increase tobacco taxes, there is very little point linking to a general CBC feature on medical research into the harmful effects of smoking. On the other hand, a link to good background on previous government efforts to reduce tobacco consumption through advertising restrictions, higher taxes, etc., would likely be worthwhile.
-   **As specific as possible.** This is also known as "deep linking." When faced with the option of sending audiences to, say, a general feature on the Olympics versus a piece on controversies in figure-skating judging at past Games, pick the more specific link as long as it's directly tied to the current article. This saves readers from the chore of hunting for the most-relevant material on a page of broad content.
-   **Limited to the most valuable of what's available.** We may have already published a dozen stories about a certain high-profile murder trial. A link to a timeline of coverage, with each headline listed in chronological order, would be helpful to our audience. A separate link to a recent story about certain related testimony might also be worthwhile. But there's no point indiscriminately adding too many internal links. People can run their own keyword searches if they want to scan everything.
-   **Out of date only if flagged as a snapshot in time.** Previous stories can be worth looking at even though they contain only the information that was known back then (e.g., the wrong number of dead in the initial coverage of a plane crash). But all in-depth features we promote should be as current as possible (e.g., the correct number of dead, the confirmed cause of the plane crash). Avoid linking to CBC features, profiles, etc., that are significantly out of date. And always alert the in-depth team if you spot something that's wrong or dated.
-   **Legally and journalistically sound.** Past CBCNews.ca coverage may include information that, while accurate, we may no longer want to flag through links for legal or editorial reasons. Details could violate a publication ban that has since been imposed, for example, or an old piece may include especially gruesome photos that no longer merit being highlighted months after the story broke. See [legal issues](/home/l/links/home/l/links/home/l/links#legal_issues) below for more cautionary tips.
-   **Clearly identified to help people make informed judgments about whether to click.** Brief text (e.g., a news headline or other meaningful capsule) covering the gist of the content is essential. Unless the link is to a past CBCNews.ca article (generally implied by the headline), indicate the format whenever possible (e.g., whether it's an in-depth feature, a broadcast report, a photo gallery, a PDF). Avoid unnecessary phrases, such as "Click here."

**Examples of acceptable internal link hypertext in page margins:**

_(Note: On CBCNews.ca, such links are normally indicated by different colour text. They're underlined in these guidelines, however, for ease of illustration.)_

RELATED
Raucous YouTube videos embarrass senators

Copy of MP's disputed expense receipts (PDF)

VIDEO
Airport surveillance video of RCMP using Taser on Robert Dziekanski. Warning: Contains graphic scenes (Runs 9:59)

Watch amateur video of the planes colliding (Runs 0:51)

AUDIO
Iranian journalist Saeed Kamali Dehghan tells the CBC's _As It Happens_ about the clashes (Runs 7:04)

Listen to more of Wayne Gretzky's news conference (Runs 12:20)

PHOTO GALLERY
Barack Obama in Ottawa
A presidential visit

IN DEPTH
Timeline
Mulroney-Schreiber affair

BLOG
Tech Bytes
Facebook and the latest photo flap

YOUR VIEW
Any tips on dealing with growing garbage piles?

Remember that online slugs are visible in people's browsers after they click on content. So it's important to choose words carefully (e.g., slugs that are brief, meaningful, accurate, neutral) and to spell words accurately in filenames as well as in hypertext (i.e., in the actual links' labels).

**Use internal links to:**

-   **Add depth while keeping the narrative flowing.** Instead of piling on a lot of background in the middle of a story (from scientific details about the swine flu virus to the history of the latest Mideast peace proposal), provide a brief summary and then let the link fill in the rest for people who want more information. But never assume people already know important background, and do not rely solely on links for content that's central to the audience's understanding of a story. In other words, always add a condensed version of essential material in the main body of the story even if it's covered much more thoroughly via a link.
-   **Layer information effectively.** Instead of adding another series of paragraphs under a subhead in the main story, consider writing a related sidebar and then linking to it (as long as there's enough good material for a separate piece). This not only prevents stories from becoming overly long, it helps our audience find key content quickly via clear signposts and logical navigation.
-   **Create unique web content.** When practical and effective, use links to craft journalism that goes beyond standard, linear storytelling. Audio, video, photos and text can be interconnected in ways that are distinct online. Interactive graphics and narrated slide shows are examples.
-   **Promote related CBC material and user-generated content that adds value to our coverage**, such as a broadcast program's profile of someone in the news, a columnist's stand on a particular controversy or people's contributions to an online survey or contest.

Internal links do not need to open in new browser windows, and can be included either along the margin of a page or within the main body of the story itself (as an inline link). Always check the published version to make certain that the internal link you've added works. One wrong or missing character can cause problems.

## EXTERNAL

**External links direct people to content not published and controlled by the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation** (i.e., to content beyond CBC.ca and Radio-Canada.ca). These include websites run by governments, businesses, universities, charities, etc., as well as online space belonging to individuals, such as personal blogs. Actual authorship may not be a factor. For example, a ruling on the Supreme Court of Canada's site would be external, while a PDF of the same document created by and posted on CBCNews.ca would technically be an internal link to third-party content.

**External links should be:**

-   **On point in a meaningful way**, as outlined in internal links above. In a piece on political unrest in Iran, it makes sense to add links to the current government's (president's) website as well as those of the main opposition parties, as long as these are all available in English. But posting an external link to, say, the UN's website when the United Nations is mentioned only peripherally in the story adds nothing to our journalism.
-   **As specific as possible.** This is also known as "deep linking," as outlined in internal links above. For instance, in coverage of hamburger tainted with E. coli, we should link to the specific government web page dealing with the recall (www.inspection.gc.ca/recarapp/2009/20090630-2e.shtml) rather than to a generic web address, such as the Canadian Food Inspection Agency's main page (www.inspection.gc.ca). This saves our audience time.
-   **Limited to the most valuable of what's available**, as outlined in internal links above. In a story about international currency fluctuations, for instance, it may make sense to add links to a few key central banks' websites. But adding links to dozens of countries' central bank sites would be overkill.
-   **Legally and journalistically sound.** Always exercise care when linking to external content, especially if it's not a known and "trusted" site (e.g., material posted by a government department or by an established company generally requires less scrutiny than something published by a fringe group or private citizen). Watch out for anything that might offend a lot of readers or cause other concerns (e.g., content advocating hatred and violence, featuring pornography, promoting commercial products). See [legal issues](/home/l/links/home/l/links/home/l/links#legal_issues) below for more cautionary tips.
-   **Clearly identified**, as outlined in internal links above, so people can make an informed judgment about whether to click. Brief text covering the gist of the content is essential, including information about the source of the material (e.g., the author or where it's located on the internet). Unless the link is to another page of web text, indicate the format (e.g., audio, video, PDF). Avoid unnecessary phrases, such as "Click here," and obvious detail, such as "website."

**Some examples of acceptable external link hypertext in a page's margin:**

_(Note: On CBCNews.ca, such links are normally indicated by different colour text. They're underlined in these guidelines, however, for ease of illustration.)_

Supreme Court of Canada decision
(Link takes audience directly to ruling. No need to add names of parties, since the story makes this clear. No need to add technical details, such as docket number. No need to specify PDF or other format if the decision appears as a standard HTML page.)

The Oliphant inquiry into the Mulroney-Schreiber affair
(No need to use commission's long, formal name. When shortening, look for a widely used nickname or an acceptable description that emphasizes meaningful keywords.)

List of recalled products: CFIA (PDF)
(Canadian Food Inspection Agency does not need to be spelled out in external link as long as it's used in the story.)

NASA's shuttle landing blog
(Example of "deep linking." A specific spot on the NASA site has been chosen rather than simply the agency's main "nasa.gov" page.)

YouTube: 'Senators behaving badly' video, Part 1 (Runs 6:47)
(If using an external site's title for specific content, such as video, add single quotation marks unless the words are neutral. In this case, the phrase "Senators behaving badly" editorializes, along the lines of "behaving stupidly." An adverb such as "raucously," by contrast, would be more objectively descriptive. Exercise judgment.)

**Use external links to:**

-   **Add depth that's unique to online journalism.** Our story quotes the judge, cites the scientific report, outlines highlights of the federal budget, etc. But when the original material is also available on the web (and it often is), we should also add a link that gives people easy access to the complete ruling, the entire study or all of the budget documents.
-   **Provide balance.** If there are two or more sides to a story, these views should be reflected in external links whenever possible (i.e., if all sides actually have pertinent content online). If a provincial political party elects a new leader, for instance, there's no need to include an external link to every other provincial party. In the middle of an election campaign, on the other hand, a story about a particular party's latest platform promise should include links to all parties running candidates in the election. And in coverage of a demonstration for or against legalized abortions, both stands should be represented by external links.
-   **Increase diversity.** Beyond bolstering balance and fairness, links can add new voices to coverage that might not otherwise have been heard before. In the same way that we should avoid always interviewing the same players (organizations, people) in stories, or picking the same individuals for columns and other commentary, we should go beyond the usual suspects for external links. It doesn't matter if someone has a low profile or lives in a remote area. Insightful researchers, pundits, bloggers, etc., can provide a refreshingly different take on things.
-   **Offer variety.** Beyond the sheer quantity (depth) of material that can be added through external links, there's also remarkably vast versatility. Stories can be enhanced by far more than just pages of text — from a webcam above a busy border crossing to interactive graphics, a photo gallery to entries in a music contest, a statistical database to compelling audio from an interview. Always look for ways to add editorial value to CBCNews.ca coverage with relevant links that inform, entertain, etc., in a range of ways.

External links should open in new browser windows. A disclaimer is generally included that makes it clear the CBC is not responsible for the content. Except in rare cases approved by senior online journalists, external links should not be embedded as "inline text" in the main body of the story itself. Always check the published version to make certain that the external link you've added works. One wrong or missing character can cause problems.

## INLINE

**Inline links are embedded directly in the main body of a story** (i.e., in lines of text). **They are usually** **highlighted words** (e.g., bold, underlined, a different colour) **within paragraphs**, but can also be put in graphics, photo captions, etc. CBCNews.ca began expanding the use of inline links in 2010 to better serve audience needs and expectations.

**Generally prefer inline links** when faced with the choice of placing hypertext to core CBCNews.ca content (e.g., an updated profile) in a story's margin or main narrative.

**Many of the rudimentary legal and editorial guidelines for "side links"** (i.e., links along page margins or otherwise outside the story's main narrative) **outlined above also apply** to inline links. Given their prominent placement in narratives, **however, inline links introduce additional considerations**, addressed below.

## Inline link parameters
 

-   **Normally use inline hypertext to link to internal (CBC) content only**, such as previous news stories, current, related news stories, background features, timelines, photo galleries, glossaries of terms, etc.
-   **External inline links can be added to some journalistic content that does not involve routine reporting**, especially when the point of the piece is to compare external postings or to offer a roundup of external postings, and when the material does not normally feature external links along page margins. **Examples are: columns and analysis, blogs, arts reviews. When uncertain whether external inline links are permitted, check with your supervisor.** No matter where these links are placed (i.e., inline or in page margins) the general [guidelines governing external links](/home/l/links/home/l/links#external) above still apply — including the need for a disclaimer making it clear that the CBC is not responsible for the external content showcased through inline links. If the publishing tool you're using does not automatically generate this warning (e.g., when posting a blog), a pre-approved disclaimer should be manually entered.
-   **Avoid repeating identical inline links on a page**, including in the margin, unless the duplication is unavoidable (i.e., a key inline link is also automatically displayed along the side of the page as part of a package of links out of a writer or editor's control).
-   **Generally steer clear of inline links in leads.** Instead, pick the story's first reference to a person, place or thing after the lead as the text for a given inline link, unless there's a strong editorial reason to select a different spot. If a proper noun's first reference is in the lead (United Nations, Michael Jackson), and only abridged forms appear in subsequent references after that (UN, Jackson), the shortened version is normally fine for hypertext (e.g., "previous UN resolutions"). Since inline links are not generally used for external content, this example would direct readers to relevant CBCNews.ca content about past UN resolutions. Note: When a clipped form of a noun is used for hypertext, always make sure it suits the content on the other end of the link. (In an inline link to a background feature on Michael Jackson, for instance, the hypertext "Jackson died in June" is OK but "The Jackson family has requested privacy" is not because the surname is part of a compound noun that refers to the dead singer's relatives rather than to the pop star himself).
-   **Limit the number of inline links published**, to avoid hypertext from becoming too distracting. While there may be exceptions, the rule of thumb is:

**Per sentence: 2** (maximum)
**Per paragraph: 3** (maximum)
**Per routine story** (under 500 words): **4** (maximum)
**Per routine feature** (800 to 1,000 words): **8** (maximum)

Some stories may have no inline links. Others may scream out for more than the recommended maximum, depending on what relevant content is available, and whether it enhances our online storytelling when highlighted as hypertext.

-   **Always restrict the choice of inline links to content directly relevant to the narrative**, as outlined in "on point in a meaningful way" in the [internal links](/home/l/links/home/l/links/home/l/links#internal) section above. Resist the temptation to post too many inline links, such as the Wikipedia practice of adding hypertext to virtually every noun that someone has written about at some point in some way (e.g., the month of July or the year 1969).

When **Neil Armstrong** stepped off a **ladder** and into history on **July** 20, **1969**, the images of the **first moon walk** riveted hundreds of millions of **TV** viewers around the world. But it appears the moment wasn't historic enough for **NASA** to keep the original **videotape**.

The above illustrates a poor choice of inline links. Many are vague or off-topic. The story is not about the definition of ladder, the etymology of the word July, other events that happened in 1969, the history of TV, an overview of the U.S. National Aeronautics and Space Administration or the invention of videotape. There are also an unnecessarily large number of links clustered in a single paragraph.

When **Neil Armstrong** stepped off a ladder and into history on July 20, 1969, the images of the **first moon walk** riveted hundreds of millions of TV viewers around the world. But it appears the moment wasn't historic enough for NASA to keep the original videotape.

In the revised version, the inline links are directly tied to the narrative. The first is to a CBCNews.ca profile of the mysteriously reclusive Neil Armstrong and the second to a feature on the Apollo 11 mission.

-   **Prefer specific ("deep") inline links over generic ones**, as outlined in the [internal links](/home/l/links/home/l/links/home/l/links#internal) section above. This does not automatically meaning picking a single, tightly focused story over a broader background feature if that feature offers richer content that's still on topic. It simply means serving our audience by getting them to relevant material quickly, without forcing them to be miners.

The investigation into Jackson's death is widening as more questions are asked about whether **prescription drugs** use may have contributed to his cardiac arrest.

To be effective, the above hypertext should link directly to content about Michael Jackson's reported use of painkillers, powerful anesthetics, etc., rather than to general background on prescription drugs (with no mention of Jackson) or a general feature on the singer (with only peripheral mention of drugs).

-   **Use brief and meaningful text for each inline link** (generally one to three words), avoiding space-wasting directives such as "click here." People's names and other proper nouns are effective as keywords (Mark Carney, Bank of Canada) for material focused on them, such as profiles and timelines. More general words can be good hypertext, too, if the terms are in the news (e.g., credit crisis, Ponzi scheme) or succinctly sum up the content on the other end of the link (latest economic update).

In Canada, Friesen's Corp. of Altona, Man., was chosen to print 300,000 copies of the latest **Harry Potter** book, mainly because of its central location. Shipments can be easily sent across the country from the Prairies. But the company also has a proven record for handling **top-secret publishing** projects.

The first inline link is to a feature on the Harry Potter series, while the second is to a CBCNews.ca story about secrecy in Altona, a small town south of Winnipeg, where the fourth book (_Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire_) was quietly printed months before the title or cover had been officially revealed anywhere in the world. The archived story points out that Friesen's had been previously entrusted to keep a lid on other printing projects, including a Diana biography and Salman Rushdie's _The Satanic Verses_.

**Ellingsen's testimony** is considered crucial for the Crown because she is the only witness who says she saw Pickton with a dead body. She denies defence claims that she was so high on crack cocaine at the time she mistook an animal's carcass for a woman.

The inline link is to a full story on Ellingsen's recent testimony. Pickton's former friend tells the jury that she walked into the slaughterhouse on the accused's Port Coquitlam pig farm and saw him standing, covered in blood, next to a dead woman who was hanging from a chain.

-   **Make certain the narrative is not hurt by an inline link.** Sentences should remain clear, tight, accurate, etc. Avoid disrupting the natural flow with awkward or out-of-place hypertext. Stories should read equally well for those who can see the highlighted inline link and for those who can't (e.g., people on certain wireless devices).
-   **Keep hypertext sensibly consistent through a story.** This is more helpful to readers than illogical variety.

When Bakhtiar published her first novel, **_Bubbling Gravy_**, she received good reviews but very little money. By the time her fourth book, **_Monkeys in Taxis_**, came out a decade later, she sold one million copies within days and was among the country's highest-paid authors.

In the above example, novel titles are used consistently for hypertext. This is preferred if both links are to background on the specific books.

When Bakhtiar published her first novel, _Bubbling Gravy_, she received **good reviews** but very little money. By the time her fourth book, _Monkeys in Taxis_, came out a decade later, she sold **one million copies** within days and was among the country's highest-paid authors.

In the second version, hypertext other than novel titles is used. This is a signal to readers that both links are to content beyond mere general background about the books. The first, "good reviews," suggests an inline link to a piece on the author's early critical success. The second, "one million copies," suggests an inline link to a story focused on the fourth novel's whopping sales.

### 5 tips to keep hypertext brief
 

**1.** Use acceptable shorthand when the formal name is long.

**Mulroney-Schreiber inquiry**

There's no need to adopt the official title used by Parliament: "The Commission of Inquiry into Certain Allegations Respecting Business and Financial Dealings Between Karlheinz Schreiber and the Right Honourable Brian Mulroney." There's also no need to use a long nickname, such as "The Oliphant inquiry into the Mulroney-Schreiber affair," if it buries important keywords.

**2.** Use a generic noun for the hypertext when the proper noun is long.

The **final book** in the series, _Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows_, was published in 2007. It's being turned into two movies, with Part 1 scheduled to be released in November 2010.

This is an example of adding an inline link to content about the final Harry Potter book, without turning the entire italicized title into hypertext.

**3.** Leave titles out of hypertext.

Supreme Court of Canada Chief Justice **Beverley McLachlin**

**4.** Highlight only the relevant part of a proper noun

**Charles Schwab & Company**

(An inline link to content about the company.)
 

**Charles Schwab** & Company

(An inline link to content focused on the firm's founder and chairman.)

**5.** Leave possessives out of hypertext unless on-topic.

**Stockwell Day**'s decision to step down as leader ...

(Example of an inline link to a profile of Stockwell Day.)
 

The fight over **Marlon Brando's will** ...

(Example of an inline link to previous coverage of the legal battle over the actor's will.)

### 2 copy editing caveats

Links in the main bodies of stories affect web writing and editing in a more direct way than side links. In particular:

**1\. Typos and other problems can creep in when hypertext is added to already edited and posted content.** If a journalist returns to a live story to add inline links, it's possible that a few paragraphs will need to be recast to accommodate the most sensible hypertext. Special care must be taken to avoid introducing errors during this stage of publishing.

**2\. Inline links can be inadvertently deleted if the hypertext is revised or deleted.** Tracking down lost "HTTP" code and reinserting links takes time that could be better spent on posting new content. All writers and editors must be vigilant when typing in passages that contain inline links.

## LEGAL ISSUES

The following is an abridged version of guidelines in CBC's _Online News Fundamentals_ book. It's intended to provide general direction only. If you have any specific legal questions about a web story you're working on, you should contact your supervisor and/or the CBC Law Department.

#### Internal links

**When writing about criminal investigations and court cases, be cautious with internal links** to previous CBC stories. Past coverage may include information that, while accurate, should no longer be reported or highlighted through links. **In particular, watch out for:**

-   Criminal history or other details that might prejudice a jury trial.
-   Publication bans.
-   Restrictions on naming young people.

The CBC does not generally delete old stories since these are part of the public record. But for legal reasons, we must sometimes avoid linking to them.

**Also, be careful when posting original, scanned documents, user-generated contributions, etc. In particular, watch out for content that violates:**

-   A court order (e.g., information covered by a ban).
-   Copyright.
-   Other laws (e.g., pornography, hate crimes).

Keep in mind that something as seemingly harmless as a reporter's notes scrawled in the margin of a document we've scanned and published could come back to haunt us for legal or editorial reasons.

#### External links

External links may pose other potential legal and editorial problems because the material is not controlled by the CBC. **When deciding whether to link to an external source, ask yourself if there might be anything on the outside site that for legal or editorial reasons could:**

-   Prejudice a jury trial against a defendant.
-   Violate a publication ban.
-   Identify a young person protected by law.
-   Be considered defamatory.
-   Violate copyright.
-   Break other Canadian laws, including those dealing with hate propaganda and child pornography.
-   Offend readers.
-   Be dangerous (e.g. describe how to build a bomb).

**Since checking every nook and cranny of an external website is unrealistic, consider the reliability of the person or organization behind the site as you scan through it**, and always link to a specific page that you've actually viewed. **Also, be prepared to revisit and remove old links if we receive complaints that turn out to be valid.** Remember: Even when an external website seems fine editorially, there's no guarantee it won't be changed. One day you might link to a page that seems benign and the next day discover content that's unacceptable.

## Publishing priorities

**Never hold up breaking news just to insert links.** One of the web's defining features is speed, as urgent stories are built in front of readers' eyes ― from brief bulletins with "More to come" at the bottom to comprehensive packages. All links (external and internal, side or inline) should be added to breaking news at some point in between, along with various other enhancements (e.g., photos, video, audio).

**In the case of other (non-urgent) coverage**, from news stories to lengthy features, **core links should ideally be added when the content is first posted.** As long as the initial publication of routine news is not significantly delayed by the addition of hypertext, the audience is best served when key, relevant links are there from the start (e.g., an electronic version of the court decision a story is based on or a CBCNews.ca in-depth page about the issue underpinning the lawsuit). **Lower priority can be given to more peripheral links** (e.g., a CBCNews.ca column about the ruling or the external websites of groups on both sides of the dispute).

**There's no single formula or chronology to follow. It largely depends on how readily available the links are** (e.g., if URLs are already known or need to be searched for; if a court ruling or government report has already been posted online or won't be ready for a few hours; if internal, scanned documents or PDFs are already on the CBC's main internet server or need to be created and FTP'd).

## Technical (template) reminders

**All links** (internal, external, margin, inline) **must be added to our journalism using appropriate fields within CBC-sanctioned publishing tools or content management systems.** Avoid any attempts to insert raw HTML yourself (e.g., <HREF>). It can cause serious technical problems. It can also be a waste of time, if CBC's automated HTML filters wind up stripping out your manually written code. 

**There's no need to make decisions about typographical design** (e.g., the colour and boldness of text or whether certain links are underlined). **Central style code automatically determines the actual appearance of links on the site.**

If you're unfamiliar with the technical steps involved in adding links, ask a colleague or your supervisor.

See also [URL](/home/u/urls) for how to handle rare cases of web addresses posted as text rather than in the HTML code of live hypertext, including domain names (CBC.ca, CNN.com) treated as proper nouns in news stories.

### Loblaws

**Loblaws**

The corporation’s full name is actually “Loblaw Cos. Ltd.” (singular “Loblaw,” plural “companies”).

But the division generally referred to in news stories is: Loblaws Supermarkets Ltd. (plural Loblaws, no apostrophe).

**So we write:**

Loblaws Supermarkets or **Loblaws** (for the chain of retail outlets)

**a Loblaws store** or **several Loblaws stores** (for more specific references)

### lockdown\_shutdown

**Lockdown, shutdown**

These **nouns often imply complete confinement** (a school lockdown) **or complete stoppage** (a factory shutdown). **But English is sometimes figurative** (e.g., to "break one's heart" means deep sadness rather than cardiac arrest), which makes imposing literal meanings across the board neither practical nor necessary. Conventions and context matter.

It's **OK to use terms such as "lockdown" and "shutdown" in less absolute ways, as long as the intended meaning is clear**. For example, during coverage of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020, countries were often referred to as being in various stages of lockdown (citizens urged to stay at home) and shutdown (entire sectors of their economies at a standstill).

In cases like this, **a good practice is to either:**

**1\. Specify what is meant**, since definitions can vary; or

**2\. Qualify words such as lockdown and shutdown at least once, relatively high in a story** (e.g., first few paragraphs, although not necessarily in a web headline or TV banner), **to ensure the intended meaning is conveyed**. For instance, depending on the facts that apply:


> **widespread** shutdown
> **partial** lockdown
> **virtual** shutdown
> **substantial** shutdown


As with a lot of language, **common sense is the key. We must avoid wording that is incontestably inaccurate or misleading** — e.g., claiming that large numbers of Canadians have been "ordered" to stay indoors or have been officially "quarantined" when federal and provincial governments have primarily relied on voluntary recommendations to stay at home as much as possible for an extended period. **At the same time, there's no need to ban instantly understood idiomatic phrasing solely because of narrow, literal interpretations.** For instance, when talking about "an economy slowly reopening" after pandemic emergency measures begin easing, there's no need to fret over the fact that some sectors many never actually have "closed," including food production, grocery sales, automotive repair and telecommunications.


**TYPOGRAPHY** **(FUSE NOUNS NOT VERBS)**


**lockdown** (n.), as in a school _lockdown_, a prison _lockdown_
**lock down** (v.), as in to _lock down_ a neighbourhood, to _lock down_ the country

**shutdown** (n.), as in a factory _shutdown_, a industry _shutdown_
**shut down** (v.), as in to _shut down_ production, to _shut down_ a team's offence


### Londonderry versus London

**Londonderry, also known as Derry**

**To remain as neutral as possible in a political fight over language, CBC News refers to this city in Northern Ireland by both names in first reference whenever possible:**


> _“Three people died in the explosion in Londonderry, also known as Derry.”_


This policy, adopted years ago, was reviewed in 2005 and upheld as the best approach for our journalism (radio, television and online).

CBC.ca headlines can use Londonderry alone, but an "also called Derry" reference must appear high in the story. Londonderry can be used after that.


**Background**
This ancient city was originally called Derry based on the Irish word Doire, which meant "place of oaks." But when it was rebuilt with money from investors in London in the 1600s, it was renamed Londonderry.

Unionists (mainly Protestants in Northern Ireland) still call it Londonderry, which is how it’s been conventionally known in many parts of the world for years. But nationalists (mainly Irish Catholics in the region) never accepted the new name and continue to call the community Derry or Derry City.

Although nationalist politicians have adopted Derry at the municipal level, where Catholics are in the majority, unionists argue that the official name is specified as Londonderry in a Royal Charter.

BBC journalists are told to use Londonderry first, with Derry or Derry City acceptable in subsequent references.

See also [U.K.](/home/u/united-kingdom), [Britain](/home/b/britain) and [Northern Ireland](/home/i/ireland).

### like versus such as

**Lunar New Year**

**Prefer Lunar New Year in generic references** to the holiday that's known by different names in various East Asian countries (e.g., the Chinese New Year and the Spring Festival in China, Seollal in South Korea and Tet in Vietnam).

It's **OK to use more specific names in stories focused on a particular community** (e.g., the **Chinese New Year** in a report about festivities in China, the **Korean New Year**, the **Vietnamese New Year**).

The festival begins between the end of January and the end of February, depending on moon phases. It's determined by a lunisolar calendar first adopted in China. "Lunisolar" means that a given number of moon phases is eventually lined up with a traditional solar year of 365 days. An ordinary lunisolar year has 353 to 355 days while a lunisolar leap year has between 383 and 385 days.

Be aware that **there's technically more than one "lunar new year."** For example, the Islamic New Year is a completely separate lunar-based holiday that slowly shifts through the entire Gregorian calendar over the centuries. The Islamic calendar is lunar but not "lunisolar," which means there's no attempt to use leap years to "correct" a given number of moon phases in order to match a traditional solar year of 365 days.) **Nevertheless, it's generally unnecessary to specify East Asian** when referring to the Lunar New Year because the entrenched meaning is understood by context. In rare cases when there might be ambiguity, compounds such as **East Asian New Year** or **East Asian Lunar New Year** are fine.

The Chinese horoscope is a key feature of the lunisolar calendar. Each year is assigned one of 12 animals from the Chinese zodiac (e.g., rat, dragon, dog). A few of the animals vary, depending on where the New Year is being celebrated (e.g., a cat instead of a rabbit in Vietnam). Use initial caps in the names (e.g., **Year of the Tiger**, **Year of the Horse**).

See [holidays](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/h/holidays/ "Holidays") for related capitalization guidelines.

In the case of legislation, however, it's often easier to paraphrase (e.g., Canada's medical marijuana regulations). Keep in mind that government department programs are not treated as proper nouns, and do not need to be capitalized or spelled in the same way. For instance, what Health Canada calls its "Medical Marihuana Access Program" can be referred to by us more generically as Health Canada's medical marijuana access program. Although once considered a tad lofty in certain contexts, cannabis has become increasingly common in day-to-day reporting. Keep in mind that even proper nouns can be defined or described in more than one way (e.g., the Cannabis Act tabled in the House of Commons in 2017 "set the stage for the legal production and sale of marijuana in Canada"). Pot, believed to be derived from a Spanish term related to cannabis leaves, "_potiguaya,_" is a common and generally acceptable synonym for cannabis or marijuana. However, **be aware that colloquialisms like "pot," or other similar terms such as “weed,” can affect the tone of stories**. So consider that when choosing which words are best suited to the story. Recreational use of marijuana became legal across Canada on Oct. 17, 2018, although new rules were created to control production, distribution, sale and possession, as outlined in the federal government's [cannabis legalization overview](http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/cj-jp/cannabis/). **mentally ill** (refers to insanity, mental instability, depression, schizophrenia, etc.) See [disability terms](/home/d/disability-language#mentallyill) for editorial caution

**menswear, womenswear** (See also [female-male](/home/f/femalemale))

****Mercedes-Benz*

*merchant marine****

**mercy killing** (requires care) See [assisted dying](/home/a/assisted_dying)

**MERS** (Middle East respiratory syndrome) Can be referred to as either the **MERS coronavirus** or as **MERS** in first reference. Spelling out in full at some point in stories is optional but usually unnecessary. The SARS-like condition was first documented in 2012. It was named the **Middle East respiratory syndrome** by the World Health Organization in early 2013. Do not refer to MERS, itself, as a "virus." It's a respiratory illness caused by a virus, in the same way that [AIDS](/home/a/aids) and [SARS](/home/s/sars) are caused by viruses.

**the Messiah, a messiah**

**Meta Platforms Inc.** (formerly called Facebook Inc.) OK to use **Meta** throughout stories. The parent company of Facebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp changed its name in October 2021. Use lowercase **metaverse**, a sci-fi term coined in the 1990s, when referring to the company's virtual reality 3D project.

**meteor, meteoroid, meteorite** (these words have separate meanings) When meteoroids enter a planet's atmosphere, they become meteors. A lot of meteors falling in a short period are known as **meteor showers**. Meteors that don't burn up entirely and actually hit the planet are called meteorites. See [asteroids, comets and meteors](/home/a/asteroids-meteors) for details.

**meter**
meter (**a gauge**); thermometer, barometer, parking meter, taxi meter, etc. In rare cases, also used as a suffix for a specific type of measurement (diameter, pentameter, etc.)

**metre**
metre (**a metric measurement** equivalent to about 39.4 inches) When shortened, use "**m**" alone with no period, singular or plural (akin to km/h) See [metric versus imperial](/home/m/metric-versus-imperial).

**methadone**

**methodology** (implies an established approach to something) Almost always refers to formal research in the sciences, social sciences, etc. The term usually implies traditional statistical analysis (e.g., representative samplings of populations) that produce results within specified margins of error. It's OK to talk about **methods** used by researchers (e.g., phone surveys). But "methodology" is the preferred term when referring to the overall collection and interpretation of data, including various assumptions found in footnotes (e.g., interest rate projections, economic growth forecasts).

**Métis** Métis broadly refers to descendants of people of mixed First Nations and European ancestry who share a common culture. However, there are varying definitions of what it means to be Métis, and who is or isn't Métis can be contentious. In most cases, Métis citizens will be a member of a recognized Métis organization and can trace their family lineage to recognized Métis families and geographic locations. See [Indigenous](/home/i/Indigenous)

**metrication** (not metrification, but avoid both)

**metro** (lowercase for generic use, such as describing new bus routes in a large city as changes to "metro transit"); Metro (when the word is part of a proper noun, such as Metrorail or the Washington Metro). Use Metro to refer to Montreal's subway system (e.g., a Montreal Metro station) even though the word is often all lowercase in English in Quebec to match preferred French capitalization. See [French words](/home/f/french-words-and-accents#capitalization) for the relevant guidelines on using English capitalization. See also [the Underground](/home/l#Underground) for style guidelines on London's subway system.

**Middle East, Mideast** (_never_ Near East) Conventionally means: Iraq, Iran, Israel and the [Palestinian territories](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#palestine), Jordan, Syria, Lebanon, Turkey, Cyprus, Egypt, Libya, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Yemen, Oman, Bahrain, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates. It does _not_ normally refer to the Sudan or to Islamic countries in northwestern Africa (Tunisia, Morocco and Algeria), even though these are sometimes mentioned in stories about the region. It also does _not_ normally mean Afghanistan, which is historically considered to be in Central Asia — sandwiched between the Mideast and the Indian subcontinent. See also [**Middle East glossary**](/home/m/middle-east-glossary) for detailed language guidelines.

See [**royal titles**](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/r/royal-titles/#princewilliam "Royal titles") for more detailed guidelines.

When referring to the conurbation, it's OK to use a hyphen: **Minneapolis-St. Paul**. This form is also found in some proper nouns, such as **the Minneapolis-St. Paul Airport**. **misogyny** (n.), **misogynistic** (adj.) The meaning of misogyny has broadened beyond "hatred of women" since the late 20th century. It's now defined by the Oxford English Dictionary as "hatred or dislike of, or prejudice against, women." Misogyny is not limited to violence, threatening behaviour, etc. It also commonly refers to the dehumanization or objectification of women, including sexist mockery, belittlement, hateful body shaming and other denigration.

**Mississippi (Miss.)** See [United States](/home/u/united-states)

**Mississippi Delta** (large, flat area in Mississippi's northwest). Although technically not a delta (a term for land formed at the mouth of a river), Mississippi Delta is the common name for this part of the state. Its initial letters are capitalized. _Do not confuse this noun with the_ **Mississippi River delta**, which is a true delta between the Mississippi River and the Gulf of Mexico. To distinguish the two, keep delta lowercase when referring to the latter. The Mississippi River delta is about 500 kilometres south of the Mississippi Delta.

**Missouri (Mo.)** See [United States](/home/u/united-states)

**mistress** (requires caution) OK when used as the female equivalent of "master" (e.g. a dominant woman in a sadomasochistic relationship). Otherwise, **generally avoid to mean a man's extramarital lover** unless attributed (e.g., in court testimony), since there's no comparable "master" form for a married woman's lover. If adultery is relevant to a story, the detail can often be conveyed in a factual statement (e.g., "Smith said she didn't know her husband had been having an affair for the past five years"). If labels are required, prefer conversational, gender-inclusive words (e.g., **lover**) over lofty alternatives (e.g., **paramour**). Historically, a mistress was not merely an extramarital lover but also financially supported by a man over a long period of time. Regardless, the dated, gender-specific term is at odds with CBC's commitment to preferring inclusive language whenever practical. See also [limiting the '-ess' suffix](/home/e/-ess) for related guidelines.

**MK-ULTRA** (all caps, with hyphen) The code name of a mind control program secretly conducted by the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency at a psychiatric clinic in Canada in the 1950s and '60s. The two-letter prefix is rooted in an obscure system of CIA cryptonyms. The four-letter suffix reflects an extreme classification level — i.e., "ultra" secret. Although there are many spellings, MK-ULTRA has become relatively entrenched in recent decades. The hyphen helps make the code name easier to read. It also matches the pronunciation. (See [quirky capitalization](/home/q/quirky-capitalization) for general caveats about all-uppercase or all-lowercase terms.)

**MMIWG** (missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls) Use the full abbreviation when referring to the inquiry ordered by the federal government in 2016, or to related issues and criminal cases (i.e., prefer MMIWG over MMIW). Generally limit use of such abbreviations to places where space is tight (e.g., web headlines). In French, "women and girls" is covered by two Fs (for _femmes_ and _filles_) in the initials FFADA: _L’Enquête nationale sur les femmes et les filles autochtones disparues et assassinées_. Always spell out MMIWG at least once in stories. In generic references, all words except Indigenous are lowercase — e.g., **the police investigation into missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls**. In the case of the **MMIWG inquiry**, the word inquiry is lowercase unless the full title is given (i.e., the **National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls**). See [Indigenous](/home/i/Indigenous) as well as [abbreviations](/home/a/abbreviations) for related guidelines.

**mom, mommy, mommies** (colloquial shorthand for **momma,** which, in turn is a variation of a child's pronunciation of "ma ma." meaning "mother") For consistency, prefer the common North American spelling "mom" over the primarily British version mum (mummy, mummies) in most generic contexts (e.g., **their mom, a mom-and-pop store**). Exceptions are proper nouns (e.g., book titles), attributed verbatim text excerpts from written sources (e.g., the poignant "Mummy" card on top of Princess Diana's coffin in 1997), and other entrenched usage (e.g., the [**Queen Mum**](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/r/royal-titles/#kingvsqueen "Royal titles")). Do not confuse with the adjective [mum](#mum), which means to be silent.

**monsignor** (abbreviate as **Msgr.** only if context makes the meaning clear) Monsignor is an honorary title in the Roman Catholic Church given to priests for distinguished service. Since Msgr. is not an instantly recognized abbreviation, it's often easiest to spell out in full: **Monsignor Raymond Hanna**, with either Hanna or the monsignor in second reference. The title can also be abbreviated before the person's full name: **Msgr. Raymond Hanna**. If a [priest](/home/p#priest) is a monsignor, there's no need to use the term reverend or the abbreviation [Rev.](/home/r#Rev) The word monsignor is acceptable as a noun (e.g., "The monsignor waved hello").

**mpox** (new name of **monkeypox** adopted by the World Health Organization in November 2022) Use mpox (pronounced "EM-pocks") in first reference, including headlines, leads, TV banners, etc. It's OK to define briefly in stories once (e.g., "previously called monkeypox" or "formerly known as monkeypox") to avoid confusion until mpox becomes more familiar. This means that **while mpox should be our default choice, it's also crucial to be clear we're not reporting on a new or different disease.** The term monkeypox was coined in the 1950s before WHO guidelines were established to avoid disease names that were stigmatizing, potentially misleading, etc.

**MP3 player, MP3.com** (company)

**MRI** (magnetic resonance imaging) There is no need to spell out the abbreviation. MRIs rely on a gigantic magnet that lines up the nuclei of hydrogen atoms in a patient's body. A computer then generates an image based on how this magnetic field changes when exposed to radio waves. The scans are relatively costly to produce and aren't available at all hospitals or diagnostic centres. MRIs are considered especially valuable for examining soft tissues because these have a high concentration of water (i.e., hydrogen molecules). X-rays, on the other hand, cannot be used to photograph soft tissues. (See also [CT and CAT scans](/home/c/ct-and-cat-scans), which rely on X-rays)

**MS** (OK in headlines and second reference, but generally spell out **multiple sclerosis** at least once); **MS therapy** (See also [Zamboni therapy, so-called "liberation therapy"](/home/z/zamboni-liberation-ms-therapy))

**Mt. Gox** (Toyko-based [bitcoin](/home/b#bitcoin) exchange) Prefer this English spelling over various alternatives, including MTGOX.

**Muzak** ([trademark](/home/t/trade-names) for recorded background music)

**MV** (nautical term for "motor vessel"); unlike [HMCS](/home/h/hmcs), "the" may be used in front of this craft's name, as in "the MV Canadian Princess" and "the MV Hamilton Transfer."

**MX** (See [Montreal Stock Exchange](/home/m#MontrealExchange))

**myalgic encephalomyelitis** (also known as **chronic fatigue syndrome**) It's OK to use the entrenched term "chronic fatigue syndrome" high in a story because it's clearest to our audience (e.g., "myalgic encephalomyelitis, commonly called chronic fatigue syndrome ..."). But generally **prefer ME/CFS in second reference**, to acknowledge the medical community's move away from the old name. **In broadcast scripts, more conversational options include ME alone in second reference**, as well as "the illness," "the syndrome," "the disorder," etc. ME/CFS is a mysterious, complex and disabling condition characterized by overwhelming exhaustion. The term myalgic encephalomyelitis (ME) was coined in the 1930s, when the first cases were recorded. The illness was dubbed chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS) in the 1980s — language that some doctors now argue was a mistake. Critics of the term CFS say it trivializes a serious medical condition, and is akin to calling dementia "chronic forgetfulness syndrome."

**Myanmar** (Use this name of the country throughout stories, including in headlines and leads) OK to add "**also known as Burma**" once in second reference when deemed helpful to audience. The largest city is **Yangon** (formerly called "Rangoon"). For more details, including use of the entrenched English word **Myanmarese**, see **[Myanmar](/home/m/Myanmar)**.

****

### mad cow disease

**Mad cow disease**

**This is the common term for "bovine spongiform encephalopathy."**

It's fine in first reference, but **the disease should be identified** as bovine spongiform encephalopathy **at some point in the story whenever practical**. [Do not use italics](/handy-links/punctuation/italics).

The scientific term can be shortened to **BSE** after that. BSE has no periods and is lowercase when spelled out. (See [abbreviations](/home/a/abbreviations) for details)

**Do not use the expression "so-called" mad cow disease.** (See [so-called](/home/s/so-called))

Be aware that BSE falls within the umbrella of **transmissible spongiform encephalopathy (TSE)**, an umbrella category of incurable, fatal brain diseases that can affect people, cattle, sheep, deer and other animals.

See also [CJD](/home/c/cjd) (Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease) as well as [zombie deer disease](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/z/#zombiedeer "Z").

See also [scientific names](/home/l/latin-scientific-names) for more detailed guidelines on Latin terms

Read the CBCNews.ca 2012 feature [Quick facts about mad cow disease](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews%2Ftechnology%2Fquick-facts-about-mad-cow-disease-1.1134991&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2JYREeB6m596a-4jLSnYFu)

### Magazine

**Magazine versus magazine**

**Keep "magazine" lowercase unless it's part of a publication's proper name:**

Harper's Magazine (Harper's in second reference)
_but_ Maclean's magazine
Report on Business Magazine
_but_ The New Yorker magazine

Check the masthead if you're not certain.

The generic word "magazine" doesn’t have to be appended to the names of well-known publications, such as:

The Atlantic Monthly
Maclean's
Newsweek
The New Yorker
Time

See also [The versus the](/home/t/the-versus-the)
See also [capitalization](/home/c/capitalization) (an overview)

### Mormon Mormonism

**Mass shooting**

There's no consensus over the definition of "**mass shooting**." In our journalism, however, it conventionally means that **at least four people have been killed or wounded by gunfire in a short amount of time** at one or more nearby locations. The figure does not include the deaths or injuries of assailants.


**NOTE:** This style was adopted in May of 2023. Previously, we had generally followed the FBI’s definition of “mass shooting” as at least four people killed. But that narrow meaning raised questions about clear coverage of attacks involving multiple injuries (e.g., a dozen wounded) but few or no deaths. **We continue to use the term “[mass murder](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/h/homicide/#mass-murder "Homicide")” to mean four or more homicides** at roughly the same time in a small geographical area.



**Background on the number 4**
In January of 2013, the U.S. Congress defined "mass shooting" as three or more deaths in a single incident. and some criminologists began compiling statistics using that figure. Later that year, the FBI adopted a different definition of "at least four people" murdered with a gun in one attack, and the U.S. Congressional Research Service eventually mirrored that metric.

Around the same time, meanwhile, the independent, U.S. non-profit group [Gun Violence Archive](https://www.gunviolencearchive.org/) decided to focus on total casualties rather than just fatalities. As a result, it defined “mass shooting” as at least four or more people dead OR injured in a single attack, not including the assailant.

This has left news organizations divided. In the spring of 2023, for instance, Associated Press continued to define mass shootings as at least four dead, while CNN and some others used the broader definition of at least four dead or injured. A [February 2023 Poynter Institute feature](https://www.poynter.org/fact-checking/2023/definition-mass-shooting/) provides additional background on the inconsistent approaches.


**Define 'mass shooting' in stories when statistics are quoted**
No reasonable person would ever dispute that, say, the slaughter of a dozen children inside a school is a "mass shooting." So it's often unnecessary to explain why we're using that language in our coverage of such a horrific tragedy. We’re also **not obligated to describe every attack as a “mass shooting” solely because a specific, debatable threshold is met** (e.g., one killed and three injured). Other factors may have a bearing on the language chosen (e.g., a person killing his family and then taking his own life inside a house versus a shooting at a public place like a school, church or shopping mall). Exercise your own judgment.

But **when quoting statistics about the number of "mass shootings" in a given country over a given time period, it's important to define what we mean**, and to make sure that the data we're citing is from sources that measure death and injury tolls the same way. In particular, we should be transparent with our audience about what we mean when reporting a rise or fall in mass shootings from year to year.

Be aware that some people prefer terms like **mass casualty events** instead of mass shootings across the board because they feel that "mass casualty" better reflects the trauma experienced by all victims, including survivors — from the injured and those who saw others gunned down to friends and relatives of the dead. While such language can have its place in stories, the term "mass casualty" is comparatively nebulous (e.g., it could apply to victims of a plane crash, subway explosion, building collapse), and, so, less meaningful without context. But **the spirit of the word "casualty" is worth considering in coverage of mass shootings. The noun conveys death as well as injury, including trauma.** And, so, in addition to reporting the specific number of lives lost and people wounded on a given day, we should remember that there can be countless individuals changed forever by a single mass shooting.

See also [massacre](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/m/#massacre "M")
See also [shooting spree](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/s/spree/ "Spree") (avoid)
See also [firearms](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/w/weapons/#assault_rifle "Weapons") (e.g., distinguish between assault-style weapons and assault weapons)
See also [serial killer](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/s/#serialkiller "S")

**Mayor versus mayor**

**Keep the word "mayor" lowercase unless it's before the name of someone who currently holds the office:**

Mississauga Mayor Hazel McCallion
the mayor of Mississauga
former mayor McCallion
acting mayor McCallion (_temporary_ post)
the acting mayor
mayor-elect McCallion (_not sworn_ in yet)

### metric versus imperial

**Metric versus imperial**

[General guidelines](/home/m/metric-versus-imperial#generalguidelines) (metric versus imperial)

[Key metric exceptions](/home/m/metric-versus-imperial#keyexceptions) (pounds, feet, etc.)

[Distances](/home/m/metric-versus-imperial#distances) (kilometres, not hours; map estimates)

[Temperatures](/home/m/metric-versus-imperial#temperatures) (C, F, degrees, etc.)

[Spelling out](/home/m/metric-versus-imperial#spellingout) (cm versus centimetres, etc.)

[Abbreviating](/home/m/metric-versus-imperial#abbreviating) (km/h, etc.) 

[Sports](/home/m/metric-versus-imperial#sports) (10K run, etc.)

**General guidelines**
**In general, use metric not imperial measurements in news stories.** This includes the heights of airplanes and mountains (metres not feet), the sizes of farms (hectares not acres), most weights (kilograms not pounds), distances, even at sea (kilometres not miles), speeds (km/h), etc.

> _They drove 800 kilometres on a single tank of gas._
>
> _The earth is roughly 150 million kilometres from the sun._
>
> _The cheetah ran the 100-metre dash in 5.95 seconds._
>
> _Winds were clocked at more than 220 km/h when the storm hit._
>
> _The plane was at 7,000 metres when trouble began._
>
> _Mount Everest is estimated to be 8,848 metres._
>
> _The average size of a farm in Saskatchewan is 675 hectares._


**Key metric exceptions**
**The main exceptions are: people's height** (_He was six feet two inches_) and **people's weight** (_185 pounds_), **real estate descriptions** of buildings and standard municipal lots (_1,200-square-foot bungalow and 40 by 100 feet, but 10 hectares_), **some construction materials and hardware** (e.g., half-inch nails and two-by-fours), **certain price ratios entrenched by an industry or commercial sector** (e.g., the lobster fishery's _per pound_ pricing, precious metals reported in troy _ounces_, and natural gas consumption measured in cubic feet) , **various idiomatic expressions** (e.g., _giving an inch, going a mile a minute_), **and other terms established through convention** (e.g., _a ten-gallon hat, a half-ton truck_).

See also [**entrenched industry standards**](/home/m/metric-versus-imperial#industrystandards) below for limits to preferences such as "_per pound_ " lobster prices, **[real estate versus land area](/home/m/metric-versus-imperial#landarea)** for more on hectares instead of _acres_, as well as **[heights and weights](/home/n/numbers#heightsandweights)** for details on figures versus spelled-out numbers (e.g., six feet two inches can also be informally expressed as 6-2), when to use hyphens (_a 7,100-square-foot mansion versus the mansion was 7,100 square feet_), etc.


**Entrenched industry standards**
**To determine whether metric exceptions apply to certain commercial or industrial contexts, consider how the sector as a whole handles the measurements.** Some farmers may prefer "acres" and some gas station owners may like "gallons," but we would still report on _hectares_ and _litres_ in these cases. On the other hand, since the entire financial sector continues to use _ounces_ for gold, this has become a newsroom preference too. Note: Gold is traditionally measured in troy ounces, which are slightly heavier units, and baldly converting to grams would be inaccurate. In other words, while the adjective _troy_ is implied and normally unnecessary when reporting precious metals, it could not be ignored if we actually decided to perform calculations based on a 12-ounce pound instead of a 16-ounce one.

**Even when an industry standard is imperial** (e.g., the lobster fishery uses per pound rather than per kilogram pricing), **there are limits to such usage**. It would not apply to marine exhibits, grocery sales, cooking, etc. So a CBCNews.ca story about the lobster industry as a whole can use imperial measurements throughout (e.g., _fishermen received $4 per pound_). But a story focused on the century-old lobster Big Dee-Dee caught in New Brunswick in 2008 should report the crustacean’s weight in metric (i.e., _10 kilograms_ rather than _22 pounds_), just as any recipe would be reported in metric (in the case of lobster, beef, chicken, etc.).

**Always keep the best interest of readers in mind when an industry's imperial exceptions are preserved. A metric equivalent in brackets should be considered if it’s deemed helpful.** For instance, in an article about the lobster fishery, the first reference to "per pound" prices could include a metric conversion if the story also happened to feature information about what consumers were paying for the same product in the store (which should be reported as a "per kilogram" ratio):

> _In Nova Scotia last year, lobster prices on the wharf fell to $3.50 per pound ($7.70 per kilogram). By contrast, sale prices for live lobsters in grocery stores dropped to about $13 per kilogram._


Such extra detail should aid a reader’s understanding of the story rather than simply clutter the page with alternative figures and units. Use your judgment.


**Real estate versus land area**
**Living space, factory space, etc., are OK in imperial** (a _600-square-foot apartment_, an _11,000-square-foot_ film studio). Although standard municipal lot sizes can also be reported this way (_40 by 100 feet_) as part of an established real estate convention, all other **land size should generally be reported in metric**, including farms and the amount of damage caused by forest fires. These guidelines are based on common usage. Even when governments or other authorities occasionally specify imperial units in regulations (a _3,000-acre maximum_), CBCNews.ca style is to convert for consistency (_a 1,214-hectare maximum_).


See [dimensions](/home/n/numbers#dimensions) for related guidelines

**Adding metric conversions to quotes**
**If people use imperial measurements in direct quotes, provide metric equivalents either in square brackets or separate sentences if this additional information helps readers.** For instance, clarifying nautical miles is beneficial: _"Ottawa must do more to protect Canada's 200-nautical-mile \[370-kilometre\] fishing limit."_ But converting a commonly understood measurement like "50 yards" would unnecessarily spoil a quote's flow: _"The hunters had walked about 50 yards down the path, just out of sight, when — bang — we heard a gunshot."_ Use common sense.


**Distances (kilometres, not hours; map estimates)**
**Avoid measuring distances in time** (e.g., _the community is one hour west of Toronto_). The duration of a trip can vary substantially, depending on weather, traffic, the type of vehicle, the driver, etc. Include time only when it's relevant (e.g., if an ambulance took 25 minutes to travel a distance normally covered in 10 minutes).

**Generally use "straight-line" map measurements when reporting distances** unless the actual driving stretch is well known (e.g., two nearby communities separated by one road) or essential details of a story are lost with a "crow flies" calculation (e.g., in an article about the trucking industry that benefits from specific reference to the number of actual kilometres logged). For simplicity, **the convention is to estimate distances from the centre of each community** (e.g., from one downtown core to another), partly because a given municipality's official boundary can vary over time through annexation, economic development, etc.

For consistency and accuracy, it's a common practice to measure distances in Canada using the "point-to-point" calculation tool provided by the [Canadian Geographical Names Service](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww4.rncan.gc.ca%2Fsearch-place-names%2Fsearch%3Flang%3Den&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2lOY1kZcpa3sVZHHX8XWOf) of **Natural Resources Canada**, the same authority we turn to for the official spellings of most geographical names across the country. Its distance calculator is found at the bottom of whatever entry you're starting with (e.g., Winnipeg). Another option is to use a reliable web-based tool such as **Google Maps**. Since all these tools generally rely on universally catalogued latitude and longitude co-ordinates,  the **"straight line" results should be virtually identical** (e.g., the **distance from Winnipeg to Iqaluit** is estimated at **2291 kilometres** on the CGNS website, and **2290 kilometres** on Google Maps, if you start and end in the centre of each community's downtown). 


**Nautical miles**
A mile is 5,280 feet (about 1,600 metres). At sea, the term mile represents a slightly greater distance (i.e., a nautical mile is roughly 1,850 metres). **Generally use metres or kilometres for all distances, whether on land, over water or above the ground.** Consider exceptions when established by convention (e.g., report on "Canada's 200-nautical-mile zone") if this serves our audience best. In these cases, extra information is often helpful (e.g., adding "or about 370 kilometres" in brackets in our web journalism).


**Hectares and acres**
Never refer to "_square hectares_" (or "_square acres_"), since these units are, by definition, already squared. A hectare is 10,000 square metres, while an acre is 4,840 square yards. A hectare is roughly 2.5 times bigger than an acre. (See also [conversions](/home/m/metric-versus-imperial#conversions) below)


**Temperatures**
**Prefer a figure and then C when writing temperatures** (instead of using the word "degrees"). Generally report in Celsius unless there is a specific reason to use Fahrenheit, such as in a directly transcribed quote. Always leave a space between the figure and the uppercase letter (C or F). This blank spot not only makes the number stand out, it also represents an invisible degree symbol (˚) in standard typography:

> _17 C_ but never 17 degrees C (the blank spot, itself, indicates "degrees")
>
> _5 C_
>
> _28 C (82 F)_


**Use an "[en dash](/handy-links/punctuation/dash)" (HTML code &#8211;), **not** a hyphen, for the minus sign (–15 C)**. Do not put a space between the dash and the figure:–34 C

The "one to nine" rule (figures under 10 spelled out) only applies to temperatures when the C or F abbreviation is dropped:

> _The room was 8 C._
>
> _The temperature inside the car rose eight degrees._
>
> _The child's body temperature fell two degrees._
>
> _2 C_ or _two degrees_ (but never 2 degrees or 2 degrees C)


**Celsius is generally implied when C or F are dropped.** Write out Celsius and Fahrenheit when they appear on their own as words:

> _28 degrees_
>
> _–15 degrees_
>
> _The agency reported temperatures in Celsius and Fahrenheit._


For caveats about the term "wind chill," see [weather words](/home/w/weather-words#windchill).


**Spelling out**
**It's OK to use shortened forms** (km, kg, etc.) **where space is limited** (e.g., in headlines, tables, graphics). **Otherwise, spell out most metric units**.

> _The towns are about 60 kilometres apart._
>
> _By dawn, 50 millimetres of [**rain**](/home/w/weather-words#rain) had fallen._
>
> _He walked 40 kilometres carrying a 30-kilogram backpack, which included 20 grams of marijuana and one litre of lemonade._


**The main exceptions are temperatures** (_12 C_), **rates of speed** (_100 km/h_), **fuel consumption** (_8.4 L/100 km_) **and widely used abridged forms** (e.g., _8-mm film,
105-mm cannon, a 100-GB hard drive, a 50-KB file_), which are all OK in first and subsequent references.

Note: When spelling out fuel consumption, drop the capital L for litre (7.8 L/100 km) which is used in the abbreviation to avoid possible confusion with the figure 1:

> _The vehicle also costs less to run, using an average of 7.2 litres of gas per 100 kilometres of highway driving._


If a term is widely used by industry but still relatively uncommon in everyday speech, spell out in full in brackets in first reference. The abbreviation can be used on its own after that. Retain the imperial unit (Mcf) if it's entrenched through convention:

> _Natural gas prices dropped to about $4 Mcf (million cubic feet) in June._


**(Abbreviating) mm, cm, km, kg, etc.**
**When shortened, metric units are both singular and plural. They do not include periods or a letter "s" at the end.** The abbreviations for "square" (sq.) and "cubic" (cu.), however, do include periods. Put a space between the figure and the metric term. When writing adjectives, replace the space with a hyphen (_9-mm handgun_).


 **cm**

 centimetre, centimetres

 **cu. cm** 

 cubic centimetres

 **cu. m**

 cubic metres

 **GB**

 gigabyte, gigabytes

 **g**

 gram, grams

 **ha**

 hectare, hectares

 **KB**

 kilobyte, kilobytes

 **kg** 

 kilogram, kilograms

 **km**

 kilometre, kilometres

 **km/h**

 kilometres an hour

 **kW**

 kilowatt, kilowatts

 **kWh**

 kilowatt hour, kilowatt hours

 **l**

 litre, litres (_\* lowercase, but see L/100 km below_)

 **L/100 km** 

 litres per 100 kilometres (_\* Use L to avoid confusion with the figure 1_) 

 **MG**

 megabyte, megabytes

 **m**

 metre, metres

 **m/s**

 metres per second

 **mg**

 milligram, milligrams

 **ml**

 millilitre, millilitres

 **mm**

 millimetre, millimetres

 **sq. cm**

 square centimetres

 **sq. m**

 square metres

 **sq. mm**

 square millimetres

 **TB**

 terabyte, terabytes

 **t** 

 tonne, tonnes


**Imperial abbreviations are also singular and plural, but most include periods** (e.g., in., ft., sq. ft., yd., oz., lb.)


**50K, 10K, 5K**
When referring to long-distance running, **a capital K is often used to represent kilometres**. Type it flush to the figure (an exception to the general rule, based on long-established convention).

> _10,000-metre race_
>
> _10-kilometre race_
>
> _10K_


See [Olympics](/home/o/olympic-games) for more details on CBCSports.ca style


**Conversions**
**Sometimes it makes editorial sense to add an imperial measurement in brackets**, if we think this detail will help a large segment of our audience. **Round figures when converting** (e.g., "_about 300 hectares,_" "_just over 10,000 litres,_" etc.)

NOTE: **It's generally sufficient to round to the nearest half unit** (e.g., 0.5 inches), unless a more precise measurement is deemed necessary for the story (e.g., in medical or scientific reporting):


> _The maximum size of carry-on luggage is 55 by 35 by 20 centimetres (21.5 by 13.5 by 7.5 inches)._


**There are many good spots on the web to convert measurements, including a tool offered by Google.** (All you need is a starting number, the desired units and the word "in." For instance, you type "_125 miles in kilometres_" in Google's search engine and hit enter.)


See also **[numbers](/home/n/numbers)** (main overview)
