### Mi'kmaq

**Mi'kmaq versus Mi'kmaw**

[Mi'kmaq](/home/m/mi-kmaq#Mi-kmaq) (plural n.)
[Mi'kmaw](/home/m/mi-kmaq#Mi-kmaw) (singular n., plus default adj.)


**4 rules at a glance**

It's **important to distinguish between these proper nouns**. Here are the basics:


> 1\. Limit use of Mi'kmaq to plural subjects/nouns.
> 2\. Generally avoid adding "people" after Mi'kmaq.
> 3\. Use Mi'kmaw for ALL adjectives, outside of certain established names.
> 4\. Refer to the language, itself, as Mi'kmaw.


The rest of this entry provides details and examples. There's also a section at the bottom summarizing a style shift in the fall of 2020 that expanded our use of "Mi'kmaw" in news coverage.

 See also [pronunciation](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fmtlntapps08.apps.in.cbcsrc.ca%2Fapps%2Flng%2Frecherche%2Findex.aspx%3FProId%3D37401&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw34y-u_YZy8pu8duoeNHQSY) (VPN connection required outside CBC)


**Mi'kmaq**

**Mi'kmaq is a plural noun that refers to an Indigenous people** originally from areas now known as Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, P.E.I., Newfoundland and the Gaspé Peninsula in Quebec. For many years, the word was spelled "Micmac" in English. But the revised transliteration, Mi'kmaq, better reflects the extant Indigenous pronunciation, according to linguists. **Avoid the spelling Micmac** except in rare historical references (e.g., "HMCS Micmac was a destroyer built during the Second World War"). **Mi'kmaq can mean all members of the nation or smaller groups of people:**


> The top court agreed that the treaty rights of **Mi'kmaq** are clear.
> Local **Mi'kmaq** want to sell more lobsters to non-Indigenous people.
> The first hockey sticks were made by the **Mi'kmaq** in the 1800s.
> The **Mi'kmaq** entered the conference room on the third day of talks.


**NEVER add an "s" to Mi'kmaq**, which is already plural. And **generally avoid saying or writing "Mi'kmaq people,"** which is considered quasi-tautological. Mi'kmaq is roughly translated as "allies" or "kin," so the word "people" is already implied. It's similar to why we discourage "Inuit people," which literally means "people" people when translated from Inuktut.


**Mi'kmaw**

**Mi'kmaw is the singular form of Mi'kmaq** (i.e., to describe a member of the Mi'kmaq). But generally **avoid using it as a noun in this context** outside of transcribed quotes (e.g., write "She is Mi'kmaw" NOT "She is a Mi'kmaw," along the lines of "He is Indigenous" and "They are Black" rather than "He is an Indigenous" and "They are Blacks").

**Mi'kmaw is the preferred adjective modifying ANY noun**, whether plural or singular:


> **Mi'kmaw leaders** met with the premier.
> Their exhibit showcases **Mi'kmaw artists**.
> **Mi'kmaw treaty rights** must be respected, the court ruled.
> The **Mi'kmaw delegation** included a poet, a doctor and a retired judge.
> She's a **Mi'kmaw lawyer**.
> The **Mi'kmaw engineering student** won first place.
> He returned to the **Mi'kmaw community** a decade ago.
> The **Mi'kmaw custom** dates back to the 1500s.


**The main exceptions are proper nouns**, which may vary in style — including in spelling. Follow the declared preferences of individual groups:


> The **Assembly of Nova Scotia Mi’kmaq Chiefs** backed the proposal.
> The **Paqtnkek Mi'kmaw Nation** is near Antigonish, N.S.
> She's a member of the **Listuguj Mi'gmaq government** in Quebec (proper noun), but the **Mi'kmaw** students are from Listuguj, Que.
> **Mi’kmaq Warrior Peacekeepers** came to the wharf the next day.



**TIP:** It can be **useful for English speakers** differentiating between Mi'kmaw and Mi'kmaq **to substitute "Canadian" and "Canadians" in a sentence to see if it sounds right** — even though these words do not function in perfect syntactical parallel. For instance, "A fishery **regulated by Mi'kmaq**" versus "A **Mi'kmaw-regulated** fishery" corresponds to "A fishery regulated by Canadians" versus "A Canadian-regulated fishery." It would be unorthodox to write "A Canadians-regulated fishery." It's equally illogical and jarring to write "A Mi'kmaq-regulated fishery," according to these guidelines..



**Mi'kmaw language**

**Mi'kmaw is the name of the Algonquian language** written and spoken by Mi'kmaq:


> He said the prayer in **Mi'kmaw**, English and French.
> Ji'ka'we'katik Trail comes from a **Mi'kmaw name** for "place where bass are plentiful."
> The word caribou is an English version of the **Mi'kmaw word** for "snow shoveller."
> They say the French word Gaspé likely comes from the **Mi'kmaw term** for territorial edge.
> Her [**Mi'kmaw version of the Beatles song**](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=99-LoEkAA3w&feature=youtu.be) Blackbird went viral on YouTube in 2019.


Be aware that the language is in flux and that there are regional dialects affecting certain pronunciations. See the 2019 CBC Indigenous feature [Original Voices](https://www.cbc.ca/originalvoices/?maplang=mikmaw) for more information about the Mi'kmaw language.


**Shift in CBC News style**

**Since CBC News reports in English, we don't normally insist on adopting another language's rules of grammar, syntax, etc.**, when alternative English conventions exist. **But we balance this approach with the equally important principle of respect for handling proper nouns** in a way that's preferred by specific communities, whenever practical.

In the **case of Mi'kmaq and Mi'kmaw**, there's been **a gradual shift away from using the former across the board**. In 2017, **CBC became one of the first major news organizations to start incorporating "Mi'kmaw" as an adjective for singular nouns**, based on requests by some Indigenous speakers. This more complex style was classified as relatively uncommon but acceptable by the Oxford Guide to Canadian English Usage. A few years later, however, **Mi'kmaw scholars flagged the approach as flawed**. They **disputed the use of Mi'kmaq as an adjective in any construction** (singular or plural). They **also said their language should be referred to as Mi'kmaw** rather than as "Mi'kmaq."


**ACKNOWLEDGMENT:** When we overhauled this entry in 2020, particularly helpful feedback came from Nova Scotia linguist Bernie Francis — co-founder of "Francis-Smith orthography," a spelling system officially recognized by Nova Scotia's Mi’kmaw chiefs.



See also [Indigenous](/home/i/Indigenous) (an overview)

### Middle East glossary

**Middle East glossary**

Certain topics require special care. They're highly controversial and under intense scrutiny by all sides. Middle East coverage falls into this category. Is it a _border_ or a _line_, a _fence_ or a _barrier_, _occupied_ or _disputed_ territory? Some common shorthand is imprecise or easily perceived as biased, while other terms are simply incorrect. 

This Mideast glossary reflects CBC News style. Entries are based on the journalistic principles of accuracy, clarity, impartiality and fairness.

[At a glance](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#ataglance) (Key terms in brief)
[](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#glossaryindex) (List of all glossary entries)

**At a glance**
[**East Jerusalem**](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#eastjerusalem) – Occupied. It was captured and then annexed by Israel after the 1967 war.
[**West Bank**](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#westbank) – Occupied by Israel.
[**Gaza Strip**](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#gazastrip) – Technically not occupied. Israeli forces withdrew in 2005, although Israel largely controls all movement in and out.
[**Golan Heights**](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#golanheights) – Occupied. It was captured and annexed by Israel after the 1967 war.
[**Hamas**](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#hamas) – Militant group democratically elected in the Gaza Strip and West Bank to head a unity government with Fatah in 2006. Seized control of Gaza in 2007, throwing Fatah out.
[**Palestine vs. Palestinian territories**](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#palestine) – There is no modern country of Palestine, although Palestinians want to establish one as part of a two-state solution.
[**barrier**](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#barrier) – Avoid security fence, anti-terror fence, apartheid wall, etc.
[**border**](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#border) – Many of Israel's borders are actually ceasefire lines, so nuanced language such as boundary is often necessary.
[**right of return**](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#rightofreturn) – When referring to Palestinian refugees, use "fled or were forced out" of Israel in 1948 or 1967 wars.
[**settlements**](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#settlement) – Jewish settlements in occupied territories are illegal. Avoid neighbourhoods or Israeli housing.
[**terrorist/terrorism**](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#terroristterrorism) – Avoid labelling specific people or acts this way without attribution. As a rule, describe rather than judge the person or act (e.g., a bomber, a bombing).

**MAIN GLOSSARY**
**antisemitic** — A widely used and normally acceptable term to describe bigotry against Jewish people, from subtle prejudice to open hostility. But it's often a poor choice in stories focused on the Middle East since Arabs are also Semitic people, a word that broadly refers to a family of languages (Arabic, Hebrew, Maltese). In these cases, more specific language is preferred (e.g., anti-Israel or anti-Jewish, depending on the facts). Just because people oppose the state of Israel's policies, or even the existence of the Jewish state (an anti-Zionist) doesn't make them antisemitic. Such critics include Jews, themselves. TYPOGRAPHICAL NOTE: CBC News adopted the fused, lowercase spelling in the spring of 2021, along with AP, CP and others: **antisemitic, antisemitism, antisemite**. The previous spelling (anti-Semitic, anti-Semitism, anti-Semite) was standard for more than a century. In recent years, a growing number of Jewish organizations have adopted the new rendering, partly in response to critics who said the capital "S" was misleading. See the [International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance's memo on the spelling of antisemitism](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/media/bdhdpv4z/ihra_memo-on-spelling-of-antisemitism_april-2015.pdf "IHRA Memo On Spelling Of ANTISEMITISM April 2015") for additional background.

**Arab** — Originally from what is now Saudi Arabia and neighbouring countries, Arabs live throughout the [Middle East](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#mideast) and beyond. Never use as a synonym for Muslim. The word Arab refers to a Semitic people and is tied to language, culture and geography rather than to religion. Since most Arabs are Muslim, relevant references to other faiths are sometimes helpful, depending on the story (e.g., Arab Christians living in Lebanon). The preferred adjective is Arab (Arab leaders, old Arab autocracies). The noun Arabic refers to language.

**assassination vs. targeted killing** — [Assassination](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/a/assassination/ "Assassination") is an acceptable term to describe the intentional killing of a prominent person, especially a political or religious leader. (e.g., Egyptian President Anwar Sadat was assassinated in 1981). Targeted killing is an increasingly common alternative used by governments, especially when the country carrying out the attack has laws or special executive orders in place that prohibit assassinations (e.g., in 2010 the Obama administration authorized the "targeted killing" of Anwar al-Awlaki, a radical American-born Muslim cleric believed to be hiding in Yemen). Since targeted killing is clear, neutral, and not actually euphemistic — assassinations themselves are essentially targeted killings — it's OK in our journalism. But there's no need to shy away from the potentially more controversial words assassinate or assassination, as long as the facts fit the story.

**barrier** (not fence or wall) — Many different labels have been assigned to the structure that Israel began building between its citizens and the Palestinian population in the [West Bank](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#westbank) in 2002. But words such as "fence" and "wall" are inadequate descriptions of the combination of trenches, razor wire, concrete slabs and electric fencing. Instead, use the terms **barrier, West Bank barrier, separation barrier**, etc. Israel prefers "security barrier," but given the structure's evolution that adjective is hotly contested and, so, shouldn't be used without attribution. For the same reason, avoid loaded adjectives like "apartheid" wall. Never imply that it follows the [Green Line](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#greenline). The barrier actually zigzags through large parts of the West Bank, depending on where Jewish populations live, and does not merely follow the old armistice line. In the case of [Jerusalem](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#jerusalem) or some West Bank communities (e.g., Qalqilya), it's an accepted convention to use the terms "wall" and "barrier" interchangeably.

**border vs. line** — A border is a permanent boundary widely recognized internationally (e.g., Israel's border with Egypt). A ceasefire or armistice line is a preliminary boundary, drawn when fighting stops but not officially ratified as part of a peace agreement. Many of Israel's "borders" are technically ceasefire lines. So when reporting on the region's politics or peace negotiations, nuanced language is necessary (e.g., the boundary between Israel and the West Bank, 1967 boundary lines, prewar boundaries). But when reporting on narrower topics that simply require clear locators (e.g., violence along a particular boundary on any given day), using the word border is an accepted convention (e.g., "Israel's border with the West Bank"), since the armistice line is a de facto border. See also [Green Line](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#greenline).

**collective punishment** — A common way to describe sweeping measures taken by Israel against a large number of Palestinians, such as a mass curfew, in response to threats from a much smaller group (sometimes only one or two people). The term is frequently used by UN officials and other critics of Israel's [Gaza blockade](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#gazablockade). They say Israel has a right to respond to security threats but should not collectively punish everyone living in the [Gaza Strip](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#gazastrip) for attacks from Palestinian-controlled territory. Although collective punishment is listed as a war crime under the Geneva Conventions, in that context it's often more narrowly interpreted to mean the mass and indiscriminate killing of unarmed civilians.

**destruction of Israel** — Be cautious when reporting that people or groups advocate the destruction of Israel. If facts are not in dispute, attribution is unnecessary (e.g., the militant group Islamic Jihad wants to replace the state of Israel with a Palestinian state, and [Hamas](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#hamas) still calls for Israel's destruction, no matter how some of its supporters qualify the language). Otherwise attribution is crucial. For instance, during a speech in Tehran in 2005, Iranian President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad reportedly said "Israel must be wiped off the map." But the English translation has subsequently been challenged, and Ahmadinejad, himself, has said he meant only the collapse of Israel's government. So while it might be accurate to say that Israel fears Iran wants it wiped off the map, or that some people think that's what Ahmadinejad meant, it's misleading to baldly report that Iran wants the state of Israel annihilated. **CBC's ombudsman has responded to complaints about various references to the 2005 remarks and ruled that we are violating accuracy standards if we state without attribution that Ahmadinejad called for the destruction of Israel.**

**East Jerusalem** — It's OK to use the word "occupied" if an adjective is needed in a story (**occupied East Jerusalem**). While the modifier is often unnecessary in generic references, it's a good practice to include "occupied" in stories about evictions, demolitions, protests, etc., in East Jerusalem neighbourhoods to give our audience key background/context. Israel captured East Jerusalem in [1967](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#1967) and then annexed it in 1980. But its claim to this half of the city is not recognized internationally. Canada, the United States, Britain, the European Union and most other members of the international community consider East Jerusalem [occupied territory](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#occupiedterritories), like the West Bank. It includes [Old Jerusalem](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#oldjerusalem), where historic religious sites stand that are important to Jews, Muslims and Christians. See also [Jerusalem](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#jerusalem).

**extremist vs. fundamentalist** — In a religious context, the word extremist suggests a zealot or fanatic engaged in some type of "holy war." This person is not merely an advocate of a strict interpretation of a doctrine. The individual is also prepared to go to extreme measures (including violence) in a campaign to promote this religious belief. By contrast, fundamentalism alone does not mean militancy. A fundamentalist subscribes to (and generally, but not always, advocates) what is perceived to be the literal truth of a given religion's holy writings. Millions of law-abiding citizens of many different faiths are fundamentalists. Far fewer are extreme fundamentalists or militant fundamentalists. Since extremists are not limited to a particular faith, always specify relevant detail (e.g., a Christian extremist, an Islamic extremist). A separate Language Guide entry ([**fundamentalist, extremist, militant**](/home/f/fundamentalist-extremist)) provides more details and examples. See also [Islamist](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#islamists), as well as special caveats around the term [terrorist](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#terroristterrorism).

**Fatah** — Started in the late 1950s as a resistance group, Fatah became the foundation of Yasser Arafat's Palestine National Liberation Movement. The political party was a dominant force within the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO), and then the undisputed ruling faction of the [Palestinian Authority](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#palestinianauthority) for years. But Fatah has lost influence since Arafat's death in 2004. Critics accuse it of being outdated and corrupt. Fatah is considered a secular nationalist party, unlike its Islamic rival faction [Hamas](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#hamas), which has ruled the [Gaza Strip](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#gazastrip) since 2007.

**Gaza blockade** — Set up by Israel in 2007, it virtually cuts off the [Gaza Strip](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#gazastrip) from the outside world. Israel continues to control most of the flow of people and goods into and out of Gaza, including aid supplies from relief agencies, although specific restrictions have changed over time. Egypt looks after its own border with the territory, including the Rafah crossing. Israel's blockade began after the militant group [Hamas](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#hamas) took control of Gaza. Israel says it must defend itself against rocket attacks and other threats. But critics consider the blockade an unjust and inhumane [collective punishment](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#collectivepunishment) of more than a million civilians in Gaza. Some organizations, such as the International Red Cross, say the blockade violates international law.

**Gaza Strip** — A narrow swath of land along the Mediterranean. Gaza is an acceptable clipped form, even in first reference. Israel captured the area from Egypt during the [1967 war](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#1967). Jewish settlers then moved in. Decades later, Israel evicted the settlers as it handed over control of the land to Palestinian leaders. In 2005, Israel withdrew the last of its troops from the Gaza Strip but continued to maintain control over airspace, seafront and virtually all movement into or out of the area. A notable exception is the territory's border with Egypt, including the Rafah crossing, which is under Cairo's authority. Instead of referring to the end of occupation — a term disputed by Palestinians — it's more neutral to describe the end of Israel's permanent military presence in the Gaza Strip. See also [occupied territories](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#occupiedterritories). The militant group [Hamas](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#hamas) has ruled Gaza since 2007. The term [Gazan](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/g/#Gazan "G") (plural Gazans) is OK in occasional second reference to residents of the enclave.

**Golan Heights** — A rocky plateau that Israel captured from Syria during the [1967 war](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#1967). UN observers have monitored a ceasefire line since 1974. Although Israel annexed the Golan Heights in 1981, the move has not been recognized by the international community, which still considers the region [occupied territory](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#occupiedterritories).

**Green Line** — The boundary between Israel and the [West Bank](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#westbank). It's technically a line not a border because it's based on a mid-century ceasefire rather than an actual peace agreement. (See [border vs. line](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#border) for preferred usage.) The Green Line is more formally known as the 1949 armistice line, drawn when the [1948 Israeli-Arab war](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#1948) ended. A key issue in negotiations to create a Palestinian state is whether pre-1967 boundaries should be the starting point of mutually agreed land swaps. Palestinians favour this, but Israel rejects the return of [East Jerusalem](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#eastjerusalem). The term Green Line requires a brief definition, if used.

**Hamas** — The Palestinians' largest militant group, Hamas takes its name from the Arabic initials for the Islamic Resistance Movement. When created in 1987, the founding documents called for the [destruction of Israel](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#destructionofisrael). Its stated goals include driving all Israeli forces from [occupied territories](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#occupiedterritories) and setting up an Islamic state. Many countries, including Israel and Canada, consider Hamas a [terrorist](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#terroristterrorism) organization for carrying out suicide bombings and other attacks. The Islamic militant group has controlled the [Gaza Strip](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#gazastrip) since 2007, after defeating rival faction [Fatah](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#fatah) in Palestinian Legislative Council elections a year earlier. See also [Palestinian Authority](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#palestinianauthority).

**Hezbollah** — A Lebanon-based [Shia](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#shia) militant group formed in 1982 primarily to combat occupying Israeli forces in southern Lebanon. It also has a political wing. The name means "Party of God" in Arabic. It's considered a [terrorist](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#terroristterrorism) organization by many countries, including Canada and the U.S.

**intifada** — An Arabic word to describe more than one Palestinian uprising over the decades. When using it, specify the time period you mean (e.g., at the start of the first intifada in 1987, during the second intifada that began in the fall of 2000). Prefer this [transliteration](/home/t/transliterations) over alternatives, such as "intefadeh."

**Islamists** — Followers of a political and cultural movement known as Islamism. They believe that the Qur'an should rule all aspects of life (religious, political and personal). A common implication is: A Muslim radical or extremist who not only believes that Western values are eroding Islam but who is prepared to use violence to create Islamic states that promote fundamental doctrines and enforce Shariah law (the legal code of Islam). See also [**Islam**](/home/i/islam) for more details, including why common alternatives such as Islamic radicals or Muslim extremists are often recommended, as long as the facts fit the story. Never confuse Islamists with Islamicists, who are scholars or experts on Islamic culture, history, religion, etc.

**Israeli-Palestinian conflict** — Unresolved issues include final borders, the future of [Jerusalem](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#jerusalem) as well as the fate of Palestinian refugees (i.e., their "[right of return](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#rightofreturn)" claim) and Jewish [settlements](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#settlement). It's part of the larger Arab-Israeli conflict in the [Middle East](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#mideast), which began with the [1948 Arab-Israeli war](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#1948). So while a lasting peace deal between Israel and the Palestinians has the potential to make the region more stable, it's an exaggeration to report it as an agreement to "bring peace to the Middle East."

**Jerusalem** — Designated Israel's capital, although recognition has been withheld by many countries. Refer to it by name rather than using the label "capital." The city was effectively divided between 1948 and 1967, with Israel controlling West Jerusalem and Jordan controlling [East Jerusalem](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#eastjerusalem), including [Old Jerusalem](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#oldjerusalem). Israel captured East Jerusalem during the [1967 war](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#1967) and annexed it in 1980, a claim not recognized internationally. Israel's parliament, the Knesset, is in Jerusalem, as well as the residences of the president and prime minister. But most foreign embassies are in [Tel Aviv](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#telaviv). East Jerusalem is still considered [occupied territory](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#occupiedterritories), and reaching a consensus over its status remains one of the more contentious issues in the [Israeli-Palestinian conflict](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#israelipalestinianconflict).

**jihad** — Acceptably defined as a "holy war" carried out by certain Muslims against enemies of their faith. From the Arabic term for "to strive," it can also more broadly mean a struggle to improve oneself or to do good. But since it's closely associated with violence, any other meaning needs to be specified in a story. Some Islamic scholars argue that jihad is often misused because a true holy war must be in self-defence. The word is found in the names of several well-known organizations, including the Islamic Jihad, a militant group that vows to destroy Israel and set up an Islamic Palestinian state.

**Middle East, Mideast** (never "Near East," now considered archaic) — The Middle East conventionally means: Iraq, Iran, Israel and the Palestinian territories, Jordan, Syria, Lebanon, Turkey, Cyprus, Egypt, Libya, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Yemen, Oman, Bahrain, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates. It does not normally refer to the Sudan or to the Islamic countries in northwestern Africa (Tunisia, Morocco and Algeria), even though these are sometimes mentioned in stories about the region. It also does not normally mean Afghanistan, which is historically considered to be in Central Asia — sandwiched between the Mideast and the Indian subcontinent.

**Nakba** — Arabic for "catastrophe." This is how Palestinians describe Israel's declaration of independence in [1948](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#1948), which led to the displacement of hundreds of thousands of people. Always use balanced wording such as "fled or were forced from their homes," for reasons outlined under [right of return](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#rightofreturn). Prefer the English definite article (i.e., **the Nakba** rather than "al" Nakba). It's useful to remind our audience that Israel's statehood celebration (Independence Day) is marked by Palestinians as a disaster (**Nakba Day**). The actual commemoration dates are different, however. The former changes each year, based on the Hebrew calendar, while the latter is normally held May 15th. Not to be confused with **Naksa Day** in June, marking Palestinian displacement after the [1967 war](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#1967).

**1948 Arab-Israeli war** — The first major conflict between Israel and its neighbours (Lebanon, Syria, Jordan and Egypt) began hours after the Jewish state declared independence. Technically fighting continued into early 1949. The armistice, signed in 1949, did not formally determine borders. Instead, a [Green Line](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#greenline) was established. During the [Six Day War in 1967](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#1967), Israel expanded control over territory.
**
1967 Arab-Israeli war** — Also known as the 1967 Six Day War. During the fighting, Israel took over [East Jerusalem](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#eastjerusalem) and the [West Bank](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#westbank) from Jordan, the [Gaza Strip](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#gazastrip) and the [Sinai Peninsula](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#sinai) from Egypt, and the [Golan Heights](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#golanheights) from Syria. See also [Green Line](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#greenline) for background on the meaning of "pre-1967 boundaries" in modern-day peace talks.

**occupied territories** — This term conventionally refers to Israeli military occupation of the [West Bank](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#westbank) and [East Jerusalem](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#eastjerusalem). It also technically applies to the [Golan Heights](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#golanheights) (taken from Syria during [1967](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#1967)). While context generally makes the meaning clear, avoid lumping the Golan Heights into stories about the [Israeli-Palestinian conflict](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#israelipalestinianconflict). The adjective "occupied," used by the United Nations, is more meaningful to our audience than "disputed," since it underscores military control over the region. Avoid referring to the [Gaza Strip](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#gazastrip) as occupied without attribution, since Israel declared an end to its occupation of that region in 2005. Palestinians argue that the occupation continues, since Israel still controls the airspace, seafront and virtually all movement into or out of the region. For this reason, it's preferable to refer to the end of Israel's permanent military presence in the Gaza Strip rather than an end to its occupation, since the former is factual while the latter's meaning is debated.

**Old Jerusalem** — The ancient walled city is part of [East Jerusalem](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#eastjerusalem). Old Jerusalem is short for **the Old City of Jerusalem**, also known as **the Old City**. All three versions are acceptable, as long as the context makes the proper noun clear. Old Jerusalem includes historic religious sites important to Judaism, Islam and Christianity. What the Jews call the Temple Mount is known as Haram Ash-Sharif, or the Noble Sanctuary, to Muslims. It includes the Dome of the Rock mosque. At the foot of the western edge of the Temple Mount is the [Western Wall](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#westernwall), sometimes known as the Wailing Wall, one of the most sacred sites in Judaism.

**outposts** — Very small [Jewish settlements](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#settlement). They're often ramshackle living quarters, sometimes little more than a caravan or two on a remote hilltop. Outposts are set up for various reasons, from expanding a nearby settlement's boundaries to defying the Israeli government. Some are considered "unauthorized" by Israel. In that case, it's OK to call them "unauthorized" if this detail is relevant to the story but avoid labelling them as "illegal." According to the UN, all Jewish settlements in the [occupied territories](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#occupiedterritories) are unlawful, including outposts, and calling some "illegal" implies that others are not.

**Palestine vs. Palestinian territories** — There is no modern country of Palestine, although there's a movement to establish one as part of a [two-state](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#twostatesolution) peace agreement with Israel. So **do not refer to Palestine as an independent country without attribution** or show a map with Palestine as a sovereign state. Use the term "pro-Palestinian" instead of "pro-Palestine" when referring in generic ways to Palestinian supporters. Areas under the control of the [Palestinian Authority](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#palestinianauthority) are considered Palestinian territories: [Fatah](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#fatah)\-run [West Bank](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#westbank) and [Hamas](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#hamas)\-run [Gaza Strip](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#gazastrip). The terms Palestinian territories and [occupied territories](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#occupiedterritories) are not synonymous. The former includes the [Gaza Strip](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#gazastrip), where Israel no longer maintains a permanent military presence. The latter includes the [Golan Heights](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#golanheights), which Israel and Syria are at odds over. **The name Palestine is fine in established proper nouns** (e.g., the Palestine Liberation Organization, the Palestine Children's Relief Fund). In November 2012, the United Nations voted to grant "non-member observer state" status to Palestine. We can accurately mention this in stories when relevant. But the UN does not grant nationhood, and it remains premature to call Palestinian territories the country of Palestine. Take the same approach with other global bodies. **Be fact-based and fair. For instance, it's fine to say that the International Olympic Committee lets qualified athletes compete for a team called Palestine.** But just as with the UN, the IOC does not resolve disagreements over disputed territory or declare the existence of sovereign states. So when covering events such as the Olympics, generally refer to the Palestinian flag, Palestinian athletes, etc., to avoid confusion and inconsistency. When making references to historical Palestine, use clear language (e.g., "British Palestine" is the accepted term for the British Mandate of Palestine, which administered the region between 1920 and the birth of Israel in 1948).

**Palestinian** — The preferred term for people of Palestinian descent. It can be a noun (the Palestinians) or modifier (a Palestinian refugee). Do not use Palestinian as a synonym for Muslim or Israeli as a synonym for Jewish. Specify where people are living when it's relevant. In the case of the [Palestinian territories](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#palestine), be aware that the word "resident" is deemed offensive by some because it's perceived to minimize citizenship granted by the [Palestinian Authority](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#palestinianauthority) (implying a kind of "permanent residency" status instead). For this reason, generally prefer "Palestinian" over labels like "Palestinian resident" or "resident of the Palestinian territories." In the case of Palestinians with Israeli citizenship, use neutral, fact-based references (e.g., "Palestinian citizens of Israel") rather than vague or disputed labels (e.g., the "Arab minority" and "internal Arabs").

**Palestinian Authority** — An administrative body based in Ramallah that governs [Palestinian territories](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#palestine) (i.e., the [Gaza Strip](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#gazastrip) and parts of the [West Bank](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#westbank)). Although it changed its name to the "State of Palestine" in January 2013, we and most major news services continue to call it the Palestinian Authority to avoid audience confusion (i.e., an administrative body cannot unilaterally turn itself into a "state"). The Palestinian Authority deals with everything from security to health and education. The full name, Palestinian National Authority, is optional but unnecessary in first reference. It was formed in 1994 under the Oslo peace accords between Israel and Yasser Arafat's PLO (Palestine Liberation Organization). The PA was intended to be a provisional government of Palestinian-controlled parts of the West Bank and Gaza Strip until a peace agreement led to the creation of a Palestinian state. [East Jerusalem](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#eastjerusalem) was specifically excluded from the accords. In 2007, the Palestinian Authority became divided by bickering between [Fatah](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#fatah)\-run West Bank and [Hamas](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#hamas)\-run Gaza Strip. But in April 2011, both factions renewed abandoned plans to form a unity government. The PA's parliament is the **Palestinian Legislative Council**.

**peace in the Middle East** — This is a sweeping statement about a very big and diverse region. A solution to the [Israeli-Palestinian conflict](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#israelipalestinianconflict) is not the same thing as peace throughout the Middle East.

**right of return** — This expression is based on a principle of international law, adopted by the United Nations, backing any person's right to return to her or his country of origin. In Middle East coverage, it's important to specify who is claiming the right to return where (e.g., Israel has a Law of Return that gives all Jews the right to seek Israeli citizenship through immigration). In the case of Palestinians, the phrase "who fled or were forced out of their homes" during the [1948](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#1948) and [1967](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#1967) Arab-Israeli wars is a balanced way to describe refugees claiming the right of return. That's because there's disagreement over why hundreds of thousands of Palestinians became displaced (i.e., Israelis say the Palestinians left on their own to avoid war started by their Arab neighbours while Palestinians say they were forced out by the threat of ethnic cleansing). The right of return of Palestinian refugees is a key issue in the [Israeli-Palestinian conflict](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#israelipalestinianconflict) since Israel considers the sheer number of people a threat to the future of the Jewish state. Today, more than four million UN-registered Palestinian refugees claim links to the 1948 exodus. Always attribute refugee numbers to specific sources. See also [Nakba](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#nakba).

**security barrier** — Avoid. See [barrier](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#barrier).

**settlement vs. housing**— The widely used term "settlement" is generally the clearest choice when referring to Israeli communities in [occupied territories](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#occupiedterritories). The Jewish settlements are considered illegal under international law, although Israel disagrees and has actively supported expansion in some areas through government subsidies. The term settlement conveys far more information to our audience than the generic word housing, which could refer to any residential areas. It can be helpful, however, to add details when known and relevant (e.g., some settlements are actual villages or small cities while others are old neighourhoods in [East Jerusalem](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#eastjerusalem) that were Jewish even before the [1967 war](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#1967)). Always attribute specific numbers of settlers to sources. Be sure related language is accurate (e.g., distinguish between construction of new settlements that's "frozen" rather than merely limited through curbed government subsidies). Really small and remote settlements are sometimes called [outposts](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#outposts).

**Shia** — The second-largest branch of [**Islam**](/home/i/islam), followed by an estimated 10 to 15 per cent of the world's Muslims. Most live in Iran and Iraq, where they are in the majority, as well as in Pakistan and India where they remain in the minority. Lebanon also has a sizable number of Shia Muslims. Avoid other transliterations, including Shiite. Shia is a noun and an adjective. The plural is Shias. See also [Sunni](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#sunni).

**Sinai Peninsula** — A triangular peninsula in Northeast Egypt. Israel took control of it during the [1967 war](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#1967) but then withdrew all military forces and civilians as part of a peace agreement with Egypt in 1979.

**Sunni** — The largest branch of [**Islam**](/home/i/islam), followed by an estimated 85 per cent of the world's Muslims. Sunni is a noun and an adjective. The plural is Sunnis. See also [Shia](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#shia).

**Tel Aviv** — Although Israel's seat of government is in [Jerusalem](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#jerusalem), most foreign embassies are in the coastal city of Tel Aviv. When Israel was founded, Tel Aviv was the state government's temporary centre. In 1949, however, Israel declared Jerusalem its capital. Refer to Tel Aviv by its name alone. Never call it the capital or administrative capital. Do not use it to represent Israel or the Israeli government as a synecdoche or other figure of speech. See also [East Jerusalem](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#eastjerusalem).

**terrorist, terrorism** — Exercise extreme caution. Don't judge specific acts as "terrorism" or people as "terrorists." Instead, describe the act (e.g., bombing, shooting) or individual (e.g., bomber, gunman) and then let our audience decide. While terrorism generally implies attacks against unarmed civilians for political, religious or some other ideological reason, it's a highly controversial term that can leave journalists taking sides. It's OK to refer to terrorists and terrorism in general (e.g., the war against terrorism, antiterrorism legislation). But attribute any specific references (e.g., if officials call an attack an act of terrorism, if one or more governments classify a group as a terrorist organization). See the separate Language Guide entry on [**terrorist and terrorism**](/home/t/terrorist-and-terrorism) for more details and examples, as well as the entry on [**fundamentalist, extremist, militant**](/home/f/fundamentalist-extremist) for related guidelines.

**two-state solution** — A proposal to settle the [Israeli-Palestinian conflict](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#israelipalestinianconflict) by creating two sovereign countries: the Jewish state of Israel and a separate Palestinian state. The exact borders, including control over [East Jerusalem](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#eastjerusalem), are a contentious issue in peace talks. Not everyone favours a two-state solution, including Arabs who refuse to acknowledge Israel's right to exist. Since "two state" is self-explanatory, no definition is required. By contrast, the lesser-known term "three-state solution" requires background, if used. The latter refers to a proposal that the [Gaza Strip](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#gazastrip) and the [West Bank](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#westbank) be put under the control of the countries that held them before the [1967 war](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#1967) — Egypt and Jordan, respectively — once Israel's [borders](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#border) are finally agreed on.

**unilateral statehood** — Refers to Palestinians declaring statehood on their own. Also called a **unilateral declaration** of statehood. Supporters say it can increase Palestinians' leverage in legal arguments over occupied territory as well as in negotiations with Israel. Critics say an effective [two-state](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#twostatesolution) solution to the [Israeli-Palestinian conflict](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#israelipalestinianconflict) can be reached by negotiations only. Be sure to specify declared borders (e.g., [pre-1967 boundaries](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#1967)). Keep in mind that Palestinians have unilaterally proclaimed statehood several times since Israel was created in [1948](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#1948). For example, in 1988 the UN General Assembly "acknowledged" a statehood declaration by Palestinians without actually voting on endorsing recognition of Palestine as a country. And in November 2012, the UN General Assembly voted to grant "Palestine" non-member observer state status. But the United Nations, itself, does not have the authority to grant statehood. Furthermore, the UN Security Council has veto powers over granting full membership to the United Nations, which means the General Assembly cannot simply admit a unilaterally declared state of Palestine into the UN on its own.

**West Bank** — The full noun, "West Bank of the River Jordan," is implied and unnecessary. Israel seized it from Jordan during the [1967 war](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#1967). This [occupied territory](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#occupiedterritories) includes [East Jerusalem](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#eastjerusalem) and many historically significant communities, such as Bethlehem and Jericho. Much of the West Bank is under Palestinian control and, so, acceptably referred to as Palestinian territory. It's also where the [Palestinian Authority](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#palestinianauthority) is based. There is no officially agreed on [border](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#border) with Israel. Instead, there's a so-called [Green Line](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#greenline) tied to a 1949 armistice. The West Bank and [Gaza Strip](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#gazastrip) are central to the [Israeli-Palestinian conflict](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#israelipalestinianconflict). Since there's a dispute over the exact population of the West Bank, including the number of Israelis living there in Jewish [settlements](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#settlement) as well as the number of Palestinian refugees claiming a [right of return](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#rightofreturn), always attribute figures.

**Western Wall** — The preferred name of this spot in [Old Jerusalem](/home/m/middle-east-glossary#oldjerusalem). Although Wailing Wall is OK in transcribed quotes, it's actually a European term describing passionate praying at the site, where Jews feel close to God but also mourn the loss of their historic temple.

### migrant\_foreign\_worker

**Migrant workers, temporary foreign workers**

**Migrant worker** is an entrenched and generally acceptable term for **a foreign worker performing unskilled or low-skilled labour on short-term contracts.** The word **"migrant" traditionally means "on the move"** in English and is **not inherently pejorative.** It instantly conveys the sense of itinerant employees (e.g., fruit and vegetable pickers going from one crop to another, and one location to another, over different growing seasons).

**Temporary foreign worker** is synonymous with migrant workers in some contexts, but it **can imply a much broader and more diverse pool of labour.** This **includes employees brought to Canada to perform skilled jobs on longer-term contracts** (e.g., teachers, software engineers, computer programmers, chefs, stone masons). Furthermore, under the [federal government's temporary foreign worker program](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.canada.ca%2Fen%2Femployment-social-development%2Fservices%2Fforeign-workers.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1IsUola5WaKUsRsaaBl3NH), certain applicants may be eligible to become permanent residents.

Be aware that some people object to "migrant" as both a noun and an adjective, even though it's been a neutral, fact-based description of people journeying from one place to another since the 1700s — either in search of a new permanent home or to set up a temporary residence for a specific reason, such as short-term work. While it's **OK to refer to migrant workers as temporary foreign workers**, it's not required.

**Alternative phrasing is acceptable as long as it's accurate, clear and conversational**. For instance, "seasonal agricultural workers" is too ambiguous because it could apply to, say, students and other Canadian citizens hired for the summer. By contrast, **seasonal foreign workers** would be fine as a synonym for migrant workers if the context were clear (e.g., that they're working on farms).

Be aware, too, that some employers insist that their workers are not "migrants" because they're on long-term contracts. The employees, however, may actually enjoy very little job security or other assumed rights. It's one of the reasons that **the [Canadian Council for Refugees](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fccrweb.ca%2Fen%2Fmigrant-workers-issues&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0vRugs62Pjnp9itUvSX89Y) and other advocacy groups commonly use the label "migrant workers" when laying out various challenges faced by certain foreign employees**, especially those performing manual labour and other low-skilled work.

See also [refugee, asylum seeker, migrant](/home/r/refugee) for related guidelines, including why we **avoid the modifier "illegal" when describing people** (e.g., do not refer to "illegal migrants").


### Military forces

**Military forces**

**Soldiers, sailors, air personnel**
In general, the land, sea and air units within a military can be referred to as **the army, navy** and **air force**. Sometimes, a **special forces** unit or command outside of the military's main three branches is worth noting when relevant to the story (e.g., Joint Task Force 2, known as JTF2 in second reference, is a counter-terrorism response unit of the Canadian Special Forces Operational Command).

Members of the army, navy and air force are known as **soldiers**, **sailors** and **air personnel** (preferred over "airmen" and "airwomen"). Never assume that someone in the air force is a pilot. The person could be anything from a cook or mechanic to a meteorologist or aerospace engineer.


**Troops, squads, platoons, etc.**
**Troop** technically refers to a military unit. But it's an imprecise word. **The plural term "troops" is acceptable to describe members of a military group** (e.g., "About 100 troops attacked the camp"), **but avoid using it in the singular as a substitute for soldier**.

Definitions of military units vary widely. In Canada, some typical ranges are: a **squad** or **section** has fewer than a dozen members, a **platoon** between about 35 and 50, a **company** between about 125 and 150, a **battalion** between about 375 and 600, and a **brigade** between about 1,200 and 2,000). **Given the inexact meanings of many of these words, however, and the fact that most people outside the military haven't memorized the jargon, it's best to provide specific troop numbers when known.**


**Canadian Armed Forces, Canadian Forces**
**Capitalize _Armed Forces_ or _the Forces_ only when referring to the _Canadian Armed Forces_** (also known as **_the Canadian Forces_**):


the Canadian Armed Forces or the Canadian Forces (Normal first reference)
the Armed Forces or the Forces (Standard second reference to Canadian Forces)
U.S. forces
British forces
British and Canadian forces (lowercase for plural)

coalition forces (several countries; lowercase even when Canada is included)


**Royal Canadian Air Force, Royal Canadian Navy, Canadian Army**
Between 1968 and mid-2011, the Canadian Forces renamed its unified air, sea and land components. They became known as the Air Command, Maritime Command and Land Force Command respectively. In August 2011, however, the federal government officially restored the old designations (the **Royal Canadian Air Force**, the **Royal Canadian Navy** and the **Canadian Army**). This did not require legislative amendment since the 1968 Canadian Forces Reorganization Act was unaffected by the change.

When specifying the air, sea or land branches of the Canadian Forces, **generally use the full, proper noun in first reference:**

Royal Canadian Air Force
Royal Canadian Navy
Canadian Army

**In second reference, these normally become:**

**air force** (lowercase) or **RCAF**
**navy** (lowercase; RCN is normally too obscure)
**army** (lowercase)

NOTE: There's normally no need to specify the old nouns (Air Command, Maritime Command and Land Force Command) for historical references between 1968 and 2011. Instead, it's an accepted convention to use air force, navy and army. More detail is usually needed only when directly relevant to the story (e.g., "Johnson says that when he joined the air force in 1975, some pilots continued to use the word "royal" and the letters "RCAF").


**army, navy, air force (lowercase)**
**When reporting on other countries' military branches, almost always keep broad categories such as army, navy and air force lowercase.** Many do not use these nouns in the proper names of their armed forces.

For consistency, we do not use capital letters simply because a country is mentioned. (Write the _Russian army_ or _Russia's army_, not the Russian Army.) **But in the case of Britain, use Royal Navy** (uppercase) **and Royal Air Force** (uppercase) **in first reference** since they're historically treated as proper nouns:

Canada's air force (versus "Royal Canadian Air Force" listed above)
air force jet
army spokesperson
North Korea's navy
Israeli army
**British navy, Britain's navy,** _but_ **the Royal Navy** (proper name)
**British air force, Britain's air force,** _but_ **the Royal Air Force** (proper name)
**U.S. air force, American air force** _but_ **U.S. 11th Air Force** (a proper noun)
British army
U.S. army


**Army, Fleet, etc. (uppercase)**
**Use uppercase when referring to the full, specific name of a military or paramilitary formation:**

7th Army Reserve Command
British 21st Army
Chinese 27th Army
U.S. 7th Fleet (specific group)
U.S. Pacific Fleet (specific formation)
but the U.S. fleet (entire navy)
2nd Field Artillery Regiment
French Foreign Legion
Canadian Coast Guard
U.S. National Guard

_Capital letters are also used for official sites_, such as bases or command headquarters (Canadian Forces Base Petawawa, CFB Petawawa), **ships** ([HMCS](/home/h/hmcs) Athabaskan), **official names of units and commands** (Pacific Fleet, 5th Battalion, 76th Infantry Brigade, 42 Squadron, C Company) **recognized nicknames** ([Van Doos](/home/v#vanDoos), Green Berets), **major conflicts** (French Revolution, Battle of Britain, Six-Day War) **and important positions in combat** (Western Front).

**
Ordinal numbers (10 versus 10th)**
**Some proper nouns include ordinal numbers. Others do not.** Don't assume. Check.

1 Royal Canadian Horse Artillery
2nd Battalion, Royal Canadian Regiment
10 Tactical Air Group
48th Highlanders of Canada

**There are several options for second references, including:**

the 2nd Battalion; the battalion
the 22nd Regiment; the 22nd; the regiment
10 Tactical; the air group
**
Prefer English versions of names established by convention:
**
3rd Battalion (rather than _3e Bataillon_)
Royal 22nd Regiment (rather than _Royal 22e Regiment_)

See also [French words](/home/f/french-words-and-accents#retain) for related guidelines (e.g., prefer University of Montreal over Université de Montréal).

**Units within larger military groups can be linked by prepositions or commas.** Choose whichever format works best to make a sentence clear:

He was a member of the 24 Field Engineer Squadron, 2 Combat Engineer Regiment, serving with the 3rd Battalion of the Royal Canadian Regiment.

Last year, she joined the 3rd Battalion of the Royal 22nd Regiment, based at Canadian Forces Base Valcartier near Quebec City.

**Military police**
**Keep "military police" lowercase unless the words are being used as part of the full, formal name of a unit:**

They attacked a military police convoy.
Military police have launched a search for a missing cadet.
He's a member of the 18th U.S. Military Police Brigade.
The 720th U.S. Military Police Battalion heads to Iraq next month.

See also [police forces](/home/p/police-forces)
See also [military terms](/home/m/military-terms-overview) (an overview) and [military ranks](/home/m/military-ranks)
See [capitalization](/home/c/capitalization) (an overview)

### Military ranks

**Military ranks**

**TV TEXT REMINDER:** Be aware that television graphics, banners, supers, etc., have some unique typographical conventions. The biggest difference is the use of more initial capital letters in titles, job descriptions, etc. (e.g., "Former Prime Minister" instead of former prime minister, and "High School Principal" instead of high school principal). See the [**TV Text overview**](/home/t/tv_text) for details.


[Abbreviations](/home/m/military-ranks#Abbreviations) (Brig.-Gen. versus brigadier-general)
[List of ranks](/home/m/military-ranks#List-Canada) (army, air force, navy)




[Canadian Armed Forces](/home/m/military-ranks#CAF) (the Armed Forces, the Forces)


**Abbreviations** (Brig.-Gen. versus brigadier-general)
**Use abbreviations only (a) before names and (b) if the rank is currently held. The short forms are always capitalized:**

> Capt. John Stone
>
> Brig.-Gen. Betty MacKay


This **applies to the Salvation Army as well** (e.g., Maj. Dusty Rhodes).
**In second reference, the abbreviated rank is optional but generally preferred.** Keep the best interests of readers in mind. Although surnames are sufficient, it's often helpful to remind people who someone is. Repeating ranks can aid identification, especially in long stories:

> Capt. Stone (preferred second reference in a military story, brief or long)
>
> Rhodes (acceptable second reference in a short Salvation Army story)


**Some ranks have no abbreviations. They're written in full.** The first letter is capitalized unless the position is no longer held:

> Admiral Jim Smith
>
> Vice-Admiral Harold

**
**Write out ranks or titles when used without names:****

> The lieutenant-colonel signed the documents.
>
> The general talked to reporters.


**When military personnel die while still in active service, their ranks are conventionally retained** before their names:

> Maj. Jane Jones was killed in the explosion.

To acknowledge this, we and most other Canadian news organizations, including CP, spell out the word "navy" (lowercase) before the abbreviation** (e.g., "**navy Capt. Ruth Oikawa**"). By contrast, the CAF adds a capital N in brackets after the naval rank to mark the distinction. We think our approach conveys the same detail more conversationally in broadcast scripts. It also avoids needless audience confusion about what the "N" stands for in web stories or TV supers.

\*^ = SAILOR replaces 'SEAMAN.' The Royal Canadian Navy's former ranks of ordinary seaman, able seaman, leading seaman and master seaman were changed in August 2020 to the gender-neutral alternatives of sailor third class, sailor second class, sailor first class and master sailor, respectively.

**Lt. instead of Lieut.**
While the word lieutenant has two acceptable abbreviations, CBC News abandoned use of "Lieut." in the fall of 2007. Our new style is simpler and equally valid: **Always use Lt. for the abbreviation Lieutenant in ranks before names** (Lt. Martin Martel and Lt.-Col. Ann Atwood). The old preference was to reserve Lt. for compound ranks such as Lt.-Gen. CP took a similar step around the same time, but has continued to use "Lieut." in some cases. We, however, do not.

**The Armed Forces uses its own system for abbreviations** (LCol for Lt.-Col, CPO for Chief Petty Officer, etc.), but the typography is idiosyncratic. **For consistency, we follow CBC guidelines on periods and capital letters.** These reflect standard newsroom publishing conventions.

 For phonetic preferences, including an ["f" sound in lieutenant](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2Flng%2Frecherche%2Findex.aspx%3FProId%3D35060&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0bx5don-5st3Ogst__FMl4), see the [CBC Pronunciation Database](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2Flng%2Frecherche%2Findex.aspx&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1XFPfiGVRPwO63-NkaNyUm).

See also [police ranks](/home/p/police-ranks)
See also [\-general](/home/g/generalsuffix) (as a suffix)


**Commissioned vs. non-commissioned**
**It's rarely necessary to distinguish between commissioned and non-commissioned military personnel.** For starters, the modifier "commissioned" is not meaningful to most of our audience. In this context, a commission refers to a legal document from the Crown that formally specifies an individual's rank and duties. To complicate matters, there are two types of non-commissioned officers. Some are called "warrant officers" because their ranks are actually conferred through a warrant — another type of legal document that's occasionally dubbed a lower-grade commission. In most stories, this level of detail is unnecessary.

It's **usually sufficient to specify a rank** from the [tables above](/home/m/military-ranks#List-Canada) (e.g., Maj. Jane Smith and Petty Officer 2nd Class John Jones) **and, when relevant, briefly describe a person's role** (e.g., fighter pilot, mechanic, soldier, records clerk).

**Two common mistakes:
**

> **1\. Avoid wrongly implying that non-commissioned members carry out only junior duties or administrative work.** Non-commissioned officers, for example, may well have leadership roles (e.g., as corporals and sergeants). And many other non-commissioned members can perform a wide range of jobs, from operating artillery and other combat weapons to conducting peacekeeping missions. One Defence Department manual puts it this way:

> > _"Warrant officers and non-commissioned officers are frequently called ‘the backbone of the Forces.’ Their role is to translate the intentions of commanders into action and they are the link connecting the sailors, airmen and soldiers to their officers."_

> **2\. Avoid confusing a given person's job title and rank.** Ranks are positions within a military's hierarchy. Appointments, by contrast, are specific assigned duties (e.g., to be a quartermaster sergeant in charge of regiment's supplies). For instance, a person might be informally referred to as a "sergeant" when they're actually a master warrant officer (rank) assigned the duties of a quartermaster sergeant (duties). Calling that individual a sergeant in our story would technically be inaccurate because the non-commissioned member does not actually hold the rank of sergeant.


**If you have any doubts about people's ranks or primary roles in the military, ask them.** If that's not possible, or if you're still unsure, contact a Canadian Forces spokesperson.

**Former, retired, etc.**
**Former titles are always lowercase.** When people retire, their ranks are normally included in stories only when relevant and, even then, usually as background information after the name unless the person is well known and the rank is central to the story:

> Cheng, who was a second lieutenant in the Canadian Forces, said ...
>
> They met with retired general John de Chastelain to discuss ...


**In rare cases, disgraced personnel lose their rank** and the wording should make this clear:

> Convicted murderer Russell Williams had been a colonel for less than a year. He was stripped of his commission ...
