 (avoid Spc.) ◊ _see below_

 technical sergeant

 Tech. Sgt.

 wing commander

  Wing Cmdr.


\* These three ranks are exceptions. In first reference, do not use them before names. Do not capitalize them. Instead, place them after names and include an explanation (e.g., Merry Brandybuck, _the master chief petty officer of the U.S. navy_, Sam Gamgee, t_he sergeant major of the U.S. army_, and Peter Pan, _the chief master sergeant of the U.S. air force_). Only one person holds these positions at any given time. They are the highest-ranking enlisted members of each service. In second reference, write _Master Chief_ Brandybuck, _Sgt. Maj._ Gamgee, _Chief Master Sgt._ Pan.

◊ In the U.S. military, the rank of specialist falls between private and corporal. It suggests extra technical rather than combat skills. Avoid the abbreviation Spc., which is unfamiliar to most Canadian readers. Instead, write out the full rank when it appears directly before a person's name (_Specialist Sam Gamgee_).

**Canadian Armed Forces** (the Armed Forces, the Forces)
The **Canadian Armed Forces** and the **Canadian Forces** are equally acceptable in first reference. In second reference, the **Armed Forces** and **the Forces** are both OK. The generic terms **army, navy** and **air force** do not have capital letters on their own, even when referring to Canadian military personnel (e.g., _The navy hopes to buy more submarines, The U.S. army has launched a new recruitment drive_). When specifying the air, sea and land branches of the Canadian Forces, use capital letters in first reference to the full, proper noun: the **Royal Canadian Air Force**, the **Royal Canadian Navy**, the **Canadian Army**. See also [military forces](/home/m/military-forces) for more guidelines on specific nouns, such as Royal 22nd Regiment instead of Royal 22e Regiment. 


See also **[titles](/home/t/titles)** (for mayors, prime ministers, etc.)
For a general overview of military language, see [**military terms**](/home/m/military-terms-overview)

### Military terms overview

**Military terms | An overview**

**As with all of our journalism, stories about the military must be:**

-   **Accurate** (an artillery "shell" is the projectile launched not the casing)
-   **Clear** (dead or wounded civilians, not "collateral damage")
-   **Neutral** ("precision-guided," not "smart" bomb)

**A consistent in-house style** ("Lt." not "Lieut." or "Ltn.") **is also important** to maintain a level of professionalism expected of a national news service. **At the CBC, this includes using Canadian preferences** ("half-mast" rather than "half-staff").

**The Language Guide offers direction on various military words, expressions and abbreviations.** To make finding content easier, **the most frequently consulted terms have been compiled on this page** under the following general categories:

[Ceremonies and salutes](/home/m/military-terms-overview#ceremonies) (guard of honour, half-mast, ramp ceremony, etc.)
[Names of forces and personnel](/home/m/military-terms-overview#forces) (army but Canadian Armed Forces, etc.)
[Ranks](/home/m/military-terms-overview#ranks) (Pte., Sgt., Lt.-Col., etc.)
[Weapons, equipment, machinery, vessels, etc.](/home/m/military-terms-overview#weapons) (armada, artillery, guns, HMCS, mortars, rifles, etc.)
[Miscellaneous](/home/m/military-terms-overview#miscellaneous) (AWOL, dismissed with disgrace, embedded, friendly fire, etc.)

In many cases, links to longer entries are included.

The [Deciding what is clear](/home/m/military-terms-overview#deciding) section at the bottom provides general direction on dealing with new military terms and evolving language.

 For preferred phonetics, such as including an ["f" sound in lieutenant](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2Flng%2Frecherche%2Findex.aspx%3FProId%3D35060&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0bx5don-5st3Ogst__FMl4) and rhyming the second half of [missile](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2Flng%2Frecherche%2Findex.aspx%3FProId%3D28354&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3BFc0cILu04uP08VOevtKL) with "file" rather than "fill," see the [CBC Pronunciation Database](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2Flng%2Frecherche%2Findex.aspx&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1XFPfiGVRPwO63-NkaNyUm).




**Ceremonies and salutes**
[guard of honour](/home/g/guard-of-honour) (not honour guard)
dignitaries **inspect** a guard (in the U.S., they "review" it)
[half-mast](/home/h/half-mast) (not half-staff)
[Last Post](/home/l/last-post) (not _Taps_)

**Names of forces and personnel**

-   members of the **army** are called **soldiers**; members of the **navy** are called **sailors**; members of the **air force** are called **air personnel** (preferred over "airmen" and "airwomen")
-   the **Canadian Armed Forces** or the **Canadian Forces** in first reference, with the **Armed Forces** and **the Forces** both OK in second reference; but the **U.S. forces**, the **British forces**, and **coalition forces**, etc. (lowercase for generic foreign references)
-   the **Royal Canadian Air Force**, the **Royal Canadian Navy** and the **Canadian Army** when using the full, formal names of the air, sea and land branches of the Canadian Forces
-   the **Chinese 27th Army** (capital letters for specific divisions, foreign or domestic); but **Israel's army**, the U.S. navy, etc. (lowercase for general descriptions)
-   [Van Doos](/home/v#vanDoos) or Royal 22nd Regiment rather than Royal 22e Régiment


See the [military forces overview](/home/m/military-forces) for more details and examples, including a caution against using troop as a synonym for the singular word "soldier."

**Ranks**
**Some ranks have no abbreviations** (e.g., **Admiral Lewis Garner**). **Others are abbreviated only when directly in front of the person's name** (**Lt. Gillian Poole** versus "The **lieutenant** said she was told about the accident around noon").

**In web journalism, we follow a conventional publishing style for ranks.** This includes **using periods** (e.g., **Lt.-Col.** not "Lt-Col"), **adopting standard shorthand** before names (**Sgt.** rather than "Srgt." or "Srg" or any other variation of "sergeant," and **Pte.** rather than "Pvt." or "Pv." or any other variation of "private"), and **reserving capital letters for currently held titles** (e.g., **Gen. Pierre Fournier** versus "retired general John de Chastelain").
**The style for TV supers** (text superimposed over clips and images) **can be slightly different**, depending on what's most effective for the viewer (e.g., more initial capital letters tend to be used in TV supers, such as "Retired Gen. John de Chastelain"). **For the most part, however, the same style applies** (e.g., Col. Jane Dyson, Lt.-Col. Salima Habib and Pte. Anne Gray).

For [**a complete list of ranks for the army, air force and navy**](/home/m/military-ranks) used by CBC News, see the [**military ranks overview**](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/m/military-ranks/ "Military ranks").


> Note: Military forces often have their own internal rules for abbreviations. These are merely in-house style preferences and should not be misinterpreted as the only correct forms. Indeed, such abbreviations tend to be inconsistent across different branches of the same country's military, with letters or punctuation added or dropped. For this reason, the CBC has its own set of guidelines for ranks based on media publishing conventions. Our abbreviations closely match those used by CP, AP and several other major news organizations.

**Weapons, equipment, machinery, vessels, etc.**

-   **armada** refers to warships
-   **[assault rifle](/home/w/weapons#assault_rifle)** is usually better than a specific but obscure name or model; if you do use a name or model, be certain it's the correct one (e.g., an **M-14** versus an **M-16** and an **AK-47** versus an **AK-74**)
-   Distinguish between **military firearms** (fully automatic) and [military-style firearms](/home/w/weapons)
-   **flak** (anti-aircraft fire) is clearly not the same as "flack" (a promoter)
-   **frigates, destroyers**, etc., are **[ships](/home/b/boat-versus-ship)** not boats; but submarines are technically boats
-   [**HMCS**](/home/h/hmcs), HMCS Protecteur (never "the" HMCS)
-   [**IED**](/home/i#IED) (improvised explosive device)
-   **MiG-25** (not MIG-25; see [aircraft names](/home/a/aircraft-names) for general guidelines)
-   **precision-guided** or **laser-guided** (not "smart") **bomb**, missile or other weapon
-   A **sortie** is a single mission by one plane. When the air force reports, say, "600 sorties flown in less than four days," it's impossible to know how many planes or pilots were actually involved unless additional information is obtained.
-   [**tanks**](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/w/weapons/#military "Weapons") should be identified by name (e.g., Challenger 2, Leopard 2) when specific detail is relevant to a given story.
-   A **volley** (virtually simultaneous shots from several weapons) is not the same as a **fusillade** (a sequence of shots fired from one weapon). The concentrated discharge of weapons in battle or salute is known as a salvo. Artillery fires in salvos.

See the [weapons overview](/home/w/weapons) for details about artillery, rifles, guns, missiles, mortars, etc.

**Miscellaneous**

-   **AWOL** (OK) For many years, the Canadian term for being **absent without leave** was AWL. But AWOL has become much more common and is now generally preferred in everyday speech because it's an [acronym](/home/a/acronyms) — i.e., an abbreviation that can be spoken as a word.
-   **basic military training** (_not_ "boot camp," which is preferred in the U.S.)
-   **collateral damage** (**AVOID**) Use dead or wounded civilians collateral damage, instead.
-   **dismissed** or **dismissed with disgrace** (OK, depending on the military ruling, but **NOT "dishonourably discharged,"** which is an American term) A court martial must be convened before Canadian military personnel can be dismissed with disgrace. But they can still be kicked out of the Armed Forces and lose their rank (be stripped of their commission) if a court martial is either not possible or deemed unnecessary. In these cases, the word "dismissed" is technically inaccurate and should be avoided. Instead, the person is said to be "released" from the military, although less-bureaucratic expressions such as "forced out" or "removed" are also fine.
-   **embedded** (OK) A common term to describe journalists and other civilians travelling and living with military forces in a combat zone. Although initially resisted by some news editors because it appeared to suggest that members of the media were "in bed" with a particular country's military, the word simply means "to be within a larger group." Embedded has become a clear and convenient way to refer to civilians who are first-hand witnesses but who are not independently deciding where and when to travel in the region.
-   **friendly fire** (Generally **AVOID** this jargon) If military forces accidentally injure or kill their own troops, prefer direct language rather than a euphemism.
-   **Geneva Conventions** (Almost always plural) Use the singular form only when referring to one of the four international treaties, such as "the Second Geneva Convention.")
-   **incursion** (OK when facts apply) An acceptable term for a brief raid or assault, especially along a border. An incursion normally implies a quick withdrawal. By contrast, an _invasion_ suggests something longer term, which may include _occupation_. These difference often become apparent only after enough time has past, which can make historical references to a specific ground operation different from initial coverage. 
-   **invasion** (**Requires caution**) The word not only implies a foreign-led force moving into another country or sovereign territory but also evidence of widespread resistance. This introduces two editorial considerations: Is the area disputed territory, and are local residents and/or military personnel fighting back? Military action by Russia against Ukraine illustrates conventional usage. In 2014, Russia annexed [Crimea](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/c/crimea/ "Crimea") and began what most of the world community considered an unlawful occupation of the peninsula. There was, however, virtually no documented resistance, which meant that the noun "invasion" was considered misleading because it strongly implied military battles during the takeover. By contrast, Russia launched an all-out invasion against Ukraine in February 2022. See [war](#war) below for related guidelines.
-   **lethal aid** (Generally **AVOID** unless attributed and defined) **Prefer clearer, more meaningful wording**, whether generic (**military weapons**) or specific (**guns, tanks, bombs**). While it's important to be accurate (e.g., differentiating between providing another country with troops versus providing, say, only weapons or only ammunition), "lethal aid" is perceived by many as highly euphemistic. By contrast, the expression "**non-lethal aid**" is **OK** if defined/explained because "non-military aid" is often inaccurate. **But never forget that unambiguous language is better** when specific facts are known (e.g., food, communications equipment, body armour, training).
-   **military campaign** (**_not_ "crusade,"** which is historically linked to church-backed religious fighting, especially the famous Christian Crusades)
-   **Molotov cocktail** (OK) Coined in the 1940s to describe handmade explosives that Finnish fighters threw at Russian tanks, the colloquial term has become entrenched in English and, so, **generally does not need to be defined in stories**. Molotov cocktail refers to any improvised explosive device made out of a bottle or other breakable container, a flammable liquid and something like a rag as a fuse. Synonyms include gasoline bomb, bottle bomb, fire bomb and homemade grenade.
-   **_Rouse_** (not "_Reveille_") Historically, _Rouse_ was the bugle call Commonwealth forces played to get their troops up in the morning. It is now sometimes played after the _Last Post_ at memorial ceremonies.
-   **war** (broad term to describe ongoing hostilities) The word can mean fighting between sovereign countries (often across disputed borders), or between different groups within the same country (conventionally called a **civil war** if the battles are between political factions, religious or ethnic communities, etc.). Sometimes more than one preposition can apply. For instance, **Russia's war against Ukraine** launched in February of 2022 also quickly became known as **the war in Ukraine**, since virtually all of the fighting took place there. The conflict could also accurately be called **Russia's invasion of Ukraine**, given the indisputable fact that it started with a Moscow-led attack. See also [invasion](#invasion) above for related caveat.
-   **women and children** (**AVOID as a synonym for civilians** outside of direct attribution) The outmoded phrasing was once common in various UN declarations on the protection of people not considered combatants in armed conflicts. However, women now serve in the military forces of many countries. **Specific detail about unarmed citizens remains OK in stories**, and can often be a meaningful way to convey the indiscriminating brutality of war (e.g., "including hundreds of civilians" and "including children and elderly residents").

**Deciding what is clear**
**Since language evolves, what begins as jargon to be avoided** (or, at the very least, defined each time) **sometimes winds up part of everyday speech.** Parents have been heard to describe their truant teens as "AWOL." We get flak from critics. A glitch is labelled a "snafu" by people who may not know or care that the original military acronym stood for "situation normal, all f--ked up."

In more recent years, "ramp ceremony" has entered the lexicon. It means a tribute paid by troops to a fallen comrade whose casket is being loaded on a plane for a final trip home. Originally, a number of journalists refused to use the term because of justifiable concerns that its meaning was unclear. Today, however, ramp ceremony is much more widely known and is OK in news coverage without explanation as long as the story's context makes the meaning clear.

How do we know what's OK for routine news reporting? HQ for headquarters is obvious and convenient. But "hooch" and "haybox" are just slang (for an improvised shelter and an insulated rations container, respectively). **When embracing or rejecting military vernacular, use common sense. Is the wording muddy or awkward or otherwise poor? Is there a better option? Always keep our audience in mind.**

### mines

**Mines**

**The word "mine" is almost always treated as a generic term and kept lowercase.**

> Barrick's **Lagunas Norte mine** in Peru.
>
> The old **Jericho mine** in Nunavut.
>
> The **Mount Polley mine** in B.C.


In this sense, "mine" is similar to "factory" or "warehouse" (e.g., the Heinz **ketchup factory**).

Any detail added before the word "mine" (e.g., "gold" or "open-pit") should also be kept lowercase:

> Barrick's Lagunas Norte **gold mine** in Peru is …
>
> The old Jericho **diamond mine** in Nunavut hasn't been …
>
> The Mount Polley **copper and gold mine** in B.C. will soon …


**Capitalize "mine" or related words (e.g., "mining") only when they're officially part of a proper noun**, such as organization's formal name or a book title:

> the **Mining** Association of British Columbia wants ...
>
> the Canadian **Mining** Innovation Council says ...
>
> Buffalo Bill's Diamond **_Mine_** was published in ...


See also [capitalization](/home/c/capitalization) (an overview)

### Ministry

**Ministry**

**Capitalize federal and provincial government ministries, even if the name has been shortened:**

> Ministry of Crown-Indigenous Relations and Northern Affairs
>
> Ministry of Crown-Indigenous Relations
>
> Crown-Indigenous Affairs Ministry
>
> Ministry of Northern Affairs
>
> Ministry of Fisheries and Oceans
>
> Finance Ministry

**
The words "department" and "ministry" are conventionally used as synonyms** in this context:

> Department of Crown-Indigenous Relations and Northern Affairs
>
> Department of Crown-Indigenous Relations
>
> Crown-Indigenous Relations Department
>
> Department of Northern Affairs
>
> Department of Fisheries and Oceans
>
> Finance Department


See also [Department versus department](/home/d/department)
**When a government department is known by more than one name, generally prefer what's known as the "applied title,"** which reflects the government's current preference and is normally featured in public documents, on official websites, etc.


> Department of Industry (still the legal name, but no longer commonly used)
>
> Industry Canada (former "applied title" until late 2015)
>
> Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada (new common, "applied title")


**Exceptions are entrenched names that remain clearer to our audience** than the new form (e.g., Foreign Affairs instead of Global Affairs, especially since the cabinet minister is still known as the minister of Foreign Affairs). A [**full list of legal names and applied names**](https://www.tbs-sct.canada.ca/ap/fip-pcim/reg-eng.asp) is kept up-to-date by the Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat.

**It's sometimes acceptable to clip or slightly recast a ministry's name** to emphasize what's most relevant to a given story:

> Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada
>
> Ministry of Citizenship and Immigration
>
> Ministry of Immigration and Refugees
>
> Ministry of Citizenship


**But retain (or add) key detail to avoid confusion.** For instance, since the fall of 2015, the Department of Industry (which had commonly been called "Industry Canada") has been known as Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada. The department is overseen by two different cabinet members, including a science minister:

> Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada
>
> Ministry of Economic Development (refers to one of the cabinet portfolios)
>
> Ministry of Science (refers to the same department but identifies a different minister)


**If a ministry's name** (full or shortened) **is used as a stand-alone _noun_, keep it capitalized.**

> Staff cuts were made at Defence and Indigenous Affairs.
>
> She moved from Health to Finance.
>
> He started in Foreign Affairs in 1993.
>
> She took over Fisheries and Oceans six months later.
>
> Flaherty ran the Finance Department for eight years.


**If it's an _adjective_, make it lowercase unless the full name is used:**

> A defence spokesperson denied the report.
>
> The health budget might increase.
>
> A finance official said ... (The proper name is Department of Finance Canada)
>
> Several veterans affairs workers ... (The proper name is Veterans Affairs Canada)
>
> A health department memo ...
>
> A Health Canada probe turned up no evidence. (Capital letters because the ministry's official name used)


This style also applies to the names of other government agencies, regulatory bodies, independent offices, etc.

**Generally avoid departmental abbreviations, even in web headlines, unless they're well known** (e.g., DND is OK for Department of National Defence but FOC is too obscure to be effective for Fisheries and Oceans Canada, especially since the ministry's official name remains the [Department of Fisheries and Oceans](/home/f/fisheries-and-oceans)). **Bear in mind that some initially obscure abbreviations can gain common currency over time, such as CRA** for the [Canada Revenue Agency](/home/c/canada-revenue-agency), which used to be called Revenue Canada.

**Although the federal Treasury Board is actually a special cabinet committee, it's conventionally treated in the same way as any ministry. Retain the initial capital letters even in adjectival constructions, since this is the full name:**

> Treasury Board President Stockwell Day
>
> Day, who became president of the Treasury Board in January ...
>
> a Treasury Board official ...
>
> She works at the Treasury Board.


**If a ministry's name is part of a person's current title, capitalize only when that title is _directly before_ the person's name:**

> Health Minister Leona Aglukkaq
>
> Aglukkaq, Canada's health minister ...
>
> Raj Opus, the minister of community and cultural affairs ...
>
> Takasaki, who served as minister of transportation and public works ...
>
> Hnatyshyn, a former justice minister ...


**This applies to junior cabinet members as well:**

> Minister of State for Sport Gary Lunn
>
> Minister of State for the Status of Women Helena Guergis


**Since some titles are long, recasting often helps make sentences easier to scan. Depending on the rewrite, lowercase letters may be required:**

> Sports Minister Gary Lunn
>
> junior cabinet minister Helena Guergis
>
> Helena Guergis, the minister of state for the status of women


See also [titles](/home/t/titles) for related guidelines

**Capitalize foreign government ministries, even when they're English translations:**

> the British Defence Ministry
>
> the French Foreign Ministry
>
> Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry
>
> the Russian Interior Ministry


Be sure to use [Canadian spellings for American departments](/home/d/defence-labour-and-centre), such as Defence and Labour.

See also [capitalization](/home/c/capitalization) (an overview)

### dilemma

**Misinformation**

Refers to **false or misleading information** that could be mistaken as factual. **Misinformation is a broad label** coined more than 400 years ago that **can include honest mistakes, misunderstandings, intentional or unintentional exaggerations, conspiracy theories, nonsensical fallacies, orchestrated deceit, etc.**

When incorrect information is spread on purpose, it's sometimes called disinformation. The key difference: **Misinformation can be unintentional**. By contrast, **[disinformation](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/d/#disinformation "D") inherently implies that falsehoods are repeated on purpose**. For this reason, it's crucial to be precise in our language, and make sure that any suggestion of intent is supported by fact.

The word lie conventionally means an intent to deceive. **Just because someone is repeating falsehoods does not automatically mean they are "lying."** Bear in mind that it can be difficult, if not impossible, to objectively determine the motive behind someone repeating a falsehood. Be aware, too, **there can be legal consideration when accusations of deception are levelled** against an individual.

**Fabricated claims, political propaganda, hoaxes, etc., all fall into the category of misinformation** (e.g., if they're unwittingly repeated on social media) **AS WELL AS into the category of disinformation** when the aim to deceive is indisputable.

Since around 2015, **the colloquial term **fake news** has become a common synonym for misinformation**. Because the label remains closely associated with sweeping criticism of mainstream media outlets by certain politicians and their supporters, **however, misinformation is often a better choice than "fake news"** outside of direct attribution.

When covering any form of misinformation, **be specific about what's considered misleading or erroneous and why. Cite sources whenever practical** when fact-checking. If something is ambiguous or open to interpretation, make this clear. **Avoid amplifying the original misinformation** (e.g., by repeating inaccuracies or out-of-context detail in a way that could be misheard or misread as validation).

### Money

**Money**

[Lowercase names](/home/m/money#lowercasenames) (from dollars to bitcoins)









**Lowercase names (from dollars to bitcoins)**
Keep the names of currencies lowercase (dollars, pounds, yen, kronor), even when they're based on a proper noun element (e.g., euros from Europe). This applies to cryptocurrencies, such as [bitcoin](/home/b#bitcoin), virtual money, such as various online gaming credits, and promotional coupons and store vouchers (25 cents in Canadian Tire money).


**Generally prefer Canadian dollars**
**Unless there's a strong editorial reason to refer to a foreign currency, report virtually all monetary amounts in Canadian dollars.** The four most common exceptions:

-   When a story focuses on the United States, it's often easiest to present all figures in U.S. dollars. See [conversions](/home/m/money#conversions) for more details and examples.
-   When the converted currency is volatile or the original amount is extremely large (e.g., a country's debt), it's often clearest to present the figures in the original unit first (e.g., euros) with a conversion to Canadian dollars in brackets whenever practical (e.g., adding the $ conversion in the main body of a web story but sticking with € in the headline). See [pounds (£) and euros (€)](/home/m/money#others) for more details.
-   When the currency, itself, is part of the story's focus (e.g., a feature on bitcoins or a background piece on euros)
-   When we want to add colour to a feature by specifying a local currency (e.g., a young child polishing a 10-kwacha coin she bought from a tourism shop in Zambia).

**The best interests of our audience should always be served.** Since it's unrealistic to expect our viewers, listeners or online readers to know how much a Polish zloty or a Latvian lat is worth, **conversion to Canadian dollars normally provides the most meaningful detail.**


**Use figures: $7, $60,000, $1 million**
_In online journalism, use figures_ not words like "thousand" or "hundred thousand" **for amounts up to $999,999** that include currency symbols. Avoid broadcast constructions full of hyphens, such as _one-hundred-and-thirty-five-thousand dollars_:

> _$7_
>
> _$123.50_
>
> _$60,000_
>
> _$135,000_
>
> _$1 million_
>
> _$12 billion_


**When a currency symbol** such as $ or € **is not used, spell out figures below 10:**

> _six million pesos_
>
> _seven billion euros or €7 billion_


**For dollar amounts, prefer $ sign because the constructions are easier to scan:**

> _$8 million (instead of eight million dollars)_ See [$ sign](/home/m/money#$sign) below for more details and examples.


**Do not use unfamiliar terms, such as "quintillion" or even "quadrillion."** Instead, write a million billion, a billion billion, etc., to make it clear to our audience what we're talking about.

**When reporting ranges involving large numbers** (million, billion, trillion), **repeat the unit in our web journalism to avoid any ambiguity** (e.g., while _$5 to $10 million_ could be easily interpreted as _"five dollars to ten million dollars," $5 million to $10 million_ is crystal clear):

> _$7 to $10_
>
> _$100,000 to $150,000_
>
> _$5 million to $10 million_
>
> _$20 billion to $30 billion_


**Money in headlines**
**In web headlines, thousand (K), million (M), billion (B) and trillion (T) can be abbreviated** when referring to money. There is no space between the the currency sign ($, €), the number and the uppercase letter:

> _$13K_
>
> _$175M_
>
> _€25B_
>
> _$3T_


**The $ implies Canadian currency** unless otherwise specified. **Sometimes, [U.S. currency](/home/m/money#CdnUS) is included in headlines**. In those rare cases, follow our standard style (US, no periods, after the figure):


> _$1.17 US_
>
> _$200 US_
>
> _$50M US_


**It's acceptable to abbreviate dollars, euros and pounds in headlines: $, € and £.** But avoid more obscure currency symbols, such as ¥ for yen and ₣ for franc. See [pounds (£), euros (€)](/home/m/money#others) below for more details. See also [numbers in headlines](/home/n/numbers#inheadlines) for related guidelines (e.g., "10 million people" _not_ "10M people").


**Limit hyphens to adjectives before nouns**
Some news organizations use hyphens in routine currency constructions to avoid any possible confusion (e.g., $100 million would always be reported as $100-million to avoid any possible misreading of the amount as "$100" during a quick scan). But this is not a standard publishing convention, is not the approach taken by The Canadian Press and is not the style at CBCNews.ca.

On the other hand, **hyphens help clearly convey financial amounts used adjectivally before nouns:**

> _$1 million but a $1-million project_
>
> _$5 million US but a $5-million US profit_ (no hyphen before "US")
>
> _$12 billion but a $12-billion bailout_


Keep in mind that **recasting sentences with figures after the noun is sometimes preferred:**

_a $5.5- to $6.5-million loss_ (hyphens needed)
_a loss of $5.5 million to $6.5 million_ (hyphens not required)

See the [overview on hyphens](/handy-links/punctuation/hyphens) for related punctuation guidelines.


**The $ sign**
**Use figures next to the $ sign** (or other [acceptable currency symbols](/home/m/money#others) as outlined below), **even for numbers below 10:**

> _They printed one million tickets, which sold for $5 a piece._
>
> _The prize was $1 million._


**Generally use the currency sign** ($) **instead of writing out "dollar."** While small amounts are sometimes treated as exceptions, **keep in mind that words are not as easy to scan as symbols and figures:**

> _She gave him $1._
>
> _She gave him one dollar._ (OK based on convention, but not preferred)
>
> _He gave her $3._
>
> _He gave her three dollars._ (OK based on convention, but not preferred)


**Normally use the dollar sign** ($) **only when referring to Canadian or U.S. currency:**

> _$750 US_
>
> _$1,000 Cdn_ (see note on Cdn below)


**Conversions**
**Many countries call their monetary units "dollars,"** including Antigua, Australia, Fiji, Guyana, Hong Kong, Namibia, New Zealand and Tuvalu. But instead of writing "$120 million (Australian)," **we generally convert the figure into Canadian dollars** ("$117 million").

**The Bank of Canada's website features a handy [conversion tool](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.bankofcanada.ca%2Frates%2Fexchange%2Fdaily-converter%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2_uRPFCLKnykyVbawpRiXn). For consistency, use it rather than other sources when calculating currency values.**

**It's OK to express figures in U.S. dollars, if the story focuses on the United States** (e.g., the size of the U.S. defence budget). **U.S. dollars are also sometimes preferred for consistency if established as an industry standard** (e.g., commodities such as oil and gold are commonly traded in American dollars).

If there's a major difference between the value of the two currencies, adding one Canadian conversion in brackets after the first reference can be helpful to our audience. But it's not essential as long as U.S. currency values are clearly specified. See guidelines on the use of $ US below.


**Cdn, US (no periods)**
**In our news stories, Canadian dollars are normally implied. But if the context is not clear** (e.g., in stories that refer to different countries' currencies), **specify "Canadian." In web journalism, this means adding the abbreviation "Cdn"** after the figure. **Indicate American dollars by putting "US" after the figure:**

> _The committee wants an additional $54 million US put into the project by February._
>
> _She deposited $475 US into her account. She got $633, but had to pay a $10 Cdn service fee._


**Do not include periods in Cdn or US when identifying the country's money, except at the end of a sentence:**

> _The airfare cost $743 Cdn._
>
> _The airfare cost $743 Cdn once tax was added._
>
> _The company promises to spend $15 million US._
>
> _The company promises to spend $15 million US on the project._


**In adjectival constructions, do not include hyphens before the currency notation** (US or Cdn). Instead, treat these abbreviations as parenthetical additions that do not require extended punctuation:

> _She negotiated a $5-million US signing bonus._
>
> _They agreed to a $2-billion US investment over five years._


Be sure to include periods in "U.S." when referring to the geographical area or to the government rather than to the country's currency (see [abbreviations](/home/a/abbreviations)). Never abbreviate Canada or Canadian outside of the currency designation "Cdn" noted above, even in headlines.


**Decimal points (1.50)**
**Use decimal points only if they're followed by more than just zeros** (e.g., $1.50 but never $1.00, $2.00, etc.)

**Generally round dollar figures to a maximum of two decimal points** (e.g., about $5.25 million instead of $5.2467 million), unless a more precise amount is essential for editorial reasons.


**Pounds (£), euros (€), yen, pesos, kronor, etc.**
**When a currency is volatile or if the original figures are extremely large** (e.g., a country's debt) and even slight fluctuations can be significant during a brief period, **it's often preferable to report the figure in the original currency first** — with the most up-to-date Canadian dollar conversions supplied in brackets.


> Example: During the spring of 2010, the European Union and International Monetary Fund agreed to provide Greece with a conditional €110-billion bailout. Given swings in the value of the euro, the conversion figure fluctuated by several million dollars over the course of a few months. The least confusing way to report on this story was to mention euros first (consistently using €110 billion), and then to supply Canadian dollar conversions in brackets (generally hovering between $146 billion and $148 billion, usually rounded to no more than two decimal places as required: $146.94 billion).


**Otherwise, generally don't bother mentioning pounds, euros, etc., unless transcribing a direct quote or publishing a story that is improved by references to local currency** (e.g., a travel piece that includes currency amounts as colourful detail).


> Example: If a Pakistan court imposes a 3,000-rupee fine, it's probably clearest to day "a fine of about $35" — Canadian dollars are already implied — rather than to confuse our audience by reporting "a 3,000-rupee fine" (which sounds large) only then to add a meaningful conversion in brackets ("about $36.50"). On the other hand, if the fine is extremely large (in the millions of dollars), the original currency figure followed by a Canadian dollar conversion may be preferred, especially if the figure is likely to be cited again because the story is ongoing. Use your judgment. And always keep in mind that context is helpful (e.g., a fine that seems small by North American standards may actually represent, say, a month's wages to the citizen who has to pay it). Providing relevant details like that elevates our journalism.
>
> Example: If renovations on a museum in Italy are going to cost 12 million euros, simply converting the figure into Canadian dollars is often the most effective way to report this detail. Unlike Greece's bailout story cited above, a museum renovation piece is probably not going to keep surfacing in the news. And the one-time conversion saves space, since the original euro figure needs to be expressed in Canadian dollars to be meaningful to a wide CBC News audience. Of course, if the renovation costs later soared and it became important to compare the original value to a new value, then providing the amounts in euros first would probably make the most sense in a followup story, especially if conversion rates had changed significantly as well. Use your discretion, keeping in mind the best interests of our audience.


**For the most part, we avoid foreign currency symbols** (e.g., ¥ for yen or ₣ for franc), **even in headlines.** Instead we either spell out the word or convert the amount to dollars (and use the $ symbol).

The only exceptions:

-   **The symbols for pound (£) and euro (€) are OK in headlines.**
-   **£ is also acceptable in the main body of a story**, although we’re not locked into using the symbol for the word "pound(s)" — just as there are times when we write out "dollar(s)" instead of using $. Be sure to use £ instead of ₤ (which stands for lira). The correct international banking code for the United Kingdom's currency unit is GBP (Great Britain pound) rather than UKP, although avoid using either abbreviation.
-   **€ can be used in the main text of an article, too, but make certain the context is clear** because the euro sign is still not as widely known as £. If, for example, a series of figures obviously refers to euros, € is fine. But if there's only one reference to a euro amount in the middle of a story, consider spelling out the word. Keep in mind that readers might either (i) not understand the meaning of €, or (ii) see the € as a $ during a quick scan of the article.

**When publishing foreign currency symbols, always put them flush and to the left of the figure** (e.g., £500,000), just as you would with the $ sign. See [money in headlines](/home/m/money#headlines) above for related guidelines.

Use CBC-approved publishing tools to add such special characters to stories, rather than raw HTML.

**When writing out foreign currency names, use lowercase lettering and place the name after the figure or spelled-out number:**

> _125,000 pounds_
>
> _15,000 euros_
>
> _15 million francs_
>
> _three billion pesos_
>
> _one trillion rubles_


**Be sure to pick the correct word. Plurals require special care** (lira becomes lire). So do certain terms, such as krona:

> _krona_ (singular), _kronur_ (plural) Icelandic

> _krona_ (singular), _kronor_ (plural) Swedish
>
> _krone_ (singular), _kroner_ (plural) Danish and Norwegian

**A note about euros**
Since Jan. 1, 2002, the euro has been used as a common currency in more than 10 European countries, including Austria, Belgium, Finland, France, Germany, Greece and Italy.

The names of some well-known monetary units — such as francs and lire — are still active in other parts of the world, however, so check which term applies to a specific place. (See also [pounds, euros, yen, pesos, kronor](/home/m/money#others) above for guidelines on the use of the € symbol.)

For more information, read the 2003 CBCNews.ca feature [Here Comes the Euro](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews%2Fbackground%2Feuro%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0Gn6l0VVzippNsukSHN13r)

**See also [numbers](/home/n/numbers)** (an overview), **which includes guidelines on when to write out figures (e.g., four million litres versus 10 houses).**

### more than versus over

**More than versus over**

**Some writers limit "over" to spatial relationships** (e.g., over the Atlantic Ocean, over the moon), **and prefer the expression "more than" when referring to something exceeding a specific number. But there's no grammatical or editorial reason to insist on this approach.** Either version is OK:

> More than 200 people showed up.
>
> Over 200 people showed up. 
>
> They travelled more than 500 kilometres.
>
> They travelled over 500 kilometres.


Indeed, numerous entrenched constructions feature "over" and specific figures:

> The actors are all over 30.
>
> They're hoping for bids over $1 million.


As Bill Bryson observed in his classic 1984 book, _The Penguin Dictionary of Troublesome Words:_

> _**"The notion that 'over' is incorrect for 'more than' — as in 'over 300 people were present' — is a widely held superstition.** The stricture has been traced to Ambrose Bierce's Write It Right (1909), a usage book teeming with quirks and quiddities, most of which have since been discarded. **There is no harm in preferring 'more than,' but also no basis for insisting on it."**_


For this reason, CBC News does not prefer one construction over the other. Use whatever wording is the most natural/conversational to you in a given story.

### Mormon Mormonism

**Mormon, Mormonism:** **the** **Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints**

**Periodic use of** the words **Mormon** and **Mormonism** is **OK in stories, including in headlines** where space is tight (e.g., **the Mormon Church**). But **include at least one complete reference to the religion's full name**, the **Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints**, high up. **Whenever practical, the name should be spelled-out in first reference.** NOTE: The word **"day" is hyphenated and lowercase**.

**LDS is fine in occasional second reference** to the church (e.g., **LDS charities**, **LDS Church**) as long as the abbreviation's meaning is obvious from context. Other options include generic phrasing (e.g., **the church, church members**).

Be aware that many Canadians may not instantly recognize the name the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. **While the word Mormon provides key context** (e.g., "widely known as the Mormon Church") **exercise restraint**, given a shift in language within the religious community, itself. **The church began discouraging use of the colloquial name Mormon in 2018** (e.g., the "Mormon Tabernacle Choir" became **the Tabernacle Choir at Temple Square**). LDS leaders prefer the church's full, formal name be used, and that church members call themselves "Latter-day Saints." **The deeply entrenched proper noun Mormon, however, remains common.**

There's no linguistic evidence that there's anything inherently pejorative about the word Mormon. Therefore, **we think our approach of permitting occasional use of a colloquial name balances respect for one group's preference** to use a lengthy proper noun **against the need for brevity and audience comprehension.**

**Mormons are not polygamists**
Founded in the U.S. in the 1830s, Mormonism is a Christian faith based in Salt Lake City, Utah. It reported a membership of roughly 16 million in 2020, including a large missionary service around the globe. In addition to the Bible, the central scripture is the **Book of Mormon**.

As with descriptions of any church in our journalism, **be cautious when summing up general beliefs, common practices**, etc. **Modern Mormonism, for example, has actively denounced polygamy for more than a century** — excommunicating those who practice it. By contrast, breakaway sects still espouse certain 19th century traditions, including polygamy.

**Never refer to members of the polygamist group the Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints** (capital "D" in Day) **as Mormons or Mormon fundamentalists**, since this implies a direct relationship with the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (Mormons). **The polygamist group can accurately be called a splinter sect**. (See [cult versus sect](/home/c/cult-versus-sect))

### mulatto


**Mulatto**

**In general, avoid using the term "mulatto"** in news stories.**

Exceptions are when we're** (1) **quoting someone** who prefers to be known by this term, (2) **citing a literary passage**, or (3) **providing historical context** – e.g., referring to the wording of old legislation against interracial marriage.

There are two reasons:

-   Mulatto, based on the word "mule," offends many people and is considered as inappropriate as now-discarded terms such as "half-caste" (which means "half pure") and "half breed."


-   Old racial categories (e.g., mulatto, quadroon and octoroon) are dismissed by many experts as pseudo-scientific and misleading.

We're not the first news organization to adopt this stand. In its 1998 Style Book, for instance, the Globe and Mail warns: "We should not get into the game of measuring skin shade to declare that a person obviously of mixed race is either Caucasian or Black, nor should we use such specific terms as mulatto, quadroon, octoroon, or half-breed."

CBC journalists are reminded to avoid including a person's skin colour in stories unless this detail is deemed relevant.

Alternatives for "mulatto" include **biracial, multiracial**, or a specific description rather than a label. For example, in a child custody dispute largely based on race that was heard by the Supreme Court of Canada in 2001, we simply reported that the boy's mother was white and his father was Black.

For more background, see the 2002 Words: Woe & Wonder column, [Mulatto and Malignity](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews2%2Findepth%2Fwords%2Fmulatto.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0WpoLrjtNWbzgt21Zd21-e).

See also **[racial terms](/home/r/racial-terms).**

### Myanmar

**Myanmar**

**Use Myanmar in headlines** (broadcast and web) **as well as in leads.**

In a subsequent reference, it's OK to add "**Myanmar, also known as Burma**" once if editorially sensible (e.g., when someone in a broadcast clip or transcribed web quote has referred to Burma). **For consistency, use Myanmar after that** — the country's official name.

The optional detail "also known as Burma" has become less important as the name Myanmar has gained wider recognition. Use your judgment. It's more easily inserted online than on air. In broadcast scripts, the extra words are sometimes too clunky to read naturally. In these cases, consider inserting the fact as a short sentence on its own ("Myanmar is also known as Burma") rather than as a fragment or clause.

Language: **Burmese** (citizens of Myanmar speak Burmese)

Noun: Either **Burmese** (traditional) or **Myanmarese** (increasingly common English form), as in "Four of the artists are Myanmarese"

Modifier: Either **Myanmar** (the Myanmar government) or **Myanmarese** (a group of Myanmarese writers)

NOTE: While some Burmese speakers reject the term "Myanmarese" as an anglicized corruption, the word has become entrenched in English. It conveys clear meaning ("of or related to Myanmar") succinctly.

Largest city and commercial centre: **Yangon** (previously referred to as "Rangoon")

Capital city: **Naypyitaw** (fused), previously spelled as "Naypyidaw"

**In web or TV maps, use Myanmar as the principal entry** for the country (e.g., in bold or larger type). **Burma can be added in brackets** and/or a smaller point size to provide context, **but this is optional.** Generally use only one name for cities and towns. For instance, when reporting on Yangon there's normally no reason to add "previously known as "Rangoon" unless that historical detail is relevant to a particular story.


**Background**
Burma gained its independence from Britain in 1948. **The names Myanmar and Burma were both widely used in the country, even after a coup in 1962. But in 1989, references to Burma were essentially outlawed** to try to quell a growing pro-democracy movement. Freelance journalist Swe Win put it this way in a July 2012 New York Times column: "Before this question of vocabulary got hijacked by politics, both names were used almost interchangeably in the Burmese language. It’s just that Myanmar had a more literary and ceremonial quality and Burma a more colloquial usage."

Military rulers declared that the names Myanmar (for the country) and Yangon (for the largest city) better reflected pre-colonial culture. They passed the Adaptation of Expression Law, requiring that all English names be aligned with Burmese pronunciation. Their decision was not approved by any of the country's democratically elected leaders, however, and **many foreign governments continued to use Burma for decades. So did most Western news organizations.**

While the generals also officially moved the capital to the remote jungle community of Naypyitaw in 2006, most foreign diplomatic missions remained in Yangon. For this reason, Naypyitaw is commonly described as the country's administrative capital.

**Governments around the world gradually began referring to the country as Myanmar** after a range of political reforms were adopted. **Canada officially embraced the proper noun in 2016**, after Myanmar's first democratically elected president in more than half a century was sworn into office. **The same year, CBC News style was updated to "Myanmar" alone in first reference** (replacing the wordier expression "Burma, also known as Myanmar," that had been preferred in coverage).


See also [country names](/home/g/geography-cities)

**nationalism** (strongly implies ideology of supremacy) Nationalism is at the heart of Nazi (a 1920s clipped form of _Nationalsozialistische_, which translates as "national socialist"). And that, in itself, conveys a great deal about why the word requires care. When originally used in the 1790s, "nationalism" simply meant love of country, especially in the context of self-determination and independence. But by the 1900s, the term's common definition had become "advocating the interests of one's own nation to the exclusion or detriment of others." For this reason, nationalism is distinct from **patriotism**, which means love of country without the pejorative sense of cultural or racial superiority. It's also not the same as **jingoism**, which describes a blend of blustering patriotism and bellicose foreign policy — often favouring military aggression abroad. The connection between nationalism and **[Nazism](/home/n#Nazi)** is well established. The term "[**white nationalism**](/home/w#white_nationalism)" is also entrenched as a racist ideology.

**Nazi** (party supporter); **Nazism** (fascist ideology originally associated with the National Socialist German Workers’ Party, commonly called the **Nazi Party**, translated from "_Nationalsozialistische Deutsche Arbeiterpartei_"); **neo-Nazism** (post-WW II ideology of ultranationalism, racism, antisemitism, etc., in various places around the world) ; **Nazi Germany** (conventionally refers to Germany between 1933 and 1945, with Adolf Hitler as its chancellor). To distinguish Nazi Germany from modern-day Germany, the modifier "Nazi" should generally be used when referring to the country during this period, at least in first reference. The term **Nazi-occupied** refers to countries invaded by Hitler's armies (e.g., **Nazi-occupied France**, **Nazi-occupied Holland**, and **Nazi-occupied Poland**). Such descriptions are helpful because they place specific events in important historical context. **Avoid the expression "Nazi-occupied Germany,"** since Nazis were, themselves, Germans. Instead, prefer the shorter, entrenched label "Nazi Germany." Although historians agree that the Nazis rose to power through intimidation and abuse of the electoral process, it's misleading to characterize Hitler's dictatorship as an "occupation." Do not refer to **Auschwitz** or any of the other concentration camps in **occupied Poland** as "Polish." They were **Nazi extermination camps** or **Nazi death camps** built in Poland after Hitler's troops invaded. Even camps erected inside Germany (e.g., **Dachau**) are conventionally referred to as "Nazi" rather than as "German" camps. Adjectives such as "death" and "extermination" are considered appropriate, since these facilities were part of the mass murder of Jews, known as **the Holocaust**. (See also [**nationalism**](/home/n#nationalism) and [**white nationalism**](/home/w#white_nationalism))

**neo (prefix)**
The prefix "neo" is generally followed by a hyphen when terms are new or relatively uncommon (e.g., neo-colonialism, neo-paganism). The punctuation is often dropped when terms become widely used (e.g., neoclassical, neonatal). But there are exceptions, based on entrenched usage (e.g., neo-Nazism).
