### Nagorno-Karabakh

**Nagorno-Karabakh** (also known as **Artsakh**)

A landlocked **part of the [South Caucasus](/home/s#SouthCaucasus).
**
It's **generally OK to use Nagorno-Karabakh throughout stories** because it's more familiar to our audience. The name is a blend of several languages, including Azerbaijani, Russian and Persian. When practical, pointing out that it's also known as the Republic of Artsakh (or Artsakh) in Armenian can be helpful in some reports, especially if the latter proper noun surfaces in broadcast clips or verbatim web quotes.

**Call Nagorno-Karabakh a disputed region** to avoid taking sides in a conflict between Azerbaijan and Armenia. The local ethnic Armenian majority has administered political control over the enclave since the late 1980s. Nagorno-Karabakh Armenians continue to campaign for independence, as well as for eventual reunification with Armenia. This has led to disagreements over broad principles, such as the territorial integrity of a UN member state versus the self-determination of a region's citizens.


**Background** (fighting, ceasefire, line of contact)

The **modern conflict began in February of 1988**, when the majority Armenian population of the Nagorno-Karabakh Autonomous Region asked the central Soviet authorities to transfer authority over the territory from Azerbaijani jurisdiction to Armenian jurisdiction. The move reignited simmering ethnic tensions between Azerbaijanis and Armenians leading to violence. While the majority of Azerbaijanis are Shia Muslim and the majority of Armenians are Orthodox Christians, it is not a religious conflict.

Skirmishes between lightly armed Armenian militia groups, Azerbaijani special police forces and the Soviet military started in early 1990. Full-scale fighting over the enclave erupted after the breakup of the Soviet Union at the end of 1991, when both sides inherited the Soviet military equipment left behind on their respective territories.

**A 1994 ceasefire** paused the conflict and created what's called the **line of contact** between Azerbaijani and Armenian forces in Nagorno-Karabakh. **Do not call it an "occupation line." Also, avoid referring to the disputed territory as "occupied" or "liberated" unless attributed.** Even then, always put such statements into context. Be aware that Turkey sides with Azerbaijan in the dispute.


### names\_common

**Names (common versus legal)**

**People sometimes adopt pseudonyms for various reasons.** This is **particularly true of public figures** (e.g., **Cary Grant** was born Archibald Alec Leach, **Natalie Wood** was born Natalia Nikolaevna Zakharenkoand, and **Elton John** was born Reginald Kenneth Dwight). They may or may not legally change their names (e.g., **Woody Allen** was born Allan Stewart Konigsberg but legally changed it to Heywood Allen at age 17).

**Unless an original but obscure** or virtually abandoned **(birth) name is directly relevant to a given story** (e.g., appears prominently in a lawsuit), **it's perfectly acceptable to use the individual's common or publicly known name** throughout our coverage (e.g., **writer George Orwell** instead of Eric Arthur Blair, and porn star [**Stormy Daniels**](/home/d#Daniels_Stormy) instead of Stephanie Clifford). **Preferring familiar names makes our journalism clearer**, and, so, serves our audience best.

**Even when a legal name is an essential detail, it's usually better to stick to the common name** (stage name, pen name) in first and subsequent references, **and simply add an explanation, once, in brackets** (e.g., "whose real name is ...").

It's worth noting that **people sometimes start their careers with invented names and then return to their legal or birth names** (e.g., novelist **Stephen King** wrote several books credited to Richard Bachman). **So never assume the less familiar name is the birth name.** Instead, verify the facts. In King's case, Bachman was actually an early _nom de plume_.


**'Kanye' to 'Ye'**
**We lean toward respecting a person's preference, including the use of new legal names** (e.g., in 2021, rapper Kanye West officially became Ye). **To ensure audience understanding, however, we should include brief background in stories** (e.g., "formerly known as Kanye West"). **Generally continue to use a public figure's most recognizable name in first reference, including in web headlines** (e.g., "Adidas ends partnership with Kanye West over antisemitic remarks"). **After that, the new name is OK as long as it's succinctly explained** ("who has legally changed his name to Ye").

Some old names eventually fall out of circulation and, so, can be dropped. In other cases, **public figures may end up being known by more than one name for many year**s (e.g., Cat Stevens and Yosuf often now rendered as **Cat Stevens/Yosuf** for the artist born as Steven Demetre Georgiou). **Be aware that there are exceptions to the general principle of respecting people's preferences**, from handling names that are highly offensive (e.g., that feature the F-word) to dealing with extremely long names that are unwieldy (e.g., containing dozens of letters and symbols).

See also [transgender](/home/t/transgender#former-names) for handling so-called "dead" (former) names.
See also [nicknames and colloquial names](/home/n/nicknames) (Babe Ruth, Dizzy Gillespie), as well as [family versus first names](/home/q/quotes-overview#second-reference-names) in second reference (e.g., for people under 18)
See also [names](/home/n#names) (for general guidelines on Arabic, Asian, French, German and other non-English names)

### names versus logos

**Names versus logos**

**As cute as they are, we're not obligated to publish or broadcast logos masking as proper nouns,** especially when people or organizations take big liberties with capitalization, symbols and punctuation.

**For example:**

> Bravo! and Yahoo! have no exclamation marks: **Bravo and Yahoo** 
>
> RE/MAX Canada has no slash mark and is not all uppercase: **ReMax Canada**
>
> IKEA and INTERPOL are not all uppercase: **Ikea** and [**Interpol**](/home/i#Interpol)
>
> We don't flip the "R" in **Toys "R" Us.**
>
> We don't add invented umlauts (ö and ü) to **Motley Crue.**
>
> \*NSYNC gets standard punctuation for a contraction: **'N Sync**


**This rule applies to the text of our stories as well as to text in our links, and is generally extended to all proper nouns**, including the names of movies and TV programs (e.g., **MASH** not M\*A\*S\*H or M-A-S-H).

The **main exception** is **when a special character** (e.g., + or &) **is actually PRONOUNCED as part of a proper noun or proper noun equivalent** like a company name, brand name, informal association name or event name (e.g., **Disney+**, **Apple TV+**, [**OPEC+**](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/o/#OPEC "O"), **A&E** and **A&W**). But guard against such characters replacing text outside of proper nouns or proper noun equivalents (e.g., we still write "300-plus people" and "the invitation calls for a plus-one," and "their teacher gave them a B-plus").

NOTE: Treat non-standard text commonly found in logos and promos (e.g. "cbcnews" and "cbc radio") as graphical variations of the proper nouns preferred in our journalism (CBC News and CBC Radio).


**Evolving logos, such as Wal-Mart to Walmart**
Companies sometimes change their logos, fiddling with capitalization, punctuation, etc. CBC News does not automatically adopt these changes. Adjustments often depend on whether the organization's actual name has been officially revised, and on how widely entrenched the new version becomes. In addition, our general guidelines on names versus logos still apply (e.g., we would not use a symbol such as an asterisk, regardless of the external preference).

Wal-Mart's move to Walmart in its marketing is a good illustration. When the company was founded in the early 1960s, it was known as "WALMART" on signs but Walmart in news coverage. By the 1970s, it was "WAL-MART" on signs but **Wal-Mart** in news coverage. In the early 1990s, the company replaced the hyphen with a star ("WAL\*MART"), but most major news organizations did not (i.e., they retained the noun Wal-Mart). In 2008, the company moved the star to the end of the word and got rid of all but the initial capital letter ("Walmart\*") in its general branding (e.g., Walmart Canada) but not in its actual legal name (Wal-Mart Canada Corp. and Wal-Mart Stores Inc.).

By 2010, the company was using Walmart on its signs and in virtually all general news releases but still retained Wal-Mart for some official, legal documents. A few news organizations attempted to reflect this complexity by using a different noun depending on the story (e.g., Walmart for store expansions but Wal-Mart for corporate earnings). This became overly confusing, however. So in 2014, editors at different news organizations came up with competing solutions. The Associated Press reverted to Wal-Mart in all of its journalism because that was still the company's legal name. The New York Times, by contrast, ruled that Walmart should always be used, since this is the company's main preference as well as how the store is known to most people.

**To keep our in-house style as simple as possible, CBC News also prefers one spelling.** In late 2014, we switched from Wal-Mart to **Walmart** for the same reasons outlined by the New York Times: **It's the most common spelling used by Walmart, itself, and, therefore, the most recognized form of the name known to our audience.**

When relevant, of course, nothing prevents us from mentioning the company's longer and slightly different legal name, especially in business stories. But in most of our journalism, the spelling **Walmart** is clearest and preferred, including **Walmart Canada** instead of "Wal-Mart Canada Corp."

See also [quirky capitalization](/home/q/quirky-capitalization) for related guidelines

### nation versus country

**Nation versus country**

**The word country usually refers to the physical or geographical features of a state** (e.g., "_It's one of the world's largest countries" and "The country's climate is perfect for icewine_"), **as well as to its government** (e.g., "_Canada is a democratic country_").

**The term nation, on the other hand, refers to the language, culture, etc., of people.** In colloquial contexts, the word is sometimes extended to communities informally united by a specific sport (e.g., a hockey nation) or similar passions.

In parts of the world (e.g., Europe), many countries are known as "nation-states" because most citizens within a given set of borders share a common heritage. But in other places on the planet, where immigration has played a key role in a state's growth (e.g., Canada), **the word "nation" is a poor synonym for country.**

This distinction has become particularly important in recent years, as various communities have begun asserting their status as nations within the same country (i.e., emphasizing bonds of common identity and demanding recognition). Some [Indigenous people](/home/i/Indigenous) in Canada, for instance, have adopted the term _First Nations_.

Careful writers do not use the term "nation-state" as another label for "sovereign state." They also **avoid tossing words like "nationwide" into news stories when they simply mean "across the country," "countrywide," or "Canada-wide."**

### Netherlands versus Holland

**the Netherlands versus Holland**

The country in northwestern Europe is called **the Netherlands**.

Adjective: **Dutch** (a Dutch company, the Dutch people).

Noun: **Dutch** (the language as well the citizens). _Dutch_ is preferred over _Netherlanders_ to avoid confusion with Caribbean members of the Kingdom of the Netherlands discussed below.

Official capital: **Amsterdam**

Administrative capital (seat of government): **The Hague**

Currency: euro (formerly the guilder)

**Holland is the name of two large, coastal provinces.** North Holland and South Holland are merely one part of the country in the same way that England is one part of the [United Kingdom](/home/u/united-kingdom). Holland includes the three largest cities in the Netherlands: Amsterdam, The Hague and Rotterdam.

**In news stories, generally prefer the _Netherlands_ over _Holland_** when referring to the entire country. Reserve Holland for historical references (e.g., Second World War military campaigns), entrenched colloquial usage (e.g., in soccer coverage) and other casual contexts.

The **Kingdom of the Netherlands** is a constitutional monarchy. It's made up of the Netherlands as well as two distant states, each with separate, self-government: **the Netherlands Antilles** (which includes several islands in the Caribbean) and Aruba. Their citizens are **Netherlands Antilleans** and **Arubans**, respectively.

See also [The versus the](/home/t/the-versus-the) for related guidelines (the Netherlands but The Hague)

### Newfoundland and Labrador

**Newfoundland and Labrador**
**N.L. instead of Nfld.**

The official name of the province was changed to Newfoundland and Labrador in late 2001, although the abbreviation Nfld. remained common for several years. **CBC News adopted N.L. during the summer of 2005.** Do not use the old shorthand, Nfld., except in rare cases in web headlines when referring specifically to the island — as outlined below. **Be aware that many stories refer only to "Newfoundland" or only to "Labrador"** (i.e., that **you do not need to use the full, spelled-out name of the province in all coverage**, especially in broadcast scripts).

     As noted in our Pronunciation Database, [Newfoundland rhymes with grand](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2Flng%2Frecherche%2Findex.aspx%3FProId%3D27017&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0thYDgx3UQ5TRWqvwfWYw8). (VPN access required)

[Web headlines and decks](/home/n/newfoundland-and-labrador#headlines) (usually N.L., but sometimes Nfld. or Labrador alone) 

[Story bodies](/home/n/newfoundland-and-labrador#story) (N.L., as in Witless Bay, N.L.)

[Retain proper names](/home/n/newfoundland-and-labrador#propernames) (Royal Newfoundland Constabulary) 

[Time zones](/home/n/newfoundland-and-labrador#timezones) (NT and AT) 

[Beware of nicknames](/home/n/newfoundland-and-labrador#nicknames) (the Rock, the Front) 

**Political entity vs. geographical location**
**Newfoundland and Labrador** (abbreviated as **N.L.**) is the compound name of a single province. This means the proper noun constitutes a **pan-regional reference** to a political entity.

**Newfoundland** and **Labrador** on their own **are specific geographical references** within the province (e.g., "central Newfoundland" and "the northern coast of Labrador").

**St. John's**, therefore, is t**he capital of Newfoundland and Labrador** rather than the "capital of Newfoundland." But it's **located on the southeastern coast of Newfoundland** and NOT on the "coast of Newfoundland and Labrador." Anything that happened to be simultaneously on the shores of Newfoundland and Labrador would be newsworthy in its own right.

Be aware that **online and on-air conventions can vary slightly.**

-   **In WEB writing, N.L. is commonly used when specific geographical detail is deemed necessary** in a string of proper nouns (e.g., **Bonavista, N.L.**, and **Red Bay, N.L.**, but St. John's on its own, for [reasons explained below](/home/n/newfoundland-and-labrador#story)).

-   **In BROADCAST stories, "N.L." is not generally used in the same way.** Instead of spelling out the entire abbreviation, **only one of the components is normally added to a string of proper nouns** (e.g., "Most of the movie was shot in **Bonavista, Newfoundland**," and "The treasure was discovered at the bottom of **Red Bay, Labrador**").

**Web headlines and decks**
**Use N.L. in almost all web headlines:**

> _N.L. demands new deal with Canada_
>
> _Abitibi cuts paper production in Ontario, N.L._
>
> _N.L. fishermen vow to fight cod limits_
>
> _PM slams N.L. premier over flag flap_


**Use Nfld. in web headlines in rare cases when you mean the island only,** as in _central Nfld._ (not "central N.L."). The on-air equivalent would be a headline at the start of a broadcast program that referred to "central Newfoundland." **Spell out Labrador when used alone in web headlines**, however, since there is no conventional abbreviation. Coining shorthand (e.g., "Lbrd.") can confuse our audience and make CBC internet content harder to find through search engines.

**Never drop the periods in geographical shorthand.** Standard abbreviations for provinces and territories include punctuation (e.g., Alta., Ont. and N.L.), according to the Geographical Names Board of Canada (GNBC). Postal code "symbols" (AB, ON and NL), by contrast, do not. (See [provinces and cities](/home/p/provinces-and-cities#abbreviating) for details)


**Story bodies, photo captions, etc.**
**Use N.L. after community names** to represent the provincial component of geographical locations **IN ONLINE STORIES**. A second comma is always required Unless the abbreviation falls at the end of the sentence:

> _Labrador City, N.L._
>
> _They flew to Happy Valley-Goose Bay, N.L., last March._
>
> _She was born in Swift Current, Sask., but grew up in Pouch Cove, N.L._
>
> _The bus broke down near Witless Bay, N.L._


**The province's capital does not require N.L. after it** (i.e., refer to **St. John's**, not to "St. John's, N.L."), for the same reason we don't write "Edmonton, Alta." or "Regina, Sask." or "Winnipeg, Man." See the [provinces and cities](/home/p/provinces-and-cities) overview for comprehensive guidelines.

**Do not use N.L. as an adjective or as a noun on its own**, as you would B.C. or P.E.I. (e.g., "The B.C. town" and "Their trip to P.E.I.") **The test is whether an abbreviation is established in spoken English. N.L. is not**, while B.C. and P.E.I. are as common as UN, RCMP, U.K. and U.S. **Instead, apply the same guidelines to N.L. that you do for N.S. and N.B. Spell out the region's name when using it as an adjective or as a noun** on its own in the main body of a story:

> _A Labrador town ..._
>
> _Their trip to Newfoundland ..._
>
> _The treasure was discovered in southern Newfoundland ..._ (not _"in southern Nfld."_ )
>
> _Newfoundland and Labrador's education system ..._ (not _"N.L.'s education system"_ ) 

**When to add 'and Labrador'**
**When specifically referring to just Newfoundland or to just Labrador, you do not need to use the region's full title:**

> _They're fighting to keep the Labrador mine open._
>
> _Dozens of boats were stolen from six Newfoundland villages._
>
> _Authorities believe the ship sank somewhere along northern Labrador's coastline._
>
> _The planes collided about 30 kilometres southeast of Newfoundland._
>
> _Labrador's economic development was badly hurt by the hydro project's collapse._


**But whenever you're writing about the entire province (or implying a provincial context), use the full name and treat it as a collective singular:**

> _Newfoundland and Labrador Premier Danny Williams refused to sign the accord._
>
> _They're suing the government of Newfoundland and Labrador for $5 million._
>
> _Newfoundland and Labrador disputes the federal scientists' findings._ (not _"dispute"_ )
>
> _She says Newfoundland and Labrador's deficit is still too high._ (not _"deficits are"_ )
>
> _Newfoundland and Labrador promises to back B.C. at the trade hearing._ (not _"promise"_ )


**This conventionally applies even to provincial references before 2001, when Labrador was officially added to the proper noun.**

> _Former Newfoundland and Labrador premiers Brian Tobin and Clyde Wells both ..._


**NOTE: Follow the traditional "bacon and eggs" exception to the [serial comma](/handy-links/punctuation/commas#serial) rule** and include the punctuation:

> _They talked to prosecutors from Quebec, New Brunswick**,** and Newfoundland and Labrador._

**Newfoundlanders and Labradorians**
Residents of Newfoundland are **Newfoundlanders**.
Residents of Labrador are **Labradorians**.
Reserve **Newfoundlanders and Labradorians** to pan-provincial contexts (i.e., in general references to citizens of the entire province).


> NOTE: **Avoid the colloquial but non-parallel construction "Newfoundland and Labradorians."** Just as we refer to Albertans and Manitobans rather than to "Alberta and Manitobans," we need to add suffixes to both proper noun elements in N.L. (i.e., Newfoundlanders and Labradorians). In English, these words are known as demonyms (Canadians, Albertans, Calgarians, Ontarians, Nova Scotians, New Brunswickers). We get audience complaints when such terms are used inconsistently or improperly.

**Retain proper names**
**Do not invent new names for established nouns.**

It's still the **Royal Newfoundland Constabulary**, even though the force describes itself as Newfoundland and Labrador's provincial police service. (For the record, officers patrol only certain places, such as St. John's, Corner Brook, Labrador City and Churchill Falls. These communities make up about 40 per cent of the province's total population. As in many other parts of Canada, the rest of the policing is handled by the RCMP.)

See [police forces](/home/p/police-forces) for relevant details on capitalization rules, etc.


**Time zones (NT and AT)**
NT stands for **Newfoundland time**. Never call it "Newfoundland and Labrador time."

In fact, most of Labrador is on Atlantic time (30 minutes behind St. John's).

**Always use the relevant local time zone (either NT or AT)**. Avoid the abbreviations NST, AST, NDT or ADT. See [time](/home/t/time) for other relevant style rules.


**Beware of nicknames**
The colloquial term **the Rock** conventionally refers to the island only, not to Labrador. This is the definition given by the Canadian Oxford Dictionary. The label is considered very informal and should be posted only if the piece's tone is appropriately light. In general, we should limit its use to transcribed quotes.

Some other less widely known nicknames are OK but should be defined for readers. For instance, **the Front** (the traditional name of the seal hunt along Newfoundland's northeast coast) and **the Gulf fishery** (a common name for the cod catch along Newfoundland's southwest coast) require brief descriptions.


**N.L. background**
Although some media outlets continued to use Nfld. as their abbreviation for the province for many years, **CBC News adopted N.L. for five reasons:**

**1\. It recognizes the province's official name change.** (When Canada's Constitution was amended on Dec. 6, 2001, "Newfoundland" became "Newfoundland and Labrador.")

**2\. It matches the Government of Canada's official geographical names database** (compiled and updated by Natural Resources Canada). Ottawa now uses N.L. as the preferred abbreviation for Newfoundland and Labrador.

**3\. It's similar to the official Canada Post abbreviation** (NL) embraced by Newfoundland and Labrador's government, although our style requires periods.

**4\. It's a close cousin of many of our other provincial short forms** (N.S., N.B., and B.C.).

**5\. It's much shorter than other proposals**, such as Nfld.-Lab.

**2005 Update: The Canadian Press officially adopted N.L. a few months after CBC News.**


> See also Canadian [provinces and cities](/home/p/provinces-and-cities)

### Nicknames

**Nicknames, colloquial nouns**

[Overuse](/home/n/nicknames#overuse) (Does Red Planet add colour?) 

[Accuracy](/home/n/nicknames#caution) (Beware Big Ben)

**Overview**
**Use initial caps for most entrenched nicknames and colloquial or fanciful names.** For example:

> _Babe Ruth_
>
> _the Big Nickel_  (Sudbury)
>
> _the Big Smoke_
>
> _the Big Three_
>
> _Boat People_
>
> _the Cold War_
>
> _the Deep South_
>
> _Generation Z or Gen Z_
> the _Golden Horseshoe_
>
> _Grits_
>
> _the Industrial Revolution_
>
> _the Iron Curtain_
>
> _Mother Nature_
>
> the _Panhandle_ (in Florida)
>
> _the Quiet Revolution_
>
> _Red Chamber_
>
> _Red Planet_
>
> _the Rust Belt_
>
> _Silicon Valley_
>
> _the Superstack_  (iconic smokestack in Sudbury)
>
> _Tiger Williams_
>
> _Tories_
>
> _the Windsor Hum_


**This includes various names from science, religion, etc., treated as proper noun equivalents:**


> the Ark of the Covenant (Judaism, Christianity)
>
> the Big Bang
>
> the Crown of Thorns
>
> the Holy Grail (but holy water)
>
> the Holy Mantle (Islam)
>
> the Last Supper
>
> the Shroud of Turin


NOTE: Initial caps do not telegraph that something is proven, genuine, etc. The Big Bang is a prevailing theory about how the universe began, but it's still a theory. And pieces of wood said to be from the True Cross are conventionally described as religious relics that some people believe are from the Crucifixion of Jesus Christ.

For religious names, see [the Deity but the devil](/home/d/the-deity-and-the-devil) (e.g., the Almighty, the Father, the Holy Spirit, the Prophet, the Son, Satan).

**TIP: The primary capitalization tests are whether nouns are unique** (or at the very least apply to a relatively small number of people, places or things), **and reasonably established**. This does not mean they need to be widely known. Sometimes a colloquialism has simply been adopted by a given group (e.g., residents of a community, auto industry analysts, sports writers, historians). In those cases, the key is making sure that the term is understood in the story — either by context or definition.

**If only part of a compound is used in second reference, drop the capitalization:**

> _the Big Three_ becomes _the three_
>
> _the Red Planet_ becomes _the planet_
>
> _the Windsor Hum_ becomes _the hum_ (i.e., "hum" on its own is treated as generic)

**But retain capitalization when an optional proper noun is dropped** in second reference:


> the Florida _Panhandle_ becomes _the Panhandle_ because Florida is not essential to the original compound (e.g., the Panhandle in Florida, Florida's Panhandle)


**Sometimes an entire term is kept lowercase in first reference because it's simply not unique** (e.g., there has been only one _Iron Age_ but several ice ages). See [historical periods](/home/h/historical-periods) for details and more examples.

**Narrow meaning of term 'nickname'**
**The term _nickname_ normally refers to a second, often shorter, name:**

> _The four-engine KC-135 jet, nicknamed the Weightless Wonder, is used to train astronauts._


**If something doesn't have a proper name, it technically can't have a nickname. So avoid using the word as a mere synonym for _named, called, dubbed, known as_, etc.**

> _The shallow depression near the rover’s landing spot is called_ (not nicknamed) _Sleepy Hollow._


This spot on Mars does not have any formal name. It's simply a small depression, about half the length of a bowling alley, within the Gusev crater. Until the International Astronomical Union (IAU) gives it a name, the depression can't have a nickname.

Scientists, by the way, reportedly began calling it Sleepy Hollow in January 2004 because they didn’t get much rest studying all the pictures being transmitted to Earth. It would be misleading to say NASA formally _named_ it Sleepy Hollow, since this would be up to the IAU. But it would also be wrong to say the space agency _nicknamed_ it. Scientists simply dubbed it Sleepy Hollow on their own. So **while it's certainly OK to say that an agency like NASA has informally named something in space, avoid wording that implies the name is official** unless it's been approved by the IAU.

**Brackets optional
****Use brackets, **not** quotations marks, to identify a nickname inserted into a proper noun:**

> _John Birks (Dizzy) Gillespie_
>
> _Joseph (Joey) Smallwood_
>
> _Dave (Tiger) Williams_


**But you can also use a nickname alone in first reference if it's more common than the proper name.**

> _Dizzy Gillespie_
>
> _Joey Smallwood_
>
> _Tiger Williams_
>
> _Cy Young_ (His first name was actually Denton; Cy was short for _The Cyclone_.)



**Reserve quotation marks to mean 'so-called'**
**When a nickname is not widely known, quotation marks can help flag it. But** since inverted commas normally suggest "so-called" in this context, **it's generally best to limit the use of such punctuation for times when you want to convey that added meaning:**

> _There's no doubt Anderson is the new "It Boy" of hip-hop._
>
> _The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo was the "It Girl" of IT last year._


See [quotation marks](/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks) for general guidelines on when to use single (' ') or double (" ") inverted commas.

**Spelling disputes**
**In general, use CBC News style for generic words in a nickname unless this spelling conflicts with well-established convention or an individual's clear personal preference.**

**Do not rely solely on the dictionary. Check the Language Guide first.** For instance, both CBC News and CP prefer phoney over phony, even though the Canadian Oxford lists phony as its primary spelling:

> _Larry (Phoney Baloney) Brooks_

**An individual's personal preference trumps in-house style.** For instance, while smoky is our usual spelling, with smokey listed as only a variation in the Canadian Oxford, the following Canadian war hero and his family embraced the extra vowel:

> _Ernest (Smokey) Smith_


**Also, retain the original spellings of proper nouns and well-established nicknames:**

> _Smokey Bear_ (this is a noun not a nickname, and there's no "the" in the middle)
>
> _Smokey Robinson_ (a spelling clearly preferred by this U.S. citizen)


**One helpful guide is the absence of brackets.** If the label in question is _not_ in brackets, it's generally either a proper noun or a very well-established nickname that functions as a proper noun.

**Does the 'Red Planet' add colour?**
**Use capital letters for names and nicknames**, such as _the Milky Way_ and _the Rockies_.

Nicknames can help writing. They provide variety and often a welcome dash of colour.

But they can also become tiresome quickly within the same story. For instance, repeatedly calling Mars the Red Planet or Canada's Senate the _Red Chamber_ will probably be considered trite by many readers, listeners or viewers, so it's wise to e_xercise some restraint_.

**Beware Big Ben**
**Colloquial names require care. Make sure they apply.**

For instance, **_Big Ben_ is the name of the massive, 13.5-ton bell in the famous clock on the Houses of Parliament in Britain** that marks the hours. It is not the name of the bells that strike on the quarter-hours. It is also **not the name of the tower or of the clock itself** — which for more than a century was technically known as either the "Westminster Clock Tower" or as "the clock on St. Stephen's Tower at the Palace of Westminster."

In September 2012, the structure was renamed **Elizabeth Tower** in honour of Queen Elizabeth II's Diamond Jubilee. Until this name becomes widely used, however, it's acceptable to continue to refer to it as **Big Ben's tower** (lowercase "t"), since this possessive form accurately describes the famous landmark that holds the iconic bell.

See also [brackets](/handy-links/punctuation/brackets) as well as [common versus legal names](/home/n/names_common) (George Orwell instead of Eric Arthur Blair), and [second reference names](/home/q/quotes-overview#second-reference-names) (family versus first).

### Nobel Prizes

**Nobel Prizes**

**The generic word "prize" is uppercase if it's next to the name Nobel:**

Nobel Prize
Nobel Prizes
Nobel Prize winner
Nobel Prize laureate
Nobel Prize-winning researcher
the prize, the peace prize, the prize for chemistry, the prizes, etc.


**Nobel in always capitalized** because it's a proper noun element:

a Nobel
the Nobel for physics

**Official names of the prizes**
the Nobel Peace Prize
the Nobel Prize in Chemistry
the Nobel Prize in Literature
the Nobel Prize in Medicine (or Physiology, whichever applies)
the Nobel Prize in Physics
the Nobel in economics (not the "Nobel Prize in Economics")
or the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science (See explanation below)

**Why no "Prize" in economics?**

The economics award is not strictly a Nobel Prize because it’s funded by the Bank of Sweden in memory of Alfred Nobel. It’s known as the Bank of Sweden Prize in Economic Sciences in Memory of Alfred Nobel.

But in news stories it can be called the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science (singular, uppercase), or the Nobel Memorial Prize in economics (plural lowercase), or the Nobel in economics (plural, lowercase).

**A capital C, for consistency
**
The Canadian Press and some other news organization don't capitalize most of the categories (e.g. chemistry or literature). They make an exception for "Peace" because it's in the middle of "Nobel" and "Prize."

CBC News, the New York Times and many other media organizations take a different approach. We capitalize all the words in the name of each award (except economics for reasons outlined above). So in a wire story, you might see "the Nobel Prize in physics" but should write "the Nobel Prize in Physics."

For more information about Nobel Prizes, including past winners, visit the [Nobel Foundation's website.](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nobel.se%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2o3uO3lrFIjXHeQiEA023p)

See also [Awards versus awards](/home/a/award-versus-award)

### non-confidence

**Non-confidence vote**

**Canadian governments need the confidence of a majority of MPs in the House of Commons to stay in power.**

Governments can fall if they fail to pass an official test of this confidence, but such a loss doesn’t automatically trigger an election. The Governor General might refuse the prime minister’s request for dissolution and, instead, call on the Official Opposition to form the government if there were evidence that this party could secure and maintain the confidence of the House.

**Non-confidence motions come in several forms.** The most common is a vote on a major piece of legislation (such as a throne speech, which sets out the direction the government plans to take), or a money bill (including the budget). The government can also attach confidence motions to any measures, no matter how minor. And opposition parties can table non-confidence motions on certain days.


**Non-confidence versus no-confidence**
The term "no-confidence" was used for years. Authoritative manuals such as _Beauchesne's Parliamentary Rules and Forms_ backed it. This was also the language found in the 1985 Report of the Special Committee on Reform of the House of Commons (known as "the McGrath report"), and in the old House Standing Orders, when all supply motions were considered matters of confidence in the government.

But more recent guides, such as the _House of Commons Procedure and Practice_ by Robert Marleau and Camille Montpetit (first published in 2000), have featured "no-confidence" and "non-confidence" interchangeably. And several books, including _The Language of Canadian Politics and The House of Commons at Work_, use only "non-confidence." In November 2005, the head of communications for the Speaker’s office told CBC News that both labels were considered acceptable. By the end of the decade, however, there had been a noticeable shift toward "non-confidence" as the preferred choice off and on Parliament Hill.


**Use non-confidence**
Language evolves. Although the traditional term "no-confidence" still crops up from time to time, **non-confidence** is the much more widely used adjective and noun. That's why it was adopted as the **CBC News preference** at the end of April 2010:

> a non-confidence motion
>
> a non-confidence vote
>
> a motion of non-confidence
>
> a vote of non-confidence
>
> a confidence motion
>
> a confidence vote


The only exceptions are directly transcribed quotes that feature the older phrase "no-confidence." Such verbatim quotes should not be changed.

**When there are different approaches to certain words, it's important to be consistent.** Our writers and editors don't need to waste time debating which version to go with, and our audience isn't left bouncing between different forms on a whim. That's why we pick the adverb [backward](/home/w/ward-versus-wards), for instance, instead of "backwards" (e.g., "They walked backward"), and spellings such as colour and skeptic (instead of "color" and "sceptic").

For more background on minority governments and non-confidence motions in Canada, see the feature: [When the majority doesn’t rule](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews%2Fcanada%2Fwhen-the-majority-doesn-t-rule-1.728726&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2XF0RDQ7g9TsJ5Ks1735kT).

### non-consensual-sex

**Non-consensual sex**

This entrenched **expression requires care.**

**1\. The first issue is whether consent can actually be granted.
**

> **Children**
>
> The **term "non-consensual sex" is inappropriate in stories about minors** who've been allegedly assaulted by adults. **So are expressions like "underage sex partners,"** which imply something far different from the accusations of abuse and exploitation that are at the heart of such criminal cases.
>
>
> **Adults**
>
> **Even when the alleged victims are 18 and older, it's possible that consent cannot be lawfully given** — e.g., because someone is impaired by alcohol or drugs, by a cognitive condition, etc. So be sure the facts fit before referring to "non-consensual" sex. Be aware, too, that the age of consent may vary from country to country.


**2\. The second issue is whether more direct wording is better** because it's clearer.

In our adversarial legal system, "non-consensual" is commonly used to contest a person's claim that a given act was "consensual." This includes various federal Justice Department documents and Supreme Court of Canada rulings that refer to "non-consensual sex."

However, **the term "non-consensual sex" can be a roundabout, almost bureaucratic, way of saying "sexual assault."** So while it's OK to report that "the accused says the sex was consensual," it's often best to balance the story with the language actually used by the alleged victim (e.g., "She says he sexually assaulted her despite being repeatedly told to stop").

See also [child prostitute (avoid), child sex trafficking](/home/c/child_prostitution)

See also [child, teen, young adult, etc.](/home/c/child_teen) (for guidelines on age ranges)


### none\_is\_are

**None is and none are**

**BOTH are OK in virtually all contexts:
**

> _None is ...
> None are ..._


**ALL major English grammar authorities surveyed agree on this point** — from Fowler and Bernstein to Gowers and Partridge.

Some people cling to the idea that "none" is an abbreviation for "not one." But this is simplistic. "None" also conventionally means "not any" and "no people or things." In his classic 1984 treasury, _A Dictionary of Troublesome Words_, Bill Bryson starts his entry bluntly:


> "The widely held belief that none must be singular is a myth.... "


**The key is to be consistent within the same web article, broadcast script, etc.** So pick one (none is/none are) and stick to it throughout a given story.

The Oxford Guide to Canadian English Usage points out that **the only time we're required to use the singular verb with "none" is when we mean "no part of a mass or whole,"** as in:


> _None of it MAKES sense._ (SINGULAR CORRECT)
> _None of it MAKE sense._ (PLURAL WRONG)


See [grammar](/handy-links/grammar) for an alphabetical list of various guidelines

### nor versus or

**Nor versus or**

**Neither ... nor, either ... or**
**There's usually no confusion when pairing these conjunctions with their correlatives** (_neither ... nor_ on the one hand, and _either ... or_ on the other).

> They can have **either** beer **or** wine. (correct and conversational)
>
> He **neither** sings **nor** dances. (correct but formal)
>
> He **doesn't** sing **or** dance. (correct and conversational)


But a few structural weaknesses are common. Always remember:

**1\. Sentences should be parallel**, especially when written for the eye (the web) rather than for the ear.

> They can have **either** sugar **or** honey. (balanced; _either_ refers to nouns)
>
> They can either have sugar or honey. (unbalanced; _either_ refers to verb _have_)
>
> She's **either in** Saskatoon **or in** Regina. (prepositional form is balanced)
>
> She's either in Saskatoon or Regina. (unbalanced; a second preposition is usually recommended)
>
> He will **neither do** this **nor do** that. (clauses balanced)
>
> He will neither do this nor that. (unbalanced; a second verb is usually recommended)


**2\. When singular subjects are connected by nor/or, the verb should generally be kept singular.**

> **Neither** Burton nor Kashinato **supports** the proposal. (not "support")
>
> **Either** French or English **is** fine. (not "are")


**3\. When any subjects are plural, however, the rules of disjunctive conjunctions kick in**, which means that the elements being linked to by nor/or are considered separately, depending on sentence construction. **In formal writing, one custom is to match the verb with the nearest subject:**

> Either several cards or just one **is** chosen.
>
> Either just one or several cards **are** chosen.

**But such constructions can wind up being needlessly stilted**. As a result, **many good editors recommend either recasting so that the plural comes last, or simply using a plural verb, regardless of word order:**

> Neither the team's owner nor players **agree**.
> Neither the players nor the team's owner **agree**.

**Not ... or, not ... nor**
**When the word "not" refers to two or more verbs, nouns, adjectives, etc., we normally connect these parts of the sentence with "or."**

> He **didn't** laugh **or** cry.
>
> The bicycle is **not** in the garage **or** in the basement.


**It's perfectly acceptable to use "nor" after a pause, however, if we want to emphasize a second verb, noun, adjective, etc.** This can be at the start of a new fragment, clause or an entirely new sentence.

> The players **couldn't** stand the coach's pep talks. **Nor** could they put up with his wild mood swings.
>
> His grandmother **didn't** call that weekend, **nor** the next. He knew something was wrong.
>
> The typographical error **did not create** ambiguity **nor alter** the sentence's meaning.


**But using a negative conjunction this way has its limits.** The most common mistake is to use "nor" for "or" when there's no need to separate a sentence's parts in a special way for emphasis:

> They **weren't** buying necklaces **or** bracelets. (correct)
>
> They weren't buying necklaces nor bracelets. (poor; non-standard)


**As with a lot of writing, of course, the choice between "or" and "nor" is often subjective. Sometimes it largely depends on whether you want to underscore a certain word or idea.**

> Their immediate problem is **neither** food **nor** shelter. It's water. (correct)
>
> Their immediate problem is **not** food **or** shelter. It's water. (correct)
>
> Their immediate problem is **not** food, **nor** is it shelter. It's water. (correct)

### normality

**Normality versus normalcy**

For consistency, generally **prefer the noun normality over normalcy** (e.g., "return to normality").

**Both terms refer to a common or usual state.** They're used with roughly equal frequency across the country, according to the Oxford Guide to Canadian English.

**Normality is the older word**, coined in the 1830s. **Normalcy**, which surfaced a few decades later, **gained popularity in the United States in the 1920s**, according to lexicographers.

**Some grammarians initially derided normalcy**, saying the -acy suffix is typically found only in nouns tied to adjectives ending in "t" or "te" (e.g., _accuracy, complacency, hesitancy_ and _pregnancy_ are linked to the modifiers _accurate, complacent, hesitant_ and _pregnant_). However, **normalcy gradually became entrenched as an acceptable synonym**.

### North, South, East and West

**North, South, East and West**

**Capitalize recognized regions** (whether a local neighbourhood, such as _Vancouver's Downtown Eastside_, a group of communities, such as _Upstate New York,_ a section of a country or continent, such as the _Eastern Seaboard_, or a large part of the globe, such as the _Western Hemisphere_). **But do not generally capitalize mere derivatives** (_Western Canada_ but a _western Canadian_, and the _East Coast_ but the _eastern provinces_).

Sometimes this can lead to debates. _Southern California_ is uppercase because it's frequently referred to this way while _southern Oregon_ and _northern France_ are not. When deciding whether to use initial caps, survey a few large Western news organizations, such as CP and AP, to see if consistent usage has become entrenched. Keep in mind that logic can help determine style. For instance, _western Sudan_ has always been lowercase as a generic reference. By contrast, _Southern Sudan_ was given initial capital letters after winning limited autonomy as a region. The latter eventually became the independent country of _South Sudan_ in 2011.

For consistency **we write _eastern Quebec, southern Ontario, western Saskatchewan, northern Alberta_, etc. But regions, such _the B.C. Interior_, are uppercase, as are terms such as _Western governments_ and _Western leaders_ and _Western media_** when referring to the _Western Hemisphere_. This is also the approach taken by most wire services.

**In plural constructions, common noun elements become lowercase** (e.g., _the Northern and Southern hemispheres_).
**The points of the compass** (mere direction or position) **are lowercase** (the North but a _northern city_, the West Coast but the _west coast of Vancouver Island_, Quebec's Eastern Townships but the _east end of Montreal_).

Although cardinal direction (N, S, E, W) can help our audience pinpoint a geographical location, **be aware that entrenched terminology preferred in a given region can sometimes be confusing to a national audience.** For example, Ontario is traditionally divided into two broad halves: north and south. Since the city of Ottawa is in the south, it's technically (and accurately) part of [**southern Ontario**](/home/s#southernOntario) — as noted by numerous authorities, from official government of Ontario road maps to Elections Canada riding maps. However, **Ottawa** is also conventionally referred to as being in **eastern Ontario** rather than to being in **southern Ontario** or **southeastern Ontario**. In cases like this, generally prefer the established, local convention as long as the meaning is clear (e.g., "Lockdown restrictions have been extended to eastern Ontario"). Another option is to use a specific community's name (e.g., "Pandemic lockdown restrictions in parts of southern Ontario have been extended to Ottawa and neighbouring communities").

### Numbers

**Numbers**
The following rules apply to the main text of web stories, most TV graphics, etc. A separate section on headlines appears at the bottom of the page.

[One to nine](/home/n/numbers#general) (general)
[1 to 9](/home/n/numbers#exceptions) (exceptions)

[Symbols](/home/n/numbers#symbols) ($, %, etc.)
[Series](/home/n/numbers#series) (page 2 but Chapter 8)
[Alphanumeric designations](/home/n/numbers#alphanumeric) (M-16 versus M16; DC-10 but J50)
[Figures written out](/home/n/numbers#figures) (Grade 9 but ninth grade)
[10 and up](/home/n/numbers#10andup) (general)
[Ten and up](/home/n/numbers#tenandup) (exceptions)

[Combinations](/home/n/numbers#combinations) (two and 11)
[Heights, weights, etc.](/home/n/numbers#heightsandweights) (imperial versus metric)
[Dimensions](/home/n/numbers#dimensions) (a 4-by-6 photo, the room is 12 by 9 feet)
Generally use [arabic not roman](/home/n/numbers#arabicroman) numerals
[Ordinals](/home/n/numbers#ordinals) (1st, 2nd, 3rd)

Use of "[per cent](/home/n/numbers#percent)"


[Miscellaneous](/home/n/numbers#miscellaneous) (three degrees or 3 C, 1950s or '50s, .22-calibre rifle, addresses, phone numbers, etc.)

See also the [**imperial versus metric**](/home/m/metric-versus-imperial) overview

**One to nine** **(general)**
**In most cases, write out numbers between one and nine:**

> _The report was written by six people. It included seven recommendations._
>
> _The truck was carrying more than four million litres of fuel._
>
> _The Detroit Three and the Big Five banks refused to comment._
>
> _CBC Radio One will broadcast the event live._


**This includes common names of vehicles** (four-by-four), **types of lumber**, etc., unless in [headlines](/home/n/numbers#inheadlines) (4x4).The four-by-four drove over a two-by-four about one-third into the race. **But convention plays a role, including in how standard dimensions are reported** (e.g., four-by-four lumber versus a photo that's 4 by 6).


**1 to 9** **(common exceptions)**
5-4 ruling, 6-2 odds, a ratio of 3.5 to 1, the quake had a magnitude of 7.2, Grade 6, Highway 3, they met at 5 o'clock (also known as 5 p.m.), it was 9 C outside, Act 2, Scene 3, page 4, paragraph 5, line 6, verse 7, Chapter 8, Day 1, Type 2 diabetes, Level 3 charger, Category 4 hurricane, 5G wireless network, Treaty 7, Article 8, Cloud 9, Phase 2, a 3D film, a glossy 8 by 10, Round 5, Room 6, size 7 shoes, a V-8 engine, an 8-mm camera, a 9-mm pistol, Channel 6, a Dash 7, behind the 8-ball, Apollo 9, they're No. 1, back to Square 1, a Leopard 1 tank, aboard the QE2, listening to CBC Radio 3, drinking 7Up, 1 MB, 2 GB, RR3, the 4-H club, Lotto 6/49, [9/11](/home/s#Sept11) (for informal references to Sept. 11, 2001), and [911](/home/p/phone-numbers) (the phone number).

**Generally maintain exceptions, even when this results in a blend of figures and words** within the same sentence or story. **When reporting measurements, however, avoid combining spelled-out numbers with figures. Instead, generally prefer figures across the board**, especially when they apply to the same units (inches, metres):

> _She worked for CBC Radio One before joining CBC Radio 3._
>
> _At least six people died in the Category 3 hurricane._
>
> _They fought over an autographed 8 by 10._
>
> _A 16-by-9 aspect ratio means 16 units wide by 9 units high._


See [single-sentence combinations](/home/n/numbers#combinations) (two and 11) for related guidelines.

See also [ages](/home/n/numbers#ages) and [symbols](/home/n/numbers#symbols) below, as well as the [capitalization overview](/home/c/capitalization) (for details on distinctions such as "Category 5 hurricane" versus "Hurricane Katrina was a Category 5 storm").

**For guidelines on handling two-digit numbers and higher, see [10 and up](/home/n/numbers#10andup)** below, which covers general principles as well as exceptions (e.g., when a figure like 10 is written as ten, such as at the start of a sentence).


**Ages**
**Use figures for all ages that stand alone immediately after a name. Otherwise, spell out numbers under 10:**

> _Elizabeth, 4, has a sister, six, and a brother, nine._
>
> _Danny, five months old, stopped crying as soon as the taxi began moving._


**Don't bother adding "years" or "years old" when the context makes it obvious:**

> _She was 63 at the time._
>
> _His granddaughter was seven._

**Hyphenate ages in adjectives as well as nouns:**

> _The eight-year-old girl laughed._
>
> _The 16-year-old scoffed._

**TIP –** **Cumbersome compounds can be avoided if ages are set off by commas:**

> _Wilson, 22, is studying chemistry_ (instead of _The 22-year-old chemistry student ..._)

See also [child, teen, young adult, etc.](/home/c/child_teen), for general guidelines on labelling age groups.


**Symbols**
**Use figures, **not** words, when the number under 10 is tied directly to a symbol:**

> _$2_ or _two dollars_ but never 2 dollars. (See also [money](/home/n/numbers#money))
>
> _5 C_ or _five degrees_ but never 5 degrees. (See also [temperatures](/home/m/metric-versus-imperial#temperatures))
>
> _3%_ or _three per cent_ but never 3 per cent. (See also [per cent](/home/n/numbers#percent))


**But figures are OK when the number under 10 that's tied to a symbol is a fraction:**

> Four francs, but _4.5 francs_.
>
> Three percentage points but _3.5 percentage points_.


(See also [common fractions](/home/n/numbers#fractions))


**Series**
**Generally capitalize nouns before figures if the units represent one part of a numbered series** (Act 3, Article 4, Bill C-5, Block 6, Channel 7, Chapter 8, Cloud 9, Figure 10, Grade 11, Part 2, Phase 3, Room 404, Section 50, Square 1, Round 2, Volume 11, Ward 6). But **words after the figure generally remain lowercase** (e.g., a [Category 5 hurricane](/home/w/weather-words#category), Level 3 chargers, Type 2 diabetes). This typography is different from colour-based shorthand, which is lowercase (e.g., [code red, code blue](/home/c#codecolours)).

**Use lowercase for plural constructions** (articles 14 and 15, chapters 5-6, grades 8-12), **as well as for a smattering of nouns** (almost all tied to publishing) **that are rarely capitalized based on convention** (number 1, page 2, paragraph 3, sentence 4, size 5, verse 6, line 7). This includes subjective groupings that are common only within certain communities (e.g., references by some Canadian police officers to level 1 sexual assault, level 2 sexual assault, etc., even though these rankings do not appear in the Criminal Code).

**Although a few words can be abbreviated before a figure** (page 2 or p. 2, Section 50 or Sec. 50, Volume 11 or Vol. 11), **it's generally best to spell them out in news stories.** The term **"number" is a common exception worth noting.** When abbreviated, the word takes on an initial capital (number 1, number 2, number 3 becomes No. 1, No. 2, No. 3).

Unlike in boxing, the term **Round of 16** doesn't refer to a sequence (the "sixteenth round"). Rather, it describes the number of teams remaining (16 out of 32) in the second phase of the [FIFA World Cup](/home/f/fifa-world-cup-2010).


**Alphanumeric designations**
**There's no single alphanumeric naming system.** For instance, **M-16** (with a hyphen) commonly refers to a rifle, while **M16** (fused) is a "deep space object" that astronomer's also call the Eagle nebula.

We **normally follow established industry letter-number naming conventions, including typography**, unless there's an editorial reason to diverge (e.g., if a given set of numbers and letters is too difficult to read without the aid of punctuation, or if unorthodox capitalization clashes with our own general style).

For instance, some types of aircraft feature hyphens (e.g., **DC-10, MD-11**) while others don't (**A340, CS300**). Punctuation depends on various factors, including whether the letters represent true abbreviations or merely spots in a sequence. Regardless, when used, we usually place the hyphens before figures rather than after them (**747B**), based on traditional publishing style. See [aircraft names](/home/a/aircraft-names) for details and other examples.

**It's generally OK to adopt widely followed naming conventions we encounter during routine newsgathering**, unless a specific exception is listed in the Language Guide. **If you have doubts about a proper noun, nickname, letter-number combination, etc., consult a reputable authority.** In marine biology, for instance, scientists track individual **orcas** by giving them unique alphanumeric labels (e.g., **J50** and **L123**). These designations traditionally have no hyphens or spaces. The letter represents an identified group of whales (e.g., **J pod** and **L pod**), while the number represents a specific orca within that population. And in the case of air quality measurements, scientists tend to fuse terms such as **PM2.5** to underscore that the fine "particulate matter" is 2.5 microns or less in diameter, versus say **PM5** or **PM10** pollutants.

Be aware that **there's no universal approach to typography even within the same field.** In astronomy, for instance, various cataloguing systems are used, so the same galaxy, nebula, globular cluster, etc., is sometimes known by more than one label — e.g., the "Owl nebula" is referred to as both **M97** (M fused to the numerical designation) as well as **NGC 3587** (with a space between the letters and numbers).

**For serial numbers, manufacturing codes, etc., it's normally quickest and clearest to render the sequence verbatim**, including hyphens or other characters (e.g., in a web story about a product recall).

**Figures written out**
**Sometimes an abbreviation that uses a figure** (the G8) **can also be written out** (the Group of Eight countries).

**Figures are almost always used in headlines** (a "rugby 7s" team) **even when normally spelled out in the main body of storie**s (the sport "rugby sevens"). See [numbers in headlines](/home/n/numbers#inheadlines) below for more details.

**In many cases, uppercase terms that use figures** (Grade 6, Act 2, Round 3, Scene 4, 7 C) **are written out using lowercase versions** (the sixth grade, the second act, the third round, the fourth scene, seven degrees, etc.)

See also [starting sentences](/home/n/numbers#starting) below


**10 and up (general)**
**In most cases, use figures for 10 and up:**

> _The convoy included 23 trucks, 16 jeeps and 10 tanks._
>
> _Did Edward de Vere, the 17th Earl of Oxford, actually write all 154 sonnets?_
>
> _The 21st century began with security concerns along the 49th parallel._
>
> _The Sept. 11 attacks against the United States changed everything._
>
> _How many 30-somethings like the latest films from 20th Century Fox?_


**Ten and up** **(exceptions)**
**But there are some exceptions** (e.g., ten-pin bowling, not 10-pin, the Ten Commandments, not 10, and the Twelve Apostles, not 12).


**Starting sentences**
**Generally write out figures at the start of sentences:**

> _Eleven tanks rumbled up the hill._ (**NOT** 11 _tanks rumbled up the hill._)
>
> _Thirty people were on the boat._ (**NOT** 30 _people were on the boat._)


**It's usually best to rewrite sentences that include long numbers at the start:**

> _Medals were given to 99 soldiers._ (**NOT** _Ninety-nine soldiers received medals._)


**Ages are handled the same way.** Instead of starting a sentence with a figure, recast whenever practical:


> _Twenty-seven-year-old Jane Smith and 58-year-old John Doe both died in the crash._ (Traditional publishing style)
>
> _27-year-old Jane Smith and 58-year-old John Doe both died in the crash._ (**NOT** recommended)
>
> _Jane Smith, 27, and John Doe, 58, both died in the crash._ (Preferred)



**NOTE: Broadcast journalists** accustomed to writing scripts for the ear **sometimes overlook the value of subordinate clauses in text written for the eye.** Inserting a detail, such as an age, between commas can help keep sentences shorter.


See [ages](/home/n/numbers#ages) above for related guidelines.

**In rare cases, it's acceptable to begin sentences with figures** if spelling out would be jarring or much harder to read. **For instance, years and numbers in addresses do not have to be written out**, although it's usually best to try to rewrite whenever possible:

> _1995 was a good year for wine._
>
> _24 Sussex Drive is not far from Parliament Hill._


**Never change proper nouns to avoid figures** at the start of sentences:

> _20th Century Fox plans to release ..._ (**NOT** _Twentieth Century Fox ..._)


**Combinations (two and 11)**
**Sentences sometimes include combinations of figures and words that represent numbers:**

> _"In two minutes we'll see all 12 jurors," the guard predicted._
>
> _About 100 inmates watched Channel 7's coverage of the trial on three large TVs._


When reporting [dimensions](/home/n/numbers#dimensions), however, generally use figures across the board (e.g., 8 by 10).

**Heights, weights, etc.**
**For people, use imperial units** (feet, inches, pounds and ounces). **Otherwise, generally use metric units** (e.g., "_The dog weighed 40 kilograms_") **unless an industry standard has been entrenched** (e.g., "_The average price of gold last year was $850 per ounce_").

**We normally spell out numbers under 10.** Commas are not necessary:


> _He's six feet three inches tall and weighs 200 pounds._
>
> _She's five feet 11 inches._
>
> _The baby is nine pounds 10 ounces._


**Include hyphens when the numbers are part of an adjective:**


> _The five-foot-three-inch woman._
>
> _The seven-foot-two-inch shooting guard._


**Heights can also be expressed less formally using figures** instead of words:


> _She stands 5-10._
>
> _Half of the team is over 6-11._


Although this shorthand is sometimes expressed using an apostrophe and quotation marks (e.g., _She stands 5'10"_), **prefer a single hyphen rather than ' and " marks**, as long as the context makes the meaning (feet and inches) clear.

**Use imperial for real estate** (_2,100 square feet_), **but metric for most land size, including farms and forests**. See [imperial versus metric](/home/m/metric-versus-imperial) for more details, including when to add a metric conversion in brackets to an established imperial standard.


**Dimensions**
While details about height and weight may involve more than one unit (e.g., feet and inches), the total in each case represents a single measurement. By contrast, **the plural term "dimensions" refers to at least two separate measurements** (e.g., width and height). **Generally use the preposition "by" when reporting dimensions**, rather than symbols such as "x" or ":" _(the ratio is 16 by 9_). This is standard publishing style. It's also in line with effective broadcast script writing, since words are easier to read on air than symbols. **The main exception is web headline writing** (e.g., 8x10 is OK instead of 8 by 10 in headlines, graphics, etc.), as [outlined below](/home/n/numbers#inheadlines). Although traditional race descriptions, such as the 4x100 relay, commonly feature the "x" symbol, these are not dimensions (i.e., the first figure refers to the number of athletes each team has in the race, and the second figure refers to the distance each sprinter runs). See our [Olympics overview](/home/o/olympic-games#distance) for relevant guidelines.

**Prefer figures except in rare cases when spelled-out numbers have been established by convention**, such as lumber sizes (e.g., _the old Graflex used 4 by 5 film, but he smashed the camera with a two-by-four_).

**The relevant unit of measurement** (inch, foot, metre) **normally appears at the end** of the "by" string of figures (e.g., _the maximum size is 20 by 14 by 6 inches_), **unless it's easier to read as a series of units without the preposition "by"** (e.g., _the subway cars are roughly 23 metres long, 3 metres wide, and 4 metres high_). **Prefer words over symbols** (e.g., inches instead of ").

**Hyphens are usually added only when dimensions directly modify a noun** (_a 4-by-3 format_ versus a _ratio of 4 to 3_, an image _4 units wide by 3 units high_, etc.)

Examples of preferred ways to report common dimensions:


> _The room was 12 by 9 feet._
>
> _A 12-by-9 foot room._
>
> _The standard size is roughly 60 by 30 by 15 centimetres._
>
> _The vehicles are roughly 13 by 2.5 metres._
>
> _The new buses are 12.8 metres long, 2.6 metres wide, and 4.2 metres high._
>
> _They used four-by-fours to replace the rotting fence posts._


**In rare cases, it's unnecessary to specify units of measurement** when this detail is clearly implied:


> _She had a stack of signed 8 by 10s._
>
> _The standard printer paper is 8½ by 11._


**When adding imperial units in brackets, generally round to the nearest half unit** (e.g., 0.5 inches), unless a more precise measurement is deemed necessary for the story (e.g., in medical or scientific reporting).


> _The Mona Lisa is relatively small, at 77 by 53 centimetres (30 by 21 inches)._
>
> _The maximum size of carry-on luggage is 55 by 35 by 20 centimetres (21.5 by 13.5 by 7.5 inches)._


See **[industry standards](/home/m/metric-versus-imperial#keyexceptions)** for details about building materials (e.g., **lumber is conventionally spelled out in imperial units**, such as two-by-fours), as well as certain real estate dimensions (e.g., **structure and room sizes are still commonly reported in feet** rather than metres). See [imperial versus metric](/home/m/metric-versus-imperial) for general guidelines.


**Arabic versus roman**
**Use arabic, **not** roman, numerals except in rare cases** (e.g., when referring to popes, the monarchy, and some other nouns widely assigned such sequential designation):

> _Henry VIII, Elizabeth I, Pope John XXIII, Australia II_ (yacht), _LAV III_ (armoured vehicle), _The Godfather, Part II_ (film), _SALT II_ (strategic arms limitation talks), _Vatican II_ (Second Vatican Council)


Although _WW I_ and _WW II_ are allowed in stories that feature these common abbreviations in their web headlines, we generally prefer [First World War and Second World War](/home/w#WW1WW2) in all other cases.
**Do not assume a proper noun includes roman numerals.** While the official names of some vessels and films do, for instance, most feature standard arabic numerals:

> _Bluenose II_ **but** _QE2_ (Queen Elizabeth 2)
>
> _Rocky IV_ **but** _Stuart Little 3_


**Ordinal figures (1st, 2nd, 3rd)**
**In most cases, ordinal numbers below 10 are spelled out:**

> _It was the **first** time she flew in a plane._
>
> _He groaned after the **second** strike was called._
>
> _He placed **third** in the men's 1,500 metres._


**Common exceptions** are proper nouns, such as book or film titles, as well as certain nouns traditionally treated as names, such as military units:

> _The **2nd** Field Artillery Regiment_
>
> _The U.S. **7th** Fleet_


**For most ordinals above nine, use figures:**

> _Not a bad way to begin her **18th** year._
>
> _They're members of the **47th** Highlanders of Canada_


**Common exceptions** are extremely large figures (e.g., a millionth, billionth) and proper nouns, such as book and film titles:

> _He borrowed a copy of Graham Green's The **Tenth** Man._
>
> _They watched a Miracle on **34th** Street for the **millionth** time._


When abbreviating, leave out the ordinal notation (st, nd, rd, th) in [standard date constructions](/home/a/abbreviations#dates): 

> _July 2, 2011_
>
> _Oct. 8, 2013_


The exception for dates is when a sentence's syntax requires this additional detail, such as in a prepositional clause:

> _Before the 2nd of July..._
>
> _On the 8th of October..._


See also [addresses](/home/a/addresses) (11th Street not Eleventh Street), [numbers in headlines](/home/n/numbers#inheadlines) (8th not eighth), and "uncommon [fractions](/home/n/numbers#fractions)" (33/100ths).

**Fractions**
**Decimal points are a convenient way to express many fractions. Use them unless English convention calls for a solidus (/) or a written-out form.**

> _5.5 million bushels_ (instead of 5½ or five-and-a-half)
>
> _$8.25 billion_ (instead of 8¼ or eight-and-a-quarter)
>
> _2½-year-old_ girl (instead of 2.5-year-old)
>
> _three-quarters complete_ (instead of 0.75 complete)


Bear in mind that a decimal is read as "point" when scanned, which can strongly influence which form to pick (e.g., we don't say a "two-point-five-year-old"). **So prefer decimals, even when both forms are commonly used** (as in the case of bushels and dollars above). **But avoid imposing decimals if they clash with entrenched conversational usage.**

Decimal constructions always feature figures. Other forms of fractions are sometimes written out. **In general, use figures for fractions when the total amount is above one.** Keep these numbers flush (i.e., do not add spaces):

> _4¾ days_ (no hyphen)
>
> _3½-year-old boy_ (hyphens needed in adjectives, but only after the flush figures)


**Write out most other common fractions, such as one-third and one-half:**

> _two-thirds of the carton_
>
> _three-quarters finished_


NOTE: It's common to write "a" instead of "one" in some fractions (e.g., _one-third_ or a _third_ are equally acceptable in many cases). It's also common and OK to drop "a" or "one" in some fractions involving the word "half" (e.g., _half of the delegates, half a cup of flour_).

**Use figures for uncommon fractions, even when the total amount is below one:**

> _5/8ths_ (numbers flush to letters)
>
> _33/100ths_ (numbers flush to letters)


**Use figures if established by convention or part of a typographically acceptable proper noun:**

> _24/7_ (for 24 hours a day, seven days a week)
>
> _Lotto 6/49_



**Per cent**
**Write per cent** (two words, never percent) Use % only in headlines

> _They sell more than 40 per cent of their products over the internet._
>
> _They're expecting a 10 per cent increase._ (No hyphens required. See [hyphens](/handy-links/punctuation/hyphens))


**Write words, not figures, for percentages under 10, unless these are fractions:**

> _Interest rates rose by three percentage points._
>
> _Support grew by 5.5 percentage points._


(See also [symbols](/home/n/numbers#symbols))

**Since the term per cent indicates a collective amount, use "less" not "fewer" when referring to quantity:**

> _Less than 40 per cent of students finished the exam. Fewer than two in 10 passed._


(See also [fewer versus less](/home/f/fewer-versus-less))

**Be sure to observe the difference between** [**per cent** and **percentage**](/home/p/per-cent-versus-percentage)


**Large numbers**
In broadcast journalism, we often write out all big numbers in scripts because these are easier to read on-air: "_ten thousand dollars._" **Online, we spell out the words million, billion and trillion, but not thousand, based on established publishing conventions designed to make scanning text easier:**

_15,000 fans, 10 million records, six million litres, $2.5 billion_

**Use commas to indicate thousands, except in years, page numbers or sets of figures used solely for identification** (such as serial numbers, [phone numbers](/home/p/phone-numbers) and street [addresses](/home/a/addresses)):

> _1,000_
>
> _2004_ (year)
>
> _1582 Inukshuk Ave._
>
> _She ran along the 3600 block of Centre Street._
>
> _416-205-2464_ (phone number)
>
> page _1103_


**Do not use unfamiliar terms, such as "quintillion" or even "quadrillion."** Instead, write a million billion, a billion billion, etc. to make it clear to our readers what we're talking about.


**Money**
Here are some main points. A link to more detailed guidelines appears below.

**In online journalism, use figures (not words like "thousand" or "hundred thousand") for amounts up to $999,999:** _$5, $123.50, $70,000, $1 million, $12 billion
_
**On the web, generally use the $ sign instead of writing out "dollar."** But small amounts (under $10) can be written as either _$2_ or _two dollars_. (See [symbols](/home/n/numbers#symbols) for other examples.) **Include the abbreviation US** (with no periods) **at the end when you want to indicate American currency** (_$250 US_).

**Canadian currency is normally implied. When a story mentions other countries' dollars** (U.S., Australian, etc.) **specify "Canadian dollars" by using the abbreviation "Cdn"** (with no period except at the end of a sentence).

For specific examples, as well as tips on everything from monetary conversions to the use of words such as euro or franc, see [**money**](/home/m/money)


**Miscellaneous**
Occasionally numbers can represent something on their own without related words providing context. For instance, while calling 911 is a synonym for requesting help, and batting 1,000 is a synonym for having a perfect record, the meanings are clarified by the verbs "call" and "bat." But in an expression such as a [420 rally](/home/f#420) the jargon "420" on its own might not automatically convey the meaning ("marijuana use") to our entire audience. In such cases, a definition or additional context may be required to ensure the story is clear.

For some other uses of numbers, see [abbreviations](/home/a/abbreviations) (dates and addresses), [aircraft names](/home/a/aircraft-names), [chemical names](/home/c/chemical-names) (CO2), [metric versus imperial](/home/m/metric-versus-imperial), [military forces](/home/m/military-forces), [military ranks](/home/m/military-ranks), [phone numbers](/home/p/phone-numbers) (0, 911, etc.), [temperatures](/home/m/metric-versus-imperial#temperatures) (3 C, etc.), [time](/home/t/time#1950s) (1950s, etc.), and [weapons](/home/w/weapons) (.22-calibre rifle, 9-mm pistol, etc.)


**Numbers in headlines**
The following guidelines apply to web headlines, subheads, graphics, bulleted lists, and so forth:

**Generally use figures** (even under 10 or when normally spelled out in common terms, such as four-by-four vehicle). **The numbers can be placed anywhere** (beginning, middle or end) **and be cardinal** (1, 2, 3) **or ordinal** (1st, 2nd, 3rd).

> _3 die in Via train crash_
>
> _China confirms 8th SARS death_
>
> _Why a 2nd wave of COVID-19 is more dangerous than it looks_
>
> _Sabres hand Leafs 1st loss at ACC in 13 games_
>
> _Rugby 7s team set for Commonwealth Games_
>
> _Halifax police scour 4x4 for murder clues_


**Writers and editors do have a degree of discretion when handling numbers in headlines**, subheads, decks, etc. For instance, **sometimes it's either clearer or less jarring to spell them out**:

> _one of the reasons_
>
> _two-state solution_
>
> _one-two punch_

Such **exceptions are rare**, however. **Factors to consider are headline length, clarity, tone and conversational flow.** For instance, the word "one" in an expression such as "one of the reasons" instead of "1 of the reasons" is arguably a more natural choice in a headline based on conventional usage. And going with a "one-two punch" rather than a 1-2 punch avoids the possibility of the figures being misread as a "12" punch. In the case of ordinals, **spelled-out numbers occasionally better convey specific or unique meanings** (e.g., Second Amendment refers to gun rights in the U.S. rather than to a designated "2nd" spot within a numerical sequence).


**Familiar symbols are often OK** to save space. For instance, **always use %** for "per cent" and **sometimes use x** for "by" if context is clear:

> _Inflation falls to 1% in March_
>
> _Signed 8x10 Apollo 11 photo sells for $50K_
>
> _Did a 2x4 save B.C. man from bear?_


(For general guidelines on two-by-four versus 2x4, see [dimensions](/home/n/numbers#dimensions) above)


**Use K** (for thousand) **for racing distances when entrenched as a label. Keep the figure and the capital letter flush:**

> _Bekele breaks Olympic record in 5K win_


(See [metric versus imperial](/home/m/metric-versus-imperial#sports) for more details on related sports style)

**Use K** (for thousand), **M** (for million), **B** (for billion) and **T** (for trillion) **after financial figures. Leave out the spaces between the currency sign** ($, €), **the number, the uppercase letter:**

> _No small change: From surplus to $85B deficit_
>
> _Nortel projects $175M loss_
>
> _NFL fines player $10K for uniform violation_
>
> _Canada's population tops 35 million_


**In business headlines, use Q1, Q2, Q3, Q4 to specify a fiscal year's quarter:**

> _Inco stuns analysts with Q3 profits_

**oligarch, oligarchs** (n.) Members of a small number of extremely wealthy people with significant political influence in a country (e.g., **Russian oligarchs**). Usually does not need to be explained in stories because the term is entrenched and widely understood. The related and older word **oligarchy**, coined in the 1500s, was originally defined as government by a small number of people. But the terms oligarchy and oligarch have since evolved to include the more figurative sense of colossal political influence and power by a wealthy elite, often operating behind the scenes.

The word means "people's representative" in Scandinavian. Although various gender-neutral forms have been proposed in English over the years (e.g., **ombud,** ombuds and **ombudsperson**), there's no consensus on the best approach and, so, the original term remains relatively entrenched: **Canada Post's ombudsman**, the **Canadian Forces ombudsman**. When reporting on specific people or offices, generally prefer the official title used (e.g., the **B.C. ombudsperson** versus the **New Brunswick ombud**). Capitalize proper nouns when used in full (e.g., the **Association of Canadian College and University Ombudspersons,** the **Organization of News Ombudsmen**, the **International Ombudsman Institute**). In generic references, a gender-neutral form is OK (e.g., Northern Ireland's **police ombud** rather than its police ombudsman), along the lines of the word "chair" instead of chairman or chairwoman. For clarity and consistency in such cases, distinguish between **ombud** (singular) and **ombuds** (plural), as in "the ombud said" and an "ombud complaint," but "both provinces' ombuds endorsed the report").

**OPEC** (Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries) _Avoid writing "OPEC countries," which is redundant._ Try "OPEC members," "the world's big oil exporters," "the cartel," etc. OPEC had five members when founded in 1960, including Saudi Arabia and Venezuela. As of 2022, it had 13 members. The cartel's head office has been in Vienna since 1965, even though Austria is not part of organization. Distinguish between **OPEC** and **non-OPEC oil producers** when relevant to a given story. For instance, Canada and the U.S. are non-OPEC producers. In 2016, the name **OPEC+** (pronounced "OPEC plus") was coined. OPEC+ refers to a loose alliance of roughly two dozen OPEC and non-OPEC oil producers, including Russia and Mexico. They formally work together to control world oil prices by setting and meeting production quotas. It's OK to use the term OPEC+, but the name should be briefly explained (e.g., "OPEC and OPEC allies") if the meaning is not already clear from context.  (See also [acronyms](/home/a/acronyms))
