### Offensive language

**Offensive language (audio, video, photos, text)**



> Is the language essential?
> Is bleeping/masking required?



[Lengthy transcripts](/home/o/offensive-language#transcripts) (verbatim renderings)


[Explicit details](/home/o/offensive-language#explicit-details) (e.g., sexual assault allegations)
[Unique nature of each medium](/home/o/offensive-language#medium-properties) (TV, radio, web)

**WARNING: THIS ENTRY CONTAINS COARSE CONTENT**

**Overview**

Our Journalistic Standards and Practices (JSP) policy governing language and taste is broad. It reflects shifting societal mores, evolving English usage, etc.

**We generally:**

-   **Discourage gratuitous use of language that's likely to offend large segments of our audience.**

-   **Mask the most objectionable words with bleeps on air and with hyphens online.**

**"Gratuitous"** in this context doesn't merely mean casual or vacuous vulgarity. It also means language that's unnecessary if a paraphrase or alternative wording conveys virtually the same detail as effectively. For instance, it's normally sufficient to report that an athlete has been suspended for yelling "a homophobic slur" during a game without actually specifying that he said "[faggot](/home/l/lgbt#homophobic-slurs)," or that the N-word was painted on a door without spelling out the racist epithet.

**"Most objectionable"** is subjective but certainly includes what are euphemistically known as the F-word and the N-word.

When making decisions about coarse or explicit language, we:

-   **Take into account society's overall tolerance levels for certain words**, which tends to shift over time. In the 1950s, for instance, our news service's Directives and Style Guide told staff to avoid profane language, including "bloody," "damn" and "hell." A few decades later, such words were considered only mildly offensive, at most.

-   **Consider whether controversial remarks can be dropped altogether by paraphrasing, by picking a different clip or transcribed quote or by editing** (e.g., choosing a different start or ending). Transparently excising web text is straightforward using ellipses ("…"). By contrast, removing brief chunks of audio or video from the middle of broadcast clips can be more challenging.

-   **Acknowledge that even the most offensive language is occasionally broadcast or published uncensored** when it's editorially justified. **In these rare cases, audience warnings are required**, based on our JSP policy governing "words that shock."

-   **Recognize both broadcast and online journalism have unique properties** that are considered when we make decisions about offensive language. On-air reports, for instance, usually zip by the listeners or viewers once while online text is comparatively permanent and easily retrieved through keyword searches.
    **At the end of the day, however, the same rudimentary editorial principles apply across all of our platforms, including the need for audience warnings when necessary.** So while a broadcast report or a web article might handle, say, the use of the F-word differently from time to time, the journalists involved will have all weighed whether the language was gratuitous, and whether broadcasting or publishing in full was justified in a particular case. (See the [unique nature of each medium](/home/o/offensive-language#medium-properties) below.)

**The rest of this entry expands on the decision-making process** — from assessing how offensive certain language is from society's standpoint (mildly, moderately and highly) to handling proper nouns (e.g., the titles of films and books). **A detailed section on censoring words with hyphens is included** to address various typographical questions that have led to inconsistency in the past.


**NOTE: The verb "censor" should not be confused with the noun.** The former is commonly defined as "to make deletions or revisions," while the latter can imply something political rather than editorial (e.g., a war censor, a government censor). **In these guidelines, "censor" and "censoring" refer to bleeping audio, masking text and blurring images for journalistic reasons.**



**No list of banned words**

**Choice and tone of language is enormously important in all of the corporation's journalism because it reflects the character of CBC News.** While the Canadian Oxford Dictionary tells us how to spell, say, "motherfucker" (i.e., as a fused compound), we decide whether the word should ever appear on our website or airwaves — and, if so, under what conditions.

Vulgarity is defined as "likely to offend." Deciding what falls into that category can be subjective. **Individuals have different views about certain language.** Furthermore, **community standards change over time,** which means that there can be regional, cultural and generational divides about various expressions.

**It's not practical to proscribe a list of words and phrases that are off limits.** The relevant [Journalistic Standards and Practices policy on good taste](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fio.cbcrc.ca%2F%23%2Fresources%2Flanguage-langue-1.4523261&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw00j0MyNt5WClLhwDOEulcB) points out that we **generally avoid profanity and other coarse or explicit language "except where its omission would alter the nature and meaning of the information reported."**

**Two key questions**
When deciding whether to broadcast or publish potentially offensive material, two questions should be asked:


**1\. Is the language essential to the journalism?**

The first step in the decision-making process is determining whether the language is even necessary. Since all words should serve an editorial purpose in stories, gratuitous profanity should be axed whenever practical (e.g., by editing, paraphrasing, choosing a different clip or quote).


**2\. Is bleeping/masking required?**

**Unsuitable or problematic language falls across a spectrum.** So slightly different approaches are adopted, depending on whether the language is considered mild, moderate or extreme. A senior journalist is often involved in the decision. **Here is some general direction:**


> **MILDLY OFFENSIVE** words (e.g., **crap, piss off**), including some religious oaths (e.g., **God damn, Jesus, Christ**), should not be used indiscriminately but can be left intact when published or broadcast. When in doubt about whether a term falls into this category, check with your supervisor.
>
> **MODERATELY OFFENSIVE** words (e.g., **shit, bullshit, asshole**) normally require approval by a supervisor (senior producer or higher) before being published or broadcast. When considered important enough to a story to be used, the language is commonly spelled out in full rather than censored on the web because renderings like "s--t" can appear preciously prudish to the eye. In broadcast stories, however, programmers may decide to bleep moderately offensive content depending on various factors, including when it's being aired. Audience warnings for moderately offensive content are optional, and depend in large part on the overall impact of specific wording (e.g., a single expletive versus repeated profanity).
>
> **EXTREMELY OFFENSIVE** words (e.g., **f--k, c--t, c--ksucker, n----r**) should almost never be broadcast or published in full. When considered important enough to a story to be used, the language should generally be expurgated with hyphens online or bleeps on air. Approval for an uncensored version hinges on criteria outlined in "rare cases" below, and must be accompanied by audience warnings. Be aware that some slurs aimed at specific ethnic groups, religious groups, etc., now make many in our audience cringe (e.g., "chink" and "kike"). When in doubt about whether a term falls into this category, check with your supervisor.


**Deciding which of the above categories applies in any particular case is the first step a senior journalist takes when ruling on whether such language should be published or broadcast.**


**CASE STUDY 1:** In May 2020, the word "asshole" was used three times by a protester in Washington during live CBC News Network coverage of anti-racism demonstrations. **[Our response to an ombudsman complaint](/media/ow3hrc3o/cbcnews_coarse-language-in-tv-coverage-of-protests_reply-to-ombud-complaint_june-2020.pdf)** underscores the need to determine whether coarse or explicit language is gratuitous. It also illustrates some practical ways to assess possible shifts in society's overall tolerance for certain words.



**CASE STUDY 2:** In October 2019, we censored the word "c--t" in one story but reported the word "faggot" in another. **[Our response to an ombudsman complaint](/media/14pfs2m3/cbcnews_handling-offensive-terms-like-faggot_reply-to-ombud-complaint_nov-2019.pdf)** outlines factors we consider when bleeping or masking various words, as well as the need to include an audience warning if an [anti-2SLGBTQ+](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/l/2slgbtq/#preferspecific "2SLGBTQ+") slur is used.



**Censoring with hyphens**

While objectionable audio can be bleeped out in broadcast coverage, we use hyphens to mask most text (aside from photographs of signs, graffiti, etc., which are usually blurred).

As outlined above, **mildly and moderately offensive terms** (e.g., God damn, shit, asshole) **considered important to a web story should generally be used as is or not at all.**


> Jack Rabinovitch said his late wife, Doris Giller, was an unabashedly frank writer and editor. "When she saw shit, she said shit."


**But words such as fuck and cunt are almost always censored with hyphens when included in our web journalism:**


> "You all heard him. He called me a c--t," the mayor said.
>
> "If those assholes in Ottawa think they're going to take away my fishing rights with this f--ked up legislation, they're crazy."



**Proper nouns**
**This includes censoring extremely offensive words in some proper nouns,** from movie titles to the names of bands, pets and website domains, **as well as excerpts from books, lyrics, poems, etc.**, which can be communicated clearly with hyphens. Remember: Just because some person or organization has decided to use certain language for shock value doesn't mean we're required to follow suit in our coverage. This matches the spirit of cropping an explicit photo from a gallery exhibit when reporting on a particular work.


> His first film, Young People F--king, debuted at the 2007 Toronto International Film Festival

> Holy F--k's second album, LP, was nominated for a Juno in 2008.


In the case of website names — including URLs that contain highly offensive language but which are deemed editorially valuable to overall coverage — the hidden HTML reference code must be left untouched in order for the link to work. The **visible hypertext** posted by CBCNews.ca, however, **can be masked with hyphens:**


> F--kingdumbpoliticians.net (_Text displayed in a story_)



> <a href="http://www.fuckingdumbpoliticians.net/"></a> (_HTML code hidden in story_)



**Clear, consistent and accurate punctuation**
**When censoring text, be sure to:**

-   **Avoid confusing readers.** Insert **one hyphen for every missing vowel or consonant** being transcribed verbatim. Do not use long dashes, asterisks or other symbols. Normally, retain only the first and last letter of root words (**e.g., f--k** rather than "f—k" or "f-ck" or "f---" or "----," **and n----r** rather than "n--ger" or
    "n---er" or "n-----" or "------"). It's OK to include one or two additional letters for clarity in some cases (e.g., "**ch--k**" instead of "c---k" for the anti-Chinese slur), but be aware that removing too many hyphens defeats the purpose. Keep prefixes or suffixes intact (e.g., **motherf--king idiot** rather than "------f--k--- idiot") because excessive omissions are harder to scan.

-   **Adopt entrenched abbreviations** (e.g., the "N-word" rather than "n-----r") if it's the most common and conversational way to refer to highly offensive language we've decided not to spell out, and which we're not quoting directly.

-   **Transcribe accurately.** If someone actually says "effing," for instance, spell out the euphemism in full rather than implying the person swore (i.e., rather than inaccurately censoring the comment as "f--king"). The same applies to terms such as "BS," "the N-word," "the F-word," and "an F-bomb."

If the offensive language being censored is transcribed from signs, placards, etc., follow relevant CBCNews.ca guidelines on [using quotation marks and capitalizing principal words](/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks#slogans).


**Abbreviations and euphemisms**

Mildly and moderately offensive abbreviations (e.g., SOB) do not need to be censored when spelled out ("son of a bitch"). Treat potentially offensive shorthand as already censored (e.g., snafu, WTF). Add hyphens only when spelling out the abbreviations ("Situation normal: all f--ked up" and "What the f--k?)."

Keep in mind that some euphemisms ("effing") and acronyms ("snafu") may be considered entirely inoffensive because of widespread usage (e.g., the "fu" in "snafu" has also come to mean "fouled up" over the years). By contrast, terms that are likely to offend even in the condensed (censored) form should not be used indiscriminately. And relatively obscure abbreviations (e.g., FFS and STFW) may need to be defined to aid the average reader (e.g., "For f--k's sake" and "Search the f--king web").


**Rare cases: Uncensored but extremely offensive words**

**A higher threshold must be met to justify broadcasting or publishing extremely offensive language in full.** Merely portraying a colourful scene or conveying strong emotion is not sufficient. There must also be **an identifiable public good** behind using this type of raw language, such as putting accusations against a high-ranking official into fuller context to give our audience a better understanding of key facts.


> **Example 1:** Uncensored, highly offensive language might be needed in **thorough reporting of a public inquiry if the language, itself, is central to the story** (e.g., [former Ontario premier Mike Harris repeatedly denying claims](https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/ipperwash-inquiry-spreads-blame-for-george-s-death-1.666937) that he said, "I want the fucking Indians out of the park," just hours before an Indigenous protester died during a clash with police in 1995).
>
> **Example 2:** Uncensored, highly offensive language might be needed **to capture the complete record of an important, historic event** (e.g., the sexually explicit descriptions in documents submitted by an independent counsel recommending the impeachment of a U.S. president). See also [lengthy transcripts](/home/o/offensive-language#transcripts) below for related guidelines on verbatim renderings.
>
> **Example 3:** Uncensored, highly offensive language might be needed **for comprehensive coverage of an important public policy debate, or for a frank conversation about a societal problem**, especially if a high-ranking political leader has uttered or written unvarnished language to convey a particular message (e.g., [U.S. President Barack Obama's use of the word "nigger" in a June 2015 interview about racism](https://www.cbc.ca/news/trending/obama-uses-n-word-to-argue-racism-is-alive-in-america-1.3123070) in his country), or if a government is being asked to revise maps or other official documents (**e.g., the debate over changing geographical names** like "Nigger Rapids" in Quebec).


**IMPORTANT: When a senior journalist authorizes publication of uncensored, highly offensive language, an audience warning must be included** (i.e., in a broadcast report's intro or at the top of an online article). This means we should **avoid including such language in headlines** or other places where advance warning cannot be incorporated effectively.


**Lengthy transcripts** (verbatim renderings)

Sometimes transcripts are published as separate documents to supplement our journalism (e.g., court proceedings and taped interviews). If the excerpts are lengthy and contain a lot of highly offensive language, it may be impractical to censor the text.

In such cases, the files can be treated as PDFs or scanned excerpts of original material. But they should be:

-   Clearly identified as verbatim transcripts.

-   Self-contained (i.e., on pages linked to but separate from CBCNews.ca stories).

-   Flagged with a warning at the top about explicit language.

**Audio and video captions**

**When we post audio or video files online that are known to contain uncensored offensive language, an effort should be made to warn our web audience about the content.** Since there are sometimes technical limitations placed on the number of characters permitted in such captions (which often function as web page promos), **the notices should be kept brief** (e.g., "WARNING: Explicit audio"). To save space, a small but clear graphical warning should be considered instead of text when possible. **The original radio or television intros should also be retained in the encoded audio or video files** if these include warnings about explicit language.


**Text inside photos**

**Sometimes offensive language can be seen in an image** (e.g., on a sign at a demonstration). **Just because this text has appeared in a video report does not automatically mean it should be posted as a photo in on CBCNews.ca**, where still pictures take on special weight.

Each case is different, and a senior journalist should be involved in the final decision. Factors to consider include:

-   The wording itself (i.e., whether it's mildly, moderately or extremely offensive).

-   How clear and prominent the text is (e.g., if it's in the background or centre stage).

-   How central the text is to the story (e.g., if removing this part of the image would make the journalism poorer).

**Cropping pictures or blurring pixels should be considered in extreme cases.**

NOTE: These guidelines deal with offensive language only. Censoring may also be called for when handling images that are graphic and disturbing (e.g., particularly violent, gruesome). Relevant Journalistic Standards and Practices policies should be followed. In the case of explicit nudity, it's also a good idea to consult with CBC legal counsel, since laws governing obscenity, pornography, etc., may apply.


**Explicit details** (e.g., sexual assault allegations)

**Sometimes the specific nature of a description can be offensive**, even when the words, themselves, are not actually crude or profane. **Particular care is needed when reporting allegations of sexual assault, obscene acts, etc.**

Once again, **the first hurdles are determining what's essential** versus what's gratuitous, **as well as what's shocking or highly offensive** (requiring an audience warning). In general, **we should avoid overly detailed accounts when virtually the same information can be conveyed by a general statement** (e.g., "She says he then reached under her dress"), **and we should limit references to specific sexual acts, body parts, body fluids, etc.** (e.g., "He's accused of unzipping his pants and masturbating"). While clinical terminology (penis, vagina) is normally considered less crude than colloquialisms, such details can sometimes be dispensed with altogether without sacrificing any meaning.

**The benefit of providing a complete picture should be weighed against the harm of graphic and disturbing details** — upsetting not only to our audience but also to the victims and their families. So **while we don't necessarily need to reduce everything to vague generalities** (e.g., "brutal physical attacks"), **we also don't need to catalogue all the horrors alleged**. Instead, we can consider defining what's meant by "brutal physical attacks" with a bit more information when it's deemed editorially necessary (e.g., "The jury was told that he videotaped many of the assaults, which included mutilation and sodomy"). But even in those cases, **always exercise restraint**. And remember to **add an audience warning** whenever specific language collides with the public's boundaries of tolerance and taste.


**CASE STUDY 3:** In May 2020, former U.S. vice-president Joe Biden denied allegations of sexual assault by a woman who worked for him in the Senate in 1993. Our coverage included the sentence, "She says … he pinned her up against the wall, started kissing her, put his hands under her clothing, and penetrated her with his fingers." **[Our response to an ombudsman complaint](/media/srdle4sf/cbcnews_description-of-allege-faca8ce400cf4067.pdf)** underscores why we felt such explicit language was necessary to tell the story. It also illustrates the nuances that are sometimes required when assessing relevance and clarity.



**Unique nature of each medium**

As pointed out in the overview, electronic publishing has introduced some unique challenges at CBC News. Posting an uncensored word such as "fuck" on the web can be different from putting it into broadcast journalism. **Senior journalists should take into account the unique nature of a given medium (TV, radio and online) when making decisions about airing or publishing offensive language.** In particular:

1\. The written word can carry a weight that is different from on-air clips (i.e., the way the text is processed by readers). Offensive language remains on the screen after the eye scans it, rather than disappearing as soon as the ear hears it.

2\. There's no blanket rule about the spoken versus written words. The impact of certain audio may depend on context, phrasing, the emotion in the voice, etc. Once stripped of a specific person's voice, transcribed quotes on the web are more closely identified with CBCNews.ca than with the original speaker. At the same time, hearing a CBC journalist utter even moderately offensive language verbatim in a broadcast script can be more jarring than reading the same words on a screen.

3\. Published text is invariably considered a deliberate editorial decision rather than as an inadvertent act. In live news broadcasting, by contrast, certain words may sometimes be spoken on the fly before it's technically possible to bleep them out.

4\. Profanity on a website is virtually permanent, and can be found quickly through word searches 24 hours a day. By contrast, broadcast reports are comparatively ephemeral. Furthermore, unlike conventional broadcasting, there is no practical way to differentiate between traditional "daytime" and "late-night" audiences, including when children are reading our online content.

5\. Bleeps are a blunt instrument in broadcast journalism. The sound can sometimes lead viewers and listeners to assume that something far worse than, say, "shitty" or "ass" was said. Unless given language is highly offensive, therefore, it's sometimes better to either pick a different clip or to leave the audio as is. Be fair to the person speaking and consider whether bleeping might actually be misleading.


**External partners**

Other websites and digital platforms displaying CBC News content may have their own standards in place for handling profanity. In general, external partners are encouraged to either post CBC News text as is or to remove the stories from their lineups. This avoids audience misunderstandings about an outside organization's decision to edit CBC News content and then publish the material as though the CBC actually deleted/altered certain wording. When in doubt about an external partner's use of CBC material, Business Affairs and/or the Law Department should be consulted to confirm the conditions of existing agreements.

****

### oilsands versus tarsands

**Oilsands versus tarsands**

**Use oilsands when referring to the energy deposits in northern Alberta. Reserve tarsands for directly transcribed clips.**

The word **oilsands** is considered **more neutral and more accurate** because the substance eventually refined from the extracted bitumen is oil. The word tarsands, by contrast, is founded on a simile (i.e., that the heavy, viscous oil trapped in the sand, clay and water is "tar-like"). Tar comes mainly from trees and coal.

Although oilsands and tarsands were used interchangeably for decades, the term tarsands has become closely associated with critics of the bitumen development, who consider it an environmentally harmful project as well as a dirty form of energy.

CBC News must not take sides in such disputes, and always balance coverage with as many viewpoints as possible. But our language also needs to be neutral and accurate. Just as we refer to the offspring of seals as "pups" rather than as "babies" — regardless of the wording preferred by critics of seal hunting — we refer to the bitumen reserves in Alberta as oilsands rather than tarsands, unless "tarsands" is directly attributed to a specific person or organization.

See also [**bitumen**](/home/b#bitumen), which includes a caution about the need to define the obscure term "**dilbit**" (as **diluted bitumen**).


**Spelling (oilsands but sometimes 'Oil Sands')**

The **generic term** oilsands is **one word**, along the lines of **oilfield** and **oilpatch**. This has become the standard in Canada, adopted by many news organizations, including the CBC, CP and Alberta's biggest papers.

**But the compound may or may not be fused in names**, depending on the organization's preference (e.g., **Sunshine Oilsands Ltd.** and **Alberta Oilsands Inc.** versus **Athabasca Oil Sands Corp.** and the **Oil Sands Developers Group**). When in doubt, always double-check proper nouns.

### Olympic Games

**Olympic Games**
[Overview](/home/o/olympic-games#overview) (including caveat about editorial vs. non-editorial usage)









[Miscellaneous style](/home/o/olympic-games#miscellaneous) (opening ceremony, flag-bearer, etc.)

**Overview**
**This entry is focused on our journalism. It covers a range of editorial and stylistic points that have surfaced over the years. For guidance on copyright issues, including something as basic as the use of the word "Olympics" in web addresses (URLs) and filenames when the CBC is not the official broadcaster, check with your supervisor and/or [the Law Department](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fio.cbcrc.ca%2F%23%2Fresources%2Flegal-juridique-1.3096749&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2C6aikrr0IlVx2eKzOPjfy).**

**Certain proper nouns tied to the Olympics are closely guarded by the International Olympic Committee (IOC).** Adhere to relevant first-reference and second-reference guidelines outlined below.

**Stories about specific competitions should identify winners and include relevant details early on** (e.g., top results and comparisons to Olympic or world records). Always mention Canadian participants, and look for Canadian angles.
**
Limit the number of figures you cram into a single sentence or paragraph.** When possible, feature a large group of results in a graphic.

**Avoid jargon.** If you include terms such as snowboard "chatter" (vibration) or biathlon "clicks" (small adjustments to a rifle's sights), a cycling "peloton" (group of main riders) or a rowing rig's "skeg" (stabilizing fin), be sure to define these words.


**EDITORIAL VS. NON-EDITORIAL:** Be aware that certain usage permitted in our journalism may not be allowed elsewhere. For example, while the conversational compounds '**Summer Olympics**' and '**Winter Olympics**' are OK **in second reference in news stories** based on entrenched convention (see below), the same shorthand is NOT permitted by the IOC in graphics, logos, banners, promotional material, etc. Stringent, separate guidelines cover non-editorial usage. When in doubt, ask your supervisor.


**Olympic, Olympics, Olympiad**
**In first reference** (not including headlines), **stories should generally use one of the following constructions:
**

the 2024 Olympic Games
the 2024 Paris Olympic Games
the 2024 Paris Games
the 2024 Paris Olympics
the Summer Olympics in Paris
the Summer Games in Paris

the 2022 Olympic Games
the 2022 Beijing Olympic Games
the 2022 Beijing Games
the 2022 Beijing Olympics
the Winter Olympics in Beijing
the Winter Games in Beijing

the 2020 Tokyo Olympics ([see 2021 anomaly](/home/o/olympic-games#Tokyo-2020) below)
the 2014 Olympic Games
the 2014 Sochi Olympics
the Winter Olympics in Sochi
the 2014 Sochi Olympics
the 2012 Olympic Games
the 2012 London Olympics
the Summer Olympics in London
the 2010 Vancouver Olympics
the Winter Olympics in Vancouver
the 2006 Torino Games (the event, held in [Turin](/home/t#Turin) the city)


**In plural constructions, keep all proper noun elements capitalized:**



the Summer and Winter Olympics
the Summer and Winter Games


**In some cases, a city's full name is clipped** based on entrenched usage:


the 2016 Rio Games (rather than Rio de Janeiro Games)
the Summer Olympics in Rio (rather than in Rio de Janeiro)


**In rare cases, a country's name may also be used when a** **city's name is not widely known:**



the 2018 Pyeongchang Olympic Games
the 2018 Pyeongchang Olympics
the Winter Olympics in South Korea (rather than always writing Pyeongchang)
the Winter Games in South Korea (rather than always writing Pyeongchang)



**THE 2021 ANOMALY:** Although the **2020 Summer Olympics** were postponed for a year because of the COVID-19 pandemic, the International Olympic Committee said the event's name would remain the same:


> the 2020 Olympic Games
>
> the 2020 Tokyo Olympic Games
>
> the 2020 Tokyo Games
>
> the 2020 Tokyo Olympics


When relevant, we can briefly explain to audiences why the 2020 Games were held in 2021. But **it's inaccurate to call the Games of the 32nd Olympiad the "2021 Games."** So AVOID wording that implies an official name change.

**Keep in mind that some cities have hosted more than one Olympics** (e.g., Athens in 1896 and 2004, Lake Placid in 1932 and 1980, and Paris in 1900 and 1924). In these cases, it's often important to specify the year to ensure that the historical reference is clear. But there's no need to worry about confusion between a recent or current Olympics (e.g., the Paris Games in 2024) and an event held in the same city a century ago (e.g., the Paris Games in 1924). In other words, the **Paris Games** implies the 2024 Games. It's not considered a historical reference but, rather, is instantly identified by our audience as the name of the most recent Olympics in that city. Even when the Games are held in the same location less than a decade or two apart (e.g., the **Beijing Games**), there's rarely any danger of confusion when one was a Summer Olympics (e.g., Beijing 2008) and the other a Winter Olympics (Beijing 2022).

**While more than one community may have venues** (e.g., Vancouver and Whistler, B.C.), **the Games are almost always officially linked to a single host city by the International Olympic Committee (IOC).** Exceptions feature two city names in IOC documentation (e.g., Italy's 2026 Milan-Cortina Winter Olympics held in Milan and the Cortina d'Ampezzo ski resort several hundred kilometres away). The host city's name (Tokyo, Sochi, Vancouver, London, Athens, Calgary, Beijing) is normally straightforward. When more than one form is common (e.g., Turin and Torino, Milan and Milano), consult and follow in-house style for consistency. The use of Torino for the name of the Games and Turin for the city was adopted by CBC News and CBC Sports in 2004, as explained in a [Words: Woe & Wonder column](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews2%2Findepth%2Fwords%2Fkiev-or-kyiv.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1NAvZSqCruI4DyZUlkwCwM), and has been used in our journalism since. When there are competing spellings, including different approaches to capitalization, consult and follow in-house style for consistency (e.g., [Pyeongchang](/home/p#Pyeongchang)).

**In second and subsequent references**, journalists writing news stories have several options, including:

the Olympics
the Summer Olympics
the Paris Olympics
the Summer Games
the Paris Games
the Winter Olympics
the Beijing Olympics
the Winter Games
the Beijing Games
the Games

**
Headlines can be reduced further as long as the context is clear.** Here are some options:


Olympics
2020 Games
Tokyo
Beijing
Vancouver
London
Torino (refers to Games)
Turin (refers to geographical location)


See **[editorial vs. non-editorial](/home/o/olympic-games#editorial)** above for caveat about non-journalistic usage.

**Do not use the word Olympiad to mean the Games.** The term refers to a four-year period that wraps up with the Olympic Games. Use arabic not roman numerals for all olympiads (e.g., _the 21st Winter Olympiad, the Games of the 30th Olympiad_).

**The word "Olympic"** (singular) **is an adjective** (e.g., Olympic athlete, Olympic accreditation, Olympic Charter, Olympic event, Olympic Games, Olympic Organizing Committee, Olympic sites, Olympic story, Olympic Village, Olympic writers). **It's sometimes part of a compound modifier** (e.g., Olympic-size pool).

**The word "Olympics"** (plural) **is short for Olympic Games. It's normally a noun not an adjective.**


_At the Olympics, all Olympic writers in the Olympic unit had Olympic accreditation._


The **International Olympic Committee** should be spelled out once in first reference. **IOC** is fine in headlines and second reference.

**Paralympics**
**Use the same first-reference format above for the Paralympics**, such as:


> the 2022 Beijing Paralympic Games
>
> the 2022 Winter Paralympic Games
>
> the Beijing Paralympic Games
>
> the 2022 Paralympic Games


**Use the same approach to second-reference capitalization** as well:



the Paralympic Games
the Summer Paralympics
the Winter Paralympics
the Paralympics
the Games


**Capitalize the word Para on its own**, such as:


> Para archery
>
> Para badminton
>
> Para canoe
>
> Para ice hockey
>
> Para powerlifting
>
> Para snowboard
>
> Para rowing
>
> Para triathlon


This includes references to competitors (e.g., **Para judo athlete**, **Para judoka**, **Para snowboarder**, **Para swimmer**).

**Keep sports featuring more than one word all lowercase**:


> cross-country skiing
>
> wheelchair basketball
>
> wheelchair curling
>
> sitting volleyball


**Bans against countries, boycotts, etc.**
**When a country is banned from taking part in the Olympics as a nation but some of its athletes are still permitted to compete, be accurate but as conversational as possible** (e.g., "Russian athletes" rather than "Russia," and the "Russian medal count" rather than "Russia's medal count"). Include explanatory context whenever practical. For instance, at the 2022 Beijing Games and 2020 Tokyo Games, Russians competed as members of the **Russian Olympic Committee (ROC)**, and at the 2018 Pyeongchang Olympics they represented a group known as **Olympic Athletes from Russia (OAR)**. They were not allowed to use Russia's flag or national anthem because of a punishment handed down by the World Anti-Doping Agency.

**Distinguish between different types of boycotts.** If one or more countries refuse to send anyone, including athletes, the word "boycott" on its own is fine as long as context is clear (e.g., the U.S.-led boycott of the 1980 Olympics in Moscow, and the Soviet-led boycott of the 1984 Olympics in Los Angeles). By contrast, the 2022 Olympics involved a **diplomatic boycott**, with Canada, the U.S., and several other countries, including the U.K. and Australia, refusing to send government representatives to the Winter Games as part of a human rights protest.


**Medals**
**Medals are always lowercase** (gold, silver and bronze).

The word **medallist has two l's.**


_She's an Olympic gold medallist._

**
Avoid using medal as a verb** (i.e., people are not _expected to medal_).

**Placements**
**When reporting results, some phrases or terms can be abbreviated.** For instance: _Canadians finished **first and second**_ or _Canadians finished **1-2**. They're now **number 1** in the world_ or _They're now **No. 1** in the world._


_Canadians finished 1-2 in the race, less than four seconds apart and more than half a minute ahead of the bronze medallist.

If the rowing team could knock three seconds off its time, it would become No. 1 in the world.

The Canadian men's volleyball team was eliminated from medal contention after being swept 3-0 by Venezuela (26-24, 25-16, 29-27)._


CBCNews.ca general guidelines governing numbers apply to sports stories on the web.

**Distance**
**Always spell out the metric measurement in first reference. Do not add hyphens unless it's a compound adjective.**


_He placed fourth in the men's 1,500 metres.

After the false start, she walked 20 metres down the track before turning around.

He sprinted past the leader about 10 metres before the finish line.

The wind was 0.7 metres per second.

_

**Adjectives**


_She won the 100-metre hurdles.

He's better known as a 200-metre runner.

Both swimmers also won bronze in the 4x100-metre medley relay.
_

**Implied measurement**
**Do not bother repeating a distance unit, such as metre, if it's implied by an earlier reference** in the story:


_Germany is favoured to win the men's 4x100 relay. She placed fifth in the women's 1,500 at the Sydney Olympics.

Canadian Lefty Lifter came in fifth in the men's shot put, throwing a personal best of 19.96 metres. Ambi Dextrous of France won with a toss of 21.74.

Canadian Marty Short placed fourth in the men's high jump, clearing 2.14 metres. Frank Tower of Australia jumped 2.4 to win the gold._

**
Do not add zeros to decimal places when the ciphers are implied** (e.g., use _2.4_ not _2.40 metres_) **except in rare cases when established by convention** (e.g., _"Under the old judging system, a perfect score was 6.0"_).

**Metric terms**
**In first reference, measurements are normally spelled out** (metres, kilometres, kilograms, etc.). **Metric abbreviations do not include periods or an "s"** (matching our style for other common shorthand, such as 20 _km/h_ and 8_\-mm_ film). **Always add a space between the figure and the abbreviation:**


_Olympic welterweight boxers (63.5-67 kg) will begin competing Thursday._

or

_Olympic welterweight boxers weigh between 63.5 and 67 kilograms._

**
Letters representing short metric distances, such as "m," are optional but generally unnecessary for a Canadian audience.**They're often found in wire stories written for a U.S. market, which is more accustomed to imperial measurements. (But compare to 5K, 10K below.)

**First reference**

> _He also competed in the men's 4x100-metre relay at the 2000 Olympics._

**Second and subsequent references**

> _Both men also ran in the 4x100 relay at the 2000 Olympics._


**Leave out the abbreviation "m"** (e.g., 4x100 m relay) in second reference because it's implied.

**Headline shorthand**

******In headline writing, the metric unit is also generally dropped** to save space:

****

> _4x100 relay: The fear of screwing it up_

****
**50K, 10K, 5K**
When referring to long-distance events, **a capital K is often used to represent kilometres**. Type it flush to the figure**** (an exception to the general rule, based on long-established convention).

> _10,000-metre race
> __10-kilometre race
> __10K_

****
**Height and weight (of athletes)**
Although **boxing categories are measured in kilograms** (see metric terms above), **use imperial terms when describing other athletes:**

****

_Broder stood six foot three and weighed 198 pounds._

****
Or if it's clear from the context:

****

_Broder, 6-3, weighed 198 pounds_

****
Or, using an adjective:

****

_The six-foot-three swimmer weighed 198 pounds._

******Avoid mixing imperial and metric measurements in one sentence****** (e.g., T_he six-foot-three swimmer splashed into the lead in the last 15 metres of the race._)******Instead, recast into two sentences.**

**Time**
**0:27.55**  (_represents 27.55 seconds_)
**3:37.23** (_represents three minutes 37.23 seconds_)
**1:48:24.02** (_represents one hour 48 minutes 24.02 seconds_)

**When the duration of a sports event first appears in a story, spell out hours, minutes and seconds. Do not include commas** between the various time elements.

****

_Wong crossed the finish line in one hour 44 minutes 23.05 seconds._

******
Subsequent time references can be abbreviated******, with colons signalling hours and minutes and a decimal point indicating tenths and hundredths of a second. If you end a sentence with a figure, be sure to include the period.

_She won a silver medal in the women's 5,000 metres, finishing in 14 minutes 29.11 seconds, less than five seconds behind the world record of 14:24.68.

He placed fifth in the men's 1,500 metres with a time of 3:46.72.

Mary Thon of Kelowna, B.C., came in fourth in the women's 800 with a time of 1:59.99. McKee came in second, with a time of 1:48:24.02.

She ran the 100 metres in 11.46 seconds._

******
It's often more natural to spell out all times under one minute****** (e.g., 13.52 seconds_instead of 0:13.52_, and 8-100ths of a second_instead of 0:08_), ****unless one paragraph contains a cluster of results.****See also [sports](/home/s/sports-overview) (for links to terms not tied to the Olympics, such as football and golf).
******Opening ceremony, flag-bearer, etc.**
CBCSports.ca writers follow the same guidelines for [capitalization](/home/c/capitalization), [numbers](/home/n/numbers), [punctuation](/handy-links/punctuation), [abbreviations](/home/a/abbreviations), [metric abbreviations](/home/m/metric-versus-imperial), [spelling](/home/s/spelling),**** etc., as other CBC journalists working online. This means, for example, that **_flag-bearer_** has a hyphen; that **_opening ceremony_** is lowercase; and that **_figure skating_** and **_speed skating_** are two words as nouns but hyphenated as adjectives, as in a **_figure-skating jump_**.

### oilsands versus tarsands

**One of the**

There are **three common pitfalls with "one of the"** constructions:

**1\. Verbosity.** A sentence such as "One of the reasons for her departure" is usually clearer and stronger when shortened (e.g., "One reason for her departure …").

**2\. Subject-verb disagreement** when the writer or speaker wrongly assumes that the singular "one" governs a later clause. **Examples of CORRECT usage:** "**He is one of the few people over 60 who have** \[not has\] **climbed Mount Everest,"** and "**She is one of the tenants in the building who love** \[not loves\] **taking the stairs."** The quick test is to reverse the order of each sentence: "Of the few people over 60 who have climbed Mount Everest, he is one," and, "Of the tenants in the building who love taking the stairs, she is one." In each case, the subject governing the verb in question is plural (people and tenants).

**3\. Lack of parallel structure when a subordinate clause** **is added.** **Example of a TYPICAL ERROR**, especially in spoken English: **"She is one of the best, if not the best, singers in the choir."** The flaw here is that the clause "if not the best" requires a singular noun (i.e., "if not the best singer"). At the same time, "one of the best" demands a plural noun (i.e., "one of the best singers"). **The quickest solution is either to remove the subordinate clause or to recast** (e.g., **"She is one of the best, if not the best, of the singers in the choir,"** or "**She is one of the best singers in the choir, if not the best**," or "She is possibly the best singer in the choir").


**One of the only**

**No entry on "one of the" is complete without addressing "one of the only," a common construction that's much maligned and yet demonstrably OK.** While some writers and editors prefer alternative phrasing, such as **"one of the few,"** it really boils down to a stylistic choice rather than a matter of grammar.

**It's a myth that the word "only" must automatically be tied to the figure "one"** (i.e., to a single person, a single object, etc.). For instance, if only three people show up to a party — despite dozens of invitations — then the word "only" refers to the three guests who came. In that case, the phrasing **"one of the only people"** as well as "**one of the few people**" would both mean "**one of the three people**" who attended.

It's worth noting that talking and writing conversationally can include something known as "scalar implicature" in linguistics. This jargon refers to the implicit rather than the literal meaning of various numbers, sizes, etc., as well as to the intentional use of an ambiguous term (e.g., "some") instead of more specific phrasing. It's also worth remembering that **"one of only"** (sans the definite article "the") is frequently used without comment or complaint (e.g., **"One of only three skaters"**). Revising this wording slightly (e.g., **"One of the only skaters,"** which simply means "**One of the few skaters**") is neither jarring nor problematic.

At the end of the day, **"one of the only" is deeply entrenched,** dating back centuries, **widely understood, and violates no rules of standard English.**


**One of the finest, one of the best**

Related "superlative" constructions (e.g., finest, best) are not inherently at odds with the word "one," either. The 2015 New Fowler's Modern English Usage cites **"one of the finest poems"** and **"one of the best books"** as examples of common, acceptable usage. Yes, such sentences could be recast as "one of the finer" and "one of the better." But such rewrites are optional. They also come at a cost in some writers' eyes, since the comparative adjectives "finer" and "better" do not stress the stellar nature of the poems or books in the same way.

See also [grammar](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/handy-links/grammar/ "Grammar")



### onstage

**Onstage versus on stage**

The word onstage is both an adjective and an adverb. For this reason, it's almost always the correct choice:


**ONSTAGE (adjective)**

> _The onstage performance included dry ice and pyrotechnics._
>
> _She is still recovering from an onstage accident in Calgary last month._
>
> _"Let's keep onstage nudity above the waist," he warned._


**ONSTAGE (adverb)**

> _They stumbled onstage 15 minutes late._
>
> _"Onstage, everyone!" shouted the director._
>
> _The band was onstage when the fire started._


Adverbs wear many hats. In the above case, they're indicating place. In the first sentence, there's a specific action. "Where did they stumble?" Onstage. In the second sentence, the verb "go" is implied but missing. "\[Go\] onstage, everyone!" In the third sentence, there's additional information supplied about a "to be" verb (i.e., "was"). "Where was the band when the fire started?" Onstage.


**ONSTAGE, OFFSTAGE, BACKSTAGE**
Since offstage and backstage are also adjectives and adverbs, a good rule of thumb is to substitute them in your head to confirm that the fused word "onstage" works:

_They were onstage when gunshots rang out.
They were offstage when gunshots rang out.
They were backstage when gunshots rang out._

_
The booing began as they walked onstage.
The booing began as they walked offstage.
The booing began as they walked backstage._


**ON STAGE (two words)
**
In some sentences, "on" can function as a preposition before the noun "stage." It's generally a more wordy construction, such as:

> _They were on the small, cramped stage when the fire started._


Unless the preposition "onto" is chosen, however, you normally have the option to treat onstage as a fused word:

> _They ran onto the stage._
>
> _They ran on the stage._
>
> _They ran onstage._ (cleanest and preferred)


Compare with [on-camera, on-screen](/home/o#on-screen)
For related guidelines, see also [onto versus on to](/home/o/onto-versus-on-to)

### onto versus on to

**Onto versus on to**

Some writers always use "on to," but they're ignoring a useful distinction that many language authorities encourage observing.


**ONTO**
**When "on" functions as a preposition immediately in front of "to," the words should be joined into a single, fused preposition. This is usually the case with movement that puts people or things on top of a specific physical location.**

_"We walked onto the runway,"_ for instance, means that we stepped on the runway.

A quick test reveals both words are needed in this construction. If you drop either ("on" or "to"), the sentence's meaning changes.

_"We walked to the runway"_ says nothing about being on it.
_"We walked on the runway"_ says nothing about how you got there.


**ON TO**
**When "on" functions as an adverb, it should be kept separate from "to."** In these cases, "to" alone is the preposition introducing the next phrase.

_"We walked on to the runway,"_ for instance, means that we kept walking up to the runway but didn't necessarily step onto the tarmac.

Dropping "on" in this case changes the meaning only slightly. ("We walked to the runway.") Although the notion of walking farther is lost, the essence of the sentence remains — a good indication that "on" and "to" should be kept separate.

Note: **If the words "on to" are not fused, "on" frequently means something other than a physical location.** It could, **for example**, suggest **awareness**: "We're on (wise) to your tricks." Or, it could mean **continuation**: "We drove on (farther) to the next town."

It's now time to move on to something else.

See also: [onstage versus on stage](/home/o/onstage)

**Opposition versus opposition**

**Capitalize “opposition” only when referring to the Official Opposition in Parliament, a provincial legislature, etc.** (i.e., the non-governing party with the most number of seats).

the Official Opposition
the Opposition party
the Opposition leader
Opposition leader Jill Wong
Conservative Leader Jill Wong (See [Leader versus leader](/home/l/leader))

**Otherwise, keep the generic word “opposition” lowercase:**

the opposition parties
the opposition is growing

_The MP spent her career in **opposition**, but she was never actually a member of the **Official Opposition**._

### Order of Canada

**Order of Canada**

The awards were first handed out on Canada’s 100th birthday (July 1, 1967).

**There are three levels. All of them are lowercase when spelled out.** In descending (highest to lowest) order these are:

**companion of the Order of Canada** (do _not_ use abbreviation CC)
**officer of the Order of Canada** (do _not_ use abbreviation OC)
**member of the Order of Canada** (do _not_ use abbreviation CM)


The above abbreviations frequently appear in people’s biographical blurbs. _When mentioning a specific level of the Order of Canada in a news story, spell it out._ Note: CM was chosen for “member” because MC (Military Cross) was already in use.

Only so many people can be appointed to each category in a given year. The highest level has an additional limit. There can be no more than a total of 165 living companions at any time.

**Order of Canada is uppercase only when written in full.**

Order of Canada medal
companion of the order
the order


**Other common constructions in news stories:**


They've been appointed to the _Order of Canada._
He was made an officer of the _Order of Canada._
She was elevated to the highest level, a _companion of the order._
_The order’s medal_ is in the shape of a snowflake.


Twice a year, the Advisory Council of the Order of Canada meets to consider nominations for these honours. The council then passes its recommendations on to the Governor General, who actually makes the appointments.

The Governor General's website has more information about the [Order of Canada](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.gg.ca%2Fdocument.aspx%3Fid%3D14940&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0ZCGd-WawYzI9h6Kvvw-ca), including the names of members, officers and companions.

**passport** (n.) Commonly refers to a government-issued document for global travel. However, the definition of passport has expanded over the centuries to include more figurative meanings, from "a passport to heaven" and "a passport to fame" to a special events passport to enjoy, say, diverse food kiosks at a summer fair. Given such entrenched usage, the compounds **vaccine passport** and **vaccination passport** are instantly recognized and perfectly acceptable terms for an official **vaccine certificate** or **vaccine card** or other **proof of vaccination** document issued by public health authorities. Be aware that some governments, groups and individuals specifically avoid using the term "vaccine passport" for various reasons. While we should report this detail when it's directly relevant to a story, we do not have to adopt an external source's style ourselves. If one noun is more common in a given province or territory (e.g., "card" instead of "passport"), it can make editorial sense to prefer that language in local coverage because it's more familiar. Use your own judgment.

**Peshmerga** (name of Kurdish fighters backed by the Kurdistan regional government in northern Iraq) The Kurdish word, originally from Persian, literally means "ready to confront death." Our former style (lowercase and italics) was changed to regular type with a capital "P" in June 2014, based on evolving conventions in English news coverage. The term has become synonymous with Kurdistan's army: ****Peshmerga troops, Peshmerga forces****

**PFAS** (perfluoroalkyl and polyfluoroalkyl substances) OK in headlines and first reference, such as "a group of synthetic chemicals known as PFAS," but the abbreviation should be spelled out once high in stories. They've been dubbed **forever chemicals** because some of more than 4,700 substances don't degrade naturally, according to scientists, and, so, might be capable of remaining in the environment indefinitely. PFAS are found in a wide range of manufacturing processes and consumer products (e.g., clothing, cosmetics, food packaging, non-stick cookware, firefighting foam), and have been detected in humans and animals. It's accurate to describe them as potentially harmful chemicals, but experts say more research is needed to better understand health risks, including to organs, the nervous system and the immune system. Often plural as a noun or adjective (e.g., "PFAS were developed in the late 1930s"), but can be singular ("PFAS was found in the water"), particularly when a specific substance is meant. When spelling out PFAS, the clipped version **per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances** is a common and conversational alternative to **perfluoroalkyl and polyfluoroalkyl substances**, especially in broadcast scripts. If using this shorthand, note the hyphen after per- before the conjunction. (See [hyphens](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/handy-links/punctuation/hyphens/#various "Hyphens") for related punctuation guidelines involving orphaned prefixes in compound sequences.)

**PGA** (Usually OK as an abbreviation, even in first reference) When spelled out, include the possessive apostrophe: **the Professional Golfers' Association**. Be aware that there are separate organizations around the globe, such as the **PGA of America** and the **PGA of Canada**, formerly known as the Canadian Professional Golfers’ Association (CPGA) until 2011. These groups are part of an international PGA alliance called **the Confederation of Professional Golf** (the CPG). See also [golf](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/g/golf/ "Golf") for various style preferences.

**Pickton, Robert William** (B.C. serial killer, charged in 2002 and convicted in 2007) Because of his notoriety, it's usually sufficient to refer to him as **Robert Pickton** in first reference. During coverage of his trial and various appeals, CBC News generally called him Robert William Pickton in first reference to match court documents. When context is required, it's OK to mention that Pickton also went by the name of Wille (e.g., to explain a specific quote or clip). But this background is rarely necessary. In web stories, the optional detail is easiest to add in brackets: **Robert William (Willie) Pickton**. For consistency, avoid the alternative spelling of Willy.

**PKK** (**Kurdistan Workers' Party**) Abbreviation OK in headlines, but spell out in full at least once high in a story. Prefer this entrenched English translation over alternatives, such as "People's Worker Party," because it's clearer. The PKK can be described as an outlawed rebel group fighting for an independent Kurdish state in eastern Turkey. The militants began their armed insurgency decades ago (in 1984). The group is classified as a [terrorist group](/home/t/terrorist-and-terrorism) by Turkey and a number of other countries, including Canada, the U.S. and Germany, as well as by NATO. Be aware that Turkey considers a Kurdish-led militia in neighbouring Syria known as the **People's Protection Units (YPG)** to be a terrorist group. The YPG can be accurately called the armed wing of the **Syrian Kurdish Democratic Union Party (PYD)**. The government in Ankara says the YPG in Syria is an offshoot of the PKK in Turkey. Avoid using too many obscure abbreviations, especially in broadcast scripts, which can quickly become incomprehensible. (See also **[Kurds](/home/k#Kurds)**)

**PLC** (A common abbreviation for "public limited company") No need to spell out in business stories. If you're adding this detail to a story, use all uppercase lettering and insert immediately after company's name, without periods, commas, etc., in first reference (e.g., **Vodafone Group PLC** and **Barclays PLC**, with **Vodafone** and **Barclays** sufficient in headlines and later references). When referring to such nouns in general news stories, PLC can be dropped (e.g., "BP PLC" becomes [BP](/home/b#BP)). This is based on a long-standing journalism convention. It serves our audience by communicating key information without adding peripheral jargon, and avoids awkward pileups such as "BP PLC CEO Tony Hayward." (See also [LLP](/home/l#LLP) and [LP](/home/l#LP))

**point-of-sale (POS) terminal** (Spell out in first reference, with POS in brackets) This is the equipment retailers use to debit bank accounts or to add charges to credit cards. Some terminals are wireless (e.g., they can be brought directly to a restaurant table). Others are attached to data lines next to cashiers. In either case, don't assume that customers have "swiped" their cards. Newer technology features "data chip" rather than "card-swiping" readers. The former involves inserting a card into the bottom of a POS, in the same way you insert a card into an [ABM](/home/a#ABM). In many stories, a generic term such as "debit card terminal" or "credit card reader" or even "[PIN](/home/p#PIN) pad" is often sufficient.

**Pokemon, Pokemon Go** (no accents, no quotation marks; initial caps only) The original Nintendo video game was created in the 1990s. A smartphone version, **Pokemon Go**, was released in 2016. **Ponzi scheme** (capital P; named after 1920s fraudster Charles Ponzi) No need to define in news stories as long as the context makes the nature of the fraud clear. See [Ponzi versus pyramid](/home/p/ponzi-versus-pyramid-scheme)

**Pope Francis** (**Francis** OK in second reference and headlines) Do not add roman numerals. Pope Francis won't become Francis I until there's actually a Francis II. The preferred possessive is **Francis's** (e.g., "Pope Francis's inaugural homily," along the lines of "the witness's testimony" and "a business's profit"). **Pope** is capitalized on its own for the current pontiff only (e.g., "They met with the Pope for an hour"). Otherwise, use **pope** for general references (e.g., "Only cardinals under 80 can pick the next pope"). Pope is still capitalized in historical references to former popes as long as the word appears directly in front of a papal name (e.g., "Pope John Paul II" but "John Paul II became pope in 1978). See [**Pope versus pope**](/home/p/pope) for more details, including how to handle **pope emeritus** and related terms.

**Popular Party** (Spanish political party) For consistency, use this entrenched English translation of **_Partido Popular_**, rather than the alternative version "People's Party." The latter name is fine when attributed to others, as long as the context makes the meaning of the proper noun clear. It's OK to say "**also known as the People's Party**" in stories when both versions appear in clips or quotes.

**post (versus post-)** Many words are fused, including: **postdate** (v.), **postdated** cheque; **postelection; postgraduate; postmark; postmaster general, postmasters general** (see also [\-general](/home/g/generalsuffix)); **postscript; postwar;** Others have hyphens, depending on convention: **post-game; post-mortem; post-production; post-season; post-secondary.**

**postal** (related to the post office or mail delivery); **go postal, went postal** (avoid) These informal terms refer to uncontrollable anger and violence, often set off by stress. They do not mean mere annoyance and have no place in hackneyed puns (e.g., we should not report on people "going postal" over crummy mail service). The colloquialisms were coined after a series of fatal shootings at U.S. post offices in the 1980s. They're considered offensive generalizations since they directly link postal workers with deranged behaviour — implying that these employees commit more acts of violence than others. The terms are acceptable when attributed (i.e., in clips and transcribed quotes). Otherwise, use a synonym (e.g., berserk, crazy, nuts) that matches the story's facts and tone.

**pot** Believed to be derived from a Spanish term related to cannabis leaves, "_potiguaya,_" pot is a common and generally acceptable synonym for cannabis or marijuana. However, **be aware that colloquialisms like "pot," or other similar terms such as “weed,” can affect the tone of stories**. So consider that when choosing which words are best suited to the story. See [marijuana](/home/m#marijuana).

**PotashCorp** (OK in web headlines and second reference) Generally use **Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan** in first reference whenever practical, since that's the official name and because it provides helpful geographical background. The fused abbreviation PotashCorp (two capital letters, no period) rather than Potash Corp., has become standard in recent years and is now preferred. (See also Corp. versus Corporation for related guidelines)

**PricewaterhouseCoopers** (Do _not_ add spaces or hyphens). The formal name of this accounting firm is "PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP." It was created in 1998 by the merger of Price Waterhouse and Coopers & Lybrand. **In headlines, Pricewaterhouse** on its own is fine. Use **PricewaterhouseCoopers in first reference** in the main body of a story. Either **Pricewaterhouse** or **PwC** is OK in second reference. The Canadian division is **Pricewaterhouse Coopers Canada**. Second reference is **Pricewaterhouse Canada** or **PwC Canada**. (See also LLP for general guidelines)

In other religions, there's no formal hierarchy and the word priest is a common descriptive term (e.g., Hindu priest Pandit Roopnauth Sharma and Sikh priest Punjab Singh.) The title Rev. is used before full names of many priests, including Roman Catholics. See [**Rev.**](/home/r#Rev) for details.

**Prime Minister** Tom Haliburton, **the prime minister** spoke for an hour, **the Prime Minister's Office (PMO), Deputy Prime Minister** Sam Slick, **the deputy prime minister** told reporters, **former prime minister** Brian Mulroney, etc. (See [titles](/home/t/titles) for more guidelines)

Prefer the person's name in second reference (**WIlliam** has championed the cause for decades; **Anne**'s official title is _Princess Royal_, although it's clearer and acceptable to call her **Princess Anne**) See [**royal titles**](/home/r/royal-titles) for detailed guidelines, including background on the informal use of "Princess Diana."

The term **guard** remains common and acceptable, however, including in second reference to correctional officers.
