### particles de du van von

**Particles (de, du, von, van, etc.) in names**

Most particles found in proper names in Europe originally functioned as what we would think of as prepositions (of, at) — linking someone to a geographical place (a _sobriquet de terre_). Centuries ago, the rules were relatively simple. In French names, for instance, when the surname was used alone the particle was virtually always dropped: _Alexis de Tocqueville_ became **Tocqueville**, not de Tocqueville. But then the small words became a big deal if associated with rank or nobility (a _particule nobiliaire_), and they started hanging around certain surnames like aristocrats around court: **Marquis de Sade** became **de Sade**, not just Sade. At this point, only a masochist would try offering tips. But here goes.

**There's no convenient, universal rule about when to retain particles in surnames in second reference.** (Vincent van Gogh becomes **van Gogh** but Ludwig van Beethoven becomes just **Beethoven**.) There is, however, an important guideline: **When deciding whether to drop or retain particles in news stories, find out if there's either an established usage** (e.g., a historical figure) **or an expressed personal preference.** Since some patterns have been linked to different nationalities, additional broad direction appears below:

**1\. French names
2\. Spanish names
3\. Dutch names
4\. Other European names
5\. Fused particles
6\. Vietnamese names
7\. Arabic names**

**1\. In French names, particles are generally dropped after first reference** (**Alfred de Musset** becomes **Musset** and **Dominique de Villepin** becomes **Villepin**). **But there are exceptions, usually based on a person's specific preference or historical usage** (Charles de Gaulle becomes **de Gaulle**). Personal preferences vary in different parts of the world. **Many but not all people with French names who are citizens of English-speaking countries tend to retain the particle** (Thomas De Quincey becomes **De Quincey**). This is **also true in Canada** (retired general John de Chastelain becomes **de Chastelain**). Note: **When two particles appear, especially in French names, the trend is to keep only the second one** (Jean de La Fontaine becomes **La Fontaine**), **but there are exceptions** (Walter de la Mare becomes **de la Mare**). If a lowercase particle is retained, it's always capitalized at the start of a sentence or headline: De Gaulle, De la Mare.

**2\. Particles in Spanish names follow a similar pattern:** Manuel de Falla becomes Falla and Miguel de Cervantes becomes Cervantes. If the particle is in the middle of what's considered the surname, however, it's kept: Félix Lope de Vega becomes Lope de Vega.

**3\. In Dutch names, the particles are generally retained** (Vincent van Gogh becomes van Gogh, Gerard ter Borch becomes ter Borch and Janwillem Lincoln van de Wetering becomes van de Wetering). Again, if a lowercase particle is retained, it's always capitalized at the start of a sentence or headline. Van Gogh, Ter Borch, Van de Wetering.

**4\. In other European languages such as German, Austrian, Italian and Portuguese, the particles are often but not always dropped**, depending on a person's specific preference or historical usage (Ludwig van Beethoven becomes Beethoven, but Josef von Sternberg is conventionally written as von Sternberg and members of Georg von Trapp's family in _The Sound of Music_ are known as the von Trapps). In the case of some famous figures, the first name is commonly used in second reference (Leonardo da Vinci becomes Leonardo, except in popular phrases such as _The Da Vinci Code_). If a lowercase particle is retained, it's always capitalized at the start of a sentence or headline: Von Sternbeg, Von Trapps.

**5\. A particle actually fused to a last name is considered part of a single unit and is always retained** in second reference (**D'Armato, duBois, d'Hervilly, Debussy, Demers**). If lowercase, it's always capitalized at the start of a sentence or headline: DuBois, D'Hervilly.

**6\. In Vietnamese names, Van is normally uppercase in the full name and frequently dropped in second reference** (Vietnamese Prime Minister Phan Van Khai becomes Khai, and Nguyen Van Thanh becomes Thanh). See also [Asian names](/home/a/asian-names) for related guidelines.

**7\. Particles in Arabic names** are somewhat different. Since they're frequently tied to another person (e.g., bin = "son of") rather than to a specific geographic location, they're **often retained** (**Osama bin Laden** becomes **bin Laden** in second reference). See [Arabic names](/home/a/arabic-names) for related guidelines.

### Party

**Party versus party**

**Keep the generic word "party" lowercase unless (a) it’s part of an official name** or **(b) a common abridgment** that retains most of the official name:


> He helped found the country's first socialist **party**.
>
> Before becoming a Liberal premier, he led the old federal Tory **party** for three years.
>
> She joined the New Democratic **Party** in 2005.
>
> He supported John Turner at the Liberal **Party**'s leadership convention.


NOTE: Using "Party" in common abridgments was adopted by CBCNews.ca in September 2009. We decided that CP's more formal approach (Liberal party but Liberal Party of Canada) is not as easy for readers to scan, harder for journalists to remember and sometimes leads to inconsistent treatment of parties in the same story (e.g., the Liberal _party_ policy but the New Democratic _Party_ policy).

The word "party" should be **lowercase in plural** constructions, even when proper nouns are used:


> The Conservative and Liberal **parties** are holding fundraising dinners the same night.


Here are **some common uses of "Party" in news stories**, including acceptable short forms of official names:

**Conservative Party** (_common name of federal party founded in 2003_)
Conservative Party of Canada (_formal name of federal party_)
**Democratic Party
Green Party** (_common name of federal party founded in 1983_)
Green Party of Canada (_formal name of federal party_)
**Labor Party** (_Australia_) but **Labour Party** (_Britain_) See [defence, labour, centre](/home/d/defence-labour-and-centre) for relevant guidelines
**Liberal Party** (_common name of federal party_)
Liberal Party of Canada (_formal name_)
**New Democratic Party** (**NDP**, _but never "NDP Party"_)
Progressive Conservative Party (_common name of old PC Party_)
Progressive Conservative Party of Canada (_formal name of old PC Party_)
**Republican Party**
Saskatchewan Party
[**United Conservative Party**](/home/u#UCP) (in Alberta)

**When reporting on political parties in other countries, make certain the location is clear.** Sometimes the proper noun includes this information (e.g., the **Sri Lankan Freedom Party**). In other cases, adjectives or other descriptive detail should be added (e.g., **Britain's Labour Party**) unless the story's context already makes the party's identity clear (e.g., the Democratic Party in an article about politics in Washington or the **Baath Party** in a story about Iraq).


**Federal Conservative Party**

In the fall of 2003, the Canadian Alliance merged with the Progressive Conservative Party of Canada to form the new federal **Conservative Party of Canada**, which we usually call the **Conservative Party** for short. Its members are _Conservatives_. In second reference, we can use the term Tory (Tories) sparingly for variety, but the longer word _Conservatives_ should appear more often. _Tory and Tories are fine in headlines_. When referring to the **old Progressive Conservative Party**, be sure to include the word "Progressive." It can also be called the **old PC Party** or the old Tory party. **This generally includes historical references to former politicians, especially when they, themselves, make a point of distinguishing between specific party affiliations** (e.g., prefer Joe Clark was a Progressive Conservative MP over a "Conservative MP").


**Provincial PC parties**

Although the letters PC are no longer in the federal Conservative Party's name, **the words "Progressive Conservative" remain in the names of numerous provincial parties across the country.** This detail can be reported in spelled-out long form (e.g., Ontario Progressive Conservatives, the Progressive Conservative Party of Nova Scotia) or in short form (e.g., PCs in Ontario and Nova Scotia's PCs).


**Other usage notes**
**Canadian Alliance** (The word party is already implied by the noun Alliance. If it's added, keep it lowercase: the **old Canadian Alliance party**.) The official name of that federal party was the Canadian Reform Conservative Alliance, although this was almost always shortened to Canadian Alliance. See [Conservative Party](/home/p/party#ConservativeParty) above

**Bloc Québécois** (Party is already implied; no need to add). Prefer **the Bloc** in second reference, although BQ is fine in headlines. The possessive is spelled Bloc Québécois’s (but prefer **the Bloc’s**). The extra "s" is not spoken on air.
**Parti Québécois** ("Parti" is "Party" in French; do not add "Party" again, or it becomes the Quebec Party Party). **PQ** is fine in second reference or headlines. The possessive is spelled Parti Québécois’s (but prefer **PQ’s** instead). The extra "s" is not spoken on air. Prefer **PQ membe**r to Péquiste.

Use English capitalization for the names of French political parties (e.g., **Action Démocratique du Québec** not _Action démocratique du Québec_, **Coalition Avenir Québec** not _Coalition avenir Québec_, and **Québec Solidaire** not _Québec solidaire_.) This is an extension of a well-established convention. In French, for example, the PQ’s official name should technically be half lowercase (_Parti québécois_), according to _Le guide du rédacteur_, a style manual published by the federal government’s official translation bureau. But Parti Québécois is much more common. See [French words and accents](/home/f/french-words-and-accents#capitalization) for more detailed guidelines, as well as [separatist and sovereigntist](/home/s/separatist-sovereigntist) for a related editorial note.

Use terms such as **left-wing** and **right-wing** with care when describing political parties or people. See [left-wing versus right-wing](/home/l/left-wing-versus-right-wing) for more details.

See also [Leader versus leader](/home/l/leader)
See also [capitalization](/home/c/capitalization) (an overview)

### pedal versus peddle

**Pedal versus peddle**

The verb pedal means moving a pedal (e.g., riding a bicyle). The verb peddle means to sell. But a seller is called a pedlar, which leaves some spellers’ brains spinning.


**cycling**
**pedal, pedaller, pedalling**


**selling**
**peddle, pedlar, peddling**

**Common slips**
1\. A pedlar (seller) is wrongly referred to as a pedaller (cyclist).

2\. The words pedaller and pedalling are given only one “l” each (the American spellings).

3\. When describing a seller, a variant spelling (“peddler”) is used instead of the traditional one (“pedlar”).


**softpedal**
The word “softpedal,” by the way, can be applied to selling (to describe a person who doesn’t push a product or service too hard).

But the spelling shouldn’t be changed. The term comes from the world of pianos (referring to the pedal that makes the sound softer).

### pedophile

**Pedophile**

Pedophilia is not a crime. It's a psychiatric condition. **Never imply that people have been convicted of pedophilia** (e.g., "Convicted pedophile John Smith ..."). **Instead, specify the crime they've pleaded guilty to or have been found guilty of** (e.g., sexual assault, distributing child pornography, etc.).

**The terms "pedophilia" and "pedophile" can be used to describe people who are sexually attracted to YOUNG children as long as this sexual attraction is not in doubt.** There's no universally accepted age range, but **the word commonly implies prepubescent children** (normally under 12).

**When stories involve older children,** the label pedophilia in considered inaccurate. While other jargon exists (e.g., "pederasty" traditionally refers to men having sexual relations with boys between roughly 12 and 17), it's too obscure for routine news reporting. So instead of using confusing or imprecise labels, **prefer meaningful, conversational descriptions** (e.g., "sex with underage boys").

**While the word pedophile requires editorial judgment, it doesn't require a psychiatric assessment or legal finding** before we adopt it (unlike terms such as "mentally fit" or "insane"). We should have no qualms about using pedophile when it's applicable.


> EXAMPLE: A Quebec man, Richard Reber, sexually assaulted a four-year-old girl and videotaped the crime. After his guilty plea, there was nothing wrong with describing him as a pedophile, or with using this word high in our court coverage, including in the headline: "Quebec pedophile sentenced to 10 years." To ensure that our audience fully understood the story, we also needed to specify what he had actually confessed to (i.e., sexual assault and distribution of child pornography). But referring to him as a "convicted pedophile" would have been inaccurate, since pedophilia is not a crime.


 For the [preferred way to say pedophile](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2Flng%2Frecherche%2Findex.aspx%3FProId%3D35460&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3qpsLJ8AG028yQEmseL2o3), see the CBC Pronunciation Database.

### per

**Per versus a/an**

**Although English is full of Latin** (caveat, [percentage](/home/p/per-cent-versus-percentage)), **using too much Latin on its own can give the impression of being full of oneself**. For example, saying "caveat emptor" instead of "buyer beware" serves little purpose in a news story. If you don't explain it, you risk confusing members of our audience unfamiliar with the expression. And if you do explain it, you make a story longer than it needed to be.

**The word "per" has become so common it's worth special mention.** In the past, many editors discouraged its use as a preposition ("per person") or as an adverb or adjective outside of bona fide Latin compounds ("per annum," "per capita"). However, **using "per" instead of an indefinite article ("a" or "an") is now largely stylistic**:


> $25 an hour / $25 per hour
> $100 a person / $100 per person
> $75,000 a year / $75,000 per year


This **more relaxed approach to incorporating the Latin "per"** into English syntax **is primarily based on a growing number of increasingly common expressions**, such as:


> kilometres per hour 
> megabytes per second
> miles per gallon
> parts per million
> pixels per inch
> as per usual


See also [Latin (scientific names)](/home/l/latin-scientific-names) and [Latin plurals](/home/l/latin-plurals)


### per cent versus percentage

**Per cent versus percentage**

If there's any math in your stories, be sure the calculations are correct. For starters, double-check additions and subtractions. If a legislature has 103 seats, for instance, then the number of winners on election night should add up correctly.

When dealing with large numbers, you don't have to balance to the penny. In a story about proposed government spending, for example, figures can be rounded (e.g., about $115 million instead of $113,985,671). But make certain that the breakdown makes sense. Too much rounding can leave readers puzzled if the figures listed in one paragraph don't add up to the total given in another part of the story.

**One of the most common traps journalists fall into is using the wrong language when comparing figures.** We claim that something has risen or dropped by, say, "five per cent," when in fact the change may be a lot larger. What we generally mean is that something has moved up or down "five percentage points."


**Per cent**
The term "percentage point" can sound too technical in some stories. It may also hide the true extent of a shift. But **if we want to express a "percentage point" change as a specific "per cent" of the original amount, _we can't simply switch words_. We need to perform a calculation first.**

Example 1: A political party's popularity goes from 20 per cent to 15 per cent, according to the latest public opinion poll. This is a five percentage point decrease, but a 25 per cent plunge. (15 – 20 = -5, and -5 represents a drop of one-fourth, or - 25 per cent, of the original 20, because 5 x 4 = 20.)

Example 2: A political leader's popularity goes from 12 per cent to 16 per cent, according to the latest public opinion poll. This is a four percentage point increase, but a 33 per cent leap (16 – 12 = 4, and four represents a jump of one-third, of 33.3 per cent, of the original 12, because 4 x 3 = 12.)


**Percentage point**
**"Percentage points" are a convenient way of looking at a change in a figure already expressed as a fraction of 100 (a percentage)**, such as the inflation rate, unemployment rate, [GDP](/home/g/gdp-versus-gnp) or central  [bank rate](/home/b/bank-rate).

The smaller the original number, the more volatile the same change will be when expressed as a "per cent" of it.

Example1: If short-term interest rates go from five to 7.5 over one year, they've risen 2.5 percentage points but have actually jumped 50 per cent. (2.5 is half of the original 5.0).

Example 2: If short-term interest rates go from 7.5 to five per cent over one year, they've dropped 2.5 percentage points but have actually fallen 33.3 per cent (2.5 is one-third of the original 7.5).

**To compare percentages, use simple subtraction:**

7.5 – 5.0 = 2.5 percentage points

**To calculate a "per cent" change, use subtraction, division and multiplication:**

( New Number – Original Number ) ÷ Original Number X 100 = %
( 7.5 – 5.0 ) ÷ 5.0 x 100 = 50 % increase

See also [numbers](/home/n/numbers) (for guidelines on spelling out figures, using fractions, etc.)

See also [fewer versus less](/home/f/fewer-versus-less) (for guidelines on phrases such as "less than 10 per cent of adults")

### Persian Gulf

**Persian Gulf**

For consistency, call the arm of the Arabian Sea that borders the coast of Iran, Iraq and Saudi Arabia (and a few other countries) "**the Persian Gulf.**" In second reference, "**the Gulf**" is fine.

**Do _not_ refer to this body of water as the Arabian Gulf or the Gulf of Arabia**, which can confuse Canadians unfamiliar with the region. (It's a bit like suddenly calling the Gulf of Mexico the Florida Gulf or the Gulf of Texas).

The official name of the Persian Gulf is disputed in the region. Arab countries prefer Arabian Gulf. Iran insists on Persian Gulf. CBCNews.ca isn't interested in taking sides but does want to be accurate and consistent.

Persian Gulf is the long-established term in western Europe, a translation of various Latin terms (including Sinus Persicus and Mare Persicum) that date back to the days when Iran was known as Persia.

The 2003 Globe and Mail Style Book also recommends calling it the Persian Gulf. The 2009 Associated Press manual agrees: "Use Arabian Gulf only in direct quotations," AP advises, "And explain in the text that the body of water is more commonly known as the Persian Gulf."

To sum up: CBCNews.ca prefers the term Persian Gulf (the Gulf in second reference).

**Continue to refer to the Arabian Sea by its name, of course.** (This is the large body of water along the coast of Oman, Pakistan and India.) The Arabian Sea is part of the Indian Ocean, and stretches through the Gulf of Oman, past the Strait of Hormuz and into the Persian Gulf.

See also [Persian Gulf War](/home/p/persian-gulf-war)

### Persian Gulf War

**Persian Gulf War**

Do _not_ use terms like the First Persian Gulf War or Gulf War I.

Instead, call the first military clash between Saddam Hussein and U.S.-led coalition forces **the 1991 Persian Gulf War.**

The 1991 war was by no means the “first” war in the Persian Gulf.

See also [Persian Gulf](/home/p/persian-gulf) versus Gulf of Arabia.

### phone numbers

**Phone numbers**

**Prefer a standard publishing style for phone numbers.** This means **hyphens between** **clusters,** including area codes (e.g., 604- and 403-) **but NOT between individual numbers that make up clusters** (e.g., 416- rather than 4-1-6), including within traditional groupings of three or four characters after area codes:

> 416-205-3311
>
> 514-597-6000
>
> 867-920-5400

**
Maintain this style for abridged phone numbers used as nouns and adjectives**, including the term 911:

> She dialed **0** by mistake.
>
> The **911** dispatcher phoned him back.
>
> They live in what's known as the **905** region near Toronto.
>
> He disputed the $2 charge for using **411**.


Note: A solidus (/) rather than a hyphen is generally used for dates, such as 9/11 for [Sept. 11, 2001](/home/s#Sept11).

**Be aware that punctuation is highly subjective.** For instance, SOS (our style) will sometimes appear elsewhere as S.O.S., S-O-S, etc. The same applies to numbers, such as 911, which some organizations write as 9-1-1. **There's no single correct approach. For consistency, however, we prefer to use the standard publishing conventions outlined above.** Text is easier for our audience to scan when it's uncluttered by unnecessary hyphens, periods, etc. Also, it's faster and easier for us to rewrite wire copy under deadline pressure because our style matches the approach taken by CP, AP and most other major news organizations in North America.

See also [numbers](/home/n/numbers) (an overview)
See also [addresses](/home/a/addresses)
See also [hyphens](/handy-links/punctuation/hyphens) (an overview)

### Plants

**Plants**

**Generally capitalize only the proper noun components of plant names** (e.g., maple trees but Italian parsley), keeping generic words lowercase:


> **Alberta red winter
> basil
> dandelion
> dogwood
> Douglas fir
> Fraser fir
> Italian parsley
> Japanese primrose
> Kentucky blue grass
> maple tree
> McIntosh apples
> Meyer lemons**
> **poinsettia** (entrenched lowercase, even though originally based on a man's name: Joel Roberts Poinsett)
> **Scotch pine
> Selkirk wheat
> white Dutch clove**r


**Common exceptions are specific varieties of fruits, vegetables and other plants with colloquial names that are treated as proper noun equivalents** (Royal Gala apples, Afghan Kush marijuana) based on convention:


> **Cabernet Sauvignon** grapes (see wines and spirits)
> **Delicious** (apples)
> **Golden Russet** (pears)
> **Granny Smith** (apples)
> **Purple Haze** (cannabis)
> **Pure Sativa** (cannabis)
> **Yukon Gold** (potatoes)


See also [grain](/home/g/grain) (e.g., Marquis and Selkirk but durum and hard red spring)
See also [food](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/f/food/ "Food") (French bread, Kobe beef but french fries, kalamata olives)
See also [scientific names](/home/l/latin-scientific-names) (e.g., _Taraxacum officinale_ for dandelion, _Castor fiber canadensis_ for Canadian beaver), and _Cannabis sativa_ and _Cannabis indica_ for two common species of [marijuana](/home/m#marijuana))
See also [capitalization](/home/c/capitalization) (an overview)

### Plurals

**Plurals**

**In most cases, you add an "s"** (_writer_ becomes _writers_) **or "es"** (_lens_ becomes _lenses_).

**But there are irregular forms to watch for,** and they're not easily explained (_ox_ becomes _oxen_, but _box_ does not turn into _boxen_):

1.  **Sometimes** you use **a different word** (_child_ becomes _children_) 2.  **Sometimes** you stick with **the same word** (one _aircraft_, five _aircraft_; _one deer, five deer; one moose, four moose_) 3.  **Sometimes you have the option to tack on an s** (_one beer, five beer_ or _five beers_) and it comes down to internal style (i.e., CBC News prefers "beers" for the plural, as in "He had a few beers" and "Some beers have a much higher malt content").
4.  **Sometimes you change a vowel or other letter**, based on old Greek forms (_crisis_ become _crises_, _basis_ becomes _bases_, _thesis_ becomes _theses_, etc.).
5.  **Sometimes old Latin rules apply** (_medium, media_) while **in other cases they're ignored** (_referendums, aquariums, stadiums, insurance premiums,_ etc.).
6.  **Sometimes old Latin rules** (_larva, larvae_) **are applied to the same word differently**, depending on context (_antennae_ for insects, but _antennas_ for broadcasting).
7.  **Sometimes an "f" turns into a "v"** (_calves, knives, shelves_ and _scarves_) **but not always** (_handkerchiefs, hoofs, roofs_ and _wharfs_). In several cases, more than one option exists, which means the CBC needs a preference (_dwarfs_, not _dwarves_).
8.  **Sometimes it's "oes"** (_buffaloes, dominoes, echoes, embargoes, frescoes, heroes, innuendoes, mosquitoes, potatoes, salvoes, tomatoes, tornadoes, volcanoes_) and **sometimes it's "os"** (_avocados, concertos, dynamos, Eskimos, Filipinos, ghettos, lassos, pianos, silos, solos, sopranos, zeros,_ etc.) In several cases, more than one option exists, which means the CBC needs a preference (_banjos_, not _banjoes_).
9.  **Sometimes you change "y" to "ies"** (_cherry, cherries_ and _mommy, mommies_) even in the case of certain names (_Johnny, Johnnies_ and _Rocky Mountains, Rockies_), **but often you use "ys" with such proper nouns** (many _Little Italys_, unification of the _two Germanys_, she knew _three Kennedys_, the room was full of _Marys_, they all had _BlackBerrys_) based largely on convention. 

**If you're not sure about a plural form, check this site's alphabetical directory. If it's not there, consult the Canadian Oxford Dictionary dictionary.**

See also [compound plurals](/home/c/courts-martial-and-other-plural-compounds) (courts martial, etc.)
See also [Latin plurals](/home/l/latin-plurals) (media are, not media is)
See also [verb agreement](/home/v/verb-agreement) (compound nouns, sports teams, musical groups, RCMP, etc.)
See also [possessive apostrophe](/handy-links/punctuation/possessive-apostrophe) (its versus it's, premiers' meeting but Leafs player)  
See also [s' versus s's](/handy-links/punctuation/s-versus-s-s) (Eves's not Eves')

### PM designate

**\-designate versus -elect**

**When someone is named to a position but hasn't actually begun working in an official capacity yet, the qualifier "designate" is often used.** In these cases, add only one hyphen and keep the label lowercase, even before a full name.

> UN secretary general-designate Ban Ki-moon


Other less formal options exist, of course, including generic descriptions such as "next" or "incoming."

**Avoid using the term "elect" in a temporary title unless it actually applies** (e.g., president-elect but prime minister-designate). The difference is outlined below.



[president-elect, senator-elect, etc.](/home/p/pm-designate#president) (U.S.)

**prime minister-designate**
**_Never_ use the term prime minister-elect** in stories about Ottawa. It is wrong.

In our parliamentary system, **Canadians do not pick prime ministers in general elections.** They vote for candidates who represent parties. **Parties form governments** (minority or majority). **Political parties choose their own leaders.
**
If the person who was PM in the previous Parliament wins the election and forms the next government, we simply continue to call the person prime minister. The same convention applies to premiers. For details, see: [titles during elections](/home/e/election-titles).

**When someone new is waiting to enter 24 Sussex Drive** (after an election, for instance, or following a leadership convention), **we refer to this person as the "next prime minister"** or the **"incoming prime minister"** (lowercase).

She or he can also be called **"prime minister-designate"** (lowercase, with one hyphen, even before the name) before they're officially sworn in. This is both CBC News and CP style:

> Prime Minister John Thompson sat down with prime minister-designate Mackenzie Bowell to talk about the transition of power.


**The title "prime minister-designate" is the official term used by the Prime Minister's Office** (e.g., in news releases after a leadership convention or a general election). Avoid uppercase letters or extra hyphens, however, which are sometimes tossed in at random in news releases.

So in November 2003, when the Liberals picked a new leader (Paul Martin) to replace retiring MP Jean Chrétien, Martin became the prime minister-designate until he was officially sworn in one month later. And in January 2006, when Stephen Harper's Conservatives defeated Martin's Liberals, Harper became prime minister-designate until he officially took office in early February.

In this context, "designated" means "appointed to a position but not yet occupying it," as defined in the Canadian Oxford. In the same way that a cabinet minister is named to a job, Canada's "first" or "prime" minister is also technically selected by the Crown based on that MP's position as leader of a federal political party chosen to form the government. **Based on convention, we can begin using the term "prime minister-designate" immediately, even though it generally takes time for the King's representative to sign the necessary papers.**

When a minority government falls, Canadians normally face a general election. But under certain circumstances it's possible for the Governor General to pick a different federal party leader if it's felt that this person could secure and maintain the confidence of the House of Commons (e.g., through a coalition with another party, depending on the overall seat distribution). This is a clear example of how MPs are "named" or "designated" rather than "elected" as prime minister.

Generally avoid the label **prime-minister-in-waiting** (lowercase with three hyphens). The term _in-waiting_ originally meant royal _servant_ (e.g., a lady-in-waiting), although it's now sometimes applied to political figures preparing to assume power. CBC News prefers **prime minister-designate**.

**The title "prime minister" is capitalized only when it's followed by the name of the current head of government. This is true regardless of the country** (Canada, Britain, etc.)

> Prime Minister Namof Aperson ...
>
> The prime minister met with her cabinet ...
>
> Former prime minister John Turner ...


**premier-designate**
The above guidelines also apply to premiers before they're officially sworn in. We use words such as **"incoming premier"** and **"next premier"** and **"premier-designate"** (but _never_ "premier-elect").

**Based on convention, we can begin using the term "premier-designate" immediately, even though it generally takes time for the King's representative to sign the necessary papers.**


**governor general-designate**
This is the official term used for the individual chosen to become the monarch's next representative in Canada. Although government officials tend to use uppercase letters and no punctuation, CBC News (and CP) style is **governor general-designate** (lowercase with one hyphen).

Only the current Governor General gets capital letters, and there is no hyphen. For more details, see [governor general versus Governor General](/home/g/governor-general)


**president-elect, senator-elect, etc. (U.S)**
**For stories about political change in the United States, which has a different electoral system, we use the term "president-elect"** (lowercase with a hyphen).

> U.S. president-elect Norm Reynolds wrote to CBC.ca requesting a photograph of Mr. Dressup.

The same approach is taken with other American political figures before they're officially sworn in (e.g., a senator-elect or a representative-elect heading to [Congress](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/c/congress/ "Congress")).

**mayor-elect, MP-elect, MPP-elect**
**We also use the word _elect_ to describe some incoming political office holders in Canada, such as a riding's new MP or MLA, a city's new mayor or a town's new councillor**, because voters actually pick these people directly:

> The strikers asked for a meeting with mayor-elect Cam Conway.


**But this term does NOT apply to incumbents.** During election campaigns, Parliament still has MPs, provincial legislatures still have MPPs, MLAs (or whatever other term applies in a given region), municipalities still have mayors. These people continue to be paid. If they win on election night, therefore, they're simply "re-elected." It's neither necessary nor accurate to refer to them as an "MP-elect" or an "MPP-elect" or a "mayor-elect."

**Even for winning candidates who defeated incumbents, we normally drop the qualifier "elect" within days of the vote** (e.g., the labels MP-elect or MPP-elect are replaced by "incoming" or "newly elected" MP or MPP).

There is normally a two-step process to become a member of Parliament or a member of a provincial/territorial legislative body in Canada. First, the chief electoral officer issues an official list of winning names tied to the returning of writs from all constituencies. The process can take weeks. Second, declared winners who are not part of the government's cabinet then schedule private appointments to take relevant oaths of office. But it's not practical to insist on using terms such as "MP-elect" or "MPP-elect" until we've confirmed that all of the oaths have been taken. Instead, **CBC News follows the convention of calling virtually all of the winners MPs, MPPs, etc., within about a week of the general election** — normally around the time of the new cabinet's swearing-in ceremony. **The only exceptions are close races that have triggered official recounts.**

See also [**titles during elections**](/home/e/election-titles) and our main [election primer](/home/e/election-primer) for related guidelines, as well as the general [titles overview](/home/t/titles) for detailed typographical style

### Police forces

**Police versus police**

**Keep the generic word "police" lowercase, except in formal names:**

Royal Canadian Mounted Police
Ontario Provincial Police (_actual name_)
Quebec provincial police (See [Sûreté du Québec](/home/s#SQ) for related guidelines on use of French noun)
[Newfoundland and Labrador](/home/n/newfoundland-and-labrador) provincial police
_but_ the Royal Newfoundland Constabulary (proper noun)
Frederitcon Police Force
Halifax Regional Police
Vancouver Police Department
Calgary Police Service
but Calgary police commission
Toronto Police Service
Toronto police
police station
police car
police officer (_better than policeman or policewoman_)


**Generic use of 'force'
**It's **generally OK to use the lowercase noun "force" as a synonym for service, department, etc., in generic references** (e.g., Vancouver's police force to mean the Vancouver Police Department). **Sometimes context and a given story's tone can influence word choice.** For instance, "force" directly conveys the sense of law enforcement (e.g., when criminal charges are laid), while "service" can telegraph something broader (e.g., crowd control at a parade).


**RCMP but not CPD
****With the exception of well-known initialisms such as the RCMP, we generally avoid abbreviating the names of police forces in national stories.** So instead of writing CPD for the Chicago Police Department in second reference, use conversational alternatives (e.g., Chicago police, the city's police force). While **LAPD** and **NYPD** are common enough to use in stories in headlines and second reference, they still require spelling out once in full (i.e., as the Los Angeles Police Department and the City of New York Police Department).  Another example is **OPP**, which needs to be defined at least once as the Ontario Provincial Police, since not everyone in our audience will be familiar with the abbreviation.


**police officer**
**The term "police officer" is acceptable for any rank on a given force.** Police in Canada do not follow the military's practice of clearly branding its members as commissioned or non-commissioned officers.


**military police**
**Keep "military police" lowercase unless the words are being used as part of the full, formal name of a unit:**

They attacked a military police convoy.
Military police have launched a search for a missing cadet.
He's a member of the 18th U.S. Military Police Brigade.
The 720th U.S. Military Police Battalion heads to Iraq next month.

For a discussion of "police chief" versus "police Chief," etc. see [police ranks](/home/p/police-ranks)
See also [RCMP are versus RCMP is](/home/r/rcmp-are-versus-rcmp-is)
See also [capitalization](/home/c/capitalization) (an overview)

### Police ranks

**Police ranks**

**TV TEXT REMINDER:** Be aware that television graphics, banners, supers, etc., have some unique typographical conventions. The biggest difference is the use of more initial capital letters in titles, job descriptions, etc. (e.g., "Former Prime Minister" instead of former prime minister, and "High School Principal" instead of high school principal). See the [**TV Text overview**](/home/t/tv_text) for details.

**Use abbreviations only before names. The short forms are always capitalized:**

Supt. Janice Bird
Det. John Sparrow

**Write out ranks used without names:**

The superintendent spoke to the family.
The detective said nothing.

Some terms, such as chief and commissioner, are not abbreviated.

**Keep descriptive words like “police” and “fire” in lowercase** unless they’re part of a force’s name:

_They demanded to see police Chief Fred Ming.
Reporters talked to fire Chief Ruth Buzz.
She's a member of the Toronto Police Service.
The Ontario Provincial Police budget._

**Don't insert words like “police” or “fire” in the middle of ranks.** Write _Deputy Chief Rick McKee_ instead of Deputy police Chief Rick McKee (because the rank is _Deputy Chief_).

For a more detailed discussion of “Police versus police,” see [police forces](/home/p/police-forces).

If someone is temporarily assigned to a rank that is abbreviated, (e.g., _acting Staff Sgt. Rick McKee or acting Insp. Laurie Smith_), **the word acting is lowercase** but the rank retains its initial capital letters.

If someone is temporarily assigned to a rank that is not abbreviated (e.g., _acting police chief Laurie Smith, acting deputy chief Rick McKee_), the word acting and the rank are both lowercase.

(See also [titles](/home/t/titles) for general guidelines on handling past and temporary positions, such as retired _general John de Chastelain_.)
**
We prefer the general term “police officer” over policeman or policewoman.

The word officer is acceptable for any rank on a given force.** (Police in Canada do not follow the military’s practice of clearly branding its members as commissioned or non-commissioned officers.)
