### Polls

**Polls**

**General guidelines**
**We do not report on all polls.** Among other things, **CBC News considers the source**. For instance, we do not cover "push" or "advocacy" polls (e.g., a survey about teachers' pensions conducted by a union representing teachers).

**CBC also looks at the methodology, amount of information available** on how questions were phrased **as well as the significance of the results**. To determine if a survey is scientific, we look at several factors including **the sample size, how people were chosen, the response rate and the margin of error**. (For example, the CBC's Research Department traditionally discourages reporting on polls with margins of error that are greater than 3.1. And even if overall poll results have acceptable margins of error, care must always be taken when certain breakdowns are looked at — e.g., national versus regional results — because smaller sample sizes may carry significantly larger margins of error.)

**It's normally OK to make a brief reference to a poll from a reputable organization** (e.g., "_The U.S. president's approval rating has dipped to its lowest level in two years, according to a new CNN survey_"), **as long as the source is transparently identified and the poll is deemed sound** based on CBC Research guidelines. **But before reporting on any poll in any depth** (i.e., as the main focus of a given story), **the CBC Research Department should be asked to assess the methodology and interpretation of results.** At the very least, a unit's senior journalists should be consulted before anyone writes about polls that have not already been reviewed by the main newsgathering desk and assigned to a CBC reporter.

**When writing about polls, be sure to follow specific rules about language and interpretation of data outlined in the CBC's Journalistic Standards and Practices policies.** (See below)

**During election campaigns, it's also helpful to consult our detailed [election primer](/home/e/election-primer), which features a wide range of other guidelines** (e.g., how to refer to incumbents, organize political panels), including a summary of rules about commissioning polls, election day blackouts and election night coverage. **It summarizes why we limit coverage of "horse race" poll results.** There's also a section dealing with [unscientific surveys](/home/e/election-primer#unscientificsurveys), such as invitations for audience votes during broadcasts, and the need to avoid even implying that the results are representative.


**Language**
Public opinion **polls suggest, they do not "show."** Always attribute, and avoid language such as "indicate" or "show" when referring to the results.


> _The poll suggests support for XYZ has fallen about 10 percentage points._
>
> _Support for XYZ has fallen about 10 percentage points, according to the poll._

Be sure to **avoid mixing up [per cent and percentage](/home/p/per-cent-versus-percentage)**.

**Mandatory content**
**When writing about a poll, always mention:**

-   **Who conducted the survey** (e.g., the polling company as well as the organization that commissioned it).
-   **When** it took place.
-   **Who was surveyed** (e.g., teachers in Alberta, eligible voters across Canada, etc.)
-   The **number of people interviewed.**
-   The **margin of error** (e.g., "The results are considered accurate within 2.5 percentage points 19 times out of 20"), **unless it's an online survey** — since pollsters don't agree on the scientific validity of calculating margins of error unless a given sample is considered sufficiently random and representative. **In those cases, always contact the CBC's research department to see if there are any concerns about a given poll's methodology** or overall soundness before reporting the results.

**It's often helpful to include:**

-   **How questions were asked** (e.g., over the phone).
-   The **response rate** (i.e., the percentage of people contacted who agreed to take part).

If it's a political poll, **be sure to flag whether an organization with ties to a political party commissioned the survey.

For more tips and caveats about the mandatory content tied to polls**, including the meaning and the limitations of margins of error, **see the CBC Research Department's four-page [Poll Reporting Guide Sheet](/media/qe2eeik2/poll-reporting-guide-sheet_cb-a29d4cb8a12f2bc2.pdf)**.


**Focus**
**In straight news reporting, emphasize actual data over interpretation** of the numbers (e.g., "_The poll suggests support for XYZ is falling_" rather than why it's falling). See [interpretation](/home/p/polls#interpretation) below for more details about attributed opinion.

**Try to include context**, such as the results of other polls we've reported recently and trends over time, to help our audience understand the story.

**Never give the impression that polls are predictive.** They're snapshots taken at a specific moment in time and may, in fact, be unrepresentative. The results should be treated as such.


**Interpretation**
**In news stories, interpretation of surveys should come from experts we interview** (e.g., a pollster can talk about the methodology and general trends, a political scientist can weigh in with perspective and predictions, etc.). **Their remarks should be attributed.
**
**In content branded as analysis**, including election features such as the Canada Poll Tracker, **interpretation of surveys can be provided by qualified CBC News staff** (i.e., news employees with experience/expertise in the field).

**In columns, the views of the authors are often sufficient** as long as they're clearly identified as such.


**External links**
Given the nature of the web, it's a good idea to **provide whatever additional information we can on surveys in our online stories** (e.g., the exact wording of one or two questions, plus an external link to the research company's site that gives more background on the specific poll).


**Journalistic Standards and Practices**
For more information, see the CBC's [Journalistic Standards and Practices policy on polls](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fio.cbcrc.ca%2F%23%2Fresources%2Fpolitics-1.4523351&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1JzlIMztzK0lZtiRHnpBNa), which includes an overview of general principles as well as specific, mandatory guidelines (e.g., pre-approval requirements for CBC-commissioned polls).

**ADDITIONAL RESOURCES ABOUT POLLS**
 Before writing about public opinion surveys, **make sure you're familiar with accepted industry standards about conducting polls and interpreting results** ― including how the margin of error can change drastically when attempting to extrapolate, say, provincial results from certain national surveys because the relevant sample size shrinks disproportionately. The CBC Research Department's 2017 [**Poll Reporting Guide Sheet**](/media/qe2eeik2/poll-reporting-guide-sheet_cb-a29d4cb8a12f2bc2.pdf) (PDF) is a good starting point.

 To help news organizations develop a critical eye when assessing whether to report polls, the U.S. National Council on Public Polls has created a document worth reading: [**20 questions a journalist should ask about poll results**](https://docs.google.com/a/radio-canada.ca/viewer?a=v&pid=sites&srcid=Y2JjLmNhfGxhbmd1YWdlZ3VpZGV8Z3g6M2RjM2Y4MjIyZGRjZDY4Mw) (PDF). It hammers home the need to understand who asked what questions, when, how, etc.

### Ponzi versus pyramid scheme

**Ponzi versus pyramid scheme**

**In news stories, avoid describing simple pyramid schemes as Ponzi scams.** They're similar but not identical. **When defining Ponzi, it's OK to say it's a _pyramid-like scheme_** as long as details in the story make it clear how people were actually defrauded. This is based on conventional usage. **But it's wrong to call simple pyramid operations actual Ponzi scams.**

 **Only real similarity**A large number of people contribute to a pool of money that is moved around but never actually generates true returns on investment. This is essentially the only overlap.


**Main differences**

-   A true **Ponzi** scheme is managed by only a few con artists (often only one). This individual or small group is actively conspiring to defraud everyone else. Chronology is irrelevant (i.e., when a person joins).
-   A **pyramid** scheme is a trickling-down process. Profits are not limited to the original organizers but, rather, depend on which level of the pyramid a person is on (i.e., whether you're an early participant or a latecomer). An entry fee is often charged for the right to participate.
-   A **pyramid** scheme depends on a steady stream of new recruits, actively sought after by recently signed up members. A **Ponzi** scheme can be sustained for a longer period without new recruits if the original fraudster(s) can keep tricking current participants into "reinvesting" their earnings.

**Definitions optional**
The term Ponzi scheme became fairly well known in 2008-09, given extensive coverage of the Bernard Madoff case cited below. So **in the same way that we don't need to define the common label _pyramid scheme_, we don't necessarily need to define _Ponzi_** (which also happens to be in the dictionary). **Just make sure the story's details are clear enough to let our audience know what sort of fraud was committed** (or is _alleged_ to have been committed, if the case is still under investigation or before the courts). On the web, internal links to background features, glossaries, etc., are a good way of offering extra detail. On air, promoting in-depth web content can be highly effective.


**Details and examples**
**Ponzi scheme**
A true **Ponzi scheme** involves a very small number of masterminds who trick others into believing that they're making a profit from legitimate investments. It's often only one con artist. In reality, cash is simply stolen and moved around, with the swindler paying one group a portion of the money invested by others. No returns are actually earned, although some participants may technically profit if they persuade the mastermind(s) to let them withdraw all original investments after they've already received bogus earnings (which were probably paid to "investors" only as an incentive to plow in more money). There is actually **no suggestion of a pyramid structure** to those fooled. They are **not asked to recruit people** or do any other work. **Their returns are not dependent on when they begin injecting money into the scam.** They are simply asked for cash and promised good returns (usually an unrealistically high amount) in the masquerade.


> **Example:** In New York, disgraced financier **Bernard Madoff** was sentenced in 2009 to the maximum 150 years behind bars for fleecing hundreds of investors out of tens of billions of dollars in a **massive Ponzi scheme**. Madoff had encouraged thousands of people to invest huge sums of money over many years. Investigators said he created fictitious account statements that claimed big profits were being made. But Madoff didn’t actually trade securities or made other bona fide investments. Instead, he simply kept, spent or passed on to others large amounts of the money.


**Pyramid scheme**
By contrast, a **pyramid scheme** generally involves more than the original masterminds making money from others’ investments on a trickle-down basis. In fact, **many of the early participants in a pyramid scam automatically profit from the cash paid by those who join later.** How much of the total pot an individual can possibly collect before there's no new money coming in depends on when the person joins. **Chronology, in other words, is crucial** — especially since people are often asked to pay some sort of fee for the right to participate. Simple pyramids are sometimes marketed as such, with **people encouraged to rise through the ranks by recruiting others**. Again, there are no true earnings from investments. Money is simply moved around until the scheme collapses.


> Example: In California, eight women were charged with fraud in 2002 with what authorities said was a $12 million **pyramid scheme**. According to police, investors were invited to Women Helping Women parties in beauty salons and residences and promised a chance to make money. At each party, a “birthday girl” would receive up to $40,000. The money came from participants, who had to pay $5,000 each for the right to attend future parties. Each person counted on eventually celebrating her own $40,000 “birthday.” For many, however, the big cheque never came.


See also the CBCNews.ca features: [How a Ponzi scheme works](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fmoney%2Fstory%2F2008%2F12%2F15%2Ff-langan-bmis.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw07WUZVYSlZF6TjLMj6PIIy) and [Ponzi schemes: New Canadian scandals highlight old scam](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fmoney%2Fstory%2F2009%2F09%2F15%2Ff-new-ponzi-backgrounder-2009.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3DO8p74FBa-za_Zyk7AezA)

### pope

**Pope versus pope**
[Pope](/home/p/pope#capitalized) (capitalized; roman numerals not needed)
[interregnum](/home/p/pope#interregnum) (after the Pope's death)
[pope](/home/p/pope#lowercase) (lowercase) 


**Pope**
**Capitalize all references to the current head of the Roman Catholic Church:**

> _Pope Francis waved at the crowd._
>
> _The Pope will visit Canada next month._
>
> _Pope Francis's age is irrelevant, she said._


See [plural possessives](/handy-links/punctuation/s-versus-s-s) for related guidelines (_the witness's testimony, a business's profits, Charles's horse_)

**Generally _avoid_ the term Holy Father** except in direct quotes (i.e., transcribed clips).

> _The Pope talked to them for more than three hours._
>
> _"The Holy Father needs to rest," a Vatican spokesperson said._


**Roman numerals are not required for Francis:** Pope Francis (NOT Francis I)


There has been only one Pope Francis. The name chosen by Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio in March 2013. Until there's a Francis II, the papal name Francis alone is sufficient.


**Roman numerals rarely needed for recent popes**
**Even for past popes, roman numerals are often not required, especially in headlines or second reference.**

When papal names have been used before, roman numerals are rarely needed when referring to recent pontiffs (e.g., _Pope Benedict_ instead of _Pope Benedict XVI_, unless there's reason to believe there would be confusion with, say, Benedict XV's papacy, which ended in 1922).

**On the rare occasion when the same papal name appears in one story, use roman numerals for clarity:**

> _John Paul II became pontiff in October 1978, about three weeks after John Paul I's unexpected death._


**For former pontiffs, capitalize Pope only before a single papal name**
**Use an uppercase "P" for former popes only when the title appears directly in front of one name:**

> _Pope Leo XIII_
>
> _The last pope to issue such a decree was Leo XIII._


**In plural, always use a lowercase "p" even before the name:**

> _... popes John Paul II, Pius XII, and Benedict XV._

**
If the former pope is still living, use [pope emeritus](/home/p/pope#emeritus)** or less lofty synonyms (e.g., retired pope) as outlined below.


**interregnum (after the Pope's death)**
**During the start of an interregnum** (after the Pope has died but before a replacement has been chosen), **continue to use an uppercase "P"** in all references since mourners are honouring "the" Pope not "a" pope:

> _The Pope's funeral will be held on Friday._


But after his body has been buried avoid calling him simply "the Pope." At this point, prefer his papal name, either with or without the title:

> _The conclave began about a week after Pope John Paul II's funeral._
>
> _In his final days, John Paul had trouble speaking._
>
> _The late Pope John Paul wrote about his illness in his will._


**pope**
Unless immediately followed by a name (e.g., Pope Leo XIII), **use a lowercase "p" when referring to former popes** (including the recently deceased pontiff once a successor is picked). Also, **use a lowercase "p" for general references to popes** (including a not-yet-chosen successor during the interregnum).

> _The conclave to pick a new pope had been expected to last at least two days._
>
> _Most Roman Catholic popes have been Italian._


**pope emeritus**
**In 2013, Benedict XVI became the first pope to voluntarily resign in almost 600 years.** Until his death in December 2022, he was officially known as the "roman pontiff emeritus" at the Vatican. **In our journalism, Benedict was referred to in various ways**, depending on the story's context and writer's preference. Here are some examples:

> _retired pope Benedict XVI_ (roman numerals optional)
>
> _former pope Benedict XVI_ (roman numerals optional)
>
> _pope emeritus Benedict XVI_ (roman numerals optional)
>
> _retired pope Benedict_
>
> _former pope Benedict_
>
> _pope emeritus Benedict_
>
> _the pope emeritus_

**
The modifier emeritus** — Latin for "a recognition (or merit) from service" — **is conventionally used after the noun** (e.g., pope emeritus, professor emeritus, archbishop emeritus of Montreal), **but can also be placed in front** (e.g., the emeritus pope). The latter construction sometimes makes editorial sense, especially in certain broadcast scripts (e.g., in a 2018 story about Pope Francis that made reference to Benedict XVI, putting emeritus in front of his name helped instantly underscore we meant the former pontiff).

> _emeritus pope Benedict XVI_ (roman numerals optional)
>
> _emeritus pope Benedict_
>
> _the emeritus pope_


**Since "pope emeritus" is more familiar than "emeritus pope," it's our preferred style.** But use your own judgment about what works best in a given story. Since the possessive of pope emeritus is **pope emeritus's** (see [s's](/handy-links/punctuation/s-versus-s-s) for details), it's often easiest to recast with the noun pope at the end (e.g., the former pope's, the past pope's, Benedict's or the emeritus pope's).

Bear in mind that **when citing past events (recent or historical), the most conversational way to refer to previous popes is to** avoid terms like former, retired, past, deceased, emeritus, etc., and simply **put a sentence into context with a time element** tied to when the person was still pontiff:

> _Pope Gregory XII stepped down in 1415_
>
> _The College of Cardinals met for first time since Pope Benedict's resignation last week_


In each sentence above, the person was still pope at the time (Gregory in 1415, and Benedict the week he resigned). See [past versus present](/home/t/titles#droppingformer) in the titles overview entry for related guidelines


**pontiff, papal, papacy**
Derivatives (e.g., _papal_ and _papacy_) are always lowercase, along with terms used as synonyms for official titles, such as _pontiff_.

See also [Titles](/home/t/titles) for general guidelines

For related style points, see: [cardinal versus Cardinal](/home/c#cardinal), as well as [Rev.](/home/r#Rev), [priest](/home/p#priest), [Monsignor](/home/m#monsignor) and [Father, Mother, Sister, Brother](/home/f/father-mother-brother-sister)

The [Vatican's website](https://www.vatican.va/content/vatican/it.html) includes background on all popes from the past century.

### pope

**Pornography, porn**

[Traditional usage OK](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/p/pornography/#traditionalusage "Pornography") (porn film, porn star)
[Certain figurative usage fine](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/p/pornography/#figurativeusage "Pornography") (food porn, weather porn)

**Traditional usage OK**
There's **no universal definition of pornography, commonly called porn.** The English version of the word was coined in the 1840s, shortly after photography was invented. It was based on a French term for "obscene painting," which, in turn, came from an ancient Greek expression that's generally translated as "writing about prostitutes." The etymology, in other words, is directly tied to money and sex.

**Porn now conventionally refers to a range of explicit material of a sexual nature, including video, photos and text**, that's associated with carnal lust rather than artistic, aesthetic eroticism. It's often created by, and for, men, and is frequently criticized by opponents who say it objectifies women. Deciding what's pornography and what's art can be highly subjective, however, as noted in this [2019 CBC feature](https://www.cbc.ca/arts/art-101-what-s-the-difference-between-porn-and-art-1.5062752) on evolving societal mores.

In news stories, **the terms porn and pornography are generally OK when referring to the commercial production of nude or sexually explicit material that involves consenting adults, and that lacks intrinsic artistic value**. Although the last clause is vague and, so, open to debate, traditional interpretation provides broad direction. For example, a Penthouse photo layout is usually called pornography, while a sex scene in a movie shown at the Toronto International Film Festival is usually considered art, whether well or poorly crafted. There is, of course, overlap. Gratuitous and/or bawdy sex scenes in popular cable TV dramas might be called "soft porn" by some.

Compounds such as **porn actor, porn actress, and porn star are common and acceptable synonyms for adult film actor** when the facts fit. Coverage of the [Stormy Daniels story](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/updates/2018/2018-05-28/ "2018 05 28") during Donald Trump's presidency illustrates options. But **be mindful of the difference between professionals who describe themselves as porn stars and amateurs who are branded in hurtful ways** based on a few photos or images that have surfaced online. Also bear in mind that word choice affects a story's overall tone, and that labels can be dehumanizing — as outlined in our entry on [prostitute, sex trade worker, etc.](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/p/prostitute/ "Prostitute") Use editorial judgment.


**Certain figurative usage fine** (food porn, weather porn)
Since the 1970s, the clipped term porn has also been used in **compounds that have nothing to do with sex** (e.g., **disaster porn, food porn, grief porn, horror porn, weather porn**). The implication is that this material is intended to be as titillating as words or images about sex.

**Such entrenched colloquialisms are normally fine**. Exceptions are stories focused on sexual exploitation and abuse, where use of the word "porn" so blithely would be unsuitable.


**Avoid 'revenge porn' unless attributed**
The term "**revenge porn**," coined in the early 1990s, **originally referred to a subgenre of action films that featured extremely violent or highly sensational revenge plots**, according to the Oxford English Dictionary. **By 2007, however, the expression was being applied to the vindictive act of uploading nude, semi-nude or sexually explicit images of someone to the internet without the person's permission**, usually after a couple's relationship had ended. The label quickly caught on, but a decade later activists began calling for different wording that better conveyed the true nature of what amounts to cyber assault and sexual abuse.

CBC News agrees that **the compound "revenge porn" can be misleading**. First, **the modifier "revenge" seemingly blames the victim** for the unauthorized, unwanted distribution of revealing personal images by stressing the perpetrator's perceived self-justification (along the lines of a "revenge killing"). Second, **the noun "porn" mischaracterizes the intimate videos or photos being leaked** by wrongly insinuating that the material was actually created as the equivalent of commercial pornography.

For this reason, **references to "revenge porn" in stories should be limited and attributed** (e.g., directly transcribed clips or proper noun equivalents, such as an organization's Revenge Porn Helpline).

There's currently **no pithy, clear and neutral synonym**. Language such as "**non-consensual intimate image sharing**" can be used in stories, especially when quoting from academic studies, legislation and other government documents, like the Canadian Department of Justice's 2013 report: [Cyberbullying and the Non-consensual Distribution of Intimate Images](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/media/pcipnyma/cndii-cdncii-eng_dept-of-justice_canada_june-2013.pdf "Cyberbulling_Cdncii_Dept Of Justice Canada June 2013")[.](/umbraco#/media/media/edit/15425) But **be aware that this sort of phrasing is often so thick and mushy that it can obscure the pain suffered by victims** ― sounding more like a “sharing” copyright violation than a vicious and devastating cyber assault that leaves individuals traumatized and publicly humiliated.

One option is to use words like "abuse" or "betrayal" to encapsulate the sense of malevolent, non-consensual distribution, as in "**intimate image betrayal,**" and then to report whatever facts apply to a given case in conversational English (e.g., "**posted a sex tape they had made without her permission**," or "**published some nude pictures of her without consent**").

NOTE: The above entry deals with material recorded by consenting adults. For stories about the production, possession and distribution of unlawful videos or images of minors, see [**child pornography**](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/c/child_pornography/ "Child_pornography").


### Prairies

**Prairie versus prairie**

**Keep the generic word “prairie” lowercase unless referring to all or part of the specific region** that runs from southeastern Alberta through southern Saskatchewan and into southwestern Manitoba. (These are the **three Prairie provinces**.)

Some common constructions:

> Prairie provinces
>
> the Prairies
>
> It looked like a prairie field.
>
> The prairie stretched as far as the eye could see.
>
> Their Prairie farm is for sale.
>
> A prairie snake.
>
> Snakes are multiplying on Canada’s Prairies.


Note: Do not apply the U.S. term “Midwest” to Canada.

See also [North, South, East and West](/home/n/north-south-east-and-west)
See also [regions of Canada](/home/r/regions-of-canada) (the West Coast, the Maritimes, etc.)
See also [provinces and cities](/home/p/provinces-and-cities)




### Prepositions at the end of sentences

**Prepositions at the end of sentences**

If you believe a sentence looks or sounds better with a preposition at the end, write it that way. Grammarians won't quarrel. In fact many will applaud.

**Not only is it harmless to end on a preposition, it's also natural** — an important consideration for writers at the CBC who have their words read aloud on radio and television. Consider the following sentences:

"She refused to come _in_."

"What's the world coming to?"

"This is a point people still fight _over_."


**'A ridiculous affectation'**
If **ending a sentence with a preposition is perfectly acceptable**, why do so many people assume it's wrong?

**The myth appears to have started with an influential book by an 18th-century bishop**, Robert Lowth, according to Bill Bryson's The Penguin Dictionary of Troublesome Words.

In Lowth's Short Introduction to English Grammar, the "gentleman grammarian" urged his readers to be polite by avoiding prepositions at the end of their sentences if they possibly could. To Lowth, for example, writing "this is something you should go to" was less appealing than "this is something to which you should go."

"Too many people took him too literally and for a century and a half the notion held sway," Bryson says. "Today, happily, it is universally condemned as a ridiculous affectation."

The late novelist Kingsley Amis was a bit harsher, calling the rule "one of those fancied prohibitions dear to ignorant slobs."

See also [grammar](/handy-links/grammar) for a list of common topics, including [split infinitives](/home/s/split-infinitives)

### Problems with pronouns

## Problems with pronouns

In news stories, there are **THREE COMMON MISTAKES with pronouns**.


**1\. Inappropriate gender** **('her' engine rather than 'its' engine)**

**For people, use known and preferred pronouns.** When referring to [t](/home/t/transgender)[ransgender](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/transgender/#pronouns "Transgender") people, this may include adopting the [plural "they" as a singular](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/they_singular/ "They_singular"), rather than the traditional binary choices of "she/her/hers" or "he/him/his."

**For other life** (fauna, flora, etc.), **including most animals, use it and its.** The only exceptions are references to animals with established gender, such as a pet. In those cases, binary singular pronouns are OK (e.g., "scratched her ears" and "wagged his tail").

**For inanimate objects, including ships, planes, automobiles, guns, etc., use it and its.** Sometimes, we interview people who prefer "she" or "he" in these contexts (e.g., the nautical tradition of using female pronouns for some vessels). While this usage is fine in directly transcribed quotes, use it and its outside of quotes, including in paraphrases (e.g., "its engine" rather than "her engine").


**2\. Wrong word** **('they' rather than 'it')**
In Britain, words such as “**company**” and “**government**” are frequently treated as collective nouns that can be plural or singular. But in Canada such constructions (the “company are” and the “government have”) are generally viewed as wrong. **CBC News treats these words as singular**, which means we use the pronoun “it” not “they.”


> _The **company** has been losing money for the past two years. But **they’ve** come up with a plan to try to increase sales._

> Since the word company is singular, the second sentence should be: "_But **it’s** come up with a plan …_"

> The **_government_** is planning to introduce new legislation this fall. **They** hope the expanded food protection program will be in place by the end of the year.

> Since the word government is singular, the second sentence should be: “_It hopes the expanded …_”


For a more detailed look at collective nouns that can be singular or plural (e.g., couple and family) see [verb agreement.](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/v/verb-agreement/ "Verb agreement")


**3\. Ambiguity** **(Does 'he' refer to Smith or Williams?)**
**Guard against muddy meaning. Rewrite as required.**


> _Turner will meet Wong on Friday. **He** asked for the meeting to get more details about the proposed merger._
>
> Who asked for the meeting? Turner or Wong?
>
> _The witness testified that after Smith talked to Williams, **he** ran out of the building screaming that **he** planned to kill him._
>
> Who ran out of the building? Smith? Williams? The witness? And was “he” running away scared or running away in a mad fit threatening murder?


**When you use _they, he, her, it_, etc. make sure that the identity of the person or thing is 100 per cent clear** or rewrite the sentence. **The easiest solution is to repeat the noun** (e.g., Smith or Williams). **Breaking up long confusing sentences is always helpful too:**


> _The witness said Smith talked to Williams the day of the murder. According to her testimony, **Smith** then ran out of the building screaming that **Williams** planned to hill him._


Writers often have alternatives. In this example, a term such as “the accused” would work in place of the first “Williams” if it’s clear from the story that Williams is on trial. Otherwise, repeat the name Williams as shown.

See also [I versus me](/home/i/i-versus-me), [who versus whom](/home/w/who-versus-whom), [it's versus its](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/i/its-versus-its/ "Its versus its") and [grammar](/handy-links/grammar).


### Prostitute

**Prostitute, sex-trade worker, etc.**

Clarity, neutrality and relevance help guide us when we choose language to describe women or men who receive payment for sexual services.


**Clarity and neutrality**
**The term "prostitute" is often the first choice because it's clearest.** The word is common and direct without being glib or glamorous. Despite some objections to the word, prostitute is an entrenched part of everyday writing and speech. As a verb, in fact, its meaning has widened to include people who sell themselves in a figurative rather than in a literal sense (e.g., "Art critics say the painter is prostituting his skills").

**The term "sex-trade worker" is also OK, although it's comparatively roundabout and vague.** Technically, people who answer phones at brothels also work in the sex trade. So do prostitutes' chauffeurs, [porn stars](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/p/pornography/ "Pornography") and so forth. In our journalism, **if a woman or man wants to be known as a sex-trade worker, we generally follow that preference, as long as the context of the story makes the meaning clear.** We do not adopt euphemisms to cloud what can be a very gritty reality.

**Do not use pejorative terms like "whore." And generally avoid colloquial words such as "hooker" in routine news coverage** because the tone is often inappropriate. **Terms such as "escort" or "streetwalker" may be OK in second reference**, depending on whether the context makes the facts clear. For example, if a story focuses on traffic jams in a red-light district, the term "streetwalker" might be suitable.

**The word "john"** (lowercase) **is acceptable and widely understood**, but since the tone is very informal **it's often preferable to use "client" or "customer."** People arrested for solicitation are sometimes asked to attend "john schools."


**Relevance**
**Labels can be dehumanizing.** In a story about murdered women, for instance, it's important to include the accused killer's relationship with the victims (e.g., police say they were hitchhikers, police say they were working as prostitutes). But it's insensitive and unnecessary to repeatedly refer to the missing or dead women as prostitutes throughout a story. In other words, **terms such as "prostitute" and "sex-trade worker" must be used with care and for specific editorial reasons.**

### protest

**Protest, protest against; avoid protest 'for'**

**The word protest means to express opposition or disapproval****, whether a noun** ("a protest on Parliament Hill") **a verb** ("they protest the recent pension cuts") **or a modifier** ("a protest vote"). Even in the infrequent sense of a solemn oath ("to protest one's innocence") or in phrasing that echoes Shakespeare ("critics say he protests too much"), dissent, disavowal or other forms of disagreement are central.


**This fact has a bearing on which prepositions** (by, over, under) **we pick in certain contexts**:

[protest against](/home/p/protest#protest_against) (common and fine)
[protest 'for'](/home/p/protest#protest_for) (discouraged, if not actually nonsensical)
[by, over, under, etc.
](/home/p/protest#protest_by_over)

## **Protest against**

**It's a myth that "protest against" should be avoided** because "against" is already implied by the verb. **The construction is entrenched and acceptable**, going back more than a century in North America. **It's also a myth that "protest" cannot be used intransitively. The verb may or may not take a direct object**, depending on the choice of the writer or speaker:


> They **_protested_** NATO-led bombing. (TRANSITIVE VERB)
>
> They **_protested against_** the war. (INTRANSITIVE VERB)


**Either construction is fine.** The first illustrates protest as transitive verb because the focus of the action is a direct object: the bombing. The second illustrates protest as an intransitive verb because it's followed by a prepositional phrase ("against the war") rather than by a direct object.

## **Protest 'for'**

**Avoid "protest for" as a synonym for championing a given cause.** Since protest means to oppose, it's odd and potentially confusing to use the word this way. **To keep sentences clear, pick a different verb** with a broader meaning (e.g., **fight for, lobby for, campaign for**).

For instance, people can fight for free trade and protest against protectionism, but it's not instantly clear how people can "protest for" free trade. **When we adopt the verb "protest" in the context of arguing "for" something** instead of arguing against it,, **we gain nothing but risk jarring some in our audience** — who are left wondering how one can express opposition "for" something. **To many, it's as foreign as saying "promote against."**

In the relatively rare, narrow sense of advocacy, of course, **"protest for" is perfectly acceptable when "for" means on behalf of someone** (e.g., to protest for abused children).

## **By, over, under, etc.**

**Careful writers pay attention to the prepositions they pair with protest.** Here are some distinctions worth observing:


> **protest against** (to voice disapproval; demonstrate opposition) NOTE: "Protest against" is **almost always recommended over "protest of"** and other comparatively vague and unorthodox constructions because "against" better underscores the sense of opposition to something (e.g., "a protest against the mine" instead of "a protest of the mine").
>
> **protest by** (to identify participants, such as students, workers).
>
> **protest for** (to demonstrate on behalf of someone; otherwise avoid for [reasons outlined above](/home/p/protest#protest_against)).
>
> **protest over** (to identify a campaign's cause; to specify what's being opposed, such as budget cuts, war). NOTE: **protest about** is OK, too, especially when "protest" is a noun (e.g., "two protests about pipelines").
>
> **under protest** (to do something unwillingly).


Other constructions commonly describe dates, times, physical locations and conditions (**protest in, protest on, protest at**), as in a "protest in the rain" and a "protest at noon." For this reason, the compounds "protest over" or "protest about" are generally better than the sometimes-used "**protest at**" when specifying the theme or purpose of a demonstration: "A protest over sex education curriculum."

For consistency, **use the spelling protester** instead of "protestor."


See also [grammar](/handy-links/grammar)
See also [protest, protester](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/p/protest_protester/ "Protest_Protester")
See also [civil disturbances](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fio.cbcrc.ca%2F%23%2Fresources%2Fcivil-disturbances-troubles-et-desordres-1.4517514&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1rVC7eMmEVDfkTt9oAo2FF) for related Journalistic Standards and Practices policy on covering riots, demonstrations, etc.


### protester

**Protest, protester**

**Both are generally good default choices** when covering different types of demonstrations.

## Protest

**Protest is a clear, common and neutral noun**, often used in its attributive form (e.g., "a protest march"). It's also a broad  term, which means that **reporting specific facts about a given protest are important**. Are people on the move? Is a road or bridge being blocked? Have police been called?

There's **no time limit to protests.** A rally might wrap up after a few hours, but a hunger strike could last days or weeks, and some past anti-logging demonstrations have gone on for months. They're all considered protests.

**Be mindful of unintended meaning when considering synonyms.**

**Demonstration** is common and acceptable across the board, although the clipped form "demo" can introduce a casual tone that may not match a given story.

**Rally** generally implies a peaceful gathering where supporters have gathered to listen to speeches (e.g., a political rally). Given its close association with positive movement upward (e.g., a stock price rally, a trailing team's rally to win a game, an ill patient's sudden recovery), **rally is usually not a good choice to describe controversial protests involving violence or threats of violence**, confrontations with authorities, etc.

**Standoff** is fine when there's an impasse between protesters and authorities, or between two different groups (e.g., protesters and counter-protesters).

**Blockade** is suitable when vehicles and people are prevented from travelling forward (e.g., a road blockade, a bridge blockage, a rail blockade). If traffic is merely slowed, stories should make this clear (e.g., a **partial blockade** of a border crossing).

Other specific labels are OK as long as the facts match, including various nouns formed out of verbs (e.g., **march, sit-in, walkout**).

**Attribute contestable terms, such as "occupation," unless the facts incontrovertibly match** (e.g., an MP's office has been taken over and locked). The word occupation normally implies more than merely trespassing or, say, a few vehicles blocking some downtown streets. Occupation generally conveys the sense that one or more people effectively control access to a given area, have set up camps to live in, and are preventing authorities, journalists and passersby from walking into the space without permission. So while a protest can occupy one or more streets for an extended period, the demonstration, itself, is not necessarily an "occupation." **NOTE: If some protesters dig in for days or weeks, refusing to leave roadways or land that isn't theirs, despite repeated requests by authorities to move on, then the noun "occupation" might apply without attribution. In those cases, however, it's still important to be precise to avoid misleading phrasing** (e.g., "an occupation of some streets around Parliament Hill" rather than the "Ottawa occupation"). If uncertain whether the language is accurate, check with your supervisor. 

## Protester

**Protester is considered a neutral, fact-based description of anyone demonstrating for or against something**  — from environmental critics opposing government policy to human rights supporters rallying to defend victims of violence. **Demonstrator is common and fine as a synonym** for protester, but note that the suffixes are spelled differently (i.e., _\-or_ versus _\-er_).

Be aware that some activists object to the term "protester" in certain contexts, such as when they're on their own land fighting annexation or development. Our core journalistic principles of accuracy, fairness and impartiality guide us. **We don't adopt one side's preferred terminology** (e.g., "land defenders" or "environmental champions") **without attribution for the same reason we don't adopt another side's terminology** (e.g., "injunction violators" or "pipeline obstructionists") without attribution.

**There's no reason to insist on the word protester in all cases**, as long as fact-based, neutral alternatives exists (e.g., "landowner" instead of "protester" in a dispute over property rights). **But "protester" is often a good choice when demonstrations go beyond mere public rallies, and start disrupting the livelihoods of ordinary citizens** (e.g., traffic jams, bridge closures, railway blockades, office occupations).

See also [protest (v.)](/home/p/protest), as in protest against, protest over, etc.
See also [hunger strike](/home/h/hunger-strike)
See also [civil disturbances](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fio.cbcrc.ca%2F%23%2Fresources%2Fcivil-disturbances-troubles-et-desordres-1.4517514&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1rVC7eMmEVDfkTt9oAo2FF) for related Journalistic Standards and Practices policy on covering riots, demonstrations, etc.


### protester

**Protest, protester**

**Both are generally good default choices** when covering different types of demonstrations.

## Protest

**Protest is a clear, common and neutral noun**, often used in its attributive form (e.g., "a protest march"). It's also a broad  term, which means that **reporting specific facts about a given protest are important**. Are people on the move? Is a road or bridge being blocked? Have police been called?

There's **no time limit to protests.** A rally might wrap up after a few hours, but a hunger strike could last days or weeks, and some past anti-logging demonstrations have gone on for months. They're all considered protests.

**Be mindful of unintended meaning when considering synonyms.**

**Demonstration** is common and acceptable across the board, although the clipped form "demo" can introduce a casual tone that may not match a given story.

**Rally** generally implies a peaceful gathering where supporters have gathered to listen to speeches (e.g., a political rally). Given its close association with positive movement upward (e.g., a stock price rally, a trailing team's rally to win a game, an ill patient's sudden recovery), **rally is usually not a good choice to describe controversial protests involving violence or threats of violence**, confrontations with authorities, etc.

**Standoff** is fine when there's an impasse between protesters and authorities, or between two different groups (e.g., protesters and counter-protesters).

**Blockade** is suitable when vehicles and people are prevented from travelling forward (e.g., a road blockade, a bridge blockage, a rail blockade). If traffic is merely slowed, stories should make this clear (e.g., a **partial blockade** of a border crossing).

Other specific labels are OK as long as the facts match, including various nouns formed out of verbs (e.g., **march, sit-in, walkout**).

**Attribute contestable terms, such as "occupation," unless the facts incontrovertibly match** (e.g., an MP's office has been taken over and locked). The word occupation normally implies more than merely trespassing or, say, a few vehicles blocking some downtown streets. Occupation generally conveys the sense that one or more people effectively control access to a given area, have set up camps to live in, and are preventing authorities, journalists and passersby from walking into the space without permission. So while a protest can occupy one or more streets for an extended period, the demonstration, itself, is not necessarily an "occupation." **NOTE: If some protesters dig in for days or weeks, refusing to leave roadways or land that isn't theirs, despite repeated requests by authorities to move on, then the noun "occupation" might apply without attribution. In those cases, however, it's still important to be precise to avoid misleading phrasing** (e.g., "an occupation of some streets around Parliament Hill" rather than the "Ottawa occupation"). If uncertain whether the language is accurate, check with your supervisor.

Be aware that some activists object to the term "protester" in certain contexts, such as when they're on their own land fighting annexation or development. Our core journalistic principles of accuracy, fairness and impartiality guide us. **We don't adopt one side's preferred terminology** (e.g., "land defenders" or "environmental champions") **without attribution for the same reason we don't adopt another side's terminology** (e.g., "injunction violators" or "pipeline obstructionists") without attribution.

### Provinces and cities

**Provinces, territories and cities**

[Abbreviating](/home/p/provinces-and-cities#abbreviating) (Alta., not AB)

[Alternative forms and spellings](/home/p/provinces-and-cities#alternative-spellings) (Magdalen Islands not Îles-de-la-Madeleine)

**Abbreviating**

**NOTE: This section focuses on standard text in stories**, including headlines, subheads, photo captions and the main bodies of web articles. **Maps, graphics, etc., sometimes require more condensed abbreviations**, as noted below.


**With the exception of** British Columbia **(B.C.)**, Prince Edward Island **(P.E.I.) and** the Northwest Territories **(N.W.T.), do not abbreviate provincial or territorial names unless they appear after cities, towns or other communities in the body of a story:**


> _They bought a farm near Estevan, Sask., in 1955.
> __She was born in Quebec in 1970.
> __He died in a plane crash near Fort McPherson, N.W.T., three years ago._


**In these cases, always use a comma after the community and a second comma after the province or territory. NOTE: When the geographical reference is used as compound adjective, however, it's generally best to recast the sentence** so that the second comma doesn't disrupt the sentence's flow.


> _They started a Surrey, B.C., company that created jobs for dozens of ..._ (OK but somewhat jarring)
> _They started a company in Surrey, B.C., that created jobs for dozens of ..._ (Preferred)


**Never shorten [Yukon](/home/y/yukon) or Nunavut:**


> _They plan to visit **Yukon** this summer.
> The fire began at the base of a mountain near **Faro, Yukon**, a community of about 500 people.
> She married an Inuk artist and moved to **Pangnirtung, Nunavut**, in 1988._


**When abbreviations are appropriate, use the following:
**

> **Alta.** (Alberta)
> **B.C.** (British Columbia)
> **Sask.** (Saskatchewan)
> **Man.** (Manitoba)
> **Ont.** (Ontario)
> **Que.** (Quebec)
> **N.B.** (New Brunswick)
> **N.S.** (Nova Scotia)
> **P.E.I.** (Prince Edward Island, [the Island](/home/i#island) in later references)
> **N.L.** ([Newfoundland and Labrador](/home/n/newfoundland-and-labrador)), but see the note about web headlines below

> **Nunavut** (no abbreviation - see above)

> **N.W.T.** (Northwest Territories, _not_ "North West")

> **Yukon** (no abbreviation - see above)


**Never drop the periods in this geographical shorthand.** Standard abbreviations for provinces and territories include punctuation (e.g., Alta., Ont. and N.L.), according to the Geographical Names Board of Canada (GNBC). Postal code "symbols" (AB, ON and NL), by contrast, do not. Details can be found on page 36 (appendix 8) of the GNBC's booklet, [Principles and Procedures for Geographical Naming](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/media/if1lijp4/gnbc_principles-and-procedure-a616765edcebb503.pdf "GNBC_Principles-and-Procedure-a616765edcebb503.pdf"). **We prefer standard geographical abbreviations in our journalism rather than postal code shorthand.** This matches the official style at all major news organizations across the country, including CP. It's also the recommended style for all federal government departments, as outlined in [The Canadian Style manual](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.btb.termiumplus.gc.ca%2Ftcdnstyl-chap%3Flang%3Deng%26lettr%3Dchapsect1%26info0%3D1.09&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0gPrm0CwETjsdHJwn75Tu1) published by Public Works Canada.

See also the [**abbreviations overview**](/home/a/abbreviations#propernouns-geocomponents) for guidelines on handling geographical components of proper nouns (e.g., B.C. Hydro but WorkSafeBC).

**In web headlines**, provincial abbreviations are often used to save space. But they're not mandatory (e.g., Alberta or Alta. are both fine). **Do not shorten Yukon or Nunavut. Do not abbreviate Canada or Canadian** outside of currency references (see [Money](/home/m/money#CdnUS) for details). The abbreviation **Nfld.** is sometimes used in web headlines, but only in rare cases when referring to the island itself (e.g., "southern Nfld," spelled out as "southern Newfoundland" in the main story). Otherwise, the shorthand is [N.L.](/home/n/newfoundland-and-labrador) **Labrador is never abbreviated when used on its own**, even in web headlines.

**In maps and other graphics**, **two-character "postal" abbreviations are acceptable because of severe space constraints.** For consistency, follow official shorthand established in a given region (e.g., [Canada Post](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.canadapost.ca%2Ftools%2Fpg%2Fmanual%2FPGaddress-e.asp%3Fecid%3Dmurl10006450&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0uGjYJduIsr9rYPKHHsn11), the [U.S. Postal Service](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fpe.usps.com%2Ftext%2Fpub28%2F28apb.htm&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0O24qE5qIEDxSJH_WXvCUX)). This means AB and MB for Alberta and Manitoba, and AL and MA for Alabama and Massachusetts in maps, graphics, etc. Be aware that two-character postal short forms have no periods or other punctuation because they're treated as "symbols" rather than true abbreviations, along the lines of km for kilometre. For instance, the two-character symbol for British Columbia is BC rather than B.C., and the two-character symbol for North Dakota is ND rather than N.D.


**Alternative forms and spellings**
**We normally use one spelling of geographical names across platforms.** It often boils down to accuracy (e.g., the Ontario city of St. Catharines has only one "e" and no possessive apostrophe). But occasionally there are competing, equally correct forms, and we pick a preference (e.g., senior CBC News management in Quebec recommends [Magdalen Islands](/home/m#Magdalen_Islands) instead of Îles-de-la-Madeleine based on entrenched English usage).

**In rare cases, a geographical name may depend on the context and platform.** For instance, a conurbation such as Kitchener-Waterloo (also known as the separate Ontario cities of Kitchener and Waterloo), as well as [Minneapolis-St. Paul](/home/m#Minneapolis) (also known as the separate Minnesota cities of Minneapolis and St. Paul) may or may not feature the conjunction "and." The same is true of an archipelago like [St-Pierre-Miquelon](/home/s#St-Pierre-Miquelon), which might be read on air differently as either St-Pierre-et-Miquelon (with the French conjunction "et"), or even as Saint Pierre and Miquelon (with the English conjunction "and," the hyphens dropped and "Saint" spelled out). **In other words, there is a degree of latitude with certain proper nouns, especially if adding or removing hyphens, conjunctions, etc., makes broadcast scripts more conversational.** The main criterion is whether the specific form chosen is already entrenched as an alternative.


**Web stories: Montreal but 'Milk River, Alta.,'**
**Since online articles are often read by people outside a given province or territory, it's important to make the story's location clear. Never assume that context will automatically be provided for our audience.**

For instance, a headline is also a "headlink" on its own (appearing in lists of other headlines on various web pages, portable devices, etc.). People will not have the benefit of seeing the lead, a photo or anything else that could shed extra light on the headline's wording. So the headlink must be as clear as possible on its own. A story may also be simultaneously displayed on various CBCNews.ca pages (e.g., in the online service's national lineup) rather than just on a given regional site. This means that surrounding clues, such as a provincial banner or other geographical marker, may not be present for a substantial percentage of our audience.

Instead of using placelines (uppercase indicators, such as SURREY, B.C., that suggest a writer is actually filing from that particular community), **CBCNews.ca identifies the specific province high up —usually in the headline, deck** (secondary headline) **or lead**. Local readers who already know this information will generally accept that the news is being presented to a national or global audience. Everyone else will benefit from the extra detail.

**In a headline, only the province** (B.C.) **or municipality** (Surrey) **needs to be included.

In the main body of the story, however, most Canadian communities must be identified by more than their name. We generally add the province or territory** (Surrey, B.C.), **even if this detail is already in the headline:**

> _They drove to Milk River, Alta., on Saturday._


**Exceptions are made for well-known spots** (_She moved to Montreal in 1969_ ), **as well as for other places when the story has already established the location.** If a piece focuses on aid to farmers hurt by a severe drought in southern Saskatchewan, for example, we can write _Moose Jaw_ (instead of _Moose Jaw, Sask._,) midway through the copy:

> _Some crops near Moose Jaw were wiped out by hail._

**Generic words such as city, town and village are generally kept lowercase** (e.g., "near the town of Biggar, Sask.") But on rare occasions when we're referring to the proper legal name of a community (e.g., in a lawsuit against "the City of Calgary"), then a capital letter is required. See the separate entries on [City](/home/c#city), [Town](/home/t#town) and [Village](/home/v#village) for other examples.

**Spellings and maps
****For the spellings of domestic place names** (cities, towns, lakes, rivers, etc.), **consult the [Canadian Geographical Names Database](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww4.rncan.gc.ca%2Fsearch-place-names%2Fsearch%3Flang%3Den&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2lOY1kZcpa3sVZHHX8XWOf)** published by Natural Resources Canada. To find the spot on a map, go to the federal government's [Atlas of Canada](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nrcan.gc.ca%2Fearth-sciences%2Fgeography%2Fatlas-canada&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2KYnGQVzp6PBFC51ieot7A).

**In rare cases, geographical names are known by more than one spelling.** When a local preference has clearly become entrenched (e.g., the [**St. John River**](/home/s/st-saint-ste) instead of the "Saint John River" in New Brunswick), we adopt this conventional spelling if there's other official support for it (e.g., the provincial government uses St. John River most of the time). Such exceptions are listed in this intranet site's A to Z index.

**For communities outside of Canada, we rely on the National Geographic Atlas of the World**, but check the Language Guide for any spelling exceptions first (e.g., we write Bangkok, Dunkirk and _Taipei_). These exceptions are often English versions of local spellings that have become entrenched over time (e.g., _Rome_ instead of _Roma_).

**Q** 

**_Q_** (CBC Radio program) Launched as **_Q_** in 2007, the name was formally changed to lowercase _**q**_ from 2015 until early 2021. It's since been officially rebranded with a capital _Q_. For consistency, **use _Q_** in all references to the program, regardless of the specific year cited. See also [CBC](/home/c/cbc#unorthodox_typography) and [italics](/handy-links/punctuation/italics).

**Q&A** (no hyphens or spaces) The abbreviation stands for the singular **question and answer** (n.), and **question-and-answer** (adj.), as in a Q&A session. The plural is **Q&As**, akin to VIPs and FAQs. (See also [ampersand](/home/a/ampersand))

**qamutik** (Inuit sled towed behind a snowmobile or dog team) Use this spelling, not "komatik" or other variations.

**Qatar**

**QR code** (fine in first reference) Stands for "quick response code," but the abbreviation is now virtually never spelled out. QR codes typically contain text and numerical data that can be read by various devices, including smartphone apps. The now-ubiquitous squares filled with tiny monochromatic block patterns were first used in Japan in the mid-1990s.

**Q-Tips** ([trademark](/home/t/trade-names) for cotton swabs on a stick)

**quadriplegic** (see [disability terms](/home/d/disability-language#quadriplegic))

**Quakers** (an acceptable term for all references to the Society of Friends and its members)

**quandary**

**quarantine, self-quarantine** (hyphen) Refers to separating one or more people from the rest of a community, usually to try to stop the spread of a virus, infectious disease, etc. Quarantines can be ordered by authorities or self-imposed. Distinguish between **mandatory** and **voluntary** isolation whenever the detail is not obvious from context. Although the word quarantine literally means "40 days" in Italian, specific duration varies widely, depending on circumstances (e.g., a **10-day quarantine**, a **two-week quarantine**). It's **OK to use quarantine and isolation interchangeably** in most news stories (e.g., **self-isolation**). Be aware that some health authorities reserve "isolation" for confirmed cases of infection and "quarantine" for possible or suspected cases. These narrower definitions are debatable. Furthermore, such contested nuance is lost on most of our audience given widespread generic use of the words as synonyms. However, if officials in a given jurisdiction are stressing a distinction, and if the detail is relevant to given coverage (e.g., it helps put a given quote into context), then it's a good idea to point this out in a story whenever practical. We always distinguish between indisputably factual differences in medical stories (e.g., diagnosis vs. prognosis, and virus vs. bacteria). But when vernacular is less clearcut, we take into account entrenched, generic meanings of words to avoid confusing our audience (e.g., we do not restrict the words "mania" or "phobia" to narrowly defined clinical definitions). See [health reporting](/home/h/health_reporting#accuracy) for details and related principles.

**quarterfinal** (hyphen dropped to match **semifinal**)

****quarter-horse*

*quartet*

*quarto, quartos****

**quaver, quavering** (a sound, especially a voice, that vibrates or trembles)

**Quebec** (no accent in geographical name; abbreviated as **Que.**) Using "Que." instead of Quebec in web headlines is optional (See [provinces and cities](/home/p/provinces-and-cities)); **Quebec City** (not Ville de Québec), but **Hydro-Québec**, etc. (See [French words in our English journalism](/home/f/french-words-and-accents) for detailed guidelines)

**Quebec Bar** (instead of Barreau du Québec) Avoid adding "Association" to the translated proper noun (i.e., use Quebec Bar rather than "Quebec Bar Association"), based on entrenched usage. OK to use the bar, the organization, the association, etc., lowercase in second reference. See [French](/home/f/french-words-and-accents#bar) for details, other examples, and related guidelines.

**Québec Solidaire** (not _Québec solidaire_) The abbreviation **QS** is fine in second reference, even though this political party is not as well known as PQ or ADQ. See [French words and accents](/home/f/french-words-and-accents) for relevant capitalization guidelines.

**Quebecer** (_not_ -cker)

**Québécois, [Parti Québécois](/home/p#PQ) (PQ), Bloc Québécois (the Bloc** preferred to **BQ)** See also [Party versus party](/home/p/party)

**Quebecor** (OK in first reference to **Quebecor Inc.**) The company adopted an accent in the French version of its name (Québecor) in 2012, but the English version remains without an accent. See [French](/home/f/french-words-and-accents) for detailed guidelines on handling French words in our English journalism, including [names of organizations](/home/f/french-words-and-accents#namesoforganizations) (e.g., Hydro-Québec but Quebecor).

**Quebec provincial police** (lowercase, no abbreviation) See [Sûreté du Québec](/home/s#SQ) for guidelines on use of the French noun and the short form SQ, as well as [police forces](/home/p/police-forces).

**Queen** (of the U.K. and Canada); former British monarchs retain a capital "Q," as in **Queen Victoria** and the **former Queen**; use **queen** lowercase when referring to the monarchs of other countries, as in **former queen Astrid** of Belgium, unless the title appears before the name of the reigning queen (e.g., Queen Silvia of Sweden but the queen of Sweden). See [**royal titles**](/home/r/royal-titles) for detailed guidelines, including the difference between **Queen Consort** and Queen dowager, and why it's normally unnecessary to use roman numerals when referring to Elizabeth (i.e., **Queen Elizabeth** rather than Queen Elizabeth II).

**Queen Elizabeth 2** (ocean liner), **QE2**

**Queen Elizabeth Way** (the QEW, but avoid in national stories) A highway in southern Ontario named after the _Queen Mother_, not her daughter the Queen.

**Quebec lieutenant** (lowercase) This is a commonly used term applied to a federal cabinet minister from Quebec who advises the prime minister on matters involving that province. This person often runs the federal party's organization in Quebec as well.

**Queen Mother** (1900-2002) The widow of King George VI. Do not use her name, as in "Queen Mother Elizabeth," because of confusion with her daughter, Queen Elizabeth. Instead, write "the Queen's mother" (possessive) or "the Queen Mother" (the Queen dowager's designation for about 50 years). The term **Queen Mum** is fine in second reference and headlines. (See also [**royal titles**](/home/r/royal-titles) for more details about the Queen dowager versus the Queen Consort)

**queer** (still considered highly offensive by many) See [**2SLGBTQ+**](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/l/2slgbtq/#queer "2SLGBTQ+") for guidelines on limited use

**Quebec National Assembly** (the **National Assembly** in second reference) See also [legislative bodies](/home/l/legislative-bodies) for related guidelines, including capitalization style.

**Queen's Park** (see also [Ontario Legislature](/home/o#OntarioLegislature)), **Queen's Plate, Queen's Printer, Queen's University** (Kingston, Ont.)

**Queensberry Rules** (the standard rules, especially when referring to boxing)

**question-and-answer** (adj.), as in "a question-and-answer session" (See also [Q&A](/home/q#Q&A))

****questionnaire****

**question period** (lowercase)

**queue** (a line of people) _Do not confuse with_ **cue** (a prompt or billiards stick)

****quiche Lorraine****

**quick** (adj. and adv.) The preferred adverb is **quickly**, but quick is also acceptable in some cases. As an adverb, quick is most commonly found in idiomatic expressions, such as "Get rich quick."

**Quiet Revolution** (A period of major social, economic and educational reform in Quebec between 1960 and 1966, when Jean Lesage was premier.) See [historical periods](/home/h/historical-periods)

**Quonset, Quonset hut** ([trademark](/home/t/trade-names) for a prefabricated metal building commonly found on farms) Named after Quonset Point, R.I., where it was first made.

**quote, quotes** (acceptable abbreviations for the nouns "quotation" and "quotations")

**Qur'an** (not Koran) See also [transliterations](/home/t/transliterations)

For rules on when to capitalize "prime minister," see [titles](/home/t/titles).
