### Quirky capitalization

**eBay, iTunes and other** **quirky capitalization**

Most proper nouns begin with a capital letter (_Ford_). Some are made up of more than one word (_Canadian Broadcasting Corporation_). A few are fused (such as the old _SkyDome_, renamed the _Rogers Centre_ in February 2005).

**We generally adopt the original form of names**, including routine references to companies (_Microsoft_), computer software (_FrontPage_) and many other proper nouns ([_ChatGPT_](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/c/#ChatGPT "C")), **unless (i) they're difficult to read** (_Kazaa_ not _KaZaA_), **(ii) are all lowercase or all uppercase** without being actual abbreviations (_Adidas_ not _adidas_, _Craigslist_ not _craigslist_, _Imax_ not _IMAX_, _Kiss_ not _KISS_, _Lego_ not _LEGO_, _Lululemon_ not _lululemon_, _Nabisco_ not _NABISCO_, _Nasdaq_ not _NASDAQ_, _Nike_ not _NIKE_, the PBS program _Nova_ not _NOVA_, _Scrabble_ not _SCRABBLE_, _Via_ not _VIA_, _Visa_ not _VISA_), **or (iii) use a jarring uppercase graphical treatment** of what normally would be lowercase lettering (_Athletes Can_ not _Athletes CAN_ and _Nav Canada_ not _NAV Canada_):


> **eBay** (but EBay at the start of a sentence)
> **ePub** as in an ePub file (but EPub at the start of a sentence)
> **iMac** (but IMac at the start of a sentence)
> **iPods** (but IPods at the start of a sentence)
> **iTunes** (but ITunes at the start of a sentence)
> **MuchMusic
> ****PowerPoint** (proprietary computer software)
> **Teleprompter** (not TelePrompTer)
> **WestJet
> ****WikiLeaks**


We avoid most all-lowercase names in published news stories. And while we normally restrict all-uppercase nouns to initialisms, such as CD-ROM, exceptions are made when there are compelling editorial reasons (e.g., the CIA code name **[MK-ULTRA](/home/m#MK-ULTRA)**).

**How to handle specific, unorthodox lettering sometimes boils down to individual judgment.** For example, the Calgary-based company **ReSourceYYC** is OK because it's reasonably close to modern, standard publishing norms (e.g., **ePub** and **HarperCollins**), and there's no point trying to muck around with a name that begins with an initial cap, and then includes a limited number of other initials caps later. By contrast, "EVOLVsolar" and "geoLOGIC" would we written as **EvolvSolar** and **GeoLogic** because the original versions are harder to read quickly — appearing more like typos than intended text. Bear in mind that companies, themselves, can be inconsistent in their own marketing (e.g., in 2019, "EVOLVsolar" graphics were commonly rendered as the equivalent of "EVOLVSOLAR," but with uppercase "SOLAR" in a smaller point size and a different colour).

For the purposes of our journalism, therefore, **it's OK to change typography slightly to make words clearer, to keep text consistent with CBC in-house style, etc.** This lets us put the interests of our audience first (e.g., to boost comprehension, to steer clear of "shouted" uppercase advertising, like "VISA" instead of Visa). It also allows us to retain editorial control (e.g., to censor anything potentially offensive, such as the F-word or other profanity embedded in proper nouns). **But when imposing something as basic as more standardized capitalization, we should always respect the spirit of the non-traditional lettering** (e.g., "EVOLVsolar" becomes "EvolvSolar" rather than "Evolvsolar" because the capital S helps the word "Solar" stand out — which is clearly intended, based on the company's use of colour, font size, etc., in its logos.

**If fiddling with an unorthodox combination of uppercase and lowercase characters makes a name harder to read** (e.g., _Outtv_) or the exact opposite of the original (e.g., _OutTV_), **then we generally leave the noun untouched** (e.g., _OUTtv_). Since companies can change their branding on a whim, altering what is and is not capitalized without notice or explanation, it's worth remembering that some of these nouns wind up having relatively short shelf lives (e.g., _ROBTv_ became _BNN_ within a few years, and the analytics company **_comScore_** switched to **_Comscore_**). 

Keep in mind that some forms used in generic constructions (e.g., [e-](/handy-links/punctuation/hyphens#email) as in _e-book_ and _e-health_) may be altered in proper nouns (e.g., **eHealth Ontario**, which has no hyphen.

**If a proper noun is identified as an abbreviation**, whether pronounceable as an [acronym](/home/a/acronyms) or not, **all-uppercase letters are fine** (e.g., the company _DAVE Wireless_ instead of _Dave Wireless_). But if the proper noun is not immediately thought of as an abbreviation, or has been conventionally treated as a word rather than as an abbreviation (e.g., the musical group _Abba_ instead of _ABBA_), only an initial capital letter is generally used. The best test is whether the name is spelled out at least once in a story:

> Data & Audio-Visual Enterprises Wireless (**DAVE**) calls its new cellular service Mobilicity.
>
> He hummed an **Abba** song while she steeped the tea. \[The musical group is not spelled out.\]


**Since we're writing words, not logos, we drop unorthodox or superfluous punctuation**, such as the **!** after _Bravo_ and Yahoo and _Mamma Mia_ (the musical), the \* in _\*NSYNC_ (which we write as '_N Sync_), and the asterisk at the end of _Walmart_. Note: For years, Walmart's official logo was all uppercase with a star in the middle (WAL\*MART). But most news organizations, including CBCNews.ca, used a hyphen and limited capitalization (_Wal-Mart_) instead. The company eventually adopted a fused form ([Walmart](/home/n/names-versus-logos#Walmart)).

In 2000, The Canadian Press ruled that virtually all proper nouns must begin with capital letters (so _eBay_ became _EBay_). But a few years later, it began writing _iTunes_ not _ITunes_ so the policy wasn't consistent. In 2005, CP added the entry "IPod not iPod" to its revised Caps and Spelling manual. We, however, continued to use iPod and eBay for the reasons outlined above. In mid-2008, CP revised its style to iPod and eBay as well.

CBC News agrees with the Washington Post and many other publications that are relatively relaxed about lowercase letters at the beginning of proper nouns, as long as a capital letter appears soon afterward. One of the Post's former senior editors, Bill Walsh, says it's no more jarring than writing _van Gogh_ or _de Gaulle_.

**Note: Sentences and headlines almost always start with a capital letter, even in the case of most quirky nouns that are lowercase**, such as eBay or k.d. lang — which should be posted as **EBay** and **K.d. lang** at the start of sentences (or as **Lang** alone, if it's a second reference).

See also [names versus logos](/home/n/names-versus-logos) for additional examples
See also [capitalization](/home/c/capitalization) (an overview)
See also [CBC](/home/c/cbc) for guidelines on handling program, channel and website names
See also [internet terms](/home/i/internet-terms)
See also [trade names](/home/t/trade-names)

### Quotes editing

**Editing quotes on CBCNews.ca**

[Verbatim defined](/home/q/quotes-editing#verbatim) (limits on 'cleaning up')

[Examples of edits](/home/q/quotes-editing#examples) (cutting, clarifying)
[Bad grammar](/home/q/quotes-editing#badgrammar) (fixing versus retaining)
[Capital letter latitude](/home/q/quotes-editing#capital) (We not \[W\]e)
[Attribution](/home/q/quotes-editing#attribution) (can be a substitute for an ellipsis)

[Pronunciations](/home/q/quotes-editing#gonna) (gonna, gotcha, etc.)
[Instant replay](/home/q/quotes-editing#replay) (repeating audio; rereading quotes)










**Overview**
**Do not invisibly clean up people's quotes on the web by changing syntax, grammar or words, with the exception of removing ums, ehs and other disfluencies** defined under "verbatim" below.

**Use square brackets \[ \] when inserting your own words in quotes to clarify something for readers.** (Examples appear below. See also [brackets](/handy-links/punctuation/brackets) for separate, detailed guidelines.)

**Use an ellipsis (...) to indicate that words have been removed from the middle of a statement, but not from its beginning or end.** (Examples appear below. See also [ellipses](/handy-links/punctuation/ellipses) for separate, detailed guidelines.)

**When chopping words or phrases, never change the meaning of someone's statement** — e.g., avoid distorting "We will probably vote yes" into "We will ... vote yes."


**Verbatim defined**
**Quotation marks indicate that the exact words were spoken or written.

We quote people verbatim, undetectably removing only two types of distracting speech disfluencies** (i.e., cutting them without alerting our website's readers):
**
1\. False starts** (e.g., "ru-re-regardless," which we would transcribe as "regardless").

**2\. Sounds that fill pauses but aren't normally considered words** (e.g., eh, um, er).

**Exception No. 2 has limits.** While it's OK to cut "ah," it's not acceptable to delete "like" or "I mean" or other conversational padding without alerting the reader. So "the inter, intura, I mean intranet" would be transcribed as "the ... intranet."
**Do not _invisibly_ fix bad syntax, poor grammar, etc.** Instead, leave the wording as is, flag the edit or choose a different quote. There are no exceptions.


**Accuracy and transparency**
**Clearer and tougher rules about transcribed speech were introduced at CBCNews.ca in the spring of 2006.** These are stricter than guidelines found in the Canadian Press and Globe and Mail manuals, which give writers and editors vague discretion when "fixing" quotes.

**Under CBCNews.ca's system, the people we quote are treated more consistently.** Our journalists no longer have to waste time debating whether to polish the comments of one person, such as a premier or prime minister, while ignoring the subject-verb disagreement of another.

Some news organizations, such as the New York Times, have had similar policies for years. And a few others, such as the Washington Post, have also recently adopted stricter guidelines on quotes —abandoning the practice of letting writers and editors quietly fix wording between inverted commas.

**Transcribing virtually verbatim quotes increases our website's accuracy.** Since we're a broadcasting corporation, readers are often given the option to click on various audio and video reports, and CBC.ca's wording should match what was said. (Removing disfluencies, such as um, is a publishing convention that helps the reader without requiring judgment calls about fixing grammar or changing diction.)

**The new rules also make our journalism more transparent by clearly disclosing edits** (i.e., ellipses show that words are missing while square brackets indicate that words have been added by our journalists).



**EXAMPLES**

**Fairly and accurately abridging**

Original:

> "My government will act. We're not, uh, going to, to, we're not going to wait another day."


Correct and smooth edit:

> "My government will act," Harper said. "We're not going to wait another day."


Correct but less smooth edit (with ellipsis flush to period, indicating a full stop):

> "My government will act.... We're not going to wait another day," Harper said.


Technically OK but poorer edit because the ellipsis is in an unnatural spot:

> "My government will act. We're not ... going to wait another day."

**Clarifying a word's meaning**
Original:

> "Nobody told us about the, um, dangers. They assured us everything was OK."


Correct edit, removing "um" and clarifying the identity of "they":

> "Nobody told us about the dangers. They \[gondola workers\] assured us everything was OK."

**Fixing grammatical errors**
**If a glaring grammatical blunder is in a quote**, and you've decided you need to use this part of the quote in a story (i.e., you can't shorten the wording or paraphrase), **and if for editorial reasons you've chosen to fix the gaffe, then flag the edit with square brackets.**

Original (the last lines of one of Jean Chrétien's final speeches as prime minister):

> "My friend, I believe in Canada. And it's why I say to yous tonight: _Au revoir, et vive le Canada_ !"


Correct but poor because the edits are distracting:

> "My friend\[s\], I believe in Canada. And it's why I say to \[you\] tonight: _Au revoir, et vive le Canada_ !"


Another less-than-ideal option:

> "I believe in Canada. And it's why I say to \[you\] tonight: _Au revoir, et vive le Canada_ !"


Better choice, if long quote is used:

"I believe in Canada. And it's why I say ... _Au revoir, et vive le Canada_ !"

Best choice:

"I believe in Canada,” Chrétien said as he ended his final speech to the Liberal Party with his trademark rallying cry: "_Vive le Canada_ !"

**The last version is superior because it's accurate, it flows smoothly** (without distracting grammatical revisions) **and it provides our readers with context by pointing out that his final words were very familiar ones.**

(See also [foreign words](/home/f/foreign-words) for detailed guidelines on using accents and italics.)

**Retaining grammatical errors**
**Avoid the instinctive rush to impose rigorous written grammar on natural, spoken English. Doing so can easily ruin quotes.**

For example, do not "clean up" a plural pronoun that should technically be singular as long as the speaker's meaning is clear.

Original (OK to publish):

> "That company poisoned our water. They made people sick. They should pay."


Poor and unnecessarily pedantic edit:

> "That company poisoned our water. \[It\] made people sick. \[It\] should pay."


**Even in the case of subject-verb disagreements, the original quote can be used if it's deemed an asset to the story.**

Original left intact:

> "We makes the money, we should keeps it too," Johnson said.


Poor edit:

> "We \[make\] the money, we should \[keep\] it too," Johnson said.


Fixing the above errors with square brackets would be unsatisfactory because of the number of visible edits in such a short statement.

Keep in mind that the words you're tempted to change have probably already been broadcast on radio or TV. **If you're uncomfortable posting a grammatical construction because you think it makes the speaker seem inarticulate or unintelligent, consider either picking a different quote or paraphrasing.**


**English as a second language**
**When transcribing a quote from someone who barely speaks English**, such as the refugee claimant facing deportation below, there's no point trying to rewrite the entire statement with a series of square brackets. Instead, **paraphrase**.

Original, too confusing to publish:

> "They says they's going to, um, deporting me and me's family. We can'ts go there. Need help. Danger. Not go back. No hopes. Um. Very sad."


Paraphrase:

Pleading to stay in Canada, Woo said his family would be in danger if deported.

**Brief quotes** such as "very sad" **can be blended in as long as the wording is accurate and the addition benefits the reader.** But posting too many partial quotes in one story can make the piece seem either fragmented or incomplete.

See also [long, medium and short](/home/q/quotes-overview#length) in the overview on quotes for a more detailed discussion about length, including fragments.


**Capital letter latitude, as in 'We' not '\[W\]e'**
**Capital letters can be added to the beginning of quotes, and punctuation can be changed at the end, according to long-standing publishing convention.** This practical approach keeps unwanted square brackets and ellipses from cluttering up stories, since people often say things before and after the words we've decided to report.

Original end of a famous speech delivered by Winston Churchill in 1940:

> "We shall go on to the end. We shall fight in France, we shall fight on the seas and oceans, we shall fight with growing confidence and growing strength in the air, we shall defend our island whatever the cost may be. We shall fight on the beaches, we shall fight on the landing grounds, we shall fight in the fields and in the streets, we shall fight in the hills, we shall never surrender; and if, which I do not for a moment believe, this Island or a large part of it, were subjugated and starving, then our Empire beyond the seas, armed and guarded by the British fleet, would carry on the struggle, until, in God's good time, the New World, with all its power and might, steps forth to the rescue and the liberation of the Old."


One of many correct and acceptable excerpts used in news coverage:

> "We shall defend our island whatever the cost may be. We shall fight on the beaches, we shall fight on the landing grounds, we shall fight in the fields and in the streets, we shall fight in the hills. We shall never surrender."


Another correct option:

> "We shall never surrender."


Wrong (unnecessary ellipses):

> "... We shall never surrender...."


Wrong (unnecessary capital letter in square bracket):

> "\[W\]e shall never surrender."


**Attribution instead of an ellipsis**
**Inserting attribution sufficiently flags the end of a quote for readers, according to a well-established convention.** Adding an ellipsis to highlight that a quote does not continue directly into the next sentence or paragraph is considered superfluous.

Wrong (unnecessary ellipsis):

> "Like Toronto, we're discovering money — money at all cost. We have to stop thinking about money and start thinking about our well-being...," Tremblay said.
>
> "Of course, it's easy for me to say that since I'm a multimillionaire," he added with a laugh.


Correct:

> "Like Toronto, we're discovering money — money at all cost. We have to stop thinking about money and start thinking about our well-being," Tremblay said.
>
> "Of course, it's easy for me to say that since I'm a multimillionaire," he added with a laugh.


This approach is followed by many news organizations, including The Canadian Press and CBC.ca. **We embrace the idea that inverted commas reflect the words spoken or written between that punctuation. But we reject arguments that attribution itself is not a substitute for an ellipsis.**

Once a quote is closed, all bets are off. We make no promise to our readers that a subsequent open quote represents an immediate continuation of the previous statement. It may or it may not, just as the original quote may or may not have started with the first words of a self-contained sentence.

**The identity of speakers should always be placed high in quotes** (generally within the first 30-40 words) to help our readers. See also the [overview on quotes](/home/q/quotes-overview) for a brief discussion of when attribution is unnecessary.


**Handling paragraph breaks**
When a long quote is split into two paragraphs, the closing inverted commas are left off the end of the first paragraph to indicate that the same person is speaking in the next one.

As previously mentioned, ellipses are not used at the opening or closing of quotes.

This means that **you retain an ellipsis at the end of a paragraph if, and ONLY IF, this paragraph break happens to coincide with an edit** (i.e., you've chosen to remove words from a quote in the exact same spot where you've decided to extend the quote into a second paragraph).

Original Stephen Leacock quote from 1912:

> "Many of my friends are under the impression that I write these humorous nothings in idle moments when the wearied brain is unable to perform the serious labours of the economist. My own experience is exactly the other way. The writing of solid, instructive stuff fortified by facts and figures is easy enough. There is no trouble in writing a scientific treatise on the folklore of Central China, or a statistical enquiry into the declining population of Prince Edward Island. But to write something out of one’s own mind, worth reading for its own sake, is an arduous contrivance only to be achieved in fortunate moments, few and far between. Personally, I would sooner have written 'Alice in Wonderland' than the whole Encyclopaedia Britannica."


Correct quote 1 (featuring an ellipsis that coincides with a paragraph break):

> "Many of my friends are under the impression that I write these humorous nothings in idle moments when the wearied brain is unable to perform the serious labours of the economist," Leacock wrote in 1912.

> "My own experience is exactly the other way. The writing of solid, instructive stuff fortified by facts and figures is easy enough....
>
> "But to write something out of one’s own mind, worth reading for its own sake, is an arduous contrivance only to be achieved in fortunate moments, few and far between. Personally, I would sooner have written 'Alice in Wonderland' than the whole Encyclopaedia Britannica."


**In reality, such an ellipsis is still in the middle of the quote. It simply happens to fall at the start of a paragraph break.**

Other options include splitting the paragraph in a different spot or closing the first part of the quote with attribution:

Correct quote 2 (with ellipsis falling inside a paragraph):

> "Many of my friends are under the impression that I write these humorous nothings in idle moments when the wearied brain is unable to perform the serious labours of the economist. My own experience is exactly the other way," Leacock wrote in 1912.
>
> "The writing of solid, instructive stuff fortified by facts and figures is easy enough.... But to write something out of one’s own mind, worth reading for its own sake, is an arduous contrivance only to be achieved in fortunate moments, few and far between.
>
> "Personally, I would sooner have written 'Alice in Wonderland' than the whole Encyclopaedia Britannica."


Correct quote 3 (shorter, and with attribution replacing ellipsis):

> "The writing of solid, instructive stuff fortified by facts and figures is easy enough," Leacock wrote in 1912. 
>
> "But to write something out of one’s own mind, worth reading for its own sake, is an arduous contrivance only to be achieved in fortunate moments, few and far between.
>
> "Personally, I would sooner have written 'Alice in Wonderland' than the whole Encyclopaedia Britannica."


For more detailed typography and punctuation guidelines, see [ellipses](/handy-links/punctuation/ellipses) as well as [quotation marks](/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks). The ellipses entry includes a famous example of Pierre Trudeau talking about sex.


**Pronunciations (gonna, gotcha, etc.)**
**Prefer standard English when typing quotes, such "I'm going to see you later" instead of "I'm gonna see ya later."** Colloquialisms such as "gonna" are reserved for a dash of local dialect or colour in features, but should be used only if accurate and never to make someone look uneducated.

Some terms such as "gotcha" have become informal words in their own right. But they should be used only if they truly reflect what was said. There's a big difference between someone hurriedly saying "I got you that book," and someone else pausing, grinning and then distinctly uttering "gotcha."

**Always give speakers the benefit of the doubt when a word is slightly mispronounced, as long as the slip is obvious.**

For instance, type "nuclear" even if the person clearly said "new-cue-lurr" (with an extra vowel between the "c" and the "l"), and "government" even if the individual said "gov-er-mint" (dropping the "n" and changing the last vowel sound).

If we didn't follow this approach, we couldn't report sensibly. We'd be writing down sounds rather than words ("per-scrip-shun" instead of "prescription"), constantly arguing over whether a certain noun or verb or modifier has more than one acceptable pronunciation. And our readers would end up struggling through bizarre phonetic terrain rather than gliding smoothly down a well-travelled road of conventional spellings.

So just because some British speakers add an "r" to "Canada," and many other English speakers slip an extra "r" in "sherbet," and virtually all of us put an "r" in "colonel," doesn't mean we should when transcribing quotes.


**Instant replay**
**All writers and editors should carefully read direct quotes to ensure they make sense.** If something doesn't look right, there's a very good chance the comments have been transcribed incorrectly.

**But never guess about the text inside inverted commas.** Never assume what the correct quote is.

The only way to be certain that a dubious quote is wrong is to **check it against the original audio.**

Note: All CBC.ca writers must take the time to transcribe quotes before submitting stories for publication. See [broadcast script warning](/home/q/quotes-editing#broadcast) below for more details.


**But that's what she meant**
**Be careful not to indiscernibly "fix" diction on the false grounds that this is what the speaker intended.** Replacing one word with another is not the same as applying standard spelling to an uncommon or twisted pronunciation.

If someone clearly says "perspective" and you're certain they meant "perceptive," do not simply change the wording.

Your options include picking a different quote, choosing a different "in" and "out" (i.e., avoiding the problematic part of the direct quote), deleting part of the quote with an ellipsis, paraphrasing rather than quoting, publishing the mistake as is and letting readers draw their own conclusions, or fixing the mistake in a transparent way with square brackets — as long as you're sure that the text you're inserting is correct.


**Avoid contestable 'corrections'**
**Do not change the wording of quotes simply to match a CBC.ca stylistic preference. While some rules of speech are indisputable**, such as a plural subject (e.g., "they") generally matching a plural verb (e.g., "are"), **others fall into a much greyer area.**

If, for example, someone says "none were hurt," do not change this to "none \[was\] hurt." For starters, many authorities embraced "none were" as equally acceptable years ago. Such edits also tend to distract readers and insult speakers.

For the same reason, if someone says "disinterested," do not replace this with "uninterested" in square brackets. Direct quotes are the wrong place to enforce certain CBC.ca preferences, such as the distinction between "not biased" and "not interested."

**Quotes feature someone else's words, and as long as their meaning is clear we respectfully publish and attribute debatable "errors" rather than imposing our copy editing voice on them.**


**Fix factual errors**
**If you realize that people have accidentally misspoken but haven't corrected themselves** (e.g., "he was acquitted in 1975" instead of "he was convicted in 1975"), **generally abandon the quote and paraphrase instead**. In rare cases, when the direct quote is essential to the piece, the correct detail should be presented in a way that's least likely to confuse readers and disrupt the story's flow. This usually means publishing square brackets in place of the false information.

**Only in exceptional instances should the original mistake be published as is, with a correction delayed until the sentence immediately after the direct quote.** This type of postponed correction must be justified for editorial reasons, such as in a story about a person accused of inventing historical facts or making other sweeping statements that we've determined aren't true.

**Never use the term "_sic_" in daily journalism to highlight an error in speech. It carries a condescending tone. Either pick a different quote, leave the error as is and let readers draw their own conclusions, or remove the mistake and replace it with correct wording in square brackets.** The word _sic_ (Latin for "thus" or "so") is appropriate only in rare cases — e.g., when posting long written excerpts in features, to let readers know that we have transcribed a published error intentionally.


**Revise certain spelling in quotes**
As with many media organizations, including the New York Times, **we generally change generic spellings to conform to our own style**.

So we would write "centre" not "center," even if the U.S. president has read the word from a prepared text, and we would write "tire" not "tyre," even if a British court's transcript assigned a "y" to a witness's testimony.

In the case of proper nouns, however, we follow the preferences of individual organizations, such as the National Arts Centre in Ottawa versus the Kennedy Center in Washington. (See [spelling](/home/s/spelling) and [defence, labour, centre](/home/d/defence-labour-and-centre) for more detailed guidelines)


**Symbols as words**
**Usually punctuation marks and other special characters are spelled out as words** in quotes:


> "That's it. Period."
>
> "What the blank blank are you talking about?"
>
> "We dropped our lawsuit after the company tacked a couple of zeros onto the settlement."


**The test is whether the spelled-out version not only reflects what was said but also helps our audience understand the meaning**. For example, by using the word "period" instead of just the symbol for closing punctuation above, the quote's intended stress is captured. And by writing out "blank blank" instead of adding dashes ( — — ) or other special characters that represent spaces, we avoid ambiguity (i.e., the unintended suggestion that parts of the quote have been censored).

**The most common exceptions are units that specify quantity** ($ for dollar) or **other forms of measurement** (C for Celsius):


> "They're expected to report a loss of $5.5 million."
>
> "The back of the bus felt like it was 40 C."


**Other exceptions are rare, and involve cases when words would needlessly hinder comprehension:**


> "We want customers to share all complaints/concerns."


Rendering a quote like this as "complaints slash concerns" serves no editorial purpose.


**Sometimes, people being quoted fail to repeat a crucial word that provides important context** (e.g., "million" or "dollar"). The **recommended practice is to render these quotes in the clearest but least-jarring manner.** This usually means adding a missing spoken word in square brackets but adding an implied symbol without square brackets:


> VERBATIM QUOTE: "I know that they have 50 to 60 million dollars."
>
> PUBLISHED QUOTE: "I know that they have $50 \[million\] to $60 million."
>
> VERBATIM QUOTE: "I know that they have 50 million to 60 million dollars."
>
> PUBLISHED QUOTE: "I know that they have $50 million to $60 million."


**Verbatim renderings**
**Brief excerpts from published material, such as a book, can also be altered to match our spelling style if inserted in our daily journalism. But longer excerpts posted on their own** (e.g., an 800-word editorial from a U.S. newspaper reproduced as part of a CBCNews.ca feature, or a web page highlighting a series of excerpts lifted from court documents) **should be kept intact, with the original spelling, for ease of editing.** These should be treated as verbatim renderings, akin to offering our readers a PDF of the original document. Such text should be identified as unedited, with the source and context clearly marked.


**Transcripts versus prepared text**
Transcriptions are written versions of spoken words. When we transcribe audio clips we're providing readers with brief transcripts inside inverted commas.

**When external sources provide transcripts, clearly identify the words as such** (e.g., "according to a transcript of the trial provided by the Court of King's Bench in Saskatchewan").
**
Always distinguish between actual transcripts and the published text of speeches provided to us before delivery. Name the source unless it's already clear from the context** (e.g., "The risk is obvious, but the danger of doing nothing is even higher," the defence minister said in prepared text released just before his speech).

**Whenever possible, text released ahead of time should be checked against actual delivery. Our reference to "prepared text" can be dropped only if the words spoken have been confirmed.**

Normally, there is no value in noting minor discrepancies between prepared and delivered versions, and we simply publish what was actually spoken. Occasionally, however, something that's been changed at the last minute can be newsworthy. So **be alert when comparing versions, wearing a journalist's hat rather than a transcriber's.**

Embargoed content, of course, must never be posted until the time specified in whatever agreement has been worked out.

For practical guidelines on handling lengthy excerpts from court transcripts, etc., published on their own, see [verbatim renderings](/home/q/quotes-editing#renderings) above.


**Excerpts from user-generated content, emails, social media, etc.**
**When quoting content from people's emails, blogs**, Facebook pages or other social media accounts, comments at the bottom of stories, **etc., in our journalism, follow our general approach to editing outlined above.
**
NOTE: Standalone user-generated content clearly branded as such (e.g., a thread of comments at the bottom of a web article) is normally published unedited. In the case of UGC, these guidelines apply only to excerpts inserted directly in CBC stories.

To make external text added to our journalism easier for our audience to read, **fix spelling mistakes but then flag the changes with square brackets** to maintain our principle of transparency:

Original:

> "More than 200 means where doing good," she replied in a tweet.


Edited version for a CBCNews.ca story:

> "More than 200 means \[we're\] doing good," she replied in a tweet.


Notice that the grammar ("good" instead of "well") has not been changed, as outlined in the previous section on [avoiding contestable corrections](/home/q/quotes-editing#corrections).

**Small changes in punctuation, capitalization, numerical style, etc., can usually be made without the need to highlight the edit**, including when we remove gratuitous speech sounds ("waaay" for way). This matches the spirit of the sections on [revising certain spellings](/home/q/quotes-editing#spelling) in quotes and [pronunciations](/home/q/quotes-editing#gonna) above.

Original:

> "I don't mind a fine...... but 7500"


Edited version for a CBCNews.ca story:

> "I don't mind a fine. But $7,500?"


Original:

> "9 hours is waaay tooooo long."


Acceptable edit for a CBCNews.ca story that retains drawn-out vowel sounds:

> "Nine hours is waaay tooooo long."


Preferred edit for a CBCNews.ca story because it's clearest and easiest to scan:

> "Nine hours is way too long."


**Do not retain unorthodox uppercase or lowercase lettering.**

Original:

> "i too, am UNABLE to get tickets .... Some people are even selling them on Ebay for 108.00 !"


Edited version for a CBCNews.ca story:

> Ottawa resident Cathy Wong wrote: "I, too, am unable to get tickets. Some people are even selling them on eBay for $108!"

**Generally avoid repeating emoticons** (e.g., smiley faces) **or other special characters in news copy, except in rare cases when deleting the symbols removes essential context/meaning** (e.g., sarcasm).

Original:

> "What a shame it ended this way. :( The country treated her like dirt."


Edited version for a CBCNews.ca story (superfluous emoticon removed):

> "What a shame it ended this way. The country treated her like dirt."


Original:

> "He's beyond a doubt the BEST prime minister we've ever had. :-p "


Edited version (emoticon retained to convey key meaning):

> "He's beyond a doubt the best prime minister we've ever had. :-p "


CAUTION: Emoticons can be distracting as well as confusing (e.g., "QQ" might be two eyes shedding tears to some and a weird typo to others). Retain symbols as a last resort. If a mediocre comment hinges on a wink ;-), a dunce's cap <|:-/ or some other combination of dots, lines and curves, generally look for a different quote. Our bar is set high (i.e., usually only stellar remarks keep their emoticons because the price of unorthodox typography in these cases is worth the editorial value of the accompanying words).
**
[Use full names in attribution](/home/q/quotes-editing#attribution) whenever known** (e.g., a remark taken from someone's Facebook page or other social media account). **If actual authorship has not been confirmed and there's doubt about who wrote a remark, report only what is known** (e.g., where a comment appeared rather than assumptions about who composed it). **In some cases, it's impossible to verify authorship. If such quotes pass editorial muster, it's stylistically OK to use lowercase letters and special characters when citing people's web identities** (hans345 or @smartalec). But we must make it clear where the material is lifted from (e.g., from a particular website, in a thread of comments at the bottom of a CBCNews.ca story, in an email to the newsroom). Depending on circumstances, repeating a pseudonym or vague account name might help our audience find more content by the individual. A phrase such as "one person wrote," however, is sometimes sufficient — along the lines of brief clips in a string of "streeters" in a radio piece.

IMPORTANT: When handling any vague attribution, adhere to all relevant CBC journalistic policies about unnamed sources.

**Follow our normal approach to abbreviations in web journalism. If the shorthand is widely known, it does not need to be spelled out** (e.g., ASAP rather than "as soon as possible" and FYI rather than "for your information"). If it's comparatively obscure (e.g., the text message term LOL for "laughing out loud" was initially assumed to mean "lots of love" by some people), it should be defined in square brackets. The dictionary is a good guide. See [offensive language](/home/o/offensive-language#abbreviationsandeuphemisms) for guidelines on terms such as WTF.

**Make sure the tweet, email excerpt, etc., adds value to the story.** As outlined in the [overview on quotes](/home/q/quotes-overview), it's sometimes better to paraphrase or to post only part of a verbatim comment.


**Broadcast script warning**
**Do not rely on radio and television scripts when posting quotes. They're not written to be read by the eye.** When the material is put on the air, the "quotes" are replaced by taped voices. We have to treat quotation marks differently because of the medium we work in.

**Always listen to the broadcast items to verify the words spoken. Even a small discrepancy can make a big difference to a story's meaning and to CBC.ca's credibility.**

Take our coverage of a blackout in downtown Vancouver in January 2001. We wrote:

> "It was a switch and it caused other stations along the system to fail," said B.C. Hydro spokesperson Wayne Cousins.


But it turns out this "quote" was lifted from a broadcast script, and that the radio reporter had merely paraphrased what was on the tape. Cousins actually said:

> "This was a switch, and this caused other substations along the system, specifically in the downtown core, to shut down."


Not only were several words changed (e.g., "this" and "substations") and deleted ("specifically in the downtown core"), but key language was revised at the end — "shut down" wrongly became "fail," which carries a different meaning. The other stations didn't actually fail. They merely shut down as expected.

People notice when CBC.ca quotes don't match the audio in radio or television reports. In this case, one B.C. reader emailed a complaint to our national newsroom: "If the other stations failed instead of shutting down, then this system would not have worked correctly."

**When reading quotes in broadcast scripts, of course, don't automatically assume they're wrong. Verification is the key.** Take the case of "gig" versus "jig."

On June 5, 2001, MP Deborah Grey was asked about the future of her party's leader, Stockwell Day. Here's what she told reporters outside the House of Commons:

> "I think he has to make some pretty serious decisions right now. And I think, fairly simply, the gig is up."


Radio and TV scripts correctly featured the word "gig," as in an engagement. But a web writer looking at the scripts changed the "g" to a "j" to match the cliché about a scheme being foiled ("the jig is up"). He even checked the Canadian Oxford to be sure. But he should have checked the tape.

Someone who heard the MP's clip on the air sent an email challenging our erroneous edit, which by this time was already featured in a headline. We fixed the mistake.

**CBC.ca journalists must take the time to transcribe all clips taken from original radio and television reports before posting these words on the web.** Broadcast journalists use inverted commas much more loosely than we do. Their scripts often contain only rough approximations of clips rather than verbatim renderings. **Until the audio has been checked, either postpone posting quotes or turn the typed versions provided by radio and television journalists into paraphrases.**


**Ethical, undistorted editing**
**CBC Journalistic Standards and Practices guidelines apply to internet and broadcast material.** Therefore, any changes permitted by CBCNews.ca's strict policy on transcribing quotes (outlined above) must also meet conditions laid out in the corporation's general policies on [editing interviews](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fio.cbcrc.ca%2F%23%2Fresources%2Finterviews-entrevues-1.4523175&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3g4ewwTurcEkcNR3NdAsHB).

**In brief, quotes must not be distorted through editing.** For example: "It's a really great example of bad government policy" must never become "It's a really great ... government policy." This would be unethical and violate CBC journalistic standards.

Another example: "We will probably, although we're not sure yet, and still have to discuss it further, lower taxes" could be shortened to "We will probably ... lower taxes." But it must never be twisted into "We will ... lower taxes."

Much of CBCNews.ca's original material comes from broadcasts reports. In the case of radio in particular, it's often impossible to tell if journalists have already manipulated the audio tracks by cutting chunks from the middle of a quote.

**If you think that a condensed version has been used in a broadcast item, try to find an original, unedited version to determine whether an ellipsis is needed.** Audio tracks are sometimes recorded at an encoding station during a live event, such as news conferences and speeches. **If it's not possible to check original recordings, treat the quotes in broadcast reports as unaltered** — i.e., never insert an assumed ellipsis unless you've confirmed that words have been chopped.
**
On the web, quotes can always be responsibly shortened with the use of punctuation** (...) to make them clearer, to remove profanity, etc., as long as the original meaning is not changed.

**But quotes should not be covertly revised for any reason other than those listed above** (i.e., to remove ehs, ums and other disfluencies). **When in doubt about changing a quote, check with a senior CBC.ca journalist.**

See also [quotation marks](/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks) (for general punctuation guidelines)

See overview on [quotes](/home/q/quotes-overview) for tips on attributing, paraphrasing, etc.

### Quotes overview

**Quotes (an overview)**










**Summary**
**Web stories without quotes can be as deficient as radio or television reports without clips.** Rather than hearing directly from the people and organizations we cover, readers are given only our summaries of what was said or written.

**But when picking and placing quotes, editorial judgment is required.** Always keep the following in mind:

-   **Good quotes in the right spots elevate our journalism**, providing everything from vivid detail or key context to improved story flow.
-   **Not all quotes are worth publishing.**
-   **Even when quotes are reasonably good, jamming too many into one story can cause more harm than good —** leaving readers with unnecessarily long and dense text they may well decide to abandon.
-   **Quotes are not paraphrases.** Inverted commas indicate that the words were spoken or written by someone else. **Do not use this punctuation unless you're satisfied the text is accurate** (i.e., you've verified the typed version against the original audio or have taken the quote from a trustworthy publishing source).

**This page features general tips on attribution, adding quotes to web journalism** (e.g., what's worth transcribing versus what should be paraphrased), **the length of quotes, etc.**

**See a separate entry on [editing quotes](/home/q/quotes-editing) for strict rules governing the removal or revision of words inside inverted commas** — including guidelines on what to do about factual and grammatical errors.


**Skip dull stuff**
Colourful, emotional or poetic quotes add life to stories. But **if someone is merely rattling off facts or presenting dense information in a confusing way, paraphrase instead.**

**
Avoid quotes like this**

> "All bills introduced before the 1934 legislative session required that a second typewritten copy be sent to the archives. These were placed in boxes, brown boxes I believe, and when theses boxes became full a civil servant sealed them with masking tape. "

**Paraphrasing is sufficient**

> Until 1934, the province kept duplicate copies of bills at the legislature's archives.


As journalists with electronic word-processing equipment, we can condense and clarify such straightforward statements easily and accurately. We must, of course, remain true to a dull quote's original meaning. But we have more time to craft sentences than people speaking off the top of their heads.

By chopping here and revising there, we can frequently come up with a paraphrase that's shorter and easier for our readers to scan.


**Don't overuse quotes**
**Just because someone said something doesn't automatically mean it's worth transcribing and publishing.** This is particularly important to remember when we're offered a feast of comments from an informal scrum, a formal news conference, etc.
**Instead of providing what amounts to a transcript, be selective.** Pick a few good quotes and weave these into your copy.

In daily journalism, few remarks are as pithy or witty as bon mots from Oscar Wilde or Groucho Marx. But good quotes are still all around us. H**umour, imagery, unexpected turns of phrase and so forth can add a welcome dash of spice to otherwise relatively bland topics.**


**Words that grab our attention**

> "I do not think I have ever been accused of seducing anyone, even my wife," Harper quipped before pausing to look up in the public gallery, where his spouse nodded.
>
> > (From a story on Stephen Harper's first Question Period as prime minister in April 2006. Harper was responding to an accusation by the NDP that he had "seduced" former Liberal MP David Emerson to cross the floor and join his cabinet right after the election.)
>
> "The problem here is that there will always be some uncertainty about how quickly he can acquire nuclear weapons," U.S. national security adviser Condoleezza Rice told CNN. "But we don't want the smoking gun to be a mushroom cloud."
>
> > (From a 2002 story about Washington's push to topple Saddam Hussein's regime. Note: The pronoun "he" in the first sentence does not require clarification — i.e., followed by the name \[Saddam\] in square brackets — because the word's meaning is obvious based on the story's context.)


**Criteria for picking quotes**
**In general, look for strong or vibrant words that:**

-   Concisely convey emotion.
-   Neatly summarize opinion.

Ideally, the language itself is also engaging — e.g., picturesque, poignant, etc. — although this is not essential.

**Consider the following examples of effective and relatively ineffective remarks, all taken from a single story** about four RCMP officers killed during a raid on a farm in Alberta in March 2005:


**Poor quote**

> Asked if the victims had been ambushed, RCMP spokesperson Cpl. Wayne Oakes said, "I don't know."


A simple paraphrase would get to the point sooner. Also, general attribution (the RCMP) rather than the name of a specific Mountie is sufficient in this case.


**Borderline quote**

> "It's my sad duty to inform you that four members of the RCMP were killed today in the line of duty – four brave, young members," said RCMP Assistant Commissioner Bill Sweeney.


The above sentence mainly conveys factual information. But the emotion ("sad duty") and description of the officers ("brave, young") makes it worth including if no other more compelling words were spoken.


**Fairly good quote**

> "You'd have to go back to 1885, to the Northwest Rebellion, to have a loss of this magnitude. It's devastating," said Sweeney.


We could report the 1885 historical context in a paraphrase. But leaving it in a brief quote that also includes emotion ("It's devastating") is an effective way to convey such information.


**Memorable quote**

"He's not my son, he's a wicked devil," said the suspect's father, Bill Roszko.

Comments such as "wicked devil" leap off the page. Our readers are told a great deal in just a few words.

**In some cases, even relatively pedestrian quotes can be effectively used to:**

-   Record key wording and nuances in statements.
-   Attribute potentially controversial remarks.
-   Support third-person statements that a story is built on (especially paraphrases in headlines and leads).
-   Reveal personal characteristics about a speaker or writer.

**Whether catchy or boring, other people's words should never be added to stories just for the sake of doing so. There should be a reason for including every quote.** In some cases, this may boil down to a writer or editor trying to improve the story's pacing — which is justified as long as the quote actually does this.


**Short, medium and long**
**Quotes do not have ideal lengths, although extremely long ones can hurt a story's flow and too many really short ones can leave readers feeling short-changed.**

When deciding where to place the inverted commas, keep a few things in mind:

-   Is the entire comment compelling, or is there an earlier and equally natural ending?
-   Is it easier for the reader if the quote is split into two paragraphs?

Brevity is not always a virtue. Be sure to provide readers with context if something inside inverted commas in unclear or could be misunderstood.

**In broadcast journalism, brief bursts of audio are sometimes used to help propel the radio or television piece along. But the web is a different medium**, and quotes should be based on the eye's needs not what a broadcaster feels suits the ear.

Partial quotes incorporated into the main body of a story can be effective if used sparingly and for a reason (e.g., to lift a brief, colourful phrase from a long, confusing or otherwise unusable quote, or to attribute catchy but controversial wording). But **extremely short excerpts are often unnecessary and distracting, especially when the language is generic.**

**Acceptable fragments**

> Existing copyright law is "arcane and insane," she said. 
>
> They're part of an "axis of evil," Bush said, and must be confronted by the rest of the world.


**Pointless fragments**

> Canada must "move quickly" to tighten border security, she said. 
>
> Police will "probably" call off the search Thursday, he said.

**He says repetition is tiresome. 'Avoid repetition,' he warned.**
**Setting up a quote can help move a story forward** (e.g., introducing the speaker's identity, outlining a country's position in an international dispute, etc.)

**But paraphrasing what is about to be said** (before a quote) **or what's just been said** (after a quote) **is redundant**.


**Fine**

> France and Russia are both opposed to the resolution, but it's not clear if either will use its veto at the United Nations Security Council.

> "The time for a vote will come, but that's a long way off," said the UN secretary general. "We must concentrate on fruitful dialogue and diplomacy, not on division and demagoguery."

**Redundant**

> France and Russia are both opposed to the resolution, but it's not clear if either will use its veto at the United Nations Security Council.
>
> The UN secretary general says all countries should focus on dialogue and diplomacy.
>
> "The time for a vote will come, but that's a long way off," he said. "We must concentrate on fruitful dialogue and diplomacy, not on division and demagoguery."


**In this case, either leave out the quote or the paraphrase. Since the quote adds a bit of zest to the story, the paraphrase should be dumped.**


**Attribution**
**We normally attribute quotes. There are three exceptions:**

-   **Brief remarks that amount to "sound bites" taken from broadcast scripts** (e.g., _"This is crazy!" shouted one protester as the police moved forward_). In these cases, we rarely know the identity of the speaker. Such quotes are acceptable in moderation as long as they actually improve an article by adding colour or useful detail.
-   **The online equivalent of brief audio mentioned above, such as a tweet** or other microblogging post (e.g., _"This proves that new governments don't mind using old tactics," wrote one person from P.E.I. Of the more than 500 comments posted on CBCNews.ca within two hours of the announcement, 95 per cent were critical of the PM's decision_).
-   **Key quotes from confidential sources in scoops, investigative reports, etc.** In these rare cases, senior journalists must have already ruled that the unnamed sources are essential to the story, as outlined in existing CBC News editorial policy. See the Journalistic Standards and Practices policy on [Protection of Sources](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fio.cbcrc.ca%2F%23%2Fresources%2Fsources-sources-1.4523572&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0BNv0y2uDfyvcFk1vXAgQ7) for more details about criteria governing the use of confidential and anonymous material. (NOTE: "Confidential" refers to known but unnamed sources. "Anonymous" refers to sources that are unknown, even to the CBC. Use of anonymous sources is exceedingly rare and requires special approval from news management, in accordance with our JSP policy.)

**In all other cases, readers should be left with no doubts about the source of a quote. Attribution must be clear** (e.g., a person's name and, when relevant, title or other helpful identifying information), **placed high in the quote** (i.e., generally no more than 30-40 words after the first inverted commas), **and inserted in a natural spot** (e.g., at the end of a phrase or complete thought if not a full sentence). **Context is important as well.** For example, we should let our readers know whether words were spoken from a witness box or in a scrum outside a courthouse, in Question Period or during a speech at a business luncheon.

**When comments are lifted from written statements, such as emails and news releases, the quotes should be identified as such** to make it clear to our audience that we have not transcribed an interview. See [transcripts versus prepared text](/home/q/quotes-editing#texts) for rules on publishing material taken from advance copies of speeches.

**In long quotes spread out over several paragraphs, attribution must appear in the first paragraph.** Sometimes, of course, the placement of attribution depends on how someone's statement has been shortened. See [editing quotes](/home/q/quotes-editing) for examples of how attribution can be used instead of an ellipsis.


**Second reference names**
**We initially identify most people by their "full" (first and last) names in stories.** Two common exceptions: When the family name is already understood based on context (e.g., a spouse or child), or when an individual is widely known by a single name (e.g., Drake, Adele, Madonna) or [nickname](/home/n/nicknames).

Be aware that **in some cultures, family names are not actually "surnames"** (i.e., are not last in the sequence of names). For instance, the Chinese name Xi Jinping becomes Xi in second reference. (See [Asian names](/home/a/asian-names) for related guidelines.)

**There's no need for honorifics tied to gender or marital status** (Mrs., Ms. or Mr.) **before names in first or second reference** (e.g., Nawab rather than "Ms. Nawab"). **Avoid adding such honorifics to most titles, too**  (e.g., do NOT say or write "Mr. mayor" or "Madam premier" or "Mr. minister" **in first or second reference**). Even in on-air interviews, the title alone can normally suffice (e.g., "I'd like to clarify, premier, when you were told"). Optional exceptions are formal references to certain judicial figures, based on convention (e.g., Madam Justice Rosalie Abella"). See also [Dr.](/home/d/dr)

**In second reference, we normally refer to people by their family (usually last) name** (e.g., Jane Jones becomes Jones). **Exceptions are OK if a first name better suits the story** (e.g., to maintain a tone of informality), **or if a family name alone would cause confusion.** Sometimes, repeating a person's full name in second reference is necessary for clarity (e.g., when people sharing the same family name are mentioned). Always use a spouse's full name in first reference if the family name is different. [Particles](/home/p/particles-de-du-van-von) (de, du, van, von) can be a source of confusion. Convention and known personal preference are important factors when deciding whether to retain particles in second reference.

**Given names** (usually first names) **alone are particularly common when identifying people under 18 in second reference** (e.g., using Amanda instead of Todd in coverage of the death of 15-year-old Amanda Todd). **While we often follow this convention, there's no blanket rule** that applies to all young people. Exceptions include certain coverage of the arts and sports (e.g., using family names when referring to singers, film stars, athletes, etc., who happen to be under 18).


**Told CBC News**
**Avoid unnecessary self-promotion.** It's usually unwise to credit the CBC more than once in any given story, and very often no such attribution is required.

Most people reading our site assume that direct quotes have been obtained by the corporation's journalists. (We heard the speech; we participated in the scrum; we watched Question Period; we interviewed someone at their office or home.) So in routine stories there's no need to boast that "so and so told CBC News." Such tooting can be grating, CBC News has learned over the years.

**When credit is merited, generally use the catch-all attribution "CBC News"** rather than specifying individual platforms or services like CBC-TV, CBC Radio or CBCNews.ca for comments gathered by CBC News staff:

> "The verdict won't bring back my son, but I'm relieved the monster is being locked up for life," the victim's father told CBC News \[instead of _said in an interview on the CBC News Network_\].
>
> "The ban on beef from Brazil is stupid but not surprising," a former government scientist wrote in an email to CBC News \[instead of wrote _in an email sent to CBCNews.ca_\].


If a web story is based on an exclusive report from a specific program, however, we can make that clear when the story breaks as long as the credit is justified (i.e., no one else has the information) and it helps our readers better understand context:

> Ottawa plans to ground its new fleet of search-and-rescue helicopters, according to Defence Department documents obtained by CBC News: _The National_ Wednesday night.
>
> The catcher refused to comment, beyond saying that he first learned of the trade in a story posted Sunday on CBCSports.ca.
>
> "It's a matter of particles and waves, not magic wands. This is science, not Harry Potter," she said in an interview on CBC Radio's _Quirks & Quarks_.


(See also [CBC](/home/c/cbc) for guidelines on handling a range of CBC nouns)


**Prefer 'said' over 'say'
**One of the obvious differences between broadcast and online journalism is the possible lag between delivery and consumption of our stories — i.e., people may read our material long after it is posted.

**The print convention of using the past tense in direct attribution works well on the web** (e.g., _the premier said Monday, the court ruled Tuesday_). **This is the preferred style on CBCNews.ca.**

In breaking news, the present tense can sometimes be temporarily used. But these stories must be updated during a shift and should never be archived on our website in that form.

**_Indirect_ attribution** (paraphrases and partial quotes) **can be in the present tense, however, as long as no time element** (e.g., day of the week) **is included in the same sentence.** This is common in leads:

> A U.S. military lawyer prosecuting a Canadian teen at Guantanamo Bay says he's sickened by sympathetic portrayals of Omar Khadr, calling him an al-Qaeda "terrorist" who should spend the rest of his life in jail.
>
> At a news conference on Tuesday, chief prosecutor Col. Moe Davis made no attempt to hide his disdain for human rights activists who have rallied to defend Khadr, now 19.
>
> "It's really sometimes nauseating to read some of the things that have been written on how these terrorists are down here standing up for the Bill of Rights," Davis said a day before Khadr was to make his first appearance before a special military court at the U.S. naval base in Cuba.



(The start of a January 2006 story that meets CBCNews.ca style on "said" and "says")

**Avoid unnecessarily bouncing readers back and forth between tenses in the same story.** For instance, once a time element has been introduced (as in the second paragraph above), direct quotes should be kept in the past tense.


**Don't replace 'said' with inaccurate verbs**
The words "say" and "said" are common for a reason. They're short, neutral and natural. While people do say the darndest things, they don't necessarily _admit, concede, lament, maintain, opine_, etc.

You may want to write that someone _grumbled, shouted_ or _scoffed_ if you're certain they did. But **don't bother replacing "say" or "said" with supposed synonyms that, in reality, sacrifice accuracy, objectivity or just plain conversational style for the sake of variety. (**For details, see [say versus admit, claim, concede, etc.](/home/s/say))


**Check quotes carefully**
**The marks " " have special meaning.** They do not represent a paraphrase. **They highlight words that have been spoken or written.

If you haven't checked a quote that appears in a broadcast journalist's script, never use quotation marks.**

Do not presume that these were the words spoken. Such hastily typed "quotes" are almost never 100 per cent correct because TV and radio reporters are merely using them as guides (e.g., so that a producer or other person vetting the script has some sense of what the premier said, and so the reporter knows the "in" and "out" when editing the piece).

Broadcast scripts are not written to be read by the eye. When the material is put on the air, the "quotes" are replaced by actual spoken words. We have to treat quotation marks differently because of the medium we work in.

Understanding this is essential; the rule is worth repeating. **If the quote you're posting comes from either television or radio, you must transcribe the audio.** Do not rely solely on quick summaries of clips found in broadcast scripts.

**Even famous quotes should be verified by consulting a reliable source. Do not rely on your memory.** Shakespeare wrote about gilding gold not a lily; Milton said "Revenge at first though sweet, bitter ere long back on itself recoils" (not merely "Revenge is sweet"); and Sir Arthur Conan Doyle never had Sherlock Holmes say "Elementary, my dear Watson." (For a longer discussion about common misquotes, see the Words: Woe & Wonder column [Quibbling over Quotes](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews2%2Findepth%2Fwords%2Fmisquotes.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0ZJ2mOE0AM8I09fmGLS73N).)


**Punctuation**
**Several typographical conventions must be followed when adding quotes to web journalism on CBC.ca.**

See [quotation marks](/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks) for rules on punctuation inside inverted commas, single versus double quotation marks in headlines, handling slogans, expressing irony, etc.

See [ellipses](/handy-links/punctuation/ellipses) for rules on chopping text from quotes.

See square [brackets](/handy-links/punctuation/brackets) for rules on adding text to quotes.

As mentioned at the top of this page, [editing quotes](/home/q/quotes-editing) outlines strict limits on "cleaning up" words inside inverted commas.

**R** 

**[r-rd](/home/r#r)**

**[re-rh](/home/r#re)**

**[ri-ry](/home/r#ri)**

**r-rd**
**rabbi, Rabbi Erwin Schild**

**raccoon, raccoons** (_double c_)

**race** (Black, white, etc.) See **[racial terms](/home/r/racial-terms)** for general reporting guidelines.

**[racism, racist](/home/r/racial-terms#racist-racism)** (editorial guidelines, caveats)

****racecourse, racehorse, racetrack, raceway****

**Rachmaninoff, Sergei** (Russian composer and pianist) Use the conventional transliteration. Do not adopt revised spellings, such as "Rakhmaninov" or "Rachmaninov." (See also [Russian names](/home/r/russian-names))

**raid** (n., v.) A common term for sudden or unexpected attacks by police, troops, etc. (e.g., a **drug raid**, a **military raid**). The word has other entrenched definitions, including a surprise assault "to commit a crime or to do harm," according to the Canadian Oxford. There is also acceptable figurative usage about plundering (e.g., a **kitchen raid** for snacks, a stock market **bear raid** involving price manipulation), as well as mischief-making (e.g., a **dorm raid** by students). There's often no confusion about the term's meaning (e.g., in a story about one **criminal gang's raid** on another gang's turf). CAUTION: **Be aware, however, that a noun or verb like "raid" can sometimes be misconstrued as tacit legitimization of one group's action against another.** Specifically, "raid" in a headline might wrongly suggest a sanctioned bust by authorities rather than an angry mob's violent, unlawful attack. It might also be perceived as downplaying the seriousness of a crime that endangered lives. **In such cases, always supply key context** (e.g., if people are accused of trespassing, making threats, damaging or destroying property). **To avoid ambiguity, consider clearer alternative wording** that fits the facts (e.g., nouns like attack or assault, and verbs like vandalize or ransack).

**RAM** (random access memory)

**Rama Navami** (Hinduism) This festival celebrates the birth of Lord Rama, the seventh incarnation of Vishnu and the hero of the _Ramayana_, a Sanskrit epic of 24,000 stanzas. He is a popular religious figure and considered a supreme god by some Hindus. In news stories, **Rama** is fine in first reference. A dispute over a holy site in Rama's birthplace in Ayodhya, India, led to violence between Hindus and Muslims for many years. Hindus wanted to construct a **Rama temple** while Muslims wanted to rebuild a demolished mosque. For consistency, do not use alternative spellings ("Ram" or "Ram temple").

**Ramadan** (A holy time during the ninth month of the lunar-based Islamic calendar) Ramadan is marked by special prayers, blessings, fasting, etc. **Eid al-Fitr**, often abbreviated to **Eid** in second reference, is a Muslim holiday that marks the end of Ramadan. Dates of observance vary from year to year, depending on the moon and the country or region.

**ramp ceremony** (military term for solemn tribute to soldiers killed abroad as the caskets are loaded on transport planes and flown back to their home countries) Although this expression has become more widely known over the years, don't use it unless the context of the story makes the meaning immediately obvious. Otherwise, prefer clearer language, such as "farewell ceremony" or "departure ceremony." For example, a report on a Canadian soldier's body being loaded on a military plane at Kandahar Airfield in southern Afghanistan instantly conveys the meaning of "ramp ceremony." But a story with a totally different focus that only indirectly refers to "ramp ceremony" requires more explanatory language. Avoid the jargon "repatriation" of bodies, which sounds highly bureaucratic. (See [military terms](/home/m/military-terms-overview) for an overview of related language)

**rape** (forced sexual intercourse) In Canada, there's no actual charge of _rape_. Instead, people are prosecuted for sexual assault, aggravated sexual assault, etc. Although we can sometimes use the generic words "rape" in news stories, we should avoid any wording that suggests this is the actual Criminal Code charge. Since inappropriate kissing and forced sexual intercourse both fall under the broad heading of "sexual assault," putting certain charges into context with additional details can be highly useful to our audience. (See [**rape versus sexual assault**](/home/r/rape-versus-sexual-assault) for more details, as well as [serial rapist](/home/s#serialrapist))

**As a prefix, "re" is not normally followed by a hyphen unless (1) it's next to another "e" or (2) it could be confused with another word:** readmit, reapply, reassess, rebrand, rebroadcast, rebuild, rebuilt, recheck, re-cover (cover again), recover (regain possession or use of something, recuperate), recur, recurrence, redeem, redefine, re-edit, re-educate, re-elect, re-election, re-emerge, re-employ, re-engineer, re-enter. re-entry, re-examine, refinance, reinstate, reissue, re-lay (lay again), relay (pass on), remortgage, reopen, reorganize, republish, reread, reroute, rerun, re-sent (sent again), resent (feel indignation), re-sign (sign again), resign (give up or be reconciled to), resold, resole, retry, reunite, reuse, reusable, rewrite.

**regime** (requires editorial caution in political coverage) Avoid calling governments in bona fide democracies "regimes." In this context, the term conventionally implies totalitarian or non-democratically elected governments. So it's OK to refer to, say, **the Taliban regime, North Korea's regime**, etc., as long as the facts fit. This includes historical references (e.g., **the Gadhafi regime, the Stalin regime**). But avoid labels like the Harper regime, the Nixon regime, etc. Use common sense when assessing whether a country is non-democratic. There is no ideal voting system — from first-past-the-post counting in Canada to regional-based weighting in the U.S. electoral college. Such structural flaws, however, are different from incontestably non-democratic governance. For instance, we have received complaints over the years from people suggesting that places like China and Iran are democracies simply because they hold elections. But China is objectively authoritarian for many reasons, beginning with its single-party system as well as the fact that only a certain percentage of the adult population is granted direct national voting rights. The same is true of the Islamic Republic of Iran, where an unelected body known as the Guardian Council exercises sweeping electoral powers, disqualifying any candidates deemed insufficiently loyal to the clerical establishment that has run the country since the late 1970s. For these reasons, it's acceptable to refer to, say, **China's regime** and **Iran's regime** as occasional synonyms for each country's government. Be aware that in other contexts, the word "regime" has a broader, generic meaning that is normally fine (e.g., **a tax regime, a fitness regime**). See [administration](/home/a#administration) for related guidelines (e.g., the Obama administration but the Trudeau government), as well as [dictator](/home/d#dictator).

**regimen** (a strict routine; a prescribed schedule, especially medical) While expressions such as an **eating regimen** (specific diet) and **exercise regimen** (specific fitness program) are entrenched and accurate, the shorter, related word regime has become an increasingly common synonym (**exercise regime**). Both are acceptable.

Jean-Marie Benjamin**; write either **Benjamin** or **the priest** in second reference, _never_ "Rev. Benjamin" or "the Reverend." The abbreviation Rev. appears before the full names of ministers and [priests](/home/p#priest) from many faiths (e.g., Roman Catholic, Anglican, United Church, Presbyterian, Buddhist). Do not use Rev. or Reverend as a noun for clergy member. For instance, in second reference to **Rev. Frank Jones**, write **Jones says** but _never_ "the Reverend says." By contrast, the honorary title monsignor is conventionally used as a noun. If a cleric is a [monsignor](/home/m#monsignor), Rev. is not required. **Rh factor** (Rh stands for "Rhesus") Blood is classified in several ways. In addition to types (A, B, etc.) there is an "Rh factor test." More than 80 per cent of people have the Rhesus antigen in their blood. They are **Rh positive**. Those without the antigen are **Rh negative**. The antigen was first discovered in rhesus monkeys. **Do not assume that readers will know the definition or significance of Rh factors.** When writing about safe blood donations, pregnancy complications, etc., the term and its relevance to the story should be made clear.

**ride-hailing** (hyphen) Preferred description of app-based ride-booking services, such as [UberX](/home/u#UberX), because it's clear and neutral. The term ridesharing, by contrast, has been challenged by critics who say it conveys altruistic "sharing" of a destination, along the lines of carpooling, rather than a commercial transaction between driver and passenger. Some people dislike using "hail" to describe requests made by electronic devices, but it's no different from the word "call" being adopted during the early days of telephones. **Ride-booking** is an acceptable alternative to ride-hailing.

**Royal Canadian Air Force** (first reference), Canada's **air force** in second reference; **Royal Canadian Navy** (first reference), Canada's **navy** in second reference (See [military forces](/home/m/military-forces) for details)

**Royal Canadian Legion**, the **legion's fundraising** campaign, parade of **legionnaires, legionnaires' disease**, etc.

**Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP)** RCMP car, RCMP musical ride, **the Mounties**, an RCMP officer, but avoid redundant "RCMP police officer") See also [police forces](/home/p/police-forces) and [RCMP are](/home/r/rcmp-are-versus-rcmp-is) (versus RCMP is)

**Royal Newfoundland Constabulary** (See [Newfoundland and Labrador](/home/n/newfoundland-and-labrador) for details)

**Royal Ontario Museum** (in Toronto) Use **ROM** only in second reference, after being spelled out in story; if used in a headline, the abbreviation must be spelled out very high in the story — preferably in the lead)

**Royal 22nd Regiment** (_not_ "Royal 22e Régiment") See [military forces](/home/m/military-forces) and [Van Doos](/home/v#VanDoos)

**Roy Thomson Hall** (no "p" in name) This concert hall, which opened in downtown Toronto in 1982, was designed by architect Arthur Erickson.

**r.p.m.** (revolutions per minute)

**RRSP** (registered retirement savings plan)

**RSS** (fine in first reference to "Really Simple Syndication"; does not need to be spelled out in story, but meaning needs to be clear from context, a brief description, etc.)

**ruble** (not rouble), for monetary unit; **rubble** (fragments of stone, brick, etc.)

[rugby terms](/home/r/rugby) (e.g., the sport "rugby sevens" (lowercase) in stories, but "rugby 7s" in headlines)
