### reign versus rein

**Reign versus rein**

**Reign means to hold office** (a _person's reign_), **especially when referring to royalty** (the King_'s reign_). A constitutional monarch _reigns but does not rule_.

Reign also means **to prevail** (_confusion reigns, Reign of Terror, reign supreme_), **and to hold a title** (_reigning champion_).

**Rein means a leather strap or other type of restraint** (_rein in, keep a tight rein on, free rein_). It can also mean **a symbol of power** (as in the _reins of_ government).

Be particularly careful not to confuse a person's _reign_ with the _reins of power_ when writing about authority.

### replacement worker

**Replacement workers**

**Prefer the neutral term "replacement workers"** for someone brought in to perform the jobs of those locked out or on strike.
**
Generally avoid the noun "strikebreakers."** The vague term could mean replacement workers or members of striking unions who have decided to cross their own picket lines. The word is also problematic in the case of lockouts, since these are not technically "strikes."

Note: Accusing someone of crossing a picket line can be very serious if the allegation is unfounded. It may also put an alleged strikebreaker at risk during a heated contract dispute.

**Avoid inflammatory and pejorative terms (e.g., "scab")** unless attributed in directly transcribed quotes.

Prefer the neutral term "**contract dispute**" over [labour dispute](/home/l#labourdispute), since the disagreements involve both management and labour.

See also: [strike versus lockout](/home/s#strike)

### Residential schools

**Residential schools**

**The noun "residential schools" does not need to be defined** in our journalism. **Whenever practical, however**, it's helpful to **provide brief context**.

Residential schools were church-run, government-funded boarding centres for Indigenous children that operated in Canada for more than 100 years. Indian, Inuit and Métis children were removed from their families and culture and forced to learn English, embrace Christianity and adopt the customs of the country's white majority. In 2008, the federal government formally apologized for the residential school system and other policies of assimilation. **Avoid phrasing that suggests the program involved voluntary enrolment** (i.e., do NOT simply say children "attended" or "went to"). Instead, always make it clear that they were "forced to attend" or "required to go to."

**Although no modifier is required, if placing an adjective before residential schools choose Indigenous rather than "First Nations"** (which is technically limited to status and non-status Indians).

When reporting on the suffering and loss of young Indigenous people taken from their families and forced to attend residential schools, the term **survivor** has become the preferred way to describe former students. It refers to surviving a harmful policy of assimilation, of being victims of abuse — emotional, and in some cases physical and sexual. The label **former students** generally remains fine, especially when suffering and loss is not the story's focus, or when individuals being reported on have specifically said they don't consider themselves "survivors." It's also OK as a synonym for variety, if you feel the word survivor is becoming overly repetitive within a piece. **Be aware that the Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Canada used both terms** ("former student" and "survivor") in its final report. It also called for the creation of a **National Residential School Student Death Register**.

See also: [Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Canada](/home/t/trc)
See also: [Indigenous](/home/i/Indigenous)

For more background on residential schools, see the CBC News feature [Stolen Children](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Faboriginal%2Ftruth-reconciliation%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2RYC94vVZSyMyMTQfGZbbD)

### royal commissions

**Royal commissions**

**Capitalize both the full and the shorter common names** (often featuring surnames) **of royal commissions:**

_The Royal Commission on National Development in the Arts, Letters and Sciences_ is also known as _the Massey Commission_ or t_he Massey Commission on the Arts._

**But use lowercase “commission” for general references:**

The royal commission
The commission on economic development
The health-care commission

The federal Privy Council Office offers an alphabetic list of more than 200 past royal commissions in its main "[commissions of inquiry](https://www.canada.ca/en/privy-council/services/commissions-inquiry.html)" index online.

See also [green versus white](/home/g/green-paper-versus-white-paper) papers

See [royal titles](/home/r/royal-titles) for detailed guidelines on when the word royal is capitalized (e.g., Royal Family for Canada's sovereign, royal family for other monarchs, royal assent, royal proclamation, royal visit, royal wedding)

### Pronunciation FAQs

**When Canada's monarch dies:****
Crown succession facts, terminology**

**In many ways, reporting on the death of Canada's Queen or King is no different from any other story about the end of a life.** It requires mindfulness about everything from the **tone of overall coverage** to the **accuracy of words** chosen. **In other ways, however, the story is unique because of how central the Queen or King is to a parliamentary democracy** that's also a constitutional monarchy — from the omnipresence of the person's name and portrait, including on our currency, to the role of the Crown in passing laws and prosecuting offenders. **It's also unique because we cannot ignore the inevitable calls from some citizens to end ties with the Royal Family** and have Canada start electing its head of state. We would not be doing our jobs if we ignored criticism of the monarchy as an institution. At the same time, we must remember that to a large number of Canadians, the death of a steadfast figure who's been on the throne for many years can be, in some ways, akin to the death of a family member. **The key is balance and respect.**

**This entry answers common questions that have come up in the past about how to report on the death of Canada's monarch.** The FAQs were written in the spring of 2022, the year Queen Elizabeth, then 96, marked 70 years on the throne. THE TEXT WAS UPDATED IN THE DAYS AFTER HER DEATH in September of the same year:

1\. [Is there specific wording to use when reporting the Queen's death?](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/r/royal-succession-faqs/#FAQ1 "Royal succession FAQs") No.
2\. [Is it accurate to call Charles the new King?](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/r/royal-succession-faqs/#FAQ2 "Royal succession FAQs") Yes.
3\. [Will he be King Charles III?](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/r/royal-succession-faqs/#FAQ3 "Royal succession FAQs") Probably. Yes. (Confirmed hours after Elizabeth's death on Sept. 8, 2022).
4\. [Can we drop the 'III' in most stories?](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/r/royal-succession-faqs/#FAQ4 "Royal succession FAQs") Yes.
5\. [Does he become King of Canada?](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/r/royal-succession-faqs/#FAQ5 "Royal succession FAQs") Yes.
6\. [Is it OK to refer to Camilla as the Queen Consort?](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/r/royal-succession-faqs/#FAQ6 "Royal succession FAQs") Potentially. Yes. (Confirmed hours after Elizabeth's death.)
7\. [Does William instantly become Prince of Wales?](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/r/royal-succession-faqs/#FAQ7 "Royal succession FAQs") No. (UPDATE: New title granted the day after Charles became King.)
8\. [Will the funeral be a national day of mourning?](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/r/royal-succession-faqs/#FAQ8 "Royal succession FAQs") Yes.
9\. [Do we get new money right away?](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/r/royal-succession-faqs/#FAQ9 "Royal succession FAQs") No.
10\. [Will some proper nouns change?](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/r/royal-succession-faqs/#FAQ10 "Royal succession FAQs") Yes.

**1\. Is there specific wording to use when reporting the Queen's death?** **No.**
**The first key editorial consideration is accuracy. This means the death must be confirmed** by an official source (e.g., a palace news bulletin). The source's authenticity needs to be verified before we broadcast or publish the news, and our initial bulletins should include the attribution at some point fairly high up, although not necessary in the lead. We do not report on rumours of the monarch's death (e.g., based on unverified reports by other media or on claims being made on social media). Be aware that even official websites and personal online accounts can be hacked as part of an elaborate hoax. At the end of the day, being right is more important than scrambling to be first by a few seconds. **Once we decide to run with the story, there's no set script that must be used.** An on-air lead could be as brief and powerful as: "**Queen Elizabeth is dead.**" Certainly there are other options, especially as the hours roll by and the story becomes more about reaction, funeral plans and the heir's ascension. Some journalists, for instance, may want to stress her historical status, including how many years she was on the throne, in their leads. And, of course, the medium can make a difference. A web piece, for instance, might have far more detailed opening paragraphs with comparatively long but still compelling subordinate clauses that are deemed suitable for the eye.

NOTE: It's a myth that as a Crown corporation we handle breaking news about the monarch's death in some roundabout, highly formal way. A few generations ago, when TV was in its infancy and mobile devices like smartphones were found only in science fiction books, the protocol might have been to prepare the masses for bad news by, say, playing sombre music on air for several minutes before reading rather flowery prose. Now, however, it seems more appropriate simply to interrupt regular programming for major breaking news that's conveyed in a clear, direct way.

**2\. Is it accurate to call Charles the new King?** **Yes.**
**Charles automatically becomes King the moment Elizabeth dies**, which means his reign begins immediately, regardless of when the official coronation ceremony is held. The latter might not actually take place for many months or longer. In Elizabeth's case, for instance, she became Queen in February 1952 but wasn't ceremoniously crowned until June of 1953. **Charles** can be said to be the **new monarch**, the **King**, to have **ascended to the throne**, etc. A reminder that **the possessive of Charles is Charles's.** There is a statutory protocol in place that symbolically confirms the change in monarch. This involves a body known as the Accession Council in the United Kingdom, which normally convenes within 48 hours of the sovereign's death to sign documents and issue a ceremonial proclamation. Ottawa's representative is traditionally the High Commissioner of Canada (the equivalent of an ambassador to the U.K.). Regardless, **Charles can still be referred to as King before the Accession Council meets.** Its proclamation from St. James's Palace simply confirms in writing what is already a reality. Be aware that in the event the Queen became so severely incapacitated that medical experts said she could no longer perform her duties as monarch, Charles would become **Prince Regent** rather than "King," unless Elizabeth abdicated.

**3\. Will he be King Charles III?** Probably.**Yes. (Confirmed hours after Elizabeth's death on Sept. 8, 2022).**
One of the first details to confirm after Elizabeth's death is what's known as her successor's "regnal name" — i.e., what the monarch decides to call himself. Therefore, **do NOT use the name King Charles III until it's confirmed by an official spokesperson**, such as the private secretary to the sovereign, the Buckingham Palace press office or the communications secretary at Clarence House. Although the odds may not be great in the eyes of some bookies, **it's possible that the King could pick a different regnal name**. Many past monarchs have gone this route. For example, Elizabeth's father King George VI had previously been known as Prince Albert. **Charles's options include King Philip I and King George VII**, which are already part of his formal name (Charles Philip Arthur George).

**4\. Can we drop the 'III' in most stories?** **Yes.**
Assuming the new monarch sticks with what people have called him since 1948, **the name King Charles on its own will normally be sufficient in most news reports**. Just as we rarely referred to Queen Elizabeth as "Elizabeth II" in routine stories, there will be no need to insist on Charles III across the board.

**5\. Does he become King of Canada?** **Yes.**
**The King or Queen of the United Kingdom is automatically the King or Queen of Canada**, according to law. Changing this would require amending Canada's Constitution. NOTE: **There's usually no need to specify "King of"** in stories about the British monarchy because the prepositional detail is understood. Charles will not only be King of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, but also the King of Canada and various other Commonwealth countries. Saying King Charles III or King Charles will suffice in most stories, just as it did in news reports about his mother.

**6\. Is it OK to refer to Camilla as the Queen Consort?** Potentially.**Yes. (Confirmed hours after Elizabeth's death.)**
**Camilla is expected to become Queen Consort**, based not only on tradition but [the specific wishes of Queen Elizabeth in a February 2022 public statement](https://www.royal.uk/accession-day-2022) marking the 70th anniversary of her ascension to the throne: "_And when, in the fullness of time, my son Charles becomes King, I know you will give him and his wife Camilla the same support that you have given me; and it is my sincere wish that, when that time comes, Camilla will be known as Queen Consort as she continues her own loyal service_.” **HOWEVER, do not refer to the Duchess of Cornwall as Queen Consort until officials have confirmed the wording is accurate.** Even if we verify that this is her new title, **avoid calling her the "new Queen,"** since that implies she is replacing the monarch. Bear in mind, too, that any reference to a Queen other than Elizabeth may be considered jarring or confusing until after the funeral, even in the attributive noun Queen Consort. **One option is to call her Camilla** during this period. Use your judgment. Technically, the British Parliament could pass legislation that imposed specific restrictions about her title. Unless that happens, however, she will likely be crowned Queen Consort with the King at a similar but simpler ceremony. **The tradition is to crown the Queen Consort on the King's coronation day**, although the event can be held later. By convention, the title **Queen Consort can be shortened to Queen alone as long as the context makes her identity as the spouse of the reigning monarch clear** (e.g., Elizabeth's grandmother **Queen Mary** was the Queen Consort of King George V). This is why, for example, stories about the historic, month-long visit to Canada by Elizabeth's parents in 1939 often referred to **the King and Queen** rather than to the King and Queen Consort.

**7\. Does William instantly become Prince of Wales?** **No.**
Prince William does not automatically become Prince of Wales after Charles's ascension. **He is likely to be given that title eventually, as the next in line to the throne, but it is ultimately up to the new monarch.** While the Prince of Wales traditionally becomes King, the title is technically not heritable. **UPDATE: Charles confirmed that William had become the new Prince of Wales the day after the Queen's death. William's wife, Catherine, became the Princess of Wales.** 

**8\. Will the funeral be a national day of mourning?** **Yes.**
**Based on tradition, the sovereign's funeral will be declared a national day of mourning in Canada** and many other parts of the Commonwealth. However, it's not automatically a paid statutory holiday. That normally requires either a proclamation by the federal cabinet or legislation through Parliament. The most likely scenario based on procedural manuals written half a century ago is that Canada's prime minister will publicly express sympathy over the Queen's death as well as the country's support for the new King, followed by an order in council declaring "a national holiday" on the day of the funeral. Flags will be ordered to fly at half-mast on all federal buildings, including the Peace Tower, until sunset of the day of the funeral, and both the House of Commons and the Senate will adjourn for a declared period of mourning. **UPDATE: Less than 48 hours after the Queen's death, the date of her state funeral was announced:** **Monday, Sept. 19, 2022.** **Canada's prime minister declared it both a national day of mourning and a federal holiday, although whether non-federal workers got paid time off varied across the country, depending on the province or territory.**

**9\. Do we get new money right away?** **No.**
**There will be no immediate change to Canada's money.** The Royal Canadian Mint and the Bank of Canada do not have templates in place for coins and paper dollars featuring a different sovereign. Therefore, after Canada's Governor General declares that there is a new “lawful and rightful liege," a plan will be set in motion to gradually produce and introduce money featuring the King. But there's no estimate on how quickly the new money will start to appear, since the reigning monarch must approve whatever portrait is used in the design. Meanwhile, old currency featuring Elizabeth will remain legal tender for many years.

**10\. Will some proper nouns change?** **Yes.**
**Beyond money, there will be a lot of paperwork**, as government officials start slowly changing every dated reference to the Queen and Her Majesty on various documents, including future Canadian passports, which, unless the phrasing is revised, will eventually be issued "in the name of His Majesty the King." The country's royal anthem, God Save the Queen, becomes **God Save the King**. Be aware that **Charles's ascension will automatically affect various institutional names** in Canada — from Her Majesty's Loyal Opposition becoming **His Majesty's Loyal Opposition** in Parliament to the Court of Queen's Bench becoming **the Court of King's Bench** and the Queen's Printer becoming **the King's Printer**. The change in monarchs will not, however, affect other unique proper nouns, such as the Queen's Own Rifles of Canada, founded in the early 1880s under Victoria, Elizabeth's great-great grandmother.

See also [Royal titles](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/r/royal-titles/ "Royal titles") for an overview of various style points, including capitalization.

### Royal titles

**Royal titles** 

[Camilla](/home/r/royal-titles#camilla) (Queen Consort) 

[Prince William](/home/r/royal-titles#princewilliam) (and Catherine) 

[Prince Harry](/home/r/royal-titles#princeharry) (and Meghan) 

[Other royal families](/home/r/royal-titles#otherroyalfamilies) (e.g., King Albert II of Belgium) 

[Miscellaneous](/home/r/royal-titles#miscellaneous) (Royal vs. royal, sheik, life peerages, etc.)

**Overview**

Use **king and queen** when referring to heads of state. The titles are **capitalized before names. But in generic second references, the nouns are lowercase except for Canada's sovereign and former British monarchs.**

> the King (_Canada's monarch_)
>
> King Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden
>
> the king (_foreign monarch_)
>
> Sweden's queen
>
> Victoria became Queen at 18 (_former British monarch_)
>
> Queen Elizabeth's Platinum Jubilee (_former British monarch_)


Be aware that **there's a different between ascension to the throne and a coronation**. Both are a part of royal succession. But **the former happens almost immediately** (usually within hours) of the death of a monarch while **the latter conventionally refers to an official "crowning" ceremony** — one that often takes place long after ascension (sometimes more than a year later). This detail is relevant in many ways. It affects everything from calculations about **a monarch's reign** (which **begins at ascension** rather than at coronation) to accurate use of the title queen or king before the official coronation ceremony. It also explains the meaning behind sayings such as, "The Queen is dead. Long live the King." (See our [Crown succession FAQs](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/r/royal-succession-faqs/ "Royal succession FAQs") published before Elizabeth's death in 2022 for details about various JSP and stylistic considerations after the death of Canada's monarch.)

**Royals rarely use surnames. So when titles have been inherited or bestowed, they’re generally needed to help identify people** (e.g., prince and princess for the children and certain grandchildren of monarchs, duke and duchess for the spouses of some royals). **These titles are not capitalized, however, unless directly before the name** (e.g., Prince Harry is a prince not a Prince) **or as part of a compound title** (e.g., the Prince of Wales arrived early, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge spent Canada Day in Ottawa).

**Never assume that a spouse holds a matching title** (e.g., Queen Elizabeth's husband, Philip, was a prince and a duke but not a king, and King Charles's second wife, Camilla, was referred to as a duchess not as a princess after their marriage in 2005 when he was still the Prince of Wales). Double-check if you're not sure.

**Limit use of formal titles to keep coverage uncluttered and understandable** (e.g., prefer Princess Beatrice over "Princess Beatrice of York" as long as the context makes it clear she's Prince Andrew's daughter). **Also, leave out royal rankings** (e.g., HIH for Her/His Imperial Highness, HRH for Her/His Royal Highness, HGDH for Her/His Grand Ducal Highness), which are inessential and overly stilted for news stories. While **HRH variations** are sometimes used in place of names (e.g., "their royal highnesses"), especially in live on-air coverage, it's optional. It can also be tricky (e.g., the Duchess of Cambridge is a "royal highness" but the Duchess of York is not). So don't use the term unless you're sure.

**Always keep the best interests of our audience in mind** (e.g., see [Harry vs. Duke of Sussex](/home/r/royal-titles#princeharry) below). **The overriding principles are accuracy and clarity, not blind conformity to abstruse protocol.**

NOTE: The capitalization rules outlined below apply to online journalism. They're based on long-standing publishing conventions. Different style is acceptable in [TV supers and graphics](/home/t/tv_text), however, depending on relevant in-house guidelines.



**King vs. Queen**
**The word king applies only to male monarchs**, not to consorts. So **the husband of a reigning queen is not a king** (e.g., Queen Elizabeth's spouse was Prince Philip).

**The word queen, by contrast, is used in three ways:**

-   **Queen regnant** (the monarch, as in Queen Elizabeth): _Regnant is implied and never used in stories_.
-   **Queen Consort** (wife of the reigning King; capitalized, as in "the Queen Consort died 17 years after King George V"): _While consort can be used it's normally implied_, as in "She's expected to become Queen Catherine when her husband, Prince William, ascends to the throne." See also [other royal families](/home/r/royal-titles#otherroyalfamilies) for use of "queen consort" lowercase.
-   **Queen dowager** (lowercase; mother of the reigning Queen, as in the late Queen Mum — Elizabeth's mother and husband of King George VI): _Dowager is almost never used in stories_ because the person's profile usually makes this narrower meaning of Queen clear.



**King Charles**
**Born: Nov. 14, 1948.** Married Diana Spencer in 1981. They were divorced in 1996. Married Camilla Parker Bowles in 2005.
**Became monarch in September 2022** after the death of his mother, Elizabeth II.

**In first reference, Canada's current head of state is normally called:**

> **the King**
>
> **King Charles**
>
> **King Charles III** (**\***)
>
> **\*** = The _current Canadian monarch's ordinal designation ("III") is optional but often unnecessary in routine reporting. The roman numerals are usually reserved for highly formal settings, such as coverage of a coronation ceremony, or in cases when there might be confusion with a past historical figure_.

**In second reference:**

> **the King**
>
> **Charles**


The **possessive of Charles is Charles's**, as in **Charles's reign**, **Charles's speech**, **Charles's sons**. It's no harder to say on air than the "bus's engine," a "business's profits," a "witness's testimony," their boss's retirement," "St. James's Palace" or "Mars's orbit." See [s' versus s's](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/handy-links/punctuation/s-versus-s-s/ "S versus s s") for an in-depth look at various rules and conventions tied to possessive apostrophes.


It's **unnecessary to say or write His Majesty**, but if it's spelled out (e.g., in transcribed quotes) the first letters are capitalized.

**Avoid calling him the King of England** (a subsumed title that hasn't been used by a sovereign since 1707). While he is King of the United Kingdom, generally steer clear of that wording. Instead, say or write **King of Canada** if you think such detail is called for in a particular story. This prepositional context is often superfluous, since it's usually implied by the shorter title "the King." In certain cases, however, the longer phrase ("King of Canada") can be helpful to underscore his constitutional role in our parliamentary democracy. For the same reason, use **Royal Family** rather then "British" Royal Family.


**Camilla**
**Born: July 17, 1947.** Became Queen Consort in September 2022.

**In first and subsequent references, Charles's wife can be called:**

> **the Queen Consort** (as in the King and the Queen Consort)
>
> **Camilla** (as in Charles and Camilla)
>
> **Queen Camilla** (**^**) or Queen Consort Camilla
>
> **the Queen** (**^**)
>
> **^** = _**By convention, the title Queen Consort can be shortened to Queen alone as long as the context makes her identity as the spouse of the reigning monarch clear** (e.g., Elizabeth's grandmother Queen Mary was the Queen Consort of King George V). This is why, for example, stories about the historic, month-long visit to Canada by Elizabeth's parents in 1939 often referred to the King and Queen rather than to the King and Queen Consort. It's also why many British news organizations ran headlines about "King Charles and Queen Camilla" leaving Balmoral Castle the day after Elizabeth's death._



**Prince William (and Catherine)**
**In first reference, Charles's elder son and heir to the throne can be called:**

> **Prince William** (_a title he's had since birth in 1982_)
>
> **the Prince of Wales** (_a title given to him by his father in 2022, the day after Charles became King_)  **\*\***
>
>
> **\*\*** = William has other honours that are largely irrelevant in daily journalism because "Prince of Wales" identifies him instantly. For instance, _William was granted the Duke of Cambridge title on his wedding in 2011, and his father's Duke of Cornwall title was passed to him when Charles became King in 2022. He's also, among other things, the Earl of Strathearn and Baron Carrickfergus._
>
> **In second reference:**

> **William** (_preferred_)
>
> **the prince** (_rare; keep lowercase when this title is used on its own_)


Although **the clipped form Will** is acceptable in headlines and light features, it's generally a poor choice in routine news coverage because some in our audience perceive it as overly informal (along the lines of calling King Charles "Charlie" or "Chuck"). **Avoid the British shorthand Wills** with an "s." See related guidelines about "Kate" below.

**In first reference and subsequent references, William's wife is called:**

> **Catherine** (_as in William and Catherine_)
>
> **the Princess of Wales**
>
> **Catherine Middleton** (_acceptable convention in some contexts; see below for details_)
>
> **Kate** (OK sometimes, but informal so use sparingly) **\*^\***
>
>
> **\*^\*** \= **For several years, "Kate" was preferred over Catherine**, which she spells with a C not with a K. **After she became the Princess of Wales in the fall of 2022, however, CBC News switched to Catherine as our default** to better reflect the Royal Family's known preference. The BBC and several other British media outlets adopted a similar style. This **does NOT mean that the familiar but breezy diminutive is automatically wrong.** It largely depends on context, a given story's tone, etc. But **Kate is now generally considered a notably informal alternative, along the lines of the occasional use of "Di" for Diana**, the late Princess of Wales. So while it's fine to mention, say, a crowd's chant of "Will and Kate," our usual style is to refer to William and Catherine in stories.

**There is no need to use any of Catherine's other titles**, such as the Duchess of Cornwall and Cambridge, or the Countess of Strathearn and Baroness Carrickfergus.

Just as the Duchess of Cornwall was referred to as Camilla Parker Bowles in news stories for several years after her marriage to Charles, **the Princess of Wales is still sometimes called Catherine (or Kate) Middleton** when it's the clearest way to introduce her (e.g., if there's no pertinent reference to Prince William that puts her name, alone, in context). **This is an acceptable convention that helps our audience**.

See also [**Prince and Princess of Wales**](#princeandprincessofwales) below for additional background about the titles.

**William and Catherine's children are:**


> **Prince George** (born in July 2013)
>
> **Princess Charlotte** (born in May 2015)
>
> **Prince Louis** (born in April 2018)

There's **no need to add the prepositional detail "of Wales" after their names** (e.g., **Prince George of Wales**), even though the longer form appears in various official documents.


The **[official line of succession on the Royal Family's website](https://www.royal.uk/succession)** lists 20 heirs, with Prince William first, Prince Harry fifth, Prince Andrew eighth, Prince Edward 13th and Princess Anne 16th.


**Prince Harry (and Meghan)**
**In first reference, Charles's youngest son can be called:**

> **Prince Harry**  (_preferred; virtually no one has called him by his formal name, "Prince Henry," since his birth in 1984_)
>
> **the Duke of Sussex** (_a title granted on his wedding in 2018_)


**There's no need to call him the Duke of Sussex unless the detail is relevant to the story or the title is considered the simplest way to introduce Harry and his wife** (i.e., the Duke and Duchess of Sussex). He has other titles, too, that are irrelevant in daily journalism, including Earl of Dumbarton and Baron Kilkeel.

**In second reference:**

> **Harry** (_preferred_)
>
> **the prince** (_rare; keep lowercase when this title is used on its own_)


**In first and subsequent references, Harry's wife is called:**

> **Meghan** (_as in Harry and Meghan_)
>
> **Meghan Markle** (_acceptable convention in some contexts; see "Catherine Middleton" above for reasoning and details_)
>
> **the Duchess of Sussex**
>
> **the duchess** (_rare; keep lowercase when this title is used on its own_)


**Meghan is not a princess**, so do not call her "Princess Meghan." See [Prince of Wales](/home/r/royal-titles#princeandprincessofwales) below for details about the relatively narrow rules governing the title "princess."


There’s **no need to use her full birth name** (Rachel Meghan Markle) since she’s known as Meghan rather than as Rachel. There's also **no need to use any of Meghan's other titles**, such as Countess of Dumbarton and Baroness Kilkeel.

Harry and Meghan's **children are:**


> **Prince Archie** Mountbatten-Windsor (born in May 2019)  **\*\*\***
>
> **Princess Lilibet** Mountbatten-Windsor (born in June 2021)  **\*\*\***
>
> **\*\*\*** = _There's no need to add the prepositional detail "of Sussex" after their names (e.g., Prince Archie of Sussex), even though the longer form appears in various official documents. As grandchildren of a reigning King, the titles prince and princess were expected to be automatically granted to Harry's children when Queen Elizabeth died and Charles ascended to the throne. However, the final decision rested with the new King. In March 2023, Buckingham Palace confirmed that the children would be known as Prince Archie and Princess Lilibet._



**NOTE:** Less than two years after their May 2018 marriage, the couple moved to North America and announced plans to step back from royal duties. **Effective April 1, 2020, they officially stopped representing the Queen at public events, and stopped using their "HRH"** (His/Her Royal Highness) **honorifics.** Their other titles remain in place, however, which means **it's OK to continue to call him Prince Harry, and to use the proper nouns Duke and Duchess of Sussex** to help identify them. In February 2021, Buckingham Palace reaffirmed that the couple would "not be returning as working members of the Royal Family."




**Queen Elizabeth** (1926-2022)
Born: April 21, 1926. **Died: Sept. 8, 2022** at the age of 96.
Married Philip Mountbatten (formerly Prince Philip of Greece) in 1947.
**Became monarch in February 1952** at the age of 25 after the death of her father, George VI.

**In first and subsequent references, Canada's previous head of state is normally called:**

> **the former or the late Queen**
>
> **Queen Elizabeth**

> **Queen Elizabeth II** (**\*\***)
>
> **Elizabeth**
>
>
> **\*\*** = Roman numerals are optional. There's **often no need to identify her as Queen Elizabeth II,** unless the story makes a historical reference to Elizabeth I and the "II" detail helps clarify which monarch you're talking about.


Elizabeth was indisputably the **longest-serving sovereign in British history** (just over **70 years and seven months** on the throne). **Be aware that some historians also argue that she was "effectively" the longest-serving monarch in world history.** That's because Elizabeth assumed the daily duties of Queen the moment her father died in 1952. By contrast, France's Louis XIV was only four when he became that country's sovereign in 1643, which meant that the boy's mother was technically in charge as regent until he turned 13. So while on paper Louis was a monarch for just over 72 years — roughly 20 months longer than Elizabeth — in reality she reigned more than half a decade longer than him.


**Prince Philip** (1921-2021)
Born: June 10, 1921. **Died: April 9, 2021** at the age of 99.

**In first reference, Elizabeth's deceased husband can be called:**

> **Prince Philip** (_a title he was given in 1957_)
>
> **the former or the late Duke of Edinburgh** (_a title he had since his marriage to Elizabeth in 1947_)


**In second reference:**

> **Philip** (_preferred_)
>
> **the late Duke of Edinburgh**
>
> **the duke** (_rare; keep lowercase when this title is used on its own_)


The term Prince Consort (husband of a reigning monarch) is accurate but was virtually never used in Philip's case. Although he was not technically a member of the Royal Family, as narrowly defined by monarchy scholars who traditionally exclude male consorts, it's an accepted convention to refer to him as such without qualification. On the Queen's own website, Philip was described this way in 2013: "Though the Duke of Edinburgh does not appear in the immediate line of succession, he appears directly after the Queen in the order of precedence as he is considered the second most senior member of the Royal Family."



**ALSO DECEASED**

> **the Queen Mum** (Elizabeth's mother: 1900-2002)
>
> **Princess Margaret** (Elizabeth's sister: 1930-2002)




**The rest of the Royal Family**
**In first reference:**

> **Princess Anne** (_acceptable and preferred, even though she's been officially known as **the Princess Royal** since 1987; children are Peter Phillips and Zara Tindall_)
>
> **Prince Andrew** (_children are Princess Beatrice and Princess Eugenie_), the **Duke of York** (since 1986)
>
> **Prince Edward** (_children are Lady Louise Windsor and James, the Earl of Wessex_), the **Duke of Edinburgh** (since 2023)


**In second reference, first names are sufficient:** Anne, Andrew, Edward.

**Lady Sarah, the Duchess of Edinburgh, the Duchess of York**
The **late Princess Margaret's children** are David Armstrong-Jones, the **Earl of Snowdon**; and **Lady Sarah** Armstrong-Jones.

Princess Edward's wife, **Sophie Rhys-Jones**, has been the **Duchess of Edinburgh** since 2023. Before that, she was known as the Countess of Wessex.

Prince Andrew's ex-wife, **Sarah Ferguson**, is still the **Duchess of York** but should not be referred to as a member of the Royal Family. Prefer Sarah in second reference. Generally avoid the colloquial clipped surname "Fergie," except in light features.

The Royal Family's other members have much lower profiles and are rarely included in Canadian news stories (e.g., the Queen's first cousins, the Duke of Kent and his sister, Princess Alexandra).


**The titles Prince and Princess of Wales**
In the Commonwealth, **the Prince of Wales is the male "heir apparent" to the throne.** Under succession protocol, **if a woman is first in the line to the throne, she is normally known as "heir presumptive"** rather than as the "Princess of Wales" (e.g., until her father's death in 1952, the Queen was Princess Elizabeth and heir presumptive.) In news stories, **the shorter and clearer expression "heir to the throne" is preferred in all contexts.**

The spouse of the male heir to the throne is normally called **the** **Princess of Wales**. But since the title was so closely associated with Diana, Charles's first wife, through the 1980s and 90s, his second wife, Camilla, was known only as the Duchess of Cornwall when he was still the Prince of Wales. **Catherine Middleton became Princess of Wales the day after Charles became King in 2022.**

**"Princess" is properly used before a name only if the woman was given that title at birth** (e.g., Princess Margaret). It's becoming increasingly common, however, to report the courtesy title Princess of Wales this way (e.g., the officially correct title "Diana, Princess of Wales" is often shortened to the late "Princess Diana"). See [Diana](/home/r/royal-titles#diana) below for more details.

If the Prince of Wales has sons or daughters, the children's titles are technically tied to the father's on paper (e.g., Prince George of Wales, Princess Charlotte of Wales) but not in practice (i.e., we simply refer to Prince George and Princess Charlotte). **Confusion sometimes arises when an heir to the throne's son marries. That's because the official title of the wife counterintuitively features the husband's name** (e.g., Catherine Middleton technically became "Princess William of Wales" upon marriage in 2011). **Such forms are never used in news stories**, however.

See [Prince William and Kate](/home/r/royal-titles#princewilliam) above for related guidelines.


**Diana**
Born Diana Spencer in 1961. Became "Lady Diana" in 1975 when her father, a viscount, inherited the title of earl. Married Charles in 1981 at age 20. Announced separation in 1992. Divorced in 1996. Killed in a car crash in Paris with companion Dodi Fayed on Aug. 31, 1997, at age 36. Mother of Princes William and Harry.

**In first reference, prefer constructions such as:**

> **Diana, the former Princess of Wales**
>
> **the late Princess Diana** (_see usage note below about accepted convention_)
>
> **the late Lady Diana**
>
> **Diana** (_Her name is iconic and normally understood on its own_)


**Second references can include:**

> **Diana**
>
> **Lady Di, Princess Di** (_also fine in headlines_)
>
> **the former Princess of Wales**


She is commonly remembered as "Princess Diana" or "Princess Di" based on popular but incorrect rewording of the title she held while married to Charles (as outlined in [Prince and Princess of Wales](/home/r/royal-titles#princeandprincessofwales) above). **Diana was not actually a princess** — a style point closely enforced for several years after her divorce. **Since her death, however, the compounds Princess Diana and Princess Di have become the norm.** Given that the actual historical reference is correct (she is primarily remembered for her time as the Princess of Wales), **it's OK to use the form Princess Diana, especially when space is at a premium** (e.g., in a headline or lead). But avoid generic references to her as "a princess" in stories.


**House of Windsor vs. Mountbatten-Windsor**
**Windsor is the former Queen's family name, as well as the name of King Charles** **and his sons. The rest of Elizabeth's children**, and all their descendants not in line to the throne, **have a hyphenated last name: Mountbatten-Windsor.
**
**Royalty rarely use surnames, however, so this is not normally a concern in news stories.** It's perfectly acceptable to talk about **the House of Windsor** and **the Windsors** when reporting on **the Royal Family** in general

The Duke of Windsor was the title given to Elizabeth's uncle, King Edward VIII, after his abdication in 1936.


**Other royal families**
**Use capital letters only for the Canadian sovereign's family: the Royal Family.** All other royal families are lowercase (e.g., Sweden's **royal family**, the Danish **royal family**).

**The titles king, queen, prince and princess are capitalized only in front of the names of living members of foreign royal families** (e.g., King Albert II of Belgium but Belgium's king; Queen Sofia of Spain but the king and queen of Spain, Spain's queen consort; the former queen Astrid of Belgium).

**Full names are optional in first reference** (e.g., Saudi Arabia's King Abdullah Bin-Abd-al-Aziz Al Saud). **But generally prefer a shorter version** (King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia) **unless there's an editorial reason for the longer proper noun** (e.g., possible confusion with someone else in the story, such as a monarch's recently deceased parent).

**Keep in mind that the head of a royal family may not actually be a king or queen** (e.g., the Grand Duke Henri Guillaume of Luxembourg and Prince Albert of Monaco).


**Miscellaneous (Royal vs. royal, Sheik, life peerages, etc.)**
**The word royal is virtually always lowercase** (_royal assent, royal proclamation, royal residences, royal salute, royal tour, royal wedding, royalty_) **unless part of a proper noun** (_Royal Canadian Mounted Police, Royal Ontario Museum, Royal Newfoundland Constabulary_). **The primary exception is Royal Family**, applied only to Canada's (the Commonwealth's) monarch as outlined above. See also [royal commissions](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/r/royal-commissions/ "Royal commissions").

**When applicable, generally include roman numerals in first references to monarchs unless they are Canada's current head of state** (_King Abdullah II of Jordan_) **unless space is tight** (e.g., in headlines). **Use the name alone in second reference** (_King Abdullah or Abdullah_). See also [King Charles III](/home/r/royal-titles#kingcharles) above for related convention.

**Ordinals are not normally used for other titles unless the detail helps our audience** understand the story better (e.g., Diana's brother Charles can be called the _Earl Spencer_ rather than _the 9th Early Spencer_ as long as overall context makes his identity clear).

**Drop supplementary honorifics such as Sheik before names if a primary title has already been used** (e.g., _King Hamad of Bahrain_; second reference _King Hamad_ or _Hamad_ but not "_Sheik Hamad_").

**Avoid superfluous titles unless there's obvious editorial merit.** For example, before Charles became the King in 2022, there was generally no need to refer to him as the Duke of Cornwall, a title he'd held since the age of 4. The most common exceptions were when the detail was relevant to a given story, or when it was considered the simplest way to introduce Charles and his wife (i.e., the Duke and Duchess of Cornwall). Dukedom is the highest rank in British peerage.

**Don't stuff stories with formal titles** (e.g., marquess and marchioness, viscount and viscountess). **Instead, prefer simpler language** — as long as its accurate and clear (e.g., _Lord Bristol_ or _Lady Bathrather_ than _Marquess of Bristol_ and the _Marchioness of Bath_).

**Life peerages** (titles that are not hereditary) **should be used only if relevant to the story.** The most common life peerage granted by the Crown is baron. In these cases, type in the full title: **Lord Black of Crossharbour (Lord Black** in second reference). Otherwise, stick to the name that's more familiar (**Conrad Black**).

**Generally avoid knighthood-related honorifics "Sir" and "Dame"** (e.g. Alfred Hitchcock, not "Sir Alfred Hitchcock," Elizabeth Taylor, not "Dame Elizabeth") **unless referring to historical figures whose titles have become entrenched over time** (e.g., Sir John A. Macdonald). These chivalry addresses are not actually peerages. See [honorary titles](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/titles/#honorary "Titles") for more details.

**Constitutional monarchs reign** rather than rule. Do not confuse [reign and rein.](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/r/reign-versus-rein/ "Reign versus rein")

### rugby

**Rugby terms**

centre, fly half, flying winger, fullback, goal line (two words), halftime, inside centre, lineout, number 8 position (_specific team role_), offside, outside centre, right flank, scrum half, Test match (_uppercase T, lowercase m_), try, tries

The sport rugby sevens (lowercase) should be written as rugby 7s (no apostrophe) in headlines to save space. Since it's not a widely known noun, it should be briefly defined in stories. For example: "Rugby sevens is designed to be faster-paced than the traditional version of the sport. Each team fields seven players instead of 15."

See the [sports overview](/home/s/sports-overview) for links to various other entries, including baseball, basketball, curling, football, golf, hockey, soccer and Olympics.

### Russian names

**Russian names**

**Names converted from Cyrillic to Latin characters are sometimes wildly different**, depending on the approach taken by the person you're identifying. **Follow an individual's preference**.

For instance, if "x" has been chosen instead of "ks," it would be _Alexander_ instead of the more common Russian version, _Aleksandr_.)

**Although some conversions are standard** (ov and ev, not off or eff), **retain traditional spellings of names that have become entrenched through usage:**

> Alexander Solzhenitsyn (not _Aleksandr_)
>
> czar (not _tsar_)
>
> Khrushchev (not _Khrushchyov_)
>
> Peter the Great (not _Pyotr_)
>
> Rachmaninoff (not _Rakhmaninov_)
>
> Tchaikovsky (not _Chaikovsky_)

**If a person's preference is not known, do _not_ make up your own spellings.** For further guidance, see [transliterations](/home/t/transliterations).


**Kyiv, Chornobyl, etc.**
**Since the breakup of the Soviet Union, many Russian transliterations have been replaced** by different spellings that more closely represent local languages now used in the former Soviet republics. **For instance, we write Kyiv** (not _Kiev_), **Chornobyl** (not _Chernobyl_) and **Odesa** (not _Odessa_) because these combinations of letters better reflect the [Ukrainian names](/home/u/ukrainian-names).

NOTE: **Our main source for the spellings of communities outside of Canada is the National Geographic Atlas of the World.** But there are exceptions (e.g., Kabul not "_Kabol_," Damascus not "_Dimashq_," and Rome not "_Roma_"). So always check the CBC Language Guide first.

See also [Soviet Union](/home/s/soviet-union) and [Kremlin](/home/k/kremlin)
See also [cities of the world](/home/g/geography-cities)

The name of the largest city in New Brunswick doesn't need to be followed by the abbreviation N.B. But don't call it the province's capital, which is Fredericton. And be sure to spell Saint John correctly. Do not confuse it with the capital of Newfoundland and Labrador, St. John's. See also [provinces and cities](/home/p/provinces-and-cities)

Do not confuse with New Brunswick's largest city, Saint John.) See also [St., Saint, St-, Sainte, Ste-](/home/s/st-saint-ste) and [provinces and cities](/home/p/provinces-and-cities)

**St-Laurent, Louis Stephen** (1882-1973) Use the spelling Louis St-Laurent not "Saint-Laurent" or "St. Laurent" (See also [St., Saint, St-, Sainte, Ste-](/home/s/st-saint-ste))

**St. Lawrence, Gulf ofSt. Lawrence RiverSt. Lawrence Seaway, the seaway, St. Lawrence Seaway Authority**

**St. Martin** (French side of Caribbean island), **St. Maarten** (Dutch side of Caribbean island) **St.** is abbreviated in both cases. No Hyphen. Collectively, it's **generally OK to refer to St. Martin alone when we mean the entire island** (e.g., in hurricane coverage). But avoid implying that it's a single territory by adding descriptive detail whenever possible, such as the "**French and Dutch sides of St. Martin**." There is no need to adopt the long and awkward proper noun, "St. Martin/St. Maarten." On the other hand, do not rely solely on the name "St. Martin" when specifically referring to "St. Maarten." Instead, add a qualifying description such as "the Dutch side of St. Martin." In stories focused on only one of the territories, it can be simpler to use applicable spellings to identify the location (e.g., "Canada's consulate in St. Maarten" rather than "Canada's consulate on the Dutch side of St. Martin"). In either case, stick with "St." **Avoid adopting foreign variations, such as the Dutch word "Sint,"** for the same reason we write "Cape" instead of the Portuguese word "Cabo" in Cape Verde. (See [country names](/home/g/geography-cities#citiesaroundtheworld))

**St. Paul** (Minn.)  Although it's the capital of Minnesota, we generally add the state abbreviation after the name in first reference to aid our audience. St. Paul is the smaller half of the **Twin Cities** of [**Minneapolis-St. Paul**](/home/m#Minneapolis)

**St. Petersburg** (formerly Leningrad)

**St-Pierre-Miquelon** (France's eight small islands off Newfoundland's southern coast) It's common and **generally easiest to treat this name as a fused compound with hyphens and no conjunction** (St-Pierre-Miquelon), especially on the web. This is also CP style, which means St-Pierre-Miquelon is common in wire copy. It's OK to add either "et" (**St-Pierre-et-Miquelon**) or to use the more conversational English form (**Saint Pierre and Miquelon**, without hyphens), especially in broadcast scripts. "St" traditionally becomes "Saint" when the English conjunction "and" is added. Generally **stick to one spelling within any given story**. These are **all entrenched and acceptable short forms** for the archipelago (officially referred to as _La collectivité d'outre-mer de Saint-Pierre-et-Miquelon_, translated as France's overseas collectivity of Saint Pierre and Miquelon). It's unnecessary to use the full, formal proper noun. (See also [country names](/home/g/geography-cities) for general guidelines about common geographical names)

**Saamis Teepee** (in Medicine Hat, Alta.) Use this spelling for consistency. Tourism officials sometimes refer to the gigantic steel structure as the "Saamis Tepee." But it's a common convention to prefer in-house spellings of generic words in such nouns.

**Salish Sea** A large area of coastal waters between Vancouver Island, mainland British Columbia and Washington State [was officially named the Salish Sea](https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/b-c-waters-officially-renamed-salish-sea-1.909504) by Coast Salish and government leaders in 2010. The Salish Sea includes Puget Sound, the Juan de Fuca Strait and the Strait of Georgia; the original names for those three areas have been retained, but Salish Sea refers to the entire body of water.

**say, says, said** (a common and highly recommended verb for attribution) "Say" is sometimes undervalued. It's well tailored to journalism because it's short, neutral and unobtrusive. See [say vs. admit, claim, concede, etc.](/home/s/say)

**scalp** (v.) An acceptable way to describe the reselling of tickets, normally at inflated prices. People who engage in **ticket scalping** are called **scalpers**. These terms have been widely used in North America since the 1800s. They're instantly understood and, so, preferred over bureaucratic-sounding synonyms (e.g., "ticket speculation"). The verb scalp is also neutral. In the context of ticket sales, it refers to one person exploiting another by taking a significant profit (cut off the top), and is unrelated to the act of skinning conquered enemies' heads. Worth noting: Historians say warriors in Europe and other parts of the world engaged in battlefield scalping over the centuries. So when writing about this different, barbaric meaning of scalping, it's inaccurate to imply that the practice is linked solely to Indigenous people in North America.

**sea anchor, sea biscuit, sea bottom, sea breeze, sea cadet, [sea can](#sea_can) (_no hyphen_); sea captain, sea chest (_no hyphen_), sea cow, sea floor, sea horse, sea ice, sea kayak, sea lane, sea legs, sea level, sea lion, sea mile, sea monkey, sea otter, sea salt, sea scallop sea serpent, sea urchin

**sea can** (two words) Colloquial and relatively obscure term for "sea canister." Generally reserve for directly transcribed quotes. Otherwise, prefer common descriptions such as **large shipping crate, marine freight container**, etc. Be aware that there are several spellings of the clipped noun (e.g., fused, hyphenated, "C" instead of sea). If used, stick with sea can for consistency. Few compounds involving the word "sea" are hyphenated, and many of them are evolving (e.g., "sea-chest" is now "sea chest"). Proper nouns are exceptions (e.g., the Alberta-based company **Sea-Can Containers**).

**selfie, selfies** (self-portrait, often photographed with a smartphone or other mobile device and uploaded to [social media](/home/s#socialmedia) sites such as Facebook, Flickr or X, formerly known as Twitter) The term selfie has been around since at least 2002, although it didn't become popular until years later. The word is now common enough that it doesn't require a definition, as long as the meaning is clear by the story's context. There's also no need for quotation marks, even in web headlines.

**sell-off** (n.), as in "The sell-off continued Tuesday." When sell is a verb, there's no hyphen (e.g., "They will sell off the rest of the stocks"). But the preposition "off" is often redundant in such cases (i.e., "They will sell the rest of the stocks").

**sellout** (n. and adj.), as in "It was another sellout" and "The sellout crowd cheered wildly." When sell is a verb, the words are not fused (e.g., "The band is expected to sell out the stadium").

**semi (as a prefix)**
semi-annual, semi-automatic, semicircle, semicolon, semi-conscious, semi-detached, semifinal, semifinalist, semi-formal, semigloss, semi-official, semi-sweet, semitone, semi-trailer, semitransparent, semitropical, semi-weekly

**semi-trailer** or **tractor-trailer** (but _never_ semi-tractor-trailer). The abbreviated form **semi** is fine in second reference to these trucks.

**Senate**
Use uppercase **Senate** for a national legislature, but **California's senate**, a **university senate**, etc. (See [legislative bodies](/home/l/legislative-bodies)) Generally _avoid_ the terms **upper chamber** and **upper house** for the Canadian Senate because they can be confusing when juxtaposed against [the House](/home/h/house) (the conventional label for the House of Commons). **Red Chamber** is OK as a widely understood colloquialism, but see [nicknames](/home/n/nicknames#caution) for editorial caution about overuse. Use abbreviation **Sen.** directly before the names of current members of Canada's Senate or the U.S. Senate: **Sen. Joyce Fairbairn**, but "Fairbairn has been a **senator** since 1984." (See also [titles](/home/t/titles) for general guidelines). While some party affiliations have become less clear in Canada's Senate over the years, generally follow the choice of individual members, themselves. This includes continued use of the word Liberal, regardless of whether senators belong to a specific parliamentary caucus (e.g., **[Liberal Sen.](/home/l/liberal-senator) George Baker**). Reserve the term "[Independent](/home/i#Independent)" for senators who no longer have ties to any political party. Canadian senators are picked by the prime minister. The choice may be partisan or non-partisan. Although senators are technically appointed by the [Governor General](/home/g/governor-general), the selection is always based on the PM's wishes. So while it's constitutionally inaccurate to say the prime minister _appoints_ senators, it's equally misleading to say the Governor General appoints them without putting that verb in context. It's usually simplest to report that the PM has _named_ new senators, or _picked_ new senators, etc. But in debates over Senate reform, it's conventional to link the PM directly to terms such as _senate appointments_. (See also [Congress](/home/c/congress) for related guidelines on U.S. Senate)

**senility** (See [dementia versus senility](/home/d/dementia))

**seniors' residence** (generally implies a nursing home, although it can mean an apartment building or condo building specifically for seniors paying to receive various levels of care); **seniors' home** (See also [possessive apostrophe](/handy-links/punctuation/possessive-apostrophe) for related guidelines, such as _musicians' instruments_ but _farmers market_)

**sensual** (implies carnal delights, especially sexual pleasure); **sensuous** (appealing to the senses, especially through beauty)

**separate** (_not_ seper-) **separate school, separate school board,** etc.

**separatist** (-ar _not_ -er) See [**separatist and sovereigntist**](/home/s/separatist-sovereigntist)

**Sept. 11 attacks, Sept. 11** (adding "2001" is optional, but requires a comma — **the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks** — to conform to our [dates](/home/a/abbreviations#dates) style) **9/11** is fine in headlines, but use an oblique stroke,**/**, not a hyphen. The [phone number 911](/home/p/phone-numbers), by contrast, is written without a slash, hyphen or other punctuation. Do not spell out September in full unless in a proper noun (e.g., the **National September 11 Memorial and Museum**, also known as the 9/11 Memorial and Museum). See [Ground Zero](/home/g#GroundZero). **Do not refer to the Sept. 11 attacks as** [terrorist attacks](/home/t/terrorist-and-terrorism). The hijackings led to passenger jet crashes in Washington, D.C., Pennsylvania and Manhattan. The World Trade Center (WTC in second reference) was destroyed. (The [September 11 Digital Archive](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2F911digitalarchive.org%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2gC2NQwvVNurM21GNrPX6G) is an excellent resource for details about the attacks. It was created by several U.S. universities, historical societies and foundations.)

**sergeant** (Sgt.), **staff sergeant** (Staff Sgt.), **sergeant major** (Sgt. Maj.), etc. For details on using abbreviations, see [military ranks](/home/m/military-ranks) as well as [police ranks](/home/p/police-ranks)

**sergeant-at-arms** (the person who carries the ceremonial sceptre, known as the mace, in and out of the House of Commons), **sergeants-at-arms** (plural)

**serial killer** (avoid misleading or inaccurate usage) There's no universally accepted definition. The obvious criterion is that the person be accused of a series of killings. While two homicides technically qualifies, the term **serial killing normally suggests three or more murders by the same suspect or suspects on different dates**. The time lag is important. Killing a dozen people at once is [mass murder](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/h/homicide/#mass-murder "Homicide") rather than serial killing.) Avoid sensationalizing crime stories. If someone is charged with killing two hitchhikers over three years, reporting the facts rather than reaching for a label such as "serial killer" is the best way to serve our audience.

**serial rapist** (A key caveat outlined in [serial killer](/home/s#serialkiller) above applies: There must be a series of rapes over time. Whether the term is appropriate requires editorial judgment.) See also [rape versus sexual assault](/home/r/rape-versus-sexual-assault) for important, related guidelines.

**series** (usually lowercase, as in "World Cup series), but **the World Series** (baseball championship) also known as **the Series** in second reference

**sh (not sch-)
****Use _sh_ not _sch_ at the start of many common Yiddish terms:** shemozzle, shlemiel, shlep, shlock, shmaltz, shmo, shmooz, shnook, shtick; (_Avoid_ "Shmuck," which is based on the word for "penis")

**Shad** (national charity); the **Shad program**; **Shad students** (capital S only; avoid all-uppercase renderings) Shad is an Ontario-based organization that places high school students into month-long summer courses at participating universities across the country. Previously known as the Shad Valley program. "Shad" comes from the name of a creek in Aurora, Ont., where the first program was held in the early 1980s. Since the letters are not an abbreviation, they should not be put in all-caps. Although the charity now prefers "SHAD," we don't adopt this type of whimsical all-uppercase or all-lowercase typography — often rooted in marketing, and which can change overnight. (See [quirky capitalization](/home/q/quirky-capitalization), such as Visa instead of VISA, and [acronyms](/home/a/acronyms) for related guidelines)

**shakable** (_not_ -eable)

**shake down** (v.), **shakedown** (n. and adj.)

**shake up** (v.), **shakeup** (n.), **shaky, shakier, shakiness**

**shaming** (participle), as in **online shaming**. While the term "shaming" sometimes refers to exposure of socially unacceptable attitudes or behaviour (e.g., shining a light on bullying), be aware that the word can also convey a sense of malicious or vengeful vigilantism (i.e., that the "shaming" itself can refer to a form of bullying). No hyphen is required in "online shaming" because the modifier describes a method of criticism rather than a topic. By contrast, prefer hyphens in compounds that convey a single idea, as in **body-shaming, fat-shaming, [slut-shaming](/home/s#slut-shaming)**. This typographical style is based on convention and ease of comprehension (e.g., **online shaming** but **online body-shaming**). Guard against overuse of the word shaming, especially in uncommon or awkward coinages  (e.g., "grammar-shaming" and "salary-shaming").

For variety, the proper noun, which means "Bay of the Sheikh" can be shortened to **Sharm** in occasional subsequent references. For consistency, use this spelling. **Shebaa Farms** (avoid alternative English spellings such as Chebaa and Shaba) This is the name of a strip of disputed territory where the Lebanese, Syrian and Israeli borders meet. Israel controls the land, which it insists was captured from Syria in 1967. But Lebanon and Syria say that it's Lebanese territory and must be returned. The 14 farms are named after the village of Shebaa, on the western slopes of Mount Hermon.

**slash** (**/**) Do not confuse with a backslash (\\), which is rare punctuation used in some computer programming. A slash (/) is a forward-sloping diagonal line, also known as a solidus. In addition to appearing in a lot of internet addresses ([URLs](/home/u/urls)), slashes are used in ratios ([km/h](/home/m/metric-versus-imperial#spellingout)), fractions ([6/49](/home/l#Lotto)) and various other terms established by convention, such as the historic date [9/11](/home/s#Sept11) and "either/or" constructions. There's no need to say "forward" slash on air. The left-to-right lean is implied.

**snafu** (a glitch or blunder; a muddled state) Originally, an abbreviation for "**situation normal, all f--ked up,**" according to most dictionaries. The term is believed to have been coined by the U.S. military during the Second World War. Since then, however, the Canadian Oxford points out that "fu" has also come to mean "fouled up." Snafu is an acceptable word in our journalism, especially to describe a series of problems (e.g., frequent subway shutdowns) rather than merely one-time snags. The shorthand form is considered sufficiently censored. See [offensive language](/home/o/offensive-language) for related guidelines, including how to handle similar abbreviations.

**sneak, sneaked** (also **snuck**) For years, the preferred past tense and past participle of sneak was sneaked: _He sneaked past the guard. They have sneaked into several movies._ But snuck, which has been around since the late 1800s, has become more common in speech and is now widely accepted. Either form is OK in our journalism. Since snuck is more conversational, it's often preferred: _He snuck past the guard. They have snuck into several movies._

**social distancing** (prefer **physical distancing**) The term "social distancing" was initially used by the World Health Organization and other medical authorities during the [COVID-19 pandemic](/home/c/coronavirus#novelcoronavirus) in early 2020. The synonym "physical distancing" was later recommended, however, because it better conveyed the same meaning: Stay away from other people to avoid getting ill or spreading the infection. In today's internet age, it's possible to keep one's distance from family and friends while remaining socially connected via technology. Furthermore, experts say it's beneficial to maintain contact with others by text, voice and/or video communications during quarantine periods. So while the expression "social distancing" remains relatively common, generally prefer alternatives like "physical distancing" when covering outbreaks. Plain, descriptive language is another option (e.g., "stay home as much as possible" and "keep at least two metres away from others when you go outside").

**social media** (interactive platforms for sharing photos, videos, audio or text) The term commonly refers to websites and digital services such as YouTube, Facebook, Flickr and X, formerly known as [Twitter](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/#Twitter "T"). The compound social media is now so widely used, it no longer requires a definition in news stories. (For editorial direction, see [Use of Social Media](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fio.cbcrc.ca%2F%23%2Fresources%2Fuse-of-social-media-medias-sociaux-1.4523590&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1zXH-yM-1HqHysoCF1JkEe) in the CBC's Journalistic Standards and Practices policies, as well as the corporation's 2017 [Social Media Guidance](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.radio-canada.ca%2F_files%2Fcbcrc%2Fdocuments%2Fpolicies%2Fsocial-media-guidance-oct-2017-en.pdf&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3EeeSXN-KQf88AQnt64YME) handout for all employees)

**Socialist** (political party or one of its members); **socialist** (philosophical attitude embracing socialism)

Soleimani had been one of Iran's top military commanders, as well as the architect of Tehran’s proxy wars in the Middle East. At the time of his death, he was head of the Quds Force — an elite unit within Iran's Islamic Revolutionary Guard. The Quds Force is listed as a terrorist organization by several governments, including Canada and the U.S.

While such differentiation can be meaningful to a local or regional audience, it can also be potentially confusing to the rest of Canada. In those cases, more precise wording may be merited. **strait** (generic) a narrow passage between two seas or other large bodies of water. Capitalized when part of a proper noun (e.g., the **M'Clure Strait** off the Northwest Territories, the **Taiwan Strait**, the **Strait of Hormuz**). For hundreds of years, "strait" was an alternative English spelling of "straight." Now, however, its use is mainly limited to the nautical sense of a relatively small waterway, as well as to the figurative sense of something confining or distressing (**dire straits**).

**strike, strikers, strikebound** (one word) Always distinguish between a **strike** (when workers have walked off a job) and a **lockout** (when an employer refuses to let employees work). A **walkout** is another word for strike. As a dispute evolves, briefly provide context (e.g., "Canada Post employees were locked out after 12 days of rotating strikes"), and make sure adjectives are accurate (e.g., **striking workers** become **locked-out workers**). If particular action is deemed illegal, specify why (e.g., the employer was not given enough notice, legislation prevents the workers from striking). A [**wildcat strike**](/home/w#wildcatstrike) is a sudden walkout that's not authorized by the workers' union. Use **contract dispute** rather than "[labour dispute](/home/l#labourdispute)." Prefer [**picket**](/home/p#picket) over "picketer." Use **union leader, union head**, etc., instead of [union boss](/home/u#union-boss-bosses). Exercise extreme caution before using the work **strikebreaker**, even in quotations. Accusing someone of crossing a picket line can be very serious if the allegation is unfounded. It may also put an alleged strikebreaker at risk during a heated contract dispute. See also [**replacement worker**](/home/r/replacement-worker). The word **negotiation** is a generic description, although it often implies bargaining between the employer and employees only. In Canada, **conciliation** normally refers to a third party's attempt to help end an impasse before there's a walkout or lockout by clarifying positions and identifying possible compromises. The term **mediation** generally refers to negotiations with the aid of a third party after there's a walkout or lockout. Conciliators and mediators facilitate bargaining with suggestions but make no actual decisions. **Arbitration** refers to formal dispute resolution involving a third party who listens to both sides and then makes decisions. Since arbitration can be **binding** or **non-binding**, always specify. See also [**student strike**](/home/s#studentstrike) below, as well as **[boycott](/home/b/boycott)** for related guidelines and **[fired](/home/f/fired)** for caveats about contract termination.

While it's OK to report these proper nouns verbatim, neutral phrasing is often better in generic contexts  (e.g., referring to **special powers** or **expanded powers** given to some mayors). See [Act (legislation)](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/a/act/ "Act") for details.

**student strike** (Acceptable way to describe a large number of students refusing to attend class. Other options include [**boycott**](/home/b/boycott), protest and demonstration.) While the word [**strike**](/home/s#strike) is traditionally associated with employees who walk off the job, it's broadened over the years to include "a refusal to take part in scheduled or otherwise expected activity." This can range from the actions of a large group to one person (e.g., an individual's "hunger strike"). See the related note about the [Quebec student strike](/updates/2012/2012-05-24) of 2012.

**super (as a prefix)
**Generally, "super" is fused to the other word — even when the latter begins with another "r." For example: **superabundant, superbug, supercritical, superfine, superhuman, supermarket, supermom, supernatural, supernova, superpower, superrefined, supersize** (adj. and verb),**superstar, superstore, superstructure, supertanker**. But in a few cases there's a hyphen, based on convention, such as: **super-absorbent, super-angry, super-Conservative, super-duper, super-jail**. Check the Canadian Oxford dictionary if you're uncertain. Use the modifier "super" on its own (without a hyphen) in compound constructions only when it's treated as part of a proper noun (e.g., **Super Bowl, Super Continental**).

**Super Bowl** (See also [football terms](/home/f/football))

**superbug** (drug-resistant bacteria or other microorganism) See also [bacteria versus virus](/home/b/bacteria-versus-virus) for related style and editorial guidelines, as well as the CBCNews.ca feature [Battling germs that keep getting stronger](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews%2Ftechnology%2Fbattling-germs-that-keep-getting-stronger-1.781633&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw35TVhrJDNLUlXEkPZe9i1Z) for specific background on superbugs.

**supercilious** (_not_ -silious)

**superintendent** (Supt.) See also [police ranks](/home/p/police-ranks)

**super PAC** (two words; no hyphen; lowercase "s") Refers to groups that can essentially spend unlimited amounts of money to try to influence U.S. elections as long as they don't actually contribute funds to specific parties or candidates. It's normally unnecessary to spell out PAC as "**political action committee**," since the term is now entrenched. But be sure that the story's context makes the meaning clear. See also [abbreviations](/home/a/abbreviations) for more detailed guidelines on applicable capitalization rules.

**supersede** (take the place of; set aside; appoint someone else; cease to employ)

**superspreader, superspreading** (fused) Refers to the transmission of an infection to an unusually high number of people (e.g., the wedding became a **superspreader event**). Generally avoid describing individual people as "superspreaders" (i.e., do not use the word as an agent noun) because it's considered unnecessarily demonizing, especially in the middle of an [epidemic or pandemic](/home/e/endemic-epidemic-pandemic).

**Superstack** (iconic smokestack in Sudbury) See also [nicknames](/home/n/nicknames)

**supervised injection site** (common and acceptable term) While the older label **safe injection site** remains OK when space is tight (e.g., in web headlines), the adjective "supervised" is fact-based, more descriptive and, so, generally best. There's no ban against "safe" as a modifier in established constructions (e.g., "**safe sex**" conventionally means "safer" or "protected sex," and "**safe injection**" conventionally means "safer" or "medically supervised" injection). But there's also no need to rely on this sometimes contested use of "safe" as our default wording when common and equally conversational alternatives exist. Be aware that some people prefer the broader word "consumption" over "injection" to cover nasal and oral drug delivery. It's OK to use phrasing like **supervised consumption site** as long as the meaning is clear from a given story's context, but it's not mandatory. While some drugs may be inhaled or swallowed at these centres, needles are still widely used — which means the facilities, themselves, can still be accurately described as supervised "injection" sites rather than "consumption" sites. The noun **clinic** is generally fine as a synonym for "site" in our stories, as long as a modifier like "injection" or "consumption" is included to distinguish these centres from routine medical clinics. It's worth noting that the word clinic is broadly defined in English (e.g., blood donor clinics, dental clinics, golfing clinics, legal clinics, writing clinics). (See also [Insite](/home/i#Insite))

**support** (n. normally singular) The word **"support" is a common verb** (e.g., "She supports him" and "They have a family to support"). It's **also a common adjective** (e.g., "A support beam") that sometimes functions as one part of a compound noun rather than as a simple modifier (e.g., "support staff"). **As a standalone noun, "support" is normally singular** (e.g., "They applied for financial support"), unless specific, individual supports are treated as countable rather than non-countable elements (e.g., "The bridge's steel supports buckled"). This distinguishes the word from a term like "services" (e.g., "The Opposition says the cost of those services is out of control"). Outside of direct quotes, resist the unorthodox use of the plural noun "supports" in non-countable contexts (e.g., "They qualified for federal and provincial support" rather than "They qualified for federal and provincial supports").

**suppress, suppression, suppressor supremacist** (_not_ supremist)

**Supreme Court** (federal, provincial, state)

**Supreme Court of Canada** (**SCC**, not "SCOC") Since neither abbreviation is well known, it's generally best to use other short forms (e.g., "top court" or "highest court"). But in TV graphics or web headlines where space is tight, SCC is OK. For details on why O is conventionally left out, see [abbreviations](/home/a/abbreviations).

**Sûreté du Québec** (**SQ** fine in second reference, as well as in web headlines) Since this noun is not instantly recognized across the country, be sure the story makes it clear that Sûreté du Québec refers to Quebec's provincial police. For CBC journalism outside Quebec, especially broadcast material, it's fine to prefer the description **Quebec provincial police** throughout. See also [police forces](/home/p/police-forces) and [French words](/home/f/french-words-and-accents) for related guidelines.

**Suriname** (_not_ "Surinam") A country on the northeast coast of South America. The capital city is Paramaribo.

**surveys** (see public opinion [polls](/home/p/polls))

**Suu Kyi, Aung San** (pro-democracy leader in **[Myanmar](/home/m/Myanmar)** for several decades, and winner of the 1991 Nobel Peace Prize) **Suu Kyi** is fine in web headlines and in second reference, as explained more fully in our overview of [Asian names](/home/a/asian-names).
  (See also [pronunciation](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2Flng%2Frecherche%2Findex.aspx%3FProId%3D32903&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3D6ALIpL5AunOo_q5QmnU2))

**SUV** (**sport utility vehicle**, _not_ "sports")

**swap** (_not_ swop)

**SWAT** ("special weapons and tactics" team) See also [acronyms](/home/a/acronyms)

**swath** (n.), a strip, mowed path or broad stretch; **swathe** (v.) to cover or wrap

**Swaziland** (now called **[Eswatini](/home/e#Eswatini)**)

**swear in** (v.) The past participle is **sworn in**: "She was sworn in last month." **swearing-in** (n.) "The swearing-in was delayed by an hour." **swearing-in** (adj.) "The swearing-in ceremony will be held on Friday."

**sweatshirt**

**sweetgrass**

**swine flu, swine flu virus, swine flu vaccine** (lowercase) OK in first reference (headlines and leads). Generally use the alphanumeric name of the influenza A virus after that (e.g., **H1N1, H1N2, H3N2**). In TV and web graphics, prefer H1N1, H1N2, etc. When adding scientific context in second reference, options include: the **H1N1 influenza virus**, the **H1N1 flu virus**, the **H1N2 flu** and the **H1N2 virus**. Avoid hyphens, slashes, etc. It's a **Type A flu**. (See [**flu**](/home/f/flu) for detailed guidelines on influenza, as well as [bacteria versus virus](/home/b/bacteria-versus-virus) for related terminology.)
