**symposium, symposiums** (See also [Latin plurals](/home/l/latin-plurals))

**synagogue**, but **Beth Emeth Bais Yehuda Synagogue**, etc. (See also [churches](/home/c/church))

**sync** (short for synchronization) Prefer this spelling (**out of sync, synced, lip-syncing**). For consistency, avoid the alternative "h" version.

**syndrome, Reye's syndrome, Down syndrome**, etc.

**synod, an Anglican synod**; but uppercase when referring to a national or international body (**the General Synod**) as well as in specific proper nouns (the **Northeastern Pennsylvania Synod** is one of 65 synods in the Evangelical Lutheran Church; the **Orthodox Holy Synod**)

### SARS

**SARS**

**SARS is a contagious and sometimes fatal respiratory illness caused by a strain of [coronavirus](/home/c/coronavirus)** — the same family of viruses tied to the common cold.

**The abbreviation is in capital letters with no periods. The full name is lowercase** (i.e., we write "**severe acute respiratory syndrome**"). This is also the case with AIDS. (See [abbreviations](/home/a/abbreviations))

SARS is now a relatively common acronym. Whenever practical, the full name of the illness should be spelled out at some point in web stories. In broadcast scripts, however, more conversational options are generally OK (e.g., simply referring to SARS in second reference as an "acute respiratory illness").


**'SARS virus'**
Be careful when using medical terms. **SARS is an illness rather than a virus**. It's caused by the SARS-associated coronavirus (SARS-CoV-1). **Referring to SARS as a virus is as imprecise as calling AIDS a virus.** Put another way: Just because [AIDS](/home/a/aids) is believed to be caused by a virus (HIV) doesn't make AIDS, itself, a "virus."

In most stories, there's **generally no need to use long, formal names like "SARS-associated coronavirus."** Instead, **it's an acceptable convention to write about SARS**, a SARS outbreak, people with SARS, **the SARS virus**, the **virus that causes SARS**. etc.


**SARS-like infections**
Although the last case of SARS connected to the original (2002-03) outbreak was reported in China in 2004, experts have warned that it could resurface, perhaps in mutated forms. In 2012, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control listed SARS as a severe potential health threat to the world. In 2017, scientists found bats infected with SARS-related coronaviruses.

Term such as **SARS-like illness**, a **SARS-like virus**, etc., are **OK as long as medical experts are using similar language.** But **prefer specific names when known**. In January 2020, for example, there were reports of a SARS-like outbreak in China. Eventually, the illness was named [COVID-19](/home/c/coronavirus#COVID), reflecting the fact that the first case was actually recorded in late 2019. The **COVID-19 virus, itself, was eventually named SARS-CoV-2** for reasons explained in this [February 2020 World Health Organization post](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.who.int%2Femergencies%2Fdiseases%2Fnovel-coronavirus-2019%2Ftechnical-guidance%2Fnaming-the-coronavirus-disease-\(covid-2019\)-and-the-virus-that-causes-it&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3xQ7lDAvO6aXB5XXE4EYzf). When reporting on emerging viruses and diseases, it's **helpful to mention key similarities** (e.g., respiratory illness) **and any known or apparent differences**, especially in standard virulence measurements (e.g., mortality rates, transmission risks and rates).


**Illness, infection, disease**
Writers and editors looking for SARS synonyms have a number of options. Health Canada and the U.S. Centers for Disease Control use words like **"illness," "infection" and "disease." All these terms are OK in our news stories.** Although the word "syndrome" on its own is accurate, it seems unnecessarily lofty, especially when there are alternatives. (See also [bacteria versus virus](/home/b/bacteria-versus-virus) for guidelines on using the correct terminology in health and science stories.)


**Avoid dated terms**
**The World Health Organization initially called the illness ARS** (acute respiratory syndrome) after hundreds of people became sick in China's Guangdon province in late 2002. In February 2003, one of the organization's experts on communicable diseases, Dr. Carol Urbani, renamed the disease SARS. He contracted it during his research and died. The first SARS death in Canada was in March 2003. **WHO officials called SARS "atypical pneumonia" a lot early on, but they stopped using that expression in later news releases. Be wary of repeating old terms that are no longer considered appropriate.**


See also the 2004 CBCNews.ca feature, [SARS](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews2%2Fbackground%2Fsars%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1tjGES9Q3GjednCPpoOb9p)

### say

**Say versus admit, claim, concede, etc.**

**NOTE:** For brevity, the word "say" is primarily used in this entry. But these guidelines apply to all forms of "say," including "says" and "said."


Some words are **superb workhorses**, including **say, says, and said.** They're **highly effective** because they're **neutral and unobtrusive.**

**"Say" is clear and conversational.** It doesn't change the meaning of sentences or the tone of stories. It doesn't distract attention or occupy much space. It's **well suited to our journalism**, and remains **the default choice of many good writers and editors.**

People don't always just SAY certain things, of course. Sometimes they acknowledge, agree, argue, ask, certify, challenge, conclude, contend, deduce, demand, dispute, insist, interrupt, lament, question, recall, reiterate, reply, respond, etc. Such **alternatives are perfectly acceptable as long as they're accurate.** For instance, there's a world of difference between **recount** (to tell) and **recant** (to retract). There's also a crucial distinction between **reject** (to disagree) and **refute** (to disprove).

**Always pause to consider whether specific wording is factual and suitable. Two tips:**


> **1\. Avoid using an assortment of "say" verbs solely to jazz up stories.** "Admit" is an example. Someone might agree with certain facts, confirm certain behavior, etc. But acknowledgment is not the same as admission.
>
> **2\. Refrain from repeating previously common but inappropriate or archaic expressions.** "Admit," again, is an example. We should never refer to someone who "admits" being gay, bi, trans, etc. The verb implies wrongdoing — as pointed out in our [2SLGBTQ+ overview](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/l/2slgbtq/#miscellaneous "2SLGBTQ+").


Here's **a list of some words that have caused headaches in broadcast scripts and web articles in the past** because of their narrower, conventional meanings. They're **NOT merely "say synonyms"** and, so, must be used with care.


> **Admit** implies a confession of wrongdoing or a concession.
> **Affirm** asserts strongly or confirms.
> **Allege** suggests an unproven accusation. (See [allege](/home/a/allege) for legal caveats)
> **Assert** declares resolutely.
> **Claim** suggests doubt or dispute.
> **Concede** admits or allows defeat.
> **Confess** acknowledges fault, impropriety, illegality, etc.
> **Confide** implies a confidence.
> **Declare** proclaims publicly or explicitly.
> **Disclose** presumes prior concealment.
> **Explain** gives reasoning or explanation.
> **Note** calls attention to details.
> **Maintain** can wrongly imply defensiveness.
> **Opine** expresses opinion directly.
> **Rebut** implies a tenable counterargument
> **Refute** conventionally means to disprove with evidence (i.e., NOT merely to deny)
> **Reveal** suggests prior concealment.


Remember: **The arena of standard English is teeming with nuance. So be cautious and thoughtful.** An assertion is something beyond a statement, and a rebuttal is something more than a bald rejection. As an old CBC Radio style manual put it many decades ago: "_Almost always prefer the simple, honest and unpretentious 'say' over its many substitutes and variants. You can use the variants, of course, but you must use them for accuracy, not for the sake of variety._"

See also [quotes](/home/q/quotes-overview) for general attribution best practices, and [editing quotes](/home/q/quotes-editing) for verbatim rendering guidelines

### scandal

**Scandal**

This **word requires care**, especially in political reporting.

**Scandal generally implies public outrage**. Although the Canadian Oxford Dictionary also lists "malicious gossip or backbiting" as a secondary definition, that meaning is conventionally associated with tabloid coverage of celebrities.

To maintain fairness and impartiality, **it's important to distinguish between common partisan outcry**, which can be strategically theatrical, **and genuine public anger or shock**, which can be comparatively harder to assess. Resignations are seen as signposts to many, but the departures, themselves, may warrant a closer look.

In December 2019, for example, federal Conservative Leader Andrew Scheer announced plans to step down. Some news organizations ran headlines like "Scheer resigns after private school scandal." However, the leader of the Official Opposition denied any wrongdoing in the ruckus over his use of Conservative Party money for his children's private school tuition. And while details of those expenditures caused some internal party bickering, there was no evidence of widespread public outrage.

It's **OK to use the noun "scandal" when the facts fit** (e.g., Canada's [**Senate expenses scandal**](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews%2Fpolitics%2Fsenate-expense-scandal-timeline-1.3677457&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0JYJNhBZ6ziL8Dme2yZkdY) between 2012 and 2016 exposed lax rules and improper financial reimbursement). **But if details are ambiguous and the indignation largely appears confined to partisan camps, different wording is often better**. For instance:


> **Affair** (connotes a notable and potentially troubling misstep).
> **Controversy** (describes anything disputed or controversial).
> **Probe** (refers to something under formal investigation).


**Another option is to use fact-based, descriptive phrasing** (e.g., "an ethics breach" instead of "an ethics scandal" in a story about a violation of conflict of interest guidelines).

See also [crisis](/home/c/crisis)

**School versus school**

The word **"school" is lowercase unless part of the proper name of a building or educational institution**. (A school, such as law or medicine, within a college or university is also lowercase unless the formal name is used):

_but_ York University's business school
day school, night school

### Sea-of-Japan\_East-Sea

**Sea of Japan, also known as the East Sea**

**To maintain impartiality and fairness** in a dispute over the name of a body of water between Japan and the Korean Peninsula, **point out that it's called the Sea of Japan as well as the East Sea whenever practical.** In particular, we should:

-   **Add the alternative name once** high up in stories (e.g., "also known as …").
-   **Prefer TV and web maps that use both names** (e.g., Sea of Japan / East Sea).

Brackets are an effective option in web articles. While it can be challenging to include the same information in broadcast scripts, **we should strive to add the detail in the most conversational way, regardless of the platform** — along the lines of how we refer to "[Londonderry, also known as Derry](/home/l/londonderry-versus-london)."


**Story focus, audience familiarity**

It's **normally fine to use Sea of Japan in first reference in generic stories** because the name is so deeply entrenched, and **then add wording such as "also known as the East Sea" once.** This approach is also sensible in first reference when reports are exclusively or primarily about Japan.

**Prefer East Sea in first reference in stories that are exclusively or primarily about South Korea or North Korea,** and **then add wording such as "also known as the Sea of Japan" once.** This parenthetical detail is crucial since the former name is not as well known to most Canadians, based on historical usage, and since East Sea might be wrongly confused with East China Sea.


**Background and UN position**

Japan joined the United Nations in 1956. South Korea and North Korea joined in 1991 as the Republic of Korea and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea, respectively. The dispute over the name Sea of Japan erupted at the UN shortly afterward and has continued for decades, with each country lobbying governments and media around the world.

**Tokyo argues for Sea of Japan** because it says the established hydronym is well known around the globe in numerous languages (e.g., "Mer du Japon" in French). **Seoul argues that the name East Sea has deep historical roots** on and around the Korean Peninsula, and labels the name Sea of Japan an offensive relic of colonial power. **Pyongyang, meanwhile, frequently adds a modifier** to Seoul's compass-point name: Korean East Sea. **The United Nations says it does not have jurisdiction to resolve the dispute**. While the UN Secretariat tends to use Sea of Japan in its own documents, it has explicitly stated that this does not mean that the United Nations has actually ruled on the merits of either name. **UN committees, meanwhile, have repeatedly encouraged the countries involved to settle the matter themselves.**

For decades, Tokyo cited use of the Sea of Japan by **the International Hydrographic Organization (IHO)** as evidence that its position is broadly backed by the international community. But Seoul disagreed, pointing out that when the IHO officially adopted "Sea of Japan" in 1929, the Koreas could not participate in discussions about the name because they were under Japanese rule. The IHO, which has observer status at the UN, is considered an authority on oceanic surveying. Among other things, it sets standards for nautical cartography. Various IHO committees reviewed the dispute between Japan and the Koreas over the years but declined to issue a final ruling. In November 2020, the IHO announced it was adopting **a new system of numerical designations for bodies of water**. Critics called use of numbers instead of words an interesting diplomatic strategy, but one that ultimately sidesteps a meaningful solution to controversial names. They also said numerical designations for seas, lakes, rivers, etc., had zero chance of becoming widespread in everyday speech and writing around the globe.


### separatist sovereigntist

**Separatist and sovereigntist / sovereignist**

The terms **separatist and sovereigntist are used interchangeably in Canada** to describe supporters of Quebec independence. **Both are acceptable.**
**In Quebec, the spelling sovereignist is seen and heard more frequently** because it more closely matches the French equivalent, _souverainiste_. **CBC News used to prefer a "-tist" suffix (i.e., sovereigntist instead of sovereignist)** based on the term's root: sovereignty. This was also the approach taken at many other major English news services, including CP. **But either spelling is now acceptable** (i.e., sovereigntist or sovereignist), based on common usage. **For consistency, use one spelling throughout a news story** (and in the case of TV or radio, throughout a newscast whenever possible).

**The above latitude (-tist or -ist) applies to the spoken word as well.**
 See [pronunciation](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fmtlntapps08.apps.in.cbcsrc.ca%2Fapps%2Flng%2Frecherche%2Findex.aspx%3FProId%3D34494&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2gf9RCtVBOU9OkZpQwkt-U) for details

Neither separatist nor sovereigntist (sovereignist) appears in the federal government's 2000 Clarity Act, which uses "secession" throughout. But **"secessionist" is not part of the common Canadian lexicon, so it's generally a poorer choice** for English news stories about Quebec independence. **Anglicized forms of the French word indépendantiste** (i.e., "independantiste" and "independentist") **are rarely used for the same reason**.

Constitutional experts point out that **independence, itself, does not automatically mean the severance of all ties** with Canada. R**egardless, "Quebec sovereignty" and "Quebec separation" do imply formal secession** from the federation.

**Be aware that not everyone perceives the words "sovereignty" and "separation" as neutral.** The Oxford Guide to Canadian English Usage points out that separatist is "commonly used by those who dislike the idea of Quebec's breaking up" while sovereigntist is "favoured by those who espouse a sovereign Quebec." **For this reason, it can be a good practice to include both terms in our stories when there's space.**

The term **sovereignty-association** has been around since the 1960s. It is the standard English translation of one of the original slogans of the Mouvement Souveraineté-Association in Quebec. The exact meaning is debatable since there's no consensus on the nature and depths of ties being proposed.

See also [referendums versus plebiscites](/home/r/referendum-versus-plebiscite)
See also [Parti Québécois (PQ)](/home/p/party#BQ)

### slum, ghetto, shantytown

**Slum, ghetto, shantytown, etc.**

**There's no universally accepted definition of "slum." It's applied to a range of substandard housing conditions in different parts of the world.** Since the term is so broad, context is relevant. The rental property of a "slum landlord" in North America, for example, usually means something very different from, say, the dwellings in Dharavi, on the outskirts of Mumbai, where parts of the movie _Slumdog Millionaire_ were filmed.

**Here are some general guidelines about "slum" and a few related words:**

**_favela_**
**Portuguese for shantytown in Brazil. Slum is an acceptable alternative.** Examples are Rocinha and the Alemao complex. **_Favela_ is too obscure to use in our journalism without a brief definition** (e.g., "Drug trafficking is rampant in the many shantytowns, or _favelas_, around Rio de Janeiro"). The same principle applies to similar nouns plucked from other languages (e.g., the Spanish term **_villa miseria_** used in Argentina and the French word _bidonville_ used in Morocco). In web stories, all of these labels should be in italics because they're considered [foreign rather than English](/home/f/foreign-words). See also [shantytown](/home/s/slum-ghetto-shantytown#shantytown) below.


**ghetto**
**A specific type of [slum](/home/s/slum-ghetto-shantytown#slum) based on the shared ethnic or religious roots of its inhabitants.** The plural is **ghettos**.


**shantytown**
**Acceptable as a synonym for [slum](/home/s/slum-ghetto-shantytown#slum) in some places**, based on entrenched usage. The word **originally applied to densely populated camps of shanties** (flimsily constructed shacks of discarded metal, plywood and other makeshift materials). But it **now also describes districts that feature larger and more permanent structures** (e.g., multi-storey concrete and brick buildings) in several countries, including Brazil. **It's generally OK to use the terms "shantytown" and "slum" interchangeably** — something the United Nations and various other aid organizations routinely do. See also [**_favela_**](/home/s/slum-ghetto-shantytown#favela) above.


**slum**
**A crowded area of either squalid or generally substandard housing inhabited by poor people.** Levels of filth vary, as do outbreaks of disease, rates of crime, and so forth. **They lack at least some— but not necessarily all — of the very basics** (e.g., reliable sources of clean water and electricity, good sanitation systems, regular policing, firefighting and garbage removal). Actual land titles and registered addresses do not always exist, making some occupants more like squatters than renters. **Extreme poverty is the underlying common denominator and is what really distinguishes a "low-income neighbourhood" from a slum.** In some countries, slums are primarily found in areas that were once new but are now dilapidated. In other places, especially in the developing world, slums have grown almost entirely out of makeshift structures (e.g., tents, shanties) built near large urban centres. [**Ghettos**](/home/s/slum-ghetto-shantytown#ghetto) are specific types of slums. [**Shantytowns**](/home/s/slum-ghetto-shantytown#shantytown) are commonly and acceptably referred to as slums. See also [**slum landlord**](/home/s/slum-ghetto-shantytown#slumlandlord) and [**slum-like**](/home/s/slum-ghetto-shantytown#slumlike) for broader uses of the word.


**slum landlord**
An acceptable term used primarily in North America to describe **the owner of rental property that's well below acceptable housing standards in Canada and the U.S.** If someone is accused of being a slum landlord, no reasonable person would assume that this means the building in question is actually in a [**slum**](/home/s/slum-ghetto-shantytown#slum) or that the conditions are comparable to the very worst housing conditions on the planet. Rather, the claim being made is that the property is [**slum-like**](/home/s/slum-ghetto-shantytown#slumlike).


**slum-like**
Describes **property that is so well below local housing standards it would be considered uninhabitable by most reasonable people.** An old but structurally sound building that desperately needs a coat of paint and windows repaired is not slum-like. But housing in some parts of North America may well be, including on Indigenous reserves. **To make our journalism clear, be as specific as possible about the problems** (e.g., mice, bugs or other pests, holes in walls, a leaking roof, unsafe wiring, backed-up sewage) when likening any housing to an actual [**slum**](/home/s/slum-ghetto-shantytown#slum).

### so-called

**So-called**

The adjective has **two contradictory meanings:**

**(1) "known as," "commonly called"**


> It's an example of the so-called "Stockholm syndrome."
> The company plans to use the so-called "poison pill defence."


**(2) "wrongly named," "insincerely called"**


> "Her so-called ‘friends' are a big help," he scoffed.
> "His so-called ‘poetry' hasn't been published," she said.

**
Always define meanings that aren't widely known.**


> The "poison pill defence" is a way to fend off hostile takeovers. A company can flood the market with extra shares, for instance, making the unwanted bid more expensive.


In broadcast copy, the term so-called can be an effective substitute for punctuation that's missing from scripts intended for the ear only. On the web, it can also be a good way to emphasize certain wording. And **sometimes the adjective is required to comply with existing CBC News guidelines**, such as "[so-called honour killings](/home/h#honourkillings)."
**But editorial caution is required both online and on air. Never use "so-called" in a story if the meaning could be misconstrued** (e.g., if definition 1 above is intended but definition 2 could be easily inferred by mistake). For instance, _a so-called road map to peace_ might suggest "what's commonly referred to as the road map to peace" as well as "a path that will lead to more violence, not actual peace." Since the wording is unclear the sentence should be changed.

> **wrong**
>
> They're debating details of the so-called road map to peace in the Middle East.
>
> **correct**
>
> They're debating details of a U.S.-backed proposal known as the "road map to peace" in the Middle East.


**Routinely using "so-called" as a substitute for fact-based attribution can quickly, and needlessly, lead to perceptions of bias** by some members of our audience, as noted in a 2022 [CBC Ombudsman's post about "so-called"](https://cbc.radio-canada.ca/en/ombudsman/blog/Ombud_Inbox_April_2022). For instance, instead of writing about "the so-called Freedom Convoy" that rolled into Ottawa in February of that year, we can convey the same point neutrally by referring to, say, the **self-styled "Freedom Convoy,"** or to **what organizers dubbed the "Freedom Convoy."**


**Quotation marks and so-called**
**Quotation marks are optional after _so-called_**, according to various usage authorities. In CBCNews.ca stories, **such punctuation is recommended for terms that are relatively new, or for fragments of direct quotations when the speaker is stressing irony** (e.g., "She was abandoned by her so-called 'friends,'" he said).

Always use single quotation marks around words that already fall within double quotations. For a more detailed look at quotation marks, see [punctuation](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks/ "Quotation marks").

See also the Words: Woe & Wonder column [Should 'so-called' be culled?](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews2%2Findepth%2Fwords%2Fsocalled.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2ZSfCQtfcZPKRIJXbyq_Ta)

### soccer

**Soccer terms**

attacking midfielder, chip pass, chip shot, close down, corner kick, counterattack, defensive midfielder, goal line, goalkeeper, goal kick, halfway line, handball, marking back, midfield, midfielder, offside, own-goal (n., adj.), penalty shot, red card, red-carded, Round of 16 (FIFA World Cup term), shoot out (v.), shootout (n.), through ball, throw in (v.), throw-in (n., adj.), wingback, yellow card, yellow-carded

**FIFA** (Does NOT need to be spelled out as **Fédération Internationale de Football Association**.) The abbreviation should be identified as "soccer's world governing body" as high as possible in stories, unless it's simply included as part of an event's name (e.g., the FIFA World Cup). It's common practice to use the full name of a given World Cup tournament once in first reference (e.g., the [**2010 FIFA World Cup South Africa**](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/f/fifa-world-cup-2010/ "Fifa world cup 2010")), and then to use shorthand variations in second reference (e.g., the **2010 FIFA World Cup** or the **FIFA World Cup** or even the **World Cup** once context has been established). The full, formal name often includes a single geographical location, such as Brazil, Germany or Qatar, but there are exceptions (e.g., the **2026 FIFA World Cup** was awarded to Canada, the U.S. and Mexico). When distinguishing between gender-specific competitions, capitalize the modifier for consistency (i.e., **Men's World Cup** and **Women's World Cup**). Be aware that FIFA technically includes the possessive word Women's only in its official tournament names (e.g., the [**2011 FIFA Women's World Cup**](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/updates/2011/2011-06-25/ "2011 06 25") in Germany and the **2023 FIFA Women's World Cup** in Australia and New Zealand). For consistency, however, our style is to treat the detail Women's and Men's the same way, assuming either possessive is actually needed in a given report.

**Generally prefer the word "soccer" over "football" when referring to the sport**, unless it's part of a proper noun (e.g., TFC stands for the Toronto Football Club, also known as Toronto FC). This extends to coverage of international contests (e.g., a World Cup soccer match) because the word "soccer" is clearest to our general audience. It's worth noting that Toronto's **BMO Field,** itself, is commonly described as a "**soccer field**" for TFC matches, and as a "**football field**" for Toronto Argonaut games.

**NOTE: It's a myth that the word "soccer" is an Americanism.** In fact, the term was coined in Britain in the 1880s. "Soccer" — originally known as "assocer" — was a clipped version of "association football." Over the decades, "assocer" was shortened to "soccer." The name was intended as a quick way to distinguish "association football" from "rugby football" in the U.K. Although the word "soccer" was largely abandoned in Britain by the 1970s, it became increasingly entrenched in Canada and the U.S.

See the [sports overview](/home/s/sports-overview) for links to various other entries, including baseball, basketball, curling, football, golf, hockey and Olympics.

### South Asian, Indian, Indo-Canadian

**South Asian, Indian, Indo-Canadian**

**Avoid the invented term "East Indian,"** which offends many people of South Asian descent. It wrongly suggests they are either from a fictional land or from the Malay Archipelago. (The East Indies, now known as the Malay Archipelago, refers to Indonesia and several other states between Australia and Vietnam.)

There is no country or region officially called East India. There is, however, a place called **India**. Its citizens and descendants are **Indian**.

**Indian, Bangladeshi, Bhutanese, Nepalese, Pakistani, Sri Lankan, etc.**
**When specific South Asian background is known, specify:**

> The bombing killed 329 people, including 82 children. Among the victims were 280 Canadian citizens, mostly born in India or of _Indian_ descent.

**South Asian**
**When such details are not known,** or when we're referring to people from more than one country in the Indian subcontinent, use the general terms **South Asia, South Asian:**

> Two days before the bombings, police say a man of South Asian descent went to the Canadian Pacific Airlines ticket office in downtown Vancouver. He paid cash for two tickets. Both were registered under the last name "Singh."

**Indo-Canadian**
**Indo-Canadian traditionally refers to migrants from the Indian subcontinent** now living in Canada, **or to Canadian citizens who are descendants of people from that region.**

> The statements outraged leaders of the local _Indo-Canadian_ community.
>
> Many _Indo-Canadian_ business leaders belong to the Indo-Canada Chamber of Commerce.
>
> The _Indo-Canadian_ Friendship Society of British Columbia agrees.


Be aware, however, that **some people consider the term Indo-Canadian outmoded.** Respect individual preferences when known.

See also [geographical demonyms](/home/r/racial-terms#geographical) (African American, Korean Canadian) for related guidelines.


**Indigenous, Aboriginal, First Nations**
"East Indian" was coined years ago in an effort to distinguish Indigenous people in North America from citizens of India. In most stories, however, the context is already clear.

**Two sentences that provide enough context to use "Indian" instead of South Asian:**

> Curry is often used in _Indian_ food.
>
> To him, _Indian_ food suggests pemmican not pappadum.


**A headline that requires "South Asian" instead of "Indian" to be clear:**

> B.C. restaurateur starving for _South Asian_ chefs


**Both sets of examples illustrate an important point: Do not automatically type "South Asian" instead of "Indian." Common sense is required.**

There are several deciding factors in the restaurateur case above. First, web headlines float on their own as links in lists of stories, so they aren't read in the context of a lead paragraph, a photograph, etc. Second, "Indian chefs" could be misinterpreted as "Indigenous chefs" because the expression is not as well known as "Indian food" or "Indian restaurant." Finally, Indian "chefs" could easily be misread as "chiefs."

**When referring to Indigenous people in North America, using the adjective Indigenous, Aboriginal or First Nations** (when applicable) **can help avoid possible confusion.** (See [Indigenous](/home/i/Indigenous) for details.)

See also [racial terms](/home/r/racial-terms).

### Soviet Union

**Soviet Union**

**The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (U.S.S.R.) was formed in 1922**. By the early 1940s it had grown to 15 republics (after annexing three Baltic states in a deal with Nazi Germany). **The Soviet Union dissolved at the end of 1991.**

_Avoid the abbreviation U.S.S.R._ except in transcribed quotes or when providing historical context. Use the term _“the former Soviet Union”_ instead.

There is usually no need to include the Russian abbreviation (C.C.C.P.) in news stories. When transliterated into our alphabet, these Cyrillic letters actually become S.S.S.R. (Soyuz Sovyetskikh Sotsialisticheskikh Respublik). The term U.S.S.R. was adopted years ago in the English-speaking world.

See also [Kremlin](/home/k/kremlin)

### space terms

**Space terms**

astronaut (_lowercase, even before a name_)
galaxy
launch pad or launching pad
liftoff (n.), as in "_The liftoff is scheduled for Thursday_"
lift off (v.), as in "_They're scheduled to lift off at 8 a.m. ET_"
[light-year](/home/l/light-year) (_a measure of distance, not time_)
rocket, Mercury rocket
satellite, Anik E2 satellite
solar system
space
takeoff (n.), as in "_The takeoff was postponed_"
take off (v.), as in "_The astronauts hope to take off this weekend_"
universe


**space (prefix and suffix)**
The term "space" is used in a lot of compounds. **Some are two words without a hyphen. Others are fused.** Here's a list of the most common terms:

deep space
outer space (but redundant so avoid except in quotes)
spacecraft (one word; singular and plural)
space flight
space probe
a space shuttle, the space shuttle Discovery
spaceship (usually reserved for science fiction)
space station
spacewalk (one word)
space agency
the Space Age (began in October 1957 with Sputnik 1) See also [historical periods](/home/h/historical-periods)


**sun and moon, but Earth and earth**
**The sun and moon** as well as their derivatives (helio- and lunar) **are always lowercase. Capitalize "Earth" only when emphasizing that it's a planet** (e.g., in stories about a NASA mission, a study into global warming or astronomy):

before the rocket left Earth's atmosphere
the sun is about 150 million kilometres from Earth
down to earth
move heaven and earth
what on earth
it's heaven on earth
a lunar landing
the Earth has one moon


**Various other names, nicknames**
**Capitalize the proper names of all other planets** (Mars) a**s well as their derivatives** (Martian) **and nicknames** (the Red Planet):

Jupiter, Jovian
Mars, Martian
Mercury, Mercurial
Venus, Venusian
Saturn, Saturn's rings
Neptune, the planet Neptune
distant planet, gaseous planet (descriptions)
but the Red Planet (nickname for Mars)

**Capitalize the proper names and widely used nicknames of unique celestial objects, such as planets, stars, constellations, asteroids, comets, etc. But keep generic words such as "star" lowercase** (Barnard's star) **except in rare cases** when both parts of the noun are generic (as in the North Star):

an [asteroid](/home/a/asteroids-meteors); Vesta the brightest asteroid, the asteroid Vesta
black hole
a constellation; the constellation Canis Major
Big Dipper
a [comet](/home/a/asteroids-meteors#comets)
Ceres
Crab nebula
crater; the Tycho crater
Halley's comet
Milky Way
nebula; the Andromeda nebula
Luyten's star; but the North Star (_exception explained above_)
Orion
Pegasus
Polaris
pulsar
quasar
red giant
supernova
Ursa Major

See [asteroids, comets, meteors](/home/a/asteroids-meteors) to avoid mixing up some commonly confused words (e.g., meteoroids versus meteorites)
**
Keep the proper names of meteorological phenomena lowercase:**

meteor shower
northern lights
aurora australis
aurora borealis
**Use arabic numerals** (Saturn 5 not Saturn V) **for spacecraft and launch vehicles:**

Sputnik 1, Apollo 13, Gemini 4, Mercury 7, Pioneer 10, Alouette 2, Anik C1, Anik D2, etc.

See also [nicknames](/home/n/nicknames)

### speaker

**Speaker**

**To avoid confusing the generic word “speaker” (one who speaks) with the title Speaker, we always use a capital “S”** when referring to the person who keeps order and makes rulings inside national or regional legislative assemblies.

**This applies even if the title does not appear before a name, if it refers to a deputy, or if a person no longer holds the office** (a departure from our normal practice with capital letters):

Speaker Peter Puck
the Speaker
deputy Speaker Patrick Puck
the deputy Speaker
former Speaker Gilbert Parent
House of Commons Speaker
House Speaker
the Speaker of the Saskatchewan Legislature
the Speaker of Quebec's National Assembly \*

\* = _In French, this position is known as "président" of the National Assembly. However, we and virtually all other English news organizations use the term Speaker in this case for the same reason we call the head of Quebec's government the premier rather than the "prime minister." Entrenched English translation conventions apply. It's worth noting that in the House of Commons, the Speaker is also called "le président" in French._

See also [legislative bodies](/home/l/legislative-bodies) and [titles](/home/t/titles)

### Spelling

**Spelling overview**



**Canadian preferences**
**Canadians use a blend of British** (_cheque_ not _check_) **and North American** (_tire_ not _tyre_) **spellings**. Although some preferences are fairly common (_plow_ and _axe_, for instance, instead of _plough_ and _ax_), other words are frequently written in more than one way (_acknowledgement_ and _acknowledgment_).

Sometimes a word has more than one spelling on both sides of the Atlantic. The reasons for this vary, from evolution ("_expresso_" based on many people's mispronunciation of _espresso_) to the lack of consensus over a transliteration (_Muhammad_ and _Mohammed_). It can be _whacky_ (although we prefer _wacky_).

**We follow a [modified Canadian Press style](/home/s/spelling/modified-cp-style)**. Some of the broad guidelines include retaining the "u" in many "our" endings (_colour, labour, favour_), doubling the "l" before many suffixes (_carolling, labelling, signalling, travelling_), dropping the "muted e" when adding "able" to certain words (_likable, movable, sizable_), and shortening ligatures such as "æ" to "e" in many words (_anesthetic, encyclopedia, medieval, paleontology_). See [lingering ligatures](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/s/spelling/lingering-ligatures/ "Lingering ligatures") for exceptions (e.g., _archaeology_ and _caesarean_).

**When two or more spellings are fairly widespread, CBC News declares a preference to maintain the professional sheen of consistency** (e.g., catalogue, program and raccoon instead of catalog, programme and racoon).

**Never assume a spelling.** _Vapour_ and _honour_ both have a "u," for instance, but _vaporize_ and _honorary_ do not. (See [our and or](/home/s/spelling/our)) And while we generally follow the official spelling of a proper noun in English (e.g., the _World Trade Center_, not _Centre_), we make an exception for U.S. government departments. (See [defence, labour and centre](/home/d/defence-labour-and-centre) as well as the overview [Avoid inapt Americanisms](/home/a/americanisms))


**Check this site first**
**CBC journalists should consult this intranet site for any spellings they're not sure about** before looking elsewhere. **The Language Guide includes certain words not found in other reference material** (e.g., some proper nouns and newly coined terms), **as well as exceptions to our primary external source for spelling**, the Canadian Oxford Dictionary.

There is an alphabetical list, where you'll find _Muhammad_ and more than 5,000 other terms. If you don't spot what you're looking for in the A to Z indexes, try the Language Guide's search engine. It's an effective tool for quickly finding entries.

We do not generally list words that have only one spelling, unless they're commonly used and misspelled a lot (e.g., _occurred_ and _accommodation_ both appear but _exuberant_ does not because it doesn't show up in news stories very often, and _bedbug_ is included because some people still write it as two words but _bedroom_ and _bedspread_ are not because errors are rare).


**Canadian Oxford Dictionary**
**If a word is not listed in this Language Guide, look at the Canadian Oxford Dictionary. An [online version](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.oxfordreference.com%2Fview%2F10.1093%2Facref%2F9780195418163.001.0001%2Facref-9780195418163&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2mRZaIul-Z7mN0jH4lOO-e) of the latest edition is available to all staff from any CBC newsroom. Passwords are not required.**

Since dictionaries often include alternative spellings, **pick the main entry** (e.g., _raccoon_ and _dexterous_) **rather than a variation**. If two or more spellings have separate entries, variations (e.g., _racoon_ and _dextrous_) are always identified either by the word "also" or by the abbreviation "var."

**If the preferred entry isn't clear, consult the separate Canadian Oxford Spelling Dictionary** (CBCNews.ca's national newsroom has a copy).

_NOTE: Only a limited number of CBC employees can use the online version of the Canadian Oxford at the same time. If you're denied access because "the maximum number of concurrent user sessions" has been reached, try again a few minutes later. **And please remember to LOG OUT when you're finished.**_


**Geographical names**
**For the names of Canadian places** you're not 100 per cent certain about (cities, towns, villages, lakes, rivers, etc.), **consult the** **[Canadian Geographical Names Database](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww4.rncan.gc.ca%2Fsearch-place-names%2Fsearch%3Flang%3Den&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2lOY1kZcpa3sVZHHX8XWOf)** published by Natural Resources Canada. For guidelines on when provincial names are required for context, see [provinces and cities](/home/p/provinces-and-cities).

**For communities outside of Canada, we normally follow entrenched English spellings used by CP and AP unless there's a compelling editorial reason to diverge.** Exceptions to CP and AP are listed in our Language Guide, along with some proper nouns that are being spelled inconsistently. 

While the Canadian Press and Associated Press are usually good guides for anglicized forms of foreign communities (Rome, not Roma), be aware that some preferred transliterations have changed since the breakup of the old [Soviet Union](/home/s/soviet-union) (e.g., it's _Chornobyl_ and _Kyiv_  not _Chernobyl_ or _Kiev_  because the former transliterations are based on Ukrainian while the latter are closer to Russian.) See [cities around the world](/home/g/geography-cities#citiesaroundtheworld) as well as the [transliterations](/home/t/transliterations) overview.

**The National Geographic Atlas of the World can be helpful, but always check the CBC Language Guide for spelling exceptions** (e.g., we write Athens, Copenhagen, Munich, Nuremberg, Taipei, Venice and Warsaw based on established English convention). For guidelines on when country names are required for context, see [cities around the world](/home/g/geography-cities#citiesaroundtheworld).


**Stylistic latitude** (B.C. Place, not 'BC Place')



**IMPORTANT: Logos, graphics, building banners, etc., do NOT automatically represent the definitive spellings of proper nouns in our journalism.** For example, "**CBC News**" is not "CBCnews" or "cbcnews," even though such versions may be found in CBC-sanctioned promotional material (e.g., posters, T-shirts, coffee mugs, TV advertisements), and "**B.C. Place**" is not "BC Place," regardless of the stadium signage. **It's a myth that all typography must be matched verbatim to maintain the principle of accuracy**. That's because some spelling decisions by governments, companies, community groups, etc., simply reflect stylistic preferences and branding choices. In Britain, for instance, it's common to see references to the "U.K."without periods, even on official websites (e.g., as the "UK House of Lords," conventionally written as the "**U.K. House of Lords**" in North America). **We'd open ourselves up to the chaotic whims of third parties if we insisted on reproducing each external source's typographical style** — from all lowercase or all uppercase renderings to unorthodox punctuation — especially since such choices can change overnight, and may not be used consistently across a given organization. In a world where it's OK to recast the "Republic of Korea" as "[South Korea](/home/s#SouthKorea)" for editorial reasons, it's illogical to become obsessed with the fact that the proprietary term "[Teleprompter](/home/q/quirky-capitalization)" was actually registered with the bizarre spelling of "TelePrompTer," that the "B.C. Coroner's Act" refers to "BC Coroners Services" (which we write as "**B.C. Coroners Services**"), or that a Prince Edward Island Crown corporation calls itself the "PEI Liquor Control Commission" (a name we write as the "**P.E.I. Liquor Control Commission**" for consistency). See [**Geographical components of proper nouns**](/home/a/abbreviations#propernouns-geocomponents) for additional examples and detailed guidelines.


**Transcribed speech: 'going to' vs. 'gonna'**
**Prefer standard English when typing quotes,** such "I'm going to see you later" instead of "I'm gonna see ya later." Colloquialisms such as "gonna" are reserved for a dash of local dialect or colour in features, but should be used only if accurate and never to make someone look uneducated.

**Some terms such as "gotcha" have become informal words in their own right. But they should be used only if they truly reflect what was said.** There's a big difference between someone hurriedly saying "I got you that book," and someone else pausing, grinning and then distinctly uttering "gotcha."

**Always give speakers the benefit of the doubt when a word is slightly mispronounced,** as long as the slip is obvious. For more details, see [Pronunciations (gonna, gotcha, etc.)](/home/q/quotes-editing#gonna) in the general guidelines on [editing quotes](/home/q/quotes-editing).


**Beware: Homophones can cause headaches**
It's worth noting that **some of the most common spelling errors are homophones** (words with different meanings that sound virtually the same), such as [arrant and errant](/home/a#arrant), [borne and born](/home/b#born) and [reign and rein](/home/r/reign-versus-rein). For a humorous look at some of the early mistakes we made as a broadcaster turned web publisher, see the 2006 column, [CBC learns to spell](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2F10th%2Fcolumns%2Fcbclearnstospell_blairshewchuk.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw108c0exPOO6qpWk-3zZF4N), which was posted on the 10th anniversary of CBC.ca. The piece's use of e-mail instead of [email](/handy-links/punctuation/hyphens#email) reflects the ever-evolving nature of typography.


**Suggesting an entry, requesting a spelling**
CBC News journalists should always take the time to confirm the proper spellings of nouns in their stories, such as the names of people, organizations, medical terms and other technical jargon.

If one or more words are being frequently misspelled in scripts, let us know so we can add an entry to the Language Guide. Also, email us if a preferred spelling is unclear and a ruling is required for consistency. In either case, go to the [contact us](/contact-us) page and send a note to the standards editor.

### our common "our" spellings

**Lingering ligatures**

The last four letters of **queue** are arguably dispensable, illustrating the sometimes whimsical, if not utterly illogical, conventions that underpin various English spellings. **Depending on the sentence,** in fact, **superfluous vowels and consonants can seem to be the rule rather than the exception** — from the "k" in **knife**, the "w" in **two**, and the "t" in **listen**, to the "gh" in **weight**, the "ue" in **tongue**, and the "p" and "h" in **psychology**.

Into this chaos waddle a couple of old diagraphs, **"ae" and "oe,"** originally **bound as single characters in the early days of publishing** and, so, dubbed **"ligatures"** — i.e., letters tied together by printers to match old-style handwriting. These once common pairings gave us spellings like "**oeconomics**," "**praemium**" and "**tragoedy**" for what we now know as economics, premium and tragedy.

Virtually all true ligatures yoked in unique typeset glyphs have been discarded and forgotten, outside of esoteric journals in fusty corners of academia. But **a few of the original spellings live on** in spirit as inseparable vowels, **often by choice** (e.g., "**archaeology**" instead of "archeology"). **but occasionally as the only orthodox version** (e.g., **subpoena, oeuvre,** and **onomatopoeia**).

American and British journalists have comparatively little difficulty dealing with what amount to optional ligatures. The former tend to ignore them (cesarean, eon, estrogen) while the latter tend to embrace them (caesarean, aeon, oestrogen). Wandering between these camps, **Canadian media frequently, but not always, go with the shorter spellings common in the U.S.**

**CBC News style**, in bold on the left, **reflects this distinctly Canadian mix** of preferences, based on a review of numerous authoritative sources, including the Canadian Oxford Dictionary, CP Caps and Spelling, and Editing Canadian English published by the Editors' Association of Canada:

**aegis** — not _egis_
**amoeba** — not _ameba_
**anemia** — not _anaemia_
**anesthetic** — not _anaesthetic_
**archaeology** — not _archeology_ **\***
**caesarean** — not _cesarean_
**caesar salad** — not _cesar salad_
**diarrhea** — not _diarrhoea_
**encyclopedia** — not _encyclopaedia_ **^**
**eon** — not _aeon_
**esophagus** — not _oesophagus_
**esthetics** — not _aesthetics_
**estrogen** — not _oestrogen_
**feces** — not _faeces_
**fetid** — not _foetid_
**hemophilia** — not _haemophilia_
**hemorrhage** — not _haemorrhage_
**manoeuvre** — not _maneuver_
**medieval** — not _mediaeval_
**pediatrics** — not _paediatrics_
**pedophile** — not _paedophile_
**paleontology** — not _palaeontology_
**paleolithic** — not _palaeolithic_

**\*** = **Archaeology differs from CP style.** This "ae" spelling was **adopted by CBC News in November 2022** after public feedback from several academics who stressed that most archaeologists in North America still use the ligature, including members of the **Canadian Archaeological Association** and the **Archaeological Institute of America**. The same spelling is found at virtually all Canadian universities, and at Parks Canada heritage sites. Furthermore, the 2004 Oxford Canadian Spelling manual specifically recommends keeping the "ae" in "archaeology" while simultaneously discouraging it in "encyclopedia" and "paleontology," based on a review of a database of more than 8,000 Canadian publications, from newspapers and magazines to novels and works of non-fiction.

**^** = Exceptions are made for names reported as capitalized proper nouns. For example, the **Canadian Encyclopedia** versus the **Encyclopaedia Britannica**, and the Canadian Association of Aesthetic Medicine versus the government of Alberta's publication Health Standards and Guidelines for Esthetics.


**Canadian preferences**
**As noted in the Canadian Encyclopedia**, and quoted in our [Avoid inapt Americanisms](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/a/americanisms/ "Americanisms") overview:

_"**The main characteristic of Canadian spelling is the absence of any consistent pattern**, with choices between American and British forms varying by word, context, publication, genre, region and social group."_

**We get occasional audience letters about missing ligatures**. The feedback, which has included more than one formal complaint to the ombudsman, usually accuses us of ignorance and inaccuracy. **Our typical response: Many words can be spelled in more than one way.** So it's not not wrong to go with, say, medieval with an "ie" instead of an "iae." Rather, it's **an in-house style preference** between competing versions. **The key for us is to pick an established spelling widely used in Canada and to stick with it for consistency. We must also be ready to drop a lingering ligature as usage evolves** (e.g., in the 1990s, Canadian [anesthesiologists](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/a/anesthesiologist-versus-anesthetist/ "Anesthesiologist versus anesthetist") got rid of the "ae" in their professional society's name).

At the end of the day, a few truths should be remembered: **A lot of English spelling is highly subjective and wildly idiosyncratic**, and **Canadian English, in particular, is known for its novel amalgamation of British and U.S. spellings**. Experience suggests that people blasting us for writing, say, **hemorrhage** instead of "haemorrhage" might, themselves, never write "aeons ago" for **eons ago**, or stomach "oesophagus" for **esophagus**. So like cherries off a tree, ligatures tend to be handpicked by folks who simply think that certain familiar "ae" and "oe" pairings look good and feel right.

See our [spelling overview](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/s/spelling/ "Spelling") for related guidelines


### Modified CP Style

**Web publishing: Why a 'modified' CP style?**

We're known as Canada's public broadcaster. But we've also become a publisher in a very big way, with a lot of text posted on our various websites and other digital platforms every day. There are many popular guides to written English (e.g., Strunk and White, Fowler's, the Chicago Manual of Style). Choosing one helps us stay consistent in our online journalism. **In the late 1990s, CBC News picked the Canadian Press Stylebook as our primary reference manual for typography** (spelling, capitalization, punctuation, etc.). **Although we've since established our own publishing style, CP remains a major influence.
**


**The CP Stylebook**
The Canadian Press's approach is sound. It's similar to the paths taken by AP, Reuters and other wire services that we deal with on a daily basis. This is helpful. On top of that, CP adopts a "Canadian" approach where appropriate (_labour_ not _labor_, for instance, and _half-mast_ not _half-staff_). Many of these preferences were already entrenched at the CBC long ago.

The CP Stylebook, which is about 500 pages thick, covers in highly useful detail thousands of minute matters that crop up when you're writing and editing words that other people will see. ("Is there an extra period in an ellipsis when it falls at the end of a complete sentence?" she asked. "An ellipsis?" he replied. "I'm not sure....")

At the turn of the century, most journalists filing web stories on a regular basis kept a copy of the manual nearby to stay on top of rules like that. Since 2003, however, the CBC News Language Guide has been our main resource, instead. It goes beyond the basics to tackle even relatively obscure topics, including the answer to the ellipsis question about an extra period raised in the previous paragraph (which is Rule C on the [ellipsis page](/handy-links/punctuation/ellipses)).


**Exceptions to CP**
Although CP remains a primary reference for typography, **as pointed out in the [CBC News Style](/cbc-news-style) overview, the corporation sets its own policies on editorial content and presentation**. We cannot operate effectively if writers and editors feel they're obligated to follow every "rule" or preference written down by some other organization.

There are **four primary reasons for diverging from CP style from time to time:**

**1\. Sometimes CP's language clashes with CBC News policy.**

In the 2003 Caps and Spelling, CP added an entry on Sept. 11, which it described as an acceptable term to refer to the "day of terrorist attacks in the United States." But CBC News does not call these "[terrorist attacks](/home/t/terrorist-and-terrorism)" without attribution.


**2\. Sometimes we think CP is wrong.**

We're all fallible. But when typos and other mistakes get published in Caps and Spelling they're not usually corrected for at least two years. The CBC News Language Guide, by comparison, can be revised within seconds. In 2003, for example, The Canadian Press misspelt the first and last names of Supreme Court of Canada Chief Justice Beverley McLachlin. CP didn't fix the mistakes ("-ly" and "-lan") until August 2005. And the 2007 Caps and Spelling transposed two letters in a new entry on the Tlicho First Nation (which was published as "Tilcho").


**3\. Sometimes we think CP is out of date.**

Just before the 2007 Caps and Spelling was published, the name of BCE Inc. was officially changed to Bell Canada Inc. But the new noun didn't make it into the new book. And in 2000, the "Guinness Book of Records" changed its name to the "Guinness World Records" book. But CP still listed the old (incorrect) title in its 2003 Caps and Spelling. The Canadian Press finally fixed the mistake in 2005 when the next edition of its manual was published. (See [Guinness Book of Records](/home/g/guinness-world-records)) CBCNews.ca, on the other hand, adopted both changes right away. And in 2018, we adopted the Tsuut'ina Nation's revised (fused) spelling of its name. But the change didn't appear in the online version of CP's Caps and Spelling until 2021. 


**4\. Sometimes we disagree with CP's choice.**

The 2005 Caps and Spelling, for instance, listed EBay, IPod and ITunes — which we have always written as [eBay, iPod and iTunes](/home/q/quirky-capitalization). (In mid-2008, CP revised its style to eBay, iPod and iTunes as well.) For years, The Canadian Press recommended 9-11 as the shorthand form for Sept. 11, 2001, for years. (We prefer the more common [9/11](/home/s#Sept11).) Until 2016, CP clung to the tradition of putting the title Cardinal between a person's first and last name (e.g., Jean-Claude Cardinal Turcotte), even though many news services, including CBC, had abandoned the style a decade earlier. We've gone with [Cardinal Jean-Claude Turcotte](/home/c#cardinal) since 2005. And CP has followed AP's spelling of "archeology" for years, even though there's strong evidence that the preferred Canadian version includes the "ae" ligature. We switched to [archaeology](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/s/spelling/lingering-ligatures/ "Lingering ligatures") in November of 2022 after reviewing evidence submitted in public complaints.

There are **several other important reasons to have our own central repository of language rulings:**

-   _Sometimes CP does not deal with a term._

Over the years, countless entries have been added to the CBC News Language Guide before they've appeared in the next edition of Caps and Spelling — from CT scan, Type 1 diabetes, grow-ops and BlackBerrys to PricewaterhouseCoopers, EpiPen and N.L. (instead of Nfld. for [Newfoundland and Labrador](/home/n/newfoundland-and-labrador)).

Foreign names of people or organizations suddenly in the news fall into this category as well. Osama bin Laden's al-Qaeda network, for instance, didn't appear in CP's updated Caps and Spelling until the summer of 2003, almost two years after the Sept. 11 attacks. The entry read: "al-Qaida," which was AP's preference. CBCNews.ca, the BBC and many others adopted a different transliteration. (See [Arabic names](/home/a/arabic-names))

-   _Sometimes CP is incomplete._

The 2009 Caps and Spelling tells you how to spell Richter scale, but doesn't warn you not to use it. The larger stylebook merely cautions against automatically assuming that seismologists mean "Richter." The CBC, Globe and Mail, New York Times and numerous other organizations, however, recommend not using "Richter" at all. (See [earthquakes](/home/e/earthquakes))

-   _Sometimes CP is inconsistent._

The 2007 Caps and Spelling listed breakdancing and weeklong on some pages but "break dancing" and "week-long" on others. Similar slips occurred in past editions, such as paralyzing and shotgun in the book's main P and S indexes and "paralysing" and "shot-gun" elsewhere (under separate entries on mace and guns respectively).

See [Canadian Press](/home/c/cpap) for guidelines on the distinctions between "The Canadian Press" (as a noun), "the Canadian Press" (as an adjective), and "the Canadian Press Stylebook" (as the title of a manual).


**Exceptions are just that**
We frequently turn to the Canadian Press Stylebook, just as we consult the Canadian Oxford Dictionary (our main source for spellings), the Canadian Permanent Committee on Geographical Names (for the spelling of communities in this country) and the National Geographic Atlas of the World (our main source for spots outside of Canada) — as pointed out in the **[spelling overview](/home/s/spelling).**

**We resist abandoning CP preferences on a whim.** This would leave our writers and editors struggling to keep up with the latest rulings, and defeat the purpose of trying to have a consistent style.

**But we reserve the freedom to take our own path.** Often our choices reflect approaches that we think are simpler for our journalists (e.g., sticking with the one spelling of [whisky](/home/w/whisky) rather than embracing CP's 2007 decision to start using "whiskey" in certain cases) as well as easier for our audience (e.g., rejecting CP's move to "US$550" from $550 US because we considered the fused [currency](/home/m/money) construction harder to read on the web).

As the years pass, CBC News style steadily expands and becomes more established. **We have already stopped consulting the CP Caps and Spelling manual on a regular basis since our own electronic Language Guide is far more current and comprehensive.** Although the list of exceptions gradually grows, the main Canadian Press Stylebook remains our primary external reference for typographical guidance. **In short, we follow a modified CP style when publishing text.**

**We often use "our" at the ends of words that Americans prefer to spell "or."

But writers must be careful when a suffix is added.** In these cases, **the original "u" sometimes disappears:**

**Colour versus color**
**In the case of proper nouns, we generally adopt the original spelling** (e.g., **Technicolor**, which is a registered [trademark](/home/t/trade-names), the movie _The **Color** Purple_, and the U.S. organization "the National Association for the Advancement of **Colored** People"). For exceptions, see [defence, labour and centre](/home/d/defence-labour-and-centre)

### split decision

**Split decision**

**Appeal courts render two types of decisions:
**

> **1\. UNANIMOUS** (all judges on the panel agree)
>
> **2\. SPLIT** (one or more judges on the panel disagree)


**Avoid "non-unanimous,"** which is non-standard English. In addition to being jarring and unorthodox, the term can be misheard in broadcast scripts as "unanimous."

**Within almost every split ruling there is a majority decision and a minority or dissenting decision.** But it's potentially confusing to label the overall, divided ruling (e.g., 7-2, 4-1), itself, a "majority decision." Instead, the majority decision is only part of the overall split decision.


**Prefer precise breakdowns in headlines, bulletins** (e.g., 8-1, 5-4-, 4-1, 3-2)
The expression "split decision" was originally used in boxing. It has since become common in legal circles. **"Split" is a vague modifier in both fields. It applies regardless of the division** (e.g., 8-1, 7-2-, 6-3-, 5-4). The **Canadian Oxford Dictionary's definition reflects this:**


> _SPLIT DECISION (noun) 1. A decision in a boxing match in which the judges and referees are **not unanimous** in their choice of a winner; 2. A court ruling etc., which is **not unanimous.**_


Denotation and connotation are sometimes are odds, however, **The traditional definition of "split decision" can cause confusion** among people who assume "split" refers only to "evenly divided" (4-4, 3-3) or to "closely divided" (5-4-, 4-3, 3-2) decisions. **This misunderstanding has prompted more than one audience complaint** about our coverage of court cases over the years.

**In first reference, therefore, it's generally better to use specific breakdowns** (e.g., 4-1 or 7-2) **rather than to rely on vague modifiers like "split" or "divided"** — **especially in news bulletins and headlines,** The following tweets illustrate how precise numbers better convey relevant detail:


> (i) _BREAKING NEWS: In a split decision, Ontario's top court has upheld the ..._
>
> (ii) _BREAKING NEWS: In a 4-1 decision, Ontario's top court has upheld the ..._ 


Version (i) is accurate but also potentially confusing to members of our audience who may infer that "split" means a closer ruling.

**Version (ii) is preferred.** It's clearer and slightly shorter, which makes it better **in the constrained space of a news alert.**


### split infinitives

**Split infinitives**

You can’t split an infinitive in Latin, because it’s one word — e.g., amare (to love) and crescere (to grow).

But **you can** (are able to) **and may** (are allowed to) **split infinitives in English**. Even some of the more conservative grammarians concede this point.


**What’s an infinitive?**
An infinitive is a type of verb that's in the "infinite mood" — a term grammarians use to describe words that indicate action without specifying who's involved (e.g., the first or third person), the number involved (plural or singular), and the time involved (past, present, or future tense).

In the last sentence, for instance, "to describe" is an infinitive: "They had hoped _to_ _describe_," "I will try _to describe_," "She won't be able _to describe_," and so on. "Full infinitives" always include the word _to_, while "bare infinitives" do not.


**How do you split it?**
**If you put something** (usually an adverb) **between the particle to and the verb** (e.g., _go_) **you are said to have "split the infinitive"** (_to boldly go_). The modern-day expression has been around only since the late 1800s, although the rule against splitting infinitives was actually concocted by some intolerant grammarians hundreds of years earlier.


**Why split it?**
Sometimes slipping an adverb in the middle of the infinitive can soften a thought, emphasize an idea or improve a sentence's rhythm. Common examples include "to more than double" and "to really understand."

Writers and editors do not have to put the structure of the infinitive above the needs of the adverb. **As long as the wording is natural and the sentence’s meaning is clear, feel free to split.**

For a longer discussion, see the Words: Woe & Wonder column [To Boldly Split Infinitives](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews2%2Findepth%2Fwords%2Finfinitives.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw33al-1Ysa7Jrb_ra02Fhja)

See also [grammar](/handy-links/grammar) for a list of common topics, including [prepositions at the end of sentences](/home/p/prepositions-at-the-end-of-sentences)

### spokeperson

**Spokesperson, spokeswoman, spokesman**

**The entrenched word "spokesperson" is preferred** because it's a common and acceptable way to avoid a sexist suffix.


> _A company spokesperson said power should be restored by midnight._
> _A spokesperson said the ad agency has not received any complaints about the billboard._


Be aware that some of the people we interview continue to prefer specific rather than generic forms in their titles. **While we do not ban use of "spokesman" or "spokeswoman," standard guidelines about accuracy and parallel construction apply**. In particular:

-   Never assume that someone speaking on behalf of a company or organization is a man.
-   Do not call women "spokesmen."
-   Avoid the inconsistency of always calling a man a "spokesman" while referring to a woman as a "spokesperson."

**Given the above caveats, it's generally best to use spokesperson across the board**, regardless of whether the word "spokesman" or "spokeswoman" appears in a given individual's title.

See also [chair](/home/c/chair) (chairman, chairwoman, etc.)
