### spree

**Spree**

**OK to describe a bout of frivolous or non-violent behaviour**, from sudden splurges to certain unlawful activity.


> buying spree
> shopping spree
> spending spree
>
> building spree
> expansion spree
> takeover spree
>
> crime spree — (_NON-VIOLENT_)
> shoplifting spree — (_NON-VIOLENT_)
> vandalism spree — (_NON-VIOLENT_)


**But do not use in the context of violence** unless attributed (e.g., in a transcribed clip).


> killing spree — (_AVOID_)
> murder spree — (_AVOID_)
> shooting spree — (_AVOID_)


**The word is too breezy to mean "rampage" or "assault"** — introducing what can be easily perceived as a disrespectful and unsuitably cavalier tone in stories about bloodshed, death, etc.


**Background**

"Spree" was coined in the early 1800s. The noun originally meant extravagant or reckless indulgence, as well as riotous merrymaking, especially binge-drinking. This sense remained entrenched for almost two centuries. In the 1980s, "spree" started being used in the U.S. to describe multiple murders committed by the same person within a brief time period (e.g., "spree killings"). This usage has been controversial for decades, however, given the word's strong association with lively, lighthearted romps.

Some people broadly use "spree" to mean any outburst of activity or frenzied sequence of events (e.g., "shooting spree" is now listed in the Canadian Oxford Dictionary). But this practice offends segments of our audience, based on the complaints we periodically receive. Given this reality, and the fact that different, equally conversational phrasing is readily available (e.g., "shooting rampage"), **there's no editorial merit in characterizing a series of violent attacks as a "spree."**

CBC News adopted the above guidelines in April 2020.

See also [**mass shooting**](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/m/mass-shooting/ "Mass shooting")


### st saint ste

**St., Saint, St-, Sainte, Ste-**

[Canonization title](/home/s/st-saint-ste#canonization) (St. Paul, St. Joseph, St. Anne)
[Other proper nouns](/home/s/st-saint-ste#otherpropernouns) (surnames, cities, rivers, etc.)
[St. John River](/home/s/st-saint-ste#StJohnRiver) (New Brunswick)

**Canonization title**
**The generic word saint is lowercase:**

> She was declared a saint in 1982.
>
> He's the first Canadian to become a saint this century.


**As a title before the names of people canonized, the abbreviation St. is used for men and women** (rather than St. and Ste.), based on standard English spelling.

> St. André Bessette
>
> St. Marguerite Bourgeoys


Unless a historical figure is well known (St. Peter, St. Christopher, St. Francis of Assisi), surnames are normally included in first reference.

See also [Father, Mother, Sister, Brother](/home/f/father-mother-brother-sister) for related guidelines (e.g., St. Brother André Bessette)


**Other proper nouns** (surnames, cities rivers, etc.)
**In Quebec proper nouns, the abbreviations for Saint and Sainte do not generally have periods and are followed by hyphens** (St-Jean-Baptiste Day and Montreal’s Ste-Catherine Street). In the names of communities, the **abbreviations St- and Ste- are frequently used**, such as Ste-Anne-des-Monts. But in people’s names, **Saint or Sainte may also be spelled out** (Raymond Saint-Gelais, Buffy Sainte-Marie, Chloé Sainte-Marie).

In the rest of Canada, it’s rare to encounter St- or Ste- without periods in the name of a city, town or village. But there is still a wide range of possibilities. **Never assume spellings.** (It’s Saint Mary’s University in Halifax, for instance, but St. Marys, Ont.) Here are a few more examples:

[St. John’s](/home/s/st-saint-ste#StJ) (in Newfoundland and Labrador)
[Saint John](/home/s/st-saint-ste#SaintJ) (in New Brunswick)
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.
Saint-Antoine, N.B.
Sainte-Marie among the Hurons (historical site near Midland, Ont.)

Outside of Canada, all bets are off. **Follow the North American convention of adding a period to the abbreviation "St." even when different typography is used abroad** (e.g., **St. Andrews, Scotland** instead of "St Andrews," Scotland). We also add periods to abbreviations such as "Dr." and "Mr." (instead of the British spellings, "Dr" and "Mr"). Proper nouns like St. Andrews require care. In Canada for instance, "St." might be spelled out in a virtually identical town's name (e.g., **Saint Andrews, N.B.**). Neither version features a possessive apostrophe.

Check all names you’re not 100 per cent sure about. **If you can’t find a reliable spelling, don’t guess. Leave the proper noun out of the story.**

Some correct or common and recommended "St." preferences can be found at the [**top of S index**](/home/s#top).


**St. John River**
**In rare cases, geographical names are known by more than one spelling.** We generally follow the Natural Resources Canada [official list](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww4.rncan.gc.ca%2Fsearch-place-names%2Fsearch%3Flang%3Den&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2lOY1kZcpa3sVZHHX8XWOf) of domestic cities, towns, villages, lakes, mountains, etc. But **when a local preference has clearly become entrenched** (e.g., the St. John River instead of the "Saint John River" in New Brunswick), **we adopt this conventional spelling if there's other official support for it** (e.g., the provincial government often uses St. John River).

For consistency, we need to extend such exceptions (St. John River) to any proper nouns tied to that specific geographical name (e.g., the **St. John River Forecast Centre** rather than the "Saint John River Forecast Centre"), in the same way that we put a "c" in the U.S. [Department of Defence](/home/d/defence-labour-and-centre) to maintain a consistent in-house style. But this does NOT mean altering any other proper nouns (e.g., it's still the **Saint John Harbour Bridge Authority**).

**CBC News style has been St. John River for decades, based on a recommendation from CBC New Brunswick journalists.** This spelling was last reviewed and reaffirmed in May 2019. We periodically receive emails from people who insist that the only correct spelling is "Saint John River." However, historical records show that both versions have been used for hundreds of years. There's also evidence that "St. John River" is the original spelling, appearing on maps from the 1600s. A non-profit organization that champions good stewardship of the waterway continues to call itself the [St. John River Society](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.stjohnriver.org%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3yW43u0UiGbnrrB6jknrAV). And in the summer of 1993, Canada Post issued a 43-cent "St. John River" stamp, honouring it as one of the country's "five most important heritage rivers."


**Louis St-Laurent**
**Sometimes people are known by more than one spelling.** An example is former prime minister Louis Stephen St-Laurent, also known to many as Louis Saint-Laurent. The Library of Parliament refers to him as "Saint-Laurent" and "St-Laurent" on the same web page. The Globe and Mail recommends the English form "Louis St. Laurent." CP preferred "Louis Saint-Laurent" until 2005, when it switched to St-Laurent.

**CBC.ca now prefers "Louis St-Laurent" too.** It’s consistent with the National Library of Canada’s archives as well as with the spelling that appears in so many tributes to the former prime minister (e.g., the Louis St-Laurent National Historic Park at his hometown of Compton, Que., and the Louis St-Laurent government building in Gatineau, Que.).

See also [French words and accents](/home/f/french-words-and-accents)
See also [spelling](/home/s/spelling) (an overview)
See also [provinces and cities](/home/p/provinces-and-cities)

### State of the union

**State of the union**

No hyphens or capital letters.

In the United States, the president is required by law to give [Congress](/home/c/congress) updates "from time to time." They're usually delivered every January nowadays, but do not have to be.

**The state of the union message** is the _president's written report_ to Congress. This is the term used for the document that's actually delivered.

**The state of the union address** (also known as **the state of the union speech**) is the related _spoken version_. Although some people also call the speech a message, the New York Times and many other news outlets continue to distinguish between the spoken and the written word.


**Use state of the union address**
**In first reference, CBC News style is _state of the union address_** because this is generally what we're covering (i.e., the president's address to Congress and the nation).

In second reference, it can also be called a _speech_ or the president's _message_ (since these nouns on their own are generic terms).

The text of every state of the union speech or written message since 1790 is available on the University of California's website: [The American Presidency Project](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.americanpresidency.org%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1rdGxOxr8SvzAFp78QOiqq)

### Station

**Station versus station**

**Capitalize the names of a few well-known railway stations because they're considered important buildings:
**
Grand Central Station
Union Station

**But use lowercase "station" when the noun simply refers to a particular community, street or railway system:**

the Finch subway station
the Oakville GO station
Ottawa's train station
a Via Rail station

See [capitalization](/home/c/capitalization) for general guidelines

### Suicide

**Suicide**

**CBC News does not routinely report suicides. If a death is newsworthy, however, the cause of death is relevant.**


> **Example:** In 2002, British weapons expert David Kelly killed himself after being identified as the source of BBC reports accusing the U.K. government of exaggerating evidence to justify military action against Saddam Hussein in Iraq. Comprehensive coverage of the original story, as well as the inquiry and findings (known as the Hutton report) the next year, would have been impossible without reference to suicide.


The rest of this entry is intended to supplement the corporation's general [Journalistic Standards and Practices policy on suicide coverage](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fio.cbcrc.ca%2F%23%2Fresources%2Fcrime-and-police-reporting-faits-divers-1.4523145&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2mm8TbQXX61Da1Th2qvUQV) by offering specific direction on the structure and wording of news stories:

[Mentioning suicide in headlines](/home/s/suicide#unusualcases) (i.e., unusual or unavoidable cases)


[Specific wording](/home/s/suicide#specificwording) (e.g., killed himself, took her own life, committed suicide)

(For stories about grievously and irremediably ill people seeking aid to end their lives, see [**assisted dying**](/home/a/assisted_dying), which **has largely replaced the term "assisted suicide"** in Canada.)

**Generally avoid reference to suicide in headlines
**When reporting on a specific suicide, **the death should normally be the story's focus rather than the cause. This usually means avoiding reference to suicide in the headline:** _Alberta MP Jones dies at 58 rather than Alberta MP Jones kills himself or Alberta MP's death a suicide._


> **Example:** In September 2009, the Quebec writer Nelly Arcan killed herself, only eight years after her first, award-winning book Putain (_Whore_) was published. She had just finished writing a new novel that centred on suicide. Her death was the focus of the story. The cause of death (suicide) was not mentioned in the headline or lead:
>
> **Headline:** Quebec writer Nelly Arcan dies at 35
>
> **Lead:** Celebrated Quebec writer Nelly Arcan was found dead in her Montreal apartment late Thursday evening. She was 35 years old.
>
> **Fourth paragraph:** A spokesperson for her publishing house Coup de Tête, Myriam Comtois, confirmed Arcan's death, but refused to elaborate on what might have caused it. But Montreal police said Friday they are treating it as a suicide.


**One of the concerns is copycat behaviour.** Mental health professionals refer to this as "suicide contagion." Research suggests that some vulnerable people may be prompted to take their own lives if the deaths of others are covered in a certain way by the media. And emphasizing suicide in a headline can inadvertently sensationalize or romanticize the act, the experts warn. 

 
**Mentioning suicide in headlines: Unusual or unavoidable cases**
**There are times when the cause of death may merit special prominence in the lead or headline. For example, if a suicide involves a public figure** or someone else who's already in the news **and moves a top story in an entirely different direction** (e.g., _Toronto teacher facing sex charges commits suicide_). A mass suicide (e.g., Jonestown in 1978) or a murder-suicide may also require emphasis on the cause of death, depending on the facts and what serves the audience best.

**Just because a death takes place in public** (e.g., someone jumping in front of subway train), **however, does not automatically mean the suicide should be mentioned in the headline or lead.** When in doubt, check with your supervisor.


**Don't speculate about cause of death or motive**

**Never presume that people have taken their own lives simply because it appears to be a suicide.** If authorities say someone died of a drug overdose, the possibilities could range from accidental to intentional death — including at someone else's hands. And **be cautious when reporting on "attempted suicides" and potentially unlawful "assisted deaths"** (e.g., when there's a dispute over whether "medical assistance in dying" eligibility requirements were met). If charges are possible or a case is before the courts, certain wording could be prejudicial. Check with the Law Department if uncertain.

**Never jump to conclusions about the reason someone has committed suicide** (e.g., because she or he was molested in the past). There may be many factors. Report facts that are known, but don't speculate about motive.


**Privacy concerns**
**While stories about a specific suicide often involve a public figure** (Virginia Woolf, Ernest Hemingway, Freddie Prinze), **this is not always the case. Relevant journalistic standards and practices** (e.g., [respecting privacy](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fio.cbcrc.ca%2F%23%2Fresources%2Fprivacy-1.4523423&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1UE2yZUVKjUPE2QtJEUFMz)) **should always be considered.**


> **Example:** In a story about bullying at school, the parents of a boy who hanged himself speak out. They want more done to stop bullying, and they want other parents to watch for signs of trouble that they missed. Concerns about violating a grieving family's privacy don't apply, since the mother and father have consented to talk about their loss. A public good is also identified: The parents believe that discussing their son's death may prevent other suicides.

**Specific wording**
**There are many ways to refer to suicide that are brief, factual and carry no judgment**, from _"She took her own life"_ to _"He killed himself."_

**Be aware that some people strongly object to the term "committed suicide."** They feel it unnecessarily suggests criminal behaviour (e.g., committed murder, committed fraud), and inaccurately portrays all people who kill themselves as being "committed to death" when many are actually very vulnerable and in need of help.

**CBC News does not ban the entrenched expression "committed suicide." But we recommend considering alternatives** such as those outlined above, **especially when referring to young people taking their own lives.** One approach is to recast the intransitive verb into a modified noun (e.g., instead of saying _"the number of teenagers committing suicide"_ you can write _"the number of teenage suicides"_). Another is to write "death by suicide," along the lines of "death by accident." Use your own judgment.

**Avoid glorifying or sensationalizing a death by painting a picture that's too colourful.** For example, reference to a suicide note may be worth including but lengthy excerpts from the note probably carry little editorial value. **Never use adjectives such as "successful" or "unsuccessful"** when reporting on suicides or attempted suicides.

**Be aware that terminology such as "depression" has a specific medical meaning.** It's not merely a synonym for sadness or moodiness. Major or clinical depression often involves feelings such as overwhelming hopelessness or emptiness, extremely low self-esteem, etc. There may be biological (e.g., brain chemistry), psychological or other causes. Factors like substance addiction can play a role. Research suggests that many people who commit suicide have a significant psychiatric illness that is undiagnosed and/or untreated.

**When reporting on suicide in general, including statistical trends, avoid terms such as "epidemic" that suggest a widespread pattern.** Instead, state that the suicide rate within a certain population (e.g., Canadians of a certain age, or in a specific region of the country) is up and down. The actual figures should be given and attributed to a named source.

Our [general guidelines on reporting death](/home/d/death-general-guidelines) list related advice (e.g., avoiding euphemisms, redundancies, sensational synonyms).


**External resources**
The [**Mindset Media Guide**](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fsites.google.com%2Fa%2Fjournalismforum.ca%2Fmindset-mediaguide-ca%2Fmindset-download&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0KGqBWwcjxlMTnSApbcH4O) (2nd edition, 2017) from the Canadian Journalism Forum on Violence and Trauma offers both valuable perspective and some practical tips. The project was partly sponsored by CBC News. The [Canadian Association for Suicide Prevention](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.suicideprevention.ca%2Funderstanding%2Ffor-media%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0NOlwgeToUW3SvDuQsoIcz) is another good source of information about suicide. For additional background, see also [Recommendations for Reporting on Suicide](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Freportingonsuicide.org%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1vEHfuF2bzgjoIgz3I5Vwq), developed by various U.S.-based suicide prevention experts, public health organizations, schools of journalism and others.

### suspect\_accused

**Suspect, accused, person of interest**

**NOTE:** This entry provides only general guidance based on Journalism and the Law workshops designed for CBC staff over the decades. If you have any legal questions, including doubts about the wording of a specific story, always consult a CBC lawyer before publishing or broadcasting.


To keep our journalism accurate and clear, **we distinguish between suspects and accused:**


> **SUSPECT** — Person police say is **suspected of a crime.** May or may not ever be charged.
> **ACCUSED** — Person **formally charged with a crime.**


These are entrenched definitions. NOTE: **Just because someone is arrested does NOT mean the word "accused" automatically applies.** The word "arrest" conventionally means detention by police. People who are arrested in Canada may be released a short time later without being charged.

**We also distinguish between convicted offenders and accused in custody** when reporting on jails and other detention facilities:


> **OFFENDER** — Person **convicted** of an offence.
> **INMATE or DETAINEE** — Person **held in custody**, including an accused remanded while awaiting a trial or other court appearance.


**Avoid wrongly implying that everyone locked up in a correctional facility has been convicted**. A 2020 pandemic story about a jail on the Prairies illustrates preferred wording. We should write something along the lines of "masks must be worn by all **_inmates_** and staff" rather than "masks must be worn by all _offenders_ and staff," since the latter version either ignores mask rules for individuals remanded in custody or wrongly implies they've been convicted of a crime.

NOTE: [Steer clear of terms such as "young offender"](/home/y#youthjustice) to describe an accused under 18.

**The words "suspect" and "accused" are attractive** because they help us report on crime neutrally, without stating or implying guilt. **But there are still pitfalls** to avoid. **The rest of this entry highlights three areas of confusion that sometimes surface in scripts:**

[1\. JSP caution:](/home/s/suspect_accused#JSP-caution) We routinely name accused but rarely name suspects
[2\. Stylistic reminder:](/home/s/suspect_accused#diction-reminder) Suspects have identities
[3\. Ambiguous labels require care](/home/s/suspect_accused#ambiguous-labels) (e.g., person of interest)

## **1\. JSP caution: We routinely name accused but rarely name suspects**

**The decision to name a suspect is governed by relevant CBC policy.** Our default practice: **We generally name an accused** unless doing so is unlawful (e.g., if a court order protects the identity because the person is a minor). **We do not usually name a suspect unless there's a compelling public interest** (e.g., when authorities are trying to capture someone they say is dangerous) . **Naming suspects requires the approval of a managing editor,** as outlined in relevant Journalistic Standards and Practices policy ([JSP: Identification of Persons Involved in Legal Proceedings](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fio.cbcrc.ca%2F%23%2Fresources%2Fcourt-reporting-affaires-judiciaires-1.4523139&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw01yFlRiqp0Iw8F6esj3PLk)).

Limiting when we name suspects is a long-standing CBC News policy. **The mere act of reporting someone's identity can irrevocably damage the person's reputation.** A suspect may, in fact, never be charged. For example, investigators might change their minds after detaining someone for questioning. Or they might make a mistake (e.g., circulate the wrong name and photo of someone, only later to determine that the person they're actually after is someone else).

## **2\. Stylistic reminder: Suspects have identities**

"Suspect" has a relatively narrow meaning. **Before charges are laid, the word "suspect" applies when police:**

-   **Know the identity of someone they think committed a crime** but have simply not released the name (e.g., "the suspect was last seen ...").
-   **Release video or pictures of people they think committed a crime** (e.g.., "photos of the suspects") because the images are a form of identification.

Careful writers **avoid the common but nonsensical use of "suspect" as a generic synonym for unidentified wrongdoers.** It boils down to this: **Authorities cannot technically suspect anyone of a crime unless they actually know the person's identity.** Otherwise, they're simply referring to the unknown perpetrator of a crime (e.g., the robber, the assailant, the killer).


> EXAMPLES: In a news story about, say, a deadly school rampage, it's accurate to say "**the shooter fled the school**" but illogical to say "the suspect fled the school" unless the shooter's identity is known to police. The same applies to routine physical descriptions of people being sought. Instead of formulaically reporting that "the suspect is described as," consider more accurate, generic wording that applies to a given set of facts (e.g., "the **man is described as**" or "the **driver is described as**" or "the **robber is described as**").


Some writers like the broad term "perpetrator," which simply means criminal or wrongdoer (i.e., someone who carried out a given act, such as robbery, assault or murder). But the **downside of "perpetrator" is that it's lofty**. And while the clipped form "perp" is common in some circles, such slang can unintentionally change a story's overall tone — making it more unnatural than truly conversation, like outmoded dialogue lifted from a 1930s gangster film that refers to a police lineup as a "perp walk."

## **3\. Ambiguous labels require care (e.g., person of interest)**

**Be cautious with vague terminology** sometimes used by the police. Certain wording can be easily interpreted as the equivalent of "suspect."

For instance, **a "person of interest" may simply be a potential witness** — e.g., someone the authorities want to talk to because they think the individual might have information about a specific crime. Therefore, **try to nail down exactly what investigators mean by nebulous labels** (e.g., prefer "potential witness" over "person of interest" as long as authorities confirm that the clearer language is accurate in a given case).

**Avoid qualifying "person of interest" with waffling words like "possible"** (i.e., "possible person of interest"). Police either want to talk to someone or they don't. Be aware that detectives sometimes attempt to use media reports to ferret out folks as part of their process of elimination. If an editorial decision is made to report the identity of a "person of interest," based on our guiding JSP principles, never imply that the individual is an actual suspect.

See also [allege, allegedly](/home/a/allege) as well as [Canadian court terms](/home/c/canadian-court-terms) (e.g., accused not criminal "defendant," and witness box not "stand")


### Station

**swastika**

This is the **common and acceptable name** for a **Nazi symbol** virtually everyone in our audience recognizes. The plural is **swastikas**.

Be aware that we receive complaints from time to time from people who object to this usage because of the word's Sanskrit origins ("to be good"), as well as its historic connections to Hinduism and other faiths and cultures. They prefer alternative labels, such as **gammadion** (which means four joined capital gammas, the fourth letter of the Greek alphabet) or _**hakenkreuz**_ (which means "**hooked cross**" in German), or **fylfot** (which is an English relic from the 1500s for a type of cross featuring cramped ends, sometimes dubbed a **_cramponnée_**).

**But such alternatives are not nearly as well known to most of audience**, and, so, would generally need to be explained if included in a story. **Furthermore, gammadion, _hakenkreuz_ and fylfot are succinctly defined in most English dictionaries as swastikas**, reflecting more than a century of common usage — from documents published by governments and scholars to news releases from national and international Jewish organizations, such as B'nai Brith Canada and the [U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum](https://encyclopedia.ushmm.org/content/en/article/history-of-the-swastika). It's worth noting that the Hindu American Foundation used the word "swastika" when it issued a joint statement with the American Jewish Committee in 2008 called, [The Swastika: Use and Abuse of a Sacred Symbol](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/media/mfpjslet/theswastika_use-and-abuse_haf-ajc_2008-brochure.pdf "Swastika-Use-And-Abuse-Brochure-2008-Statement").

As we've pointed out in more than one response to complaints sent to the CBC ombudsman over the years: **We use standard English in our reporting, diverging only when there's a compelling editorial reason** (e.g., when a word or phrase is indisputably inaccurate, misleading or biased). **The noun swastika, however, does not fall into this category**. Instead, it illustrates a reality of linguistics: Words with unrelated denotations or etymologies sometime take on new meanings in a different tongue over time.


### systemic\_systematic

**Systemic versus systematic**

There's a notable difference between systemic and systematic:


> **SYSTEMIC discrimination** commonly refers to inherent or **built-in biases that are real but less obvious** than blatant racism, sexism, etc.



> **SYSTEMATIC discrimination** commonly refers to **stark biases that are purposeful and undisguised.**


The Oxford Guide to Canadian English Usage puts it this way:


> _"**'Systemic discrimination'** has to do with **inequities and prejudices** within the operation of a system (the education system, etc.) **that are not overt or easy to locate**, but that are present nonetheless. For example, **a requirement that all firefighters be over six feet** tall could be seen as evidence of systemic discrimination against most women and, in some minority groups, most men as well.... To be **'systematic'** in your approach to a task is to make a plan and carry it out in a **thorough and orderly** way. Thus **'systematic discrimination'** and 'systematic racism' involve **not unconscious prejudice but deliberate acts of repression.** The **Nazis' treatment of the Jews** during the Second World War was an extreme example of 'systematic racism.' **Apartheid in South Africa** — an explicit government policy of exclusion of the basis of race — was another."_

> > — 2007 Oxford Guide to Canadian English Usage


The choice of modifier depends on a given story's facts. But **in routine coverage of institutional discrimination, the word "systemic" normally applies**.


**Systemic racism**

Since at least the 1880s, the word "systemic" has had several meanings, including "throughout an entire system" as well as "inherent in the system," according to the Oxford English Dictionary. **Systemic racism is an umbrella term for built-in bias that's real but often subtle**. It's sometimes perpetuated by institutions because people are not mindful, and because traditional policies and practices are deeply entrenched.

**Although the expression "systematic racism" is familiar, its exact meaning is neither precisely defined nor instantly understood by all.** To illustrate shades of connotation, **consider these two complementary definitions** found in a 117-page House of Commons study into systemic racism in Canada published in 2018:


> _"People have a hard time understanding what systemic discrimination is and what systemic racism is. This is because it's not the kind of racism that comes necessarily from the behaviour, words, and actions of individuals, other than the fact that they are guided by the system in which they are functioning. The phrase that I always like to use is that **systemic racism is the racism that's left over after you get rid of the racists.** Once you get rid of the racists within the justice system, for example, you will still have racism perpetrated by the justice system. This is because the justice system follows certain rules, procedures, guidelines, precedents, and laws that are inherently discriminatory and racist because those laws, policies, procedures, processes, and beliefs — including beliefs that direct individuals on how and when to exercise their discretion — come from a history of the common law, which comes from a different culture, a different way of thinking."_

> > — Manitoba Senator Murray Sinclair



> _"**Systemic racism is often caused by conscious or unconscious biases in policies, practices and procedures** that privilege or disadvantage particular groups of people based on perceptions of race. It's not always intentional, but **whether or not it's intentional has little bearing on the inequitable outcomes** Indigenous and racialized people experience."_

> > — Sam Erry, Associate Deputy Minister, Diversity and Anti-Racism Division, Government of Ontario



> > [**Taking Action Against Systemic Racism and Religious Discrimination including Islamophobia**](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ourcommons.ca%2FContent%2FCommittee%2F421%2FCHPC%2FReports%2FRP9315686%2Fchpcrp10%2Fchpcrp10-e.pdf&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2l9AN63aa4pRsnKSNabrG0)
>
> > Report of the Standing Committee on Canadian Heritage — February 2018 — House of Commons — Pages 19-20


Some audience members dispute that systemic racism exists in Canada. CBC News rejects such claims, which have come in various forms, including as official ombudsman complaints. Certain people may question the conventional meaning of "systemic racism." They may also contest whether it exists in their country's police forces, judicial system or other institutions. But just because they hold those positions or choose to define language in extremely narrow and unorthodox ways, does not mean that our use of the entrenched compound "systemic racism" is inaccurate, confusing, misleading or otherwise inappropriate when the facts fit. **Given Canada's history** — including the historical underrepresentation of Indigenous people and other non-white people in positions of wealth and power — **the existence of systemic racism is considered undeniable and unsurprising to many public figures today**. For example, in June 2020 [the RCMP's commissioner acknowledged that systemic racism exists within the force she leads](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews%2Fpolitics%2Fbrenda-lucki-systemic-racism-rcmp-1.5610355&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw17jpP2a_5RZHHZDHhIVY8W).

See also [racial terms](/home/r/racial-terms)

**Taser** (n., adj., and v.) The name of a gun designed to incapacitate people with an electric shock. Since the word is proprietary, it must be uppercase even as a verb ("Police Tasered him"), along the lines of Google ("They Googled themselves once a week"). See also [trade names](/home/t/trade-names). Taser is now widely known and, therefore, OK in first reference. But it's not always the best choice, especially if the weapon being reported on is not actually manufactured by Taser International Inc. A common, generic alternative is **stun gun**. Tasers are [electrical](/home/e#electrical) rather than electronic. Generally avoid the obscure abbreviation CEW unless you need to explain the jargon (e.g., transcribing a quote). In that case, spell it out as "conducted electrical weapon." Other definitions of CEW are sometimes used (e.g., the E is referred to as "energy"), but these forms are rarer, disputed and less meaningful to our audience. **technician** (generic) Conventionally refers to people who run and/or repair certain equipment (a computer technician, a mechanical technician); **technologist**; (technical specialists in a given field). For example, a **sonographer** is an **ultrasound technologist**. Be aware that use of the term "technologist" is governed by legislation in some jurisdictions. It often implies a professional status tied to a defined educational program or other credentials. The health-sector illustrates this distinction. **Medical technicians** may be trained to operate sophisticated lab equipment that produces complex results, but they're probably not qualified to interpret the scientific meaning of those results. By contrast, **medical technologists** do much more than operate equipment. They also calibrate/adjust as they go. This means that medical technologists usually need to know a lot about whatever part of the anatomy they're examining — sort of health-care detectives in search of the best evidence they can collect for doctors. Indeed, the quality of some medical exams can heavily depend on the skills of the technologist rather than merely on correct operation of the equipment. While there's no need to get bogged down in arcane jargon in stories, we should avoid inaccuracy, such as wrongly calling a lab technician a "technologist."
