### Taiwan

**Taiwan**

**Taiwan is an island** roughly 180 kilometres from mainland China. The waterway between the island and the continent is commonly called **the Taiwan Strait** in English. **Beijing insists that Taiwan is part of its country**. But **Taiwan's leaders reject Beijing's sovereignty claim**, which means that political control over the territory is disputed.

CBC News practice is to maintain impartiality. This means we **refer to Taiwan on its own in stories**, including in TV locators, but **avoid calling it a country or nation** outside of direct attribution. For instance:


> **Taiwan** (not "Taiwan, China")
> **Taipei, Taiwan**
> **Taiwan's election** is scheduled for ...
> The **island's economy** has ... (not "the country's" or "the nation's")
> She said **the self-governing island** is ...


There are **two main reasons** for this approach:


> **1\. It's impossible to satisfactorily convey the complexities of political or territorial disagreements in a few words** (i.e., in the limited real estate of a TV banner or locator).
>
> **2\. It's an acceptable convention to identify well-known geographical areas alone** (e.g., an island like **Sicily**, a peninsula like [**Crimea**](/home/c/crimea)), as in, "They met in Sicily" rather than "They met in Sicily, Italy."


NOTE: Although a linguistic distinction is often made between the terms [country and nation](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/n/nation-versus-country/ "Nation versus country"), such attempted nuance can easily cause confusion in coverage of territorial disputes. Therefore, avoid either word when referring to Taiwan for the reasons outlined above.

Use the entrenched spelling **Taipei**. Avoid competing [transliterations](/home/t/transliterations), including, "Taibei."

In stories about political tensions over the region, it's a good practice to succinctly remind our audience about relevant positions of each side. In the case of **the Taiwan Strait**, for example, it's accurate to say that **China considers the passageway its own economic zone** while **the U.S. and its allies, including Canada, contend the waters are international**, regularly sailing through and flying over the strait to stress this stance.


**Additional background**
The **sovereignty dispute began in the late 1940s**, when Mao Zedong swept to power at the end of China's civil war. **Taiwan has its own government, holds its own elections and in many practical ways acts as an independent state. But Beijing considers Taiwan a breakaway province**, and is on the record saying that the region must be reunited with the mainland — either peacefully or by force.

**Beijing refuses to have official diplomatic relations with any country that openly recognizes Taiwan as a separate state.** This is commonly known as the "**One China policy**." As a result, Taiwan, is the world's most populated region (as well as the biggest economy) not to be a member of the United Nations. Nevertheless, many countries have informal relations with Taiwan through trade offices, cultural institutes, etc.

**Be aware that the official names of China and Taiwan are sometimes a source of confusion.** Mainland China is, technically, **the People's Republic of China (PRC)**. And Taiwan is, technically, **the Republic of China (ROC)**. The word "China" in Taiwan's own name is not an accident. For more than half a century, Taipei countered Beijing's claim to the island of Taiwan by asserting that Taiwan is the seat of China's true government. In recent decades, however, some of the island's politicians have tempered this stance, no longer insisting that the island of Taiwan has true sovereignty over mainland China. **In most news stories, this level of detail is not required.** It's also **rarely necessary to point out that Taiwan calls itself the "Republic of China."** Instead, prefer the proper noun Taiwan throughout.

See also [country names](/home/g/geography-cities)


### terrorist and terrorism

**Terrorist and terrorism**

**Overview**
**Exercise extreme caution before using the words terrorist and terrorism.** While the language is not seriously disputed in some cases, it's less clear if not highly contested at other times — which can lead to virtually endless questions about consistency and impartiality in our coverage of various attacks around the world. Put another way: **The words, themselves, can become impediments to reporting**. For this reason, generally **avoid labelling any specific bombing or other assault as a "terrorist act" unless this term is attributed** (in a TV or radio clip, or in a direct quote on the web).


> Examples: We should refer to the deadly suicide bombing at an airport in Moscow in January 2011 as an "attack," not as a "terrorist attack." The same applies to the London bombings in July 2005, the Madrid train bombings in March 2004 and the attacks against the United States in 2001, which CBC News prefers to call "**the Sept. 11 attacks**" or some similar expression. (The BBC, Reuters and some other news organizations follow a similar practice.)


Terrorism generally implies attacks against unarmed civilians for political, religious or some other ideological reason. But it's a highly controversial term that can leave journalists taking sides in a conflict.

**By restricting ourselves to neutral language, we aren't faced with the problem of calling one incident a "terrorist act"** (e.g., the destruction of the World Trade Center) **while classifying another as, say, a mere "bombing"** (e.g., the destruction of a crowded shopping mall in the Middle East).


**Use specific descriptions**
**The long-standing CBC News preference is straightforward: Generally don't judge specific acts as "terrorism" or people as "terrorists."** Instead, describe the act or individual and then let the viewers, listeners or readers make their own judgments.

**So rather than reaching for a label** ("terrorist" or "terrorism") when news breaks, **try summarizing what happened**. For example, "A suicide bomber blew up a bus full of unarmed civilians early Monday, killing at least two dozen people." The details of these tragedies give our audience the information they need to form their own conclusions about what type of attack it was.

**Instead of calling assailants "terrorists," we can refer to them as bombers, hijackers, gunmen** (if we're sure no women were in the group), **militants, extremists, attackers** or some other appropriate noun.

**When authorities declare a specific group a terrorist organization, it can be important to include this information to provide our audience with key context** (e.g., mentioning that [Hamas](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/m/middle-east-glossary/#hamas "Middle East glossary") has been classified as a terrorist group by Canada and more than a dozen other countries). **Attribution remains crucial, however**, especially since different governments around the world have been known to make highly contentious assertions about various organizations for political reasons (e.g., Myanmar's junta labelled Aung San Suu Kyi's exiled National Unity Government a terrorist organization, and Russia classified jailed Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny's regional campaign offices part of a terrorism network).

See also [fundamentalist, extremist, militant, etc.](/home/f/fundamentalist-extremist), for related guidelines.


**'Terror' and other derivations**
Related words such as "terror" also require care. As a generic noun (e.g., the bombing caused widespread terror), terror is OK as long as it's an accurate description of fear and chaos tied to a given story. But as an attributive noun (e.g., a terror group, a terror plot), it essentially means "terrorist" and, so, should be treated no differently.


> Example: In a TV banner, TERROR IN LONDON would be OK over images of a bombing aftermath, but TERROR ATTACK would be a poor choice because that text is the equivalent of TERRORIST ATTACK.


**No 'ban' in place**
There's a big difference between crafting guidelines on how to use controversial words in a certain way (e.g., cautiously and neutrally) and actually imposing a ban on those words.

**It's not practical to draft a list of all contexts in which the words _terrorist_ and _terrorism_ are appropriate in CBC News stories.** For instance, we might write that Canada and other countries have passed "anti-terrorism" legislation, or that intelligence agencies have lists of groups that they consider "terrorist" organizations, or that the U.S. government has issued another warning about an increased risk of "terrorist attacks" in the next few weeks, or that certain people have been charged with acts of "terrorism." **Use common sense**.

See also [Sept. 11 attacks](/home/s#Sept11)
See also [Middle East glossary](/home/m/middle-east-glossary)

For background on the word _terrorism_, including the UN's futile attempts to reach consensus on a definition, see the 2001 Words: Woe & Wonder column [Terrorists and Freedom Fighters](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews2%2Findepth%2Fwords%2Fterrorists.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3kZoLXaViBu6eZenIk-HJK).

### that versus which

**That versus which**

Before picking one of these words, determine what you’re trying to say.


**That**

**If the detail in the sentence is essential, you need _that_.** This is known as a defining or restrictive clause. **Commas are not required:
**
_"The pianist plans to record the concerto that she wrote in Banff once she settles a contract dispute."_

This sentence implies that the musician composed only one concerto in Banff. She plans to record it.
_
"The truck that’s blue was searched by police."_

There may be a lot of trucks in the parking lot. This sentence tells us that the blue one was searched by police. It could be shortened to: _"The blue truck was searched by police."_


**Which**
**If the information is simply an aside, which can be separated by commas, choose which.** This is known as a non-defining or non-restrictive clause:

_"The pianist plans to record the concerto, which she wrote in Banff, once she settles a contract dispute."_

This sentence identifies the town where the concerto was written, but it says nothing about what else may have been composed there. It lifts the earlier restriction.

_"The truck, which is blue, was searched by police."
_
This sentence does not use colour to identify the vehicle inspected by police. The detail is tossed in as an aside. The clause could be removed without changing the overall meaning.

See also [commas](/handy-links/punctuation/commas)

### The versus the

**The versus the**
[Using 'The'](/home/t/the-versus-the#usingThe) (titles of books, movies, TV or radio progams, etc.)

    [Most nicknames](/home/t/the-versus-the#nicknames) (the Red Planet, the Oscars but The Show for baseball) 
    [Most geographical references](/home/t/the-versus-the#geographical) (the Arctic, the Netherlands, but The Hague) 
    [Miscellaneous](/home/t/the-versus-the#miscellaneous) (newspapers, reference books, companies, buildings, music groups) 
[Pronunciation](/home/t/the-versus-the#pronunciation) ("thee" sound versus "thuh" sound) 
[Abbreviations](/home/t/the-versus-the#abbreviations) (the UN, the RCMP)

**Using 'The'**
**Capitalize "the" when it begins the title of a book** (unless it's a dictionary, encyclopedia or other reference publication), **movie, television or radio program, song, magazine** (unless it's a scholarly journal or other reference periodical), **painting, sculpture or other composition:**


> _The Fifth Symphony in C minor_ by Beethoven
> _The Loved and the Lost
> __Michelangelo's The Last Judgment
> _but the _Mona Lisa_ (article "the" not in actual title of Leonardo's work)
> _CBC News: The National
> __[_The Fifth Estate_](/home/f#Fifth_Estate)_ _The New Yorker_ (not in [italics](/handy-links/punctuation/italics) because it's a magazine)
> _The Old Curiosity Shop
> __The Purple Rose of Cairo
> __The Threepenny Opera_ by Kurt Weill and Bertolt Brecht
> _CBC News: The World at Six_


See also [CBC](/home/c/cbc) for general guidelines on program titles, including CBC News: _The National_ versus _The National_ in second reference.

**Also, use "The" for wire services and broadcast channels that include the article in their proper names:**


> The Associated Press
> The Canadian Press
> The Sports Network (TSN)


See [The Canadian Press, The Associated Press](/home/c/cpap) for more details, including guidelines on distinguishing between nouns ("told The Canadian Press") and adjectives ("the Associated Press reporter").


**Using 'the'**
**Most nicknames**

**A lowercase "the" is used for most nicknames and other informal labels**, except in very rare cases when the article gives a singular meaning to an ordinary word that might not otherwise be clear:


> the Last Supper
>
> the Red Planet
>
> the Oscars
>
> the Rockies
>
> The Show (baseball's major leagues)

**Most geographical names**
**Use a lowercase "the" in virtually all geographical references. Capitalize "the" only in those rare instances when it's part of the official name:
**

> The Hague, but the Netherlands
>
> The Pas
>
> [the Arctic](/home/a/arctic)
>
> [the Barrens](/home/b/barrens)
>
> the [Central African Republic](/home/c#CentralAfricanRepublic) (_the_ is common but optional)
>
> the Northwest Territories
>
> the Rocky Mountains
>
> the West Coast
>
> the West Indies
>
> [the Yukon](/home/y/yukon) (also known as Yukon)

**Be aware that in many cases, "the" is conventionally dropped** unless a full, formal name featuring a known like "kingdom" or "republic" is actually used in a given story:

>
>
> [Congo](/home/c/Congos) (_not the or The_)
>
> [Gambia](/home/g#Gambia) (_not the or The_)
>
> [Ivory Coast](/home/i#IvoryCoast) (_not the or The_)


**KEY TAKEAWAYS: "The" is sometimes, but rarely, required before geographical names** (e.g., A city called The Hague is in the Netherlands). **"The" is  sometimes always wrong** (e.g., [**Ukraine**](/home/u#Ukraine) but NEVER "the Ukraine" because the country has only one, official name), and **[Punjab](/home/p#Punjab)** but NEVER "the Punjab." **Frequently "the" is technically OK but simply not usually recommended** (e.g., Gambia rather than "The Gambia" or "the Republic of The Gambia") **because the shortened name is so entrenched.** (See also [country names](/home/g/geography-cities) for related guidelines)

**Miscellaneous**
**Keep "the" lowercase in almost all other contexts**, including at the start of almanacs, academic journals, directories, dictionaries, encyclopedias, handbooks, newspapers, holy books, most buildings, companies, ships, trains, music groups, awards, sports events, etc.


> the Academy Awards
>
> the Anglican Church
>
> the Bay
>
> the Bible, the Qur'an, the Torah
>
> the Calgary General Hospital
>
> the Canadian Farmers' Almanac
>
> the Canadian Press Stylebook
>
> the CBC
>
> the Chateau Laurier Hotel
>
> the Glenbow Museum
>
> the Globe and Mail
>
> the Holy Ghost
>
> the House of Commons
>
> the Ministry of Health
>
> the Masters (_golf tournament_)
>
> the Mendel Art Gallery
>
> the New England Journal of Medicine
>
> the Nobel Prize
>
> the Old Farmer's Almanac
>
> the Olympics
>
> the Order of Canada
>
> the Oxford English Dictionary
>
> the Prince of Wales
>
> the Rolling Stones
>
> the United Nations

**Rare exceptions are generally based on entrenched usage tied to audience clarity** — e.g., when the capitalized article gives an otherwise single-word proper noun a distinct meaning:

> [The Rooms](/home/t#TheRooms) (a cultural facility in Newfoundland that includes a museum, art gallery and the provincial archives)

For more details about why newspaper names feature a lowercase "the" and no italics, see [newspaper names](/handy-links/punctuation/italics#newspapers) in our "italics" guidelines.


See also the Pronunciation Database for a note on [**the's vowel sound**](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2Flng%2Frecherche%2Findex.aspx%3FProId%3D27782&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1CEAlzxSBxciivqN3b7ywF) ("thee" versus "thuh")


**Abbreviations**
**Although it's common to put "the" in front of many abbreviations that represent organizations** (the UN or the RCMP), **we often drop this convention with well-known [acronyms](/home/a/acronyms)** (e.g., we write NATO not "the NATO," NASA not "the NASA," and OPEC not "the OPEC").

See also [CBC versus the CBC](/home/c/cbc)
See also [HMCS](/home/h/hmcs) (never "the HMCS")
See also [principal words definition](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/handy-links/punctuation/quotation-marks/#principalwords "Quotation marks") for capitalization convention (e.g., "at" in _The World at Six_ but "It" in _As It Happens_)
See also [Magazine versus magazine](/home/m/magazine)

### they\_singular

**They** (singular)

**The pronoun "they" is normally plural. But it's become an acceptable convention to use it in some singular constructions**, either to eliminate sexist writing or to avoid gender-specific identification.

**Standard plural use**
The words they, them, their and themselves are traditionally plural.


> They held their breath.
> The car almost hit them.


**Acceptable 'singular they'**
**When gender is irrelevant, it's become increasingly common to use "they" as a singular pronoun rather than to clutter our speech with sexist choices** (e.g., always using "he") **or with clumsy, wordy constructions** (e.g., she/he, hers/his). For instance:


> If **your child** is under 18, **he** may qualify for the grant. **(POOR** — SEXIST)
> If **your child** is under 18, **she/he** may qualify for the grant. (**POOR** — AWKWARD)
> If **your child** is under 18, **they** may qualify for the grant. (**OK — SINGULAR 'THEY'**)


**Rewriting options**
**While using "they" as a singular pronoun can be fine, recasting is sometimes preferable.** The most common rewrites involve turning singular subjects into plurals, using the articles "a" or "the" in place of plural constructions, and simply dropping superfluous pronouns.


> If your children are under 18, **they** may qualify for the grant.
> Children under 18 may qualify for the grant.



> **The customer** should be told ahead of time they have to pay extra for shipping.
> **Customers** should be told ahead of time they have to pay extra for shipping.



> Each student was given six months to declare **their** major.
> Each student was given six months to declare **a** major.



> A tenant slipped on a wet floor and hit **their** head, suffering a minor concussion.
> A tenant slipped on a wet floor and suffered a minor concussion.


I**n many cases, however, such rewrites are not possible** — especially when a generic, unknown individual is the subject of the sentence. For instance:


> **Someone** left **their** iPhone in the washroom.


In this case the phone, itself, could be made the subject of the sentence. But that sort of rewrite may be deemed less satisfactory for various reasons, including a shift to the passive voice:


> An iPhone was left in the washroom.


**Writers and editors must make their own judgments** about effective word choice. **As they do, however, they should ignore unfounded claims that "they" must be treated exclusively as a plural pronoun.** Its use as a singular pronoun in certain cases is now an entrenched aspect of modern English.

**Themself, themselves**
Although the standard reflexive form of "them" is plural ("themselves"), the alternative **"themself" is recommended when "them" is tied to a singular subject.** For historical perspective: "Themself" was actually common from the 14th to 16th centuries before virtually disappearing. The pronoun started making a comeback **as part of a wider trend toward gender-neutral writing and speech in the 1980s** (e.g., **"How could anyone defend themself?"** rather than "How could anyone defend himself?").

Some traditionalists object to this trend, classifying "themself" as obsolete and insisting on the plural reflexive in singular cases (e.g., "How could anyone defend themselves?"). But **it's a myth that "themself" is inherently ungrammatical.** As the 2015 edition of Fowler's Dictionary of Modern English Usage puts it: "The final battle for a set of gender-free pronouns will probably be fought over 'themself,' but it's hard to see what could comfortably replace it."

In 2004, linguist Pam Peters expressed support for "themself" even more forcefully:

_"If we allow the use of 'they/them/their' for **referring to the singular, 'themself' seems more consistent than 'themselves.'** We make use of 'yourself' alongside 'yourselves' in the same way. 'Themself' has the additional advantage of being gender-free, and thus \[is\] preferable to both 'himself' and 'himself/herself.' **It's time to reinstate it** to the set of reflexive pronouns."_

— Cambridge Guide to English Usage

**In most news stories, of course, an emphatic reflexive can usually be dropped** without loss of meaning or significant reduction in narrative force (e.g., "The protesters, themselves, say they don't care" can be trimmed to, "The protesters say they don't care"). **But in other constructions, reflexive pronouns may be needed** unless entire sentences are recast. **In such cases, generally prefer "themself" when the subject is singular and "themselves" when the subject is plural** (e.g., "Everyone was asked to look after themself" versus "They were all asked to look after themselves").

**Transgender**
**In recent years, "they" has been used as a non-binary, singular pronoun by many transgender people** who do not identify as either a man or as a woman:

"They were asked to look after themself at a young age."
"They said being able to poke fun at themself was a crucial first step in their stand-up comedy career."

**Such usage in fine in our journalism, as long as we guard against possible audience confusion.** See **[transgender](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/transgender/#pronouns "Transgender")** for details.

See also [grammar](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/handy-links/grammar/ "Grammar") as well as common [problems with pronouns](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/p/problems-with-pronouns/ "Problems with pronouns")[](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/p/problems-with-pronouns/ "Problems with pronouns")


### Time

**Time**[](/home/t/time#local)

[Two-letter time zone shorthand](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/time/#Shorthand "Time") (e.g., ET not EDT)


[Prefer figures](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/time/#Prefer "Time") (but noon, midnight are fine)
[Abbreviating clock readings](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/time/#Abbreviating "Time") (2:01 p.m., 40.7 seconds)

[Dating stories](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/time/#dating "Time") (and other caveats)

**Specify local time**

Since stories written by CBC journalists in different parts of the country may be read, watched or heard by people outside of a specific province or territory, **one of Canada's seven time zones should be specified** when clock readings are included in editorial content. **On air, this is often done by using the word "local" or naming a city or province** (e.g., 2 p.m. Vancouver time). Online, time zone abbreviations are generally preferred because they're shorter and easier to scan (e.g., 2 p.m. PT).

Each zone has a two-letter abbreviation, but only four use uppercase lettering when spelled out:
Newfoundland time (NT)
Atlantic time (AT)
eastern time (ET)
central time (CT)
mountain time (MT)
Pacific time (PT)
Yukon time (YT) \*

**Use local times for all domestic stories**. For instance, specify 4:30 p.m. AT when referring to something happening in the Atlantic time zone (not 3:30 p.m. ET), and 11 a.m. MT when referring to the mountain time zone (not 1 p.m. ET).

**For international coverage, it's sometimes helpful but rarely necessary to include a Canadian time zone in parentheses**. In certain cases, a straight conversion is also OK. (In a story from Berlin, for instance: "Olaf Scholz called Trudeau at 4 a.m. Ottawa time to tell him about the tragedy.") Otherwise, local times are implied and sufficient.

**Almost always use the two-letter time zone abbreviations** (uppercase, with no periods) **after specific clock readings year-round**:

5:28 p.m. NT, 7:13 a.m. AT, 10:35 p.m. ET, 8:19 a.m. CT, 11:12 p.m. PT.

**The only anomalies are most of Saskatchewan**, which is on central standard time all year, **and parts of northeastern British Columbia**, which operate on mountain standard time all year.

12:45 a.m. CST
3:15 p.m. MST

See [Saskatchewan](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/time/#Saskatchewan "Time") and [Northeastern B.C.](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/time/#Northeastern "Time") below for more details.

**ET not EST, PT not PDT, etc.**

**With the exception of Saskatchewan and northeastern British Columbia, avoid specifying "standard" (S) or "daylight" (D) time**.

For instance, simply write 2:15 a.m. ET instead of 2:15 a.m. EST or 2:15 a.m. EDT.

This format eliminates the need to worry about which extra letter to add and avoids confusion over whether the S represents "standard" or "saving." It also matches commonly used date/time stamps that are automatically generated by CBC's web publishing tool when stories are first posted or updated, such as:

Last Updated: Monday, June 26, 2006 | 1:46 p.m. MT.

Canadians who really want the extra detail (S or D) can determine the correct information themselves, based on the date.

****Examples of common time references in stories:****

**A disaster in Halifax**

_The ship blew up at 9:15 a.m. AT.
or
The ship blew up at 9:15 a.m. local time._

**A blackout in southern Ontario**

_The lights went out around 4:15 p.m. ET._

**A train derailment in Saskatchewan**

_The freight trains collided just west of Swift Current around 11 p.m. CST._
or
_The freight trains collided just west of Swift Current around 11 p.m. local time._

**An attack in Afghanistan**

_The Canadian soldiers were killed about 12:55 a.m. local time Thursday (5:25 p.m. ET Wednesday)._

**If the time zone difference between Canada and another country is unusual** (e.g. 7.5 hours) **it's a good idea to include an explanation** to help readers who might be puzzled by the conversion.

**Time zones are generally determined by provinces or territories, though they are also sometimes decided upon by municipalities.** That means **they do not always neatly follow provincial borders and there are important regional exceptions**. 

Most of British Columbia is on PT, but an area in the southeastern part of the province is on MT and a region in northeastern B.C. is on MST (see [Northeastern British Columbia](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/time/#Northeastern "Time") below for details).

Yukon time was established in March of 2020. The territory aligns with MST during the fall and winter and PDT during the spring and summer. The simplest label, however, is "Yukon time" (YT). Although one could argue Yukon is simply on mountain standard time all year, the spirit of the change embraces a permanent West Coast daylight time. And while one could also say Yukon is on Pacific daylight time all year, that label becomes potentially confusing when "PT" (Pacific time) is used for stories about British Columbia.

Use CST for Saskatchewan. Most of the province, except for an area near and including Lloydminster, is officially on central standard time all year (see [Saskatchewan](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/time/#Saskatchewan "Time") below for details).

The western part of Ontario is on CT, unlike most of the province, which is on ET.

Nunavut is spread over three time zones: MT, CT and ET.

Most of Labrador is on AT. So do not refer to NT as "Newfoundland and Labrador time."

**Saskatchewan**

To ensure accuracy and clarity, **use CST in all Saskatchewan clock readings**.

Although a few of its border communities change their clocks to match shifts in daylight time in neighbouring provinces, **Saskatchewan as a whole can be accurately described as being on CST 12 months of the year**. Even though CST = MDT between mid-March and early November, never imply that Saskatchewan actually shifts to mountain time. It does not.

Keep in mind that it can be a mental chore for people to convert a story's time into something more meaningful to them, even if they have the basics memorized (e.g., even if they know that Regina on CST and Calgary on MT share the same time from early spring to late fall, that Regina on CST and Winnipeg on CT share the same time from late fall to early spring, or that there's always a three-hour difference between PT and ET). So **when reporting key details that hinge on time elements, consider offering context for a broader audience** (e.g., "He promised to announce the decision at 4 p.m. Regina time, but then said he forgot that this meant 5 p.m. in Winnipeg because Manitoba is on daylight time").

See also: [Limit use of daylight and standard time](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/time/#Limit "Time") below.

**Northeastern British Columbia**

Somewhat similar to Saskatchewan, **there is an area in northeastern B.C.** – including Fort Nelson, Fort St. John, Dawson Creek and other communities – **that follows mountain standard time all year and does not observe daylight time**.

Functionally, that means that the area is in line with Pacific time for part of the year. However, because the people in these areas have specifically selected to follow mountain standard time, it would not be accurate to say that they follow Pacific time.

It is important to avoid confusion with other areas of B.C. and nearby communities in Alberta that follow mountain daylight time.

So, **when referencing times in the area of northeastern B.C. that operates on mountain standard time the entire year, use MST as an abbreviation**.

See also: [Limit use of daylight and standard time](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/time/#Limit "Time") below.

In Canada, **most provinces move their clocks ahead one hour on the second Sunday in March (they "spring" ahead to daylight time)**. 

The "D" in time clock readings refers to "daylight" time (EDT, PDT). It's usually unnecessary except in stories focused on semi-annual time changes. **Steer clear of the longer term "DS" for "daylight saving" time** (e.g., do NOT use EDST, PDST), for reasons outlined above. And **if you DO spell out "DS," keep the "S" singular for consistency** (i.e., "daylight saving" NOT "savings").

BROADCAST VS. WEB: To reiterate, **it's rarely necessary to specify daylight or standard time in stories**, except when writing about something directly tied to the seasonal adjustment of clocks. In these cases, use the term "daylight time" (not daylight _"saving"_ time) in web articles.

_She missed her plane by an hour because her watch was still set to daylight time._

This in-house CBCNews.ca preference matches Canadian Press guidelines. Therefore, **while it's conversational and acceptable to say "daylight saving" in broadcast journalism, it's not the corporation's default web style** — based on established publishing conventions.

**When spelled out, the words "daylight" and "standard" are lowercase**:

Newfoundland standard time, Atlantic standard time, Pacific standard time, eastern standard time, central standard time, mountain standard time

Newfoundland daylight time, Atlantic daylight time, Pacific daylight time, eastern daylight time, central daylight time, mountain daylight time

**Changes introduced in 2007**

Daylight time used to begin later and end sooner (on the first Sunday in April and the last Sunday in October, respectively). A new system was adopted by the U.S. and most of Canada in March 2007. 

For more details, see the CBCNews.ca feature on [time change in Canada](http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/springing-forward-falling-back-the-history-of-time-change-1.755925).


**Prefer figures**
Generally use figures for times (11:30 a.m.), but write noon and midnight (lowercase), _not_ 12 noon or 12 midnight:

_The plane crashed around noon PT._

**Abbreviating clock readings** (2 a.m., 2:01 p.m., a winning time of 2:38:40.7)

**The terms a.m. and p.m. are always lowercase with periods**.

**Use colons to separate hours and minutes** (2:01 p.m. NT). **But leave out colons in all top-of-the-clock readings** (2 p.m. NT, not 2:00 NT).

**In digital publishing, generally repeat a.m. and p.m. in time ranges** for clarity (e.g., 8 a.m. to 11 a.m., 1 p.m. to 2 p.m.).

**In broadcast scripts, it's an acceptable convention to drop abbreviations** that are implied and clear from context in order to keep our writing conversational (e.g., 8 to 11 a.m., and 1 to 2 p.m.). The most common exception are time ranges that straddle noon or midnight (e.g., 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. and 11 p.m. to 3 a.m.). **In certain video and radio coverage, it's OK to report hour readings only** (e.g., "9 to 4" and "11 to 3"), **as long as the time of day is obvious from context**.

**When reporting duration**, such as the winning time of a sports race, **use colons to separate hours, minutes and seconds, and periods to indicate tenths of a second** (2:38:40.7). **When spelling out such abbreviations, avoid adding conjunctions** (e.g., His time was two hours 38 minutes 40.7 seconds). See [Olympics](/home/o/olympic-games) for more detailed guidelines.

**Outside of clock readings, units of time are almost always spelled out** (e.g., 15 minutes rather than 15 "min."). **But in graphics, TV text, etc., it's OK to abbreviate words if space is severely limited**. In those cases, **include periods and leave singular even in plural constructions** (e.g., hr. for hour and hours, min. for minute and minutes, and sec. for second and seconds). See [abbreviations](/home/a/abbreviations#measurements) for related guidelines.

**GMT**
When converting clock readings from overseas, keep in mind that **Greenwich mean time (GMT) is five hours ahead of eastern standard time** (during Canada's fall and winter), **and four hours ahead of eastern daylight time** (during Canada's spring and summer).

**Although Greenwich mean time (GMT) stays the same all year, Britain adjusts its clocks in the spring and fall.** It moves to "summer time" (the equivalent of our "daylight time") in April, and then switches back in October. **So for six months, London is actually one hour ahead of GMT.**


**Dating stories with inappropriate time references**
As today becomes yesterday tomorrow, it's almost impossible for editors and writers to find and change every dated reference that may be hiding in someone else's copy. So **be careful when using terms like "this morning" or "today" or "last night"** in our online journalism.

There's value in the immediacy of certain phrasing (e.g., "The plane will try an emergency landing in the next few minutes" and "The premier is expected to announce his resignation at 1 p.m. ET"), including how we word various headlines (e.g., "Court decides Senator's fate today").

**Web writers are obligated to ensure that evolving stories remain current, and this sometimes involves dealing with time references that can become dated.** So before the end of your shift, make sure either (i) dated wording is changed or (ii) that plans are made to have dated wording changed (e.g., _"This afternoon's court ruling"_ would become **_"Thursday's court ruling"_**).

Also **avoid redundancies** (e.g., write "4:15 p.m. Thursday," _not_ "4:15 p.m. _Thursday afternoon._") And **avoid contradictory terms like "at about."** Pick one. It either happened at 4:15 p.m. or it happened about (or _around_) 4:15 p.m., but not _at about_.


**1950s, 2010s, Dirty '30s, March 15, Aug. 12**
**Add apostrophes to plural forms of INDIVIDUAL letters , whether lowercase or capitalized,** to help distinguish the "s" from the rest of the group (p's and q's, X's and O's). This applies to SINGLE letters of the alphabet only.  **But do NOT add apostrophes to form the plurals of clusters of capital letters or numbers** (ABCs, FAQs, MPs, SOBs, 747s). See also [apostrophes](/handy-links/punctuation/apostrophes)

**Prefer figures to label decades**: the 1930s, the '30s (instead of the Thirties), the Dirty '30s. Exceptions are certain entrenched names treated as proper nouns (e.g., the '60s but the [Sixties Scoop](/home/s#Sixties_Scoop)).

**Do not put apostrophes before the "s" in the plural forms of years** (1980s, 1920s, mid-1940s). Also, generally treat a decade as a descriptive adjective rather than a true possessive (a 1950s radio).

**Use a hyphen with "mid"** (mid-1950s, mid-1990s) **but not with "early" or "late"** (early 1970s, late 1990s).

**Abbreviate years with apostrophes when seeking an informal tone** (the '70s), **but not when referring to an official name that doesn't include the punctuation** (Expo 67, Expo 86). See also [World Fair versus world fair](/home/w/world-fair)

**The first two decades of the new millennium merit special mention.** They initially caused confusion for many because previous, entrenched naming patterns did not apply. After a thousand years of using the word hundred (e.g., 1700s, 1800s), a shift was required. No one says "twenty hundred" (for 2000) the way they say "nineteen hundred" (for 1900). Instead, we refer to the year 2000 as "two thousand." Therefore, **the current century's first decade is commonly called the 2000s** (pronounced the "two-thousands"), **and its second decade is commonly called the 2010s** (usually pronounced either the "twenty tens" or the "two-thousand tens"). This matches traditional naming conventions used by historians. For example, the 1610s (pronounced "sixteen tens") and the 1910s ("pronounced "nineteen tens").


> 2000s
>
> the '00s   \*\*
>
> 2010s
>
> the '10s   \*\*
>
> mid-2010s
>
> 2020s


\*\* As long as the specific decade meant is obvious

**Be aware that the name given to a century's first decade** (e.g., 1800s) **could also used to mean the entire century.** For instance, "the mid-1800s" can narrowly mean around 1805 (in the same way that the mid-1880s suggests around 1885). But "the mid-1800s" can also strongly suggest the middle of the 19th century (i.e., the 1850s). **To avoid ambiguity, consider different wording** (e.g., a specific year or a range of years) **if a story's context doesn't make the time reference clear.**

**Colloquial names are sometimes given to decades** (e.g., the 1920s were dubbed the Roaring '20s). Depending on a story's tone, **such nicknames can be OK as long as they're reasonably well known or the specific years being referred to are clear.**

**Technically, decades, centuries and millennia all start at the "01" mark because there was no "year zero"** (i.e., because "1 [BC](/home/b#BC)" was followed by "[AD](/home/a#AD) 1"). **However, it's a common convention to use more tidy, intuitive ranges** (e.g., **the 1970s** traditionally means **1970-79** rather than 1971-80). For this reason, 2000 is widely and acceptably considered the start of the 21st century as well as the beginning of the third millennium).

**Centuries can be clipped in second reference**, using the following guidelines:


> 1965-81
>
> 1997-98
>
> 1892-1903
>
> 1999-2002


See also [hyphens](/handy-links/punctuation/hyphens)

**For guidelines on months** (March 15 versus Aug. 12, etc.), **see** [abbreviations](/home/a/abbreviations)

### Titles

**Titles**
[Overview](/home/t/titles#overview) (includes detailed chart)
[Titles versus occupations and temporary appointments](/home/t/titles#occupations) (Judge Gillian Jones but special prosecutor Becky Bones) 

[Apposition latitude](/home/t/titles#apposition) (Canada's Auditor General Jane Smith)

[Dropping former](/home/t/titles#droppingformer) (past versus present)
[Honorary and hereditary titles](/home/t/titles#honorary) (Sir, Lord, etc.)
[Speaker](/home/t/titles#Speaker) (never speaker)

**This page primarily focuses on typography**, including how to handle titles before names versus titles on their own, and when to distinguish between formal titles (capitalized) and mere job descriptions (lowercase). **For editorial direction not listed above, see specific entrie**s elsewhere in the Language Guide (e.g., [Royal titles](/home/r/royal-titles) such as king, princess and duke, [Titles during elections](/home/e/election-titles) and the honorific [Dr.](/home/d/dr) for people with medical degrees).

**TV TEXT REMINDER:** Be aware that television graphics, banners, supers, etc., have some unique typographical conventions. The biggest difference is the use of more initial capital letters in titles, job descriptions, etc. (e.g., "Former Prime Minister" instead of former prime minister, and "High School Principal" instead of high school principal). See the [**TV Text overview**](/home/t/tv_text) for details.

**Overview**
**Capitalize all references to Canada's reigning monarch and the country's current Governor General, as well as to the current Pope:**

> the Pope's letter, the King's visit, the Governor General's speech


**Otherwise, generally use capital letters for other _currently_ held titles only when they appear _immediately before a name_.** A few of these words are abbreviated (e.g., Coun. for councillor and Prof. for professor). Some of the more common titles are:

 **TITLE**

 TITLE **before** name

 TITLE **after** name

 **chief justice**

 Chief Justice Red Buttons 

 Red Buttons, the province's chief justice …

 **city councillor**

 Coun. Red Buttons

 Red Buttons, a city councillor …

 **doctor**

 Dr. Red Buttons
 (_medical only,_ [_not PhD_](/home/d/dr))

 Buttons, a doctor in Mayberry …

 **fire chief**

 Oz fire Chief Red Buttons

 Red Buttons, the fire chief, said …

 **judge**

 Judge Red Buttons

 Red Buttons, the judge who ordered …

 **mayor**

 Mayor Red Buttons

 Red Buttons, the mayor of Mayberry …

 **police chief**

 Oz police Chief Red Buttons

 Red Buttons, the police chief, said …

 **premier**

 Alberta Premier Red Buttons

 Buttons, the premier of Alberta …
 (The premiers of B.C. and Alberta …)

 **prime minister**

 Prime Minister Red Buttons

 Buttons became prime minister two years ago …

 **other ministers**

 Health Minister Red Buttons

 Buttons, Canada's health minister, …
 Buttons, the minister of health … (See [ministry](/home/m/ministry) for related guidelines)

 **junior ministers**

 Minister of State for Sport Gary Lunn

 Lunn, minister of state for sport …
 (See also [long titles](/home/t/titles#longtitles) below)

 **attorney general**

 Attorney General Red Buttons

 Buttons, Canada's attorney general, …

 **auditor general**

 Auditor General Red Buttons

 Buttons, the federal auditor general, …

 **MP**

 MP Red Buttons

 Buttons, a member of Parliament …
 Buttons, the MP for …

 **lieutenant-governor**

 Lt.-Gov. Red Buttons

 Buttons became lieutenant-governor in …

 **senator**
 (_Canada_)

 Sen. Red Buttons

 Less than a year after becoming a senator, Buttons …

 **senator**
 (_U.S._)

 Sen. Red Buttons

 Buttons, a Democratic senator from Massachusetts …

 **representative**

 Rep. Red Buttons

 Buttons, a Republican in the U.S. House of Representatives …

 **president**
 (_of a country_)

 U.S. President Red Buttons

 Buttons, the third U.S. president to …

 **vice-president**
 (_of a country_) 

 U.S. Vice-President Red Buttons

 Buttons became vice-president after …

 **ambassador**

 U.S. Ambassador Red Buttons 

 Buttons, the U.S. ambassador …

 **professor**

 Prof. Red Buttons

 Buttons, a history professor …

 **various ranks**

 Sgt. Red Buttons

 Buttons, a sergeant in the army …
 (See [military ranks](/home/m/military-ranks) for more examples)

**Although cabinet ministers' titles are capitalized before names, secondary** (often informal) **government positions are not:** Finance Minister Red Buttons but _junior finance minister Red Buttons;_ Trade Minister Red Buttons but _deputy trade minister Red Buttons;_ etc.

**When titles are particularly long** (especially **in the case of junior cabinet ministers), it's often helpful to recast the sentence to make the details easier for web readers to scan**. For instance, while all of the following are acceptable, the first version is somewhat unwieldy:

> _Minister of State for the Status of Women Helena Guergis_
>
> He talked to _junior cabinet minister Helena Guergis_
>
> _Helena Guergis, the minister of state for the status of women_
>
> _Minister of State for Sport Gary Lunn_
>
> _federal Sports Minister Gary Lunn_


**The expression shadow cabinet is common and OK**, especially in coverage of Canadian, British and other parliamentary systems. It refers to members of an opposition party designated as counterparts to government cabinet ministers. By contrast, **the narrower term shadow minister requires care.** Although shadow cabinets are by definition made up of shadow ministers, not all Canadians are familiar with the latter label. Some opposition parties in Canada have begun using the expression "shadow minister" a lot in recent years at the provincial, territorial and federal level, which may increase comprehension. As long as the meaning is obvious from context, a term such as "shadow finance minister" is fine in political coverage. But **be mindful of potential audience confusion and lean toward alternative wording** (e.g., a given party's "finance critic") **when there's risk of ambiguity.**


**Prefer the word councillor when referring to municipal politicians**. Use alderman and alderwoman only if this is the official title adopted by a municipality. Before names, it's: _Ald. Fred Russell, Ald. Betty Ali._ In plural: _alderwomen Betty Ali and Janice Heinz_.

**In Canada, "premier" is now conventionally assigned to the leader of the governing party in provinces as well as territories.** The word is uppercase only when directly before the name of the current premier: _Nunavut Premier Paul Okalik_ versus _Paul Okalik, the premier of Nunavut; Ontario Premier Dalton McGuinty_ versus _Dalton McGuinty, the premier of Ontario_. **Avoid the expression "premiers and territorial leaders,"** which is redundant. By contrast, **"provincial and territorial leaders" is fine.**

**Include geographical modifiers in the titles of foreign leaders in first reference**, regardless of the person's profile (e.g., _U.S. President Donald Trump_). See **[United States](/home/u/united-states)** for related guidelines. **Avoid the American convention of leaving out "past" or "former" for previous office holders** (e.g., our style is _former U.S. president Bill Clinton_). See [former, retired, acting, interim](/home/t/titles#former) below for details and related guidelines.


**Titles versus occupations and temporary appointments**
**Distinguish between formal titles and mere job descriptions** (e.g., a company's president versus the person in the White House). **A few positions are conventionally treated as titles before names** (e.g., a judge versus a school principal). **Abbreviations often mask what would otherwise be lowercase lettering** (e.g., MP versus "member of Parliament," Prof. versus "professor," and Dr. versus "doctor").

**If an office is unique, capital letters are generally used** when the title appears before the name (e.g., Privy Council Clerk Joseph Olivier Côté versus Appeal Court clerk Joe Coats). **This includes top medical health officers across the country** — a style we enshrined during coverage of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020. **If a position is unique but relatively junior, however, the title is usually kept all lowercase** (e.g., parliamentary librarian Bill Young). **Temporary appointments are also lowercase across the board** (e.g., special prosecutor, special envoy, special mediator, special prosecutor, special rapporteur), even before the person's name.

> ABC president Red Buttons
>
> Air Canada president Red Buttons
>
> Alberta Chief Medical Officer of Health Red Buttons
>
> Appeal Court clerk Red Buttons
>
> Appeal Court Judge Red Buttons
>
> astronaut Red Buttons
>
> Auditor General Red Buttons
>
> chief of staff Red Buttons
>
> Chief Public Health Officer Dr. Red Buttons
>
> federal Privacy Commissioner Red Buttons
>
> general manager Red Buttons
>
> historian Red Buttons
>
> Judge Red Buttons
>
> Parliamentary Budget Officer Red Buttons
>
> parliamentary librarian Red Buttons
>
> Privy Council Clerk Red Buttons
>
> school principal Red Buttons
>
> special prosecutor Red Buttons
>
> special rapporteur Red Buttons
>
> taxi driver Red Buttons
>
> Treasury Board President Red Buttons
>
> trustee Red Buttons


**Deputy versus deputy**
**The word Deputy is capitalized only if it's part of an official designation.** If the position is informal (such as deputy premier), keep the term deputy lowercase:

> Deputy Chief Medical Health Officer Red Buttons (_when an official title_ in a given jurisdiction)
>
> Deputy Chief Red Buttons (never Deputy _police_ Chief since rank is _Deputy Chief_ )
>
> Deputy Mayor Red Buttons (_an official title_)
>
> deputy premier Red Buttons (_not an official title_)
>
> Deputy Prime Minister Red Buttons (_an official title_)
>
> deputy trade minister Red Buttons (_not an official title_)
>
> NDP deputy leader Red Buttons (_not an official title_)



**Apposition latitude**
In the boggy terrain of bona fide versus false titles, the word "apposition" sometimes surfaces. It's a fancy way of describing certain noun sequences — usually one or more nouns placed in front of another to provide additional information. For instance, "high school math teacher" Nirmila Rajput is an appositive description of someone's job rather than a genuine title. These types of **appositives are common in journalism** because they help convey key detail succinctly.

**Some editors argue that virtually all appositives should be kept lowercase** because they're not true titles. Others, however, regard this approach as overly simplistic because it can lead to wildly jarring renderings. For instance, the respected but sometimes idiosyncratic Chicago Manual of Style recommends that when "German" is added to "Chancellor Angela Merkel" the revised block of nouns should be written as "German chancellor Angela Merkel" with a lowercase "c" because the geographical modifier technically turns her official title into a descriptive appositive. The core of the argument is that the formal title ("Chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany") can be shortened to "Chancellor of Germany Angela Merkel" or to "Chancellor Angela Merkel," but that the noun "Germany" cannot actually be changed to "German" and shifted forward without eroding the true title. **It's a contestable view that does not reflect CBC News style:
**

>
>
> Chancellor Angela Merkel (_fine_)
>
> German Chancellor Angela Merkel (_fine_)
>
> German chancellor Angela Merkel _(not CBC style_)


**Certain possessive constructions are debated in a similar way**. It boils down to whether a formal, universally accepted construction such as "Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany" can be colloquially recast as "Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel" (OK) or if it must automatically become either "Germany's chancellor Angela Merkel" (NOT CBC style), or "Germany's chancellor, Angela Merkel," with the person's name set off by commas to mark a non-restrictive appositive.

To be clear: **There's no need to prefer possessive forms when equally common and conversational alternatives exist.** Why write "Manitoba's Premier Jane Smith" when "Manitoba Premier Jane Smith" generally does the job? **At the same time, there's no need to insist on imposing lowercase titles just because a key geographical detail is reported in the possessive form before a proper noun.** The only exceptions are rare cases of intentionally written, non-restrictive appositives that use commas to mark a person's name as secondary, optional detail:


> Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe
>
> Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe (_acceptable shorthand for Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan_)
>
> Japan's prime minister Shinzo Abe (_not CBC style_)
>
> Japan's prime minister, Shinzo Abe, (_rare; limited to cases when name is considered parenthetical_)
>
> French President Emmanuel Macron
>
> France's President Emmanuel Macron (_acceptable shorthand for President Emmanuel Macron of France_)
>
> France's president Emmanuel Macron (not _CBC style_)
>
> France's president, Emmanuel Macron, (_rare; limited to cases when name is considered parenthetical_)


**We apply the above template to other appositives treated as genuine titles before names** in order to avoid introducing debatable and befuddling capitalization complexity into our journalism:


> Chief Public Health Officer Dr. Theresa Tam
>
> Canada's Chief Public Health Officer Dr. Theresa Tam
>
> Canada's chief public health officer Dr. Theresa Tam (not CBC style)


Some veteran editors are quick to point out that **possessives like this are rarely necessary**. It's a sound observation. **But in certain cases, such constructions have become relatively entrenched** in everyday speech:


> Britain's Prime Minister Boris Johnson
>
> Canada's Auditor General Sheila Fraser
>
> Toronto's Medical Officer of Health Eileen de Villa


**These possessive forms are instantly perceived as titles, or proper title equivalents**, which means there's no risk of confusion. And given the relatively arbitrary nature of syntactic capitalization preferences, **there's no need to make our audience ride a roller-coaster of uppercase and lowercase characters** before finally arriving at a given individual's name.


**Former, retired, acting, interim, outgoing, etc.**
Even when titles appear directly before names, **do not use capital letters if people haven't been sworn in yet** (U.S. president-elect), **if they're just temporarily filling in** ("acting prime minister" versus the proper title "Deputy Prime Minister" or someone appointed on a longer, [interim](/home/a/acting-versus-interim) basis), **if their designations are informal** ("deputy premier" or "party whip"), and **in most cases when the positions are no longer held** (former prime minister Joe Clark, former premier Ralph Klein) unless they continue to carry out duties (e.g., retired cardinals under 80 can still be called on to help pick a new Pope, so it's retired Cardinal Jean-Claude Turcotte). **Continue to use uppercase for departing political leaders until an interim replacement is announced** (e.g., outgoing Liberal Leader Stéphane Dion). **Avoid the American convention of leaving out "past" or "former" for previous office holders** (e.g., our style is former U.S. president Barack Obama). Note: In certain historical references, it's sometimes best to drop terms such as "former" or "ex," as outlined in [past versus present](/home/t/titles#droppingformer).

> _acting_  prime minister Red Buttons
>
> _acting_  Staff Sgt. Red Buttons
>
> _acting_  police chief Red Buttons
>
> _assistant_  attorney general Red Buttons
>
> _former deputy mayor Red Buttons_
>
> ex-president Red Buttons (but see "[dropping ex-](/home/t/titles#droppingformer)" _below_)
>
> ex-prime minister Red Buttons (but see "[dropping ex-](/home/t/titles#droppingformer)" _below_)
>
> _former_  prime minister Joe Clark (but see "[dropping former](/home/t/titles#droppingformer)" _below_)
>
> _former_  premier Ralph Klein (but see "[dropping former](/home/t/titles#droppingformer)" _below_)
>
> _former_  president Jimmy Carter (but see "[dropping former](/home/t/titles#droppingformer)" _below_)
>
> _former_  vice-president Al Gore (but see "[dropping former](/home/t/titles#droppingformer)" _below_)
>
> _outgoing_  Conservative Leader Andrew Scheer (flags departure before interim replacement announced; see also [post-election titles](/home/e/election-titles#defeated))
>
> _interim_  Auditor General John Wiersema (see also [acting versus interim](/home/a/acting-versus-interim))
>
> _interim_  Liberal Leader Bill Graham (see also [acting versus interim](/home/a/acting-versus-interim))
>
> _interim_  Premier Dave Hancock (see also [acting versus interim](/))
>
> _then_  president Jimmy Carter (_but see_ "[dropping then](/home/t/titles#droppingformer)" _below_)
>
> _then_  prime minister Brian Mulroney (_but see_ "[dropping then](/home/t/titles#droppingformer)" _below_)
>
> governor general-_designate_  Red Buttons
>
> mayor-_elect_  Red Buttons
>
> prime minister-_designate_  Red Buttons
>
> U.S. president-_elect_  Red Buttons
>
> when he was president, Red Buttons …
>
> _retired_  general John de Chastelain
>
> _retired_  senator Red Buttons
>
> _retired_  Cardinal Jean-Claude Turcotte (capital C an exception because retiree still active)
>
> party whip Red Buttons (_not an official title_ )


See also [\-designate versus -elect](/home/p/pm-designate)

**Capitalize the first letter of words that begin sentences, headlines, etc.** _So retired general_  John de Chastelain would become Retired general John de Chastelain if this is the first word.


**Past versus present** (dropping former)
**When referring to past events, don't use terms such as former**, ex-, the late, then, etc. Instead, use the year and then **keep the title in uppercase:**

    On Jan. 26, 1976, Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau became the first Canadian leader to pay an official visit to Cuba.

Although ex- is a good choice for headlines (e.g., ex-PM), be careful when using the term before compound nouns (e.g., ex-prime minister) and adjectives (e.g., ex-Liberal MP). See also [ex-](/home/e#ex-) and [the late](/home/l#thelate)


**Honorary and hereditary titles**
**Canada's reigning monarch can usually be called the King or** (depending on the story's context) **the King of Canada.** Adding a name is optional (King Charles or King Charles III). **For other members of the Royal Family, use titles before first names** (Prince William, Princess Beatrice). **Titles are kept in uppercase for past Canadian** (and British) **monarchs** (e.g., Queen Victoria, King George VI). Use uppercase King and Queen for _reigning_ foreign monarchs only if the title appears directly before the name. (See [**royal titles**](/home/r/royal-titles) for detailed guidelines)
**
Do not confuse knighthoods with the nobility. The titles are chivalry honours and should generally be avoided in stories except in directly transcribed quotes** (e.g., Elton John _not_ Sir Elton John, Alfred Hitchcock _not_ Sir Alfred Hitchcock, Elizabeth Taylor not Dame Elizabeth). **An exception is made for historical figures whose titles have become entrenched over time:** Sir John A. Macdonald. This approach has nothing to do with minimizing the merit of a particular honour. Rather, it's to be consistent in limiting our use of titles (e.g., we don't call people with honorary PhDs "[Dr.](/home/d/dr)"). It's worth noting that many high-profile people have actually turned down chivalry honours from Buckingham Palace, which helps put into perspective any celebrity's insistence on being called Sir or Dame during interviews.

**Life peerages should be used only if relevant to the story.** In these cases, type in the full title: Lord Black of Crossharbour (Lord Black in second reference). Otherwise, stick to the name that's more familiar (Conrad Black).


**Speaker**
**The word Speaker is always uppercase when referring to Parliament and provincial legislatures** to avoid confusion with the generic meaning "one who speaks." (So it's Speaker Red Buttons and deputy Speaker Red Buttons.) **A capital letter is also used even when the person no longer holds the office** (former Speaker Gilbert Parent). See [Speaker](/home/s/speaker)


**Leader**
**The word leader is always lowercase unless it's immediately after the name of a political party and directly before a name.** (Conservative _Leader_ Red Buttons, but party _leader_ Red Buttons.) See [Leader versus leader](/home/l/leader)

See also specific entries, such as [Pope versus pope](/home/p/pope) and [Governor General](/home/g/governor-general)
See also [military ranks](/home/m/military-ranks), [police ranks](/home/p/police-forces), [\-general](/home/g/generalsuffix) as a suffix, as well as [abbreviations](/home/a/abbreviations) for terms such as MP and [Dr](/home/d/dr).

### ton versus tonne

**Ton versus tonne**

Try to **use tonne rather than ton** when including specific measurements of weight in stories. You must do more than simply add a consonant and a vowel to the word ton. You have to perform **a straightforward calculation**.


**From tons to tonnes**
A "**ton**" is also known as a "short ton," although we don’t use that term. It’s **2,000 pounds (or 907.19 kilograms)**. When given a weight in tons, multiply this number by 0.907 to get tonnes (also known as "metric tons").

5.5 tons = 5.5 x .907 = 4.99 tonnes, which can be rounded to "nearly five tonnes"


**From tonnes to tons**
A "**metric ton**" (a tonne) is **1,000 kilograms (or 2,204.62 pounds)**. To go from metric tons (tonnes) to tons, multiply by 1.1

5 tonnes = 5 x 1.1 = 5.5 tons


**From long tons to tonnes**
**Unless specified, a "ton" in North America normally refers to a "short ton."** A slightly heavier amount, known as a "long ton," is common in Britain. **A "long ton" is 2,240 pounds (or 1,016.05 kilograms)**. It’s virtually the same as a metric tonne (about 35 pounds heavier). To go from a "long ton" to a metric tonne, multiply by 1.016

5.5 long tons = 5.5 x 1.016 = 5.588 tonnes, which can be rounded to "about 5.6 tonnes" or "just over 5.5 tonnes," etc.

**Since there’s a difference of only about 35 pounds between a long ton and a metric ton, the conversion isn’t significant in stories dealing with relatively small numbers.** For every 63 long tons, there is roughly one extra tonne (63 x 35 = 2,205 pounds).


**A ton of information**
Although we prefer metric measurements for most weights, **use "ton"** not tonne **in colloquial expressions** (e.g., "_a ton of bricks_" and "_weighed a ton_"). This includes various industry conventions, such as the hauling capacity of some vehicles (e.g., a _half-ton truck_, a _four-ton truck_).

See also [metric versus imperial](/home/m/metric-versus-imperial)

### top\_doctor

**Top doctor**

A conversational and **acceptable synonym for the senior public health officer in a given country, province or community.** The idiomatic term **conventionally means that the physician is considered a specific government's authoritative voice for recommended public health measures**. The person's advice is almost always based on extensive consultation with others. "Top doctor" does not mean that the office holder has managerial powers over other doctors or is objectively the "best" physician.

**Use in moderation** to avoid becoming tiresome, especially during extensive coverage of a pandemic or other crisis when the colloquialism can quickly become clichéd.

**Always include the physician's formal title in stories to make the meaning of "top doctor" clear** (e.g., Canada's chief public health officer, Ontario's chief medical officer of health, Toronto's medical officer of health). Use initial caps [when the titles appear before names](/home/t/titles#apposition) (Chief Public Health Officer Theresa Tam). Be aware that some jurisdictions refer to their senior health officials without modifiers like "chief" (e.g., B.C.'s provincial health officer).

The informal label **"top doctor" implies that the person has a medical degree** rather than merely a PhD in science, so make sure the facts fit before using (i.e., that the "top doctor" is an MD).

**Avoid wording that implies there's a hierarchy when reporting on more than one senior public health official** in Canada. We get audience complaints if we wrongly suggest that regional "top doctors" report to a national "top doctor." For this reason, it's **often clearest to talk about federal and provincial counterparts** (e.g., "top doctors" or "top public health officers" across the country). They're all members of the **Council of Chief Medical Officers of Health**, which is part of the [Pan-Canadian Public Health Network](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.phn-rsp.ca%2Findex-eng.php&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0M77cLVHijEub1Bag-jnGU) — a technical detail rarely necessary in any routine coverage. Canada's chief public health officer runs the [Public Health Agency of Canada](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.canada.ca%2Fen%2Fpublic-health%2Fcorporate%2Forganizational-structure%2Fcanada-chief-public-health-officer%2Frole-chief-public-health-officer.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0rKS59g68xUXSdItBPDYw6), which was created in part to respond to national public health emergencies, including infectious disease outbreaks.

### Trade names

**Trade names, trademarks, etc.**

[Verify case by case](/home/t/trade-names#verify) (Skip the dictionary, use government database)

[Prefer generic but natural](/home/t/trade-names#generic) (tissue, cola not Kleenex, Coke; but Jell-O, Frisbees)

[**List of commonly encountered trade names, trademarks**](/home/t/trade-names#list) (Aspirin to Zamboni)

[Avoid medial madness, logo lunacy](/home/t/trade-names#medial) (Teleprompter, Scrabble not TelePrompTer, SCRABBLE)



**Overview**

**Some companies have legal ownership over certain words. These terms generally require capital letters at the start** to flag them as commercial assets. **Trademarks are distinctive logos or words** (slogans or names) **that are legally registered** in a specific jurisdiction. **Sometimes a trademark is a single word and/or logo.** In other cases, it's a comparatively complex cluster. **Brand names can also have this protection. They're often called "trade names," although in Canada a "trade name" traditionally refers to a registered company name.**

**Investors can be very territorial about proprietary terms.** They often don't want "their" words to appear in lowercase. They want to preserve a brand name, not hurl it into a sea of generic labels.

**When common words are no longer associated with specific products, proprietary status can vanish.** This is referred to as _debasement_. For instance, a capital L is no longer needed in "**laundromat**" because the name is now considered a generic term for a coin-operated laundry, and the capital C in "**cellophane**" has been similarly washed away. Another example is "**dumpster**," which used to be written as Dumpster because it was based on the name of a waste disposal system patented by a U.S. company, Dempster Brothers. The portmanteau (from the word dump and the family name Dempster) was legally protected for more than half a century. But the capital D has since been tossed away, and "dumpster" is now considered a generic word for any large, outside waste bin. **Although debasement often leads to lowercase renderings, proper noun elements sometimes retain initial capitals** (e.g., referring to any folding wall bed as a **Murphy bed**) based on familiar usage. In those instances, the capital letter is not proprietary but merely eponymous.



**Verify case by case**

When deciding whether to capitalize, **the first step is verifying facts. Don't use a proprietary name** (e.g., a business installing Plexiglas) **when you're actually referring to a generic product** (e.g., a business installing a generic acrylic sheet, commonly known as "plexiglass").

**Accuracy matters.** If someone sends you an email and refers to "kleenex" instead of **Kleenex**, no one is going to sue. But if you write "kleenex" on CBC.ca, millions of people may see it, including a few lawyers. And you're dreaming in **Technicolor** (note the "T") if you think you can safely ignore all capital letters on a whim. **The digital era has made it easier for companies to spot improper or unauthorized use of registered names.** Free, unsophisticated computer apps can now send them alerts whenever a certain word or phrase appears in news stories.

**Dictionaries are not the best guide for trade names.** Lexicographers don't always acknowledge the words with capital letters. And some terms have protection in one country but not another (**Aspirin in Canada**, for instance, but **aspirin in the United States**). Even when trade names are included in dictionaries, there are lags between the loss of proprietary status and the appearance of small letters in updated editions of reference books.

**CBC News uses the [Canadian Trademarks Database](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ic.gc.ca%2Fapp%2Fopic-cipo%2Ftrdmrks%2Fsrch%2Fhome&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0DYqUWlY2JMIRzZVNgtlso)** as our primary source to determine which trade names remain under protection. **A few dozen proprietary terms** that appear in news copy with some frequency are [**listed below**](/home/t/trade-names#list)

**Be aware that not all registered names and certification marks need to be capitalized.** In particular, if an expression such as "disclaimed apart from the certification mark" appears in the above database's entry, lowercase rendering is generally fine in our journalism. This disclaimer often signals that **COMMON words capitalized in a name, logo or other graphical representation constituting a trademark do not have to be treated the same way in ordinary writing or speech.** Two separate complaints to CBC News over the years illustrate these differences. The occupational designation of **Realtor** requires a capital R because the UNIQUE noun continues to enjoy special proprietary status. By contrast, the everyday occupational designations of **certified orthotist** and **certified prosthetist** can be reported lowercase, in the same way we'd refer to chartered accountants, licensed architects, registered nurses, cardiologists, neurosurgeons, etc.


**Prefer generic but natural**

**It's best to avoid trade names when possible** (write "_tissue_" not Kleenex, "_cola_" not Coke, "_disinfectant_" not Lysol, "_bleach_" not Javex, "_jeans_" not Levi's, "_hot tub_" or _"whirlpool"_ not Jacuzzi, _"in-line skating"_ not Rollerblading, _"plastic bags"_ not Baggies, and so forth).

**But sometimes the most natural way to describe the world around us** — a world full of proprietary items that are difficult to describe generically — **is to say that the dog chased a Frisbee** (rather than a "plastic disc the size of a pie plate"), **or that the children ate Jell-O** (not a "gelatinous dessert"), as the Globe and Mail's style manual pointed out years ago.

That old advice remains valid today, which is why **people Google things** rather than "enter keywords into search engines." And it can be far too shackling to prohibit all proprietary words from being used in novel or creative ways, especially if certain constructions help make a story clearer or more engaging (e.g., describing a space gizmo that collects samples from the moon's surface as being like, say, **a giant lunar Roomba**, or calling a large beach-cleaning tractor **a kind of sand Zamboni**). Nevertheless, **when we're literally rather than figuratively referring to products, it's usually best to stick to generic phrasing** (e.g., "_ice resurfacing equipment_" or "_ice resurfacers_" instead of Zambonis), **unless we know the specific trade name is accurate** (e.g., "the rink spent half the money it raised from the raffle on an electric Zamboni").  


**Seek legal guidance as required**

**If you receive a formal complaint about alleged improper use of a proprietary term, do not ignore or dismiss the claim.** Options include verifying that capitalization is required and then revising, accordingly, or simply recasting with a lowercase, generic synonym.

**If the complaint is about more than simply capitalization** (e.g., a company or person is demanding we not use a proprietary term in a given context), **it's best to contact the [CBC Law Department](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fio.cbcrc.ca%2F%23%2Fresources%2Fcontacts-for-all-lawyers-coordonnees-de-tous-les-avocats-1.3096758&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw3w_B4CnHUS7T9u7Wl_dGqe) for guidance**, including possible help drafting whatever response we, as a corporation, may decide is appropriate. The internal GMail is **lawdepartment@cbc.ca**.

**Be aware that companies may sometimes make contestable or unreasonable demands**, such as removing properly capitalized proprietary terms from news stories simply because they don't like "their" names appearing in various contexts. Figurative expressions, in particular, are sources of debate (e.g., a Band-Aid solution that's temporary but not very good, a bumbling, unpopular Teflon politician nothing sticks to).

**There may be times when a rewrite request has merit** (e.g., if using one manufacturer's name to describe another company's new product might cause confusion). **But before revising a script based solely on a company's complaint** about alleged improper use of a proprietary name, **consult the Law Department if you have any doubts.** Relevant factors to consider include entrenched English usage, acceptable figurative speech and journalistic purpose (e.g., clear imagery in a radio script).

**Don't go overboard with capitalization**. We've had email complaints, for instance, insisting that it's "Jumbo Jet." But it's not (and never was). It's jumbo jet as outlined in the Words: Woe & Wonder column [Jumbo Jets and other Jargon](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews2%2Findepth%2Fwords%2Fjumbo.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2a9FlPFQnNoWSvI_j4lnCK).

**When the legal protection disappears, the capital letters should go too.** Until 2003, for instance, The Canadian Press recommended **TV Dinner**. It's now **TV dinner**. Other examples are **yo-yo** and **trampoline**, as well as laundromat, cellophane and dumpster, as noted in the [overview](/home/t/trade-names#overview) above.


**NOTE:** If a proprietary term is causing confusion but is not in the Language Guide, forward the information to [CBC's standards editor](/contact-us) to help buttress accuracy and consistency.
