**Avoid medial madness, logo lunacy**

A final point: **We ignore most "medial" capitals** (i.e., those BigLetTers shoved in the middle of words as a marketing gimmick). So while CP suggests **TelePrompTer**, for instance, we agree with the Globe and Mail and type **Teleprompter**. Exceptions are less-jarring spellings, such as fused names with only one capital letter in the middle (e.g., PowerPoint, WestJet, WikiLeaks).

We also write [words, not logos](/home/n/names-versus-logos). So it's **ReMax Canada** and **Yahoo**, _not_ _RE/MAX Canada_ and _Yahoo!_ featuring special characters like slashes and exclamation marks. See also [quirky capitalization](/home/q/quirky-capitalization) for related guidelines (**Scrabble** and **Visa**, not SCRABBLE and VISA, but **eBay**, **iMac**, etc.)

For an overview of capital letters in news stories, see [capitalization](/home/c/capitalization)

See also [spelling](/home/s/spelling)



### transgender

**Transgender**


[Pronouns](/home/t/transgender#pronouns) (he, she, 'they' as a singular)
[Transition, transitioning](/home/t/transgender#transition) (e.g., gender surgery)
[Former names, misstated ID/gender](/home/t/transgender#former-names) ('deadnaming' and 'misgendering')

[Miscellaneous](/home/t/transgender#miscellaneous) ('-der' not '-dered,' trans)
[Tautology vs. clarity](/home/t/transgender#tautology) (axe awkward clutter)

**TRANSGENDER** commonly refers to someone who **identifies with a gender** **that doesn't match the person's biological classification at birth**. They may or may not decide to alter their bodies through hormone therapy or other medical procedures. Transgender **also refers in a broader way to someone whose identity does not narrowly conform to conventional notions of female or male.** Instead, they combine or move between traditional classifications according to individual expressions of gender identity.

Avoid including this detail in stories unless it's directly relevant.

**Gender vs. sex**
Common **GENDER** classifications: **woman, man, non-binary**
Common **SEX** classifications: **female, male**

English is in constant flux. For more than half a millennium, "gender" applied primarily to grammar (e.g., masculine or feminine nouns, pronouns), and "sex" referred to anatomical classifications (i.e., male and female), which, in turn, simply reflected reproductive organs. But **roughly a century ago, "gender" became increasingly common as a synonym for "sex,"** especially after the latter started being used more frequently to mean intercourse, according to the 2015 Fowler's Dictionary of Modern English Usage.

**In recent decades, "gender" has taken on a much narrower meaning in scholarly circles, where it's used to describe "socially constructed" characteristics of men and women** (e.g., traditional norms, roles and relationships within a society, which are unfixed and largely taught/learned). **This has led to inconsistency and misunderstanding.** As the 2007 Oxford Guide to Canadian English Usage puts it:


> _"Many people today use 'gender' as a synonym for 'sex.' \[But many academic writers\] ... use 'gender' to refer to the roles and characteristics associated with men and women by society, and 'sex' to refer to characteristics that can be classified as anatomical, genetic, or biological; this distinction can be useful."_


**In our journalism, we usually distinguish between sex** (biological classification) **and gender** (personal identity), **especially if using the terms interchangeably causes confusion** (e.g., in stories about transgender rights). **The entrenched practice of using "gender" and "sex" as synonyms in some contexts can be OK when there's no ambiguity** (e.g., **gender equality, gender gaps** in hiring and pay, **gender stereotypes**). This includes references to "gender" details on certain government ID, such as a driver's licence or passport — not only because such usage is established, but because some jurisdictions now have options beyond just M and F (e.g., "X" for non-binary identity as well as for undisclosed gender identity).

**However, the word "sex" should be our default term for biological classifications.** A 2021 ombudsman complaint about the discovery of two badly decomposed corpses in a downtown Toronto apartment illustrates preferred usage. We reported that the "gender" of one of the bodies could not be determined when we should have said that the "sex" could not be determined. Although medical examiners can virtually always tell what reproductive organs people were born with, they cannot objectively ascertain gender identities.


**CONVENTIONAL SYNTAX:** (i) **The biological classifications of male and female are commonly used as adjectives** (e.g., _a female athlete, a male nurse_), when this detail is considered relevant to the story. The test should be whether adding "female" or "male" is essential to our audience's understanding of a given report, as well as whether we're treating both sexes equally (e.g., if we wouldn't routinely refer to a "male" doctor or judge, then we shouldn't routinely refer to a "female" doctor or judge either). (ii) **The gender identities of man and woman are commonly used as nouns** (e.g., _a missing man, a Winnipeg woman_). Be aware that **some people prefer to use the word woman as an adjective, too**, in order to stress gender over biology (e.g., _a woman athlete, a woman construction worker_). **But sentences can wind up lacking parallel construction** because the word man is rarely used an adjective in the same way (e.g., _a man athlete, a man construction worker_). **One workaround is to recast phrasing to avoid inconsistency** (e.g., _She is the only woman on an otherwise all-man space crew_).




**Sex/gender assigned at birth**
**Entrenched references to biological classification at birth are not considered transphobic when used in generic contexts** (e.g., "They're expecting a baby girl" and "She gave birth to a boy"). Calling infants "girls" and "boys" conventionally implies sex assignment rather than actual gender identification. **Some transgender people object to this language, however, in stories about them. Be respectful.** In particular, take into account the following:

-   **Polarizing expressions like "born a boy" and "born female" are often unnecessary.** Such detail is sometimes obvious from context. For instance:

> > DISPUTED WORDING: _He came up with the idea for the special swimsuit when he and his daughter, who was born a boy, were getting ready for a trip to Central America._
>
>
>
> > REWRITE: _He came up with the idea for the special swimsuit when he and his daughter, who is transgender, were getting ready for a trip to Central America._

-   **If detail about sex at birth is deemed essential, use the least-wordy, most conversational phrasing possible** — keeping in mind that such constructions tend to sound relatively clinical no matter how they're phrased. For instance:

> > POOR (verbose, awkward): _She was assigned the classification of male at birth_.
>
> >
> > BETTER (less wordy, more direct): _She was born with male sex organs_.
>
> >
> > POTENTIALLY BEST (as long as the individual doesn't object): _She was born with the body of a boy_.

-   **Avoid inaccuracies**, such as claiming someone was "born a man" or "born a woman." **People are not born as adults**, and using "man" or "woman" to mean male genitalia and female genitalia at birth offends people fighting to educate society about gender identification. 

**NOTE: The modifier "biological" can be problematic in stories about gender** for two reasons: (i) **It can emphasize sexual classification in a way that supplants the individual's own gender identity** (e.g., calling a trans woman a "biological male" or a trans man a "biological female"); and (ii) **It can oversimplify the actual science of sex.**

Be aware that **some opponents of transgender rights use the term "biological" in misleading ways.** Their language presumes communities are monolithic, ignoring the reality that some transgender people may have undergone a range of medical treatment, from hormone therapy to surgery, which complicates the semantics debate over the meaning of the modifier "biological" in this context. For instance, does being "male" depend on having a penis or having a certain level of testosterone? Does it rely on the presence of X and Y chromosomes in a scientific age that can document sex development differences in some "boys" and "girls," including a condition known as androgen insensitivity syndrome? Our recommended style: **Outside of attribution, limit use of terms like biological male and biological female to scientific stories**, such as reports on medical research, zoology, animal physiology, etc.


**Pronouns**
**Adopt pronouns used by the transgender person** (he, his, him, she, her, hers). If an established practice is unknown, go with pronouns that reflect how the person lives publicly (e.g., wording used by them on social media, biographical details on an employer's website). **Some transgender people** do not identify as either male or female and **use the plural pronoun "they" in a singular form** (they, them, theirs, [themself](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/they_singular/#themself "They_singular")). **We should respect this choice while being mindful of clarity.** This means:

-   **If it's obvious a story is referring to one person, as is often the case, there's no need to add additional detail** (e.g., to specifically point out that the individual uses "they," "them" and "their"). **But if it's not clear from context, it's a good idea to briefly explain why the plural pronoun is singular** (e.g., "Smith, who uses the pronoun 'they,' says ..." ) If such background is deemed relevant, keep it as brief as possible, and convey it in the spirit of practical consideration, the way someone might add a "she/her" or "they/them" pronoun signature to the bottom of an email.

-   **If one or more sentences are potentially confusing, it can be helpful to consider recasting** without third person pronouns when practical (e.g., "Smith's" instead of "theirs"), **especially in broadcast scripts**, which can be challenging for the ear.

**Do not use less common non-binary pronouns** (e.g., zhe, yo, xe, ve, thon, hu, ey). It's OK to report that a given person prefers a neologism like "zhe" or "hu" in a story. But attempting to actually construct an entire report using such words introduces major challenges — from nailing down pronunciation to determining case form (e.g., if "zhe" is chosen as the nominative "she" and "he" equivalent, then you must also decide on the accusative "her" and "him" equivalents, as well as on the possessive "hers" and "his" forms).

**Aim for consistent pronoun use for the same person within a story.** If someone has no set preference for singular or plural, go with what the individual uses most often. **If someone asks us to use a mix of pronouns** (e.g., alternating between singular and plural), **request that the person pick one approach in a given report to avoid confusion.** When balancing respect for an individual's identity against the need for audience clarity, keep in mind that there are alternative ways to present information to avoid inconsistency (e.g., limiting the use of pronouns by using the possessive form of a person's name as noted above).


**CAUTION: The word PREFER has more than one meaning in English.** For centuries it's been defined as "to favour" as well as "to choose." **In the context of transgender language, "prefer" virtually always means** the latter — i.e., **usage chosen** by individual members of the transgender community. Avoid implying that decisions about names, pronouns, etc., are merely favoured options. Rather, such "preferences" are **designated language choices**. To avoid confusion, **stick to unambiguous wording in stories**. For example: "British pop star Sam Smith **uses the pronouns** 'they/them' ... " (NOT "prefers the pronouns 'they/them' ...").


See also "[**they as a singular pronoun**](/home/t/they_singular)" for general grammar guidelines.


**Transition, transitioning** (e.g., gender surgery)
The verb **transition** has become a common way to describe embracing a gender identity (i.e., male/female) that's different from one's biological classification at birth. The participle is **transitioning**. These **terms do not have to be defined in stories**, as long as the context makes their meaning clear. **Transitioning may or may not involve medical procedures**, broadly known as **gender-affirming care** — from hormone therapy and electrolysis to various types of surgery. There can be a wide range of reasons against medical treatment, from personal choice (e.g., happiness with one's own body) to financial costs, physical and emotional concerns, and other barriers. 

**When referring to surgery, generally prefer short, fact-based descriptions** (e.g., **gender surgery, transgender surgery**). While terms such as **gender-affirming** and **gender-confirming** procedures are OK, especially if they're the choice of a given transgender person, be aware that not all members of the 2SLGBTQ+ community use or endorse these labels for various reasons. **Avoid the dated term "reassignment" surgery**, which critics say wrongly implies that an external authority is reclassifying an individual. Exceptions should be attributed (e.g., when medical personnel mention "gender reassignment" in a transcribed quote). **Avoid the archaic expression "sex change" operation** outside of direct quotes (e.g., verbatim references to historical documents).

**It's rarely necessary to use obscure jargon when referring to surgery** (e.g., vaginectomy, gaginoplasty, penectomy, phalloplasty). **Common descriptions are clearer and generally satisfactory** (e.g., facial surgery, breast surgery, genital reconstruction), assuming this level of clinical detail is even relevant to given coverage (e.g, something has gone wrong). The word surgery alone is normally sufficient in second reference.


**Former names, misstated ID/gender**
**We don't usually refer to anyone's former name unless the detail is directly relevant** to a story. This kind of **information is rarely pertinent** (e.g., Woody Allen was born Allan Stewart Konigsberg). For details, see: [Names — Common versus legal](/home/n/names_common).

The **bar is higher for transgender people**, since names are directly tied to gender identity. **We almost always use their current, preferred names.** This generally applies **even if someone is charged with a crime and court documents list a different legal name**. Reporting it usually serves little public interest compared to the personal pain associated with unilaterally resurrecting an abandoned gender identity. **Exceptions are rare** (e.g., a case of fraud involving alleged use of false IDs and personas). A key test is whether the birth name is fundamental or merely incidental to fully understand the story.

**Public figures are in a special category. Limited references to former names are sometimes OK**, based largely on audience familiarity. For instance, **Caitlyn Jenner** should be referred to either as **a woman** or as a transgender woman when the latter is relevant. But **imposing an outright ban against periodically mentioning certain biographical detail would be far too restrictive**. Therefore, it's **potentially OK to point out that her birth name was Bruce Jenner**, that she won Olympic gold medals as a male decathlete, etc., **as long as this background is germane to given coverage**. But this does not mean that public figures' past identities can be inserted into stories capriciously. The editorial threshold of demonstrable relevance must still be met. **When a public figure already known by one name and gender suddenly switches to another name and gender, audience recognition becomes a consideration.** This normally means referring to both identities in coverage during a transition period to keep our journalism clear. The [Bradley/Chelsea Manning case](/updates/2013/2013-08-23) in August 2013 is an example. NOTE: **Using a transgender person's former name sparingly for historical context, etc., does not mean using old pronouns**, which is as unnecessary as it is potentially offensive (e.g., Jenner's Olympic accomplishments remain "hers" not "his").

**Be aware that jargon like "deadnaming" and "misgendering" can be problematic** for various reasons. **Deadname means former name** (often a **birth name**). The term is **potentially confusing** because it's not well known. Also, **"deadname" is not embraced by all transgender people for various reasons** — including the emotional connection some maintain to a former identity that they say helped shape them. So while many individuals we talk to may be comfortable labelling their past identities as "dead," others might feel differently. It's **one more reason that entrenched, fact-based, instantly recognizable expressions like "former" name and "birth" name tend to be preferred by careful writers.** The transitive verb **misgender means "to mistake or misstate a person's gender"** — including the use of pronouns that clash with the individual's expressed gender identity. But **misgender**, coined in 1989, **remains relatively obscure and potentially jarring**, especially in broadcast scripts, since "gender" is not normally used as a verb. **The same is true of the noun "misgendering," which is neither conversational nor crystal clear** to a general audience.


**Cisgender**
An increasingly common word to describe **someone who is not transgender**. It's **OK in news stories as long as the meaning is obvious from context.** Otherwise, the word should be briefly defined. **Never use terms such as normal** to describe someone who gender identity matches their sex classification at birth. 

Bear in mind that most people who are not transgender do not call themselves "cisgender." Be aware, too, that **some people do not want to be referred to as cisgender.** This preference should be respected. The alternative **"non-transgender"** is as common, neutral and unambiguous as many other "non-" terms, including non-Indigenous and non-binary. It's **sometimes** **both clearer and more conversational to say something like "people who are not transgender"** or "people outside the transgender community," rather than to refer to the majority of the population as "cisgender." While non-transgender is an option in certain contexts, **there can be other ways to cast sentences.** For instance: "_Actors like Eddie Redmayne and Jared Leto have won Oscars for playing transgender characters without actually being transgender, themselves_," rather than, "_Non-transgender actors like Eddie Redmayne and Jared Leto have won Oscars for playing transgender characters._"

**Cisgender can be a convenient, succinct way to report certain facts** (e.g., in a story on medical research that distinguishes between, say, cisgender women and transgender populations). **However, it may not always be the clearest choice.** In a story about some parents falsely accusing a young teen of violating a gender-specific sports tournament's rules by competing as a girl, for instance, it would be accurate to report that "the girl is cisgender," but it might not be as meaningful to our overall audience as simply reporting that "the girl is not transgender."


**HISTORICAL PERSPECTIVE:** More than a century ago, **"cis" was occasionally used to flag something "on one side" of a boundary or place** (e.g., cis-Atlantic instead of mid-Atlantic or trans-Atlantic). **But the prefix was never as popular as "trans,"** which was embedded in dozens of words that continue to be used today (e.g., transit, transfer, transfix, transfuse, translate, transmit, transpire, transport). **The label cisgender, itself, was first embraced by the transgender community in the 1990s**, according to the Oxford English Dictionary. Some people believe "cisgender" was coined earlier, although lexicographical facts are unclear.




**Miscellaneous** ('-der' not '-dered,' trans)
**Never equate gender identification or gender change with sexual orientation.** As scholar Susan Stryker puts it in the 2017 edition of her book _Transgender History_: "A transgender man could be gay or straight or bi ... just as he could be Black or poor or disabled."

Transgender is a noun and adjective (e.g., a **transgender person**). For consistency, stick with "-der" rather than "-dered." **Avoid "transgendered."**

The shorthand **"trans" is increasingly common and acceptable in second reference** in certain contexts (e.g., a **trans activist**). But be aware that trans conveys a breezy tone that may not always be suitable, depending on the story. Use your own judgment. (See also [tautology vs. clarity](/home/t/transgender#tautology) below) With the exception of directly transcribed quotes, **generally steer clear of other clipped forms, such as "tranny,"** because they can be confusing and/or offensive.

Don't confuse the word transgender **with cross-dressing**. Also, **use the word [cross-dresser](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/l/2slgbtq/#glossary-cross-dresser "2SLGBTQ+") instead of transvestite**, which is widely considered outmoded.

**Avoid the outdated term hermaphrodite**, which historically referred to people with male and female reproductive organs who could not be clearly classified as either boy or girl at birth. While the word has gradually been replaced by terms like "**intersexual**" and  [**intersex**](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/l/2slgbtq/#glossary-intersex "2SLGBTQ+") person, the latter are still not widely known and often imply an intermediate stage or change after birth. For this reason, **specific descriptions rather than labels are often clearest** (e.g., "He was born with both male and female genitals").


**Tautology vs. clarity**
**Remove awkward clutter**, such as the expression "female to male," when the same information is already conveyed by other detail or context. For instance:

### **Awkward and unnecessary wording**

_Going to the washroom has never been easy for Bob Doe. While the female to male transgender student makes no secret about identifying as a man, finding a safe bathroom has been a problem._

### Preferred, shorter wording

_Going to the washroom has never been easy for Bob Doe. While the transgender student makes no secret about identifying as a man, finding a safe bathroom has been a problem._

**Avoid adding the nouns "man" or "woman" to sentences unnecessarily**, especially when the **transgender person** at the heart of a given story openly opposes these binary classifications. For example, transgender teacher, transgender actor, transgender politicians, etc., all convey detail without specifying male or female. In many cases, standard pronouns fill in blanks. (See also [pronouns](/home/t/transgender#pronouns) above) When the compounds **transgender man** and **transgender woman** are used, generally spell them out in full unless transcribing direct quotes. Be aware that certain shorthand forms, such as **trans man** and **trans woman**, can be jarring and unintentionally change a story's tone to a wider audience. (See [miscellaneous](/home/t/transgender#miscellaneous) above)

See [2SLGBTQ+](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/l/2slgbtq/ "2SLGBTQ+") for related guidelines.

### Transliterations

**Transliterations**

**There's no such thing as a single correct transliteration, since we're trying to represent one word with the closest corresponding letters found in another language's alphabet.** In Arabic, for instance, terms such as _al-Din_ (the Religion) can be written as _ed-Din_, _ed-dine, uddin_, etc.

**Sometimes words are pronounced differently depending on the region, which can lead to different spellings. In addition, certain conventions don't apply in some places.** For instance, Muslim countries such as Pakistan and Afghanistan are not actually Arabic but, for religious reasons, they use some Arabic names. These spellings have taken their own paths over the centuries.


**Entrenched usage and known preferences**
English is full of foreign words that have been altered in a variety of ways, from French, Russian, German and Chinese to Algonquian, Cree and Mi'kmaq. **Traditional spellings and common pronunciations often play a large role, especially for generic terms.
**
The Inuktut word _inukshuk_, for instance, features an "sh" sound in most parts of English Canada. The alternative spelling _inuksuk_ is far less common. Also, the plural inukshuks is much more familiar than the Inuktut-inspired plurals "_inuksugait_" or "_inuksuit_." Despite periodic complaints from people with expertise in any given tongue, the CBC's preference for an entrenched form such as **inukshuk** (plural **inukshuks**) does not represent ignorance, inaccuracy or disrespect. Rather, it reflects familiar usage. The Canadian Oxford Dictionary and Nunavut's Inuktitut Living Dictionary both list inukshuk as the primary English spelling. It's important to remember that we report in English, and that English is a melting pot of other languages. So for generic words, such as inukshuk, we normally stick with what's entrenched because it's the English version that's clearest to our audience.

**Proper nouns are treated in a different way**, however. In the case of names, **if someone has adopted a specific spelling in English, use that preference. If there's no personal preference but a particular spelling has been established through usage, follow that.**
**Audience recognition is crucial**. In historical references, for example, always include the most established English name at least once in brackets for clarity (e.g., "_Pîhtokahanapiwiyin, widely known as [Chief Poundmaker](/home/p#Chief-Poundmaker), was_ ...").

See [Indigenous spellings and phonetics](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/i/indigenous/#spellings "Indigenous") for related guidelines (e.g., **saskatoon berry** comes from the Cree word _**misâskwatômin**_).


**Check CBC Language Guide first, then look to CP**
Reuters, AP, AFP and others can have significantly different approaches to the same names. (At the start of the U.S.-led attack against Iraq in 2003, for instance, Reuters picked _Tareq_ and AFP _Tarek_ for the person AP and CBC called "_Tariq_ Aziz.")

**Always consult the CBC News Language Guide first.** For example, we use the Reuters preference _Kim Jong-il_ instead of _AP's Kim Jong Il_ for North Korea's former leader, partly because the latter looks too much like roman numerals. And we use _KHL_ for _Russia's Kontinental Hockey League_ because the Cyrillic K helps avoid confusion with Canada's _CHL_.
**In general, we follow Canadian Press transliterations when they're available. Exceptions are listed on this website** (e.g., CP now uses the AP spelling _al-Qaida_, but after years of writing _al-Qaeda_ we're sticking with the latter). **If the word you're looking for is not in the Language Guide and no CP references can be found, look to AP for guidance before Reuters.**

**Be cautious when using your own spellings**
**It's difficult and unwise to devise transliterations on your own. If you can't find a transliteration from a reliable source but want to quote someone** (for instance, a radio reporter has filed a script with only a phonetic spelling of an individual's name), **transcribe the clip and then consider using generic attribution** (e.g., "according to a government official," or "said one Iraqi man as he joined the protest in the heart of Baghdad").


**Some transliterations are in transition** (Kyiv versus Kiev)
**Preferred transliterations can change over time. _Kyiv_ and _Chornobyl_, for instance**, are considered closer to Ukrainian than Kiev and Chernobyl, which were based on Russian. CBC News, CP and many others now use Kyiv and Chornobyl. **Other examples are _Kolkata_**  (instead of _Calcutta_ ) because it's a better approximation of the original Bengali name, **and _Mumbai_**  (instead of _Bombay_ ), which more accurately reflects the local Indian language. "Bombay" is considered a corrupted English version of the old Portuguese name for the city, and an unwanted legacy of British colonial rule. (See also [cities around the world](/home/g/geography-cities#citiesaroundtheworld).)

The preferred transliterations above refer to proper geographical names. Other entrenched usage, such as a recipe for **chicken Kiev**, is unchanged. This matches our approach to, say, a dish of **Peking duck** — even though the old name Peking was switched to Beijing back in the 1980s, based on China's preference for the Pinyin spelling system. The same is true of **Bollywood**, the ubiquitous nickname for India's Hindi cinema. Critics of the word point out that it's a portmanteau of "Bombay" and "Hollywood," and that the city's name is now officially Mumbai. But the term [Bollywood](/home/b#Bollywood) remains widely used and acceptable in stories about the film industry, specific dance choreography, etc., because it's so entrenched.

We prize consistency and don't want to revise words willy-nilly when there's no consensus that a proposed transliteration is more accurate. **When a different spelling surfaces and competes with the established one, the news service's [standards editor](/contact-us) rules on whether to abandon the old for the new.**

See also [Arabic names](/home/a/arabic-names), [Asian names](/home/a/asian-names), [German names](/home/g/german-names), [Russian names](/home/r/russian-names) and [Ukrainian names](/home/u/ukrainian-names), as well as the [**Non-English words and foreign languages**](/home/f/foreign-words) overview (El Niño, but Mexico not "México")

### TRC

**Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Canada**

Formal name (not required in stories): Residential Schools Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Canada

**Common and preferred name**, even in first reference: **Truth and Reconciliation Commission**, as long as the story makes it instantly obvious that the commission was Canadian and focused on residential schools (e.g., "_Canada's Truth and Reconciliation Commission examining residential schools_"). Since other countries have had their own commissions with similar names (e.g., South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission set up after the end of apartheid), this context is key to serve our audience.

**Second reference: the commission,** or **the TRC**

It was set up in 2008. Justice Murray Sinclair chaired the commission, which issued its [final report in 2015](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews%2Fpolitics%2Ftruth-and-reconciliation-commission-urges-canada-to-confront-cultural-genocide-of-residential-schools-1.3096229&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw13yvsxoxfrzief-sCoDRZl). Material collected by the TRC is now housed at the **National Centre for Truth and Reconciliation at the University of Manitoba**. These archives include everything from thousands of statements by former students to previously sealed court documents about the way the schools were run.

**Do not imply that the TRC was a parliamentary commission or suggest that the commission was judicial** or even quasi-judicial. **The TRC's goal was not to assign blame or determine guilt.** Rather, it was to create a historical account of a significant part of the country's past still unknown to many of its citizens, to help victims heal, and to encourage reconciliation between Indigenous and non-Indigenous people in Canada.

The Truth and Reconciliation Commission was established as part of a court-approved agreement between survivors of residential schools, the churches that ran them, the federal government and various Indigenous organizations. It was an independent body that heard the stories of anyone affected by the failed and destructive assimilation policy of residential schools. Participation was voluntary. A banner on the commission's original website summed up a great deal: "For the child taken, for the parent left behind."

Grammatically, the compound "**truth and reconciliation**" is conventionally considered a [composite theme](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/v/verb-agreement/#themes "Verb agreement"), which means it's **commonly treated as a singular subject** (e.g., _truth and reconciliation begins_ ... _means_ ... _is_ ...).

See also: [residential schools](/home/r/residential-schools) for guidelines on "**survivor**" versus "former student"
See also: [Indigenous](/home/i/Indigenous)

For more background, see the CBC News feature [Stolen Children](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Faboriginal%2Ftruth-reconciliation%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2RYC94vVZSyMyMTQfGZbbD), as well as the [TRC's own archived website](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.trc.ca%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1t09Rje0PTkQ0FBWJvxWHU), which includes [**PDFs of the commission's reports**](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fnctr.ca%2Frecords%2Freports%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1GYgriCZfGa4gq1tYUwNPz).

### Treaty

**Treaty versus treaty**

**Generally capitalize only when referring to the formal names of agreements or other proper nouns:**

a treaty
Canada's tax treaty with China
Treaty 4
Treaty 6 (not Six)
North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO)
the Office of the Treaty Commissioner in Saskatchewan


**But also capitalize when an informal name is treated like a proper noun based on convention:
**
the Nisga'a Treaty
the Nisga'a Land Treaty

A "T" is used in the above examples because these compounds are more common than the actual name, "the [Nisga'a Final Agreement](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Flaws-lois.justice.gc.ca%2Feng%2Facts%2Fn-23.3%2FFullText.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0QDB08lKfhgSKhYxpRMOQ7)."

**This includes abridged versions of formal names:**

the 1752 Peace and Friendship Treaty
the 1752 Treaty
a Treaty of Peace and Friendship signed on March 10, 1760 in Halifax.

**Generic plural constructions are normally lowercase:**

the treaties
peace treaties


**But capitalize specific plural forms treated as distinct proper nouns based on convention:**

the Peace and Friendship Treaties
Treaties 4 and 6

See also [Act versus act](/home/a/act)
See also [Indigenous](/home/i/Indigenous)

### trial versus hearing

**Trial versus hearing** (after guilty plea)

The word trial implies resolution of a dispute (criminal or civil) in a court of law. In Canada, criminal trials are associated with arguments by the prosecution and the defence.

**In the case of a guilty plea at the start of criminal proceedings**, however, the term **"trial" is no longer suitable. At that point, "hearing" is a better choice**, as the Crown presents an agreed statement of facts to the judge, who will then decide whether to accept the guilty plea. **Until the plea is accepted, the accused is not formally convicted.**

Depending on the amount of information presented, this stage can take several days. If the judge accepts the plea, a conviction is officially entered in the books and the sentencing phase (known as the "**sentencing hearing**") begins.

See also [verdict](/home/v#verdict)

### tuque versus toque

**Tuque versus toque**

**tuque**
**Tuque is the preferred Canadian spelling of the knitted cap worn in winter.**
_
“They ran so hard across the snowy field their faces were as red as their tuques.”_

The term tuque is French Canadian. Some etymologists think it probably comes from an Old Spanish word (_toca_) for a type of headdress — specifically, a soft, close-fitting cap worn about 500 years ago.


**toque**
**Toque is the spelling we use for some other types of headwear. But these are rarely mentioned in news stories.**

Toques include conical or plumed hats from previous centuries, the tall white crowns worn by chefs, and modern snug hats that fall into the rather vague category of high-fashion.

See also [spelling](/home/s/spelling) (an overview)

### Taiwan

**Turkey vs. 'Türkiye'**

**Use the traditional English spelling and pronunciation** of the republic known for the past century as **"Turkey."**

In the spring of 2022, the government in Ankara asked other countries to adopt **the Turkish spelling ("Türkiye")** and pronunciation (**"TUR-kee-yeh"**) to disassociate the proper noun from the lowercase homograph "turkey." Organizations such as the UN, NATO and the IOC embraced the change within months. As of December 2022, however, most major English news organizations had maintained the customary spelling and pronunciation.

Although we may eventually adopt Türkiye, depending on how familiar the name becomes, **we continue to use Turkey for now because it's clearest to our audience, and because we report in English using established spelling and phonetic conventions.** It's why we refer to **Spain, Belgium** and **Poland** instead of to **España, Belgique** and **Polska**, why we describe **Munich** being in **Germany** rather than **München** being in **Deutschland**, why we prefer **Ivory Coast** and the **Magdalen Islands** over **Côte d'Ivoire** and **Îles-de-la-Madeleine**, and why we use common, anglicized pronunciations of places like **Paris** and **Mexico**.

Country names do change, of course. **Iran, Thailand** and **Zimbabwe** used to be known as **Persia, Siam** and **Rhodesia**, respectively. In this case, however, Turkey has not actually switched to a different proper noun. In fact, it's been known as **Türkiye Cumhuriyeti** (the **Republic of Turkey**) since being founded after the First World War. Instead, the country's government is asking people to stop using a common English version of its name.

The case is arguably different from an old transliteration being updated — such as when **Beijing** replaced **Peking**, **Mumbai** replaced **Bombay**, and **Kyiv** replaced **Kiev** — because of the nature of the objection to "Turkey" looking and sounding like the completely different word "turkey." It's also not comparable to the **Czech Republic** encouraging the world to start using the name **"Czechia"** back in 2016, a name that still hasn't gained much popularity.

It's worth noting that the Turkish spelling, Türkiye, and accompanying phonetic are based on a different alphabet with 29 letters, rather than merely on a slight variation of the roman alphabet using a diacritical marking. See **[non-English words, foreign languages, accents](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/f/foreign-words/#roman_alphabet "Foreign words")** for related guidelines (e.g., we refer to Latvia's military based as **Camp Adazi** instead of as **Camp Ādaži** for the same reason that Latvian media refer to **New Brunswick** and **Canada** as **Ņūbransvika** and **Kanāda**).

See also [country names](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/g/geography-cities/ "Geography cities") 


### TV\_Text

**TV TEXT: Supers, banners, graphics, etc.**

FAQs

> [1\. Identification](/home/t/tv_text#identities)
>
> [2\. Capitalization](/home/t/tv_text#capitalization)
>
> [3\. Spelling](/home/t/tv_text#spelling)
>
> [4\. Geographical locators](/home/t/tv_text#locators)
>
> [5\. Accents](/home/t/tv_text#accents)
>
> [6\. Military ranks](/home/t/tv_text#militaryranks)

  **COMPREHENSIVE MANUAL AVAILABLE:** This Language Guide page provides only brief answers to a few commonly asked questions about TV supers. For detailed direction on everything below and a lot more, see the latest **[CBC NEWS TV SUPERS STYLE GUIDE](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1-2sGp-PMA0T1OX8NM0OlodYwxjTl-elzh1cYJKgceeo/edit)** in Google Docs.

**Overview**
**TV text is unique in several ways.** Whether superimposed over other material (as a "super" or banner), or occupying the entire screen as a full-frame graphic, the words are:

-   **Temporary** (usually on the screen for just a few seconds); and
-   **Supplementary** (generally supporting images and audio, rather than serving as the primary source of information).

This means TV text should be:

> -   **Brief**  (There's only so much space on the screen.)
> -   **Clear**  (People don't have much time to scan the information.)
> -   **Synced**  (Words must match whatever else is being seen and/or heard, from locators to bullet-point graphics.)

But in other ways, TV text is not unique. **Like the rest of our journalism, it must also be:**

> -   **Accurate**  (Correct spellings, facts, figures, etc.)
> -   **Fair**  (Condensed without being misleading.)
> -   **Relevant**  (Help tell the story.)
> -   **Editorially consistent**  (Adhere to all CBC News guidelines, such as [anti-abortion](/home/a/abortion) instead of "pro-life" and [Myanmar](/home/m/Myanmar) instead of "Burma.")
> -   **Stylistically consistent**  (Follow in-house style, such as [SCC](/home/s#SupremeCourt) instead of "SCOC" and [half-mast](/home/h/half-mast) instead of "half-staff.")

The rest of this entry answers frequently asked questions about specific style points — from capitalizing descriptions in TV supers to spelling geographical locators.


**FAQs**
**1\. Is everyone identified?**
**The list of people we don't traditionally super on TV is very short.** It can vary slightly but is **usually limited to: Canada's monarch, current Governor General and current prime minister; the current U.S. president; the pope. Otherwise, the standard practice is to add identifying text.** This includes supering previously high-profile politicians, such as former prime ministers, especially since they may be less widely recognized now than some movie stars, musicians, athletes or other celebrities.

**When identifying people on camera, names alone are sometimes sufficient to keep supers from becoming too cluttered.** For instance, if we're interviewing people who witnessed a tragedy, it's irrelevant whether they're a student, a pastry chef or an appellate court judge.  In those cases, a description such as **eyewitness** rather than an occupation, title, etc., can be helpful if the clip's content or context doesn't already make this clear. **Keep the best interests of our audience in mind.** For example, specific detail (**off-duty paramedic**) might well be better than a name alone or the vague label "eyewitness" in a story about a tragedy abroad that includes clips of a vacationing Canadian paramedic who pitched in to help treat the injured. Use common sense.


**2\. How do I know what to capitalize?**
Since TV text is not scanned in the same way as, say, words on a web page or in a newspaper, **certain conventions have been established**. In particular, **capital letters tend to be used at the start of more words on TV** than in our online journalism, especially in titles, occupations, etc., put next to (or under) names. **Sometimes, every principal word has a capital letter** because it's treated as a formal title, and **sometimes only the first letter is capitalized** to flag the start of what amounts to a description:


> **Former Defence Minister** rather than former defence minister
>
> **Head of Emergency Medicine** rather than head of emergency medicine
>
> **Criminal lawyer** rather than criminal lawyer
>
> **Rally organizer** rather than rally organizer


**This is the main typographical difference between TV text style and general CBCNews.ca style**, and it should be kept in mind when consulting any Language Guide entries about **[capitalization](/home/c/capitalization)**. For instance, while the [abbreviations overview](/home/a/abbreviations) points out that AIDS is spelled out as "acquired immune deficiency syndrome" on CBCNews.ca, a TV graphic might be considered easier to read as: Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome. **Latitude is allowed** based on entrenched TV text convention.



**3\. How do we handle words spelled in more than one way?**
**For consistency, almost always use one version.** For example:


> **colour** (not "color")
>
> **judgment** (not "judgement")
>
> **raccoon** (not "racoon")
>
> **travelling** (not "traveling")


Rare exceptions involve observed distinctions (e.g., [financial **adviser** versus financial **advisor**](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/a/adviser/ "Adviser")). This includes differences between certain parts of speech (e.g., the [noun **licence** versus the verb **license**](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/l/#licence-license "L")).

See the **[spelling overview](/home/s/spelling)** for details on how CBC News preferences are determined.

**Two of the biggest sources of confusion are:**

**(i) TRANSLITERATIONS** (e.g., **al-Qaeda** not "al-Qaida" and the **Qur'an** not the "Koran").
Traditional spellings and common pronunciations often play a large role. See the **[transliterations overview](/home/t/transliterations)** for details and more examples.

**(ii) U.S. GOVERNMENT DEPARTMENTS, TITLES** (e.g., U.S. Labour Secretary not "Labor" Secretary)

**While U.S. spellings** (e.g., "Center" instead of "Centre" and "Color" instead of "Colour" and "Harbor" instead of "Harbour") **are retained in most proper nouns** (e.g., book and film titles, as well as building and geographical names), **foreign government departments, foreign political titles, etc., are not treated in the same way** because they're not unique (i.e., many countries have the equivalent of defence ministers and labour secretaries):


> Lincoln Centre
>
> Pearl Harbor
>
> The Color Purple
>
> **U.S. Defence Department** (not the U.S. "Defense" Department)
>
> **U.S. Defence Secretary** (not the U.S. "Defense" Secretary)
>
> **U.S. Labour Department** (not the U.S. "Labor" Department)
>
> **U.S. Labour Secretary** (not the U.S. "Labor" Secretary)


See **[defence, labour and centre](/home/d/defence-labour-and-centre)** for details

**For perspective, when U.S. newspapers, broadcasters and other media report on Canada they follow an identical approach by sticking with "American spellings" throughout their stories**  — referring to Ottawa's "Defense Department" and "defense spending" rather than to its Defence Department and defence spending, as well as to a given province's "Labor Ministry" rather than to its Labour Ministry. In the U.S., reporters also write about "Labor Day" weekend celebrations (regardless of country) while on CBC it's always **Labour Day**, even in our coverage of the holiday south of the border.


**4\. Are there spelling guidelines for geographical locators?**
**Yes. For domestic place names** (cities, towns, lakes, rivers, etc.), consult the [**Canadian Geographical Names Database**](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww4.rncan.gc.ca%2Fsearch-place-names%2Fsearch%3Flang%3Den&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2lOY1kZcpa3sVZHHX8XWOf) published by Natural Resources Canada. The database is looked after by the Geographical Names Board of Canada, which includes representatives from all provinces and territories, and is routinely updated as required. In rare cases, when CBC News prefers a different spelling or name than the one listed, exceptions are noted in our Language Guide's main A to Z indexes, as explained in our [**provinces and cities overview**](/home/p/provinces-and-cities). **For communities outside of Canada, the National Geographic Atlas of the World is generally a good source.** But **check the Language Guide for any spelling exceptions first** (e.g., we write **Bangkok, Dunkirk** and **Taipei)**. These exceptions are often English versions of local spellings that have become entrenched over time (e.g., **Rome** instead of "Roma" and **Damascus** not "Dimashq"). See [**cities around the world**](/home/g/geography-cities#citiesaroundtheworld) for more details.

**Two of the biggest sources of confusion are:
**
**(i) TRANSLATIONS and SHIFTING TRANSLITERATIONS**
**Always prefer English conventions when entrenched.** In the case of translations, for example, this means using **Ivory Coast** instead of "Côte d'Ivoire" and **Cape Verde** instead of "Cabo Verde" based on widespread usage and audience familiarity. In the case of shifting [transliterations](/home/t/transliterations), widespread adoption of revised local English spellings means:


> **Chennai** instead of "Madras" (India)
>
> **Chornobyl** instead of "Chernobyl" (Ukraine)
>
> **Kolkata** instead of "Calcutta"
>
> **Kyiv** instead of "Kiev"
>
> **Mumbai** instead of "Bombay"


**(ii) SHORT, COMMON NAMES versus LONG, FORMAL NAMES**
**It's OK to clip the wordy, formal names of many countries.** For example: **Afghanistan** (not the "Islamic Republic of Afghanistan"), **China** (not the "People's Republic of China") and **Sri Lanka** (not the "Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka"). **In some cases, entrenched colloquial names serve our audience best** because they include details to avoid ambiguity (e.g., the compass points in **North Korea** and **South Korea**, which are more meaningful than the "Democratic People's Republic of Korea" and the "Republic of Korea"). See [**country names**](/home/g/geography-cities#citiesaroundtheworld) for details.


**Limit the focus of routine locators to providing a geographical marker** for our audience. This means generally steering clear of detail about political sovereignty, shifting military control, etc., such as "occupied." So go with "**Ramallah, West Bank**" rather than "Ramallah, occupied West Bank," even though the modifier "occupied" is frequently and accurately mentioned in a broadcast script, itself. The same approach is taken with occupied places such as [**Crimea**](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/c/crimea/ "Crimea"), since the tight space constraints of locators make it virtually impossible to satisfactorily capture the complexities of fluid war zones and other disputed land around the globe.


**5\. What about accents?**
**Include diacritical markings in foreign names or words as long as:**

-   **They're accurate** (confirmed or already known); and
-   **No accent-free "English" versions are entrenched** (.e.g, Mexico instead of México).

This style was adopted by CBC News in March of 2019. Previously, only French accents were routinely included in our journalism.

**6\. Is it Lt.-Col or Lt-Col or LCol? Military ranks reviewed.**
**There are many ways to abbreviate military ranks.** Sometimes people fuse letters. Sometimes they add hyphens. Sometimes they include periods. So it's a myth that certain punctuation is right or wrong solely because a given government website or military manual features a specific style. It all boils down to in-house preference.

**CBC follows standard newsroom publishing conventions rather than the various idiosyncratic styles used by military services around the world**, including the Canadian Armed Forces. **The biggest differences are that we include periods, add ordinal numbers**, such as "1st" (first) and "2nd" (second), **and avoid obscure or unintuitive shorthand** by spelling out the words instead (e.g., Chief Warrant Officer instead of CWO):


> **Maj.-Gen.** (not "MGen") for Major-General
>
> **Lt.-Col.** (not "LCol") for Lieutenant-Colonel
>
> **2nd Lt.** (not "2Lt") for Second Lieutenant
>
> **Lt.-Cmdr.** (not "LCdr") for Lieutenant-Commander
>
> **Acting Sub-Lt.** (not "A/SLt") for Acting Sub-Lieutenant
>
> **Officer Cadet** (not "OCdt") for Officer Cadet


**For details and a complete list of Armed Forces abbreviations, see [military ranks](/home/m/military-ranks).**

REMINDER: In our online journalism, unabbreviated ranks such as Major-General and Second Lieutenant would be lowercase (major-general, second lieutenant). But in TV text, initial capital letters are conventionally used far more often, as outlined in [FAQ 2](/home/t/tv_text#capitalization) above.

NOTE: **When someone no longer actively holds a rank, always supply this context by prominently adding a term such as "former" or "retired"** (e.g., Retired Gen. John de Chastelain). Avoid the U.S. convention of retaining certain people's titles without qualification even after they've left office. See the **[titles overview](/home/t/titles)** for details and other examples.

  **COMPREHENSIVE MANUAL AVAILABLE:** This Language Guide page provides only brief answers to a few commonly asked questions about TV supers. For detailed direction on everything below and a lot more, see the latest **[CBC NEWS TV SUPERS STYLE GUIDE](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1-2sGp-PMA0T1OX8NM0OlodYwxjTl-elzh1cYJKgceeo/edit)** in Google Docs.

**Overview**
**TV text is unique in several ways.** Whether superimposed over other material (as a "super" or banner), or occupying the entire screen as a full-frame graphic, the words are:

-   **Temporary** (usually on the screen for just a few seconds); and
-   **Supplementary** (generally supporting images and audio, rather than serving as the primary source of information).

This means TV text should be:

> -   **Brief**  (There's only so much space on the screen.)
> -   **Clear**  (People don't have much time to scan the information.)
> -   **Synced**  (Words must match whatever else is being seen and/or heard, from locators to bullet-point graphics.)

But in other ways, TV text is not unique. **Like the rest of our journalism, it must also be:**

> -   **Accurate**  (Correct spellings, facts, figures, etc.)
> -   **Fair**  (Condensed without being misleading.)
> -   **Relevant**  (Help tell the story.)
> -   **Editorially consistent**  (Adhere to all CBC News guidelines, such as [anti-abortion](/home/a/abortion) instead of "pro-life" and [Myanmar](/home/m/Myanmar) instead of "Burma.")
> -   **Stylistically consistent**  (Follow in-house style, such as [SCC](/home/s#SupremeCourt) instead of "SCOC" and [half-mast](/home/h/half-mast) instead of "half-staff.")

The rest of this entry answers frequently asked questions about specific style points — from capitalizing descriptions in TV supers to spelling geographical locators.


**FAQs**
**1\. Is everyone identified?**
**The list of people we don't traditionally super on TV is very short.** It can vary slightly but is **usually limited to: Canada's monarch, current Governor General and current prime minister; the current U.S. president; the pope. Otherwise, the standard practice is to add identifying text.** This includes supering previously high-profile politicians, such as former prime ministers, especially since they may be less widely recognized now than some movie stars, musicians, athletes or other celebrities.

**When identifying people on camera, names alone are sometimes sufficient to keep supers from becoming too cluttered.** For instance, if we're interviewing people who witnessed a tragedy, it's irrelevant whether they're a student, a pastry chef or an appellate court judge.  In those cases, a description such as **eyewitness** rather than an occupation, title, etc., can be helpful if the clip's content or context doesn't already make this clear. **Keep the best interests of our audience in mind.** For example, specific detail (**off-duty paramedic**) might well be better than a name alone or the vague label "eyewitness" in a story about a tragedy abroad that includes clips of a vacationing Canadian paramedic who pitched in to help treat the injured. Use common sense.


**2\. How do I know what to capitalize?**
Since TV text is not scanned in the same way as, say, words on a web page or in a newspaper, **certain conventions have been established**. In particular, **capital letters tend to be used at the start of more words on TV** than in our online journalism, especially in titles, occupations, etc., put next to (or under) names. **Sometimes, every principal word has a capital letter** because it's treated as a formal title, and **sometimes only the first letter is capitalized** to flag the start of what amounts to a description:


> **Former Defence Minister** rather than former defence minister
>
> **Head of Emergency Medicine** rather than head of emergency medicine
>
> **Criminal lawyer** rather than criminal lawyer
>
> **Rally organizer** rather than rally organizer


**This is the main typographical difference between TV text style and general CBCNews.ca style**, and it should be kept in mind when consulting any Language Guide entries about **[capitalization](/home/c/capitalization)**. For instance, while the [abbreviations overview](/home/a/abbreviations) points out that AIDS is spelled out as "acquired immune deficiency syndrome" on CBCNews.ca, a TV graphic might be considered easier to read as: Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome. **Latitude is allowed** based on entrenched TV text convention.



**3\. How do we handle words spelled in more than one way?**
**For consistency, almost always use one version.** For example:


> **colour** (not "color")
>
> **judgment** (not "judgement")
>
> **raccoon** (not "racoon")
>
> **travelling** (not "traveling")


Rare exceptions involve observed distinctions (e.g., [financial **adviser** versus financial **advisor**](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/a/adviser/ "Adviser")). This includes differences between certain parts of speech (e.g., the [noun **licence** versus the verb **license**](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/l/#licence-license "L")).

See the **[spelling overview](/home/s/spelling)** for details on how CBC News preferences are determined.

**Two of the biggest sources of confusion are:**

**(i) TRANSLITERATIONS** (e.g., **al-Qaeda** not "al-Qaida" and the **Qur'an** not the "Koran").
Traditional spellings and common pronunciations often play a large role. See the **[transliterations overview](/home/t/transliterations)** for details and more examples.

**(ii) U.S. GOVERNMENT DEPARTMENTS, TITLES** (e.g., U.S. Labour Secretary not "Labor" Secretary)

**While U.S. spellings** (e.g., "Center" instead of "Centre" and "Color" instead of "Colour" and "Harbor" instead of "Harbour") **are retained in most proper nouns** (e.g., book and film titles, as well as building and geographical names), **foreign government departments, foreign political titles, etc., are not treated in the same way** because they're not unique (i.e., many countries have the equivalent of defence ministers and labour secretaries):


> Lincoln Centre
>
> Pearl Harbor
>
> The Color Purple
>
> **U.S. Defence Department** (not the U.S. "Defense" Department)
>
> **U.S. Defence Secretary** (not the U.S. "Defense" Secretary)
>
> **U.S. Labour Department** (not the U.S. "Labor" Department)
>
> **U.S. Labour Secretary** (not the U.S. "Labor" Secretary)


See **[defence, labour and centre](/home/d/defence-labour-and-centre)** for details

**For perspective, when U.S. newspapers, broadcasters and other media report on Canada they follow an identical approach by sticking with "American spellings" throughout their stories**  — referring to Ottawa's "Defense Department" and "defense spending" rather than to its Defence Department and defence spending, as well as to a given province's "Labor Ministry" rather than to its Labour Ministry. In the U.S., reporters also write about "Labor Day" weekend celebrations (regardless of country) while on CBC it's always **Labour Day**, even in our coverage of the holiday south of the border.


**4\. Are there spelling guidelines for geographical locators?**
**Yes. For domestic place names** (cities, towns, lakes, rivers, etc.), consult the [**Canadian Geographical Names Database**](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww4.rncan.gc.ca%2Fsearch-place-names%2Fsearch%3Flang%3Den&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2lOY1kZcpa3sVZHHX8XWOf) published by Natural Resources Canada. The database is looked after by the Geographical Names Board of Canada, which includes representatives from all provinces and territories, and is routinely updated as required. In rare cases, when CBC News prefers a different spelling or name than the one listed, exceptions are noted in our Language Guide's main A to Z indexes, as explained in our [**provinces and cities overview**](/home/p/provinces-and-cities). **For communities outside of Canada, the National Geographic Atlas of the World is generally a good source.** But **check the Language Guide for any spelling exceptions first** (e.g., we write **Bangkok, Dunkirk** and **Taipei)**. These exceptions are often English versions of local spellings that have become entrenched over time (e.g., **Rome** instead of "Roma" and **Damascus** not "Dimashq"). See [**cities around the world**](/home/g/geography-cities#citiesaroundtheworld) for more details.

**U** 

**[u-um](/home/u#u)**

**[un-uz](/home/u#un)**

**u-um**
**UAP** (**unidentified anomalous phenomenon)**; **UAPs** (**unidentified anomalous phenomena**) The term UAP refers to any aerial sighting that cannot be immediately identified or explained. UAP has largely replaced the 1950s abbreviation **UFO** (**unidentified flying object)** in scientific circles, including at government agencies such as NASA. When UAP was coined in the 1960s it originally referred to "unidentified aerial phenomenon." The term remained relatively obscure until the early 2020s, when the adjective "anomalous" replaced "aerial." **Until UAP becomes commonplace, the recommended practice is to define the abbreviation in a brief, understandable way in given coverage** (e.g., "**UAPs, previously known as UFOs**"). NOTE: It's a convention to add an "s" to form the plural of UAP, even though the P stands for "phenomena," which is an irregular plural form from Greek and Latin. Experts point out that the label UFO remains commonly linked to science fiction tales of flying saucers and aliens visiting earth. By contrast, the name UAP is thought to better convey the sense of a broader range of mysterious sightings, including optical illusions caused by reflected light, which are not "flying objects" at all. Be aware that we're not obligated to use less-familiar terminology in our journalism solely because the language is in fashion within certain groups. This means that **the term UFOs may remain fine in certain headlines and TV banners.** At the same time, it's important to be accurate, especially when reporting proper nouns (e.g., in September 2023, NASA appointed a **director of UAP research**). Use your judgment based on a given story's facts.

**Uber** (company), **UberX** (app-based ride-booking service) The official name of the company is Uber (with a capital "U"), according to legal documents, even though it sometimes appears all lowercase or all uppercase in various forms of marketing. UberX was launched in 2012, and has expanded to various cities around the world. Proponents say ride-hailing services such as UberX can be cheaper and more convenient than using traditional cabs, while critics say they can be potentially risky since drivers do not need to have standard taxi licences. **UberX can often be shortened to Uber**, especially in second reference, as long as the story makes the context clear. But be aware that **the lowercase prefix "uber" is a generic term that means "extreme" or "ultimate."** When a company such as Uber also operates a taxi brokerage with officially licensed drivers, **use full names to distinguish between different services** (e.g., **UberTaxi** versus UberX). Avoid referring to UberX and similar services as taxis or as cabs. **Prefer the terms [ride-hailing](/home/r#ridehailing) or ride-booking**. Although the industry, itself, often markets these services as ridesharing, the word "sharing" can wrongly convey the sense of altruistic carpooling. By contrast, "ride-hailing" and "ride-booking" better describe the commercial transaction between driver and passenger.

**U-boat** (Use this English form for submarines, **not** the original German _U-boot_, which is short for _Unterseeboot_, an undersea boat.) See also [boat versus ship](/home/b/boat-versus-ship)

**UFO** (for unidentified flying object), **UFOs** (plural) See [**UAP**](#UAPs-UFOs) above.

Uighurs (use **[Uyghurs](/home/u#Uyghurs)**) Spelling change adopted in March 2021

**U.K.** (use periods for geographical abbreviations) See also [United Kingdom](/home/u/united-kingdom)

**Ukraine, Ukrainian** (_never_ refer to it as "the" Ukraine) Ukraine's old, official name was the "Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic," which, in the West, was frequently shortened to "the Republic of Ukraine" or simply "the Ukraine." After the [Soviet Union](/home/s/soviet-union) began to collapse in the late 1980s, Ukraine held a sovereignty referendum. A majority of citizens voted for independence in 1991, and the country became officially known as Ukraine. Unlike many sovereign states, Ukraine has no formal (longer) alternative name, which makes use of "the" always wrong. See [country names](/home/g/geography-cities) for details and other examples, as well as [Ukrainian names](/home/u/ukrainian-names) for guidelines on preferred transliterations Kyiv and Chornobyl. See also [Donbas](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/d/donbas_donetsk_luhansk/ "Donbas_Donetsk_Luhansk") (Donetsk, Luhansk) as well as [Crimea](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/c/crimea/ "Crimea") for handling language over disputed territory, and our [military overview](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/m/military-terms-overview/#war "Military terms overview") for wording of stories about Russia's February 2022 invasion of Ukraine.

**Ukrainian Christmas** (_generally avoid outside of attribution_; prefer generic phrasing such as **Orthodox Christmas** instead) The once-entrenched compound **"Ukrainian Christmas" is now considered outmoded and inaccurate** for a couple of reasons. First, members of certain Eastern Orthodox churches in various countries celebrate Christmas in January (according to the Julian calendar), rater than in December (according to the Gregorian calendar), including congregants in Russia, Greece, Romania, Serbia and parts of the Middle East. So calling Jan. 7th "Ukrainian" Christmas is viewed as narrowly misleading. Second, a few years after Russia's 2022 invasion of Ukraine, political leaders in Kyiv encouraged Ukrainians to switch to December 25th Christmas celebrations to distance the country from the Russian Orthodox Church calendar. See also [holidays and other special times](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/h/holidays/ "Holidays") for general capitalization guidelines.

**ultimatum, ultimatums** (See also [Latin plurals](/home/l/latin-plurals))

**ultra-Orthodox**, as in _ultra-Orthodox Jew_, Jerusalem's _ultra-Orthodox mayor_, etc.

****ultrasound****

**ultra vires** ("beyond the powers," _but avoid using this legal jargon_)

**umiak** (A large Inuit open boat used for cargo and passengers, traditionally paddled by women. This word requires an explanation, while the one-person "kayak" used by hunters does not.)

**umlauts** (ö, ü, etc.) See [German names](/home/g/german-names)

**[u-um](/home/u#u) - [un-uz](/home/u#un) - [bottom](/home/u#bottom)**

**un-uz**
**UN** (no periods) See [United Nations](/home/u/united-nations)

**unabomber** (lowercase)

**unchristian**, but ****non-Christian*

*unco-operative*

*unco-ordinated****

**underprivileged** (one word)

**underrepresented** (one word)

**undersecretary** (one word)


**under as an adverb**
Sometimes "under" is fused as an adjective (**underwater**), as in "an _underwater creature_," but detached as an adverb (**under water**), as in "_They were swimming under water when they discovered the treasure._" Often, however, the adverb is one word too (e.g., **underground, underhand** and **underneath**), as in "_The mouse was underneath the sofa._" Note: Treat **underway** as a one-word adverb, as in "_Contract talks got underway at dawn Monday._" Although the Oxford Guide to Canadian English Usage says a two-word adverbial form is equally common, we follow CP's preference and use the fused version in this case.

**UNESCO** (United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization) See [acronyms](/home/a/acronyms) and [United Nations](/home/u/united-nations) for general guidelines

****unforeseen****

**unforgivable** (_not_ -eable)

**UNICEF** (fine in first reference) See also [abbreviations](/home/a/abbreviations) and [United Nations](/home/u/united-nations)

**Unifor** (OK in all references. Does _not_ need to be spelled out as "Union for Canada.") Formed in 2013 when the Canadian Auto Workers (CAW) and the Communications, Energy and Paperworkers Union of Canada (CEP) merged. NOTE: In historical references to CAW and CEP, there are no [possessive apostrophes](/handy-links/punctuation/possessive-apostrophe#workers) when those nouns are spelled out. As well, the generic term autoworker is fused, even though the old union's name included a space between this compound (Canadian Auto Workers).

**uninterested** (not interested); **disinterested** (impartial)

**union** (lowercase in all generic references) For example, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters is commonly known as the **Teamsters union**. But capitalize when reporting full proper nouns (e.g., the **Canadian Union of Public Employees**). Be aware that the term "union" is conventionally used to mean any group involved in collective bargaining for specific workers, including various professional associations, such as a teachers' federation.

**union boss, union bosses** (_**caution**_) Generally avoid, especially in coverage of contract negotiations. These terms lack neutrality (i.e., we normally don't say "corporate bosses") and precision. They're also perceived as pejorative by some, conveying a link to "mob bosses" or conjuring up negative images of those in the labour movement as bullies or thugs. Alternatives include "**union leader**(s)" and "**union head**(s)." The same caveat about "union boss" applies to all "labour-related" language (e.g., prefer **labour council head, labour leader**). Whenever possible, be more precise by specifying a title (e.g., **union president**, **union director**), including whether the person's position is at the national, regional or local level. See also [strike versus lockout](/home/s#strike), and why we use contract dispute instead of [labour dispute](/home/l#labourdispute).

****Union Jack****

**Union Nationale** (A Quebec political party founded in 1935 by Maurice Duplessis. The coalition of Conservatives and disgruntled Liberals held office for many years.)

**union, state of the** (lowercase) See [state of the union](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/s/state-of-the-union/ "State of the union") (message versus address)

**former Union of Soviet Socialist Republics** (U.S.S.R.) See [Soviet Union](/home/s/soviet-union)

**[United Arab Emirates](/home/u/united-arab-emirates) (the Emirates, the U.A.E.)**

**United Conservative Party** (**UCP** is OK in headlines and second reference) Political party formed in Alberta in 2017 after a **merger between the [Wildrose Party](/home/w#WildroseParty)** (technically called the Wildrose Political Association) **and the Progressive Conservative Party of Alberta** (commonly known as the Alberta PCs but technically called the Progressive Conservative Association of Alberta). Unless regional context is already clear, it's helpful to modify the proper noun with the province's name in first reference (e.g., **Alberta's United Conservative Party, Alberta UCP** members). See [Party versus party](/home/p/party) for related capitalization guidelines.

**[United Kingdom](/home/u/united-kingdom) (U.K.)**

**[United Nations](/home/u/united-nations) (UN)**

**[United States](/home/u/united-states) (U.S.)**

**Université Laval / Laval University** (Both of these versions are acceptable. Not University of Laval or Université de Laval)

[**universities and colleges**](/home/u/universities-and-colleges) (guidelines on capitalization)

[**university degrees**](/home/d/degrees) (BA, MA, PhD, etc.)

****Unknown Soldier**** See also [the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier](/updates/2025/2025-06-03-tomb-of-the-unknown-soldier/).

**unmistakable** (_not_ -eable)

**unshakable** (_not_ -eable)

**unvaccinated** (not vaccinated) When more than one dose is required, add modifiers like **partially vaccinated** or **fully vaccinated** to avoid ambiguity (see [immunization, inoculation, vaccination](/home/i/immunization-vaccination) for details)

**unwieldy**

**Upper Canada** (region) Name for Ontario from 1791 to 1841

****uppercase****

**upper chamber, upper house** (informal terms for the Senate; generally avoid in daily news stories, except in transcribed quotes, unless the meaning is immediately clear) See also [House](/home/h/house) (preferred over "lower house" for references to the Commons) as well as [legislative bodies](/home/l/legislative-bodies) for related guidelines

**Upstate New York** (See also [capitalization](/home/c/capitalization))

**upward** (_not_ upwards) See [**\-ward** versus -wards](/home/w/ward-versus-wards)

[**URL**](/home/u/urls) (prefer "web address" in most contexts)

**U.S.** (_use periods when referring to country or its government_) See [**United States**](/home/u/united-states) for general guidelines (e.g., include U.S. in the title of the country's president in first reference).

**US** (_do not include periods when identifying currency: $550 US_) See [money](/home/m/money)

**usable** (_not_ useable)

**usage** (_not_ useage)

**USA Today** (proper noun; no periods)

**U Sports** (national governing body of sports at degree-granting universities in Canada) Previously known as **CIS** (Canadian Interuniversity Sport) and **CIAU** (Canadian Interuniversity Athletics Union). The name U Sports was adopted in 2016. Avoid all-uppercase spellings of proper nouns like this, which can either appear too distracting or wrongly imply abbreviations, along the lines of NATO. Using "initial caps" only is standard publishing style (e.g., Imax, Lego, Scrabble and Visa rather than IMAX, LEGO, SCRABBLE and VISA). See [quirky capitalization](/home/q/quirky-capitalization) for details and other examples

**Utah** (no abbreviation) See [United States](/home/u/united-states)

_**Utopia**_ (Use an uppercase "U" only when referring to the spot in Sir Thomas More's book, which is virtually never in news stories. The word is Latin for "no place." It comes from the Greek term "not \[a\] place.") The book title, itself, requires [italics](/handy-links/punctuation/italics). See "utopia" below.

a **utopia**, a **utopian enterprise**, a **utopian** (someone who believes in a place that's impossibly perfect), etc.

****U-turn****

**UWO** (generally avoid to reduce confusion, given the school's 2012 name change) See [Western University](/home/w#WesternUniversity) for details

**Uyghurs** (for consistency use this spelling, which has gradually replaced the centuries-old "Uig-" version listed in the Canadian Oxford) This "y" form is preferred by English-speaking Uyghurs, and matches the names of organizations like the **World Uyghur Congress**. It's also the transliteration commonly used by Ottawa and a number of other governments around the world. This includes English documents published by Chinese authorities. Uyghurs are members of an ethnic group from Central Asia. Most now live in [Xinjiang](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/x/#Xinjiang "X"), a vast area of western China that borders Afghanistan, Pakistan, Russia and several other countries. They're Turkic-speaking Muslims who accuse China of religious and political persecution. Beijing, in turn, says Uyghur dissidents are leading an Islamic separatist movement. To give readers context, Uyghurs are often briefly defined in stories as **Chinese Muslims**. Outside of proper nouns, avoid other [transliterations](/home/t/transliterations), including "Uyhur" and "Uighur."
 (See also [pronunciation](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2Flng%2Frecherche%2Findex.aspx%3FProId%3D32858&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw15r9OQsFoMZsrYeNjNxaQM))

**Uzi** (n. and adj.) Originally a lightweight submachine gun named after the Israeli army officer who designed it. Some later models were manufactured as pistols; **Uzis** (plural n.), as in "They learned to fire Uzis early in their training."
