### Ukrainian names

**Ukrainian names**

**Although many languages use variations of the Cyrillic alphabet, each is slightly different.** In the case of Ukrainian and Russian, for example, a few characters appear in one alphabet but not in the other, while several identical characters are pronounced in separate ways.

Some parts of Ukraine are predominately Russian-speaking, especially in eastern areas. But **the country's official language is Ukrainian**, which uses **a modified Cyrillic alphabet** with **33 letters** that represent 38 distinct phonemic sounds. As noted below: **The romanization of a lot of Ukrainian geographical names has changed since the collapse of the Soviet Union in the late 1980s**, and Ukraine's declaration of independence in 1991 (e.g., the shift from the Russian-based "ie" to the Ukrainian-based "yi" transliteration of the capital city: **Kyiv**).



**PEOPLE**
Be aware that the **English spellings of people's names in countries like Ukraine can vary widely** for several reasons:


> **(i) Pronunciation decisions**, including regional differences/preferences.
> **(ii) Transliteration choices** when contrasting conventions may apply.
> **(iii) The whims of bureaucrats registering names**, such as passport office clerks.


**In general, adhere to the individual's known preference** unless there's a strong editorial reason to diverge — for example, when a different English spelling is deeply entrenched (e.g., in the case of a public figure), or when truly bizarre typography might needlessly confuse our audience (e.g., fusing [non-English characters](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/f/foreign-words/#roman_alphabet "Foreign words") and diacritical markings into the Latin alphabet).

**Volodymyr Zelenskyy** illustrates this principle. After he was elected Ukraine's president in April 2019, media in the West reported inconsistent spellings, including **Zelenskiy, Zelenskyi, Zelenskyy** and **Zelensky**. As a political candidate the previous few months, he'd actually used "Zelenskiy," himself, on platforms like Instagram and Facebook. After winning the election, however, he switched to Zelenskyy on social media. A few months later, Ukraine's largest, oldest English newspaper, [the Kyiv Post, said the move away from "Zelenskiy" was understandable](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/media/jebb0qrh/zelensky_y-so-many-ys_kyiv-post-editorial_june-14-2019.pdf "Zelensky Y So Many Ys KYIV POST Editorial June 14 2019 (1)") because it was viewed by many as an old, Russian-based transliteration. At the same time, its editorial board considered the "yy" choice odd and inelegant. The president's aides, meanwhile, confirmed that the English name on his passport was "Volodymyr Zelenskyy," but also said that this spelling was based on a decision by the passport office, itself, and that [the newly elected president did not object to alternative versions](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/media/wo1hhoro/zelenskyy_spelling_tweet_june-2019.jpg "Zelenskyy Spelling Tweet June 2019") in English. As a result, CBC News and many other major western media initially went with the shortened form, Zelensky, including AP, the BBC and the New York Times. So did the Kyiv Post. During the next two years, however, "Zelenskyy" appeared consistently in official Ukrainian documents translated into English. Then Western governments and various international organizations, such as NATO, adopted the "yy" version of the president's name. The Associated Press officially switched to Zelenskyy in the spring of 2022. But some English news organizations in Europe and North America stuck with the single "y" spelling, which left more than a few people in our audience confused. **In July 2022, we reviewed the transliteration debate and agreed with AP that it made sense to identify the man by his unambiguously stated preference, Volodymyr Zelenskyy**, because there was no compelling editorial reason to diverge from what had become an entrenched English spelling.


**GEOGRAPHICAL LOCATIONS**
Inconsistent spellings of people's names should not be confused with the politics of other proper nouns, including geographical names. **Since the breakup of the old Soviet Union, transliterations of cities and towns based on Russian have been revised in many former republics** to reflect the official language of each new, independent country. **In Ukraine, this means:**

>      **Kyiv** (capital city; _not "Kiev"_)
>
>   The [preferred CBC pronunciation](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2Fapps%2Flng%2Frecherche%2Findex.aspx%3FProId%3D37206&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2fgVb8rmHYPFggv1qX3W5G) is "**KEE-ef**."
>
>
> **Chornobyl** (_not "Chernobyl"_)
>
> **Donetsk** (_not "Doneck" or "Stalino"_)
>
> **Kharkiv** (_not "Kharkov"_)
>
> **Luhansk** (_not "Lugansk"_)
>
> **Lviv** (_not "Lvov"_)
>
> **Odesa** (_not "Odessa"_)
>
> **Slovyansk** (_not "Sloviansk"_)
>
> **Zakarpattia** (_not "Zacarpatia"_)


**PRONUNCIATION PHILOSOPHY:** We aim for **a consistent, respectful pronunciation** that acknowledges the country's preferred phonetics (i.e., Ukrainian rather than Russian) **without expecting CBC journalists to speak Ukrainian in our English news and current affairs programming**. See the March 2022 [**pronunciation of Ukrainian names**](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/updates/2022/2022-03-01/ "2022 03 01") memo for details.


**Ukraine formally adopted the new English spellings after declaring independence in the 1990s**, and requested that other governments follow suit. A 2011 document entitled the [Romanization System in Ukraine](https://unstats.un.org/unsd/geoinfo/ungegn/docs/26th-gegn-docs/WP/WP21_Roma_system_Ukraine%20_engl._.pdf) submitted to the United Nations is representative. Over time, these Ukrainian transliterations have been embraced by foreign affairs departments in Ottawa, Washington and elsewhere, as well as by the UN.

**CBC News prefers the revised spellings for two reasons:**



1.  **Accuracy.** The Ukrainian transliterations more closely reflect the official names. 
2.  **Respect for a known local preference.** [Ukraine's request for specific transliterations](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.kyivpost.com%2Fukraine-politics%2Fkyivnotkiev-campaign-asks-foreign-media-to-change-their-spelling-of-ukraines-capital.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0fdAireLldNaiNPZskLwXP) is compelling, given the now-sovereign country's efforts to rid itself of Russian influence over its language and culture.

**In the case of rivers and mountain ranges that cross several countries, generally prefer conventional spellings that are widely known** (e.g., the **Danube River** instead of the "Dunai River"). **Otherwise, adopt romanized spellings that match related Ukrainian names** (e.g., the **Dnipro River** rather than the "Dnieper River," since the **Dnipropetrovsk** oblast is commonly shortened to **Dnipro**). NOTE: It can be challenging to cover a region where old and new transliterations sometimes still coexist in official arenas (e.g., the "Dnipro River" and the "Dnieper River" both appeared Ukrainian government documents in 2022). Consistency and audience familiarity should always be considered major factors when weighing options. 


IMPORTANT: Avoid adding the definite article "[the](/home/t/the-versus-the#geographical)" in front of the country's name. It's Ukraine, NEVER "the Ukraine." The sovereign country has no alternative, formal name featuring a noun like "republic" or "kingdom" — unlike, say, the People's Republic of China or the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka.


**Slow transition toward new geographical transliterations**
**Decades after Ukraine declared independence, a mix of inconsistent Ukrainian spellings remained common in English news coverage** — including in stories by prominent media organizations that refer to, say, Ukrainian-based _Kyiv_ in one paragraph but to Russian-based _Chernobyl_ in the other. This incongruity continued after Russia's invasion of Ukraine in 2022.

**However, a primary source of CBC wire copy, The Canadian Press, adopted Ukrainian transliterations** (Kyiv, Chornobyl, Odesa, and so forth) **at roughly the same time we did. This is good news from a practical standpoint, since a lot of the wire material we get** (even from AP) **goes through CP first.** In other words, Ukrainian transliterations in CP and AP stories generally match CBC style.

NOTE: **Our main source for the spellings of communities outside of Canada remains the National Geographic Atlas of the World.** But there are exceptions (e.g., Kabul not "Kabol," Damascus not "Dimashq," and Rome not "Roma"). So **always check the CBC Language Guide first**. It's impossible for this site to list all foreign geographical names. **When spellings of Ukrainian cities, towns, villages, etc., are in doubt,** good external sources include the United Nations, the Ukrainian Canadian Congress, and the Canadian Embassy in Ukraine. **A fast and valuable source is the [Kyiv Post newspaper](https://www.kyivpost.com/)**. For instance, a quick keyword search for "Borodyanka" confirms that local Ukrainian journalists prefer a "y" instead of an "i" in their English coverage of the small community near Kyiv. 


**What about 'chicken Kiev'?**
Keep in mind that the preferred transliterations above refer to proper geographical names. Other entrenched usage, such as a recipe for **chicken Kiev**, continues to be spelled the old way. This matches our approach to, say, a dish of **Peking duck** — even though the old name Peking was switched to Beijing back in the 1980s, based on China's preference for the Pinyin spelling system.

See also [Ukraine](/home/u#Ukraine)
See also [Russian names](/home/r/russian-names) as well as the general guidelines on [transliterations](/home/t/transliterations)
See also [Soviet Union](/home/s/soviet-union) and [Kremlin](/home/k/kremlin)
See also [cities of the world](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/g/geography-cities/ "Geography cities")
See also the Words: Woe & Wonder column [Kiev or Kyiv? Turin or Torino?](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews2%2Findepth%2Fwords%2Fkiev-or-kyiv.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1NAvZSqCruI4DyZUlkwCwM)

### United Arab Emirates


**United Arab Emirates**

**The United Arab Emirates is a country along the southern base of the Persian Gulf.** It was founded in the early 1970s when seven oil-rich states formed a federation.

Spell out the noun in first reference: **United Arab Emirates**. This can be shortened to **the Emirates** after that. The abbreviation **U.A.E.** is fine in headlines, graphics and alternative second references. Periods are included because it's a [geographical abbreviation](/home/a/abbreviations#uppercase).

Although the seven members have their own monarchs, they are not considered separate countries. Rather, they should be described as states or emirates within the U.A.E. **The emirates are Abu Dhabi, Ajman, Dubai, Fujairah, Sharjah, Ras al-Khaimah and Umm al-Quwain.**

**Rulers are sheiks not emirs**
Traditionally, the term emirate refers to a region controlled by an emir. **But the ruler of each U.A.E. member uses the title sheik rather than emir.** These monarchs govern the United Arab Emirates. They sit on the **Supreme Council**, which formulates federal policies, approves national laws, ratifies treaties, etc.


**Abu Dhabi and Abu Dhabi City**
The name Abu Dhabi sometimes causes confusion. It refers to one of the emirates as well as to the country's capital (**Abu Dhabi City**). While context normally provides sufficient detail, include the word "City" in first reference (along the lines of [New York City](/home/n#NewYork)) to ensure there's no ambiguity. In web headlines where space is limited, Abu Dhabi alone is OK. **But be sure to include the word "City" in first reference to U.A.E.'s capital in the main body of the story.**

**United Arab Emirates is a singular noun**
Some style manuals suggest treating U.A.E. as a plural rather than as a collective singular because it's made up of seven emirates. But since it's a country, the conventional approach is to consider it singular along the lines of the United States (e.g., the United Arab Emirates "is" not "are"), unless the short form the Emirates is used (e.g., the Emirates "have" always not "has" always).

### United Kingdom

**United Kingdom**

The actual name is "the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland," but it does not need to be spelled out in full in news stories. United Kingdom is sufficient.



**What's included**
The **United Kingdom** consists of **England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland**. The population is roughly twice the size of Canada's.

The noun **Britain** technically refers to **one island: England, Scotland and Wales**. (It used to be called Great Britain to distinguish it from Brittany.) "Britain" and "British" are conventionally used as synonyms for the United Kingdom, except in stories involving Northern Ireland.

The initials U.K. are fine in headlines when applicable, but **in many routine stories "British" is the preferred adjective** (e.g., the "British government" rather than the "U.K. government"), unless coverage is focused on Northern Ireland.


**What's excluded**
**U.K. does not include the bailiwicks of Jersey and Guernsey in the English Channel, and the Isle of Man in the Irish Sea.** These three islands are classified as _Crown dependencies_, which means they're independently administered jurisdictions separate from (but owned by) the United Kingdom. This can have ramifications for everything from news coverage of taxation rates to reports on immigration and health care.

Although Crown dependencies have their own governments, they're not separate countries, and some legislation they pass still requires approval by the Privy Council in London. It's common and acceptable to refer to the Isle of Man, the Channel Island of Jersey and the Channel Island of Guernsey, without using jargon such as "British Crown dependencies." Just make sure we **don't imply that they're part of the U.K.** Technically, they're part of the **British Islands** (which is made up of England, Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland, Jersey, Guernsey and the Isle of Man).

In addition to excluding nearby Crown dependencies, **the United Kingdom does not include more than a dozen British "overseas territories"** (sometimes called "dependent territories"), such as Gibraltar, Bermuda, the Cayman Islands, the Falkland Islands and Montserrat.


**Why U.K. 'devolution' requires special care**
**The United Kingdom is no longer a unitary state with a single parliament** at Westminster. The specifics are complicated and evolving. After centuries of a relatively straightforward structure, **government authority is now less centralized**. This means it's **inaccurate to use U.K. as a default noun or modifier across the board** when we're reporting on various regional or "subnational" powers and policies.

**The transfer of certain authority** to England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland since the late 1990s **is known as "devolution."** The **U.K. government in London remains responsible for national policy in areas that have not been "devolved" — known as "reserved powers."** This includes **defence, national security, foreign affairs, immigration, citizenship, etc.**, but NOT agriculture, education, housing and health care.

One wrinkle: **There is no regional legislative body in England comparable to** those now sitting in Wales (the Welsh Assembly at **Cardiff Bay**), in Scotland (the Scottish Parliament at **Edinburgh**) and in Northern Ireland (the Northern Ireland Assembly at **Belfast**). Instead, the U.K. Parliament in London remains responsible for any devolved authority in England.

Another wrinkle is that **some "reserved powers" have not been formally tested in courts**, This means, for example, that during a global health emergency, it's possible that the U.K. government could try to impose specific policies on all subnational jurisdictions in the name of public safety. Instead, however, there's generally been a more collaborative, patchwork approach to such crises, first during the 2009 H1N1 flu pandemic and then again during the 2020 COVID-19 pandemic.

**KEY TAKEAWAY: U.K often remains the right choice** in news stories. **But be aware that a headline or TV banner that at one time would have automatically featured "U.K." might now need to be changed to "England" or "Scotland" or whatever proper noun applies.** For instance, during coverage of a deadly virus outbreak, we might need to refer to an easing of "England lockdown" restrictions (for policies outlined by the PM in London), or of "Scotland lockdown" restrictions (for policies outlined by Scottish parliamentary leaders), etc., rather than to an easing of "U.K. lockdown" restrictions, especially since the details may vary from region to region.


**TIP: If you're unsure whether "U.K." applies, it can be helpful to scan coverage from the BBC**, where journalists routinely deal with the complexities of devolved powers in their country.


See also [Britain](/home/b/britain) and [Northern Ireland](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/i/ireland/#Northern-Ireland "Ireland")

### United Nations

**United Nations (UN)**

**The United Nations should be spelled out in first reference, although UN is fine in headlines:**


> UN General Assembly, the General Assembly, the Assembly
> UN Secretary General Kofi Annan, the secretary general (See also [\-general](/home/g/generalsuffix))
> UN Security Council, the Security Council


Be aware that a few news organizations add periods to UN because they treat it as a geographical location, along the lines of B.C., rather than as a name. But **CBC News style is UN without punctuation.**

**UN organizations**
Some UN bodies are frequently referred to in stories. There's no need to add "UN" unless it's part of the proper name:


> **Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations** (_Avoid_ abbreviation FAO. Prefer "the organization" on second reference.)
>
> **IMF** (_Use_ **International Monetary Fund** _on first reference_. Initials IMF fine in headlines.)
>
> **International Civil Aviation Organization** (**ICAO** or the organization on second reference.)
>
> **International Court of Justice** (No abbreviation.)
>
> **International Labour Organization** (**ILO** or the organization on second reference.)
>
> **UNICEF** (Fine in first reference, but define as the _"United Nations Children's Fund" at some point in story_.) It's no longer called "the UN International Children's Emergency Fund," even though the old abbreviation is still used.
>
> **UN High Commissioner for Refugees**
>
> **United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization** (**UNESCO** fine in second reference.)
>
> **World Bank** (Acceptable in all references to the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development. _There's no need to use the longer title_.)
>
> **World Food Program** (preferred North American spelling, rather than _Programme_, based on the entrenched convention of adopting more familiar spellings of certain words — even when these are technically proper noun components of international organizations' English names.)
>
> **World Health Organization** (**WHO** OK in headlines and second reference) There's usually no need to use a definite article before the abbreviation — i.e., make it "according to WHO" rather than "according to the WHO" — based on convention. Be aware, however, that WHO on its own can sometimes sound more like a pronoun ("who") than an abbreviation in broadcast scripts. Adding "the" in those cases is fine. Using a synonym like "the organization" or "the UN body" is another effective option. See [acronyms](/home/a/acronyms) for other examples of dropped articles.


See also [abbreviations](/home/a/abbreviations)

### United States

**United States, U.S., US**
[General](/home/u/united-states#general) (include periods unless referring to currency; add U.S. to otherwise ambiguous names, titles)
[State abbreviations](/home/u/united-states#states) (Ala., Calif., Ky., N.Y., Pa., S.D., Vt., W.Va., Wyo.)
[Standalone cities](/home/u/united-states#cities) (state detail not required when cities well known)


**General**
Prefer **United States** or **the U.S.** rather than _United States of America_ or the _U.S.A._

**U.S.** has periods **except in currency ($300 US)** See [money](/home/m/money)

**"American" is fine as an adjective** describing people and things in general (an **American city**, an **American scientist**), but try to use U.S. for more formal references to the country or its government (e.g., **U.S. Embassy** or **U.S. trade representative**).

**Ordinarily avoid "America" as a synonym for the country**, itself, outside of verbatim quotes **for two reasons:**


> **1\. Accuracy. The U.S. is only one part of the Americas** — which technically refers to the entire Western Hemisphere, including the Caribbean and West Indies. As a plural collective, "the Americas" is suitable for stories about both continents (North and South America).
>
> **2\. Entrenched Canadian convention.** As the Oxford Guide to Canadian English points out: "Canadians seldom refer to the United States as 'America,' although this usage is common around the world. Canadians say 'the United States' or, informally, 'the States.'" For large segments of our audience, therefore, constantly referring to the U.S. as "America" is like dropping the "u" from "honour."


**Occasional exceptions are fine when there's a compelling editorial reason**, especially in stories about trade, politics, world affairs, etc., that feature established phrases, such as "**America First**" or "**Death to America**" or "**Make America Great Again**." This headline from 2020 is OK, for example, because its colloquial use of "America" adds acceptable colour, and because repeating "U.S." would unnecessarily spoil the conversational phrasing:


> _First **U.S.** presidential debate 'not a very good night' for **America**_


The same approach is sometimes taken in TV banners or graphics (e.g., "America Votes" rather than "The U.S. Votes").

See **[Avoid inapt Americanisms](/home/a/americanisms)** for an overview of Canadian versus American English (e.g., avoid _DUI, half-staff, railroad_)

**Add U.S. to the names of most government departments, agencies and other organizations in first reference** to make stories clearer (e.g., the U.S. State Department) unless the proper noun is instantly recognized (e.g., NASA, NSA, FBI, CIA). **Even when popular short forms are spelled out, our default practice is to add U.S.** (e.g., the U.S. National Aeronautics and Space Administration, the U.S. National Security Agency, the U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation, the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency). NOTE: The [official names of hundreds of U.S. government departments and agencies](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.usa.gov%2Ffederal-agencies%2Fa&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0_x97cYtsF4H9CmLuUigO9) are listed in alphabetical order on USA.gov. 

**Words such as "national" and "federal" require particular care** because American media reports frequently leave out a key geographical modifier (U.S.) because the detail is assumed. **To avoid ambiguity, we need to specify what's not Canadian** (e.g., the U.S. National Institutes of Health, the U.S. National Security Agency, the U.S. Federal Communications Commission, the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration). **When Canadian and U.S. agencies have similar names, take special care** to avoid misidentifying either:


> _Transportation Safety Board of Canada_
>
> _U.S. National Transportation Safety Board_


For example, it can be confusing and potentially misleading to call Canada's Transportation Safety Board the "national" Transportation Safety Board even in the context of a Canadian story. In broadcast scripts, the lowercase "national" is heard by some of our audience as a capitalized "National" — i.e., as the official U.S. name being misapplied to a Canadian agency.

**Add U.S. to the titles of most federal politicians in first reference:
**

> _U.S. President Donald Trump says ..._


**In second reference, the name or abbreviated title alone is sufficient.** Options include:


> _President Trump tweeted ..._
>
> _Trump tweeted ..._
>
> _The president tweeted ..._


Remember that the world has many presidents. **Avoid mirroring the style of American news organizations, such as AP, which tend to drop U.S.** from the title because it's implied. For the same reason U.S. journalists invariably identify foreign political figures with geographical modifiers (e.g., "Canadian" Prime Minister Justin Trudeau), it's CBC News style to add locators to the titles of foreign leaders, regardless of their profiles.

See [**titles**](/home/t/titles) for related guidelines (e.g., add "former" to titles of past U.S. presidents). See also [**TV text**](/home/t/tv_text) for specific television guidelines. (While most people are identified in supers at least once in TV stories, current U.S. presidents are among the rare exceptions.)

### Universities and colleges

**Universities and colleges**

**Capitalize the names of universities and colleges:**

Carleton University
Dalhousie University
McMaster University
Memorial University of Newfoundland (also known as Memorial University)
Nunavut Arctic College
Red Deer College
Toronto Metropolitan University (formerly Ryerson University)
University of British Columbia
University of Manitoba
University of Toronto

**Abbreviations are OK, especially in second reference, as long as they're entrenched:**

BYU
MUN (or just Memorial)
UBC
UCLA
U of A
U of T

**Often a principal word is sufficient in second reference.** The initial "U" is generally unnecessary when the word "university" falls at the end of the proper noun unless the school's name has recently changed and we want to emphasize its new status to keep the story clear:

Carleton
Dalhousie
McMaster
[OCADU](/home/o#OCADU) (or OCAD alone in second reference if new university status is already obvious in story)

**Keep departments, schools, programs, courses, etc. lowercase:
**
the Queen’s University medical school
the biology department
a political science professor
the faculty of arts
a chemistry course
an English class

**Use the abbreviation Prof.** for professor **before names. Reserve “Dr.” for people with medical degrees:**

Prof. Kriss Kringle …
Kriss Kringle, an economics professor at Laval University
Kringle, who teaches business ethics …

See also [degrees](/home/d/degrees) (B.Sc. but BA)
See also [abbreviations](/home/a/abbreviations)
See also [Dr.](/home/d/dr)

The Association of Universities and Colleges of Canada lists virtually all degree-granting, post-secondary institutions in the country. The [AUCC directory](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.univcan.ca%2Funiversities%2Fmember-universities%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0zbLvqsj-tTSupIUcw8jiS) includes brief background about each university and college, as well as links to every school's website.

### URLs

**URL**

**This computer term** (often pronounced "Earl") stands for **uniform resource locator** (although some people use "_universal_" and "_uniform_" interchangeably, including a few programmers writing explanatory notes at the World Wide Web Consortium).
**
URL refers to the address used to find a "resource" on the internet** (**normally a web page**, although it could also locate CGI and Java programs as well as graphic files).

**In news stories, use the term "web address" instead of URL.** Avoid other jargon tied to these addresses as well (e.g., pointer or protocol) unless it’s explained.


**Dot and slash dissection**
**URLs are broken down into four main components. Each part helps a computer locate files.** For instance: _http://www.cbc.ca/news/viewpoint/vp\_murray/20021021.html_

**1.** _http://_ stands for _hypertext transfer protocol_. It’s the most common protocol in URLs, although others exist (including _ftp://_, which stands for file transfer protocol).

**2.** _www_ is a pointer attached to the _domain name_. It’s the most common pointer.

**3\.** _cbc.ca_ is the _main domain name_.

**4.** The last part (_/news/viewpoint/vp\_murrary/20021021.html_) is a _pointer_ that directs the computer to _a specific file on the server_ (in this case, a column by CBC News foreign correspondent Don Murray).


**Slash (/), not backslash (\\)**
**When reading internet addresses on air, use the term "slash"** rather than "backslash." **A slash** (/) **is a forward-sloping diagonal line**, also known as a solidus, that appears in a lot of URLs.
**
There's no need to say "forward" slash on air.** The left-to-right lean is implied.

The backslash (\\) is relatively rare punctuation, known as a reverse solidus. It's used in some computer programming languages.


**Text instead of hypertext**
On CBCNews.ca, we normally add actual links with HTML code instead of writing out web addresses as part of a story's main text. **In rare cases when the URL is written out, don’t bother including http:// because it’s implied** (www.cbc.ca, not http://www.cbc.ca). **If another protocol is used, however, specify which one** (e.g., ftp).

**Generally drop www from the URLs of well-known websites** (e.g., cbc.ca rather than www.cbc.ca), **and leave out the last slash** (e.g., news.bbc.co.uk rather than news.bbc.co.uk/).

Also, **generally match the pathway’s lowercase lettering** (e.g., "The Great Canadian Wish List's web address contained a four-letter word that was easy to remember: cbc.ca/wish"). **This represents an exception to our normal approach to domain names , which are usually treated as proper nouns featuring capital letters** (e.g., CBC.ca, and [CBCNews.ca](/home/c/cbc)).


**An or a URL?**
Is it "_an URL_" or "_a URL_"? The answer _depends entirely on pronunciation_. If you say the letters individually (i.e., "_you-are-ell_") the abbreviation requires an "a" before it. But if you treat the cluster as an acronym (pronounced "_Earl_") then the word "an" is needed.

See also [a versus an](/home/a/a-versus-an)

See also [internet terms](/home/i/internet-terms)

**V** 

**[v-vh](/home/v#v)**

**[vi-vy](/home/v#vi)**

**VE-Day** (May 8, 1945), **VJ-Day** (Aug. 14, 1945) These abbreviations refer to the official dates during the final year of the Second World War when the Allied forces declared "Victory in Europe" (VE) and "Victory over Japan" (VJ). The latter date is sometimes reported as Aug. 15 because of time zone differences between North America and Asia (i.e., the announcement was made at 7 p.m. ET by U.S. President Harry Truman). But for consistency, Aug. 14 is the preferred date. Use uppercase letters, no periods and a hyphen, as in D-Day.

**Villepin, Dominique de** (former French prime minister) Use **Villepin** alone in second reference. For general guidelines on de, du, van, von, etc., see [particles](/home/p/particles-de-du-van-von).

**Vaisakhi** (annual April event celebrated by Sikhs and Hindus) For Hindus, it represents the start of the traditional solar new year. For Sikhs, it marks not only the new year but also the formal establishment of their faith — making it one of the most significant dates on their calendar. Vaisakhi is also an ancient spring harvest festival in parts of India. Use this entrenched spelling. Avoid other [transliterations](/home/t/transliterations), such as "Baisakhi" and "Vasakhi."

**valentine** (card, gift, etc.), _but_ **Valentine's Day** (See [holidays and other special times](/home/h/holidays))

Be aware of a person's preference as well as established convention. In some cases, van is dropped in second reference (e.g., **Ludwig van Beethoven** becomes Beethoven). In other cases, Van is always uppercase in the full name and may be dropped altogether in subsequent references. (See [particles](/home/p/particles-de-du-van-von) for more details on da, de, du, van, von, etc.)

**Van Doos** (This is an English version of the French word for 22nd, _vingt-deuxième_. It's an acceptable nickname for Quebec's Royal 22nd Regiment, in headlines and second reference); Van Doo (one member), **the Van Doos** (plural for all or some of the regiment); Use the English form of the full proper noun ("Royal 22nd Regiment") rather than the French ("Royal 22e Régiment"). Options for shortened second references include the 22nd Regiment, the 22nd and the regiment. Although Royal 22nd Regiment is also officially known by its French name (akin to Montreal and Montréal being equally correct in the eyes of federal officials), CBC News adopts entrenched English equivalents. So just as we write "4th Battalion, Princess Patricia's Canadian Light Infantry" our Radio-Canada colleagues use "4e Bataillon" rather than the English form. See [French words](/home/f/french-words-and-accents) as well as [military forces](/home/m/military-forces) for general guidelines.

Avoid the phrase "known as VANOC" in leads, but try to insert it within the first three to four paragraphs if the abbreviation appears in the headline. Second-reference options include the **committee**, the **organizing committee** and VANOC. (See also [Olympics](/home/o/olympic-games) for general style guidelines)

For consistency, however, stick with Vodou outside of proper nouns (e.g., the **Voodoo Spiritual Temple and Cultural Center**). Modern vuvuzelas are often plastic. Critics say the horns are too loud and distracting. Defenders say vuvuzelas are an important part of South African sports culture.

### verb agreement

**Verb agreement** (plural versus singular)

Subjects and verbs can be at odds. The inconsistency _are_ usually obvious. In the last sentence "are" is clearly out of place — which is another way of saying that the inconsistency _is_ obvious. But sometimes writing requires careful deconstruction before a ruling can be made.

Consider this line from the Ottawa Citizen:

> _Kagan's list of hopes that parents have for their children do not seem to jive with the literature or my own experience._


It should be _**does** not seem_ to jive because the verb does is tied to **_Kagan's list_**. (The example is cited by Oxford's Guide to Canadian English Usage.)

**In some cases, the correct verb is debatable because the subject can be viewed as singular or plural.** There are **five broad categories** worth reviewing:

1. [Collective nouns](/home/v/verb-agreement#collectivenouns) (couple, family, RCMP, etc.)
2. [Sports teams and musical groups](/home/v/verb-agreement#teamsandgroups)
3. [Measurements](/home/v/verb-agreement#measurements) (money, time, weight, etc.)
4. [Tricks with "ics"](/home/v/verb-agreement#ics) (ethics, politics, etc.)
5. [Composite themes](/home/v/verb-agreement#themes) (tar and feather, etc.)

**1\. Collective nouns**
Word such as **"family," "staff," and "couple"** are a frequent source of confusion because **we sometimes imply the group while at other times we mean members of the group.**

Since English is flexible enough to give us options, **pick what's most natural for the context and remain consistent within a sentence:**

> _If his family **show** up_ (not shows up), **_they_** (not "it") _will probably come by train._
>
> _His family **is**_ (not are) _going to Europe._ 
>
> _Each couple **is** asked to donate $100._ 
>
>     (Couple viewed as a single group here.) 
>
> _The couple got divorced last year, and **they**_ (not "it") _now live in different cities._
>
>     (Couple thought of as plural in this case.)


**Use the same approach for certain proper nouns** (e.g., "the Taliban is/are"), **keeping in mind that preferences have sometimes been established** through convention (e.g., "the RCMP are" in most cases):

> _The Taliban **are**_ (more natural than "is") _living in caves in the area._
>
>     (Members of the Taliban emphasized here.)
>
> _She said the Taliban **was**_ (more natural than "were") _a misogynistic regime._ 
>
> (The Taliban as a ruling body emphasized here.)
>
> _The RCMP **are**_ (preferred to "is") _investigating._ 
>
>     (Members of the police force emphasized here.) 
>
> _The RCMP has_ (preferred to "have") _a new commissioner._ 
>
>     (The police force itself emphasized here.)


See [RCMP are versus RCMP is](/home/r/rcmp-are-versus-rcmp-is) for a more detailed explanation


**Couple**
Couple is worth a couple of extra words, since it crops up quite a bit. **The New York Times recommends treating the word as a plural most of the time, since we're usually emphasizing a relationship between two distinct individuals:**

> _The couple argued a lot. **They**_ (not it) _tossed insults and glassware at each other._
>
> _The couple **were** married in 1975. They_ (not it) _had **their**_ (not its) _first child two years later._


**Once you pick a form, be sure not to switch in the middle of the stream:**

Wrong: _That couple **was**_ (singular) _the richest in the area. **They**_ (plural) _bought ..._

(For more on "they," see [problems with pronouns](/home/p/problems-with-pronouns))


**2\. Sports teams, musical groups, etc.**
**In general, treat the names of sports teams as plural nouns** even if they don't end with an "s." This is a well-established convention:

> _The Miami Heat **have** signed another forward._
>
> _The Edmonton Elks **are** trading their star quarterback._


When the names of communities are used alone instead, however, the noun is singular.

> _The Colorado Avalanche **win**._
>
> _The Avalanche **win**._
>
> _Colorado **wins**._
>
> _The Toronto Blue Jays **have** fortified their bullpen._
>
> _The Blue Jays **have** fortified their bullpen._
>
> _Toronto **has** fortified its bullpen._


**In general, treat the names of musical groups as singular nouns unless these end in an "s."** In North America, this is a well-established convention:

> _U2 is planning another world tour._
>
> _The Clash **was** virtually unknown in the U.S. until 1980._
>
> _The Rolling Stones **have** released a new album._


**In these cases, be sure to avoid adding apostrophes to false possessives** (e.g., the Leafs winger liked Beatles songs versus the Leafs' last Stanley Cup victory was just before the Beatles' breakup). See ['s versus s's](/handy-links/punctuation/s-versus-s-s) for more details.

Also, remember that sports teams and musical groups always take lowercase definite articles, except at the beginning of sentences (e.g., the Rolling Stones not The Rolling Stones). See [the versus The](/home/t/the-versus-the) for more details.


**3\. Money, time, weight, etc.**
**Plural measurements of money, time, weight and so forth almost always take singular verbs because they're usually viewed as a unit:**

> _Forty dollars **is** missing from her purse._ 
>
>     (not are missing, since the focus is the sum)
>
> _Five kilograms **is** a lot of beef._
>
> _Three weeks **is** enough time._
>
> _Twenty million litres of fuel **was** on the ship._


**But:**

> _Three days **have** passed since the quake._ 
>
>     (days referred to separately, not as a unit)
>
> _Eight million barrels of oil **were** sold._


**In some cases, either approach is correct depending on emphasis:**

> _Two inches of snow **is** not much._ 
>
>     (focus is the sum of snow)
>
> _Six inches of snow **is** on the ground._ 
>
>     (focus is the sum of snow)
>
> _Six inches of snow **have** fallen during the past 24 hours._ 
>
>     (focus is on individual units)


**At other times, there is only one option** (based on the sentence's subject):

> _Lots of rain **has** fallen._ 
>
>     (not have, since "lots of" is comparable to the adjective "much")
>
> _Lots of apples **have** fallen off the truck._
>
>     (not has, since "lots of" is comparable to the adjective "many")


**4\. Tricks with "ics"**
**Several words that end with "ics" (classics, ethics, politics, etc.) may take either plural or singular verbs, depending on the context:**

> _Ethics **is** a tough course._ 
>
>     (field of study)
>
> _Your ethics **are** questionable._ 
>
>     (beliefs)
>
> _Politics **is** not as rewarding as she hoped._ 
>
>     (public service, governing)
>
> _Politics **have** a lot to do with it._ 
>
>     (partisan positions, ideological views)


**5\. Composite themes** (tar and feather)
Two or more words sometimes form what grammarians call **a "composite theme."**

These are **treated as a single subject. But deciding what falls into this category can be highly subjective.** Here are two examples from Fowler's 1998 Modern English Usage:

(a) _The extent and severity of alcoholism in Russia **has** been a shock to the visiting addiction counsellors_ should probably be **_have been_** a shock because "extent" and "severity" do not form a single theme. (The writer is making two comments about alcoholism, not one, since something can be widespread but not very serious.)

(b) On the other hand, _Tarring and feathering **was** too good for him_ is OK because here "tarring and feathering" constitutes a single act of punishment that would not be conveyed adequately with a plural verb.

So _chicken and beef **are** on the menu,_ but _gin and tonic **is** a good combination._
Be aware that **conventional usage can be a factor in determining composite themes**. The expression "truth and reconciliation," for example, has been frequently considered a singular subject since the end of apartheid in South Africa in the 1990s — e.g., _truth and reconciliation **begins**_ and **_means_** and **_is_** rather than _truth and reconciliation begin_ and mean and _are_.

See also [plurals](/home/p/plurals) (an overview)
See also [they as a singular pronoun](/home/t/they_singular) ("Someone left their iPhone in the washroom") as well as [transgender](/home/t/transgender#pronouns) for "they" as a non-binary singular pronoun
See also [grammar](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/handy-links/grammar/ "Grammar")

**Walmart** (fused, lowercase "m") The company started using "Walmart" on its store signs in late 2008, and now prefers this spelling in virtually all documents, including news releases. Although the company's legal name remains slightly different (Wal-Mart), we adopted Walmart as our style in 2014 because this is how the company is now known to most people. For simplicity and consistency, therefore, prefer this spelling across the board (**Walmart, Walmart Stores Inc., Walmart Canada Corp.**, etc.) Since abbreviations such as Inc. and Corp. are conventionally used only in business journalism, the nouns **Walmart** or **Walmart Canada** are generally sufficient in most of our reporting. See [names versus logos](/home/n/names-versus-logos) for additional background on the switch from Wal-Mart to Walmart.

[**war**](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/m/military-terms-overview/#war "Military terms overview") (broad term to describe various types of ongoing hostilities, such as the **civil war in Syria** and the **war in Ukraine**); [**War** versus **war**](/home/w/war) (**cold war** and **war of words** but the **Second World War** and the **Vietnam War**)

**war crimes** (the violation of laws or conventions governing armed conflict) War crimes are generally linked to unacceptable treatment of prisoners and civilians. Such allegations are often dealt with by permanent tribunals, such as the International Criminal Court in The Hague, which also handles accusations of [genocide](/home/g/genocide) and other crimes against humanity. Not all countries are formal members of the International Criminal Court, however, and some prosecute their own accusations of war crimes, revising the definition based on their own laws (e.g., charging alleged terrorists with fighting on foreign soil without the authority of that land's government). Since this use of the term "war crime" can be controversial, however, qualifying language is generally recommended (e.g., U.S.-laid or U.S.-prosecuted war crimes in the case of the military hearings in Guantanamo Bay). See the October 2010 editorial note about [War crimes and Khadr coverage](/updates/2010/2010-10-26) for details.

**War Measures Act** (repealed by the Parliament of Canada in 1988) Replaced by the [**Emergencies Act**](/home/e#EmergenciesAct)

**well**
Most, but not all, compound adjectives featuring the word "well" have a hyphen when used attributively (i.e., before the noun being modified). Some common exceptions are included below. When the combination appears after the noun, however, the hyphen is generally dropped (e.g., _a **well-cut** diamond_ versus _a diamond that's **well cut**_). Some compound nouns featuring "well" always have a hyphen (e.g., **well-being** and **well-wishers**). (See also [hyphens](/handy-links/punctuation/hyphens))

ADJECTIVES BEFORE NOUNS BEING MODIFIED (e.g., _A well-known person_)
**well-balanced, well-behaved, well-built, well-chosen, well-defined, well-deserved, well-developed, well done** (no hyphen), **well-educated, well equipped** (no hyphen), **well-kept, well-known, well-liked, well-lit, well-loved, well-made, well off** (no hyphen), **well-organized, well-paid, well placed** (no hyphen), **well-planned, well-prepared, well-preserved, well-read, well-received, well-rounded, well-spent, well-spoken, well-stocked, well-suited, well-to-do, well-used, well versed** (no hyphen), **well-worn**

COMPOUNDS AFTER NOUNS BEING MODIFIED (e.g., _She's well known_)
**well aware, well balanced, well behaved, well built, well chosen, well defined, well deserved, well developed, well done, well educated, well equipped, well kept, well known, well liked, well lit, well loved, well made, well off, well organized, well paid, well placed, well planned, well prepared, well preserved, well read, well received, well rounded, well spent, well spoken, well stocked, well suited, well-to-do, well used, well versed, well worn**

**Western Canadian Select (WCS)** A blend of heavy oil (bitumen, conventional oil, synthetic crude) from Alberta. Considered a benchmark price for heavy oil. WCS is often compared to the per-barrel price of lighter density crude, such as **West Texas Intermediate (WTI)**. Be aware that the C in WCS is sometimes spelled out as "Canada." For consistency, however, prefer the attributive noun "Canadian," which is the older and more common form. When using names like WCS or WTI, be sure that a given story's context makes their meanings clear. Otherwise, briefly define/explain.

**Western University** (second reference, **Western**) In 2012, the University of Western Ontario officially adopted the name Western University. The longer noun remains the school's legal name, and continues to be used on students' degrees and transcripts. But Western University is now preferred in news stories. For this reason, _avoid_ the abbreviation UWO unless it's explained. And always include a geographical reference high in stories to make the school's identity clear (e.g., "London, Ont.-based," or "Ontario's" Western University). See also [universities and colleges](/home/u/universities-and-colleges) for general guidelines.

**white nationalism** (a racist ideology that promotes either white-only or white-dominated citizenry); **white supremacy** is one common subgroup of white nationalism, while **white separatism** is another. If a given group or person is known to be white supremacist (e.g., the Ku Klux Klan), prefer this more specific wording in stories (i.e., white supremacy instead of white nationalism). Otherwise, the more general description is probably best. Be aware that some people's irrational bigotry may be more rooted in distrust and a fear of integration than in actual supremacy (e.g., opposition to interracial marriage). Be cautious when labelling anyone a white nationalist or a white supremacist. Usual libel guidelines apply. When in doubt, consult a senior journalist or the CBC Law Department. **wildcat strike** (_avoid using as a mere synonym for illegal strike_) A wildcat strike is a sudden walkout not authorized by the union. The protest is almost always illegal because the workers are either not in a legal strike position or have not given the employer proper notice. Although wildcat strikes can reflect a high level of anger toward management, they can also signal dissatisfaction within the union itself. (See [strike](/home/s#strike) for related guidelines)

**woke** (OK in literal sense of being awake) The expression "they woke up" has been a conversational alternative to "they awakened" for centuries; **woke** (**_avoid in figurative sense unless attributed_**) The use of "woke" to mean social enlightenment began in the 1960s. It became politicized in the late 2010s, however, and now has different meanings, depending on the speaker or writer. To "**be woke**" initially referred to being aware of issues of racial inequality and other injustices. But the expression has taken on a separate, derogatory definition, especially among conservatives, who routinely use "woke" to describe what they consider unjustified overreactions by various activists and their supporters (e.g., "woke corporations" and "woke policies"). For this reason, the word should be attributed in our journalism. Keep in mind that if the specific meaning of "woke" is not obvious in a given case, additional context may be necessary.

**World Trade Center** (_not Centre_) because it was the proper name of the structure destroyed in the Sept. 11 attacks. **WTC** on second reference. The site can also be called **Ground Zero** (uppercase) in stories about the collapse of the two towers. Use the abbreviated form of the month ([**Sept. 11**](/home/s#Sept11), **not** September 11). **9/11** is fine in headlines. Write the "Sept. 11 attacks" not "terrorist attacks." See also [terrorism and terrorist](/home/t/terrorist-and-terrorism), as well as [defence, labour and centre](/home/d/defence-labour-and-centre)

**World War I** (WW I), **World War II** (WW II) On air, CBC News has discouraged use of the terms "World War One" and "World War Two" for years. The main reason: Placing a figure at the beginning rather than at the end of an expression is considered more natural to the ear (e.g., the First World War, the second day of the conference, his third serving of ice cream). In most stories, _generally prefer_ **First World War** and **Second World War**. In web headlines, however, **WW I** and **WW II** are allowed because they’re short and commonly understood. In these cases, always use [roman numerals](/home/n/numbers#arabicroman), continue to use the same style throughout the body of the story (WW I and WW II) to match the headline, and spell out the abbreviation WW once in first reference (World War I). Note the space between the letters and roman numerals: A long-lost WW II sub. A WW I-era gun.

**worldwide**, _but_ **World Wide Web (WWW)** as an entrenched name (See [web](/home/w#web))

**World Wildlife Fund** (_not_ Federation) Although better known outside North America by a new name adopted in the 1980s ("the World Wide Fund For Nature"), prefer the original noun from the 1960s (World Wildlife Fund) in all stories. This shorter form remains the organization's legal name in Canada and the United States. Always specify which member of the WWF global network is being referred to (e.g., "She joined WWF-Japan in 1978" and "The proposal was made by WWF-Austria's conservation director"). Generally use **World Wildlife Fund-Canada** in first reference. **WWF-Canada** is OK in second reference, as well as in web headlines.

**worshippers**

**worthwhile**

**wrack** (_Archaic term_ for wreckage, surviving in expression "wrack and ruin") _Do not confuse with_ **rack** (as in "racked their brains") See [rack versus wrack](/home/r/rack-versus-wrack)

**wreak, wreaked** (to unleash anger or to cause damage, as in "the storm wreaked havoc"); **wrought** (_archaic word_ for "worked," surviving in expressions like "What hath God wrought?" and in terms like "wrought iron.")

**wrest** (to force away, to wrench out of someone's grasp); **wrestle** (to fight, to grapple or struggle with)

**write down** (v.), as in "Write down this message"; **writedown** (n.), as in "The stock fell after news of the writedown"

**write off** (v.), as in "Don't write off the idea before listening to all options"; **writeoff** (n.), as in "The insurance company says it's a writeoff"

****wrongdoer, wrongdoing, wrongful*

*[wrongful conviction](/home/w/wrongful-conviction)****

**WTC** (See [World Trade Center](/home/w#WTC))

**[WW I, WW II](/home/w#WW1WW2)** (see above)

**Wyoming (Wyo.)** See [United States](/home/u/united-states)

****

### W five

**_W5_**

**Refer to this CTV current affairs investigative unit as _W5_.**

Originally, _W5_ was the name of one of CTV's longest-running television programs. It first aired in the fall of 1966. The proper noun's spelling changed slightly several times over the next half a century (e.g., _W-5_, "_W5 with Eric Malling_" and _W-Five_). In the fall of 2009, _W-Five_ became _W5_.

**In 2024, CTV announced that the standalone program was being cancelled** because of budget cuts, **but that the established W5 brand would continue to be used** for a range of investigative reports across its platforms.

Be aware that, technically, the show was called _W-FIVE_ (all uppercase) for many years. But most major news services (including The Canadian Press and CBC) referred to it as W-Five back then. That's because **we don’t generally put entire names in capital letters. We also write Amtrak** (not AMTRAK), **Ikea** (not IKEA), **Scrabble** (not SCRABBLE), **Via Rail** (not VIA Rail), **Visa** (not VISA), etc. **This is a standard approach to capitalization.**

Be aware, too, that in online news stories, we normally impose standard capitalization on program titles to help our audience scan for comprehension, regardless of the way shows brand themselves through logos, etc. For example: **_Play_** (not >_play_) and **_Counterspin_** (not _counterSpin_). See also [quirky capitalization](/home/q/quirky-capitalization).

Related reminder: Program names and their equivalents should be rendered in [italics](/handy-links/punctuation/italics) in our web journalism. For consistency, this includes **_W5_**.

### War

**War versus war**

**Capitalize “war” in the names of major armed conflicts:**

War of the Roses
War of 1812
Civil War (U.S.)
First World War (_preferred, but see [WW I](/home/w#WW1WW2) for headline use_)
1991 [Persian Gulf War](/home/p/persian-gulf-war)
Second World War (_preferred, but see [WW II](/home/w#WW1WW2) for headline use_)
Six-Day War
Korean War
Vietnam War

**Generally use lowercase in all other contexts:**

antiwar protests
the war in Iraq
they predict a third world war
war against drugs
war against poverty
cod war
trade war
warhorse, warlord, warmonger, wartime
but Cold War (_widely used name for a specific_ [historical period](/home/h/historical-periods))
[War Measures Act](/home/e#EmergenciesAct) (_name of legislation_)
War and Peace (_name of book_)

See also [capitalization](/home/c/capitalization) (an overview)
See also [military terms](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/m/military-terms-overview/#miscellaneous "Military terms overview") for general editorial guidelines (e.g., **war, incursion, invasion**)

### Ward versus wards

**\-ward versus -wards**

_Is it backward or backwards? Forward or forwards?_

Although the "s" is normally dropped in the case of adjectives (e.g., a _backward policy_), Canadians do not appear to have a preference at the end of adverbs (e.g., _they moved backward versus they moved backwards_), according to Oxford's Guide to Canadian English Usage.


**Use -ward**
For simplicity and consistency, we follow the lead of the Globe and Mail and some other news organizations and **use -ward** (not _\-wards_) **at the end of all words indicating direction or time:**


_**afterward, backward, downward, inward, forward, outward, toward, upward**_, etc.

**This preference applies to adverbs** ("he slipped backward") **as well as adjectives** ("a downward glance").

### Warsaw pact

**Warsaw Pact** (former)

This term refers to **an agreement signed by the old Soviet Union and some eastern European countries in 1955** called the _Warsaw Treaty of Friendship, Co-operation and Mutual Assistance.
_
The alliance was formed as **a response to the creation of NATO**. Although it was officially known as the Warsaw Treaty Organization, the “Warsaw Pact” is a widely used and acceptable label for both the treaty and the organization.

**The Warsaw Pact was officially disbanded in the summer of 1991.** Some members have since joined NATO.
**In stories, write “the former Warsaw Pact”** _in first reference_, and then the old treaty, the former pact, the disbanded Warsaw alliance, etc. after that

See also [Soviet Union](/home/s/soviet-union)

### WASP

**WASP**

Stands for **white Anglo-Saxon Protestant**. The abbreviation, popularized by sociologists in the 1960s, has since morphed into a family of nouns and modifiers, including: **WASPy, WASPish, WASPiness**.

Generally **avoid the acronym in any of its various forms unless attributed** (i.e., in a broadcast clip or directly transcribed quote), **especially as a synonym for "whiteness"** or for members of a specific socio-economic white community. **Even when attributed, be aware that WASP is widely considered inaccurate and offensive** because **it implies that followers of a specific form of Christianity represent a much larger, monolithic Caucasian group** (e.g., the white middle class, or a given society's white elite).

**WASP is flagged by the Canadian Oxford Dictionary as "usually derogatory."** Various commentators have complained about its relatively common and mindless usage for decades, given the direct ties to Protestantism. In 1988, for example, American writer Edward Hoagland called the cudgel "**WASPy**" as jarring, hurtful and inappropriate as "**Jewy**."

**Rare references to fact-based academic works that LITERALLY describe the historical influence of white Anglo-Saxon Protestants remain OK** — e.g., when WASPs are compared to, say, white Catholics or to white eastern Europeans — such as in this [Canadian Encyclopedia's overview of The Vertical Mosaic](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca%2Fen%2Farticle%2Fvertical-mosaic&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2Ktrvt6_fb_wYOWBPTw5sJ), the seminal 1965 book by sociologist John Porter:


> _"Members of the British “charter group” (**white, Anglo-Saxon, Protestant or WASP**) were greatly overrepresented at the top levels of the occupational and reward structures of Canadian society.... Elites came overwhelmingly from **WASP** upper- and upper-middle class backgrounds...."
> _

> > — The Canadian Encyclopedia


**Otherwise, steer clear of the term** (e.g., "mainly white suburbs" rather than "WASPy suburbs").

### Weapons

**Weapons**
[Firearms overview](/home/w/weapons#firearms) (various definitions and caveats)



[Assault rifle vs. assault-style rifle](/home/w/weapons#assault_rifle) (military vs. military-style)
[By the numbers](/home/w/weapons#handguns) (9-mm pistol, .22-calibre rifle, etc.)
[Military](/home/w/weapons#military) (missiles, mortars, salvos, tanks, volleys, etc.)

**Firearms** (overview)
**Be precise** when reporting on firearms. **Specify relevant details** (e.g., rifles versus handguns, automatic versus semi-automatic, prohibited versus restricted). **Use language that's accurate and meaningful.** If you're uncertain, check. **Certain wording is incontestably wrong** (e.g., calling a shotgun a rifle). **Other language is broader and may be OK** in various contexts. For example, **the term "gun" is acceptable for any firearm.** But **very few pistols can accurately be called revolvers**.

Here are some general guidelines:

-   Generally **limit use of the word "weapon" in stories about gun safety.** The Criminal Code of Canada defines a firearm as "a barrelled weapon." But gun owners are correct when they point out that Canada issues "firearms licences" and registration certificates for "prohibited firearms" and "restricted firearms" under the federal Firearms Act. **The term weapon is always OK when specifically referring to armed attacks**, such as deadly shootings, military conflicts, etc. It's **also fine as an occasional synonym** in other stories. **But repeatedly using "weapon" as the default term for gun is perceived as biased by some people**. They liken it to always calling a knife a weapon — even when interviewing chefs about kitchen accidents. For this reason, **more specific language** (e.g., firearm, rifle) **is often a better choice**, especially in coverage of public policy debates.

-   [**Automatic weapons**](/home/w/weapons#automatic) keep firing as long as the trigger is pulled and there are bullets left (i.e., rounds in the magazine).

-   [**Semi-automatic weapons**](/home/w/weapons#automatic) reload after each shot but don't fire again unless the trigger is pulled once more.

-   **The word "assault" requires special care.** There's no universal definition, and only sporadic attempts at statutory meaning in some countries (e.g., Washington's now-expired 1994 federal "assault weapons ban" in the U.S. Public Safety and Recreational Firearms Use Protection Act, which outlawed certain semi-automatic rifles for 10 years). Reserve the term "**assault rifle**" for military-grade, fully automatic weapons. In other cases, use [**assault-style rifle**](/home/w/weapons#assault_rifle).

-   A firearm's **magazine is a storage device that holds extra ammunition**. There are many types. Some weapons are fed new rounds from belts, for instance, while others rely on either fixed or detachable compartments. **Detachable magazines are often called clips**.

-   **A cartridge is a casing that includes an explosive charge and a bullet or other projectile** (e.g., steel pellets). **Magnum is a trademark for a high-powered cartridge**, as in a .44-calibre Magnum.

-   The adjectives high-powered and high-power are equally correct. For consistency, however, prefer "-powered," as in a **high-powered firearm**. "Power," in this context, conventionally means the type of ammunition fired, as well as its velocity, distance travelled and penetrating force on impact.


-   The words **handgun and pistol are interchangeable** in news stories.

-   **Revolvers are handguns that have cartridges in revolving cylinders** made famous in Hollywood westerns. Some modern weapons still fall into this category, including the .357-calibre Magnum revolver.

-   **Rifles have grooved bores and fire bullets from cartridges.** The rifling spins the bullets, increasing their range and accuracy.

-   **Shotguns have smooth bores and fire pellets of lead or steel (called "shot") packed in shells containing powder.** Some shotguns are double-barrelled.

-   **Long guns generally requires two hands to use** effectively, and are normally braced against the shoulder. **Shotguns are one type. Standard rifles are another.** The noun long gun has a hyphen when used as an adjective (long-gun registry, long-gun owner).

-   **Carbines are rifles with shorter barrels** — commonly used by the military and police tactical units because they're lighter and easier to handle. It's an umbrella term. There are many types of carbines. Avoid the redundancy "carbine rifle," since carbines are by definition rifles.

-   Barrel becomes **barrelled** as a modifier (two l's) in Canadian English, as in **short-barrelled** rifle, **double-barrelled** gun.

-   **Machine-guns can accurately and repeatedly fire rifle-size ammunition for a long time** without overheating. Some of these weapons require more than one person to load, aim and shoot.

-   **Submachine-guns fire pistol-size ammunition.** They're much lighter than machine-guns, but they're also less accurate and have shorter ranges.

-   **Pick the noun that's most familiar to our audience** (e.g., an AK-74 rather than a Kalashnikov assault rifle, assuming the widely used model number is accurate). See the ["by the numbers"](/home/w/weapons#handguns) technical jargon section below for a caution about AK-series rifles. **If important detail is left out of a colloquial name, be sure that the story provides the context** (e.g., a Thompson machine-gun is often called a tommy-gun, but not everyone knows the latter is a type of machine-gun).

-   [**Tasers**](/home/t#Taser) are a specific type of stun gun. The T is capitalized because it's proprietary. **Air guns** use compressed air (or other gases) instead of combustible propellants to shoot projectiles.

-   **Make sure that all images of weapons used in a story apply**. For example, **avoid pictures of pistols in graphics about the old long-gun registry** introduced by Ottawa in 1995 and ended in 2012. Coverage of that registry, or a similar registry introduced in Quebec in 2018, should focus on non-restricted rifles and shotguns. (See [licensing versus registration](/home/w/weapons#registration) below for details.)

**Non-restricted, restricted, prohibited**
**Canada does not actually define "assault" or "combat" weapons in either the Firearms Act or the Criminal Code of Canada. Instead,** federal legislation refers to **three classifications:
**

> **1\. Non-restricted** (e.g., many shotguns, many rifles).
>
> **2\. Restricted** (e.g., most handguns, most semi-automatic guns).
>
> **3\. Prohibited** (e.g., fully automatic firing, unlawfully powerful, illegally altered).


There are **also detailed regulations about everything from ammunition** (e.g., the size of magazines) **to the safe transportation, storage and use of firearms. This includes where restricted weapons can be fired.** For instance, virtually no one except law enforcement officers can lawfully use semi-automatic handguns outside of shooting ranges or other designated areas in Canada. In some cases, professional trappers can seek permission for limited use of such handguns in remote wilderness.


**Licensing versus registration**
It's important to distinguish between the licensing and the registering of guns. **In Canada, you need a licence to acquire and possess** (own or borrow) **any firearm, as well as to obtain ammunition.** The RCMP manages licences under the Canadian Firearms Program. Licences must be renewed.

By contrast, **registration rules are more complex. All restricted and prohibited firearms must be registered in a special database** (i.e., officially logged and assigned a unique registration number to the weapon, which remains in place even if ownership of the weapon changes). This includes all handguns. **But laws about the registration of non-restricted firearms have changed** in recent years. For example, **in 2012 the controversial long-run registry was officially scrapped** by the federal government, which meant non-restricted firearms (e.g., standard hunting rifles and shotguns) no longer needed to be registered. **In 2018,  however, Quebec introduced its own long-gun registry.**

**Common errors:**

-   **Implying that non-restricted firearms are not controlled.** You still need a licence to own virtually any gun, and to get ammunition.
-   **Implying that there's no longer a gun registry in Canada.** All restricted and prohibited weapons must be registered, including handguns.
-   **Implying that Canadians no longer need to register non-restricted firearms.** It depends where you live.

**Automatic versus semi-automatic**
**Whenever possible, specify the type of gun** (e.g., M-16, AR-15, AK-47), **including its firing capability** (automatic or semi-automatic).

Outside of military units and special police tactical squads, firearms are almost always **semi-automatic (one round per trigger pull)** rather than **fully automatic (continuous firing as long as the trigger is pressed)**. But **this fact does not make semi-automatic firearms significantly less deadly in non-combat settings**, such as a church, park or shopping mall, where the people being targeted are usually unarmed. For example, in Connecticut in 2012, the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooter used a Bushmaster XM-15 — a semi-automatic, assault-style rifle similar to an AR-15. Police said he fired more than 150 bullets in less than five minutes, killing 26 people, including 20 children.

In coverage of mass shootings, public policy debates over gun control, etc., here are **some other facts worth knowing:**

-   **Semi-automatic weapons load themselves** (ejecting the spent cartridge, loading a new cartridge and cocking the firing mechanism as part of a single cycle), which means pulling the trigger in rapid succession can produce a virtually automatic burst of bullets, depending on the given firearm and its settings.

-   **Fully automatic weapons** (e.g., machine guns) **are already prohibited in many countries, including Canada.** Even in the U.S., where gun laws are far less restrictive, it's very hard to get permission to own a fully automatic weapon (especially if the firearm was manufactured after 1986). **The modifier "fully" helps underscore that the trigger needs to be pressed only once.**

-   **Most fully automatic weapons can also be set to semi-automatic mode**, so that each shot requires a trigger pull.

-   **A bump stock** is a special attachment that **lets a semi-automatic rifle virtually mimic a fully-automatic weapon.** The device uses the rifle's natural recoil to push back into the shooter's trigger finger, producing rapid, nearly continuous fire. Since "bump stock" is a relatively obscure term, it should be briefly defined/explained.

-   **A firearm's appearance can be highly misleading.** So while it's OK to include an eye-witness account of the weapons a killer may have been spotted carrying, a given rifle's esthetics may be insignificant if not irrelevant. **For example, while some rifles are large and intended to appear menacing** (e.g., painted black and fitted with big scopes), **the weapons may, in fact, be less powerful than certain automatic handguns.** By contrast, a rifle with a wooden stock might appear to look less daunting but actually shoot more powerful ammunition more rapidly — such as the semi-automatic Ruger Mini-14 used in the École Polytechnique massacre in Montreal in 1989.

**A cache of seized weapons can sometimes create a false impression.** For instance, does the pile at the front of the news conference include air guns, realistic toy guns, etc.? It's a good idea to **ask authorities for details about the weapons**, including a list of the **gun names or models**, their **basic firing power** (e.g., fully or semi-automatic, type of ammunition), and **whether they've been illegally modified** (e.g., shortened barrel, larger magazine).

**If you don't know much about firearms, double-check any details causing doubt.** There's often at least one gun buff in every newsroom. A colleague may be able to clear up confusion about specific terminology, regulations, etc.


**Assault rifle versus assault-style rifle**
**Fact-based descriptions of firearms are often clearest.** For instance:


> _"The man who killed 51 people at the Christchurch mosque in New Zealand in 2019 is believed to have modified his **two semi-automatic rifles** with high-capacity magazines so they could hold more bullets."_


**The term "assault" requires special care. Distinguish between "assault rifles" and "assault-style rifles"** whenever reporting on firearms — from breaking news about a deadly shooting to public policy debates over stricter gun control. **Using the labels interchangeably causes confusion, and can lead to accusations of inaccuracy and bias.**

-   **Assault rifle narrowly refers to military-grade, fully automatic firearms.** They're **often carbines** (i.e., they have shortened barrels designed for tactical operations). Such firearms are generally lightweight and easy to aim, often include a selector switch that can be set to either fully automatic or semi-automatic mode, and feature detachable magazines, usually with between 10 and 30 rounds. Examples: **M-16s, AK-47s** and the **C7s** now commonly issued to Canadian soldiers. **Since bona fide assault rifles are capable of fully automatic firing, they're prohibited in Canada.** (See [automatic versus semi-automatic](/home/w/weapons#automatic) as well as [non-restricted, restricted, prohibited](/home/w/weapons#restricted_prohibited) for details.)

**Assault-style rifle refers to a broad group of semi-automatic firearms.** Some may be **fashioned to look like assault rifles, but they're neither fully automatic nor military-grade** (e.g., their ammunition is different, their range is lower, their firing speed is slower). Examples: **AR-15, AR-57** and the **XM-15**. The word "style" is vital to avoid ambiguity, and to accommodate more nuanced conversations between pro-gun and anti-gun activists. Assault-style rifles are **not designed for deer hunting or protecting livestock from coyotes, but** they're also **not identical to actual assault rifles used by soldiers and special tactical teams.** Our reporting should reflect this.

Some people prefer **military-style rifle** over **assault-style rifle**. **Both are acceptable as long as the meaning is clear** (i.e., that a military-style rifle is not the same as a military-grade rifle). It's worth noting that "assault-style rifle" has become increasingly common in public policy discussions in Canada in recent years — including in the federal government roundtable hearings in 2018: [Reducing Violent Crime: A Dialogue on Handguns and Assault-Style Firearms](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.publicsafety.gc.ca%2Fcnt%2Frsrcs%2Fpblctns%2F2019-rdcng-vlnt-crm-dlg%2Findex-en.aspx&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2f_75sVWhkoGz96FvL0aq6). The Office of the Federal Ombudsman For the Victims of Crime also used "assault-style rifle" in a [2018 report to Parliament](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.victimsfirst.gc.ca%2Fvv%2FVC-CV%2Findex.html&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2qV1xSVygJDkYMV57jMst6).

**Don't assume the weapon used at a [mass shooting](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/m/mass-shooting/ "Mass shooting") is an assault rifle or an "assault-style" rifle.** It may turn out to be a high-powered **sniper rifle** designed for distance, such as an SR-25.


CAUTION: **In breaking news about a deadly shooting, try to confirm as much information as possible about the weapon(s) — not to use the jargon in stories, necessarily, but simply to verify whether certain wording applies.** In 2016, for instance, virtually all media claimed that a man had used an AR-15 in a nightclub massacre in Orlando, Florida (i.e., an "assault-style rifle"). Fifty people died, including the gunman, and dozens of others were injured. Within 24 hours, however, officials confirmed the killer actually used a Sig Sauer MCX carbine designed for military use (i.e., an "assault rifle"). The police, it turns out, had vaguely described the weapon as an "AR-15 style" rifle without providing more details. Such **mislabelling can prompt law-abiding rifle owners to level accusations of bias and ignorance against news organizations** — putting journalists on the defensive and impeding fact-based debates over the merits of stricter gun control.



**By the numbers** (9-mm pistol, .22-calibre rifle, etc.)
**Rifles, pistols and other small arms are usually identified by the diameter of their barrels (measured inside). This figure, known as calibre, is expressed either in metric or in decimal fractions of an inch.** The word calibre is not used with metric units. Note the use of hyphens:


> _9-mm pistol_
>
> _75-mm gun_
>
> _.357-calibre Magnum_
>
> _.22-calibre rifle_
>
> _.45-calibre automatic_
>
> _.22-calibre rifle_
>
> _.30-30 gun_ (only one decimal; a specific type of _.30-calibre firearm_)


**The names of some firearms, however, are not based on calibre, including many common military assault rifles:**


> _M-16 rifle_ (_an M-16_)
>
> _AK-47 rifle_ (_an AK-47_)


**When using specific names or models, make sure the designation is accurate** (e.g., the M-16 replaced the older, heavier M-14 as a combat rifle in the U.S. military in the late 1960s). Even widely known proper nouns can trip up reporters. For instance, there are many Kalashnikov assault rifles (AK-47s, AK-74s, AK-101s, etc.). The number 47 refers to the year that particular weapon was first manufactured (1947). Although new designs are now common, especially the AK-74 introduced in the 1970s, AK-47s are still made and used. **Unless you're sure about a specific model, it's generally best to use a general label that applies** (e.g., in this case, assault rifles, AK-series rifles, AKs, AK-47-like rifles).

**Abbreviations can be a source of errors**. Never assume you know what the letters mean. For instance, **AR in AR-15 does NOT stand for "assault rifle."** The initials represent the original manufacturer's name (Armalite Rifle). Colt later bought the rights to the assault-style firearm, and has made numerous modifications since, including production of a military-grade assault rifle we now know as the M-16.

**Shotguns are commonly identified by a bizarre calculation, known as gauge, that combines ammunition weight and the diameter of a firearm's barrel.** The figure was originally based on the number of lead balls of a certain size that would weigh exactly one pound. So a 12-gauge shotgun (accommodating 12 fictional balls of a given diameter) has a larger barrel than a 20-gauge (20 smaller balls, weighing the same amount). **A few shotguns are described by their "bore," which is equivalent to calibre** (e.g., .410 inches):


> _10-gauge shotgun_ (barrel's interior diameter is .775 inches)
>
> _28-gauge shotgun_ (barrel's interior diameter is .615 inches)
>
> _.410-bore shotgun_ (barrel's interior diameter is .410 inches)

**Missiles, mortars and other military words**
**Avoid loaded jargon. For instance, "smart weapon" is dumb propaganda.** If you want to describe a missile, **use a more neutral approach, such as "precision-guided."** But be sure your label is accurate (i.e., that the missile is guided by radar, heat sensors or some other technology).

**There are many types of missiles**, including intercontinental, medium-range, short-range, anti-tank, surface-to-air, air-to-surface and surface-to-surface. Ballistic missiles, which are guided only to the top of their arc, follow a normal ballistic trajectory (i.e., one based on gravity) when they come down.

**If you're unsure about military terminology, check don't guess. For writers covering combat stories, here are a few facts worth remembering:**

-   **Shells used in military weapons have a different meaning.** Although a shotgun shell refers to the casing that the pellets are stored in (see above), **an artillery shell is the actual projectile.**

-   A **volley** refers to several different weapons each firing a single shot simultaneously (or within seconds of each other). A **fusillade** refers to a series of shots fired from a single weapon over a short amount of time. This means that **one person can fire a fusillade but not a volley**. The concentrated discharge of weapons in battle or salute is also generally known as a **salvo**.

-   The term **artillery** describes large-calibre guns. Artillery weapons fire in **salvos**.

-   **Large naval and artillery guns fire shells**. Some combat weapons, including **bazookas, fire rockets**. Some aircraft can fire missiles, shoot guns or drop bombs. A howitzer is a type of cannon. **A cannon can be called a gun**, even though it shoots at a slower speed and with a higher trajectory.
