**Overview**

Trusted wire services that the CBC subscribes to can be used to help stories in one of three ways, depending on existing contracts and individual editorial judgment:

1.  As a source of news only, read but not copied by us without substantial rewrite.
2.  As chunks of text that can either be lifted verbatim or rewritten to suit our needs, as long as appropriate credit is included at the bottom.
3.  As entire articles, cut or revised if required, as long as correct credit is included.

Everything we publish must also satisfy the corporation's overall journalistic standards, including accuracy, fairness, good taste and strictly controlled use of unnamed sources. Intentionally repeating another news service's work when we have any concerns about its content is unacceptable.

Acknowledging an external source's work (when we draw on key information from their reports), and crediting an external source's writing (when we use verbatim excerpts), helps reinforce honesty and transparency in our journalism.

All CBC News employees must clearly understand and follow the rules governing wire copy when rewriting, resembling or reproducing (i.e., copying) this material.

You can learn more about the agreements CBC News has with other broadcasters and news agencies, as well as what that means in terms of content use, [on this page from CBC Busines and Right](https://io.cbcrc.ca/?lang=en/#/resources/cbc-s-rights-agreements-with-other-broadcasters-and-news-agencies-1.3260230)s. If you have questions specific to your platform or program, please be in touch with your supervisor or the CBC Business and Rights contact on that page.


**When and how to use wire copy**

Reputable external news services can supplement CBC journalism without replacing or compromising it, as long as the material is used judiciously and correctly. In television, for instance, legally obtained video from syndication feeds and international partners can be added to video reports and newscasts.

Wire services that the CBC subscribes to, on the other hand, supply content written in a way that's often much more suited to the online world. Radio and video units frequently need to substantially revise such material to make it more conversational.

When broadcast scripts do appear on wire services, they are rarely publishable in their original form online because they're written for the ear not the eye. Even when spelled and punctuated properly, the text needs fleshing out (e.g., additional detail about a study's findings) or restructuring (e.g., a more direct lead) to work well on the internet.

This does not mean, however, that we should simply shovel wire copy onto our website. Whenever possible, we should take the time to blend original CBC elements into our stories to help set our journalism apart on the internet.

At its core, CBC.ca is the online division of Canada's public broadcaster. So to distinguish ourselves from the rest of the World Wide Web, we should showcase as much of the corporation's original journalism as possible and practical — and not just occasional scoops and lengthy investigative pieces.

For example, we can feature:

-   Colourful detail from daily CBC radio and video reports.
-   Transcribed clips from on-air interviews.
-   Additional facts from CBC producers or reporters (by phone or email).
-   Insightful context from veteran broadcast correspondents.
-   Extra information from people we interview on our own.

Truly adding value to our website is a far better investment of our time than heavily rewriting wire material and presenting virtually the same information in a different way.

Excerpts from wire copy are not needed when we have enough original CBC News content to post a good online article that offers our readers all key information as well as the desired amount of depth.

Excerpts from trusted wire copy should be considered when we have significant original CBC News content on any given story (as much as 50 per cent or more from the corporation's radio, television and online staff), but are missing some valuable elements available to us through CP, AP, or other "full rights" sources. A _"With files from"_ credit is required at the bottom of these articles.

Entire non-CBC.ca (external) bylined articles should be considered when we don't have much, if any, original CBC News coverage on any given story but still want to post a piece. Given the corporation's vast domestic newsgathering operation, this is more likely to apply to certain international stories.

We should never lock ourselves into a single approach. There may be times when we begin with a verbatim wire story and then, as the day progresses, replace this with a CBC bylined article that we think is better for our audience. There may also be times when we begin covering what initially appears to be major breaking news, and then decide to abandon our version and post verbatim wire copy instead because the story doesn't merit our full-time attention.

By incorporating wire copy we trust (along with either non-CBC bylines or proper _"With files from"_ credits, as the case may be), we clearly acknowledge the original source of external material while freeing our limited editorial resources to enhance current web content, as well as to update old stories and pursue new ones.

**Current rights**
**Here are more [details about the agreements CBC News has](https://io.cbcrc.ca/?lang=en/#/resources/cbc-s-rights-agreements-with-other-broadcasters-and-news-agencies-1.3260230) with other broadcasters and news agencies, as well as what that means in terms of content use.** If you have questions specific to your platform or program, please discuss with your supervisor or the CBC Business and Rights contact on that page.

**
Full rights**

**As a source of information**

**We can use information from full rights wire sources** when writing our own content from scratch unless we think the details might be wrong, legally problematic or in violation of existing CBC News standards.

**Attribution is unnecessary** when reported facts are peripheral, such as the height of a building or the model of an aircraft.

**Attribution is required**, however, when unverified information is central to a story (e.g., _Disciplinary action was taken against two other skating judges the same year but officials kept the suspensions quiet, according to The Associated Press_).

**_No "With files from"_ credit is given** at the bottom of such articles because the source was used for information only in a story written entirely by CBC online staff. A CBC byline appears at the top.


**Substantial rewrites
**

Writing from scratch does not mean changing the odd word. For example:

**Original**
_Riot police on horseback galloped through the shouting crowd, clubbing protesters trying to flee._

**Unacceptable rewrite**
_Riot police on horseback charged through the screaming crowd, hitting protesters trying to flee._

**Substantial, acceptable rewrite**
_Riot police on horseback used clubs to round up fleeing protesters._

In this case, the original wording contained more detail than either the unacceptable rewrite (we no longer know they were hit with clubs) or the OK but substantially shorter sentence (we no longer know the crowd was shouting).

Colourful descriptions can make our journalism more informative and engaging. So if an article from a news source we have full rights to features a lot of good writing, we may well want to incorporate the best content into our story verbatim (as long as a "With files from" credit is included, as outlined below). But never dump wire or partner copy into our own stories merely to make them longer. The key criterion is what serves our audience best.

****Quotes (public domain versus specific source)
****

Quotes in the public domain (e.g., comments from Question Period, from a scrum, from court testimony, from a news release, etc.) don't require a news source credit (e.g., "_I warned her to stay away," he sobbed during cross-examination;_ not _"I warned her to stay away," he sobbed during cross-examination, according to The Canadian Press)_.

This also applies to interviews conducted by specific news organizations (e.g., _"We can't sit back and wait for another 9/11," Anderson told NBC's Meet the Press;_ not _"We can't sit back and wait for another 9/11," Anderson told NBC's Meet the Press, The Associated Press reported Sunday_).

When quotes not in the public domain are taken from our "full rights" sources and pasted into CBC bylined articles, however, always add "With files from" credit at the bottom of the story (see next section).

**_'With files from'_ credit at bottom**

Verbatim excerpts from any full rights wire sources can be used in a CBC byline story (e.g., CBC News, CBC Sports, CBC Arts), as long as:

-   We have no reason to believe the details are wrong.
-   The content is not legally problematic.
-   The journalism meets overall CBC News standards.
-   A "_With files from_ \[specified source(s)\]" credit is included at the bottom of the story, with the full name of the source used (e.g., The Canadian Press not CP).
-   No less than 50 per cent of the story's content is written by CBC journalists.
-   The lead is written by CBC.
-   The added material is logically placed and helps rather than hinders the story's structure and flow.

More than one source can be listed at the bottom of the story. The brief but clear credit line should be in parentheses, italics and follow this format:

Example 1: (_With files from The Canadian Press_)

Example 2: (_With files from The Associated Press and Sports Network_)

When incorporating external material into our stories, we also have the right to revise the material slightly or substantially (i.e., we're not limited to verbatim excerpts).

When cutting and pasting quotes from material that we have full rights to, avoid adding specific credit to the wire service in the main body of our story (e.g., _"It's like cheating at solitaire," Jenkins said;_ not _"It's like cheating at solitaire," Jenkins told Canadian Press_). But be sure to include appropriate "With files from" credit at the bottom of the story.

If, however, a quote is attributed to a specific newspaper or other news agency, repeat this source in the story (e.g., _"We hope to pull the troops out by this fall," Woo told the Globe and Mail_). Provide an additional, general wire service credit at the bottom (e.g., _With files from The Canadian Press_) only if other material has been used (i.e., content in addition to the credited quote).

**Source byline at the top**

Entire articles from any of full rights sources can be published, either as is or revised (shortened, restructured or reworded) to suit our site, as long as:

-   We have no reason to believe the details are wrong.
-   The content is not legally problematic.
-   The journalism meets overall CBC News standards.
-   A source byline replaces the CBC byline at the top of the story.

Keep in mind that placelines, such as "TOKYO (AP) –," should be removed from wire copy to match overall CBC.ca style. Be certain, however, that the location is clearly indicated high up in each story (usually in the headline or lead).

We have the right to enhance such articles with photos, internal and external links, CBC audio and video, etc.


**Limited rights (source only)**

**Canadian Press 'local outs'**

We do not have full rights to CP stories branded as "local out," but we can treat them as a source of information.

CBC.ca is considered a single editorial entity in the eyes of CP, not a chain of local and national online sites. Since identical regional, national and international stories may be showcased on different CBC.ca web pages, the same wire copy and partnership rights rules must apply to all our journalism.

In Canadian cities with more than one newspaper, CP tends to protect members of its newsgathering co-operative by preventing papers in that market from reprinting a direct competitor's contribution. This is referred to as a "local out."

Such stories can be readily identified in iNEWS by warnings in bold at the top, such as:

-   HFX OUT HQQ
-   TOR OUT YYY
-   WPG OUT WQQ
-   CLG OUT CQQ

The source of the "local out" story generally appears in brackets at the bottom, such as:

-   (Halifax Daily News)
-   (Toronto Star)
-   (Winnipeg Free Press)
-   (Calgary Herald)

We can consult such material when writing our own content from scratch unless we think the details might be wrong, legally problematic or in violation of existing CBC News standards.

Substantial rewrites ([as defined above](/home/w/wire-copy#rewrites)) are required, and a CBC byline is used at the top. No "_With files from_" credit is given at the bottom.

Attribution is unnecessary when reported facts are peripheral, such as a crowd estimate.

Attribution is required, however, when unverified information is central to a story. Credit must be given to the newspaper that supplied CP with the "local out" story rather than to The Canadian Press itself (e.g., _A similar recommendation was dropped from the last study into ferry safety, according to the Vancouver Province_).

Quotes in the public domain (e.g., comments from a budget speech, from a scrum, from a news release, etc.) do not need attribution. Other quotes can be used but require clear credit to the specific member paper (e.g., _"Ottawa's offer is about as inviting as stew made out of manure," Stonechild told the Winnipeg Free Press_).

When there's a double credit given at the bottom of a "local out" article (i.e., the names of two newspapers appear because CP has blended material from two competitors to create a third story for clients outside the local community), do not use any quotes or other information requiring attribution unless it's possible to determine the exact source of that specific content (e.g., the Ottawa Citizen versus the Ottawa Sun). Verifying the specific source might require visiting a few newspapers' websites to see if the material in question has been posted there.


**No rights**

**General rules**

Nothing prevents us from looking at copyrighted material in the public domain (e.g., online articles on the websites of newspapers, other broadcasters, and so forth).

If we want to incorporate any of this content in our stories, however, clear credit must be given (e.g., _India won't decide whether to extradite the suspects for at least a month, Manmohan Singh told the BBC, because the evidence needs to be reviewed_).

Direct quotes can be republished as long as the source (newspaper, broadcaster, etc.) is acknowledged in the same paragraph. But all text needs to be substantially rewritten, as [defined above](/home/w/wire-copy#rewrites), and not merely credited.

Such material should be used only if:

-   We have no reason to believe the details are wrong.
-   The content is not legally problematic.
-   The journalism meets overall CBC News standards.
-   We have a strong editorial reason for drawing on a competitor's journalism.

The last bulleted point drives home the need to think about more than just copyright rules and accuracy when writing stories. It's illegal to post content we don't have rights to without crediting the source in the main body of the story. But it's also irresponsible and lazy to give other people credit for minor material that we could easily confirm ourselves (e.g., by making a quick phone call to, say, an RCMP detachment or a CBC bureau, or by scanning a court judgment or some other document).

**AFP**
Keep in mind that just because wire content appears in CBC's internal system (iNEWS) doesn't mean we have permission to use it on the web.

Unlike Radio-Canada.ca, for example, CBC.ca does not have rights to use daily stories from Agence France-Presse. We occasionally buy temporary privileges to cover special events.

Unless specifically told that we've purchased Agence France-Presse rights (e.g., for the Olympics), avoid adding any AFP wire copy to our journalism beyond directly attributed paraphrases of trusted and exclusive reports that we decide should be brought to our readers' attention (e.g., _The hijackers originally planned to land in Madrid but then ordered the pilot to fly to Germany, Spanish police told Agence France-Presse_).

Since the original content will be in French, make sure our translations are accurate.

Once Agence France-Presse information is verified by us — or by a wire service we trust and have full rights to use — the AFP credit can be dropped.

**Reminders**

**Accuracy first
**

The wire services CBC subscribes to are generally reliable. But just as we're fallible, they too make mistakes.

To maintain the integrity of CBC News, we must avoid publishing anything doubtful. If something from the wires is believed to be wrong or highly suspicious, leave it out.

If something newsworthy is merely uncorroborated (and if we have no reason to believe it's untrue), it can generally be responsibly published with attribution as long as it doesn't violate legal guidelines or CBC News standards.

In breaking news, details are often sketchy (e.g., the number of passengers on a hijacked plane) and frequently incomplete or quickly out of date (e.g., the number of victims killed in an explosion). When such key information is tentative or unconfirmed, attribution is essential (e.g., _The company refused to release details about the miners' condition, but The Associated Press reported Tuesday night that at least three of the men were alive_).

If there's a conflict between wire content and CBC reporters in the field, we should generally assume our corporation's own employees are right unless we're certain a mistake has been made in their coverage. In these cases, concerns should be forwarded to the national assignment desk.

Just because someone writes or phones to complain about our journalism doesn't mean we're wrong. But when we publish errors, we must correct them as quickly as possible.

**Writing the right lead**

As mentioned above, all stories with CBC bylines must feature leads written by us.

Deciding what is news, of course, is subjective — from choosing which stories to cover to selecting specific content (the focus, the people interviewed, the structure, the wording, and so forth).

When writing stories, we should keep an eye on the wires and on the competition, but we don't necessarily have to follow their approaches.

Whenever possible, we should also review relevant coverage from other CBC platforms and incorporate the finest elements of each medium's stories into our own online journalism (e.g., colour, context, transcribed clips).

Our editors must not automatically change a CBC writer's lead simply because AP or _World Report_ or _The National_ has picked a different focus. On the other hand, our writers must be able to justify their leads as superior when challenged by a CBC editor.

In the end, we should make informed decisions about coverage — including focus and content — based on our news judgment, our views about what best serves our readers, any applicable legal guidelines, and overall CBC journalistic standards and practices.

**If you have any questions about the use of wire copy, talk to your supervisor.**

### Workers

**Workers (versus Workers’) Compensation Board**

**The names of these organizations are different across the country. Follow the preference for each** province and territory:


> **Workers Compensation Board** (no apostrophe in P.E.I., Manitoba)
>
> **Workers' Compensation Board** (with apostrophe in Alberta, Saskatchewan, N.S., N.W.T. and Nunavut)
>
> **Workers' Compensation, Health and Safety Board** (Yukon)
>
> **WorkplaceNL**, formerly the Workers' Compensation Board (Newfoundland and Labrador)
>
> **WorkSafeBC**, formerly the Workers' Compensation Board (British Columbia)
>
> **WorkSafeNB**, formerly Workplace Health, Safety and Compensation Commission (New Brunswick)
>
> **Workplace Safety and Insurance Board** (Ontario)


See also [possessive apostrophe](/handy-links/punctuation/possessive-apostrophe)

### World fair

**World’s fair**

**Keep the term world’s fair lowercase unless it’s part of the event’s official name, which is rare:
**
A world’s fair.
Several world’s fairs. (_plural_)
They went to the 1970 world’s fair in Japan.
They went to the 1964 New York World’s Fair. (_official name_)

**The abbreviated form of exhibition, however, is uppercase (Expo).** There is no hyphen or apostrophe before the year, which may be **two or four numbers depending on what organizers have chosen:**

They went to the Vancouver world’s fair in 1986.
They went to the 1986 Canadian World Exhibition. (_official name_)
They went to Expo 86. (_no apostrophe_)
Montreal’s world fair was held during Canada’s centennial celebrations.
They went to the 1967 Montreal world’s fair.
They went to Expo 67. (_no apostrophe_)
Germany’s Expo 2000.
Switzerland’s Expo 02.


**International Exhibitions Bureau**
**There are different types of world’s fairs** (some are larger and last longer).

**The sanctioning body that decides when and where they will be held is called the Bureau International des Expositions**, which was set up in 1928. In news stories, **call it the International Exhibitions Bureau.**

**Avoid using the official abbreviation (BIE)** in second reference. Instead, call it the exhibitions bureau, the bureau, the organization, the sanctioning body, etc.

The International Exhibitions Bureau offers a lot of background about world’s fairs on its website, including a [list of past events](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.bie-paris.org%2Fsite%2Fen%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1CxBwH2ortqG2reKRIMPxr).

### wrongful conviction

**Wrongful conviction**

**Be careful when using this phrase.** If someone merely says they've been wrongfully convicted, attribution is required.

If a previous conviction is overturned, the adjective **"wrongful" applies only if new evidence shows that the original conviction was incorrect or if officials acknowledge that a mistake was made.
**

> Example: David Milgaard was convicted of the 1969 murder of Saskatoon nursing aide Gail Miller. In 1992, the Supreme Court of Canada ordered a new trial. The Crown decided not to prosecute again. While he was technically not acquitted, the government of Saskatchewan formally apologized to Milgaard. In 1999, he received $10 million in compensation for spending more than 20 years in prison for a crime he did not commit. New DNA evidence, meanwhile, led to the arrest and 1999 conviction of Larry Fisher for Miller's murder. A public inquiry was later ordered into Milgaard's wrongful conviction.


**If a conviction is overturned but the Crown simply decides not to retry an individual, the case should not automatically be classified as a "wrongful conviction."**

See the CBCNews.ca feature [Canada's wrongful convictions](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews%2Fcanada%2Fcanada-s-wrongful-convictions-1.783998&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw0eGDmbg6Ezvh5R64yjKi7u) for more background.

**X**

**x** (_lowercase for unknown quantities_) "x amount of money"

**X** (_uppercase for a mark or a nickname_) "He signed the document with an X," "X marks the spot," "agent X" and "The mysterious Mr. X."

**[X](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/#Twitter "T")** ([formerly known as **Twitter**](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/#Twitter "T"))

**X'd out** (to cover a mistake with **x's**, as in XXXX or xxxxxx), **X'ing**, etc.

**X's and O's** (_tick-tack-toe_)  See [apostrophe](/handy-links/punctuation/apostrophes) for related guidelines on single letter plurals (p's and q's, the three Rs) versus other standard plurals of two or more letters (ABCs, FAQs, VIPs)

**X-Acto** ([trademark](/home/t/trade-names) for utility knives with small, sharp blades)

**Xbox** (a video game system made by Microsoft)

**X chromosome(s), Y chromosome(s)**

**Xerox ([trademark](/home/t/trade-names) for a photocopier)** _Do **not** use it as a verb._ Use copy or photocopy instead.

**_X-Files, The_** (television program) see [italics](/handy-links/punctuation/italics) and [The versus the](/home/t/the-versus-the)

**Xi Jinping** (became China's president in March 2013, replacing Hu Jintao) Xi Jinping is pronounced "[SHE jin-PING](http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fpronunc.cbcrc.ca%2FApps%2FLNG%2Frecherche%2Findex.aspx%3FProId%3D37152&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw1d6lVJZj3b4vhF8eaBmuYE)." He's either **Xi** or **President Xi** in second reference. (See [Asian names](/home/a/asian-names) for related guidelines)

**Xinhua News Agency** (**Xinhua** fine in first reference) The name stands for "New China." In stories identify it with a brief description, such as: " ... according to the official Chinese government news agency Xinhua." (See also [Asian names](/home/a/asian-names))

**Xinjiang** (China) Officially known as the **Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region**. The full name does not normally need to be spelled out in most stories. Xinjiang is a vast area of western China that borders Afghanistan, Pakistan, Russia and several other countries. It's home to about 12 million [Uyghurs](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/u/#Uyghurs "U"). **Avoid calling Xinjiang a "province."** Prefer nouns such as "region" and "area." In China, autonomous regions enjoy more administrative control than provinces. While both have local governments, legislators in autonomous regions are delegated broader local legislative powers under rules set by Beijing. Neither has the legal right to secede. Other examples of autonomous regions are [Tibet](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/t/#Tibet "T") and Inner Mongolia.
 (See also [pronunciation](http://pronunc.cbcrc.ca/apps/LNG/Recherche/index.aspx?ProId=37528))

**Xmas** (Generally avoid this abbreviation for Christmas, even in headlines)

**X-rated** (as in movies)

**X-ray** (n. and v.), **X-rayed**

**Y** 

**[y-yn](/home/y#y)**

**[yo-yw](/home/y#yo)**

**y-yn**
**yahoo** (a coarse or backward person) The term, originally uppercase, was the name Jonathan Swift gave an imaginary race of people in Gulliver's Travels about 300 years ago.

**Yahoo** (_not_ Yahoo!) for the internet media company and web search engine. See [quirky capitalization](/home/q/quirky-capitalization) for relevant guidelines on writing words instead of logos.

**Yangon** (previously called "Rangoon") The commercial centre and former capital city of Myanmar, a country also known as Burma. See [**Myanmar**](/home/m/Myanmar) for guidelines.

**Yanukovych, Viktor** (Ukrainian politician)

**yard (prefix)**
yardage, yardmaster, yard sale, yardstick, yardwork


**yard (suffix)**
yard as a suffix is usually one word: backyard _but_ front yard, barnyard, churchyard, graveyard, jail yard, lumberyard, prison yard, schoolyard, shipyard

**yarmulke** (Yiddish term for skullcap) Many Jews in North America prefer the Hebrew term "[kippa](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/k/#kippa "K")," so it's generally best to use the word "**skullcap**" unless it's in a direct quote. See also [zucchetto](/home/z#zucchetto)

**yearlong** (see also [long as a suffix](/home/l#longsuffix))

**year-round** (hyphenated) Synonymous with "all year," as in: It's a year-round service. It's open year-round.

**Yellowhead Pass** (One of the main routes through the Canadian Rocky Mountains. It's west of Jasper, Alta., and includes a major highway and rail line.)

**Yellowknife** (capital of N.W.T.) Does not need territorial name after it, even in first reference. See [provinces and cities](/home/p/provinces-and-cities) for related guidelines; **Yellowknifer** (resident of Yellowknife); **the Yellowknifer** (newspaper); "Yellowknives" plural is correct in the proper noun: **Yellowknives Dene First Nation**. In second reference, their members are called Yellowknives Dene or Yellowknives. See also [Indigenous](/home/i/Indigenous) for related guidelines.

**yeti, yetis** (plural) Use this term when referring to stories about the abominable snowman of the Himalayas. See also guidelines on [sasquatch versus Bigfoot](/home/a#abominable).

**Yiddish** (Do _not_ refer to Jewish people as Yiddish, which is a language with roots in German. Many Jews speak Hebrew, which is a Semitic tongue more closely related to Arabic.)

**yin** (_not_ ying) and **yang**; also **yin-yang** (n.) **and yin-yang symbol**, etc. In Chinese philosophy, yin-yang refers to the harmonious interaction of the universe's passive female (yin) and active male (yang) forces. Do not confuse with yingyang (see below).

**yingyang** (slang for "a lot" or "to a large degree," as in "_They billed them up the yingyang for it._") This word is not likely to crop up much in our journalism. But when it does (e.g., in a directly transcribed quote), be sure to spell yingyang correctly. Do not mix it up with the Chinese philosophical term "yin-yang" (see above).

**YMCA** (Young Men's Christian Association) As with [YWCA](/home/y#YWCA), there's no need to spell out this initialism because it's well-known. (See also [abbreviations](/home/a/abbreviations) for general guidelines)

**[y-yn](/home/y#y) - [yo-yw](/home/y#yo)**

**yo-yw**

**yogurt**

**Yom Kippur** (One of the most sacred days of the Jewish calendar, also known as the Day of Atonement. It's observed just over a week after the Jewish New Year, which is called **Rosh Hashanah**. Yom Kippur is marked by fasting and prayers of repentance.)


Young Offenders Act (_no apostrophe_) This federal legislation was replaced by the **Youth Criminal Justice Act** in April 2003. Avoid expressions such as "young offender" and "juvenile delinquent" to describe an accused. These labels imply guilt. Instead, prefer terms that presume innocence, such as youths, young people, young suspects, etc. When known, the specific age of the detained or charged person is better than a broad category such as "teen" — which doesn't actually apply to people 12 and under, and which technically also covers young adults (i.e., people who are 18 and 19). See [child, teen, young adult](/home/c/child_teen) for related guidelines.

**Yoon Suk Yeol** (elected president of South Korea in 2922) This is his preferred spelling, with no hyphens and initials caps in Suk Yeol. Refer to him as **Yoon** in second reference. (See [Asian names](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/a/asian-names/ "Asian names") for related guidelines)

**yours** (This possessive pronoun does not need an apostrophe) "Yours hasn't arrived yet," she told him before closing the door. See [possessive apostrophe](/handy-links/punctuation/possessive-apostrophe)

**Yousafzai, Malala** (Pakistani teenage activist born July 12, 1997) An outspoken advocate for women's education and other rights in Pakistan, she was shot in the head by the Taliban in October 2012 but survived. In early worldwide coverage of the story, Yousafzai was identified as a 14-year-old. But she was actually 15 when critically wounded. Although there are various spellings of her name, use the [transliteration](/home/t/transliterations) with only one "u" for consistency.

**YouTube** (See [social media](/home/s#socialmedia))

**yo-yo, yo-yos**

**[Yugoslavia](/home/b/balkans#Yugoslavia)** (A former communist federal republic that began breaking up in 1991 during violent ethnic fighting)

**[Yukon](/home/y/yukon)** (no abbreviation) Adding the definite article "the" is optional (i.e., **the Yukon**). For example, "She moved to Yukon"and "She moved to the Yukon" are both acceptable, based on entrenched local convention.

**yule, yuletide**

**yuppie** (_not_ yuppy), **yuppies** (plural) The colloquial term for "young urban professional" doesn't need to be spelled out, but it often conveys a derogatory tone so use with care.

**Yushchenko, Viktor** (Ukrainian politician)

**YWCA** (Young Women's Christian Association) As with [YMCA](/home/y#YMCA), there's no need to spell out this initialism because it's well-known. (See also [abbreviations](/home/a/abbreviations) for general guidelines)

### Yukon

**Yukon**

The **official name of the territory is Yukon.** But it's **OK to add a definite article ("the") when deemed more natural.** Be aware that "the Yukon" has become the entrenched preference of some in the North, and is often used by the territorial government, itself, outside of legal documents and other formal contexts.

**Examples of acceptable usage**, with Yukon as a noun:


> He's from the Yukon.
> She moved to Yukon in 2004.
> The capital of the Yukon is Whitehorse.
> The governments of Alberta, B.C. and Yukon oppose the proposal.
> Yukon's unemployment rate dropped slightly last month.
> He dismissed the figures for Yukon as unreliable.


**If Yukon functions as an adjective, "the" may be required because it's tied to other nouns**, such as delegation, company, government.


> The Yukon delegation left Monday.
> She bought the Yukon company in 2007.
> The study was paid for by the Yukon government.

**Background on** **'the' Yukon** (dropped, restored)
For years, "the" was placed before Yukon because it was tied to a compound noun that included the word territory (i.e., "the Yukon Territory," which was often shortened to "the Yukon"). **In April 2003, the territory's name was officially changed to Yukon.** For several years, "the" lingered — even on the territorial government's own website. Although the definite article gradually became less common, it remained popular in some circles.

**In August 2021, the territorial government voted to make "the Yukon" its preference outside of official documents** (e.g., in news releases but NOT in legislation, formal agreements). The [government's updated online style manual](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fguide.yukon.ca%2Fen%2Fcontent-and-design%2Fstyle-guide%2Fgovernment-references%2Fyukon-and-yukon&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AOvVaw2pPTomFD29-6XN3npVBOax) said this change was "to recognize that for many people referring to 'the Yukon' is part of the territory’s unique culture." But the legal name of the territory remained Yukon. Therefore, even in speeches, public policy documents, etc., staff were advised to use wording that reflected an individual minister's choice. They were also told to respect known preferences of local governments, organizations, etc.

**Continue to add "the" to the Northwest Territories because the definite article remains part of the N.W.T. compound noun. But never add "the" to Nunavut**, which would be as jarring and inaccurate as writing "the Alberta" or "the Ontario."


**Miscellaneous**

-   Residents of Yukon are known as **Yukoners**.
-   Territorial leaders are now conventionally called premiers ("**Yukon Premier** Dennis Fentie says …"), a word once reserved for the heads of provincial governments.
-   Ottawa's official representative is known as the **Commissioner of Yukon**, although it's acceptable to recast as Yukon's Commissioner (as a title before the name) or as Yukon's commissioner (lowercase in a generic reference, along the lines of Ontario's lieutenant-governor).
-   **[Yukon time (YT)](/home/t/time#local) was established in 2020.** The territory no longer changes its clocks, effectively staying on permanent West Coast daylight time (i.e., YT = MST).
-   While technically a town, the name **Dawson City** is acceptable based on legislation as well as long-standing convention. But avoid the generic, lowercase term "city" in second reference. See [Dawson City](/home/d#DawsonCity) for more details.
-   While **Gwich'in** is the standard spelling for the northern [Indigenous people](/home/i/Indigenous), adopt the recognized variation (Gwitchin) if used in a proper noun ("the Vuntut Gwitchin First Nation of northern Yukon").

See [provinces and cities](/home/p/provinces-and-cities) for an overview of related spelling, capitalization and punctuation guidelines, including a link to a federal government database of official geographical names in Canada.

**Z**

**Zaire** (_It changed its name_ to the Democratic Republic of Congo in 1997.) **Call it "Congo, formerly known as Zaire,"** to differentiate it between another, smaller country in the region known as "the Republic of Congo." For other tips on avoiding confusion between these two separate states, see [Congo-Kinshasa and Congo-Brazzaville](/home/c/Congos).

**Zamboni** (A [trademark](/home/t/trade-names) name for a machine that resurfaces ice at arenas)

**Zamboni therapy** (use **MS therapy**) See [Zamboni therapy, so-called "liberation therapy"](/home/z/zamboni-liberation-ms-therapy) for details

**Zelenskyy, Volodymyr** (elected president of Ukraine in April 2019) There are numerous English spellings of his name, including "Zelenskiy," "Zelenskyi" and "Zelensky." See **[Ukrainian names](/home/u/ukrainian-names)** for general guidelines, as well as the specific reasons that **Zelenskyy** has been CBC's preference since July 2022..

**Zellers** (no apostrophe)

**Zen Buddhism** (no hyphen)

**zero, zeros** (plural noun) as in "There are a lot of zeros on that cheque," **but zeroes** (verb) as in "It zeroes in on the problem."

**Zhou Enlai** (formely spelled Chou En-lai) See [Asian names](/home/a/asian-names)

**zidovudine** (an [HIV/AIDS](/home/a/aids) drug, also called AZT) The term zidovudine is an arbitrary alteration of the chemical name azidothymidine, according to the Canadian Oxford. The former label is becoming more common than the latter, but neither term is well-known. In our stories, we must go beyond simply spelling nouns correctly. We must also make it clear what we're talking about.

**zigzag** (no hyphen)

**Zimbabwe**

**zine** (_not_ ‘zine), **zines** (plural) A colloquial term for small (often online) magazines. A lot of people are not familiar with the word, so _provide a definition if you use it_.

**Zinfandel** (can refer to either a specific variety of grape or to a type of wine made from that grape) See also [wines and spirits](/home/w/wines_spirits) for related guidelines

**Zion, Zionism, Zionist**

**zip code** (_not_ ZIP code) _Americans have zip codes, Canadians have postal codes._ The U.S. abbreviation stands for "zoning improvement plan," although it does not need to be spelled out in stories. The term is fine for addresses in the United States, but the generic term "postal code" works just as well and avoids any possible confusion.

**zip fastener, zip file** (compressed computer file), **zip line, zip wire**

**zipper** (capital Z no longer needed because the [trademark](/home/t/trade-names) has become a generic term)

**zodiac, signs of the zodiac** (lowercase)


**zombie deer disease** (OK in first reference, including headlines) This is a common and acceptable colloquialism for a type of **chronic wasting disease (CWD)**. To keep our journalism clear, however, the formal name (CWD) should be used at least once in stories whenever practical, in the same way we approach [mad cow disease](https://language-guide.cbcrc.ca/home/m/mad-cow-disease/ "Mad cow disease") (BSE). Using quotation marks to flag "zombie deer disease" as an informal label is fine but optional. Be aware that CWD falls under the larger heading of **transmissible spongiform encephalopathy (TSE)**, an umbrella category of incurable, fatal brain diseases that can affect people, cattle, sheep, deer and other animals.

**zone (ending a compound noun)**
**danger zone, disaster zone, flood zone, time zone**, etc. (two words)

**zucchetto, zucchettos** (Caps worn by the Roman Catholic clergy) There are different colours: black for priests, purple for bishops, red for cardinals and white for the Pope. The term skullcap is more widely understood and, so, generally a better choice. See also [yarmulke](/home/y#yarmulke).

**zucchini**

### Zamboni liberation MS therapy

**Zamboni therapy, so-called 'liberation therapy'**

In first reference (including headlines and TV supers), use neutral, descriptive and meaningful phrases, such as: **MS vein therapy, MS vein treatment**, or even **MS therapy**. The medical term, _venous angioplasty_, is too technical unless defined. An alternative phrase, such as **angioplasty for people with MS**, is fine, as long as the context makes the meaning clear, especially since many people associate angioplasty with the heart.

Words like _therapy_ and _treatment_ are vague, of course, so our journalism should always include details about what's actually involved (see below). If we call it **Zamboni therapy** in a later reference, be sure to point out that the treatment was pioneered by Paolo Zamboni, an Italian doctor.

**The procedure is controversial.** It's based on a theory that narrowed neck veins cause blood-borne iron deposits to build up and damage brain cells, and that unblocking the veins will help people with multiple sclerosis. But some researchers have challenged the validity of the preliminary research.

**There's no need to use jargon to tell our stories.** Zamboni, for instance, named the condition "chronic cerebrospinal venous insufficiency," or CCSVI. We, however, should stick with something understandable (e.g., "clogged neck veins").

If there's room in a story, it's fine to point out that advocates call the procedure "liberation therapy." This might be particularly important in our web journalism where the use of certain keywords can help get our material to a wider audience because of how search engines work. But it's not a neutral noun and, so, requires either attribution or the qualifier so-called (i.e., **so-called "liberation therapy"**).

See also: [so-called](/home/s/so-called) for related guidelines
